Subject: hypokalemia
Value: hypokalaemia

Subject: decreased circulating potassium level
Value: hypokalaemia

Subject: abnormal right lung cranial lobe morphology
abnormal right lung middle lobe morphology
abnormal right lung caudal lobe morphology
abnormal olfactory bulb glomerular layer morphology
abnormal olfactory bulb granule cell layer morphology
abnormal olfactory bulb internal plexiform layer morphology
abnormal olfactory bulb mitral cell layer morphology
abnormal cerebellum vermis lobule I morphology
abnormal cerebellum vermis lobule II morphology
abnormal cerebellum vermis lobule III morphology
abnormal cerebellum vermis lobule IV morphology
abnormal cerebellum vermis lobule IX morphology
abnormal cerebellum vermis lobule V morphology
abnormal cerebellum vermis lobule VI morphology
abnormal cerebellum vermis lobule VII morphology
abnormal cerebellum vermis lobule VIII morphology
abnormal cerebellum vermis lobule X morphology
abnormal cerebellum vermis lobule VIIa morphology
abnormal cerebellum vermis lobule VIIb morphology
abnormal ansiform lobule crus I morphology
abnormal ansiform lobule crus II morphology
prolonged excitatory postsynaptic current decay time
short excitatory postsynaptic current decay time
abnormal inner renal medulla vasa recta morphology
abnormal kidney outer medulla vasa recta morphology
unbalanced complete atrioventricular canal, left dominant
increased mammary gland tumor incidence in virgin females
anastomosis between common carotid and vertebral artery
absent proximal internal carotid artery segment
fusion of axis and occipital bones
abnormally deep median sulcus of tongue
absent connection between subcutaneous lymph vessels and lymph sac
abnormal left vena cava superior connection
intramural bleeding in blood vessel wall
abnormal pancreatic duct epithelial transmembrane transport
abnormal pancreatic duct epithelial chloride transmembrane transport
decreased pancreatic duct epithelial chloride transmembrane transport
increased pancreatic duct epithelial chloride transmembrane transport
abnormal pancreatic duct epithelial sodium ion transmembrane transport
increased pancreatic duct epithelial sodium ion transmembrane transport
decreased pancreatic duct epithelial sodium ion transmembrane transport
decreased susceptibility to thrombosis induced morbidity/mortality
mammalian phenotype
Value: the observable morphological, physiological, behavioral and other characteristics of mammalian organisms that are manifested through development and lifespan

Subject: abnormal adipose tissue morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the connective tissue composed of fat cells enmeshed in areolar tissue

Subject: increased brown adipose tissue amount
Value: increased amount of the thermogenic form of adipose tissue that is composed of brown adipocytes

Subject: increased white adipose tissue amount
Value: increased quantity of fat-storing cells/tissue

Subject: abnormal abdominal fat pad morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the encapsulated adipose tissue in the abdomen

Subject: abnormal adipose tissue distribution
Value: alterations in the normal placement of body fat

Subject: abnormal ear pigmentation
Value: anomaly in the coloration of the skin of the outer ear due to changes in the amount, shape, or distribution of cells producing pigment

Subject: big ears
Value: outer ears of a greater than normal size

Subject: small ears
Value: outer ears of a smaller than normal size

Subject: thick ears
Value: increased width of the epidermal and cartilaginous tissue that makes up the ear

Subject: scaly ears
Value: ears covered with shedding scales or flakes

Subject: prominent ears
Value: protuberant outer ears

Subject: abnormal ear shape
Value: any anomaly in the characteristic surface outline or contour of the external ear

Subject: abnormal ear position
Value: anomaly in the space between or the placement of the outer ears

Subject: lowered ear position
Value: outer ears are situated below the normal location often giving the perception of protruding from the head

Subject: otic hypertelorism
Value: greater than normal space between the outer ears

Subject: abnormal inner ear morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any components of the labyrinth, including the semicircular canals, vestibule and cochlea

Subject: abnormal pars superior vestibularis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the part of the vestibular ganglion that receives fibers from the maculae of the utricle and the sacculae and the ampullae of the anterior and lateral semicircular ducts

Subject: abnormal malleus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the largest of the three auditory ossicles, which resembles a club or hammer

Subject: abnormal tympanic ring morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bony ring at the ear canal to which the tympanic membrane is attached

Subject: abnormal cochlea morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the spiral-shaped bony canal in the inner ear containing the hair cells that transduce sound

Subject: cochlear degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of the spiral-shaped bony canal in the inner ear containing the hair cells that transduce sound

Subject: absent scala media
Value: missing spiral tube within the cochlea that contains the organ of Corti, the neuroepithelial receptor organ for hearing

Subject: abnormal inner ear vestibule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cavity between the semicircular canals and the cochlea of the inner ear

Subject: abnormal membranous labyrinth morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the complex arrangement of communicating canaliculi and sacs suspended within the cavity of the bony labyrinth of the inner ear

Subject: absent semicircular canals
Value: missing organ of balance; consists of three bony tubes within which the semicircular ducts are located

Subject: abnormal lateral semicircular canal morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the lateral long bony tube of the labyrinth that is involved in the sense of balance

Subject: abnormal otic capsule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cartilage or bony capsule surrounding the inner ear mechanism

Subject: absent middle ear ossicles
Value: missing small bones of the tympanic cavity

Subject: absent endolymphatic duct
Value: missing small membranous canal of the inner ear; connecting membranous labyrinth with the endolymphatic sac

Subject: abnormal organ of Corti morphology
Value: any structural anomaly associated with the highly specialized epithelium in the floor of the ductus cochlearis; also referred to a spiral organ (organum spirale), or acoustic papilla

Subject: organ of Corti degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of all or part the highly specialized epithelium in the floor of the ductus cochlearis

Subject: absent organ of Corti
Value: absence of the highly specialized epithelium in the floor of the ductus cochlearis

Subject: abnormal hair cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the sensory epithelial cells of the inner ear

Subject: abnormal sulcus ampullaris morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the transverse groove on the membranous amupulla of each semicircular duct, where the nerve enters the ampullary crest

Subject: abnormal stria vascularis morphology
Value: <any structural anomaly in the stratified, secretory epithelium which lines the upper part of the cochlear spiral ligament and maintains potassium ion homeostasis in the endolymph; stria vascularis normally consists of marginal, intermediate, and basal cells: basal and marginal cell tight junctions preclude paracellular diffusion into and out of the intrastrial space while basal and intermediate cells secrete into this space potassium ions derived from fibrocytes through gap junctions>

Subject: abnormal middle ear morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any components of the tympanic cavity or its ossicles

Subject: early ear unfolding
Value: early onset of the opening and spreading out of the outer ear

Subject: excessive ear growth
Value: overly robust development of the ear

Subject: delayed ear emergence
Value: late onset of the growth of the outer ear

Subject: delayed bone ossification
Value: late onset of the formation of bone

Subject: fragile skeleton
Value: easily damaged or broken bones

Subject: increased bone mineral density
Value: increase in the quatitative measurment value of mineral content of bone; BMD is used as an indicator of bone strength used as a measure of structural strength and screen for osteoporosis; bone mineral density is the ratio of bone mineral content to bone size

Subject: decreased bone mineral density
Value: reduction in the quatitative measurment value of mineral content of bone; BMD is used as an indicator of bone strength used as a measure of structural strength and screen for osteoporosis; bone mineral density is the ratio of bone mineral content to bone size

Subject: failure of bone resorption
Value: inability to degrade the organic and inorganic phases of bone by absorption, usually by the abnormal function or by absence of osteoclasts

Subject: abnormal bone marrow cavity morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the medullary cavities of the bones

Subject: osteoporosis
Value: reduction in bone mass or atrophy of skeletal tissue; may lead to skeletal fragility

Subject: osteopetrosis
Value: excessive formation of dense trabecular bone and excessive calcified cartilage formation; may lead to anemia and extramedullary hematopoiesis

Subject: kyphoscoliosis
Value: kyphosis combined with scoliosis

Subject: axial skeleton hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size in the skeletal elements of the trunk, usually due to reduced cell number

Subject: absent craniofacial bones
Value: missing skeletal elements comprising the cranium and face

Subject: abnormal neurocranium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bones of the skull enclosing the brain

Subject: absent neurocranium
Value: missing bones of the skull enclosing the brain

Subject: abnormal interparietal bone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bone of the cranium that lies above and anterior to the occipital bone in some mammals

Subject: abnormal supraoccipital bone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bone on the dorsal side of the great foramen of the skull, usually forming a part of the occipital in the adult, but distinct in the young

Subject: abnormal basioccipital bone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the basilar process of the occipital bone in the base of the cranium, frequently forming a direct part of the occipital in the adult, but usually distinct in the young

Subject: abnormal exoccipital bone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bone or region on the lateral sides of the great foremen of the skull, which often forms a part of the occipital in the adult, but is usually distinct in the young

Subject: premature cranial suture closure
Value: early closure of one or more of the joints (sutures) between the bones of the skull; can cause alterations in head shape, facial features, brain growth and, in rare cases, damage to the brain due to increased pressure inside the skull

Subject: overlapping parietal bones
Value: parietal bones of the skull partly coincide instead of articulating

Subject: abnormal fontanelle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the membranous interval at the margins of cranial bones in neonates

Subject: large anterior fontanelle
Value: enlarged diamond-shaped membranous interval at the junction of the coronal, sagittal and metopic sutures of the cranium

Subject: absent mandible
Value: missing the lower bony framework of the mouth where the inferior teeth are held

Subject: short mandible
Value: reduced length of the lower bony framework of the mouth where the inferior teeth are held

Subject: absent premaxilla
Value: missing anterior and interior portion of the maxilla

Subject: short premaxilla
Value: length reduction or truncation of the anterior and interior portion of the maxilla

Subject: absent alveolar process
Value: missing projecting ridge on the inferior surface of the body of the maxilla and mandible containing the tooth sockets

Subject: short maxilla
Value: reduced length of the upper jaw bone

Subject: abnormal vomer bone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the triangular flat bone of the nasal septum

Subject: absent vomer bone
Value: missing triangular flat bone of the nasal septum

Subject: abnormal ethmoid bone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the single midline facial bone that separates the nasal cavity from the brain, located at the roof of the nose between the two orbits; it is cubical in shape, relatively lightweight because of its spongy construction, and contributes to the anterior cranial fossa

Subject: absent ethmoid bone
Value: missing the single midline facial bone that separates the nasal cavity from the brain, located at the roof of the nose between the two orbits; it is cubical in shape, relatively lightweight because of its spongy construction, and contributes to the anterior cranial fossa

Subject: abnormal nasal bone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of either of two rectangular bone plates forming the bridge of the nose

Subject: nasal bone hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, in the bone which forms the nasal bridge

Subject: abnormal sphenoid bone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the irregularly shaped bone of the base of the skull

Subject: impaired ossification of basisphenoid bone
Value: anomaly in the formation of the bone at the base of the sphenoid bone; arises from an ossification center independent of the remainder of the sphenoid bone

Subject: abnormal basisphenoid bone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of part of the base of the cranium between the basioccipital and the presphenoid, which usually ossifies separately in the embryo or in the young, and becomes a part of the sphenoid in the adult; in many animals it persists as a separate bone between the basioccipital bone and the presphenoidal bone

Subject: abnormal frontal bone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the single bone forming the forehead and roof of the eye orbit

Subject: midline facial cleft
Value: incomplete merging or fusion of the tissues (e.g. the two globular processes) along the facial midline that normally unite to form the face

Subject: abnormal parietal bone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of either of a pair of membranous bones of the roof of the skull located between the frontal and occipital bones that are large, curved and quadrilateral in outline, articulate with each other at the midline in the sagittal suture, and form most of the superior and lateral aspects of the cranium

Subject: cleft palate
Value: congenital fissure of the tissues normally uniting to form the palate

Subject: cleft chin
Value: incomplete fusion of the chin; usually a fissure

Subject: abnormal tooth development
Value: any anomaly in the formation of the teeth

Subject: absent tooth placode
Value: missing the local thickening that is normally formed within the primary dental lamina and grows into a solid epithelial tooth bud that invades the underlying mesenchyme; the placodes consist of thickened epithelium and underlying neural crest derived mesenchyme, and they function as the first signaling centers of the tooth

Subject: arrest of tooth development
Value: failure of differentiation of the teeth

Subject: abnormal tooth eruption
Value: any anomaly in the developmental process in which a tooth moves in an axial and occlusal direction from its developmental position within the alveolar crypt in the jaw to its final functional position in the occlusal plane

Subject: malocclusion
Value: perturbations in the normal patterned arrangement of the teeth or alignment of the jaw, resulting in the incorrect position of biting or chewing surfaces of the upper and lower teeth

Subject: failure of tooth eruption
Value: inability of the teeth to grow into the oral cavity

Subject: premature tooth eruption
Value: early onset of the growth of the teeth out of the gums

Subject: absent incisors
Value: absence of the pairs of long teeth that are the most anterior and prominent in the jaw

Subject: brittle teeth
Value: fragile and likely to break teeth

Subject: degenerate molars
Value: deterioration or loss over time of the molars

Subject: growth retardation of molars
Value: developmental delay of the growth of the molars

Subject: ameloblast degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of the epithelial cells of the inner later of the enamel organ of the developing tooth

Subject: abnormal trabecular bone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of bone that has a lattice-like or spongy structure; it is highly vascular and contains intercommunicating spaces filled with bone marrow

Subject: abnormal long bone epiphysis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the rounded end of a long bone

Subject: thickened long bone epiphysis
Value: wider than normal rounded end of a long bone

Subject: abnormal long bone metaphysis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the conical section of bone between the epiphysis and diaphysis of the long bones; this section grows during childhood and juvenile stages and is completely ossified in adults

Subject: abnormal compact bone thickness
Value: reduced or increased width of the superficial layer of compact bone

Subject: decreased compact bone thickness
Value: thinner than normal superficial layer of compact bone

Subject: abnormal microglial cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small, migratory, phagocytic, interstitial cells derived from myeloid progenitor cells and found in the parenchyma of the central nervous system; microglia are scavengers, engulfing dead cells and other debris, and in Alzheimer's disease, microglia are found associated with dying nerve cells and amyloid plaques

Subject: abnormal vertebrae morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bony segments of the spinal column

Subject: absent vertebrae
Value: missing all of the bony segments of the spinal column

Subject: absent vertebral transverse processes
Value: loss of the bony protrusions on either side of the arch of a vertebrae at the point where the lamina joins the pedicle, between the superior and inferior articular processes; muscles and ligaments attach to these processes

Subject: absent vertebral pedicles
Value: loss of the two short, thick processes, which project backward, one on either side, from the upper part of the body to the laminae

Subject: abnormal vertebral body morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the main cylindrical portion of the vertebra ventral to the vertebral canal

Subject: abnormal scapula morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of either or both of the large, flat bones of the back part of the shoulder

Subject: abnormal rib morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bones forming the bony wall of the chest

Subject: absent ribs
Value: absence of all the pairs of bony structures that make up the body wall

Subject: absent proximal rib
Value: missing part of rib structures near the spine, ribs do not contact vertebrae

Subject: rib bifurcation
Value: forking or division of ribs, may be a result of partial rib fusions

Subject: rib fusion
Value: appearance of one or more ribs as a single structure

Subject: asymmetric rib joints
Value: loss of bilateral symmetry in rib attachments to the vertebral column or to the sternum

Subject: abnormal sternum morphology
Value: <any structural anomaly of the long flat bone of the chest that articulates with clavicle and first seven rib pairs; from rostral to caudal positions, the sternum consists of three parts: manubrium, body, and xiphoid process>

Subject: absent sternum
Value: missing long flat bone of the chest; articulates with clavicle and first seven rib pairs

Subject: abnormal xiphoid process morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the caudal tip of the sternum

Subject: kyphosis
Value: forward curvature of the spine, characterized by extensive flexion

Subject: scoliosis
Value: lateral and rotational curvature of the spine

Subject: lordosis
Value: anteriorly convex curvature of the spine

Subject: abnormal cartilage morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the nonvascular, resilient, flexible connective tissue found primarily in joints, walls of the thorax, and tubular structures, but which also comprises most of the skeleton in early fetal life

Subject: abnormal cartilage development
Value: anomaly in the formation of the nonvascular, resilient, flexible connective tissue found primarily in joints, walls of the thorax, and tubular structures, but which also comprises most of the skeleton in early fetal life

Subject: abnormal long bone hypertrophic chondrocyte zone
Value: anomaly of the layer of the epiphyseal plate of a long bone where chondrocytes mature and enlarge

Subject: abnormal chondrocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a polymorphic cell that forms cartilage

Subject: decreased chondrocyte number
Value: fewer than normal numbers of polymorphic cells that form cartilage

Subject: abnormal bone marrow development
Value: anomaly in the formation of the soft, pulpy tissue filling the medullary cavities of bones

Subject: abnormal bone marrow cell number
Value: increased or decreased number of cells that make up the core cavities of bones when compared to controls

Subject: absent bone marrow cell
Value: lack of cells that make up the core cavities of bones

Subject: abnormal circulating cholesterol level
Value: anomaly in the amount in the blood of the principal sterol of vertebrates and the precursor of many steroids, including bile acids and steroid hormones; it is a component of the plasma membrane lipid bilayer and of plasma lipoproteins and can be found in all animal tissues

Subject: abnormal circulating LDL cholesterol level
Value: <any anomaly in the amount in the blood of the lipoprotein:cholesterol complex that transports cholesterol out of the arteries and around the body, for use by various tissues in normal bodily functions>

Subject: increased circulating LDL cholesterol level
Value: <greater amount in the blood of the lipoprotein:cholesterol complex that transports cholesterol out of the arteries and around the body, for use by various tissues in normal bodily functions>

Subject: decreased circulating LDL cholesterol level
Value: <reduced amount in the blood of the lipoprotein:cholesterol complex that transports cholesterol out of the arteries and around the body, for use by various tissues in normal bodily functions>

Subject: abnormal circulating HDL cholesterol level
Value: <any anomaly in the amount in the blood of the small lipoprotein:cholesterol complex that transports cholesterol out of the arteries and to the liver for reprocessing or excretion>

Subject: decreased circulating HDL cholesterol level
Value: <reduced amount in the blood of the small lipoprotein:cholesterol complex that transports cholesterol out of the arteries and to the liver for reprocessing or excretion>

Subject: abnormal triglyceride level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration of triglyceride, a glycerol esterified at each of its three hydroxyl groups by a fatty acid; triglyceride is an important molecule for storage of fatty acids in adipose tissue

Subject: abnormal circulating glucose level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration in the blood of the major monosaccharide of the body

Subject: hypoglycemia
Value: low levels of plasma glucose in the circulating blood; this generally refers to a pathological state

Subject: abnormal mineral level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration of any inorganic substance that has importance in body functions

Subject: increased circulating calcium level
Value: abnormally high concentration of calcium ions in the circulating blood

Subject: decreased circulating calcium level
Value: subnormal concentrations of calcium ions in the circulating blood

Subject: decreased circulating phosphate level
Value: abnormally low concentrations of phosphates in the circulating blood

Subject: abnormal circulating serum albumin level
Value: anomaly in the blood level of the major blood protein that is important in maintaining the colloidal osmotic pressure, fatty acid transport and transporting large organic molecules

Subject: abnormal circulating alkaline phosphatase level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration in the blood of the enzyme which hydrolyzes orthophosphoric monoesters; low levels are seen in cases of hypophosphatasia

Subject: abnormal circulating aspartate transaminase level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration in the blood of the enzyme which catalyzes the reversible transfer of an amine group from l-glutamic acid to oxaloacetic acid, forming alpha-ketoglutaric acid and l-aspartic acid

Subject: decreased hematocrit
Value: less than the average percentage of a volume of a blood sample occupied by red blood cells

Subject: absent erythrocytes
Value: lack of mature red blood cells

Subject: absent erythroid progenitor cell
Value: lack of progenitors of the erythrocyte lineage

Subject: abnormal leukocyte cell number
Value: any anomaly in the number of nucleated cells of the myeloid or lymphoid lineages, found in blood or other tissue

Subject: increased leukocyte cell number
Value: greater than normal number of nucleated cells of the myeloid or lymphoid lineages, found in blood or other tissue

Subject: increased neutrophil cell number
Value: greater than normal number of the immature or mature forms of a granular leukocyte that in its mature form has a nucleus with three to five lobes connected by slender threads of chromatin, and cytoplasm containing fine inconspicuous granules and stainable by neutral dyes

Subject: increased monocyte cell number
Value: greater count of the large, phagocytic mononuclear leukocytes produced in the vertebrate bone marrow and released into the blood

Subject: decreased leukocyte cell number
Value: reduction in the number of nucleated cells of the myeloid or lymphoid lineages, found in blood or other tissue

Subject: decreased neutrophil cell number
Value: reduced count of the immature or mature forms of a granular leukocyte that in its mature form has a nucleus with three to five lobes connected by slender threads of chromatin, and cytoplasm containing fine inconspicuous granules and stainable by neutral dyes

Subject: decreased monocyte cell number
Value: reduced count of the large, phagocytic mononuclear leukocytes produced in the vertebrate bone marrow and released into the blood

Subject: abnormal mean corpuscular volume
Value: deviation from normal for the average amount of space occupied by each red blood cell, calculated from the hematocrit and red cell count, in erythrocyte indices

Subject: abnormal thrombopoiesis
Value: abnormal development of the non-nucleated cells of the blood (platelets, thrombocytes) involved in blood coagulation

Subject: abnormal megakaryocyte differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce the giant 50 to 100 micron diameter cells with greatly lobulated nuclei found in the bone marrow; mature blood platelets are released from their cytoplasm

Subject: abnormal systemic arterial blood pressure
Value: altered tension of the blood within the systemic arteries

Subject: hypertension
Value: sustained high blood pressure at a level that is likely to result in cardiovascular disease and/or other pathological states

Subject: abnormal blood flow velocity
Value: any anomaly in the rate of flow of the blood through vessels

Subject: absent pre-B cells
Value: <absence of the cells in the B lymphocyte lineage that have undergone VDJ rearrangement of the immunoglobulin heavy chain and are in the process of V-J rearrangement of the light chain: these cells express mu heavy chain on the cell surface>

Subject: absent common myeloid progenitor cells
Value: lack of progenitor cells committed to myeloid lineage, including the megakaryocyte and erythroid lineages

Subject: extramedullary hematopoiesis
Value: formation and development of blood cells outside the bone marrow, e.g., in the spleen, liver, or lymph nodes

Subject: impaired fertilization
Value: defect or reduced ability in the process beginning with penetration of the secondary oocyte by the spermatozoon and completed by fusion of the male and female pronuclei

Subject: myoclonus
Value: involuntary shock-like contractions, variable in rhythm and amplitude, followed by relaxation, of a muscle or a group of muscles; generally due to a central nervous system lesion

Subject: abnormal erythropoiesis
Value: atypical process of the formation of enucleated fetal and adult erythrocytes

Subject: macrocytosis
Value: condition in which erythrocytes are larger than normal in size

Subject: abnormal blood vessel physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of any of the tubes that convey blood including the arteries, arterioles, capillaries, venules, and veins

Subject: abnormal vasoconstriction
Value: anomaly in the narrowing of the blood vessels by smooth muscle contraction

Subject: blood vessel congestion
Value: obstruction of the normal flux of blood within the blood vessel network

Subject: echinocytosis
Value: a state in which the red blood cells have multiple small projections appearing over the cell circumference resembling a small burr or a sea urchin

Subject: abnormal vascular development
Value: aberrant process of vascular formation

Subject: abnormal angiogenesis
Value: aberrant process of blood vessel formation and the subsequent remodeling process; does not refer to the initial establishment of the vascular network

Subject: poor arterial differentiation
Value: failure of or inadequate acquisition of the characteristics and/or functions of the arteries

Subject: absent organized vascular network
Value: formation of vasculature, but failure to differentiate into stereotypic organized pattern

Subject: failure of vascular branching
Value: failure of vasculature to form divisions (offshoots)

Subject: blood vessel atresia
Value: abnormal closure or absence of the lumen of one or more blood vessels

Subject: abnormal heart morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the hollow, muscular organ that maintains the circulation of the blood

Subject: abnormal heart development
Value: aberrant formation or incomplete differentiation of the heart

Subject: abnormal heart looping
Value: any anomaly in the characteristic morphogenetic movements where the primitive heart tube loops asymmetrically during early development; this looping brings the primitive heart chambers into alignment preceding their future integration

Subject: abnormal heart tube morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the primitive epithelial cardiac tube before the division into the chambers of the mature heart

Subject: abnormal aorta morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the main trunk of the systemic arterial system that originates from the base of the left ventricle of the heart and extends to the abdomen at the point where it branches into the common iliac arteries

Subject: overriding aortic valve
Value: congenitally abnormal position of the aorta where the valve origin straddles the ventral septum and so receives ejected blood from the right ventricle as well as the left, frequently in conjunction with a ventricular septal defect

Subject: enlarged heart
Value: increase over normal size of the heart

Subject: heart hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size of the heart, usually due an increased number of cells

Subject: heart right ventricle hypertrophy
Value: enlargement of heart right ventricular wall from the increase in size of its cells

Subject: abnormal heart shape
Value: any anomaly in the characteristic surface outline or contour of the heart

Subject: abnormal myocardial fiber morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the terminally differentiated, non-proliferative, cardiac muscle fibers, the multinucleated muscle cells of the heart

Subject: ventricular hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of one or both of the two lower chambers of the heart

Subject: thin ventricular wall
Value: decreased depth of the cardiac wall of the heart ventricles

Subject: abnormal interventricular septum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the wall between the two lower chambers of the heart; the ventricular septum consists of a very small membranous portion just beneath the aortic valve, and a large thick muscular portion consisting of three sections including the inlet septum, the trabecular septum, and the outlet septum

Subject: abnormal interatrial septum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thin membranous structure between the two heart atria

Subject: double outlet right ventricle
Value: both the aorta and the pulmonary trunk originate, either in whole or in part, from the right ventricle; often found in conjunction with a ventricular septal defect

Subject: abnormal heart valve morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the membranous folds of the heart that prevent reflux of fluid

Subject: abnormal mitral valve morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the valve between the left atrium and the left ventricle of the heart, and contains two cusps, the anterior cusp and the posterior cusp, attached to the outer fibrous ring (annulus)

Subject: heart valve hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the heart valves, usually due to a reduced number of cells,

Subject: abnormal pericardium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the fibroserous membrane covering the heart and beginning of the great vessels

Subject: enlarged pericardium
Value: extended fibroserous membrane covering the heart and beginning of the great vessels

Subject: distended pericardium
Value: an expansion in the volume of the sac-like structure contained by the outer parietal layer of the pericardium

Subject: absent myocardial trabeculae
Value: absence of the supporting bundles of muscular fibers lining the walls of the heart

Subject: trabecula carnea hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the supporting bundles of muscular fibers lining the walls of the ventricles of the heart, usually due to a reduced number of cells

Subject: absent trabeculae carneae
Value: missing supporting bundles of muscular fibers lining the walls of the ventricles of the heart

Subject: abnormal atrioventricular cushion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the mounds of embryonic connective tissue that bulge into the fetal atrioventricular canal; these mounds eventually fuse to form the valves between the right and left atrioventricular orifices and the atrioventricular septum

Subject: absent atrioventricular cushions
Value: absence of the mounds of embryonic connective tissue that bulge into the fetal atrioventricular canal

Subject: failure of atrioventricular cushion closure
Value: failure of the mounds of embryonic connective tissue that bulge into the fetal atrioventricular canal to fuse to form the valves between the right and left atrioventricular orifices

Subject: thin atrioventricular cushion
Value: reduced thickness of the mounds of embryonic connective tissue that bulge into the fetal atrioventricular canal

Subject: decreased atrioventricular cushion size
Value: smaller than normal mounds of embryonic connective tissue that bulge into the fetal atrioventricular canal

Subject: abnormal cardiac stroke volume
Value: anomaly in the volume of blood pushed into the aorta with each beat of the heart

Subject: abnormal cell death
Value: any anomaly in the cessation of function at the cellular level

Subject: schistocytosis
Value: the appearance of poikilocytes in the blood that owe their abnormal shape to fragmentation occurring as the cells flow through damaged small vessels

Subject: hemoglobinuria
Value: the presence of hemoglobin in the urine, including certain closely related pigments that are formed from slight alteration of the hemoglobin molecule

Subject: cellular necrosis
Value: pathologic death of cells, usually from irreversible damage

Subject: increased bone marrow cell number
Value: increased number of cells that make up the core cavities of bones when compared to the normal state

Subject: increased granulocyte number
Value: greater than expected number of leukocytes that have abundant granules in the cytoplasm, including basophils, neutrophils, and eosinophils

Subject: increased mast cell number
Value: greater than expected number of the cells that are found in almost all tissues, containing numerous basophilic granules and capable of releasing large amounts of histamine and heparin upon activation

Subject: hemosiderinuria
Value: the presence of hemosiderin in the urine; hemosiderin is an intracellular storage form of iron, found in the form of pigmented yellow to brown granules consisting of a complex of ferric hydroxides, polysaccharides, and proteins with an iron content of about 33 per cent by weight

Subject: increased enterocyte cell number
Value: greater than expected number of the epithelial cells that have an apical plasma membrane folded into microvilli to provide ample surface for the absorption of nutrients from the intestinal lumen

Subject: hemoglobinemia
Value: the presence of free hemoglobin in the blood plasma, an indication of significant intravascular hemolysis

Subject: decreased bone marrow cell number
Value: decreased number of cells that make up the core cavities of bones when compared to the normal state

Subject: decreased granulocyte number
Value: fewer than expected number of leukocytes that have abundant granules in the cytoplasm, including basophils, neutrophils, and eosinophils

Subject: decreased mast cell number
Value: fewer than expected number of the cells that are found in almost all tissues, containing numerous basophilic granules and capable of releasing large amounts of histamine and heparin upon activation

Subject: decreased enterocyte cell number
Value: fewer than expected number of the epithelial cells that have an apical plasma membrane folded into microvilli to provide ample surface for the absorption of nutrients from the intestinal lumen

Subject: abnormal bile color
Value: any change in the color of the bile from the normal yellowish brown or green

Subject: altered response to myocardial infarction
Value: change in the physiological response to necrosis of the cardiac tissue, often resulting from the sudden insufficiency of arterial or venous blood supply due to emboli, thrombi or mechanical factors

Subject: absent Cajal-Retzius cell
Value: the absence of a distinct population of large, bipolar cells, distributed in a continuous band along the marginal zone of the cortex extending to the molecular layer of the dentate gyrus

Subject: broad head
Value: a greater ear- to -ear distance resulting in the appearance of a wide face and a flattened snout

Subject: abnormal aerobic fitness
Value: any change in the metabolism resulting in an altered ability to do physical work; for example, alterations in running capacity

Subject: abnormal cell proliferation
Value: anomaly in the ability of a cell population to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: increased cell proliferation
Value: increase in the expansion rate of a cell population by cell division

Subject: decreased cell proliferation
Value: reduction in the expansion rate of a cell population by cell division

Subject: abnormal cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the minute protoplasmic masses that make up organized tissues and which are the fundamental structural and functional units of living organisms

Subject: abnormal mast cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a cell that is found in almost all tissues, containing numerous basophilic granules and capable of releasing large amounts of histamine and heparin upon activation

Subject: decreased mast cell protease storage
Value: reduced amounts of proteolytic enzymes stored in mast cells

Subject: decreased mast cell histamine storage
Value: reduced amounts of histamine stored in mast cells

Subject: abnormal vascular regression
Value: premature regression or persistence of vessels programmed to regress and/or loss of vessels not programmed to regress

Subject: abnormal coat/ hair morphology
Value: any anomaly in the color, structure, growth, or texture of the hair

Subject: head blaze
Value: the appearance of a stripe of white fur on the head

Subject: diluted coat color
Value: a coat color that appears lighter in intensity or paler than normal

Subject: irregular coat pigmentation
Value: uneven coloration of the hair

Subject: belly spot
Value: the appearance of a round area of white fur on the belly

Subject: folliculitis
Value: inflammatory reaction in hair follicles

Subject: abnormal hair follicle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the invagination of the epidermis from which the hair shaft develops

Subject: absent hair follicles
Value: missing epidermal invaginations from which the hair shaft develops

Subject: decreased hair follicle number
Value: fewer number of the epidermal invaginations from which the hair shaft develops

Subject: small hair follicles
Value: reduced size of the invagination of the epidermis from which the hair shaft develops

Subject: enlarged hair follicles
Value: increased size of the epidermal invaginations from which the hair shaft develops

Subject: underdeveloped hair follicles
Value: arrest of or retarded differentiation of the epidermal invaginations from which the hair shaft develops

Subject: abnormal hair follicle orientation
Value: misaligned hair follicles; hair follicles that do not orient in a typical pattern

Subject: distorted hair follicle pattern
Value: twisted or contorted configuration of the arrangement of hair follicles in the skin

Subject: distended hair follicles
Value: follicles that have swollen or expanded from the skin

Subject: disorganized inner root sheath cells
Value: disorganization of the epithelial cells that resides in the inner root sheath of the hair follicle

Subject: absent hair follicle inner root sheath
Value: absence of the multilayered tube composed of terminally differentiated hair follicle keratinocytes that is surrounded by the outer root sheath; the layers of the inner root sheath include the companion layer, Henle's layer, Huxley's layer and the inner root sheath cuticle

Subject: disorganized outer root sheath cells
Value: disordered enveloping layer of cells of the hair follicle; surrounds inner root and is continuous with basal and spinous layers of the epidermis

Subject: disorganized matrix sheath cells
Value: disordered layer of matrix cells of the hair follicle

Subject: premature hair follicle generation
Value: early onset of hair follicle development

Subject: accelerated hair follicle regression
Value: earlier onset of catagen phase during the cyclic transformation of the hair follicle

Subject: persistent hair follicle morphogenesis
Value: continuous induction of de novo hair follicles in the epidermis

Subject: absent hair follicle melanin granules
Value: absence of the pigment polymers located in the hair follicles

Subject: increased curvature of hairs
Value: greater bending arch of the distinct C- or S- shaped curvature of the hairs

Subject: abnormal guard hair morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the long, straight truncal hairs that contain two air cells in the medulla

Subject: splitting of guard hairs
Value: intercellular splits and kinks within or along the hair shaft of the long, straight truncal hairs that contain two air cells in the medulla

Subject: increased curvature of guard hairs
Value: greater bending arch of the guard hairs

Subject: abnormal awl hair morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of truncal hairs that are straight, but are shorter than guard hairs, and contain two or more air cells in the medulla

Subject: increased curvature of awl hairs
Value: greater bending arch of the awl hairs

Subject: abnormal zigzag hair morphology
Value: any structural anomaly or amount of the truncal hairs that have two or more sharp bends with diameter constrictions at the bends, and contain one air cell in the medulla

Subject: increased curvature of zigzag hairs
Value: greater bending arch of the zigzag hairs

Subject: decreased curvature of zigzag hairs
Value: smaller bending arch of the zigzag hairs

Subject: abnormal auchene hair morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of truncal hairs having a single constriction and bend about midway along the hair shaft, and contain two or more air cells in the medulla

Subject: increased curvature of auchene hairs
Value: greater bending arch of the auchene hairs

Subject: abnormal duvet hair morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the fine under hair of the coat

Subject: absent duvet hair
Value: absence of the of the fine under hair of the coat

Subject: waved hair
Value: hair or fur having undulations or a sinusoidal shape

Subject: shiny fur
Value: fur with a glossy or glistening appearance

Subject: excessive hair
Value: greater amount of body hair compared to controls

Subject: polyphalangy
Value: increased number of phalanges in any of the digits

Subject: alopecia
Value: absence of hair due to loss of hair; not in reference to primary genetic hairlessness but may be due to dietary, stress or secondary to immune condition

Subject: sparse hair
Value: body hair that is less dense; may be due to reduced follicle numbers or due to the inability to retain some of the hairs of the coat over time

Subject: short hair
Value: reduced average length of the hairs

Subject: focal hair loss
Value: focal absence of hair in areas where hair is normally expected; in rodents, often appearing behind the ears and on the tail, resulting in visible patches of skin and uneven spots of hair growth on the body

Subject: ruffled hair
Value: fuzzy, irregular appearance of the hair

Subject: mottled coat
Value: coat has spots, streaks, and/or blotches of a different color

Subject: delayed hair appearance
Value: late onset of the first appearance of the fur

Subject: delayed hair regrowth
Value: slow initiation and asynchrony of the hair growth cycle (anagen) after catagen phase

Subject: retarded hair growth
Value: slow growth of the hair, appears at normal time

Subject: loss of eyelid cilia
Value: inability to retain the eyelashes

Subject: ectopic hair growth
Value: positional abnormality of hair

Subject: abnormal hair cycle
Value: aberrant timing of growth and regression of the hair follicles

Subject: abnormal craniofacial morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the face or head affecting appearance

Subject: absent maxillary shelf
Value: missing bony projection of the maxilla that normally fuses with palatine shelf to form secondary (hard) palate

Subject: absent palatine bone horizontal plate
Value: missing bony plate of the palatine bone that normally fuses with maxillary shelf to form secondary (hard) palate

Subject: abnormal head morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the portion of the body containing the brain and organs of sight, hearing, taste, and smell

Subject: microcephaly
Value: an abnormally small head

Subject: megacephaly
Value: an abnormally large size of the head

Subject: shortened head
Value: reduced anterior-posterior length of the head

Subject: abnormal head movements
Value: any anomaly in the motion of the portion of the body containing the brain and organs of sight, hearing, taste, and smell

Subject: taut facial appearance
Value: skin of face has appearance of being drawn or pulled tightly

Subject: abnormal cranium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bones of the head

Subject: enlarged cranium
Value: increased size of the cranium

Subject: domed cranium
Value: increased curvature to the hemispherical shape of the upper cranial case

Subject: increased cranium width
Value: having an increased side-to-side, or lateral distance of the cranium

Subject: abnormal snout morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anterior facial part of the face or muzzle containing the oral and nasal regions

Subject: short snout
Value: reduced length of the anterior facial part of the muzzle

Subject: long snout
Value: the anterior facial part of the muzzle having a length greater than seen in controls

Subject: flattened snout
Value: a snout flattened laterally along the whole length without the appearance of distinctive curvature

Subject: pointed snout
Value: muzzle tapers to a small tip, sharper angle than wild type

Subject: broad nasal bridge
Value: wider than normal upper part of the ridge of the nose

Subject: absent snout
Value: absence of the anterior facial part of the face or muzzle containing the oral and nasal regions

Subject: scaly muzzle
Value: muzzle covered with shedding scales or flakes

Subject: abnormal mouth morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the oral cavity

Subject: absent mouth
Value: absence of the oral cavity

Subject: abnormal jaw morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bony framework of the mouth where the teeth are held

Subject: abnormal maxilla morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the upper bony framework of the mouth where the superior teeth are held

Subject: maxilla hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the upper bony framework of the mouth where the superior teeth are held

Subject: abnormal mandible morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the lower bony framework of the mouth where the inferior teeth are held

Subject: abnormal presacral vertebrae morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the vertebrae anterior to the sacrum

Subject: mandible hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the lower bony framework of the mouth where the inferior teeth are held

Subject: decreased presacral vertebrae number
Value: reduced number of the vertebrae anterior to the sacrum

Subject: abnormal digestive system morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the system dedicated to the mechanical, chemical, and enzymatic processing of food

Subject: increased presacral vertebrae number
Value: greater number of the vertebrae anterior to the sacrum

Subject: gastrointestinal hemorrhage
Value: bleeding in the stomach and/or the intestines

Subject: esophageal epithelium hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due an increased number of cells in the epithelial layer lining the luminal space of the esophagus

Subject: abnormal esophagus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the part of the digestive canal through which food passes from the pharynx to the stomach

Subject: abnormal esophageal epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the epithelial layer that lines the luminal space of the esophagus

Subject: abnormal esophageal squamous epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the scaly epithelial layer of the esophagus

Subject: abnormal stomach morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the hollow, sac-like structure of the digestive canal between the esophagus and the small intestine that functions to emulsify food

Subject: abnormal stomach epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the epithelial layer of the stomach

Subject: abnormal stomach non-glandular epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the squamous epithelium that lines the distinct rodent non-glandular region of the stomach, i.e. the forestomach (aka anterior or proximal stomach); in neonatal and adult mice, this epithelium is stratified, fully keratinized, and devoid of gastric glands

Subject: abnormal stomach glandular epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the gland-containing epithelial layer of the stomach

Subject: abnormal foregut morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anterior portion of the primitive digestive tube of the embryo that lies cephalic to the junction of the yolk stalk, consists of endodermal tissue, and gives rise to the pharynx, lower respiratory system, esophagus, stomach, duodenum proximal to the biliary tract, liver, pancreas, biliary tract, and gall bladder

Subject: abnormal intestine morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the digestive tube passing from the stomach to the anus, consisting of the small and large intestine divisions

Subject: delayed intestine development
Value: slowed progression to a structurally mature intestine

Subject: abnormal enterocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the epithelial cells that have an apical plasma membrane folded into microvilli to provide ample surface for the absorption of nutrients from the intestinal lumen

Subject: increased rib number
Value: greater than normal numbers of the pairs of bony structures that are elements of the body wall

Subject: abnormal enterocyte cell number
Value: deviation from the normal numbers of enterocytes

Subject: long fibula
Value: increased length of the lateral and smaller of bone of the lower leg

Subject: abnormal pulmonary artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the artery that arises from the right ventricle and conveys unaerated blood to the lungs

Subject: abnormal pulmonary trunk morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the region of the pulmonary artery that arises from the right ventricle to the division of the right and left pulmonary artery

Subject: absent enterocytes
Value: absence of the epithelial cells that have an apical plasma membrane folded into microvilli to provide ample surface for the absorption of nutrients from the intestinal lumen

Subject: abnormal intestinal epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cellular avascular layer of the digestive tube passing from the stomach to the anus

Subject: abnormal large intestine morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the portion of the digestive tube extending from the ileocecal valve to the anus, consisting of the cecum, colon, rectum and anal canal

Subject: abnormal crypts of Lieberkuhn morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tubular intestinal glands found in the mucosal membranes

Subject: crypts of Lieberkuhn abscesses
Value: an exudate collection associated with inflammation in the crypts of Lieberkuhn of the intestinal mucosa; often associated with ulcerative colitis

Subject: abnormal rectum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the terminal portion of the intestinal tube adjacent to the anus

Subject: rectal prolapse
Value: downward movement and external appearance of the rectum through the anus

Subject: abnormal cecum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the large sac at the ileum and large intestine junction

Subject: abnormal colon morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the portion of the large intestine between the cecum and the rectum

Subject: abnormal small intestine morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the portion of the digestive tube between the stomach and the cecum, consisting of the duodenum, ileum and jejunum

Subject: abnormal small intestine placement
Value: different location or arrangement of the small intestinal tract

Subject: absent jejunum
Value: missing portion of the small intestine that extends from the duodenum to the ileum

Subject: absent ileum
Value: missing portion of the small intestine that extends from the jejunum to the colon

Subject: small intestinal prolapse
Value: the descent of the small intestine through a weakness in the supporting tissues at the apex of the vagina gives rise to an enterocele, frequently caused by a weakness or separation of the cardinal and sacro-uterine ligaments

Subject: abnormal digestive secretion
Value: anomaly in the production and/or release of a physiologically active substance (usually but not exclusively in liquid form) from a cell or a gland of the digestive system

Subject: excessive digestive secretion
Value: increase in the production and/or release of a physiologically active substance (usually but not exclusively in liquid form) from a cell or a gland of the digestive system

Subject: obsolete excessive digestive mucosecretion
Value: increase in the production and/or release of a physiologically active substance (usually but not exclusively in liquid form) from the mucous membrane of the digestive system

Subject: decreased digestive secretion
Value: reduction in the production and/or release of a physiologically active substance (usually but not exclusively in liquid form) from a cell or a gland of the digestive system

Subject: obsolete decreased digestive mucosecretion
Value: reduction in the production and/or release of a physiologically active substance (usually but not exclusively in liquid form) from the mucous membrane of the digestive system

Subject: absent digestive secretion
Value: failure to produce and/or release a physiologically active substance (usually but not exclusively in liquid form) from a cell or a gland of the digestive system

Subject: right-sided isomerism
Value: anomaly in the asymmetry of the visceral paired organs (e.g. lungs) such that organs on the left and right side have the morphology normally seen on the right side of the body; this may also be associated with absence of the spleen

Subject: obsolete absent digestive mucosecretion
Value: failure to produce and/or release a physiologically active substance (usually but not exclusively in liquid form) from the mucous membrane of the digestive system

Subject: remittent intestinal hemorrhage
Value: loss of blood from the intestines that is characterized by temporary periods of abatement

Subject: abnormal intestinal mucosa morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the mucous lining of the intestine; this consists of epithelium, lamina propria, and a layer of smooth muscle cells

Subject: intestinal ulcer
Value: lesions in the mucous lining of the intestine

Subject: abnormal renal/urinary system morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the organs or tissues responsible for fluid volume regulation, regulating electrolytes, maintaining acid-base homeostasis, and elimination of water and water soluble waste products in an organism

Subject: hydronephrosis
Value: dilation of the pelvis and calices of one or both kidneys

Subject: absent kidney
Value: absence of the two excretory organs that filter wastes (especially urea) from the blood and excrete them and water in urine

Subject: abnormal kidney cortex morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the outer portion of the kidney located between the renal capsule and the renal medulla and involved in ultrafiltration; it contains the renal corpuscles, the renal tubules (except for parts of the loop of Henle which descend into the renal medulla), blood vessels and cortical collecting ducts

Subject: kidney cortex cysts
Value: abnormal membranous sacs appearing in the outer portion of the kidney located between the renal capsule and the renal medulla and involved in ultrafiltration, containing the renal corpuscles, the renal tubules (except for parts of the loop of Henle which descend into the renal medulla), blood vessels and cortical collecting ducts

Subject: cortical renal glomerulopathies
Value: any disease of the capillary plexus in the kidney cortex

Subject: decreased renal tubule number
Value: fewer of the loops of Henle, the proximal convoluted tubules or the distal convoluted tubules

Subject: renal tubular acidosis
Value: a clinical syndrome characterized by the inability to acidify urine

Subject: small inner medullary pyramid
Value: reduced size of pyramidal masses; contain part of the secreting tubules and collecting tubules

Subject: abnormal kidney development
Value: any anomaly in the differentiation of the paired organs responsible for urine secretion

Subject: delayed kidney development
Value: late onset of the induction and/or differentiation of the kidney

Subject: abnormal kidney blood vessel morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the network of tubes that carries blood through the organ of excretion

Subject: right pulmonary isomerism
Value: anomaly in the asymmetry of the lung such that the lobes on both the left and right side have the morphology normally seen on the right side of the body

Subject: kidney vascular congestion
Value: obstruction of the normal flux of blood within the blood vessel network of the organ of secretion

Subject: kidney hemorrhage
Value: bleeding in the organ of excretion

Subject: abnormal ureter morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tube that conducts the urine from the renal pelvis to the bladder

Subject: ureter urothelium hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due an increased number of cells, of the luminal epithelium of the tube that conducts the urine from the renal pelvis to the bladder

Subject: hydroureter
Value: distention of the ureter with urine, due to blockage from any cause

Subject: abnormal urethra morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the fibromuscular tubular canal through which urine is discharged from the bladder to the exterior via the external urinary meatus; in males, the urethra is joined by the ejaculatory ducts and serves as a passageway for semen during ejaculation, as well as a canal for urine during voiding; in females, the urethra is shorter and emerges above the vaginal opening

Subject: abnormal urinary bladder morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the distensible musculomembranous organ that serves to collect and store urine excreted by the kidneys

Subject: distended urinary bladder
Value: stretched musculomembranous organ that serves to collect and store urine excreted by the kidneys

Subject: abnormal urinary bladder urothelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the epithelial lining of the luminal space of the urinary bladder

Subject: obsolete abnormal urinary bladder transitional epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the transitional epithelial layer of the urinary bladder

Subject: left-sided isomerism
Value: anomaly in the asymmetry of the visceral paired organs (e.g. lungs) such that organs on the left and right side have the morphology normally seen on the left side of the body; this may also be associated with the presence of multiple spleens

Subject: absent urinary bladder urothelium
Value: missing the transitional epithelial layer of the urinary bladder

Subject: thin urinary bladder urothelium
Value: decrease in the thickness of the transitional epithelial layer of the urinary bladder

Subject: short limbs
Value: reduced average length of the extremities

Subject: long limbs
Value: increased average length of the extremities

Subject: absent limbs
Value: absence of the projecting paired appendages of an animal trunk, used in particular for movement and grasping; usually denotes the arm and/or legs in mammalian species

Subject: abnormal forelimb morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the projecting rostral-most paired appendages of an animal trunk, used in particular for movement and grasping; usually denotes the arm or front limb in mammalian species

Subject: absent forelimb
Value: absence of the projecting rostral-most paired appendages of an animal trunk, used in particular for movement and grasping; usually denotes the arm or front limb in mammalian species

Subject: abnormal radius morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the short bone of the lateral forearm

Subject: absent radius
Value: missing the short bone of the lateral forearm

Subject: abnormal carpal bone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the nine nodular bones of the joint between the forelimb bones and the front paws/hands consisting of the scapholunar, triangular, greater multiangular, lesser multiangular, capitate, hamate, centrale and the sesamoids

Subject: absent carpal bone
Value: absence of any or all of the nine nodular bones of the joint between the forelimb bones and the front paws/hands, consisting of the scapholunar, triangular, greater multiangular, lesser multiangular, capitate, hamate, centrale and the sesamoids

Subject: abnormal hindlimb morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the projecting caudal-most paired appendages of an animal trunk, used in particular for movement and grasping; usually denotes the legs or back limbs in mammalian species

Subject: absent hindlimb
Value: absence of the projecting caudal-most paired appendages of an animal trunk, used in particular for movement and grasping; usually denotes the legs or back limbs in mammalian species

Subject: abnormal tibia morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the medial and larger of the two bones of the lower leg

Subject: abnormal femur morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the long bone of the thigh

Subject: adactyly
Value: missing one or more digits, or all digits

Subject: polydactyly
Value: greater than the normal complement of digits on one or more autopods

Subject: syndactyly
Value: any degree of webbing or fusion of the digits, may involve only soft tissues or also can include bone

Subject: oligodactyly
Value: congenital condition in which some digits or parts of digits are missing

Subject: synostosis
Value: osseous union of two bones that are not normally connected

Subject: truncation of digits
Value: absence of the most distal region of the digits

Subject: ectopic digits
Value: positional abnormality of a digit

Subject: abnormal digit pigmentation
Value: anomaly in the coloration of the fingers or toes due to changes in the amount, shape, or distribution of cells producing pigment

Subject: interdigital webbing
Value: fold of skin, or web, between the toes that is not normally present

Subject: abnormal autopod morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the distal elements of the limb of vertebrates including the pedal or prehensile appendages (e.g. hand, foot, paw, phalanges and/or digits)

Subject: enlarged hind paws
Value: larger than average size of the rear feet

Subject: abnormal foot pad morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the body of fat on the foot

Subject: increased foot pad pigmentation
Value: darker color of the foot pads due to excess pigment

Subject: clubfoot
Value: congenital deformation of the feet; foot is plantarflexed, inverted and adducted

Subject: absent eccrine glands
Value: absence of the coiled tubular glands situated on the digits and footpads of the paws of rodents, and both in the histologically thick skin of the palmar and plantar surfaces and in the thin skin that covers most of the rest of the body in humans

Subject: ulcerated paws
Value: inflammatory, often suppurating lesions on the paws; often become necrotic

Subject: abnormal nail morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the horny plates covering the dorsal surface of the distal end of each terminal phalanx of the digits

Subject: deformed nails
Value: atypical shape or size of the nails

Subject: toenail hyperkeratosis
Value: keratin extensions from the toenails

Subject: long toenails
Value: increased length of the toenails

Subject: kinked tail
Value: a sharp bend or zigzag in the tail

Subject: thick tail
Value: a tail with a greater diameter than normal

Subject: thin tail
Value: a tail with a smaller diameter than normal

Subject: short tail
Value: reduced length of tail compared to control

Subject: abnormal liver development
Value: any anomaly in the differentiation of the bile-secreting organ that is important for detoxification, for fat, carbohydrate, and protein metabolism, and for glycogen storage

Subject: delayed hepatic development
Value: late onset of the induction and/or differentiation of the liver

Subject: abnormal liver morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bile-secreting organ that is important for detoxification, for fat, carbohydrate, and protein metabolism, and for glycogen storage

Subject: enlarged liver
Value: larger than average size of the liver

Subject: liver hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the liver, usually due to a reduced number of cells,

Subject: small liver
Value: reduced size of the liver

Subject: dilated liver sinusoidal spaces
Value: an expansion in the volume or area of the lumen (space) that is enclosed by a liver sinusoid

Subject: pale liver
Value: liver lacking normal coloration, often refers to bloodless condition

Subject: amyloidosis
Value: an accumulation of extracellular amyloid in tissues of the body

Subject: decreased hepatocyte number
Value: fewer than normal number of parenchymal liver cells

Subject: abnormal hepatocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the main structural specialized epithelial cells which normally organize into interconnected plates called lobules

Subject: dissociated hepatocytes
Value: disorganization of cohesive hepatocyte structure

Subject: abnormal liver physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the bile-secreting organ that is important for detoxification, for fat, carbohydrate, and protein metabolism, and for glycogen storage

Subject: cholestasis
Value: impairment of bile flow due to obstruction in small bile ducts (intrahepatic cholestasis) or obstruction in large bile ducts (extrahepatic cholestasis)

Subject: jaundice
Value: clinical manifestation of hyperbilirubinemia, with deposition of bile pigments in the skin, resulting in yellowish staining of the skin and mucous membranes

Subject: abnormal salivary gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the saliva-secreting glands of the oral cavity

Subject: absent salivary gland
Value: missing any of the saliva-secreting glands of the oral cavity

Subject: abnormal palatine gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the salivary gland of the hard palate

Subject: decreased ductal branching in the palatine gland
Value: fewer branches and distal tips of the vesicles of the palatine gland

Subject: increased salivary gland mucosal cell number
Value: greater than normal number of cells that form mucus in the salivary glands

Subject: small salivary gland
Value: reduced size of the saliva-secreting glands of the oral cavity

Subject: salivary gland epithelial hyperplasia
Value: increased cell number in the epithelium of the salivary gland

Subject: narrow salivary ducts
Value: reduced diameter of the tubular canals that carry saliva

Subject: increased salivary adenocarcinoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a malignant neoplasm of the secreting cells of the salivary gland, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased salivation
Value: greater than normal amounts of flowing saliva

Subject: decreased salivation
Value: reduction in the flow, secretion, or amount of saliva

Subject: xerostomia
Value: dryness of the mouth resulting from reduced salivary secretion

Subject: abnormal mammary gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the compound, alveolar and apocrine accessory gland of the skin of mammals that secretes milk

Subject: abnormal mammary gland development
Value: aberration in the differentiation of the mammary gland during early embryogenesis or during sexual maturity

Subject: absent mammary gland
Value: absence of the specialized accessory gland of the skin of mammals that secretes milk

Subject: mammary gland hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size of the mammary gland, usually due an increased number of cells

Subject: abnormal neuroendocrine gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the organized aggregations of cells that function as secretory or excretory organs and that release hormones in response to neural stimuli

Subject: abnormal pineal gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the unpaired epithalamic structure that is shaped like a tiny pine cone and located above the posterior commissure near the level of the habenular complex and the sylvian aqueduct; it is both a circumventricular organ and an endocrine organ that secretes melatonin, a serotonin-derived hormone involved in the regulation of circadian rhythms; the pineal parenchyma, consisting of pinealocytes, interstitial (glial-like) cells, phagocytes and capillaries, is arranged into large folliculi separated by septae of connective tissue and blood vessels

Subject: abnormal pituitary gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the compound gland suspended from the base of the hypothalamus, which secretes somatotropins, prolactin, TSH (thyroid-stimulating hormone), gonadotropins, adrenal corticotropin from the anterior lobe; melanocyte stimulating hormone from the intermediate lobe and hormones involved in blood pressure regulation from the posterior lobe

Subject: pituitary gland hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due to increased cell number, of the pituitary gland

Subject: enlarged pituitary gland
Value: increased size of pituitary gland

Subject: abnormal adrenal gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the pair of endocrine glands located above the kidney that are responsible for steroid hormone secretion from the cortex and neurotransmitter (such as epinephrine and norepinephrine) secretion from the medulla

Subject: adrenal gland hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the endocrine glands located above the kidney and responsible for hormone and epinephrine secretion

Subject: enlarged adrenal glands
Value: increased size of the pair of endocrine glands located above the kidney that are responsible for steroid hormone secretion from the cortex and neurotransmitter (such as epinephrine and norepinephrine) secretion from the medulla

Subject: absent adrenal medulla
Value: absence of the inner portion of the adrenal gland that consists mainly of chromaffin cells which produce, store and secrete neurotransmitters such as epinephrine and norepinephrine

Subject: dextrocardia
Value: congenital defect in which the heart is located on the right side of the thorax instead of on the left side (levocardia, the normal position)

Subject: absent adrenergic chromaffin cells
Value: absence of the cells of the medulla of the adrenal gland that are innervated by the splanchnic nerve and that are responsible for epinephrine secretion

Subject: enlarged adrenocortical cells
Value: larger size of cells of the steroid hormone-producing cells of the cortex of the adrenal gland

Subject: abnormal sebaceous gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the holocrine glands that secrete sebum into the hair follicles or in hairless areas into ducts

Subject: absent sebaceous gland
Value: absence of the holocrine glands of the dermis that secrete sebum into the hair follicles

Subject: sebaceous gland atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of the holocrine glands of the dermis that secrete sebum into the hair follicles, associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: mesocardia
Value: congenital defect in which the heart is located in the middle of the thorax instead of on the left side (levocardia, the normal position)

Subject: enlarged sebaceous gland
Value: increased size of the sebum secreting glands of the hair shaft

Subject: abnormal sex gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the organized aggregations of cells that function as secretory or excretory organs and are associated with reproduction

Subject: absent sex gland
Value: missing any of the organized aggregations of cells that function as secretory or excretory organs and are associated with reproduction

Subject: dilated sex gland
Value: stretched appearance or excessive fluid in of any of the sex glands

Subject: prostate gland hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due an increased number of cells in the prostate

Subject: lateral prostate gland hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, in the lateral lobe of the prostate

Subject: small prostate gland ventral lobe
Value: reduced size of the rodent prostate lobe that is located below the ventral aspect of the bladder neck

Subject: abnormal branching of the mammary ductal tree
Value: anomaly in the development of the channels that secrete milk and direct milk to the nipple

Subject: small prostate gland anterior lobe
Value: reduced size of the rodent prostate lobe that appears as a thin tubular structure, attached to the lesser curvature of the paired seminal vesicles

Subject: decreased ductal branching in the coagulating gland
Value: fewer branches and distal tips of the vesicles of the coagulating gland

Subject: decreased prostate gland duct number
Value: fewer than normal minute canals that pass the prostatic secretions to the urethra

Subject: bulbourethral gland hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced cell number, of the bulbourethral gland

Subject: abnormal sweat gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the coil glands of the skin that secrete sweat

Subject: abnormal eccrine sweat gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the coiled tubular glands situated on the digits and footpads of the paws of rodents, and both in the histologically thick skin of the palmar and plantar surfaces and in the thin skin that covers most of the rest of the body in humans; in mice these are the only sweat glands present

Subject: abnormal body water content
Value: more or less than the normal total amount of water retained in the body

Subject: abnormal parathyroid gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of one of the two small, paired endocrine glands, usually found embedded in the connective tissue capsule on the posterior surface of the thyroid gland; they secrete parathyroid hormone (PTH) that regulates calcium and phosphorous metabolism

Subject: increased percent water in carcass
Value: more than the normal total amount of water retained in the body measured post mortem

Subject: absent parathyroid glands
Value: missing the two small, paired endocrine glands, usually found embedded in the connective tissue capsule on the posterior surface of the thyroid gland, which secrete parathyroid hormone (PTH)

Subject: abnormal thyroid gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the endocrine gland located in the front and to the sides of the upper part of the trachea and which secretes thyroid hormone and calcitonin

Subject: decreased percent water in carcass
Value: less than the normal total amount of water retained in the body measured post mortem

Subject: abnormal immune system morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the organs or cells associated with the development and formation of lymphocytes

Subject: small lymphoid organs
Value: reduced size of lymphatic tissues

Subject: lymphoid hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due to increased cell number, of lymphatic tissues

Subject: abnormal spleen morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the organ that functions to filter blood and to store red corpuscles and platelets

Subject: absent spleen
Value: missing organ that functions to filter blood and to store red corpuscles and platelets

Subject: enlarged spleen
Value: increased spleen size

Subject: small spleen
Value: decreased spleen size

Subject: spleen hyperplasia
