Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due to increased cell number, in the spleen

Subject: spleen hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced cell number, in the spleen

Subject: abnormal Peyer's patch morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the protruding lymphoid tissue located on the mucosa of the small intestine that is composed of densely packed B cell follicles

Subject: abnormal lymph node number
Value: deviation from the normal number of lymph nodes

Subject: abnormal lymph node size
Value: deviation from the normal lymph node size

Subject: enlarged lymph nodes
Value: lymph nodes of increased size

Subject: abnormal thymus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the primary lymphoid organ that is required for maturation of T cells and secretion of thymosins, hormones that stimulate the development of antibodies; the thymus also stimulates the production of certain pituitary gland hormones that promote growth and sexual maturation

Subject: abnormal thymus development
Value: anomaly in the formation and/or differentiation of the thymus

Subject: athymia
Value: absence of the primary lymphoid organ

Subject: small thymus
Value: reduced size of the thymus

Subject: thymus hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due to increased cell number, in the thymus

Subject: enlarged thymus
Value: increased size of thymus

Subject: thymus cortex hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced cell number, of the outer part of a thymus lobule that surrounds the medulla and is composed of closely packed lymphocytes

Subject: increased thymocyte number
Value: greater than expected number of immature T cells located in the thymus

Subject: decreased thymocyte number
Value: fewer than expected number of immature T cells located in the thymus

Subject: abnormal immune system cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of immune cells

Subject: abnormal lymphocyte cell number
Value: deviation from the normal number of the cells involved in adaptive immune reactions of the body in most inflammatory and autoimmune diseases, including B cells, T cells and natural killer cells

Subject: absent lymphocyte
Value: absence of the cells involved in adaptive immune reactions of the body in most inflammatory and autoimmune diseases, including B cells, T cells and natural killer cells

Subject: absent CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells
Value: lack of the set of single-positive T cells that express CD8 on their surface

Subject: abnormal myogenesis
Value: anomaly in embryonic formation of muscle cells or fibers

Subject: increased satellite cell number
Value: greater number of unfused cells in muscle that play a role in muscle regeneration

Subject: increased collagen deposition in the muscles
Value: accumulation of collagen within the muscles

Subject: delayed primary myocyte appearance
Value: development of initial muscle cells at a later time than is normal

Subject: abnormal muscle development
Value: any anomaly in the differentiation of muscle tissue

Subject: muscle hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of muscle, usually due to a reduced number of cells

Subject: delayed muscle development
Value: late onset of the induction and/or differentiation of skeletal muscle

Subject: abnormal myotome development
Value: malformation of or absence of the part of the somite that develops into the musculature

Subject: impaired muscle contractility
Value: inability or reduced ability of a muscle to shorten or to develop increased tension

Subject: impaired smooth muscle contractility
Value: inability or reduced ability of the smooth muscle to shorten or to develop increased tension

Subject: impaired contractility of urinary bladder detrusor smooth muscle
Value: inability or reduced ability of the detrusor smooth muscle of the urinary bladder to shorten or to develop increased tension voluntarily or involuntarily; stretching of the smooth muscle fibers by accumulation of urine in the bladder leads to nervous signaling giving the urge to urinate; contraction of the detrusor muscle leads to urination, via emptying of the urine contained in the bladder through the urethra and urine excretion

Subject: impaired contractility of ileal smooth muscle
Value: inability or reduced ability of the ileal smooth muscle to shorten or to develop increased tension

Subject: muscle spasm
Value: an involuntary and often painful muscle contraction or cramps having a number of causes ranging from nutritional deficiency to serious nervous system conditions

Subject: tremors
Value: repetitive, cyclical movements of the body or a body part; usually involuntary, but can also manifest in response to an attempt at movement

Subject: weakness
Value: state of being infirm or less strong than normal

Subject: muscle weakness
Value: loss of muscle strength

Subject: progressive muscle weakness
Value: increasing loss of muscle strength over time

Subject: muscle degeneration
Value: pathological deterioration of muscle tissue, often accompanied by loss of function

Subject: abnormal muscle regeneration
Value: anomaly in the ability to repair muscle after injury or disease

Subject: myopathy
Value: any abnormal condition or disease of the skeletal muscle

Subject: dystrophic muscle
Value: progressive weakness and wasting of muscle

Subject: paralysis
Value: severe or complete loss of power of voluntary movement in a muscle through injury or disease of its nerve supply

Subject: paresis
Value: mild or partial loss of power of voluntary movement in a muscle through injury or disease of it or its nerve supply

Subject: hindlimb paralysis
Value: severe or complete loss of power of voluntary movement in the muscles of the hindlimb through injury or disease of it or its nerve supply

Subject: forelimb paralysis
Value: severe or complete loss of power of voluntary movement in muscles of the forelimb through injury or disease of it or its nerve supply

Subject: herniated abdominal wall
Value: protrusions through and/or into the abdominal wall often resulting in the extrusion of viscera

Subject: abnormal skeletal muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the striated muscle fibers connected at either or both extremities with the bony framework of the body

Subject: thin diaphragm muscle
Value: reduced thickness of the diaphragm muscle

Subject: abnormal tongue morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the mobile mass of muscular tissue and surrounding epithelial tissue occupying the cavity of the mouth and forming part of the floor

Subject: abnormal filiform papillae morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the keratinized projections on the dorsal surface of the tongue

Subject: abnormal tongue epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the epithelial layer of the tongue

Subject: abnormal tongue squamous epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the scaly epithelial layer of the tongue

Subject: absent tongue squamous epithelium
Value: missing the scaly epithelial layer of the tongue

Subject: abnormal smooth muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the unstriated muscle fibers of the internal organs, blood vessels, hair follicles, etc.

Subject: abnormal brain size
Value: deviation from the average range of brain size for an organism

Subject: decreased brain size
Value: smaller appearance of the brain

Subject: abnormal inferior colliculus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the paired inferior eminence of the mesencephalic tectum that is involved in preliminary visual processing, and control of eye movements

Subject: increased inferior colliculus size
Value: enlargement of the paired inferior eminence of the mesencephalic tectum

Subject: abnormal nervous system tract morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the structure of any bundle of myelinated nerve fibers following a defined path through the brain and/or spinal cord

Subject: abnormal corpus callosum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a thick bundle of nerve fibers comprising a commissural plate connecting the two cerebral hemispheres; it consists of contralateral axon projections that provides communications between the right and left cerebral hemispheres

Subject: decreased corpus callosum size
Value: smaller thick bundle of nerve fibers comprising a commissural plate connecting the two cerebral hemispheres; it consists of contralateral axon projections that provides communications between the right and left cerebral hemispheres

Subject: abnormal forebrain morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anterior of the three primary divisions of the developing chordate brain or the corresponding part of the adult brain (in vertebrates, includes especially the cerebral hemispheres, the thalamus, and the hypothalamus and especially in higher vertebrates is the main control center for sensory and associative information processing, visceral functions, and voluntary motor functions)

Subject: forebrain hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, in the anterior of the three primary divisions of the developing chordate brain or the corresponding part of the adult brain (in vertebrates, includes especially the cerebral hemispheres, the thalamus, and the hypothalamus and especially in higher vertebrates is the main control center for sensory and associative information processing, visceral functions, and voluntary motor functions)

Subject: telencephalon hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, in of the enlarged anteriolateral part of the brain; consists of the paired cerebral hemispheres and olfactory bulbs, the basal ganglia and the connecting structures

Subject: abnormal embryonic neuroepithelial layer differentiation
Value: abnormal or arrest of differentiation or patterning of the epithelial cell layer that lines the neural tube and develops into the nervous system and into the neural crest cells

Subject: abnormal telencephalon morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the enlarged anteriolateral part of the brain; consists of the paired cerebral hemispheres and olfactory bulbs, the basal ganglia and the connecting structures, and is considered to be the seat of conscious mental processes; it develops from the anterior-most embryological division of the brain that develops from the prosencephalon

Subject: abnormal cerebral cortex morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of thin layer of grey matter on the surface of the cerebral hemisphere that folds into gyri; it is responsible for intellectual faculties and higher mental functions

Subject: thickened cerebral cortex
Value: increased depth of the mantle covering the surface of the cerebral hemispheres

Subject: abnormal stratification in cerebral cortex
Value: abnormal formation or pattern of the layers of the cerebral cortex

Subject: delaminated cerebral cortex
Value: splitting of the layers of the grey cellular mantle covering the surface of the brain

Subject: abnormal cortical marginal zone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the developing superficial cortical layer located just under the pia matter

Subject: abnormal parietal lobe morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the upper central part of the cerebral hemisphere

Subject: abnormal postcentral gyrus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the area of the parietal lobe that receives general sensation from the body

Subject: abnormal sensory dissociation area morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the area of the parietal lobe that integrates tactile and visual stimuli

Subject: abnormal supramarginal gyrus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the area of the frontal lobe that is involved in perception based on sensory stimuli

Subject: abnormal frontal lobe morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anterior part of the cerebral hemisphere

Subject: abnormal precentral gyrus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the area of the frontal lobe that contains the cell bodies of the primary motor pathways

Subject: abnormal supplemetal motor cortex morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the area of the frontal lobe that is involved with integration of voluntary movements and with speech

Subject: abnormal temporal lobe morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the lower lateral part of the cerebral hemisphere

Subject: abnormal superior temporal gyrus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of one of three major convolutions of the external surface of the temporal lobe of the cerebral hemispheres that is uppermost and borders the lateral (sylvian) fissure, and contains the primary auditory cortex

Subject: abnormal transverse gyrus of Heschl morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the area of the temporal lobe concerned with hearing

Subject: abnormal occipital lobe morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the posterior part of the cerebral hemisphere

Subject: abnormal visual cortex morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the area of the occipital cortex concerned with vision

Subject: abnormal hippocampus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the deep lying structure of the cerebrum involved with memory storage and spatial navigation

Subject: abnormal hippocampus development
Value: improper differentiation of the hippocampus

Subject: absent hippocampus
Value: missing convoluted brain structure below the cerebral hemispheres; forms part of the limbic system

Subject: hippocampal neuron degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of the neuronal cells in the hippocampus

Subject: abnormal dentate gyrus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of one of two interlocking gyri of the hippocampus formation that contains granule cells, which project to the pyramidal cells and interneurons of the CA3 region of the ammon gyrus

Subject: abnormal hippocampus layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the layers of the laminar structure of the hippocampus

Subject: absent dentate gyrus
Value: lack of the section of the hippocampus normally situated above the gyrus hippocampi and composed of three layers, the molecular, granular, and polymorphic layers

Subject: abnormal Ammon gyrus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of one or both of the two interlocking gyri of the hippocampus formation; a circonvolution of rhinencephalon, the grey substance of which is rich in big pyramidal neuronal cells

Subject: abnormal amygdala morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the almond-shaped body of basal nuclei anterior to the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle of the brain, within the temporal lobe; this area is involved in aggression and fear responses

Subject: abnormal olfactory bulb morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the forebrain region that coordinates neuronal signaling involved in the perception of smell; it receives input from the sensory neurons and outputs to the olfactory cortex

Subject: abnormal choroid plexus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the infoldings of blood vessels of the pia mater covered by a thin coat of ependymal cells that form tufted projections into the third, fourth, and lateral ventricles of the brain; choroid plexuses secrete cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and act as a filtration system, removing metabolic waste, foreign substances, and excess neurotransmitters from the CSF

Subject: choroid plexus hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due an increased number of cells located in the infoldings of blood vessels of the pia mater covered by a thin coat of ependymal cells that form tufted projections into the third, fourth, and lateral ventricles of the brain

Subject: abnormal brain ventricle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the system of four communicating cavities within the brain that are continuous with the central canal of the spinal cord

Subject: abnormal lateral ventricle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cavity in each of the cerebral hemispheres derived from the cavity of the embryonic neural tube; they are separated from each other by the septum pellucidum, and each communicates with the third ventricle by the foramen of Monro, through which also the choroid plexuses of the lateral ventricles become continuous with that of the third ventricle

Subject: dilated lateral ventricles
Value: the luminal space of the lateral ventricles is increased in volume or area, usually with an increase in contained fluid, in the cavity in each of the cerebral hemispheres derived from the cavity of the embryonic neural tube; they are separated from each other by the septum pellucidum, and each communicates with the third ventricle by the foramen of Monro, through which also the choroid plexuses of the lateral ventricles become continuous with that of the third ventricle

Subject: abnormal third ventricle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the narrow cleft inferior to the corpus callosum, within the diencephalon, between the paired thalami; its floor is formed by the hypothalamus, its anterior wall by the lamina terminalis, and its roof by ependyma; it communicates with the fourth ventricle by the cerebral aqueduct, and with the lateral ventricles by the interventricular foramina

Subject: dilated third ventricle
Value: the luminal space of the third ventricle is increased in volume or area, usually with an increase in contained fluid, in the narrow cleft inferior to the corpus callosum, within the diencephalon, between the paired thalami; its floor is formed by the hypothalamus, its anterior wall by the lamina terminalis, and its roof by ependyma; it communicates with the fourth ventricle by the cerebral aqueduct, and with the lateral ventricles by the interventricular foramina

Subject: abnormal fourth ventricle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the irregularly shaped cavity in the rhombencephalon, between the medulla oblongata, the pons, and the isthmus in front, and the cerebellum behind; it is continuous with the central canal of the cord below and with the cerebral aqueduct above, and through its lateral and median apertures it communicates with the subarachnoid space

Subject: dilated fourth ventricle
Value: the luminal space of the fourth ventricle is increased in volume or area, usually with an increase in contained fluid, in the irregularly shaped cavity in the rhombencephalon, between the medulla oblongata, the pons, and the isthmus in front, and the cerebellum behind; it is continuous with the central canal of the cord below and with the cerebral aqueduct above, and through its lateral and median apertures it communicates with the subarachnoid space

Subject: abnormal diencephalon morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the paired caudal parts of the prosencephalon from which the thalamus, hypothalamus, epithalamus and subthalamus are derived; these regions regulate autonomic, visceral and endocrine function, and process information directed to the cerebral cortex

Subject: diencephalon hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due an increased number of cells in the rostral portion of the brain stem

Subject: abnormal thalamus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the large ovoid mass of paired bodies containing mostly grey matter and forming part of the lateral wall of the third ventricle of the brain

Subject: thalamus hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due an increased number of cells in the thalamus

Subject: abnormal subthalamus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anterior part of the diencephalon that lies between the thalamus, hypothalamus, and tegmentum of the mesencephalon, including subthalamic nucleus, zona incerta, the fields of Forel, and the nucleus of ansa lenticularis

Subject: abnormal subthalamic nucleus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the lens-shaped nucleus located in the ventral part of the subthalamus on the inner aspect of the internal capsule that is concerned with the integration of somatic motor function

Subject: abnormal substantia nigra morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the layer of grey substance that separates the posterior parts of the cerebral peduncles (tegmentum mesencephali) from the anterior parts; it normally includes a posterior compact part with many pigmented cells (pars compacta) and an anterior reticular part whose cells contain little pigment (pars reticularis)

Subject: abnormal hypothalamus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the ventral part of the diencephalon extending from the region of the optic chiasm to the caudal border of the mammillary bodies and forming the inferior and lateral walls of the third ventricle; this region regulates the autonomic nervous system via hormone production and release

Subject: hypothalamus hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due an increased number of cells in the hypothalamus

Subject: abnormal epithalamus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small dorsomedial area of the thalamus including the habenular nuclei and associated fiber bundles, the pineal body, and the epithelial roof of the third ventricle

Subject: abnormal hindbrain morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the part of the brain developed from the posterior of the three primary brain vesicles of the embryonic neural tube from which the metencephalon and myelencephalon are derived; the metencephalon (anterior part of the embryonic hindbrain), gives rise to the cerebellum and pons while the myelencephalon (posterior portion of the embryonic hindbrain) gives rise to the medulla oblongata

Subject: absent superior olivary complex
Value: missing nucleus of neurons on the dorsal part of the lateral surface of the pons; it normally receives projection fibers from the cochlear nuclei and is prominently involved in spatial localization of sound

Subject: absent facial nuclei
Value: missing nucleus of neurons in the hindbrain; receives fibers from the facial muscles, stapedus muscle and stylohyoid muscle

Subject: abnormal pontine flexure morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the dorsally concave bend of the embryonic rhombencephalon that produces a thinning of the roof of the pons and medulla oblongata and defines the boundary between the metencephalon and myelencephalon in the embryo

Subject: abnormal medulla oblongata morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the most caudal region of the brainstem that lies directly rostral to the spinal cord; includes regions responsible for autonomic functions such as digestion, breathing and control of heart rate

Subject: abnormal metencephalon morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anterior part of the developing vertebrate hindbrain or the corresponding part of the adult brain composed of the cerebellum and the pons Varolii

Subject: abnormal pons morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the band of nerve fibers in the brain connecting the medulla oblongata and the mesencephalon; this region conveys information about movement from the cerebral hemisphere to the cerebellum

Subject: abnormal cerebellum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the part of the metencephalon that lies in the posterior cranial fossa dorsal to the pons and medulla that is concerned with the coordination of movement and learning of motor skills

Subject: absent cerebellum
Value: missing the part of the metencephalon that lies in the posterior cranial fossa dorsal to the pons and medulla that is concerned with the coordination of movement

Subject: cerebellum hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced cell number, in the cerebellum

Subject: small cerebellum
Value: reduced size of cerebellum

Subject: absent cerebellar foliation
Value: missing small branches of the cerebellar lobules

Subject: abnormal cerebellum development
Value: aberrant or incomplete differentiation of the part of the metencephalon that lies dorsal to the pons and medulla behind the brain stem and controls balance for walking and standing, modulates the force and range of movement and is involved in the learning of motor skills

Subject: accelerated formation of intralobular fissures
Value: formation of the major fissures of the cerebellum earlier in development than normal

Subject: abnormal cerebellar plate morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the embryonic pseudostratified epithelium of the fourth cerebellar ventricle that eventually forms the vermis and ventral neuroepithelium

Subject: abnormal cerebellar foliation
Value: any anomaly of the pattern of the ten cerebellar lobules; in mammals, the vermis portion of the cerebellum has a foliation pattern along the AP axis that is distinct from the lateral cerebellar hemispheres and the intermediate zone that separates the vermis from the lateral hemispheres; in addition, each of the ten basic lobules can be subdivided into sublobules but strain and species differences are reported

Subject: altered metastatic potential
Value: altered likelihood of a tumor cell spreading from the site of the initial tumor formation and forming a secondary tumor at another site not directly connected with it

Subject: abnormal somatosensory cortex morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the area of the parietal lobe that lies posterior to the central sulcus and is concerned with receiving and processing general sensations from the body surface

Subject: abnormal primary somatosensory cortex morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the area of the postcentral gyrus and central sulcus that is involved in somatic sensation

Subject: disorganized barrel cortex
Value: derangement of the pattern of the discrete functional units of the somatosensory cortex that processes tactile information derived from the vibrissae

Subject: absent barrels in primary somatosensory cortex
Value: missing pattern of the discrete functional units of the somatosensory cortex that processes tactile information derived from the vibrissae

Subject: abnormal secondary somatosensory cortex morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the area of the upper bank of the lateral sulcus that is involved in somatic sensation

Subject: abnormal cerebellum vermis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the narrow medial zone between the two hemispheres of the cerebellum that is delimited by two longitudinal furrows; it may be continuous with the cerebellar hemispheres in some areas of the cerebellum, e.g., dorsally, or separated by deeper fissues in others (e.g., ventrally); it receives inputs from the spinocerebellar tracts which carry to the vermis information on the position and balance of the torso, and it sends projections to the fastigial nucleus of the cerebellum, which then sends output to the vestibular nuclei

Subject: absent cerebellum vermis
Value: missing narrow middle zone between the two hemispheres of the cerebellum

Subject: cerebellum vermis hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, in the vermis

Subject: abnormal cerebellum anterior vermis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anterior portion of the narrow middle zone between the two hemispheres of the cerebellum that is located anterior to the primary fissure

Subject: decreased anterior vermis size
Value: smaller appearance of the narrow middle zone between the two hemispheres of the anterior lobe of the cerebellum

Subject: abnormal cerebellum posterior vermis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the posterior portion of the narrow middle zone between the two hemispheres of the cerebellum that is located posterior to the primary fissure

Subject: absent cerebellum vermis lobule VIII
Value: missing part of the inferior vermis of the cerebellum (vermis lobule VIII)

Subject: absent cerebellum vermis lobule IX
Value: missing triangular elevation on the vermis of the cerebellum

Subject: abnormal cerebellum external granule cell layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the transient layer of the cerebellar cortex present during development which is composed of the dividing and migrating granule cells

Subject: thin external granule cell layer
Value: reduced thickness of the transient layer of the cerebellar cortex present during development which is composed of dividing and migrating granule cells

Subject: irregular external granule cell layer thickness
Value: uneven thickness of the transient layer of the cerebellar cortex present during development which is composed of dividing and migrating granule cells

Subject: abnormal cerebellar Purkinje cell layer
Value: any structural anomaly of the cell layer that lies just underneath the molecular layer of the cerebellar cortex; it contains the neuronal cell bodies of the Purkinje cells that are arranged side by side in a single layer, and candelabrum interneurons are vertically oriented between the Purkinje cells

Subject: Purkinje cell degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of the large neurons located at the interface of the molecular and internal granule layers of the cerebellar cortex

Subject: abnormal Purkinje cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the neurons located at the interface of the molecular and internal granule layers of the cerebellar cortex; these inhibitory neurons provide the output of the cerebellar cortex through axons that project into the white matter, and extensive dendritic trees from the Purkinje cells extend upward in a single plane into the molecular layer where they synapse with parallel fibers of granule cells

Subject: abnormal Purkinje cell number
Value: different from average number of neuronal cells that are located in the interface of the molecular and granular layers of the cerebellar cortex

Subject: increased Purkinje cell number
Value: greater than normal number of neuronal cells that are located in the interface of the molecular and granular layers of the cerebellar cortex

Subject: decreased Purkinje cell number
Value: fewer than normal neuronal cells that are located in the interface of the molecular and granular layers of the cerebellar cortex

Subject: delaminated Purkinje cell layer
Value: splitting or disorganization of the layer of large neuron cell bodies between the molecular and granular layers of the cerebellum

Subject: abnormal cerebellar granule layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the innermost cortical layer of the cerebellum; contains densely packed small neurons, mostly granule cells with some Golgi cells are found at the outer border

Subject: delaminated cerebellar granule layer
Value: splitting or disorganization of the deepest of the three layers of the cerebellum that contains granule cells

Subject: absent cerebellar granule layer
Value: absence of the innermost cortical layer of the cerebellum; contains densely packed small neurons, mostly granule cells with some Golgi cells are found at the outer border

Subject: abnormal cerebellar molecular layer
Value: any structural anomaly of the outermost layer of the cerebral cortex that contains the parallel fibers of the granule cells, interneurons such as stellate and basket cells, and the dendrites of the underlying Purkinje cells

Subject: thin cerebellar molecular layer
Value: reduced width of the outermost layer of the cerebral cortex that contains the parallel fibers of the granule cells, interneurons such as stellate and basket cells, and the dendrites of the underlying Purkinje cells

Subject: abnormal midbrain morphology
Value: any structural anomaly associated with the brain region derived from the middle of the three cerebral vesicles of the embryo; this region controls sensory and motor functions in the adult, including eye movement and coordination of auditory and visual reflexes

Subject: midbrain hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due an increased number of cells associated with the brain region derived from the middle of the three cerebral vesicles of the embryo; this region controls sensory and motor functions in the adult, including eye movement and coordination of auditory and visual reflexes

Subject: abnormal corpora quadrigemina morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the inferior and superior colliculus

Subject: decreased colliculi size
Value: smaller inferior and superior colliculus

Subject: altered position of colliculi
Value: positional abnormality of the inferior and superior colliculus

Subject: abnormal superior colliculus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the paired superior eminence of the mesencephalic tectum that is involved in auditory processing

Subject: increased superior colliculus size
Value: enlargement of the paired superior eminence of the mesencephalic tectum

Subject: abnormal trigeminal V mesencephalic nucleus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the group of sensory neurons residing in a long, narrow plate in the midbrain; axons pass with the trigeminal nerve

Subject: small mesencephalic trigeminal nucleus
Value: reduced size of the group of sensory neurons residing in a long, narrow plate in the midbrain; axons pass with the trigeminal nerve

Subject: absent mesencephalic trigeminal nucleus
Value: missing group of sensory neurons residing in a long, narrow plate in the midbrain; axons pass with the trigeminal nerve

Subject: abnormal facial motor nucleus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the group of motor neurons residing in the pons that innervate the muscles of facial expression

Subject: small facial motor nucleus
Value: reduced size of the group of motor neurons residing in the pons that innervate the muscles of facial expression

Subject: abnormal trigeminal motor nucleus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the group of motor neurons innervating the muscles of mastication

Subject: small trigeminal motor nucleus
Value: reduced size of the group of motor neurons innervating the muscles of mastication

Subject: abnormal brain development
Value: aberrant or incomplete differentiation of the brain

Subject: exencephaly
Value: neurocranial defects resulting in exposure or extrusion of the brain

Subject: obstructive hydrocephaly
Value: hydrocephaly due to a block in cerebrospinal fluid flow in the ventricular system

Subject: cranioschisis
Value: incomplete closure of the skull, usually congenital

Subject: abnormal myelination
Value: any anomaly in the process by which myelin sheaths are formed and maintained around neurons; oligodendrocytes in the brain and spinal cord and Schwann cells in the peripheral nervous system wrap axons with compact layers of their plasma membrane

Subject: demyelination
Value: a partial absence or patchy, incomplete area of a myelin sheath over all or part of an axon or fiber tract due to degeneration or destruction of the myelin sheath

Subject: abnormal roof plate morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the single row of specialized glial cells that occupies the dorsal midline of the developing neural tube along the entire anterior-posterior axis; the roof plate serves as a critical embryonic signaling center for the organization of dorsal neuronal cell types, and acts as a barrier preventing axons and cells migrating across the dorsal midline

Subject: absent roof plate
Value: absence of the single row of specialized glial cells that occupies the dorsal midline of the developing neural tube along the entire anterior-posterior axis; the roof plate serves as a critical embryonic signaling center for the organization of dorsal neuronal cell types, and acts as a barrier preventing axons and cells migrating across the dorsal midline

Subject: abnormal floor plate morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the specialized glial structure (non-neuronal cells) situated at the ventral midline of the embryonic neural tube; this structure spans the anteroposterior axis from the midbrain to the tail regions, separating the left and right basal plates of the developing neural tube, and serves as an organizer to ventralize tissues in the embryo as well as to guide neuronal positioning and differentiation along the dorsoventral axis of the neural tube

Subject: absent floor plate
Value: absence of the specialized glial structure (non-neuronal cells) situated at the ventral midline of the embryonic neural tube; this structure spans the anteroposterior axis from the midbrain to the tail regions, separating the left and right basal plates of the developing neural tube, and serves as an organizer to ventralize tissues in the embryo as well as to guide neuronal positioning and differentiation along the dorsoventral axis of the neural tube

Subject: small floor plate
Value: reduced size of the specialized glial structure (non-neuronal cells) situated at the ventral midline of the embryonic neural tube; this structure spans the anteroposterior axis from the midbrain to the tail regions, separating the left and right basal plates of the developing neural tube, and serves as an organizer to ventralize tissues in the embryo as well as to guide neuronal positioning and differentiation along the dorsoventral axis of the neural tube

Subject: incomplete rostral neuropore closure
Value: arrest of the fusion of the cephalic neural folds

Subject: open neural tube
Value: failure of completion of the last step in the formation of the neural tube, where the paired neural folds are brought together and fuse at the dorsal midline

Subject: wavy neural tube
Value: undulations in the embryonic neural tube

Subject: absent notochord
Value: missing axial fibrocellular cord in embryos around which develops the vertebral primordia

Subject: abnormal rhombomere morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the transiently divided segments of the developing neural tube of vertebrate embryos found within the hindbrain region in the area that will eventually become the rhombencephalon; the rhombomeres appear as a series of slightly constricted swellings in the neural tube, caudal to the cephalic flexure

Subject: abnormal telencephalon development
Value: anomaly in the progression of the enlarged anteriolateral part of the brain; consists of the paired cerebral hemispheres and olfactory bulbs, the basal ganglia and the connecting structures, and is considered to be the seat of conscious mental processes; it develops from the anterior-most embryological division of the brain that develops from the prosencephalon

Subject: abnormal folding of telencephalic vesicles
Value: malformation of the stereotypic invaginations forming the paired diverticula of the telencephalon

Subject: small embryonic telencephalon
Value: reduced size of the paired diverticula of the embryonic telencephalon, from which the forebrain develops

Subject: abnormal motor neuron morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of cells that innervate an effector (muscle or glandular) tissue and are responsible for transmission of motor impulses

Subject: motor neuron degeneration
Value: retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of the cells that innervate an effector (muscle or glandular) tissue and are responsible for transmission of motor impulses

Subject: decreased motor neuron number
Value: fewer than normal numbers of cells that innervate an effector (muscle or glandular) tissue and are responsible for transmission of motor impulses

Subject: abnormal motor neuron innervation pattern
Value: any changes in the placement, morphology or number of motor nerve fibers to an effector motor tissue, or failure of refinement of neuronal connections during development

Subject: convulsive seizures
Value: seizures characterized by uncontrolled motor activity

Subject: nonconvulsive seizures
Value: seizures without uncontrolled motor activity, but with impairment of consciousness

Subject: abnormal seizure response to pharmacological agent
Value: anomaly in the seizure activity response that is brought about by treatment with pharmacological agents

Subject: sporadic seizures
Value: occasional seizures occurring at irregular intervals

Subject: abnormal CNS glial cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of non-neuronal cells of the central nervous system that form the myelin insulation of nervous pathways, guide neuronal migration during development, and exchange metabolites with neurons

Subject: abnormal oligodendrocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the neuroglia of the central nervous system that form the insulating myelin sheath of axons in the CNS

Subject: decreased oligodendrocyte progenitor number
Value: fewer cells that differentiate into a type of glial cell in the central nervous system

Subject: abnormal spinal cord morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cylindrical tissue of the vertebral canal that extends from the medulla oblongata to the conus medullaris

Subject: decreased spinal cord size
Value: smaller appearance of the spinal cord

Subject: peripheral nervous system degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of the ganglia and peripheral nerves that lie outside the brain and spinal cord

Subject: abnormal somatic sensory system morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the neural tissue involved in the transmission of sensory signals

Subject: abnormal sensory ganglion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the clusters of neurons in the somatic peripheral nervous system which contain the cell bodies of sensory nerve axons, interneurons and non-neuronal supporting cells

Subject: abnormal dorsal root ganglion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a group of sensory nerve cell bodies located on the dorsal spinal roots within the vertebral column

Subject: disorganized dorsal root ganglion
Value: loss of segmentation pattern of dorsal root ganglia or loss of regular spacing between the ganglia

Subject: fused dorsal root ganglion
Value: loss of DRG spacing pattern and the appearance of two or more ganglia as one

Subject: small dorsal root ganglion
Value: reduced size a group of sensory nerve cell bodies located on the dorsal spinal roots within the vertebral column

Subject: abnormal sensory neuron morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of cells that innervate an effector (muscle or glandular) tissue and are responsible for transmission of sensory impulses

Subject: decreased sensory neuron number
Value: fewer than normal numbers of cells that innervate an effector (muscle or glandular) tissue and are responsible for transmission of sensory impulses

Subject: abnormal sensory neuron innervation pattern
Value: any changes in the placement, morphology or number of sensory nerve fibers to sensory termini or to spinal cord

Subject: abnormal nociceptor morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the peripheral receptors for pain, including receptors sensitive to painful mechanical stimuli, extreme heat or cold, and chemical stimuli

Subject: abnormal polymodal receptor morphology
Value: anomaly in a sensory receptor that may be stimulated by mechanical, thermal or chemical means

Subject: abnormal thermoreceptor morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the cellular receptors that mediate the sense of temperature; in vertebrates, these are most often located under the skin

Subject: abnormal mechanoreceptor morphology
Value: anomaly in the receptors of the body, usually nerve termini, that respond to mechanical pressure or distortion

Subject: abnormal cutaneous/subcutaneous mechanoreceptor morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the neuronal receptors that respond to mechanical pressure or distortion in the skin

Subject: abnormal hair guard neuron morphology
Value: anomaly of the subcutaneous mechanoreceptors that innervate hair follicles of guard hairs, and are involved in the amplification of slow-moving and/or light touch stimuli signals

Subject: absent hair guard neurons
Value: absence of the subcutaneous mechanoreceptors that innervate hair follicles of guard hairs, and are involved in the amplification of slow-moving and/or light touch stimuli signals

Subject: hyperinnervation of hair guard cells
Value: more robust innervation of the subcutaneous mechanoreceptors that innervate hair follicles of guard hairs, and are involved in the amplification of slow-moving and/or light touch stimuli signals

Subject: abnormal hair-tylotrich neuron morphology
Value: anomaly of the subcutaneous mechanoreceptors that innervate tylotrich hair follicles

Subject: hyperinnervation of hair-tylotrich cells
Value: more robust innervation of the hair tylotrich cells

Subject: abnormal hair-down neuron morphology
Value: anomaly of the subcutaneous mechanosensitive D-hair (down-hair) neurons, which innervate hair follicles, and are characterized by a large-amplitude Cav3.2 T-current involved in the amplification of slow-moving and/or light touch stimuli

Subject: absent hair-down neurons
Value: absence of the subcutaneous mechanosensitive D-hair (down-hair) neurons, which innervate hair follicles, and are characterized by a large-amplitude Cav3.2 T-current involved in the amplification of slow-moving and/or light touch stimuli

Subject: hyperinnervation of hair-down cells
Value: more robust innervation of the subcutaneous mechanosensitive D-hair (down-hair) neurons, which innervate hair follicles, and are characterized by a large-amplitude Cav3.2 T-current involved in the amplification of slow-moving and/or light touch stimuli

Subject: abnormal Meissner's corpuscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the numerous oval bodies found in the dermal papillae of glabrous skin that transmit information about skin motion and slipping objects

Subject: enlarged Meissner's corpuscles
Value: larger than average size of any of the numerous oval bodies found in the dermal papillae of glabrous skin that transmit information about skin motion and slipping objects

Subject: hyperinnervation of Meissner's corpuscle
Value: more robust supply of nerve fibers connected to any part of any of the numerous oval bodies found in the dermal papillae of glabrous skin that transmit information about skin motion and slipping objects

Subject: abnormal Merkel's receptor morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the modified epidermal cells located in the stratum basale and found mostly in areas where sensory perception is acute

Subject: increased Merkel's receptor number
Value: greater than the normal number of the modified epidermal cells located in the stratum basale and found mostly in areas where sensory perception is acute

Subject: hyperinnervation of Merkel's receptor
Value: more robust supply of nerve fibers connected to the modified epidermal cells located in the stratum basale and found mostly in areas where sensory perception is acute

Subject: abnormal pacinian corpuscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the rapidly adapting mechanoreceptors found in subcutaneous tissue beneath both hairy and glabrous skin, and which normally contain an afferent nerve fiber surrounded by a capsule with multiple concentric layers; trasmit signals generated by vibrations when grasping an object

Subject: abnormal Ruffini's corpuscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the sensory cells in the subcutaneous tissue of the digits specialized to transduce mechanical stimuli, skin stretch, direction of object motion, hand shape and finger position

Subject: abnormal skeletal muscle mechanoreceptor morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the receptors that respond to mechanical pressure or distortion in the skeletal muscle

Subject: abnormal primary muscle spindle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the sensory organ in muscle; involved in the stretch reflex and sensitive to stretch velocity

Subject: absent primary muscle spindle
Value: missing sensory organ in muscle; involved in the stretch reflex and is sensitive to stretch velocity

Subject: partial loss of primary muscle spindle
Value: missing a portion of the sensory organ in muscle; involved in the stretch reflex and is sensitive to stretch velocity

Subject: abnormal secondary muscle spindle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the sensory organ in muscle; involved in the stretch reflex and not sensitive to stretch velocity

Subject: absent secondary muscle spindle
Value: lack of the sensory organ in muscle; involved in the stretch reflex and is not sensitive to stretch velocity

Subject: partial loss of secondary muscle spindle
Value: missing a portion of the sensory organ in muscle; involved in the stretch reflex and is not sensitive to stretch velocity

Subject: abnormal synovial joint capsule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the sac or its contents that encloses the articulating ends of bones participating in a synovial joint

Subject: absent synovial joint capsule
Value: missing the sac that encloses the articulating ends of bones participating in a synovial joint

Subject: abnormal golgi tendon organ morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the sensory organ in muscle that is involved in regulating muscle tension

Subject: absent golgi tendon organ
Value: missing sensory organ in muscle that is involved in regulating muscle tension

Subject: abnormal chemoreceptor morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the cells specialized to detect chemical substances and relay that information centrally in the nervous system

Subject: abnormal taste bud morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small sensory organs located in the tongue that contain gustatory receptor cells, basal cells, and supporting cells

Subject: abnormal olfactory receptor morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the proteins, usually projecting from the cilia of olfactory receptor neurons, that specifically bind odorant molecules and trigger responses in the specialized neurons of the olfactory epithelium

Subject: abnormal retinal photoreceptor morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a cell specialized to detect and transduce light, including rods and cones of the retina

Subject: abnormal retinal rod cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of one of the photoreceptor cell types of the vertebrate retina, in which the photopigment is in stacks of membranous disks separate from the outer cell membrane; rods are more sensitive to light than cones, but rod mediated vision has less spatial and temporal resolution than cone vision

Subject: abnormal retinal cone cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of one of the photoreceptor cell types in the retina, in which the photopigment is in invaginations of the cell membrane of the outer segment; cones are less sensitive to light than rods, but they provide vision with higher spatial and temporal acuity, and the combination of signals from cones with different pigments allows color vision

Subject: abnormal sympathetic system morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the part of the autonomic nervous system that innervates smooth muscle, cardiac muscle and glands and mediates the body's response to stressful situations

Subject: abnormal sympathetic ganglion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the ganglia of the sympathetic nervous system including the paravertebral and the prevertebral ganglia, which include the sympathetic chain ganglia, the superior, middle, and inferior cervical ganglia, and the aorticorenal, celiac, and stellate ganglia

Subject: paravertebral ganglia hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due to increased cell number, of the groups of postsynaptic neurons located at intervals along the sympathetic trunk, including the superior cervical, middle cervical and stellate (cervicothoracic) ganglia as well as the thoracic, lumbar and sacral ganglia

Subject: prevertebral ganglia hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due to increased cell number, of the sympathetic ganglia located in front of the vertebral column and are associated with the major branches of the abdominal aorta; these include the celiac, aorticorenal, superior and inferior mesenteric ganglia

Subject: abnormal superior cervical ganglion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the group of neurons that is the largest of the sympathetic trunk; normally lies at the base of the skull and innervates the head and neck

Subject: superior cervical ganglion hypertrophy
Value: increase in the size of cells in the group of neurons that is the largest of the ganglia of the sympathetic trunk; normally lies at the base of the skull and innervates the head and neck

Subject: enlarged superior cervical ganglion
Value: increased size of the group of neurons that is the largest of the ganglia of the sympathetic trunk; normally lies at the base of the skull and innervates the head and neck

Subject: absent superior cervical ganglion
Value: lack of the group of neurons that is the largest of the sympathetic trunk; normally lies at the base of the skull and innervates the head and neck

Subject: small superior cervical ganglion
Value: reduced size of the group of neurons that is the largest of the ganglia of the sympathetic trunk; normally lies at the base of the skull and innervates the head and neck

Subject: abnormal middle cervical ganglion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small ganglion located at the level of the cricoid cartilage of the laryngeal wall

Subject: abnormal stellate ganglion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the group of neurons formed by the fusion of the inferior cervical and first thoracic ganglia

Subject: abnormal L4 dorsal root ganglion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the group of nerve cell bodies located on the dorsal spinal roots within the vertebral column at the level of the fourth lumbar vertebra

Subject: L4 dorsal root ganglion hypertrophy
Value: increased bulk size of the L4 spinal ganglion

Subject: small L4 dorsal root ganglion
Value: reduced size of the L4 spinal ganglion

Subject: abnormal L5 dorsal root ganglion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the group of nerve cell bodies located on the dorsal spinal roots within the vertebral column at the level of the fifth lumbar vertebra

Subject: L5 dorsal root ganglion hypertrophy
Value: increased bulk size of L5 spinal ganglion

Subject: small L5 dorsal root ganglion
Value: reduced size of the L5 spinal ganglion

Subject: abnormal sympathetic neuron morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the neurons of the part of the autonomic nervous system that innervates smooth muscle, cardiac muscle and glands and mediates the body's response to stressful situations

Subject: abnormal adrenergic neuron morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the neurons which secrete norepinephrine as a neurotransmitter; adrenergic neurons are mostly sympathetic postganglionic nerves plus some within specific brainstem foci

Subject: abnormal peptidergic neuron morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the nerve fibers that release small peptides as their neurotransmitter

Subject: abnormal parasympathetic system morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the part of the autonomic nervous system that innervates smooth muscle, cardiac muscle and glands and generally acts to conserve resources and restore homeostasis, often with effects reciprocal to the sympathetic nervous system

Subject: abnormal parasympathetic ganglion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the ganglia of the parasympathetic nervous system, including the ciliary, pterygopalatine, submandibular, and otic ganglia in the cranial region and intrinsic (terminal) ganglia associated with target organs in the thorax and abdomen

Subject: abnormal submandibular ganglion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the ganglion associated with the lingual nerve that provides postsynaptic fibers to the submandibular and sublingual glands

Subject: small submandibular ganglion
Value: reduced size of the small parasympathetic ganglion of the lingual nerve

Subject: abnormal parasympathetic neuron morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the neurons of the autonomic nervous system that are responsible for innervation of smooth muscle, cardiac muscle and glands

Subject: abnormal cholinergic neuron morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the neurons that utilize acetylcholine as a neurotransmitter, including include alpha-motor neurons of the spinal cord, cranial nerves innervating skeletal muscle, preganglionic sympathetic and postganglionic parasympathetic neurons

Subject: deficient enteric cholinergic innervation
Value: defective or incomplete supply of nerve fibers to the intestinal system that utilize acetylcholine as a neurotransmitter

Subject: abnormal enteric nervous system morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the part of the autonomic nervous system that innervates the gastrointestinal tract, the pancreas, and the gallbladder and can autonomously sense the tension and the chemical environment in the gut and regulate blood vessel tone, motility, secretions, and fluid transport

Subject: abnormal enteric ganglia morphology
Value: any structural anomaly or deformity of the groups of nerve cell bodies associated with the enteric neurons

Subject: abnormal enteric neuron morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the neurons that innervate the esophagus, stomach, small and large bowel

Subject: abnormal enteric cholinergic neuron morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the neurons that utilize acetylcholine as a neurotransmitter and innervate the esophagus, stomach, small and large bowel

Subject: absent enteric neurons
Value: absence of the neurons that innervate the esophagus, stomach, small and large bowel

Subject: abnormal enteric cholinergic innervation
Value: any structural anomaly of the supply of nerve fibers that utilize acetylcholine as a neurotransmitter to the intestinal system

Subject: abnormal somatic motor system morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the neural tissue involved in the transmission of motor signals

Subject: abnormal innervation pattern to muscle
Value: any changes in the placement, morphology or number of sensory, sympathetic or motor nerves to targets in muscle

Subject: abnormal neuromuscular synapse morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the membrane to membrane contact of a motor axon and a muscle myofiber that is responsible for the transmission of nerve impulses

Subject: failure of neuromuscular synapse presynaptic differentiation
Value: inability of nerve terminals to find target and/or form terminal arbors for synaptic transmission at the neuromuscular synapse

Subject: failure of neuromuscular synapse postsynaptic differentiation
Value: inability of an effector cell to form a differentiated postsynaptic membrane in response to innervation at the neuromuscular synapse

Subject: abnormal cranial nerve morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the twelve nerves that emerge from the cranium as opposed to the spinal nerves

Subject: optic nerve atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of the optic nerve, associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: abnormal oculomotor nerve morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the third cranial nerve, which normally sends motor fibers to the levator muscles of the eyelid and to the superior rectus, inferior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles of the eye; and also sends parasympathetic efferents to the muscles controlling pupillary constriction and accommodation

Subject: absent oculomotor nerve
Value: absence of the third cranial nerve, which normally sends motor fibers to the levator muscles of the eyelid and to the superior rectus, inferior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles of the eye

Subject: abnormal trochlear nerve morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the fourth cranial nerve, which normally carries the motor innervation of the superior oblique muscles of the eye

Subject: absent trochlear nerve
Value: absence of the fourth cranial nerve, which normally carries the motor innervation of the superior oblique muscles of the eye

Subject: abnormal trigeminal nerve morphology
Value: <any structural anomaly of the chief sensory nerve of the face and motor nerve of the muscles of mastication; has three major divisions: ophthalmic, maxillary and mandibular>

Subject: absent trigeminal nerve
Value: <lack of the chief sensory nerve of the face and motor nerve of the muscles of mastication; has three major divisions: ophthalmic, maxillary and mandibular>

Subject: absent mandibular nerve
Value: missing third division of the trigeminal nerve

Subject: abnormal mandibular nerve branching
Value: malformed or misprojected axons of the mandibular nerve

Subject: abnormal abducens nerve morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the sixth cranial nerve, which originates in the abducens nucleus of the pons and sends motor fibers to the lateral rectus muscles of the eye

Subject: abnormal facial nerve morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the sensory and motor nerve that supplies the muscles of facial expression and the expression and taste at the anterior two-thirds of the tongue; principal branches are the superficial opthalmic, buccal, palatine and hyomandibular

Subject: abnormal vestibulocochlear nerve morphology
Value: <any structural anomaly in the composite sensory nerve innervating the receptor cells of the membranous labyrinth; it consists of two major, anatomically and functionally distinct components, each of which have different central connections: the vestibular nerve and the cochlear nerve>

Subject: abnormal glossopharyngeal nerve morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the sensory and autonomic axons to the parotid gland, carotid body, posterior third of the tongue; the branchial motor component contains motor fibers that innervate muscles that elevate the pharynx and larynx, and the tympanic branch supplies parasympathetic fibers to the otic ganglion

Subject: abnormal vagus nerve morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the autonomic, sensory and motor axons of the tenth cranial nerve; it is primarily sensory but also has visceromotor components; it originates in the brain stem and controls many autonomic functions of the heart, lungs, stomach, pharynx, larynx, trachea, esophagus and other gastrointestinal tract components, and also controls some motor functions such as speech; the sensory branches mediate sensation from the pharynx, larynx, thorax and abdomen; it also innervates taste buds in the epiglottis

Subject: abnormal accessory nerve morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the eleventh cranial nerve, which normally originates from neurons in the medulla and in the cervical spinal cord

Subject: abnormal hypoglossal nerve morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the motor nerve which innervates all the intrinsic and all but one of the extrinsic muscles of the tongue

Subject: abnormal spinal nerve morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the any of the 31 paired peripheral nerves formed by the union of the dorsal and ventral spinal roots from each spinal cord segment

Subject: abnormal phrenic nerve morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of motor, sensory and sympathetic neuron axons that project to the diaphragm and other tissues

Subject: absent phrenic nerve
Value: absence of the motor, sensory and sympathetic neuron axons that project to the diaphragm and other tissues

Subject: defasiculated phrenic nerve
Value: misprojection or failure to bundle the motor, sensory and sympathetic neuron axons that project to the diaphragm and other tissues

Subject: abnormal cranial ganglia morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the groups of nerve cell bodies associated with the twelve cranial nerves

Subject: abnormal geniculate ganglion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the group of sensory neuron cell bodies associated with the facial nerve (seventh cranial nerve)

Subject: small geniculate ganglion
Value: reduced size of the geniculate ganglion or decreased size of sensory neuron cell bodies associated with the facial nerve

Subject: abnormal petrosal ganglion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the larger, lower group of sensory neuron cell bodies associated with the glossopharyngeal nerve

Subject: small petrosal ganglion
Value: reduced size of the lower group of sensory neuron cell bodies associated with the glossopharyngeal nerve

Subject: absent petrosal ganglion
Value: absence of the lower group of sensory neuron cell bodies associated with the glossopharyngeal nerve

Subject: abnormal nodose ganglion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the large group of sensory neuron cell bodies, anterior to the jugular vein, associated with the vagus nerve (tenth cranial nerve)

Subject: small nodose ganglion
Value: reduced size of the large group of sensory neuron cell bodies, anterior to the jugular vein, associated with the vagus nerve (tenth cranial nerve)

Subject: absent nodose ganglion
Value: absence of the large group of sensory neuron cell bodies, anterior to the jugular vein, associated with the vagus nerve (tenth cranial nerve)

Subject: abnormal trigeminal ganglion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the group of sensory neuron cell bodies associated with the trigeminal nerve (fifth cranial nerve)

Subject: small trigeminal ganglion
Value: reduced size of the trigeminal ganglion

Subject: trigeminal ganglion hypertrophy
Value: increased bulk size due to increased cell size of the trigeminal ganglion

Subject: enlarged trigeminal ganglion
Value: increased size of the group of sensory neuron cell bodies associated with the trigeminal nerve

Subject: abnormal glossopharyngeal ganglion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the two groups of sensory neuron cell bodies associated with the ninth cranial nerve

Subject: abnormal superior glossopharyngeal ganglion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the upper, smaller ganglion of the glossopharyngeal nerve located at the jugular foramen

Subject: small superior glossopharyngeal ganglion
Value: reduced size of the upper ganglion of the glossopharyngeal nerve located at the jugular foramen

Subject: abnormal vagus ganglion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the group of sensory neuron cell bodies associated with the vagus nerve

Subject: abnormal superior vagus ganglion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the upper ganglion of the vagus nerve located at the jugular foramen

Subject: small superior vagus ganglion
Value: reduced size of the upper ganglion of the vagus nerve located at the jugular foramen

Subject: abnormal PNS glial cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of non-neuronal cells that form the myelin insulation of nervous pathways, guide neuronal migration during development, and exchange metabolites with neurons

Subject: abnormal Schwann cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cells which form the insulating myelin sheaths of peripheral axons

Subject: decreased Schwann cell number
Value: fewer than normal number of cells that sheath the axons of the peripheral nervous system

Subject: absent Schwann cells
Value: missing cells that sheath the axons of the peripheral nervous system

Subject: absent Schwann cell precursors
Value: missing progenitors of cells that sheath the axons of the peripheral nervous system

Subject: small gonad
Value: reduced size of the testis or the ovary

Subject: absent gametes
Value: absence of mature reproductive cells, ovum or spermatozoon, capable of fusing with a cell of similar origin, but opposite sex to give a zygote

Subject: abnormal female reproductive system morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the organs associated with producing offspring in the gender that bears the offspring

Subject: abnormal uterus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the female muscular organ of gestation in which the developing embryo or fetus is nourished until birth

Subject: uterus hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the uterus, usually due to a reduced number of cells

Subject: dilated uterus
Value: stretched or widened luminal space of the female muscular organ of gestation

Subject: abnormal gametes
Value: anomaly of any mature reproductive cell, ovum or spermatozoon, capable of fusing with a cell of similar origin, but opposite sex, to produce a zygote

Subject: abnormal oocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the mature germ cells in the female

Subject: abnormal ovary morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the female reproductive gland containing the germ cells

Subject: small ovary
Value: reduced size of the female reproductive gland containing the germ cells

Subject: ovary hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due an increased number of cells in the ovary

Subject: impaired ovarian folliculogenesis
Value: a block in the formation of the spherical ovum in the ovary

Subject: abnormal ovarian folliculogenesis
Value: atypical formation or failure to form the spherical ovum in the ovary

Subject: abnormal ovarian follicle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the sac-like structure in the ovary which surrounds an ovum

Subject: absent mature ovarian follicles
Value: absence of ovarian follicles that are ready for ovulation and present a blanched spot (the follicular stigma) where the graafian follicle is about to rupture on the surface of the ovary; a first maturation (meiotic) division of the primary oocyte usually occurs just prior to rupture of the follicle

Subject: impaired luteal cell differentiation
Value: abnormal development of the cells of the corpus luteum of the ovary

Subject: absent corpus luteum
Value: absence of the yellow endocrine body formed in the ovary after follicle rupture

Subject: abnormal uterine cervix morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the lower opening of the uterus to the vagina

Subject: dilated uterine cervix
Value: stretched or widened aperture of the lower opening of the uterus to the vagina

Subject: abnormal uterine cervix epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the epithelial layer of the cervix

Subject: abnormal uterine cervix squamous epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the scaly epithelial layer of the cervix

Subject: abnormal vagina morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the part of the genital canal in the female that extends between the cervix of the uterus and the vestibule; it is an organ of copulation that receives the penis during sexual intercourse

Subject: abnormal vagina epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the epithelial layer of the vagina

Subject: thickened vaginal epithelium
Value: increased depth of the vaginal epithelial layer

Subject: abnormal vagina orifice morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the median slit located inferior and posterior to the external urethral orifice in the female; the exit for menstrual flow and birth and the entrance for the penis during sexual intercourse; the size and appearance of the vaginal orifice varies inversely with that of the hymen (G. membrane), a thin fold of mucous membrane that surrounds the vaginal orifice

Subject: constricted vagina orifice
Value: shrunken, narrowed external median slit located inferior and posterior to the external urethral orifice in the female

Subject: vagina atresia
Value: imperforation or occlusion of the vagina, or adhesion of the walls of the vagina

Subject: abnormal male reproductive system morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the organs associated with producing offspring in the gender that produces spermatozoa

Subject: abnormal testis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the male reproductive glands

Subject: small testis
Value: reduced size of the male reproductive glands

Subject: enlarged testis
Value: increased size of the male reproductive glands

Subject: testicular hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due an increased number of cells in the testes

Subject: enlarged scrotum
Value: increased size of the external sac of skin that encloses the testes

Subject: enlarged foreskin
Value: increased size of the loose fold of skin that covers the penis

Subject: Leydig cell hyperplasia
Value: increased number of interstitial cells of the seminiferous tubules that secrete testosterone

Subject: small seminiferous tubules
Value: reduced diameter of the tubules in the testes where spermatogenesis occurs

Subject: seminiferous tubule degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of the tubules in the testes where spermatogenesis occurs

Subject: arrest of spermatogenesis
Value: block of the process by which spermatogonial stem cells divide and differentiate into spermatozoa

Subject: abnormal spermatogenesis
Value: incomplete maturation or aberrant formation of the male gametes

Subject: small seminal vesicle
Value: reduced size of one of the two folded, sac shaped, glands that is a diverticulum of the ductus deferens

Subject: abnormal prostate gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the gland in males that secretes part of the seminiferous fluid

Subject: absent prostate gland
Value: missing gland in males that secretes part of the seminiferous fluid

Subject: abnormal prostate gland anterior lobe morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the rodent prostate lobe that appears as a thin tubular structure, attached to the lesser curvature of the paired seminal vesicles

Subject: prostate gland epithelial hyperplasia
Value: epithelium is multi-layered instead of columnar and has increased cell number

Subject: abnormal prostate gland epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the prostate epithelium

Subject: abnormal bulbourethral gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the small paired racemose (compound tubulo-alveolar) glands below the apex of the prostate in males, located posterolateral to the membranous portion of the urethra at the base of the penis, between the two layers of the fascia of the urogenital diaphragm, in the deep perineal pouch, and enclosed by transverse fibers of the sphincter urethrae membranaceae muscle; they secrete a clear fluid known as pre-ejaculate (Cowper's fluid), and are homologous to the greater vestibular (Bartholin's) glands in the female

Subject: bulbourethral gland hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due an increased number of cells in the bulbourethral gland

Subject: abnormal lung morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the paired lobed visceral organs of respiration in the pulmonary cavity of the thorax where aeration of the blood normally occurs

Subject: abnormal lung development
Value: anomaly in the process of formation of the paired lobed visceral organs of respiration in the pulmonary cavity of the thorax where aeration of the blood normally occurs

Subject: atelectasis
Value: decrease or absent air in the entire or part of a lung, with resulting loss of lung volume, due to trauma, blockage or congenital defect

Subject: pulmonary hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the respiratory organ due to reduced cell number in all or part of the organ

Subject: thick pulmonary interalveolar septum
Value: increased width of the tissue intervening between two adjacent pulmonary alveoli, which consists of the basement membranes of alveolar-lining epithelium (mostly type I pneumocytes) and capillary endothelium

Subject: absent lungs
Value: absence of the paired lobed visceral organs of respiration in the pulmonary cavity of the thorax where aeration of the blood normally occurs

Subject: lung hemorrhage
Value: bleeding within the paired lobed visceral organs of respiration in the pulmonary cavity of the thorax where aeration of the blood normally occurs

Subject: overexpanded pulmonary alveoli
Value: expanded volume of the saclike terminal dilation of the respiratory bronchioles, alveolar ducts and alveolar sacs across which gas exchance occurs between alveolar air and the pulmonary capillaries

Subject: absent pulmonary alveoli
Value: absence of the saclike terminal dilation of the respiratory bronchioles, alveolar ducts and alveolar sacs across which gas exchance occurs between alveolar air and the pulmonary capillaries

Subject: pigmentation phenotype
Value: the observable morphological and physiological characteristics of mammalian organisms that are manifested through the deposition or aggregation of coloring matter in any tissue or cell of the organism

Subject: hyperpigmentation
Value: excess of pigment in any or all tissues or a part of a tissue

Subject: absent skin pigmentation
Value: lack of pigmentation of the skin

Subject: reddish skin
Value: skin has a more intense ruddy appearance than normal, often due to capillary congestion

Subject: abnormal skin condition
Value: any anomaly in the state or quality of the skin

Subject: scaly skin
Value: skin covered with shedding scales

Subject: psoriasis
Value: chronic skin lesions characterized by inflammation and silvery-scaly patches

Subject: dermatitis
Value: inflammation of the skin (redness and itching) caused by an allergic reaction or contact with an irritant

Subject: flaky skin
Value: shedding flakes on the skin

Subject: shiny skin
Value: skin with a glossy or glistening appearance

Subject: oily skin
Value: skin secreting an unusually high amount of oil, resulting in a glossy, shiny appearance

Subject: tight skin
Value: skin has a taut, stretched appearance

Subject: thin skin
Value: reduced thickness of the outer protective layer of the body

Subject: thick skin
Value: greater thickness of the outer protective layer of the body

Subject: translucent skin
Value: skin that is more transparent to light than normal

Subject: skin photosensitivity
Value: abnormally heightened reactivity of the skin to sunlight

Subject: increased sensitivity to skin irradiation
Value: increased incidence of aberrant or damaged cells due to irradiation induced genotoxic damage

Subject: decreased sensitivity to skin irradiation
Value: decreased incidence of aberrant or damaged cells due to irradiation induced genotoxic damage

Subject: blistering
Value: accumulation of fluid- filled thin walled structures under the epidermis or within the epidermis

Subject: spontaneous skin ulceration
Value: unpredictable appearance of skin lesions, usually with inflammation

Subject: skin ridges
Value: long raised strips of skin, usually aligned to the proximal-distal axis

Subject: wrinkled skin
Value: irregular folds and/or indentations on the skin

Subject: skin lesions
Value: focal pathological and/or inflammatory changes characterized by alteration in the size, shape and organization of the cellular components of the skin

Subject: abnormal skin cell number
Value: greater than or fewer than the expected numbers of cells in the cutis

Subject: skin hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due an increased number of cells in the skin; usually results in thick skin

Subject: skin hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment of the cutis, usually due to a deficiency in the number of cells

Subject: abnormal epidermal layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the superficial epithelial portion of the skin

Subject: absent epidermis
Value: missing the epidermal cell layer in the skin

Subject: thin epidermis
Value: reduced thickness of the superficial epithelial portion of the skin

Subject: thick epidermis
