Value: increase in the width of the epidermal cell layer in the skin

Subject: epidermal necrosis
Value: morphological changes resulting from pathological death of the epidermal layer of skin; usually due to irreversible damage

Subject: epidermal atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of epidermal layer of the skin, associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: epidermal hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due an increased number of cells in the epidermis

Subject: abnormal keratinocyte apoptosis
Value: aberrant programmed cell death or anomaly in the number of the cells of the epidermis that produce keratin in the process of differentiating into the dead and fully keratinized cells of the stratum corneum

Subject: epidermal desquamation
Value: shedding of the cuticle of the epidermis in scales or shreds

Subject: abnormal epidermis stratum basale morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the deepest layer of the epidermis, which is composed of dividing stem cells and anchoring cells

Subject: absent epidermis stratum basale
Value: absence of the deepest layer of the epidermis, which is composed of dividing stem cells and anchoring cells

Subject: abnormal epidermis suprabasal layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the suprabasal layer of the epidermis

Subject: absent suprabasal layer
Value: absence of the suprabasal layer of the skin

Subject: disorganized suprabasal layer
Value: derangement of the pattern of the suprabasal layer of the skin

Subject: abnormal epidermis stratum spinosum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the layer of polyhedral cells in the epidermis; shrinkage and adhesion of these cells gives a spiny or prickly appearance

Subject: enlarged spinous cells
Value: increased size of the immature keratinocytes of the spinous layer of the epidermis

Subject: thin epidermis stratum spinosum
Value: reduced thickness of the stratum spinosum; the polyhedral cell layer

Subject: abnormal epidermis stratum granulosum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the layer of flattened cells containing basophilic granules of keratohyalin and lying just above the stratum spinosum (spiny layer) of the epidermis

Subject: abnormal epidermis stratum corneum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the outer layer of the epidermis, consisting of several layers of flat keratinized non-nucleated cells

Subject: absent epidermis stratum corneum
Value: absence of the outer layer of the epidermis, composed of several layers of keratinized non-nucleated cells

Subject: hyperkeratosis
Value: thickening of the horny layer of the epidermis

Subject: abnormal dermal layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly or atypical condition of the dermal layer of the skin

Subject: thin dermal layer
Value: reduced thickness of the dermis

Subject: thick dermal layer
Value: increased depth of the dermis

Subject: mixed cellular infiltration to dermis
Value: gradual accumulation of mixed cell types in the dermis that are not normally found there

Subject: dermal cysts
Value: abnormal membranous sacs appearing in the dermis

Subject: dermis papillary layer hypercellularity
Value: increased cell density of the superficial layer

Subject: abnormal body height
Value: any anomaly in the shoulder to floor distance compared to controls

Subject: increased body height
Value: increased shoulder to floor distance compared to controls

Subject: decreased body height
Value: decreased shoulder to floor distance compared to controls

Subject: abnormal body length
Value: any anomaly in the measure of the head and trunk (head, thorax and abdomen) in the rostral-caudal direction

Subject: increased body length
Value: increased measure of the head and trunk (head, thorax and abdomen) in the rostral-caudal direction

Subject: decreased body length
Value: decreased measure of the head and trunk (head, thorax and abdomen) in the rostral-caudal direction

Subject: abnormal body weight
Value: anomaly in average weight compared to controls

Subject: increased body weight
Value: greater than normal average weight

Subject: obese
Value: a status with body weight that is grossly above the average, acceptable or desirable weight, usually due to accumulation of excess fat tissue in the body

Subject: decreased body weight
Value: lower than normal average weight

Subject: weight loss
Value: progressive reduction of body weight below normal average for age

Subject: increased body size
Value: larger than average body weight, height and/or length of an organism compared to controls

Subject: decreased body size
Value: smaller than average body weight, height and/or length of an organism compared to controls

Subject: enlarged chest
Value: wider diameter, or distended chest cavity

Subject: barrel chest
Value: distended circumference of the thoracic and abdominal areas

Subject: distended abdomen
Value: abdomen appears curved outward or swollen

Subject: increased metastatic potential
Value: greater likelihood of a tumor cell spreading from the site of the initial tumor formation and forming a secondary tumor at another site not directly connected with it

Subject: decreased metastatic potential
Value: reduced likelihood of a tumor cell spreading from the site of the initial tumor formation and forming a secondary tumor at another site not directly connected with it

Subject: curly vibrissae
Value: coiled or spiral shape of the stiff hairs that project from the face around the nose of most mammals, and which act as touch receptors

Subject: tangled vibrissae
Value: snarled or intertwined stiff hairs that project from the face around the nose of most mammals, and which act as touch receptors

Subject: kinked vibrissae
Value: sharp bends in the stiff hairs that project from the face around the nose of most mammals, and which act as touch receptors

Subject: wavy vibrissae
Value: undulations or a sinusoidal shape of the stiff hairs that project from the face around the nose of most mammals, and which act as touch receptors

Subject: loss of vibrissae
Value: inability to retain the stiff hairs that project from the face around the nose of most mammals, and which act as touch receptors

Subject: increased vibrissae length
Value: longer average length of the stiff hairs that project from the face around the nose of most mammals, and which act as touch receptors

Subject: short vibrissae
Value: decreased length of the stiff hairs projecting from the face around the nose of most mammals which act as touch receptors

Subject: sparse vibrissae
Value: few and widely spaced stiff hairs that project from the face around the nose of most mammals, and which act as touch receptors

Subject: absent vibrissae
Value: absence of the stiff hairs that project from the face around the nose of most mammals, and which act as touch receptors

Subject: abnormal eye development
Value: malformation or arrest of differentiation of the visual organ

Subject: abnormal lens induction
Value: any anomaly in the signaling at short range between the head ectoderm and the optic vesicle that results in the head ectoderm forming a lens

Subject: persistence of hyaloid vascular system
Value: failure of the degeneration of the transient vascular system of the eye during development, that normally nourishes the retina, immature lens and primary vitreous of the developing eye

Subject: delayed eyelid opening
Value: late average time for the first postnatal eye opening

Subject: abnormal lens vesicle development
Value: malformation or abnormal patterning of the ectodermal invagination that forms opposite the optic cup in the primordium of the lens of the eye

Subject: anophthalmia
Value: absence of the globe and ocular tissue from the orbit, with or without the presence of ocular adnexa (eyelids, conjunctiva, and lacrimal apparatus); remnants of the globe sometimes appear in ectopic locations

Subject: macrophthalmia
Value: increased average size of the eyes

Subject: microphthalmia
Value: reduced average size of the eyes; generally refers to a congenital defect

Subject: abnormal eye distance/ position
Value: abnormal placement of the eyes in relation to each other or in relation to other craniofacial structures

Subject: ocular hypertelorism
Value: increased interpupillary distance, i.e. increased distance between the center of the pupils of the two eyes

Subject: eyelids open at birth
Value: open eyes instead of closed at perinatal stage; failure of the upper and lower thin folds of skin and muscle that cover the exposed portion of the eye to fuse completely together during development and an individual is born with the eye(s) uncovered leading to degrees of injury and blindness

Subject: abnormal lens morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the transparent structure of the eye responsible for focusing light rays

Subject: cataract
Value: complete or partial opacity of the lens

Subject: enlarged lens
Value: increased size of the transparent structure of the eye responsible for focusing light rays

Subject: small lens
Value: reduced size of the transparent structure of the eye responsible for focusing light rays

Subject: fused cornea and lens
Value: condition in which the transparent anterior portion of the fibrous coat of the eye is joined to the transparent biconvex cellular refractive structure lying between the iris and vitreous humor of the eye

Subject: abnormal lens polarity
Value: failure of normal orientation of the lens during development

Subject: hydropic eye lens fibers
Value: swollen cortical fibers of the eye lens

Subject: abnormal conjunctiva morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the mucous membrane that lines the inner surface of the eyelids and the front of the eyeball

Subject: abnormal cornea morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the transparent anterior portion of the fibrous coat of the eye that covers the iris, pupil, and anterior chamber; together with the lens, the cornea refracts light

Subject: increased incidence of corneal inflammation
Value: greater than average occurrence and/or persistence of the local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the cornea

Subject: corneal opacity
Value: complete or partial clouding of the cornea

Subject: corneal scarring
Value: appearance of fibrous tissue on the cornea after healing in response to injury

Subject: abnormal pupil morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the central circular aperture of the iris through which light rays enter the eye

Subject: pupil opacity
Value: milky or cloudy appearance of the central circular aperture of the iris through which light rays normally enter the eye

Subject: irregularly shaped pupil
Value: shape defects in the aperture of the iris through which light rays enter the eye, usually circular

Subject: small pupils
Value: smaller than normal size of the central circular aperture of the iris through which light rays enter the eye

Subject: abnormal iris morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the adjustable membrane, composed of the stroma and pigmented epithelium, located just in front of the crystalline lens within the eye

Subject: abnormal eye pigmentation
Value: change in the normal pigmentation of the eye to another color, or lack of color

Subject: abnormal retina morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thin layer of neural tissue lining the back of the eyeball which contains visual receptors

Subject: retinal degeneration
Value: retrogressive pathological change in the thin layer of neural tissue lining the back of the eyeball, which contains visual receptors and can result in the impairment or cessation of retinal neural function

Subject: decreased retinal photoreceptor cell number
Value: fewer than the expected number of rods and/or cones

Subject: disorganized retinal layers
Value: derangement of the pattern of the sheets of cells comprising the optic part of the retina

Subject: retina hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due an increased number of cells in the thin layer of neural tissue lining the back of the eyeball which contains visual receptors

Subject: abnormal optic nerve morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the second cranial nerve which is responsible for conveying visual information from the retina to the brain; it extends from the retina to the optic chiasma where part of its fibers become the optic tract and cross to the opposite side and pass to the geniculate bodies

Subject: abnormal optic nerve innervation
Value: misprojection or aberrant target finding of the second cranial nerve which is responsible for conveying visual information from the retina to the brain

Subject: absent optic nerve
Value: absence of the second cranial nerve which is responsible for conveying visual information from the retina to the brain

Subject: absent optic tract
Value: absence of the band of the paired bands of optic nerve fibers running from the optic chiasma mostly to the lateral geniculate body, with a smaller number of fibers terminating in the superior colliculus and the pretectal region

Subject: dry eyes
Value: absence of natural or normal moisture in the eye

Subject: abnormal eyelid morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the skin folds covering the front of the eyeball

Subject: absent eyelids
Value: missing skin folds covering the front of the eyeball when closed

Subject: pronounced eyelids
Value: strongly protruding eyelids

Subject: blepharoptosis
Value: ptosis, drooping eyelids

Subject: Meibomian gland atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of the sebaceous glands embedded in the tarsal plate of each eyelid, associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: abnormal lacrimal gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the glands that secrete tears

Subject: absent lacrimal glands
Value: missing the glands that secrete tears

Subject: abnormal lacrimal gland physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the glands that secrete tears

Subject: excessive tearing
Value: an unusually high amount of fluid in the eye, either oversecreted by the lacrimal glands, or due to imperfect drainage by the tear conducting passages, often resulting in overflow of fluid from the eye onto the cheek

Subject: increased aggression towards mice
Value: when compared to controls, subjects exhibit greater than the normal level of domineering, assaultive posture and/or hostile physical action toward other mice

Subject: increased aggression towards males
Value: when compared to controls, subjects exhibit greater than the normal level of domineering, assaultive posture and/or hostile physical action toward male mice

Subject: submission towards male mice
Value: no domineering, assault posture nor hostile physical action toward male mice

Subject: increased aggression towards females
Value: when compared to controls, subjects exhibit greater than the normal level of domineering, assaultive posture and/or hostile physical action toward female mice

Subject: increased aggression towards humans
Value: when compared to controls, subjects exhibit greater than the normal level of domineering, assaultive posture and/or hostile physical action toward humans

Subject: aggression towards inanimate objects
Value: a domineering, assault posture and/or hostile physical action toward inanimate objects

Subject: abnormal social investigation
Value: altered behavior of animals to approach and examine other animals

Subject: social withdrawal
Value: reclusive behavior; the tendency to refrain from participating in social situations and to seek isolation

Subject: abnormal anxiety-related response
Value: altered emotional response related to anticipation of a non-specific threat

Subject: increased anxiety-related response
Value: when compared to controls, subjects exhibit more responses thought to be indicative of anxiety in behavioral tests

Subject: decreased anxiety-related response
Value: when compared to controls, subjects exhibit fewer responses thought to be indicative of anxiety in behavioral tests

Subject: abnormal mating preference
Value: any change from the common preference of an initiating organism to initiate sexual contact with a receptive partner; in rodents, this usually refers to males that attempts to initiate sexual behavior with males and females indiscriminately

Subject: abnormal mating receptivity
Value: deviation from the normal cycle or inability of females to respond favorably to males that initiate sexual behavior

Subject: abnormal mating frequency
Value: increased, reduced or absent attempt of sexual behavioral contact between an initiating organism and a receptive partner

Subject: abnormal ejaculation
Value: anomalies in the ability to propulse semen from the genital ducts and the urethra to the exterior

Subject: abnormal penile erection
Value: altered ability to achieve a rigid state of the penis obtained in the condition in which the erectile tissue is filled with blood

Subject: reduced male mating frequency
Value: males do not as frequently initiate sexual behavior (as scored by the presence of copulation plugs in rodents, not due to infertility)

Subject: abnormal nursing
Value: females show anomlies in the feeding of offspring from mammary glands, or do not nurse offspring, or nurse offspring infrequently

Subject: abnormal pup retrieval
Value: any anomaly in the ability of a nesting female to retrieve stray pups to the nest or a delay in retrieving stray pups

Subject: pup cannibalization
Value: the killing and eating of newborn mice by the mother; however, this can be a normal response if the mother does not recognize the pups as her own

Subject: abnormal maternal nurturing
Value: anomaly in the behaviors related to a female tending to young

Subject: abnormal stationary movement
Value: altered ability or inability to change body posture or shift a body part

Subject: abnormal eye movement
Value: deviation from the normal motility of the visual organs

Subject: abnormal tail movements
Value: a change from the normal manner of moving the tail

Subject: abnormal locomotor behavior
Value: altered ability or inability to move from place to place in response to stimuli

Subject: ataxia
Value: inability to coordinate voluntary muscular movements

Subject: circling
Value: repeated movement in a circle; often associated with inner ear defects

Subject: bidirectional circling
Value: circling behavior exhibited in both clockwise and counterclockwise directions

Subject: unidirectional circling
Value: circling behavior in one direction only, either clockwise or counterclockwise

Subject: hyperactivity
Value: general restlessness or excessive movement; more frequent movement from one place to another or having an increased state of activity

Subject: hyperresponsive
Value: increased reaction to touch

Subject: jumpy
Value: marked by fitful, jerky movements

Subject: hypoactivity
Value: general reduced locomotor activity; reduced movement from one place to another or having a decreased state of activity

Subject: no spontaneous movement
Value: failure of neonates or embryos to initiate any voluntary or spontaneous change in position or posture, with or without external stimulus

Subject: impaired coordination
Value: reduced ability to execute integrated movements of muscle

Subject: abnormal gait
Value: abnormal pattern of movement of the limbs of animals, characterized by elements of progression, stability, speed and length over the ground

Subject: short stride length
Value: reduced average distance between steps

Subject: stereotypic behavior
Value: repetitive, invariant, perseverative motor patterns that do not appear to be purposeful

Subject: increased stereotypic behavior
Value: more frequent incidence of repetitive, invariant, perseverative motor patterns that do not appear to be purposeful

Subject: head bobbing
Value: repetitive up and down movement of the head

Subject: spinning
Value: repetitive rolling of the body

Subject: excessive scratching
Value: compulsive scraping of the skin, usually with the nails

Subject: abnormal response to new environment
Value: altered behavioral reaction associated with placing an animal in a new location

Subject: increased exploration in new environment
Value: greater amount of time spent investigating new location

Subject: decreased exploration in new environment
Value: less amount of time spent investigating a new location

Subject: abnormal drinking behavior
Value: an altered pattern of fluid consumption or altered preference for particular fluids

Subject: abnormal liquid preference
Value: the desire to drink more or less fluids than average, or to drink unusual fluids

Subject: abnormal alcohol consumption
Value: aberrant behavioral-related or physiological-related intake of alcohol into the body

Subject: polydipsia
Value: abnormally large intake of fluids by mouth, usually due to excessive thirst that is relatively prolonged

Subject: adipsia
Value: failure to drink

Subject: dehydration
Value: excessive water loss from the body or from an organ or bodily part

Subject: abnormal eating behavior
Value: altered ability to consume foods or atypical consumption pattern

Subject: abnormal food preference
Value: the desire to eat more or less food than average, or to eat unusual foods

Subject: polyphagia
Value: eating to excess

Subject: absent suckling reflex
Value: inability to orient and open/close mouth in sucking pattern in response to external light touching or stroking of the chin

Subject: abnormal suckling behavior
Value: reduced ability or inability to exert suction by the mouth, or atypical suckling pattern

Subject: no swallowing reflex
Value: inability to pull food through the esophagus to the stomach in response to feeding

Subject: aphagia
Value: failure to eat

Subject: abnormal grooming behavior
Value: defects in the standard of behavior of cleaning and/or keeping outward appearance tidy (self, mate or offspring)

Subject: increased grooming behavior
Value: increased amount of time spent cleaning and/or keeping outward appearance tidy (self, mate or offspring)

Subject: decreased grooming behavior
Value: reduced amount of time spent cleaning and/or keeping outward appearance tidy (self, mate or offspring)

Subject: poor grooming
Value: below average standard of cleaning and/or keeping outward appearance tidy (self, mate or offspring)

Subject: abnormal whisker trimming behavior
Value: anomaly in the behavior of plucking or biting off of the whiskers/vibrissae from other individuals of a cohort

Subject: abnormal nest building behavior
Value: deviation from the usual behavior of nesting animals to build sleeping nests out of any available materials, or of nesting animals to build nests to protect offspring

Subject: abnormal huddling behavior
Value: deviation from the usual tendency of mice to pile together when sleeping

Subject: abnormal cued conditioning behavior
Value: anomaly in the ability of an animal to learn and remember an association between an aversive experience (the unconditioned stimulus (US), usually a shock) and a neutral stimulus (the conditioned stimulus (CS), usually an auditory cue or light flash)

Subject: abnormal object recognition memory
Value: anomaly in the ability to recognize objects that the animal has previously encountered; recognition is measured by relative amount of time exploring objects, which should decrease upon subsequent or multiple presentations of the same object when presented with novel objects at the same time

Subject: abnormal olfactory discrimination memory
Value: anomaly in the ability to exhibit a differential response to olfactory stimuli that is achieved by the reinforcement of the desired response for each particular olfactory stimulus

Subject: abnormal avoidance learning behavior
Value: anomaly in the ability to associate a previously neutral stimulus with an unpleasant or punishing stimuli so that the animal learns to avoid the previously neutral stimulus

Subject: abnormal spatial learning
Value: anomaly in the ability to ascertain or acquire spatial location information in order to improve navigation or other behavior using such location cues

Subject: abnormal temporal memory
Value: anomaly in the ability to recall temporal events and stimuli

Subject: abnormal contextual conditioning behavior
Value: anomaly in the ability of an animal to learn and remember an association between an aversive experience (the unconditioned stimulus (US), usually a shock) and the neutral, unchanging environment (the conditioned stimulus (CS), or the environmental context in this case)

Subject: reduced long term potentiation
Value: less than the normal persistent robust synaptic response induced by synchronous stimulation of pre- and postsynaptic cells

Subject: reduced long term depression
Value: less than the normal, persistent activity-dependent decrease in synaptic efficacy between neurons, often following slow, weak stimulation of CA1 neurons

Subject: abnormal pinna reflex
Value: anomaly in the response to an auditory stimulus by a characteristic ear twitch

Subject: abnormal startle reflex
Value: aberrant threshold or reflex response to variable stimuli, often auditory; usually measured by amplitude of whole body flinch

Subject: increased startle reflex
Value: reduced threshold or more severe reflex response to variable stimuli, often auditory; usually measured by amplitude of whole body flinch

Subject: decreased startle reflex
Value: greater threshold or less severe reflex response to variable stimuli, often auditory; usually measured by amplitude of whole body flinch

Subject: abnormal vibrissae reflex
Value: animals do not change position in response to stimulation of the whiskers

Subject: unresponsive to tactile stimuli
Value: absence of reflex action normally induced by touch or pain

Subject: abnormal pilomotor reflex
Value: anomaly in the involuntary bristling of hairs that occurs when an organism is cold or experiences strong emotions such as fear or awe

Subject: audiogenic seizures
Value: a reflex seizure triggered by loud noises

Subject: abnormal kindling response
Value: any anomaly in the long-lasting epileptogenic changes normally induced by daily sub threshold electrical brain stimulation, often used as an induced model for epilepsy

Subject: reduced kindling response
Value: fewer epileptogenic changes normally induced by daily sub threshold electrical brain stimulation

Subject: abnormal sleep pattern
Value: deviation from the normal wake/sleep cycle

Subject: obsolete abnormal circadian rhythm
Value: deviation from the normal 24 hour biological activity cycle

Subject: abnormal posture
Value: atypical intentionally or habitually assumed position of the limbs or carriage of the body

Subject: hunched posture
Value: stooped low with the limbs pulled in close to the body and arched back

Subject: limp posture
Value: lack of rigidity of the carriage of the body

Subject: abnormal coat appearance
Value: anomaly in the visual aspect of the coat or hair

Subject: disheveled coat
Value: coat that looks generally unkempt

Subject: trunk curl
Value: posture of the trunk in a curled position

Subject: limb grasping
Value: mice clasp front and/or hind feet almost immediately upon being lifted by tail

Subject: abnormal grip strength
Value: altered ability to grasp and hold objects, often measured as time spent hanging from an object or wire

Subject: abnormal motor coordination/balance
Value: altered ability of an animal to maintain skillful and effective interaction of movements or maintenance of equilibrium

Subject: impaired swimming
Value: reduced ability or inability to swim

Subject: impaired righting response
Value: reduced ability or greater amount of time needed to recover from an unnatural position to a normal position and/or to resist any force acting to place an organism into a false position

Subject: impaired limb coordination
Value: reduced ability to organize limb movements to execute complex maneuvers, such as walking

Subject: impaired balance
Value: reduced ability of an animal to maintain equilibrium

Subject: abnormal placing response
Value: altered ability to stretch and lift the forelimbs and head to grab a close edge

Subject: athetotic walking movements
Value: characterized by slow, writhing involuntary movements of flexion, extension, pronation and supination of the paws and toes

Subject: abnormal vocalization
Value: an inability, decreased ability or altered ability to produce sound from the vocal organs; or a general increase or decrease in the production of vocal sound

Subject: abnormal skeleton physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the bony framework of the body

Subject: decreased caudal vertebrae number
Value: reduced number of the bony segments of the tail or tail remnant

Subject: abnormal osteoclast physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the specialized phagocytic cells associated with the absorption and removal of the mineralized matrix of bone tissue

Subject: abnormal bone strength
Value: change in the ability of bone to endure the application of force without yielding or breaking

Subject: abnormal cardiovascular system physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the heart or vascular tissue

Subject: abnormal hematopoietic system physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the fluid and/or its suspended elements that circulate(s) through the heart, arteries, capillaries, and veins

Subject: abnormal lipid level
Value: any anomaly in the concentrations of fat-soluble substances (molecules composed of carbon and hydrogen and are characteristically insoluble in water) in the body

Subject: hyperlipidemia
Value: abnormally high concentration of lipids in the circulating blood

Subject: increased circulating triglyceride level
Value: greater concentration of naturally occurring esters of three fatty acids and glycerol in the blood; triglycerides are widespread in adipose tissue, commonly circulate in the blood in the form of lipoproteins, and are involved in the process of bidirectional transference of adipose fat and blood glucose with the liver

Subject: abnormal circulating free fatty acids level
Value: any anomaly in the blood concentrations of the fatty acids which occur in plasma as a result of lipolysis in adipose tissue or when plasma triacyglycerols are taken into tissues

Subject: increased circulating free fatty acids level
Value: higher than normal levels of the fatty acids which occur in plasma as a result of lipolysis in adipose tissue or when plasma triacyglycerols are taken into tissues

Subject: increased circulating HDL cholesterol level
Value: <higher amount in the blood of the small lipoprotein:cholesterol complex that transports cholesterol out of the arteries and to the liver for reprocessing or excretion>

Subject: hyperglycemia
Value: abnormally high concentration of glucose in the blood; generally refers to a pathological state

Subject: abnormal circulating insulin level
Value: any anomaly in the blood concentration of the polypeptide hormone, secreted by beta cells of the pancreas, that promotes glucose utilization, protein synthesis, and the formation and storage of neutral lipids

Subject: abnormal circulating calcium level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration of calcium in the blood

Subject: abnormal circulating phosphate level
Value: any anomaly in the blood concentrations of the salt or ester of phosphoric acid

Subject: increased circulating phosphate level
Value: abnormally high concentrations of phosphates in the circulating blood

Subject: abnormal circulating bilirubin level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration in the blood of the bile pigment bilirubin, normally found in the liver and in red blood cells

Subject: abnormal circulating enzyme level
Value: aberrant concentration in the blood of any of the proteins that act as catalysts for biological reactions

Subject: abnormal circulating alanine transaminase level
Value: aberrant concentration in the blood of the enzyme which transfers amino groups from l-alanine to 2-ketoglutarate, or the reverse (from l-glutamate to pyruvate); serum concentration is increased in viral hepatitis and myocardial infarction

Subject: abnormal oxygen level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration of the gaseous element that is essential for animal and plant life

Subject: cyanosis
Value: a dark bluish or purple skin discoloration resulting from deficient oxygenation of the blood

Subject: anemia
Value: less than normal levels of red blood cells and/or hemoglobin within red blood cells, or volume of packed red blood cells in the bloodstream, resulting in insufficient oxygenation of tissues and organs

Subject: hemolytic anemia
Value: deficiency of red cells resulting from an increased rate of erythrocyte destruction

Subject: abnormal erythrocyte cell number
Value: altered number of the cells that transport oxygen, red blood cells, per unit

Subject: abnormal hemoglobin
Value: defects in the levels or the function of the oxygen-carrying protein of erythrocytes

Subject: abnormal mean corpuscular hemoglobin
Value: anomalies in the average levels of hemoglobin contained in an erythrocyte

Subject: hypotension
Value: sustained low blood pressure at a level that is likely to result in cardiovascular disease and/or other pathological states

Subject: abnormal blood viscosity
Value: anomaly in the resistance to flow of the blood through the vessels

Subject: abnormal blood volume
Value: any anomaly in the amount of space occupied by the blood in the vessels

Subject: abnormal myelopoiesis
Value: anomaly in the process of, or atypical formation of myeloid cells from the pluripotent hematopoietic stem cells in the bone marrow from myeloid stem cells, including the production of leukocytes in blood, such as monocytes and granulocytes and precursor cells for macrophage and dendritic cells found in the lymphoid tissue

Subject: impaired myelopoiesis
Value: atypical process of bone marrow cell formation and/or the formation of bone marrow-derived blood cells with the result of fewer of these cells being formed

Subject: failure of myelopoiesis
Value: missing the process of bone marrow cell formation and/or the formation of bone marrow-derived blood cells

Subject: impaired hematopoiesis
Value: atypical process of blood cell formation with the result of fewer of these cells being formed

Subject: abnormal vasodilation
Value: anomaly in the physiological widening of the lumen of the blood vessels by relaxing the underlying vascular smooth muscle

Subject: abnormal blood vessel morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the network of tubes that carries blood through the body

Subject: abnormal vascular permeability
Value: anomaly in the ability of the blood vessels to permit the passage of substances such as fluid, heat, or gases

Subject: abnormal vasculogenesis
Value: aberrant process of the initial establishment of the vascular network

Subject: cardiac hypertrophy
Value: an increase in size of the cardiac tissue, not due to increased cell number

Subject: abnormal cardiac output
Value: anomaly in the blood volume pumped by each ventricle per minute (stroke volume x heart rate)

Subject: abnormal heart rate
Value: greater than or fewer than average resting heart beats per minute, usually measured by the number of times the heart ventricles contract per unit of time, usually per minute

Subject: poor circulation
Value: insufficient movement of blood throughout the body, often manifesting in cold and/or pale skin

Subject: internal hemorrhage
Value: blood loss in the interior of the body due to vessel rupture or dysmorphology

Subject: irregular heartbeat
Value: uneven timing of heart contraction

Subject: abnormal apoptosis
Value: excessive or absent cell death in a particular tissue or cell type

Subject: abnormal mandibular symphysis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the fibrocartilagenous union of the two halves of the mandible (embryonic stages)

Subject: abnormal seizure response to electrical stimulation
Value: anomaly in the seizure activity response that is brought about by high or low frequency electrical stimulation

Subject: obsolete necrosis
Value: pathological death of cells or a portion of a tissue or organ; usually due to irreversible damage

Subject: colonic necrosis
Value: morphological changes resulting from pathological death of some or all colon tissue; usually due to irreversible damage

Subject: gastric necrosis
Value: morphological changes resulting from pathological death of gastric tissue; usually due to irreversible damage

Subject: hepatic necrosis
Value: morphological changes resulting from pathological death of liver tissue; usually due to irreversible damage

Subject: multifocal hepatic necrosis
Value: morphological changes resulting from multiple localized areas of pathological death of liver tissue; usually due to irreversible damage

Subject: focal hepatic necrosis
Value: morphological changes resulting from one or more localized areas of pathological death of some or all liver tissue; usually due to irreversible damage

Subject: abnormal induced morbidity/mortality
Value: differences from the expected diseased state or death caused by an external intervention

Subject: increased mortality induced by gamma-irradiation
Value: greater sensitivity to doses of ionizing radiation

Subject: extended life span
Value: persistence of life for a longer period than is normal for an organism

Subject: abnormal digestive system physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the organ system that converts ingested food to nutrients and energy

Subject: abnormal digestion
Value: any anomaly of the physical, chemical, and biochemical processes carried out by multicellular organisms to break down ingested nutrients into components that may be easily absorbed and directed into metabolism

Subject: chronic diarrhea
Value: prolonged diarrhea

Subject: abnormal intestinal absorption
Value: any anomaly in the quantity or rate of any nutrient taken up from the contents of the intestine

Subject: obsolete abnormal carbohydrate absorption
Value: any anomaly in the ability of the body to take in substances composed of carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen according to the general formula Cn(H2O)n; sugars and starches are examples

Subject: abnormal intestinal fructose absorption
Value: any anomaly in the ability of the small intestine to absorb fructose into the bloodstream

Subject: abnormal intestinal glucose absorption
Value: any anomaly in the ability of the small intestine to absorb glucose into the bloodstream

Subject: abnormal intestinal mineral absorption
Value: any anomaly in the ability of the body to take up inorganic substances that have importance in body functions into the blood by absorption from the small intestine

Subject: abnormal vitamin absorption
Value: any anomaly in the ability to take in any of a group of organic substances, present in food, that are essential to normal metabolism

Subject: abnormal embryo development
Value: anomaly in the establishment of the characteristic configuration of the embryonic body

Subject: abnormal germ layer development
Value: abnormal development of the three primary germ layers of the embryo

Subject: abnormal ectoderm development
Value: any abnormality in the formation of the outer of the three primary germ layers of the embryo (the others being mesoderm and endoderm) that originates in the epiblast and is formed during gastrulation; ectoderm is in contact with the amnionic cavity and gives rise to two distinct lineages, i.e. the surface ectoderm and the neural ectoderm; it is the source of Rathke's pouch and forms the central and peripheral nervous systems, the sensory epithelia of the eye, ear, and nose, the epidermis and its appendages (nails and hair), the mammary, pituitary and subcutaneous glands, the tooth enamel, and the mucous membranes of the mouth and anus

Subject: abnormal apical ectodermal ridge morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the multilayered ectodermal region at the tip of a limb bud necessary for the proper development of the underlying mesenchyme

Subject: absent apical ectodermal ridge
Value: missing the multilayered ectodermal region at the tip of a limb bud necessary for the proper development of the underlying mesenchyme

Subject: thick apical ectodermal ridge
Value: increase in the thickness of the multilayered ectodermal region at the tip of a limb bud necessary for the proper development of the underlying mesenchyme

Subject: thin apical ectodermal ridge
Value: decrease in the thickness of the multilayered ectodermal region at the tip of a limb bud necessary for the proper development of the underlying mesenchyme

Subject: abnormal mesoderm development
Value: failure or abnormality in the formation of the middle of the three primary germ layers of the embryo (the others being ectoderm and endoderm) during gastrulation; mesoderm is the origin of connective tissues, myoblasts, blood, the cardiovascular and lymphatic systems, most of the urogenital system, and the lining of the pericardial, pleural, and peritoneal cavities

Subject: absent mesoderm
Value: absence of the middle of the three primary germ layers of the embryo (the others being ectoderm and endoderm) during gastrulation; mesoderm is the origin of connective tissues, myoblasts, blood, the cardiovascular and lymphatic systems, most of the urogenital system, and the lining of the pericardial, pleural, and peritoneal cavities

Subject: abnormal axial mesoderm morphology
Value: failure or abnormality in the formation of part of the middle of the three primary germ layers of the embryo which includes the prechordal mesoderm and the chordamesoderm and gives rise to the prechordal plate and to the notochord

Subject: abnormal endoderm development
Value: any abnormality in the formation of the innermost of the three primary germ layers of the embryo (the others being mesoderm and ectoderm) during gastrulation; endoderm gives rise to the epithelial lining of the gastrointestinal and respiratory tracts; the parenchyma of the tonsils, the liver, the thymus, the thyroid, the parathyroids, and the pancreas; the epithelial lining of the urinary bladder, urethra, and prostate; and the epithelial lining of the tympanic cavity, tympanic antrum, and auditory tube

Subject: thin endoderm
Value: reduced thickness of the innermost germ layer of the embryo

Subject: abnormal somite development
Value: any anomaly in the formation of mesodermal clusters that are arranged segmentally along the anterior posterior axis of an embryo; somites are transient structures - balls or blocks of paraxial mesoderm cells with an epithelial outer layer and a mesenchymal cell core - that emerge sequentially through a mesenchymal-to-epithelial transition (MET) from the morphologically unpatterned presomitic mesoderm; they give rise to the metameric anatomy of the vertebral column itself, and the associated skin, muscle and tendons

Subject: incomplete somite formation
Value: arrest of differentiation or patterning of the somites

Subject: failure of somite differentiation
Value: disorganized or absent somite tissue or somite pattern in development

Subject: abnormal somite shape
Value: anomaly in the characteristic surface outline or contour of mesodermal clusters that are arranged segmentally along the anterior posterior axis of an embryo

Subject: failure of primitive streak formation
Value: inability to form the epiblast ridge from which arises the germ layers of the embryo

Subject: absent egg cylinders
Value: inability of inner cell mass cells to grow towards the abembryonic pole to form a cylinder-like structure

Subject: abnormal gastrulation
Value: any anomaly in the development and invagination of the embryonic germ layers

Subject: failure to gastrulate
Value: inability to differentiate and invaginate the primary germ layers

Subject: abnormal embryo size
Value: <any anomaly in the proportions of embryo compared to littermates (sensu Mus: up to E14, or the completion of organogenesis)>

Subject: decreased embryo size
Value: <smaller proportions of an embryo compared to littermates or other controls (sensu Mus: up to E14, or the completion of organogenesis)>

Subject: increased embryo size
Value: <larger proportions of embryo compared to littermates or other controls (sensu Mus: up to E14, or the completion of organogenesis)>

Subject: abnormal embryo turning
Value: atypical axial rotation of the germ layers of the embryo during the primitive streak/early somite stage during which the curvature of the entire trunk region is normally reversed and the neural ectoderm moves to the convex region and the midgut region becomes located in the concave region

Subject: incomplete embryo turning
Value: arrest of the axial rotation of the germ layers of the embryo during the primitive streak/early somite stage

Subject: abnormal dorsal-ventral axis patterning
Value: anomaly in the development or formation of the axis that runs from the front to the back surface of the body

Subject: abnormal proximal-distal axis patterning
Value: anomaly in the formation or development of a body structure, often a limb, in relation to the structure's proximity to the trunk or point of origin

Subject: abnormal left-right axis patterning
Value: anomaly in the formation or development of the body or a specific organ of the body in relation to the left and right sides of the body or organ

Subject: absent amniotic folds
Value: failure of the amnion to form involutions

Subject: abnormal placenta morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the organ of metabolic interchange between fetus and mother, which is partly of embryonic origin and partly of maternal origin

Subject: abnormal placenta development
Value: malformed or incomplete differentiation of the organ of metabolic exchange between the fetus and mother

Subject: decreased trophoblast giant cell number
Value: fewer than normal number of cells of the extraembryonic cell layer that contributes to the placenta

Subject: absent trophoblast giant cells
Value: missing cells of the extraembryonic cell layer that contribute to the placenta

Subject: placental labyrinth hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the placental labyrinth, the structure where embryonic blood vessels are surrounded by trophoblast cells and maternal blood

Subject: abnormal placenta labyrinth morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the placental layers where embryonic blood vessels are surrounded by trophoblast cells and maternal blood, and is the site where the exchange of nutrients and waste products occurs between the maternal and fetal circulation

Subject: absent ectoplacental cone
Value: missing the thickened trophoblast of the blastocyst in rodents that becomes the fetal portion of the placenta

Subject: abnormal visceral yolk sac morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the extraembryonic tissue membrane, formed from the visceral endoderm and the extraembryonic mesoderm, which is located ventral to the embryonic disc and is connected to the presumptive midgut of the embryo; the yolk that it contains is the site of embryonic hematopoiesis and vitelline circulation is involved in early embryonic circulation; it is the origin of the primordial germ cells

Subject: absent vitelline blood vessels
Value: absence of the vascular network that supplies the yolk sac

Subject: absent visceral yolk sac blood islands
Value: absence of the masses of developing blood cells attached to endothelium in the yolk sac

Subject: pale yolk sac
Value: bloodless yolk sac

Subject: disorganized yolk sac vascular plexus
Value: derangement in the pattern of the primary (honeycomb-like) vasculature of the yolk sac prior to remodeling into a mature vascular network

Subject: abnormal extraembryonic endoderm formation
Value: malformation of the derivative of the hypoblast cells that migrate into the blastocyst cavity, and line the cavity, giving rise to the primary and definitive yolk sacs; the extraembryonic endoderm fills the remaining cavity of the blastocyst

Subject: abnormal umbilical cord morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the connective stalk between the fetus and the placenta

Subject: abnormal allantois morphology
Value: any structural anomaly fetal membrane which contributes to the formation of the umbilical cord and placental blood vessels

Subject: abnormal embryo implantation
Value: anomaly in the process in which the blastocyst and/or the uterine environment to successfully synchronize allowing attachment of the blastocyst to the epithelial lining of the uterus, its penetration through the epithelium and any subsequent physiological interactions necessary to sustain embryonic development

Subject: failure of embryo implantation
Value: inability of the blastocyst and/or the uterine environment to successfully synchronize allowing attachment of the blastocyst to the epithelial lining of the uterus, its penetration through the epithelium and any subsequent physiological interactions necessary to sustain embryonic development

Subject: impaired embryo implantation
Value: impaired ability of the blastocyst and/or the uterine environment to successfully synchronize allowing attachment of the blastocyst to the epithelial lining of the uterus, its penetration through the epithelium and any subsequent physiological interactions necessary to sustain embryonic development

Subject: embryonic growth arrest
Value: the cessation of development beyond a particular stage

Subject: abnormal postnatal growth
Value: anomaly in reaching a developmental stage or stages after birth

Subject: postnatal growth retardation
Value: slow or limited development after birth

Subject: abnormal adrenal gland secretion
Value: altered ability of the surparenal gland to produce or secrete hormones

Subject: failure of adrenal epinephrine secretion
Value: inability of adrenal gland to deliver epinephrine into the blood stream

Subject: absent circulating adrenaline
Value: absence in the circulation of a catecholamine hormone that stimulates the adrenergic receptors and causes systemic vasoconstriction and gastrointestinal relaxation, stimulates the heart, and dilates bronchi and cerebral vessels

Subject: absent circulating noradrenaline
Value: absence of the hormone secreted by the adrenal medulla and acts as a neurotransmitter in the sympathetic peripheral nervous system and in some tracts of the CNS; noradrenaline is the demethylated biosynthetic precursor of epinephrine

Subject: hypersecretion of corticosterone
Value: increased release of this adrenocortical steroid that induces glycogen deposition and regulates sodium conservation and potassium secretion

Subject: increased circulating corticosterone level
Value: greater than the normal blood amount of an adrenocortical steroid that induces glycogen deposition and regulates sodium conservation and potassium secretion

Subject: abnormal pituitary secretion
Value: anomaly in the production and/or release of biologically active substances from pituitary tissue

Subject: hypersecretion of adrenocorticotropin
Value: increased release of this pituitary hormone from the pituitary gland that stimulates the secretion of adrenal cortical steroids and induces growth of the adrenal cortex

Subject: increased circulating adrenocorticotropin level
Value: elevated concentration in the blood of the pituitary hormone that stimulates the secretion of adrenal cortical steroids and induces growth of the adrenal cortex

Subject: suppressed circulating follicle stimulating hormone level
Value: repression of secretion into the blood of FSH, the hormone that, in females, stimulates the graafian follicles of the ovary and assists in follicular maturation and the secretion of estradiol; in the male it stimulates the epithelium of the seminiferous tubules and is partly responsible for spermatogenesis

Subject: increased circulating follicle stimulating hormone level
Value: higher than normal levels in the blood stream of FSH, the hormone that, in females, stimulates the graafian follicles of the ovary and assists in follicular maturation and the secretion of estradiol; in the male it stimulates the epithelium of the seminiferous tubules and is partly responsible for spermatogenesis

Subject: increased circulating luteinizing hormone level
Value: higher than the normal levels in the bloodstream of LH, the hormone that regulates steroid production by the interstitial cells of the testis and the ovary

Subject: abnormal hypothalamus secretion
Value: altered ability of the hypothalamus to produce or release biologically active substances

Subject: hypersecretion of corticotropin-releasing hormone
Value: excessive release of this factor, which normally stimulates the pituitary to release adrenocorticotropic hormone, from the hypothalamus

Subject: increased circulating corticotropin-releasing hormone level
Value: higher than average amount of CRH in blood; CRH is normally released by the hypothalamus and stimulates the release of corticotropin by the anterior pituitary gland

Subject: abnormal urination
Value: anomaly in the process in which parasympathetic nerves stimulate the bladder wall muscle to contract resulting in the expulsion of urine from the body

Subject: abnormal urine glucose level
Value: any change in the amount of glucose in the urine

Subject: increased urine glucose level
Value: a greater amount of glucose in the urine compared to the normal state

Subject: abnormal urine enzyme level
Value: any change in the level of enzymes in the urine

Subject: abnormal urination pattern
Value: increased or decreased frequency of urination episodes, or extended periods of anuria

Subject: polyuria
Value: increased volume of urine produced and excreted

Subject: abnormal homeostasis
Value: anomaly in the processes involved in the maintenance of an internal equilibrium of various functions and chemical or protein composition of the fluids and tissues

Subject: abnormal ion homeostasis
Value: anomaly in the processes involved in the maintenance of an internal equilibrium of charged molecules in the fluids and tissues

Subject: abnormal iron level
Value: any anomaly in the concentrations of the metallic element that normally occurs in the heme of hemoglobin, myoglobin, transferrin, ferritin, and iron-containing porphyrins and is an essential component of enzymes such as catalase, peroxidase, and various cytochromes

Subject: abnormal circulating magnesium level
Value: any anomaly in the blood concentration of magnesium

Subject: abnormal selenium level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration of selenium, which is required for glutathione peroxidase and other enzymes

Subject: abnormal circulating sodium level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration in the blood of sodium, the most plentiful extracellular ion in the body and the principal determinant of extracellular fluid volume

Subject: abnormal body temperature homeostasis
Value: any anomaly in the process in which an organism modulates or maintains its internal body temperature

Subject: abnormal brown adipose tissue amount
Value: anomaly in the amount of the thermogenic form of adipose tissue that is composed of brown adipocytes

Subject: decreased brown adipose tissue amount
Value: reduced quantity of the thermogenic form of adipose tissue that is composed of brown adipocytes

Subject: abnormal white adipose tissue amount
Value: anomaly in the quantity of the white fat-storing cells/tissue

Subject: decreased white adipose tissue amount
Value: reduced quantity of fat-storing cells/tissue

Subject: abnormal fluid regulation
Value: any anomaly in the control of intracellular and/or extracellular fluid

Subject: edema
Value: an accumulation of an excessive amount of watery fluid in cells or intercellular tissues

Subject: skin edema
Value: accumulation of an excessive amount of fluid in the skin layers or just underneath the skin

Subject: pericardial edema
Value: accumulation of watery fluid in the pericardial sac of the heart

Subject: periorbital edema
Value: accumulation of an excessive amount of fluid in the area around the orbit

Subject: abnormal immune system physiology
Value: deviation from the normal function of the immune system

Subject: impaired wound healing
Value: reduced ability or inability to self-repair and close wounds

Subject: altered susceptibility to infection
Value: a change in the likelihood that an organism will develop ill effects from a pathogenic invasion or from components of or toxins produced by pathogens

Subject: impaired macrophage phagocytosis
Value: reduced ability of macrophage phagocytic cells to internalize particulate matter

Subject: abnormal humoral immune response
Value: any functional anomaly of the aspect of immunity that is mediated by secreted antibodies produced in the cells of the B lymphocyte lineage (B cell) and the accessory processes that accompany it, including Th2 activation and cytokine production, germinal center formation and isotype switching, affinity maturation and memory cell generation; it also refers to the effector functions of antibody, which include pathogen and toxin neutralization, classical complement activation, and opsonin promotion of phagocytosis and pathogen elimination

Subject: arrested B cell differentiation
Value: inability to produce mature B cells, and accumulation of B cell precursors

Subject: decreased IgG level
Value: less than normal immunoglobulin class G level

Subject: decreased IgM level
Value: less than normal immunoglobulin class M level

Subject: decreased IgA level
Value: less than normal immunoglobulin class A level

Subject: abnormal immune cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the cells of the immune system

Subject: thymus hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced cell number, in the thymus

Subject: abnormal thymus involution
Value: premature or late decline in thymic function normally associated with advancing age

Subject: arrested T cell differentiation
Value: failure of T cell formation to proceed past a defined stage

Subject: abnormal T cell activation
Value: anomaly in the process of producing effector T cells from naive T cells

Subject: increased activated T cell number
Value: greater than normal numbers of effector T cells

Subject: decreased activated T cell number
Value: reduced numbers of effector T cells

Subject: abnormal antigen presentation
Value: aberration in the process by which by which an antigen-presenting cell expresses antigen (peptide or lipid) on its cell surface in association with an MHC protein complex

Subject: abnormal antigen presentation via MHC class I
Value: anomaly in the process by which peptide, bound to major histocompatibility complex class I, is presented to lymphocytes at the surface of antigen presenting cells

Subject: defective assembly of class I molecules
Value: impaired production of major histocompatibility complex class I molecules

Subject: defective intracellular transport of class I molecules
Value: impaired ability to move major histocompatibility complex class I molecules to the cell surface

Subject: abnormal level of surface class I molecules
Value: deviation from the normal concentration of major histocompatibility complex class I molecules expressed at the cell surface

Subject: increased level of surface class I molecules
Value: greater than normal expression of major histocompatibility complex class I molecules at the cell surface

Subject: decreased level of surface class I molecules
Value: reduced expression of major histocompatibility complex class I molecules at the cell surface

Subject: autoimmune response
Value: condition in which cells and/or antibodies arise from and are directed against one's own tissues

Subject: abnormal inflammatory response
Value: aberrant reaction of the microcirculation characterized by movement of fluid and leukocytes from the blood into extravascular tissues

Subject: increased inflammatory response
Value: greater than expected response to injury, infection, or insult

Subject: brain inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the brain

Subject: choroid inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the thin, highly vascularized membrane covering most of the posterior of the eye between the retina and the sclera

Subject: ear inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins and leukocytes in the ear

Subject: increased susceptibility to otitis media
Value: greater likelihood of middle ear inflammation, with an accumulation of a thick, mucous-like fluid; usually associated with a viral or bacterial respiratory infection

Subject: eye inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the eye

Subject: conjunctivitis
Value: inflammation of the mucous membrane that lines the inner surface of the eyelids and the front of the eyeball

Subject: heart inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the heart

Subject: atrial endocarditis
Value: inflammation affecting the atrial chambers of the heart

Subject: abnormal atrial thrombosis
Value: any anomaly in the formation or presence of one or more thrombi in the atria of the heart

Subject: myocarditis
Value: inflammation of the heart walls

Subject: pericarditis
Value: inflammation of the pericardium, the fibroserous sac surrounding the heart and the roots of the great vessels

Subject: intestinal inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the intestine

Subject: kidney inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the kidney

Subject: liver inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the liver

Subject: lung inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the lung

Subject: interstitial pneumonia
Value: any of a group of inflammatory and fibrotic disorders of the lower respiratory tract, primarily affecting the supporting framework of the lung, including the alveolar wall, but may also involve the small airways and blood vessels of the lung parenchyma

Subject: blood vessel inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in a blood vessel

Subject: vascular inflammation
Value: inflammation of any blood and/or lymphatic vessel

Subject: nasal inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the proximal portion of the respiratory passages

Subject: rhinitis
Value: inflammation of the mucous membrane of the nose

Subject: ovary inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the ovary

Subject: pancreas inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the pancreas

Subject: salivary gland inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in one or more salivary glands

Subject: sinus inflammation
Value: increase in susceptibility of the hollow cavities in bone (usually but not exclusively those in the skull) to allergens and/or pathogens

Subject: stomach inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the stomach

Subject: acanthosis
Value: diffuse hyperplasia of the spinous layer of the skin

Subject: testis inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the testis

Subject: decreased inflammatory response
Value: less than expected response to injury, infection, or insult

Subject: abnormal lymphatic vessel morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any component of the network of vessels that carries lymph around the body

Subject: abnormal mammary gland physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the compound, alveolar and apocrine milk-secreting gland that lies within the breast

Subject: abnormal lactation
Value: atypical production of milk from the mammary gland

Subject: increased mammary adenocarcinoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of malignant tumors of the mammary gland

Subject: mammary gland alveolar hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due an increased number of cells of the sac-like structure of the mammary gland that secretes milk after pregnancy

Subject: mammary gland duct hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due an increased number of cells of the tubular structure running from the nipple to the alveoli clusters in the mammary gland

Subject: delayed brain development
Value: the delay or slower progress of the growth and differentiation of the brain

Subject: anencephaly
Value: anomaly that occurs when the anterior neuropore of the neural tube fails to close, resulting in the congenital partial or complete absence of the cranial vault accompanied by absence of overlying tissues, including the brain and cerebral hemispheres, skull and scalp; in affected organisms, the forebrain remains in contact with the amniotic fluid and subsequently degenerates, including the cerebrum (areas responsible for cognition); any remaining brain tissue, such as the brain stem, is often exposed

Subject: hydrocephaly
Value: excessive accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid in the brain, especially the cerebral ventricles, often leading to increased brain size and other brain trauma

Subject: non-obstructive hydrocephaly
Value: abnormal cerebrospinal fluid absorption where there is no obstruction to fluid flow in the ventricular system

Subject: abnormal long term depression
Value: change from the normal, persistent activity-dependent decrease in synaptic efficacy between neurons, often following slow, weak stimulation of neurons

Subject: absent long term depression
Value: lack of the normal, persistent activity-dependent decrease in synaptic efficacy between neurons, often following slow, weak stimulation of CA1 neurons

Subject: impaired synaptic plasticity
Value: decrease or inability of a synapse to change its strength as a result of successive activations

Subject: absence of NMDA-mediated synaptic currents
Value: absence of a measured amplitude, current density or duration of response to stimulation of NMDA receptors

Subject: reduced NMDA-mediated synaptic currents
Value: reduction in the measured amplitude, current density or duration of response to stimulation of NMDA receptors

Subject: abnormal dopamine level
Value: greater or less than the normal amount of this catecholamine neurotransmitter and neurohormone, derived from tyrosine and the precursor to norepinephrine and epinephrine; functions as a neurotransmitter in the brain and as a hormone to inhibit the release of prolactin from the anterior lobe of the pituitary

Subject: increased dopamine level
Value: greater than the normal amount of dopamine, a catecholamine neurotransmitter and neurohormone that is derived from tyrosine and is the precursor to norepinephrine and epinephrine; it functions as a neurotransmitter in the brain and as a hormone to inhibit the release of prolactin from the anterior lobe of the pituitary

Subject: abnormal somatosensory cortex physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the area of the parietal lobe that lies posterior to the central sulcus and is concerned with receiving and processing general sensations from the body surface

Subject: reduced NMDA receptor mediated synaptic activity in barrel cortex
Value: lower than normal levels of excitatory synaptic current in the barrel cortex

Subject: abnormal cerebrospinal fluid production
Value: anomaly in the normal output of the fluid that fills the ventricles and other cavities of the brain and spinal cord

Subject: increased cerebrospinal fluid production
Value: increase in the normal output of the fluid that fills the ventricles and other cavities of the brain and spinal cord

Subject: decreased cerebrospinal fluid production
Value: reduction in the normal output of the fluid that fills the ventricles and other cavities of the brain and spinal cord

Subject: hemorrhage
Value: loss of blood from the vascular compartment to the exterior or into nonvascular body space as a result of rupture or severance of the blood vessels

Subject: intracranial hemorrhage
Value: bleeding within the skull, including hemorrhage into the brain and within the cranial epidural, subdural, and subarachnoid spaces

Subject: intracerebral hemorrhage
Value: bleeding within the cerebrum

Subject: intraventricular hemorrhage
Value: bleeding into the brain ventricles

Subject: abnormal reproductive system physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the organs associated with producing offspring

Subject: reduced fertility
Value: diminished ability to produce live offspring

Subject: reduced male fertility
Value: reduced ability of male to produce live offspring

Subject: reduced female fertility
Value: reduced ability of female to produce live offspring

Subject: infertility
Value: inability to produce live offspring

Subject: male infertility
Value: inability of male to produce live offspring

Subject: female infertility
Value: inability of female to produce live offspring

Subject: abnormal estrous cycle
Value: failure of progression or aberrant timing of the regular female reproductive cycle of non-primate placental mammals that is under hormonal control and includes a period of heat (mating receptivity), followed by ovulation and complex changes in the reproductive tract, followed by reabsorption of the endometrium if pregnancy does not occur

Subject: abnormal ovulation
Value: aberration in the release of an ovum from a rupturing Graafian follicle, normally regulated by a surge in luteinizing hormone

Subject: abnormal gametogenesis
Value: defective formation or differentiation of germ cells

Subject: abnormal meiosis
Value: anomaly in the process of nuclear division that results in gametes with one half the normal number of the original cell

Subject: abnormal oogenesis
Value: atypical formation or failure to form the female germ cells

Subject: abnormal spermiogenesis
Value: anomaly in the process by which a spermatid transforms into a functional spermatozoon

Subject: abnormal litter size
Value: deviation from the normal number of live born pups in a litter

Subject: increased litter size
Value: greater numbers of live born pups in a litter compared to average

Subject: decreased litter size
Value: fewer live born pups in a litter compared to average

Subject: abnormal sexual maturation
Value: a delay or a block in the development of the sexual organs at a given age

Subject: delayed sexual maturation
Value: immaturity of the sexual organs at a given age

Subject: secondary sex reversal
Value: secondary sexual phenotype is not consistent with the chromosomal sex, i.e., internal and/or external genitalia are inconsistent with chromosomal sex

Subject: testis hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, in the testicles

Subject: abnormal lung volume
Value: anomaly in the amount of air that the lungs contain at various points of the respiratory cycle

Subject: abnormal respiration
Value: anomaly in the movement of gases into and out of the lung

Subject: abnormal pancreas morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the organ that secretes pancreatic juice into the duodenum and secretes glucagon and insulin into the bloodstream

Subject: bronchoconstriction
Value: reduction in the caliber of the bronchus or bronchi

Subject: abnormal mucociliary clearance
Value: anomaly in the mechanism that removes mucus and other foreign particles and microorganisms from the lungs by directed ciliary movement and secretory activity of the tracheobronchial submucosal glands

Subject: vesicoureteral reflux
Value: the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder into the ureters and kidneys

Subject: abnormal respiratory sounds
Value: any anomaly in the noises heard over any part of the respiratory tract

Subject: abnormal breathing pattern
Value: irregular or atypical breathing pattern, or absence of breathing

Subject: increased airway responsiveness
Value: more easily provoked into bronchoconstriction in bronchial provocation tests

Subject: respiratory failure
Value: cessation of or failure to commence breathing

Subject: respiratory distress
Value: <physical difficulty or impaired ability to breathe; signs include: shortness of breath, labored breathing, gasping, increased work of breathing, inadequate respiratory effort, and/or irregular breathing>

Subject: hypopnea
Value: breathing that is shallower and/or slower than normal

Subject: apnea
Value: temporary cessation of breathing; sometimes episodic

Subject: emphysema
Value: an abnormal condition of the lung characterized by permanent enlargement of airspaces distal to the terminal bronchioles, accompanied by destruction of their walls and without obvious fibrosis; results in decreased respiratory function including increased air retention and reduced exchange of gases

Subject: abnormal reflex
Value: anomaly in an involuntary response to a peripheral stimulus

Subject: abnormal hearing physiology
Value: any functional anomaly in the ability to perceive auditory stimuli

Subject: deafness
Value: inability to hear; the ability to detect and/or recognize certain frequencies of sound is completely impaired

Subject: abnormal touch/ nociception
Value: change in the ability to sense contact with objects or in the ability to sense pain, most often registered by mechanoreceptors in the skin and mucous membranes

Subject: abnormal pain threshold
Value: increased or decreased average level of perception of pain

Subject: increased thermal nociceptive threshold
Value: a greater than average point at which thermal pain sensation is first detectable

Subject: abnormal chemically-elicited antinociception
Value: change in the analgesic effect of chemical substances

Subject: increased chemically-elicited antinociception
Value: greater than the normal analgesic effect of chemical substances

Subject: decreased chemically-elicited antinociception
Value: less than the normal analgesic effect of chemical substances

Subject: abnormal olfactory system physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the system relating to smell

Subject: abnormal olfaction
Value: anomaly in the ability to smell

Subject: abnormal gustatory system physiology
Value: any functional anomaly in the perception of taste

Subject: abnormal taste sensitivity
Value: changes in the ability to perceive a particular flavor(s) or suggestion of something imparting a flavor by the chemoreceptors of the gustatory system

Subject: alcohol preference
Value: predilection to ingest alcohol over other substances

Subject: cocaine preference
Value: predilection to ingest cocaine over other substances

Subject: abnormal blinking
Value: anomaly in the normal reflex of closing the eyes frequently and rapidly

Subject: increased blinking frequency
Value: greater number of occurrences of the normal reflex of closing the eyes frequently and rapidly

Subject: decreased blinking frequency
Value: reduced number of occurrences of the normal reflex of closing the eyes frequently and rapidly

Subject: photosensitivity
Value: alterations in the response to sunlight or UV irradiation, especially sensitivity of the eyes

Subject: blindness
Value: loss of the sense of sight

Subject: miotic pupils
Value: contraction of the pupils

Subject: neoplasm
Value: the observable morphological and physiological characteristics of  a benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation in a mammalian organism that are manifested through development and lifespan

Subject: increased cellular sensitivity to gamma-irradiation
Value: increased incidence of cell death following exposure to gamma-irradiation

Subject: preneoplasia
Value: state preceding the pathological process resulting in a neoplasm; does not necessarily imply cancerous development

Subject: increased trichofolliculoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of dome-shaped hamartoma tumors which contain multiple abortive and/or misaligned hair follicles

Subject: increased pilomatricoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplasms that arise from hair matrix cells occurring in a specific population in a given time period; pilomatricoma is an encapsulated tumor containing irregularly shaped, lobules of cells separated by fibrovascular connective tissue stroma; two distinct cell populations comprise this tumor, basaloid cells with scant cytoplasm located towards the periphery and the ghost (or shadow) cells occupying the central portion

Subject: increased papilloma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of benign tumors consisting of villous or arborescent outgrowths of fibrovascular stroma covered by neoplastic epithelial cells occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: epithelioid cysts
Value: abnormal membranous sacs appearing in an epithelium

Subject: ovary cysts
Value: the appearance of fluid-filled sacs within the ovary

Subject: increased malignant tumor incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of locally invasive, destructive and metastatic tumors

Subject: abnormal tumor incidence
Value: deviation from the expected number of abnormal growths in a specific population

Subject: increased tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplasms in a specific population in a given time period, usually of a specific type

Subject: increased incidence of induced tumors
Value: higher than normal frequency of tumor incidence induced by a carcinogen, mutagen or virus

Subject: increased B cell derived lymphoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of heterogeneous lymphoid tumors generally expressing one or more B-cell antigens or representing malignant transformations of B-lymphocytes

Subject: increased T cell derived lymphoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of a group of heterogeneous lymphoid tumors representing malignant transformations of T-lymphocytes

Subject: increased leukemia incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of a cancer characterized by progressive proliferation of abnormal leukocytes in hematopoietic tissues, organs and blood

Subject: increased lung adenocarcinoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a malignant neoplasm of epithelial cells in the lung, usually with a glandular organization, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased neurofibrosarcoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a highly aggressive malignant neoplasm arising from the fibrous connective tissue surrounding peripheral nerves, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased adrenal gland tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplams in the adrenal gland occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased sarcoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a connective tissue neoplasm associated with the proliferation of embryonically-derived mesodermal cells, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased malignant triton tumor incidence
