Value: greater than the expected number of a malignant tumor with neurogenic and myogenic differentiation, occurring in a specific population in a given time period; usually arises in tissues of neural crest origin

Subject: increased leiomyosarcoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a malignant tumor derived from smooth (nonstriated) muscle, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased rhabdomyosarcoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a malignant tumor derived from skeletal (striated) muscle, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased fibrohistocytoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of slowly growing skin nodules derived from cellular fibrous tissue occurring in a specific population in a given time period; these often surround capillaries

Subject: increased carcinoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of any of a variety of malignant neoplasms arising from epithelial cells, occurring in a specific population in a given time period; carcinomas are usually glandular or squamous in origin

Subject: increased neuroblastoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a malignant neoplasm characterized by immature nerve cells of embryonic type, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased pituitary adenoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of benign neoplasms of the pituitary, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased colon hamartoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of benign focal malformations in the colon in a specific population in a given time period; results from faulty colonic development, and is composed of an abnormal mixture of tissue elements, or an abnormal proportion of a single element normally present at that site

Subject: increased colon adenoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign epithelial neoplasm with a glandular organization arising in the colon, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased renal cystadenoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign epithelial neoplasm with a glandular organization and a cyst-like appearance arising in the kidney, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased hepatic hemangioma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign tumor characterized by blood-filled spaces lined by benign endothelial cells in the liver, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased lung adenoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign epithelial neoplasm with a glandular organization arising in the lung, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased extremity angiosarcoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of malignant neoplasm of soft tissues; thought to arise from endothelial cells of blood vessels

Subject: increased pheochromocytoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign neoplasm derived from adrenal medullary cells, occurring in a specific population in a given time period; usually associated with hypertension

Subject: increased skin papilloma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a circumscribed, benign epithelial tumor projecting from the surrounding surface, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: decreased tumor incidence
Value: less than the expected number of neoplasms in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: decreased incidence of induced tumors
Value: reduced frequency of tumor incidence induced by a carcinogen, mutagen or virus

Subject: neonatal lethality
Value: <death within the neonatal period after birth (Mus: P0)>

Subject: abnormal seminal vesicle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of either of the paired sac-like glandular structures situated posterolateral to the urinary bladder in the male and functioning as part of the reproductive system; each sac is pyramidal in shape and convoluted in appearance and at the anterior extremity becomes constricted into a narrow straight duct that joins the ipsilateral vas deferens to form the ejaculatory duct; seminal vesicles secrete seminal fluid and nourish and promote the movement of spermatozoa through the urethra

Subject: abnormal skin morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the membranous protective covering of the body

Subject: abnormal aggression-related behavior
Value: domineering, assaultive or forceful physical action

Subject: abnormal associative learning
Value: anomaly in the ability to change the frequency or form of a behavior as a result of the influence of the environment

Subject: abnormal learning/memory/conditioning
Value: altered ability to receive, store, process or recall informational stimuli

Subject: seizures
Value: sudden and often acute manifestation of epileptic attack, sometimes convulsive

Subject: abnormal fear/anxiety-related behavior
Value: altered response in tests for fear or anxiety related behaviors

Subject: abnormal motor capabilities/coordination/movement
Value: altered ability to coordinate voluntary movement or repetitive, compulsive movements

Subject: abnormal sensory capabilities/reflexes/nociception
Value: inability or altered ability to respond to a sensory stimulus

Subject: abnormal parental behavior
Value: altered behavior of animals that affects the ability of offspring to survive

Subject: abnormal consumption behavior
Value: altered ability or inability to eat or drink, or unusual choice or avoidance of foods or drink

Subject: abnormal hair growth
Value: absence or reduced amount of hair or abnormal onset of hair growth cycle or development, or abnormal hair pattern

Subject: abnormal hair texture
Value: irregular or unusual appearance of the structure of the hair

Subject: abnormal coat/hair pigmentation
Value: irregular or unusual pigmentation of the hair

Subject: abnormal glucose homeostasis
Value: anomaly in the processes involved in the maintenance of an internal equilibrium of glucose in the fluids and tissues

Subject: increased circulating insulin level
Value: greater than normal levels of insulin in blood

Subject: prenatal lethality
Value: <death anytime between fertilization and birth (Mus: approximately E18.5)>

Subject: perinatal lethality
Value: <death anytime within the perinatal period (Mus: E18.5 through postnatal day 1)>

Subject: postnatal lethality
Value: <premature death anytime between the neonatal period and weaning age (Mus: P1 to approximately 3 weeks of age)>

Subject: premature death
Value: <death after weaning age, but before the normal life span (Mus: after 3 weeks of age)>

Subject: abnormal developmental patterning
Value: abnormal systematic arrangement of the developing body along an axis

Subject: abnormal embryonic tissue morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the embryonic tissue part of the whole embryo

Subject: abnormal extraembryonic tissue morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the membranes involved with embryonic protection and nutrition

Subject: abnormal embryonic growth/weight/body size
Value: <limited or accelerated growth or development apparent during the embryonic period (sensu Mus: up to E14, or the completion of organogenesis)>

Subject: abnormal postnatal growth/weight/body size
Value: increased or decreased average body size, weight or growth characteristic abnormalities manifesting after birth

Subject: abnormal vision
Value: inability or decreased ability to see

Subject: abnormal eye morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the spheroid organ and optic nerve that serves to detect light

Subject: abnormal skin pigmentation
Value: anomaly in the coloration of the skin due to changes in the amount, shape, or distribution of cells producing pigment

Subject: abnormal vibrissa morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the stiff hairs projecting from the face around the nose of most mammals which act as touch receptors

Subject: abnormal tooth morphology
Value: any anomaly in the size, shape or structure of the hard or soft tissues of the skeletal element within the mouth that is composed of dentine and used to procure or masticate food

Subject: abnormal ear morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the structures involved in the ear or vestibular system

Subject: abnormal muscle physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the muscle, not due to an anatomical defect

Subject: abnormal muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the contractile tissue that produces movement in animals

Subject: abnormal limb morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the projecting paired appendages of an animal trunk, used in particular for movement and grasping; usually denotes the arm and/or legs in mammalian species

Subject: abnormal digit morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the fingers or toes

Subject: abnormal tail morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the flexible elongated appendage located at the caudal end of the torso in many species; it is usually continuous with the vertebral column

Subject: abnormal skeleton development
Value: any anomaly in the formation of bone tissue

Subject: abnormal axial skeleton morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the articulated bones of the cranium and vertebral column

Subject: abnormal limb bone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the limb or autopod bones

Subject: abnormal craniofacial bone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cranial or facial bones

Subject: abnormal lipid homeostasis
Value: anomaly in the processes involved in the maintenance of an internal equilibrium of lipids in the fluids and tissues

Subject: dipsosis
Value: excessive desire to drink, or to drink unusual fluids

Subject: abnormal definitive hematopoiesis
Value: abnormal development of blood cells in the fetal and adult organism; in the fetus cells develop in the aorta, genital ridge and mesonephros region and later in the liver; in adults cells normally develop in the bone marrow and lymphatic tissues

Subject: abnormal cardiovascular system morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the heart or vascular tissue

Subject: abnormal blood circulation
Value: failure or atypical movement in the flow of blood from the heart to the vasculature and back to the heart

Subject: abnormal respiratory system morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of pulmonary tissues

Subject: abnormal respiratory system physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the pulmonary system; inability or reduced ability to intake and exchange oxygen and carbon dioxide with the environment

Subject: abnormal kidney morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of either of the two excretory organs that filter wastes (especially urea) from the blood and excrete them and water in urine

Subject: abnormal kidney physiology
Value: any functional anomaly and/or activity of either of the two excretory organs that filter wastes (especially urea) from the blood and excrete them and water in urine

Subject: abnormal hepatobiliary system morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the tissues of the liver or biliary system

Subject: abnormal hepatobiliary system physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the tissues of the liver or biliary system

Subject: abnormal B cell differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce mature B cells, and/or accumulation of B cell precursors

Subject: abnormal T cell differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce mature T cells, and/or accumulation of T cell precursors

Subject: abnormal hypersensitivity reaction
Value: immune response that results in tissue injury

Subject: abnormal neural tube morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the hollow epithelial tube found on the dorsal side of the vertebrate embryo that develops into the central nervous system (i.e. brain and spinal cord)

Subject: abnormal brain morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the brain, one of the two components of the central nervous system and the center of thought and emotion; controls coordination, bodily activities and the interpretation of information from the senses (sight, hearing, smell, etc.)

Subject: abnormal reproductive system morphology
Value: structural or developmental anomaly of any of the tissues involved in the reproductive system

Subject: abnormal fertility/fecundity
Value: anomaly in the reproductive capability of an organism or population to produce live offspring

Subject: abnormal gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of an organ that functions as a secretory or excretory organ

Subject: abnormal gland physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of an organ that functions as a secretory or excretory organ

Subject: altered tumor susceptibility
Value: greater than or less than the average number of tumors, usually a specific type, arising in a given organism when compared to controls

Subject: obsolete other aberrant phenotype
Value: anomaly or dysmorphology not attributable to any other category

Subject: no abnormal phenotype detected
Value: normal viability, fertility, appearance and behavior; reported phenotype is indistinguishable from controls

Subject: abnormal gastrulation movements
Value: failure of embryonic cells to migrate, or migrate to the appropriate target during the development and invagination of the primary germ layers

Subject: decreased brain weight
Value: lower than average weight of the brain

Subject: increased brain weight
Value: greater than average weight of the brain

Subject: abnormal outer ear morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any components of the auricles or external acoustic meatus

Subject: abnormal astrocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the large neuroglial (macroglial) cells in the central nervous system - the largest and most numerous neuroglial cells in the brain and spinal cord; astrocytes are irregularly shaped with many long processes, including those with 'end feet' which form the glial (limiting) membrane and directly and indirectly contribute to the blood-brain barrier; astrocytes regulate the extracellular ionic and chemical environment, and 'reactive astrocytes' (along with microglia) respond to injury

Subject: gliosis
Value: increased growth pattern of neuroglia in a damaged area of the brain or spinal cord

Subject: abnormal innervation
Value: the malformation, misprojection, abnormal fasciculation or abnormal refinement of the connection, of nerve fibers to a target

Subject: abnormal fibula morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the lateral and smaller bone of the lower limb

Subject: small heart
Value: reduced size of the heart relative to average

Subject: abnormal myocardial trabeculae morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the supporting bundles of muscular fibers lining the walls of the heart

Subject: disorganized myocardium
Value: derangement of the patterned architecture of the myocardium

Subject: abnormal artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the blood vessels that carry blood away from the heart

Subject: hydrops fetalis
Value: an abnormal accumulation of serous fluid in fetal tissues

Subject: minimal clonic seizures
Value: seizures involving rhythmic face and forelimb clonus including arm movement, and it may include rearing and falling and ventral flexion of the neck; a seizure is scored as minimal when it satisfies the minimal criteria up to or including ventral flexion, but does not include maximal tonic hindlimb extension

Subject: maximal tonic hindlimb extension seizures
Value: seizures induced by electrical stimulation of the brainstem; manifesting as a tonic-clonic flexion/extension sequence, starting in tonic extension of the forelimbs and terminating in a full tonic hindlimb extension, which is defined when the angle of the hindlimbs to the torso exceeds 90 degrees (although it is usually 180 degrees)

Subject: psychomotor seizures
Value: low frequency, tetanic stimulation used to evoke partial limbic seizures, with currents ranging from 8 mA to 20 mA, depending on the strain and gender; manifesting as rhythmic face movements and extensive forelimb clonus (e.g. shadow-boxing forelimb movements), dorsal flexion of the neck, rearing and falling, and/or transient wobbliness/ataxia; seizure lasts only 10-15 seconds and when antiepileptic drugs are present may last only a few seconds

Subject: absent corpus callosum
Value: absence of the commissural plate interconnecting the cortical hemispheres of the brain

Subject: abnormal brain commissure morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the nerve fiber tracts that span the longitudinal fissure between the cerebral and/or cerebellar hemispheres of the brain

Subject: abnormal brain ventricular system morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the brain ventricles, their associated choroid plexuses or the intercommunicating channels that connect the ventricular system

Subject: abnormal neurotransmitter level
Value: anomaly in the amount of endogenous signaling molecules into a synaptic cleft; neurotransmitters are released on excitation from the axon terminal of a presynaptic neuron of the central or peripheral nervous system and travel across the synaptic cleft to either excite or inhibit the target cell

Subject: abnormal CNS synaptic transmission
Value: defect in the communication from a neuron to a target across a synapse in the central nervous system

Subject: abnormal long term potentiation
Value: alterations in a persistent robust synaptic response induced by synchronous stimulation of pre- and postsynaptic cells

Subject: abnormal germ cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the germ cell, that is, any of the reproductive (generative) cells of a multicellular organism, whether they are undifferentiated or fully differentiated

Subject: decreased germ cell number
Value: reduced numbers of any of the reproductive (generative) cells of a multicellular organism, whether they are undifferentiated or fully differentiated

Subject: abnormal sex determination
Value: anomaly of primary or secondary sexual development or characteristics

Subject: abnormal primary sex determination
Value: aberrant gonadal development resulting in either abnormal or absent gonads or the development of gonads inconsistent with the chromosomal sex

Subject: abnormal secondary sex determination
Value: gonadal development may or may not be normal, and the phenotype of the animal outside the gonad does not match chromosomal sex or is ambiguous

Subject: true hermaphroditism
Value: the presence of both unequivocal ovarian tissue and testicular elements in the same individual regardless of karyotype; these two tissue types may be present in the same gonad (ovotestis) or may be present as separate ovaries and testis tissue elements in the same individual regardless of sex chromosome complement

Subject: streak gonad
Value: impairment of genital ridge development; aplasia of gonadal tissue which is sometimes replaced with functionless tissue

Subject: abnormal seminiferous tubule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tubules in the testes where spermatogenesis occurs

Subject: small lymph nodes
Value: lymph nodes of decreased size

Subject: increased lymph node number
Value: greater than the normal number of lymph nodes

Subject: decreased lymph node number
Value: fewer than the normal number of lymph nodes

Subject: large lymphoid organs
Value: increased size of lymphatic tissues

Subject: abnormal lymph organ size
Value: change in the normal size of lymphatic tissues

Subject: lymphoid hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced cell number, in lymphatic tissue

Subject: abnormal spleen size
Value: deviation from the normal spleen size

Subject: abnormal spleen capsule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the connective tissue that surrounds the spleen

Subject: abnormal spleen trabecular vein morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of one of the veins that feed the splenic vein

Subject: neurodegeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of neural tissue

Subject: abnormal primitive streak formation
Value: anomaly in the establishment of the midline ridge of embryonic epiblast that later develops into mesoderm and endoderm

Subject: abnormal primitive streak morphology
Value: anomaly in the midline ridge of the embryonic epiblast that later develops into mesoderm and endoderm

Subject: abnormal nose morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the organ that is specialized for smell and is part of the respiratory system

Subject: abnormal pharynx morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the passage between the mouth and the posterior nares and the larynx and esophagus

Subject: abnormal external nares morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anterior opening to the nasal cavity

Subject: abnormal internal nares morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the portion of the opening of the nasal cavity into the nasal pharynx

Subject: abnormal nasal cavity morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cavity of the respiratory tract that extends from the nares to the pharynx; the nasal cavity is lined with ciliated mucosa

Subject: abnormal nasal mucosa morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the mucous membrane that lines the nasal cavity

Subject: abnormal nasal septum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the dividing wall that runs down the midline of the nose separating the two nasal cavities, each of which ends in a nostril; it is formed by the septal nasal cartilage, parts of skull bones (ethmoid bone; vomer), and membranous parts

Subject: abnormal paranasal sinus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the paired air-filled cavities surrounded by the bones of the face that are lined by mucous membranes and are continuous with the nasal cavity

Subject: abnormal laryngeal mucosa goblet cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the epithelial cells lining the larynx, which produce mucins

Subject: abnormal olfactory mucosa morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the portion of the nasal mucosa that contains the olfactory sensory endings

Subject: abnormal vomeronasal organ morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tubular, crescent-sensory organ with a luminal epithelium that contains chemosensitive receptor cells with microvilli that are thought to detect pheromones and transmit signals to the remainder of the accessory olfactory system; the organ lies at the base the nasal cavity and is split into two, separated by the nasal septum

Subject: abnormal turbinate morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small curved bones that extends horizontally along the lateral wall of the nasal passage

Subject: abnormal ethmoid sinus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the evaginations of the mucous membrane of the nasal cavity into the ethmoidal bony labyrinth, forming multiple small paranasal sinuses

Subject: abnormal frontal sinus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the paired evaginations of the mucous membrane of the nasal cavity into the lower part of the squama of the frontal bones

Subject: abnormal maxillary sinus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the largest of the paranasal sinuses, a paired pyramid-shaped air sinus located within the maxillary bone which drains via the maxillary ostium into the infundibulum, then through the hiatus semilunaris into the middle meatus of the nose

Subject: abnormal sphenoid sinus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the most posterior paranasal sinus located in the sphenoid bone near the optic nerve and the pituitary gland on the side of the skull; it drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess superior to the superior concha; the sinus is divided into right and left parts by a bony septum

Subject: abnormal larynx morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the organ of voice production located between the pharynx and the trachea

Subject: abnormal hypopharynx morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the portion of the pharynx that lies below the upper edge of the epiglottis and opens into the larynx and the esophagus

Subject: abnormal nasopharynx morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the section of the pharynx that lies above the soft palate

Subject: abnormal oropharynx morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the portion of the pharynx that lies between the soft palate and the upper edge of the epiglottis

Subject: abnormal pharyngeal muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the muscles of the pharynx, the inferior, middle and superior constrictors, salpingopharyngeus, and stylopharyngeus

Subject: reproductive system inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in any of the reproductive organs

Subject: abnormal glottis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the vocal apparatus of the larynx, which includes the vocal cords and the opening between them

Subject: abnormal laryngeal cartilage morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cartilaginous structures that support the larynx

Subject: abnormal arytenoid cartilage morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the paired triangular cartilages located postlaterally at the level of the thyroid cartilage

Subject: abnormal cricoid cartilage morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the most inferior of the laryngeal cartilages

Subject: abnormal thyroid cartilage morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the largest of the laryngeal cartilages

Subject: abnormal laryngeal mucosa morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the mucous lining of the larynx, which is composed of squamous epithelium in the upper larynx and ciliated columnar epithelium in the lower larynx

Subject: abnormal nasal mucosa goblet cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cells lining the nasal epithelium that produce and secrete mucins

Subject: abnormal laryngeal muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the muscles associated with the larynx

Subject: abnormal bronchus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the upper conducting airways of the lung; these airways arise from the terminus of the trachea

Subject: abnormal left major bronchus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the conducting airway leading to the left lobe of the lungs

Subject: abnormal right major bronchus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the conducting airway leading to the right lobe of the lungs

Subject: abnormal bronchiole morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the conducting airway of the lungs found terminal to the bronchi; these structures contain neither cartilage nor mucous-secreting glands; the epithelium of the bronchioles becomes thinner with each branching

Subject: abnormal terminal bronchiole morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the last conducting structure of non-respiratory bronchioles; after this point, the airways have alveoli in their walls

Subject: muscular atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of muscle tissue associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes; occurs with age, immobilization, weightlessness, malnutrition or denervation

Subject: abnormal pulmonary alveolus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small sac-like dilations of the distal airspace of the lung; they are present along the walls of the alveolar sacs, alveolar ducts and terminal bronchioles; gas exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide between alveolar air and blood in the pulmonary capillaries takes place across the cell walls

Subject: abnormal pulmonary alveolar duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the respiratory conducting tubes distal to the respiratory bronchiole that lead to the alveolar sacs and the alveoli

Subject: abnormal nervous system electrophysiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the nervous system as it relates to conduction of electrical impulses

Subject: abnormal pulmonary alveolus epithelial cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cells lining the alveoli

Subject: abnormal type I pneumocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the flattened, branched squamous cells that covers more than 98 percent of the alveolar surface, and have thin (50-100 nm) cytoplasmic extensions to form the air-blood barrier essential for normal gas exchange

Subject: abnormal type II pneumocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the granular and roughly cuboidal cells typically found at the alveolar-septal junction that modulate the fluid surrounding the alveolar epithelium by secreting and recycling surfactants, and also contribute to tissue repair and can differentiate after injury into a type I pneumocyte; type II cells cover a much smaller surface area than type I cells (less than 5 percent), but are much more numerous and contain lamellar bodies on the apical surface where surfactant is stored

Subject: abnormal lung interstitium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the connective tissue located between the respiratory (airway and alveolar) epithelium, the capillary endothelium and pleural mesothelium; it contains basement membrane composed of collagen, elastin, proteoglycans, and fibronectin; it functions in the mechanical behavior of the lung, and forms a barrier to regulate the flow of plasma constituents from the capillaries to the airway and alveolar spaces

Subject: abnormal respiratory mucosa morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the mucous membrane lining the respiratory tract

Subject: abnormal diaphragm morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thin musculomebranous barrier that separates the abdominal and thoracic cavities; these muscles often used for breathing control

Subject: abnormal intercostal muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the respiratory muscles that arise from the lower border of one rib and insert into the upper border of the adjoining rib

Subject: abnormal respiratory mucosa goblet cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cells of the respiratory epithelial lining that produce and secrete mucins

Subject: abnormal trachea morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tube descending from the larynx and branching into the right and left main bronchi

Subject: abnormal tracheal smooth muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the smooth muscle lining the trachea

Subject: abnormal tracheal ciliated epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the epithelial lining of the trachea which contains numerous ciliated cells

Subject: cryptorchism
Value: failure of one or both of the testes to descend into the scrotum around the time of birth

Subject: abnormal gestational length
Value: anomaly in the usual duration of time between when a fertilized egg implants in the wall of the uterus and the birth of offspring

Subject: long gestation period
Value: increase in the average duration of a pregnancy

Subject: short gestation period
Value: decrease in the average duration of a pregnancy

Subject: abnormal pulmonary circulation
Value: any anomaly in the circulation of blood through the lungs

Subject: aspiration
Value: inspiration into the airways of fluid or any foreign material

Subject: abnormal forced expiratory flow rates
Value: anomaly in the rates of airflow during forced vital capacity determination

Subject: abnormal total lung capacity
Value: anomaly in the volume of air contained in the lungs at the end of maximal inspiration

Subject: abnormal functional residual capacity
Value: anomaly in the volume of air remaining in the lungs at the end of a normal expiration

Subject: abnormal residual volume
Value: anomaly in the volume of air remaining in the lungs at the end of maximal expiration

Subject: abnormal vital capacity
Value: anomaly in the amount of air that is exhaled by a maximal expiration following a maximal inspiration

Subject: decreased susceptibility to hepatic steatosis
Value: less likely than normal to develop hepatic steatosis

Subject: abnormal inspiratory capacity
Value: anomaly in the maximal volume of air that can be inspired after the end of a normal expiration

Subject: abnormal inspiratory reserve volume
Value: anomaly in the extra volume of air that can be inspired with maximal effort after reaching the end of a normal inspiration

Subject: abnormal tidal volume
Value: anomaly in the volume of air inspired or expired during each normal respiratory cycle

Subject: abnormal respiratory mechanics
Value: anomaly in the action of the lungs, diaphragm, ribs and chest wall during respiration

Subject: anoxia
Value: absence or almost complete absence of oxygen from inspired gases, in blood or tissues

Subject: hypercapnia
Value: elevated concentration of CO2 in the blood, alveoli or other tissues resulting in the increased pressure of this component of body gases

Subject: hyperoxia
Value: elevated concentration of O2 in the blood, alveoli or other tissues resulting in the increased pressure of this component of body gases

Subject: hyperventilation
Value: a state in which there is a increased amount of air entering the pulmonary alveoli (increased alveolar ventilation), which causes an decrease in arterial carbon dioxide level

Subject: hypoventilation
Value: a state in which there is a reduced amount of air entering the pulmonary alveoli (decreased alveolar ventilation), which causes an increase in arterial carbon dioxide level

Subject: abnormal respiratory transport
Value: anomaly in the process of gas exchange

Subject: decreased susceptibility to hyperlipidemia
Value: less likely than normal to develop abnormally high levels of circulating lipids

Subject: abnormal alveolocapillary membrane morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the membrane between the capillary blood and alveolar air, comprised of the alveolar epithelium and the capillary epithelium and their adherent basement membranes and epithelial cell cytoplasm

Subject: abnormal pulmonary diffusing capacity
Value: anomaly in the amount of gas taken up by pulmonary capillary blood per minute per unit of average oxygen pressure gradient between alveolar gas and pulmonary capillary blood

Subject: abnormal ventilation-perfusion ratio
Value: anomaly in the ratio of alveolar ventilation to simultaneous capillary blood flow in the lung

Subject: abnormal respiratory function
Value: anomaly in any measure of the processes involved in respiration

Subject: abnormal airway resistance
Value: anomaly in the opposition to flow of air caused by the forces of friction, measured as the ratio of driving pressure to the rate of air flow

Subject: abnormal blood gas level
Value: anomaly in the amount of oxygen and carbon dioxide in the blood

Subject: abnormal bronchial provocation
Value: anomaly in the results of measures of responsiveness to allergens, pharmacological solutions, or control solutions

Subject: abnormal exercise endurance
Value: improved or impaired performance during controlled physical activity

Subject: abnormal lung compliance
Value: anomaly in the ability of the lung to distend in response to pressure without disruption, usually expressed as the unit volume of change in the lung per unit of pressure

Subject: abnormal airway responsiveness
Value: anomalous response in bronchial provocation tests

Subject: decreased airway responsiveness
Value: less easily provoked into bronchoconstriction during bronchial provocation testing

Subject: abnormal pulmonary gas exchange
Value: anomaly in the exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide between the alveolar air and pulmonary capillary blood

Subject: abnormal whole-body plethysmography
Value: anomaly in the measurements gathered in a chamber that encloses the body and in which changes in volume are recorded

Subject: abnormal pulmonary ventilation
Value: anomaly of the respiratory minute volume, or the total volume of gas per minute inspired or expired expressed in liters per minute; refers to the exchange of air between the total respiratory space and the environment

Subject: abnormal lymph node morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the oval or bean shaped bodies located along the lymphatic system that consist of densely packed lymphocytes, lymph fluid and connective tissue, and is the site where acquired immune responses are launched

Subject: abnormal axillary lymph node morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the lymph nodes located around the axillary vein that receive lymphatic drainage from the upper or forelimb, scapular region and pectoral region

Subject: abnormal lymph node trabecula morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the membranous processes on the internal surface of the lymph node capsule, consisting of connective tissue and muscle fibers

Subject: abnormal lymph node cortex morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the outer area of the lymph node that has B and T cell domains

Subject: abnormal lymph node B cell domain morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the part of the lymph node cortex in which B lymphocytes home to primary follicles to survey follicular dendritic cells (FDCs); antigen stimulated B cells proliferate and differentiate within the follicles forming distinctive germinal centers

Subject: abnormal lymph node primary follicle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of an unstimulated network of follicular dendritic cells and small resting B cells in the lymph node cortex

Subject: abnormal lymph node secondary follicle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a lymph node primary follicle that has undergone antigenic challenge and is characterized by a ring of concentrically packed B lymphocytes surrounding a germinal center, which contains proliferating B cells, and a mantle area that contains nondividing B cells and some helper T cells with macrophages and follicular dendritic cells interspersed

Subject: abnormal lymph node T cell domain morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the paracortex and interfollicular cortex of the lymph node in which T lymphocytes home to survey dendritic cells; T lymphocytes proliferate in the paracortex and enlarge it but do not produce structures analogous to germinal centers

Subject: abnormal lymph node medulla morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the area of the lymph node through which lymph leaves the node; it contains macrophages and antibody-secreting plasma cells

Subject: abnormal afferent lymphatic vessel morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the lymphatic tubes entering the lymph node

Subject: abnormal efferent lymphatic vessel morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the lymphatic tube exiting the lymph node

Subject: abnormal cervical lymph node morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the lymph nodes found near the neck and shoulders

Subject: abnormal popliteal lymph node morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the lymph nodes which drain the legs

Subject: abnormal inguinal lymph node morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the lymph nodes located in the groin area

Subject: abnormal spleen trabecular artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of one of the branches of the splenic artery

Subject: abnormal spleen red pulp morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the parenchymatous tissue network of the spleen that consists of loose plates or cords (sinuses) infiltrated with red blood cells where most of the blood filtration occurs and degenerate erythrocytes are removed from the circulation

Subject: abnormal spleen white pulp morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the parenchymatous tissue of the spleen that surrounds splenic blood vessels, consists of compact masses of lymphatic cells and is where foreign material removed from the blood is used to initiate an immune reaction that results in the production of antibodies

Subject: abnormal spleen periarteriolar lymphoid sheath morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the area of the spleen in which T cells surround the central arteriole

Subject: abnormal spleen germinal center morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the area of the spleen secondary B follicle where rapid B-cell proliferation, somatic hypermutation, and selection for antigen binding occurs

Subject: abnormal spleen B cell corona morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the area of the spleen secondary B follicle that surrounds the germinal center and harbors the small recirculating B lymphocytes

Subject: abnormal spleen central arteriole morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the blood vessel surrounded by the periarteriolar lymphoid sheath that connects the trabecular artery to the trabecular vein

Subject: abnormal spleen marginal zone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the zone between the red and white pulp of the spleen containing numerous macrophages and lymphocytes, and a rich plexus of sinusoids supplied by white pulp arterioles carrying blood-borne antigens

Subject: abnormal spleen marginal sinus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the border region surrounding the spleen B cell follicles and the periarteriolar lymphoid sheath (PALS) that separates it from the marginal zone that mediates lymphocyte entry into the white pulp from the blood

Subject: abnormal thymus size
Value: deviation from the normal size of the thymus

Subject: abnormal thymus lobule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the basic structural unit of the thymus

Subject: abnormal thymus capsule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the fibrous connective tissue surrounding the thymus

Subject: abnormal thymus subcapsular epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the epithelial cells lining the capsule and trabeculae of the thymus

Subject: abnormal thymus trabecula morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thymic connective tissue which extends into the parenchyma

Subject: abnormal thymus cortex morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the outer part of a thymus lobule that surrounds the medulla and is composed of closely packed lymphocytes

Subject: abnormal thymus medulla morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the inner area of thymus lobules

Subject: abnormal dendritic cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the immunocompetent cells of the lymphoid and hemopoietic systems and skin, which function to process antigens and present them to T cells, thus stimulating cellular immunity

Subject: abnormal mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the regional immune system associated with the mucosa

Subject: abnormal gut-associated lymphoid tissue morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the regional immune system located in the gut

Subject: abnormal oropharyngeal lymphoid tissue morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the circular lymphoid tissue formed by the lingual, pharyngeal, and facial tonsils

Subject: abnormal palatine tonsil morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of either of the two small almond-shaped masses of lymph tissue found on either side of the oropharynx

Subject: abnormal nasopharyngeal tonsil morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the lymph tissue in the roof and posterior wall of the nasopharynx

Subject: abnormal lingual tonsillar tissue morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the lymph tissue on the floor of the oropharyngeal passage, near the root of the tongue

Subject: abnormal tubal tonsil morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the lymph tissue associated with the pharyngeal opening of the auditory tube

Subject: abnormal Peyer's patch epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the specialized epithelium of the Peyer's patch

Subject: abnormal Peyer's patch follicle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the area of the Peyer's patch normally occupied by B cells

Subject: abnormal Peyer's patch germinal center morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the area of the Peyer's patch where B cells proliferate and differentiate into plasma cells

Subject: abnormal Peyer's patch T cell area morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the Peyer's patch area normally occupied by T lymphocytes

Subject: abnormal bronchus-associated lymphoid tissue morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the regional immune system located near the bronchus

Subject: abnormal hematopoietic system morphology/development
Value: any structural or developmental anomaly of the blood cells or the organs associated with the development and formation of blood cells

Subject: abnormal bone marrow morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the soft tissue that fills the cavities of bones

Subject: abnormal bone marrow cell morphology/development
Value: any structural anomaly of the cells found in the bone marrow

Subject: abnormal pluripotent precursor cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cells that give rise to most types of cells necessary for fetal development

Subject: abnormal multipotent stem cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the specialized cells that are committed to giving rise to cells with particular functions

Subject: abnormal lymphopoiesis
Value: atypical formation of lymphocytes and plasma cells from lymphoid stem cells which develop from the pluripotent hematopoietic stem cells in the bone marrow; lymphoid stem cells differentiate into T-lymphocytes; B-lymphocytes; plasma cells; or NK-cells (natural killer cells), depending on the organ or tissues to which they migrate

Subject: abnormal pre-B cell morphology
Value: <any structural anomaly of the cells in the B lymphocyte lineage that have undergone VDJ rearrangement of the immunoglobulin heavy chain and are in the process of V-J rearrangement of the light chain: these cells express mu heavy chain on the cell surface>

Subject: increased intestinal adenoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign epithelial neoplasm with a glandular organization arising in the small and/or large intestine, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: respiratory system inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the respiratory system

Subject: increased susceptibility to infection
Value: greater likelihood that an organism will develop ill effects from a pathogenic invasion or from components of or toxins produced by pathogens

Subject: abnormal double-negative T cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the subset of T cells found in the thymus that express neither CD4 nor CD8

Subject: abnormal double-positive T cell morphology
Value: any anomaly of the subset of T cells found in the thymus that express both CD4 and CD8

Subject: decreased susceptibility to infection
Value: reduced likelihood that an organism will develop ill effects from a pathogenic invasion or from components of or toxins produced by pathogens

Subject: decreased susceptibility to viral infection
Value: reduced likelihood that an organism will develop ill effects from a viral infection or from components of or toxins produced by a virus

Subject: decreased susceptibility to bacterial infection
Value: reduced likelihood that an organism will develop ill effects from a bacterial infection or from components of or toxins produced by bacteria

Subject: increased susceptibility to bacterial infection
Value: greater likelihood that an organism will develop ill effects from a bacterial infection or from components of or toxins produced by bacteria

Subject: abnormal megakaryocyte progenitor cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the progenitor cells of the thrombocytic (platelet) line of cells

Subject: abnormal myeloblast morphology/development
Value: any structural anomaly of the cells found in the bone marrow that give rise to the granulocyte line of blood cells

Subject: abnormal neutrophil differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce the granular leukocytes that have a three- to five-lobed nucleus and a cytoplasm that contains inconspicuous granules stainable by neutral dyes

Subject: abnormal proerythroblast morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the immature, nucleated erythrocyte precursors that give rise to reticulocytes and are derived from erythroid progenitor cells

Subject: abnormal megakaryocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the giant 50 to 100 micron diameter cells with greatly lobulated nuclei found in the bone marrow; mature blood platelets are released from their cytoplasm

Subject: increased susceptibility to viral infection
Value: greater likelihood that an organism will develop ill effects from a viral infection or from components of or toxins produced by a virus

Subject: abnormal innate immunity
Value: anomaly in the function of the early phase of the response to infection; normally, it is present at all times, does not increase with exposure to specific pathogens, and does not discriminate between pathogens

Subject: abnormal adaptive immunity
Value: anomaly in the function of the response of antigen-specific lymphocytes to antigen, including the development of immunological memory

Subject: abnormal cell-mediated immunity
Value: abnormal function of any adaptive immune response in which T cells play a main role

Subject: abnormal basophil morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the immature or mature forms of a granular leukocyte that in its mature form has an irregularly shaped, pale-staining nucleus that is partially constricted into two lobes, and with cytoplasm that contains coarse, bluish-black granules of variable size; these cells contain vasoactive amines such as histamine and serotonin, which are released on appropriate stimulation

Subject: abnormal mast cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the granulated cells found in most tissues and which contain large amounts of histamine and heparin in granules

Subject: abnormal reticulocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of immature erythrocytes characterized by a meshlike pattern of threads and particles at the former site of the nucleus

Subject: altered susceptibility to autoimmune disorder
Value: a change in the likelihood that an organism will develop disease characterized by production of antibodies that react with host tissues or immune effector cells that are autoreactive to endogenous peptides

Subject: disproportionate dwarf
Value: abnormally undersized with disproportionate body parts; usually with more significant shortening of the limbs in proportion to the trunk size

Subject: abnormal semicircular canal morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the organ of balance composed of three long bony tubes of the labyrinth

Subject: abnormal blood cell morphology/development
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the cells found in the blood or hematopoietic organ

Subject: abnormal CD4-positive, alpha beta T cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the subset of T lymphocytes that carry the CD4 marker, recognize intravesicular peptides bound to MHC class-II molecules, and turn on antibody production

Subject: abnormal T-helper 1 cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the type of T-helper cell whose cytokine production favors cellular immune responses and delayed type hypersensitivity

Subject: abnormal T-helper 2 cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the type of T-helper cell whose cytokine production promotes defense against extracellular parasites and humoral immune responses typical of allergy

Subject: abnormal effector T cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a differentiated T cell with ability to traffic to peripheral tissues and is capable of mounting a specific immune response

Subject: abnormal CD8-positive, alpha-beta cytotoxic T cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cell capable of killing target cells in an antigen specific manner

Subject: abnormal plasma cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a terminally differentiated, post-mitotic, short-lived cell of the B cell lineage devoted to producing large amounts of immunoglobulin

Subject: abnormal memory B cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a distinctly differentiated long-lived B cell that is readily activated upon reencounter of its antigenic determinant; memory B cells differentiate from antigen-activated B cells which have been selected for expression of higher affinity immunoglobulin

Subject: abnormal granulocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of leukocytes that have abundant granules in the cytoplasm, including basophils, neutrophils, and eosinophils

Subject: abnormal leukocyte physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of any of the white blood cells (basophils, eosinophils, neutrophils, lymphocytes, or monocytes)

Subject: abnormal eosinophil differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce the immature or mature forms of a granular leukocyte with a nucleus that usually has two lobes connected by one or more slender threads of chromatin, and cytoplasm containing coarse, round granules that are uniform in size and which can be stained by the dye eosin and is involved in clearance of parasitic infections and in allergic reactions

Subject: abnormal T cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of lymphocytes that are responsible for cell-mediated immunity and immune system regulation

Subject: abnormal mononuclear cell differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce a leukocyte with a single non-segmented nucleus in the mature form

Subject: abnormal macrophage morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the large mononuclear phagocytes which differentiate from monocytes, are typically resident in a particular tissue, and capable of phagocytosing a variety of extracellular particulate material, including immune complexes, microorganisms, and dead cells

Subject: abnormal erythrocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a mature red blood cell, an ennucleate biconcave disk about 7 micrometers in diameter that contains hemoglobin confined within a lipid membrane; it is the major cellular element of the circulating blood and transports oxygen as its principal function

Subject: abnormal lymph organ development
Value: anomaly in the process of morphological maturation of the organs of the lymph system

Subject: abnormal macrophage physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the large mononuclear phagocytes which differentiate from monocytes, are typically resident in a particular tissue, and capable of phagocytosing a variety of extracellular particulate material, including immune complexes, microorganisms, and dead cells

Subject: abnormal professional antigen presenting cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of a cell capable of processing and presenting lipid and protein antigens to T cells in order to initiate an immune response

Subject: abnormal B lymphocyte antigen presentation
Value: anomaly in the ability of B lymphocyte to process and/or present antigen

Subject: abnormal macrophage antigen presentation
Value: anomaly in the ability of macrophage phagocytic cells to process and present antigen to T lymphocytes

Subject: abnormal dendritic cell antigen presentation
Value: anomaly in the ability of dendritic cells to process and present antigen to T lymphocytes

Subject: abnormal Langerhans cell antigen presentation
Value: anomaly in the ability of phagocytic cells of the epidermis to display antigen for recognition by T lymphocytes

Subject: abnormal B cell number
Value: deviation from the normal count of cells that are formed in the bone marrow, migrate to the peripheral lymphatic system, and mature into plasma cells or memory cells; these cells are involved in humoral immunity

Subject: abnormal B cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of lymphocytes that expresses membrane-bound antibody, and differentiate into antibody-secreting plasma cells and memory cells upon interaction with antigen; B cells are the primary lymphocyte responsible for humoral immunity, and are most effective against extracellular pathogens

Subject: decreased immunoglobulin level
Value: less than normal immunoglobulin level

Subject: increased immunoglobulin level
Value: greater than normal immunoglobulin level

Subject: abnormal granulocyte physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of neutrophils, eosinophils, or basophils

Subject: abnormal neutrophil physiology
Value: abnormal function of the immature or mature forms of a granular leukocyte that in its mature form has a nucleus with three to five lobes connected by slender threads of chromatin, and cytoplasm containing fine inconspicuous granules and stainable by neutral dyes

Subject: abnormal basophil physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the leukocyte that contains granules that stain with basic dyes

Subject: abnormal eosinophil physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the immature or mature forms of a granular leukocyte with a nucleus that usually has two lobes connected by one or more slender threads of chromatin, and cytoplasm containing coarse, round granules that are uniform in size and which can be stained by the dye eosin and is involved in clearance of parasitic infections and in allergic reactions

Subject: impaired neutrophil phagocytosis
Value: reduced ability of neutrophils to internalize particulate matter

Subject: abnormal complement pathway
Value: impaired ability of the complement proteins to act sequentially to directly kill microbes, dispose of immune complexes, and regulate other immune processes

Subject: impaired complement alternative pathway
Value: abnormal function of the plasma protein cascade triggered by direct contact with pathogen surfaces

Subject: impaired complement classical pathway
Value: <abnormal function of the plasma protein cascade triggered by antigen:antibody complexes>

Subject: abnormal immunoglobulin level
Value: deviation from the normal levels of glycoproteins present in the blood and other tissue, often functioning as antibodies

Subject: decreased IgD level
Value: less than normal immunoglobulin class D level

Subject: decreased IgE level
Value: less than normal immunoglobulin class E level

Subject: increased IgG level
Value: greater than normal immunoglobulin class G level

Subject: increased IgM level
Value: greater than normal immunoglobulin class M level

Subject: increased IgA level
Value: greater than normal immunoglobulin class A level

Subject: increased IgD level
Value: greater than normal immunoglobulin class D level

Subject: increased IgE level
Value: greater than normal immunoglobulin class E level

Subject: abnormal acute inflammation
Value: aberrant early and often transient reaction of the microcirculation, characterized by movement of fluid and leukocytes from the blood into extravascular tissues; initiated by injury, infection, or local immune response

Subject: chronic inflammation
Value: persistent inflammatory response, often caused by persistent infection or during an autoimmune response

Subject: granulomatous inflammation
Value: chronic inflammation resulting from the failure of the acute inflammatory response and persistence of the injurious agent; characterized by a central area of macrophages, often fused into giant cells, and surrounded by T cells

Subject: abnormal histamine physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of this amine that is involved in local immune response, in regulating physiological function in the gut, and that acts as a neurotransmitter

Subject: abnormal type I hypersensitivity reaction
Value: anomaly in a reaction manifested by localized or generalized reaction that occurs immediately (minutes) after exposure to an antigen to which the person/animal was previously sensitized; it is IgE-mediated, and mast cell activation and degranulation are hallmarks

Subject: abnormal type II hypersensitivity reaction
Value: anomaly in the response caused by an Ag-Ab reaction; antibodies are directly or indirectly cytotoxic to antigens on cell surfaces or in connective tissues; most often involves IgG and IgM; complement activation is usually involved

Subject: abnormal type III hypersensitivity reaction
Value: anomaly in the tissue injury mediated by immune complexes; generally involves immune complexes formed in the blood via Abs encountering circulating Ag-Ab complexes then deposit in tissues (especially blood vessels and glomeruli), induce complement activation, and result in tissue injury

Subject: abnormal type IV hypersensitivity reaction
Value: anomaly in an antigen-elicited cellular immune reaction that results in tissue damage, but does not require Ab participation; the response is seen at the area of contact

Subject: brachyphalangia
Value: abnormally short phalanges

Subject: brachydactyly
Value: abnormally short digits

Subject: mydriasis
Value: increased diameter of one or both central circular aperture of the iris through which light rays enter the eye

Subject: abnormal blood coagulation
Value: altered ability or inability of the blood to clot

Subject: preference for addictive substance
Value: strong predilection for an addictive substance

Subject: aversion to addictive substance
Value: purposeful avoidance of an addictive substance due to dislike

Subject: addiction
Value: strong dependence on an addictive compound such as alcohol or narcotics that results in uncontrollable cravings for such compounds

Subject: abnormal cocaine consumption
Value: aberrant behavioral-related or physiological-related intake of cocaine into the body

Subject: abnormal social/conspecific interaction
Value: deviation of the normal behavior of animals towards each other

Subject: obsolete abnormal circadian period
Value: any change in the cycle length expressed when exposed to constant conditions without temporal cues

Subject: obsolete abnormal circadian persistence
Value: anomaly in the ability for an animal to retain a circadian rhythm when time cues are removed

Subject: obsolete arrhythmic circadian persistence
Value: loss of any rhythmic pattern upon removal of time cues

Subject: obsolete abnormal circadian phase
Value: anomaly in the phase relationship between a temporal synchronizing event (such as light cycle) and a phase reference point of an animal (such as activity onset)

Subject: obsolete prolonged circadian period
Value: increase in the cycle length expressed when exposed to constant conditions without temporal cues

Subject: obsolete shortened circadian period
Value: decrease in the cycle length expressed when exposed to constant conditions without temporal cues

Subject: obsolete advanced circadian phase
Value: increase in the phase relationship between a temporal synchronizing event (such as light cycle) and a phase reference point of an animal (such as activity onset)

Subject: obsolete delayed circadian phase
Value: decrease in the phase relationship between a temporal synchronizing event (such as light cycle) and a phase reference point of an animal (such as activity onset)

Subject: abnormal sexual interaction
Value: altered initiation, failure of initiation or incomplete mating behavior

Subject: alcohol aversion
Value: purposeful avoidance of alcohol due to dislike

Subject: senility
Value: a degenerative state of brain function manifesting in an impairment of memory, judgment, attention span, problem solving skills, the inability to perform previously learned skills that cannot be attributed to deficits of motor or sensory function, and a global loss of cognitive abilities

Subject: abnormal emotion/affect behavior
Value: altered response in tests for emotional related behaviors

Subject: behavioral despair
Value: depression assayed by reduced escape attempts and/or immobility when placed in a stressful situation such as a forced swim test or a suspension test; or failure to seek pleasurable stimuli

Subject: increased vertical activity
Value: greater than average time spent jumping or rearing

Subject: increased circulating ketone body level
Value: greater than the normal amount of acetoacetate, 3-hydroxybutyrate (beta-hydroxybutyrate) and/or acetone in the blood, which are produced by fatty acid and carbohydrate metabolism and seen in conditions such as starvation and diabetes mellitus

Subject: abnormal enamel morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the hard outer coating of the exposed portion of the tooth

Subject: reduced enamel thickness
Value: thin hard coating of the exposed portion of the tooth

Subject: impaired ability to fire action potentials
Value: anomaly resulting in reduced changes in membrane potentials occurring in nerve or other excitable tissue when excitation occurs

Subject: disorganized secondary lens fibers
Value: deformation or misalignment of the elongated cells that form the crystalline lens

Subject: duodenal lesions
Value: focal pathological changes characterized by alteration in the size, shape and organization of the cellular components of the duodenum epithelium tissue

Subject: abnormal ileum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the portion of the small intestine that extends from the jejunum to the colon

Subject: disorganized extraembryonic tissue
Value: a lack of the regular arrangement of the membranes involved with the embryo's protection and nutrition

Subject: absent extraembryonic ectoderm
Value: absence of the endoderm layer of the extraembryonic tissue

Subject: small ectoplacental cone
Value: reduced size of the thickened trophoblast of the blastocyst in rodents that becomes the fetal portion of the placenta

Subject: abnormal platelet volume
Value: anomaly in the content of platelet cells over normal

Subject: increased mean corpuscular volume
Value: greater than the average amount of space occupied by each red blood cell, calculated from the hematocrit and red cell count, in erythrocyte indices

Subject: decreased mean corpuscular volume
Value: less than the average amount of space occupied by each red blood cell, calculated from the hematocrit and red cell count, in erythrocyte indices

Subject: high mean erythrocyte cell number
Value: greater than average numbers of red blood cells

Subject: low mean erythrocyte cell number
Value: less than average numbers of red blood cells

Subject: abnormal hematocrit
Value: greater or less than the average percentage of a volume of a blood sample occupied by red blood cells

Subject: increased mean platelet volume
Value: increased average content of platelet cells over normal

Subject: abnormal eosinophil cell number
Value: deviation from the normal numbers of eosinophils

Subject: increased basophil cell number
Value: higher than average number of basophils as measured by the percent of the total number of leukocytes

Subject: decreased basophil cell number
Value: lower than average number of basophils as measured by the percent of the total number of leukocytes

Subject: increased hematocrit
Value: greater than average percentage of a volume of a blood sample occupied by red blood cells

Subject: abnormal lymphocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cells involved in adaptive immune reactions of the body in most inflammatory and autoimmune diseases, including B cells, T cells and natural killer cells

Subject: abnormal monocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the large, phagocytic mononuclear leukocytes produced in the vertebrate bone marrow and released into the blood

Subject: delayed neural tube closure
Value: delay in the last step in the formation of the neural tube, where the paired neural folds are brought together and fuse at the dorsal midline

Subject: abnormal cochlear hair cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the sensory epithelial cells of the cochlea; these cells are in synaptic contact with the auditory nerve

Subject: abnormal vestibular hair cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the mechanoreceptor cells in the sensory epithelium of the maculae and cristae of the membranous labyrinth of the internal ear; afferent and efferent nerve fibers of the vestibular nerve end synaptically on them; from the apical end of each cell a bundle of stereocilia and a kinocilium extend into the statoconial membrane of the maculae and the cupula of the cristae

Subject: abnormal tricuspid valve morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the valve located between the right atrium and the right ventricle of the heart, and contains three cusps, the anterior cusp (infundibular cusp), the posterior cusp (marginal cusp), and the septal cusp (medial cusp), attached to the outer fibrous ring (anulus)

Subject: heart left ventricle hypertrophy
Value: enlargement of heart left ventricular wall from the increase in size of its cells

Subject: increased heart rate
Value: greater than average resting heart beats per minute, usually measured by the number of times the heart ventricles contract per unit of time, usually per minute

Subject: increased teratoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of generally benign germ cell-derived tumors of male or female containing derivatives from all three germ layers with differentiation in the malignant form being poor; malignant tumors are highly metatstatic

Subject: hepatic steatosis
Value: an accumulation of fat deposits in the liver

Subject: hyperactivity elicited by ethanol administration
Value: increased activity after ingestion of alcohol

Subject: abnormal endocochlear potential
Value: any alterations in the electrical potential difference (+80 - 100 mV) between the endolymphatic and perilymphatic compartments of the cochlea; this potential is generated by the stria vascularis

Subject: abnormal epididymis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the elongated structure connected to the posterior surface of the testis that transports, stores, and matures spermatozoa between testis and vas deferens

Subject: vestigial tail
Value: a trace or rudimentary caudal structure, often a short boneless filament; the degenerated remains of any tail structure

Subject: persistent truncus arteriosis
Value: complete failure of the common arterial trunk opening out of both ventricles to divide into the aorta and pulmonary artery during development

Subject: abnormal sensorimotor gating
Value: malfunction of the process by which inhibitory neural pathways filter multiple stimuli and allow attention to be focused on one stimulus; usually measured by pre-pulse inhibition (PPI)

Subject: reduced sensorimotor gating
Value: attenuation of the process by which inhibitory neural pathways filter multiple stimuli and allow attention to be focused on one stimulus; usually measured by pre-pulse inhibition (PPI)

Subject: delayed vaginal opening
Value: the opening of the genital canal in a female occurring at a later than expected age

Subject: small uterus
Value: reduced size of the female muscular organ of gestation

Subject: abnormal pupillary reflex
Value: alterations or failure of the pupil to change in diameter as a reflex response to any stimulus

Subject: micrognathia
Value: abnormally reduced size of the jaws, especially of the mandible

Subject: reticulocytosis
Value: an increase in the number of circulating reticulocytes, which is normally less than 1 per cent of the total number of red blood cells

Subject: anisopoikilocytosis
Value: presence in blood of RBCs of abnormal shapes and sizes

Subject: anisocytosis
Value: considerable variation of the size of red blood cells compared to a normal range

Subject: poikilocytosis
Value: blood cells of variable shape on smear

Subject: decreased circulating triglyceride level
Value: reduced concentration of naturally occurring esters of three fatty acids and glycerol in the blood; triglycerides are widespread in adipose tissue, commonly circulate in the blood in the form of lipoproteins, and are involved in the process of bidirectional transference of adipose fat and blood glucose with the liver

Subject: abnormal intestinal cholesterol absorption
Value: any anomaly in the ability of the body to take up cholesterol into the blood by absorption from the small intestine

Subject: increased intestinal cholesterol absorption
Value: augmented ability of the body to take up cholesterol into the blood by absorption from the small intestine

Subject: decreased intestinal cholesterol absorption
Value: reduced ability of the body to take up cholesterol into the blood by absorption from the small intestine

Subject: delaminated enamel
Value: separation of the hard outer coating of the exposed portion of the tooth from the underlying hard tissue

Subject: abnormal enamel rod pattern
Value: any anomaly in the orientation of the structural unit of tooth enamel

Subject: abnormal ameloblast morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tall, columnar, polarized epithelial cell in the innermost layer of the enamel organ (inner enamel epithelium) of a developing tooth, involved with the formation of enamel matrix

Subject: abnormal sciatic nerve morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the nerve which originates in the lumbar and sacral spinal cord (L4 to S3) and supplies motor and sensory innervation to the lower extremity

Subject: thin myocardium
Value: reduced thickness of the cardiac muscle layer

Subject: abnormal ependyma morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cellular membrane that lines the brain ventricles and the central canal of the spinal cord

Subject: spongiform encephalopathy
Value: a neurodegenerative state characterized by the appearance of large vacuolated areas in the brain cells, resembling a sponge

Subject: abnormal keratinocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cells of the epidermis that produce keratin in the process of differentiating into the dead and fully keratinized cells of the stratum corneum

Subject: abnormal keratinocyte differentiation
Value: developmental anomaly of the cells of the epidermis that produce keratin in the process of differentiating into the dead and fully keratinized cells of the stratum corneum

Subject: chondrodystrophy
Value: abnormal development of the cartilage primordia of long bones, resulting in abnormally short extremities but normal head and trunk

Subject: abnormal liver regeneration
Value: deviation from the normal ability of liver to regenerate healthy tissue following partial hepatectomy

Subject: pituitary gland hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the pituitary gland

Subject: abnormal caput epididymis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the head of the epididymis

Subject: abnormal corpus epididymis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the body of the epididymis

Subject: abnormal cauda epididymis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tail of the epididymis

Subject: absent blastocoele
Value: developmental anomaly resulting in the absence of the cavity in the blastocyst of the developing embryo

Subject: decreased circulating adrenocorticotropin level
Value: decreased concentration in the blood of the pituitary hormone that stimulates the secretion of adrenal cortical steroids and induces growth of the adrenal cortex

Subject: decreased circulating corticosterone level
Value: less than the normal blood amount of an adrenocortical steroid that induces glycogen deposition and regulates sodium conservation and potassium secretion

Subject: increased circulating aldosterone level
Value: increased in the blood concentration of the hormone that is secreted by the adrenal cortex and regulates sodium conservation and potassium secretion in the distal renal tubule

Subject: decreased circulating aldosterone level
Value: decreased in the blood concentration of the hormone that is secreted by the adrenal cortex and regulates sodium conservation and potassium secretion in the distal renal tubule

Subject: abnormal circulating potassium level
Value: anomalous concentration in the blood of this alkaline metallic element, the most abundant intracellular ion; anomalies in the extracellular (circulating) concentration have important implications for the function of excitable tissues, such as nerve and muscle

Subject: abnormal scrotum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the external sac of skin that encloses the testes

Subject: absent scrotum
Value: missing the external sac of skin that encloses the testes

Subject: belted
Value: the appearance of a stripe of white fur around the circumference of the abdomen

Subject: abnormal pharyngeal arch artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the vessels formed within the six (five in mammals) pairs of branchial arches in embryogenesis; in the adult, some of these vessels give rise to the great vessels

Subject: abnormal sperm number
Value: increased or decreased numbers of spermatozoa

Subject: abnormal sperm motility
Value: anomalies in the mobility of the spermatozoa

Subject: asthenozoospermia
Value: loss or reduction of the mobility of the spermatozoa, frequently associated with infertility

Subject: uterus hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due an increased number of cells in the uterus

Subject: increased follicle recruitment
Value: greater frequency of the entry of arrested primordial follicles into the pool of growing follicles

Subject: abnormal corpus luteum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the yellow endocrine body formed in the ovary after follicle rupture

Subject: decreased corpora lutea number
Value: fewer than normal numbers of yellow endocrine body formed in the ovary after follicle rupture in a given oestrous cycle

Subject: increased corpora lutea number
Value: greater than normal numbers of yellow endocrine body formed in the ovary after follicle rupture in a given oestrous cycle

Subject: decreased mature ovarian follicle number
Value: fewer than normal numbers of ovarian follicles that are ready for ovulation and present a blanched spot (the follicular stigma) where the graafian follicle is about to rupture on the surface of the ovary; a first maturation (meiotic) division of the primary oocyte usually occurs just prior to rupture of the follicle

Subject: delayed fertility
Value: ability to produce live offspring occurring at a later than expected age

Subject: abnormal spermatogonia proliferation
Value: anomaly in the proliferation of the spermatogonial stem cells either due to abnormal mitosis or apoptosis

Subject: globozoospermia
Value: any structural anomaly of the acrosome resulting in a round sperm head

Subject: oligozoospermia
Value: reduced concentration of spermatozoa in the seminal fluid

Subject: abnormal molar morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the most posterior teeth located on either side of the jaw, characterized by a large crown and broad chewing surface

Subject: akinesia
Value: acquired absence of voluntary movement or loss of the ability to move such as temporary or prolonged paralysis or freezing in place

Subject: small stomach
Value: reduced size of the stomach

Subject: abnormal pancreas physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the organ that secretes pancreatic juice into the duodenum and secretes glucagon and insulin into the bloodstream

Subject: abnormal pancreas secretion
Value: anomaly in the production and/or release of biologically active substances from pancreatic tissue

Subject: abnormal circulating glucagon level
