Value: anomaly in the blood concentration of the peptide hormone secreted by the alpha cells of the pancreas that normally plays an important role in regulation of blood glucose concentration, ketone metabolism, and several other biochemical and physiological processes

Subject: decreased circulating glucagon level
Value: reduction in the blood concentration of the peptide hormone secreted by the alpha cells of the pancreas that normally plays an important role in regulation of blood glucose concentration, ketone metabolism, and several other biochemical and physiological processes

Subject: abnormal eye size
Value: deviation from the average range of eye size for a given organism

Subject: abnormal sclera morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the fibrous, outer envelope of the eyeball, covering it entirely excepting the segment covered anteriorly by the cornea

Subject: abnormal vitreous body morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the transparent, semigelatinous substance that fills the cavity behind the crystalline lens of the eye and in front of the retina

Subject: opacity of vitreous body
Value: the transparent gel filling the inner portion of the eyeball between the lens and retina becomes cloudy and impervious to light

Subject: decreased circulating free fatty acids level
Value: lower than normal levels of the fatty acids which occur in plasma as a result of lipolysis in adipose tissue or when plasma triacylglycerols are taken into tissues

Subject: abnormal renal tubule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the loops of Henle, the proximal convoluted tubule or the distal convoluted tubule

Subject: tubular nephritis
Value: inflammation of the renal tubules

Subject: dilated renal tubules
Value: stretched or widened aperture of the luminal space of the loops of Henle, the proximal convoluted tubule or the distal convoluted tubule

Subject: abnormal kidney size
Value: anomalous physical bulk one or both of the organs responsible for urine secretion

Subject: abnormal kidney weight
Value: anomaly in the average weight of the organs responsible for urine secretion

Subject: nephrolithiasis
Value: calculi occurring in the kidney

Subject: increased glucagon secretion
Value: greater than normal production or release of this hormone secreted by the alpha cells of the islets of Langerhans; it normally plays a role in regulation of blood glucose concentration, ketone metabolism, and other biochemical and physiological processes

Subject: decreased glucagon secretion
Value: reduction in the production or release of this hormone secreted by the alpha cells of the islets of Langerhans; it normally plays a role in regulation of blood glucose concentration, ketone metabolism, and other biochemical and physiological processes

Subject: increased circulating glucagon level
Value: increase in the blood concentration of the peptide hormone secreted by the alpha cells of the pancreas that normally plays an important role in regulation of blood glucose concentration, ketone metabolism, and several other biochemical and physiological processes

Subject: abnormal glycogen catabolism
Value: inability to breakdown glycogen; or reduced or increased rate of glycogen breakdown

Subject: increased glycogen catabolism rate
Value: increased breakdown of this highly branched polysaccharide composed of glucose subunits; glycogen is the major carbohydrate storage form in the body

Subject: decreased glycogen catabolism rate
Value: decreased breakdown of this highly branched polysaccharide composed of glucose subunits; glycogen is the major carbohydrate storage form in the body

Subject: small male preputial glands
Value: reduced size of the sebaceous glands of the corona and neck of the glans penis

Subject: abnormal male preputial gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the paired, lobulated, modified sebaceous glands of the corona, the neck of the glans penis, and the inner surface of the prepuce with pheromonal functions in male rodents; male preputial secretions strongly attract females, may accelerate estrus, and have been implicated in intermale aggression; homologous to the clitoral glands (aka female preputial glands) in female rodents; there is no true anatomical equivalent in humans

Subject: abnormal inner cell mass morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cells of the blastocyst that develop into the body of the embryo and some extraembryonic tissues

Subject: abnormal immune system organ morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of lymphoid organs

Subject: abnormal immune serum protein physiology
Value: abnormal concentration or function of circulating immune proteins

Subject: enhanced wound healing
Value: increased ability to self-repair and close wounds

Subject: abnormal vein morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the blood vessels that carry blood towards the heart

Subject: abnormal pulmonary vein morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the veins that return oxygenated blood from the lungs to the left atrium of the heart

Subject: decreased circulating insulin level
Value: less than normal levels of insulin in the blood

Subject: absent tibia
Value: missing the medial and larger of the two bones of the lower leg

Subject: abnormal inner ear canal morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tubular ducts of the inner ear

Subject: head shaking
Value: repetitive movement of the head in the horizontal plane

Subject: megacolon
Value: extreme dilation of the colon

Subject: increased trichoepithelioma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of benign hair follicle tumors that lack mature hair follicles, derived from basal cells of the hair follicles enclosing small keratin cysts, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: abnormal thermal nociception
Value: abnormal capability to sense pain elicited by thermal stimulation

Subject: abnormal mechanical nociception
Value: abnormal capability to sense pain elicited by mechanical stimulation

Subject: abnormal chemical nociception
Value: abnormal capability to sense pain elicited by chemical stimulation

Subject: abnormal nociception after inflammation
Value: changes in pain thresholds after inflammation

Subject: hyperresponsive to tactile stimuli
Value: exaggerated reflex action normally induced by touch or pain

Subject: abnormal olfactory bulb development
Value: abnormality in the progression of the formation of the olfactory bulb

Subject: heart hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the heart, usually due to a reduced number of cells

Subject: small olfactory bulb
Value: reduced size of the forebrain region that coordinates neuronal signaling involved in the perception of smell; it receives input from the sensory neurons and outputs to the olfactory cortex

Subject: enlarged submandibular lymph nodes
Value: increased size of the submandibular lymph nodes

Subject: glomerulonephritis
Value: inflammation and scarring damage to the glomerulus usually resulting from an autoimmune response; often characterized by decreased production of urine, the presence of blood and protein in the urine, and/or by edema; often leads to kidney failure

Subject: abnormal atrioventricular valve morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the valves that gate the flow of blood from the atria into the ventricles

Subject: abnormal semilunar valve morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the valves that gate the flow of blood from the ventricles into the aorta and pulmonary trunk

Subject: abnormal aortic valve morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the valve between the left ventricle and the ascending aorta which prevents backflow into the left ventricle, and contains three cusps, the posterior (non-coronary), right anterior and left anterior cusps, attached to an outer fibrous ring (annulus)

Subject: abnormal pulmonary valve morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the valve between the right ventricle and the pulmonary trunk, and contains three cusps, the anterior, right posterior and left posterior cusps, attached to an outer fibrous ring (annulus)

Subject: exophthalmos
Value: forward displacement, bulging, or protrusion of one or both eyeballs

Subject: abnormal autonomic nervous system morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the function of the sensory and motor neurons that run between the central nervous system (especially the hypothalamus and medulla oblongata) and various internal organs (heart, lungs, endocrine and exocrine glands), responsible for controlling involuntary bodily functions

Subject: abnormal somatic nervous system morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the part of the peripheral nervous system that is responsible for conveying voluntary motor and external sensory information, including all nerves controlling the skeletal muscular system and external sensory receptors (including balance, smell, sight, taste, touch and hearing sensory inputs)

Subject: dilated heart left ventricle
Value: the luminal space of the lower left chamber of the heart is increased in volume or area, usually with an increase in contained fluid

Subject: dilated heart right ventricle
Value: the luminal space of the lower right chamber of the heart is increased in volume or area, usually with an increase in contained fluid

Subject: decreased vertical activity
Value: lesser than average time spent jumping or rearing

Subject: long tail
Value: increased length of tail relative to average of a given reference population

Subject: abnormal caudal vertebrae morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bony segments of the coccyx or tail

Subject: abnormal hippocampal mossy fiber morphology
Value: absence or misprojection of axons of neuronal cells in the dentate gyrus

Subject: ectopic cerebellar granule cells
Value: granule cell body resides in a place other than the external or internal granule layer of the cerebellum

Subject: ectopic Bergmann glia cells
Value: abnormal position of one or more astrocyte-type glia cells associated with Purkinje cells in the cerebellum

Subject: short tibia
Value: reduced length of the medial and larger bone of the lower leg

Subject: short fibula
Value: reduced length of the lateral and smaller of bone of the lower leg

Subject: situs inversus
Value: lateral transposition or mirroring of the viscera of the thorax and abdomen, sometimes incomplete, with all organs maintaining the normal relative position with respect to each other

Subject: situs ambiguus
Value: an abnormality in which the thoracic and abdominal organs are positioned in such a way with respect to each other and the left-right axis as to be not clearly lateralised and thus have neither the usual, or normal (situs solitus), nor the mirror-imaged (situs inversus) arrangements

Subject: small adrenal glands
Value: reduced size of the pair of endocrine glands located above the kidney that are responsible for steroid hormone secretion from the cortex and neurotransmitter (such as epinephrine and norepinephrine) secretion from the medulla

Subject: abnormal vas deferens morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the secretory duct of the testicle that carries spermatozoa, running from the epididymis, of which it is the continuation, to the prostatic urethra where it terminates to form ejaculatory duct

Subject: absent bulbourethral gland
Value: absence of any of the small paired racemose (compound tubulo-alveolar) glands below the apex of the prostate in males, located posterolateral to the membranous portion of the urethra at the base of the penis, between the two layers of the fascia of the urogenital diaphragm, in the deep perineal pouch, and enclosed by transverse fibers of the sphincter urethrae membranaceae muscle; they secrete a clear fluid known as pre-ejaculate (Cowper's fluid), and are homologous to the greater vestibular (Bartholin's) glands in the female

Subject: absent prostate gland anterior lobe
Value: absence of the rodent prostate lobe that appears as a thin tubular structure, attached to the lesser curvature of the paired seminal vesicles

Subject: brachypodia
Value: abnormally short feet

Subject: decreased circulating luteinizing hormone level
Value: lower than normal levels in the bloodstream of LH, the hormone that regulates steroid production by the interstitial cells of the testis and the ovary

Subject: small prostate gland
Value: reduced size of the gland in males that secretes part of the seminiferous fluid

Subject: Sertoli cell hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due an increased number of cells of the seminiferous tubules that create the blood-testes barrier and enable spermatogenesis

Subject: absent ovarian follicles
Value: absence of the sac-like structure in the ovary which surrounds an ovum

Subject: meroanencephaly
Value: type of anencephaly in which the brain and cranium are present in rudimentary form

Subject: abnormal sex gland secretion
Value: anomaly in the production and/or release of hormones from a cell or a gland of the reproductive system

Subject: decreased circulating testosterone level
Value: reduction in the blood concentration of a potent androgen that promotes development of male secondary sex characteristics and the development of spermatozoa and may regulate sexual desire and help maintain bone and muscle health in both males and females

Subject: increased circulating testosterone level
Value: greater than the normal blood concentration of a potent androgen that promotes development of male secondary sex characteristics and the development of spermatozoa and may regulate sexual desire and help maintain bone and muscle health in both males and females

Subject: abnormal testes secretion
Value: anomaly in the production and/or release of hormones from testicular tissue

Subject: abnormal ovarian secretion
Value: anomaly in the production and/or release of hormones from ovarian tissue

Subject: abnormal Sertoli cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the supporting cells of the seminiferous tubule epithelium that create the blood-testes barrier and enable spermatogenesis

Subject: absent Leydig cells
Value: lack of the interstitial cells of the seminiferous tubules that secrete testosterone

Subject: abnormal Leydig cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the interstitial cells that are found adjacent to the seminiferous tubules in the testicle and produce testosterone in the presence of luteinizing hormone (LH); Leydig cells are polyhedral in shape, display a large prominent nucleus, an eosinophilic cytoplasm and numerous lipid-filled vesicles

Subject: pseudohermaphroditism
Value: unambiguous gonadal sex (i.e. possesses either testes or ovaries, consistent with chromosomal sex) but has ambiguous secondary sexual characteristics

Subject: female pseudohermaphroditism
Value: pseudohermaphroditism in which the gonads are female (ovaries) and the karyotype is XX but the secondary sex characteristics are male-like or ambiguous

Subject: male pseudohermaphroditism
Value: pseudohermaphroditism in which the gonads are male (testes) and the karyotype is XY but the secondary sex characteristics are female-like or ambiguous

Subject: decreased circulating follicle stimulating hormone level
Value: less than expected blood concentration of the hormone that, in females, stimulates the graafian follicles of the ovary and assists in follicular maturation and the secretion of estradiol; in the male it stimulates the epithelium of the seminiferous tubules and is partly responsible for spermatogenesis

Subject: steatorrhea
Value: passage of large amounts of fat in the feces due to the inability to digest and absorb it

Subject: abnormal retinal vasculature morphology
Value: any anomaly of the structure or arrangement of blood vessels supplying the retina

Subject: lenticonus
Value: a conical bulging of the lens capsule and the underlying cortex of the eye

Subject: dilated cardiomyopathy
Value: decreased function of the heart associated with cardiac enlargement and congestive heart failure

Subject: impaired skin barrier function
Value: impaired ability of the skin to regulate water loss; frequently leads to dehydration

Subject: increased thigmotaxis
Value: greater than average preference for staying at the perimeter walls of an open area or in an enclosed versus exposed area; may be used as an indicator of increased anxiety response

Subject: abnormal active avoidance behavior
Value: anomaly in the ability to escape a hostile environment to actively avoid the unpleasant or punishing stimuli ( e.g. shock) previously encountered in this environment

Subject: abnormal passive avoidance behavior
Value: anomaly in the ability of an animal to enter an hostile environment where it receives a unpleasant or punishing stimuli applied previously with prolonged latency

Subject: abnormal short term object recognition memory
Value: anomaly in the short-term memory for objects is established during the first few minutes after training

Subject: abnormal long term object recognition memory
Value: anomaly in long-term memory for objects that is consolidated over hours and days after training

Subject: abnormal discrimination learning
Value: anomaly in the ability to exhibit a differential response to different stimuli that is achieved by the reinforcement of the desired response for each particular stimulus

Subject: abnormal operant conditioning behavior
Value: anomaly in the operant conditioning system refers to abnormalities in scheduled controlled behavior; behavioral assessment occurs in an automated chamber where responses are reinforced with food

Subject: abnormal motor learning
Value: anomaly in the ability to repeat a motor task requiring well coordinated movements and balance; measures cerebellar dependent learning

Subject: abnormal conditioned taste aversion behavior
Value: anomaly in the ability of an animal to learn to avoid food sources that were previously associated with aversive internal stimuli or sickness such as a drug that induces sickness

Subject: abnormal conditioned emotional response
Value: anomaly in an emotional response that has been acquired by conditioning

Subject: abnormal eye blink conditioning behavior
Value: anomaly in the ability of an animal to learn to blink in anticipation of an aversive stimulus (e.g., an air puff to the eyelid) following repeated pairings with a neutral stimulus (e.g., a tone); such learning is only adaptive if the animal is able to learn the precise timing between the conditioned and unconditioned stimuli

Subject: abnormal barbering behavior
Value: anomaly in the behavior of plucking of fur/hair or whiskers/vibrissae from other individuals of a cohort (hetero-barbering) or oneself (self-barbering); it is recognized as patches of unevenly chopped hair and the underlying skin is seldom inflamed

Subject: increased spinal cord size
Value: larger appearance of the spinal cord

Subject: microcytic anemia
Value: a reduction in the mean total mass of erythrocytes in which the remaining circulating erythrocyte corpuscular volume is smaller than normal; most commonly due to iron deficiency but also sickle cell disease and other conditions that result in hemoglobin synthesis failure or insufficiency

Subject: macrocytic anemia
Value: deficiency of red blood cells in which the remaining circulating erythrocyte corpuscular volume is larger than normal; most commonly due to megaloblastic anemia, or a deficiency of either vitamin B12 or folic acid

Subject: spherocytosis
Value: the presence of sphere-shaped erythrocytes in the circulating blood

Subject: microcytosis
Value: the presence of unusually small erythrocytes in the circulating blood

Subject: hyperchromasia
Value: increased capacity of a cell to stain with dye; usually refers to staining of cell nuclei with hematoxylin

Subject: colitis
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the colon region of the large intestine

Subject: abnormal tooth mineralization
Value: abnormalities in the process by which calcium salts are deposited into the dental enamel, dentin and cementum

Subject: abnormal dentin morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the hard portion of the tooth surrounding the pulp, covered by enamel on the crown and cementum on the root

Subject: abnormal dental pulp cavity morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the central space (cavity) of a tooth that is bounded by dentin and contains the dental pulp; the portion of the cavity within the crown of the tooth is the pulp chamber; the portion within the root is the pulp canal or root canal

Subject: abnormal premaxilla morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anterior and inner portion of the maxilla

Subject: catalepsy
Value: a condition characterized by inactivity, lack of response to stimuli, and a tendency to maintain an immobile posture; the limbs tend to remain in whatever position they are placed (waxy rigidity); occurs with some psychoses, nervous system drug toxicity, and other conditions

Subject: abnormal rib development
Value: anomalous formation of the bones forming the bony wall of the chest

Subject: abnormal chorioallantoic fusion
Value: anomaly in the process by which a highly vascularized extra-embryonic fetal membrane is formed by fusion of the chorion and allantois; in most mammals, the chorioallantois constitutes the fetal portion of the placenta

Subject: abnormal notochord morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the axial fibrocellular cord in embryos around which develops the vertebral primordia

Subject: tonic seizures
Value: increased number or decreased threshold for the induction of a seizure characterized by muscle rigidity

Subject: abnormal renal corpuscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the structure containing the glomerular capsule and the glomerulus that serves as the initial blood-filtering component of a nephron

Subject: abnormal renal glomerular capsule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the expanded beginning of a nephron that contains the glomerulus

Subject: abnormal juxtaglomerular apparatus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the complex of modified smooth muscle cells consisting of juxtaglomerular cells, extraglomerular mesangium lacis cells, the macula densa of the distal convoluted tubule, and granular epithelial peripolar cells; these cells are found in the walls of afferent and efferent glomerular arterioles

Subject: gallstones
Value: caliculi in the gallbladder or a bile duct; chemical composition of cholesterol, calcium carbonate or calcium bilirubinate

Subject: absent Peyer's patches
Value: lymphoid tissue missing from the mucosa of the small intestine

Subject: coarse hair
Value: hair shafts that are twisted or coiled and are of uneven thickness produce an overall rugged or uneven appearance and roughness to the touch

Subject: increased heart weight
Value: greater than average weight of the heart compared to controls

Subject: decreased heart weight
Value: less than average weight of the heart compared to controls

Subject: abnormal cranial suture morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the dense, fibrous connective tissue joint between the bones of the head

Subject: abnormal chorion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the outermost extraembryonic membrane

Subject: dystrophic cardiac calcinosis
Value: a condition characterized by the localized deposition of calcium salts in the heart; often occurring in association with inflammation or atherosclerotic lesions and other pathological states

Subject: decreased susceptibility to dystrophic cardiac calcinosis
Value: less likely to be stricken by dystrophic cardiac calcinosis

Subject: increased susceptibility to dystrophic cardiac calcinosis
Value: more likely to be stricken by dystrophic cardiac calcinosis

Subject: abnormal lens fiber morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the elongated cells of the crystalline lens of the eye

Subject: impaired skeletal muscle contractility
Value: inability or reduced ability of the skeletal muscle to shorten or to develop increased tension

Subject: increased systemic arterial blood pressure
Value: increased tension of the blood within the systemic arteries

Subject: decreased systemic arterial blood pressure
Value: decreased tension of the blood within the systemic arteries

Subject: aortic hypertrophy
Value: increase in the bulk size of the aorta

Subject: abnormal aortic weight
Value: anomaly in the average weight of the aorta

Subject: abnormal aortic mass
Value: altered physical volume or bulk of the aorta

Subject: abnormal renal glomerular filtration rate
Value: anomaly in the rate of the process in which plasma is filtered through the glomerular membrane, which consists of capillary endothelial cells, the basement membrane, and epithelial cells; the glomerular filtrate is the same as plasma except it has no significant amount of protein

Subject: abnormal saccharin consumption
Value: anomaly in the amount of saccharin consumed in relation to other food

Subject: saccharin preference
Value: subjects demonstrate predilection for saccharine over other offered substance

Subject: abnormal circulating sulfate level
Value: altered concentration of sulfate in the blood

Subject: hypersulfatemia
Value: abnormally high concentration of sulfate in the circulating blood

Subject: hyposulfatemia
Value: abnormally low concentration of sulfate in the circulating blood

Subject: abnormal cochlear ganglion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the group of nerve cell bodies that conveys auditory sensation from the organ of Corti to the hindbrain and resides on the cochlear part of the vestibulocochlear nerve (eighth cranial nerve)

Subject: abnormal vestibular ganglion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the group of neurons associated with the vestibular part of the eighth cranial nerve that are involved in equilibration

Subject: cochlear ganglion degeneration
Value: loss of neural cell bodies in the group of nerve cell bodies that conveys auditory sensation from the organ of Corti to the hindbrain

Subject: abnormal posterior semicircular canal morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the posterior segment of the long bony tube of the labyrinth that is involved in the sense of balance

Subject: abnormal inner ear canal fusion
Value: any structural anomaly or mistiming of the fusion of the canal primordia during development

Subject: abnormal tail bud morphology
Value: anomalous formation of the primordial region of the embryo that arises to form the tail of the adult; appears approximately ten days following conception as a short stump, and then initiates elongation and thinning in normal development

Subject: altered righting response
Value: altered ability or changed amount of time needed to recover from an unnatural position to a normal position and/or to resist any force acting to place an organism into a false position

Subject: improved righting response
Value: faster ability or less amount of time needed to recover from an unnatural position to a normal position and/or to resist any force acting to place an organism into a false position

Subject: abnormal ocular fundus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the posterior concave interior of the eye, consisting of the retina, the choroid, the posterior segment of the sclera, the optic disk, and blood vessels, visible by an ophthalmoscope

Subject: increased growth rate
Value: reduced length of time to reach a developmental stage or stages

Subject: abnormal glutamic acid decarboxylase level
Value: aberrant concentration of the enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of glutamate to gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) and carbon dioxide, and regulates GABA levels in nervous tissues

Subject: increased glutamic acid decarboxylase level
Value: greater than normal concentration of the enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of glutamate to gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) and carbon dioxide and regulates GABA levels in nervous tissues

Subject: decreased glutamic acid decarboxylase level
Value: less than normal concentration of the enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of glutamate to gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) and carbon dioxide, and regulates GABA levels in nervous tissues

Subject: increased anti-insulin autoantibody level
Value: elevated level of antibodies to insulin present in the sera

Subject: decreased anti-insulin autoantibody level
Value: reduced level of antibodies to insulin present in the sera

Subject: albuminuria
Value: presence of excess albumin in the urine

Subject: polycythemia
Value: an excess of circulating red blood cells

Subject: decreased hemoglobin content
Value: decrease in the total hemoglobin content in the circulating blood

Subject: decreased erythrocyte cell number
Value: reduced number of the cells that transport oxygen, red blood cells, per unit

Subject: abnormal thyroid gland physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of this endocrine gland that normally produces hormones that regulate the metabolic rate of the body

Subject: abnormal melanocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cells that produce pigment

Subject: abnormal corticospinal tract morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the corticospinal fibers that arise from the pyramidal cells within the cerebral cortex layer V of the precentral motor area, the premotor area and the postcentral gyrus, then descend into and through the medulla to form the lateral corticospinal tract and the anterior corticospinal tract

Subject: increased cellular sensitivity to X-ray irradiation
Value: increased incidence of cell death following exposure to X-ray irradiation

Subject: opisthotonus
Value: a form of tetanic spasm in which the head, neck and spine are bent backward and the body is bowed forward

Subject: long hair
Value: increased average length of the coat hairs

Subject: abnormal neuron morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cells of the nervous system that receive, conduct, and transmit impulses

Subject: chromatolysis
Value: the dissolution of the granules of chromophil substance in a nerve cell body that may occur in injured cells or axons

Subject: abnormal pharyngeal arch morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the transient structures of the embryo that develop into regions of the head, neck and ears

Subject: abnormal AMPA-mediated synaptic currents
Value: change in the measured amplitude, current density or duration of response to stimulation of AMPA receptors

Subject: abnormal glutamate-mediated receptor currents
Value: change in the measured amplitude, current density or duration of response to stimulation of glutamatergic receptors

Subject: decreased susceptibility to pharmacologically induced seizures
Value: ability to withstand doses of pharmacological drugs that induce seizure activity in normal animals; exhibit a higher threshold to induce seizure activity

Subject: abnormal NMDA-mediated synaptic currents
Value: change in the measured amplitude, current density or duration of response to stimulation of NMDA receptors

Subject: increased insulin sensitivity
Value: greater ability to clear glucose from the bloodstream when given insulin than normal; can result in hypoglycemia

Subject: decreased superior colliculus size
Value: decreased size of the paired superior eminence of the mesencephalic tectum

Subject: ketoaciduria
Value: elevated amount of acetoacetate, 3-hydroxybutyrate (beta-hydroxybutyrate) and/or acetone in the urine, which are produced by fatty acid and carbohydrate metabolism and seen in conditions such as starvation and diabetes mellitus

Subject: abnormal otolith morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the crystalline particles composed of calcium carbonate and a protein which adhere to the gelatinous membrane of the maculae of the utricle and saccule (otolithic membrane)

Subject: abnormal otolithic membrane morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the gelatinous membrane which is supported by the stereocilia of the hair cells of the maculae of the saccule and utriculus of the inner ear; adhering to its surface are numerous calciferous crystalline particles called otoliths (statoconia)

Subject: abnormal bone mineralization
Value: defect in the process by which minerals are deposited into bone

Subject: blotchy skin
Value: regions of spotted discoloration appearing in the dermal tissue

Subject: absent cartilage
Value: absence of the nonvascular, resilient, flexible connective tissue found primarily in joints, walls of the thorax, and tubular structures, but which also comprises most of the skeleton in early fetal life

Subject: fatigue
Value: easily exhausted due to mental or physical exertion

Subject: abnormal urine phosphate level
Value: any change in the amount of phosphate in the urine

Subject: increased urine phosphate level
Value: an increase in phosphate amount in the urine

Subject: decreased urine phosphate level
Value: reduced phosphate amount in the urine

Subject: abnormal circulating parathyroid hormone level
Value: anomaly in the blood concentration of the hormone that regulates and maintains intracellular calcium levels in the body

Subject: increased circulating parathyroid hormone level
Value: greater blood concentration of the hormone that regulates and maintains intracellular calcium levels in the body

Subject: decreased circulating parathyroid hormone level
Value: reduction in the blood concentration of the hormone that regulates and maintains intracellular calcium levels in the body

Subject: increased susceptibility to pharmacologically induced seizures
Value: inability to withstand doses of pharmacological drugs that induce seizure activity in normal animals; exhibit a lower threshold to induce seizure activity

Subject: abnormal parturition
Value: defect in the process of labor and delivery in female animals

Subject: delayed wound healing
Value: longer time requirement for the ability to self-repair and close wounds than normal

Subject: abnormal adrenal gland physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the suprarenal gland, including the ability to produce and secrete hormones

Subject: abnormal excitatory postsynaptic currents
Value: defect in the size or duration of currents detected in postsynaptic cells when an excitatory impulse arrives at the synapse causing depolarization

Subject: abnormal inhibitory postsynaptic potential
Value: defect in the membrane potential detected in postsynaptic cells when an inhibitory impulse arrives at the synapse causing hyperpolarization

Subject: abnormal excitatory postsynaptic potential
Value: defect in the potential detected in postsynaptic cells when an excitatory impulse arrives at the synapse causing depolarization

Subject: abnormal PNS synaptic transmission
Value: defect in the communication from a neuron to a target across a synapse in the peripheral nervous system

Subject: abnormal endplate potential
Value: defect in the excitatory response of peripheral synapses to stimulation; these amplitudes are larger than central synapse potentials

Subject: abnormal synaptic depression
Value: changes in the duration of the reduction of effectiveness of synaptic connections between neurons and target after repetitive stimulation

Subject: increased synaptic depression
Value: increase in the duration of the reduction of effectiveness of synaptic connections between neurons and target after repetitive stimulation

Subject: decreased synaptic depression
Value: decrease in the duration of the reduction of effectiveness of synaptic connections between neurons and target after repetitive stimulation

Subject: abnormal paired-pulse facilitation
Value: defects in the enhanced response of central synapses when activated twice in rapid succession; indicative of defects in short-term plasticity due to lack of increase of neurotransmitter release at the second stimulus

Subject: enhanced paired-pulse facilitation
Value: increase in the response of central synapses when activated twice in rapid succession; indicative of defects in short-term plasticity due to greater increase of neurotransmitter release at the second stimulus

Subject: decreased paired-pulse facilitation
Value: reduction in the response of central synapses when activated twice in rapid succession; indicative of defects in short-term plasticity due to lack of increase of neurotransmitter release at the second stimulus

Subject: abnormal post-tetanic potentiation
Value: defects in the size or duration of potentials that persist after tetanic stimulation of central synapses

Subject: decreased post-tetanic potentiation
Value: reduction in the size or duration of potentials that persist after tetanic stimulation of central synapses

Subject: increased post-tetanic potentiation
Value: increase in the size or duration of potentials that persist after tetanic stimulation of central synapses

Subject: delayed CNS synapse formation
Value: increase in time required to complete the process of generating connections between an axon and effector tissue or neuron

Subject: abnormal cardiovascular development
Value: aberrant formation or incomplete differentiation of the cardiovascular system

Subject: aganglionic megacolon
Value: extreme dilation of the colon due to defects in innervation from the ganglia, or absence of the ganglia of the myenteric plexus

Subject: toxic megacolon
Value: severe non-obstructive dilation of the colon

Subject: abnormal bile duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the channels that secrete bile from the liver to the gall bladder and intestines

Subject: abnormal bile duct development
Value: incomplete or aberrant differentiation of the channels that secrete bile from the liver to the gall bladder and intestines

Subject: glutaricadicuria
Value: an accumulation of an intermediate of tryptophan catabolism in the urine

Subject: abnormal joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the moveable articulation point of two or more bones

Subject: joint inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the joints

Subject: acute joint inflammation
Value: early and often transient reaction of the microcirculation, characterized by movement of fluid and leukocytes from the blood into the joints; initiated by injury, infection, or local immune response

Subject: chronic joint inflammation
Value: persistent inflammatory response in the joints, often caused by persistent infection or during an autoimmune response

Subject: joint swelling
Value: enlargement of the joints, usually due to an accumulation of fluid

Subject: synovial hyperemia
Value: an increased blood flow to a synovial joint

Subject: white spotting
Value: the appearance of patches of white fur

Subject: head spot
Value: the appearance of a round area of white fur on the head

Subject: variable body spotting
Value: the appearance of patches of white fur at random on the coat

Subject: increased circulating alanine transaminase level
Value: increased concentration in the blood of the enzyme which transfers amino groups from l-alanine to 2 ketoglutarate, or the reverse (from l-glutamate to pyruvate); serum concentration is increased in viral hepatitis and myocardial infarction

Subject: decreased circulating alanine transaminase level
Value: decreased concentration in the blood of the enzyme which transfers amino groups from l-alanine to 2 ketoglutarate, or the reverse (from l-glutamate to pyruvate); serum concentration is increased in viral hepatitis and myocardial infarction

Subject: abnormal lactate dehydrogenase level
Value: abnormal level of the tetrameric enzyme that, along with the coenzyme NAD+, catalyzes the interconversion of lactate and pyruvate

Subject: increased lactate dehydrogenase level
Value: elevated level of the tetrameric enzyme that, along with the coenzyme NAD+, catalyzes the interconversion of lactate and pyruvate

Subject: abnormal inhibitory postsynaptic currents
Value: defect in the size or duration of currents detected in postsynaptic cells when an inhibitory impulse arrives at the synapse causing hyperpolarization

Subject: delayed axon extension
Value: an increased amount of time required for an axon to extend from a neuron cell body and find the target

Subject: increased hemangioma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign tumor characterized by blood-filled spaces lined by benign endothelial cells, occurring in a specific population in a given time period; a cavernous hemangioma is characterized by large endothelial spaces (caverns), and a capillary hemangioma is characterized by small endothelial spaces

Subject: abnormal neuron specification
Value: defects in the developmental patterning of neurons resulting in ectopic placement, decreased numbers or absence of mature neurons

Subject: abnormal neural crest cell migration
Value: any anomaly in the dispersion of the transient and migratory group of cells that emerge from the dorsal region of the neural tube and migrate to many peripheral locations to form various tissues of the adult

Subject: small thyroid gland
Value: reduced size of the endocrine gland located in the front and to the sides of the upper part of the trachea, and which secretes thyroid hormone and calcitonin

Subject: ventricular cardiomyopathy
Value: diseases of the ventricles of the heart

Subject: thick ventricular wall
Value: increased depth of the cardiac wall of the heart ventricles

Subject: increased compensatory renal growth
Value: increased additional growth of a kidney upon removal of the other kidney through surgery or disease

Subject: decreased compensatory renal growth
Value: decreased additional growth of a kidney upon removal of the other kidney through surgery or disease

Subject: increased intestinal adenocarcinoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of a malignant neoplasm of epithelial cells in the intestine

Subject: cerebral aqueductal stenosis
Value: the most common form of obstructive hydrocephaly and results from narrowing of the aqueduct of Sylvius, which connects the third and fourth ventricles

Subject: increased urine microalbumin level
Value: greater than the normal amount of microalbumin in the urine

Subject: decreased urine microalbumin level
Value: less than the normal amount of microalbumin in the urine

Subject: abnormal axon guidance
Value: defect in the signaling mechanisms that allow precise navigation and connections of axonal growth cones to effector tissues

Subject: increased urine protein level
Value: greater than the normal amount of proteins in the urine

Subject: decreased urine protein level
Value: less than the normal amount of proteins in the urine

Subject: aortic elastic tissue lesions
Value: focal pathological changes in the elastic lamella of the main trunk of the arterial system

Subject: increased circulating serum albumin level
Value: blood serum albumin concentration above the normal range

Subject: decreased circulating alkaline phosphatase level
Value: reduced concentration in the blood of the enzyme which hydrolyzes orthophosphoric monoesters

Subject: increased circulating alkaline phosphatase level
Value: elevated concentration in the blood of the enzyme which hydrolyzes orthophosphoric monoesters

Subject: impaired social transmission of food preference
Value: defect in the ability to recall and prefer foods associated with odors recently smelled on the breath of other mice; an indicator of defects in learning and memory of olfactory cues

Subject: abnormal white adipose tissue morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the connective tissue consisting of fat-storing cells and arranged in lobular groups or along minor blood vessels

Subject: abnormal brown adipose tissue morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thermogenic form of adipose tissue that is composed of brown adipocytes

Subject: abnormal cardiac muscle contractility
Value: altered ability of the heart muscle to shorten or to develop increased tension, often measured by dP/dT max, fractional shortening (FS), velocity of circumferential fiber shortening (Vcfc), peak of aortic outflow velocity (PAV), and ventricular ejection fraction volume

Subject: vascular smooth muscle hypertrophy
Value: increase in size or thickness of the smooth muscle of the vascular wall

Subject: vascular smooth muscle hypotrophy
Value: decrease in size or thickness of the smooth muscle of the vascular wall

Subject: absent otoliths
Value: absence of the crystalline calciferous particles adhering to the otolithic membrane

Subject: abnormal postural reflex
Value: any anomaly in the responses that control the normal position of the trunk and extremities and/or posture

Subject: increased liver weight
Value: a greater than average weight of the bile-secreting exocrine gland

Subject: abnormal primordial germ cell migration
Value: any anomaly in the orderly movement of a primordial germ cell, a cell specialized to produce haploid gametes, from one site to another during development

Subject: increased retinal ganglion cell number
Value: greater number of ganglion neurons located in the innermost nuclear layer of the retina of that receive visual information from photoreceptors via various intermediate cells such as bipolar cells, amacrine cells, and horizontal cells; axons from these cells form the optic nerve and connect mainly to the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) and to the suprachiasmatic nucleus in the brain

Subject: retina hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, in the thin layer of neural tissue lining the back of the eyeball which contains visual receptors

Subject: abnormal urine calcium level
Value: any change in the amount of calcium in the urine

Subject: decreased urine calcium level
Value: abnormally low amounts of calcium in the urine

Subject: abnormal urine osmolality
Value: changes in the amount of ions in the urine compared to the normal state

Subject: decreased urine osmolality
Value: reduction in the amount of ions in the urine compared to the normal state

Subject: small kidney
Value: reduced physical bulk one or both of the organs responsible for urine secretion

Subject: short ureter
Value: reduced length of the tube that conducts the urine from the renal pelvis to the bladder

Subject: abnormal sebaceous gland physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the holocrine glands that secrete sebum into the hair follicles or in hairless areas into ducts

Subject: abnormal sebaceous lipid secretion
Value: abnormal function of the sebaceous gland resulting in changes to the lipid profile secreted onto the hair and skin

Subject: arthritis
Value: autoimmune joint inflammation, marked by changes in the synovial membranes and thickening of articular structures, widespread degeneration of the collagen fibers in connective tissues, and by atrophy and rarefaction of bony structures

Subject: primary sex reversal
Value: gonad type is not consistent with chromosomal sex

Subject: ovotestis
Value: state in which a single recognizable gonad contains both testicular and ovarian tissue

Subject: enlarged seminal vesicle
Value: increased size of one of the two folded, sac shaped, glands that is a diverticulum of the ductus deferens

Subject: abnormal bone remodeling
Value: aberrant process of the continuous turnover of bone matrix and mineral that involves a balance of resorption and reactive bone formation by osteoclasts and osteoblasts, respectively

Subject: abnormal bone healing
Value: defects in the restoration of integrity to bone after trauma

Subject: abnormal hippocampal fimbria morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the flattened band of efferent fibers arising from the subiculum and medial border of the hippocampus, which then thickens to form the fornix and fibers of the hippocampal commissure

Subject: abnormal hippocampal fornix morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the compact, white, heavily myelinated fiber bundle arising from the Ammon horn of the hippocampus in each cerebral hemisphere and projecting to the hypothalamus and the mammillary body

Subject: ectopic thymus
Value: ectopic location of the thymus primordium, which normally resides in the superior mediastinum and lower part of the neck

Subject: enhanced long term potentiation
Value: greater than the normal persistent robust synaptic response induced by synchronous stimulation of pre- and postsynaptic cells

Subject: abnormal cytokine secretion
Value: anomaly in the production or cellular release of any of the non-antibody proteins made by inflammatory leukocytes and some non-leukocytic cells that affect the behavior of other cells

Subject: decreased mortality induced by ionizing radiation
Value: reduced sensitivity to lethal doses of ionizing radiation such as ultraviolet light, X-rays, or gamma rays

Subject: delayed dark adaptation
Value: increase in time required for the eye to recover its sensitivity in the dark following exposure to bright lights

Subject: no phenotypic analysis
Value: no description of morphological, physiological or behavioral information presented

Subject: abnormal kidney medulla morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the inner portion of the kidney consisting of the renal pyramids

Subject: abnormal circulating bicarbonate level
Value: aberrant concentration of inorganic salts that contain the -HCO3 radical in the circulation, which are an important factor in regulating the pH of the blood

Subject: increased circulating bicarbonate level
Value: elevated concentration of inorganic salts that contain the -HCO3 radical in the circulation, which are an important factor in regulating the pH of the blood

Subject: decreased circulating bicarbonate level
Value: reduced concentration of inorganic salts that contain the -HCO3 radical in the circulation, which are an important factor in regulating the pH of the blood

Subject: abnormal circulating chloride level
Value: aberrant chloride concentration in the blood

Subject: increased circulating chloride level
Value: elevated chloride concentration in the blood

Subject: decreased circulating chloride level
Value: reduced chloride concentration in the blood

Subject: abnormal coronary flow rate
Value: aberrant rate of blood flow in the blood vessels supplying the heart

Subject: increased coronary flow rate
Value: elevated rate of blood flow in the blood vessels supplying the heart

Subject: decreased coronary flow rate
Value: reduced rate of blood flow in the blood vessels supplying the heart

Subject: coronary artery stenosis
Value: constriction or narrowing of any of the blood vessels supplying the heart

Subject: increased vasoconstriction
Value: greater ability to constrict the nonstriated, involuntary muscle tissue of the blood vessels

Subject: decreased vasoconstriction
Value: reduced ability to constrict the nonstriated, involuntary muscle tissue of the blood vessels

Subject: abnormal blood pH regulation
Value: anomaly in the function of the buffer systems of the blood in combination with the respiratory and renal systems that control the relative acidity or alkalinity of the blood, as measured by the concentration of the hydrogen ion

Subject: alkalosis
Value: a pathological condition characterized by a decrease in the hydrogen ion concentration in tissues and in blood; caused by an increase in the concentration of alkaline compounds, or by a decrease in the concentration of acidic compounds or carbon dioxide to the body fluids

Subject: alkalemia
Value: decreased concentration of H-ion in the blood or a rise in pH in the arterial blood

Subject: acidemia
Value: increased concentration of H-ion in the blood or a fall below normal in pH in the arterial blood

Subject: acidosis
Value: a pathological state characterized by an increase in the hydrogen ion concentration in tissues and blood caused by an decrease in the concentration of alkaline compounds, or by a increase in the concentration of acidic compounds or carbon dioxide to the body fluids

Subject: hypocapnia
Value: reduced concentration of CO2 in the blood, alveoli or other tissues resulting in the decreased pressure of this component of body gases

Subject: abnormal pulmonary vascular resistance
Value: deviation from the normal force opposing blood flow in the lung blood vessels

Subject: increased pulmonary vascular resistance
Value: greater than the normal force opposing blood flow in the lung blood vessels

Subject: decreased pulmonary vascular resistance
Value: less than the normal force opposing blood flow in the lung blood vessels

Subject: vertebral transformation
Value: homeotic transformation of a specific vertebrae to adopt the fate of another

Subject: increased myocardial infarction size
Value: increased size of necrotic area from normal of the myocardium resulting from a sudden insufficiency of arterial or venous blood supply due to emboli, thrombi or mechanical factors

Subject: decreased myocardial infarction size
Value: decreased size of necrotic area from normal of the myocardium resulting from a sudden insufficiency of arterial or venous blood supply due to emboli, thrombi or mechanical factors

Subject: increased time of peak ischemic contracture
Value: increased duration of time from normal necessary to achieve full irreversible contraction of the cardiac muscle in response to myocardial infarction

Subject: decreased time of peak ischemic contracture
Value: decreased duration of time from normal necessary to achieve full irreversible contraction of the cardiac muscle in response to myocardial infarction

Subject: increased time of onset of induced ischemic contracture
Value: increased duration of time from normal necessary to initiate the irreversible contraction of the cardiac muscle in response to induced myocardial infarction

Subject: decreased time of onset of induced ischemic contracture
Value: decreased duration of time from normal necessary to initiate the irreversible contraction of the cardiac muscle in response to induced myocardial infarction

Subject: hypoalgesia
Value: decreased sensitivity to painful stimuli; can be due to chemical intervention, neuropathies or due to damage to soft tissue containing nociceptors or injury to a peripheral nerve; it can be primary (at the site of the injury) or secondary (in the surrounding undamaged area)

Subject: impaired basement membrane formation
Value: defect in the development of the extracellular supportive tissue closely adjacent to the basal surface of the epithelium of muscle cells, fat cells and Schwann cells, which is comprised of type IV collagen, laminin, and sulfated proteoglycans and other components

Subject: obsolete fibrosis
Value: invasion of fibrous connective tissue into any organ or multiple organs, often resulting from inflammation or injury

Subject: liver cirrhosis
Value: liver disease in which the occurrence of fibrotic nodules cause diffuse damage to parenchymal cells, disruptions in microcirculation, vascular anatomy and hepatic architecture, resulting in hepatic dysfunction and ultimately, hepatic failure

Subject: abnormal thoracic vertebrae morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any or all of the thirteen bony segments of the spine located anterior to the lumbar vertebrae and posterior to the cervical vertebrae

Subject: abnormal cervical vertebrae morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any or all of the seven bony segments of the spine located anterior to the thoracic vertebrae and caudal to the skull

Subject: abnormal lumbar vertebrae morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any or all of the six bony segments of the spine located anterior to the sacral vertebrae and posterior to the thoracic vertebrae

Subject: abnormal sacral vertebrae morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any or all of the bony segments of the spine located posterior to the lumbar vertebrae and anterior to the caudal vertebrae

Subject: curly tail
Value: a loop or corkscrew-like curl in the tail

Subject: omphalocele
Value: protrusion of abdominal viscera at the base of the umbilical cord, with a covering membranous sac of peritoneum-amnion, that is caused by a severe body wall defect

Subject: delayed tooth eruption
Value: postponed onset of the growth of the teeth out of the gums

Subject: spina bifida
Value: common congenital midline defect of fusion of the vertebral arch

Subject: abnormal long bone epiphyseal plate morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cartilaginous center of ossification located at one or both ends of bones between the epiphysis (end) and the diaphysis (shaft) of long bones; longitudinal growth of the bone occurs at the plate during development in children and juveniles

Subject: abnormal hyoid bone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the U-shaped bone lying between the mandible and the larynx that supports the tongue muscles

Subject: abnormal epicardium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the visceral layer of the pericardium that surrounds and attaches to all the surfaces of the heart

Subject: increased insulin secretion
Value: greater production or release of this hormone secreted by beta cells of the pancreas, that promotes glucose utilization, protein synthesis, and the formation and storage of neutral lipids

Subject: decreased insulin secretion
Value: reduction in the production or release of the hormone secreted by beta cells of the pancreas that promotes glucose utilization, protein synthesis, and the formation and storage of neutral lipids

Subject: increased aerobic running capacity
Value: greater ability to run at defined speeds and/or distances compared to controls

Subject: decreased aerobic running capacity
Value: reduced ability to run at defined speeds and/or distances compared to controls

Subject: abnormal coping response
Value: altered ability to respond productively to a stressful situation or stimulus, or failure to seek pleasurable stimuli

Subject: increased coping response
Value: enhanced ability to respond productively to a stressful situation

Subject: decreased coping response
Value: reduced ability to respond productively to a stressful situation

Subject: abnormal liver copper level
Value: anomaly in the amount of copper present in the liver tissue

Subject: increased liver copper level
Value: a greater accumulation of copper in the liver tissue compared to controls

Subject: decreased liver copper level
Value: a reduced amount of copper in the liver tissue compared to controls

Subject: enlarged kidney
Value: larger than average size of the kidney

Subject: abnormal superior semicircular canal morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the upper, superior segment of the long bony tube of the labyrinth that is involved in the sense of balance

Subject: increased vascular permeability
Value: greater or faster ability of the blood vessels to permit the passage of substances such as fluid, heat, or gases

Subject: decreased vascular permeability
Value: reduced or slower ability of the blood vessels to permit the passage of substances such as fluid, heat, or gases

Subject: abnormal metatarsal bone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the five bones of the hindpaws/feet that articulate proximally with the cuneiform and cuboid bones of the tarsus and distally with the phalanges

Subject: abnormal metacarpal bone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the five bones of the forepaws/hands that articulate proximally with the carpal bones and distally with the phalanges

Subject: absent metacarpal bones
Value: missing all of the five bones of the forepaws/hands that articulate proximally with the carpal bones and distally with the phalanges

Subject: altered response to CNS ischemic injury
Value: altered response to lack of adequate blood flow, due to trauma or disease, to support the normal functioning of a tissue in the central nervous system

Subject: increased susceptibility to ischemic brain injury
Value: increased frequency or more severe response, such as necrotic tissue size, to lack of adequate blood flow, due to trauma or disease, to support the normal functioning of all or part of the brain tissue, compared to controls

Subject: abnormal cell cycle
Value: failure to progress or abnormal progression through the stages of the cell cycle

Subject: aphakia
Value: absence of the crystalline lens of the eye

Subject: decreased susceptibility to induced joint inflammation
Value: reduced or absent inflammatory response in the joints due to chemical or mechanical agents

Subject: increased natural killer cell mediated cytotoxicity
Value: increased ability of directed killing of a target cell by a natural killer cell through the release of granules containing cytotoxic mediators or through the engagement of death receptors

Subject: abnormal soleus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the superficial flat broad muscle of the calf that is responsible for plantar flexion of the foot

Subject: abnormal gastrocnemius morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the two-headed large muscle of the posterior portion of the lower hindleg, the most superficial of the calf muscles

Subject: abnormal tibialis anterior morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the muscle of the shin that is responsible for dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot

Subject: abnormal skeletal muscle fiber morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the skeletal muscle fibers, the large multinucleated cells that make up the skeletal muscles

Subject: abnormal egg cylinder morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the transient cup-like structure of the epiblast that consists of a single layer of embryonic cells

Subject: hydromyelia
Value: increased fluid in the central canal of the spinal cord

Subject: absent allantois
Value: missing fetal membrane which contributes to the formation of the umbilical cord and placenta

Subject: abnormal prepulse inhibition
Value: anomaly in the ability of a relatively mild stimulus to suppress the response to a strong, startle-eliciting stimulus

Subject: decreased skin tensile strength
Value: reduction in the normal maximum tension the skin can withstand without tearing

Subject: abnormal muscle precursor cell migration
Value: defects in the movement of cells that will develop into muscle cells out of the somites and/or to the appropriate location in the body

Subject: abnormal cell migration
Value: any anomaly in the movement of cells from one site to another, often occurring during developmental or chemotactic processes

Subject: decreased corneal stroma thickness
Value: reduced width of the lamellated connective tissue layer of the cornea

Subject: abnormal cornea anterior stroma morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anterior segment of the lamellated connective tissue layer of the cornea

Subject: abnormal cornea posterior stroma morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the posterior segment of the lamellated connective tissue layer of the cornea

Subject: abnormal corneal stroma development
Value: anomalous differentiation of the lamellated connective tissue layer of the cornea

Subject: increased corneal light-scattering
Value: anomaly in the normal transmission of light through the cornea; light is reflected or absorbed instead; often due to anomalies in the arrangement of lamella in the corneal stroma

Subject: abnormal tendon stiffness
Value: altered ability of tendon to maintain tensile strength and load

Subject: decreased tendon stiffness
Value: reduced ability of tendon to maintain tensile strength and load

Subject: retinal detachment
Value: detachment of the retina from the underlying inner wall of the eye, often from tension of the vitreous; may occur with aging or as a result of trauma

Subject: myopia
Value: optical condition in which only rays from a finite distance from the eye focus on the retina

Subject: high myopia
Value: an optical condition involving enlarging of the eye, scleral thinning and frequent detachment of the retina resulting from stress associated with excessive axial elongation

Subject: sclera thinning
Value: reduction in the width of the fibrous, outer envelope of the eyeball, the sclera may appear blue as a result of the underlying epithelium showing through

Subject: liver degeneration
Value: deterioration of the liver due to injury or disease, often accompanied by loss of function

Subject: acrania
Value: complete or partial absence of a skull; usually associated with anencephaly

Subject: abnormal heart atrium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of one or both of the two upper chambers of the heart, to which the blood returns from the circulation

Subject: abnormal fear-related response
Value: altered emotional response related to anticipation of specific pain or danger

Subject: abnormal response to novelty
Value: alteration in amount of exploration/investigation of a novel object, situation or environment

Subject: short zygomatic bone
Value: reduced length of the bone that forms the prominence of the cheek

Subject: short femur
Value: reduced length of the long bone of the thigh

Subject: absent malleus processus brevis
Value: absence of the short projection extending from the base of the manubrium of the malleus which contacts the upper part of the tympanic membrane where the tympanic cavity makes a deep pocket (epitympanic pocket) surrounding the cartilaginous nodule

Subject: abnormal cell nucleus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a membrane-bounded organelle of eukaryotic cells in which chromosomes are housed and replicated; in most cells, the nucleus contains all of the cell's chromosomes except the organellar chromosomes, and is the site of RNA synthesis and processing, but in some species, or in specialized cell types, RNA metabolism or DNA replication may be absent

Subject: enlarged parathyroid gland
Value: increased size of the two small, paired endocrine glands, usually found embedded in the connective tissue capsule on the posterior surface of the thyroid gland; they secrete parathyroid hormone (PTH) that regulates calcium and phosphorous metabolism

Subject: small parathyroid gland
Value: decreased size of the two small, paired endocrine glands, usually found embedded in the connective tissue capsule on the posterior surface of the thyroid gland; they secrete parathyroid hormone (PTH) that regulates calcium and phosphorous metabolism

Subject: pigmented parathyroid gland
Value: presence of melanocytes and/or melanin in either of the two small, paired endocrine glands, usually found embedded in the connective tissue capsule on the posterior surface of the thyroid gland; they secrete parathyroid hormone (PTH) that regulates calcium and phosphorous metabolism

Subject: abnormal respiratory system development
Value: aberrant differentiation of pulmonary tissues

Subject: rickets
Value: overproduction and deficient calcification of osteoid tissue due to vitamin D deficiency; can lead to skeletal deformities, growth defects, hypocalcemia, and sometimes tetany; skeletal fractures occur frequently

Subject: abnormal digestive system development
Value: abnormal formation of the organ system that converts ingested food to nutrients and energy

Subject: abnormal tracheal cartilage morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cartilaginous structures that support the trachea

Subject: genetic imprinting
Value: any anomaly in the process that modulates the frequency, rate or extent of the chemical reactions and pathways involving macromolecules by a mechanism that is mediated by DNA, is mitotically or meiotically heritable, or is stably self-propagated in the cytoplasm of a resting cell, and does not entail a change in DNA sequence

Subject: maternal imprinting
Value: the establishment of heritable alterations in the activity of a gene that depend on whether it passed through the maternal germline, but that are not encoded by DNA itself

Subject: paternal imprinting
Value: establishment of heritable alterations in the activity of a gene that depend on whether it passed through the paternal germline, but that are not encoded by DNA itself

Subject: hypospadia
Value: a urethral opening located below the normal location; in males, the abnormally placed opening is usually on the ventral surface of the penis, and in females, the abnormally placed opening is usually in the vagina

Subject: abnormal septation of the cloaca
Value: absence of or reduction in the separation of the single opening of the digestive, urinary, and reproductive tracts (cloaca) into multiple isolated openings during development, may result in hypospadia, reduced anogenital distance, or persistent cloaca

Subject: abnormal external female genitalia morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the external feminine genital organs, collectively known as the vulva and composed of the mons pubis, the labia majora and minora, the clitoris, the vestibule of the vagina and its glands, and the opening of the urethra and of the vagina

Subject: abnormal clitoris morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small, erectile body located at the anterior end of the vulva

Subject: splayed clitoris
Value: flattened or spread out clitoris

Subject: persistent cloaca
Value: persistence of an early embryonic state in which the urinary, genital, and gastrointestinal tracts remain confluent and communicate with the exterior through a single perineal opening; due to failure of the urogenital septum to divide the embryonic cloaca into rectal and urogenital portions

Subject: anal atresia
Value: congenital absence of an anal opening due to the persistence of the epithelial plug (persistence of the anal membrane) or to complete absence of the anal canal

Subject: increased erythrocyte cell number
Value: greater number of the cells that transport oxygen, red blood cells, per unit

Subject: increased pre-B cell number
Value: greater number of progenitor cells that form the B cell component of the immune system

Subject: increased early pro-B cell number
Value: greater number of cells in the B lymphocyte lineage that undergo D-J rearrangement of the immunoglobulin heavy chain

Subject: increased late pro-B cell number
Value: greater number of the cells in the B lymphocyte lineage that undergo V-DJ rearrangement of the immunoglobulin heavy chain

Subject: increased erythroid progenitor cell number
Value: greater numbers of progenitors of the erythrocyte lineage

Subject: yellow coat color
Value: amount and distribution of yellow pigment (phaeomelanin) relative to black or brown pigment (eumelanin) is maximally increased in agouti hair

Subject: abnormal impulse conducting system conduction
Value: any functional anomaly in the impulse-conducting system composed of modified cardiac muscle and having the power of spontaneous rhythmicity and conduction more highly developed than the rest of the heart

Subject: absent tympanic ring
Value: missing the bony ring at the ear canal to which the tympanic membrane is attached

Subject: patent ductus arteriosus
Value: failure of the fetal connection between the aorta and pulmonary artery to close after birth

Subject: dilated heart atrium
Value: the luminal space of one or both of the upper chambers of the heart is increased in volume or area, usually with an increase of contained fluid

Subject: cardiac fibrosis
Value: formation of fibrous tissue within the heart often resulting from inflammation or injury

Subject: anotia
Value: congenital absence of one or both auricles of the ears

Subject: enlarged otoliths
Value: increased average size of the crystalline calciferous particles adhering to the otolithic membrane

Subject: decreased otolith number
Value: reduced average number of the crystalline calciferous particles adhering to the otolithic membrane

Subject: detached otolithic membrane
Value: the otolithic (otoconial) membrane is abnormally detached from the underlying neuroepithelium

Subject: absent cochlear ganglion
Value: absence of the group of nerve cell bodies that conveys auditory sensation from the organ of Corti to the hindbrain and resides on the cochlear part of the vestibulocochlear nerve (eighth cranial nerve)

Subject: absent cochlea
Value: absence or agenesis of the spiral-shaped bony canal in the inner ear containing the hair cells that transduce sound

Subject: decreased cochlear coiling
Value: a reduction in cochlear coiling or number of turns; in wild-type mice, the cochlea most commonly exhibits one and three-fourth turns

Subject: abnormal tectorial membrane morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the overlaying membrane of cochlear duct, an extracellular matrix of the inner ear that contacts the stereocilia bundles of specialized sensory hair cells; sound induces movement of these hair cells relative to the tectorial membrane, deflects the stereocilia, and leads to fluctuations in hair cell membrane potential, transducing sound into electrical signals

Subject: detached tectorial membrane
Value: tectorial membrane is abnormally detached from the cochlear epithelium or spiral limbus

Subject: absent tunnel of Corti
Value: complete absence of the triangular, fluid-filled space normally found between the inner and outer rows of supporting pillar cells in the organ of Corti

Subject: abnormal pillar cell differentiation
Value: abnormal differentiation of the supporting cells that form the inner and outer walls of the tunnel in the organ of Corti

Subject: early eyelid opening
Value: early average time for the first postnatal eye opening

Subject: abnormal soft palate morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the musculomembranous fold that partly separates the mouth and pharynx, located behind the hard palate in the adult

Subject: abnormal telomere length
Value: abnormal length of the terminal repetitive DNA section of a chromosome that is involved in chromosomal replication and senescence and protects the end of the chromosome from deterioration; normal length is a few hundred base pairs

Subject: abnormal leukocyte migration
Value: altered ability of blood leukocytes to move within or between different tissues and organs of the body by binding to high endothelial venules (HEV), then tethering and rolling along the luminal aspects of HEV

Subject: impaired muscle relaxation
Value: reduced or absent ability of muscle to lengthen following contractions

Subject: dysphagia
Value: difficulty in swallowing food or liquid

Subject: abnormal esophageal smooth muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the nonstriated, involuntary muscle tissue lining the esophagus

Subject: abnormal esophagus development
Value: aberrant formation of the part of the digestive canal through which food passes from the pharynx to the stomach

Subject: absent lateral semicircular canal
Value: absence of the lateral long bony tube of the labyrinth that is involved in the sense of balance

Subject: decreased lateral semicircular canal size
Value: small size of the lateral long bony tube of the labyrinth that is involved in the sense of balance

Subject: absent posterior semicircular canal
Value: absence of the posterior segment of the long bony tube of the labyrinth that is involved in the sense of balance

Subject: decreased posterior semicircular canal size
Value: small size of the posterior segment of the long bony tube of the labyrinth that is involved in the sense of balance

Subject: absent superior semicircular canal
Value: absence of the upper, superior segment of the long bony tube of the labyrinth that is involved in the sense of balance

Subject: decreased superior semicircular canal size
Value: small size of the upper, superior segment of the long bony tube of the labyrinth that is involved in the sense of balance

Subject: abnormal scala tympani morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the division of the spiral canal of the cochlea lying on the basal side of the spiral lamina

Subject: abnormal scala vestibuli morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the division of the spiral canal of the cochlea lying on the apical side of the spiral lamina and vestibular membrane

Subject: abnormal scala media morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the division of the spiral canal of the cochlea that contains the organ of Corti (the neuroepithelial receptor organ for hearing)

Subject: phenotypic reversion
Value: wild-type phenotype restored from a previously characterized mutant phenotype

Subject: abnormal lysosome physiology
Value: ability of lysosomes to produce enzymes necessary for digestion of exogenous material is impaired

Subject: decreased lysosomal enzyme secretion
Value: production or release of glycoprotein hydrolytic enzymes is decreased compared to normal

Subject: increased lysosomal enzyme secretion
Value: production or secretion of glycoprotein hydrolytic enzymes is increased compared to normal

Subject: reversion by mitotic recombination
Value: cross-over event between sequences containing mutant and wild-type alleles during DNA replication in a heterozygote resulting in cells with two wild-type alleles

Subject: reversion by viral sequence excision
Value: restoration of wild-type phenotype by removal of a viral sequence or a viral- related sequence that produced a mutant phenotype

Subject: allodynia
Value: condition in which nonpainful stimuli evoke a pain sensation

Subject: left pulmonary isomerism
Value: anomaly in the asymmetry of the lung such that the lobes on both the left and right side have the morphology normally seen on the left side of the body

Subject: thrombocytopenia
Value: fewer than the normal numbers of the non-nucleated cells found in the blood and involved in blood coagulation

Subject: abnormal pulmonary endothelial cell surface
Value: altered morphology or area of the semipermeable membrane that encloses the cytoplasm of a pulmonary endothelial cell

Subject: increased pulmonary endothelial cell surface
Value: increased total area of the semipermeable membrane that encloses the cytoplasm of a pulmonary endothelial cell

Subject: decreased pulmonary endothelial cell surface
Value: reduced total area of the semipermeable membrane that encloses the cytoplasm of a pulmonary endothelial cell

Subject: obsolete abnormal peptide metabolism
Value: anomaly in the biochemical modification and homeostasis of molecules consisting of linked amino acids and their derivatives

Subject: increased angiotensin I-converting enzyme activity
Value: greater activity of the exopeptidase that catalyses the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II, a potent vasoconstrictor, and is also involved in the inactivation of bradykinin

Subject: decreased angiotensin I-converting enzyme activity
Value: reduced activity of the exopeptidase that catalyses the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II, a potent vasoconstrictor, and is also involved in the inactivation of bradykinin

Subject: abnormal redox activity
Value: defect in the processes that maintain the redox environment of a cell or compartment within a cell

Subject: fused joints
Value: partial or complete absence of a functional articulation point of two or more bones

Subject: fused synovial joints
Value: partial or complete absence of separations containing synovial fluid between bones

Subject: abnormal cellular cholesterol metabolism
Value: impaired regulation of cellular cholesterol levels

Subject: increased cholesterol efflux
Value: greater level of removal of excess cholesterol from cells by an active transport pathway

Subject: decreased cholesterol efflux
Value: reduced level of removal of excess cholesterol from cells by an active transport pathway

Subject: abnormal frequency of paradoxical sleep
