Value: abnormal incidence or duration of the sleep stage in which dreams occur and the body undergoes marked changes including rapid eye movement, loss of reflexes, and increased pulse rate and brain activity

Subject: calcinosis
Value: pathologic deposition of calcium salts in tissues

Subject: calcified skin
Value: pathologic deposition of calcium salts in the skin

Subject: nephrocalcinosis
Value: diffusely scattered foci of calcification in the renal parenchyma, with microscopic or macroscopic deposits of calcium salts

Subject: calcified tendon
Value: pathologic deposition of calcium salts in the tendons

Subject: calcified muscle
Value: pathologic deposition of calcium salts in muscle

Subject: calcified joint
Value: pathologic deposition of calcium salts in the joints

Subject: extremity edema
Value: an accumulation of serous fluid in the limbs, paws and tail

Subject: abnormal neuron apoptosis
Value: change in the timing or the number of neurons undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: increased neuron apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of neurons undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: decreased neuron apoptosis
Value: decrease in the number of neurons undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: testicular atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of the testis associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: decreased cellular sensitivity to gamma-irradiation
Value: decreased incidence of cell death following exposure to gamma-irradiation

Subject: abnormal neuromere morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the segments of the developing neural tube

Subject: abnormal pulmonary elastic fiber morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a slender connective tissue fiber in pulmonary tissue characterized by great elasticity

Subject: abnormal heart elastic fiber morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the slender connective tissue fiber in cardiac tissue characterized by great elasticity

Subject: abnormal aorta elastic fiber morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the slender connective tissue fiber in aortic tissue characterized by great elasticity

Subject: increased susceptibility to age related obesity
Value: increased probability of excessive weight gain that is progressive with age

Subject: decreased susceptibility to age related obesity
Value: reduced probability of excessive weight gain that is progressive with age

Subject: neurofibrillary tangles
Value: dense intraneuronal accumulations of helical filaments (neurofilaments and microtubules) that assume twisted contorted patterns; found in subclasses of cells of the neocortex, hippocampus, brain stem, and diencephalon in individuals with Alzheimer disease and other tauopathies

Subject: renal interstitial fibrosis
Value: formation of fibrous tissue within the functional space in the kidney beneath the individual filters (glomeruli) as a result of repair or a reactive process

Subject: absence seizures
Value: impairment of consciousness without convulsions associated with sudden behavioral arrest and widespread bilaterally synchronous spike-and-wave discharges (SWDs) in the electroencephalogram (EEG)

Subject: increased spike-wave discharge type I
Value: increase in one type of epileptiformic electroencephalographic (EEG) activity detected in generalized absence epilepsy, characterized by immediate, bilaterally symmetric discharges, generalized over the cortex and lasting longer than spike-wave discharge type II

Subject: decreased spike-wave discharge type I
Value: decrease in one type of epileptiformic electroencephalographic (EEG) activity detected in generalized absence epilepsy, characterized by immediate, bilaterally symmetric discharges, generalized over the cortex and lasting longer than Spike-wave discharge type II

Subject: increased spike-wave discharge type II
Value: increase in one type of epileptiformic electroencephalographic (EEG) activity detected in generalized absence epilepsy, characterized by local occipital-parietal discharges that are shorter and have less clear waves than spike-wave discharge type I

Subject: decreased spike-wave discharge type II
Value: decrease in one type of epileptiformic electroencephalographic (EEG) activity detected in generalized absence epilepsy, characterized by local occipital-parietal discharges that are shorter and have less clear waves than spike-wave discharge type I

Subject: abnormal cardiomyocyte apoptosis
Value: change in the timing or the number of cardiac muscle cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: increased cardiomyocyte apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of cardiac muscle cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: decreased cardiomyocyte apoptosis
Value: decrease in the number of cardiac muscle cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: neuron degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of the functional cells of the nervous system that receive, conduct, and transmit impulses

Subject: axonal dystrophy
Value: axon degeneration that may result from genetic abnormalities or inadequate or faulty metabolism

Subject: absent cochlear modiolus
Value: absence of the central cone shaped core of spongy bone about which turns the spiral canal

Subject: abnormal vascular branching morphogenesis
Value: increase, decrease or anomaly in the process by which new vessels sprout off pre-existing vessels

Subject: abnormal sinus venosus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cavity at the caudal end of the embryonic cardiac tube in which the veins from the intra- and extraembryonic circulatory arcs unite; in the adult this becomes the portion of the right atrium known as the sinus of the vena cava

Subject: abnormal vitelline vasculature morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the vascular network that supplies the yolk sac

Subject: abnormal umbilical artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the paired arteries that bring unoxygenated blood back to the placenta from the dorsal aorta through the umbilical cord

Subject: abnormal placenta vasculature
Value: any structural anomaly of the vessels of the placenta

Subject: abnormal forebrain development
Value: anomaly in the formation or patterning of the anterior of the three primary divisions of the developing chordate brain or the corresponding part of the adult brain (in vertebrates, includes especially the cerebral hemispheres, the thalamus, and the hypothalamus and especially in higher vertebrates is the main control center for sensory and associative information processing, visceral functions, and voluntary motor functions)

Subject: prolonged QT interval
Value: increase in the length of time required for ventricular depolarization and repolarization to occur, usually as a result of increased repolarization time, and is measured from the beginning of the QRS complex to the end of the T wave

Subject: enhanced NMDA-mediated synaptic currents
Value: increase in the measured amplitude, current density or duration of response to stimulation of NMDA receptors

Subject: abnormal alisphenoid bone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of either of the broad curved wing like expanses on each side of the sphenoid bone in adults; may exist independently in the young

Subject: abnormal lens capsule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the elastic, clear, membrane-like structure, that is outer most layer of the lens

Subject: abnormal lens epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the one or more of the layers of epithelial cells in the lens

Subject: slow REM
Value: decreased rapid, periodic, jerky movement of the eyes from average during certain stages of the sleep cycle when dreaming takes place

Subject: fast REM
Value: increased rapid, periodic, jerky movement of the eyes from average during certain stages of the sleep cycle when dreaming takes place

Subject: loss of hippocampal neurons
Value: loss of neurons in the hippocampal region of the brain, commonly due to an apoptotic event

Subject: loss of cortex neurons
Value: loss of neurons in the cortex region of the brain, commonly due to an apoptotic event

Subject: loss of basal ganglia neurons
Value: loss of neurons in the basal ganglia of the brain, commonly due to an apoptotic event

Subject: abnormal dopaminergic neuron morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the neurons that utilize dopamine as a neurotransmitter

Subject: loss of dopaminergic neurons
Value: loss of the neurons that utilize dopamine as a neurotransmitter, commonly due to an apoptotic event

Subject: abnormal GABAergic neuron morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the neurons that utilize gamma-aminobutyric acid as a neurotransmitter

Subject: loss of GABAergic neurons
Value: loss of the neurons that utilize gamma-aminobutyric acid as a neurotransmitter, commonly due to an apoptotic event

Subject: abnormal glutaminergic neuron morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the neurons that utilize glutamate as a neurotransmitter

Subject: loss of glutamate neurons
Value: loss of the neurons that utilize glutamate as a neurotransmitter, commonly due to an apoptotic event

Subject: increased muscle free fatty acids level
Value: greater than normal muscle concentration of the fatty acids which occur in plasma as a result of lipolysis in adipose tissue or when plasma triacylglycerols are taken into tissues

Subject: absent gallbladder
Value: absence of the organ which serves as a storage reservoir for bile

Subject: gallbladder inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the gall bladder

Subject: abnormal bile duct physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the channels that secrete bile from the liver to the gall bladder and intestines

Subject: dilated bile duct
Value: the luminal space of the bile ducts is increased in volume or area, usually with an increase in contained fluid or bile

Subject: bile duct inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the bile ducts

Subject: bile duct proliferation
Value: the appearance of an increased number of bile ducts in the liver; a sign of progressive liver disease

Subject: biliary cirrhosis
Value: liver damage to parenchymal cells due to obstruction of bile flow in the bile ducts

Subject: abnormal abdominal wall morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the margins that enclose the abdominal cavity; the major part is muscular but also includes skin, subcutaneous fat, fascia and the parietal peritoneum

Subject: hiatal hernia
Value: protrusion of abdominal structures through the esophageal hiatus of the diaphragm

Subject: nausea
Value: gastric discomfort associated with the inclination to vomit

Subject: vomiting
Value: the retrograde expulsion of gastric contents through the oral cavity

Subject: hematemesis
Value: vomiting of blood; indicative of bleeding in the upper gastrointestinal tract

Subject: intestinal/bowel diverticulum
Value: a pouch or sac protruding from the intestinal or bowel wall

Subject: biliary cyst
Value: the appearance of fluid-filled sacs within the bile ducts

Subject: constipation
Value: incomplete, infrequent or difficult evacuation of fecal matter

Subject: chronic constipation
Value: prolonged or long-term difficulty in evacuation of fecal matter

Subject: colon polyps
Value: abnormal tissue masses that protrude into the lumen of the colon and are tethered to the wall of the colon

Subject: intestinal obstruction
Value: any impediment, blockage, or reversal of the normal flow of the intestinal contents toward the anus

Subject: abnormal duodenum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the first division of the small intestine that extends from the pyloris to the junction with the jejunum

Subject: duodenal atresia
Value: congenital blockage or absence of the lumen of the duodenum

Subject: duodenal ulcer
Value: a lesion on the mucosal surface of the duodenum, usually produced by the sloughing of inflammatory necrotic tissue

Subject: intestinal microaneurysm
Value: focal dilation of arteriocapillary junctions in the intestine

Subject: gastric microaneurysm
Value: focal dilation of arteriocapillary junctions in the stomach

Subject: esophageal atresia
Value: congenital blockage or absence of the lumen of the esophagus

Subject: increased esophageal papilloma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of a benign epithelial tumor consisting of villous or arborescent outgrowths of fibrovascular stroma of the esophagus

Subject: esophageal inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins and leukocytes in the esophagus

Subject: aneurysm
Value: a protruding sac formed by the dilation of the wall of an artery, a vein, or the heart resulting from a weakening of the vessel wall or heart muscle

Subject: urinary incontinence
Value: inability to control the urinary bladder excretory functions leading to involuntary urination

Subject: fecal incontinence
Value: inability to control the anal sphincter resulting in the involuntary passage of feces

Subject: gastric ulcer
Value: a lesion on the mucosal surface of the stomach, usually produced by the sloughing of inflammatory necrotic tissue

Subject: abnormal digestive organ placement
Value: different location or arrangement of any of the alimentary tract organs

Subject: abnormal large intestine placement
Value: different location or arrangement of the large intestinal tract

Subject: gastric hypertrophy
Value: increase in the bulk size of the stomach due to cell enlargement or accumulation of fluids

Subject: gastroesophageal reflux
Value: retrograde movement of gastric contents into the esophagus

Subject: increased intestinal hemangioma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign tumor characterized by blood-filled spaces lined by benign endothelial cells in the intestines, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: intestinal edema
Value: an accumulation of an excessive amount of serous fluid in the intestine or intestinal cells

Subject: abnormal intestinal peristalsis
Value: altered intestinal movement characterized by waves of alternate circular contraction and relaxation of the muscular walls of the bowel that move bowel contents forward

Subject: intestinal hypoperistalsis
Value: reduced intestinal movement characterized by waves of alternate circular contraction and relaxation of the muscular walls of the bowel that move bowel contents forward

Subject: interstinal hyperperistalsis
Value: increased intestinal movement characterized by waves of alternate circular contraction and relaxation of the muscular walls of the bowel that move bowel contents forward

Subject: melena
Value: dark colored, foul-smelling feces due to the presence of blood

Subject: rectal hemorrhage
Value: bleeding in the rectum

Subject: intussusception
Value: telescoping of the intestine, or the prolapse of one part of the bowel to another; usually results in obstruction

Subject: lymphomesenteric cysts
Value: cystic mass in the abdominal mesenchyme containing lymph; sometimes becomes calcified

Subject: microcolon
Value: small, unused colon in neonates, usually due to atresia or other gastrointestinal blockage

Subject: choking
Value: spasm of the larynx and trachea due to prevention of respiration by compression or obstruction

Subject: gastric polyps
Value: abnormal tissue masses that protrude into the lumen of the stomach and are tethered to the wall of the stomach

Subject: gastrointestinal ulcer
Value: any lesion on the mucosal surface of the gastrointestinal tract, usually produced by the sloughing of inflammatory necrotic tissue

Subject: peptic ulcer
Value: any lesion on the mucosal surface of the portion of the alimentary tract that is exposed to gastric acid, usually in the stomach or the duodenum

Subject: perirectal abscess
Value: acute focal inflammation of the tissues surrounding the rectum, often with accumulation of purulent material

Subject: peritoneal inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the membrane that lines the abdominal cavity and covers most of the viscera

Subject: large intestinal inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the large intestine

Subject: proctitis
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the mucous membrane of the rectum

Subject: small intestinal inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the small intestine

Subject: pyloric stenosis
Value: a narrowing of the gastric outlet of the stomach, often due to muscular hypertrophy or scarring from local inflammation

Subject: abnormal cochlear sensory epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the epithelial cell layer containing the sensory hair cells and their associated sensory nerve terminals

Subject: abnormal cochlear modiolus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the central cone shaped core of spongy bone about which turns the spiral canal

Subject: reduced cochlear modiolus
Value: a reduction in the volume of the central conical bony pillar of the cochlea

Subject: aminoaciduria
Value: excretion of amino acids in the urine, especially in excessive amounts

Subject: abnormal locomotor coordination
Value: reduced ability of an animal to maintain skillful and effective interaction of movements while engaging in behavioral locomotor activity

Subject: abnormal locomotor activation
Value: altered ability or desire of an animal to initiate locomotor activity

Subject: dysmetria
Value: an inability to control the range of motion, typified by under- or over-shooting the intended position with the hand, arm, leg or eye

Subject: abnormal perineum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the area between the genital organs and the anus that lies beneath the pelvic diaphragm

Subject: perineal fistula
Value: an abnormal anatomical passage that connects the perineum to organs such as the bladder or the rectum

Subject: anoperineal fistula
Value: an abnormal anatomical passage that connects the perineum to the anal canal

Subject: rectoperineal fistula
Value: an abnormal anatomical passage that connects the perineum to the rectum

Subject: anal fistula
Value: an abnormal anatomical passage at or near the anus that usually opens into the rectum above the internal sphincter

Subject: rectovaginal fistula
Value: an abnormal anatomical passage connecting the rectum and the vagina

Subject: tracheoesophageal fistula
Value: an abnormal passage is present between the esophagus and the trachea; may be acquired or congenital, and is often associated with esophageal atresia

Subject: biliary fistula
Value: an abnormal anatomical passage that connects any organ of the biliary tract and other organs

Subject: gastrocolic fistula
Value: an abnormal anatomical passage between the stomach and the colon

Subject: increased liver adenoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign epithelial neoplasm with a glandular organization arising in the liver, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: decreased liver function
Value: reduced normal function of this bile-secreting exocrine gland, which is important for detoxification, for fat, carbohydrate, and protein metabolism, and for glycogen storage

Subject: liver failure
Value: cessation of function of this bile-secreting exocrine gland, which is important for detoxification; for fat, carbohydrate, and protein metabolism; and for glycogen storage

Subject: liver cysts
Value: abnormal membranous sacs in any portion of the liver

Subject: portal hypertension
Value: elevation of blood pressure in the hepatic portal vein, often a result of cirrhosis or from obstruction of the portal vein

Subject: amyloid beta deposits
Value: formation of self-assembled aggregates of the cleaved App Abeta protein fragment; often seen in neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimer's disease

Subject: abnormal auditory tube morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the tube connecting the tympanic cavity and the nasopharynx that allows equalization of pressure between the tympanic cavity and the environment

Subject: increased hepatocellular carcinoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a malignant neoplasm arising from liver cells, usually in adults and caused by liver trauma due to disease or injury, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: liver abscess
Value: collection of purulent exudate within the liver as a result of infection by bacteria, protozoa, or other agents

Subject: liver fibrosis
Value: invasion of fibrous connective tissue into the liver, often resulting from inflammation or injury

Subject: pancreas fibrosis
Value: invasion of fibrous connective tissue into the pancreas, often resulting from inflammation or injury

Subject: exocrine pancreatic insufficiency
Value: inadequate synthesis and/or secretion of digestive enzymes by the exocrine portion of the pancreas, usually due to loss of acinar tissue from idiopathic atrophy or acute or chronic inflammation, causing maldigestion and malabsorption of nutrients

Subject: pancreas cysts
Value: the appearance of fluid-filled sacs within the pancreas

Subject: exocrine pancreas hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size of the portion of the pancreas that secretes digestive enzymes, usually due to an increased cell number

Subject: pancreas lipomatosis
Value: an accumulation of abnormally localized or tumor-like fat in the pancreas

Subject: decreased pancreatic beta cell number
Value: fewer than normal number of the cells of the pancreas that secrete insulin

Subject: acute pancreas inflammation
Value: early and often transient reaction of the microcirculation, characterized by movement of fluid and leukocytes from the blood into the pancreas; initiated by injury, infection, or local immune response

Subject: chronic pancreas inflammation
Value: persistent inflammatory response in the pancreas, often caused by persistent infection or during an autoimmune response

Subject: accessory spleen
Value: the splenic tissue is divided into equal masses; often related to situs inversus

Subject: mammary gland hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the mammary gland, usually due to a reduced number of cells

Subject: decreased rib number
Value: fewer than normal numbers of the pairs of bony structures that make up the body wall

Subject: abnormal pectoral muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the two muscles that make up the upper and fore part of the chest that adduct and rotate the arm and lift the ribs

Subject: hyperpituitarism
Value: hypersecretion of adenohypophyseal hormones from the glandular, anterior portion of the pituitary; often due to a functional adenoma

Subject: hypopituitarism
Value: reduction or cessation of secretion of one or more hormones from the anterior pituitary gland; this may result from ablation, tumors, infarction, or other trauma

Subject: abnormal circulating renin level
Value: aberrant blood level of the enzyme which is secreted by the kidney and cleaves a bond in angiotensionogen to generate angiotensin I

Subject: increased circulating levels of thyroid hormone
Value: increased concentration of hormones in the blood that are synthesized and secreted by the thyroid

Subject: decreased circulating levels of thyroid hormone
Value: reduced concentration of hormones in the blood that are synthesized and secreted by the thyroid

Subject: increased circulating renin level
Value: elevated blood level of the enzyme which is secreted by the kidney and cleaves a bond in angiotensionogen to generate angiotensin I

Subject: decreased circulating renin level
Value: reduced blood level of the enzyme which is secreted by the kidney and cleaves a bond in angiotensionogen to generate angiotensin I

Subject: astrocytosis
Value: a proliferation or spread of astrocytes into the area of a degenerative lesion or damaged tissue

Subject: decreased ovulation rate
Value: reduction in the frequency in which an ovum (or ova) is/are released from a rupturing ovarian follicle(s)

Subject: impaired luteinization
Value: atypical transformation of the mature ovarian follicle and its theca interna into a corpus luteum after ovulation

Subject: impaired granulosa cell differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce the supporting cells for the developing female gamete in the ovary of mammals; granulosa cells form a single layer around the mammalian oocyte in the primordial ovarian follicle and advance to form a multilayered cumulus oophorus surrounding the ovum in the Graafian follicle

Subject: abnormal hypaxial muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the muscles derived from the lateral myotome and lateral portion of the dermomyotome; these include the thoracic intercostal and abdominal muscles, limb muscles and superficial back muscles, as well as the diaphragm and the tip of the tongue

Subject: hypaxial muscle hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, in the thoracic intercostal and abdominal muscles, limb muscles and superficial back muscles, as well as the diaphragm and the tip of the tongue

Subject: abnormal depression-related behavior
Value: responses to a stressful situation or stimulus, or failure to seek pleasurable stimuli

Subject: abnormal circulating gonadotropin level
Value: aberrant blood concentration of the peptide hormones that stimulate gonadal functions such as gametogenesis and sex steroid hormone production in the ovary and the testis

Subject: increased circulating gonadotropin level
Value: greater than the normal blood concentration of the peptide hormones that stimulate gonadal functions such as gametogenesis and sex steroid hormone production in the ovary and the testis

Subject: decreased circulating gonadotropin level
Value: less than the normal blood concentration of the peptide hormones that stimulate gonadal functions such as gametogenesis and sex steroid hormone production in the ovary and the testis

Subject: increased insulinoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign epithelial neoplasm with a glandular organization arising in the pancreatic islet beta cells, occurring in a specific population in a given time period; these tumors secrete excess insulin

Subject: increased glucagonoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign epithelial neoplasm with a glandular organization arising in the pancreatic islet alpha cells, occurring in a specific population in a given time period; these tumors secrete excess glucagon

Subject: abnormal circulating glucocorticoid level
Value: aberrant blood concentration of the corticosteroids regulating carbohydrate metabolism and exhibiting anti-inflammatory activity

Subject: increased circulating glucocorticoid level
Value: greater than normal blood concentration of the corticosteroids regulating carbohydrate metabolism and exhibiting anti-inflammatory activity

Subject: decreased circulating glucocorticoid level
Value: less than normal blood concentration of the corticosteroids regulating carbohydrate metabolism and exhibiting anti-inflammatory activity

Subject: abnormal circulating estrogen level
Value: aberration in the blood concentration of any substance that causes development of the female reproductive organs and secondary sexual characteristics

Subject: increased circulating estrogen level
Value: greater than normal blood concentration of any substance that causes development of the female reproductive organs and secondary sexual characteristics

Subject: decreased circulating estrogen level
Value: reduction in the blood concentration of any substance that causes development of the female reproductive organs and secondary sexual characteristics

Subject: abnormal circulating mineralocorticoid level
Value: aberrant blood concentration of corticosteroids that influence water and electrolyte metabolism and balance

Subject: increased circulating mineralocorticoid level
Value: greater than normal blood concentration of corticosteroids that influence water and electrolyte metabolism and balance

Subject: decreased circulating mineralocorticoid level
Value: less than normal blood concentration of corticosteroids that influence water and electrolyte metabolism and balance

Subject: abnormal menstrual cycle
Value: failure of or aberrant timing of a recurring cycle in human primates in which the endometrial lining of the uterus prepares for pregnancy and ovulation occurs; if pregnancy does not occur the lining is discharged at menstruation

Subject: amenorrhea
Value: absence or abnormal cessation of the shedding of the endometrium and associated bleeding in primates

Subject: late onset of menarche
Value: the onset of menstrual cycles occurs at a later age than normal

Subject: early sexual maturation
Value: pubertal changes occur at an earlier than normal age

Subject: absent sexual maturation
Value: failure to initiate pubertal changes that result in achievement of full sexual capacity

Subject: abnormal intestine regeneration
Value: deviation from the normal ability of the intestine to regenerate healthy tissue following injury or disease

Subject: vitreal fibroplasia
Value: production of excess fibrous tissue in the vitreous body of the eye

Subject: straub tail
Value: condition in which an animal carries its tail in an erect (vertical or nearly vertical) position; often seen upon opioid and other drug treatment

Subject: abnormal gluconeogenesis
Value: anomaly in the formation of glucose from non-carbohydrates, such as proteins or fat

Subject: abnormal ventral body wall morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anterior portion of a human body or the lower surface of an animal body comprised of ectoderm and mesoderm layers that encloses the body cavity

Subject: abnormal body wall morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the external portion of an animal body comprised of ectoderm and mesoderm layers that encloses the body cavity

Subject: aorta coarctation
Value: a congenital focal constriction of the aorta most commonly found just distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery; the most commonly found form is juxtaductal coarctation, but it may occur at any point from the transverse arch to the iliac bifurcation

Subject: absent pericardium
Value: absence of the fibroserous membrane covering the heart and beginning of the great vessels

Subject: constriction of pericardium
Value: tightening of the pericardium around the heart

Subject: lymphedema
Value: abnormal swelling in the soft tissues of the limbs, or less often the trunk, caused by the buildup of lymph fluid

Subject: increased myxoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of a benign neoplasm derived from pluripotential mesenchymal stem cells of connective tissue, consisting chiefly of polyhedral and stellate cells that are loosely embedded in a soft mucoid matrix; may show multiple differentiated components

Subject: increased atrial myxoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of a benign neoplasm derived from pluripotential mesenchymal stem cells of either the left or right atrium connective tissue, consisting chiefly of polyhedral and stellate cells that are loosely embedded in a soft mucoid matrix; an increase in primary intracardiac tumor incidence

Subject: decreased cardiac output
Value: reduction in the blood volume pumped by each ventricle per minute

Subject: increased cardiac output
Value: greater than normal blood volume pumped by each ventricle per minute

Subject: abnormal subclavian artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the right or left subclavian arteries; the right subclavian artery normally extends from the brachiocephalic artery to the right side of the body and the left subclavian artery extends from the aortic arch to the left side of the body

Subject: abnormal embryonic hematopoiesis
Value: anomaly in the development of primarily large, nucleated erythroblasts as well as some megakaryocytes and primitive macrophages that circulate in the embryonic and extraembryonic tissues, and which occurs in blood islands in the yolk sac from E7-E11 in the mouse and through 10 weeks in humans

Subject: increased muscle weight
Value: greater than average muscle weight

Subject: increased skeletal muscle size
Value: greater than average dimensions of one or more of the muscles of the skeleton

Subject: kinked neural tube
Value: twists or kinks in the embryonic neural tube

Subject: enlarged tail bud
Value: increased size or area of the primordial region of the embryo that arises to form the tail of the adult

Subject: decreased liver weight
Value: reduced average weight of the bile-secreting exocrine gland

Subject: absent placental labyrinth
Value: absence of the structure where embryonic blood vessels are surrounded by trophoblast cells and maternal blood

Subject: absent enamel
Value: absence of the hard outer coating of the exposed portion of the tooth

Subject: abnormal platelet shape
Value: any anomaly in the characteristic surface outline or contour of the normal small, disk-like shape of blood plasma cells derived from megakaryocytes and which function to promote blood clotting

Subject: failure of zygotic cell division
Value: inability of a fertilized oocyte to initiate or complete early cell divisions

Subject: abnormal central nervous system regeneration
Value: changes in the ability or inability of healthy central nervous system tissue to regenerate following injury or disease

Subject: increased width of hypertrophic chondrocyte zone
Value: increased width of cartilage cell matrix layer

Subject: decreased width of hypertrophic chondrocyte zone
Value: decreased width of cartilage cell matrix layer

Subject: abnormal artery development
Value: anomaly in the process of forming the blood vessels that carry blood away from the heart

Subject: abnormal vein development
Value: anomaly in the process of forming the blood vessels that carry blood to the heart

Subject: abnormal afterhyperpolarization
Value: anomaly in the currents that follow an action potential and influence firing frequency and neuronal integration

Subject: hair follicle degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of the hair follicle

Subject: epidermal cyst
Value: a benign mass derived from the epidermis or the epithelium of a hair follicle, formed by enclosure of epithelium within the dermis and filled with keratin and lipid-rich inclusions

Subject: priapism
Value: prolonged penile erection, often painful and without sexual desire

Subject: premature bone ossification
Value: early onset of the formation of bone

Subject: premature endochondral bone ossification
Value: early onset of bone formation in bones that form from cartilage

Subject: premature intramembranous bone ossification
Value: early onset of bone formation in bones that form without a cartilaginous intermediate including the cranium and clavicle

Subject: delayed endochondral bone ossification
Value: late onset of bone formation in bones that form from cartilage

Subject: delayed intramembranous bone ossification
Value: late onset of bone formation in bones that form without a cartilaginous intermediate including the cranium and clavicle

Subject: abnormal thyroid gland development
Value: failure or abnormality in the formation of the thyroid gland during organogenesis

Subject: abnormal thrombolysis
Value: altered ability to break up (lyse) blood clots that are restricting the blood flow

Subject: reduced thrombolysis
Value: reduced ability or inability to break up (lyse) blood clots that are restricting the blood flow

Subject: premature neuronal precursor differentiation
Value: earlier than normal transformation of neuronal precursor cells into neurons

Subject: abnormal optic vesicle formation
Value: anomalous formation of the hollow outgrowth from the lateral aspects of the embryonic forebrain from which the retina and optic nerve develop

Subject: pulmonary interstitial fibrosis
Value: formation of fibrous tissue within the interstices of the lung as a result of repair or a reactive process

Subject: parakeratosis
Value: thickening of the stratum corneum of the epidermis (hyperkeratosis) with nucleated keratinocytes retained in this layer

Subject: insensitivity to growth hormone
Value: no growth response to exogenous growth hormone

Subject: increased pancreatic islet cell adenoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign epithelial neoplasm with a glandular organization arising in the islet cells of the pancreas, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: abnormal parathyroid gland physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of this paired endocrine gland that normally produces parathyroid hormone (PTH) that regulates calcium and phosphorous metabolism

Subject: increased activity of parathyroid
Value: increased function of this paired endocrine gland that normally produces parathyroid hormone (PTH) that regulates calcium and phosphorous metabolism

Subject: decreased activity of parathyroid
Value: reduced function of this paired endocrine gland that normally produces parathyroid hormone (PTH) that regulates calcium and phosphorous metabolism

Subject: decreased susceptibility to induced choroidal neovascularization
Value: reduction or absence of growth of new, abnormal blood vessels that originate in the choroid through a break in the Bruch membrane into the sub-retinal pigment epithelium or subretinal space and may result in visual loss as a result of chemical or mechanical manipulation (e.g. laser-induced trauma)

Subject: herniated seminal vesicle
Value: protrusion of the seminal vesicles through the pelvic outlet

Subject: decreased susceptibility to induced arthritis
Value: less likely to be stricken with changes in the synovial membranes and thickening of articular structures, widespread degeneration of the collagen fibers in connective tissues, and by atrophy and rarefaction of bony structures that are induced by inflammatory responses caused by chemical or mechanical agents

Subject: abnormal carotid body morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a small epithelioid structure consisting of a small cluster of chemoreceptive and supporting cells located near the bifurcation of the common carotid artery that serves as a chemoreceptive organ that senses the pH, carbon dioxide, and oxygen concentrations in the blood and plays a crucial role in their homeostatic control

Subject: abnormal carotid body physiology
Value: any functional anomaly in a small epithelioid structure consisting of a small cluster of chemoreceptive and supporting cells located near the bifurcation of the common carotid artery that serves as a chemoreceptive organ that senses the pH, carbon dioxide, and oxygen concentrations in the blood and plays a crucial role in their homeostatic control

Subject: abnormal glycerol level
Value: abnormal level of trihydroxy sugar alcohols that are precursors for synthesis of triacylglycerols, and of phospholipids and cellular glucose in the liver and adipose tissue; fat catabolism results in the release of glycerol and fatty acids into the bloodstream to be used as an energy source

Subject: decreased glycerol level
Value: reduced level of trihydroxy sugar alcohols that are precursors for synthesis of triacylglycerols, and of phospholipids and cellular glucose in the liver and adipose tissue; fat catabolism results in the release of glycerol and fatty acids into the bloodstream to be used as an energy source

Subject: increased glycerol level
Value: elevated level of trihydroxy sugar alcohols that are precursors for synthesis of triacylglycerols, and of phospholipids and cellular glucose in the liver and adipose tissue; fat catabolism results in the release of glycerol and fatty acids into the bloodstream to be used as an energy source

Subject: decreased circulating glycerol level
Value: reduced blood level of trihydroxy sugar alcohols that are precursors for synthesis of triacylglycerols, and of phospholipids and cellular glucose in the liver and adipose tissue; fat catabolism results in the release of glycerol and fatty acids into the bloodstream to be used as an energy source

Subject: increased circulating glycerol level
Value: elevated blood level of trihydroxy sugar alcohols that are precursors for synthesis of triacylglycerols, and of phospholipids and cellular glucose in the liver and adipose tissue; fat catabolism results in the release of glycerol and fatty acids into the bloodstream to be used as an energy source

Subject: abnormal neurotransmitter uptake
Value: aberration in the reabsorption of endogenous signaling molecules released into a synaptic cleft; neurotransmitters are released on excitation from the axon terminal of a presynaptic neuron of the central or peripheral nervous system and travel across the synaptic cleft to either excite or inhibit the target cell

Subject: sirenomelia
Value: fusion of the caudal-most (posterior or lower) limbs often with partial or complete fusion of the autopods

Subject: renal hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the kidney, usually due to a reduced number of cells

Subject: decreased tumor growth/size
Value: less than expected development of tumorous growth when compared to controls

Subject: abnormal tumor morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a given tumor type compared to controls

Subject: abnormal intestinal goblet cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the glandular simple columnar epithelial cell found in the mucosal lining of the small and large intestine, whose primary function is to secrete gel-forming mucins, the major components of mucus; the goblet cell is a highly polarized unicellular exocrine gland with the nucleus and other organelles concentrated at the base of the cell; the remainder of the cell's cytoplasm is occupied by membrane-bound secretory granules containing mucin; the goblet shape is due to the mucus laden granules in the apical part expanding, causing that part of the cell to balloon; the apical plasma membrane projects microvilli to give an increased surface area for secretion

Subject: enlarged pancreas
Value: increase of the size of the pancreas compared to controls

Subject: absent olfactory bulb
Value: absence of the forebrain region that coordinates neuronal signaling involved in the perception of smell; it receives input from the sensory neurons and outputs to the olfactory cortex

Subject: abnormal parotid gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of either of the largest of the major salivary glands situated below and in front of each ear

Subject: abnormal keratinocyte physiology
Value: abnormal function of the cells of the epidermis that produce keratin in the process of differentiating into the dead and fully keratinized cells of the stratum corneum

Subject: erythroderma
Value: exfoliation and widespread, intense reddening of the skin due to inflammatory skin disease

Subject: decreased susceptibility to induced retinal damage
Value: reduced or absent pathological changes in the retina due to chemical or mechanical agents

Subject: absent tail
Value: completely lacking the appendage at the caudal end of the vertebral column

Subject: abnormal circulating ketone body level
Value: aberrant amount of acetoacetate, 3-hydroxybutyrate (beta-hydroxybutyrate) and/or acetone in the blood, which are produced by fatty acid and carbohydrate metabolism and seen in conditions such as starvation and diabetes mellitus

Subject: decreased circulating ketone body level
Value: less than the normal amount of acetoacetate, 3-hydroxybutyrate (beta-hydroxybutyrate) and/or acetone in the blood, which are produced by fatty acid and carbohydrate metabolism and seen in conditions such as starvation and diabetes mellitus

Subject: increased fear-related response
Value: greater emotional response related to anticipation of specific pain or danger

Subject: decreased fear-related response
Value: reduced emotional response related to anticipation of specific pain or danger

Subject: abnormal response to novel object
Value: altered behavioral reaction associated with exposing an animal to a novel object

Subject: abnormal response to novel odor
Value: altered behavioral reaction associated with exposing an animal to a novel odor

Subject: abnormal single cell response
Value: altered values from controls obtained upon extra- or intracellular recordings from single cells

Subject: abnormal single cell response threshold
Value: any change in the value at which a stimulus first elicits a recordable response recorded in a single cell

Subject: increased single cell response threshold
Value: increase in the value at which a stimulus first elicits a recordable response recorded in a single cell

Subject: decreased single cell response threshold
Value: reduction in the value at which a stimulus first elicits a recordable response recorded in a single cell

Subject: abnormal single cell response intensity
Value: any change in the value for changes in the degree of de- or hyperpolarization or number of action potentials in response to a specific stimulus recorded in a single cell

Subject: increased single cell response intensity
Value: increase in the degree of de- or hyperpolarization or number of action potentials in response to a specific stimulus recorded in a single cell

Subject: decreased single cell response intensity
Value: reduction in the degree of de- or hyperpolarization or number of action potentials in response to a specific stimulus recorded in a single cell

Subject: abnormal summary potential
Value: anomaly in the electrophysiological recording of the activity of several cells

Subject: abnormal summary potential threshold
Value: any change in the value at which a stimulus first elicits a recordable response recorded in several cells or a tissue slice

Subject: increased summary potential threshold
Value: increase in the value at which a stimulus first elicits a recordable response recorded in several cells or a tissue slice

Subject: decreased summary potential threshold
Value: reduction in the value at which a stimulus first elicits a recordable response recorded in several cells or a tissue slice

Subject: abnormal summary potential intensity
Value: any change in the value for changes in the degree of de- or hyperpolarization or number of action potentials in response to a specific stimulus recorded in several cells or a tissue slice

Subject: increased summary potential intensity
Value: increase in the value for changes in the degree of de- or hyperpolarization or number of action potentials in response to a specific stimulus recorded in several cells or a tissue slice

Subject: decreased summary potential intensity
Value: reduction in the value for changes in the degree of de- or hyperpolarization or number of action potentials in response to a specific stimulus recorded in several cells or a tissue slice

Subject: abnormal nerve fiber response
Value: anomaly in the electrophysiological recordings from a single or several nerve fiber(s)

Subject: abnormal nerve fiber response threshold
Value: any change in the value at which a stimulus first elicits a recordable response recorded in a single or several nerve fiber(s)

Subject: abnormal nerve fiber response intensity
Value: any change in the value for changes in the degree of de- or hyperpolarization or number of action potentials in response to a specific stimulus recorded in a single or several nerve fiber(s)

Subject: increased nerve fiber response intensity
Value: increase in the value for changes in the degree of de- or hyperpolarization or number of action potentials in response to a specific stimulus recorded in a single or several nerve fiber(s)

Subject: decreased nerve fiber response intensity
Value: reduction in the value for changes in the degree of de- or hyperpolarization or number of action potentials in response to a specific stimulus recorded in a single or several nerve fiber(s)

Subject: increased nerve fiber response threshold
Value: increase in the value at which a stimulus first elicits a recordable response recorded in a single or several nerve fiber(s)

Subject: decreased nerve fiber response threshold
Value: reduction in the value at which a stimulus first elicits a recordable response recorded in a single or several nerve fiber(s)

Subject: abnormal channel response
Value: anomalies in the electrophysiological recordings from ion channels

Subject: abnormal channel response threshold
Value: any change in the value at which a stimulus first elicits a recordable response recorded from ion channels

Subject: abnormal channel response intensity
Value: any change in the value for changes in the degree of de- or hyperpolarization or number of action potentials in response to a specific stimulus recorded from ion channels

Subject: increased channel response intensity
Value: increase in the value for changes in the degree of de- or hyperpolarization or number of action potentials in response to a specific stimulus recorded from ion channels

Subject: decreased channel response intensity
Value: reduction in the value for changes in the degree of de- or hyperpolarization or number of action potentials in response to a specific stimulus recorded from ion channels

Subject: increased channel response threshold
Value: increase in the value at which a stimulus first elicits a recordable response recorded from ion channels

Subject: decreased channel response threshold
Value: reduction in the value at which a stimulus first elicits a recordable response recorded from ion channels

Subject: abnormal voluntary movement
Value: anomaly in coordinated movements executed with a purpose and can be improved by learning and/or experience

Subject: abnormal involuntary movement
Value: anomaly in movements that occur independent of planning (e.g. reflexive behavior)

Subject: parathyroid gland hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due an increased number of cells of one of the two small, paired endocrine glands, usually found embedded in the connective tissue capsule on the posterior surface of the thyroid gland; they secrete parathyroid hormone (PTH) that regulates calcium and phosphorous metabolism

Subject: parathyroid hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of one of the two small, paired endocrine glands, usually found embedded in the connective tissue capsule on the posterior surface of the thyroid gland; they secrete parathyroid hormone (PTH) that regulates calcium and phosphorous metabolism

Subject: increased parathyroid adenoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign epithelial neoplasm with a glandular organization arising in the parathyroid gland, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased thyroid adenoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign epithelial neoplasm with a glandular organization arising in the thyroid gland, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: insensitivity to parathyroid hormone
Value: no changes in calcium homeostasis in response to endogenous or exogenous hormone

Subject: thyroid gland hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due an increased number of cells of the endocrine gland located in the front and to the sides of the upper part of the trachea and which secretes thyroid hormone and calcitonin

Subject: thyroid gland hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the endocrine gland located in the front and to the sides of the upper part of the trachea and which secretes thyroid hormone and calcitonin

Subject: iodide oxidation defect
Value: thyroid defect in oxidation and organification of iodide

Subject: increased activity of thyroid gland
Value: increased function of this endocrine gland that normally produces hormones that regulate the metabolic rate of the body

Subject: decreased activity of thyroid gland
Value: reduced function of this endocrine gland that normally produces hormones that regulate the metabolic rate of the body

Subject: thyroid gland inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the thyroid gland

Subject: increased prolactinoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a pituitary adenoma characterized by secretion of prolactin, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: acromegaly
Value: excessive secretion of growth hormone resulting in progressive enlargement of the face, hands, feet, head, and thorax; organomegaly and impaired glucose homeostasis may ensue

Subject: abnormal ovary physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the ovarian follicle for the production of female germ cells or the endocrine cells for the production of estrogen and progesterone

Subject: abnormal circulating dihydrotestosterone level
Value: aberration in the blood concentration of a potent androgenic metabolite of testosterone

Subject: increased circulating dihydrotestosterone level
Value: greater than normal blood concentration of this potent androgenic metabolite of testosterone

Subject: decreased circulating dihydrotestosterone level
Value: reduction in the blood concentration of a potent androgenic metabolite of testosterone

Subject: abnormal labium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the folds of skin which form the inner lips (labia minora) and outer lips (labia majora) on both sides of the vaginal opening

Subject: enlarged labia
Value: increased size of the folds of skin which form the inner lips (labia minora) and outer lips (labia majora) on both sides of the vaginal opening

Subject: small labia
Value: decreased size of the folds of skin which form the inner lips (labia minora) and outer lips (labia majora) on both sides of the vaginal opening

Subject: interlabial sulcus
Value: the presence of grooves or furrows in the folds of skin which lips on both sides of the vaginal opening

Subject: abnormal labia majora morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the folds of skin which form the outer lips (labia majora) on both sides of the vaginal opening

Subject: absent labia majora
Value: absence of the folds of skin which form the outer lips (labia majora) on both sides of the vaginal opening

Subject: enlarged labia majora
Value: increased size of the folds of skin which form the outer lips (labia majora) on both sides of the vaginal opening

Subject: small labia majora
Value: reduced size of the folds of skin which form the outer lips (labia majora) on both sides of the vaginal opening

Subject: splayed labia majora
Value: flattened or spread out appearance of the folds of skin which form the outer lips (labia majora) on both sides of the vaginal opening

Subject: abnormal labia minora morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the folds of skin which form the inner lips (labia minora) on both sides of the vaginal opening

Subject: absent labia minora
Value: absence of the folds of skin which form the inner lips (labia minora) on both sides of the vaginal opening

Subject: enlarged labia minora
Value: increased size of the folds of skin which form the inner lips (labia minora) on both sides of the vaginal opening

Subject: small labia minora
Value: reduced size of the folds of skin which form the inner lips (labia minora) on both sides of the vaginal opening

Subject: splayed labia minora
Value: flattened or spread out appearance of the folds of skin which form the inner lips (labia minora) on both sides of the vaginal opening

Subject: vulva warts
Value: benign epithelial growths of the external genitalia of the female

Subject: vulva cysts
Value: cystic vulva; usually refers to a benign growth

Subject: small vulva
Value: decreased size of the external genitalia of the female

Subject: enlarged vulva
Value: increased size of the external genitalia of the female

Subject: enlarged clitoris
Value: increased size of the small, erectile body located at the anterior end of the vulva

Subject: small clitoris
Value: reduced size of the small, erectile body located at the anterior end of the vulva

Subject: abnormal vagina development
Value: abnormal morphogenesis of the female reproductive canal located between the uterus and the vulva

Subject: bifid vagina
Value: cleft of the female reproductive canal located between the uterus and the vulva into two parts or branches

Subject: blind vagina
Value: presence the female reproductive canal that ends in a sac and does not connect to internal genitalia

Subject: absent vagina
Value: absence of the female reproductive canal located between the uterus and the vulva

Subject: vagina dryness
Value: lack of the normal presence or reduced presence of secretions in the vagina

Subject: hydrometrocolpos
Value: collection of fluid in the vagina; often due to a congenital obstruction

Subject: abnormal hymen development
Value: anomaly in the morphogenesis of the thin membrane which may partially occlude the opening of the vagina; often absent in normal females

Subject: absent hymen
Value: absence of the thin membrane which may partially occlude the opening of the vagina

Subject: imperforate hymen
Value: absence of the normal opening of the thin membrane which may partially occlude the opening of the vagina; here the opening is completely occluded

Subject: vaginal inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the vagina

Subject: abnormal vascular endothelial cell development
Value: anomaly in the differentiation of the cells that line the vasculature

Subject: abnormal vascular endothelial cell differentiation
Value: anomaly in the process whereby a relatively unspecialized cell acquires specialized features of an endothelial cell

Subject: abnormal vascular endothelial cell migration
Value: anomaly in the movement of endothelial cell or their precursors to the appropriate location in the body

Subject: increased alcohol consumption
Value: greater than normal consumption of alcohol

Subject: decreased alcohol consumption
Value: less than normal consumption of alcohol

Subject: abnormal pulmonary pressure
Value: altered tension of the blood within the pulmonary arteries

Subject: pulmonary hypertension
Value: sustained high pulmonary pressure at a level that is likely to result in disease and/or other pathological states

Subject: pulmonary hypotension
Value: sustained low pulmonary pressure at a level that is likely to result in disease and/or other pathological states

Subject: short perineum
Value: reduced length of the area between the genital organs and the anus that lies beneath the pelvic diaphragm

Subject: blind perineal pouch
Value: opening in the perineum leading to a blind-ending sac

Subject: vagina cysts
Value: benign epithelial growths of the female reproductive canal located between the uterus and the vulva

Subject: abnormal foreskin morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the loose fold of skin that covers the penis

Subject: phimosis
Value: inability of the penis to protrude from the prepuce/foreskin; may be due to a narrow opening of the foreskin resulting in the inability to retract the distal foreskin over the glans penis

Subject: chordee
Value: acute angulation of the penis upon erection; often painful and due to disease or congenital malformation

Subject: absent vas deferens
Value: absence of the secretory duct of the testicle that carries spermatozoa, running from the epididymis, of which it is the continuation, to the prostatic urethra where it terminates to form ejaculatory duct

Subject: absent uterus
Value: absence of the female muscular organ of gestation

Subject: bifid uterus
Value: cleft of the female muscular organ of gestation into two parts or branches, often having the appearance of two lobes

Subject: osteoarthritis
Value: a type of arthritis that results in the breakdown and eventual loss of the articular cartilage of one or more joints

Subject: rheumatoid arthritis
Value: an autoimmune response that primarily affects connective tissue; it also results in chronic inflammation of the joints, especially of the hands and feet and may also cause inflammation of the tissue around the joints, as well as other organs in the body

Subject: abnormal pancreatic beta cell physiology
Value: anomaly in the function of the cells that secrete insulin and are located towards the center of the islets of Langerhans in the pancreas

Subject: abnormal pancreatic alpha cell physiology
Value: anomaly in the function of the glucagon-producing cells of the islets of Langerhans in the pancreas

Subject: abnormal insulin secretion
Value: anomaly in the production or release of the hormone secreted by beta cells of the pancreas that promotes glucose utilization, protein synthesis, and the formation and storage of neutral lipids

Subject: abnormal glucagon secretion
Value: anomaly in the production or release of this hormone secreted by the alpha cells of the islets of Langerhans; it normally plays a role in regulation of blood glucose concentration, ketone metabolism, and other biochemical and physiological processes

Subject: abnormal cell adhesion
Value: altered ability of a cell to adhere to another cell or to a non-cellular component of the environment

Subject: abnormal fetal cardiomyocyte proliferation
Value: anomaly in the ability of the differentiating cardiac muscle cell population to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: uterus atresia
Value: congenital absence of the normal opening or lumen of the uterus

Subject: increased leiomyoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign tumor derived from smooth (nonstriated) muscle, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased uterus leiomyoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign tumor derived from smooth (nonstriated) muscle of the uterus, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: uterus rupture
Value: tearing of the uterine tissue; may be due to trauma or pregnancy complications

Subject: abnormal uterus development
Value: abnormal morphogenesis of the female muscular organ of gestation

Subject: abnormal oviduct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tube through which the ova pass from the ovary to the uterus

Subject: absent oviduct
Value: absence of the tube through which the ova pass from the ovary to the uterus

Subject: oviduct hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the tube through which the ova pass from the ovary to the uterus

Subject: absent ovary
Value: absence of the female reproductive gland containing the germ cells

Subject: increased ovarian carcinoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a malignant neoplasm arising from ovarian tissue, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased fibroma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign tumor of fibrous or fully developed connective tissue, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased ovarian fibroma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign tumor of fibrous or fully developed connective tissue in the ovary, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: abnormal ovary development
Value: abnormal morphogenesis of the ovarian follicle for the production of female germ cells or the endocrine cells for the production of estrogen and progesterone

Subject: bifid ureter
Value: two ureters join before draining into the urinary bladder; a duplex kidney with a bifid renal pelvis or bifid ureter ensues when a single ureteral bud bifurcates before the ampulla bifurcates

Subject: large ureter
Value: increased size or length of the tube that conducts the urine from the renal pelvis to the bladder

Subject: dilated ureter
Value: abnormal distention of the ureter due to accumulation of fluid

Subject: ureter obstruction
Value: a partial or total blockage in any part of the ureter causing obstruction of urine flow from the kidney to the urinary bladder; may be congenital, acquired, unilateral, bilateral, acute or chronic

Subject: ureter stenosis
Value: abnormal narrowing or constriction of the ureter

Subject: abnormal ureter physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the tube that conducts the urine from the renal pelvis to the bladder

Subject: ureteral reflux
Value: retrograde movement of urine from the bladder to the kidney

Subject: urethra atresia
Value: closure, or failure to develop a connection in the canal that leads from the bladder and discharges urine externally

Subject: urethra stricture
Value: abnormal narrowing at one or more points in the urethra, almost invariably restricted to males and often secondary to injury, inflammation, tumors or any other cause of scarring; whether congenital or acquired, urethral strictures may compromise voiding and cause incontinence, bleeding, stones or even renal failure

Subject: urethrovaginal fistula
Value: an abnormal anatomical passage connecting the urethra and the vagina

Subject: small urethra
Value: decreased size or length of the canal that leads from the bladder and discharges urine externally

Subject: epididymal cyst
Value: benign growths present in the elongated structure connected to the posterior surface of the testis that transports, stores, and matures spermatozoa between testis and vas deferens

Subject: epididymal inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the elongated structure connected to the posterior surface of the testis that transports, stores, and matures spermatozoa between testis and vas deferens

Subject: increased epididymal cystadenoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign epithelial neoplasm with a glandular organization and a cyst-like appearance arising from epididymal tissue, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: epispadia
Value: congenital absence of the upper wall of the urethra, occurring in both sexes, but more often in the male, with the urethral opening somewhere on the dorsum of the penis at any point below the internal sphincter; in females, the malformed urethral opening is often located aberrantly

Subject: large penis
Value: enlarged size of the organ of copulation and urination in the male

Subject: ectopic kidney
Value: a kidney located outside of its normal position usually due to failed migration of the ureteral bud and developing metanephric blastema to the renal fossa; the most common example of renal ectopia is a pelvic kidney; other sites of ectopic kidneys include the iliac region, the abdomen, the chest, and, in some cases, the contralateral side, referred to as crossed

Subject: bifid kidney
Value: cleft of the kidney into two parts or branches, often having the appearance of two lobes

Subject: increased renal hamartoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign formation of a mass of tissue of disproportionate size and distribution in the kidney, occurring in a specific population in a given time period; hamartomas are typically composed of an overgrowth of mature cells and tissues that normally occur in this tissue

Subject: increased renal hemangioblastoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign cyst-like tumor of the kidney that is composed of multiple capillary and sinusoidal channels lined with endothelial cells, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: single kidney
Value: presence of only one of the paired organs responsible for urine secretion

Subject: fused kidneys
Value: a defect in which there is a single malformed organ resulting from partial or complete fusion of the two renal anlage

Subject: kidney failure
Value: failure of the kidneys to adequately filter toxins and waste products from the blood; classified as acute (as in acute kidney injury) or chronic (as in chronic kidney disease); a number of other diseases or health problems may cause either form of renal failure to occur

Subject: abnormal prostate gland physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the gland in males that secretes part of the seminiferous fluid

Subject: prostate gland inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the prostate

Subject: small scrotum
Value: reduced size of the external sac of skin that encloses the testes

Subject: scrotum hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increase in size, usually due to an increase in cell number, of the external sac of skin that encloses the testes

Subject: scrotum hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the external sac of skin that encloses the testes

Subject: bifid scrotum
Value: cleft of the scrotum into two parts or branches, often having the appearance of two lobes

Subject: abnormal kidney medulla development
Value: anomaly in the differentiation of the inner portion of the kidney consisting of the renal pyramids

Subject: urinary bladder prolapse
Value: hernial protrusion of the urinary bladder, usually through the vaginal wall

Subject: urinary bladder diverticulum
Value: a pouch or sac protruding from the urinary bladder wall

Subject: abnormal urachus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the fibrous remnant of the allantoic stalk, a narrow fetal canal connecting the apex of the urinary bladder with the umbilicus located in the space of Retzius, between the transversalis fascia anteriorly and the peritoneum posteriorly. its lumen is normally obliterated during development, transforming the urachus into a solid cord, a functionless remnant that persists throughout life as the median umbilical ligament; failure of complete lumen obliteration may result in distinct congenital urachal remnant anomalies

Subject: urinary bladder hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the urinary bladder, usually due to a reduced number of cells

Subject: uterine cervical atresia
Value: narrowing of the cervical opening

Subject: abnormal urine color
Value: any alteration from the usual straw-coloration of the urine

Subject: oliguria
Value: decreased volume of urine produced and excreted

Subject: dysuria
Value: difficult or painful urination

Subject: ischuria
Value: upon urination, some urine is retained in the bladder instead of being excreted

Subject: hydrocele
Value: accumulation of fluid around testes

Subject: anuria
Value: inability to form or excrete urine

Subject: kidney medulla hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due an increased number of cells of the inner portion of the kidney consisting of the renal pyramids

Subject: kidney medulla hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the inner portion of the kidney consisting of the renal pyramids

Subject: abnormal leukocyte tethering or rolling
Value: anomaly in the transient adhesive interactions between leukocytes and endothelial cells lining blood vessels mediated primarily by selectins and which are typically the first step in cellular extravasation

Subject: abnormal leukocyte adhesion
Value: anomaly in the number of or process by which leukocytes adhere to the luminal aspects of high endothelial venules prior to transmigration out of the vessel

Subject: abnormal urothelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the epithelial lining of the lumen of the organs of the urinary tract

Subject: nervous system phenotype
Value: the observable morphological and physiological characteristics of the extensive, intricate network of electochemical structures in the body that is comprised of the brain, spinal cord, nerves, ganglia and parts of the receptor organs that are manifested through development and lifespan

Subject: abnormal nervous system morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the extensive, intricate network of electochemical structures in the body that is comprised of the brain, spinal cord, nerves, ganglia and parts of the receptor organs that receive and interpret stimuli and transmit impulses to effector organs to control body functions

Subject: abnormal nervous system physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the extensive, intricate network of electochemical structures in the body that is comprised of the brain, spinal cord, nerves, ganglia and parts of the receptor organs that receive and interpret stimuli and transmit impulses to effector organs to control body functions

Subject: abnormal glial cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of non-neuronal cells of the nervous system that form the myelin insulation of nervous pathways, guide neuronal migration during development, and exchange metabolites with neurons

Subject: abnormal synaptic transmission
Value: defect in the communication from a neuron to a target across a synapse

Subject: cochlear ganglion hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the group of nerve cell bodies that conveys auditory sensation from the organ of Corti to the hindbrain and resides on the cochlear part of the vestibulocochlear nerve (eighth cranial nerve)

Subject: abnormal response/metabolism to endogenous compounds
Value: altered ability or inability to metabolize or respond to substances normally present in the body

Subject: abnormal response to vitamins
Value: altered ability or inability to respond to or metabolize a group of organic substances that are required in trace amounts for the normal metabolic homeostasis of the body

Subject: small lung
Value: reduced size of the lung compared to controls

Subject: absent seminal vesicle
Value: absence of the two folded, sac shaped, glands that is a diverticulum of the ductus deferens

Subject: spleen atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of the spleen associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: thymus atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of the thymus associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: increased pancreatic beta cell number
Value: greater than normal number of the cells of the pancreas that secrete insulin

Subject: muscle fatigue
Value: increased muscle exhaustion or increased susceptibility to muscle exhaustion

Subject: absent oligodendrocytes
Value: absence of the neuroglia of the central nervous system that form the insulating myelin sheath of axons in the CNS

Subject: abnormal radial glial cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the supporting cells of the developing central nervous system that guide neuronal migration during development and exchange metabolites with developing and migrating neurons; these cells differentiate into astrocytes and some neuronal types in the adult

Subject: decreased heart right ventricle size
Value: less than average size of the right ventricle compared to the average for a particular population

Subject: abnormal axon extension
Value: abnormality in the ability of an axon to exhibit long distance growth of a single axon process from a neuron cell body involved in cellular development

Subject: abnormal skin turgor
Value: anomaly in the ability of the skin to resist deformation; influential factors include dehydration and age

Subject: decreased skin turgor
Value: reduced ability of the skin to resist deformation; influential factors include dehydration and age

Subject: nasal bone hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due an increased number of cells in the bone which forms the nasal bridge

Subject: absent pancreas
Value: absence of the organ that secretes pancreatic juice into the duodenum and secretes glucagon and insulin into the bloodstream

Subject: abnormal erythrocyte physiology
Value: aberrant measurable or observable characteristic related to the function of or processes in the cells in the blood that carry oxygen, red blood cells

Subject: abnormal erythrocyte osmotic lysis
Value: increase or decrease in the ability of RBCs to withstand changes in osmolarity

Subject: abnormal capillary morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small branching blood vessels that form a network between the arterioles and venules, where the exchange of water, oxygen, carbon dioxide, and other nutrient and waste chemical substances occurs between the blood and the surrounding tissues

Subject: abnormal lymph circulation
Value: abnormalities in the flow of the lymph from the tissues into the veins of the circulatory system

Subject: chylothorax
Value: an accumulation of chyle in the pleural space; chyle is fluid consisting of lymph and emulsified fats that is formed in the small intestine during digestion of fatty foods and taken up by the lymph vessels

Subject: abnormal locus ceruleus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a dense cluster of neurons within the dorsorostral pons; it is the major location of neurons that release norepinephrine throughout the brain, and is responsible for physiological responses to stress and panic

Subject: abnormal long bone epiphyseal plate proliferative zone
Value: any anomaly of the germinal layer of the epiphyseal plate where cells are actively dividing as well as producing extracellular matrix

Subject: abnormal thermosensation
Value: defect in the ability to sense or display a preference for a given temperature

Subject: ocular pterygium
Value: abnormal mass of hypertrophied bulbar subconjunctival tissue arising from the conjunctiva of the inner corner of the eye that obstructs vision by growing over the cornea towards the pupil

Subject: endophthalmitis
Value: inflammation of the internal structures of the tissues in the eyeball

Subject: impaired sperm capacitation
Value: reduced ability or inability to undergo the changes in spermatozoa in the female genital tract that enables them to penetrate and fertilize an egg

Subject: increased hemangiosarcoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of a malignant tumor characterized by rapidly proliferating, extensively infiltrating, anaplastic cells derived from blood vessels and appear as irregular blood-filled or lumpy sacs that are typically filled with blood; rupture of the tumor can cause rapid death from bleeding

Subject: abnormal periodontal ligament morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the fibrous connective tissue that surrounds the root of a tooth, separating it from and attaching it to the alveolar bone; normally extends from the base of the gingival mucosa to the fundus of the bony socket, and its main function is to hold the tooth in its socket

Subject: periodontal ligament hypercellularity
Value: increased cell density of the periodontal ligament

Subject: dilated renal glomerular capsule
Value: stretched or widened aperture of the expanded beginning of a nephron that contains the glomerulus

Subject: abnormal eyelid aperture
