Value: any anomaly in the normal distance from one eyelid to the other, or closure of the eyes

Subject: abnormal ureter development
Value: any anomaly in the differentiation of the tube that conducts the urine from the renal pelvis to the bladder

Subject: abnormal inguinal canal morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the passage in the lower abdominal wall through which the spermatic cord in the male or the round ligament in the female, nerves and vessels pass from the pelvic cavity to the scrotum or labia majora, respectively

Subject: oxidative stress
Value: condition characterized by an accumulation of free radical groups in the body, which creates a potentially unstable and damaging cellular environment linked to tissue damage, accelerated aging, and degenerative disease; can result from many factors, including exposure to alcohol, medications, poor nutrition, trauma, cold or toxins; may be indicated by low antioxidant levels measured in blood plasma

Subject: kidney cysts
Value: abnormal membranous sacs in any portion of the pair of organs responsible for urine secretion

Subject: abnormal ear lobe morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the soft tissue at the base of the outer ear; consists of fat and fibrous tissue not reinforced by the auricular cartilage

Subject: absent ear lobes
Value: missing the soft tissue at the base of the outer ear; consists of fat and fibrous tissue not reinforced by the auricular cartilage

Subject: ear lobe hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, in the ear lobes

Subject: thick ear lobes
Value: an increase in the fleshiness of the ear lobes

Subject: protruding ear lobes
Value: ear lobes that project outward

Subject: linear crease in ear lobe
Value: appearance of fold-like marks in the ear lobe

Subject: prominent ear lobes
Value: conspicuous appearance of the ear lobes

Subject: abnormal inferior olivary complex morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the capsule-shaped structure in the ventral medulla located just lateral and dorsal to the medullary pyramids; neurons in the inferior olivary nucleus are the source of climbing fiber input to the cerebellar cortex and have been implicated in various functions, such as learning and timing of movements

Subject: abnormal cardiac ganglion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the parasympathetic ganglia of the cardiac plexus between the arch of the aorta and the bifurcation of the pulmonary artery

Subject: abnormal eye muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the muscles of the eye

Subject: abnormal intraocular muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the smooth muscles within the eye

Subject: ophthalmoparesis
Value: loss of strength in the muscles that control eye movement

Subject: ophthalmoplegia
Value: paralysis of the ocular muscles

Subject: abnormal glial cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of non-neuronal cells of the central nervous system that form the myelin insulation of nervous pathways, guide neuronal migration during development, and exchange metabolites with neurons

Subject: abnormal microglial cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the small, migratory, phagocytic, interstitial cells derived from myeloid progenitor cells and found in the parenchyma of the central nervous system; microglia are scavengers, engulfing dead cells and other debris, and in Alzheimer's disease, microglia are found associated with dying nerve cells and amyloid plaques

Subject: xanthoma
Value: a deposit of cholesterol rich material in a tissue, most often in the skin but also seen in tendons and in the brain

Subject: abnormal blastocyst hatching
Value: any anomaly of the hatching of the cellular blastocyst from the zona pellucida, the thick solid transparent outer membrane that surrounds the developing ovum and embryo prior to implantation

Subject: failure of blastocyst to hatch from the zona pellucida
Value: the hatching of the cellular blastocyst from the zona pellucida, the thick solid transparent outer membrane that surrounds the developing ovum and embryo prior to implantation, fails to occur

Subject: delayed blastocyst hatching from the zona pellucida
Value: the hatching of the cellular blastocyst from the zona pellucida, the thick solid transparent outer membrane that surrounds the developing ovum and embryo prior to implantation, occurs later in development than expected

Subject: abnormal zona pellucida morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thick solid transparent outer membrane that surrounds the developing ovum and embryo prior to implantation

Subject: absent zona pellucida
Value: missing the thick solid transparent outer membrane that surrounds the developing ovum and embryo prior to implantation

Subject: abnormal male reproductive system physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the male organs associated with producing offspring

Subject: abnormal female reproductive system physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the female organs associated with producing offspring

Subject: abnormal oviduct transport
Value: increased or decreased rate of passage of embryos or oocytes from the ovary to the uterus

Subject: elevated level of mitotic sister chromatid exchange
Value: increased number of crossovers between sister chromatids during mitosis resulting in increased numbers of reciprocal exchanges of DNA between the two chromosomes; normally crossover exchanges are supressed during mitosis and only occur in meiosis

Subject: abnormal chromosome morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the compact, intertwined molecules of DNA found in the nucleus which carry genetic information

Subject: abnormal vestibulocochlear ganglion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the group of neuron cell bodies associated with the eighth cranial nerve during embryogenesis; splits in later development to form the cochlear and vestibular ganglia

Subject: abnormal hair follicle development
Value: any anomaly in the development of the tube-like opening in the epidermis where the hair shaft develops and into which the sebaceous glands open

Subject: abnormal hypodermis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the irregular layer of loose connective tissue containing fibroblasts, adipose cells, and macrophages, that is immediately deep to the skin and superficial to the deep fascia; usually consisting primarily of a fatty layer and may also include a muscle layer and/or a fibrous layer, or it may occur as a membranous layer only, being nearly devoid of fat; it contains skin ligaments extending between the dermis and deep fascia, cutaneous nerves, and superficial vessels, with terminal branches passing into the skin layers

Subject: abnormal cell nucleus count
Value: absent or greater than one nuclei present per cell body when one is expected; often due to failed cytokinesis or events leading to apoptosis

Subject: increased cell nucleus count
Value: greater than one nuclei present per cell body when one is expected; often due to failed cytokinesis

Subject: binucleate
Value: two nuclei present per cell body when one is expected; often due to failed cytokinesis

Subject: anucleate
Value: absent nucleus of a cell body when one is expected; often due to events leading to apoptosis

Subject: abnormal physiological neovascularization
Value: anomalies in the development of new blood vessels in restoration of blood circulation during the healing process

Subject: pathological neovascularization
Value: the proliferation of blood vessels in abnormal tissues or in abnormal positions

Subject: raised ear position
Value: outer ears which are situated above the normal location

Subject: abnormal ear rotation
Value: outer ears that are positioned such that the ears are turned relative to the anterior-posterior body axis, but the ears emerge from the head at the usual position

Subject: absent platelets
Value: lack of non-nucleated cells found in the blood and involved in blood coagulation

Subject: posteriorly rotated ears
Value: outer ears that are positioned such that the ears are turned backwards relative to the anterior-posterior body axis, but the ears emerge from the head at the usual position

Subject: anteriorly rotated ears
Value: outer ears that are positioned such that the ears are turned forward relative to the anterior-posterior body axis, but the ears emerge from the head at the usual position

Subject: pallor
Value: an unnatural paleness to the skin, generally attributable to anemia

Subject: maternal effect
Value: expression of a phenotypic trait in a female animal's offspring that is dependent on the maternal genotype

Subject: abnormal pericyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the connective tissue cells that occurs around capillaries or other small blood vessels

Subject: abnormal neural tube closure
Value: any anomaly in the last step in the formation of the neural tube, where the paired neural folds are brought together and fuse at the dorsal midline

Subject: increased tumor growth/size
Value: greater than expected development of tumorous growth when compared to controls

Subject: absent ureter
Value: missing the tube that conducts the urine from the renal pelvis to the bladder

Subject: abnormal long bone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bones that consist of a tubular shaft (diaphysis) and two ends that are wider than the shaft (epiphysis); long bones include the femora, tibiae, and fibulae, and the humeri, radii, and ulnae of the limbs; metacarpals and metatarsals of the autopods, the phalanges of the digits, and the clavicles

Subject: increased susceptibility to induced arthritis
Value: more likely to be stricken with changes in the synovial membranes and thickening of articular structures, widespread degeneration of the collagen fibers in connective tissues, and by atrophy and rarefaction of bony structures that are induced by inflammatory responses caused by chemical or mechanical agents

Subject: increased autoantibody level
Value: elevated level of antibodies to self-antigens present in the sera; often indicative of autoimmune disease

Subject: decreased autoantibody level
Value: reduced level of antibodies to self-antigens present in the sera

Subject: abnormal retinal layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the layers that make up the retina

Subject: abnormal retinal photoreceptor layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the photoreceptor layer

Subject: abnormal photoreceptor outer segment morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the photoreceptor region that is rich in the visual pigment rhodopsin

Subject: abnormal photoreceptor inner segment morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the photoreceptor region which contains the machinery of the cell (mitochondria, golgi, endoplasmic reticulum, etc) and where opsin molecules are assembled and passed to be part of the outer segment region

Subject: abnormal retinal outer nuclear layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the retinal layer that contains the nuclei and cell bodies of rods and cones

Subject: abnormal retinal outer plexiform layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the retinal layer that is the site of synapses between the rods and cones (axons) and the horizontal and bipolar cells (dendrites)

Subject: abnormal retinal inner nuclear layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the retinal layer that contains the cell bodies of bipolar, horizontal, and amacrine cells

Subject: abnormal retinal inner plexiform layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the retinal cell layer where bipolar and amacrine cell axons synapse with ganglion cell dendrites

Subject: cup-shaped ears
Value: deeply concave appearance to the outer ear

Subject: folded helix
Value: the bending over of the upper cartilaginous rim of the outer ear

Subject: ossification of pinnae
Value: formation of bone in the outer ear, which is normally cartilaginous

Subject: dense middle ear ossicles
Value: thickening of the three small bones of the middle ear

Subject: fusion of middle ear ossicles
Value: union of the three small bones of the middle ear into a single structure

Subject: tinnitus
Value: persistent sensation of buzzing, ringing, clicking, or other noises in the ear

Subject: narrow head
Value: a shorter ear- to -ear distance resulting in the appearance of a thin face and a protruding nasal region

Subject: abnormal facial morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the face

Subject: obsolete abnormal orofacial morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the the mouth and the face

Subject: abnormal oral mucosa morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the mucous membrane that lines the inside of the mouth and consists of stratified squamous epithelium termed oral epithelium and an underlying connective tissue termed lamina propria

Subject: stomatitis
Value: inflammation of the mucous lining of the mouth

Subject: mouth mucosal ulcer
Value: lesions through the mucous membrane of the mouth, usually associated with loss of tissue

Subject: increased oral mucosa hemangioma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign tumor characterized by blood-filled spaces lined by benign endothelial cells in the oral mucosa, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: down-turned corners of mouth
Value: the lateral points of the oral cavity opening appear in a lower position that the rest of the lips

Subject: increased mouth tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplasms in the mouth tissues, usually in the form of a distinct mass, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: oral leukoplakia
Value: white patchy lesions of the mucous membranes of the oral cavity; often considered a precancerous condition

Subject: increased oral papilloma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of benign tumors consisting of villous or arborescent outgrowths of fibrovascular stroma covered by neoplastic epithelial cells in the oral cavity

Subject: increased lip papilloma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign epithelial tumor of the lip of the oral cavity, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased gingival papilloma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign epithelial tumor of the oral gum tissue

Subject: abnormal palate morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the roof of the mouth in vertebrates formed anteriorly by a bony projection of the upper jaw (hard palate) and posteriorly by the fold of connective tissue (soft palate)

Subject: abnormal hard palate morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anterior part of the palate that is supported by and includes the palatal extensions of the maxillary and palatine bones in the adult

Subject: high palate
Value: greater distance upward to the roof of the oral cavity than usual

Subject: narrow palate
Value: abnormally slim shape to the roof of the oral cavity

Subject: broad palate
Value: abnormally wide shape to the roof of the oral cavity

Subject: decreased palatal length
Value: reduction in the average distance of the deepest point in the midline of the palate relative to the midline point on the anterior crest of the alveolar gum pad ridge

Subject: arched palate
Value: abnormally concaved shape to the roof of the oral cavity

Subject: abnormal immune organ physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the organs of the immune system

Subject: abnormal thymus physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the primary lymphoid organ that is required for immune system development

Subject: abnormal palatal length
Value: any change in the average distance of the deepest point in the midline of the palate relative to the midline point on the anterior crest of the alveolar gum pad ridge

Subject: increased palatal length
Value: greater than average distance of the deepest point in the midline of the palate relative to the midline point on the anterior crest of the alveolar gum pad ridge

Subject: palate inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins and leukocytes in the palate

Subject: palatal telangiectases
Value: vascular lesion formed by dilation of a group of small blood vessels in the palate

Subject: abnormal lip morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the fleshy margins of the mouth

Subject: lip ulcer
Value: lesions through the mucous membrane of the inner surface of the lip

Subject: abnormal lip shape
Value: changes in the characteristic contours of the fleshy margins of the mouth

Subject: lip pits
Value: an abnormal hollow or depression in the fleshy margins of the mouth

Subject: eclabion
Value: an outward turning of the inner surface of the lip

Subject: thick lip
Value: lips having an abundance and often an excess of soft tissue

Subject: thin lip
Value: lips having a reduced amount of soft tissue

Subject: lip atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of the lip tissue associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: lip inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins and leukocytes in the lips

Subject: lip telangiectases
Value: vascular lesion formed by dilation of a group of small blood vessels in the lip

Subject: lip cysts
Value: fluid-filled membranous sacs present in the lips

Subject: increased lip tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of abnormal rapidly proliferating cells in the lip, usually in the form of a distinct mass, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased lip neuroma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a tumor derived from nerve cells or fibers residing in the lip, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: short lip
Value: lip that does not extend fully to the normal placement and meet the opposite lip

Subject: tented upper lip
Value: an upper lip having an inverted V- shape

Subject: thin lip vermilion border
Value: reduced thickness of the line between the lip and the facial skin around the mouth

Subject: lip mucosal nodules
Value: small mass of tissue or aggregation of cells in the mucosal tissue of the inner lip

Subject: premature aging
Value: earlier than normal occurrence of the normal signs of aging

Subject: abnormal imprinting
Value: defects in the establishment of heritable alterations in the activity of a gene that depend on whether it passed through the paternal or the maternal germline, but that are not encoded by DNA itself

Subject: increased osteosarcoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a malignant neoplasm derived form mesenchymal stem cells, osteoblasts or osteocytes, occurring in a specific population in a given time period; osteosarcoma is a highly invasive and destructive tumor rising in the skeleton with osteoid and immature woven bone

Subject: absent CD4-positive, alpha beta T cells
Value: lack of the set of single-positive T cells that express CD4 on their surface

Subject: abnormal minor salivary gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the smaller, largely mucus-secreting, exocrine glands of the oral cavity, consisting of the labial, buccal, molar, lingual, and palatine glands

Subject: abnormal major salivary gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the three largest glands of the oral cavity that secrete most of the saliva, including the parotid, submandibular, and sublingual glands

Subject: abnormal submandibular gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of either of the large major salivary glands situated beneath the mandible

Subject: delayed somite formation
Value: late onset of the induction and/or differentiation of the somites

Subject: abnormal bone structure
Value: anomaly in the composite material or the layered arrangement of the bony endoskeleton of the body

Subject: abnormal compact bone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the outer layers of solid, hard bone that covers spongy bone; consists of parallel osteons containing mineral deposits and interstitial lamellae

Subject: abnormal Harderian gland pigmentation
Value: any anomaly in the coloring of the sebaceous gland located behind the eyeball in the orbit that excretes fluid that facilitates movement of the third eyelid, due to changes in the amount, shape, or distribution of cells producing pigment

Subject: impaired macrophage chemotaxis
Value: reduced diffusion or accumulation of macrophages in tissues or cells in response to a wide variety of substances released at the sites of inflammatory reactions

Subject: monodactyly
Value: having only one toe or digit on each extremity

Subject: abnormal nucleotide metabolism
Value: any anomaly in the chemical reactions and pathways involving a nucleotide, including metabolic, catabolic and biosynthetic processes

Subject: camptodactyly
Value: permanent flexion of one or more digits; contractures may also be seen in the wrists and at the elbows

Subject: increased atrioventricular cushion size
Value: larger than normal mounds of embryonic connective tissue that bulge into the fetal atrioventricular canal

Subject: abnormal hair shaft morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cuticle, cortex and/or medulla of a hair

Subject: abnormal hair cuticle
Value: anomalies in the thin, smooth and glossy outer protective cell layer of hair shaft

Subject: abnormal hair cortex morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the spindle shaped cells of the hair shaft that contains keratin fibrils and matrix

Subject: abnormal hair medulla
Value: anomalies of hair medullary cell formation and arrangement of the innermost core of the hair shaft

Subject: abnormal hair follicle dermal papilla morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the mesodermal signaling center of the hair follicle consisting of closely packed specialized mesenchymal fibroblasts

Subject: vascular smooth muscle hypoplasia
Value: decreased numbers of smooth muscle cells in the vascular wall

Subject: hairless
Value: having no hair at any time throughout lifespan, generally referring to primary genetic hairlessness

Subject: abnormal pituitary gland development
Value: malformation or incomplete differentiation of the compound gland suspended from the base of the hypothalamus, which secretes somatotropins, prolactin, TSH (thyroid-stimulating hormone), gonadotropins, adrenal corticotropin

Subject: abnormal pituitary diverticulum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a tubular outgrowth of ectoderm from the stomodeum of the embryo; the outgrowth grows toward the infundibular process of the diencephalon, around which it forms a cup-like mass, giving rise to the pars distalis and pars juxtaneuralis of the hypophysis

Subject: abnormal eye muscle development
Value: malformation or arrest of differentiation of the muscles of the eye

Subject: increased left ventricle diastolic pressure
Value: increase in the pressure in the left ventricle between heart beats when the heart is relaxed

Subject: increased left ventricle systolic pressure
Value: increase in the pressure in the left ventricle as the heart contracts and pumps blood into the arteries

Subject: decreased left ventricle diastolic pressure
Value: decrease in the pressure in the left ventricle between heart beats when the heart is relaxed

Subject: decreased left ventricle systolic pressure
Value: decrease in the pressure in the left ventricle as the heart contracts and pumps blood into the arteries

Subject: increased left ventricle developed pressure
Value: increase in the difference between left ventricular systolic and diastolic pressures

Subject: decreased left ventricle developed pressure
Value: decrease in the difference between left ventricular systolic and diastolic pressures

Subject: abnormal pillar cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the supporting cells that form the inner and outer walls of the tunnel in the organ of Corti

Subject: abnormal Mullerian duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the transient embryonic drainage tubes of the embryonic kidney (mesonephric tubules) that empty into the cloaca and in the female develop into the oviducts, uterus, and vagina

Subject: abnormal Wolffian duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the transient embryonic drainage tubes of the embryonic kidney (mesonephric tubules) that empty into the cloaca and later develop into the ductus deferens in the male

Subject: pulmonary edema
Value: an accumulation of an excessive amount of serous fluid in the parenchyma and the alveoli via effusion of intravascular fluid from the pulmonary vascular bed

Subject: impaired febrile response
Value: reduced or absent febrile response to exogenous or endogenous pyrogens

Subject: abnormal testis development
Value: abnormal morphogenesis of the male reproductive gland containing the germ cells

Subject: decreased satellite cell number
Value: less than the normal number of unfused cells in muscle that play a role in muscle regeneration

Subject: abnormal adrenergic chromaffin cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the neuroendocrine cells of the medulla of the adrenal gland that are innervated by the splanchnic nerve and that are responsible for epinephrine secretion

Subject: abnormal milk ejection
Value: anomaly of the milk ejection reflex in response to suckling during lactation

Subject: abnormal insulin clearance
Value: increase or decrease in the rate at which insulin is removed from the blood stream

Subject: abnormal coronal suture morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the dense, fibrous connective tissue joint between the parietal bones and the frontal bone

Subject: abnormal lambdoid suture morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the dense, fibrous connective tissue joint between the superior border of the occipital bone and the posterior borders of the right and left parietal bones

Subject: abnormal metopic suture morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the dense, fibrous connective tissue joint between the frontal bones from the sagittal suture to the root of the nose; it is visible in neonates and juveniles, but it is frequently obliterated in some adult organisms; in mice and rats, the posterior frontal (PF) suture, situated between the frontal bones, is analogous to the human metopic suture; the anterior landmark for the PF suture is the jugum limitans; the posterior landmark for the PF suture is the bregma

Subject: abnormal sagittal suture morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the dense, fibrous connective tissue joint between the parietal bones

Subject: abnormal squamoparietal suture morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the dense, fibrous connective tissue joint between the squamous part of the temporal bone and the inferior aspect of the parietal bone; posteriorly, the squamous suture becomes the parietomastoid suture where the mastoid process articulates with the parietal bone; anteriorly, the squamous suture extends towards the pterion

Subject: abnormal decidualization
Value: atypical cellular and vascular changes occurring in the endometrium of the pregnant uterus just after the onset of blastocyst implantation; this process involves the proliferation and differentiation of the fibroblast-like endometrial stromal cells into large, polyploid decidual cells that eventually form the maternal component of the placenta; expected changes include the eosinophilic proliferation around arterioles after ovulation or progesterone action on endometrium which increases glandular epithelial secretion, stimulates glycogen accumulation in stromal cell cytoplasm, and promotes stromal vascularity (spiral arterioles) and edema

Subject: matted coat
Value: coat hairs sticks together to form clumps and does not lie flat

Subject: disorganized lens bow
Value: derangement of the area where the lens epithelium pushes into the lens proper and forms new lens fibers

Subject: brittle hair
Value: hair is susceptible to breakage

Subject: greasy coat
Value: fur is oily in appearance or texture

Subject: abnormal thymocyte activation
Value: anomaly in the process of producing activated thymocytes from naive thymocytes

Subject: skeletal muscle interstitial fibrosis
Value: formation of fibrous tissue within the interstices of skeletal muscle as a result of repair or a reactive process

Subject: skeletal muscle necrosis
Value: morphological changes resulting from pathological death of skeletal muscle tissue; usually due to irreversible damage

Subject: dry skin
Value: skin characterized by the lack of natural or normal moisture

Subject: abnormal forelimb stylopod morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the proximal element of the forelimb including the humerus

Subject: abnormal forelimb zeugopod morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the distal elements of the forelimb including the radius and ulna

Subject: abnormal hindlimb stylopod morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the proximal element of the hindlimb including the femur

Subject: abnormal hindlimb zeugopod morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the distal elements of the hindlimb including the tibia and fibula

Subject: enhanced coordination
Value: improved ability to execute integrated movements of muscle

Subject: abnormal Harderian gland physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the retroocular sebaceous gland found within the orbit of mammals that possess a nictitating membrane (third eyelid); the chief products of the gland vary between different groups of vertebrates, and epithelial cells possess granules or vacuoles whose contents may be mucous, serous or lipid; in rodents, the Harderian gland is especially large and secretes lipids (by a merocrine mechanism), melatonin and porphyrins; ascribed functions include a role in lubrication and protection for the eyeball and nictitating membrane (by lipids), photoprotection (by porphyrin), photoreception (by regulation of the incidence of light on the retina), and thermoregulation (in some rodents)

Subject: abnormal carbon dioxide level
Value: anomalous concentration of CO2 in the blood, alveoli or other tissues resulting in the increased pressure of this component of body gases

Subject: abnormal nervous system development
Value: impaired or altered growth of the components of the nervous system

Subject: decreased aggression towards males
Value: when compared to controls, subjects exhibit less than normal level of domineering, assaultive posture and/or hostile physical action towards male mice

Subject: decreased aggression towards mice
Value: when compared to controls, subjects exhibit less than normal level of domineering, assaultive posture and/or hostile physical action towards other mice

Subject: abnormal midbrain development
Value: anomaly in the formation of or the patterning of the part of the brainstem developing from the middle of the three primary cerebral vesicles of the embryo

Subject: lymph node inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the lymph nodes

Subject: abnormal defecation
Value: anomaly in the discharge of feces from the body

Subject: increased defecation amount
Value: increase in the amount of discharge of feces from the body

Subject: abnormal feces composition
Value: increase or decrease in the amount of compounds normally found in the feces (fat, protein etc) or presence of material not normally seen in the feces

Subject: ectopic cartilage
Value: positional abnormality of cartilage

Subject: decreased urine glucose level
Value: a reduced amount of glucose in the urine compared to the normal state

Subject: abnormal myelin sheath morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the insulating envelope that surrounds nerve fibers or axons

Subject: absent heart right ventricle
Value: missing the lower right chamber of the heart

Subject: pharyngeal arch hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the transient structures of the embryo that develop into regions of the head, neck and ears, usually due to reduced cell number

Subject: absent pharyngeal arches
Value: missing the transient structures of the embryo that develop into regions of the head, neck and ears

Subject: abnormal hair follicle regression
Value: abnormal length of time for the onset of catagen phase of the cyclic transformation of the hair follicle

Subject: abnormal serotonergic neuron morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the neurons that secrete serotonin

Subject: abnormal ear physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the ear, not due to an anatomical defect

Subject: abnormal hair cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the sensory epithelial cells of the inner ear

Subject: abnormal central pattern generator function
Value: any functional anomaly of the neural networks that produce rhythmic patterned output without sensory input and underlie rhythmic motor patterns

Subject: abnormal nephron morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the filtering unit of the kidney that includes the renal corpuscle, proximal and distal convoluted tubules, and loop of Henle

Subject: abnormal pulse pressure
Value: anomaly in the difference between systolic and diastolic blood pressure

Subject: enlarged stomach
Value: increased size of the stomach

Subject: decreased macrophage cell number
Value: fewer than the normal numbers of macrophages

Subject: abnormal rostral-caudal body axis extension
Value: anomaly in or failure of the long (rostral-caudal) axis of the body to elongate normally once patterning has been established

Subject: abnormal embryonic epiblast morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the transient structure derived from the inner cell mass which lies above the hypoblast; the epiblast tissue gives rise to the three primary germ layers (ectoderm, definitive endoderm, and mesoderm) and to the extraembryonic mesoderm of the visceral yolk sac, the allantois, and the amnion

Subject: increased hepatocyte apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of hepatocytes undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: liver hemorrhage
Value: bleeding within the liver

Subject: enhanced sensorimotor gating
Value: amplification of the process by which inhibitory neural pathways filter multiple stimuli and allow attention to be focused on one stimulus; usually measured by pre-pulse inhibition (PPI)

Subject: abnormal embryonic-extraembryonic boundary morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the delineating tissue and the segregation between the embryo proper and extraembryonic tissues

Subject: increased allantois apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of cells of the allantois undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal gastric gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the branched tubular glands in the mucosa of the fundus and body of the stomach that contain parietal cells that secrete hydrochloric acid and zymogenic cells that produce pepsin

Subject: increased hepatocyte proliferation
Value: increase in the expansion rate of the hepatocyte cell population by cell division

Subject: abnormal Purkinje cell innervation
Value: any structural anomaly of the supply of nerve fibers that connect to the Purkinje cells

Subject: increased ectoderm apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of ectoderm cells undergoing programmed cell death during development

Subject: prolonged PR interval
Value: increase in the length of time between the beginning of atrial depolarization and the beginning of ventricular depolarization, measured by the interval from the beginning of the P wave to the beginning of the QRS complex

Subject: abnormal ST segment
Value: anomaly in the length of time between the end of S-wave and the beginning of T-wave; reflects the amount of time the ventricles remain electrically depolarized

Subject: abnormal QRS complex
Value: anomaly in the largest-amplitude portion of the ECG, caused by currents generated when the ventricles depolarize prior to their contraction

Subject: abnormal QT interval
Value: anomaly in the length of time required for ventricular depolarization and repolarization to occur, usually as a result of increased repolarization time, and is measured from the beginning of the QRS complex to the end of the T wave

Subject: shortened QT interval
Value: decrease in the length of time required for ventricular depolarization and repolarization to occur, usually as a result of increased repolarization time, and is measured from the beginning of the QRS complex to the end of the T wave

Subject: abnormal PR interval
Value: anomaly in the length of time between the beginning of atrial depolarization and the beginning of ventricular depolarization, measured by the interval from the beginning of the P wave to the beginning of the QRS complex

Subject: abnormal cell mass
Value: anomaly in the total physical bulk or volume of a cell compared to the normal state

Subject: increased cell mass
Value: greater total physical bulk or volume of a cell compared to the normal state

Subject: decreased cell mass
Value: reduction in the total physical bulk or volume of a cell compared to the normal state

Subject: abnormal aorta elastin content
Value: anomaly in the physical amount of elastin in the aorta compared to the normal state

Subject: increased aorta elastin content
Value: greater physical amount of elastin in the aorta compared to the normal state

Subject: decreased aorta elastin content
Value: reduction in the physical amount of elastin in the aorta compared to the normal state

Subject: decreased stereotypic behavior
Value: less frequent incidence of repetitive, invariant, persistent motor patterns that do not appear to be purposeful

Subject: increased heart right ventricle weight
Value: greater than average weight of the right ventricle compared to the average

Subject: decreased heart right ventricle weight
Value: less than average weight of the right ventricle compared to the average

Subject: increased left ventricle weight
Value: greater than average weight of the left ventricle compared to the average

Subject: decreased heart left ventricle weight
Value: less than average weight of the left ventricle compared to the average

Subject: increased kidney weight
Value: greater weight of the organs responsible for urine secretion

Subject: decreased kidney weight
Value: reduced weight of the organs responsible for urine secretion

Subject: abnormal heart right ventricle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the right lower chamber of the heart

Subject: abnormal heart left ventricle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the left lower chamber of the heart

Subject: abnormal heart right atrium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the right upper chamber of the heart

Subject: abnormal heart left atrium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the left upper chamber of the heart

Subject: diaphragmatic hernia
Value: protrusion of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity through a hole in the diaphragm

Subject: abnormal cellular glucose uptake
Value: anomaly in the ability of a cell to take in glucose from the environment

Subject: decreased cellular glucose uptake
Value: reduced ability of a cell to take in glucose from the environment

Subject: increased cellular glucose import
Value: increased ability of a cell to take in glucose from the environment

Subject: increased heart rate variability
Value: increased variation of beat-to-beat intervals of the heart that occurs in conjunction with the respiratory cycle

Subject: decreased heart rate variability
Value: reduced variation of beat-to-beat intervals of the heart that occurs in conjunction with the respiratory cycle

Subject: abnormal tooth hard tissue morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the hard portion of the tooth surrounding the pulp, including the dentin, enamel and the cementum on the root

Subject: absent molars
Value: absence of the most posterior teeth located on either side of the jaw, and characterized by a large crown and broad chewing surface

Subject: abnormal molar crown morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the part of a molar that is covered by enamel

Subject: abnormal cementum morphology
Value: any strucutral anomaly in the bonelike rigid connective tissue covering the root of a tooth

Subject: abnormal pancreas development
Value: anomaly in the formation of the organ that secretes pancreatic juice into the duodenum and secretes glucagon and insulin into the bloodstream

Subject: abnormal craniofacial development
Value: anomaly in the process of forming the face and/or cranium

Subject: abnormal reproductive system development
Value: developmental anomaly of any of the organs involved in the reproductive system

Subject: abnormal ear development
Value: developmental anomaly of any of the structures involved in the ear or vestibular system

Subject: abnormal myotome morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the mesoderm that is derived from the somite that is fated to become the musculature

Subject: abnormal dermatome morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the mesoderm that is derived from the somite that is fated to become the dermis

Subject: abnormal skin development
Value: anomaly in the formation of the membranous protective covering of the body

Subject: abnormal urinary system development
Value: any anomaly in the differentiation of the organ system that produces, stores, and eliminates urine

Subject: abnormal hepatobiliary system development
Value: developmental anomaly of any of the tissues of the liver or biliary system

Subject: abnormal T cell subpopulation ratio
Value: deviation from the standard ratios of T cell subpopulations (e.g. double positive to single positive ratio) compared to control samples

Subject: abnormal lymphocyte physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of any of the white blood cells that includes B cells, T cells, and NK cells

Subject: renal necrosis
Value: morphological changes resulting from pathological death of renal tissue; usually due to irreversible damage

Subject: abnormal cholesterol level
Value: anomaly in the amount in the body of the principal sterol of vertebrates and the precursor of many steroids, including bile acids and steroid hormones; it is a component of the plasma membrane lipid bilayer and of plasma lipoproteins and can be found in all animal tissues

Subject: abnormal gas homeostasis
Value: anomaly in the processes involved in the maintenance of an internal equilibrium of gaseous elements in animal tissues or blood

Subject: abnormal circulating lipid level
Value: anomalous concentrations of fat-soluble substances (molecules composed of carbon and hydrogen and are characteristically insoluble in water) in the blood

Subject: abnormal plasma membrane morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the semi-permeable membrane that encloses the cytoplasm of a cell

Subject: abnormal copper homeostasis
Value: anomaly in the processes involved in the maintenance of an internal equilibrium of copper that is a cofactor in a number of proteins including amine oxidases and chaperone proteins

Subject: abnormal copper level
Value: anomaly in the concentration in the body of the metallic element atom that has formula Cu, and normally occurs as a cofactor for a number of proteins including amine oxidases and chaperone proteins

Subject: abnormal hormone level
Value: aberrant tissue or circulating concentration of any substance, usually a peptide or steroid, that has a specific metabolic regulatory effect on the activity or behavior of cells expressing a receptor for the hormone

Subject: abnormal Reichert's membrane morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the extraembryonic basement membrane that forms on the inner surface of the trophectoderm during placenta morphogenesis and is secreted by the distal parietal endoderm; required for the maternofetal exchange of nutrients and is important for the postgastrulation development

Subject: abnormal ultimobranchial body morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the outpocketing of the caudal-most branchial pouch of the embryo (interpreted as a fifth pouch in human or as the ventral component of the fourth pouch in mouse) that fuses with the thyroid diverticulum, ultimately giving rise to calcitonin-producing parafollicular cells (aka C-cells) which function in calcium homeostasis; in most mammals, these parafollicular cells fully disperse with the endodermally derived follicular cells of the thyroid by birth

Subject: abnormal body size
Value: anomaly in the average body weight, height and/or length of an organism compared to controls

Subject: abnormal nitric oxide homeostasis
Value: anomaly in the processes involved in the maintenance of an internal equilibrium of nitric oxide, a free radical gas and a potent vasodilator

Subject: heart valve hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due an increased number of cells of the heart valves

Subject: abnormal lean body mass
Value: anomaly in the amount of the fat-free physical bulk or volume of the body including all its components except adipose tissue

Subject: increased lean body mass
Value: greater amount of the fat-free physical bulk or volume of the body including all its components except adipose (fat) tissue

Subject: decreased lean body mass
Value: reduced amount of the fat-free physical bulk or volume of the body including all its components except adipose (fat) tissue

Subject: abnormal adrenaline level
Value: aberrant concentration in the blood or tissues of this catecholamine hormone that stimulates the adrenergic receptors and that causes systemic vasoconstriction and gastrointestinal relaxation, stimulates the heart, and dilates bronchi and cerebral vessels

Subject: abnormal corticosterone level
Value: anomalous blood or tissue amount of an adrenocortical steroid that induces glycogen deposition and regulates sodium conservation and potassium secretion

Subject: abnormal noradrenaline level
Value: aberrant amount of the hormone secreted by the adrenal medulla and acts as a neurotransmitter in the sympathetic peripheral nervous system and in some tracts of the CNS; noradrenaline is the demethylated biosynthetic precursor of epinephrine

Subject: abnormal pituitary hormone level
Value: aberration in the blood or tissue concentration of any of the hormones secreted by the pituitary

Subject: abnormal adrenocorticotropin level
Value: anomaly in the level of the pituitary hormone that stimulates the secretion of adrenal cortical steroids and induces growth of the adrenal cortex

Subject: abnormal follicle stimulating hormone level
Value: anomalous concentration of the hormone that, in females, stimulates the graafian follicles of the ovary and assists in follicular maturation and the secretion of estradiol; in the male it stimulates the epithelium of the seminiferous tubules and is partly responsible for spermatogenesis

Subject: abnormal growth hormone level
Value: anomalous concentration of the hormone that promotes body growth, fat mobilization, and inhibition of glucose utilization

Subject: abnormal luteinizing hormone level
Value: aberrant levels in the bloodstream of LH, the hormone that regulates steroid production by the interstitial cells of the testis and the ovary

Subject: abnormal prolactin level
Value: anomalous concentration of the hormone that stimulates milk secretion

Subject: abnormal thyroid-stimulating hormone level
Value: anomalous concentration of the hormone that stimulates the growth and function of the thyroid gland

Subject: decreased pituitary hormone level
Value: less than the expected amount of any of the pituitary hormones in the blood or tissues

Subject: increased pituitary hormone level
Value: greater than the expected amount of any of the pituitary hormones in the blood or tissues

Subject: abnormal endocardium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thin serous membrane, primarily composed of endothelial tissue, that lines the interior of the heart

Subject: increased circulating VLDL triglyceride level
Value: higher than average concentration in the blood of very low density lipoprotein, which normally transports triglycerides from the intestine and liver to muscle and adipose tissue

Subject: decreased circulating VLDL triglyceride level
Value: lower than average concentration in the blood of very low density lipoprotein, which normally transports triglycerides from the intestine and liver to muscle and adipose tissue

Subject: abnormal circulating carnitine level
Value: aberrant concentration in the blood of carnitine, a quaternary ammonium amino acid derivative involved in transport of fatty acids across the mitochondrial membrane

Subject: decreased circulating carnitine level
Value: lower than normal blood concentration of this quaternary ammonium amino acid derivative involved in transport of fatty acids across the mitochondrial membrane

Subject: increased circulating carnitine level
Value: greater than normal blood concentration of this quaternary ammonium amino acid derivative involved in transport of fatty acids across the mitochondrial membrane

Subject: increased circulating phospholipid level
Value: greater concentration in the blood of the fat derivatives in which one fatty acid has been replaced by a phosphate group

Subject: decreased circulating phospholipid level
Value: reduced concentration in the blood of the fat derivatives in which one fatty acid has been replaced by a phosphate group

Subject: increased cholesterol level
Value: greater than normal amount in the body of the principal sterol of vertebrates and the precursor of many steroids, including bile acids and steroid hormones; it is a component of the plasma membrane lipid bilayer and of plasma lipoproteins and can be found in all animal tissues

Subject: decreased cholesterol level
Value: less than normal amount in the body of the principal sterol of vertebrates and the precursor of many steroids, including bile acids and steroid hormones; it is a component of the plasma membrane lipid bilayer and of plasma lipoproteins and can be found in all animal tissues

Subject: embryonic growth retardation
Value: <slow or limited development during the embryonic period (sensu Mus: up to E14, or the completion of organogenesis)>

Subject: renal fibrosis
Value: formation of fibrous tissue in the kidney as a result of repair or a reactive process

Subject: small cochlear ganglion
Value: reduced size of the cochlear ganglion or of the sensory neuron cell bodies that conveys auditory sensation from the organ of Corti to the hindbrain and resides on the cochlear part of the vestibulocochlear nerve (eighth cranial nerve)

Subject: small vestibular ganglion
Value: reduced size of the vestibular ganglion or of the sensory neuron cell bodies associated with the eighth cranial nerve

Subject: disorganized embryonic tissue
Value: a lack of the regular arrangement of any embryonic tissues

Subject: abnormal barrel cortex morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the discrete functional units of the somatosensory cortex that processes tactile information derived from the vibrissae

Subject: decreased neurotransmitter release
Value: reduced production or release of endogenous signaling molecules normally secreted by neurons that alter the behavior of neurons or effector cells

Subject: arteriosclerosis
Value: thickening, hardening and/or loss of elasticity of the walls of arteries

Subject: increased mortality induced by ionizing radiation
Value: greater sensitivity to doses of ionizing radiation that include ultraviolet light, X-rays, or gamma rays, resulting in death

Subject: abnormal ventral spinal root morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anterior bundle of nerves emerging from the spinal cord to join with the posterior/dorsal nerve bundle at each spinal cord segment to form one of the 31 paired peripheral nerves

Subject: abnormal dorsal spinal root morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the posterior bundle of nerves emerging from the spinal cord to join with the anterior/ventral nerve bundle at each spinal cord segment to form one of the 31 paired peripheral nerves

Subject: abnormal uterine artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the branch of the internal iliac artery that supplies the uterus and the upper part of the vagina

Subject: clonic seizures
Value: increased number or decreased threshold for the induction of a seizure characterized by unilateral or bilateral rhythmic jerking movements of the arms and legs caused by alternating contraction and relaxation of muscle

Subject: tonic-clonic seizures
Value: increased number or decreased threshold for the induction of a seizure characterized by initial rigidity followed by rhythmic jerking movements

Subject: decreased thermal nociceptive threshold
Value: a lower than average point at which thermal pain sensation is first detectable

Subject: enhanced passive avoidance behavior
Value: increase in the latency of an animal to enter an hostile environment where it receives a unpleasant or punishing stimuli applied previously

Subject: impaired passive avoidance behavior
Value: decrease in or absence of the latency of an animal to enter an hostile environment where it receives a unpleasant or punishing stimuli applied previously

Subject: decreased hepatocyte proliferation
Value: reduction in the expansion rate of the hepatocyte cell population by cell division

Subject: abnormal jejunum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the portion of the small intestine that extends from the duodenum to the ileum

Subject: abnormal vascular endothelial cell physiology
Value: anomaly in the function of the cells that line the vasculature

Subject: patent ductus venosus
Value: failure of the embryonic connection between the portal vein and inferior vena cava formed by the left umbilical vein (that allows oxygenated blood to bypass the developing liver) to close in adults

Subject: impaired contractility of intestinal smooth muscle
Value: inability or reduced ability of intestinal smooth muscle to shorten or to develop increased tension

Subject: impaired contractility of jejunal smooth muscle
Value: inability or reduced ability of the jejunal smooth muscle to shorter or to develop increased tension

Subject: abnormal lung vasculature morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the blood vessels of the lung

Subject: abnormal GABA-mediated receptor currents
Value: change in the measured amplitude, current density or duration of response to stimulation of GABA receptors

Subject: abnormal diastolic filling velocity
Value: anomaly in the rate of fluid inflow to the heart during diastole compared to controls; usually measured in the left ventricle; altered filling velocity often contributes to various cardiovascular disorders

Subject: increased diastolic filling velocity
Value: greater rate of fluid inflow to the heart during diastole compared to controls; usually measured in the left ventricle; altered filling velocity often contributes to various cardiovascular disorders

Subject: decreased diastolic filling velocity
Value: reduction in the rate of fluid inflow to the heart during diastole compared to controls; usually measured in the left ventricle; altered filling velocity often contributes to various cardiovascular disorders

Subject: increased pulmonary artery pressure
Value: increased pulmonary pressure compared to controls

Subject: decreased pulmonary artery pressure
Value: reduced pulmonary pressure compared to controls

Subject: abnormal uterine environment
Value: anomaly or inability of the uterus to support embryonic development

Subject: abnormal oviduct environment
Value: anomaly or inability of the oviduct to support egg viability

Subject: decreased bone mass
Value: a reduction in the total amount of bone tissue contained in the skeleton

Subject: duplex kidney
Value: a kidney that is split into two separate collecting systems; there may be a duplex ureter or a single ureter; may present unilaterally or bilaterally

Subject: abnormal galactose homeostasis
Value: anomaly in the processes involved in the maintenance of an internal equilibrium of galactose in the fluids and tissues

Subject: abnormal vitamin homeostasis
Value: anomaly in the processes involved in the maintenance of an internal equilibrium of organic substances found in food and are not synthesized by the body and are necessary in trace amounts for normal metabolic function

Subject: polyhydramnios
Value: abnormally high amniotic fluid volume; may result from maternal diabetes, chromosomal abnormalities or other congenital abnormalities

Subject: abnormal rod electrophysiology
Value: any functional anomaly of dark adapted vision mediated by the rods

Subject: abnormal cone electrophysiology
Value: any functional anomaly of light adapted vision mediated by the cones

Subject: abnormal chromosome number
Value: chromosome count is other than the expected diploid chromosome number

Subject: aneuploidy
Value: chromosome count is not an exact multiple of the haploid number

Subject: polyploidy
Value: more than two chromosome sets are present

Subject: monosomy
Value: one chromosome missing from an otherwise diploid chromosome set

Subject: trisomy
Value: presence of an extra chromosome in an otherwise diploid chromosome set

Subject: chromosome breakage
Value: chromosome instability in the form of increased frequency of spontaneous breakage with or without rearrangements

Subject: spontaneous chromosome breakage
Value: chromosome breakage due to inherent instability of chromosomes

Subject: induced chromosome breakage
Value: chromosome breakage following treatment with a DNA-damaging agent

Subject: insulitis
Value: a histological change in the islets of Langerhans characterized by edema and the infiltration of small numbers of white blood cells

Subject: abnormal interventricular groove morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the indentation dividing the two ventricles, comprised of the sulcus interventricularis anterior and the sulcus interventricularis posterior

Subject: supernumerary teeth
Value: presence of a supernumerary, i.e., extra, tooth or teeth

Subject: belly blaze
Value: the appearance of a stripe or zigzag of white fur on the ventrum

Subject: abnormal sublingual gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small mucin-producing salivary glands in the floor of the mouth beneath the tongue, anterior to the submandibular gland

Subject: abnormal muscle relaxation
Value: altered ability of the muscle to lengthen following contractions

Subject: increased muscle relaxation
Value: greater than the normal ability of the muscle to lengthen following contractions or increase in the ability of the muscle to lengthen following contractions

Subject: lymphangiectasis
Value: dilation of the lymphatic vessels, the basic process that may result in the formation of a lymphangioma

Subject: abnormal cardiac cell glucose uptake
Value: anomalous ability of the cells of the heart to take in glucose

Subject: altered susceptibility to kidney reperfusion injury
Value: a change in the likelihood or extent of damage to the kidney when the blood supply is restored after a period of ischemia

Subject: increased susceptibility to kidney reperfusion injury
Value: an increased likelihood or extent of damage to the kidney when the blood supply is restored after a period of ischemia

Subject: decreased susceptibility to kidney reperfusion injury
Value: a diminished likelihood or extent of damage to the kidney when the blood supply is restored after a period of ischemia

Subject: abnormal pH regulation
Value: anomaly in the function of the buffer systems of the body in combination with the respiratory and renal systems that control the relative acidity or alkalinity of the body, as measured by the concentration of hydrogen ion

Subject: aortic dissection
Value: a pathologic process, characterized by splitting of the media layer of the aorta, which leads to formation of a dissecting aneurysm

Subject: abnormal cell cycle checkpoint function
Value: anomaly in the amount of time spent at the points in the cell cycle (end of G1 phase, end of G2 phase, and during metaphase) which prevent the cell from progressing to the next phase when conditions are unfavorable

Subject: abnormal mitosis
Value: anomaly in the process of cell division including both division of the nucleus (karyokinesis) and the cytoplasm (cytokinesis)

Subject: abnormal milk composition
Value: anomaly in one or more of the constituents of milk including protein, lipid, and/or mineral content or in the appearance of milk

Subject: increased acute promyelocytic leukemia incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of cancer characterized by rapid onset of abnormal leukocyte proliferation, manifesting as a severe bleeding disorder from coagulation abnormalities, and bone marrow infiltration of abnormal promyelocytes and myelocytes

Subject: abnormal synchondrosis
Value: anomalous or persistent cartilaginous fusion of two bones

Subject: abnormal periocular mesenchyme morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the mesenchymal cells that give rise to the corneal endothelium, corneal stroma, sclera, iris stroma, ciliary muscle, ciliary stroma, and trabecular meshwork of the eye

Subject: atrium hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of one or both of the two upper chambers of the heart, usually due to reduced cell number

Subject: abnormal myocardium compact layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the outer, dense layer of the myocardium uniting the epicardium and myocardium

Subject: thin myocardium compact layer
Value: reduced thickness of the outer, dense layer of the myocardium

Subject: abnormal ventricle papillary muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of one of the group of myocardial bundles which terminate in the chordae tendineae that attach to the cusps of the atrioventricular valves; each ventricle has an anterior and a posterior papillary muscle; the right ventricle sometimes has a septal papillary muscle

Subject: absent papillary muscle
Value: absence of one of the group of myocardial bundles which terminate in the chordae tendineae that attach to the cusps of the atrioventricular valves; each ventricle has an anterior and a posterior papillary muscle; the right ventricle sometimes has a septal papillary muscle

Subject: papillary muscle hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, in the papillary muscle

Subject: dilated heart right atrium
Value: the luminal space of the right upper chamber of the heart is increased in volume or area, usually with an increase in contained fluid

Subject: dilated heart left atrium
Value: the luminal space of the left upper chamber of the heart is increased in volume or area, usually with an increase in contained fluid

Subject: decreased susceptibility to induced muscular atrophy
Value: less than expected wasting of muscle tissue after experimental manipulation (starvation, neurectomy, immobilization, etc)

Subject: increased susceptibility to induced muscular atrophy
Value: greater than expected wasting of muscle tissue after experimental manipulation (starvation, neurectomy, immobilization, etc)

Subject: abnormal primitive node morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the regional thickening of cells at the rostral tip of the vertebrate primitive streak through which gastrulating cells migrate anteriorly to form tissues in the future head and neck; this region organizes the formation of the three embryonic layers and establishes the longitudinal axis and the polarity of the embryo

Subject: abnormal trabecula carnea morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the supporting bundles of muscular fibers lining the walls of the ventricles of the heart

Subject: dilated dorsal aorta
Value: stretched or widened aperture of the luminal space of the paired arterial structures of the embryo that supplies each developing somite via efferent segmental arteries; the dorsal aortae articulate with the umbilical arteries, which return mixed blood to the villi of the chorion for reoxygenation

Subject: abnormal muscle spindle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the sensory organs in muscle that are involved in the stretch reflex

Subject: abnormal P wave
Value: any anomaly in the P wave which represents atrial depolarization and corresponds to electrical impulses rather than mechanical atria contractions; irregular or absent P waves may indicate arrhythmia and the shape of the P waves may indicate atrial problems

Subject: prolonged P wave
Value: increase in the length of time of the P wave electrical impulses, measured from the beginning to the end of the P wave

Subject: abnormal frontal plane axis
Value: any anomaly found in the sum of all electrical currents in the heart during systole

Subject: caudal body truncation
Value: caudal part of body truncated; typically with the rostral portion of the body relatively normal

Subject: abnormal Schwann cell precursor morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the progenitors of cells that sheath the axons of the peripheral nervous system

Subject: decreased Schwann cell precursor number
Value: fewer numbers than normal of the progenitors of cells that sheath the axons of the peripheral nervous system

Subject: abnormal vitelline vascular remodeling
Value: anomaly in the conversion of the primary (honeycomb-like) vascular plexus of the yolk sac into a mature vascular network

Subject: abnormal striatum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a large cluster of dopaminergic nerve cells, consisting of the caudate nucleus and the putamen, that controls movement, balance, and walking

Subject: abnormal caudate nucleus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of one or both C-shaped structures that border the lateral ventricle wall and contain input neurons involved with control of voluntary movement in the brain

Subject: abnormal putamen morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the lens-shaped basal ganglion involved with control of voluntary movement in the brain

Subject: abnormal nucleus accumbens morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the group of neurons located at the head of the caudate nucleus and anterior to the putamen; these neurons normally are involved in sensations of pleasure and reactions to addictive substances

Subject: abnormal globus pallidus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of one of the basal ganglia involved with control of voluntary movement in the brain; consists of an external and an internal segment

Subject: abnormal habenula morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the group of nuclei that makes up the small eminence on the dorsomedial surface of the thalamus, just in front of the dorsal commissure on the lateral edge of the habenular trigone

Subject: polysyndactyly
Value: greater than the normal complement of digits present on an autopod with interdigital webbing also present

Subject: abnormal cardiac muscle relaxation
Value: altered ability of the cardiac/heart muscle to lengthen following contractions, often measured by dP/dt min

Subject: abnormal heartbeat
Value: anomaly in the appearance of regularly spaced contractions of the heart due to defects in the frequency, rate, pattern or extent of heart contraction

Subject: absent heartbeat
Value: lack of a spontaneously beating heart (usually due to defects in the calcium delivery mechanism or loss of a functional contractile apparatus)

Subject: abnormal muscle fiber morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the muscle fibers, the cylindrical multinucleated muscle cells that contract when stimulated

Subject: abnormal sarcoplasmic reticulum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the endoplasmic reticulum of skeletal and cardiac muscle, i.e. the complex of vesicles, tubules, and cisternae that form a continuous structure around striated myofibrils, with a repetition of structure within each sarcomere

Subject: dilated sarcoplasmic reticulum
Value: an expansion in the volume in the endoplasmic reticulum of skeletal and cardiac muscle, i.e. the complex of vesicles, tubules, and cisternae that form a continuous structure around striated myofibrils, with a repetition of structure within each sarcomere

Subject: abnormal sarcomere morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the segment of a myofibril between two Z lines comprised of multi-protein complexes composed of three different filament systems; these systems work together to contract and relax muscle

Subject: abnormal Z line morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the cross-striation bisecting the I band of striated muscle myofibrils and serving as the anchoring point of actin filaments at either end of the sarcomere

Subject: absent Z line
Value: missing the cross-striation bisecting the I band of striated muscle myofibrils and serving as the anchoring point of actin filaments at either end of the sarcomere

Subject: diffuse Z line
Value: widely spread cross-striation bisecting the I band of striated muscle myofibrils and serving as the anchoring point of actin filaments at either end of the sarcomere

Subject: abnormal M line morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the band in the center of the H band that contains proteins that crosslink the thick filament system (myosins) and the M-band part of the elastic filaments

Subject: ocular distichiasis
Value: presence of a double row of eyelashes on an eyelid, one or both of which are turned in against the eyeball

Subject: abnormal midbrain-hindbrain boundary development
Value: anomaly in the formation of the midbrain-hindbrain domain, comprised of the mesencephalic vesicle and the first rhombencephalic vesicle at early somitogenesis stages; an organizing center at the boundary patterns the midbrain and hindbrain primordia of the neural plate

Subject: abnormal cerebellar cortex morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thin mantle of grey matter that covers the surface of each cerebral hemisphere, including the six layers of nerve cells and the nerve pathways that connect them; together, these regions are responsible for the processes of conscious thought, perception, emotion and memory as well as advanced motor function

Subject: abnormal cerebellar granule cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small neurons of the cerebellar granule cell layer that send parallel fibers to the upper molecular layer, where they synapse with Purkinje cell dendrites

Subject: abnormal cerebellar glomerulus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of an intertwined cluster of nerve fibers surrounded by glia where mossy fibers from the pontine nuclei in the white matter synapse with granule cell axons, Golgi cell axons and unipolar brush interneuron axons

Subject: abnormal spinal cord interneuron morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of neurons that exclusively interact with other neurons in the spinal cord

Subject: abnormal brain interneuron morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of neurons that exclusively interact with other neurons in the brain; this includes most brain neuronal cell types

Subject: abnormal dorsal striatum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the regions of the caudate nucleus and the putamen that lie dorsal to the anterior commissure

Subject: abnormal ventral striatum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the regions of the nucleus accumbens and some nuclei of the olfactory tubercle that lie ventral to the anterior commissure

Subject: corneal abrasion
Value: scraping away or denuding of the corneal surface

Subject: lymphatic vessel hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due an increased number of cells in lymphatic vessels

Subject: abnormal thoracic duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the largest collecting lymph vessel in the body, beginning at the cisterna chyli at about the level of the second lumbar vertebra, and drains into the systemic (blood) circulation at the left brachiocephalic vein between the left subclavian and left internal jugular veins

Subject: abnormal esophageal peristalsis
Value: altered esophageal movement characterized by waves of alternate circular contraction and relaxation of the muscular walls that move the esophagus contents forward

Subject: abnormal Sertoli cell development
Value: anomalous differentiation of cells that support germ cell differentiation in males

Subject: transposition of great arteries
Value: cardiovascular structural anomaly in which the aorta arises from the right ventricle while the pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle

Subject: abnormal coronary artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the arteries that branch from the ascending aorta to supply blood to the heart

Subject: abnormal arteriole morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small diameter vessels that branch from the arteries and lead to the capillaries

Subject: abnormal aortic arch morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the convex portion of the aorta between the ascending and descending parts of the aorta; branches from it include the brachiocephalic trunk, the left common carotid artery, and the left subclavian artery; the brachiocephalic trunk further splits to form the right subclavian artery and the right common carotid artery

Subject: abnormal atrioventricular node morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small nodular mass of specialized muscle fibers located in the interatrial septum near the opening of the coronary sinus; this node gives rise to the electrical connection between the atria and ventricles and responds to the sinoatrial node

Subject: abnormal sinoatrial node morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small mass of modified cardiac muscle fibers located at the junction of the superior vena cava and the right atrium that is the source of contraction impulses for the heart

Subject: abnormal atrioventricular bundle conduction
Value: anomaly in the transfer of cardiac electrical impulses through the specialized cardiac muscle fibers that originates in the atrioventricular node and extends into the ventricle

Subject: abnormal atrioventricular bundle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the specialized cardiac muscle fibers that originates in the atrioventricular node and extends into the ventricle

Subject: abnormal baroreceptor morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the sensory nerve endings in the wall of the atria of the heart, vena cava, aortic arch and carotid sinus that are sensitive to changes in blood pressure

Subject: hypokalemia
Value: excessively low concentrations of potassium in the circulating blood; may be chronic or due to gastrointestinal and kidney depletion due to infection

Subject: cardiac ischemia
Value: inadequate blood flow to the heart; may cause infarction and is usually caused by coronary artery disease

Subject: abnormal sarcolemma morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the plasma membrane of a muscle fiber that is capable of conducting electrical impulses

Subject: abnormal sinus arrhythmia
Value: any anomaly in the normal phenomenon of mild acceleration and slowing of the heart rate that occurs during the respiratory cycle

Subject: abnormal impulse conducting system morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the impulse-conducting system composed of modified cardiac muscle and having the power of spontaneous rhythmicity and conduction more highly developed than the rest of the heart

Subject: abnormal Purkinje fiber morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the cardiac muscle fibers composing the terminal portion of the heart conduction system located in the ventricle

Subject: abnormal venule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the minute vessels that collect deoxygenated blood from the capillary plexuses returns it to the veins

Subject: thin hypodermis
Value: reduced thickness of the irregular layer of loose connective tissue containing fibroblasts, adipose cells, and macrophages, that is immediately deep to the skin and superficial to the deep fascia

Subject: thick hypodermis
Value: increase in the width of the irregular layer of loose connective tissue containing fibroblasts, adipose cells, and macrophages, that is immediately deep to the skin and superficial to the deep fascia

Subject: abnormal respiratory quotient
Value: anomaly in the ratio of the volume of carbon dioxide released to oxygen consumed by a body tissue or an organism compared to controls

Subject: abnormal muscle cell glucose uptake
Value: anomaly in the ability of muscle cells to take in glucose

Subject: abnormal motile primary cilium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cilia of the embryo found on the cells of the embryonic node, which generate flow of extraembryonic fluid surrounding the node in a distinct twirling motion that directs fluid flow asymmetrically across the cellular surface to affect asymmetric body plan organization

Subject: absent embryonic cilia
Value: absence of cilia on the cells of the embryonic node

Subject: heterotaxia
Value: abnormal arrangement of organs or parts of the body in relation to each other according to the left-right axis

Subject: abnormal chest morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the part of the body between the neck and the abdomen

Subject: abnormal mammary gland embryonic development
Value: aberration in the differentiation of the mammary gland during early embryogenesis

Subject: abnormal tongue muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the muscular portion of the tongue

Subject: abnormal gastric surface mucous cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the mucus secreting epithelial cells that line the luminal surface of the stomach and the gastric pits which secrete mucus and HCO3- to protect the gastric surface from the acidic environment of the stomach

Subject: abnormal mucous neck cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the mucin-producing epithelial cells present in the neck of the gastric glands

Subject: abnormal gastric parietal cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the gastric acid producing epithelial cells that are distributed throughout the length of the gastric gland

Subject: abnormal gastric chief cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the pepsinogen producing epithelial cells that are clustered at the base of the gastric gland

Subject: abnormal enteroendocrine cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the various hormone- or neurotransmitter-secreting epithelial cells present throughout the mucosa of the digestive tract

Subject: abnormal muscle tone
Value: anomaly in the resting tautness or laxity of a muscle, normally somewhere in the middle of the range between total contraction and total relaxation

Subject: muscle hypertonia
Value: increased muscle tension resulting in stiffness of the muscles in the resting state

Subject: hypotonia
Value: decreased muscle tension resulting in limpness of the muscles in the resting state, not to be confused with weakness

Subject: abnormal muscle electrophysiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the musculature as it relates to electrical phenomena

Subject: absent M line
Value: missing the band in the center of the H band that contains proteins that crosslink the thick filament system (myosins) and the M-band part of the elastic filaments

Subject: increased porphyrin level
Value: elevated concentration of porphyrins or protoporphyrins

Subject: increased compact bone thickness
