Value: thicker than normal superficial layer of compact bone

Subject: increased bone strength
Value: increased ability of bone to endure the application of force without yielding or breaking

Subject: absent caveolae
Value: absence of the small pockets, vesicles, caves, or recesses communicating with the outside of a cell and extending inward, indenting the cytoplasm and the cell membrane

Subject: decreased circulating iron level
Value: less than the normal concentration of iron in the blood

Subject: abnormal circulating iron level
Value: anomalous blood concentration of the metallic element that normally occurs in the heme of hemoglobin, myoglobin, transferrin, ferritin, and iron-containing porphyrins; it is an essential component of enzymes such as catalase, peroxidase, and various cytochromes

Subject: increased renal tubule apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of renal tubule cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: renal tubular necrosis
Value: morphological changes resulting from pathological death of renal tubular tissue; usually due to irreversible damage

Subject: decreased susceptibility to induced pancreatitis
Value: reduced or absent inflammatory response in the pancreatic tissue after experimental manipulation

Subject: abnormal QT variability
Value: anomaly in the index of beat-to-beat QT interval fluctuations (temporal QT interval variability), normally expressed as a unitless negative number reflecting beat-to-beat changes in ventricular repolarization; an increased, positive QTVI number indicates significant repolarization abnormalities

Subject: interrupted aortic arch
Value: complete discontinuation between the ascending and descending aorta; includes Type A, interruption distal to the subclavian artery that is ipsilateral to the second carotid artery, and Type B, interruption between second carotid artery and ipsilateral subclavian artery

Subject: right aortic arch
Value: the aortic arch lies to the right of the trachea and esophagus; results from persistence of the entire right dorsal arch and involution of a segment of the left arch

Subject: double aortic arch
Value: defect in which the main aorta tube splits into large left and right branches (right and left aortic arches), encircling the trachea and esophagus, before becoming one tube to go to the lower body

Subject: retroesophageal right subclavian artery
Value: the subclavian artery aberrantly originates from the aortic arch distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery, i.e., it is the last branch of the aortic arch

Subject: cervical aortic arch
Value: aortic arch is located above the level of the clavicle

Subject: abnormal mammillary body morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the protrusion at the posterior end of the hypothalamus that contains hypothalamic nuclei

Subject: abnormal adenohypophysis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anterior part of the pituitary that secretes a variety of hormones; its function is regulated by the hypothalamus

Subject: abnormal neurohypophysis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the posterior part of the pituitary gland that secretes hormones involved in blood pressure regulation such as oxytocin and antidiuretic hormone

Subject: abnormal lateral geniculate nucleus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the group of neurons that serve as the primary processor of visual information received from the retina via the optic tract and send processed information to the visual cortex of the occipital lobe

Subject: abnormal limbic system morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of a collection of structures in the brain involved in emotion, motivation and emotional aspects of memory; these structures act together to control the endocrine system and the autonomic nervous system

Subject: abnormal cingulate gyrus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the ridge in the cerebral cortex located dorsal to the corpus callosum that controls autonomic functions regulating heart rate and blood pressure as well as cognitive and attentional processing

Subject: abnormal parahippocampal gyrus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the ridge in the cerebral cortex that contains the olfactory cortex and that plays a role in the formation of topographical memory

Subject: abnormal fornicate gyrus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the horseshoe-shaped gyrus of the cerebral cortex that consists of the cingulate gyrus and the parahippocampal gyrus

Subject: abnormal orbitofrontal cortex morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the region of the cerebral cortex covering the basal surface of the frontal lobes; this region normally controls emotion and decision making

Subject: abnormal pallium development
Value: anomaly in the progression of the formation of the roof region of the telencephalon

Subject: abnormal subpallium development
Value: anomaly in the progression of the formation of the base region of the telencephalon

Subject: abnormal intervertebral disk morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cartilaginous and gelatinous structure found between vertebrae

Subject: abnormal spine curvature
Value: deviation from the typical S-shape of the spine

Subject: telangiectases
Value: vascular lesion formed by dilation of a group of small blood vessels

Subject: ear telangiectases
Value: vascular lesion formed by dilation of a group of small blood vessels in the ear

Subject: tail telangiectases
Value: vascular lesion formed by dilation of a group of small blood vessels in the tail

Subject: neck telangiectases
Value: vascular lesion formed by dilation of a group of small blood vessels in the neck

Subject: transmission ratio distortion
Value: the frequency that an allele or haplotype in the offspring of an organism deviates from expected Mendelian ratios

Subject: failure of initiation of embryo turning
Value: failure to begin the axial rotation of the germ layers of the embryo during the primitive streak/early somite stage

Subject: abnormal carotid artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bilaterally paired branched arteries that deliver oxygenated nutrient filled blood from the heart to the head, neck, and brain; of the two common carotid arteries, which extend headward on each side of the anterior neck, the left originates in the arch of the aorta over the heart; the right originates in the brachiocephalic trunk, the largest branch from the arch of the aorta; each common carotid artery divides into an external and an internal carotid artery near the top of the thyroid

Subject: abnormal spermiation
Value: anomaly in the process by which mature spermatozoa release from supporting Sertoli cells into the lumen of seminiferous tubules

Subject: abnormal sympathetic nervous system physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the part of the autonomic nervous system that innervates smooth muscle, cardiac muscle and glands and mediates the body's response to stressful situations

Subject: abnormal baroreceptor physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the sensory nerve endings found in the wall of the atria of the heart, vena cava, aortic arch and carotid sinus that are sensitive to changes in blood pressure

Subject: abnormal adipocyte glucose uptake
Value: anomaly in the ability of adipocytes to take in glucose

Subject: abnormal area postrema morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small, elevated area in the lateral wall of the inferior recess of the fourth ventricle, involved in the control of cardiorespiratory physiology; in addition, the area postrema is the location of the chemotoxic trigger zone at which emesis (vomiting) is induced by various toxins in the blood stream and that affect the hypothalamus to induce taste aversion

Subject: cardia bifida
Value: failure of the bilateral myocardial cells to coalesce into a single central heart tube resulting in the presence of two independent hearts

Subject: delayed embryo turning
Value: completion of axial rotation occurs later than in controls but is eventually completed

Subject: abnormal alveolar process morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thickened ridge of bone in the mandible and maxilla that holds the tooth sockets

Subject: abnormal direction of embryo turning
Value: axial rotation of the embryo in a direction other than the normal anticlockwise direction when viewed towards the caudal pole during the late primitive streak/early somite stage; clockwise rotation is frequently associated with heart and visceral defects

Subject: neuronal intranuclear inclusions
Value: presence of aggregates of protein within the nuclei of neurons; frequently seen in Huntington's disease

Subject: abnormal kidney pyramid morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the conical mass of tissue, containing part of the secreting and collecting tubules, whose base faces the renal cortex

Subject: abnormal kidney papilla morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the apex of the renal pyramid that projects into a calyx

Subject: abnormal kidney pelvis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the area at the center of the kidney formed by convergence of the major calices where urine collects and is funneled into the ureter

Subject: abnormal kidney calyx morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the branches of the renal pelvis that surround each renal papilla and collect urine

Subject: abnormal prenatal growth/weight/body size
Value: limited or accelerated growth or development apparent before birth

Subject: abnormal fetal growth/weight/body size
Value: <limited or accelerated growth or development apparent during the fetal period (sensu Mus: from E14 through birth)>

Subject: abnormal fetal size
Value: <anomalous proportions of a fetus compared to littermates (sensu Mus: from E14 through birth)>

Subject: increased fetal size
Value: <larger proportions of a fetus compared to littermates (sensu Mus: from E14 through birth)>

Subject: decreased fetal size
Value: <smaller proportions of a fetus compared to littermates (sensu Mus: from E14 through birth)>

Subject: fetal growth retardation
Value: <slow or limited development during the fetal period (sensu Mus: from E14 through birth)>

Subject: pulmonary hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due an increased number of cells of the respiratory organ in all or part of the organ

Subject: abnormal cranial flexure morphology
Value: any structural anomaly or absence of the sharp, ventrally concave bend in the developing midbrain of the embryo

Subject: absent stapes
Value: absence of the smallest and innermost of the three auditory ossicles

Subject: absent hyoid bone
Value: absence of the U-shaped bone lying between the mandible and the larynx that supports the tongue muscles

Subject: abnormal dermomyotome development
Value: any structural anomaly of the portion of the embryonic somite that remains after migration of the sclerotomic tissue

Subject: increased squamous cell carcinoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of a carcinoma that arises from stratified squamous epithelium that occurs in sites where glandular or columnar epithelium is normally present, such as the skin, esophagus, lungs and cervix

Subject: increased basal cell carcinoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a slow-growing, invasive, but usually non-metastasizing neoplasm that originates from basal keratinocytes in the epidermis, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: abnormal sweet taste sensitivity
Value: changes in the ability to perceive a particular flavor or suggestion of something sweet by the chemoreceptors of the gustatory system

Subject: abnormal bitter taste sensitivity
Value: changes in the ability to perceive a particular flavor or suggestion of something bitter by the chemoreceptors of the gustatory system

Subject: abnormal sour taste sensitivity
Value: changes in the ability to perceive a particular flavor or suggestion of something sour by the chemoreceptors of the gustatory system

Subject: abnormal salty taste sensitivity
Value: changes in the ability to perceive a particular flavor or suggestion of something salty by the chemoreceptors of the gustatory system

Subject: abnormal umami taste sensitivity
Value: changes in the ability to perceive a particular flavor or suggestion of something umami (savory) by the chemoreceptors of the gustatory system

Subject: abnormal long bone diaphysis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the main or mid section (shaft) of a long bone

Subject: abnormal myocardial fiber physiology
Value: anomaly in the function of the terminally differentiated, non-proliferative, multinucleated muscle cells of the heart

Subject: salt-resistant hypertension
Value: sustained high blood pressure that is maintained regardless of the amount of salt consumed in the diet

Subject: salt-sensitive hypertension
Value: sustained high blood pressure that is maintained with a normal or increase in the amount of salt consumed in the diet; blood pressure may return to normotensive with a low salt diet

Subject: meiotic nondisjunction during M1 phase
Value: abnormal separation of pairs of homologous chromosomes during anaphase of the first meiotic division such that each daughter cell receives one set of paired chromosomes

Subject: meiotic nondisjunction during M2 phase
Value: abnormal separation of chromosomes during anaphase of the second meiotic division such that one complete chromosome goes to each daughter cell

Subject: abnormal peripheral nervous system regeneration
Value: changes in the ability or inability of healthy peripheral nervous system tissue to regenerate following injury or disease

Subject: abnormal iridocorneal angle
Value: any structural anomaly of the acute angle occurring between the iris and the cornea at the periphery of the anterior chamber of the eye

Subject: iris synechia
Value: an adhesion (synechia) of the iris to the cornea or lens of the eye that may develop from glaucoma, cataracts, uveitis, or keratitis or as a complication of surgery or trauma to the eye; synechiae may prevent or impede flow of aqueous fluid between the anterior and posterior chambers of the eye, resulting in angle closure glaucoma

Subject: hypoplastic trabecular meshwork
Value: reduced size of the pore-like structure surrounding the entire circumference of the anterior chamber through which aqueous humor circulates

Subject: absent trabecular meshwork
Value: absence of the pore-like structure surrounding the entire circumference of the anterior chamber through which aqueous humor circulates

Subject: patent cardiac foramen ovale
Value: incomplete closure of the atrial septum after birth, resulting in a flap or a valve-like opening in the atrial septal wall

Subject: absent Schlemm's canal
Value: absence of the vascular structure encircling the anterior chamber of the eye, through which the aqueous humor is returned to the blood circulation

Subject: increased cellular sensitivity to ionizing radiation
Value: increased incidence of cell death following exposure to ionizing radiation

Subject: decreased cellular sensitivity to ionizing radiation
Value: decreased incidence of cell death following exposure to ionizing radiation

Subject: abnormal embryonic erythropoiesis
Value: anomaly in the development of primarily large, nucleated erythroblasts occurring in blood islands in the yolk sac, generally occurs from E7-E11 in the mouse and through 10 weeks in humans

Subject: abnormal embryonic erythrocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the embryonic blood cells that carry oxygen; embryonic erythrocytes arise from yolk sac blood islands and express different types of hemoglobins (beta-H1, gamma-1 and zeta) than adult erythrocytes, and can enucleate in circulation

Subject: abnormal calcium ion homeostasis
Value: anomaly in the processes involved in the maintenance of an internal equilibrium of calcium ions within the body or between a cell and its external environment

Subject: decreased muscle weight
Value: less than average muscle weight

Subject: abnormal muscle weight
Value: any anomaly in the average muscle weight

Subject: abnormal masticatory muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the muscles responsible for the movement of the jaws during mastication, including the masseter, temporal, and medial and lateral pterygoid muscles

Subject: abnormal masseter muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the masticatory muscle of posterior cheek with origin from the inferior border and medial surface of the zygomatic arch, with insertion into the lateral surface of the ramus of the mandible, with nerve supply from the masseteric nerve, and whose action closes the jaw during chewing

Subject: absent masseter muscle
Value: absence of the masticatory muscle of posterior cheek

Subject: abnormal pterygoid muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the muscles descending from the sphenoid bone to the lower jaw including the internal, or medial, pterygoid muscle and external, or lateral, pterygoid muscle; the action of the former is closing the jaws and that of the latter is opening the jaws, protruding the mandible, and moving the mandible from side to side

Subject: absent pterygoid muscle
Value: absence of either the internal or external or of both pterygoid muscles

Subject: abnormal temporalis muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the superior-most masticatory muscle whose action is closing the jaws; its posterior portion retracts the mandible

Subject: absent temporalis muscle
Value: absence of the superior-most masticatory muscle whose action is closing the jaws; its posterior portion retracts the mandible

Subject: acantholysis
Value: separation of prickle cells of the spinous layer of the epidermis, resulting in atrophy of the prickle cell layer, as in conditions such as pemphigus vulgaris and Darier disease

Subject: abnormal plasmacytoid dendritic cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of phagocytic dendritic cells that are morphologically similar to plasma cells, but do not express B lineage markers, and produce large amounts of alpha/beta interferons (IFN-/) in response to viral and bacterial stimuli; plasmacytoid dendritic cells are found in the thymic medulla and lymph node T cell areas and are responsible for immune tolerance

Subject: abnormal motor nerve collateral sprouting
Value: aberrant response of a motor neuron to form new neuritic processes (sprouts) that emerge from the nodes of Ranvier or terminal arborizations in response to nerve injury (such as denervation), application of nerve toxin, or muscle inactivity (usually due to disease)

Subject: abnormal miscarriage rate
Value: change in frequency of a natural or accidental termination of a pregnancy at a stage where the embryo or the fetus is incapable of surviving independently of the mother

Subject: genital hemorrhage
Value: bleeding into the genitals

Subject: abnormal extensor digitorum longus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the penniform muscle of the lateral front part of the leg responsible for extension of the toes and dorsiflexion of the ankle

Subject: small pancreas
Value: decrease of the size of the pancreas compared to controls

Subject: abnormal epaxial muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the muscles derived from the medial myotome; includes the intrinsic back muscles

Subject: abnormal crista ampullaris morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the elevation found on the inner surface of the ampullae of each semicircular duct; filaments of the vestibular nerve pass through the crista to reach hair cells on its surface; the hair cells are capped by the cupula, a gelatinous protein-polysaccharide mass

Subject: tau protein deposits
Value: formation of self-assembled tangles of paired helical filaments and straight filaments due to hyperphosphorylation of the tau protein; often seen in neuronal tissues of individuals with neurodegenerative disorders

Subject: failure of heart looping
Value: failure of the primitive heart tube to loop asymmetrically during early development

Subject: abnormal direction of heart looping
Value: deviation from the characteristic rightward direction of looping of the primitive heart tube; frequently seen in heterotaxy syndromes

Subject: bifid atrial appendage
Value: a cardiac anomaly whereby the left or right atrial appendage is cleaved, forming two separate pouches connected by a thin strand of muscular tissue

Subject: cerebral amyloid angiopathy
Value: a pathological condition where there is a deposition of amyloid in the walls of the small cerebral vessels which supply the brain; this results in an increased risk of infarcts and/or intracerebral hemorrhage, possibly resulting in dementia

Subject: abnormal spongiotrophoblast layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the middle layer of the placenta between the outermost giant cells and the innermost labyrinth layer; it has a structural role and also produces several layer-specific secreted factors

Subject: abnormal maternal decidual layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the maternal uterine-derived portion of the placenta

Subject: abnormal placenta weight
Value: any change in the weight of the organ of metabolic interchange between fetus and mother

Subject: abnormal placenta size
Value: anomaly in the size or shape of the organ of metabolic interchange between fetus and mother

Subject: small placenta
Value: reduced size of the size or shape of the organ of metabolic interchange between fetus and mother

Subject: enlarged placenta
Value: increased size of the size or shape of the organ of metabolic interchange between fetus and mother

Subject: abnormal embryonic neuroepithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the epithelial cell layer that lines the neural tube and develops into the nervous system and into the neural crest cells

Subject: abnormal physical strength
Value: altered ability of an organism to exert force on physical objects or of the body to support its load

Subject: abnormal limb posture
Value: atypical intentionally or habitually assumed position of the limbs compared to the normal carriage of the body

Subject: abnormal extraembryonic tissue physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the membranes involved with embryonic protection and nutrition

Subject: abnormal placental transport
Value: anomaly in the conveyance of metabolic products and nutrients across the placenta

Subject: pale placenta
Value: placenta lacking normal reddish coloration, often refers to bloodless condition

Subject: abnormal optic tract morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the paired bands of optic nerve fibers running from the optic chiasma mostly to the lateral geniculate body, with a smaller number of fibers terminating in the superior colliculus and the pretectal region

Subject: abnormal optic stalk morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the narrow, proximal portion of the optic vesicle which connects the embryonic eye and forebrain

Subject: abnormal optic cup morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of double walled structure formed by expansion and invagination of the distal end of the optic vesicle that develops into the pigmented and neuronal layers of the retina, with the mouth of the optic cup developing into the pupil of the eye

Subject: analgesia
Value: inability to sense pain

Subject: abnormal basement membrane morphology
Value: anomaly in the structure, organization and/or placement of the extracellular supportive tissue adjacent to the basal surface of the epithelia, including the epithelium of muscle cells, fat cells and Schwann cells; it is comprised of type IV collagen, laminin, and sulfated proteoglycans and other components and consists of two layers, the basal lamina and the lamina reticularis

Subject: abnormal basal lamina morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the sheet of extracellular matrix characteristically situated under epithelial cells, around muscles, nerves, capillaries, and fat cells, and situated between these elements and the underlying or surrounding connective tissue

Subject: abnormal embryonic/fetal subventricular zone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the transient proliferative population of neurons that expands exponentially during late prenatal development; it is a continuous germinal zone distinct from the ventricular zone that surrounds the brain ventricles

Subject: abnormal postnatal subventricular zone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the mitotically active layer of cells surrounding the brain ventricles in the adult that consists of migrating neuroblasts, astrocytes and transitory amplifying progenitor cells

Subject: abnormal medial ganglionic eminence morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a distinct elevation of a transient proliferating cell mass of the fetal subventricular zone; this mass contributes most of its cells to the neocortex; however, hippocampal neurons, thalamus, septum and olfactory bulb neurons are also partly derived from the MGE

Subject: abnormal lateral ganglionic eminence morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a distinct elevation of a transient proliferating cell mass of the fetal subventricular zone; this mass contributes most of its cells to the striatum; however, neocortex, thalamus, septum and olfactory bulb neurons are also partly derived from the LGE

Subject: abnormal caudal ganglionic eminence morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the caudally located, distinct elevation of a transient proliferating cell mass of the fetal subventricular zone, located adjacent to the lateral ventricle

Subject: abnormal rostral migratory stream morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the transient structure formed by neurons migrating from the subventricular zone into the olfactory bulbs

Subject: abnormal oculomotor nucleus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the group of motor neurons in the floor of the midbrain that gives rise to motor fibers of the oculomotor nerve

Subject: abnormal hypoglossal nucleus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the group of motor neurons throughout most of the length of the medulla oblongata that give rise to the motor fibers of the hypoglossal nerve

Subject: retrognathia
Value: abnormal posterior-shifted positioning of the upper or lower jaw relative to the facial skeleton and soft tissues; a type of malocclusion, that is, misalignment of the teeth caused by abnormal positioning of the jaws; the mandible is more frequently affected than the maxilla

Subject: absent corneal endothelium
Value: absence of the single layer of large flattened cells that cover the surface of the cornea

Subject: abnormal Descemet membrane morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the transparent homogeneous acellular layer found between the substantia propria and the endothelial layer of the cornea, considered to be a highly developed basement membrane

Subject: absent Descemet membrane
Value: absence of the transparent homogeneous acellular layer normally found between the substantia propria and the endothelial layer of the cornea

Subject: abnormal internal auditory canal morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the canal beginning at the opening of the internal acoustic meatus in the posterior cranial fossa, passing laterally through the petrous portion of the temporal bone to end at the fundus, where a thin plate of bone separates it from the vestibule; it gives passage to the facial and vestibulocochlear nerves together with the labyrinthine artery and veins

Subject: abnormal spiral limbus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the border of the spiral lamina, i.e. the thickened periosteum covering the upper plate of the bony spiral lamina of the cochlea

Subject: abnormal spiral ligament morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the thickened periosteal lining of the bony cochlea that forms the outer wall of the cochlear duct to which the basal lamina attaches

Subject: abnormal bony labyrinth
Value: any structural anomaly in the series of cavities (cochlea, vestibule, and semicircular canals) contained within the otic capsule of the petrous portion of the temporal bone; the bony labyrinth is filled with perilymph, in which the delicate, endolymph-filled membranous labyrinth is suspended

Subject: abnormal stapes footplate morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the flat portion of the stapes that fits in the oval window

Subject: abnormal spiral ligament fibrocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the four types of fibrocytes (types I, II , III and IV) that constitute the spiral ligament

Subject: abnormal type I spiral ligament fibrocytes
Value: any structural anomaly of type I spiral ligament fibrocytes which occupy the region beneath the stria vascularis

Subject: abnormal type II spiral ligament fibrocytes
Value: any structural anomaly of type II spiral ligament fibrocytes found in the suprastrial zone and the central area of the spiral ligament beneath the spiral prominence

Subject: abnormal type III spiral ligament fibrocytes
Value: any structural anomaly of type III spiral ligament fibrocytes which form a cell layer attached to the otic capsule

Subject: abnormal type IV spiral ligament fibrocytes
Value: any structural anomaly of type IV spiral ligament fibrocytes found in the triangular space inferior to the basilar crest

Subject: abnormal proprioceptive neuron morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the sensory neurons of the dorsal root ganglia that sense body position and send information about how much the muscle is stretched to the spinal cord

Subject: vestibular ganglion degeneration
Value: loss of the group of bipolar sensory nerve cell bodies concerned with equilibration that form a swelling on the vestibular part of the eighth cranial nerve in the fundus of the internal acoustic meatus

Subject: absent vestibular ganglion
Value: absence of the group of bipolar sensory nerve cell bodies concerned with equilibration that form a swelling on the vestibular part of the eighth cranial nerve in the fundus of the internal acoustic meatus

Subject: abnormal organ of Corti supporting cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the highly differentiated epithelial cells with distinctive morphological features surrounding the hair cells in the organ of Corti; inner hair cells (IHCs) are normally surrounded by (inner and outer) phalangeal cells while OHCs are in contact with Deiters and pillar cells; Hensen cells are positioned further laterally in the organ of Corti

Subject: absent organ of Corti supporting cells
Value: absence of the highly differentiated epithelial cells with distinctive morphological features that surround all hair cells in the organ of Corti

Subject: abnormal Deiters cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the supporting cells of the spiral organ which are attached to the basement membrane and receive the hair cells between their free extremities

Subject: abnormal Hensen cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the supporting cells that form the lateral border of the organ of Corti, immediately to the outer side of Deiters' cells

Subject: absent spiral limbus
Value: absence of the border of the spiral lamina, i.e. the thickened periosteum covering the upper plate of the bony spiral lamina of the cochlea

Subject: abnormal Rosenthal canal morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the winding tube of the bony labyrinth that makes two and a half turns about the modiolus of the cochlea; it is divided incompletely into two compartments by a winding shelf of bone, the bony spiral lamina

Subject: small Rosenthal canal
Value: reduced size of the winding tube of the bony labyrinth that makes two and a half turns about the modiolus of the cochlea

Subject: absent Rosenthal canal
Value: absence of the winding tube of the bony labyrinth that makes two and a half turns about the modiolus of the cochlea

Subject: abnormal basilar membrane morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the membrane extending from the bony spiral membrane to the basilar crest of the cochlea; it forms the greater part of the floor of the cochlear duct separating the latter from the scala tympani, and it supports the organ of Corti

Subject: absent otic vesicle
Value: absence of the simple epithelial sac formed from the otic placode that gives rise to the structures of the inner ear

Subject: small otic vesicle
Value: reduced size of the simple epithelial sac formed from the otic placode that gives rise to the structures of the inner ear

Subject: otic vesicle hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment of the simple epithelial sac formed from the otic placode that gives rise to the structures of the inner ear, usually due to a reduction in cell number

Subject: absent pillar cells
Value: absence of the supporting cells that form the inner and outer walls of the tunnel in the organ of Corti

Subject: absent vestibulocochlear ganglion
Value: absence of the group of neuron cell bodies associated with the eighth cranial nerve during embryogenesis; splits in later development to form the cochlear and vestibular ganglia

Subject: absent inner ear vestibule
Value: absence of the cavity between the semicircular canals and the cochlea of the inner ear

Subject: absent vestibular saccule
Value: absence of the smaller of the two sacs in the vestibule

Subject: enlarged vestibular saccule
Value: enlarged size of the cavity between the semicircular canals and the cochlea of the inner ear

Subject: small vestibular saccule
Value: reduced size of the cavity between the semicircular canals and the cochlea of the inner ear

Subject: absent incus
Value: absence of the middle of the three auditory ossicles

Subject: absent malleus
Value: absence of the largest of the three auditory ossicles, which resembles a club or hammer

Subject: split sternum
Value: the appearance of an abnormal division in the long flat bone of the chest which articulates with clavicle and first seven rib pairs

Subject: short sternum
Value: reduced length of the long flat bone of the chest which articulates with clavicle and first seven rib pairs

Subject: abnormal sternebra morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of one segments of the primordial sternum of the embryo; these segments fuse to form the body of the adult vertebrate sternum

Subject: sternum hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, in the sternum

Subject: vestibular hair cell degeneration
Value: degeneration or loss of the sensory epithelial cells of the maculae and cristae of the membranous labyrinth of the inner ear which are normally in synaptic contact with the vestibular nerve

Subject: absent vestibular hair cells
Value: absence of the sensory epithelial cells of the maculae and cristae of the membranous labyrinth of the inner ear which are normally in synaptic contact with the vestibular nerve

Subject: abnormal vestibular hair cell number
Value: abnormal number of cells in the sensory epithelium of the maculae and cristae of the membranous labyrinth of the internal ear

Subject: increased vestibular hair cell number
Value: increased number of cells in the sensory epithelium of the maculae and cristae of the membranous labyrinth of the internal ear which are normally in synaptic contact with the vestibular nerve

Subject: decreased vestibular hair cell number
Value: decreased number of cells in the sensory epithelium of the maculae and cristae of the membranous labyrinth of the internal ear which are normally in synaptic contact with the vestibular nerve

Subject: vestibular saccular degeneration
Value: degeneration or loss of the smaller of the two sacs in the vestibule

Subject: abnormal vestibular saccular macula morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the oval neuroepithelial sensory receptor in the anterior wall of the saccule; hair cells of the neuroepithelium support the statoconial membrane and have terminal arborizations of vestibular nerve fibers around their bodies

Subject: vestibular saccular macula degeneration
Value: degeneration or loss of the oval neuroepithelial sensory receptor in the anterior wall of the saccule

Subject: utricular degeneration
Value: degeneration or loss of the larger of the two sacs in the vestibule

Subject: abnormal utricular macula morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the neuroepithelial sensory receptor in the inferolateral wall of the utricle; hair cells of the neuroepithelium support the statoconial membrane and have terminal arborizations of vestibular nerve fibers around their bodies; normally sensitive to linear acceleration in the longitudinal axis of the body and to gravitational influences

Subject: utricular macular degeneration
Value: degeneration or loss of the neuroepithelial sensory receptor in the inferolateral wall of the utricle

Subject: enlarged utricle
Value: increased size of the larger of the two sacs in the vestibule

Subject: small utricle
Value: reduced size of the larger of the two sacs in the vestibule

Subject: clavicle hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of one or both of the doubly curved long bone that forms part of the shoulder girdle and articulates with the sternum and the scapula

Subject: small clavicle
Value: reduced size of one or both of the doubly curved long bone that forms part of the shoulder girdle and articulates with the sternum and the scapula

Subject: absent clavicle
Value: missing one or both of the doubly curved long bone that forms part of the shoulder girdle and articulates with the sternum and the scapula

Subject: short scapula
Value: reduced length of either or both of the large, flat bones of the back part of the shoulder

Subject: absent scapula
Value: missing either or both of the large, flat bones of the back part of the shoulder

Subject: scapular bone foramen
Value: presence of a hole in either or both of the large, flat bones of the back part of the shoulder

Subject: small scapula
Value: reduced size of either or both of the large, flat bones of the back part of the shoulder

Subject: scapular bone hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, in either or both of the large, flat bones of the back part of the shoulder

Subject: abnormal acromion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the lateral end of the spine of the scapula which projects as a broad flattened process and articulates with the clavicle, and forms the point of the shoulder

Subject: absent acromion
Value: lack of the lateral end of the spine of the scapula which projects as a broad flattened process and articulates with the clavicle, and forms the point of the shoulder

Subject: abnormal scapular spine morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the triangular ridge on the dorsal aspect of the scapula which separates the supra- from the infraspinatous fossa and where the trapezius and deltoid muscles are attached

Subject: long femur
Value: increased length of the long bone of the thigh

Subject: absent femur
Value: missing the long bone of the thigh

Subject: long humerus
Value: increased length of one or both of the bones of the forelimb that articulates with the scapula above and the radius and ulna below

Subject: short humerus
Value: reduced length of one or both of the bones of the forelimb that articulates with the scapula above and the radius and ulna below

Subject: absent humerus
Value: missing one or both of the bones of the forelimb that articulates with the scapula above and the radius and ulna below

Subject: abnormal deltoid tuberosity morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a rough elevation at the middle of the lateral side of the shaft of the humerus to which the deltoid muscle attaches

Subject: absent deltoid tuberosity
Value: missing the rough elevation at the middle of the lateral side of the shaft of the humerus to which the deltoid muscle attaches

Subject: short radius
Value: reduced length of the short bone of the lateral forearm

Subject: radius hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, in the short bone of the lateral forearm

Subject: long tibia
Value: increased length of the medial and larger of the two bones of the lower leg

Subject: bowed tibia
Value: increased curvature of the medial and larger of the two bones of the lower leg

Subject: short ulna
Value: reduced length of the medial and larger of the two bones of the forearm

Subject: absent ulna
Value: missing the medial and larger of the two bones of the forearm

Subject: bowed ulna
Value: increased curvature of the medial and larger of the two bones of the forearm

Subject: cochlear hair cell degeneration
Value: degeneration or loss of the sensory epithelial cells of the cochlea; these cells are in synaptic contact with the auditory nerve

Subject: stria vascularis degeneration
Value: degeneration or loss of the stratified, secretory epithelium which lines the upper part of the cochlear spiral ligament and maintains potassium ion homeostasis in the endolymph

Subject: thin stria vascularis
Value: reduced thickness of the stratified, secretory epithelium which lines the upper part of the cochlear spiral ligament and maintains potassium ion homeostasis in the endolymph

Subject: abnormal strial basal cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the polarized cells which are juxtaposed to fibrocytes in the underlying spiral ligament

Subject: abnormal strial marginal cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the polarized columnar cells of epithelial origin which cover the lateral surface of the cochlear duct, secrete potassium ions and form a continuous sheet in contact with the endolymph; marginal cells form extensive interdigitations with the basal and intermediate cells in the normal adult stria

Subject: abnormal strial intermediate cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the melanocytes known to migrate from the neural crest during ontogeny to become located between the epithelial marginal cell layer and the mesodermal basal cell layer within the intrastrial space; the predominant cellular component of the electrogenic machinery that generates an endocochlear potential (80-100 mV)

Subject: abnormal stria vascularis vasculature morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the blood vessels supplying the stria vascularis in the cochlea of the inner ear

Subject: absent utricle
Value: absence of the larger of the two sacs in the vestibule

Subject: long ulna
Value: increased length of the medial and larger of the two bones of the forearm

Subject: bowed femur
Value: increased curvature of the long bone of the thigh

Subject: bowed fibula
Value: increased curvature of the lateral and smaller bone of the lower limb

Subject: bowed humerus
Value: increased curvature of the bone of the forelimb that articulates with the scapula above and the radius and ulna below

Subject: bowed radius
Value: increased curvature of the short bone of the lateral forearm

Subject: enlarged frontal bone
Value: increased size of the bone forming the forehead and roof of the eye orbit

Subject: absent frontal bone
Value: absence of the bone forming the forehead and roof of the eye orbit

Subject: small frontal bone
Value: reduced size of the bone forming the forehead and roof of the eye orbit

Subject: frontal bone foramen
Value: presence of a hole in the bone forming the forehead and roof of the eye orbit

Subject: wide frontal bone
Value: increased width of the bone forming the forehead and roof of the eye orbit

Subject: short frontal bone
Value: reduced length of the bone forming the forehead and roof of the eye orbit

Subject: abnormal hair follicle melanocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cells that produce pigment in the hair follicles

Subject: abnormal hair follicle melanogenesis
Value: failure of or anomaly in the biosynthetic pathway of melanin formation in hair follicles

Subject: absent interparietal bone
Value: absence of the bone of the cranium that lies above and anterior to the occipital bone in some mammals

Subject: small interparietal bone
Value: reduced size of the bone of the cranium that lies above and anterior to the occipital bone in some mammals

Subject: interparietal bone hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, in the bone of the cranium that lies above and anterior to the occipital bone in some mammals

Subject: enlarged interparietal bone
Value: increased size of the bone of the cranium that lies above and anterior to the occipital bone in some mammals

Subject: abnormal prechordal plate morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the horseshoe-shaped thickening of the endoderm at the cranial (rostral) end of the primitive streak formed by the involution of Spemann's organizer cells which, together with the notochord, induces the formation of the neural plate from the overlying ectodermal cells and contributes mesodermal type cells to the surrounding tissue

Subject: absent prechordal plate
Value: absence of the horseshoe-shaped thickening of the endoderm at the cranial (rostral) end of the primitive streak formed by the involution of Spemann's organizer cells which, together with the notochord, induces the formation of the neural plate from the overlying ectodermal cells and contributes mesodermal type cells to the surrounding tissue

Subject: abnormal respiratory bronchiole morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the smallest bronchioles, which connect the terminal bronchioles to alveolar ducts and have alveoli rising from their walls

Subject: abnormal bronchoalveolar duct junction morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the branch point connecting the respiratory bronchioles to the alveolar ducts

Subject: abnormal respiratory conducting tube morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tubes of the respiratory system that allow passage of air from the trachea to the terminal bronchioles

Subject: abnormal CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the subset of T lymphocytes that express the CD8 marker on the cell surface

Subject: abnormal cochlear inner hair cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the sensory cells of the organ of Corti which are in synaptic contact with sensory as well as efferent fibers of the auditory nerve; there is a single row of flask-shaped inner hair cells tightly surrounded by supporting interphalangeal cells; the apical end of each cell is anchored to the cuticular plate and about 100 stereocilia arranged in a more or less linear (or shallow) U-shaped pattern extend from the cell's surface through the cuticular plate into the endolymphic space inferior to the tectorial membrane

Subject: abnormal cochlear inner hair cell number
Value: abnormal number of the flask-shaped inner hair sensory cells of the organ of Corti which are in synaptic contact with sensory as well as efferent fibers of the auditory nerve

Subject: increased cochlear inner hair cell number
Value: increased number (or more than the expected single row) of the flask-shaped inner hair sensory cells of the organ of Corti

Subject: decreased cochlear inner hair cell number
Value: decreased number (or less than the expected single row) of the flask-shaped inner hair sensory cells of the organ of Corti

Subject: absent cochlear inner hair cells
Value: absence of the single row of flask-shaped inner hair sensory cells of the organ of Corti

Subject: cochlear inner hair cell degeneration
Value: degeneration or loss of the single row of flask-shaped inner hair sensory cells of the organ of Corti

Subject: abnormal cochlear outer hair cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the sensory cells of the organ of Corti which are in synaptic contact with sensory as well as efferent fibers of the auditory nerve; there are three rows of columnar outer hair cells largely surrounded by cortilymph and supporting phalangeal cells; the apical end of each cell is anchored to the cuticular plate and about 100 stereocilia arranged in a V-shaped pattern extend from the cell's surface through the cuticular plate into the tectorial membrane

Subject: abnormal cochlear outer hair cell number
Value: abnormal number of the columnar outer hair sensory cells of the organ of Corti

Subject: increased cochlear outer hair cell number
Value: increased number (or more than the expected 3 rows) of the columnar outer hair sensory cells of the organ of Corti

Subject: decreased cochlear outer hair cell number
Value: decreased number (or less than the expected 3 rows) of the columnar outer hair sensory cells of the organ of Corti

Subject: absent cochlear outer hair cells
Value: absence of the columnar outer hair sensory cells of the organ of Corti

Subject: cochlear outer hair cell degeneration
Value: degeneration or loss of the columnar outer hair sensory cells of the organ of Corti

Subject: absent cochlear hair cells
Value: absence of the sensory epithelial cells of the cochlea; these cells are normally in synaptic contact with the auditory nerve

Subject: abnormal cochlear hair cell number
Value: abnormal number of the sensory epithelial cells of the cochlea, which are normally in synaptic contact with the auditory nerve

Subject: increased cochlear hair cell number
Value: increased number of the sensory epithelial cells of the cochlea, which are normally in synaptic contact with the auditory nerve

Subject: decreased cochlear hair cell number
Value: decreased number of the sensory epithelial cells of the cochlea, which are normally in synaptic contact with the auditory nerve

Subject: abnormal crista ampullaris neuroepithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the specialized sensory hair cells of the ampullary crest of the ampulla of each semicircular duct

Subject: absent endocochlear potential
Value: absence of the electrical potential difference between the endolymphatic and perilymphatic compartments of the cochlea, indicating a primary defect in fluid homeostasis of the inner ear

Subject: decreased endocochlear potential
Value: reduction of the electrical potential difference between the endolymphatic and perilymphatic compartments of the cochlea

Subject: abnormal cochlear microphonics
Value: any anomaly in the bioelectric potentials produced by the hair cells of the organ of Corti in response to sound; the cochlear microphonic (CM) is an electric response dominated by OHC receptor potentials from the basal turn of the cochlea and provides a measure of transducer function in OHCs; in an active ear, CM waveforms show post-stimulus ringing (i.e. a cochlear echo) whereas in a passive ear system, CM decays at the cessation of the tone burst

Subject: absent cochlear microphonics
Value: absence or loss of the bioelectric potentials produced by the hair cells of the organ of Corti in response to sound

Subject: decreased cochlear microphonics
Value: reduction of the bioelectric potentials produced by the hair cells of the organ of Corti in response to sound

Subject: abnormal cochlear nerve compound action potential
Value: anomaly in the combined potentials resulting from activation of the auditory division of the eighth cranial nerve; these potentials represent the summed activity of multiple cochlear afferent fibers discharging synchronously and thus assess the combined functional state of OHCs, IHCs, and their primary afferent innervation

Subject: absent cochlear nerve compound action potential
Value: absence of the combined potentials resulting from activation of the auditory division of the eighth cranial nerve

Subject: decreased cochlear nerve compound action potential
Value: reduction of the combined potentials resulting from activation of the auditory division of the eighth cranial nerve

Subject: small parietal bone
Value: reduced size of the paired membranous bones located between the frontal and occipital bones that are large, curved and quadrilateral in outline, articulate with each other at the midline in the sagittal suture, and form most of the superior and lateral aspects of the cranium

Subject: absent parietal bone
Value: absence of the paired membranous bones located between the frontal and occipital bones that are large, curved and quadrilateral in outline, articulate with each other at the midline in the sagittal suture, and form most of the superior and lateral aspects of the cranium

Subject: parietal bone hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the paired membranous bones located between the frontal and occipital bones that are large, curved and quadrilateral in outline, articulate with each other at the midline in the sagittal suture, and form most of the superior and lateral aspects of the cranium

Subject: enlarged parietal bone
Value: increased size of the paired membranous bones located between the frontal and occipital bones that are large, curved and quadrilateral in outline, articulate with each other at the midline in the sagittal suture, and form most of the superior and lateral aspects of the cranium

Subject: small temporal bone
Value: reduced size of the large, irregular bone located at the base and side of the skull

Subject: abnormal temporal bone squamous part morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anterosuperior portion of the temporal bone that is thin, scale-like, and translucent and forms part of the lateral wall of the cranial vault

Subject: temporal bone hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, in the large, irregular bone located at the base and side of the skull

Subject: abnormal otolith organ morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the utricle and saccule of the inner ear which possess otoliths and respond to linear acceleration and deceleration, including gravity

Subject: abnormal cochlear labyrinth morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the portion of the membranous labyrinth concerned with the sense of hearing (vs. the vestibular labyrinth, which is concerned with the sense of equilibration) and innervated by the cochlear nerve; it is located within the cochlea of the bony labyrinth, and consists of the cochlear duct, which contains the spiral organ

Subject: abnormal vestibular labyrinth morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the portion of the membranous labyrinth concerned with the sense of equilibration (vs. the cochlear labyrinth, which is concerned with the sense of hearing) and innervated by the vestibular nerve; it is located within the semicircular canals and vestibule of the bony labyrinth, and consists of the utricle, saccule, and the semicircular, utriculosaccular, and endolymphatic ducts

Subject: abnormal type I vestibular cell
Value: any structural anomaly in the flask-shaped sensory cells of the maculae and cristae of the vestibular labyrinth of the inner ear, which are normally enclosed in calyx endings of afferent neurons; afferent and efferent nerve fibers of the vestibular nerve synapse with them; from the apical end of each cell a bundle of stereocilia and a kinocilium extend into the otolithic membrane of the maculae or the cupula of the cristae

Subject: abnormal type II vestibular cells
Value: any structural anomaly in the cylindrical sensory cells of the maculae and cristae of the vestibular labyrinth of the inner ear which are normally contacted by bouton endings of afferent and efferent neurons; afferent and efferent nerve fibers of the vestibular nerve synapse with them; from the apical end of each cell a bundle of stereocilia and a kinocilium extend into the otolithic membrane of the maculae or the cupula of the cristae

Subject: abnormal Claudius cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the columnar cells located on the floor of the ductus cochlearis external to the spiral organ (also known as the organ of Corti)

Subject: abnormal hair cell mechanoelectric transduction
Value: anomalous conversion of mechanical energy into electric(al) energy by sensory cells, such as auditory and vestibular hair cells, required for auditory sensation

Subject: abnormal cochlear hair cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly in processes pertinent to the integrated function of cochlear hair cells i.e. the sensory cells in the spiral organ which are in synaptic contact with sensory as well as efferent fibers of the cochlear (auditory) nerve

Subject: abnormal cochlear inner hair cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly in processes pertinent to the function of cochlear IHCs which constitute the true sensory cell type sending impulses via the cochlear (auditory) nerve

Subject: abnormal cochlear outer hair cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly in processes pertinent to the function of cochlear OHCs which are known to enhance the performance of the cochlea, both qualitatively (increased selectivity) and quantitatively (increased sensitivity); in addition to the mechanoelectric transduction required for auditory sensation, OHCs also perform electromechanical transduction, whereby transmembrane voltage drives rapid changes in the length and stiffness of OHCs at audio frequencies in vitro (electromotility)

Subject: abnormal cochlear outer hair cell electromotility
Value: anomalous motility of the cochlear OHCs in response to electrical stimulation; normally, the motile response (i.e. rapid change in length and stiffness of OHCs) is closely coupled to the changing transduction current and provides a region-specific amplification in the movement of the spiral organ that enhances transduction at the IHCs in that specific region of the cochlear spiral, increasing both sensitivity and specificity; electromotility is believed to arise through voltage-gated conformational changes in motor protein (prestin) or proteins located in the lateral wall of the OHC

Subject: absent cochlear outer hair cell electromotility
Value: absence or loss of motility of the cochlear OHCs in response to electrical stimulation

Subject: decreased cochlear outer hair cell electromotility
Value: reduced motility of the cochlear OHCs in response to electrical stimulation

Subject: abnormal vestibular hair cell physiology
Value: anomalies in processes pertinent to the integrated function of the sensory epithelium of the maculae and cristae in the membranous labyrinth of the inner ear

Subject: absent Meckel's cartilage
Value: absence of this cartilage bar in the mandibular arch that forms a temporary supporting structure in the embryonic mandible; gives rise to middle ear bones and sphenomandibular and anterior malleolar ligaments

Subject: absent occipital bone
Value: absence of the bone at the lower, posterior part of the skull

Subject: small occipital bone
Value: reduced size of the bone at the lower, posterior part of the skull

Subject: occipital bone foramen
Value: presence of a hole in the bone at the lower, posterior part of the skull

Subject: absent supraoccipital bone
Value: absence of the bone on the dorsal side of the great foramen of the skull, usually forming a part of the occipital in the adult, but distinct in the young

Subject: small supraoccipital bone
Value: reduced size of the bone on the dorsal side of the great foramen of the skull, usually forming a part of the occipital in the adult, but distinct in the young

Subject: small exoccipital bone
Value: reduced size of the bone or region on the lateral sides of the great foremen of the skull, which often forms a part of the occipital in the adult, but is usually distinct in the young

Subject: split exoccipital bone
Value: the appearance of an abnormal division in the bone or region on the lateral sides of the great foremen of the skull, which often forms a part of the occipital in the adult, but is usually distinct in the young

Subject: small basioccipital bone
Value: reduced size of the bone in the base of the cranium, frequently forming a part of the occipital in the adult, but usually distinct in the young

Subject: abnormal presphenoid bone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anterior part of the body of the sphenoid bone in front of the basisphenoid; it is usually a separate bone in the young or fetus, but becomes a part of the sphenoid in the adult

Subject: absent presphenoid bone
Value: absence of the anterior part of the body of the sphenoid bone in front of the basisphenoid; it is usually a separate bone in the young or fetus, but becomes a part of the sphenoid in the adult

Subject: presphenoid bone hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the anterior part of the body of the sphenoid bone in front of the basisphenoid; it is usually a separate bone in the young or fetus, but becomes a part of the sphenoid in the adult

Subject: short presphenoid bone
Value: reduced length of the anterior part of the body of the sphenoid bone in front of the basisphenoid; it is usually a separate bone in the young or fetus, but becomes a part of the sphenoid in the adult

Subject: abnormal pterygoid process morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the process projecting downward from either side of the sphenoid bone, in vertebrates divided into two plates, an inner and an outer (sometimes called the lateral and medial); the posterior nares pass through the space, called the pterygoid fossa, between the processes

Subject: abnormal pterygoid bone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bone region which corresponds to the inner plate of the pterygoid process of the mammalian skull

Subject: absent pterygoid process
Value: absence of the process projecting downward from either side of the sphenoid bone, in vertebrates divided into two plates, an inner and an outer (sometimes called the lateral and medial); the posterior nares pass through the space, called the pterygoid fossa, between the processes

Subject: pterygoid bone hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, in the bone region which corresponds to the inner plate of the pterygoid process of the mammalian skull

Subject: small pterygoid bone
Value: reduced size of the bone region which corresponds to the inner plate of the pterygoid process of the mammalian skull

Subject: abnormal orbitosphenoid bone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bone that is situated in the orbit on either side of the presphenoid; it generally forms a part of the sphenoid in the adult, and may be independent in the young

Subject: absent alisphenoid bone
Value: absence of the broad curved wing like expanses on each side of the sphenoid bone in adults; may exist independently in the young

Subject: small alisphenoid bone
Value: reduced size of either of the broad curved wing like expanses on each side of the sphenoid bone in adults; may exist independently in the young

Subject: alisphenoid bone hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size in either of the broad curved wing like expanses on each side of the sphenoid bone in adults, usually due to reduced cell number; this bone may exist independently in the young

Subject: basisphenoid bone hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to reduced cell number, in part of the base of the cranium between the basioccipital and the presphenoid, which usually ossifies separately in the embryo or in the young, and becomes a part of the sphenoid in the adult; in many animals it persists as a separate bone between the basioccipital bone and the presphenoidal bone

Subject: small basisphenoid bone
Value: reduced size of part of the base of the cranium between the basioccipital and the presphenoid, which usually ossifies separately in the embryo or in the young, and becomes a part of the sphenoid in the adult; in many animals it persists as a separate bone between the basioccipital bone and the presphenoidal bone

Subject: basisphenoid bone foramen
Value: the presence of one or more holes in part of the base of the cranium between the basioccipital and the presphenoid, which usually ossifies separately in the embryo or in the young, and becomes a part of the sphenoid in the adult; in many animals it persists as a separate bone between the basioccipital bone and the presphenoidal bone

Subject: absent strial basal cell tight junctions
Value: absence of tight junctions from the basal cell layer of stria vascularis, resulting in destruction of the paracellular barrier between basal cells; loss of basal cell tight junctions renders the intrastrial space open to perilymph and abolishes its electrical isolation

Subject: degeneration of organ of Corti supporting cells
Value: degeneration or loss of the highly differentiated epithelial cells with distinctive morphological features that surround all hair cells in the organ of Corti

Subject: short cochlear outer hair cells
Value: reduced height of the sensory cells of the organ of Corti which are in synaptic contact with sensory as well as efferent fibers of the auditory nerve

Subject: absent zygomatic bone
Value: absence of the quadrilateral bone that forms the prominence of the cheek

Subject: small zygomatic bone
Value: reduced size of the quadrilateral bone that forms the prominence of the cheek

Subject: abnormal zygomatic arch morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bony arch in vertebrates that extends along the side or front of the skull beneath the eye socket and is formed by the temporal process of the zygomatic bone and the zygomatic process of the temporal bone

Subject: small nasal bone
Value: reduced size of either of two rectangular bone plates forming the bridge of the nose

Subject: short nasal bone
Value: reduced length of either of two rectangular bone plates forming the bridge of the nose

Subject: broad nasal bone
Value: increased width of either of two rectangular bone plates forming the bridge of the nose

Subject: absent nasal bone
Value: absence of either of two rectangular bone plates forming the bridge of the nose

Subject: enlarged nasal bone
Value: increased size of either of two rectangular bone plates forming the bridge of the nose

Subject: palatine bone hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, in either of either of two irregularly L-shaped bones located posterior to the maxilla that in part forms the back of the hard palate, part of the nasal cavity and part of the floor of the orbits

Subject: absent palatine bone
Value: absence of either of two irregularly L-shaped bones located posterior to the maxilla that in part forms the back of the hard palate, part of the nasal cavity and part of the floor of the orbits

Subject: turbinate hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, in the small curved bones that extends horizontally along the lateral wall of the nasal passage

Subject: increased testicular teratoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a usually benign tumor found in the testis that is the result of an anomaly of germ cell development, occurring in a specific population in a given time period; teratomas typically contains a diversity of tissues often representing all organ systems such as hair, teeth, bone, thyroid, or nerve tissue

Subject: abnormal oval window morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the oval opening on the medial wall of the tympanic cavity leading into the vestibule, close to the foot of the stapes

Subject: abnormal round window morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the opening on the medial wall of the middle ear leading into the cochlea, closed in life by the secondary tympanic membrane; serves to regulate fluid pressure in the inner ear

Subject: abnormal conjunctival epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the conjunctival layer of epithelial cells covering inner surface of the eyelid and the front of the eyeball except over the cornea

Subject: abnormal interdental cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the long, spindle-shaped cells arranged in parallel rows, oriented with their vertical axis perpendicular to the luminal surface of the spiral limbus; they secrete potassium ions into the endolymph and secrete the tectorial membrane

Subject: absent interdental cells
Value: absence of the long, spindle-shaped cells arranged in parallel rows, oriented with their vertical axis perpendicular to the luminal surface of the spiral limbus; they secrete potassium ions into the endolymph and secrete the tectorial membrane

Subject: altered response of heart to induced stress
Value: change in the physiological response of the heart to induced stress such as cardiac hypertrophy due to mechanical pressure overload from aortic banding

Subject: increased response of heart to induced stress
Value: increase in severity of the physiological response of the heart to induced stress such as cardiac hypertrophy due to mechanical pressure overload from aortic banding

Subject: decreased response of heart to induced stress
Value: decrease in severity of the physiological response of the heart to induced stress such as cardiac hypertrophy due to mechanical pressure overload from aortic banding

Subject: type I spiral ligament fibrocyte degeneration
Value: degeneration or loss of type I spiral ligament fibrocytes which occupy the region beneath the stria vascularis

Subject: type II spiral ligament fibrocyte degeneration
Value: degeneration or loss of type II spiral ligament fibrocytes found in the suprastrial zone and the central area of the spiral ligament beneath the spiral prominence

Subject: type III spiral ligament fibrocyte degeneration
Value: degeneration or loss of type III spiral ligament fibrocytes which form a cell layer attached to the otic capsule

Subject: type IV spiral ligament fibrocyte degeneration
Value: degeneration or loss of type IV spiral ligament fibrocytes found in the triangular space inferior to the basilar crest

Subject: abnormal orientation of outer hair cell stereociliary bundles
Value: misorientation or rotation of outer hair cell (OHC) stereociliary bundles, resulting in defective planar cell polarity of the inner ear sensory epithelium

Subject: abnormal orientation of inner hair cell stereociliary bundles
Value: misorientation or rotation of inner hair cell (IHC) stereociliary bundles, resulting in defective planar cell polarity of the inner ear sensory epithelium

Subject: dilated cochlea
Value: the luminal space of the cochlea is increased in volume or area, usually with an increase in contained fluid

Subject: abnormal synaptic glutamate release
Value: aberrant secretion across synapses of the major excitatory neurotransmitter of the central nervous system (CNS), which acts through both ligand gated ion channels (ionotropic receptors) and G protein-coupled (metabotropic) receptors

Subject: decreased synaptic glutamate release
Value: reduced secretion across synapses of the major excitatory neurotransmitter of the central nervous system (CNS), which acts through both ligand gated ion channels (ionotropic receptors) and G protein-coupled (metabotropic) receptors

Subject: abnormal organ of Corti supporting cell number
Value: abnormal number of the highly differentiated epithelial cells with distinctive morphological features which surround the hair cells in the organ of Corti

Subject: decreased organ of Corti supporting cell number
Value: decreased number of the highly differentiated epithelial cells with distinctive morphological features which surround the hair cells in the organ of Corti

Subject: increased organ of Corti supporting cell number
Value: increased number of the highly differentiated epithelial cells with distinctive morphological features which surround the hair cells in the organ of Corti

Subject: increased incidence of tumors by chemical induction
Value: higher than normal frequency of tumor incidence induced by one or more chemical carcinogens or mutagens

Subject: increased incidence of tumors by ionizing radiation induction
Value: higher than normal frequency of tumor incidence induced by radiation in which the individual particle or photon carries sufficient energy to completely remove an electron from its orbit; common types of this radiation include gamma-rays and X-rays

Subject: increased incidence of tumors by UV-induction
Value: higher than normal frequency of tumor incidence induced by exposure to ultraviolet light

Subject: decreased incidence of tumors by chemical induction
Value: lower than normal frequency of tumor incidence induced by one or more chemical carcinogens or mutagens

Subject: decreased incidence of tumors by ionizing radiation induction
Value: lower than normal frequency of tumor incidence induced by radiation in which the individual particle or photon carries sufficient energy to completely remove an electron from its orbit; common types of this radiation include gamma-rays and X-rays

Subject: decreased incidence of tumors by UV induction
Value: lower than normal frequency of tumor incidence induced by exposure to ultraviolet light

Subject: decreased renal glomerulus number
Value: reduced number of the capillary loops of the kidney that normally function as a filtration unit

Subject: abnormal pubis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the forward portion of either of the hipbones, at the juncture forming the front arch of the pelvis

Subject: abnormal ischium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the lowest of the three major bones that constitute each half of the pelvis, distinct at birth but later becoming fused with the ilium and pubis

Subject: abnormal pectoral girdle bone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bones of the shoulder by which the limbs attach to the axial skeleton

Subject: abnormal pelvic girdle bone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bones of the pelvis by which the limbs attach to the axial skeleton

Subject: myositis
Value: inflammation of muscle; local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in muscle

Subject: anosmia
Value: loss of the sense of smell

Subject: avnosmia
Value: loss of the ability to detect pheromones through the vomeronasal system

Subject: dystocia
Value: slow or difficult delivery of offspring and/or placenta

Subject: abnormal vestibular hair cell stereociliary bundle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly or disruption of the typical staircase-like arrangement of the mechanosensitive hair bundles which are composed of thick long microvilli (stereocilia) and are located at the apical end of vestibular hair cells of the utricle and saccule

Subject: fused vestibular hair cell stereocilia
Value: coalescence of the nonmotile, actin-filled specialized microvilli (stereocilia) normally arrayed on vestibular hair cells, often resulting in giant stereocilia

Subject: decreased vestibular hair cell stereocilia number
Value: decreased number of the nonmotile, actin-filled specialized microvilli (stereocilia) normally arrayed on vestibular hair cells in a staircase-like pattern

Subject: absent vestibular hair cell stereocilia
Value: complete absence of the nonmotile, actin-filled specialized microvilli (stereocilia) which are normally arrayed on vestibular hair cells in a staircase-like pattern

Subject: thin vestibular hair cell stereocilia
Value: reduced thickness of the nonmotile, actin-filled specialized microvilli (stereocilia) which are normally arrayed on vestibular hair cells in a staircase-like pattern

Subject: short vestibular hair cell stereocilia
Value: reduced length of the nonmotile, actin-filled specialized microvilli (stereocilia) which are normally arrayed on vestibular hair cells in a staircase-like pattern

Subject: abnormal cochlear hair cell stereociliary bundle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly or disruption of the typical pattern of arrangement of mechanosensitive hair bundles which are composed of thick long microvilli (stereocilia) and are located at the apical end of cochlear inner and outer hair cells

Subject: abnormal orientation of cochlear hair cell stereociliary bundles
Value: misorientation or rotation of inner and/or outer hair cell stereociliary bundles, resulting in defective planar cell polarity of the inner ear sensory epithelium

Subject: decreased cochlear hair cell stereocilia number
Value: decreased number (or less than the expected 100 or so) of the nonmotile, actin-filled specialized microvilli (stereocilia) normally arrayed on cochlear inner and outer hair cells

Subject: short cochlear hair cell stereocilia
Value: reduced length of the nonmotile, actin-filled specialized microvilli (stereocilia) which are normally arrayed on cochlear inner and outer hair cells

Subject: thin cochlear hair cell stereocilia
Value: reduced thickness of the nonmotile, actin-filled specialized microvilli (stereocilia) which are normally arrayed on cochlear inner and outer hair cells

Subject: absent cochlear hair cell stereocilia
Value: complete absence of the nonmotile, actin-filled specialized microvilli (stereocilia) which are normally arrayed on cochlear inner and outer hair cells

Subject: abnormal outer hair cell stereociliary bundle morphology
Value: <any structural anomaly or disruption of the typical V or W-like pattern of arrangement of mechanosensitive hair bundles located at the apical end of cochlear OHCs; each hair bundle is normally composed of ~100 nonmotile, actin-filled microvilli (stereocilia) arranged in rows of increasing height and coupled to one another by morphologically distinct links: tip links, horizontal top connectors, shaft connectors, and ankle links; most hair bundles also possess a single motile kinocilium immediately adjacent to the tallest (outermost) row of stereocilia; a fifth link type, the kinocilial link, connects the kinocilium to its neighboring stereocilia>

Subject: fused outer hair cell stereocilia
Value: coalescence of the nonmotile, actin-filled specialized microvilli (stereocilia) normally arrayed on cochlear outer hair cells, often resulting in giant stereocilia

Subject: decreased outer hair cell stereocilia number
Value: decreased number (or less than the expected 100 or so) of the nonmotile, actin-filled specialized microvilli (stereocilia) normally arrayed on cochlear outer hair cells

Subject: absent outer hair cell stereocilia
Value: complete absence of the nonmotile, actin-filled specialized microvilli (stereocilia) which are normally arrayed on cochlear outer hair cells

Subject: short outer hair cell stereocilia
Value: reduced length of the nonmotile, actin-filled specialized microvilli (stereocilia) which are normally arrayed on cochlear outer hair cells

Subject: abnormal inner hair cell stereociliary bundle morphology
Value: <any structural anomaly or disruption of the typically linear or U-shaped pattern of arrangement of mechanosensitive hair bundles located at the apical end of cochlear IHCs; each hair bundle is normally composed of ~100 nonmotile, actin-filled microvilli (stereocilia) arranged in rows of increasing height and coupled to one another by morphologically distinct links: tip links, horizontal top connectors, shaft connectors, and ankle links; most hair bundles also possess a single motile kinocilium immediately adjacent to the tallest row of stereocilia; a fifth link type, the kinocilial link, connects the kinocilium to its neighboring stereocilia>

Subject: fused inner hair cell stereocilia
