Value: coalescence of the nonmotile, actin-filled specialized microvilli (stereocilia) normally arrayed on cochlear inner hair cells, often resulting in giant stereocilia

Subject: decreased inner hair cell stereocilia number
Value: decreased number (or less than the expected 100 or so) of the nonmotile, actin-filled specialized microvilli (stereocilia) normally arrayed on cochlear inner hair cells

Subject: absent inner hair cell stereocilia
Value: complete absence of the nonmotile, actin-filled specialized microvilli (stereocilia) which are normally arrayed on cochlear inner hair cells

Subject: short inner hair cell stereocilia
Value: reduced length of the nonmotile, actin-filled specialized microvilli (stereocilia) which are normally arrayed on cochlear inner hair cells

Subject: abnormal palatine bone horizontal plate morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bony plate of the palatine bone that normally fuses with maxillary shelf to form secondary (hard) palate

Subject: abnormal maxillary shelf morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bony projection of the maxilla that normally fuses with palatine shelf to form secondary (hard) palate

Subject: absent maxilla
Value: missing the upper bony framework of the mouth where the superior teeth are held

Subject: small maxilla
Value: reduced size of the upper bony framework of the mouth where the superior teeth are held

Subject: absent auditory tube
Value: absence of the tube connecting the tympanic cavity and the nasopharynx

Subject: impaired acrosome reaction
Value: reduced ability or inability to execute the cellular exocytosis of a single, anterior secretory granule following a sperm's attachment to the zona pellucida surrounding an oocyte

Subject: abnormal sperm physiology
Value: anomaly in the normal function of spermatozoa

Subject: absent esophagus
Value: absence of the part of the digestive canal through which food passes from the pharynx to the stomach

Subject: enlarged esophagus
Value: increased size of the part of the digestive canal through which food passes from the pharynx to the stomach

Subject: esophagus hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due an increased number of cells of the esophagus

Subject: esophageal ulcer
Value: a lesion on the mucosal surface of the esophagus, usually produced by the sloughing of inflammatory necrotic tissue

Subject: dilated esophagus
Value: an expansion in the lumen volume of the part of the digestive canal through which food passes from the pharynx to the stomach

Subject: small trachea
Value: reduced size of the tube descending from the larynx and branching into the right and left main bronchi

Subject: short trachea
Value: reduced length of the tube descending from the larynx and branching into the right and left main bronchi

Subject: decreased tracheal cartilage ring number
Value: less than the 16-20 incomplete rings of hyaline cartilage forming the skeleton of the trachea

Subject: fused tracheal cartilage rings
Value: fusion of the 16-20 incomplete rings of hyaline cartilage that form the skeleton of the trachea

Subject: absent tracheal cartilage rings
Value: absence of the 16-20 incomplete rings of hyaline cartilage forming the skeleton of the trachea

Subject: small pharynx
Value: reduced size of the passage between the mouth and the posterior nares and the larynx and esophagus

Subject: pharynx hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the passage between the mouth and the posterior nares and the larynx and esophagus

Subject: enlarged allantois
Value: increased size of the fetal membrane which contributes to the formation of the umbilical cord and placental blood vessels

Subject: dilated allantois
Value: an expansion in the volume of the fetal membrane which contributes to the formation of the umbilical cord and placental blood vessels, as by stretching or distention

Subject: delayed allantois development
Value: late onset of development of the fetal membrane which contributes to the formation of the umbilical cord and placental blood vessels

Subject: small allantois
Value: reduced size of the fetal membrane which contributes to the formation of the umbilical cord and placental blood vessels

Subject: abnormal chorionic plate morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the portion of the chorion from which chorionic villi develop that establish a connection with the endometrium, giving rise to the fetal portion of the mature placenta

Subject: absent facial nerve
Value: absence of the sensory and motor nerve that supplies the muscles of facial expression and the expression and taste at the anterior two-thirds of the tongue

Subject: abnormal inner hair cell synaptic ribbon morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the presynaptic active zone of mature cochlear IHCs which usually contain a single synaptic ribbon, i.e. a submicrometer, electron-dense structure tethering synaptic vesicles; each spiral ganglion neuron receives input from only one IHC synapse

Subject: absent active-zone-anchored inner hair cell synaptic ribbon
Value: absence or loss of the usually single synaptic ribbon, a characteristic osmiophilic, electron-dense structure to which synaptic vesicles are tethered at the active zone of the cochlear inner hair cell afferent synapse

Subject: enlarged myocardial fiber
Value: increased size of the terminally differentiated, non-proliferative, cardiac muscle fibers, the multinucleated muscle cells of the heart

Subject: small myocardial fiber
Value: decreased size of the terminally differentiated, non-proliferative, cardiac muscle fibers, the multinucleated muscle cells of the heart

Subject: myocardial fiber degeneration
Value: deterioration or destruction of the terminally differentiated, non-proliferative, cardiac muscle fibers, the multinucleated muscle cells of the heart

Subject: decreased myocardial fiber number
Value: decreased number of the terminally differentiated, non-proliferative, cardiac muscle fibers, the multinucleated muscle cells of the heart

Subject: fusion of glossopharyngeal and vagus nerve
Value: union of the ninth and tenth cranial nerves into a single structure

Subject: glossopharyngeal nerve hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the sensory and autonomic axons to the parotid gland, carotid body, posterior third of the tongue; the branchial motor component contains motor fibers that innervate muscles that elevate the pharynx and larynx, and the tympanic branch supplies parasympathetic fibers to the otic ganglion

Subject: absent glossopharyngeal nerve
Value: absence of the sensory and autonomic axons to the parotid gland, carotid body, posterior third of the tongue; the branchial motor component contains motor fibers that innervate muscles that elevate the pharynx and larynx, and the tympanic branch supplies parasympathetic fibers to the otic ganglion

Subject: absent vagus nerve
Value: absence of the autonomic, sensory and motor axons of the tenth cranial nerve; it is primarily sensory but also has visceromotor components; it originates in the brain stem and controls many autonomic functions of the heart, lungs, stomach, pharynx, larynx, trachea, esophagus and other gastrointestinal tract components, and also controls some motor functions such as speech; the sensory branches mediate sensation from the pharynx, larynx, thorax and abdomen; it also innervates taste buds in the epiglottis

Subject: fusion of basioccipital and basisphenoid bone
Value: union of the basioccipital and basisphenoid bones into one structure, when this fusion does not normally occur (such as in a species where these bones normally persist as separate entities)

Subject: absent limb buds
Value: missing the mesenchymal outgrowth on the lateral trunk of the embryo that develops into the limbs

Subject: broad limb buds
Value: increased anterior-posterior width of the mesenchymal outgrowth on the lateral trunk of the embryo that develops into the limbs

Subject: small limb buds
Value: reduced size of the mesenchymal outgrowth on the lateral trunk of the embryo that develops into the limbs

Subject: abnormal embryonic autopod plate morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of transient  developing limb structure that forms by expansion of the distal end of the limb paddle and will give rise to the pedal appendages (e.g. hand, foot, paw)

Subject: abnormal cochlear hair cell inter-stereocilial links morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the morphologically and biochemically distinct link types that extend between the stereocilia of cochlear hair bundles; link types can be distinguished by their relative sensitivities to treatment with calcium chelators and the protease subtilisin; in the mature mouse cochlea, tip links and horizontal top connectors are the only inter-stereocilial links associated with the hair bundle; ankle links and transient lateral links are both prominent features of developing auditory hair bundles

Subject: abnormal cochlear hair bundle tip links morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in single, three-stranded interrow filaments that extend obliquely from the tip of one stereocilium to the lateral side of an adjacent taller stereocilium; in the mouse, tip links are already detectable prenatally and persist throughout life; tips links are thought to gate the mechanotransducer channel, are lost from the cell surface after exposure to either calcium chelator BAPTA or lanthanum, and resist degradation by the protease subtilisin

Subject: abnormal cochlear hair bundle horizontal top connectors morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the inter-stereocilial links that connect the top of a shorter stereocilium to an adjacent longer stereocilium at a short distance below the tip links; the appearance of horizontal top connectors, which persist into adulthood, occurs concomitant with this loss of ankle links; top connectors are essentially unaffected by treatment with subtilisin and EGTA

Subject: abnormal cochlear hair bundle transient lateral links morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the fine lateral links that interconnect stereocilia at prenatal stages; transient lateral links diminish at early postnatal stages when ankle links appear at the base of stereocilia, and are essentially unaffected by treatment with subtilisin and EGTA

Subject: abnormal cochlear hair bundle ankle links morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the long, single-stranded filaments that form a dense web or mesh around the base of cochlear hair bundles just above the region in which the stereocilia begin to taper down; in the mouse, ankle links are only a transient feature of the developing cochlear hair bundles, present predominantly from P2 though P9, but are absent by P12; ankle links are disrupted by treatment of hair cells with EGTA and subtilisin but not by La3+ and elastase

Subject: absent cochlear hair bundle ankle links
Value: absence of the long, single-stranded filaments that form a dense web or mesh around the base of cochlear hair bundles just above the region in which the stereocilia begin to taper down

Subject: abnormal vestibular hair bundle inter-stereocilial links
Value: any structural anomaly in the morphologically and biochemically distinct link types that extend between the stereocilia of vestibular hair bundles

Subject: abnormal vestibular hair bundle shaft connectors
Value: any structural anomaly in the links that connect the shafts of neighboring stereocilia in vestibular hair bundles; each shaft connector is composed of a ruthenium red-reactive, electron-dense particle that is connected to the plasma membrane by several fine strands of variable length

Subject: absent vestibular hair bundle shaft connectors
Value: absence of the inter-stereocilial links that connect the shafts of neighboring stereocilia in vestibular hair bundles

Subject: pillar cell degeneration
Value: degeneration or loss of the supporting cells that form the inner and outer walls of the tunnel in the organ of Corti

Subject: decreased cellular sensitivity to X-ray irradiation
Value: decreased incidence of cell death following exposure to X-ray irradiation

Subject: abnormal vestibular hair cell development
Value: atypical initial production, differentiation, migration or maturation of hair cells in the sensory epithelium of the maculae and cristae of the membranous labyrinth of the inner ear

Subject: abnormal cochlear hair cell development
Value: atypical initial production, differentiation, migration or maturation of the sensory epithelial cells of the cochlea

Subject: absent Deiters cells
Value: absence of the supporting cells of the spiral organ which are attached to the basement membrane and receive the hair cells between their free extremities

Subject: enlarged tectorial membrane
Value: increased size of the overlaying membrane of cochlear duct, an extracellular matrix of the inner ear that contacts the stereocilia bundles of specialized sensory hair cells

Subject: small mandible
Value: reduced size of the lower bony framework of the mouth where the inferior teeth are held

Subject: long mandible
Value: increased length of the lower bony framework of the mouth where the inferior teeth are held

Subject: abnormal mandibular coronoid process morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thin, flattened, triangular eminence that arises from the upper surface of the mandibular ramus (perpendicular portion); includes the attachment site to the temporal muscle

Subject: abnormal mandibular condyloid process morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the round bump of bone and constricted neck portion that arises from the upper surface of the mandibular ramus (perpendicular portion) and articulates with the articular disk of the temporomandibular joint

Subject: abnormal mandibular angle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the portion of the mandible where the body of the mandible (horizontal portion) and the rami (perpendicular portions) meet; these normally unite nearly at right angles

Subject: increased susceptibility to noise-induced hearing loss
Value: greater than normal reduction in hearing sensitivity following exposure to acute noise that is injurious to the cochlea

Subject: abnormal cochlear basement membrane morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the continuous basement membrane found within the membranous labyrinth of the cochlea, known to extend from the limbus, down to the inner sulcus, across the basilar membrane, up to the external sulcus to the spiral prominence and radiating into the spiral ligament ensheathing the root cell processes

Subject: abnormal vertebral arch morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the dorsal bony and/or cartilaginous part of a vertebra, consisting of a pair of pedicles, a pair of laminae, and seven processes (four articular processes, two transverse processes, and one spinous process)

Subject: abnormal vertebral transverse process morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bony protrusions on either side of the arch of a vertebrae at the point where the lamina joins the pedicle, between the superior and inferior articular processes; muscles and ligaments attach to these processes

Subject: abnormal vertebral spinous process morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the dorsal projection of the vertebral arch that projects backward and downward from the junction of the laminae, and serves for the attachment of muscles and ligaments

Subject: abnormal vertebral articular process morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bilateral flat projections that arise from the junctions of the pedicles and laminae

Subject: absent vertebral arch
Value: loss of the dorsal part of a vertebra, consisting of a pair of pedicles, a pair of laminae, and seven processes (four articular processes, two transverse processes, and one spinous process)

Subject: abnormal vertebral pedicle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the two short, thick processes, which project backward, one on either side, from the upper part of the body to the laminae

Subject: abnormal vertebral lamina morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of two broad plates directed dorsomedially from the pedicles; these fuse at the dorsal midline, and complete the dorsal wall of the vertebral foramen

Subject: absent vertebral spinous process
Value: missing the dorsal projection of the vertebral arch that projects backward and downward from the junction of the laminae, and serves for the attachment of muscles and ligaments

Subject: abnormal cervical atlas morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the first (topmost, C1) cervical vertebra which supports the globe of the head

Subject: abnormal cervical axis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the second cervical vertebra (C2) which forms the pivot upon which the first cervical (atlas, C1) vertebra rotates

Subject: vertebral fusion
Value: the union of one or more vertebrae into a single structure

Subject: small vertebrae
Value: reduced size of the bony segments of the spinal column

Subject: increased susceptibility to ototoxicity-induced hearing loss
Value: greater than normal reduction in hearing sensitivity following exposure to an ototoxic compound, such as aminoglycoside-induced hearing loss mediated via a glutamate excitotoxic process

Subject: fusion of vertebral bodies
Value: improper union of the main cylindrical portion of adjacent vertebra ventral to the vertebral canal

Subject: fusion of vertebral arches
Value: improper union of the dorsal part of adjacent vertebra

Subject: caudal vertebral transformation
Value: homeotic transformation of any caudal vertebrae to adopt the fate of another vertebrae

Subject: cervical vertebral transformation
Value: homeotic transformation of any cervical vertebrae to adopt the fate of another vertebrae

Subject: lumbar vertebral transformation
Value: homeotic transformation of any lumbar vertebrae to adopt the fate of another vertebrae

Subject: sacral vertebral transformation
Value: homeotic transformation of any sacral vertebrae to adopt the fate of another vertebrae

Subject: thoracic vertebral transformation
Value: homeotic transformation of any thoracic vertebrae to adopt the fate of another vertebrae

Subject: caudal vertebral fusion
Value: the union of one or more caudal vertebrae into a single structure in species where this does not normally occur

Subject: cervical vertebral fusion
Value: the union of one or more cervical vertebrae into a single structure

Subject: lumbar vertebral fusion
Value: the union of one or more lumbar vertebrae into a single structure

Subject: sacral vertebral fusion
Value: the union of one or more sacral vertebrae into a single structure in species where this does not normally occur

Subject: thoracic vertebral fusion
Value: the union of one or more thoracic vertebrae into a single structure

Subject: abnormal thoracic cage morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bony and cartilaginous structure enclosing the thoracic cavity, consisting of the thoracic vertebrae, ribs, costal cartilages, and sternum

Subject: abnormal rib joint morphology
Value: any anomaly in the normal joining of the ribs to the vertebral column or to the sternum

Subject: vertebral compression
Value: appearance of vertebrae that are flattened laterally along the whole length such that they appear pressed together and take up less rostrocaudal space

Subject: abnormal trochanter morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bony prominences near the upper extremity of the femur; there are two in human (greater and lesser trochanters) and three in many other mammalian species (greater, lesser and third); these normally serve as attachment points for hip and thigh muscles

Subject: Deiters cell degeneration
Value: degeneration or loss of the supporting cells of the spiral organ which are attached to the basement membrane and receive the hair cells between their free extremities

Subject: abnormal spiral modiolar artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the artery which parallels the spiral ganglion in the root of the spiral lamina of the modiolus, serving the ganglion and the cochlear duct and its contents

Subject: spiral modiolar artery stenosis
Value: abnormal narrowing of the artery which parallels the spiral ganglion in the root of the spiral lamina of the modiolus and serves the ganglion and the cochlear duct and its contents

Subject: abnormal auditory cortex morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the region of the cerebral cortex that receives the auditory radiation from the medial geniculate body, a thalamic cell group receiving auditory input from the cochlear nuclei in the rhombencephalon and is responsible for processing of auditory (sound) information

Subject: abnormal cochlear OHC efferent innervation pattern
Value: any changes in the morphology or number of efferent terminals, occurring as clusters, in the cochlear OHC region; normally, medial olivocochlear neurons, which are primarily found in rostral and ventral periolivary regions, project mainly to the contralateral cochlea, and terminate directly on OHCs

Subject: abnormal cochlear IHC efferent innervation pattern
Value: any changes in the morphology of the normally dense plexus of efferent terminals that contact radial fibers of the spiral ganglion below cochlear IHCs or of the sparser plexus of terminals positioned around IHC somata; normally, lateral olivocochlear neurons, which are found in and/or around the lateral superior olive, project mainly to the ipsilateral cochlea and terminate mostly on dendritic fibers below IHCs

Subject: short metacarpal bones
Value: reduced length of the five bones of the forepaws that articulate proximally with the carpal bones and distally with the phalanges

Subject: short metatarsal bones
Value: reduced length of the five bones of the hindpaws that articulate proximally with the cuneiform and cuboid bones of the tarsus and distally with the phalanges

Subject: decreased metacarpal bone number
Value: reduced number of the five bones of the forepaws/hands that articulate proximally with the carpal bones and distally with the phalanges

Subject: metacarpal bone hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the five bones of the forepaws/hands that articulate proximally with the carpal bones and distally with the phalanges

Subject: elongated metacarpal bones
Value: increased length of the five bones of the forepaws/hands that articulate proximally with the carpal bones and distally with the phalanges

Subject: fused metacarpal bones
Value: improper union of one or more of the five bones of the forepaws/hands that articulate proximally with the carpal bones and distally with the phalanges

Subject: decreased metatarsal bone number
Value: reduced number of the five bones of the hindpaws/feet that articulate proximally with the cuneiform and cuboid bones of the tarsus and distally with the phalanges

Subject: elongated metatarsal bones
Value: increased length of the five bones of the hindpaws/feet that articulate proximally with the cuneiform and cuboid bones of the tarsus and distally with the phalanges

Subject: fused metatarsal bones
Value: improper union of the five bones of the hindpaws/feet that articulate proximally with the cuneiform and cuboid bones of the tarsus and distally with the phalanges

Subject: abnormal vertebrae number
Value: altered number of the bony segments of the spinal column

Subject: increased vertebrae number
Value: an increase over the normal number of the bony segments of the spinal column

Subject: decreased vertebrae number
Value: a reduction from the normal number of the bony segments of the spinal column

Subject: decreased cervical vertebrae number
Value: reduced number of the seven bony segments of the spine located anterior to the thoracic vertebrae and caudal to the skull

Subject: decreased lumbar vertebrae number
Value: reduced number of the six bony segments of the spine located anterior to the sacral vertebrae and posterior to the thoracic vertebrae

Subject: decreased thoracic vertebrae number
Value: reduced number of the thirteen bony segments of the spine located anterior to the lumbar vertebrae and posterior to the cervical vertebrae

Subject: decreased sacral vertebrae number
Value: reduced number of the bony segments of the spine located posterior to the lumbar vertebrae and anterior to the caudal vertebrae

Subject: increased lumbar vertebrae number
Value: increased number of the six bony segments of the spine located anterior to the sacral vertebrae and posterior to the thoracic vertebrae

Subject: increased thoracic vertebrae number
Value: increased number of the thirteen bony segments of the spine located anterior to the lumbar vertebrae and posterior to the cervical vertebrae

Subject: small caudal vertebrae
Value: reduced size of the bony segments of the coccyx or tail

Subject: absent caudal vertebrae
Value: absence of all of the bony segments of the coccyx or tail

Subject: absent lumbar vertebrae
Value: absence of all of the six bony segments of the spine located anterior to the sacral vertebrae and posterior to the thoracic vertebrae

Subject: absent thoracic vertebrae
Value: absence of all of the thirteen bony segments of the spine located anterior to the lumbar vertebrae and posterior to the cervical vertebrae

Subject: absent sacral vertebrae
Value: absence of all of the bony segments of the spine located posterior to the lumbar vertebrae and anterior to the caudal vertebrae

Subject: small sacral vertebrae
Value: reduced size of any or all of the bony segments of the spine located posterior to the lumbar vertebrae and anterior to the caudal vertebrae

Subject: abnormal ventral tubercle of atlas morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the conical ventral projection on the arch of the atlas

Subject: abnormal odontoid process morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the large protuberance that projects upward from the cervical axis, around which the cervical atlas rotates

Subject: absent thyroid follicular cells
Value: absence of the thyroxine-producing follicular cells derived from the thyroid diverticulum which evaginates from the endodermal epithelium of the embryonic pharyngeal floor

Subject: absent thyroid parafollicular C-cells
Value: absence of the neuroepithelial secretory cells that occur singly or in small groups, close to the outer follicular borders but within the follicular basement membrane of the thyroid; these cells secrete calcitonin, 5-hydroxytryptamine and dopamine

Subject: abnormal thyroid diverticulum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the endodermal bud derived from the endodermal epithelium of the embryonic pharyngeal floor

Subject: athyroidism
Value: congenital absence of the thyroid gland or suppression or absence of its hormonal secretion

Subject: delayed inner ear development
Value: slowed progression to structurally mature components of the labyrinth, including the semicircular canals, vestibule and cochlea

Subject: abnormal stapedial artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the small artery that passes through the ring of the stapes; while the stapedial artery is a temporary artery thought to disappear at late embryonic stage in humans, the mouse stapedial artery is complete by E13 and persists into adulthood

Subject: absent stapedial artery
Value: absence of the small artery that passes through the ring of the stapes

Subject: vertebral body hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the main cylindrical portion of the vertebra ventral to the vertebral canal

Subject: absent vertebral body
Value: absence of the main cylindrical portion of the vertebra ventral to the vertebral canal

Subject: enlarged vertebral body
Value: increased size of the main cylindrical portion of the vertebra ventral to the vertebral canal

Subject: small vertebral body
Value: decreased size of the main cylindrical portion of the vertebra ventral to the vertebral canal

Subject: long ribs
Value: increased length of the bones forming the bony wall of the chest

Subject: short ribs
Value: reduced length of the bones forming the bony wall of the chest

Subject: splayed ribs
Value: any deviation from the normal curvature of the ribs such that the ribs are turned outward

Subject: thin ribs
Value: a more slender appearance of the bones forming the bony wall of the chest

Subject: rib fractures
Value: a crack or break in the bones forming the bony wall of the chest

Subject: wide ribs
Value: an increase in the width of the bones forming the bony wall of the chest

Subject: truncated ribs
Value: ribs that terminate abruptly as if having an end or point cut off

Subject: split xiphoid process
Value: the appearance of an abnormal division of the caudal tip of the sternum

Subject: xiphoid process foramen
Value: the appearance of a hole or holes in the caudal tip of the sternum

Subject: small xiphoid process
Value: reduced size of the caudal tip of the sternum

Subject: intervertebral disk hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the cartilaginous and gelatinous structure found between vertebrae

Subject: small intervertebral disk
Value: reduced size of the cartilaginous and gelatinous structure found between vertebrae

Subject: absent intervertebral disk
Value: absence of the cartilaginous and gelatinous structure found between vertebrae

Subject: intervertebral disk degeneration
Value: retrogressive pathological change of the cartilaginous and gelatinous structure found between vertebrae

Subject: calcified intervertebral disk
Value: process in which the cartilaginous and gelatinous structure found between vertebrae becomes hardened due to deposits of calcium salts

Subject: decreased length of long bones
Value: reduced end-to-end length of the several elongated bones of the extremities

Subject: split vertebrae
Value: any vertebrae or vertebral section that is cleft into two parts

Subject: absent ilium
Value: absence of the broad, flaring portion of the hip bone, which is distinct at birth, but later fuses with the ischium and the pubis

Subject: small ischium
Value: reduced size of the lowest of the three major bones that constitute each half of the pelvis, distinct at birth but later becoming fused with the ilium and pubis

Subject: ischium hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the lowest of the three major bones that constitute each half of the pelvis, distinct at birth but later becoming fused with the ilium and pubis

Subject: absent pubis
Value: absence of the forward portion of either of the hipbones, at the juncture forming the front arch of the pelvis

Subject: small pubis
Value: reduced size of the forward portion of either of the hipbones, at the juncture forming the front arch of the pelvis

Subject: pubis hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the forward portion of either of the hipbones, at the juncture forming the front arch of the pelvis

Subject: absent patella
Value: absence of the large sesamoid bone that covers the anterior surface of the knee

Subject: increased length of long bones
Value: greater end-to-end length of the several elongated bones of the extremities

Subject: abnormal thyroid follicle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small spherical vesicular components of the thyroid gland that are lined with epithelium and contain a colloid substance that both serves as a reservoir of materials for thyroid hormone production and stores thyroid hormones

Subject: abnormal thyroid follicular cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thyroxine-producing follicular cells derived from the thyroid diverticulum which evaginates from the endodermal epithelium of the embryonic pharyngeal floor

Subject: abnormal thyroid parafollicular C-cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the neuroepithelial secretory cells that occur singly or in small groups, close to the outer follicular borders but within the follicular basement membrane of the thyroid; these cells secrete calcitonin, 5-hydroxytryptamine and dopamine

Subject: unilateral deafness
Value: bilateral asymmetry in auditory function whereby one of the two ears displays auditory thresholds indicative of intact hearing while the other ear displays thresholds reflecting auditory dysfunction

Subject: abnormal circulating insulin-like growth factor I level
Value: anomalous blood concentration of this polypeptide hormone with growth-regulating, insulin-like, and mitogenic activities

Subject: decreased circulating insulin-like growth factor I level
Value: reduced blood concentration of this polypeptide hormone with growth-regulating, insulin-like, and mitogenic activities

Subject: increased circulating insulin-like growth factor I level
Value: increased blood concentration of this polypeptide hormone with growth-regulating, insulin-like, and mitogenic activities

Subject: abnormal vertebral column morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the complete structure forming the rostral-caudal axis of the skeleton formed from the alternating segments of vertebra and intervertebral discs which support the spinal cord

Subject: short vertebral column
Value: decreased rostral-caudal length of the complete structure forming the rostral-caudal axis of the skeleton formed from the alternating segments of vertebra and intervertebral discs which support the spinal cord

Subject: elongated vertebral body
Value: increased length of the main cylindrical portion of the vertebra ventral to the vertebral canal

Subject: short vertebral body
Value: reduced length of the main cylindrical portion of the vertebra ventral to the vertebral canal

Subject: enlarged lumbar vertebrae
Value: increased size of any or all of the six bony segments of the spine located anterior to the sacral vertebrae and posterior to the thoracic vertebrae

Subject: short lumbar vertebrae
Value: reduced length of any or all of the six bony segments of the spine located anterior to the sacral vertebrae and posterior to the thoracic vertebrae

Subject: cervical vertebrae degeneration
Value: retrogressive pathologic change of any or all of the seven bony segments of the spine located anterior to the thoracic vertebrae and caudal to the skull

Subject: small notochord
Value: reduced size of the axial fibrocellular cord in embryos around which develops the vertebral primordia

Subject: persistence of notochord tissue
Value: failure of notochord tissue to differentiate into the vertebral primordia during development resulting in the presence of notochord tissue at later stages than it is normally seen

Subject: notochord degeneration
Value: retrogressive pathologic change of the axial fibrocellular cord in embryos around which develops the vertebral primordia (prior to normal differentiation of this tissue into the vertebral column tissues)

Subject: split notochord
Value: the appearance of an abnormal division in the axial fibrocellular cord in embryos around which develops the vertebral primordia

Subject: truncated notochord
Value: notochord morphology that terminates abruptly as if having an end or point cut off

Subject: absent vestibulocochlear nerve
Value: absence of the composite sensory nerve innervating the receptor cells of the membranous labyrinth

Subject: abnormal cochlear nerve morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the part of the vestibulocochlear nerve [CN VIII] peripheral to the cochlear root; composed of the central nerve processes of the bipolar neurons of the spiral ganglion, which have their peripheral processes on the four rows of neuroepithelial cells (hair cells) of the spiral organ

Subject: absent cochlear nerve
Value: absence of the part of the vestibulocochlear nerve [CN VIII] that is peripheral to the cochlear root

Subject: abnormal vestibular nerve morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the part of the vestibulocochlear nerve [CN VIII] peripheral to the vestibular root; it is composed of the central processes of bipolar neurons that have the terminals of their peripheral processes on the hair cells in the ampullae of the semicircular ducts and the maculae of the saccule and utricle, and cell bodies of the vestibular ganglion

Subject: absent vestibular nerve
Value: absence of the part of the vestibulocochlear nerve [CN VIII] that is peripheral to the vestibular root

Subject: abnormal platelet morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of blood plasma cells derived from megakaryocytes, which function to promote blood clotting

Subject: abnormal platelet dense granule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the electron-dense bodies occurring in blood platelets that store and secrete adenosine nucleotides and serotonin

Subject: abnormal platelet dense granule number
Value: altered number of the electron-dense bodies occurring in blood platelets that store and secrete adenosine nucleotides and serotonin

Subject: abnormal platelet serotonin level
Value: anomaly in the amount in platelets of serotonin, a biochemical messenger and regulator, found in the CNS, gastrointestinal tract, and produced by platelets that mediates neurotransmission, gastrointestinal motility, hemostasis, and cardiovascular integrity

Subject: increased platelet serotonin level
Value: greater than normal amount in platelets of serotonin, a biochemical messenger and regulator, found in the CNS, gastrointestinal tract, and produced by platelets that mediates neurotransmission, gastrointestinal motility, hemostasis, and cardiovascular integrity

Subject: decreased platelet serotonin level
Value: reduced amount in platelets of serotonin, a biochemical messenger and regulator, found in the CNS, gastrointestinal tract, and produced by platelets that mediates neurotransmission, gastrointestinal motility, hemostasis, and cardiovascular integrity

Subject: abnormal nasal capsule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the cartilage around the developing nasal cavity of the embryo

Subject: absent epididymis
Value: absence of the elongated structure connected to the posterior surface of the testis, consisting of the head, body, and tail, which turns sharply on itself to become the ductus deferens (vas deferens)

Subject: abnormal efferent ductules of testis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the small seminal ducts that lead from the testis to the head of the epididymis

Subject: absent efferent ductules of testis
Value: absence of the small seminal ducts that lead from the testis to the head of the epididymis

Subject: abnormal circulating gastrin level
Value: anomalous concentration in the blood of polypeptide hormones secreted by the pyloric-antral mucous lining of the stomach that induces the secretion of gastric juice by the parietal cells of the gastric glands; they also occur in the central nervous system where they are presumed to be neurotransmitters

Subject: increased circulating gastrin level
Value: greater concentration in the blood of polypeptide hormones secreted by the pyloric-antral mucous lining of the stomach that induces the secretion of gastric juice by the parietal cells of the gastric glands; they also occur in the central nervous system where they are presumed to be neurotransmitters

Subject: decreased circulating gastrin level
Value: reduced concentration in the blood of polypeptide hormones secreted by the pyloric-antral mucous lining of the stomach that induces the secretion of gastric juice by the parietal cells of the gastric glands; they also occur in the central nervous system where they are presumed to be neurotransmitters

Subject: abnormal thoracic cavity morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cavity in the vertebrate body enclosed by the ribcage between the diaphragm and the neck, and contains the lungs, heart, thoracic aorta, pulmonary artery and its branches, thymus gland, and the respiratory airway

Subject: small thoracic cavity
Value: reduced size of the cavity in the vertebrate body enclosed by the ribcage between the diaphragm and the neck, and contains the lungs, heart, thoracic aorta, pulmonary artery and its branches, thymus gland, and the respiratory airway

Subject: enlarged thoracic cavity
Value: increased size of the cavity in the vertebrate body enclosed by the ribcage between the diaphragm and the neck, and contains the lungs, heart, thoracic aorta, pulmonary artery and its branches, thymus gland, and the respiratory airway

Subject: abnormal distortion product otoacoustic emission
Value: any abnormality in the sound produced by the cochlea in response to stimulation with 2 simultaneous tones of different frequencies; this measurement is particularly useful in assessing the functional state of OHCs

Subject: absent distortion product otoacoustic emissions
Value: failure to create mechanical distortions in the inner ear when two primary tones are presented, indicating failure of outer hair cells to amplify basilar membrane motion

Subject: abnormal auditory brainstem response
Value: anomaly in the electrical activity generated in the ascending auditory system in response to short tone bursts; may be used to evaluate sensorineural hearing function; measurements may include the amplitude (the number of neurons firing), latency (the speed of transmission), interpeak latency (the time between peaks), interaural latency (the difference in wave V latency between ears) and threshold

Subject: conductive hearing loss
Value: progressive hearing loss due to lesions in the external auditory canal or middle ear

Subject: sensorineural hearing loss
Value: a form of progressive hearing loss due to a lesion of the auditory division of cranial nerve VIII or the inner ear

Subject: mixed hearing loss
Value: progressive reduction in the ability to hear resulting from a combination of conductive and sensorineural hearing loss

Subject: abnormal vestibular system physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the sensory system responsible for the sense of head position and movement of the body through space; such anomalies may result in impaired balance, dizziness, poor regulation of postural muscle tone and inability to detect quick movements of the head

Subject: abnormal vestibular evoked myogenic potential
Value: anomaly in the biphasic response elicited by loud clicks or tone bursts recorded from the tonically contracted sternocleidomastoid muscle; normally, acoustic stimulation of the saccule gives rise to a vestibulocollic reflex, the output of which can be measured in the neck as inhibition of activity in the ipsilateral sternocleidomastoid muscle; VEMP testing provides diagnostic information about saccular and/or inferior vestibular nerve function (assessment of balance disorders)

Subject: reduced vestibular evoked myogenic potential
Value: reduction of the biphasic response that is elicited by loud clicks or tone bursts and recorded from the tonically contracted sternocleidomastoid muscle

Subject: absent vestibular evoked myogenic potential
Value: absence of the biphasic response that is elicited by loud clicks or tone bursts and recorded from the tonically contracted sternocleidomastoid muscle

Subject: abnormal cochlear IHC afferent innervation pattern
Value: any changes in the placement, morphology or number of afferent terminals and/or their synapses in the cochlear IHC region

Subject: abnormal cochlear OHC afferent innervation pattern
Value: any changes in the morphology, placement or number of afferent terminals and/or their synapses in the cochlear OHC region

Subject: increased susceptibility to age-related hearing loss
Value: greater than normal loss of hearing associated with advancing age, manifest as reduced ability to perceive or discriminate sounds; the pattern and age of onset vary

Subject: nonsyndromic hearing loss
Value: a form of progressive hearing loss that is not associated with visible abnormalities of the external ear or other signs and symptoms; the vast majority of hereditary hearing loss is nonsyndromic and can be associated with abnormalities of the middle ear and/or inner ear

Subject: syndromic hearing loss
Value: a form of progressive hearing loss that is usually associated with malformations of the external ear and other inherited signs and symptoms

Subject: increased length of allograft survival
Value: compared to controls, a greater length of time that transplanted tissue, in which the donor and recipient are genetically similar (same species) but not genetically identical, retains function and/or remains alive

Subject: decreased length of allograft survival
Value: compared to controls, a reduced length of time that transplanted tissue, in which the donor and recipient are genetically similar (same species) but not genetically identical, retains function and/or remains alive

Subject: abnormal miniature excitatory postsynaptic currents
Value: defect in the size or duration of spontaneous currents detected in postsynaptic cells that occur in the absence of an excitatory impulse

Subject: abnormal kidney collecting duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the kidney ducts lined by simple cuboidal epithelium that collect urine from the distal convoluted tubules, merge and become larger as they descend from the renal cortex into the medulla, and respond to vasopressin and aldosterone to regulate water, electrolyte and acid-base balance; each cortical collecting duct joints with other ducts to make a medullary connecting duct, which eventually drains into a papillary duct, emptying urine into the renal pelvis for drainage into the ureter

Subject: abnormal loop of Henle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the section of the renal tubule in the kidney medulla with a hairpin bend; consists of a descending limb and an ascending limb, and is situated between the proximal convoluted tubule to the distal convoluted tubule; it functions to reabsorb water and ions from the urine

Subject: abnormal proximal convoluted tubule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the convoluted portion of the duct system of the nephron that extends from the renal glomerular capsule in the kidney cortex into the kidney medulla where it joins the loop of Henle; fluid entering the proximal convoluted tubule is reabsorbed into the peritubular capillaries, including approximately two-thirds of the filtered salt and water and all filtered organic solutes; the most distinctive characteristic of the proximal tubule is its brush border (or striated border), not found in the distal convoluted tubule

Subject: abnormal distal convoluted tubule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the convoluted portion of the duct system of the nephron between the ascending portion of the loop of Henle and the collecting duct system in the kidney cortex; it is partly responsible for the regulation of potassium, sodium, calcium, and pH through the endocrine system

Subject: absent strial marginal cells
Value: absence or loss of the polarized columnar cells of epithelial origin which cover the lateral surface of the cochlear duct, secrete potassium ions and form a continuous sheet in contact with the endolymph

Subject: decreased mitotic index
Value: decreased number of cells in G2/M phase

Subject: increased mitotic index
Value: increased number of cells in G2/M phase

Subject: increased susceptibility to induced pancreatitis
Value: more likely than normal to develop an inflammatory response, or an increased inflammatory response in the pancreatic tissue after experimental manipulation

Subject: increased anti-double stranded DNA antibody level
Value: increase in the level of antibodies that recognize double stranded DNA

Subject: obsolete absent brainstem auditory evoked potential
Value: absence of the synchronous electrical activity generated by neurons in the ascending auditory system that can be recorded from scalp electrograms by using computer-averaged responses to short tone bursts; by varying frequency, cochlear function can be assessed throughout the hearing range; normally, ABR thresholds vary with frequency, from a sound pressure level (SPL) of 35 dB at 5.6 kHz (a relatively low frequency for a mouse) to 15 dB at 45.2 kHz (a relatively high frequency); each 20 dB corresponds to a tenfold change in amplitude

Subject: obsolete increased brainstem auditory evoked potential
Value: greater synchronous electrical activity generated by neurons in the ascending auditory system that can be recorded from scalp electrograms by using computer-averaged responses to short tone bursts; by varying frequency, cochlear function can be assessed throughout the hearing range; normally, ABR thresholds vary with frequency, from a sound pressure level (SPL) of 35 dB at 5.6 kHz (a relatively low frequency for a mouse) to 15 dB at 45.2 kHz (a relatively high frequency); each 20 dB corresponds to a tenfold change in amplitude; decreases in auditory thresholds required to generate a response may indicate a increased potential

Subject: obsolete decreased brainstem auditory evoked potential
Value: reduction in the synchronous electrical activity generated by neurons in the ascending auditory system that can be recorded from scalp electrograms by using computer-averaged responses to short tone bursts; by varying frequency, cochlear function can be assessed throughout the hearing range; normally, ABR thresholds vary with frequency, from a sound pressure level (SPL) of 35 dB at 5.6 kHz (a relatively low frequency for a mouse) to 15 dB at 45.2 kHz (a relatively high frequency); each 20 dB corresponds to a tenfold change in amplitude; increases in auditory thresholds required to generate a response may indicate a decreased potential

Subject: decreased susceptibility to age-related hearing loss
Value: less than normal loss of hearing associated with advancing age, manifest as reduced ability to perceive or discriminate sounds; the pattern and age of onset vary

Subject: increased cochlear nerve compound action potential
Value: greater combined potentials resulting from activation of the auditory division of the eighth cranial nerve

Subject: abnormal axonal transport
Value: any functional anomaly of the directed movement of organelles or vesicles along microtubules in nerve cell axons

Subject: abnormal synaptic vesicle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small, membrane bound sacs that contain various neurotransmitter molecules that are concentrated at pre-synaptic membranes and release the neurotransmitters by fusion of these vesicles with the presynaptic membrane, followed by exocytosis of their contents

Subject: abnormal synaptic vesicle recycling
Value: any functional anomaly in the process of the fusion of a subpopulation of synaptic vesicles with the cell membrane at the active zone, the subsequent endocytosis back from the plasma membrane, the refilling of these vesicles with neurotransmitters, and trafficking back to the active zone pool of vesicles

Subject: increased anti-single stranded DNA antibody level
Value: increase in the level of antibodies that recognize single stranded DNA

Subject: abnormal bile secretion
Value: any anomaly in the quantity or rate of bile secreted through the bile ducts in a given length of time

Subject: abnormal bile composition
Value: any alteration in the chemical make up of the greenish-yellow fluid secreted by the liver; normally contains bile acids and salts such as sodium glycocholate and sodium taurocholate as well as cholesterol, biliverdin and bilirubin, mucus, fat, lecithin, and cells and cellular debris

Subject: abnormal bile salt level
Value: anomalous concentration of the steroid salts derived from cholesterol in the liver, produced as bile acids and secreted in the biliary system as bile salts; these play an important role in the digestion and absorption of fats

Subject: abnormal vestibular dark cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the nonsensory epithelial cells located above the vestibular melanocytes and adjacent to the sensory structures in the utricle and in the ampullae at the ends of each of the semicircular canals; these cells provide and maintain the high potassium ionic environment within the vestibular labyrinth and are therefore homologous to the marginal cells of the stria vascularis; they are joined to each other by tight junctions and provide a barrier between endolymph and perilymph

Subject: vestibular dark cell degeneration
Value: degeneration or loss of the nonsensory epithelial cells that lie adjacent to the sensory structures in the utricle and in the ampullae at the ends of each of the semicircular canals

Subject: abnormal phospholipid level
Value: anomalous concentration of the fat derivatives in which one fatty acid has been replaced by a phosphate group

Subject: increased macrophage derived foam cell number
Value: greater than normal number of a type of macrophage containing lipids in small vacuoles and typically seen in atherolosclerotic lesions, as well as other conditions

Subject: abnormal surfactant secretion
Value: anomaly in the production or release from pneumocytes of surfactant, a phospholipid present in the lungs that controls surface tension in the alveoli

Subject: abnormal surfactant composition
Value: anomaly in the chemical constituents of surfactant, a phospholipid present in the lungs that controls surface tension in the alveoli

Subject: abnormal surfactant physiology
Value: anomaly in the production, composition or function of surfactant, a phospholipid present in the lungs that controls surface tension in the alveoli

Subject: abnormal cardinal vein morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the four veins in the developing vertebrate embryo which run along each side of the vertebral column

Subject: abnormal anterior cardinal vein morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the two paired veins draining the cephalic part of the body

Subject: abnormal posterior cardinal vein morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the two paired veins draining the caudal part of the body

Subject: abnormal common cardinal vein morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anastomosis of the anterior and posterior cardinal veins that returns blood to the developing heart

Subject: abnormal dorsal aorta morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the paired arterial structures of the embryo that supplies each developing somite via efferent segmental arteries; the dorsal aortae articulate with the umbilical arteries, which return mixed blood to the villi of the chorion for reoxygenation

Subject: abnormal auditory cortex tonotopy
Value: any abnormality in the spatial arrangement of structures that subserve various frequencies in the region of the cerebral cortex that receives the auditory radiation from the medial geniculate body

Subject: increased bile salt level
Value: increased concentration of the steroid salts derived from cholesterol in the liver, produced as bile acids and secreted in the biliary system as bile salts; these play an important role in the digestion and absorption of fats

Subject: absent upper incisors
Value: absence of the upper pair of long teeth that are the most anterior and prominent in the jaw

Subject: absent lower incisors
Value: missing the lower pair of long teeth that are the most anterior and prominent in the jaw

Subject: abnormal synaptic vesicle number
Value: anomaly in the number of the small, membrane bound sacs that contain various neurotransmitter molecules that are concentrated at pre-synaptic membranes and release the neurotransmitters by fusion of these vesicles with the presynaptic membrane, followed by exocytosis of their contents

Subject: abnormal synaptic vesicle clustering
Value: any functional anomaly in the process of accumulation of synaptic vesicles at the active zone of presynaptic membranes

Subject: increased anti-nuclear antigen antibody level
Value: elevated level of antibodies to nuclear antigens present in the sera

Subject: decreased anti-nuclear antigen antibody level
Value: reduced level of antibodies to nuclear antigens present in the sera

Subject: increased anti-histone antibody level
Value: elevated level of antibodies to histones present in the sera

Subject: increased anti-erythrocyte antigen antibody level
Value: elevated level of antibodies to erythrocyte antigen present in the sera

Subject: decreased anti-double stranded DNA antibody level
Value: reduced level of antibodies to double stranded DNA present in the sera

Subject: increased susceptibility to experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis
Value: greater likelihood that an organism will develop disease symptoms similar to human multiple sclerosis upon induction with antigens to Myelin Basic Protein (MBP), Proteolipid Protein (PLP), and/or Myelin Oligodendrocyte glycoprotein (MOG)

Subject: decreased susceptibility to experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis
Value: reduced likelihood that an organism will develop disease symptoms similar to human multiple sclerosis upon induction with antigens to Myelin Basic Protein (MBP), Proteolipid Protein (PLP), and/or Myelin Oligodendrocyte glycoprotein (MOG)

Subject: increased susceptibility to systemic lupus erythematosus
Value: greater likelihood that an organism will develop inflammatory connective tissue symptoms characteristic of lupus including skin rash, arthritis and inflammation of different organs

Subject: decreased susceptibility to systemic lupus erythematosus
Value: reduced likelihood that an organism will develop inflammatory connective tissue symptoms characteristic of lupus including skin rash, arthritis and inflammation of different organs

Subject: increased susceptibility to autoimmune diabetes
Value: greater likelihood that an organism will develop inflammatory pancreatic disease resulting from the body attacking and destroying the insulin-producing beta islet cells of the pancreas

Subject: decreased susceptibility to autoimmune diabetes
Value: reduced likelihood that an organism will develop inflammatory pancreatic disease resulting from the body attacking and destroying the insulin-producing beta islet cells of the pancreas

Subject: absent oocytes
Value: absence of mature germ cells in the female

Subject: absent germ cells
Value: absence of germ cells, that is, any of the reproductive (generative) cells of a multicellular organism, whether they are undifferentiated or fully differentiated

Subject: abnormal paired-pulse inhibition
Value: defects in the suppressive response of central synapses when activated twice in rapid succession; indicative of defects in short-term plasticity due to lack of inhibition of neurotransmitter release at the second stimulus

Subject: abnormal hematopoietic stem cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly or number of the multipotent, self-renewing stem cells found in the bone marrow, yolk sac and the fetal liver; HSCs give rise to all the types of both the myeloid and lymphoid cell lineages

Subject: increased hematopoietic stem cell number
Value: greater cell count of the multipotent, self-renewing stem cells found in the bone marrow, yolk sac and the fetal liver; HSCs give rise to all the types of both the myeloid and lymphoid cell lineages

Subject: decreased hematopoietic stem cell number
Value: reduced cell count of the multipotent, self-renewing stem cells found in the bone marrow, yolk sac and the fetal liver; HSCs give rise to all the types of both the myeloid and lymphoid cell lineages

Subject: abnormal neuron physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the cells of the nervous system that receive, conduct, and transmit impulses

Subject: abnormal linear vestibular evoked potential
Value: anomaly in the biphasic response elicited by linear acceleration transients (usually jerk pulses to an animal's head); normally, this response is measured by electrophysiological activity of the peripheral vestibular nerve; this assesses the function of the gravity receptor system including the utricles and saccules of the inner ear

Subject: absent linear vestibular evoked potential
Value: absence of the biphasic response elicited by linear acceleration transients (usually jerk pulses to an animal's head)

Subject: reduced linear vestibular evoked potential
Value: reduction of the biphasic response elicited by linear acceleration transients (usually jerk pulses to an animal's head)

Subject: abnormal somatic hypermutation frequency
Value: any anomaly in the high frequency of programmed mutation that occurs in the gene segments encoding the variable regions of antibodies during the differentiation of individual B lymphocytes into antibody producing plasma cells

Subject: abnormal class switch recombination
Value: anomaly in the rearrangement of the heavy chain genes of differentiating B cells such that the initially encoded heavy chain IgM molecule is altered to one encoding IgG, IgA or IgE; normally, this allows the body to produce antibodies with different effector functions

Subject: abnormal skeletal muscle mass
Value: anomaly in the physical bulk, or total amount of matter contained within skeletal muscle

Subject: increased skeletal muscle mass
Value: increase in the physical bulk, or total amount of matter contained within skeletal muscle

Subject: decreased skeletal muscle mass
Value: reduction in the physical bulk, or total amount of matter contained within skeletal muscle

Subject: abnormal urine potassium level
Value: any change in the amount of potassium in the urine

Subject: increased susceptibility to experimental autoimmune uveoretinitis
Value: greater likelihood that an organism will develop disease symptoms similar to human sight-threatening inflammatory eye diseases upon induction by peripheral immunization with one of several uveitogenic retinal proteins (or with peptides derived from them), or by the adoptive transfer of lymphocytes specific to these antigens

Subject: decreased susceptibility to experimental autoimmune uveoretinitis
Value: reduced likelihood that an organism will develop disease symptoms similar to human sight-threatening inflammatory eye diseases upon induction by peripheral immunization with one of several uveitogenic retinal proteins (or with peptides derived from them), or by the adoptive transfer of lymphocytes specific to these antigens

Subject: increased susceptibility to experimental autoimmune myasthenia gravis
Value: greater likelihood that an organism will develop disease symptoms similar to human myasthenia gravis upon induction with antigens to acetylcholine receptor subunits

Subject: decreased susceptibility to experimental autoimmune myasthenia gravis
Value: reduced likelihood that an organism will develop disease symptoms similar to human myasthenia gravis upon induction with antigens to acetylcholine receptor subunits

Subject: increased susceptibility to experimental autoimmune thyroiditis
Value: greater likelihood that an organism will develop disease symptoms similar to human autoimmune thyroiditis upon induction with antigens to thyroglobulin

Subject: decreased susceptibility to experimental autoimmune thyroiditis
Value: reduced likelihood that an organism will develop disease symptoms similar to human autoimmune thyroiditis upon induction with antigens to thyroglobulin

Subject: increased susceptibility to autoimmune hemolytic anemia
Value: greater likelihood that an organism will develop an abnormality of the immune system that destroys red blood cells (hemolysis) prematurely

Subject: decreased susceptibility to autoimmune hemolytic anemia
Value: reduced likelihood that an organism will develop an abnormality of the immune system that destroys red blood cells (hemolysis) prematurely

Subject: increased anti-chromatin antibody level
Value: increase in the level of antibodies that recognize chromatin

Subject: short incisors
Value: reduced length of the set of long teeth that are the most anterior and prominent in the jaw

Subject: long incisors
Value: increased length of the set of long teeth that are the most anterior and prominent in the jaw

Subject: enlarged ovary
Value: increased size of the female reproductive gland containing the germ cells

Subject: ovary atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of the ovaries associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: ovary hemorrhage
Value: presence of bleeding in the ovary

Subject: abnormal miniature endplate potential
Value: defect in the size or duration of spontaneous currents detected in PNS postsynaptic cells that occur in the absence of an excitatory impulse

Subject: abnormal synaptic acetylcholine release
Value: aberrant release into synapses of the excitatory neurotransmitter found at neuromuscular junctions, autonomic ganglia, parasympathetic effector junctions, a subset of sympathetic effector junctions, and at many sites in the central nervous system

Subject: abnormal neural fold formation
Value: any anomaly in the process by which the edges of the neural plate thicken and move up to form a U-shaped structure called the neural groove

Subject: abnormal neural fold elevation formation
Value: any anomaly in the process by which the lateral borders of the neural plate begin to migrate upwards to form the neural folds, caused by the proliferation of the underlying mesoderm

Subject: bile duct hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size of the bile ducts, usually due to an increase in the number of cells

Subject: increased Deiters cell number
Value: increased number of the supporting cells of the spiral organ which are attached to the basement membrane and receive the hair cells between their free extremities

Subject: abnormal small intestine crypts of Lieberkuhn morphology
Value: <any structural anomaly of the parallel, tubular, epithelial pits (crypts) with openings at the bases of the small intestinal villi; their thin walls are formed by columnar epithelial cells: mostly undifferentiated stem and intermediate cells and an increasing number of mucus-secreting goblet cells as the small intestine proceeds distally, all of which migrate out of the glands onto the villi, but also protein- (enzyme-) secreting Paneth cells that remain in the glands>

Subject: abnormal large intestine crypts of Lieberkuhn morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tubular intestinal glands found in the mucosal membranes of the large intestine

Subject: abnormal Paneth cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the large secretory cells containing coarse granules found at the base of the crypts of Lieberkuhn in the small intestine

Subject: abnormal vestibuloocular reflex
Value: any anomaly in the nystagmus or deviation of the eyes in response to stimulation of the vestibular system in which impulses are conveyed from the semicircular canals and the otolithic membrane to the oculomotor nerve; this stimulation may occur by angular acceleration or deceleration or by irrigation of the ear with hot or cold water; normally, this reflex functions to maintain a stable retinal image during head rotation by generating appropriate compensatory eye movements

Subject: absent vestibuloocular reflex
Value: absence of nystagmus or deviation of the eyes in response to stimulation of the vestibular system

Subject: absent skeletal muscle
Value: absence of any of the striated muscle fibers connected at either or both extremities with the bony framework of the body

Subject: abnormal liver weight
Value: anomaly in the average weight of the bile-secreting exocrine gland

Subject: abnormal liver size
Value: anomaly in the average size of the liver

Subject: abnormal testis size
Value: anomaly in the size of the male reproductive glands

Subject: abnormal testis weight
Value: anomaly in the average weight of the male reproductive glands

Subject: increased testis weight
Value: greater average weight of the male reproductive glands

Subject: decreased testis weight
Value: reduced average weight of the male reproductive glands

Subject: abnormal ovary size
Value: anomaly in the average size of the female reproductive gland containing the germ cells

Subject: abnormal ovary weight
Value: anomaly in the average weight of the female reproductive gland containing the germ cells

Subject: increased ovary weight
Value: greater average weight of the female reproductive gland containing the germ cells

Subject: decreased ovary weight
Value: reduction in the average weight of the female reproductive gland containing the germ cells

Subject: abnormal heart weight
Value: anomaly in the average weight of the heart compared to controls

Subject: abnormal nervous system regeneration
Value: changes in the ability or inability of healthy nervous system tissue to regenerate following injury or disease

Subject: abnormal synaptic plasticity
Value: anomaly in the ability of a synapse to change its strength as a result of successive activations

Subject: dilated kidney collecting duct
Value: stretched or widened aperture of the luminal space of the collecting ducts

Subject: abnormal Raphe nucleus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the subgroup of the reticular nuclei of the brain stem that are located in and along the median plane of the medulla oblongata, pons, and mesencephalon that include neurons that synthesize serotonin and extend ascending fibers to parts of the limbic system and descending fibers to other brain stem nuclei, the medulla oblongata, and the pons

Subject: small scala tympani
Value: volume reduction of the division of the spiral canal of the cochlea lying on the basal side of the spiral lamina

Subject: thin spiral ligament
Value: reduced thickness of the periosteal lining of the bony cochlea that forms the outer wall of the cochlear duct to which the basal lamina attaches

Subject: spiral ligament degeneration
Value: degeneration or loss of the thickened periosteal lining of the bony cochlea that forms the outer wall of the cochlear duct to which the basal lamina attaches

Subject: abnormal platelet calcium level
Value: anomaly in the amount in the platelet of calcium

Subject: increased platelet calcium level
Value: increased concentration in the platelet of calcium

Subject: decreased platelet calcium level
Value: decreased concentration in the platelet of calcium

Subject: increased endometrial carcinoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a malignant neoplasm arising from the endometrial tissue, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: frontal bone hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, in the bone which forms the forehead and roof of the eye orbit

Subject: small premaxilla
Value: reduced size of the anterior and interior portion of the maxilla

Subject: premaxilla hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the anterior and interior portion of the maxilla

Subject: absent nasal septum
Value: absence of the structure that separates the two nasal cavities

Subject: absent turbinates
Value: absence of the small curved bones that extend horizontally along the lateral wall of the nasal passage

Subject: abnormal timing of postnatal eyelid opening
Value: anomaly in the average time for the first postnatal eye opening, or failure of eyes to ever open

Subject: increased mean systemic arterial blood pressure
Value: increase in the average arterial pressure during a single cardiac cycle

Subject: decreased mean systemic arterial blood pressure
Value: decrease in the average arterial pressure during a single cardiac cycle

Subject: abnormal systemic vascular resistance
Value: anomaly in the normal force opposing blood flow in the peripheral blood vessels

Subject: increased systemic vascular resistance
Value: increase in the normal force opposing blood flow in the peripheral blood vessels

Subject: decreased systemic vascular resistance
Value: reduction in the normal force opposing blood flow in the peripheral blood vessels

Subject: lung cysts
Value: abnormal membranous or fluid-filled sacs appearing in the lung

Subject: abnormal lung size
Value: anomaly in the size of the lung compared to controls

Subject: enlarged lung
Value: increased size of the lung compared to controls

Subject: abnormal vascular wound healing
Value: anomaly in the repair process of damaged blood vessels after injury

Subject: abnormal testis physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the male reproductive glands

Subject: abnormal endolymph
Value: any alteration in the normal production (volume) or ionic homeostasis of the fluid contained within the membranous labyrinth of the inner ear; unlike perilymph, endolymph resembles intracellular fluid in composition and has a high concentration of potassium ion and a low concentration of sodium ion

Subject: increased endolymph production
Value: increased synthesis of the fluid that is normally contained within the membranous labyrinth of the inner ear

Subject: decreased endolymph production
Value: reduced synthesis of the fluid that is normally contained within the membranous labyrinth of the inner ear

Subject: abnormal perilymph
Value: change in the normal production (volume) or ionic homeostasis of the fluid contained within the osseous labyrinth, surrounding and protecting the membranous labyrinth; perilymph resembles extracellular fluid in composition, has a high concentration of sodium ion and a low concentration of potassium ion and, through the perilymphatic duct, is in continuity with cerebrospinal fluid

Subject: increased energy expenditure
Value: increase in the number of calories used per unit time or decrease in weight gain for a given amount of food eaten

Subject: decreased energy expenditure
Value: decrease in the number of calories used per unit time or increase in weight gain for a given amount of food eaten

Subject: abnormal adiponectin level
Value: abnormal level of a protein hormone that regulates glucose homeostasis and metabolism of lipids; it is normally produced by adipose tissue

Subject: increased adiponectin level
Value: greater level of a protein hormone that regulates glucose homeostasis and metabolism of lipids; it is normally produced by adipose tissue

Subject: decreased adiponectin level
Value: reduced concentration of a protein hormone that regulates glucose homeostasis and metabolism of lipids; it is normally produced by adipose tissue

Subject: uterus atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of the uterus associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: vagina atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of the vagina associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: abnormal endometrium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the glandular mucous membrane lining of the uterine cavity that is hormonally responsive during the estrous/menstrual cycle and during pregnancy

Subject: otosclerosis
Value: formation of spongy bone in the bony labyrinth of the ear, especially adjacent to the footplate of the stapes; it may cause bony ankylosis of the stapes, resulting in conductive hearing loss; cochlear otosclerosis results in sensorineural hearing loss

Subject: uterine hemorrhage
Value: presence of bleeding in the uterus; often in response to failed pregnancy

Subject: absent temporal bone squamous part
Value: absence of the anterosuperior portion of the temporal bone that is thin, scale-like, and translucent and forms part of the lateral wall of the cranial vault

Subject: absent zygomatic arch
Value: absence of the bony arch that extends along the side or front of the skull beneath the eye socket and is formed by the temporal process of the zygomatic bone and the zygomatic process of the temporal bone

Subject: decreased male germ cell number
Value: reduced numbers of male germ cells whether they are undifferentiated or fully differentiated

Subject: abnormal uterus size
Value: anomaly in the size of the female organ of gestation

Subject: abnormal uterus weight
Value: anomaly in the weight of the female organ of gestation

Subject: increased uterus weight
Value: increase in the weight of the female organ of gestation

Subject: decreased uterus weight
Value: reduction in the weight of the female organ of gestation

Subject: enlarged uterus
Value: increased size of the female muscular organ of gestation

Subject: abnormal seminal vesicle size
Value: anomaly in the size of one or both of the two folded, sac shaped, glands that is a diverticulum of the ductus deferens

Subject: abnormal seminal vesicle weight
Value: anomaly in the weight of one or both of the two folded, sac shaped, glands that is a diverticulum of the ductus deferens

Subject: increased seminal vesicle weight
Value: increase in the weight of one or both of the two folded, sac shaped, glands that is a diverticulum of the ductus deferens

Subject: decreased seminal vesicle weight
Value: reduction in the weight of one or both of the two folded, sac shaped, glands that is a diverticulum of the ductus deferens

Subject: absent mandibular condyloid process
Value: absence of the round bump of bone and constricted neck portion that arises from the upper surface of the mandibular ramus (perpendicular portion) and articulates with the articular disk of the temporomandibular joint

Subject: absent mandibular coronoid process
Value: absence of the thin, flattened, triangular eminence that arises from the upper surface of the mandibular ramus (perpendicular portion)

Subject: absent mandibular angle
Value: absence of the portion of the mandible where the body of the mandible (horizontal portion) and the rami (perpendicular portions) meet; these normally unite nearly at right angles

Subject: absent ultimobranchial body
Value: absence of the outpocketing of the caudal-most branchial pouch of the embryo (interpreted as a fifth pouch in human or as the ventral component of the fourth pouch in mouse) that fuses with the thyroid diverticulum, ultimately giving rise to calcitonin-producing parafollicular cells (aka C-cells) which function in calcium homeostasis; in most mammals, these parafollicular cells fully disperse with the endodermally derived follicular cells of the thyroid by birth

Subject: abnormal Reichert's cartilage morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cartilage found in the mesenchyme of the second pharyngeal arch in the embryo from which develop the stapes, styloid process, lesser horn and upper part of the body of the hyoid bone; its proximal end gives rise to the stylohyoid ligament

Subject: absent Reichert cartilage
Value: absence of the cartilage normally found in the mesenchyme of the second branchial arch in the embryo, from which develop the stapes, the styloid processes, the stylohyoid ligaments, and the lesser cornua of the hyoid bone

Subject: abnormal T cell selection
