Value: the observable morphological and physiological characteristics of the mammalian heart, blood vessels, or circulatory system that are manifested through development and lifespan

Subject: behavior/neurological phenotype
Value: the observable actions or reactions of mammalian organisms that are manifested through development and lifespan

Subject: immune system phenotype
Value: the observable morphological and physiological characteristics of the mammalian system that protects the body from foreign substances, cells, and tissues by producing the immune response and that includes especially the thymus, spleen, lymphoid tissue, lymphocytes including the B cells and T cells, and antibodies that are manifested through development and lifespan

Subject: respiratory system phenotype
Value: the observable morphological and physiological characteristics of the mammalian system responsible for the exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide with the environment that are manifested through development and lifespan

Subject: reproductive system phenotype
Value: the observable morphological and physiological characteristics of the mammalian organs associated with producing offspring that are manifested through development and lifespan

Subject: skeleton phenotype
Value: the observable morphological and physiological characteristics of the bone, cartilage, teeth, tendons, ligaments and other associated tissues of the bony framework ot the body of a mammalian organism that are manifested through development and lifespan

Subject: vision/eye phenotype
Value: the observable morphological and physiological characteristics of the mammalian spheroid organ and optic nerve that serve to detect light that are manifested through development and lifespan

Subject: taste/olfaction phenotype
Value: the observable morphological and physiological characteristics of the organs involved in and perception of taste and smell in a mammalian organism that are manifested through development and lifespan

Subject: hematopoietic system phenotype
Value: the observable morphological and physiological characteristics of the mammalian blood cells or the organs associated with the development and formation of blood cells that are manifested through development and lifespan

Subject: decreased susceptibility to fungal infection
Value: reduced likelihood that an organism will develop ill effects from infection by a yeast or mold, or from components of, or toxins produced by, these organisms

Subject: increased susceptibility to fungal infection
Value: greater likelihood that an organism will develop ill effects from infection by a yeast or mold, or from components of, or toxins produced by, these organisms

Subject: abnormal vitamin level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration of any of the organic substances found in food that are necessary in trace amounts for normal metabolic function

Subject: abnormal fat-soluble vitamin level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration of any of the organic substances found in food that are necessary in trace amounts for normal metabolic function and which require the presence of lipids for assimilation in the body

Subject: abnormal action potential
Value: change in the electric response of a nerve or other excitable tissue to its stimulation

Subject: abnormal nerve conduction
Value: anomaly in the act of transmitting electricity along a single nerve

Subject: abnormal axon morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the single process of a nerve cell that normally conducts impulses away from the cell body

Subject: axon degeneration
Value: retrogressive pathologic change in the single process of a nerve cell

Subject: abnormal heart size
Value: change from normal in the physical magnitude of the cardiac muscle or any of its component structures

Subject: hyperalgesia
Value: increased sensitivity to painful stimuli; can be due to inflammatory response or due to damage to soft tissue containing nociceptors or injury to a peripheral nerve; it can be primary (at the site of the injury) or secondary (in the surrounding undamaged area)

Subject: hypopigmentation
Value: dilution of pigment in any or all tissues or a part of a tissue

Subject: darkened coat color
Value: amount and distribution of yellow pigment (phaeomelanin) relative to black or brown pigment (eumelanin) is decreased when compared to wild-type agouti

Subject: abnormal fertilization
Value: anomaly in the process beginning with penetration of the secondary oocyte by the spermatozoon and completed by fusion of the male and female pronuclei

Subject: delayed fertilization
Value: a lag in the normal time of onset of the process beginning with penetration of the secondary oocyte by the spermatozoon and completed by fusion of the male and female pronuclei

Subject: vascular stenosis
Value: a stricture or occlusion of a lumen of vascular tissue

Subject: vascular restenosis
Value: recurrence of a narrowing or constriction of a blood vessel following surgical or mechanical removal or reduction of a previous narrowing

Subject: extrahepatic cholestasis
Value: impairment of bile flow in the large bile ducts by mechanical obstruction or stricture due to benign or malignant process

Subject: intrahepatic cholestasis
Value: impairment of bile flow due to injury to the hepatocytes, bile canaliculi, or the intrahepatic bile ducts

Subject: abnormal circulating protein level
Value: anomaly in the amount in the blood of any of the macromolecules consisting of long chains of amino acids in peptide linkage

Subject: abnormal circulating hormone level
Value: any anomaly in the blood concentration of any of the chemical substances that have specific regulatory effects on the activity of a certain organ or organs; originally applied to substances secreted by various endocrine glands and transported in the bloodstream to the target organs, it is sometimes extended to include substances that are not produced by the endocrine glands but that have similar effects

Subject: decreased circulating serum albumin level
Value: blood serum albumin concentration below the normal range

Subject: loose skin
Value: condition in which the skin hangs in folds

Subject: osteosclerosis
Value: abnormal hardening or eburnation (change in exposed subchondral bone in degenerative joint disease in which bone is converted into a dense substance with a smooth surface) of bone

Subject: abnormal somatic nervous system physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the part of the peripheral nervous system that is responsible for conveying voluntary motor and external sensory information, including all nerves controlling the skeletal muscular system and external sensory receptors (including balance, smell, sight, taste, touch and hearing sensory inputs)

Subject: jerky movement
Value: continuous, abrupt, faltering motions of the whole body or a portion of the body

Subject: increased macrophage cell number
Value: greater than the normal numbers of macrophages

Subject: tachypnea
Value: rapid breathing

Subject: absent fibula
Value: absence of the lateral and shorter of the two bones of the lower leg

Subject: decreased oocyte number
Value: reduced numbers of germ cells in the female

Subject: abnormal pro-B cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the progenitor cells of the B cell lineage, with some lineage specific activity such as early stages of recombination of B cell receptor genes, but are not yet fully committed to the B cell lineage until the expression of PAX5 occurs

Subject: absent early pro-B cells
Value: absence of cells in the B lymphocyte lineage that undergo D-J rearrangement of the immunoglobulin heavy chain

Subject: absent late pro-B cells
Value: absence of the cells in the B lymphocyte lineage that undergo V-DJ rearrangement of the immunoglobulin heavy chain

Subject: hemoperitoneum
Value: blood in the peritoneal cavity

Subject: abnormal glycogen level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration of this readily converted carbohydrate reserve, found in most tissues of the body, especially liver and muscle

Subject: abnormal glycogen homeostasis
Value: anomaly in the processes involved in the maintenance of an internal equilibrium of glycogen, a readily converted carbohydrate reserve found in most tissues of the body, especially liver and muscle

Subject: decreased glycogen level
Value: less than the normal concentration of a readily converted carbohydrate reserve, found in most tissues of the body, especially liver and muscle

Subject: increased glycogen level
Value: greater than the normal concentration of this readily converted carbohydrate reserve, found in most tissues of the body, especially liver and muscle

Subject: increased urine calcium level
Value: abnormally large amounts of calcium in the urine

Subject: abnormal ethanol metabolism
Value: altered ability to metabolize the clear, colorless liquid that has formula C2H6O

Subject: abnormal retinol metabolism
Value: altered ability to metabolize retinol, which plays an essential role in metabolic functioning of the retina, and growth of and differentiation

Subject: abnormal neurotransmitter secretion
Value: anomaly in the production or release of endogenous signaling molecules into a synaptic cleft; neurotransmitters are released on excitation from the axon terminal of a presynaptic neuron of the central or peripheral nervous system and travel across the synaptic cleft to either excite or inhibit the target cell

Subject: abnormal synaptic epinephrine release
Value: aberrant secretion across synapses of the active sympathomimetic hormone that stimulates both the alpha- and beta- adrenergic systems, causes systemic vasoconstriction and gastrointestinal relaxation, stimulates the heart, and dilates bronchi and cerebral vessels

Subject: abnormal synaptic norepinephrine release
Value: aberrant secretion across synapses of this widespread central and autonomic neurotransmitter, the principal transmitter of most postganglionic sympathetic fibers and of the diffuse projection system in the brain arising from the locus ceruleus

Subject: abnormal energy homeostasis
Value: any anomaly in the process involved in the balance between food intake (energy input) and energy expenditure

Subject: abnormal food intake
Value: any anomaly in the total number of calories/food amount taken in over time when compared to the normal state

Subject: abnormal energy expenditure
Value: utilization of calories that differs from normal

Subject: abnormal body composition
Value: aberrant relative amount and distribution of bone, body fat, muscle or lean tissue mass

Subject: abnormal adipose tissue amount
Value: more or less than the normal total amount of connective tissue composed of fat cells

Subject: increased susceptibility to weight gain
Value: greater increase in body weight over time when compared to the average increase in weight on the same diet, with equal energy (calorie) intake

Subject: abnormal percent body fat/body weight
Value: more or less fat, relative to controls, expressed as a percentage of total body weight

Subject: increased percent body fat/body weight
Value: more fat, relative to controls, expressed as a percentage of total body weight

Subject: decreased percent body fat/body weight
Value: less fat, relative to controls, expressed as a percentage of total body weight

Subject: abnormal leukopoiesis
Value: <any anomaly in the process of generating white blood cells (leukocytes) from the pluripotent hematopoietic stem cells of the bone marrow; two significant pathways generate various types of leukocytes: myelopoiesis, in which leukocytes in the blood are derived from myeloid stem cells, and lymphopoiesis, in which leukocytes of the lymphatic system (lymphocytes) are generated from lymphoid stem cells>

Subject: abnormal dendritic cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a cell of hematopoietic origin, typically resident in particular tissues, specialized in the uptake, processing, and transport of antigens to lymph nodes for the purpose of stimulating an immune response via T cell activation

Subject: abnormal mast cell differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce a cell that is found in almost all tissues, containing numerous basophilic granules and capable of releasing large amounts of histamine and heparin upon activation

Subject: abnormal CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the subset of T lymphocytes that carry the CD4 marker, recognize intravesicular peptides bound to MHC class-II molecules, and turn on antibody production

Subject: abnormal platelet physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the non-nucleated cells found in the blood and involved in blood coagulation

Subject: abnormal T-helper 1 physiology
Value: abnormal function of the type of T-helper cell whose cytokine production favors cellular immune responses and delayed type hypersensitivity

Subject: abnormal T-helper 2 physiology
Value: abnormal function of the type of T-helper cell whose cytokine production promotes defense against extracellular parasites and humoral immune responses typical of allergy

Subject: abnormal thyroid hormone level
Value: aberrant concentration of any of the hormones secreted by the thyroid gland

Subject: abnormal thyroxine level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration of the major hormone derived from the thyroid gland; it normally affects cellular metabolism

Subject: increased thyroxine level
Value: greater than the normal concentration of the major hormone derived from the thyroid gland; it normally affects cellular metabolism

Subject: decreased thyroxine level
Value: less than the normal concentration of the major hormone derived from the thyroid gland; it normally affects cellular metabolism

Subject: abnormal triiodothyronine level
Value: anomaly in the amount of a thyroid hormone that regulates growth and development, controls some metabolic processes and body temperature, and negatively regulates secretion of thyrotropin by the pituitary gland

Subject: decreased triiodothyronine level
Value: reduced amount of a thyroid hormone that regulates growth and development, controls some metabolic processes and body temperature, and negatively regulates secretion of thyrotropin by the pituitary gland

Subject: increased triiodothyronine level
Value: greater amount of a thyroid hormone that regulates growth and development, controls some metabolic processes and body temperature, and negatively regulates secretion of thyrotropin by the pituitary gland

Subject: abnormal circulating thyroxine level
Value: anomaly in the blood concentration of the major hormone derived from the thyroid gland that normally affects cellular metabolism

Subject: abnormal circulating triiodothyronine level
Value: anomaly in the amount of a thyroid hormone present in the blood that regulates growth and development, controls some metabolic processes and body temperature, and negatively regulates secretion of thyrotropin by the pituitary gland

Subject: increased circulating thyroxine level
Value: greater than the normal blood concentration of the major hormone derived from the thyroid gland that normally affects cellular metabolism

Subject: decreased circulating thyroxine level
Value: reduction in the normal blood concentration of the major hormone derived from the thyroid gland that normally affects cellular metabolism

Subject: decreased circulating triiodothyronine level
Value: reduced amount of a thyroid hormone present in the blood that regulates growth and development, controls some metabolic processes and body temperature, and negatively regulates secretion of thyrotropin by the pituitary gland

Subject: increased circulating triiodothyronine level
Value: greater amount of a thyroid hormone present in the blood that regulates growth and development, controls some metabolic processes and body temperature, and negatively regulates secretion of thyrotropin by the pituitary gland

Subject: increased chronic myelocytic leukemia incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of a heterogeneous group of myeloproliferative disorders that may evolve into acute leukemia in late stages

Subject: bronchial epithelial hyperplasia
Value: increased numbers of cells lining the inner surfaces of the bronchi

Subject: vascular smooth muscle hyperplasia
Value: increased numbers of smooth muscle cells in the vascular wall

Subject: increased club cell number
Value: increased numbers of the rounded, club-shaped, nonciliated cells found between ciliated cells in bronchiolar epithelium

Subject: pancreatic islet hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size of the clusters of hormone-producing cells that are scattered throughout the pancreas, usually due an increased number of cells

Subject: exocrine pancreas hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the portion of the pancreas that secretes digestive enzymes, usually due to a decreased cell number

Subject: stomach epithelial hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due to an increase in the number of cells, of the epithelial layer of the stomach

Subject: esophagogastric junction metaplasia
Value: conversion of one differentiated cell type to another differentiated cell type at the terminal end of the esophagus and beginning of the stomach

Subject: optic nerve cupping
Value: concave shape of the nerve often as a result of the force of pressure from glaucoma

Subject: hyporesponsive to tactile stimuli
Value: reduced reflex action normally induced by touch or pain

Subject: abnormal olfactory system morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the organs involved in smell

Subject: abnormal gustatory system morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the organs involved in taste

Subject: abnormal skin physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the membranous protective covering of the body

Subject: abnormal renal/urinary system physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of any of the organs or tissues responsible for fluid volume regulation, regulating electrolytes, maintaining acid-base homeostasis, and elimination of water and water soluble waste products in an organism

Subject: abnormal tendon morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the fibrous bands or cords of connective tissue at the ends of muscle fibers that attach muscles to bones and other structures

Subject: abnormal ligament morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the flexible bands of fibrous tissue that connect the articular extremities of bones

Subject: thrombocytosis
Value: greater than the normal numbers of the non-nucleated cells found in the blood and involved in blood coagulation

Subject: tail dragging
Value: pulling the tail along with difficulty or effort; may be due to paralysis or weakness

Subject: abnormal skeleton morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bony framework of the body in vertebrates

Subject: uveitis
Value: inflammation of part or all of the uvea, the middle (vascular) tunic of the eye, and commonly involving the other tunics (sclera and cornea, and the retina)

Subject: increased liver regeneration
Value: greater than the normal ability of liver to regenerate healthy tissue following partial hepatectomy

Subject: decreased liver regeneration
Value: less than the normal ability of liver to regenerate healthy tissue following partial hepatectomy

Subject: abnormal pancreas regeneration
Value: deviation from the normal ability of the pancreas to regenerate healthy tissue following injury

Subject: increased pancreas regeneration
Value: greater than the normal ability of the pancreas to regenerate healthy tissue following injury

Subject: decreased pancreas regeneration
Value: less than the normal ability of the pancreas to regenerate healthy tissue following injury

Subject: abnormal circulating atrial natriuretic factor level
Value: deviation from the normal concentration of the peptide hormone in the blood that regulates the water-electrolyte balance and acts as a vasodilator

Subject: increased circulating atrial natriuretic factor
Value: greater than the normal concentration of the peptide hormone in the blood that regulates the water-electrolyte balance and acts as a vasodilator

Subject: decreased circulating atrial natriuretic factor
Value: less than the normal concentration of the peptide hormone in the blood that regulates the water-electrolyte balance and acts as a vasodilator

Subject: abnormal renal plasma flow rate
Value: deviation from the normal volume of plasma passing through the kidney per unit time

Subject: increased renal plasma flow rate
Value: greater than the normal volume of plasma passing through the kidney per unit time

Subject: decreased renal plasma flow rate
Value: less than the normal volume of plasma passing through the kidney per unit time

Subject: increased renal glomerular filtration rate
Value: greater than the normal volume of water filtered out of the plasma through glomerular capillary walls into the Bowman's capsule per unit time

Subject: decreased renal glomerular filtration rate
Value: less than the normal volume of water filtered out of the plasma through glomerular capillary walls into the Bowman's capsule per unit time

Subject: abnormal renal vascular resistance
Value: deviation from the normal force opposing blood flow in the kidney blood vessels

Subject: decreased renal vascular resistance
Value: less than the normal force opposing blood flow in the kidney blood vessels

Subject: increased renal vascular resistance
Value: greater than the normal force opposing blood flow in the kidney blood vessels

Subject: abnormal vascular resistance
Value: deviation from the normal force opposing the flow of blood through a vascular bed; it is equal to the difference in blood pressure across the vascular bed divided by the cardiac output

Subject: increased body temperature
Value: greater than the level of heat natural to a living being

Subject: decreased body temperature
Value: less than the level of heat natural to a living being

Subject: abnormal body temperature
Value: deviation in the level of heat natural to a living being

Subject: Leydig cell hypoplasia
Value: reduced numbers of the interstitial cells of the seminiferous tubules that secrete testosterone

Subject: abnormal cerebral aqueduct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the channel in the mesencephalon that connects the third and fourth ventricles

Subject: decreased urine albumin level
Value: less than the normal amount of albumin in the urine

Subject: abnormal iris stromal pigmentation
Value: any anomaly in the coloring of the framework of the iris

Subject: corneal vascularization
Value: formation of blood vessels in the cornea, which normally lacks vessels

Subject: decreased cornea thickness
Value: decreased thickness of the cornea, the transparent anterior portion of the fibrous coat of the eye that serves as the chief refractory structure

Subject: corneal deposits
Value: accumulation of minerals, proteins, or other anomalous substances on the cornea

Subject: abnormal lens development
Value: aberrant formation of the transparent structure of the eye responsible for focusing light rays

Subject: choroidal neovascularization
Value: new, abnormal, vessel development of the thin, highly vascularized membrane covering most of the posterior of the eye between the retina and the sclera

Subject: abnormal Muller cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the elongated neuroglial cells that traverse all the layers of the retina and that act as supporting elements

Subject: retinal pigment epithelium atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of the epithelial layer of the retina composed of cells containing pigment granules, associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: retinal pigment epithelium hyperplasia
Value: increased numbers of cells in the epithelial layer of the retina composed of cells containing pigment granules

Subject: abnormal eye electrophysiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the eye as determined through electrophysiological recordings from single cells or summary recordings from multiple cells (e.g. electroretinogram)

Subject: increased circulating creatinine level
Value: greater than the normal blood concentration of this product of creatine catabolism; abnormal levels indicative of renal dysfunction

Subject: decreased circulating creatinine level
Value: less than the normal blood concentration of this product of creatine catabolism; abnormal levels indicative of renal dysfunction

Subject: abnormal renal filtration rate
Value: altered ability of the kidneys to remove substances from the plasma for excretion in a specific period of time

Subject: increased creatinine clearance
Value: increased rate of the process in which creatine is removed from the blood via renal filtration and its constituent parts degraded

Subject: decreased creatinine clearance
Value: decreased rate of the process in which creatine is removed from the blood via renal filtration and its constituent parts degraded

Subject: increased circulating glucose level
Value: greater than the normal concentration in the blood of this major monosaccharide of the body; it is an important energy source

Subject: decreased circulating glucose level
Value: less than the normal concentration in the blood of this major monosaccharide of the body; it is an important energy source

Subject: increased mean corpuscular hemoglobin
Value: greater than the average levels of hemoglobin contained in an erythrocyte

Subject: decreased mean corpuscular hemoglobin
Value: less than the average levels of hemoglobin contained in an erythrocyte

Subject: abnormal hemoglobin content
Value: deviation from the normal total hemoglobin content in the circulating blood

Subject: increased hemoglobin content
Value: increase in the total hemoglobin content in the circulating blood

Subject: increased blood urea nitrogen level
Value: high circulating concentration of nitrogen, in the form of urea; commonly used to measure renal function

Subject: decreased blood urea nitrogen level
Value: low circulating concentration of nitrogen, in the form of urea; commonly used to measure renal function

Subject: decreased circulating total protein level
Value: total circulating protein level below the normal range

Subject: increased circulating total protein level
Value: total circulating protein level above the normal range

Subject: decreased lactate dehydrogenase level
Value: reduced level of the tetrameric enzyme that, along with the coenzyme NAD+, catalyzes the interconversion of lactate and pyruvate

Subject: abnormal pulmonary respiratory rate
Value: deviation from the normal number of breaths per minute

Subject: increased pulmonary respiratory rate
Value: greater than the normal number of breaths per minute

Subject: decreased pulmonary respiratory rate
Value: fewer than the normal number of breaths per minute

Subject: increased pulmonary ventilation
Value: increase in the respiratory minute volume, or the total volume of gas per minute inspired or expired expressed in liters per minute; refers to the exchange of air between the total respiratory space and the environment

Subject: decreased pulmonary ventilation
Value: reduction in the respiratory minute volume, or the total volume of gas per minute inspired or expired expressed in liters per minute; refers to the exchange of air between the total respiratory space and the environment

Subject: uterus prolapse
Value: downward movement, and possible external appearance, of the uterus through the vagina

Subject: teratozoospermia
Value: presence of structurally anomalous spermatozoa in the semen; malformations include the physical bending of the sperm to produce kinks or bends

Subject: absent outer ear
Value: absence of the auricles or external acoustic meatus

Subject: periinsulitis
Value: an accumulation of macrophages, dendritic cells, and B and T lymphocytes in the periductal areas of the pancreas but outside the islet cell areas; often occurs prior to intra-insulitis of the islet cell areas

Subject: abnormal renin activity
Value: altered ability of this enzyme to cleave angiotensionogen and create angiotensin I

Subject: increased renin activity
Value: greater than the normal ability of this enzyme to cleave angiotensionogen and create angiotensin I

Subject: decreased renin activity
Value: less than the normal ability of this enzyme to cleave angiotensionogen and create angiotensin I

Subject: abnormal enzyme/coenzyme activity
Value: altered ability of any enzyme or their cofactors, to act as catalysts to induce chemical changes in other substances

Subject: increased tidal volume
Value: greater than the normal volume of air inspired or expired during each normal respiratory cycle

Subject: decreased tidal volume
Value: less than the normal volume of air inspired or expired during each normal respiratory cycle

Subject: abnormal Meckel's cartilage morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of this cartilage bar in the mandibular arch that forms a temporary supporting structure in the embryonic mandible; gives rise to middle ear bones and sphenomandibular and anterior malleolar ligaments

Subject: increased vasodilation
Value: greater than the expected or normal widening of the lumen of the blood vessels

Subject: decreased vasodilation
Value: less than the expected or normal widening of the lumen of the blood vessels

Subject: abnormal vascular smooth muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the nonstriated, involuntary muscle tissue of the blood vessels

Subject: abnormal vascular smooth muscle physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the nonstriated, involuntary muscle tissue of the blood vessels

Subject: increased susceptibility to type I hypersensitivity reaction
Value: greater likelihood of developing a response manifested by localized or generalized reaction that occurs immediately (minutes) after exposure to an antigen to which the person/animal was previously sensitized; it is IgE-mediated, and mast cell activation and degranulation are hallmarks

Subject: decreased susceptibility to type I hypersensitivity reaction
Value: less likelihood or resistance to developing a response manifested by localized or generalized reaction that occurs immediately (minutes) after exposure to an antigen to which the person/animal was previously sensitized; it is IgE-mediated, and mast cell activation and degranulation are hallmarks

Subject: decreased ventricle muscle contractility
Value: reduced ability of the heart ventricle muscle to shorten or to develop increased tension, often measured by ventricular ejection fraction volume

Subject: increased cardiac muscle contractility
Value: greater than the normal ability of the heart muscle to shorten or to develop increased tension, often measured by dP/dT max, fractional shortening (FS), velocity of circumferential fiber shortening (Vcfc), peak of aortic outflow velocity (PAV), and ventricular ejection fraction volume

Subject: increased ventricle muscle contractility
Value: greater than the normal ability of the heart ventricle muscle to shorten or to develop increased tension, often measured by ventricular ejection fraction volume

Subject: increased angiogenesis
Value: enhanced process of blood vessel formation and the subsequent remodeling process; does not refer to the initial establishment of the vascular network

Subject: decreased angiogenesis
Value: reduced process of blood vessel formation and the subsequent remodeling process; does not refer to the initial establishment of the vascular network

Subject: neuron hypertrophy
Value: increased mass of any of the structural and functional units of the nervous system, which consist of the nerve cell body, the dendrites, and the axon

Subject: hyperekplexia
Value: disorder characterized by pathologic startle responses, protective reactions to unanticipated, potentially threatening, stimuli of any type, particularly auditory

Subject: increased bone mass
Value: an increase in the total amount of bone tissue contained in the skeleton

Subject: increased bleeding time
Value: greater than the normal duration of blood flow after skin puncture; indicative of platelet and capillary function

Subject: decreased bleeding time
Value: less than the normal duration of blood flow after skin puncture; indicative of platelet and capillary function

Subject: cardiac interstitial fibrosis
Value: formation of fibrous tissue within the interstices of the heart as a result of repair or a reactive process

Subject: abnormal circulating antidiuretic hormone level
Value: deviation from the normal concentration of the peptide hormone in the blood that is normally released by the neurohypophysis to control water metabolism and balance by regulating water loss; it also contracts smooth muscle

Subject: increased circulating antidiuretic hormone level
Value: greater than the normal concentration of the peptide hormone in the blood that is normally released by the neurohypophysis to control water metabolism and balance by regulating water loss; it also contracts smooth muscle

Subject: decreased circulating antidiuretic hormone level
Value: less than the normal concentration of the peptide hormone in the blood that is normally released by the neurohypophysis to control water metabolism and balance by regulating water loss; it also contracts smooth muscle

Subject: decreased susceptibility to type II hypersensitivity reaction
Value: less likelihood of or resistance to developing a response caused by an Ag-Ab reaction; antibodies are directly or indirectly cytotoxic to antigens on cell surfaces or in connective tissues; most often involves IgG and IgM; complement activation is usually involved

Subject: increased susceptibility to type II hypersensitivity reaction
Value: greater likelihood or resistance to developing a response caused by an Ag-Ab reaction; antibodies are directly or indirectly cytotoxic to antigens on cell surfaces or in connective tissues; most often involves IgG and IgM; complement activation is usually involved

Subject: decreased susceptibility to type III hypersensitivity reaction
Value: less likelihood of or resistance to developing tissue injury mediated by immune complexes; generally involves immune complexes formed in the blood via Abs encountering circulating Ag; Ag-Ab complexes then deposit in tissues (especially blood vessels and glomeruli), induce complement activation, and result in tissue injury

Subject: increased susceptibility to type III hypersensitivity reaction
Value: greater likelihood of developing tissue injury mediated by immune complexes; generally involves immune complexes formed in the blood via antibodies encountering circulating antigen; Ag-Ab complexes then deposit in tissues (especially blood vessels and glomeruli), induce complement activation, and result in tissue injury

Subject: decreased susceptibility to type IV hypersensitivity reaction
Value: less likelihood of or resistance to developing an antigen-elicited cellular immune reaction that results in tissue damage, but does not require Ab participation; the response is seen at the area of contact

Subject: increased susceptibility to type IV hypersensitivity reaction
Value: greater likelihood of developing an antigen-elicited cellular immune reaction that results in tissue damage, but does not require Ab participation; the response is seen at the area of contact

Subject: decreased urine potassium level
Value: less than the normal amount of potassium in the urine

Subject: increased urine potassium level
Value: greater than normal amount of potassium in the urine

Subject: abnormal muscle contractility
Value: aberrant ability of a muscle to shorten or to develop increased tension

Subject: abnormal cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the vital processes of the cell

Subject: abnormal meninges morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in any of the membranes covering the spinal cord and brain, including the dura mater (external), arachnoid (middle), and pia mater (internal)

Subject: abnormal plasma anion gap
Value: measurement of the interval between the sum of routinely measured cations minus the sum of the routinely measured anions in the blood; the anion gap = (Na+ + K+) - (Cl- + HCO3-) where Na- is sodium, K+ is potassium, Cl- is chloride, and HCO3- is bicarbonate

Subject: increased plasma anion gap
Value: greater than the normal interval between the sum of routinely measured cations minus the sum of the routinely measured anions in the blood; the anion gap = (Na+ + K+) - (Cl- + HCO3-) where Na- is sodium, K+ is potassium, Cl- is chloride, and HCO3- is bicarbonate; high anion gap is indicative of metabolic acidosis

Subject: decreased plasma anion gap
Value: less than the normal interval between the sum of routinely measured cations minus the sum of the routinely measured anions in the blood; the anion gap = (Na+ + K+) - (Cl- + HCO3-) where Na- is sodium, K+ is potassium, Cl- is chloride, and HCO3- is bicarbonate; low anion gap is relatively rare but may occur from the presence of abnormal positively charged proteins, as in multiple myeloma

Subject: increased circulating potassium level
Value: greater than the normal concentration in the blood of this alkaline metallic element, the most abundant intracellular ion; anomalies in the extracellular (circulating) concentration have important implications for the function of excitable tissues, such as nerve and muscle

Subject: decreased circulating potassium level
Value: less than the normal concentration in the blood of this alkaline metallic element, the most abundant intracellular ion; anomalies in the extracellular (circulating) concentration have important implications for the function of excitable tissues, such as nerve and muscle

Subject: abnormal lung weight
Value: anomaly in the average weight of the lung

Subject: increased lung weight
Value: greater than average weight of the lung

Subject: decreased lung weight
Value: reduced average weight of the lung

Subject: decreased circulating aspartate transaminase level
Value: less than normal concentration in the blood of this enzyme, which catalyzes the reversible transfer of an amine group from l-glutamic acid to oxaloacetic acid, forming alpha-ketoglutaric acid and l-aspartic acid; aids in diagnosis of viral hepatitis and myocardial infarction

Subject: increased circulating sodium level
Value: greater than the normal concentration in the blood of this metallic element, the most plentiful extracellular ion in the body and the principal determinant of extracellular fluid volume

Subject: decreased circulating sodium level
Value: less than the normal concentration in the blood of this metallic element, the most plentiful extracellular ion in the body and the principal determinant of extracellular fluid volume

Subject: decreased circulating bilirubin level
Value: reduced concentration in the blood of the bile pigment bilirubin, normally found in the liver and in red blood cells

Subject: abnormal mineral homeostasis
Value: anomaly in the processes involved in the maintenance of an internal equilibrium of inorganic substances that have importance in body functions

Subject: abnormal iron homeostasis
Value: anomaly in the processes involved in the maintenance of an internal equilibrium of iron that normally is a cofactor in the heme of hemoglobin, myoglobin, transferrin, ferritin, and iron-containing porphyrins; it is an essential component of enzymes such as catalase, peroxidase, and various cytochromes

Subject: hemochromatosis
Value: disorder due to the deposition of hemosiderin in the parenchymal cells, causing tissue damage and dysfunction of the liver, pancreas, heart, and pituitary

Subject: hemosiderosis
Value: condition in which there is a generalized increase in the iron stores of body tissues, particularly of liver and the reticuloendothelial system, without demonstrable tissue damage

Subject: abnormal mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration
Value: deviation from the normal Hgb/Hct; the average hemoglobin concentration in a given volume of packed red cells, calculated from the hemoglobin therein and the hematocrit, in erythrocyte indices

Subject: increased mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration
Value: greater than the normal Hgb/Hct; the average hemoglobin concentration in a given volume of packed red cells, calculated from the hemoglobin therein and the hematocrit, in erythrocyte indices

Subject: decreased mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration
Value: less than the normal Hgb/Hct; the average hemoglobin concentration in a given volume of packed red cells, calculated from the hemoglobin therein and the hematocrit, in erythrocyte indices

Subject: decreased dopamine level
Value: less than the normal amount of this catecholamine neurotransmitter and neurohormone, derived from tyrosine and the precursor to norepinephrine and epinephrine; functions as a neurotransmitter in the brain and as a hormone to inhibit the release of prolactin from the anterior lobe of the pituitary

Subject: agonadal
Value: denoting the absence of gonads

Subject: abnormal hypothalamus physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the ventral and medial region of the diencephalon forming the walls of the ventral half of the third ventricle, which is normally involved in the functions of the autonomic (visceral motor) nervous system and, through its vascular link with the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland, in endocrine mechanisms

Subject: abnormal pituitary gland physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of this unpaired compound gland suspended from the base of the hypothalamus by a short extension of the infundibulum, the infundibular or pituitary stalk

Subject: abnormal sex gland physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of any of the organized aggregations of cells that function as secretory or excretory organs and are associated with reproduction

Subject: heart right ventricle degeneration
Value: replacement of cardiomyocytes in the right ventricle with fibrous tissue and/or fat

Subject: increased spleen neoplasm incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a neoplasm of the spleen, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: abnormal limb bud morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the mesenchymal outgrowth on the lateral trunk of the embryo that develops into the limbs

Subject: abnormal gonad rudiment morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the undifferentiated mesoderm that gives rise to the gonads

Subject: sex reversal
Value: development of the reproductive system is inconsistent with the chromosomal sex

Subject: phototoxicity
Value: condition caused by overexposure to UV light or from the combination of exposure to specific wavelengths and a phototoxic substance

Subject: porphyria
Value: acquired or inherited group of disorders characterized by excessive production of porphyrins or their precursors; if acquired, it results from inhibition of enzymes in the heme metabolic pathway by drugs, toxins or abnormal metabolites

Subject: increased aggression
Value: when compared to controls, subjects exhibit greater than the normal level of domineering, assault posture and/or hostile physical action

Subject: decreased aggression
Value: when compared to controls, subjects exhibit less than the normal level of domineering, assault posture and/or hostile physical action

Subject: abnormal neural plate morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the flat, thickened layer of ectodermal cells in the neuroectodermal area of the embryo's dorsal surface that develops into the neural tube and neural crest

Subject: increased susceptibility to diet-induced obesity
Value: more likely to become excessively overweight or to increase fat in the subcutaneous connective tissue as a result of consuming a diet geared to increase body fat

Subject: decreased susceptibility to diet-induced obesity
Value: less likely to become excessively overweight or to increase fat in the subcutaneous connective tissue as a result of consuming a diet geared to increase body fat

Subject: abnormal circulating adrenaline level
Value: aberrant concentration in the blood of a catecholamine hormone that stimulates the adrenergic receptors and that causes systemic vasoconstriction and gastrointestinal relaxation, stimulates the heart, and dilates bronchi and cerebral vessels

Subject: decreased circulating adrenaline level
Value: less than the normal concentration in the blood of a catecholamine hormone that stimulates the adrenergic receptors and that causes systemic vasoconstriction and gastrointestinal relaxation, stimulates the heart, and dilates bronchi and cerebral vessels

Subject: increased circulating adrenaline level
Value: greater than the normal concentration in the blood of a catecholamine hormone that stimulates the adrenergic receptors and that causes systemic vasoconstriction and gastrointestinal relaxation, stimulates the heart, and dilates bronchi and cerebral vessels

Subject: abnormal circulating noradrenaline level
Value: aberrant blood amount of the hormone secreted by the adrenal medulla and acts as a neurotransmitter in the sympathetic peripheral nervous system and in some tracts of the CNS; noradrenaline is the demethylated biosynthetic precursor of epinephrine

Subject: decreased circulating noradrenaline level
Value: less than the normal blood amount of the hormone secreted by the adrenal medulla and acts as a neurotransmitter in the sympathetic peripheral nervous system and in some tracts of the CNS; noradrenaline is the demethylated biosynthetic precursor of epinephrine

Subject: increased circulating noradrenaline level
Value: greater than the normal blood amount of the hormone secreted by the adrenal medulla and acts as a neurotransmitter in the sympathetic peripheral nervous system and in some tracts of the CNS; noradrenaline is the demethylated biosynthetic precursor of epinephrine

Subject: abnormal adipose tissue physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the connective tissue composed of fat cells enmeshed in areolar tissue

Subject: abnormal circulating leptin level
Value: anomaly in the blood concentration of the peptide hormone secreted by white adipocytes and believed to regulate food intake and energy balance

Subject: decreased circulating leptin level
Value: less than the normal blood concentration of the peptide hormone secreted by white adipocytes and believed to regulate food intake and energy balance

Subject: increased circulating leptin level
Value: greater than the normal blood concentration of the peptide hormone secreted by white adipocytes and believed to regulate food intake and energy balance

Subject: abnormal white adipose tissue physiology
Value: any functional anomaly in the connective tissue consisting of fat-storing cells and arranged in lobular groups or along minor blood vessels

Subject: abnormal response to transplant
Value: anomaly in the body's reaction to the grafting of organs, tissues, or cells taken from the same individual for another area of the body or from another individual

Subject: increased susceptibility to graft versus host disease
Value: greater likelihood of developing clinical symptoms of anorexia, diarrhea, loss of hair, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, growth retardation, and eventual death brought about by the a graft versus host reaction, which is an immunological attack mounted by a graft against the host because of tissue incompatibility when immunologically competent cells are transplanted to an immunologically incompetent host

Subject: decreased susceptibility to graft versus host disease
Value: less likelihood of developing clinical symptoms of anorexia, diarrhea, loss of hair, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, growth retardation, and eventual death brought about by the a graft versus host reaction, which is an immunological attack mounted by a graft against the host because of tissue incompatibility when immunologically competent cells are transplanted to an immunologically incompetent host

Subject: small gallbladder
Value: reduced size of the gall bladder, the organ that serves as a storage reservoir for bile

Subject: abnormal corneal epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the smooth stratified squamous epithelium that covers the outer surface of the cornea

Subject: abnormal intestinal transit time
Value: increase or decrease in the time it takes for a bolus of material to pass through the intestine

Subject: abnormal small intestinal transit time
Value: increase or decrease in the time it takes for a bolus of material to pass through the small intestine

Subject: abnormal large intestinal transit time
Value: increase or decrease in the time it takes for a bolus of material to pass through the large intestine

Subject: increased sensory neuron number
Value: greater than normal numbers of cells that innervate an effector (muscle or glandular) tissue and are responsible for transmission of sensory impulses

Subject: abnormal basal ganglion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of a group of nuclei associated with the ability to carry out willed movements, including the caudate, putamen, nucleus accumbens, globus pallidus, substantia nigra, and subthalamic nucleus

Subject: abnormal neuronal migration
Value: any anomaly in the movement of immature neurons from germinal zones to specific positions where they will reside as they mature

Subject: absent strial intermediate cells
Value: absence of the melanocytes (i.e. crest-derived intermediate cells) normally located within the intrastrial space; loss of strial intermediate cells is known to lead to loss of the endocochlear potential

Subject: abnormal endolymphatic duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small membranous canal, connecting with both saccule and utricle of the membranous labyrinth, passing through the aqueduct of vestibule, and terminating in the endolymphatic sac

Subject: dilated endolymphatic duct
Value: stretched or widened aperture of the luminal space of the endolymphatic duct

Subject: absent endolymphatic sac
Value: absence of the dilated blind extremity of the endolymphatic duct, which lies external to the dura on the posterior aspect of the petrous part of the temporal bone

Subject: dilated endolymphatic sac
Value: stretched or widened aperture of the luminal space of the endolymphatic sac

Subject: dilated lateral semicircular canal
Value: stretched or widened aperture of the luminal space of the lateral semicircular canal

Subject: dilated posterior semicircular canal
Value: stretched or widened aperture of the luminal space of the posterior semicircular canal

Subject: dilated superior semicircular canal
Value: stretched or widened aperture of the luminal space of the superior semicircular canal

Subject: abnormal tympanic membrane morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thin, tense membrane forming the greater part of the lateral wall of the tympanic cavity and separating it from the external acoustic meatus; the tympanic membrane constitutes the boundary between the external and middle ear

Subject: absent tympanic membrane
Value: absence of the thin, tense membrane forming the greater part of the lateral wall of the tympanic cavity and separating it from the external acoustic meatus; the tympanic membrane constitutes the boundary between the external and middle ear

Subject: decreased tympanic ring size
Value: smaller than average tympanic ring

Subject: abnormal Reissner membrane morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the membrane which separates the cochlear duct from the vestibular canal, i.e. the endolymph of the scala media from the perilymph of the scala vestibuli; the Reissner membrane consists of squamous epithelial cells with microvilli toward the ductus, a basement membrane, and a thin layer of connective tissue toward the scala

Subject: absent Reissner membrane
Value: loss of the membrane which separates the cochlear duct from the vestibular canal

Subject: detached Reissner membrane
Value: partial or complete loss of connection between the membrane and the stria vascularis, the periosteum covering the lamina spiralis ossea, or both

Subject: collapsed Reissner membrane
Value: the Reissner's membrane, which normally separates the scala media from the scala vestibuli, has collapsed onto the spiral limbus and the tectorial membrane of the organ of Corti

Subject: distended Reissner membrane
Value: an increase in the volume of endolymphatic fluid that results in distortion of the vestibular membrane

Subject: dilated terminal bronchiole tubes
Value: stretched or widened aperture of the luminal space of the terminal lung buds

Subject: impaired lung alveolus development
Value: a block or reduction in the formation of the sacs for holding air in the lungs, which are formed by the terminal dilation of air passageways

Subject: abnormal sclerotome morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the group of mesenchymal cells that emerge from the ventromedial part of a somite and migrate toward the notochord; normally, sclerotomal cells from adjacent somites become merged in intersomitically located masses that are the primordia of the centra of the vertebrae

Subject: abnormal otic vesicle development
Value: anomaly in the formation of the simple epithelial sac formed from the otic placode that gives rise to the structures of the inner ear

Subject: abnormal pharyngeal pouch morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the balloonlike diverticulae of the embryonic pharyngeal endoderm that line the inside of the branchial arches; these paired endodermal evaginations develop in a craniocaudal sequence between the branchial arches, e.g. pouch 1 lies between arches 1 and 2; in mammals, there are four well-developed pairs of pouches (the fifth and sixth pair is vestigial or absent); the pouch endoderm reaches the branchial groove ectoderm to form the double-layer branchial membranes that separate them

Subject: abnormal ureteric bud morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the epithelial swelling on the metanephric duct that elongates to invade the adjacent metanephric mesenchyme; interactions between the ureteric bud and the metanephric mesenchyme leads to the initiation of outgrowth and repetitive branching of the UB that ultimately generates the definitive renal collecting system and induces formation of renal vesicles from the mesenchyme tissue

Subject: abnormal external auditory canal morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the canal that connects the outer and middle ear

Subject: myoglobinuria
Value: presence of myoglobin in the urine

Subject: abnormal mitochondrial morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the semiautonomous, self replicating organelles that occur in varying numbers, shapes, and sizes in the cytoplasm of virtually all eukaryotic cells; mitochondria are notably the site of tissue respiration

Subject: abnormal mitochondrial physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the cellular organelles responsible for energy production

Subject: abnormal mitochondrial fission
Value: anomaly in the expansion rate of the cellular organelles responsible for energy production by division

Subject: increased mitochondrial fission
Value: increase in the expansion rate of the cellular organelles responsible for energy production by division

Subject: decreased mitochondrial fission
Value: reduction in the expansion rate of the cellular organelles responsible for energy production by division

Subject: increased apoptosis
Value: greater than normal programmed cell death

Subject: decreased apoptosis
Value: less than normal cell death

Subject: tricuspid valve regurgitation
Value: the backward reflux of blood through the tricuspid valve, due to insufficiency caused by disease, aging or congenital malformation

Subject: mitral valve regurgitation
Value: the backward reflux of blood through the mitral valve, due to insufficiency caused by disease, aging or congenital malformation

Subject: atrioventricular valve regurgitation
Value: the backward reflux of blood through the atrioventricular valve, due to insufficiency caused by disease, aging or congenital malformation

Subject: aortic valve regurgitation
Value: the backward reflux of blood through the aortic valve, due to insufficiency caused by disease, aging or congenital malformation

Subject: pulmonary valve regurgitation
Value: the backward reflux of blood through the pulmonary valve, due to insufficiency caused by disease, aging or congenital malformation

Subject: semilunar valve regurgitation
Value: the backward reflux of blood through the semilunar valve(s), due to insufficiency caused by disease, aging or congenital malformation

Subject: pulmonary fibrosis
Value: formation of fibrous tissue within the lung often resulting from inflammation or injury

Subject: brainstem hemorrhage
Value: bleeding into the brain stem

Subject: cerebellum hemorrhage
Value: bleeding into the cerebellum

Subject: hypothalamus hemorrhage
Value: bleeding into the hypothalamus

Subject: spinal hemorrhage
Value: bleeding into the spine

Subject: abnormal vascular endothelial cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cells that line the vasculature

Subject: increased vascular endothelial cell number
Value: greater than normal number of cells lining the vasculature

Subject: decreased vascular endothelial cell number
Value: less than normal number of cells lining the vasculature

Subject: decreased cerebral infarction size
Value: decreased size of necrotic area of the cerebrum resulting from a sudden insufficiency of arterial or venous blood supply

Subject: decreased susceptibility to ischemic brain injury
Value: less severe response, such as necrotic tissue size, to lack of adequate blood flow, due to trauma or disease, to support the normal functioning of all or part of the brain tissue, compared to controls

Subject: increased cerebral infarction size
Value: increased size of necrotic area of the cerebrum resulting from a sudden insufficiency of arterial or venous blood supply

Subject: right atrial isomerism
Value: anomaly in the asymmetry of the cardiac atria such that atria on both the left and right side have the morphology normally seen on the right side of the body

Subject: abnormal vena cava morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of either of the two largest veins in the body

Subject: abnormal inferior vena cava morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the principal vein draining blood from the lower portion of the body

Subject: abnormal superior vena cava morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the principal vein draining blood from the upper portion of the body and delivering it to the right ventricle of the heart

Subject: abnormal heart position or orientation
Value: the heart is displaced from the normal left-sided position and/or orientation

Subject: decreased clearance of atrial thrombosis
Value: slower removal of a thrombus from the atria of the heart

Subject: increased clearance of atrial thrombosis
Value: faster removal of a thrombus from the atria of the heart

Subject: abnormal retinal horizontal cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the laterally interconnecting neurons in the outer plexiform layer of the retina that connect rods of one part of the retina with cones in another part of the retina

Subject: abnormal retinal neuronal layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the neuronal layers that make up the retina, including the ganglion cell, inner plexiform, inner nuclear, outer plexiform, outer nuclear layers, the inner and outer segments

Subject: increased retinal photoreceptor cell number
Value: greater than the expected number of rods and/or cones

Subject: abnormal retinal progenitor cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cells that give rise to the various cells of the retina

Subject: abnormal retinal apoptosis
Value: change in the timing or the number of cells in the retina undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal retinal bipolar cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cells that transmit signals from the photoreceptors to retinal amacrine and ganglion cells

Subject: abnormal retinal rod bipolar cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bipolar cells that function in low light and transmit signals only through amacrine cells

Subject: abnormal retinal cone bipolar cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the retinal bipolar cells that connect to both ganglion and amacrine cells

Subject: abnormal circulating homocysteine level
Value: aberrant amount in the blood of sulfur-containing alpha-amino acid found in the plasma; blood levels are regulated by folic acid, vitamin B6 and vitamin B12

Subject: inguinal hernia
Value: hernia through the abdominal wall in the region of the groin known as Hesselbach's triangle

Subject: abnormal nipple morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the erectile projection at the apex of the mammary gland where the lactiferous ducts open

Subject: brain ischemia
Value: inadequate blood flow to a region of the brain that may lead to cerebral infarction

Subject: CNS inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the brain and/or spinal cord

Subject: abnormal blood vessel elastic tissue morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the elastic tissue layer that lines a blood vessel layer

Subject: abnormal circulating phospholipid level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration in the blood of the fat derivatives in which one fatty acid has been replaced by a phosphate group

Subject: myocardium necrosis
Value: morphological changes resulting from pathological death of myocardial tissue; usually due to irreversible damage

Subject: decreased body mass index
Value: less than normal average of a measure of weight for height

Subject: increased body mass index
Value: greater than normal average of a measure of weight for height

Subject: abnormal blood-cerebrospinal fluid barrier function
Value: anomaly in the function of the group of barriers and transport systems in the choroid plexus located in the lateral, third, and fourth brain ventricles that controls the entrance of substances into the cerebrospinal fluid from the blood

Subject: abnormal vestibular saccule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the smaller of the two sacs in the vestibule

Subject: abnormal utricle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the larger of the two sacs in the vestibule

Subject: abnormal olfactory sensory neuron morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the neurons in the olfactory epithelium that are activated by specific odorants

Subject: arteriovenous malformation
Value: fusion of an artery and vein without an intervening capillary bed

Subject: increased fat cell size
Value: increased size of fat-storing cells found mostly in the abdominal cavity and subcutaneous tissue of mammals

Subject: absent amacrine cells
Value: absence of the amacrine cells, which constitute one of the three types of interneurons found in the inner nuclear layer of the mature retina; they integrate, modulate, and interpose a temporal domain in the visual message presented to the retinal ganglion cells, with which they synapse in the inner plexiform layer

Subject: absent retinal bipolar cells
Value: absence of the cells that transmit signals from the photoreceptors to retinal amacrine and ganglion cells

Subject: abnormal cerebellar lobule formation
Value: anomaly in the formation of the lobes of the cerebellum

Subject: absent cerebellar lobules
Value: missing lobes of the cerebellum

Subject: thin cerebellar granule layer
Value: reduced thickness of the innermost cortical layer of the cerebellum that contains granule cells

Subject: abnormal tegmentum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the floor of the midbrain which extends from the substantia nigra to the level of the cerebral aqueduct

Subject: absent tegmentum
Value: absence or loss of the floor of the midbrain which extends from the substantia nigra to the level of the cerebral aqueduct

Subject: decreased tegmentum size
Value: reduced size of the floor of the midbrain which extends from the substantia nigra to the level of the cerebral aqueduct

Subject: abnormal midbrain roof plate morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the mesencephalic roof plate, including the caudal and rostral part of the midbrain roof

Subject: abnormal tectum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the rostral part of the midbrain roof

Subject: small tectum
Value: reduced size of the rostral part of the midbrain roof

Subject: absent tectum
Value: absence or loss of the rostral part of the midbrain roof

Subject: abnormal fetal atrioventricular canal morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the common canal connecting the primordial atrium and ventricle during fetal development; the dorsal and ventral endocardial cushions develop in the walls of the common atrioventricular canal, grow toward each other and fuse, dividing the common atrioventricular canal into right and left atrioventricular canals and the atrioventricular septum

Subject: abnormal hindbrain development
Value: anomaly in the formation or pattering of the caudal region of the brain

Subject: fibrillation
Value: asynchronous contraction or quivering of individual cardiac muscle fibers

Subject: ventricular fibrillation
Value: asynchronous contraction or quivering of individual cardiac muscle fibers in the ventricles

Subject: abnormal coronary circulation
Value: any anomaly in the circulation of blood through the vessels that supply the heart

Subject: angina
Value: inadequate blood flow to and/or oxygenation of the heart producing chest pain

Subject: abnormal heart septum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thin membranous structure between the two heart atria, the atria and the ventricles, or the thick muscular structure between the two heart ventricles

Subject: cardiac murmur
Value: abnormal turbulent blood flow through the valves or outflow tract results in abnormal heart sounds

Subject: aortic valve atresia
Value: congenital closure of the aortic valve

Subject: calcified aortic valve
Value: pathologic deposition of calcium salts in the aortic valve

Subject: aortic valve stenosis
Value: abnormal narrowing of the aortic valve

Subject: aortic valve prolapse
Value: collapse of one or more of the aortic valve cusps backward allowing blood to leak backwards, usually the result of enlargement of one or more of the valve cusps

Subject: mitral valve atresia
Value: congenital closure of the mitral valve

Subject: mitral valve prolapse
Value: collapse of one or more of the mitral valve cusps backward allowing blood to leak backwards, usually the result of enlargement of one or more of the valve cusps

Subject: calcified mitral valve
Value: pathologic deposition of calcium salts in the mitral valve

Subject: mitral valve stenosis
Value: abnormal narrowing of the mitral valve

Subject: tricuspid valve atresia
Value: congenital closure of the tricuspid valve

Subject: tricuspid valve stenosis
Value: abnormal narrowing of the tricuspid valve

Subject: tricuspid valve prolapse
Value: collapse of one or more of the tricuspid valve cusps backward allowing blood to leak backwards, usually the result of enlargement of one or more of the valve cusps

Subject: abnormal cardiac outflow tract development
Value: anomaly in the development of the common arterial trunk that forms the aorta and pulmonary artery and the ventricular outflow regions

Subject: pulmonary valve stenosis
Value: abnormal narrowing of the pulmonary valve

Subject: pulmonary valve prolapse
Value: collapse of one or more of the pulmonary valve cusps backward allowing blood to leak backwards, usually the result of enlargement of one or more of the valve cusps

Subject: pulmonary valve atresia
Value: congenital closure of the pulmonary valve

Subject: calcified pulmonary valve
Value: pathologic deposition of calcium salts in the pulmonary valve

Subject: calcified tricuspid valve
Value: pathologic deposition of calcium salts in the tricuspid valve

Subject: calcified artery
Value: pathologic deposition of calcium salts in the arteries

Subject: artery occlusion
Value: blockage of blood flow through one or more arteries

Subject: artery stenosis
Value: abnormal narrowing of the arteries

Subject: varicose veins
Value: enlarged, twisted, painful superficial veins resulting from poorly functioning valves

Subject: venoocclusion
Value: blockage of blood flow through one or more veins

Subject: congestive heart failure
Value: cardiac output is insufficient to supply blood throughout the body, resulting in the accumulation of fluid in the lungs and other body tissues; it is related mainly to salt and water retention in the tissues rather than directly to reduced blood flow; blood pools in the veins (vascular congestion) because the heart does not pump efficiently enough to allow it to return

Subject: increased cardiac rhabdomyoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign tumor of the myocardium, occurring in a specific population in a given time period; it is most commonly seen in the young and is often associated with tuberous sclerosis

Subject: abnormal atrioventricular node conduction
Value: anomaly in the generation or transfer of cardiac electrical impulses from the atrioventricular node to the atrioventricular bundle

Subject: abnormal sinoatrial node conduction
Value: anomaly in the generation or transfer of electrical impulses that trigger contraction of the atria and ventricles

Subject: increased systemic arterial diastolic blood pressure
Value: abnormal increase in the pressure in the arteries between heart beats when the heart is relaxed

Subject: increased systemic arterial systolic blood pressure
Value: abnormal increase in the pressure in the arteries as the heart contracts and pumps blood into the arteries

Subject: legal blindness
Value: the best corrected visual acuity is 20/200, or the visual field is 20 degrees or less (sensu H. sapiens)

Subject: monocular blindness
Value: loss of vision in only one eye, may be transient

Subject: binocular blindness
Value: loss of vision in both eyes, may be transient

Subject: decreased visual acuity
Value: loss of visual acuity or ability to distinguish small details

Subject: double vision
Value: two images are perceived when only a single object is present

Subject: astigmatism
Value: the cornea is asymmetrically curved, causing out-of-focus vision

Subject: tunnel vision
Value: loss of peripheral vision

Subject: hypermetropia
Value: light entering the eye focuses behind the retina, instead of directly on it

Subject: eye abduction
Value: abnormal movement of the eye laterally, or towards the temple

Subject: eye adduction
Value: abnormal movement of the eye medially, or towards the nose

Subject: abnormal visual pursuit
Value: anomaly in the ability to selectively track a moving object

Subject: palsy of the eye
Value: the eye fails to move properly in all directions of gaze

Subject: vertical supranuclear palsy
Value: inability to move the eye vertically

Subject: ocular albinism
Value: absence of melanin (pigment) production in the eye with identifiable melanocytes present

Subject: heterochromatic iridis
Value: a difference in color between the irises of the two eyes or between parts of one iris

Subject: thick eyelids
Value: increased width of the eyelid

Subject: ankyloblepharon filiform
Value: abnormal connection of the upper and lower eyelids formed by fibrous tissue

Subject: ectropion
Value: abnormal eversion of the upper or lower eyelid that leaves the eye exposed and dry

Subject: entropion
Value: abnormal inward rolling of the eyelid, most commonly the lower lid

Subject: eyelid retraction
Value: abnormal superior displacement of resting upper lid margin or abnormal inferior displacement of resting lower lid margin

Subject: eyelid edema
Value: an abnormal accumulation of fluid in the eyelid

Subject: epicanthus inversus
Value: a vertical fold of skin runs from the lower eyelid up either side of the nose

Subject: increased eyelid tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of abnormal rapidly proliferating cells in the eyelid, usually in the form of a distinct mass, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased eyelid myxoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of a benign neoplasm derived from pluripotential mesenchymal stem cells of eyelid connective tissue, consisting chiefly of polyhedral and stellate cells that are loosely embedded in a soft mucoid matrix

Subject: increased eyelid neuroma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a tumor composed of nerve tissue found in the eyelid, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased eyelid lipodermoid incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a congenital, yellowish-white, fatty, benign tumor located beneath the conjunctiva of the eye, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: abnormal myeloid dendritic cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of phagocytic cells of the myeloid lineage that capture antigens in the periphery and then migrate to the lymphoid organs and secrete cytokines to initiate immune responses

Subject: choroid atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of the choroid associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: choroid degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of the choroid

Subject: choroid sclerosis
Value: thickening or hardening of the choroid usually secondary to atrophy

Subject: increased choroid hemangioma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign tumor characterized by blood-filled spaces lined by benign endothelial cells in the choroid, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased retinal hemangioma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign tumor characterized by blood-filled spaces lined by benign endothelial cells in the retina, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased retina hamartoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign formation of a mass of tissue of disproportionate size and distribution in the retina, occurring in a specific population in a given time period; hamartomas are typically composed of an overgrowth of mature cells and tissues that normally occur in this tissue

Subject: increased retinal astrocytoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a malignant tumor of nervous tissue composed of well-differentiated astrocytes located in the retina, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: retinal hemorrhage
Value: bleeding into the retina

Subject: retinal fibrosis
Value: invasion of fibrous connective tissue into the retina, often resulting from inflammation or injury

Subject: retinal deposits
Value: abnormal accumulation of material on the retina

Subject: calcified retina
Value: pathologic deposition of calcium salts in the retina

Subject: retinal ischemia
Value: inadequate blood flow to the retina usually due to functional constriction or obstruction of a blood vessel

Subject: conjunctival deposits
Value: abnormal accumulation of material on the conjunctiva

Subject: abnormal conjunctival vasculature morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the blood vessel network of the conjunctiva

Subject: conjunctival telangiectasia
Value: vascular lesion formed by dilation of a group of small blood vessels in the conjunctiva

Subject: keratoconjunctivitis
Value: inflammation of the conjunctiva and cornea

Subject: ocular hypotelorism
Value: decreased interpupillary distance, i.e. decreased distance between the center of the pupils of the two eyes

Subject: enophthalmos
Value: recession of the eyeball within the orbit

Subject: hypertropia
Value: vertical misalignment between the eyes

Subject: vitreous body deposition
Value: abnormal accumulation of material in the vitreous body

Subject: vitreous body inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the vitreous body

Subject: vitreous body hemorrhage
Value: bleeding into the vitreous body

Subject: eye hemorrhage
Value: bleeding into the eye

Subject: embryonic lethality before implantation
Value: <death anytime between fertilization and implantation (Mus: E0 to less than E4.5)>

Subject: embryonic lethality between implantation and somite formation
Value: <death anytime between the point of implantation and somite formation (Mus: E4.5 to less than E8)>

Subject: embryonic lethality between somite formation and embryo turning
Value: <death anytime between somite formation and the initiation of embryo turning (Mus: E8 to less than E9)>

Subject: embryonic lethality during organogenesis
Value: <death anytime between embryo turning and the completion of organogenesis (Mus: E9-9.5 to less than E14)>

Subject: lethality throughout fetal growth and development
Value: <death anytime between the completion of organogenesis and birth (Mus: E14 to approximately E18.5)>

Subject: calcified intraocular region
Value: pathologic deposition of calcium salts in the eye

Subject: abnormal orbit size
Value: deviation from the normal size of the orbit

Subject: small orbits
Value: reduced size of the orbits

Subject: large orbits
Value: increased size of the orbits

Subject: shallow orbits
Value: decrease in the depth of the orbit

Subject: asymmetrical orbits
Value: loss of bilateral symmetry in the orbits

Subject: abnormal optic disk size
Value: deviation from the normal size of the optic disk

Subject: small optic disk
Value: reduced size of the optic disk

Subject: large optic disk
Value: increased size of the optic disk

Subject: optic nerve degeneration
Value: an active retrogressive pathologic deterioration of the optic nerve due to processes such as aberrant damage repair from injury, impaired blood flow or aging

Subject: optic nerve compression
Value: a flattened or pressed appearance of the optic nerve as if by applied pressure

Subject: optic nerve hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the fibers in the optic nerve

Subject: optic neuropathy
Value: damage of the optic nerve due to a blockage of its blood supply, to nutritional deficiencies, or to toxins

Subject: optic nerve swelling
Value: accumulation of an excessive amount of fluid in the optic nerve; usually associated with an increase in intraocular pressure

Subject: oculomotor apraxia
Value: impaired control of horizontal eye movements

Subject: ocular rupture
Value: tearing of the tissues of the eye

Subject: iris hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the iris, usually due to a reduced number of cells

Subject: iris atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of the iris associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: iris inflammation
