Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins and leukocytes in the iris

Subject: iris stroma hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the iris stroma, usually due to a reduced number of cells

Subject: increased Lisch nodule incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of benign focal malformations in the iris in a specific population in a given time period; results from faulty iris development, and is composed of an abnormal mixture of tissue elements including melanocytes, or an abnormal proportion of a single element normally present at that site

Subject: iridoschisis
Value: separation of the anterior iris stroma from the posterior stroma and muscle layers

Subject: polycoria
Value: two or more pupils in one iris each with sphincter muscle

Subject: absent Meibomian glands
Value: missing meibomian glands

Subject: abnormal choroid vasculature morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the blood vessels of the choroid

Subject: abnormal choriocapillaris morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the capillaries forming the inner vascular layer of the choroid of the eye

Subject: absent choriocapillaris
Value: missing capillaries forming the inner vascular layer of the choroid of the eye

Subject: anisocoria
Value: unequal size of pupils

Subject: abnormal placement of pupils
Value: abnormal location of the pupil so that it is not in the center of the iris

Subject: white pupil
Value: reflective white mass within the eye that gives the appearance of white pupil

Subject: impaired pupillary reflex
Value: the pupil fails to constrict fully when exposed to bright light

Subject: eyelid muscle spasm
Value: repetitive, involuntary spasm of the eyelid muscles; a twitch usually occurs in the upper eyelid, but it can occur in both the upper and lower eyelids

Subject: dislocated lens
Value: the lens is moved out of position because some or all of the supporting ligaments have broken

Subject: lagophthalmos
Value: inability to completely close the eye

Subject: phthisis bulbi
Value: small, shrunken, malformed eye that usually represents an acquired shrinkage of the eye following trauma, infection, or the end result of eye disease rather than a primary developmental defect

Subject: abnormal line of Schwalbe morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thickened peripheral margin of the vitreous membrane of the cornea

Subject: eyelid apraxia
Value: impaired ability to open the eyelids without any gross defect in eyelid morphology

Subject: lateral rectus palsy
Value: paralysis of the lateral rectus muscle preventing medially deviated and movement laterally from the midline

Subject: clinodactyly
Value: abnormal lateral curvature of one or more digits towards or away from each other

Subject: thin cerebral cortex
Value: decreased depth of the mantle covering the surface of the cerebral hemispheres

Subject: abnormal gustatory papillae morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the papillae that contain taste buds, including the fungiform, foliate, and circumvallate papillae

Subject: abnormal fungiform papillae morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the mushroom-shaped papillae, which have a single taste bud at the tip, located mostly on the dorsal anterior portion of the tongue

Subject: abnormal circumvallate papillae morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the large papillae, which have multiple taste buds in the trough surrounding the papillae, located near the base and on the dorsal side of the tongue

Subject: abnormal foliate papillae morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the papillae located on the sides of the tongue

Subject: abnormal gustatory papillae taste bud morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the taste buds located on the gustatory papillae, which includes the fungiform, foliate, and circumvallate papillae

Subject: annular pancreas
Value: an abnormal ring or collar of pancreatic tissue that encircles the duodenum

Subject: increased testis tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of abnormal rapidly proliferating cells in the testis, usually in the form of a distinct mass, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: decreased systemic arterial diastolic blood pressure
Value: abnormal decrease in the pressure in the arteries between heart beats when the heart is relaxed

Subject: decreased systemic arterial systolic blood pressure
Value: abnormal decrease in the pressure in the arteries as the heart contracts and pumps blood into the arteries

Subject: increased pulse pressure
Value: increase in the difference between systolic and diastolic blood pressure

Subject: decreased pulse pressure
Value: decrease in the difference between systolic and diastolic blood pressure

Subject: abnormal intercalated disk morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the electron dense junctional complex, at the end to end contacts of cardiac muscle cells, that contains two types of membrane junctions i.e. gap junctions and desmosomes; the intercalated discs permit communication between the cells such that there is a sequential contraction of the cells from the bottom of the ventricle to the top, facilitating maximal ejection of blood from the ventricle during contraction

Subject: absent cardiac desmosomes
Value: absence of one type of membrane junctions found within the intercalated discs that provide mechanical integrity and prevent separation of adjacent cells during contraction of cardiac tissue

Subject: abnormal mammary gland growth during pregnancy
Value: anomaly in the extensive and rapid branching of the mammary ducts, expansion of mammary epithelium in the stroma between the ducts with or without abnormalities in nipple maturation in preparation for lactation

Subject: abnormal mammary gland growth during lactation
Value: anomaly in the final stage of mammary growth that occurs during the start of lactation

Subject: abnormal involution of the mammary gland
Value: anomaly in the process during which mammary glands suspend milk protein production, the mammary alveolar structures collapse and secretory epithelial cells are lost

Subject: abnormal urine organic anion level
Value: any change in the amount of organic anions in the urine

Subject: abnormal urine organic cation level
Value: any change in the amount of organic cations in the urine

Subject: abnormal urine sodium level
Value: any change in the amount of sodium in the urine

Subject: abnormal autonomic nervous system physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the function of the sensory and motor neurons that run between the central nervous system (especially the hypothalamus and medulla oblongata) and various internal organs (heart, lungs, endocrine and exocrine glands), responsible for controlling involuntary bodily functions

Subject: abnormal parasympathetic nervous system physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the part of the autonomic nervous system that innervates smooth muscle, cardiac muscle and glands and generally acts to conserve resources and restore homeostasis, often with effects reciprocal to the sympathetic nervous system

Subject: aortic aneurysm
Value: a protruding sac formed by the dilation of the wall of the aorta resulting from a weakening of the vessel wall

Subject: abnormal limb development
Value: anomaly in the formation of the limbs

Subject: abnormal digit development
Value: anomaly in the formation of the digits

Subject: abnormal tail development
Value: anomaly in the formation of the tail

Subject: abnormal spinal cord dorsal horn morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the pronounced, dorsolaterally oriented ridge of grey matter in each lateral half of the spinal cord

Subject: increased medulloblastoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a solid, cancerous tumor originating in the cerebellum of the brain and of primitive neuroectodermal origin, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: absent hypaxial muscle
Value: absence of the muscles derived from the lateral myotome and lateral portion of the dermomyotome; these include the thoracic intercostal and abdominal muscles, limb muscles and superficial back muscles, as well as the diaphragm and the tip of the tongue

Subject: absent inner ear
Value: absence of all components of the labyrinth, including the semicircular canals, vestibule and cochlea

Subject: inner ear hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of inner ear structures, usually due to decreased cell number

Subject: inner ear cysts
Value: abnormal membranous sacs in any component of the labyrinth, including the semicircular canals, vestibule and cochlea

Subject: small otic capsule
Value: reduced size of the cartilage or bony capsule surrounding the inner ear mechanism

Subject: otic capsule hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the cartilage or bony capsule surrounding the inner ear mechanism

Subject: proboscis
Value: a long, cylindrical protuberance of the face that, in cyclopia or ethmocephaly, represents the nose

Subject: aprosencephaly
Value: the most severe form of holoprosencephaly where the entire prosencephalon (both telencephalon and diencephalon) fails to develop while the hindbrain is largely preserved

Subject: abnormal nasal placode morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the paired ectodermal placodes that come to lie in the bottom of the olfactory pits as the pits are deepened by the growth of the surrounding medial and lateral nasal processes; the nasal placode gives rise to the olfactory epithelium of the nose

Subject: absent nasal placodes
Value: absence of the paired ectodermal placodes that come to lie in the bottom of the olfactory pits as the pits are deepened by the growth of the surrounding medial and lateral nasal processes; the nasal placode gives rise to the olfactory epithelium of the nose

Subject: absent optic vesicle
Value: absence of the hollow outgrowth from the lateral aspects of the embryonic forebrain from which the retina and optic nerve develop

Subject: absent sclerotome
Value: absence of the group of mesenchymal cells that emerge from the ventromedial part of a somite and migrate toward the notochord to give rise to the ribs and vertebrae

Subject: arachnodactyly
Value: the digits are abnormally long and slender

Subject: abnormal platelet activation
Value: anomaly in the series of progressive, overlapping events triggered by exposure of platelets to signals from subendothelial tissue, including shape change, adhesiveness, aggregation, and release reactions; when carried through to completion, these events lead to the formation of a stable hemostatic plug

Subject: abnormal latent inhibition of conditioning behavior
Value: anomaly in the impairment in a conditioned response seen after repeated unpaired presentations of the conditioned stimulus prior to pairing it with the unconditioned stimulus

Subject: abnormal entorhinal cortex morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the structure in the anterior parahippocampus that lies forward of the parahippocampal cortex and immediately medial to the perirhinal cortex, bounded superiorly by the hippocampus and inferiorly by the collateral sulcus

Subject: abnormal mesenchyme morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the loosely packed, unspecialized cells that derive mostly from the mesoderm and contribute to connective tissue, bone, cartilage and circulatory and lymphatic systems

Subject: abnormal ectomesenchyme morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the mesenchymal cells derived from neural crest cells that contribute to development of the hard and soft tissue in the head and neck, including the branchial arches

Subject: abnormal retinal nerve fiber layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the layer of the retina formed by expansion of the fibers of the optic nerve

Subject: abnormal optic eminence morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the embryonic structure that gives rise to the corneal ectoderm

Subject: abnormal nasal pit morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of one or both of a pair of depressions formed in the developing face that give rise to the rostral portion of the nasal meatus; the nasal pits indent the fronto-nasal process and divide it into a medial and two lateral nasal processes

Subject: abnormal seminiferous tubule size
Value: alteration in the diameter of the tubules in the testes where spermatogenesis occurs

Subject: enlarged seminiferous tubules
Value: increased diameter of the tubules in the testes where spermatogenesis occurs

Subject: decreased retinal ganglion cell number
Value: reduced number of ganglion neurons located in the innermost nuclear layer of the retina of that receive visual information from photoreceptors via various intermediate cells such as bipolar cells, amacrine cells, and horizontal cells; axons from these cells form the optic nerve and connect mainly to the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) and to the suprachiasmatic nucleus in the brain

Subject: increased retinoblastoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of a malignant tumor of the retina composed of cells arising from the retinoblasts

Subject: abnormal urine protein level
Value: anomaly in the amount of protein in the urine

Subject: increased urine sodium level
Value: higher than normal amount of sodium in the urine

Subject: decreased urine sodium level
Value: lower than normal amount of sodium in the urine

Subject: abnormal epididymal fat pad morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the encapsulated adipose tissue associated with the epididymis

Subject: abnormal interscapular fat pad morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the encapsulated adipose tissue located between the scapulae

Subject: increased myocardial fiber number
Value: increased number of the terminally differentiated, non-proliferative, cardiac muscle fibers, the multinucleated muscle cells of the heart

Subject: abnormal perichondrium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the fibrous connective tissue that surrounds all non-joint end cartilage

Subject: abnormal extraembryonic mesoderm development
Value: malformation of the mesoderm of the extraembryonic tissue that is involved in forming the amnion, chorion, yolk sac, and body stalk

Subject: abnormal cochlear nerve fiber response
Value: anomaly in the electrophysiological recordings from a single or several auditory nerve fiber(s)

Subject: impaired hearing
Value: reduced ability to perceive auditory stimuli

Subject: conductive hearing impairment
Value: reduction in the ability to hear due to lesions in the external auditory canal or middle ear

Subject: mixed hearing impairment
Value: reduced ability to hear resulting from a combination of conductive and sensorineural hearing impairment

Subject: nonsyndromic hearing impairment
Value: a form of hearing impairment that is not associated with visible abnormalities of the external ear or other signs and symptoms; the vast majority of hereditary hearing loss is nonsyndromic and can be associated with abnormalities of the middle ear and/or inner ear

Subject: sensorineural hearing impairment
Value: a form of hearing impairment due to a lesion of the auditory division of cranial nerve VIII or the inner ear

Subject: syndromic hearing impairment
Value: hearing impairment that is usually associated with malformations of the external ear and other inherited signs and symptoms

Subject: abnormal patterning of the organ of Corti
Value: anomaly in the organization of the various cell types within the organ of Corti into a set number of distinct rows

Subject: abnormal cochlear potential
Value: anomaly in the evoked response of the cochlea

Subject: abnormal susceptibility to hearing loss
Value: anomaly in the sensitivity to loss of hearing related to age or environmental factors

Subject: abnormal hearing electrophysiology
Value: anomaly in auditory function as it relates to electrical phenomena

Subject: abnormal otoacoustic response
Value: anomaly in the acoustic energy produced by the cochlea in the presence or absence of sound stimulation

Subject: abnormal first pharyngeal arch morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the first arch which contributes to development of mastication muscles, maxilla, mandible, incus, malleus, Meckel's cartilage, trigeminal nerve, and maxillary artery

Subject: abnormal second pharyngeal arch morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the second arch which contributes to the development of the stapes, styloid process, hyoid bone, stylohyoid ligament, muscles of facial expression, stapedius muscle, stylohyoid muscle, and lining of the palatine tonsils

Subject: abnormal third pharyngeal arch morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the third arch which contributes to the development of the hyoid bone, stylopharyngeus muscle, inferior parathyroid gland, and thymus

Subject: abnormal fourth pharyngeal arch morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the fourth arch which contributes to development of the cartilage of the larynx, laryngeal, pharyngeal, and soft palate muscles, superior parathyroid gland, and C-cells of the thymus

Subject: small first pharyngeal arch
Value: reduced size of the first branchial arch

Subject: absent first pharyngeal arch
Value: absence of the structure of the first arch which contributes to development of mastication muscles, maxilla, mandible, incus, malleus, Meckel's cartilage, trigeminal nerve, and maxillary artery

Subject: enlarged first pharyngeal arch
Value: increased size of the first branchial arch

Subject: small second pharyngeal arch
Value: reduced size of the second branchial arch

Subject: absent second pharyngeal arch
Value: absence of the structure of the second arch which contributes to the development of the stapes, styloid process, hyoid bone, stylohyoid ligament, muscles of facial expression, stapedius muscle, stylohyoid muscle, and lining of the palatine tonsils

Subject: small pharyngeal arch
Value: reduced size of one or more of the branchial arches

Subject: abnormal sixth pharyngeal arch morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the sixth arch which contributes to the development of the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles

Subject: abnormal circulating copper level
Value: any anomaly in the blood concentration of copper

Subject: decreased circulating copper level
Value: less than the normal concentration of copper in the blood

Subject: increased circulating copper level
Value: greater than normal concentration of copper in the blood

Subject: abnormal glycosylated hemoglobin level
Value: aberrant concentration in the blood of modified form of hemoglobin with an attached saccharide molecule; this is commonly used to estimate blood glucose levels over the lifespan of the red blood cell

Subject: decreased glycosylated hemoglobin level
Value: lower than normal blood concentration of a modified form of hemoglobin with an attached saccharide molecule

Subject: increased glycosylated hemoglobin level
Value: greater than normal blood concentration of a modified form of hemoglobin with an attached saccharide molecule

Subject: abnormal fourth pharyngeal arch artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the vessels formed within the fourth pair of branchial arches in embryogenesis

Subject: abnormal sixth pharyngeal arch artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the vessels formed within the sixth pair of branchial arches in embryogenesis

Subject: abnormal third pharyngeal arch artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the vessels formed within the third pair of branchial arches in embryogenesis

Subject: abnormal circulating mineral level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration in the blood of any naturally occurring, homogeneous inorganic solid substance having a definite chemical composition and highly ordered atomic arrangement that is required for growth and survival

Subject: absent pinna reflex
Value: complete failure to respond to an auditory stimulus by a characteristic ear twitch

Subject: absent startle reflex
Value: failure to respond to variable stimuli, often auditory; usually measured by amplitude of whole body flinch

Subject: abnormal female germ cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly female germ cells whether they are undifferentiated or fully differentiated

Subject: abnormal male germ cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of male germ cells whether they are undifferentiated or fully differentiated

Subject: absent auchene hairs
Value: absence of truncal hairs having a single constriction and bend about midway along the hair shaft, and contain two or more air cells in the medulla

Subject: absent awl hair
Value: absence of truncal hairs that are straight, but are shorter than guard hairs, and contain two or more air cells in the medulla

Subject: absent guard hair
Value: absence of the long, straight truncal hairs that contain two air cells in the medulla

Subject: absent zigzag hairs
Value: absence of the truncal hairs that have two or more sharp bends with diameter constrictions at the bends, and contain one air cell in the medulla

Subject: absent sweat gland
Value: absence of any of the coil glands of the skin that secrete sweat

Subject: supernumerary incisors
Value: more than the usual number of incisors, normally consisting of two pairs, top and bottom, of the long teeth that are the most anterior and prominent in the jaw

Subject: abnormal hair follicle pheomelanosome pheomelanin content
Value: anomaly in the amount or distribution of yellow pigment in the hair follicle

Subject: absent hair follicle pheomelanosome pheomelanin
Value: yellow pigment is not present in pheomelanosomes of the hair follicle

Subject: impaired placental function
Value: reduction in the ability of the placenta to supply nutrients or remove waste

Subject: abnormal circulating angiotensinogen level
Value: anomaly in the concentration of the serum globulin formed by the liver that is cleaved by renin to form angiotensin I

Subject: increased circulating angiotensinogen level
Value: greater than normal concentration of the serum globulin formed by the liver that is cleaved by renin to form angiotensin I

Subject: decreased circulating angiotensinogen level
Value: less than normal concentration of the serum globulin formed by the liver that is cleaved by renin to form angiotensin I

Subject: abnormal vestibulocollic reflex
Value: any anomaly in the neural reflex which results from activation of afferents from the vestibular organs and uses neck movements to stabilize the head position in space

Subject: abnormal spermatogonia morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the large unspecialized male germ cells that give rise to spermatocytes

Subject: abnormal spermatocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of male germ cells that through meiosis give rise to spermatids

Subject: abnormal spermatid morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the male germ cells that without further cell division give rise to mature spermatozoa

Subject: abnormal lung epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the epithelial layer of the lung

Subject: abnormal cochlear frequency tuning
Value: any anomaly in the frequency resolution of the cochlea, normally determined by the passive mechanical properties of the basilar membrane and active feedback from the outer hair cells which detect and amplify sound-induced basilar membrane motions

Subject: enhanced cochlear frequency tuning
Value: increase in the sharpness of frequency resolution of the cochlea

Subject: absent somites
Value: absence of mesodermal clusters that are arranged segmentally along the anterior posterior axis of an embryo

Subject: abnormal T cell number
Value: deviation from the normal count of T cells

Subject: abnormal auditory summating potential
Value: any anomaly in the dc shift in the waveform sustained for the duration of a toneburst stimulus that represents the depolarization of sensory hair cells in the cochlea; positive summating potentials (SPs) reflect activity of basal turn hair cells while negative SPs are derived from hair cell activity in the apical turn; negative SPs tend to be obtained at low frequencies and low intensities of stimulus, while positive SPs are recorded in response to high frequencies and high intensities

Subject: abnormal vestibular endolymph
Value: change in the normal production (volume) or ionic homeostasis of the fluid contained within the vestibule of the inner ear; unlike cochlear endolymph this fluid does not have a high potential

Subject: abnormal cochlear endolymph
Value: change in the normal production (volume) or ionic homeostasis of the fluid contained within the cochlea of the inner ear

Subject: abnormal vestibular endolymph ionic homeostasis
Value: anomaly in the processes involved in the maintenance of an internal equilibrium of charged molecules in the vestibular endolymph

Subject: abnormal nucleus pulposus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the jelly-like substance in the middle of the spinal disc which is a remnant of the notochord

Subject: absent nucleus pulposus
Value: missing the notochord remnant normally found in the center of the intervertebral disc

Subject: abnormal vertebral epiphyseal plate morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the lateral cartilaginous centers of ossification; may be found on the lateral, upper, and/or lower surfaces of the vertebrae at different times during development

Subject: abnormal epiphyseal plate morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cartilaginous center of ossification on the bones permitting growth of the bone in both directions during development

Subject: decreased long bone epiphyseal plate size
Value: reduced size of the cartilaginous center of ossification located at one or both ends of bones between the epiphysis (end) and the diaphysis (shaft) of long bones; longitudinal growth of the bone occurs at the plate during development in children and juveniles

Subject: disorganized long bone epiphyseal plate
Value: a lack of the regular arrangement of the cells or zones of the epiphyseal plate

Subject: increased long bone epiphyseal plate size
Value: greater than the normal size of the cartilaginous center of ossification located at one or both ends of bones between the epiphysis (end) and the diaphysis (shaft) of long bones; longitudinal growth of the bone occurs at the plate during development in children and juveniles

Subject: abnormal long bone epiphyseal ossification zone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the layer of the epiphyseal plate where new bone matrix is deposited

Subject: decreased molar number
Value: reduction in the number of the most posterior teeth located on either side of the jaw, and characterized by a large crown and broad chewing surface

Subject: absent male preputial gland
Value: a lack of the sebaceous glands of the corona and neck of the glans penis

Subject: small molars
Value: reduced size of the most posterior teeth located on either side of the jaw, and characterized by a large crown and broad chewing surface

Subject: abnormal cochlear endolymph ionic homeostasis
Value: anomaly in the state of equilibrium in the cochlear endolymph with respect to charged molecules; cochlear endolymph is not only an unusual extracellular fluid for its high potassium ion and low sodium ion concentration but also for its low calcium ion concentration, high HCO3- concentration and low protein content

Subject: abnormal lumbar dorsal root ganglion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the group of nerve cell bodies located on the dorsal spinal roots within the vertebral column at the level of the lumbar vertebrae

Subject: abnormal L3 dorsal root ganglion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the group of nerve cell bodies located on the dorsal spinal roots within the vertebral column at the level of the third lumbar vertebra

Subject: dorsal root ganglion hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced cell number, of a dorsal root ganglion or ganglia

Subject: vestibular ganglion hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cell bodies, in the group of bipolar sensory nerve cell bodies concerned with equilibration that form a swelling on the vestibular part of the eighth cranial nerve in the fundus of the internal acoustic meatus

Subject: abnormal common myeloid progenitor cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the hematopoietic stem cells that are capable of forming any of the myeloid lineage cells (erythrocytes, granulocytes, thrombocytes, monocytes, and mast cells) but not cells of the lymphoid lineage

Subject: upturned snout
Value: muzzle has a curve or tilt such that the tip points upwards

Subject: abnormal T cell apoptosis
Value: change in the timing or the number of T cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: increased T cell apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of T cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: decreased T cell apoptosis
Value: decrease in the number of T cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: absent testes
Value: absence of the male reproductive glands containing the germ cells

Subject: abnormal rete testis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the network of canals at the termination of the straight tubules in the mediastinum testis

Subject: rete testis obstruction
Value: any impediment or blockage of the network of canals at the termination of the straight tubules in the mediastinum testis

Subject: abnormal testis cord formation
Value: any structural anomaly in the formation of the attachments derived from the primordial seminiferous cords that differentiate into seminiferous tubules in adolescence; defective testis cord formation is most likely to reflect abnormal function of either Sertoli cells or peritubular myoid (PTM) cells which normally cooperate to deposit a layer of basal lamina that defines the edges of individual testis cords

Subject: disorganized testis cords
Value: derangement of the pattern of the attachments derived from the primordial seminiferous cords that differentiate into seminiferous tubules in adolescence

Subject: abnormal peritubular myoid cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the flattened smooth myoepithelial cells of mesodermal origin that lie just outside the basal lamina of the seminiferous tubule

Subject: decreased number of peritubular myoid cells
Value: reduced number of the flattened smooth myoepithelial cells of mesodermal origin that lie just outside the basal lamina of the seminiferous tubule

Subject: increased mammary adenoacanthoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of malignant tumors in which some cells have undergone squamous metaplasia in the mammary gland

Subject: dilated rete testis
Value: an expansion in the volume or area of the network of canals located at the termination of the straight tubules in the mediastinum testis, usually with an increase in contained fluid

Subject: absent testis cords
Value: missing the attachments derived from the primordial seminiferous cords that differentiate into seminiferous tubules in adolescence

Subject: absent Mullerian ducts
Value: absence of the transient embryonic drainage tubes of the embryonic kidney (mesonephric tubules) that empty into the cloaca and in the female develop into the oviducts, uterus, and vagina

Subject: Mullerian duct degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of the transient embryonic drainage tubes of the embryonic kidney (mesonephric tubules) that empty into the cloaca and in the female develop into the oviducts, uterus, and vagina

Subject: ectopic Leydig cells
Value: abnormal position of the interstitial cells of the seminiferous tubules, which normally reside in the peritubular space and extend from the coelomic surface to the dorsal surface of the gonad

Subject: ectopic Sertoli cells
Value: abnormal position of the supporting cells of the seminiferous tubule epithelium that create the blood-testes barrier and enable spermatogenesis

Subject: abnormal hyaline cartilage morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bluish-white, glassy, translucent nonvascular, resilient, flexible connective tissue; found primarily in articular cartilage, costal cartilages, the nasal septum, the larynx, and the trachea

Subject: abnormal elastic cartilage morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the nonvascular, resilient, flexible connective tissue containing elastin fibers; found primarily in the epiglottis, external ear, and auditory tubes

Subject: abnormal fibrocartilage morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the nonvascular, resilient, flexible connective tissue containing thick bundles of collagenous fibers; found primarily in intervertebral disks

Subject: abnormal costal cartilage morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the nonvascular, resilient, flexible hyaline connective tissue that connects the end of a true rib to the sternum or the end of a false rib with the with the lower border of the costal cartilage above it

Subject: abnormal articular cartilage morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thin layer of smooth hyaline cartilage located on the joint surfaces of a bone

Subject: increased ovary tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplams in the ovary occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: hypochlorhydria
Value: reduced hydrochloric acid content of the gastric secretions

Subject: hyperchlorhydria
Value: increased hydrochloric acid content of the gastric secretions

Subject: achlorhydria
Value: absence of hydrochloric acid in the gastric secretions

Subject: abnormal stomach pH
Value: anomaly in the function of the secretory and buffer systems of the stomach that control the relative acidity or alkalinity, as measured by the concentration of the hydrogen ion

Subject: decreased stomach pH
Value: change in the function of the secretory and buffer systems of the stomach that control the relative acidity or alkalinity, such that the acidity is increased, as indicated by the increased concentration of hydrogen ion

Subject: increased stomach pH
Value: change in the function of the secretory and buffer systems of the stomach that control the relative acidity or alkalinity, such that the acidity is decreased, as indicated by the decreased concentration of hydrogen ion

Subject: abnormal cellular replicative senescence
Value: anomaly in the process in which a cell progresses from its inception to the end of its lifespan, which occurs as the cell continues cycles of growth and division

Subject: early cellular replicative senescence
Value: increase in the progression of the process in which a cell progresses from its inception to the end of its lifespan, which occurs as the cell continues cycles of growth and division

Subject: delayed cellular replicative senescence
Value: slower progression of the process in which a cell progresses from its inception to the end of its lifespan, which occurs as the cell continues cycles of growth and division

Subject: increased gastric adenocarcinoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of a malignant neoplasm of epithelial cells in the stomach

Subject: intestine polyps
Value: abnormal tissue masses that protrude into the lumen of the intestine and are tethered to the wall of the intestine

Subject: duodenum polyps
Value: development of numerous growths that are connected to and protrude from the mucous membrane of the duodenum

Subject: cecum polyps
Value: development of numerous growths that are connected to and protrude from the mucous membrane of the cecum

Subject: increased lung tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplasms in the lung, usually in the form of a distinct mass, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: abnormal female inguinal canal morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the passage in the lower abdominal wall through which the round ligament, nerves and vessels pass from the pelvic cavity to labia majora

Subject: abnormal male inguinal canal morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the passage in the lower abdominal wall through which the spermatic cord, nerves and vessels pass from the pelvic cavity to the scrotum

Subject: inguinal cysts
Value: benign epithelial growths on the walls of the passage in the lower abdominal wall through which the spermatic cord in the male or the round ligament in the female, nerves and vessels pass from the pelvic cavity to the scrotum or labia majora, respectively

Subject: increased facial tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplasms on the face, usually in the form of a distinct mass, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased liver tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplasms in the liver, usually in the form of a distinct mass, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: abnormal dermal mast cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of cells located in connective tissue of the dermis that contain numerous basophilic granules and release substances such as heparin and histamine in response to injury or inflammation

Subject: increased blastoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of a fast growing and invasive tumor composed chiefly or entirely of immature undifferentiated cells that have embryonic characteristics resembling the primordium of the organ in which the tumor arose

Subject: dilated heart ventricle
Value: the luminal space of the lower chambers of the heart is increased in volume or area, usually with an increase in contained fluid

Subject: abnormal styloid process morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the slender needle-like pointed projection that runs downward and slightly forward from the base of the inferior surface of the petrous portion of the temporal bone where it joins the tympanic portion; it gives attachment to the styloglossus, stylohyoid, and stylopharyngeus muscles and the stylohyoid and stylomandibular ligaments

Subject: absent lymph nodes
Value: absence of the oval or bean shaped bodies located along the lymphatic system that consist of densely packed lymphocytes, lymph fluid and connective tissue; these are the sites where acquired immune responses are launched

Subject: brain vacuoles
Value: the abnormal presence of cavities or fluid-filled vesicles in the soma of brain cells, often indicative of spongiosis or other pathological states

Subject: abnormal brain white matter morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the regions of the brain that are largely or entirely composed of myelinated nerve cell axons and contain few or no neural cell bodies or dendrites

Subject: abnormal spinal cord white matter morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the regions of the spinal cord that are largely or entirely composed of myelinated nerve cell axons and contain few or no neural cell bodies or dendrites

Subject: pregnancy-related premature death
Value: death occurring before the normal life span of an organism, occurring during pregnancy, parturition or lactation

Subject: abnormal paraxial mesoderm morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the mesoderm located bilaterally adjacent to the notochord and neural tube; on segmentation, paraxial mesoderm forms the paired somites

Subject: abnormal Cajal-Retzius cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the distinct population of large, bipolar cells, distributed in a continuous band along the marginal zone of the cortex extending to the molecular layer of the dentate gyrus

Subject: decreased Cajal-Retzius cell number
Value: reduced number of the distinct population of large, bipolar cells, distributed in a continuous band along the marginal zone of the cortex extending to the molecular layer of the dentate gyrus

Subject: abnormal lipolysis
Value: anomaly in the process of the hydrolysis of fat into free fatty acids

Subject: impaired lipolysis
Value: reduction in the rate of the hydrolysis of fat into free fatty acids

Subject: enhanced lipolysis
Value: increase in the rate of the hydrolysis of fat into free fatty acids

Subject: behavioral arrest
Value: locomotor activity is interrupted by sudden periods of no movement

Subject: abnormal NK T cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the distinct lineage of T cells expressing natural killer cell markers and having T cell receptors characterized by the usage of a restricted repertoire of variable region gene segments

Subject: abnormal T cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of lymphocytes that are responsible for cell-mediated immunity and immune system regulation

Subject: abnormal NK T cell number
Value: deviation from the normal number of the distinct lineage of T cells expressing natural killer cell markers and having T cell receptors characterized by the usage of a restricted repertoire of variable region gene segments

Subject: increased NK T cell number
Value: greater number of the distinct lineage of T cells expressing natural killer cell markers and having T cell receptors characterized by the usage of a restricted repertoire of variable region gene segments

Subject: decreased NK T cell number
Value: reduced number of the distinct lineage of T cells expressing natural killer cell markers and having T cell receptors characterized by the usage of a restricted repertoire of variable region gene segments

Subject: absent NK T cells
Value: absence of the distinct lineage of T cells expressing natural killer cell markers and having T cell receptors characterized by the usage of a restricted repertoire of variable region gene segments

Subject: abnormal NK T cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the distinct lineage of T cells expressing natural killer cell markers and having T cell receptors characterized by the usage of a restricted repertoire of variable region gene segments

Subject: abnormal NK cell number
Value: deviation in the number of lymphocytes that can spontaneously kill a variety of target cells without prior antigenic activation via germline encoded activation receptors, and also regulate immune responses via cytokine release and direct contact with other cells

Subject: increased NK cell number
Value: greater number of lymphocytes that can spontaneously kill a variety of target cells without prior antigenic activation via germline encoded activation receptors, and also regulate immune responses via cytokine release and direct contact with other cells

Subject: decreased NK cell number
Value: reduction in the number of lymphocytes that can spontaneously kill a variety of target cells without prior antigenic activation via germline encoded activation receptors, and also regulate immune responses via cytokine release and direct contact with other cells

Subject: absent NK cells
Value: absence of lymphocytes that can spontaneously kill a variety of target cells without prior antigenic activation via germline encoded activation receptors, and also regulate immune responses via cytokine release and direct contact with other cells

Subject: absent uterine NK cells
Value: absence of a natural killer cell subset that is found in the decidua of the uterus, is CD56-high, Galectin-1-positive and CD16-negative, and is the most abundant immune cell type in the decidual during the first trimester of pregnancy

Subject: abnormal memory T cell number
Value: deviation from the normal number of distinctly differentiated long-lived T cells that have the phenotype CD45RO-positive and CD127-positive

Subject: increased memory T cell number
Value: increase in the number of distinctly differentiated long-lived T cells that have the phenotype CD45RO-positive and CD127-positive

Subject: decreased memory T cell number
Value: reduction in the number of distinctly differentiated long-lived T cells that have the phenotype CD45RO-positive and CD127-positive

Subject: abnormal memory T cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the set of long-lived T cells differentiated from T cells activated by a specific antigen encountered during a past immune response

Subject: abnormal serous gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of glands that secrete watery albuminous material that often contains enzymes

Subject: abnormal NK cell differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce mature lymphocytes that can spontaneously kill a variety of target cells without prior antigenic activation via germline encoded activation receptors, and also regulate immune responses via cytokine release and direct contact with other cells

Subject: abnormal uterine NK cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a natural killer cell subset that is found in the decidual of the uterus, is CD56-high, Galectin-1-positive and CD16-negative, and is the most abundant immune cell type in the decidual during the first trimester of pregnancy

Subject: increased urine osmolality
Value: increase in the amount of ions in the urine compared to the normal state

Subject: abnormal retinal ganglion cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of ganglion neurons located in the innermost nuclear layer of the retina of that receive visual information from photoreceptors via various intermediate cells such as bipolar cells, amacrine cells, and horizontal cells; axons from these cells form the optic nerve and connect mainly to the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) and to the suprachiasmatic nucleus in the brain

Subject: abnormal DNA replication
Value: any anomaly in the process whereby new strands of DNA are synthesized

Subject: abnormal DNA repair
Value: any anomaly in the process of restoring DNA after damage or replication error

Subject: abnormal podocyte foot process morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the footlike extension of podocytes that interdigitate with one another to form the walls of the glomerular capillaries

Subject: abnormal podocyte slit diaphragm morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thin membrane that covers the podocyte filtration slit which allows small molecules such as water, glucose, and ionic salts to pass through while retaining larger macromolecules in the bloodstream

Subject: absent podocyte slit diaphragm
Value: absence of the thin membrane that covers the podocyte filtration slit which allows small molecules such as water, glucose, and ionic salts to pass through while retaining larger macromolecules in the bloodstream

Subject: abnormal podocyte slit junction morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the gaps between the interdigitated foot processes of the podocyte

Subject: increased otic epithelial cell apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of otic epithelial cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: decreased otic epithelial cell proliferation
Value: reduction in the expansion rate of the otic epithelial cell population by cell division

Subject: short endolymphatic duct
Value: length reduction or truncation of the small membranous canal which connects with both saccule and utricle of the membranous labyrinth, passes through the aqueduct of vestibule, and terminates in the endolymphatic sac

Subject: small endolymphatic duct
Value: reduced size of the small membranous canal which connects with both saccule and utricle of the membranous labyrinth, passes through the aqueduct of vestibule, and terminates in the endolymphatic sac

Subject: retinal ganglion cell degeneration
Value: degeneration or loss of ganglion neurons located in the innermost nuclear layer of the retina of that receive visual information from photoreceptors via various intermediate cells such as bipolar cells, amacrine cells, and horizontal cells; axons from these cells form the optic nerve and connect mainly to the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) and to the suprachiasmatic nucleus in the brain

Subject: absent retinal ganglion cell
Value: absence of ganglion neurons located in the innermost nuclear layer of the retina of that receive visual information from photoreceptors via various intermediate cells such as bipolar cells, amacrine cells, and horizontal cells; axons from these cells form the optic nerve and connect mainly to the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) and to the suprachiasmatic nucleus in the brain

Subject: abnormal joint mobility
Value: anomaly in the ability to move joints in a full range of motion and with ease

Subject: absent T cells
Value: absence of the lymphocytes that are responsible for cell-mediated immunity and immune system regulation

Subject: absent B cells
Value: absence of lymphocytes that expresses membrane-bound antibody, and differentiate into antibody-secreting plasma cells and memory cells upon interaction with antigen; B cells are the primary lymphocyte responsible for humoral immunity, and are most effective against extracellular pathogens

Subject: absent double-negative T cells
Value: absence of the subset of T cells found in the thymus that express neither CD4 nor CD8

Subject: abnormal CD4-positive, alpha beta T cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of the subset of T lymphocytes that carry the CD4 marker, recognize intravesicular peptides bound to MHC class-II molecules, and turn on antibody production

Subject: increased CD4-positive, alpha beta T cell number
Value: greater number of the subset of T lymphocytes that carry the CD4 marker, recognize intravesicular peptides bound to MHC class-II molecules, and turn on antibody production

Subject: decreased CD4-positive, alpha beta T cell number
Value: reduced number of the subset of T lymphocytes that carry the CD4 marker, recognize intravesicular peptides bound to MHC class-II molecules, and turn on antibody production

Subject: abnormal CD4-positive T cell differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce the subset of T lymphocytes that carry the CD4 marker, recognize intravesicular peptides bound to MHC class-II molecules, and turn on antibody production

Subject: abnormal CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of the regulatory subset of T lymphocytes that are involved in MHC class I restricted interactions

Subject: increased CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cell number
Value: greater number of the regulatory subset of T lymphocytes that are involved in MHC class I restricted interactions

Subject: decreased CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cell number
Value: reduction in the number of the regulatory subset of T lymphocytes that are involved in MHC class I restricted interactions

Subject: abnormal CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cell differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce the regulatory subset of T lymphocytes that are involved in MHC class I restricted interactions

Subject: abnormal single-positive T cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of T cells bearing either CD4-positive or CD8-positive markers on their surface

Subject: increased single-positive T cell number
Value: greater number of T cells bearing either CD4 or CD8 markers on their surface

Subject: decreased single-positive T cell number
Value: reduced number of T cells bearing either CD4 or CD8 markers on their surface

Subject: obsolete absent single-positive T cells
Value: absence of T cells bearing either CD4 or CD8 markers on their surface

Subject: abnormal T-helper 1 cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of the subset of the type of T-helper cell whose cytokine production favors cellular immune responses and delayed type hypersensitivity

Subject: increased T-helper 1 cell number
Value: greater number of the subset of the type of T-helper cell whose cytokine production favors cellular immune responses and delayed type hypersensitivity

Subject: decreased T helper 1 cell number
Value: reduced number of the subset of the type of T-helper cell whose cytokine production favors cellular immune responses and delayed type hypersensitivity

Subject: abnormal T-helper 1 cell differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce the subset of the type of T-helper cell whose cytokine production favors cellular immune responses and delayed type hypersensitivity

Subject: abnormal T-helper 2 cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of the type of T-helper cell whose cytokine production promotes defense against extracellular parasites and humoral immune responses typical of allergy

Subject: increased T-helper 2 cell number
Value: greater number of the subset of the type of T-helper cell whose cytokine production promotes defense against extracellular parasites and humoral immune responses typical of allergy

Subject: decreased T-helper 2 cell number
Value: reduction in the number of the type of T-helper cell whose cytokine production promotes defense against extracellular parasites and humoral immune responses typical of allergy

Subject: abnormal T-helper 2 cell differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce the type of T-helper cell whose cytokine production promotes defense against extracellular parasites and humoral immune responses typical of allergy

Subject: abnormal memory B cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of distinctly differentiated long-lived B cells that are readily activated upon reencounter of an antigenic determinant; memory B cells differentiate from antigen-activated B cells which have been selected for expression of higher affinity immunoglobulin

Subject: absent memory B cells
Value: absence of distinctly differentiated long-lived B cells that are readily activated upon reencounter of an antigenic determinant; memory B cells differentiate from antigen-activated B cells which have been selected for expression of higher affinity immunoglobulin

Subject: abnormal memory B cell differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce distinctly differentiated long-lived B cells that are readily activated upon reencounter of an antigenic determinant; memory B cells differentiate from antigen-activated B cells which have been selected for expression of higher affinity immunoglobulin

Subject: abnormal plasma cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of terminally differentiated, post-mitotic, short-lived cells of the B cell lineage devoted to producing large amounts of immunoglobulin

Subject: increased plasma cell number
Value: greater number of terminally differentiated, post-mitotic, short-lived cells of the B cell lineage devoted to producing large amounts of immunoglobulin

Subject: decreased plasma cell number
Value: reduced number of terminally differentiated, post-mitotic, short-lived cells of the B cell lineage devoted to producing large amounts of immunoglobulin

Subject: abnormal plasma cell differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce terminally differentiated, post-mitotic, short-lived cells of the B cell lineage devoted to producing large amounts of immunoglobulin

Subject: absent plasma cells
Value: absence of the terminally differentiated, post-mitotic, short-lived cells of the B cell lineage devoted to producing large amounts of immunoglobulin

Subject: lymph node hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced cell number, in the lymph nodes

Subject: lymph node hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due to increased cell number, in the lymph nodes

Subject: amacrine cell degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment or destruction of one of the three types of interneurons found in the inner nuclear layer of the mature retina; they integrate, modulate, and interpose a temporal domain in the visual message presented to the retinal ganglion cells, with which they synapse in the inner plexiform layer

Subject: abnormal amacrine cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of one of the three types of interneurons found in the inner nuclear layer of the mature retina; they integrate, modulate, and interpose a temporal domain in the visual message presented to the retinal ganglion cells, with which they synapse in the inner plexiform layer

Subject: increased amacrine cell number
Value: increase in the number of one of the three types of interneurons found in the inner nuclear layer of the mature retina

Subject: decreased amacrine cell number
Value: reduction in the number of one of the three types of interneurons found in the inner nuclear layer of the mature retina

Subject: absent retinal horizontal cells
Value: absence of the laterally interconnecting neurons in the outer plexiform layer of the retina that connect rods of one part of the retina with cones in another part of the retina

Subject: abnormal small intestinal villus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tiny hair-like projections that protrude from the inside of the small intestine that contain blood vessels that capture digested nutrients that are absorbed through the intestinal wall; the villi increase the absorptive surface area of the small intestine by approximately 30-fold

Subject: abnormal small intestinal microvillus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the additional extensions of the villi of the small intestine which protrude from the apical surface of the epithelial cells lining the villi; the microvilli increase the absorptive surface area of the small intestine by approximately 600-fold

Subject: abnormal granulocyte differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce leukocytes that have abundant granules in the cytoplasm, including basophils, neutrophils, and eosinophils

Subject: abnormal monocyte differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce the large, phagocytic mononuclear leukocytes produced in the vertebrate bone marrow and released into the blood

Subject: abnormal macrophage differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce the large mononuclear phagocytes which differentiate from monocytes, are typically resident in a particular tissue, and capable of phagocytosing a variety of extracellular particulate material, including immune complexes, microorganisms, and dead cells

Subject: abnormal Kupffer cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the phagocytic macrophages residing on the luminal surface of the hepatic sinusoids

Subject: abnormal dendritic cell differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce a cell of hematopoietic origin, typically resident in particular tissues, specialized in the uptake, processing, and transport of antigens to lymph nodes for the purpose of stimulating an immune response via T cell activation

Subject: abnormal Langerhans cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a stellate dendritic cell of myeloid origin, that appears clear on light microscopy and has a dark-staining, indented nucleus and characteristic inclusions (Birbeck granules) in the cytoplasm; Langerhans cells are found principally in the stratum spinosum of the epidermis, but they also occur in other stratified epithelia and have been identified in the lung, lymph nodes, spleen, and thymus

Subject: absent Langerhans cell
Value: absence of stellate dendritic cells of myeloid origin, that appear clear on light microscopy and has a dark-staining, indented nucleus and characteristic inclusions (Birbeck granules) in the cytoplasm; Langerhans cells are found principally in the stratum spinosum of the epidermis, but they also occur in other stratified epithelia and have been identified in the lung, lymph nodes, spleen, and thymus

Subject: decreased Langerhans cell number
Value: reduction in the number of stellate dendritic cells of myeloid origin, that appear clear on light microscopy and has a dark-staining, indented nucleus and characteristic inclusions (Birbeck granules) in the cytoplasm; Langerhans cells are found principally in the stratum spinosum of the epidermis, but they also occur in other stratified epithelia and have been identified in the lung, lymph nodes, spleen, and thymus

Subject: abnormal myeloid dendritic cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of phagocytic cells of the myeloid lineage that capture antigens in the periphery and then migrate to the lymphoid organs and secrete cytokines to initiate immune responses

Subject: increased myeloid dendritic cell number
Value: greater number of phagocytic cells of the myeloid lineage that capture antigens in the periphery and then migrate to the lymphoid organs and secrete cytokines to initiate immune responses

Subject: decreased myeloid dendritic cell number
Value: reduction in the number of phagocytic cells of the myeloid lineage that capture antigens in the periphery and then migrate to the lymphoid organs and secrete cytokines to initiate immune responses

Subject: abnormal plasmacytoid dendritic cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of phagocytic dendritic cells that are morphologically similar to plasma cells, but do not express B lineage markers, and produce large amounts of alpha/beta interferons (IFN-/) in response to viral and bacterial stimuli

Subject: decreased plasmacytoid dendritic cell number
Value: reduced number of phagocytic dendritic cells that are morphologically similar to plasma cells, but do not express B lineage markers, and produce large amounts of alpha/beta interferons (IFN-/) in response to viral and bacterial stimuli

Subject: abnormal dendritic cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of a cells of hematopoietic origin, typically resident in particular tissues, specialized in the uptake, processing, and transport of antigens to lymph nodes for the purpose of stimulating an immune response via T cell activation

Subject: increased dendritic cell number
Value: greater number of a cells of hematopoietic origin, typically resident in particular tissues, specialized in the uptake, processing, and transport of antigens to lymph nodes for the purpose of stimulating an immune response via T cell activation

Subject: decreased dendritic cell number
Value: reduction in the number of a cells of hematopoietic origin, typically resident in particular tissues, specialized in the uptake, processing, and transport of antigens to lymph nodes for the purpose of stimulating an immune response via T cell activation

Subject: abnormal brain internal capsule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the area of white matter in the brain that lies between the lenticular and caudate nuclei, and contains a group of myelinated ascending and descending axonal fiber tracts that connects the cerebral cortex to the brain stem and spinal cord

Subject: absent brain internal capsule
Value: absence of the area of white matter in the brain that lies between the lenticular and caudate nuclei, and contains a group of myelinated ascending and descending axonal fiber tracts that connects the cerebral cortex to the brain stem and spinal cord

Subject: abnormal pituitary intermediate lobe morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thin boundary between the adenohypophysis and neurohypophysis of the pituitary that produces melanocyte stimulating hormone (MSH); this area is small or absent in mammalian adults

Subject: abnormal Peyer's patch number
Value: anomaly in the number of the protruding lymphoid tissue located on the mucosa of the small intestine that is composed of densely packed B cell follicles

Subject: increased Peyer's patch number
Value: greater number of the protruding lymphoid tissue located on the mucosa of the small intestine that is composed of densely packed B cell follicles

Subject: decreased Peyer's patch number
Value: reduction in the number of the protruding lymphoid tissue located on the mucosa of the small intestine that is composed of densely packed B cell follicles

Subject: abnormal Peyer's patch size
Value: anomaly in the size of the protruding lymphoid tissue located on the mucosa of the small intestine that is composed of densely packed B cell follicles

Subject: small Peyer's patches
Value: reduced size of the protruding lymphoid tissue located on the mucosa of the small intestine that is composed of densely packed B cell follicles

Subject: enlarged Peyer's patches
Value: increased size of the protruding lymphoid tissue located on the mucosa of the small intestine that is composed of densely packed B cell follicles

Subject: absent podocytes
Value: absence of a modified epithelial cell of the visceral layer of the Bowman capsule in the renal corpuscle; it has a small perikaryon and a number of primary and secondary foot processes that interdigitate with those of other podocytes and are attached to the outer surface of the glomerular capillary basement membrane

Subject: absent podocyte foot process
Value: absence of the footlike extension of podocytes that interdigitate with one another to form the walls of the glomerular capillaries

Subject: fused podocyte foot processes
Value: coalescence of the footlike extension of podocytes that interdigitate with one another to form the walls of the glomerular capillaries

Subject: podocyte foot process effacement
Value: a podocyte reaction to injury or damage characterized by flattening of foot processes due to gradual simplification of the interdigitating foot process; the whole podocyte looks flat due to retraction, widening, and shortening of the processes of each podocyte while the frequency of filtration slits is reduced, giving the appearance of a continuous cytoplasmic sheet covering the glomerular basement membrane

Subject: decreased small intestinal microvillus size
Value: reduced size of the additional extensions of the villi of the small intestine which protrude from the apical surface of the epithelial cells lining the villi; the microvilli increase the absorptive surface area of the small intestine by approximately 600-fold

Subject: decreased small intestinal villus size
Value: reduced size of the tiny hair-like projections that protrude from the inside of the small intestine that contain blood vessels that capture digested nutrients that are absorbed through the intestinal wall; the villi increase the absorptive surface area of the small intestine by approximately 30-fold

Subject: abnormal dendrite morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the highly branched tree-like process of a neuron that serves as a receptive field and conducts impulses toward the cell body

Subject: nyctalopia
Value: decreased ability to see clearly in reduced illumination; often due to a deficiency of vitamin A or to a retinal disorder

Subject: hemeralopia
Value: reduced ability to see clearly in bright light with night vision remaining unchanged; often due to impaired retinal cone function

Subject: asymmetric sternocostal joints
Value: loss of bilateral symmetry in rib attachments to the sternum

Subject: asymmetric costovertebral joints
Value: loss of bilateral symmetry in rib attachments to the vertebral column

Subject: abnormal sternocostal joint morphology
Value: any anomaly in the normal joining of the ribs to the sternum

Subject: abnormal costovertebral joint morphology
Value: any anomaly in the normal joining of the ribs to the vertebral column, these connections are made by costovertebral ligaments between the head of the rib and the body of the thoracic vertebra

Subject: decreased diameter of long bones
Value: reduced width of the cross-sectional distance that extends from one lateral edge of a long bone, through its center and to the opposite lateral edge

Subject: increased diameter of long bones
Value: increased width of the cross-sectional distance that extends from one lateral edge of a long bone, through its center and to the opposite lateral edge

Subject: decreased diameter of femur
Value: reduced width of the cross-sectional distance that extends from one lateral edge of the femur, through its center and to the opposite lateral edge

Subject: decreased diameter of fibula
Value: reduced width of the cross-sectional distance that extends from one lateral edge of the fibula, through its center and to the opposite lateral edge

Subject: decreased diameter of humerus
Value: reduced width of the cross-sectional distance that extends from one lateral edge of the humerus, through its center and to the opposite lateral edge

Subject: decreased diameter of radius
Value: reduced width of the cross-sectional distance that extends from one lateral edge of the radius, through its center and to the opposite lateral edge

Subject: decreased diameter of tibia
Value: reduced width of the cross-sectional distance that extends from one lateral edge of the tibia, through its center and to the opposite lateral edge

Subject: decreased diameter of ulna
Value: reduced width of the cross-sectional distance that extends from one lateral edge of the ulna, through its center and to the opposite lateral edge

Subject: increased diameter of femur
Value: increased width of the cross-sectional distance that extends from one lateral edge of the femur, through its center and to the opposite lateral edge

Subject: increased diameter of fibula
Value: increased width of the cross-sectional distance that extends from one lateral edge of the fibula, through its center and to the opposite lateral edge

Subject: increased diameter of humerus
Value: increased width of the cross-sectional distance that extends from one lateral edge of the humerus, through its center and to the opposite lateral edge

Subject: increased diameter of radius
Value: increased width of the cross-sectional distance that extends from one lateral edge of the radius, through its center and to the opposite lateral edge

Subject: increased diameter of tibia
Value: increased width of the cross-sectional distance that extends from one lateral edge of the tibia, through its center and to the opposite lateral edge

Subject: increased diameter of ulna
Value: increased width of the cross-sectional distance that extends from one lateral edge of the ulna, through its center and to the opposite lateral edge

Subject: abnormal B-1a B cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the B-1 B cell subset bearing the CD5 surface marker

Subject: abnormal B-1b B cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the B-1 B cell subset not bearing the CD5 surface marker, but having other phenotypic attributes of a B-1 B cell

Subject: abnormal B-2 B cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a conventional B cell subject to antigenic stimulation and dependent on T cell help and with a distinct surface marker expression pattern from B-1 B cells

Subject: increased B-1a cell number
Value: greater number of the B-1 B cell subset bearing the CD5 surface marker

Subject: decreased B-1a cell number
Value: reduced number of the B-1 B cell subset bearing the CD5 surface marker

Subject: increased B-1b cell number
Value: greater number of the B-1 B cell subset not bearing the CD5 surface marker, but having other phenotypic attributes of a B-1 B cell

Subject: decreased B-1b cell number
Value: reduced number of the B-1 B cell subset not bearing the CD5 surface marker, but having other phenotypic attributes of a B-1 B cell

Subject: abnormal mature B cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the mature form of a B cell, a type of lymphocyte whose defining characteristic is the expression of an immunoglobulin complex

Subject: abnormal follicular B cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a resting mature B cell with distinct phenotypic characteristics (CD23-positive, CD21-positive) found typically in the B cell follicle region of the spleen and lymph nodes

Subject: increased follicular B cell number
Value: greater number of resting mature B cells with distinct phenotypic characteristics (CD23-positive, CD21-positive) found typically in the B cell follicle region of the spleen and lymph nodes

Subject: decreased follicular B cell number
Value: reduced number of resting mature B cells with distinct phenotypic characteristics (CD23-positive, CD21-positive) found typically in the B cell follicle region of the spleen and lymph nodes

Subject: absent follicular B cells
Value: absence of resting mature B cells with distinct phenotypic characteristics (CD23-positive, CD21-positive) found typically in the B cell follicle region of the spleen and lymph nodes

Subject: abnormal germinal center B cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a rapidly cycling mature B cell which have downregulated IgD expression and exhibit high levels of binding by peanut agglutinin (PNA), and are involved in T-dependent immune responses; germinal center B cells are found typically in the germinal centers of lymph nodes and spleen

Subject: increased germinal center B cell number
Value: greater number of rapidly cycling mature B cells which have downregulated IgD expression and exhibit high levels of binding by peanut agglutinin (PNA), and are involved in T-dependent immune responses; germinal center B cells are found typically in the germinal centers of lymph nodes and spleen

Subject: decreased germinal center B cell number
Value: reduced number of rapidly cycling mature B cells which have downregulated IgD expression and exhibit high levels of binding by peanut agglutinin (PNA), and are involved in T-dependent immune responses; germinal center B cells are found typically in the germinal centers of lymph nodes and spleen

Subject: absent germinal center B cells
Value: absence of rapidly cycling mature B cells which have downregulated IgD expression and exhibit high levels of binding by peanut agglutinin (PNA), and are involved in T-dependent immune responses; germinal center B cells are found typically in the germinal centers of lymph nodes and spleen

Subject: abnormal marginal zone B cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a CD23-negative, CD21-positive B cell of the marginal zone of the spleen expressing a B cell receptor usually reactive to bacterial cell wall components or senescent self components such as oxidized-LDL

Subject: increased marginal zone B cell number
Value: greater number of CD23-negative, CD21-positive B cells of the marginal zone of the spleen expressing a B cell receptor usually reactive to bacterial cell wall components or senescent self components such as oxidized-LDL

Subject: decreased marginal zone B cell number
Value: reduced number of CD23-negative, CD21-positive B cells of the marginal zone of the spleen expressing a B cell receptor usually reactive to bacterial cell wall components or senescent self components such as oxidized-LDL

Subject: absent marginal zone B cells
Value: absence of CD23-negative, CD21-positive B cells of the marginal zone of the spleen expressing a B cell receptor usually reactive to bacterial cell wall components or senescent self components such as oxidized-LDL

Subject: abnormal naive B cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a mature B cell which has not yet been activated by antigen

Subject: decreased naive B cell number
Value: reduced number of mature B cells which have not yet been activated by antigen

Subject: increased pro-B cell number
Value: greater number of the progenitor cells of the B cell lineage, with some lineage specific activity such as early stages of recombination of B cell receptor genes, but are not yet fully committed to the B cell lineage until the expression of PAX5 occurs

Subject: absent pro-B cells
Value: absence of the progenitor cells of the B cell lineage, with some lineage specific activity such as early stages of recombination of B cell receptor genes, but are not yet fully committed to the B cell lineage until the expression of PAX5 occurs

Subject: abnormal transitional stage B cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of an immature B cell of an intermediate stage between the pre-B cell stage and the mature naive stage; transitional B cells express surface immunoglobulin, and are subject to the process of B cell selection

Subject: increased transitional stage B cell number
Value: greater number of immature B cells of an intermediate stage between the pre-B cell stage and the mature naive stage; transitional B cells express surface immunoglobulin, and are subject to the process of B cell selection

Subject: decreased transitional stage B cell number
Value: reduced number of immature B cells of an intermediate stage between the pre-B cell stage and the mature naive stage; transitional B cells express surface immunoglobulin, and are subject to the process of B cell selection

Subject: abnormal follicular B cell physiology
Value: abnormal function of a resting mature B cell with distinct phenotypic characteristics (CD23-positive, CD21-positive) found typically in the B cell follicle region of the spleen

Subject: abnormal germinal center B cell physiology
Value: abnormal function of a rapidly cycling mature B cell which have downregulated IgD expression and exhibit high levels of binding by peanut agglutinin (PNA), and are involved in T-dependent immune responses; germinal center B cells are found typically in the germinal centers of lymph nodes

Subject: abnormal marginal zone B cell physiology
Value: abnormal function of a CD23-negative, CD21-positive B cell of the marginal zone of the spleen expressing a B cell receptor usually reactive to bacterial cell wall components or senescent self components such as oxidized-LDL

Subject: abnormal memory B cell physiology
Value: abnormal function of a distinctly differentiated long-lived B cell that is readily activated upon reencounter of its antigenic determinant; memory B cells differentiate from antigen-activated B cells which have been selected for expression of higher affinity immunoglobulin

Subject: abnormal professional antigen presenting cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a cell capable of processing and presenting lipid and protein antigens to T cells in order to initiate an immune response

Subject: abnormal follicular dendritic cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a cell with extensive dendritic processes found in the B cell areas (primary follicles and germinal centers) of lymphoid tissue; follicular dendritic cells have Fc receptors and C3b receptors, and hold antigen in the form of immune complexes on their surfaces for long periods and can present antigen to B cells during an immune response

Subject: abnormal follicular dendritic cell physiology
Value: abnormal function of a cell with extensive dendritic processes found in the B cell areas (primary follicles and germinal centers) of lymphoid tissue; follicular dendritic cells have Fc receptors and C3b receptors, and hold antigen in the form of immune complexes on their surfaces for long periods and can present antigen to B cells during an immune response

Subject: abnormal follicular dendritic cell antigen presentation
Value: anomaly in the ability of follicular dendritic cells to process and present antigen to B lymphocytes

Subject: increased follicular dendritic cell number
Value: greater number of cells with extensive dendritic processes found in the B cell areas (primary follicles and germinal centers) of lymphoid tissue; follicular dendritic cells have Fc receptors and C3b receptors, and hold antigen in the form of immune complexes on their surfaces for long periods and can present antigen to B cells during an immune response

Subject: decreased follicular dendritic cell number
Value: reduced number of cells with extensive dendritic processes found in the B cell areas (primary follicles and germinal centers) of lymphoid tissue; follicular dendritic cells have Fc receptors and C3b receptors, and hold antigen in the form of immune complexes on their surfaces for long periods and can present antigen to B cells during an immune response

Subject: absent follicular dendritic cells
