Value: absence of cells with extensive dendritic processes found in the B cell areas (primary follicles and germinal centers) of lymphoid tissue; follicular dendritic cells have Fc receptors and C3b receptors, and hold antigen in the form of immune complexes on their surfaces for long periods and can present antigen to B cells during an immune response

Subject: absent B-1 B cells
Value: absence of the subset of B cells found predominantly in the peritoneum, pleural cavities, and spleen, and are enriched for self-reactivity; B-1 B cells are thought to be the primary source of natural IgM immunoglobulin, that is, IgM produced in large quantities without prior antigenic stimulation and generally reactive against various microorganisms, as well as the source of T-independent IgA immunoglobulin in the mucosal areas

Subject: absent B-1a cells
Value: absence of the B-1 B cell subset bearing the CD5 surface marker

Subject: absent B-1b cells
Value: absence of the B-1 B cell subset not bearing the CD5 surface marker, but having other phenotypic attributes of a B-1 B cell

Subject: absent B-2 B cells
Value: absence of conventional B cells subject to antigenic stimulation and dependent on T cell help and with a distinct surface marker expression pattern from B-1 B cells

Subject: increased B-2 B cell number
Value: greater number of conventional B cells subject to antigenic stimulation and dependent on T cell help and with a distinct surface marker expression pattern from B-1 B cells

Subject: decreased B-2 B cell number
Value: reduced number of conventional B cells subject to antigenic stimulation and dependent on T cell help and with a distinct surface marker expression pattern from B-1 B cells

Subject: decreased pro-B cell number
Value: reduced number of the progenitor cells of the B cell lineage, with some lineage specific activity such as early stages of recombination of B cell receptor genes, but are not yet fully committed to the B cell lineage until the expression of PAX5 occurs

Subject: decreased pre-B cell number
Value: <reduced number of the cells in the B lymphocyte lineage that have undergone VDJ rearrangement of the immunoglobulin heavy chain and are in the process of V-J rearrangement of the light chain: these cells express mu heavy chain on the cell surface>

Subject: increased mature B cell number
Value: greater number of the mature form of B cells, a type of lymphocyte whose defining characteristic is the expression of an immunoglobulin complex

Subject: decreased mature B cell number
Value: reduced number of the mature form of B cells, a type of lymphocyte whose defining characteristic is the expression of an immunoglobulin complex

Subject: absent mature B cells
Value: absence of the mature form of a B cell, a type of lymphocyte whose defining characteristic is the expression of an immunoglobulin complex

Subject: absent immature B cells
Value: absence of the cells of the B lymphocyte lineage that have undergone VDJ rearrangement of the heavy chain and V-J rearrangement of the light chain; these cells express IgM on the cell surface but have not yet been selected for self-reactivity

Subject: increased immature B cell number
Value: greater number of the cells of the B lymphocyte lineage that have undergone VDJ rearrangement of the heavy chain and V-J rearrangement of the light chain; these cells express IgM on the cell surface but have not yet been selected for self-reactivity

Subject: decreased immature B cell number
Value: reduced number of the cells of the B lymphocyte lineage that have undergone VDJ rearrangement of the heavy chain and V-J rearrangement of the light chain; these cells express IgM on the cell surface but have not yet been selected for self-reactivity

Subject: absent transitional stage B cells
Value: absence of immature B cells of an intermediate stage between the pre-B cell stage and the mature naive stage; transitional B cells express surface immunoglobulin, and are subject to the process of B cell selection

Subject: abnormal B cell activation
Value: any anomaly in the normal change in morphology and behavior of a mature or immature B cell during an immune response, resulting from exposure to a mitogen, cytokine, chemokine, cellular ligand, or an antigen for which it is specific

Subject: delayed emergence of vibrissae
Value: eruption of the vibrissae from the skin later than expected

Subject: abnormal dorsal telencephalic commissure morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the fiber tracts that connect the dorsal region of the two cerebral hemispheres and span the longitudinal fissure, including the corpus callosum and hippocampal commissure

Subject: abnormal ventral commissure morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the fiber tracts that connect the ventral region of the two cerebral hemispheres and span the longitudinal fissure, including the anterior and the habenular commissures

Subject: abnormal hippocampal commissure morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the triangular subcallosal plate of commissural fibers resulting from the converging of the right and left fornix bundles which exchange numerous fibers and which curve back in the contralateral fornix to end in the hippocampus of the opposite side

Subject: decreased hippocampal commissure size
Value: reduced size of the triangular subcallosal plate of commissural fibers resulting from the converging of the right and left fornix bundles which exchange numerous fibers and which curve back in the contralateral fornix to end in the hippocampus of the opposite side

Subject: absent hippocampal commissure
Value: absence of the triangular subcallosal plate of commissural fibers resulting from the converging of the right and left fornix bundles which exchange numerous fibers and which curve back in the contralateral fornix to end in the hippocampus of the opposite side

Subject: increased hippocampal commissure size
Value: enlarged triangular subcallosal plate of commissural fibers resulting from the converging of the right and left fornix bundles which exchange numerous fibers and which curve back in the contralateral fornix to end in the hippocampus of the opposite side

Subject: abnormal anterior commissure morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a round bundle of nerve fibers that crosses the midline of the brain near the anterior limit of the third ventricle

Subject: decreased anterior commissure size
Value: reduced size of a round bundle of nerve fibers that crosses the midline of the brain near the anterior limit of the third ventricle

Subject: absent anterior commissure
Value: absence of a round bundle of nerve fibers that crosses the midline of the brain near the anterior limit of the third ventricle

Subject: increased anterior commissure size
Value: enlarged round bundle of nerve fibers that crosses the midline of the brain near the anterior limit of the third ventricle

Subject: abnormal habenular commissure morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the connection between the right and left habenular nuclei; the decussation of fibers of the two striae medullares, forming the dorsal portion of the peduncle of the pineal body

Subject: abnormal cingulum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the white matter fiber bundle that projects from the cingulate gyrus to the entorhinal cortex in the brain

Subject: abnormal pro-B cell differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce the progenitor cells of the B cell lineage, with some lineage specific activity such as early stages of recombination of B cell receptor genes, but are not yet fully committed to the B cell lineage until the expression of PAX5 occurs

Subject: absent spleen marginal zone
Value: absence of the zone between the red and white pulp of the spleen containing numerous macrophages and lymphocytes, and a rich plexus of sinusoids supplied by white pulp arterioles carrying blood-borne antigens

Subject: increased susceptibility to neuronal excitotoxicity
Value: greater than normal amount of neuronal cell death following exposure to a neurotoxic compound, such as kainate-induced neuronal cell death mediated via a glutamate excitotoxic process

Subject: decreased susceptibility to neuronal excitotoxicity
Value: less than normal amount of neuronal cell death following exposure to a neurotoxic compound, such as kainate-induced neuronal cell death mediated via a glutamate excitotoxic process

Subject: abnormal ventral coat pigmentation
Value: irregular or unusual pigmentation of ventrum hair in relation to control animals

Subject: abnormal dorsoventral coat patterning
Value: irregular or unusual pigmentation pattern of the dorsal-to-ventral axis compared to control animals

Subject: abnormal spleen marginal zone macrophage morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cells present in the splenic marginal zone and are involved in the recognition and clearance of material, such as pathogen-derived material, from the splenic circulation

Subject: abnormal metallophilic macrophage morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the macrophage cells that surround the white pulp of the spleen, adjacent to the marginal sinus

Subject: abnormal perivascular macrophage morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of macrophages that line the small blood vessels

Subject: abnormal macrophage derived foam cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a type of macrophage containing lipids in small vacuoles and typically seen in atherolosclerotic lesions, as well as other conditions

Subject: abnormal peritoneal macrophage morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a mononuclear phagocyte that develops from bone marrow precursors but is resident in the peritoneum

Subject: abnormal alveolar macrophage morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the round, granular, mononuclear phagocytes found in the alveoli of the lungs which ingest small inhaled particles resulting in degradation and presentation of the antigen to immunocompetent cells

Subject: abnormal leukocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of nucleated cells of the myeloid or lymphoid lineages, found in blood or other tissue

Subject: abnormal mononuclear cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a leukocyte with a single non-segmented nucleus in the mature form

Subject: abnormal mononuclear phagocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a vertebrate phagocyte with a single nucleus

Subject: abnormal common lymphocyte progenitor cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a progenitor cell committed to the lymphoid lineage

Subject: abnormal myeloid leukocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a cell of the monocyte, granulocyte, or mast cell lineage

Subject: abnormal phagocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of cells capable of ingesting particulate matter via phagocytosis

Subject: abnormal multinucleated phagocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a phagocyte formed by the fusion of mononuclear phagocytes

Subject: absent megakaryocytes
Value: absence of the giant 50 to 100 micron diameter cells with greatly lobulated nuclei found in the bone marrow; mature blood platelets are released from their cytoplasm

Subject: increased megakaryocyte cell number
Value: greater number of the giant 50 to 100 micron diameter cells with greatly lobulated nuclei found in the bone marrow; mature blood platelets are released from their cytoplasm

Subject: decreased megakaryocyte cell number
Value: reduced number of the giant 50 to 100 micron diameter cells with greatly lobulated nuclei found in the bone marrow; mature blood platelets are released from their cytoplasm

Subject: abnormal myometrium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the smooth muscle coat of the uterus, which forms the main mass of the organ and surrounds and supports the endometrium

Subject: thin myometrium
Value: reduced thickness of the smooth muscle coat of the uterus, which forms the main mass of the organ and surrounds and supports the endometrium

Subject: thin endometrium
Value: reduced thickness of the glandular mucous membrane lining of the uterine cavity that is hormonally responsive during the estrous/menstrual cycle and during pregnancy

Subject: abnormal optic disk morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the area in the retina where all of the axons of the ganglion cells exit the retina to form the optic nerve

Subject: abnormal autophagy
Value: abnormal catabolic process involving the degradation of a cell's own components through the lysosomal machinery

Subject: arrest of male meiosis
Value: cessation of the progression of the process of nuclear division that results in sperm with one half the normal chromosome number of the original cell

Subject: abnormal hippocampus region morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a part or parts of the hippocampus that have a particular function

Subject: abnormal hippocampus CA1 region morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a cytoarchitectural subregion of the Ammon's horn region of the hippocampal formation consisting primarily of pyramidal neurons; the pyramidal neurons of CA1 receive projections from pyramidal neurons of CA3 via the Schaffer collaterals and send outputs to the entorhinal cortex and to the subiculum

Subject: abnormal hippocampus CA2 region morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the smallest cytoarchitectural subregion of the Ammon's horn region of the hippocampal formation, located between CA3 and CA1, comprised of pyramidal neurons receiving both Schaffer collateral and mossy fiber input

Subject: abnormal hippocampus CA4 region morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the region of the hippocampal formation that is comprised of mossy cells that primarily receive inputs from granule cells in the dentate gyrus in the form of mossy fibers and from pyramidal cells in CA3, and send outputs into the dentate gyrus

Subject: abnormal bone ossification
Value: any anomaly in the formation of bone or of a bony substance, or the conversion of fibrous tissue or of cartilage into bone or a bony substance

Subject: abnormal endochondral bone ossification
Value: anomaly in the process of the formation of bone by the replacement of cartilage tissue with mineralized bone

Subject: abnormal intramembranous bone ossification
Value: anomaly in the process of the formation of bone in which osteoblasts secrete a collage-proteoglycan matrix that binds calcium salts and becomes calcified; intramembranous ossification is the way flat bones are formed

Subject: failure of bone ossification
Value: failure to initiate or a block in the process of the formation of bone or of a bony substance, or the conversion of fibrous tissue or of cartilage into bone or a bony substance

Subject: failure of endochondral bone ossification
Value: failure to initiate or a block in the process of the formation of bone by the replacement of cartilage tissue with mineralized bone

Subject: failure of intramembranous bone ossification
Value: failure to initiate or a block in the process of the formation of bone in which osteoblasts secrete a collage-proteoglycan matrix that binds calcium salts and becomes calcified; intramembranous ossification is the way flat bones are formed

Subject: abnormal sternum ossification
Value: anomaly in the process of the formation of the sternum bone by the replacement of cartilage tissue with mineralized bone

Subject: failure of sternum ossification
Value: failure to initiate or a block in the process of the formation of the sternum bone by the replacement of cartilage tissue with mineralized bone

Subject: arrest of spermiogenesis
Value: block in the process by which a spermatid transforms into a functional spermatozoon

Subject: abnormal male germ cell apoptosis
Value: presence of male germs cells that undergo programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal hippocampus size
Value: anomaly in the size of the deep lying structure of the cerebrum involved with memory storage and spatial navigation

Subject: enlarged hippocampus
Value: increased size of the deep lying structure of the cerebrum involved with memory storage and spatial navigation

Subject: small hippocampus
Value: reduced size of the deep lying structure of the cerebrum involved with memory storage and spatial navigation

Subject: abnormal hippocampus pyramidal cell layer
Value: any structural anomaly of the cytoarchitectural term denoting the layer of the hippocampus in which pyramidal cells are predominant. Its location is superficial to the Stratum oriens; it is deep to the Stratum radiatum in area CA1 and area CA2 and deep to the Stratum lucidum in area CA3

Subject: abnormal hippocampus molecular cell layer
Value: any structural anomaly of the cytoarchitectural region of the hippocampus consisting of a composite of the two outermost layers of the hippocampus, the Stratum lacunosum-moleculare and the Stratum radiatum

Subject: abnormal subiculum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the transitional zone between the parahippocampal gyrus and the Ammon gyrus

Subject: abnormal adrenal cortex morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thick outer layer of the adrenal gland that produces and secretes steroid hormones such as corticosterone, estrone and aldosterone

Subject: abnormal adrenal medulla morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the inner portion of the adrenal gland that consists mainly of chromaffin cells which produce, store and secrete neurotransmitters such as epinephrine and norepinephrine

Subject: absent adrenal cortex
Value: absence of the thick outer layer of the adrenal gland that produces and secretes steroid hormones such as corticosterone, estrone and aldosterone

Subject: abnormal adrenocortical cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the steroid hormone-producing cells of the cortex of the adrenal gland

Subject: enlarged adrenocortical cell nuclei
Value: nuclei of the cells of the cortex of the adrenal gland are larger than normal

Subject: abnormal adrenal gland zona glomerulosa morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the narrow subcapsular outer zone of the adrenal cortex where aldosterone is produced

Subject: abnormal adrenal gland zona fasciculata morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the wide middle zone of the adrenal cortex that produces cortisol (hydrocortisone)

Subject: abnormal adrenal gland zona reticularis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the inner zone of the adrenal cortex that produces the enzymes that convert pregnenolone, a 21-carbon steroid, to 19-carbon steroids

Subject: abnormal adrenal gland x-zone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the transient cortical layer juxtaposed to the medulla and the zona reticularis; in males, this zone rapidly involutes at the onset of puberty whereas this zone persists in females until the first pregnancy or later in adulthood in non-pregnant females

Subject: retention of the adrenal gland x-zone
Value: failure of the transient cortical layer juxtaposed to the medulla and the zona reticularis to degenerate after puberty in males or after pregnancy in females

Subject: adrenergic chromaffin cell hyperplasia
Value: an increase in the number of the cells of the medulla of the adrenal gland that are innervated by the splanchnic nerve and that are responsible for epinephrine secretion

Subject: adrenal cortical hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment of the thick outer layer of the adrenal gland that produces and secretes steroid hormones, usually due to an increase in the number of cells

Subject: enlarged adrenal medulla
Value: increased size of the inner portion of the adrenal gland that consists mainly of chromaffin cells

Subject: adrenal medulla hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size of the inner portion of the adrenal gland that consists mainly of chromaffin cells, usually due to an increase in the number of cells

Subject: thin adrenal cortex
Value: reduced thickness of the thick outer layer of the adrenal gland that produces and secretes steroid hormones such as corticosterone, estrone and aldosterone

Subject: early degeneration of the adrenal gland x-zone
Value: degeneration of the transient cortical layer juxtaposed to the medulla and the zona reticularis prior to the expected time; in males, this zone rapidly involutes at the onset of puberty whereas this zone persists in females until the first pregnancy or later in adulthood in non-pregnant females

Subject: abnormal organ of Corti supporting cell differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce the highly differentiated epithelial cells with distinctive morphological features that surround the hair cells in the organ of Corti

Subject: abnormal organ of Corti supporting cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly in processes pertinent to the integrated function of the highly differentiated epithelial cells with distinctive morphological features that surround the hair cells in the organ of Corti

Subject: abnormal organ of Corti supporting cell proliferation
Value: aberrant timing or any anomaly in the ability of supporting cells in the organ of Corti to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: short scala media
Value: reduced length of the spirally arranged membranous tube suspended within the cochlea, lying between and separating the scala vestibuli and scala tympani

Subject: small scala media
Value: reduced size of the spirally arranged membranous tube suspended within the cochlea, lying between and separating the scala vestibuli and scala tympani

Subject: dilated scala media
Value: stretched or widened aperture of the luminal space of the spirally arranged membranous tube suspended within the cochlea, lying between and separating the scala vestibuli and scala tympani

Subject: abnormal sympathetic preganglionic fiber morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any or all of the cholinergic axonal fibers projecting from the CNS to a sympathetic ganglion

Subject: abnormal parasympathetic preganglionic fiber morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any or all of the cholinergic axonal fibers projecting from the CNS to a parasympathetic ganglion

Subject: abnormal sympathetic postganglionic fiber morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any or all of the noradrenergic and some adrenergic axonal fibers projecting from a sympathetic ganglion to an effector organ

Subject: abnormal parasympathetic postganglionic fiber morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any or all of the cholinergic axonal fibers projecting from a parasympathetic ganglion to an effector organ

Subject: abnormal pterygopalatine ganglion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small parasympathetic ganglion that supplies nerve fibers to the lacrimal, nasal, palatine and pharyngeal glands

Subject: abnormal otic ganglion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the ganglion that supplies nerve fibers to the parotid gland

Subject: abnormal prevertebral ganglion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the sympathetic ganglia located in front of the vertebral column and are associated with the major branches of the abdominal aorta; these include the celiac, aorticorenal, superior and inferior mesenteric ganglia

Subject: abnormal paravertebral ganglion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the groups of postsynaptic neurons located at intervals along the sympatheic trunk, including the superior cervical, middle cervical and stellate (cervicothoracic) ganglia as well as the thoracic, lumbar and sacral ganglia

Subject: abnormal splanchnic nerve morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the major nerves supplying sympathetic innervation to the abdomen, including the greater, lesser, and lowest (or smallest) splanchnic nerves that are formed by preganglionic fibers from the spinal cord, which pass through the paravertebral ganglia and then to the celiac ganglia and plexuses, and the lumbar splanchnic nerves carry fibers which pass through the lumbar paravertebral ganglia to the mesenteric and hypogastric ganglia

Subject: abnormal sympathetic afferent fiber morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the fibers that conduct sensory nerve impulses from the viscera through the posterior dorsal roots into the spinal cord

Subject: absent adenohypophysis
Value: absence of the anterior part of the pituitary that secretes a variety of hormones

Subject: small adenohypophysis
Value: reduced size of the anterior part of the pituitary that secretes a variety of hormones

Subject: abnormal somatotroph morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of an acidophilic cell of the anterior pituitary that produces growth hormone, somatotropin

Subject: abnormal lactotroph morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of an acidophilic cell of the anterior pituitary that produces prolactin

Subject: abnormal melanotroph morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a cell of the intermediate pituitary that produces melanocyte stimulating hormone and other peptides from the post-translational processing of pro-opiomelanocortin (POMC)

Subject: abnormal gonadotroph morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anterior pituitary cells that can produce both follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH)

Subject: abnormal thyrotroph morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of an anterior pituitary cell that produces thyroid-stimulating hormone

Subject: abnormal corticotroph morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of an anterior pituitary basophilic cell that produces adrenocorticotrophic hormone (ACTH)

Subject: increased somatotroph cell number
Value: greater number of an acidophilic cell of the anterior pituitary that produces growth hormone, somatotropin

Subject: decreased somatotroph cell number
Value: reduced number of an acidophilic cell of the anterior pituitary that produces growth hormone, somatotropin

Subject: absent somatotrophs
Value: absence of an acidophilic cell of the anterior pituitary that produces growth hormone, somatotropin

Subject: increased lactotroph cell number
Value: greater number of an acidophilic cell of the anterior pituitary that produces prolactin

Subject: decreased lactotroph cell number
Value: reduced number of an acidophilic cell of the anterior pituitary that produces prolactin

Subject: absent lactotrophs
Value: absence of an acidophilic cell of the anterior pituitary that produces prolactin

Subject: increased gonadotroph cell number
Value: greater number of the anterior pituitary cells that can produce both follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH)

Subject: decreased gonadotroph cell number
Value: reduced number of the anterior pituitary cells that can produce both follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH)

Subject: absent gonadotrophs
Value: absence of the anterior pituitary cells that can produce both follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH)

Subject: increased thyrotroph cell number
Value: greater number of an anterior pituitary cell that produces thyroid-stimulating hormone

Subject: decreased thyrotroph cell number
Value: reduced number of an anterior pituitary cell that produces thyroid-stimulating hormone

Subject: absent thyrotrophs
Value: absence of an anterior pituitary cell that produces thyroid-stimulating hormone

Subject: increased corticotroph cell number
Value: greater number of an anterior pituitary basophilic cell that produces adrenocorticotrophic hormone (ACTH)

Subject: decreased corticotroph cell number
Value: reduced number of an anterior pituitary basophilic cell that produces adrenocorticotrophic hormone (ACTH)

Subject: absent corticotrophs
Value: absence of an anterior pituitary basophilic cell that produces adrenocorticotrophic hormone (ACTH)

Subject: abnormal gamma-delta T cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of an immature or mature T cell expressing an gamma-delta T cell receptor complex

Subject: abnormal mature gamma-delta T cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a mature T cell expressing an gamma-delta T cell receptor complex

Subject: abnormal gamma-delta T cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of immature or mature T cells expressing an gamma-delta T cell receptor complex

Subject: increased gamma-delta T cell number
Value: greater number of immature or mature T cells expressing an gamma-delta T cell receptor complex

Subject: decreased gamma-delta T cell number
Value: reduced number of immature or mature T cells expressing an gamma-delta T cell receptor complex

Subject: absent gamma-delta T cells
Value: absence of immature or mature T cells expressing an gamma-delta T cell receptor complex

Subject: abnormal gamma-delta intraepithelial T cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a gamma-delta T cell present in columnar epithelia such as in the gastrointestinal tract; intraepithelial T cells often have distinct developmental pathways and activation requirements

Subject: increased gamma-delta intraepithelial T cell number
Value: greater number of a gamma-delta T cell present in columnar epithelia such as in the gastrointestinal tract; intraepithelial T cells often have distinct developmental pathways and activation requirements

Subject: decreased gamma-delta intraepithelial T cell number
Value: reduced number of a gamma-delta T cell present in columnar epithelia such as in the gastrointestinal tract; intraepithelial T cells often have distinct developmental pathways and activation requirements

Subject: absent gamma-delta intraepithelial T cell
Value: absence of a gamma-delta T cell present in columnar epithelia such as in the gastrointestinal tract; intraepithelial T cells often have distinct developmental pathways and activation requirements

Subject: increased mature gamma-delta T cell number
Value: increased number of a mature T cell expressing an gamma-delta T cell receptor complex

Subject: decreased mature gamma-delta T cell number
Value: reduced number of a mature T cell expressing an gamma-delta T cell receptor complex

Subject: absent mature gamma-delta T cells
Value: absence of a mature T cell expressing an gamma-delta T cell receptor complex

Subject: abnormal gamma-delta T cell differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce gamma-delta T cells, and/or accumulation of gamma-delta T cell precursors

Subject: abnormal CD4-positive, gamma-delta intraepithelial T cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a CD4-positive, gamma-delta T cell of the columnar epithelia such as in the gastrointestinal tract; intraepithelial T cells often have distinct developmental pathways and activation requirements

Subject: increased CD4-positive, gamma-delta intraepithelial T cell number
Value: greater number of a CD4-positive, gamma-delta T cell of the columnar epithelia such as in the gastrointestinal tract; intraepithelial T cells often have distinct developmental pathways and activation requirements

Subject: decreased CD4-positive, gamma-delta intraepithelial T cell number
Value: reduced number of a CD4-positive, gamma-delta T cell of the columnar epithelia such as in the gastrointestinal tract; intraepithelial T cells often have distinct developmental pathways and activation requirements

Subject: absent CD4-positive, gamma-delta intraepithelial T cells
Value: absence of a CD4-positive, gamma-delta T cell of the columnar epithelia such as in the gastrointestinal tract; intraepithelial T cells often have distinct developmental pathways and activation requirements

Subject: abnormal CD8-positive, gamma-delta intraepithelial T cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a CD8-positive, gamma-delta T cell of the columnar epithelia such as in the gastrointestinal tract; intraepithelial T cells often have distinct developmental pathways and activation requirements

Subject: increased CD8-positive, gamma-delta intraepithelial T cell number
Value: greater number of a CD8-positive, gamma-delta T cell of the columnar epithelia such as in the gastrointestinal tract; intraepithelial T cells often have distinct developmental pathways and activation requirements

Subject: decreased CD8-positive, gamma-delta intraepithelial T cell number
Value: reduced number of a CD8-positive, gamma-delta T cell of the columnar epithelia such as in the gastrointestinal tract; intraepithelial T cells often have distinct developmental pathways and activation requirements

Subject: absent CD8-positive, gamma-delta intraepithelial T cells
Value: absence of a CD8-positive, gamma-delta T cell of the columnar epithelia such as in the gastrointestinal tract; intraepithelial T cells often have distinct developmental pathways and activation requirements

Subject: adenohypophysis hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced cell number, of the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland

Subject: enlarged adenohypophysis
Value: increased size of the anterior part of the pituitary that secretes a variety of hormones

Subject: absent pituitary intermediate lobe
Value: absence of the thin boundary between the adenohypophysis and neurohypophysis of the pituitary that produces melanocyte stimulating hormone (MSH); this area is small or absent in mammalian adults

Subject: small pituitary intermediate lobe
Value: reduced size of the thin boundary between the adenohypophysis and neurohypophysis of the pituitary that produces melanocyte stimulating hormone (MSH); this area is small or absent in mammalian adults

Subject: pituitary intermediate lobe hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced cell number, of the thin boundary between the adenohypophysis and neurohypophysis of the pituitary that produces melanocyte stimulating hormone (MSH); this area is small or absent in mammalian adults

Subject: enlarged pituitary intermediate lobe
Value: increased size of the thin boundary between the adenohypophysis and neurohypophysis of the pituitary that produces melanocyte stimulating hormone (MSH); this area is small or absent in mammalian adults

Subject: pituitary intermediate lobe hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due to increased cell number, of the thin boundary between the adenohypophysis and neurohypophysis of the pituitary that produces melanocyte stimulating hormone (MSH); this area is small or absent in mammalian adults

Subject: small malleus
Value: reduced size of the largest of the three auditory ossicles, which resembles a club or hammer

Subject: short malleus
Value: reduced length of the largest of the three auditory ossicles, which resembles a club or hammer

Subject: abnormal malleus manubrium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the handle of the malleus, which extends downward, inward, and backward from the neck of the malleus and is embedded throughout its length in the tympanic membrane

Subject: short malleus manubrium
Value: reduced length of the handle of the malleus

Subject: small malleus manubrium
Value: reduced size of the handle of the malleus

Subject: absent malleus manubrium
Value: absence of the handle of the malleus

Subject: small malleus processus brevis
Value: reduced size of the projection extending from the base of the manubrium of the malleus which contacts the upper part of the tympanic membrane

Subject: absent malleus head
Value: absence of the rounded portion of the malleus articulating with the body of the incus

Subject: abnormal gonial bone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the investing bone that lies on the surface of the malleus

Subject: absent gonial bone
Value: absence of the investing bone that normally lies on the surface of the malleus

Subject: gonial bone hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the investing bone that lies on the surface of the malleus, usually due to reduced cell number

Subject: enlarged gonial bone
Value: increased size of the investing bone that lies on the surface of the malleus

Subject: absent nasal capsule
Value: absence of the cartilage around the developing nasal cavity of the embryo

Subject: absent basisphenoid bone
Value: absence of the part of the base of the cranium found between the basioccipital and the presphenoid bone

Subject: absent styloid process
Value: absence of the slender needle-like pointed projection that runs downward and slightly forward from the base of the inferior surface of the petrous portion of the temporal bone to join the tympanic portion

Subject: hypochromic anemia
Value: hemoglobin deficiency resulting from a reduction in the concentration of hemoglobin in red cells, resulting in insufficient oxygenation of tissues and organs

Subject: hypochromic microcytic anemia
Value: hemoglobin deficiency resulting from a reduction in the concentration of hemoglobin in red cells, where the erythrocyte corpuscular volume is smaller than normal

Subject: hypochromic macrocytic anemia
Value: hemoglobin deficiency resulting from a reduction in the concentration of hemoglobin in red cells, where the erythrocyte corpuscular volume is larger than normal

Subject: abnormal primordial germ cell proliferation
Value: anomaly in the ability of the primordial germ cell population to undergo rapid expansion by cell division

Subject: abnormal primordial germ cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a mesodermally-derived, most primitive undifferentiated sex cell, that originates in the allantois and migrates through the hindgut and into the gonadal ridge

Subject: decreased primordial germ cell number
Value: reduced number of a mesodermally-derived, most primitive undifferentiated sex cell, that originates in the allantois and migrates through the hindgut and into the gonadal ridge

Subject: absent primordial germ cells
Value: absence of a mesodermally-derived, most primitive undifferentiated sex cell, that originates in the allantois and migrates through the hindgut and into the gonadal ridge

Subject: increased primordial germ cell number
Value: greater number of a mesodermally-derived, most primitive undifferentiated sex cell, that originates in the allantois and migrates through the hindgut and into the gonadal ridge

Subject: abnormal osteoblast differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce skeletogenic cells that secrete osteoid, are capable of producing mineralized (hydroxyapatite) matrix, are located adjacent to or within osteoid tissue, and arise from the transformation of a preosteoblast cell

Subject: abnormal osteoclast differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce the specialized phagocytic cells associated with the absorption and removal of the mineralized matrix of bone tissue

Subject: abnormal CD4-positive, CD25-positive, alpha-beta regulatory T cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a CD4-positive, CD25-positive, alpha-beta T cell which regulates overall immune responses as well as the responses of other T cell subsets through direct cell-cell contact and cytokine release

Subject: abnormal CD8-positive, alpha-beta regulatory T cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cell which regulates overall immune responses as well as the responses of other T cell subsets through direct cell-cell contact and cytokine release

Subject: abnormal alpha-beta intraepithelial T cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of an alpha-beta T cell present in columnar epithelia such as in the gastrointestinal tract; intraepithelial T cells often have distinct developmental pathways and activation requirements

Subject: abnormal CD4-positive, alpha-beta intraepithelial T cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cell of the columnar epithelia such as in the gastrointestinal tract; intraepithelial T cells often have distinct developmental pathways and activation requirements

Subject: abnormal CD8 positive, alpha-beta intraepithelial T cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cell of the columnar epithelia such as in the gastrointestinal tract; intraepithelial T cells often have distinct developmental pathways and activation requirements

Subject: increased cellular sensitivity to alkylating agents
Value: greater incidence of cell death following exposure to agents that cause DNA damage via the addition of alkyl groups to any or all of the bases of DNA

Subject: decreased cellular sensitivity to alkylating agents
Value: reduced incidence of cell death following exposure to agents that cause DNA damage via the addition of alkyl groups to any or all of the bases of DNA

Subject: increased cellular sensitivity to methylmethanesulfonate
Value: greater incidence of cell death following exposure to methylmethanesulfonate

Subject: decreased cellular sensitivity to methylmethanesulfonate
Value: reduced incidence of cell death following exposure to methylmethanesulfonate

Subject: increased cellular sensitivity to hydrogen peroxide
Value: greater incidence of cell death following exposure to hydrogen peroxide

Subject: decreased cellular sensitivity to hydrogen peroxide
Value: reduced incidence of cell death following exposure to hydrogen peroxide

Subject: decreased cellular sensitivity to hydroxyurea
Value: reduced incidence of cell death following exposure to hydroxyurea

Subject: increased cellular sensitivity to hydroxyurea
Value: greater incidence of cell death following exposure to hydroxyurea

Subject: increased cellular sensitivity to ultraviolet irradiation
Value: greater incidence of cell death following exposure to ultraviolet irradiation

Subject: decreased cellular sensitivity to ultraviolet irradiation
Value: reduced incidence of cell death following exposure to ultraviolet irradiation

Subject: increased cellular sensitivity to oxidative stress
Value: greater incidence of cell death or enhanced production of reactive oxygen species after exposure to a variety of stress conditions including ionizing radiation, exposure to xenobiotics, inflammation, and phagocytosis

Subject: decreased cellular sensitivity to oxidative stress
Value: reduced incidence of cell death or enhanced production of reactive oxygen species after exposure to a variety of stress conditions including ionizing radiation, exposure to xenobiotics, inflammation, and phagocytosis

Subject: abnormal spatial reference memory
Value: anomaly in the ability to recall spatial location information from previous encounters or training sessions in order to navigate or perform other behavior using such location cues

Subject: abnormal neurite morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a neuronal process, either a dendrite or an axon in vivo, or a filamentous projection from a neuron such as is seen in tissue culture

Subject: increased somatotroph cell size
Value: excessive growth or enlargement of an acidophilic cell of the anterior pituitary that produces growth hormone, somatotropin

Subject: decreased somatotroph cell size
Value: reduced growth or small size of an acidophilic cell of the anterior pituitary that produces growth hormone, somatotropin

Subject: abnormal cutaneous elastic fiber morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the slender connective tissue fiber in the extracellular matrix of skin tissue that is composed of microfibrils and amorphous elastin and is characterized by great elasticity

Subject: abnormal cutaneous microfibril morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the fiber-like strand of fibrillin that forms the scaffold of the cutaneous elastic fibers found in the extracellular matrix of the skin

Subject: increased thyrotroph cell size
Value: excessive growth or enlargement of an anterior pituitary cell that produces thyroid-stimulating hormone

Subject: decreased thyrotroph cell size
Value: reduced growth or small size of an anterior pituitary cell that produces thyroid-stimulating hormone

Subject: increased lactotroph cell size
Value: excessive growth or enlargement of an acidophilic cell of the anterior pituitary that produces prolactin

Subject: decreased lactotroph cell size
Value: reduced growth or small size of an acidophilic cell of the anterior pituitary that produces prolactin

Subject: increased gonadotroph cell size
Value: excessive growth or enlargement of the anterior pituitary cells that can produce both follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH)

Subject: decreased gonadotroph cell size
Value: reduced growth or small size of the anterior pituitary cells that can produce both follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH)

Subject: increased corticotroph cell size
Value: excessive growth or enlargement of an anterior pituitary basophilic cell that produces adrenocorticotrophic hormone (ACTH)

Subject: decreased corticotroph cell size
Value: reduced growth or small size of an anterior pituitary basophilic cell that produces adrenocorticotrophic hormone (ACTH)

Subject: abnormal spatial working memory
Value: anomaly in the ability to spontaneously process spatial location information in order to navigate or perform other behavior using such location cues, without previous encounters or training at that location

Subject: absent parotid gland
Value: absence of the largest of the major salivary glands situated below and in front of each ear

Subject: short temporal bone squamous part
Value: length reduction of the anterosuperior portion of the temporal bone that is thin, scale-like, and translucent and forms part of the lateral wall of the cranial vault

Subject: abnormal short term spatial reference memory
Value: anomaly in the short-term memory for spatial location information that is established during the first few minutes after training or an encounter at that location

Subject: abnormal long term spatial reference memory
Value: anomaly in long-term memory for spatial location information that is consolidated over hours and days after training or an encounter at that location

Subject: abnormal somatotroph cell nucleus
Value: any structural anomaly of a somatotroph cell nucleus

Subject: small somatotroph cell nucleus
Value: decreased size of a somatotroph cell nucleus

Subject: large somatotroph cell nucleus
Value: increased size of a somatotroph cell nucleus

Subject: decreased somatotroph secretory granule number
Value: decreased number of vesicles derived from the golgi that contain somatotropin growth hormone to be released at the cell surface

Subject: absent somatotroph secretory granules
Value: absence of vesicles derived from the golgi that contain somatotropin growth hormone to be released at the cell surface

Subject: abnormal cutaneous collagen fibril morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the connective tissue bundles in the extracellular matrix of skin tissue that are composed of collagen, and play a role in skin strength and elasticity

Subject: abnormal cortical plate morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the outer neural tube region in which post-mitotic neuroblasts migrate along radial glia to form the adult cortical layers

Subject: abnormal subplate morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the transient outer neural tube region that contains the first generated post-mitotic neurons that receive synaptic input from thalamic axons and in turn project axons to the developing cortical plate

Subject: thin cortical plate
Value: reduced thickness of the outer neural tube region in which post-mitotic neuroblasts migrate along radial glia to form the adult cortical layers

Subject: disorganized cortical plate
Value: derangement of the patterned arrangement of the cortical plate

Subject: absent subplate
Value: absence of the transient outer neural tube region that contains the first generated post-mitotic neurons that receive synaptic input from thalamic axons and in turn project axons to the developing cortical plate

Subject: retinal cone cell degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of one of the photoreceptor cell types in the retina, in which the photopigment is in invaginations of the cell membrane of the outer segment

Subject: increased retinal cone cell number
Value: greater number of one of the photoreceptor cell types in the retina, in which the photopigment is in invaginations of the cell membrane of the outer segment

Subject: decreased retinal cone cell number
Value: reduced number of one of the photoreceptor cell types in the retina, in which the photopigment is in invaginations of the cell membrane of the outer segment

Subject: absent retinal cone cells
Value: absence of one of the photoreceptor cell types in the retina, in which the photopigment is in invaginations of the cell membrane of the outer segment

Subject: abnormal retinal cone cell inner segment morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the retinal cone cell region which contains the machinery of the cell (mitochondria, golgi, endoplasmic reticulum, etc) and where opsin molecules are assembled and passed to be part of the outer segment region

Subject: abnormal retinal cone cell outer segment morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the retinal cone cell region in which the visual pigment rhodopsin is in invaginations of the cell membrane

Subject: retinal photoreceptor degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of a cell specialized to detect and transduce light, including rods and cones of the retina

Subject: retinal rod cell degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of one of the photoreceptor cell types of the vertebrate retina, in which the photopigment is in stacks of membranous disks separate from the outer cell membrane

Subject: increased retinal rod cell number
Value: greater number of one of the photoreceptor cell types of the vertebrate retina, in which the photopigment is in stacks of membranous disks separate from the outer cell membrane

Subject: decreased retinal rod cell number
Value: reduced number of one of the photoreceptor cell types of the vertebrate retina, in which the photopigment is in stacks of membranous disks separate from the outer cell membrane

Subject: absent retinal rod cells
Value: absence of one of the photoreceptor cell types of the vertebrate retina, in which the photopigment is in stacks of membranous disks separate from the outer cell membrane

Subject: abnormal retinal rod cell inner segment morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the retinal rod cell region which contains the machinery of the cell (mitochondria, golgi, endoplasmic reticulum, etc) and where opsin molecules are assembled and passed to be part of the outer segment region

Subject: abnormal retinal rod cell outer segment morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the retinal rod cell region which contains stacks of membranous discs separate from the outer cell membrane that are rich in the visual pigment rhodopsin

Subject: abnormal cortical intermediate zone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the region of the developing mammalian cortex that extends between the ventricular zone and the cortical plate (CP); normally, the IZ is a region of tangential migration of cells, and at midgestation, the lower part of the IZ develops into the subventricular zone

Subject: abnormal cortical ventricular zone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a transient region of the developing cerebral cortex that contains migrating neurons, radial glial cells, and a large population of cycling multipotent neural stem cells that generate newborn neurons

Subject: abnormal circulating pancreatic peptide level
Value: anomaly in the amount of the 36-amino acid pancreatic hormone in the blood that is secreted mainly by endocrine cells found at the periphery of the islets of Langerhans in response to ingestions, and regulates gastric secretion, gastric emptying, pancreatic enzyme secretion, and appetite

Subject: absent dorsal root ganglion
Value: absence of the groups of sensory nerve cell bodies located on the dorsal spinal roots within the vertebral column

Subject: left atrial isomerism
Value: anomaly in the asymmetry of the cardiac atria such that atria on both the left and right side have the morphology normally seen on the left side of the body

Subject: abnormal medium spiny neuron morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the inhibitory projection neurons located in the striatum that integrate glutamatergic signals arising from the cerebral cortex and thalamus

Subject: abnormal peripheral lymph node morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the lymph nodes located outside the thoracic and abdominal cavities, such as the submandibular, prescapular, axillary, inguinal and popliteal lymph nodes

Subject: absent peripheral lymph nodes
Value: absence of the lymph nodes located outside the thoracic and abdominal cavities, such as the submandibular, prescapular, axillary, inguinal and popliteal lymph nodes

Subject: absent mesenteric lymph nodes
Value: <absence of the lymph nodes located in the mesentery, of which there are 3 classes: ileocolic, juxtaintestinal mesenteric, and central superior group>

Subject: enlarged mesenteric lymph nodes
Value: <increased size of the lymph nodes located in the mesentery, of which there are 3 classes: ileocolic, juxtaintestinal mesenteric, and central superior group>

Subject: absent proprioceptive neurons
Value: absence of the sensory neurons of the dorsal root ganglia that sense body position and send information about how much the muscle is stretched to the spinal cord

Subject: absent muscle spindles
Value: absence of the sensory organs in muscle that are involved in the stretch reflex

Subject: abnormal protein level
Value: anomaly in the amount of any of the macromolecules consisting of long chains of amino acids in peptide linkage

Subject: abnormal spleen B cell follicle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the area of the white pulp where the affinity maturation of B cells and the generation of memory B cells and plasma cells occur

Subject: abnormal spleen primary B follicle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the nodules of small undifferentiated B lymphocytes and follicular dendritic cells located in the spleen white pulp

Subject: abnormal spleen secondary B follicle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the nodules of antigen-activated, differentiating B cells, follicular dendritic cells, antigen-presenting T cells and macrophages in the spleen white pulp

Subject: abnormal spleen follicular dendritic cell network
Value: any structural anomaly of the enmeshed group of antigen presenting cells with extensive dendritic processes in the spleen B cell follicle that present antigen to B cells during an immune response

Subject: absent spleen germinal center
Value: absence of the area of the spleen secondary B follicle where rapid B-cell proliferation, somatic hypermutation, and selection for antigen binding occurs

Subject: intermingled spleen red and white pulp
Value: no clear demarcation of the spleen red and white pulp tissue

Subject: increased spleen red pulp amount
Value: increase in the quantity of the parenchymatous tissue network of the spleen that consists of loose plates or cords (sinuses) infiltrated with red blood cells where most of the blood filtration occurs and degenerate erythrocytes are removed from the circulation

Subject: decreased spleen red pulp amount
Value: reduction in the quantity of the parenchymatous tissue network of the spleen that consists of loose plates or cords (sinuses) infiltrated with red blood cells where most of the blood filtration occurs and degenerate erythrocytes are removed from the circulation

Subject: increased spleen white pulp amount
Value: increase in the quantity of the parenchymatous tissue of the spleen that surrounds splenic blood vessels, consists of compact masses of lymphatic cells and is where foreign material removed from the blood is used to initiate an immune reaction that results in the production of antibodies

Subject: decreased spleen white pulp amount
Value: reduction in the quantity of the parenchymatous tissue of the spleen that surrounds splenic blood vessels, consists of compact masses of lymphatic cells and is where foreign material removed from the blood is used to initiate an immune reaction that results in the production of antibodies

Subject: absent eye pigmentation
Value: absence of melanin (pigment) in the eye either due to absent melanocytes or failure of melanin synthesis

Subject: increased spleen germinal center number
Value: greater number of spleen secondary B follicles where rapid B-cell proliferation, somatic hypermutation, and selection for antigen binding occurs

Subject: decreased spleen germinal center number
Value: reduced number of spleen secondary B follicles where rapid B-cell proliferation, somatic hypermutation, and selection for antigen binding occurs

Subject: increased spleen germinal center size
Value: greater size of spleen secondary B follicles where rapid B-cell proliferation, somatic hypermutation, and selection for antigen binding occurs

Subject: decreased spleen germinal center size
Value: reduced size of spleen secondary B follicles where rapid B-cell proliferation, somatic hypermutation, and selection for antigen binding occurs

Subject: increased muscle spindle number
Value: greater number of the sensory organs in muscle that are involved in the stretch reflex

Subject: decreased muscle spindle number
Value: reduced number of the sensory organs in muscle that are involved in the stretch reflex

Subject: abnormal mesonephros morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the excretory organ of the embryo, collective Wolffian tubules, which forms the urogenital fold from which the reproductive organs develop

Subject: abnormal semicircular canal ampulla morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the spherical enlargement at the base of each semicircular canal where they connect with the utricle, containing the crista ampullaris which detects movement of the fluid within the canals

Subject: slow postnatal weight gain
Value: the weight gain over a span of postnatal developmental time is slower than controls, with or without ever attaining a similar weight to controls as adults

Subject: enlarged dorsal root ganglion
Value: increased size a group of sensory nerve cell bodies located on the dorsal spinal roots within the vertebral column

Subject: dorsal root ganglion hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due to a increased cell number, of a dorsal root ganglion or ganglia

Subject: dorsal root ganglion degeneration
Value: retrogressive pathological change of a group of sensory nerve cell bodies located on the dorsal spinal roots within the vertebral column

Subject: alpha-synuclein inclusion body
Value: formation of aggregates of the alpha-synuclein protein in neural and glial tissue; often seen in neurodegenerative disorders such as Parkinson's disease

Subject: absence of all nails
Value: absence of all of the horny plates covering the dorsal surface of the distal end of each terminal phalanx of the digits

Subject: decreased IgG1 level
Value: less than normal immunoglobulin class G1 level

Subject: decreased IgG2a level
Value: less than normal immunoglobulin class G2a level

Subject: decreased IgG2b level
Value: less than normal immunoglobulin class G2b level

Subject: decreased IgG3 level
Value: less than normal immunoglobulin class G3 level

Subject: increased IgG1 level
Value: greater than normal immunoglobulin class G1 level

Subject: increased IgG2a level
Value: greater than normal immunoglobulin class G2a level

Subject: increased IgG2b level
Value: greater than normal immunoglobulin class G2b level

Subject: increased IgG3 level
Value: greater than normal immunoglobulin class G3 level

Subject: abnormal spinal cord grey matter morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the ridge-shaped grey matter of the spinal cord that extends longitudinally through the center of each half of the spinal cord, and are largely or entirely composed of nerve cell bodies and their dendrites and some supportive tissue

Subject: abnormal adrenal chromaffin cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the neuroendocrine cells of the medulla of the adrenal gland that are innervated by the splanchnic nerve and that are responsible for epinephrine and norepinephrine secretion

Subject: absent adrenal chromaffin cells
Value: absence of the neuroendocrine cells of the medulla of the adrenal gland that are innervated by the splanchnic nerve and that are responsible for epinephrine and norepinephrine secretion

Subject: abnormal noradrenergic chromaffin cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the neuroendocrine cells of the medulla of the adrenal gland that are innervated by the splanchnic nerve and that are responsible for norepinephrine secretion

Subject: thin retinal ganglion layer
Value: reduced thickness of the innermost nuclear layer of the retina, which contains neurons that project axons through the optic nerve to the brain

Subject: thick retinal ganglion layer
Value: increased thickness of the innermost nuclear layer of the retina, which contains neurons that project axons through the optic nerve to the brain

Subject: disorganized retinal ganglion layer
Value: derangement of the pattern of the innermost nuclear layer of the retina, which contains neurons that project axons through the optic nerve to the brain

Subject: absent retinal ganglion layer
Value: absence of the innermost nuclear layer of the retina, which contains neurons that project axons through the optic nerve to the brain

Subject: thin retinal inner nuclear layer
Value: reduced thickness of the retinal layer that contains the cell bodies of bipolar, horizontal, and amacrine cells

Subject: disorganized retinal inner nuclear layer
Value: derangement of the normal pattern of the retinal layer that contains the cell bodies of bipolar, horizontal, and amacrine cells

Subject: thin retinal inner plexiform layer
Value: reduced thickness of the retinal cell layer where bipolar and amacrine cell axons synapse with ganglion cell dendrites

Subject: absent retinal inner plexiform layer
Value: absence of the retinal cell layer where bipolar and amacrine cell axons synapse with ganglion cell dendrites

Subject: thin retinal outer nuclear layer
Value: reduced thickness of the retinal layer that contains the nuclei and cell bodies of rods and cones

Subject: disorganized retinal outer nuclear layer
Value: derangement of the normal pattern of the retinal layer that contains the nuclei and cell bodies of rods and cones

Subject: thick retinal outer nuclear layer
Value: increased thickness of the retinal layer that contains the nuclei and cell bodies of rods and cones

Subject: retinal outer nuclear layer degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment or destruction of the retinal layer that contains the nuclei and cell bodies of rods and cones

Subject: thin retinal outer plexiform layer
Value: reduced thickness of the retinal layer that is the site of synapses between the rods and cones (axons) and the horizontal and bipolar cells (dendrites)

Subject: disorganized retinal outer plexiform layer
Value: a derangement of the normal pattern of the retinal layer that is the site of synapses between the rods and cones (axons) and the horizontal and bipolar cells (dendrites)

Subject: abnormal Bowman membrane morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the layer of acellular matrix that lies beneath the corneal epithelium and above the corneal stroma, consists of randomly arranged collagen fibers in a condensed bed of intercellular substance, and provides stability and strength to the cornea

Subject: abnormal lymph node germinal center morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the area of the lymph node secondary follicle where antigen-activated B-cell blasts are stimulated by antigens and proliferate, with the immunoglobulin genes undergoing somatic hypermutation, before the cells migrate away as plasma cells or memory cells

Subject: absent lymph node germinal center
Value: absence of the area of the lymph node secondary follicle where antigen-activated B-cell blasts are stimulated by antigens and proliferate, with the immunoglobulin genes undergoing somatic hypermutation, before the cells migrate away as plasma cells or memory cells

Subject: increased plasmacytoid dendritic cell number
Value: greater number of phagocytic dendritic cells that are morphologically similar to plasma cells, but do not express B lineage markers, and produce large amounts of alpha/beta interferons (IFN-/) in response to viral and bacterial stimuli

Subject: decreased cranium height
Value: decrease in the rostral-caudal distance between the cranial base and the upper domelike portion of the skull

Subject: decreased cranium width
Value: having a decreased side-to-side, or lateral distance of the cranium

Subject: embryonic lethality at implantation
Value: <death due to failure of implantation (Mus: E4.5)>

Subject: polycystic kidney
Value: the development of innumerable cysts in the kidneys filled with fluid replacing much of the mass of the kidneys leading to reduction in kidney function and frequently kidney failure

Subject: enlarged optic nerve
Value: increased size of the second cranial nerve which is responsible for conveying visual information from the retina to the brain; it extends from the retina to the optic chiasma where part of its fibers become the optic tract and cross to the opposite side and pass to the geniculate bodies

Subject: abnormal rostral-caudal patterning of the somites
Value: anomaly in the developmental pattern of the somites along the axis that runs from the rostral to the caudal region of the body

Subject: increased chemical nociceptive threshold
Value: a greater than average concentration at which chemically induced pain sensation is first detectable

Subject: decreased chemical nociceptive threshold
Value: a lower than average concentration at which chemically induced pain sensation is first detectable

Subject: abnormal anterior visceral endoderm morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the extraembryonic tissue that is responsible for the proper orientation of the anterior-posterior axis of the embryo and for appropriate patterning of adjacent embryonic tissue

Subject: enlarged fourth ventricle
Value: increased size of the irregularly shaped cavity in the rhombencephalon, between the medulla oblongata, the pons, and the isthmus in front, and the cerebellum behind; it is continuous with the central canal of the cord below and with the cerebral aqueduct above, and through its lateral and median apertures it communicates with the subarachnoid space

Subject: enlarged lateral ventricles
Value: increased size of the cavity in each of the cerebral hemispheres derived from the cavity of the embryonic neural tube; they are separated from each other by the septum pellucidum, and each communicates with the third ventricle by the foramen of Monro, through which also the choroid plexuses of the lateral ventricles become continuous with that of the third ventricle

Subject: enlarged third ventricle
Value: increased size of the narrow cleft inferior to the corpus callosum, within the diencephalon, between the paired thalami; its floor is formed by the hypothalamus, its anterior wall by the lamina terminalis, and its roof by ependyma; it communicates with the fourth ventricle by the cerebral aqueduct, and with the lateral ventricles by the interventricular foramina

Subject: increased susceptibility to induced colitis
Value: increased severity or induction threshold of colitis upon treatment of an organism with intestinal inflammation agents such as dextran sodium sulfate (DSS)

Subject: decreased zigzag hair amount
Value: reduced number of the truncal hairs that have two or more sharp bends with diameter constrictions at the bends, and contain one air cell in the medulla

Subject: decreased susceptibility to induced colitis
Value: decreased severity or induction threshold of colitis upon treatment of an organism with intestinal inflammation agents such as dextran sodium sulfate (DSS)

Subject: abnormal cerebral hemisphere morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the largest part of the brain; the cerebrum is composed of a right and a left hemisphere each which contains an outer cerebral cortex and a subcortical basal ganglia; cerebral functions include sensorimotor, emotional, and intellectual activities

Subject: leukostasis
Value: abnormal intravascular leukocyte aggregation and clumping most commonly seen in the brain and lungs of organisms with leukemia, often with an excess of leukocytes in the blood

Subject: enlarged cervical lymph nodes
Value: increased size of the lymph nodes found near the neck and shoulders

Subject: atrial fibrillation
Value: asynchronous contraction or quivering of individual cardiac muscle fibers in the atria

Subject: impaired olfaction
Value: reduced ability to detect odors

Subject: absent sperm flagellum
Value: absence of the whiplike posterior filiform portion of the spermatozoon that provides sperm motility

Subject: abnormal vesicle-mediated transport
Value: anomaly in the directed movement of substances, either within a vesicle or in the vesicle membrane, into, out of or within a cell

Subject: abnormal neocortex morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the larger part of the mammalian cerebral cortex, distinguished from the allocortex by being composed of a larger number of nerve cells arranged in six layers

Subject: abnormal circulating interferon level
Value: anomaly in the amount in the blood of proteins secreted by vertebrate cells in response to a wide variety of inducers; they confer resistance against many different viruses, inhibit proliferation of normal and malignant cells, impede multiplication of intracellular parasites, enhance macrophage and granulocyte phagocytosis, augment natural killer cell activity, and show several other immunomodulatory functions

Subject: abnormal circulating interferon-alpha level
Value: anomaly in the amount in the blood of one of the type I interferons produced by peripheral blood leukocytes or lymphoblastoid cells that has antiviral activity and activates natural killer cells and B cells

Subject: abnormal circulating interferon-beta level
Value: anomaly in the amount in the blood of one of the type I interferons produced by fibroblasts in response to stimulation by live or inactivated virus or by double-stranded RNA with antiviral, antiproliferative, and immunomodulating activity

Subject: abnormal circulating interferon-gamma level
Value: anomaly in the amount in the blood of the major interferon produced by mitogenically or antigenically stimulated lymphocytes that is involved in immunoregulation

Subject: abnormal circulating tumor necrosis factor level
Value: anomaly in the amount in the blood of a serum glycoprotein produced by activated macrophages and NK cells and involved in initiating local inflammatory responses, particularly by its action on the endothelium of local blood vessels; its actions result in increased vascular permeability and induction of expression of adhesion molecules on the endothelium

Subject: increased circulating tumor necrosis factor level
Value: greater amount in the blood of a serum glycoprotein produced by activated macrophages and NK cells and involved in initiating local inflammatory responses, particularly by its action on the endothelium of local blood vessels; its actions result in increased vascular permeability and induction of expression of adhesion molecules on the endothelium

Subject: decreased circulating tumor necrosis factor level
Value: reduction in the amount in the blood of a serum glycoprotein produced by activated macrophages and NK cells and involved in initiating local inflammatory responses, particularly by its action on the endothelium of local blood vessels; its actions result in increased vascular permeability and induction of expression of adhesion molecules on the endothelium

Subject: abnormal interferon secretion

Value: reduction in the production or release of a serum glycoprotein produced by activated macrophages and NK cells and involved in initiating local inflammatory responses, particularly by its action on the endothelium of local blood vessels; its actions result in increased vascular permeability and induction of expression of adhesion molecules on the endothelium

Value: decrease in the production or release of one of the type I interferons produced by peripheral blood leukocytes or lymphoblastoid cells that has antiviral activity and activates natural killer cells and B cells

Subject: decreased interferon-gamma secretion

Subject: abnormal interleukin secretion
Value: anomaly in the production or cellular release of soluble factors which stimulate growth-related activities of leukocytes and other cell types, that can act to enhance cell proliferation and differentiation, DNA synthesis, secretion of other biologically active molecules and responses to immune and inflammatory stimuli

Subject: lethality at weaning
Value: premature death at weaning age, often due to the inability to make the transition to solid food

Subject: lipidosis
Value: abnormal fat metabolism with increased accumulation of specific lipids in tissue

Subject: abnormal synaptic bouton morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the knoblike enlargements along the course of axons, or more commonly at the distal terminations of axons which are specialized for the release of neurotransmitters

Subject: abnormal Purkinje cell dendrite morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the Purkinje cell body projections with hundreds of parallel spiny branches reaching up into the molecular layer

Subject: increased circulating interferon-alpha level
Value: increase in the amount in the blood of one of the type I interferons produced by peripheral blood leukocytes or lymphoblastoid cells that has antiviral activity and activates natural killer cells and B cells

Subject: decreased circulating interferon-alpha level
Value: reduction in the amount in the blood of one of the type I interferons produced by peripheral blood leukocytes or lymphoblastoid cells that has antiviral activity and activates natural killer cells and B cells

Subject: increased circulating interferon-beta level
Value: increase in the amount in the blood of one of the type I interferons produced by fibroblasts in response to stimulation by live or inactivated virus or by double-stranded RNA with antiviral, antiproliferative, and immunomodulating activity

Subject: decreased circulating interferon-beta level
Value: reduction in the amount in the blood of one of the type I interferons produced by fibroblasts in response to stimulation by live or inactivated virus or by double-stranded RNA with antiviral, antiproliferative, and immunomodulating activity

Subject: increased circulating interferon-gamma level
Value: increase in the amount in the blood of the major interferon produced by mitogenically or antigenically stimulated lymphocytes that is involved in immunoregulation

Subject: decreased circulating interferon-gamma level
Value: reduction in the amount in the blood of the major interferon produced by mitogenically or antigenically stimulated lymphocytes that is involved in immunoregulation

Subject: abnormal Purkinje cell differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce the neurons located at the interface of the molecular and internal granule layers of the cerebellar cortex

Subject: photoreceptor inner segment degeneration
Value: retrogressive pathologic change in the photoreceptor region which contains the machinery of the cell (mitochondria, golgi, endoplasmic reticulum, etc) and where opsin molecules are assembled and passed to be part of the outer segment region

Subject: disorganized photoreceptor inner segment
Value: derangement of the pattern of the photoreceptor region which contains the machinery of the cell (mitochondria, golgi, endoplasmic reticulum, etc) and where opsin molecules are assembled and passed to be part of the outer segment region

Subject: short photoreceptor inner segment
Value: decreased length of the photoreceptor region which contains the machinery of the cell (mitochondria, golgi, endoplasmic reticulum, etc) and where opsin molecules are assembled and passed to be part of the outer segment region

Subject: absent photoreceptor inner segment
Value: absence of the photoreceptor region which contains the machinery of the cell (mitochondria, golgi, endoplasmic reticulum, etc) and where opsin molecules are assembled and passed to be part of the outer segment region

Subject: photoreceptor outer segment degeneration
Value: retrogressive pathologic change in the photoreceptor region that is rich in the visual pigment rhodopsin

Subject: absent photoreceptor outer segment
Value: absence of the photoreceptor region that is rich in the visual pigment rhodopsin

Subject: disorganized photoreceptor outer segment
Value: derangement of the pattern of the photoreceptor region that is rich in the visual pigment rhodopsin

Subject: short photoreceptor outer segment
Value: decreased length of the photoreceptor region that is rich in the visual pigment rhodopsin

Subject: abnormal circulating interleukin level
Value: anomaly in the amount in the blood of soluble factors which stimulate growth-related activities of leukocytes as well as other cell types; they enhance cell proliferation and differentiation, DNA synthesis, secretion of other biologically active molecules and responses to immune and inflammatory stimuli

Subject: abnormal circulating interleukin-1 level
Value: anomaly in the amount in the blood of a soluble factor produced by monocytes, macrophages and other cells, which activates T-lymphocytes and potentiates their response to mitogens or antigens

Subject: abnormal circulating interleukin-10 level

Subject: increased circulating interleukin-6 level

Value: anomaly in the production or release of a cytokine produced by activated T-cells that stimulates the migration of CD4-positive lymphocytes and monocytes

Subject: increased interleukin-16 secretion
Value: increase in the production or release of a cytokine produced by activated T-cells that stimulates the migration of CD4-positive lymphocytes and monocytes

Subject: decreased interleukin-16 secretion
Value: reduction in the production or release of a cytokine produced by activated T-cells that stimulates the migration of CD4-positive lymphocytes and monocytes

Subject: abnormal interleukin-17 secretion
Value: anomaly in the production or release of a proinflammatory cytokine produced primarily by T-cells or their precursors

Subject: increased interleukin-17 secretion
Value: increase in the production or release of a proinflammatory cytokine produced primarily by T-cells or their precursors

Subject: decreased interleukin-17 secretion
Value: reduction in the production or release of a proinflammatory cytokine produced primarily by T-cells or their precursors

Subject: abnormal interleukin-18 secretion
Value: anomaly in the production or release of a cytokine which enhances the cytotoxic activity of NK cells and cytotoxic T-cells and appears to play a role both as neuroimmunomodulator and in the induction of mucosal immunity

Subject: increased interleukin-18 secretion
Value: increase in the production or release of a cytokine which enhances the cytotoxic activity of NK cells and cytotoxic T-cells and appears to play a role both as neuroimmunomodulator and in the induction of mucosal immunity

Subject: decreased interleukin-18 secretion
