Value: reduced total physical bulk or volume of a pancreatic beta cell compared to the normal state

Subject: abnormal fat cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a fat-storing cell found mostly in the abdominal cavity and subcutaneous tissue of mammals

Subject: abnormal brown fat cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of cells from the thermogenic form of adipose tissue found in newborns of many species, including humans, and in hibernating mammals; brown fat is capable of rapid liberation of energy and seems to be important in the maintenance of body temperature immediately after birth and upon waking from hibernation; brown adipocytes contain multiple small droplets of triglycerides and a high number of mitochondria

Subject: abnormal white fat cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of fat cells with light coloration and few mitochondria; these contain a scant ring of cytoplasm surrounding a single large lipid droplet or vacuole

Subject: increased white fat cell size
Value: increase in the size of fat cells with light coloration and few mitochondria

Subject: increased brown fat cell size
Value: increase in the size of fat cells from the thermogenic form of adipose tissue

Subject: abnormal white fat cell lipid droplet size
Value: anomaly in the size of the single large lipid droplet or vacuole of white fat cells

Subject: increased white fat cell lipid droplet size
Value: increase in the size of the single large lipid droplet or vacuole of white fat cells

Subject: decreased white fat cell lipid droplet size
Value: reduction in the size of the single large lipid droplet or vacuole of white fat cells

Subject: abnormal brown fat cell lipid droplet size
Value: anomaly in the size of the multiple small droplets of triglycerides found in brown adipocytes

Subject: increased brown fat cell lipid droplet size
Value: increase in the size of the multiple small droplets of triglycerides found in brown adipocytes

Subject: decreased brown fat cell lipid droplet size
Value: reduction in the size of the multiple small droplets of triglycerides found in brown adipocytes

Subject: abnormal brown fat cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of fat cells from the thermogenic form of adipose tissue

Subject: increased brown fat cell number
Value: increase in the number of fat cells from the thermogenic form of adipose tissue

Subject: decreased brown fat cell number
Value: reduction in the number of fat cells from the thermogenic form of adipose tissue

Subject: abnormal white fat cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of fat cells with light coloration and few mitochondria

Subject: increased white fat cell number
Value: increase in the number of fat cells with light coloration and few mitochondria

Subject: decreased white fat cell number
Value: reduction in the number of fat cells with light coloration and few mitochondria

Subject: abnormal white fat cell size
Value: anomaly in the size of fat cells with light coloration and few mitochondria

Subject: decreased white fat cell size
Value: reduction in the size of fat cells with light coloration and few mitochondria

Subject: abnormal brown fat lipid droplet number
Value: anomaly in the number of the multiple small droplets of triglycerides found in brown adipocytes

Subject: abnormal brown fat cell size
Value: anomaly in the size of fat cells from the thermogenic form of adipose tissue

Subject: decreased brown fat cell size
Value: reduction in the size of fat cells from the thermogenic form of adipose tissue

Subject: decreased brown fat lipid droplet number
Value: reduction in the number of the multiple small droplets of triglycerides found in brown adipocytes

Subject: increased brown fat lipid droplet number
Value: increase in the number of the multiple small droplets of triglycerides found in brown adipocytes

Subject: failure of Mullerian duct regression
Value: failure of the transient embryonic paramesonephric ducts, which normally develop into the oviduct, uterus, cervix and upper vagina in the female, to regress in the male; persistence of Mullerian ducts is typically consistent with a loss of anti-Mullerian hormone signaling and may allow development of the female reproductive tract in males

Subject: dilated efferent ductules of testis
Value: an expansion in the volume or area of the lumen of the small seminal ducts that lead from the testis to the head of the epididymis, usually with an increase in contained fluid

Subject: increased prepulse inhibition
Value: increase in the ability of a relatively mild stimulus to suppress the response to a strong, startle-eliciting stimulus

Subject: decreased prepulse inhibition
Value: decrease in the ability of a relatively mild stimulus to suppress the response to a strong, startle-eliciting stimulus

Subject: abnormal pancreatic duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the excretory duct of the exocrine pancreas that collects fluid containing digestive enzymes and transports it to the duodenum

Subject: dilated pancreatic duct
Value: an increase in volume of the luminal space of the excretory duct of the exocrine pancreas that collects fluid containing digestive enzymes and transports it to the duodenum

Subject: abnormal pancreatic acinus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the secretory units of the exocrine pancreas, where fluid containing digestive enzymes is produced; consists of a group of secretory cells surrounding a luminal space that connects to the pancreatic duct

Subject: abnormal pancreatic acinar cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the secretory cells of the exocrine pancreas that produce fluid containing digestive enzymes

Subject: abnormal pancreatic acinar cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the secretory cells of the exocrine pancreas that produce fluid containing digestive enzymes

Subject: pancreas necrosis
Value: morphological changes resulting from pathological death of pancreas tissue; usually due to irreversible damage

Subject: decreased pancreatic acinar cell number
Value: reduced number of the secretory cells of the exocrine pancreas that produce fluid containing digestive enzymes

Subject: pancreatic acinar cell atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the pancreatic acinar cells associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: increased pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of an adenocarcinoma that arises from the pancreatic ducts, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of noninvasive pancreatic duct lesions that affect smaller caliber ducts and do not involve the main pancreatic duct, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased pancreas tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplams in the pancreas occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: pancreatic acinar hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the secretory units of the exocrine pancreas, where fluid containing digestive enzymes is produced, usually due to a decreased cell number

Subject: pancreatic acinar hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size of the secretory units of the exocrine pancreas, where fluid containing digestive enzymes is produced, usually due to an increased cell number

Subject: absent pancreatic acini
Value: absence of the secretory units of the exocrine pancreas, where fluid containing digestive enzymes is produced; consists of a group of secretory cells surrounding a luminal space that connects to the pancreatic duct

Subject: ectopic pancreatic acinar cells
Value: abnormal position of one or more of the secretory cells of the exocrine pancreas that produce fluid containing digestive enzymes

Subject: absent pancreatic acinar cells
Value: absence of the secretory cells of the exocrine pancreas that produce fluid containing digestive enzymes

Subject: increased pancreatic acinar cell number
Value: increased number of the secretory cells of the exocrine pancreas that produce fluid containing digestive enzymes

Subject: abnormal pancreatic acinar cell zymogen granule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a membrane-bounded, cytoplasmic secretory granule found in pancreatic acinar cells and contains inactive digestive enzyme precursors

Subject: pancreatic acinar cell zymogen granule accumulation
Value: a gradually increasing number of membrane-bounded, cytoplasmic secretory granules found in pancreatic acinar cells that contain inactive digestive enzyme precursors

Subject: absent pancreatic acinar cell zymogen granule
Value: absence of a membrane-bounded, cytoplasmic secretory granule found in pancreatic acinar cells and contains inactive digestive enzyme precursors

Subject: absent pancreatic duct
Value: absence of the excretory duct of the exocrine pancreas that collects fluid containing digestive enzymes and transports it to the duodenum

Subject: exocrine pancreas atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of the acinar gland portion of the pancreas that secretes digestive enzymes, associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: abnormal endocrine pancreas morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the smaller portion of the pancreas that secretes a number of hormones into the blood stream that are produced by the cells in the islets of Langerhans

Subject: abnormal pancreatic islet number
Value: anomaly in the number of the clusters of hormone-producing cells that are scattered throughout the pancreas

Subject: increased pancreatic islet number
Value: increase in the number of the clusters of hormone-producing cells that are scattered throughout the pancreas

Subject: decreased pancreatic islet number
Value: reduction in the number of the clusters of hormone-producing cells that are scattered throughout the pancreas

Subject: pancreatic islet hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or decreased size of the clusters of hormone-producing cells that are scattered throughout the pancreas, usually due an decreased number of cells

Subject: abnormal pancreatic islet size
Value: anomaly in the size of the clusters of hormone-producing cells that are scattered throughout the pancreas

Subject: enlarged pancreatic islets
Value: increase in the size of the clusters of hormone-producing cells that are scattered throughout the pancreas

Subject: small pancreatic islets
Value: decrease in the size of the clusters of hormone-producing cells that are scattered throughout the pancreas

Subject: absent pancreatic islets
Value: absence of the clusters of hormone-producing cells that are scattered throughout the pancreas

Subject: absent pancreatic beta cells
Value: absence of the cells of the pancreas that secrete insulin

Subject: abnormal pancreatic beta cell differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce the cells that secrete insulin and are located towards the center of the islets of Langerhans in the pancreas, and/or accumulation of pancreatic beta cell precursors

Subject: increased pancreatic alpha cell number
Value: increase in the number of the cells of the pancreas that secrete glucagon

Subject: decreased pancreatic alpha cell number
Value: reduction in the number of the cells of the pancreas that secrete glucagon

Subject: absent pancreatic alpha cells
Value: absence of the cells of the pancreas that secrete glucagon

Subject: abnormal pancreatic alpha cell differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce the cells of the pancreas that secrete glucagon, and/or accumulation of pancreatic alpha cell precursors

Subject: increased pancreatic delta cell number
Value: increased number of the cells found in the pancreas that secrete somatostatin

Subject: decreased pancreatic delta cell number
Value: reduced number of the cells found in the pancreas that secrete somatostatin

Subject: absent pancreatic delta cells
Value: absence of the cells found in the pancreas that secrete somatostatin

Subject: abnormal pancreatic delta cell differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce the cells found in the pancreas that secrete somatostatin, and/or accumulation of pancreatic delta cell precursors

Subject: abnormal PP cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the polygonal pancreatic polypeptide producing cells in the islets of Langerhans in the pancreas

Subject: increased PP cell number
Value: increased number of the polygonal pancreatic polypeptide producing cells in the islets of Langerhans in the pancreas

Subject: decreased PP cell number
Value: reduced number of the polygonal pancreatic polypeptide producing cells in the islets of Langerhans in the pancreas

Subject: absent PP cells
Value: absence of the polygonal pancreatic polypeptide producing cells in the islets of Langerhans in the pancreas

Subject: abnormal PP cell differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce the polygonal pancreatic polypeptide producing cells in the islets of Langerhans in the pancreas, and/or accumulation of PP cell precursors

Subject: abnormal pancreatic epsilon cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the endocrine cells found in the Islets of Langerhans that produce the hormone ghrelin

Subject: increased pancreatic epsilon cell number
Value: increase in the number of the endocrine cells found in the Islets of Langerhans that produce the hormone ghrelin

Subject: decreased pancreatic epsilon cell number
Value: reduction in the number of the endocrine cells found in the Islets of Langerhans that produce the hormone ghrelin

Subject: absent pancreatic epsilon cells
Value: absence of the endocrine cells found in the Islets of Langerhans that produce the hormone ghrelin

Subject: abnormal pancreatic epsilon cell differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce the endocrine cells found in the Islets of Langerhans that produce the hormone ghrelin, and/or accumulation of pancreatic epsilon cell precursors

Subject: abnormal pancreatic epsilon cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the endocrine cells found in the Islets of Langerhans that produce the hormone ghrelin

Subject: abnormal PP cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the polygonal pancreatic polypeptide producing cells in the islets of Langerhans in the pancreas

Subject: abnormal pancreatic ghrelin secretion
Value: anomaly in the production and/or regulated release from pancreatic epsilon cells of a 28-amino acid, acylated, orexigenic peptide that acts centrally to stimulate growth hormone secretion and food intake, and peripherally to regulate energy homeostasis; it is cleaved from a large precursor protein, known as appetite-regulating hormone or motilin-related peptide, which contains both ghrelin and obestatin

Subject: abnormal pancreatic polypeptide secretion
Value: anomaly in the production and/or regulated release of the 36-amino acid pancreatic hormone that is secreted mainly by endocrine cells found at the periphery of the islets of Langerhans in response to ingestions, and regulates gastric secretion, gastric emptying, pancreatic enzyme secretion, and appetite

Subject: abnormal male genitalia morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the masculine organs of reproduction or generation, external or internal

Subject: abnormal external male genitalia morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the external masculine genital organs, including the penis and scrotum

Subject: enlarged external male genitalia
Value: increased size of the external masculine genital organs, including the penis and scrotum

Subject: external male genitalia atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of the external masculine genital organs, associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: small external male genitalia
Value: reduced size of the external masculine genital organs

Subject: external male genitalia hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the external masculine genital organs, usually due to a reduced number of cells

Subject: absent external male genitalia
Value: absence of the external masculine genital organs, including the penis and scrotum

Subject: abnormal internal male genitalia morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the internal masculine genital organs, including the testes, epididymides, deferent ducts, seminal vesicles, prostate, ejaculatory ducts, and bulbourethral glands

Subject: absent internal male genitalia
Value: absence of the internal masculine genital organs, including the testes, epididymides, deferent ducts, seminal vesicles, prostate, ejaculatory ducts, and bulbourethral glands

Subject: internal male genitalia hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the internal masculine genital organs, usually due to a reduced number of cells

Subject: abnormal female genitalia morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the feminine organs of reproduction or generation, external or internal

Subject: abnormal internal female genitalia morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the internal feminine genital organs, including the ovaries, uterine tubes, uterus, uterine cervix, and vagina

Subject: absent internal female genitalia
Value: absence of the internal feminine genital organs, including the ovaries, uterine tubes, uterus, uterine cervix, and vagina

Subject: absent external female genitalia
Value: absence of the external feminine genital organs, collectively known as the vulva

Subject: vulva atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of the external feminine genital organs, collectively known as the vulva, associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: absent male inguinal canal
Value: absence of the passage in the lower abdominal wall through which the spermatic cord, nerves and vessels normally pass from the pelvic cavity to the scrotum

Subject: vas deferens hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the vas deferens, usually due to a reduced number of cells

Subject: absent uterine horn
Value: absence of either one of the pair of tubular extensions from the uterine body where the uterus and the uterine tubes meet

Subject: abnormal peritoneum morphology
Value: <any structural anomaly of the serous sac, consisting of mesothelium and a thin external layer of irregular connective tissue, that lines the abdominopelvic cavity and covers most of the viscera contained therein; it forms two sacs: the peritoneal (or greater) sac and the omental bursa (lesser sac) connected by the omental foramen>

Subject: abnormal peritoneal vaginal process morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the peritoneal diverticulum in the embryonic lower anterior abdominal wall that traverses the inguinal canal; in the male it forms the tunica vaginalis testis and normally loses its connection with the peritoneal cavity; a persistent processus vaginalis in the female is known as the canal of Nuck

Subject: absent peritoneal vaginal process
Value: absence of the peritoneal diverticulum in the embryonic lower anterior abdominal wall that traverses the inguinal canal

Subject: increased prostate intraepithelial neoplasia incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of a non-invasive neoplastic proliferation of the epithelial cells that line the acini and the ducts of the prostate gland

Subject: increased prostate gland adenocarcinoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of a malignant neoplasm arising from prostate tissue

Subject: uterus adenomyosis
Value: a benign invasion of myometrium by endometrial tissue

Subject: increased uterus tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of abnormal rapidly proliferating cells in the uterus, usually in the form of a distinct mass, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased uterus carcinoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of malignant neoplasms derived from uterine epithelial cells, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: absent endometrium
Value: absence of the glandular mucous membrane lining of the uterine cavity that is hormonally responsive during the estrous/menstrual cycle and during pregnancy

Subject: abnormal uterine cervix size
Value: anomaly in the size of the lower opening of the uterus to the vagina

Subject: small uterine cervix
Value: reduced size of the lower opening of the uterus to the vagina

Subject: uterine cervix hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the cervix, usually due to a reduced number of cells

Subject: uterine cervix inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the cervix

Subject: abnormal neurohypophysis median eminence morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the raised area at the infundibular region of the neurohypophysis where the secretions of the hypothalamic neurons (releasing and inhibiting regulatory hormones) collect before entering the capillary network of hypophyseal portal system

Subject: abnormal sperm head morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the head segment of the sperm cell which contains the nucleus with densely coiled chromatin fibers, and is surrounded anteriorly by the acrosome which contains enzymes used for penetrating the female egg

Subject: detached acrosome
Value: detachment or loss of adhesion of the acrosome cap from the sperm head nucleus

Subject: abnormal sperm nucleus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the sperm head nucleus, including an abnormal nuclear shape or defects in the compaction of nuclear chromatin

Subject: enlarged sperm head
Value: increased size of the head segment of the sperm cell

Subject: absent sperm head
Value: absence of the head segment of the sperm cell

Subject: small sperm head
Value: reduced size of the head segment of the sperm cell

Subject: pinhead sperm
Value: a sperm head that is unusually oblong in shape and much smaller than normal; typically, pinhead sperm result when the centrioles from which the sperm tails develop are not correctly aligned opposite the developing acrosome so that sperm heads are lost and absorbed during epididymal transit

Subject: kinked sperm flagellum
Value: a sharp bend or zigzag in the sperm tail

Subject: coiled sperm flagellum
Value: abnormal twisting of the sperm flagellum into coils or spirals

Subject: short sperm flagellum
Value: decreased length of the whiplike posterior filiform portion of the spermatozoon that provides sperm motility

Subject: elongated sperm flagellum
Value: increased length of the whiplike posterior filiform portion of the spermatozoon that provides sperm motility

Subject: thick sperm flagellum
Value: increased thickness of the whiplike posterior filiform portion of the spermatozoon that provides sperm motility

Subject: thin sperm flagellum
Value: reduced thickness of the whiplike posterior filiform portion of the spermatozoon that provides sperm motility

Subject: hairpin sperm flagellum
Value: a structural alteration where the sperm flagellum becomes bent back (folded) on itself to form a hairpin (loop) structure; a sharp hairpin-like bend formation can disrupt the axial structures and cause the sperm tail to become kinked

Subject: abnormal acid-activated cation-mediated receptor currents
Value: change in the measured amplitude, current density or duration of response to stimulation of acid-activated cation-mediated receptors

Subject: caudal rachischisis
Value: congenitial fissure of the vertebral column at the caudal end of the body

Subject: pale spleen
Value: spleen lacks normal reddish coloration; often occurs with a bloodless or reduced vasculature condition

Subject: meteorism
Value: condition in which excess gas accumulates in the gastrointestinal tract or peritoneal cavity, often resulting in abdominal distention, excess flatulence and/or belching

Subject: small caput epididymis
Value: decrease in the average size of the head of the epididymis

Subject: enlarged caput epididymis
Value: increase in the average size of the head of the epididymis

Subject: abnormal appendicular skeleton morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bones of the limbs, shoulder and pelvic girdles

Subject: enlarged endometrial glands
Value: increase in the average size of the simple or branched tubular glands located in the mucous membrane of the uterus

Subject: absent urinary bladder
Value: absence of the distensible musculomembranous organ that serves to collect and store urine excreted by the kidneys

Subject: abnormal sympathetic neuron physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of any of the neurons of the part of the autonomic nervous system that innervates smooth muscle, cardiac muscle and glands and mediates the body's response to stressful situations

Subject: disorganized pancreatic islets
Value: derangement of the normal pattern of the hormone-producing cells within an islet; normally, the beta cells occupy the central portion of the islet and are surrounded by a corona of alpha and delta cells

Subject: degranulated pancreatic beta cells
Value: insulin-secreting cells of the pancreas do not contain vesicles containing insulin

Subject: enlarged corpus epididymis
Value: increase in the average size of the body of the epididymis

Subject: dilated seminiferous tubules
Value: the luminal space of the seminiferous tubules is increased in volume or area, usually with an increase in contained fluid

Subject: abnormal thymocyte apoptosis
Value: change in the timing or the number of immature T cells located in the thymus that are undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal vestibular saccule duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the saccular portion of the utriculosaccular duct that normally extends from the sacculus to the endolymphatic duct

Subject: abnormal utricle duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the utricular portion of the utriculosaccular duct that normally extends from the utriculus to the endolymphatic duct

Subject: abnormal utricle valve morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the utriculo-endolymphatic (UE) valve which is located in the antero-inferior wall of the utricle at the orifice of the utricular duct and serves to regulate endolymph volume in the endolymphatic sac, the utricle and the canals

Subject: absent semicircular canal ampulla
Value: absence of the spherical enlargement at the base of each semicircular canal where they connect with the utricle, containing the crista ampullaris which detects movement of the fluid within the canals

Subject: abnormal eyelid fusion
Value: anomaly in the process by which the upper and lower eyelids are joined during development

Subject: failure of eyelid fusion
Value: the upper and lower thin folds of skin and muscle that cover the exposed portion of the eye do not fuse together during development; normally fused by E17 in the mouse

Subject: delayed eyelid fusion
Value: later than average time of the joining of the upper and lower thin folds of skin and muscle that cover the exposed portion of the eye

Subject: abnormal mesendoderm development
Value: failure or abnormality in the formation of the embryonic cell layer that gives rise to both the endoderm and mesoderm

Subject: abnormal cerebellum fissure morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the deep furrows which divide the lobules of the cerebellum, including the postcentral, primary and secondary furrows

Subject: absent cerebellum fissure
Value: absence of the deep furrows which divide the lobules of the cerebellum, including the postcentral, primary and secondary furrows

Subject: decreased fat cell size
Value: reduction in the size of fat-storing cells found mostly in the abdominal cavity and subcutaneous tissue of mammals

Subject: abnormal guard hair length
Value: anomaly in the length of the long, straight truncal hairs that contain two air cells in the medulla

Subject: increased guard hair length
Value: increase in the length of the long, straight truncal hairs that contain two air cells in the medulla

Subject: decreased guard hair length
Value: reduction in the length of the long, straight truncal hairs that contain two air cells in the medulla

Subject: abnormal hair shaft melanin granule shape
Value: the form of pigment polymers in the hair shaft differs compared to controls

Subject: buphthalmos
Value: abnormal enlargement of the eye that is usually congenital and attended by symptoms of glaucoma

Subject: bruising
Value: an injury to biological tissue in which the capillaries are damaged, allowing blood to seep into the surrounding tissue; it should not be confused with ecchymosis, though the terms are related

Subject: ecchymosis
Value: an ecchymosis is a spot caused by loss of blood from a vessel; it implies a larger size than a petechiae, and has a more diffuse border than purpura; an ecchymosis can be caused by a bruise (which implies trauma), but can also be caused by bleeding diathesis

Subject: increased brain tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of abnormal rapidly proliferating cells in the brain, usually in the form of a distinct mass, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: abnormal bone marrow cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of any of the cells found in the bone marrow

Subject: abnormal activated sperm motility
Value: any anomaly in the type of sperm mobility that is observed in freshly ejaculated sperm and is thought to help propel the sperm through the female reproductive tract to the oviduct; normally, the flagellum of an activated sperm generates a symmetrical, lower amplitude waveform that drives the sperm in a relatively straight line

Subject: decreased activated sperm motility
Value: loss or reduction of the activated type of sperm mobility, resulting in immotile sperm that are generally unable to reach the uterotubal junction; decreases in activated sperm motility may result in reduced male fertility

Subject: abnormal hyperactivated sperm motility
Value: any anomaly in the type of sperm motility that is observed in most sperm recovered from the site of fertilization and is thought to help sperm detach from the oviductal epithelium, reach the site of fertilization, and penetrate the cumulus and zona pellucida of the oocyte; normally, once sperm from most species become hyperactivated, the flagellar beat becomes asymmetrical and higher amplitude, resulting in circular or figure-eight trajectories

Subject: decreased hyperactivated sperm motility
Value: loss or reduction of the hyperactivated type of sperm mobility, impairing the ability of sperm to reach the site of fertilization and to penetrate the oocyte vestments; a block in hyperactivated motility may also impair the ability of a sperm to fertilize an oocyte in vitro

Subject: decreased gonadal fat pad weight
Value: less than average weight of the encapsulated adipose tissue associated with the ovaries or testes

Subject: abnormal sympathetic neuron innervation pattern
Value: any changes in the placement, morphology or number of nerve fibers to sympathetic termini

Subject: increased gonadal fat pad weight
Value: greater than average weight of the encapsulated adipose tissue associated with the ovaries or testes

Subject: increased abdominal fat pad weight
Value: greater than average weight of the encapsulated adipose tissue in the abdomen

Subject: decreased abdominal fat pad weight
Value: less than average weight of the encapsulated adipose tissue in the abdomen

Subject: increased epididymal fat pad weight
Value: greater than average weight of the encapsulated adipose tissue associated with the epididymis

Subject: decreased epididymal fat pad weight
Value: less than average weight of the encapsulated adipose tissue associated with the epididymis

Subject: increased femoral fat pad weight
Value: greater than average weight of the encapsulated adipose tissue associated with the femur

Subject: decreased femoral fat pad weight
Value: less than average weight of the encapsulated adipose tissue associated with the femur

Subject: increased inguinal fat pad weight
Value: greater than average weight of the encapsulated adipose tissue found in the groin

Subject: decreased inguinal fat pad weight
Value: less than average weight of the encapsulated adipose tissue found in the groin

Subject: increased interscapular fat pad weight
Value: greater than average weight of the encapsulated adipose tissue located between the scapulae

Subject: decreased interscapular fat pad weight
Value: less than average weight of the encapsulated adipose tissue located between the scapulae

Subject: increased mammary fat pad weight
Value: greater than average weight of the encapsulated adipose tissue associated with the mammary gland

Subject: decreased mammary fat pad weight
Value: less than average weight of the encapsulated adipose tissue associated with the mammary gland

Subject: increased mesenteric fat pad weight
Value: greater than average weight of the encapsulated adipose tissue associated with the mesentery

Subject: decreased mesenteric fat pad weight
Value: less than average weight of the encapsulated adipose tissue associated with the mesentery

Subject: increased parametrial fat pad weight
Value: greater than average weight of the encapsulated adipose tissue associated with the extension of the subserous coat of the uterus laterally between the layers of the broad ligament

Subject: decreased parametrial fat pad weight
Value: less than average weight of the encapsulated adipose tissue associated with the extension of the subserous coat of the uterus laterally between the layers of the broad ligament

Subject: increased renal fat pad weight
Value: greater than average weight of the encapsulated adipose tissue associated with the kidney

Subject: decreased renal fat pad weight
Value: less than average weight of the encapsulated adipose tissue associated with the kidney

Subject: increased retroperitoneal fat pad weight
Value: greater than average weight of the encapsulated adipose tissue found on the dorsal side of the peritoneum

Subject: decreased retroperitoneal fat pad weight
Value: less than average weight of the encapsulated adipose tissue found on the dorsal side of the peritoneum

Subject: increased uterine fat pad weight
Value: greater than average weight of the encapsulated adipose tissue associated with the uterus

Subject: decreased uterine fat pad weight
Value: less than average weight of the encapsulated adipose tissue associated with the uterus

Subject: increased adenocarcinoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of a malignant neoplasm of epithelial cells in a glandular or glandular-like pattern

Subject: increased small intestine adenocarcinoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of a malignant neoplasm of epithelial cells in the small intestine

Subject: increased large intestine adenocarcinoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of a malignant neoplasm of epithelial cells in the large intestine

Subject: increased duodenum adenocarcinoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of a malignant neoplasm of epithelial cells in the duodenum

Subject: increased jejunum adenocarcinoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of a malignant neoplasm of epithelial cells in the jejunum

Subject: increased cecum adenocarcinoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of a malignant neoplasm of epithelial cells in the cecum

Subject: increased colon adenocarcinoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of a malignant neoplasm of epithelial cells in the colon

Subject: increased rectum adenocarcinoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of a malignant neoplasm of epithelial cells in the rectum

Subject: increased anal adenocarcinoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of a malignant neoplasm of epithelial cells in the anal canal

Subject: increased follicular lymphoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of malignant lymphoma arising from lymphoid follicular B cells which may be small or large

Subject: increased splenic marginal zone lymphoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of neoplasms arising from the B cell-rich zones of the spleen

Subject: increased small lymphocytic lymphoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of lymphocytic leukemia where the lymphocytes are not increased in the peripheral blood, but lymph nodes are enlarged and other lymphoid tissue or bone marrow is infiltrated by small lymphocytes

Subject: increased lymphoblastic lymphoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of diffuse lymphoma with supradiaphragmatic distribution and T lymphocytes having convoluted nuclei

Subject: increased histiocytic sarcoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of malignant tumors derived from histiocytes in a given population in a given time period

Subject: increased splenocyte apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of spleen cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal spleen development
Value: aberrant formation or incomplete differentiation of the organ that filters blood and stores red corpuscles and platelets

Subject: absent hippocampal fimbria
Value: absence of the flattened band of efferent fibers arising from the subiculum and medial border of the hippocampus, which eventually thickens to form the fornix and fibers of the hippocampal commissure

Subject: necrospermia
Value: condition in which spermatozoa in seminal fluid are dead or motionless

Subject: absent maternal crouching
Value: females do not assume a position over young that facilitates suckling behavior

Subject: abnormal maternal grooming
Value: females show an anomaly in eliciting the cleaning or tactile stimulus level necessary to initiate nursing by offspring

Subject: delayed heart looping
Value: late onset of the initiation and/or completion of looping of the primitive heart tube

Subject: abnormal primitive pit morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small depression in the primitive streak that is caudal to the primitive node where the cells of the epiblast initially begin to invaginate during early embryogenesis

Subject: abnormal primitive groove morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the shallow valley that extends along the length of the primitive streak

Subject: absent primitive node
Value: absence of the regional thickening of cells at the rostral tip of the vertebrate primitive streak through which gastrulating cells migrate anteriorally to form tissues in the future head and neck; this region organizes the formation of the three embryonic layers and establishes the longitudinal axis and the polarity of the embryo

Subject: abnormal splenocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a cell of the spleen

Subject: abnormal splenocyte physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of a cell of the spleen

Subject: abnormal splenocyte proliferation
Value: anomaly in the ability of a splenocyte cell population to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: decreased splenocyte proliferation
Value: reduction in the expansion rate of a splenocyte cell population by cell division

Subject: increased splenocyte proliferation
Value: increase in the expansion rate of a splenocyte cell population by cell division

Subject: abnormal splenocyte number
Value: deviation from the expected number of cells of the spleen

Subject: increased splenocyte number
Value: increase in the expected number of cells of the spleen

Subject: decreased splenocyte number
Value: reduction in the expected number of cells of the spleen

Subject: abnormal splenocyte apoptosis
Value: deviation in the number of spleen cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: decreased splenocyte apoptosis
Value: reduction in the number of spleen cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: enlarged gallbladder
Value: increased size of the gall bladder, the organ that serves as a storage reservoir for bile

Subject: dilated gallbladder
Value: abnormal distention of the gall bladder due to accumulation of fluid or bile

Subject: abnormal ovulation cycle
Value: any anomaly in the type of sexual cycle seen in female mammals, with physiologic changes in the endometrium that recur at regular intervals during the reproductive years

Subject: abnormal trabecular bone thickness
Value: anomaly in the width of bone that has a lattice-like or spongy structure

Subject: decreased trabecular bone thickness
Value: thinner than normal bone with a lattice-like or spongy structure

Subject: increased trabecular bone thickness
Value: thicker than normal bone with a lattice-like or spongy structure

Subject: abnormal urine pH
Value: any anomaly in urinary pH, indicating alterations in urine acidity or alkalinity

Subject: increased urine pH
Value: increased urine alkalinity

Subject: decreased urine pH
Value: increased urine acidity

Subject: thin hair shaft
Value: the average diameter of coat hair is less than the average diameter of hair from normal individuals

Subject: impaired spacing of implantation sites
Value: in organisms which give birth to multiple offspring in one litter, blastocysts fail to implant at intervals conducive to the formation of a normal enveloping membrane or decidua for each conceptus from the epithelial tissue of the endometrium lining of the uterus

Subject: twin decidual capsule
Value: two embryos share one decidual membrane

Subject: emprosthotonos
Value: a form of tetanic spasm in which the head and feet are drawn forward and the spine arches backward

Subject: increased liver triglyceride level
Value: greater concentration of naturally occurring esters of three fatty acids and glycerol in the liver; triglycerides are widespread in adipose tissue, commonly circulate in the blood in the form of lipoproteins, and are involved in the process of bidirectional transference of adipose fat and blood glucose with the liver

Subject: decreased liver triglyceride level
Value: reduced concentration of naturally occurring esters of three fatty acids and glycerol in the liver; triglycerides are widespread in adipose tissue, commonly circulate in the blood in the form of lipoproteins, and are involved in the process of bidirectional transference of adipose fat and blood glucose with the liverower than normal concentration of triacylglycerols in the liver

Subject: abnormal seizure response to inducing agent
Value: anomaly in the seizure activity response to an agent that normally can induce uncontrolled electrical activity in the brain, producing a physical convulsion and/or minor change in physical behavior

Subject: environmentally induced seizures
Value: seizure activity response due to changes in ambient habitat including room temperature, lighting, sounds, touching, and/ or moving cage

Subject: endometrium atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of the uterine endometrium, associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: endometrium inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the endometrium

Subject: abnormal primordial ovarian follicle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the ovarian follicle in which the primary oocyte is surrounded by a single layer of flattened follicular cells; primordial follicles are indiscernible to the naked eye and develop to primary, secondary, and finally mature vesicular follicles

Subject: abnormal primary ovarian follicle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the ovarian follicle prior to the appearance of an antrum, normally marked by developmental changes in the primary oocyte and follicular cells so that the latter form one or more layers of cuboidal or columnar cells; the follicle becomes surrounded by a sheath of stroma, the theca

Subject: abnormal secondary ovarian follicle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the ovarian follicle in which the primary oocyte attains its full size and is surrounded by an extracellular glycoprotein layer (zona pellucida) that separates it from a peripheral layer of follicular cells permeated by one or more fluid-filled antra; the primary oocyte occupies the cumulus oophorus while the theca of the follicle develops into internal and external layers

Subject: abnormal mature ovarian follicle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the ovarian follicle that is ready for ovulation and presents a blanched spot (the follicular stigma) where the graafian follicle is about to rupture on the surface of the ovary; a first maturation (meiotic) division of the primary oocyte usually occurs just prior to rupture of the follicle

Subject: abnormal theca folliculi
Value: any structural anomaly in the envelope of condensed connective tissue surrounding a secondary ovarian follicle; the theca folliculi are divided into two layers, an internal vascular layer (tunica interna) and an external fibrous layer (tunica externa)

Subject: abnormal theca interna
Value: any structural anomaly in the inner cellular and vascular layer of the theca of a secondary ovarian follicle; evidence indicates that the epithelioid cells produce androgens and contribute to the formation of the corpus luteum after ovulation

Subject: abnormal theca externa
Value: any structural anomaly in the external fibrous layer of the theca of a secondary ovarian follicle; the theca externa contains abundant collagen and is mainly supportive

Subject: absent theca folliculi
Value: absence of the internal, external or both layers of the sheath of stroma surrounding a secondary ovarian follicle

Subject: abnormal theca cell number
Value: abnormal numbers of cells in the sheath of stroma surrounding a secondary ovarian follicle

Subject: decreased theca cell number
Value: fewer than normal numbers of cells in the sheath of stroma surrounding a secondary ovarian follicle

Subject: increased theca cell number
Value: greater than normal numbers of cells in the sheath of stroma surrounding a secondary ovarian follicle

Subject: abnormal cumulus oophorus morphology
Value: atypical formation of or inability to produce a mass of epithelial granulosa cells around the oocyte in the maturing Graafian follicle; the cumulus oophorus begins to expand dramatically when cumulus cells are induced to synthesize hyaluronic acid which aggregates in a viscous intercellular matrix

Subject: abnormal cumulus expansion
Value: anomaly in the ability of the cumulus cells to synthesize and accumulate hyaluronan into an extracellular matrix (ECM), which provides an essential microenvironment for oocyte fertilization; this expanded ECM binds the oocyte and the cumulus cells together, protects the oocyte from the proteolytic and mechanical stresses during extrusion, and allows sperm binding, penetration, and fertilization

Subject: absent cumulus expansion
Value: complete inability of the cumulus cells to secrete an extensive extracellular matrix required for successful fertilization

Subject: thin zona pellucida
Value: reduced thickness of the solid transparent outer membrane that surrounds the developing ovum and embryo prior to implantation

Subject: abnormal manchette morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the conic array of microtubules that invests the posterior nucleus of a spermatid, and is believed to play a role in definitive posterior head-shaping events during spermiogenesis

Subject: ectopic manchette
Value: abnormal position of the conic array of microtubules that normally invests the posterior nucleus of a spermatid

Subject: abnormal endoplasmic reticulum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of irregular network of unit membranes, visible only by electron microscopy, that occurs in the cytoplasm of many eukaryotic cells

Subject: abnormal foot pigmentation
Value: anomaly in the coloration of the foot due to changes in the amount, shape, or distribution of cells producing pigment

Subject: abnormal prostate gland ventral lobe morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the rodent prostate lobe that is located below the ventral aspect of the bladder neck

Subject: abnormal prostate gland dorsolateral lobe morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the rodent prostate lobe that lies in the triangular area between urethra and seminal vesicle

Subject: abnormal cardiac jelly morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the gelatinous noncellular material between the endothelial lining and the myocardial layer of the developing heart

Subject: cardiac valve regurgitation
Value: the backward reflux of blood through a cardiac valve, due to insufficiency caused by disease, aging or congenital malformation

Subject: abnormal dermal pigmentation
Value: anomaly in the coloration of the dermal layer of the skin due to changes in the amount, shape, or distribution of cells producing pigment

Subject: abnormal dermal melanocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cells that produce pigment in the dermis

Subject: abnormal epidermal pigmentation
Value: anomaly in the coloration of the epidermal layer of the skin due to changes in the amount, shape, or distribution of cells producing pigment

Subject: abnormal epidermal melanocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cells that produce pigment in the epidermis

Subject: abnormal extracutaneous pigmentation
Value: anomaly in the coloration of organs and tissues excluding the integument due to changes in the amount, shape, or distribution of cells producing pigment

Subject: abnormal otic pigmentation
Value: any anomaly in the pigment or pigment-producing cells of the inner ear resulting in abnormal melanoblast numbers, distribution, or pigment during development

Subject: abnormal leptomeninges pigmentation
Value: any anomaly in the coloring of the two innermost layers of the meninges, including the pia mater and the arachnoid, due to changes in the amount, shape, or distribution of cells producing pigment

Subject: retinal gliosis
Value: increased proliferation of neuroglia in a damaged area of the retina that may lead to the formation of scar tissue

Subject: abnormal resting posture
Value: atypical intentionally or habitually assumed position of the limbs compared to normal carriage when the body is inactive

Subject: increased uterine NK cell number
Value: increased cell number of a natural killer cell subset that is found in the decidual of the uterus, is CD56-high, Galectin-1-positive and CD16-negative, and is the most abundant immune cell type in the decidual during the first trimester of pregnancy

Subject: increased nucleated erythrocyte cell number
Value: presence of increased numbers of nucleated red blood cells at stages when these cells are normally replaced by mature, enucleated, red blood cells

Subject: small endometrial glands
Value: decrease in the average size of the simple or branched tubular glands located in the mucous membrane of the uterus

Subject: increased trophoblast giant cell number
Value: greater than normal number of cells of the extraembryonic cell layer that contributes to the placenta

Subject: abnormal skeletal muscle fiber size
Value: anomaly in the size of the large multinucleated cells that make up the skeletal muscles

Subject: increased skeletal muscle fiber size
Value: increase in the size of the large multinucleated cells that make up the skeletal muscles

Subject: decreased skeletal muscle fiber size
Value: decrease in the size of the large multinucleated cells that make up the skeletal muscles

Subject: increased skeletal muscle fiber diameter
Value: increased width of the cross-sectional distance that extends from one lateral edge of a skeletal muscle fiber, through its center and to the opposite lateral edge

Subject: decreased skeletal muscle fiber diameter
Value: decreased width of the cross-sectional distance that extends from one lateral edge of a skeletal muscle fiber, through its center and to the opposite lateral edge

Subject: increased variability of skeletal muscle fiber size
Value: greater range or dispersion within a distribution of skeletal muscle fiber size within a muscle compared to controls

Subject: centrally nucleated skeletal muscle fibers
Value: cell nuclei are located at a position in the center of the skeletal myofiber, instead of their normal location at the periphery of the fiber; may be indicative of centronuclear myopathy

Subject: increased skeletal muscle fiber number
Value: increased number of the skeletal muscle fibers, the large multinucleated cells that make up the skeletal muscles

Subject: decreased skeletal muscle fiber number
Value: decreased number of the skeletal muscle fibers, the large multinucleated cells that make up the skeletal muscles

Subject: increased skeletal muscle fiber density
Value: increase in the number of skeletal muscle fibers in a given cross-sectional area of a skeletal muscle

Subject: decreased skeletal muscle fiber density
Value: decrease in the number of skeletal muscle fibers in a given cross-sectional area of a skeletal muscle

Subject: abnormal skeletal muscle fiber type ratio
Value: deviation from the standard ratios of fiber types in a given skeletal muscle compared to control samples

Subject: abnormal skeletal muscle satellite cell proliferation
Value: anomaly in the ability of unfused cells in skeltal muscle to undergo expansion by cell division, usually triggered by injury or disease

Subject: abnormal skeletal muscle fiber triad morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the skeletal muscle fiber structure comprised of the transverse tubule and the two associated terminal cisternae; each fiber normally has thousands of triads

Subject: skeletal muscle fiber degeneration
Value: pathological deterioration of skeletal muscle fiber tissue, often accompanied by loss of function

Subject: skeletal muscle fiber atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of skeletal muscle fibers associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes; occurs with age, immobilization, weightlessness, malnutrition or denervation

Subject: skeletal muscle fiber necrosis
Value: morphological changes resulting from pathological death of skeletal muscle fiber tissue; usually due to irreversible damage

Subject: skeletal muscle degeneration
Value: pathological deterioration of skeletal muscle tissue, often accompanied by loss of function

Subject: cardiac muscle degeneration
Value: pathological deterioration of cardiac muscle tissue, often accompanied by loss of function

Subject: skeletal muscle atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of skeletal muscle tissue associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes; occurs with age, immobilization, weightlessness, malnutrition or denervation

Subject: cardiac muscle atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of cardiac muscle tissue associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes; occurs with age, immobilization, weightlessness, malnutrition or denervation

Subject: skeletal muscle fibrosis
Value: formation of fibrous tissue within skeletal muscle as a result of repair or a reactive process

Subject: skeletal muscle endomysial fibrosis
Value: replacement of the layer of connective tissue that ensheaths a muscle fiber by fibrous tissue resulting in separation of individual fibers

Subject: increased gastrocnemius weight
Value: increase in the weight of the two-headed large muscle of the posterior portion of the lower hindleg, the most superficial of the calf muscles

Subject: decreased gastrocnemius weight
Value: reduction in the weight of the two-headed large muscle of the posterior portion of the lower hindleg, the most superficial of the calf muscles

Subject: increased extensor digitorum longus weight
Value: increase in the weight of the penniform muscle of the lateral front part of the leg responsible for extension of the toes and dorsiflexion of the ankle

Subject: decreased extensor digitorum longus weight
Value: reduction in the weight of the penniform muscle of the lateral front part of the leg responsible for extension of the toes and dorsiflexion of the ankle

Subject: increased soleus weight
Value: increase in the weight of the superficial flat broad muscle of the calf that is responsible for plantar flexion of the foot

Subject: decreased soleus weight
Value: reduction in the weight of the superficial flat broad muscle of the calf that is responsible for plantar flexion of the foot

Subject: increased tibialis anterior weight
Value: increase in the weight of the muscle of the shin that is responsible for dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot

Subject: decreased tibialis anterior weight
Value: redcution in the weight of the muscle of the shin that is responsible for dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot

Subject: decreased embryo weight
Value: <reduced weight of an embryo compared to littermates or other controls (sensu Mus: up to E14, or the completion of organogenesis)>

Subject: increased embryo weight
Value: <increase in the weight of an embryo compared to littermates or other controls (sensu Mus: up to E14, or the completion of organogenesis)>

Subject: decreased fetal weight
Value: <reduced weight of a fetus compared to controls (sensu Mus: from E14 through birth)>

Subject: increased fetal weight
Value: <increase in the weight of a fetus compared to controls (sensu Mus: from E14 through birth)>

Subject: polyovular ovarian follicle
Value: an ovarian follicle containing more than one oocyte (ovum)

Subject: paraparesis
Value: a weakness affecting lower or hind limbs

Subject: abnormal miniature inhibitory postsynaptic currents
Value: defect in the size or duration of spontaneous currents detected in postsynaptic cells that occur in the absence of an inhibitory impulse

Subject: fragmentation of sleep/wake states
Value: short bouts of sleep/wake stages with an increased number of transitions among these stages compared to controls

Subject: arytenoid and cricoid cartilage fusion
Value: union of the arytenoid and cricoid cartilages into one structure, when this fusion does not normally occur

Subject: cricoid and tracheal cartilage fusion
Value: union of the cricoid cartilage and one or more of the tracheal rings into one structure, when this fusion does not normally occur

Subject: increased myeloid sarcoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of a malignant tumor of immature myeloid cells, often associated with or preceeding granulocytic leukemia

Subject: increased myeloma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of a bone marrow cancer in which abnormal plasma cells multiply uncontrollably in the bone marrow and occasionally in other parts of the body

Subject: delayed skin barrier formation
Value: slowed progression in the establishment of the ability of the skin to regulate water loss

Subject: increased ovarian teratoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a usually benign tumor found in the ovary, occurring in a specific population in a given time period; ovarian teratomas are typically the result of an anomaly of oogenesis and typically contains a diversity of tissues often representing all organ systems e.g. hair, teeth, bone, thyroid, nerve tissue

Subject: parthenogenesis
Value: development of an egg into a diploid embryo without being fertilized

Subject: ovarian follicular cyst
Value: a sac filled with fluid that may develop when the structure containing the egg fails to break open at the time of ovulation

Subject: osteomalacia
Value: gradual softening and bending of the bones due to failure of osteoid tissue to calcify as a result of vitamin D deficiency or renal tubular dysfunction

Subject: abnormal platelet dense granule physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the specialized secretory organelles located in the small, irregularly shaped anuclear cells derived from fragmentation of precursor megakaryocytes that contain adenine nucleotides (ADP and ATP), ionized calcium, histamine, serotonin, and epinephrine

Subject: abnormal platelet ATP level
Value: anomaly in the amount of the major energy source adenosine triphosphate produced by dense bodies located in platelets

Subject: decreased platelet ATP level
Value: reduced concentration of the major energy source adenosine triphosphate produced by dense bodies located in platelets

Subject: increased platelet ATP level
Value: increased concentration of the major energy source adenosine triphosphate produced by dense bodies located in platelets

Subject: abnormal axon fasciculation
Value: anomaly in the process by which axons form into nerve fiber bundles

Subject: abnormal chromosomal synapsis
Value: any anomaly in the meiotic cell cycle process where side by side pairing and physical juxtaposition of homologous chromosomes is created during prophase I of meiosis; synapsis begins when the chromosome arms begin to pair from the clustered telomeres and ends when synaptonemal complex or linear element assembly is complete

Subject: abnormal synaptonemal complex
Value: an anomaly in the formation of the proteinaceous structure involved in the pairing of homologous chromosomes during first prophase of meiosis

Subject: enhanced contextual conditioning behavior
Value: increase in the ability of an animal to learn and remember an association between an aversive experience (the unconditioned stimulus (US), usually a shock) and the neutral, unchanging environment (the conditioned stimulus (CS), or the environmental context in this case)

Subject: impaired contextual conditioning behavior
Value: decrease in the ability of an animal to learn and remember an association between an aversive experience (the unconditioned stimulus (US), usually a shock) and the neutral, unchanging environment (the conditioned stimulus (CS), or the environmental context in this case)

Subject: enhanced cued conditioning behavior
Value: increase in the ability of an animal to learn and remember an association between an aversive experience (the unconditioned stimulus (US), usually a shock) and a neutral stimulus (the conditioned stimulus (CS), usually an auditory cue or light flash)

Subject: impaired cued conditioning behavior
Value: decrease in the ability of an animal to learn and remember an association between an aversive experience (the unconditioned stimulus (US), usually a shock) and a neutral stimulus (the conditioned stimulus (CS), usually an auditory cue or light flash)

Subject: whorled hair
Value: an area of hair growing opposite in direction to the rest of the hair, a curl or swirl

Subject: abnormal skeletal muscle size
Value: anomaly in the size of the striated muscle fibers connected at either or both extremities with the bony framework of the body

Subject: skeletal muscle hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size of the skeletal muscle, usually due an increased number of cells

Subject: skeletal muscle hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or decreased size of the skeletal muscle, usually due an decreased number of cells

Subject: skeletal muscle hypertrophy
Value: increase in the bulk size of the skeletal muscle due to cell enlargement

Subject: skeletal muscle hypotrophy
Value: decrease in the bulk size of the skeletal muscle due to cell shrinkage

Subject: abnormal pituitary infundibular stalk morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the apical portion of the tubular structure extending from the hypothalamus to the posterior lobe of the pituitary gland

Subject: abnormal gallbladder infundibulum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tapering portion of the gall bladder that narrows to form the neck and cystic duct

Subject: abnormal uterine tube infundibulum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the funnel-like expansion of the abdominal extremity of the uterine tube

Subject: abnormal magnocellular neurosecretory cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cells residing mainly in the hypothalamic supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei and in a number of smaller accessory cell groups between these two nuclei, and secrete the hormones oxytocin and vasopressin

Subject: absent magnocellular neurosecretory cells
Value: absence of the cells residing mainly in the hypothalamic supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei and in a number of smaller accessory cell groups between these two nuclei, and secrete the hormones oxytocin and vasopressin

Subject: increased skin hamartoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign formation of a mass of tissue of disproportionate size and distribution in the skin, but composed of an overgrowth of mature cells and tissues that normally occur in this tissue, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: mirror image duplication
Value: during embryogenesis a second structure develops with its parts arranged in a reversal of right and left orientation

Subject: abnormal urine sulfate level
Value: any change in the amount of sulfate in the urine

Subject: increased urine sulfate level
Value: an increase in amount of sulfates in the urine

Subject: abnormal skin exfoliation
Value: anomaly in the process of detachment and shedding of superficial cells of a skin epithelium

Subject: thick epidermis stratum spinosum
Value: increased thickness of the stratum spinosum; the polyhedral cell layer

Subject: abnormal nicotine-mediated receptor currents
Value: change in the measured amplitude, current density or duration of response to stimulation of nicotinic receptors

Subject: enlarged cecum
Value: increased size of the large sac at the ileum and large intestine junction

Subject: small cecum
Value: reduced size of the large sac at the ileum and large intestine junction

Subject: coiled cecum
Value: corkscrew or worm-like appearance of the large sac at the ileum and large intestine junction

Subject: abnormal cecum development
Value: malformation or aberrant differentiation of the large sac at the ileum and large intestine junction

Subject: distended cecum
Value: an expansion in the volume of the large sac at the ileum and large intestine junction, as by stretching or distention

Subject: cecum inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the cecum

Subject: ileum inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the ileum

Subject: enlarged ileum
Value: increased size of the portion of the small intestine that extends from the jejunum to the colon

Subject: ileum hypertrophy
Value: an increase in the bulk size of the portion of the small intestine that extends from the jejunum to the colon due to cell enlargement

Subject: distended ileum
Value: an expansion in the volume of the portion of the small intestine that extends from the jejunum to the colon, as by stretching or distention

Subject: rectovaginal fusion
Value: fusion of the rectum and vaginal canals

Subject: rectourethral fusion
Value: fusion of the rectum and urethral canals

Subject: abnormal pancreatic islet cell apoptosis
Value: change in the timing or the number of pancreatic islet cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal blood vessel endothelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thin layer of flat cells that line the blood vessels and form a barrier between circulating blood in the lumen and the rest of the vessel wall

Subject: abnormal heart left atrium auricular region morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small conical pouch projections located on the upper anterior portion of the left atrium of the heart

Subject: abnormal heart right atrium auricular region morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small conical pouch projections located on the upper anterior portion of the right atrium of the heart

Subject: abnormal gallbladder epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the simple columnar epithelial lining of the gall bladder

Subject: abnormal cystic duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tubular structure that conducts gall bladder contents from the gall bladder to the common bile duct

Subject: abnormal biliary ductule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the excretory ducts of the liver that connect the interlobular ductules to the right or left hepatic duct

Subject: abnormal common bile duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the part of the biliary tree formed by the union of the cystic duct and the common hepatic duct

Subject: abnormal common hepatic duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the part of the biliary tree formed by the union of the right and left hepatic ducts, and joins the cystic duct to form the common bile duct

Subject: abnormal intrahepatic bile duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the passages within the liver for the conveyance of bile

Subject: abnormal extrahepatic bile duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the passages external to the liver for the conveyance of bile

Subject: abnormal intralobular bile duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tubules located between the bile canaliculi and interlobular bile ducts near the outer edge of a classic liver lobule

Subject: abnormal interlobular bile duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the canals that carry bile in the liver between the intralobular ducts and the biliary ductules; interlobular bile ducts are part of the interlobular portal triad

Subject: abnormal hepatic duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the two canals (left and right) that collect and drain bile from the left and right half of the liver from the biliary ductules and join external to the liver to form the common hepatic duct

Subject: abnormal areola morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the circular pigmented region of the breast that surrounds the nipple and delineates the area containing the areolar glands

Subject: abnormal mammary gland duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the canals that lead from the lobes of the mammary gland to the tip of the nipple and are responsible for carrying milk toward the nipple in a lactating female

Subject: abnormal mammary gland epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the mammary gland epithelium which is normally enveloped by a basement membrane, embedded into fatty connective tissue stroma, and organized as a bilayer, with an inner luminal layer of secretory epithelial cells, and an outer basal layer; each cell layer expresses specific molecular markers; luminal epithelial cells are characterized by the expression of the receptors for systemic hormones, i.e. estrogens, progesterone and prolactin, whereas basal cells (aka myoepithelial cells) express smooth muscle contractile proteins; in functionally differentiated mammary gland, during lactation, luminal cells produce milk, whereas myoepithelial cells are contractile and serve for milk expulsion

Subject: abnormal mammary gland lobule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a group of alveoli and the intralobular portion of the terminal duct of the mammary gland

Subject: abnormal mammary gland alveolus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the sac-like structure of the mammary gland that secretes milk after pregnancy

Subject: abnormal mammary gland connective tissue morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the fibrous supportive tissue of the mammary gland

Subject: increased mammary gland ductal carcinoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of malignant tumors of the ducts of the mammary gland

Subject: absent rectum
Value: absence or loss of the terminal portion of the intestinal tube adjacent to the anus

Subject: cecal atresia
Value: congenital blockage or absence of the lumen of the cecum

Subject: distended stomach
Value: an expansion in the volume of the sac-like structure of the digestive canal between the esophagus and the small intestine, as by stretching or distention

Subject: abnormal cerebellar Golgi cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the population of large inhibitory GABAergic interneurons found in the cerebellar internal granule layer which act by altering the mossy fibre - granule cell synapse; the main synapse made by these cells is a synapse onto the mossy fibre - granule cell excitatory synapse in a glomerulus, which is composed of the mossy fibre terminal, granule cell dendrites, and golgi terminal and is enclosed by a glial coat

Subject: titubation
Value: posture distinguished by a faltering gait while walking and/or a swaying motion of the trunk or head while resting; often is a characteristic of cellebellar disease

Subject: increased gastrointestinal stromal tumor incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of non-epithelial, mesenchymal tumors of the gastrointestinal tract, thought to originate from the interstitial cells of Cajal, the pacemaker cells that regulate peristalsis in the digestive tract; approximately 70% of GISTs develop in the stomach, 20% in the small intestine, and less than 10% in the esophagus, colon, and rectum; GISTs are tumors of connective tissue, i.e. sarcomas, account for 1-3% of all gastrointestinal malignancies in human, and are typically more cellular than other gastrointestinal sarcomas

Subject: enlarged salivary gland
Value: increased size of the saliva-secreting glands of the oral cavity

Subject: abnormal salivary gland duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tubular canals that carry saliva

Subject: abnormal anterior lingual gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small glands located near the apex of the tongue on either side of the frenulum

Subject: abnormal anterior buccal gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the racemose, mucous or serous glands in the submucous tissue of the cheeks

Subject: decreased submandibular gland size
Value: reduced size of either of the large major salivary glands situated beneath the mandible

Subject: increased submandibular gland size
Value: increased size of either of the large major salivary glands situated beneath the mandible

Subject: submandibular gland hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of either of the large major salivary glands situated beneath the mandible, usually due to reduced cell number

Subject: submandibular gland hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size of either of the large major salivary glands situated beneath the mandible, usually due to an increase in the number of cells

Subject: absent submandibular gland
Value: absence of either of the large major salivary glands situated beneath the mandible

Subject: abnormal submandibular duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the duct of the submadibular gland that opens at the sublingual papilla near the frenulum of the tongue

Subject: absent sublingual gland
Value: absence of the small mucin-producing salivary glands in the floor of the mouth beneath the tongue, anterior to the submandibular gland

Subject: abnormal sublingual duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the canals that drain the sublingual gland

Subject: abnormal major sublingual duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the duct that drains the anterior portion of the sublingual gland and opens at the sublingual papilla

Subject: abnormal minor sublingual duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the 8-20 small ducts that open into the mouth on the surface of the sublingual fold

Subject: abnormal parotid main excretory duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the main excretory tubular canal that connects the parotid gland and the buccal mucosa and secretes a serous saliva into the vestibule of the oral cavity; it arises from the anterior surface of the gland, traversing the masseter muscle; the duct then pierces the buccinator muscle, moving medially, and opens out into the oral cavity near the second upper molar; saliva produced by acinar secretory cells in the glandular body flows sequentially through the intercalated ducts, striated ducts, and excretory ducts

Subject: increased parotid gland size
Value: increased size of either of the largest of the major salivary glands situated below and in front of each ear

Subject: decreased parotid gland size
Value: reduced size of either of the largest of the major salivary glands situated below and in front of each ear

Subject: absent palatine gland
Value: absence of the salivary gland of the hard palate

Subject: absent anterior lingual gland
Value: absence of the small glands located near the apex of the tongue on either side of the frenulum

Subject: abnormal skin sebaceous gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the holocrine glands of the dermis that secrete sebum into the hair follicles

Subject: abnormal interstitial cell of Cajal morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the type of cell found in the gastrointestinal tract and serving as a pacemaker that triggers gut contraction; ICCs mediate inputs from the enteric nervous system to smooth muscle cells and are thought to be the cells from which gastrointestinal stromal tumours (GISTs) arise; abnormalities in the ICC network can cause chronic intestinal pseudo-obstruction

Subject: interstitial cells of Cajal hyperplasia
Value: increased number of the pacemaker cells of the gastrointestinal tract which mediate inputs from the enteric nervous system to smooth muscle cells and trigger gut contraction

Subject: abnormal synapse morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the membrane junction site of a nerve cell to a target cell, such as another nerve cell, an effector cell, or a sensory receptor cell; transmission of nerve impulses may be mediated by chemical or by electrical means

Subject: abnormal Hassall's corpuscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small spherical bodies of epithelial cells found in the medulla of the thymus, that are arranged in a concentric pattern around clusters of degenerating lymphocytes, eosinophils and macrophages

Subject: absent Hassall's corpuscle
Value: absence of the small spherical bodies of epithelial cells found in the medulla of the thymus, that are arranged in a concentric pattern around clusters of degenerating lymphocytes, eosinophils and macrophages

Subject: increased thymocyte apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of immature T cells located in the thymus that are undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: decreased thymocyte apoptosis
Value: reduction in the number of immature T cells located in the thymus that are undergoing programmed cell death
