Value: reduced number of a type of transitional stage B cell that migrates from the bone marrow into the peripheral circulation, and finally to the spleen; this cell type has the phenotype surface IgM-positive, surface IgD-negative, CD21-negative, CD23-negative, and CD62L-negative

Subject: absent transitional stage T1 B cells
Value: absence of a type of transitional stage B cell that migrates from the bone marrow into the peripheral circulation, and finally to the spleen; this cell type has the phenotype surface IgM-positive, surface IgD-negative, CD21-negative, CD23-negative, and CD62L-negative

Subject: increased transitional stage T2 B cell number
Value: greater number of a type of a transitional stage B cell that has the phenotype surface IgM-positive, surface IgD-postive, CD21-positive, CD23-positive, CD62L-negative, and is located in the splenic B follicles

Subject: decreased transitional stage T2 B cell number
Value: reduced number of a type of transitional stage B cell that has the phenotype surface IgM-positive, surface IgD-postive, CD21-positive, CD23-positive, CD62L-negative, and is located in the splenic B follicles

Subject: absent transitional stage T2 B cells
Value: absence of a type of transitional stage B cell that has the phenotype surface IgM-positive, surface IgD-postive, CD21-positive, CD23-positive, CD62L-negative, and is located in the splenic B follicles

Subject: abnormal pinna hair pigmentation
Value: amount and distribution of yellow pigment (phaeomelanin) relative to black or brown pigment (eumelanin) is decreased or increased in hair located behind the ears when compared to control animal pigmentation

Subject: meningomyelocele
Value: hernial protrusion of the spinal cord and its meninges through an opening or defect in the vertebral column

Subject: fuzzy hair
Value: covered with upright, fine, sometimes lightly curled hair

Subject: abnormal skin appearance
Value: anomaly in the visual aspect of the skin

Subject: skin fibrosis
Value: invasion of fibrous connective tissue into the skin, often resulting from inflammation or injury

Subject: abnormal tail hair pigmentation
Value: an anomaly in the expected coloration of hair on the dorsal and/or ventral surface of the tail

Subject: abnormal hind foot hair pigmentation
Value: an anomaly in the expected color gradient of hair covering the metatarsals and phalanges often differentially expressed in females and males

Subject: abnormal Meibomian gland acinus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the sac-like structures comprising the sebaceous glands located at the rim of the eyelids and responsible for producing sebum

Subject: abnormal dendritic spine morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small membranous protrusion from the dendrite of a neuron that is involved in synaptic transmission; it typically receives input from a single synapse of an axon

Subject: abnormal neuron differentiation
Value: abnormal growth or development of the cells of the nervous system that receive, conduct, and transmit impulses

Subject: abnormal hippocampus granule cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small neurons of the hippocampal granule cell layer

Subject: abnormal hippocampus neuron morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of one or more neurons residing in the hippocampal region of the brain

Subject: abnormal hippocampus pyramidal cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a multipolar projection neuron in the hippocampus pyramidal cell layer; pyramidal cells have a pyramid-shaped soma with the apex and an apical dendrite pointed toward the pial surface and other dendrites and an axon emerging from the base; the axons may have local collaterals but also project outside their cortical region

Subject: abnormal olfactory bulb interneuron morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the group of neurons residing in the olfactory bulb that serve to process and refine signals arising from olfactory sensory neurons

Subject: abnormal olfactory bulb granule cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the main intrinsic GABAergic neuron in the granule cell layer of the main olfactory bulb; dendrites of these cells receive synaptic input from mitral and tufted cell lateral dendrites in the external plexiform layer, and have synaptic outputs on those dendrites through reciprocal dendrodendritic synapses

Subject: abnormal olfactory bulb periglomerular cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small neuron in the glomerular layer of the olfactory bulb whose dendrites arborize within a glomerulus, where it receives synaptic input from olfactory receptor cell axon terminals, and also engages in dendrodendritic interactions with mitral and tufted cell dendrites; uses both GABA and dopamine as a neurotransmitter

Subject: abnormal accessory olfactory bulb morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the forebrain region that coordinates sensory signaling arising from the vomeronasal organ; it is located on the dorsal-posterior portion of the main olfactory bulb, and the axons that leave the accessory olfactory bulb project to targets in the amygdala and hypothalamus

Subject: abnormal olfactory bulb layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the laminar structure of the forebrain region that coordinates neuronal signaling involved in the perception of smell

Subject: abnormal olfactory bulb external plexiform layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the part of the olfactory bulb, lying superior to the mitral cell layer and inferior to the glomerular layer, which is mostly neuropil composed almost entirely of mitral and tufted cell dendrites, granule cell dendrites and their synaptic inputs

Subject: abnormal olfactory bulb subventricular zone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the region of mitotically active layer of cells surrounding the lateral brain ventricles that consists of migrating neuroblasts, astrocytes and transitory amplifying progenitor cells, that produce neurons that migrate to the olfactory bulb

Subject: abnormal olfactory tubercle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the region in the ventral telencephalon, prominent in rodents, but present in all mammals, consisting of a laminated cortical part and the cap/hilus region; it is traditionally viewed as part of the olfactory cortex but recognized by some as having a striatal character; according to many authors, the structure of the OT transitions from cortical like to striatal like along the lateral medial axis

Subject: abnormal mitral cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the large glutaminergic nerve cells whose dendrites synapse with axons of the olfactory receptor neurons in the glomerular layer of the olfactory bulb, and whose axons pass centrally in the olfactory tract to the olfactory cortex

Subject: abnormal olfactory bulb tufted cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the principal glutaminergic neuron located in the outer third of the external plexiform layer of the olfactory bulb; a single short primary dendrite traverses the outer external plexiform layer and terminates within an olfactory glomerulus in a tuft of branches, where it receives the input from olfactory receptor neuron axon terminals; axons of the tufted cells transfer information to a number of areas in the brain, including the piriform cortex, entorhinal cortex, olfactory tubercle, and amygdala

Subject: abnormal cerebellar layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the laminar structure of the cerebellar cortex comprising the gray matter of the cerebellum

Subject: abnormal cerebellum vermis lobule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the region of a cerebellar lobule that resides in the central section of the cerebellum between the two hemispheres; in humans, vermis lobule regions may be nearly continuous with the cerebellar hemisphere lobules dorsally but are separated by deeper longitudinal fissues in the ventral regions; in mammals, the vermis portion of the cerebellum has a foliation pattern along the AP axis that is distinct from the lateral cerebellar hemispheres

Subject: absent cerebellar granule cells
Value: absence of the small neurons of the granule cell layer that send parallel fibers to the upper molecular layer, where they synapse with Purkinje cell dendrites

Subject: abnormal cerebellar hemisphere morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the paired regions of the cerebellum that lie outside and lateral to the central vermis

Subject: abnormal cerebellum anterior lobe morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the region of the cerebellum that is anterior to the primary fissure

Subject: abnormal flocculonodular lobe morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small region of the cerebellum that is posterior to the posteriolateral fissure in humans; it receives input from the inferior and medial vestibular nuclei and sends fibers back to the vestibular nuclei, and processes and integrates these signals to allow for the constant maintenance of balance

Subject: abnormal cerebellum posterior lobe morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the region of the cerebellum that is posterior to the primary fissure and anterior to the posteriolateral fissure

Subject: abnormal cerebellum hemisphere lobule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the region of a cerebellar lobule that resides in either of the lateral sections of the cerebellum outside the vermis; in mammals, the vermis portion of the cerebellum has a foliation pattern along the AP axis that is distinct from the lateral cerebellar hemispheres; distinct species specific differences in hemisphere lobulation occurs among mammals, with greatest complexity in primates

Subject: abnormal cerebellum lobule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the ten gyri of the cerebellar cortex

Subject: abnormal cerebellum lateral hemisphere morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the most lateral paired regions of the cerebellum; the lateral zone receives input from the parietal cortex via pontocerebellar mossy fibers regarding the location and position of the body and integrates input signals with indications of muscle activity

Subject: abnormal cerebellum intermediate hemisphere morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the paired regions of the cerebellar hemisphere that lie adjacent to the vermis and are between the vermis and lateral regions of the hemispheres; it receives input from the corticopontocerebellar fibers that originate from the motor cortex, and also receives sensory feedback from the muscles; these signals are integrated by this region, to coordinate muscle activity with motor inputs

Subject: abnormal neuron proliferation
Value: any anomaly in the ability of a neuron to undergo rapid expansion by cell division

Subject: abnormal cerebellar granule cell precursor proliferation
Value: any anomaly in the ability of a cerebellar granule cell precursor population to undergo rapid expansion by cell division

Subject: abnormal cerebral cortex pyramidal cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the projection neurons in the pyramidal cell layer of the cerebral cortex

Subject: increased hippocampus pyramidal cell number
Value: increased number of the multipolar projection neurons in the hippocampus pyramidal cell layer

Subject: decreased hippocampus pyramidal cell number
Value: decreased number of the multipolar projection neurons in the hippocampus pyramidal cell layer

Subject: absent hippocampus pyramidal cells
Value: absence of the multipolar projection neurons in the hippocampus pyramidal cell layer

Subject: increased cerebral cortex pyramidal cell number
Value: increased number of the projection neurons in the pyramidal cell layer of the cerebral cortex

Subject: decreased cerebral cortex pyramidal cell number
Value: reduced number of the projection neurons in the pyramidal cell layer of the cerebral cortex

Subject: absent cerebral cortex pyramidal cells
Value: absence of the projection neurons in the pyramidal cell layer of the cerebral cortex

Subject: abnormal cerebellar peduncle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the three large paired bundles of nerve fibers that connect the cerebellum to the brain stem

Subject: abnormal cerebellar granule cell migration
Value: any anomaly in the movement of cerebellar granule cell neurons from the germinal zone into the granule cell layer of the cerebellum along radial glia fibers during development of the cerebellar cortex

Subject: abnormal cerebellum deep nucleus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the gray matter nuclei located in the center of the cerebellum, embedded in the white matter, which receive inhibitory (GABAergic) inputs from Purkinje cells in the cerebellar cortex and excitatory (glutamatergic) inputs from mossy fiber pathways; all output fibers of the cerebellum originate from the these nuclei

Subject: abnormal cerebellum dentate nucleus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the largest and most lateral of the deep cerebellum nuclei; it receives axons of Purkinje cells in the lateral cerebellar hemisphere (neocerebellum) and receives its afferents from the premotor cortex and the supplementary motor cortex through the pontocerebellar system, and its efferents project through the superior cerebellar peduncle and is a major source of its fibers

Subject: abnormal cerebellum emboliform nucleus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small wedge shaped nucleus interposed between the dentate and fastigial nuclei; it receives axons from Purkinje cells of the intermediate area of the cerebral hemispheres and most of its efferent connections travel via the superior cerebellar peduncle

Subject: abnormal cerebellum globose nucleus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the two or three small masses of gray matter that is located medial to the emboliform nucleus and lateral to the fastigial nucleus; it receives axons from the intermediate area of the cerebellar hemispheres and its afferents exit through the superior cerebellar peduncle; it is recognized in human cerebellum but is not distinguishable in all mammalian species

Subject: abnormal cerebellum fastigial nucleus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the most medial of the cerebellar nuclei; it receives its afferent input from Purkinje cells of the flocculonodular lobe and the vermis, and most of its efferent connections travel via the inferior cerebellar peduncle to the vestibular nuclei and to the medullary reticular formation

Subject: abnormal cerebellum interpositus nucleus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the nucleus composed of the globose and emoliform nuclei of the cerebellum; in some mammalian species the globose nucleus is not distinguishable

Subject: abnormal inferior cerebellar peduncle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the paired cerebellar peduncles that connects the medulla spinalis and medulla oblongata with the cerebellum, and is composed of juxtarestiform body and restiform body; it carries many types of input and output fibers that are mainly concerned with integrating proprioceptive sensory input with motor vestibular functions such as balance and posture maintenance

Subject: abnormal middle cerebellar peduncle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the largest of the three paired cerebellar peduncles; it is composed mainly of afferent fibers that originate within the pontine nuclei as part of the massive corticopontocerebellar tract, whose fibers descend from the sensory and motor areas of the cerebral neocortex, through the pons and into the cerebellar nuclei and cortex

Subject: abnormal superior cerebellar peduncle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the major output pathway of the cerebellum; most of the efferent fibers originate within the cerebellum dentate nucleus and cerebellum interpositus nuclei, which in turn project to various midbrain structures including the red nucleus, the ventral lateral/ventral anterior nucleus of the thalamus, and the medulla; most of the fibers that pass through this peduncle are involved in pathways important in motor planning

Subject: abnormal flocculus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small region of the cerebellum that receives input from the inferior and medial vestibular nuclei and sends fibers back to the vestibular nuclei, and processes and integrates these signals to allow for the constant maintenance of balance

Subject: abnormal Purkinje cell migration
Value: any anomaly in the movement of immature Purkinje cells from the ventricular zone of the fourth ventricle along radial glial cells to the forming Purkinje cell layer during development of the cerebellar cortex

Subject: abnormal piriform cortex morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the subdivision of the laminated olfactory cortex with only three main layers that receive monosynaptic input from the olfactory bulb via the lateral olfactory tract; it is located bilaterally in the ventrolateral forebrain and is commonly divided into anterior and posterior regions

Subject: abnormal islands of Calleja morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the seven small groups of granule cells in the polymorph layer of the olfactory tubercle and one large group, the insula magna, which lies along the border between septum, nucleus accumbens and nucleus of the diagonal band

Subject: ectopic hippocampus pyramidal cells
Value: the hippocampus pyramidal cell body resides in places other than the pyramidal cell layer of the hippocampus

Subject: ectopic cerebral cortex pyramidal cells
Value: the cerebral cortex pyramidal cell body resides in places other than the pyramidal cell layer of the cerebral cortex

Subject: cerebral cortex pyramidal cell degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment or destruction of the projection neuron in the pyramidal layer of the cerebral cortex

Subject: hippocampus pyramidal cell degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment or destruction of a multipolar projection neuron in the hippocampus pyramidal cell layer

Subject: abnormal cuticular plate morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the firm laminar network of actin filaments in the organ of Corti to which the apical ends of the cochlear hair cells attach and through which their stereocilia project

Subject: variable depigmentation
Value: absence or loss of normal pigment in the skin in various and irregular patterns

Subject: visceral vascular congestion
Value: obstruction of the normal flux of blood within the blood vessel network of the internal organs enclosed within the cavity of the body, such as the thoracic, abdominal, endocrine, and pelvic organs

Subject: pulmonary vascular congestion
Value: obstruction of the normal flux of blood within the blood vessel network of the lung resulting in engorgement of pulmonary vessels; frequently precedes pulmonary edema

Subject: liver vascular congestion
Value: obstruction of the normal flux of blood within the blood vessel network of the liver

Subject: spleen vascular congestion
Value: obstruction of the normal flux of blood within the blood vessel network of the spleen

Subject: heart vascular congestion
Value: obstruction of the normal flux of blood within the blood vessel network of the heart

Subject: brain vascular congestion
Value: obstruction of the normal flux of blood within the blood vessel network of the brain

Subject: cerebral vascular congestion
Value: obstruction of the normal flux of blood within the blood vessel network of the cerebrum

Subject: increased total body fat amount
Value: greater than the normal total amount of connective tissue composed of fat cells within the entire body

Subject: decreased total body fat amount
Value: less than the normal total amount of connective tissue composed of fat cells within the entire body

Subject: decreased liver cholesterol level
Value: less than normal amount in the liver of the principal sterol of vertebrates and the precursor of many steroids, including bile acids and steroid hormones; it is a component of the plasma membrane lipid bilayer and of plasma lipoproteins and can be found in all animal tissues

Subject: increased liver cholesterol level
Value: greater than normal amount in the liver of the principal sterol of vertebrates and the precursor of many steroids, including bile acids and steroid hormones; it is a component of the plasma membrane lipid bilayer and of plasma lipoproteins and can be found in all animal tissues

Subject: aciduria
Value: excretion of urine with an acid pH

Subject: abnormal basicranium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the sloping floor of the cranial cavity that is comprised of parts of the ethmoidal, occipital and sphenoid bones

Subject: abnormal orbit morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bony ring that supports the eyeball and supporting tissues and is formed by parts of several cranial bones

Subject: abnormal cranium size
Value: deviation from the average range of cranium size compared to normal

Subject: paraphimosis
Value: inability of the penis to retract back into the prepuce/foreskin; entrapment of a retracted foreskin behind the coronal sulcus

Subject: abnormal erythrocyte clearance
Value: any anomaly in the selective elimination of aging erythrocytes from the body by autoregulatory mechanisms, often expressed as half-life

Subject: increased erythrocyte clearance
Value: increased elimination of aging erythrocytes from the body by autoregulatory mechanisms, often expressed as half-life

Subject: decreased erythrocyte clearance
Value: decreased elimination of aging erythrocytes from the body by autoregulatory mechanisms, often expressed as half-life

Subject: ectopic melanocytes
Value: pigment producing cells are not located in the normal or expected position

Subject: abnormal placenta physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the organ of metabolic interchange between fetus and mother, which is partly of embryonic origin and partly of maternal origin

Subject: abnormal trophoblast giant cell proliferation
Value: abnormality in the expansion rate of the trophoblast giant cell population by cell division

Subject: abnormal oval cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of adult liver-specific stem cells; a blast-like cell capable of self renewal and multipotent differentiation, the oval cell is capable of differentiating into mature hepatocytes or cholangiocytes

Subject: absent oval cells
Value: absence of adult liver-specific stem cells; a blast-like cell capable of self renewal and multipotent differentiation, the oval cell is capable of differentiating into mature hepatocytes or cholangiocytes

Subject: abnormal oval cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of adult liver-specific stem cells; a blast-like cell capable of self renewal and multipotent differentiation, the oval cell is capable of differentiating into mature hepatocytes or cholangiocytes

Subject: abnormal frontonasal suture morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the dense, fibrous connective tissue joint between the frontal and nasal bones

Subject: abnormal omental fat pad morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the encapsulated adipose tissue associated with the fold of peritoneal tissue that extends from the stomach to the posterior abdominal wall after associating with the transverse colon

Subject: increased omental fat pad weight
Value: greater than average weight of the encapsulated adipose tissue associated with the fold of peritoneal tissue that extends from the stomach to the posterior abdominal wall after associating with the transverse colon

Subject: decreased omental fat pad weight
Value: less than average weight of the encapsulated adipose tissue associated with the fold of peritoneal tissue that extends from the stomach to the posterior abdominal wall after associating with the transverse colon

Subject: axonal spheroids
Value: focal 10-50 micron diameter swellings of axons, which are sometimes, but not always, terminal endbulbs, and are filled with disorganized neurofilaments, tubules, organelles or multi-lamellar inclusions

Subject: abnormal primitive streak regression
Value: any anomaly in the process by which the primitive streak disappears during gastrulation, when the node moves back to a posterior position

Subject: hypermyelination
Value: increased myelin formation in a myelin sheath over all or part of an axon or fiber tract, usually resulting in a thicker myelin sheath

Subject: increased grip strength
Value: greater ability to grasp and hold objects, often measured as time spent hanging from an object or wire

Subject: decreased grip strength
Value: reduced ability to grasp and hold objects, often measured as time spent hanging from an object or wire

Subject: increased hepatoblastoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a malignant neoplasm occurring primarily in the liver and composed of tissue resembling embryonic or fetal hepatic epithelium, or mixed epithelial and mesenchymal tissues, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: abnormal sensory neuron physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of cells that innervate an effector (muscle or glandular) tissue and are responsible for transmission of sensory impulses

Subject: ectopic skeletal muscle
Value: skeletal muscle is located in a position not normally occupied by this tissue type

Subject: abnormal olfactory bulb outer nerve layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the outermost layer of the olfactory bulb; consists primarily of olfactory afferent axons and ensheathing glia

Subject: enlarged olfactory bulb
Value: increased size of the forebrain region that coordinates neuronal signaling involved in the perception of smell; it receives input from the sensory neurons and outputs to the olfactory cortex

Subject: olfactory bulb hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the forebrain region that coordinates neuronal signaling involved in the perception of smell

Subject: abnormal creatine level
Value: anomaly in the amount of the amino acid that is found in muscle tissue of vertebrates as phosphocreatine and supplies energy for muscle contraction when metabolized

Subject: increased creatine level
Value: increase in the amount of the amino acid that is found in muscle tissue of vertebrates as phosphocreatine and supplies energy for muscle contraction when metabolized

Subject: decreased creatine level
Value: reduction in the amount of the amino acid that is found in muscle tissue of vertebrates as phosphocreatine and supplies energy for muscle contraction when metabolized

Subject: abnormal circulating creatine level
Value: anomaly in the amount per unit of blood of an amino acid that is found in muscle tissue of vertebrates as phosphocreatine and supplies energy for muscle contraction when metabolized

Subject: increased circulating creatine level
Value: increase in the amount per unit of blood of an amino acid that is found in muscle tissue of vertebrates as phosphocreatine and supplies energy for muscle contraction when metabolized

Subject: decreased circulating creatine level
Value: reduction in the amount per unit of blood of an amino acid that is found in muscle tissue of vertebrates as phosphocreatine and supplies energy for muscle contraction when metabolized

Subject: abnormal red blood cell distribution width
Value: an anomaly in the coefficient of variance (reference range) of the red blood cell volume for an organism

Subject: increased red blood cell distribution width
Value: higher than normal coefficient of variance (reference range) of the red blood cell volume for an organism

Subject: decreased red blood cell distribution width
Value: lower than normal coefficient of variance (reference range) of the red blood cell volume for an organism

Subject: increased serotonin level
Value: increase in the amount of biochemical messenger and regulator, found in the CNS, gastrointestinal tract, and produced by platelets that mediates neurotransmission, gastrointestinal motility, hemostasis, and cardiovascular integrity

Subject: decreased serotonin level
Value: reduction in the amount of biochemical messenger and regulator, found in the CNS, gastrointestinal tract, and produced by platelets that mediates neurotransmission, gastrointestinal motility, hemostasis, and cardiovascular integrity

Subject: abnormal pruritus
Value: anomaly in the normal absence or presence of an uncomfortable sensation resulting from irritation of the skin or mucous membranes that evokes the desire or reflex to rub or scratch

Subject: increased pruritus
Value: abnormal presence or increased intensity of an uncomfortable sensation resulting from irritation of the skin or mucous membranes that evokes the desire or reflex to rub or scratch

Subject: decreased pruritus
Value: absence or decreased intensity of an uncomfortable sensation resulting from irritation of the skin or mucous membranes that evokes the desire or reflex to rub or scratch

Subject: stomatocytosis
Value: deformation of red blood cells to a cup-like shape, with swelling and with an elongated area of central pallor, instead of the normal biconcave shape

Subject: abnormal circulating phytosterol level
Value: anomaly in the amount of phytosterols in the blood; commonly ingested phytosterols include beta-sitosterol, campesterol, and stigmasterol

Subject: abnormal phytosterol level
Value: anomaly in the amount of plant sterols often as a result of hyperabsorbtion of phytosterols and decreased biliary excretion of dietary sterols;commonly ingested phytosterols include beta-sitosterol, campesterol, and stigmasterol

Subject: increased phytosterol level
Value: increased amount of plant sterols often as a result of hyperabsorbtion of phytosterols and decreased biliary excretion of dietary sterols; commonly ingested phytosterols include beta-sitosterol, campesterol, and stigmasterol

Subject: increased circulating phytosterol level
Value: increase in the amount of phytosterols in the blood; commonly ingested phytosterols include beta-sitosterol, campesterol, and stigmasterol

Subject: increased osteochondroma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign cartilagenous neoplasm that consists of a pedicle of normal bone capped by a region of proliferating cartilage cells, occurring in a specific population in a given time period; osteochondroma is most often associated with one or more of the long bones

Subject: abnormal hepatocyte physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the main structural specialized epithelial cells which normally organize into interconnected plates called lobules

Subject: posterior microphthalmia
Value: reduced average size of the back of the eye

Subject: sternebra fusion
Value: appearance of one or more sternebrae as a single structure

Subject: abnormal long lived plasma cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a fully differentiated plasma cell that lives for years, as opposed to months, secretes immunoglobulin, and has the phenotype weakly CD19-positive, CD20-negative, CD38-negative, strongly CD138-positive, MHC Class II-negative, surface immunoglobulin-negative, IgD-negative, and strongly CXCR4-positive; the majority of these cells of this type reside in the bone marrow

Subject: abnormal short lived plasma cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a fully differentiated plasma cell that lives for months, not years

Subject: abnormal circulating fructosamine level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration in the blood of total non enzymatic glycated proteins in the blood

Subject: increased circulating fructosamine level
Value: increase in the concentration in the blood of total non enzymatic glycated proteins in the blood

Subject: decreased circulating fructosamine level
Value: decrease in the concentration in the blood of total non enzymatic glycated proteins in the blood

Subject: abnormal circulating creatine kinase level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration in the blood of an enzyme that catalyzes the reversible transfer of creatine to phosphocreatine

Subject: increased circulating creatine kinase level
Value: an elevation in the concentration in the blood of an enzyme that catalyzes the reversible transfer of creatine to phosphocreatine

Subject: decreased circulating creatine kinase level
Value: a reduction in the concentration in the blood of an enzyme that catalyzes the reversible transfer of creatine to phosphocreatine

Subject: increased circulating magnesium level
Value: an elevation in the blood concentration of magnesium

Subject: decreased circulating magnesium level
Value: a reduction in the blood concentration of magnesium

Subject: abnormal chromosome stability
Value: anomaly in the probability that whole chromosomes or pieces of chromosomes are gained or lost during cell division, resulting in an imbalance in the number of chromosomes per cell (aneuploidy) and an reduced rate of loss of heterozygosity

Subject: increased chromosomal stability
Value: decrease in the probability that whole chromosomes or pieces of chromosomes are gained or lost during cell division, resulting in an imbalance in the number of chromosomes per cell (aneuploidy) and an reduced rate of loss of heterozygosity

Subject: abnormal incisor color
Value: anomaly in the color and shading of the incisor, which normally presents in shades of white

Subject: abnormal retinal blood vessel morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the blood vessels supplying the retina

Subject: abnormal retinal blood vessel pattern
Value: anomaly in the systematic arrangement of the blood vessels supplying the retina

Subject: abnormal thoracic cage shape
Value: anomaly in the overall regular dome shape of the ribcage

Subject: increased cervical vertebrae number
Value: increased number of the seven bony segments of the spine located anterior to the thoracic vertebrae and caudal to the skull

Subject: increased sacral vertebrae number
Value: increase of any or all of the bony segments of the spine located posterior to the lumbar vertebrae and anterior to the caudal vertebrae

Subject: increased caudal vertebrae number
Value: increased number of the bony segments of the coccyx or tail

Subject: small thoracic cage
Value: reduced size of the bony and cartilaginous structure enclosing the thoracic cavity, consisting of the thoracic vertebrae, ribs, costal cartilages, and sternum

Subject: enlarged thoracic cage
Value: increased size of the bony and cartilaginous structure enclosing the thoracic cavity, consisting of the thoracic vertebrae, ribs, costal cartilages, and sternum

Subject: abnormal sublingual ganglion morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small parasympathetic ganglion found anterior to the submandibular gland that provides postsynaptic fibers to the sublingual gland

Subject: abnormal circulating pyruvate kinase level
Value: abnormal concentration in the blood of the phosphotransferase in the glycolytic pathway that catalyzes the transfer of phosphate from phosphoenolpyruvate to ADP, forming ATP and p; deficiency results in hemolytic anemia

Subject: abnormal renal reabsorption
Value: any anomaly in the two-step process beginning with the active or passive extraction of substances (such as water, glucose, oligopeptides, amino acids, sodium (Na+) and other ions) from the renal tubule fluid into the renal interstitium, and the subsequent transport of these substances out of the renal interstitium back into the bloodstream; reabsorption begins in the proximal convoluted tubules and continues in the loop of Henle, distal convoluted tubules, and collecting tubules

Subject: abnormal renal water reabsorption
Value: any anomaly in the process by which water is passively transported out of the renal tubules back into the bloodstream

Subject: abnormal renal sodium reabsorption
Value: any anomaly in the process by which sodium ions are transported out of the renal tubules back into the bloodstream

Subject: abnormal renal phosphate reabsorption
Value: any anomaly in the process by which phosphate (salt or ester of phosphoric acid) is transported out of the renal tubules back into the bloodstream

Subject: abnormal renal calcium reabsorption
Value: any anomaly in the process by which calcium ions are transported out of the renal tubules back into the bloodstream

Subject: obsolete abnormal coccygeal vertebrae morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the 3-5 separate or fused bony segments of the coccyx

Subject: abnormal sacrum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the segment of the vertebral column that is formed by the fusion of five sacral vertebrae in adult humans and tailless primates

Subject: abnormal coccyx morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the rostral-most segment of the vertebral column that is formed by the fusion of three to five coccygeal vertebrae in adult humans and tailless primates

Subject: abnormal embryonic cloaca morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the endoderm-lined chamber that develops as pouch-like dilation of the caudal end of the hindgut and receives the allantois ventrally and two mesonephric ducts laterally; caudally it ends blindly at the cloacal membrane formed by the union of proctodeal (anal pit) ectoderm and cloacal endoderm, with no intervening mesoderm

Subject: abnormal primitive urogenital sinus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the ventral part of the cloaca remaining after septation of the rectum, which further develops into part of the bladder, part of the prostatic part of the male urethra and the urethra and vestibule in females

Subject: abnormal lateral plate mesoderm morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the portion of the middle of the three primary germ layers of the embryo that resides on the periphery of the embryo, is continuous with the extra-embryonic mesoderm, splits into two layers enclosing the intra-embryonic coelom, and gives rise to body wall structures

Subject: abnormal intermediate mesoderm morphology
Value: any anomaly of the band of mesoderm located between the segmented paraxial mesoderm and the lateral plate mesoderm, that develops into the nephrogenic cord

Subject: abnormal bone mineral density
Value: anomaly in the quatitative measurment of mineral content of bone; BMD is used as an indicator of bone strength; bone mineral density is the ratio of bone mineral content to bone size

Subject: abnormal bone mineral content
Value: any anomaly in the amount (usually in grams/cm) of bone mineral divided by a bone-scanned area

Subject: increased bone mineral content
Value: elevation in the amount (usually in grams/cm) of bone mineral divided by a bone-scanned area

Subject: decreased bone mineral content
Value: reduction in the amount (usually in grams/cm) of bone mineral divided by a bone-scanned area

Subject: abnormal parvocellular neurosecretory cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the secretory neurons of the paraventricular nucleus that synthesize and secrete vasopressin, corticotropin-releasing factor (CRF) and thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH) into blood vessels in the hypothalamo-pituitary portal system

Subject: abnormal distal visceral endoderm morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the precursors of the anterior visceral endoderm that arises at the distal tip of the embryo

Subject: hypervolemia
Value: an abnormally increased amount of space occupied by blood in the vessels

Subject: hypovolemia
Value: an abnormally decreased amount of space occupied by blood in the vessels

Subject: increased DN1 thymic pro-T cell number
Value: increased number of pro-T cells that have the cell surface marker phenotype CD4-negative, CD8-negative, CD44-positive, and CD25-negative

Subject: decreased DN1 thymic pro-T cell number
Value: reduced number of pro-T cells that have the cell surface marker phenotype CD4-negative, CD8-negative, CD44-positive, and CD25-negative

Subject: increased DN2 thymocyte number
Value: increased number of thymocytes that have the cell surface marker phenotype CD4-negative, CD8-negative, CD44-positive, and CD25-positive

Subject: decreased DN2 thymocyte number
Value: reduced number of thymocytes that have the cell surface marker phenotype CD4-negative, CD8-negative, CD44-positive, and CD25-positive

Subject: increased DN3 thymocyte number
Value: increased number of thymocytes that have the cell surface marker phenotype CD4-negative, CD8-negative, CD44-positive, and CD25-negative and expressing the T cell receptor beta-chain in complex with the pre-T cell receptor alpha chain.

Subject: decreased DN3 thymocyte number
Value: reduced number of thymocytes that have the cell surface marker phenotype CD4-negative, CD8-negative, CD44-positive, and CD25-negative and expressing the T cell receptor beta-chain in complex with the pre-T cell receptor alpha chain.

Subject: increased DN4 thymocyte number
Value: increased number of thymocytes that have the cell surface marker phenotype CD4-negative, CD8-negative, CD44-negative, CD25-negative, and pre-TCR-positive.

Subject: decreased DN4 thymocyte number
Value: reduced number of thymocytes that have the cell surface marker phenotype CD4-negative, CD8-negative, CD44-negative, CD25-negative, and pre-TCR-positive.

Subject: delayed exit from anagen phase
Value: anomaly in the growth phase of the hair cycle resulting a prolonged anagen phase

Subject: arteritis
Value: inflammation of the walls of arteries, usually as a result of infection or autoimmune response

Subject: aortitis
Value: inflammation of the aorta

Subject: phlebitis
Value: inflammation of a vein

Subject: lymphangitis
Value: inflammation of the lymphatic vessels/channels

Subject: disorganized hair shaft
Value: derangement of the normal pattern of the layered structure of the cuticle, cortex and/or medulla of a hair

Subject: enhanced fertility
Value: increased ability to produce live offspring

Subject: abnormal tumor vascularization
Value: aberrant process of blood vessel formation and the subsequent remodeling process within and/or around tumors

Subject: abnormal spermatic cord morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cord-like structure in males comprising the vas deferens and associated tissue that runs from the abdomen down to each testis

Subject: umbilical hernia
Value: an outward bulging (protrusion) of the abdominal lining or part of the abdominal organ(s) through the area around the umbilicus; occurs when the muscle through which blood vessels pass to feed the developing fetus fails to completely close

Subject: abnormal endocrine pancreas physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the smaller portion of the pancreas that secretes a number of hormones into the blood stream that are produced by the cells in the islets of Langerhans

Subject: abnormal exocrine pancreas physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the acinar gland portion of the pancreas that secretes digestive enzymes

Subject: abnormal synaptic dopamine release
Value: aberrant secretion across synapses of the catecholamine neurotransmitter and neurohormone, derived from tyrosine and the precursor to norepinephrine and epinephrine; functions as a neurotransmitter in the brain and as a hormone to inhibit the release of prolactin from the anterior lobe of the pituitary

Subject: abnormal mandibular ramus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the upturned perpendicular extremity of the mandible

Subject: abnormal spinal cord ependymal layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cellular membrane that lines the central canal of the spinal cord

Subject: abnormal brain ependyma morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cellular membrane that lines the brain ventricles

Subject: abnormal gastroesophageal sphincter morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thick circular layer of smooth gastric musculature encircling the gastroesophageal junction that functions to reduce backflow into the esophagus from the stomach

Subject: abnormal gastroesophageal sphincter physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the thick circular layer of gastric musculature encircling the gastroesophageal junction that functions to reduce backflow into the esophagus from the stomach

Subject: abnormal intestine physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the digestive tube passing from the stomach to the anus

Subject: abnormal small intestinal crypt cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the cells that make up the tubular intestinal glands found in the mucosal membranes of the small intestine

Subject: abnormal small intestinal crypt cell proliferation
Value: anomaly in the ability of the cells that make up the tubular intestinal glands found in the mucosal membranes of the small intestine to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: abnormal intestine development
Value: abnormal formation of the digestive tube passing from the stomach to the anus

Subject: abnormal enterocyte differentiation
Value: abnormal formation of the epithelial cells that have an apical plasma membrane folded into microvilli to provide ample surface for the absorption of nutrients from the intestinal lumen

Subject: increased oligodendrocyte number
Value: greater number of cells of the central nervous system that form the insulating myelin sheath of axons in the CNS

Subject: decreased brain cholesterol level
Value: less than normal amount in the brain of the principal sterol of vertebrates and the precursor of many steroids, including bile acids and steroid hormones; it is a component of the plasma membrane lipid bilayer and of plasma lipoproteins and can be found in all animal tissues

Subject: increased brain cholesterol level
Value: greater than normal amount in the brain of the principal sterol of vertebrates and the precursor of many steroids, including bile acids and steroid hormones; it is a component of the plasma membrane lipid bilayer and of plasma lipoproteins and can be found in all animal tissues

Subject: hemolysis
Value: destruction of erythrocytes such that hemoglobin is released from the cells; may occur by many different causal agents such as antibodies, bacteria, chemicals, temperature, and changes in tonicity

Subject: abnormal response to stress-induced hyperthermia
Value: any anomaly in the expected increase in core body termperature in response to stress or anticipatory anxiety

Subject: increased response to stress-induced hyperthermia
Value: greater increase or faster than expected increase in core body termperature in response to stress or anticipatory anxiety

Subject: decreased response to stress-induced hyperthermia
Value: reduction or absence of the expected increase in core body termperature in response to stress or anticipatory anxiety

Subject: increased CD4-positive, CD25-positive, alpha-beta regulatory T cell number
Value: a greater number of the CD4-positive, CD25-positive T cell subset which regulates overall immune responses as well as the responses of other T cell subsets through direct cell-cell contact and cytokine release

Subject: decreased CD4-positive, CD25-positive, alpha-beta regulatory T cell number
Value: a reduction in the number of the CD4-positive, CD25-positive T cell subset which regulates overall immune responses as well as the responses of other T cell subsets through direct cell-cell contact and cytokine release

Subject: abnormal glial cell apoptosis
Value: change in the timing or the number of glial cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal centroacinar cell of Langerhans morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of cells that line the pancreatic ducts that secrete mucins and an aqueous bicarbonate solution under stimulation by the hormone secretin

Subject: abnormal mammary gland epithelium physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the mammary gland epithelium which is normally enveloped by a basement membrane, embedded into fatty connective tissue stroma, and organized as a bilayer, with an inner luminal layer of secretory epithelial cells, and an outer basal layer; each cell layer expresses specific molecular markers; luminal epithelial cells are characterized by the expression of the receptors for systemic hormones, i.e. estrogens, progesterone and prolactin, whereas basal cells (aka myoepithelial cells) express smooth muscle contractile proteins; in functionally differentiated mammary gland, during lactation, luminal cells produce milk, whereas myoepithelial cells are contractile and serve for milk expulsion

Subject: increased mammary gland epithelial cell proliferation
Value: increase in the expansion rate of the cells of the mammary gland epithelium by cell division

Subject: decreased mammary gland epithelial cell proliferation
Value: decrease in the expansion rate of the cells of the mammary gland epithelium by cell division

Subject: leptocytosis
Value: the presence of unusually thin or flattened red blood cells that when stained show a dark center and a peripheral ring of hemoglobin, separated by a pale unstained ring containing less hemoglobin, resulting in a bull's-eye appearance and resembling a 3D sombrero when viewed under EM; seen in certain anemias, thalassemias, hemoglobinopathies, obstructive jaundice, and the post-splenectomy state

Subject: dacryocytosis
Value: presence of teardrop-shaped red blood cells

Subject: acanthocytosis
Value: presence of erythrocytes characterized by multiple spiny (thorn-like) cytoplasmic projections

Subject: increased number of Howell-Jolly bodies
Value: abnormal presence of basophilic nuclear remnants of condensed DNA (1 to 2 um in diameter) in circulating erythrocytes, typically seen in severe hemolytic anemias or after splenectomy; these inclusions are normally removed by the spleen but will persist in individuals with functional hyposplenia or asplenia

Subject: rough coat
Value: coat does not have the usual smooth appearance

Subject: increased susceptibility to weight loss
Value: greater decrease in body weight over time when compared to the average decrease in weight in response to dietary modification, fasting or caloric restriction, infection or xenobiotic treatment

Subject: decreased susceptibility to weight loss
Value: smaller decrease in body weight over time when compared to the average decrease in weight in response to dietary modification, fasting or caloric restriction, infection or xenobiotic treatment

Subject: decreased susceptibility to weight gain
Value: smaller increase in body weight over time when compared to the average increase in weight on the same diet, with equal energy (calorie) intake

Subject: abnormal CD4-positive helper T cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cell that cooperates with other lymphocytes via direct contact or cytokine release to initiate a variety of immune functions

Subject: abnormal T follicular helper cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a CD4-positive, CXCR5-positive, CCR7-negative alpha-beta T cell located in follicles of secondary lymph nodes that expresses high levels of BCL-6, ICOS and PD1 and stimulate follicular B cells to undergo class-switching and antibody production

Subject: abnormal T follicular helper cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of the CD4-positive, CXCR5-positive, CCR7-negative alpha-beta T cells located in follicles of secondary lymph nodes that expresses high levels of BCL-6, ICOS and PD1 and stimulate follicular B cells to undergo class-switching and antibody production

Subject: increased T follicular helper cell number
Value: greater number of the CD4-positive, CXCR5-positive, CCR7-negative alpha-beta T cells located in follicles of secondary lymph nodes that expresses high levels of BCL-6, ICOS and PD1 and stimulate follicular B cells to undergo class-switching and antibody production

Subject: decreased T follicular helper cell number
Value: reduced number of the CD4-positive, CXCR5-positive, CCR7-negative alpha-beta T cells located in follicles of secondary lymph nodes that expresses high levels of BCL-6, ICOS and PD1 and stimulate follicular B cells to undergo class-switching and antibody production

Subject: abnormal T follicular helper cell differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce the CD4-positive, CXCR5-positive, CCR7-negative alpha-beta T cells located in follicles of secondary lymph nodes that expresses high levels of BCL-6, ICOS and PD1 and stimulate follicular B cells to undergo class-switching and antibody production

Subject: abnormal T follicular helper cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of a CD4-positive, CXCR5-positive, CCR7-negative alpha-beta T cell located in follicles of secondary lymph nodes that expresses high levels of BCL-6, ICOS and PD1 and stimulate follicular B cells to undergo class-switching and antibody production

Subject: abnormal retinal melanocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cells that produce pigment in the retina

Subject: abnormal choroid melanocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cells that produce pigment in the choroid

Subject: abnormal retinal melanin granule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the pigment particles in the retina

Subject: abnormal choroid melanin granule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the pigment particles in the choroid

Subject: absent lymphatic vessels
Value: absence of the network of vessels which carries lymph around the body

Subject: abnormal lymphatic vessel endothelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thin layer of flat cells that line the lymphatic vessels and form a barrier between circulating lymph in the lumen and the rest of the vessel wall

Subject: abnormal lymphatic vessel smooth muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the nonstriated, involuntary muscle tissue that encompasses the lymphatic vessels

Subject: abnormal lymphatic vessel endothelial cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cells that line the lymphatic vessels

Subject: decreased lymphatic vessel endothelial cell number
Value: reduced number of the cells that line the lymphatic vessels

Subject: absent lymphatic vessel endothelial cells
Value: absence of the cells that line the lymphatic vessels

Subject: enlarged lymphatic vessel
Value: increased size of the network of vessels which carries lymph around the body

Subject: focal dorsal hair loss
Value: focal hair loss on the dorsal area of a rodent resulting in dorsal skin visible in a patch where hair loss occurs

Subject: focal ventral hair loss
Value: focal hair loss on the ventral area of a rodent resulting in ventral skin visible in a patch where hair loss occurs

Subject: abnormal astrocyte apoptosis
Value: change in the timing or the number of astrocytes undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal oligodendrocyte apoptosis
Value: change in the timing or the number of oligodendrocytes undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: pigment incontinence
Value: absence of melanin and melanosomes in the epidermis, and accumulation of melanin and melanosome in melanophages in the upper dermis

Subject: abnormal telomere morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the terminal repetitive DNA section of a chromosome which is involved in chromosomal replication and senescence, and which protects the end of the chromosome from deterioration

Subject: prognathia
Value: abnormal protrusion of the mandible relative to the facial skeleton and soft tissues

Subject: abnormal circulating chemokine level
Value: deviation from the normal levels of any of the class of pro-inflammatory cytokines that attract and activate leukocytes in the circulation

Subject: abnormal circulating cytokine level
Value: deviation from the normal levels in the blood of any of the non-antibody proteins made by inflammatory leukocytes and some non-leukocytic cells that affect the behavior of other cells

Subject: abnormal acute phase protein level
Value: deviation from the normal levels of the series of proteins found in the blood shortly after infection and which participate in the early phases of host defense against infection

Subject: abnormal circulating C-reactive protein level
Value: deviation from the normal levels of the plasma protein that circulates in increased amounts during inflammation or after tissue damage and binds to phosphocholine expressed on the surface of dead or dying cells, including all types of pneumococci, in order to activate the complement system via the C1Q complex

Subject: abnormal circulating fibrinogen level
Value: deviation from the normal levels in the blood of a globulin that is converted into fibrin by the action of thrombin in the presence of ionized calcium to produce coagulation of the blood

Subject: abnormal circulating serum amyloid protein level
Value: deviation from the normal blood levels of an acute-phase reaction protein that is a precursor to amyloid A protein; it is present in very high levels during acute inflammatory episodes, and is present in low concentrations in normal sera, but is found at higher concentrations in sera of older persons and in patients with amyloidosis

Subject: abnormal circulating complement protein level
Value: deviation from the normal levels of the serum proteins that act sequentially to allow for the direct killing of microbes, the disposal of immune complexes, and the regulation of other immune processes

Subject: abnormal circulating retinol binding protein level
Value: anomaly in the blood level of carrier proteins that bind retinol; serum levels are used to detect liver disease, protein-calorie malnutrition and vitamin A deficiencies

Subject: abnormal T-helper 17 cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cell with the phenotype RORgamma-t-positive that produces IL-17

Subject: abnormal T-helper 17 cell number
Value: deviation from the normal count of CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells with the phenotype RORgamma-t-positive that produces IL-17

Subject: increased T-helper 17 cell number
Value: increased number of CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells with the phenotype RORgamma-t-positive that produces IL-17

Subject: decreased T-helper 17 cell number
Value: reduced number of CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells with the phenotype RORgamma-t-positive that produces IL-17

Subject: abnormal T-helper 17 cell differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce the CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cells with the phenotype RORgamma-t-positive that produces IL-17

Subject: abnormal T-helper 17 cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of a CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cell with the phenotype RORgamma-t-positive that produces IL-17

Subject: abnormal immunoglobulin transcytosis
Value: any anomaly in the process of transporting immunoglobulin, via transcytosis, from one side of a cell to the other; occurs in epithelial cells and other cell types

Subject: abnormal heart ventricle outflow tract morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the superior portion of the ventricles of the heart through which blood flows into the arteries

Subject: abnormal quadriceps morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the group of four muscles (rectus femoris, vastus intermedius, vastus lateralis, and vastus medialis) which extend down the front of the thigh and are the major extensors of the knee joint

Subject: increased quadriceps weight
Value: increase in the weight of the group of four muscles (rectus femoris, vastus intermedius, vastus lateralis, and vastus medialis) which extend down the front of the thigh and are the major extensors of the knee joint

Subject: decreased quadriceps weight
Value: reduction in the weight of the group of four muscles (rectus femoris, vastus intermedius, vastus lateralis, and vastus medialis) which extend down the front of the thigh and are the major extensors of the knee joint

Subject: decreased transitional stage T3 B cell number
Value: reduced number of a type of a transitional stage B cell that expresses surface IgM and IgD, and CD62L; it is an anergic B cell that does not proliferate upon BCR signaling, is found in the spleen and lymph nodes, and has the phenotype surface IgM-positive, surface IgD-positive, CD21-positive, CD23-positive, and CD62L-positive

Subject: increased transitional stage T3 B cell number
Value: greater number of a type of a transitional stage B cell that expresses surface IgM and IgD, and CD62L; it is an anergic B cell that does not proliferate upon BCR signaling, is found in the spleen and lymph nodes, and has the phenotype surface IgM-positive, surface IgD-positive, CD21-positive, CD23-positive, and CD62L-positive

Subject: absent transitional stage T3 B cells
Value: absence of a type of a transitional stage B cell that expresses surface IgM and IgD, and CD62L; it is an anergic B cell that does not proliferate upon BCR signaling, is found in the spleen and lymph nodes, and has the phenotype surface IgM-positive, surface IgD-positive, CD21-positive, CD23-positive, and CD62L-positive

Subject: transverse fur striping
Value: presence of stripes of pigmented hair, usually black, of variable degree and location in the coat

Subject: delayed skin pigmentation appearance
Value: lag in the time that normal coloration of the skin color occurs in relation to control animals

Subject: hairless tail
Value: the tail is devoid of hair

Subject: abnormal vibrissa follicle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of one of the tubular invaginations of the epidermis enclosing the hair roots and from which grow the vibrissae located on the muzzle and face of many species

Subject: abnormal retina inner limiting membrane morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the row of fused Muller cell processes and astrocytes that separates the retinal nerve fiber layer from the vitreous

Subject: abnormal retina outer limiting membrane morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the row of junctional complexes between the plasma membranes of rod segments and the Muller glia cells; this barrier separates the layer of inner and outer segments of the rods and cones from the outer nuclear layer and forms a blood-retina barrier

Subject: abnormal skeletal muscle weight
Value: any anomaly in the average skeletal muscle weight

Subject: increased skeletal muscle weight
Value: greater than average skeletal muscle weight

Subject: decreased skeletal muscle weight
Value: less than average skeletal muscle weight

Subject: decreased skeletal muscle size
Value: less than average dimensions of one or more of the muscles of the skeleton

Subject: abnormal aortic arch development
Value: anomaly in the process of forming the convex portion of the aorta between the ascending and descending parts of the aorta; including formation of the brachiocephalic trunk, the left common carotid artery, and the left subclavian artery; the brachiocephalic trunk further splits to form the right subclavian artery and the right common carotid artery

Subject: abnormal kidney copper level
Value: an anomaly in the amount of copper present in kidney tissue

Subject: increased kidney copper level
Value: a greater accumulation of copper in the kidney tissue compared to controls

Subject: decreased kidney copper level
Value: a reduced amount of copper in the kidney tissue compared to controls

Subject: abnormal spleen perifollicular zone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the compartment located between the marginal zone and the red pulp harboring scattered B and T lymphocytes

Subject: abnormal intestine copper level
Value: an anomaly in the amount of copper present in the intestine

Subject: increased intestine copper level
Value: a greater accumulation of copper in intestinal tissue compared with controls

Subject: decreased intestine copper level
Value: a reduced amount of copper in the intestinal tissue compared to controls

Subject: lactation failure
Value: mammary glands do not secrete milk after parturition

Subject: absent thymus cortex
Value: lacking the outer part of the thymus lobule which surrounds the medulla and is normally composed of closely packed lymphocytes

Subject: subcapsular cataract
Value: a lens opacity localized beneath the anterior or posterior lens capsule

Subject: anterior subcapsular cataract
Value: a lens opacity localized beneath the anterior lens capsule

Subject: posterior subcapsular cataract
Value: a lens opacity localized beneath the posterior lens capsule

Subject: nuclear cataract
Value: a lens opacity located in the dense, central part of the lens

Subject: cortical cataract
Value: a lens opacity, frequently punctate, affecting the lens cortex in which spokes or wedges progressively extend from the outside of the lens towards the center

Subject: anterior cortical cataract
Value: a lens opacity, frequently punctate, affecting the anterior pole of the lens cortex in which spokes or wedges progressively extend from the outside of the lens towards the center

Subject: posterior cortical cataract
Value: a lens opacity, frequently punctate, affecting the posterior pole of the lens cortex in which spokes or wedges progressively extend from the outside of the lens towards the center

Subject: polar cataract
Value: a lens opacity, usually disk-shaped, that is limited to an area in the anterior or posterior pole of the lens capsular region

Subject: anterior polar cataract
Value: a lens opacity, usually disk-shaped, that is limited to an area in the anterior pole of the lens capsular region

Subject: posterior polar cataract
Value: a lens opacity, usually disk-shaped, that is limited to an area in the posterior pole of the lens capsular region

Subject: sutural cataract
Value: a lens opacity which follows the shape of anterior or posterior Y suture of the fetal lens and is not progressive; often more severe in males and is congenital, but usually does not affect vision

Subject: lamellar cataract
Value: a concentric lens opacity which is limited to layers of the cortex, affecting one lamella or zonule of an otherwise clear lens; usually congenital

Subject: total cataract
Value: a lens opacity which involves both nuclear and cortical regions, including all fibers of a lens; usually congenital

Subject: increased hepatoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of malignant tumors composed of neoplastic liver cells in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: decreased hepatoma incidence
Value: less than the expected number of malignant tumors composed of neoplastic liver cells in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: decreased liver tumor incidence
Value: less than the expected number of neoplams in the liver, usually in the form of a distinct mass, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: decreased lung tumor incidence
Value: less than the expected number of neoplams in the lung, usually in the form of a distinct mass, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: decreased lymphoma incidence
Value: less than the expected number of neoplasms characterized by a proliferation of malignant lymphocytes in lymphoid tissue in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: decreased mammary gland tumor incidence
Value: less than the expected number of neoplasms in the mammary gland, usually in the form of a distinct mass, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: decreased stomach tumor incidence
Value: less than the expected number of neoplasms in the gastric tissue usually in the form of a distinct mass, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: decreased tongue tumor incidence
Value: less than the expected number of neoplasms in the tongue tissue, usually in the form of a distinct mass, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased tongue tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplasms in the tongue tissue, usually in the form of a distinct mass, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased classified tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of tumors with a specific classification type in a given population in a given time period

Subject: increased organ/body region tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of tumors originating in a specific body region or organ in a given population in a given time period

Subject: increased melanoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of malignant neoplasms, derived from melanocytes and occurring in pigmented tissues, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased intraocular melanoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a dark-pigmented, usually malignant tumor arising from a melanocyte in the uvea of the eye, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased astrocytoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of tumors that arise from astrocytes, large neuroglia cells of nervous tissue, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased glioma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of tumors that arise from glial cells, non-neuronal cells of the nervous tissue, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased gastrointestinal tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of tumors originating in the gastrointestinal system in a given population in a given time period

Subject: increased skeletal tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplasms in the skeletal tissue, usually in the form of a distinct mass, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased nervous system tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of tumors originating in the nervous system in a given population in a given time period

Subject: decreased organ/body region tumor incidence
Value: less than the expected number of tumors originating in a specific body region or organ in a given population in a given time period

Subject: decreased classified tumor incidence
Value: less than the expected number of tumors with a specific classification type in a given population in a given time period

Subject: decreased plasmacytoma incidence
Value: less han the expected number of neoplastic plasma cells in bone or in one of the extramedullary sites occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: decreased skin tumor incidence
Value: less than the expected number of neoplasms in the skin tissue usually in the form of a distinct mass, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased plasmacytoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplastic plasma cells in bone or in one of the extramedullary sites occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased reproductive system tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of tumors originating in the reproductive system in a given population in a given time period

Subject: increased gland tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of tumors originating in a gland in a given population in a given time period

Subject: increased urinary system tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of tumors originating in the urinary system in a given population in a given time period

Subject: increased muscle tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of tumors originating in muscle tissue in a given population in a given time period

Subject: increased cardiovascular system tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of tumors originating in the cardiovascular system in a given population in a given time period

Subject: increased alimentary system tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of tumors originating in the alimentary system in a given population in a given time period

Subject: increased integument system tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of tumors originating in the integument system in a given population in a given time period

Subject: increased kidney tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of tumors originating in the kidney in a given population in a given time period

Subject: increased eye tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of tumors originating in the eye in a given population in a given time period

Subject: increased hemolymphoid system tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of tumors originating in the hemolymphoid system in a given population in a given time period

Subject: increased hepatobiliary system tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of tumors originating in the hepatobiliary system in a given population in a given time period

Subject: increased respiratory system tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of tumors originating in the respiratory system in a given population in a given time period

Subject: increased mammary gland tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplasms in the mammary gland, usually in the form of a distinct mass, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased skin tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplasms in the skin tissue usually in the form of a distinct mass, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased stomach tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplasms in the gastric tissue usually in the form of a distinct mass, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased uvea tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplasms in the uvea, usually in the form of a distinct mass, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased retina tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplasms in the retina, usually in the form of a distinct mass, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased choroid tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplasms in the choroid of the eye, usually in the form of a distinct mass, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased iris tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplasms in the iris of the eye, usually in the form of a distinct mass, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased hamartoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of benign focal malformations in a specific population in a given time period; results from faulty development of an organ, and is composed of an abnormal mixture of tissue elements, or an abnormal proportion of a single element normally present at that site

Subject: abnormal tumor latency
Value: anomaly in the expected time of onset of tumor occurrence

Subject: decreased tumor latency
Value: earlier onset of tumor occurrence than expected

Subject: increased mesothelioma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplasms derived from the lining cells of the pleura and peritoneum, in a specific population in a given time period; is composed of spindle cells or fibrous tissue which may enclose glandlike spaces lined by cuboidal cells

Subject: increased Schwannoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of benign, encapsulated nerve sheath tumors composed of Schwann cells, in a specific population in a given time period; usually associated with a peripheral or cranial nerve

Subject: increased meningioma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of encapsulated neoplasms derived from the meninges, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased oligodendroglioma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of encapsulated neoplasms derived from oligodendrocytes, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased osteoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of benign neoplasms derived from lamellar bone, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased neurofibroma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of benign, encapsulated nerve sheath tumors composed of Schwann cells, in a specific population in a given time period; proliferation is disordered and includes portions of nerve fibers

Subject: increased cholangiocarcinoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of malignant adenocarcimomas arising in the intrahepatic bile duct epithelium, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased thyroid tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplams in the thyroid occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased parotid gland tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplams in the parotid gland occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased salivary gland tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplams in the salivary gland occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased submandibular gland tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplams in the submandibular gland occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased pituitary gland tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplams in the pituitary gland occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased parathyroid gland tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplams in the parathyroid gland occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased cutaneous melanoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a dark-pigmented, usually malignant tumor arising from a melanocyte in the skin, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: retropulsion
Value: a tendency to step or walk backwards

Subject: abnormal malleus processus brevis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the projection extending from the base of the manubrium of the malleus which contacts the upper part of the tympanic membrane where the tympanic cavity makes a deep pocket (epitympanic pocket) surrounding the cartilaginous nodule

Subject: abnormal malleus head morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the rounded portion of the malleus articulating with the body of the incus

Subject: malleus hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the largest of the three auditory ossicles, which resembles a club or hammer

Subject: abnormal malleus neck morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the narrow contracted section of the malleus located between the head and the manubrium

Subject: thin malleus neck
Value: smaller diameter of the narrow contracted section of the malleus located between the head and the manubrium

Subject: abnormal lipoprotein level
Value: any anomaly in the concentrations of any complex or compound containing both lipid and protein, are important components of biological membranes and myelin, and participate in lipid transport

Subject: abnormal circulating lipoprotein level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration in the blood of any complex or compound containing both lipid and protein, are important components of biological membranes and myelin, and participate in lipid transport

Subject: abnormal apolipoprotein level
Value: anomaly in the amount of the a protein that is frequently a component of a lipoprotein complex

Subject: abnormal circulating apolipoprotein level
Value: anomaly in the amount in the blood of a protein that is frequently a component of a lipoprotein complex
