Subject: abnormal circulating apolipoprotein E level
Value: anomaly in the amount in the blood of a protein that is frequently a component of a VLDL, HDL, and chylomicron complexes, and functions in cholesterol transport

Subject: pleural effusion
Value: accumulation of excess fluid in the pleural cavity

Subject: fused first pharyngeal arch
Value: the first arch fails to fully divide along the midline

Subject: increased acute lymphoblastic leukemia incidence
Value: leukemia with an acute onset, characterized by the presence of lymphoblasts in the bone marrow and the peripheral blood

Subject: increased chronic lymphocytic leukemia incidence
Value: an indolent (slow-growing) cancer in which too many immature lymphocytes (white blood cells) are found mostly in the blood and bone marrow.; in later stages of the disease, cancer cells are sometimes found in the lymph nodes

Subject: increased desmoid tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a monoclonal, fibroblastic proliferation arising in musculoaponeurotic structures in a specific population in a given time period; this connective tissue hyperplasia infiltrates locally, recurs frequently after resection but does not metastasize; this tumor may occur at the site of any fascia, but in particular in muscle

Subject: increased cardiac fibroma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign tumor of fibrous or fully developed connective tissue in the cardiac tissue, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased lung fibroma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign tumor of fibrous or fully developed connective tissue in the lung, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased mammary gland fibroma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign tumor of fibrous or fully developed connective tissue in the mammary gland, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased facial angiofibroma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign tumor of fibrous or fully developed connective tissue on the face, in a specific population in a given time period; appear as red or yellow papules containing dilated vascular channels

Subject: increased lipoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign neoplasia derived from lipoblasts or lipocytes of white or brown fat, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased hibernoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign neoplasm derived from brown fat occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased thyroid C-cell carcinoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a malignant neoplasm derived from the calcitonin producing C-cells of the thyroid gland, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased thyroid carcinoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a malignant epithelial neoplasms of the thyroid gland, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: osseous metaplasia
Value: the formation of mature bone elements in the stroma of a neoplasm

Subject: increased pancreatic islet cell carcinoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of malignant neoplasms arising in the pancreatic islet cells, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased teratocarcinoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a mixed germ cell neoplasm contaning elements of embryonal carcinoma and teratoma, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased pituitary adenohypophysis tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplasms in the anterior part of the pituitary that secretes a variety of hormones, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased pituitary melanotroph tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplasms derived from the cells of intermediate pituitary that produce melanocyte stimulating hormone and other peptides from the post-translational processing of pro-opiomelanocortin (POMC)

Subject: gastrointestinal tract polyps
Value: abnormal tissue masses that protrude into the lumen of the gastrointestinal tract and are tethered to the wall of the gastrointestinal tract

Subject: increased odontoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a hamartomatous odontogenic tumor composed of enamel, dentin, cementum, and pulp tissue that may or may not be arranged in the form of a tooth, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased odontosarcoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of an a gnathic malignant connective tissue tumor in which the epithelial component is benign and the proliferative mesenchymal component is malignant, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: abnormal first pharyngeal arch artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the vessels formed within the first pair of branchial arches in embryogenesis

Subject: abnormal second pharyngeal arch artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the vessels formed within the second pair of branchial arches in embryogenesis

Subject: increased prostate gland tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplams in the prostate gland occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: abnormal free fatty acids level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration of the fatty acids which occur in plasma as a result of lipolysis in adipose tissue or when plasma triacyglycerols are taken into tissues

Subject: increased liver free fatty acids level
Value: elevated liver concentrations of the fatty acids which occur in plasma as a result of lipolysis in adipose tissue or when plasma triacyglycerols are taken into tissues

Subject: decreased liver free fatty acids level
Value: reduced liver concentration of the fatty acids which occur in plasma as a result of lipolysis in adipose tissue or when plasma triacyglycerols are taken into tissues

Subject: increased gangliosarcoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a highly aggressive malignant neoplasm arising from mature ganglionic neurons, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased ganglioneuroma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign neoplasm composed of mature ganglionic neurons in a given population in a given time period; cells may be scattered singly or in clumps within a relatively abundant and dense stroma of neurofibrils and collagenous fibers

Subject: increased fibrosarcoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a highly aggressive malignant neoplasm arising from fibrous connective tissue, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased fibroadenoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign mammary gland tumor composed of both fibrous tissue and glandular tissue, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased thymus tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplams in the thymus occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased adrenal cortical tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplams in the adrenal cortex occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased spindle cell carcinoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a highly malignant variant of squamous cell carcinoma, occurring in a specific population in a given time period; spindle cell carcinoma shows biphasic proliferation of conventional SCC component and malignant spindle shape cells with sarcomatous appearance

Subject: abnormal lymphatic system physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the interconnected system of spaces, organs and vessels between body tissues and organs through which fluid, fats, proteins, and lymphocytes are transported to the bloodstream as lymph, and microorganisms and other debris are removed from tissues

Subject: abnormal thalamus neuron morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the impulse-conducting cells in the thalamus or its parts, a midline paired symmetrical structure between the cerebral cortex and midbrain within the brain that controls the flow of information to the cortex

Subject: abnormal throat morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the anterior part of the neck, in front of the vertebral column comprising the pharynx and larynx

Subject: abnormal epiglottis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the most superior of the laryngeal cartilages, which is found at the root of the tongue and folds back over the entrance to the larynx during swallowing, preventing inhalation of food or drink

Subject: throat cyst
Value: presence of fluid-filled usually benign growths in the passage from the mouth to the pharynx

Subject: myeloid hyperplasia
Value: greater than normal number of nucleated cells of the myeloid lineage (a monocyte, granulocyte, or mast cell), found in blood or other tissue

Subject: bilirubinate stones
Value: caliculi in the gallbladder or a bile duct that is composed of calcium bilirubinate

Subject: increased kidney iron level
Value: increase in the amount of iron present in the renal tissue

Subject: decreased kidney iron level
Value: reduction in the amount of iron present in the renal tissue

Subject: abnormal gut flora balance
Value: anomaly in the ratio of microorganisms that live in the digestive tracts of animals, many of which perform symbiotic functions to the host

Subject: increased respiratory quotient
Value: increase in the ratio of the volume of carbon dioxide released to oxygen consumed by a body tissue or an organism compared to controls

Subject: decreased respiratory quotient
Value: reduction in the ratio of the volume of carbon dioxide released to oxygen consumed by a body tissue or an organism compared to controls

Subject: abnormal inner cell mass apoptosis
Value: the cells of the blastocyst that develop into the body of the embryo are undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal dosage compensation
Value: <anomaly in the process of compensating for the two-fold variation in X:autosome chromosome ratios between sexes by a global activation or inactivation of all, or most of, genes on one or both of the X chromosomes>

Subject: abnormal dosage compensation, by inactivation of X chromosome
Value: <anomaly in the process of compensating for the two-fold variation in X-chromosome:autosome ratios between sexes by a global inactivation of all, or most of, the genes on one of the X-chromosomes in the XX sex>

Subject: increased adenoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign epithelial neoplasm with a glandular organization, occurring in a specific population in a given time period; this tumor type usually does not invade or infiltrate surrounding tissue but may remain a benign tumor or progress to malignancy

Subject: increased renal carcinoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of malignant neoplasms arising from kidney epithelial tissue, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: abnormal glycinergic neuron morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the neurons that utilize glycine as a neurotransmitter

Subject: abnormal urinary bladder physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the distensible musculomembranous organ that serves to collect and store urine excreted by the kidneys

Subject: abnormal Bergmann glial cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of one or more astrocyte-type glia cells associated with Purkinje cells in the cerebellum

Subject: abnormal Bergmann glial cell differentiation
Value: abnormal formation of the astrocyte-type glia cells associated with Purkinje cells in the cerebellum

Subject: mosaic coat color
Value: a random coat color pattern due to genetically different populations of cells in the skin e.g. as the result of X-inactivation

Subject: increased adrenocortical adenoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign epithelial neoplasm with a glandular organization arising in the adrenal cortex, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased rhabdomyoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign neoplasm derived from striated muscle and comprised of an encapsulated mass of polygonal cells, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: prolonged QRS complex duration
Value: increase in the length of time of the largest-amplitude portion of the ECG, caused by currents generated when the ventricles depolarize prior to their contraction; prolongation of the QRS complex duration reflects slowed conduction in the heart

Subject: shortened QRS complex duration
Value: decrease in the length of time of the largest-amplitude portion of the ECG, caused by currents generated when the ventricles depolarize prior to their contraction; prolongation of the QRS complex duration reflects slowed conduction in the heart

Subject: decreased QRS amplitude
Value: reduction in the size (height or maximum displacement) of the largest-amplitude portion of the ECG, caused by currents generated when the ventricles depolarize prior to their contraction, suggesting ventricular excitation defects

Subject: abnormal pharyngeal arch development
Value: abnormal formation of the of the transient structures of the embryo that develop into regions of the head, neck and ears

Subject: ectopic pharyngeal arch
Value: abnormal location of any of the transient structures of the embryo resulting in misplaced regions of the head, neck and/or ears

Subject: abnormal otic capsule development
Value: any anomaly in the embryonic cartilage covering that surrounds the inner ear mechanism and develops into bone

Subject: decreased liver glycogen level
Value: less than the normal concentration of a readily converted carbohydrate reserve in liver

Subject: decreased skeletal muscle glycogen level
Value: less than the normal concentration of a readily converted carbohydrate reserve in skeletal muscle

Subject: increased liver glycogen level
Value: greater than the normal concentration of a readily converted carbohydrate reserve in liver

Subject: increased skeletal muscle glycogen level
Value: greater than the normal concentration of a readily converted carbohydrate reserve in skeletal muscle

Subject: ventricular septal defect
Value: abnormal communications between the two lower chambers of the heart, including such defects in the perimembranous, inlet, outlet (infundibular), central muscular, marginal muscular, or apical muscular regions

Subject: atrial septal defect
Value: abnormal communications between the two upper chambers of the heart, including such defects in any or all of the ostium primum, ostium secundum, sinus venosus, and coronary sinus regions

Subject: ostium primum atrial septal defect
Value: interatrial communication (atrial septal defect) through the most anterior and inferior aspect of the atrial septum

Subject: ostium secundum atrial septal defect
Value: large interatrial communication (atrial septal defect) through the center of the wall between the atria at the site of the foramen ovale and the ostium secundum

Subject: common atrium
Value: absence of the thin membranous structure between the two heart atria, resulting in the appearance of one upper chamber

Subject: coronary sinus atrial septal defect
Value: interatrial communication (atrial septal defect) through coronary sinus orifice, that is characterized by the absence of at least a portion of the common wall that separates the coronary sinus and the left atrium; interatrial shunting occurs through the defect in the wall on the left atrial side, which is continuous with the orifice of the coronary sinus opening on the right atrial side of the septum

Subject: sinus venosus atrial septal defect
Value: interatrial communication (atrial septal defect) through the upper atrial septum and that is contiguous with the superior vena cava (SVC); it is rostral and posterior to the fossa ovalis (where secundum type defects occur) and is separate from it

Subject: cor triatriatum
Value: a heart with 3 atria, is in which either the left or right atrium is divided into 2 parts by a fold of tissue, a membrane, or a fibromuscular band that may vary significantly in size and shape, appearing similar to a diaphragm or funnel-shaped, bandlike, entirely intact (imperforate) or contain 1 or more openings (fenestrations) ranging from small, restrictive-type to large and widely open

Subject: cor triatriatum sinistrum
Value: a heart with 3 atria, is in which the left atrium is divided into 2 parts by a fold of tissue, a membrane, or a fibromuscular band

Subject: cor triatriatum dextrum
Value: a heart with 3 atria, is in which the right atrium is divided into 2 parts by a fold of tissue, a membrane, or a fibromuscular band

Subject: atrioventricular septal defect
Value: defects in the thin membranous structure between the right atrium and left ventricle that arise from faulty development of the embryonic endocardial cushions; the spectrum ranges from a primum atrial septal defect and cleft mitral valve, known as a partial atrioventricular septal defect (partial AVSD), to defects of both the primum atrial septum and inlet ventricular septum and the presence of a common atrioventricular valve, referred to as complete atrioventricular septal defect (complete AVSD)

Subject: complete atrioventricular septal defect
Value: a type of atrioventricular septal defect in which a single atrioventricular valve annulus, a common atrioventricular valve, and a defect of the inlet ventricular septum are observed; deficiency of the atrioventricular septum also results in the presence of a large primum atrial septal defect

Subject: partial atrioventricular septal defect
Value: a type of atrioventricular septal defect in which the endocardial cushion defects present have an interatrial communication but lack an interventricular communication; the mitral and tricuspid annuli are separate but one or more additional features are present, including primum atrial septal defect (ASD), inlet ventricular septal defect (VSD), cleft of the anterior mitral valve leaflet, and wide anteroseptal tricuspid valve commissure or cleft septal tricuspid leaflet

Subject: intermediate atrioventricular septal defect
Value: a type of atrioventricular septal defect in which a partial AVSD is present together with a small interventricular communication; a single valvar annulus is usually present where the anterior and posterior bridging leaflets fuse overlying the ventricular septum, with two distinct valvar components observed

Subject: interventricular septum membranous part aneurysm
Value: a a saclike thinning, stretching and widening of the ventricular membranous septum resulting from weakening of the membraneous septum wall

Subject: subarterial ventricular septal defect
Value: abnormal communications between the two lower chambers of the heart, located beneath the pulmonic valve, communicating with the RV outflow tract above the supraventricular crest, and are associated with aortic regurgitation secondary to the prolapse of the right aortic cusp

Subject: perimembraneous ventricular septal defect
Value: abnormal communications between the two lower chambers of the heart, occurring in the membranous septum with defects in the adjacent muscular portion of the septum; it is generally located in the LV outflow tract just below the aortic valve, associated with pouches or aneurysms of the septal leaflet of the tricuspid valve, which may partially or completely close the defect; an LV-to-RA shunt may also be associated with this defect

Subject: inlet ventricular septal defect
Value: abnormal communications between the two lower chambers of the heart, located posterior to the septal leaflet of the tricuspid valve and which are not associated with defects of the atrioventricular valves

Subject: muscular ventricular septal defect
Value: abnormal communications between the two lower chambers of the heart, involving the muscular septum and often occurring as multiple communications, and includes central muscular or midmuscular, apical, or marginal communications when the defect is along the RV-septal junction; any single defect observed from the LV aspect may have several openings on the RV aspect

Subject: ventricular aneurysm
Value: thinning, stretching and bulging of a weakened ventricular wall

Subject: heart right ventricle hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the heart right ventricle, often due to a reduced number of cells

Subject: heart right ventricle aneurysm
Value: thinning, stretching and bulging of a weakened heart right ventricular wall

Subject: double chambered heart right ventricle
Value: septated right ventricle caused by the presence of abnormally located or hypertrophied cardiac muscle bands that divide the ventricular cavity into a proximal and a distal chamber; the muscle bundles typically run between an area located in the ventricular septum, beneath the level of the septal leaflet of the tricuspid valve, and the anterior wall of the right ventricle

Subject: abnormal heart and great vessel attachment
Value: any anomaly in the in the position or pattern of the connection site of the heart to any of the primary vessels, including the superior vena cavae, inferior vena cavae, pulmonary artery, pulmonary veins, and aorta

Subject: abnormal heart and great artery attachment
Value: any anomaly in the in the position or pattern of the connection site of the heart to any of the great arteries, including the pulmonary artery and aorta

Subject: double outlet left ventricle
Value: both the aorta and the pulmonary trunk originate from the left ventricle

Subject: abnormal heart right ventricle outflow tract morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anteriosuperior, smooth-walled portion of the cavity of the right ventricle, beginning at the supraventricular crest and terminating in the pulmonary trunk

Subject: abnormal heart left ventricle outflow tract morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anterosuperior fibrous portion of the left ventricle that connects to the ascending aorta

Subject: total anomalous pulmonary venous connection, supracardiac
Value: the pulmonary veins drain via a common vein into the right superior vena cava, left superior vena cava, or their tributaries instead of the left atrium

Subject: atrial situs inversus
Value: anomaly in the asymmetry of the cardiac atria such that atria on both the left and right side have the morphology normally seen on the opposite side of the body

Subject: common ventricle
Value: the presence of only one working lower chamber in the heart, usually with a virtual absence of the ventricular septum and usually present in conjunction with double inlet left or right ventricle

Subject: double inlet heart left ventricle
Value: congenital heart defect in which both atriums are connected to the left ventricle, with a hypoplastic right ventricle often present, which may be on the opposite side of the heart

Subject: double inlet heart right ventricle
Value: congenital heart defect in which both atriums are connected to the right ventricle, with a hypoplastic left ventricle often present

Subject: abnormal heart atrium and ventricle connection
Value: any anomaly in the in the position or pattern of the connection site of the heart atrium to the ventricles, usually occurring through the atrioventricular valves

Subject: abnormal coronary sinus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the short trunk that recieves most of the cardiac veins carrying the blood from the myocardium and delivers it to the right atrium, with the sinoatrial connection occurring between the inferior vena cava and the atrioventricular orifice

Subject: absent coronary sinus
Value: absence of the short trunk that recieves most of the cardiac veins carrying the blood from the myocardium and delivers it to the right atrium

Subject: pulmonary vein stenosis
Value: a stricture or occlusion of the lumen of the pulmonary vein

Subject: abnormal hepatic vein morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the veins that drain blood from the liver and terminate in three large openings to the inferior vena cava below the diaphragm and into smaller openings in more inferior positions

Subject: anomalous pulmonary venous connection
Value: abnormal development and attachment of the four pulmonary veins that normally attach to the left atrium of the heart, resulting in either partial or complete anomalous drainage back into the systemic venous circulation via an anomalous connection to the right atrium, the superior or inferior vena cava, the innominate vein, the coronary sinus or the left subclavian artery

Subject: total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
Value: abnormal development and attachment of all four pulmonary veins that normally attach to the left atrium of the heart, resulting in complete anomalous drainage back into the systemic venous circulation via an anomalous connection to the right atrium, the superior or inferior vena cava, the innominate vein, the coronary sinus or the left subclavian artery; in TAPVC, none of the four pulmonary veins are attached to the left atrium

Subject: partial anomalous pulmonary venous connection
Value: abnormal development and attachment of one to three of the four pulmonary veins that normally attach to the left atrium of the heart, resulting in partial drainage back into the systemic venous circulation via an anomalous connection to the right atrium, the superior or inferior vena cava, the innominate vein, the coronary sinus or the left subclavian artery; in PAPVC, at least one pulmonary vein remains attached to the left atrium

Subject: total anomalous pulmonary venous connection, intracardiac
Value: the pulmonary veins connect directly to the right side of heart (eg, coronary sinus or directly to the right atrium) instead of the left atrium

Subject: total anomalous pulmonary venous connection, infracardiac
Value: the common pulmonary vein travels down anterior to the esophagus through the diaphragm to connect to the portal venous system instead of the left atrium

Subject: total anomalous pulmonary venous connection, mixed
Value: the right and left pulmonary veins drain to different sites other than the left atrium; for example, the left pulmonary veins into the left vertical vein to the left innominate, and/or the right pulmonary veins directly into the right atrium or coronary sinus

Subject: heart left ventricle hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the heart left ventricle, often due to a reduced number of cells

Subject: heart left ventricle aneurysm
Value: thinning, stretching and bulging of a weakened heart left ventricular wall

Subject: heart left ventricle outflow tract stenosis
Value: abnormal constriction or narrowing of the portion of the left ventricle through which blood normally flows into the aorta

Subject: heart right ventricle outflow tract stenosis
Value: abnormal constriction or narrowing of part of the anteriosuperior, smooth-walled portion of the cavity of the right ventricle, beginning at the supraventricular crest and terminating in the pulmonary trunk

Subject: atrial septal aneurysm
Value: a saclike thinning, stretching and widening of the heart atrial septum resulting from weakening of the septum wall

Subject: kidney microaneurysm
Value: focal dilation of arteriocapillary junctions in the kidney

Subject: retina microaneurysm
Value: focal dilation of arteriocapillary junctions in the retina

Subject: abnormal coronary vein morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the veins that return blood from the heart muscles to the right atrium through the coronary sinus

Subject: abnormal truncus arteriosus septation
Value: anomaly in the process of dividing the common arterial trunk arising out of both heart ventricles to divide into the aorta and pulmonary artery during development

Subject: aortopulmonary window
Value: a defect between the great vessels that results from failure of the conotruncal ridges to fuse resulting in an abnormal communication between the aorta and the pulmonary arteries

Subject: hemitruncus
Value: congenital heart defect in which the origin of a pulmonary artery, usually the right, arises from the ascending aorta instead of the pulmonary trunk with the aortic and pulmonary valves remaining separate

Subject: pulmonary artery stenosis
Value: constriction or narrowing of the pulmonary artery

Subject: pulmonary trunk hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the region of the pulmonary artery that arises from the right ventricle to the division of the right and left pulmonary artery, usually due to reduced cell number

Subject: supravalvar pulmonary trunk stenosis
Value: diffuse constriction or narrowing of the pulmonary trunk distal to the pulmonary valve

Subject: pulmonary artery hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the artery that arises from the right ventricle and conveys unaerated blood to the lungs, usually due to reduced cell number

Subject: discontinuous pulmonary artery
Value: one or more pulmonary arteries is disconnected from the main pulmonary trunk and arises from a patent ductus arteriosus

Subject: pulmonary artery aneurysm
Value: a protruding sac formed by the dilation of the wall of a pulmonary artery resulting from a weakening of the vessel wall

Subject: aorta stenosis
Value: diffuse constriction or narrowing of the aorta

Subject: abnormal aortic arch and aortic arch branch attachment
Value: any anomaly of the connection site of the aortic branches to the aortic arch, including the attachment sites for the left common carotid artery, the left subclavian artery, and the brachiocephalic trunk which further splits to form the right subclavian artery and the right common carotid artery

Subject: aberrant origin of the right subclavian artery
Value: the right subclavian artery arises from an atypical location on the aortic arch or the proximal descending aorta

Subject: vascular ring
Value: the trachea and esophagus are completely encircled by connected segments of the aortic arch and its branches

Subject: pulmonary artery sling
Value: anomalous origin of the left pulmonary artery from the posterior aspect of the right pulmonary artery, with the anomalous left pulmonary artery coursing over the right mainstem bronchus and then from right to left, posterior to the trachea or carina and anterior to the esophagus, to reach the hilum of the left lung, which compresses the lower trachea and right mainstem bronchus

Subject: abnormal thoracic aorta morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the part of the aorta that extends from the origin at the heart to the diaphragm, and from which arises numerous branches that supply oxygenated blood to the chest cage and the organs within the chest

Subject: ascending aorta hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the portion of the aorta that arises from the base of the left ventricle and extends upward to the aortic arch and from which the coronary arteries arise, usually due to reduced cell number

Subject: ascending aorta dilation
Value: the luminal space of the ascending aorta is increased in volume or area, usually with an increase of contained fluid

Subject: supravalvar aortic stenosis
Value: a narrowing, diffuse constriction or obstruction of the ascending aorta located just distal to the aortic valve at the aortic root

Subject: abnormal ascending aorta and coronary artery attachment
Value: any anomaly of the connection site of any or all of the coronary arteries to the ascending aorta

Subject: descending aorta dilation
Value: widening or enlargment of the lumen of the descending aorta

Subject: descending aorta hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the descending aorta, usually due to reduced cell number

Subject: anomalous pulmonary origin of left coronary artery
Value: the left coronary artery arises from the pulmonary artery insead of the aorta

Subject: coronary fistula
Value: an abnormal communication between the terminus of a coronary artery, bypassing the myocardial capillary bed and entering either a chamber of the heart (coronary-cameral fistula) or any segment of the systemic or pulmonary circulation (coronary arteriovenous fistula)

Subject: coronary artery aneurysm
Value: a protruding sac formed by the dilation of the wall of a coronary artery resulting from a weakening of the vessel wall

Subject: intracranial aneurysm
Value: a protruding sac within the cranial space formed by the dilation of the wall of an artery or a vein resulting from a weakening of the vessel wall

Subject: brain aneurysm
Value: a protruding sac within the brain formed by the dilation of the wall of an artery or a vein resulting from a weakening of the vessel wall

Subject: pulmonary arteriovenous malformation
Value: abnormal communications between the pulmonary arteries and the pulmonary veins, or between a bronchial artery and the pulmonary vein

Subject: left ventricle to aorta tunnel
Value: an abnormal communication between the left ventricle and the ascending aorta in addition to the aortic valve

Subject: abnormal aortic sinus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the spaces betwen the superior aspect of each of the three cusps of the aortic valve and the dilated portion of the wall of the ascending aorta, immediately above each cusp; the three sinuses include the posterior (non-coronary sinus), and the right and left aortic sinuses (from which the left and right coronary arteries arise)

Subject: aortic sinus aneurysm
Value: a protruding sac formed by the dilation of the wall of the aortic sinus resulting from a weakening of the vessel wall

Subject: bicuspid aortic valve
Value: the presence of two cusps in the aortic valve instead of three

Subject: aortic arch hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the aortic arch, usually due to reduced cell number

Subject: absent right subclavian artery
Value: absence of one of the two subclavian arteries; the right subclavian artery normally extends from the brachiocephalic artery to the right side of the body

Subject: abnormal right subclavian artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the artery that normally extends from the brachiocephalic artery to the right side of the body

Subject: abnormal left subclavian artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the artery that extends from the aortic arch to the left side of the body

Subject: abnormal heart atrium auricular region morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small conical pouch projections located on the upper anterior portion of each atrium of the heart

Subject: abnormal inferior vena cava valve morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the semicircular fold of endocardium located on the right atrium at the point of attachment of the inferior vena cava

Subject: abnormal coronary sinus valve morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the semicircular fold of the right atrial endocardium located at the coronary sinus attachment to the right atrium that serves to prevent the reflux of blood back to the coronary arteries during atrial contraction

Subject: abnormal atrium endocardium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thin serous membrane, primarily composed of endothelial tissue, that lines the interior of the atria

Subject: abnormal atrium myocardium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the atrial part of middle layer of the heart, comprised of involuntary muscle

Subject: abnormal ventricle endocardium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thin serous membrane, primarily composed of endothelial tissue, that lines the interior of the ventricles

Subject: abnormal crista terminalis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the vertical crest of the interior wall of the right atrium that lies to the right of the sinus of the vena cava and separates this from the remainder of the right atrium

Subject: abnormal pectinate muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the prominent ridges of atrial myocardium located on the inner surface of most of the right atrium and both the right and left auricular regions

Subject: abnormal vena cava sinus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the portion of the cavity of the right atrium of the heart that receives the blood from the vena cavae and is separated from the rest of the atrium by the crista terminalis

Subject: abnormal interventricular septum muscular part morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the muscular portion of the wall between the two lower chambers of the heart

Subject: abnormal ventricle myocardium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the ventricular part of middle layer of the heart, comprised of involuntary muscle

Subject: myocardium hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the heart myocardium

Subject: atrium myocardium hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the atrial part of the heart myocardium

Subject: ventricle myocardium hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the ventricular part of the heart myocardium

Subject: myocardial trabeculae hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the supporting bundles of muscular fibers lining the walls of the heart, usually due to a reduced number of cells

Subject: abnormal RR interval
Value: anomaly in the length of the interval between an R wave and the next R wave; the RR interval is the inverse of the heart rate

Subject: abnormal T wave
Value: any anomaly in the T wave which is normally caused by the repolarization (or recovery) of the ventricles

Subject: prolonged RR interval
Value: increase in the length of the interval between an R wave and the next R wave; the RR interval is the inverse of the heart rate

Subject: shortened RR interval
Value: reduction in the length of the interval between an R wave and the next R wave; the RR interval is the inverse of the heart rate

Subject: abnormal heart electrocardiography waveform feature
Value: any anomaly in the pattern of the graphic record of the integrated action currents of the cardiac cycle represented as changes in voltage; the prominent waves in the ECG correspond to specific conduction activity in areas of the heart and the timing and amplitude of ECG waveforms provide valuable information about heart rate and rhythm

Subject: decreased P wave amplitude
Value: reduction in the size (height or maximum displacement) of the P wave

Subject: absent P wave
Value: absence of the P wave which represents atrial depolarization and corresponds to electrical impulses rather than mechanical atria contractions

Subject: shortened PR interval
Value: decrease in the length of time between the beginning of atrial depolarization and the beginning of ventricular depolarization, measured by the interval from the beginning of the P wave to the beginning of the QRS complex

Subject: absent PR interval
Value: absence of the ECG segment representing the length of time between the beginning of atrial depolarization and the beginning of ventricular depolarization, measured by the interval from the beginning of the P wave to the beginning of the QRS complex

Subject: abnormal ventricular activation time
Value: any anomaly in the length of time from the beginning of the Q wave to the peak of the R wave

Subject: fragmented QRS complex
Value: changes in QRS waveform pattern including different RSR' patterns, additional R waves, notched or absent Q or S wave, or more than one R wave

Subject: abnormal Q wave
Value: any anomaly in the downward deflection in the ECG occurring after the PR interval that represents depolarization of the interventricular septum

Subject: absent Q wave
Value: absence of the downward deflection in the ECG occurring after the PR interval that represents depolarization of the interventricular septum

Subject: abnormal Bachmann's bundle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the impulse conduction tract that originates in the sinoatrial node and transmits signal to the left atrium

Subject: atrioventricular block
Value: a partial or complete obstruction of the impulse that originates in the atria or sinoatrial node from reaching or transmitting through the atrioventricular node to the ventricles

Subject: sinoatrial block
Value: a partial or complete obstruction of the impulse leaving the sinoatrial node preventing it from activating atrial muscle

Subject: absent pulmonary artery
Value: absence of the artery that arises from the right ventricle and conveys unaerated blood to the lungs

Subject: calcified aorta
Value: pathologic deposition of calcium salts in the aorta

Subject: calcified thoracic aorta
Value: pathologic deposition of calcium salts in the part of the aorta that extends from the origin at the heart to the diaphragm

Subject: calcified aortic arch
Value: pathologic deposition of calcium salts in the convex portion of the aorta between the ascending and descending parts of the aorta

Subject: abdominal aorta coarctation
Value: a congenital focal constriction of the abdominal aorta

Subject: aortic arch coarctation
Value: a congenital focal constriction of the aortic arch

Subject: bicuspid pulmonary valve
Value: the presence of two cusps or leaflets in the pulmonary valve instead of three

Subject: pulmonary vein hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the veins that return oxygenated blood from the lungs to the left atrium of the heart, usually due to reduced cell number

Subject: hepatic arteriovenous malformation
Value: congenital vascular anomaly in the liver characterized by direct communication between an artery and a vein without passing through the capillary bed

Subject: cerebral arteriovenous malformation
Value: congenital vascular anomaly in the cerebrum characterized by direct communication between an artery and a vein without passing through the capillary bed

Subject: gastrointestinal arteriovenous malformation
Value: congenital vascular anomaly in the gastrointestinal system characterized by direct communication between an artery and a vein without passing through the capillary bed

Subject: absent atrioventricular node
Value: absence of the small nodular mass of specialized muscle fibers located in the interatrial septum near the opening of the coronary sinus

Subject: atrioventricular node hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the small nodular mass of specialized muscle fibers located in the interatrial septum near the opening of the coronary sinus

Subject: calcified myocardium
Value: pathologic deposition of calcium salts in the myocardium

Subject: myocardium steatosis
Value: an accumulation of fat deposits in the myocardium

Subject: Ebstein's malformation of tricuspid valve
Value: a congenital downward displacement of the septal and posterior leaflets of the tricuspid valve into the inlet portion of the right ventricle

Subject: tumor regression
Value: a decrease in tumor size from a formerly larger state and/or a decrease in the extent of tumors in the body

Subject: increased level of surface class II molecules
Value: increase in the concentration of major histocompatibility complex class II molecules expressed at the cell surface

Subject: decreased level of surface class II molecules
Value: reduction in the concentration of major histocompatibility complex class II molecules expressed at the cell surface

Subject: long stride length
Value: increased average distance between steps

Subject: aorta hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the main trunk of the systemic arterial system that originates from the base of the left ventricle of the heart and extends to the abdomen at the point where it branches into the common iliac arteries, usually due to reduced cell number

Subject: right ventricular myocardium hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the heart right ventricular part of the heart myocardium

Subject: aorta tubular hypoplasia
Value: a diffuse narrowing of the lumen of the aorta

Subject: interrupted aorta
Value: complete discontinuation or blockage in the aorta

Subject: abnormal heart layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the laminar structure of the heart

Subject: abnormal subendocardium layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the layer of loose fibrous tissue located between the endocardium and myocardium which contains the nerves and the impulse-conducting system (Purkinje fibers) of the heart

Subject: abnormal mesocardium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the layer of splanchnic mesoderm supporting the embryonic heart in the pericardial cavity; mesocardium normally regresses before birth

Subject: abnormal dorsal mesocardium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the part of the mesocardium that lies dorsal to the embryonic heart; the dorsal mesocardium gives rise to the transverse sinus of the pericardium in the adult

Subject: absent dorsal mesocardium
Value: absence of the part of the mesocardium that lies dorsal to the embryonic heart; the dorsal mesocardium gives rise to the transverse sinus of the pericardium in the adult

Subject: abnormal coronary vessel morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the arteries or veins that supply blood to the heart or return blood from the heart muscles to the circulation

Subject: abnormal HV interval
Value: any anomaly in the time from the initial deflection of the His bundle (H) potential and the onset of ventricular activity

Subject: prolonged HV interval
Value: increase in the length of time from the initial deflection of the His bundle (H) potential and the onset of ventricular activity

Subject: shortened HV interval
Value: decrease in the length of time from the initial deflection of the His bundle (H) potential and the onset of ventricular activity

Subject: absent epicardium
Value: absence of the visceral layer of the pericardium that surrounds and attaches to all the surfaces of the heart

Subject: thin ventricle myocardium compact layer
Value: reduced thickness of the ventricular portion of the outer, dense layer of the myocardium

Subject: dilated pulmonary artery
Value: the luminal space of the pulmonary artery is increased in volume or area, usually with an increase of contained fluid

Subject: sinus venosus hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the cavity at the caudal end of the embryonic cardiac tube in which the veins from the intra- and extraembryonic circulatory arcs unite, usually due to a reduced number of cells

Subject: heart block
Value: a partial or complete obstruction of the propogation of electric impulses through the impulse conduction system of the heart

Subject: intraventricular block
Value: absent or delayed conduction within the ventricular conducting system or in the ventricular myocardium

Subject: absent coronary vessels
Value: absence of the arteries and veins that supply blood to the heart or return blood from the heart muscles to the circulation

Subject: absent sinus venosus
Value: absence of the cavity at the caudal end of the embryonic cardiac tube in which the veins from the intra- and extraembryonic circulatory arcs unite

Subject: increased heart right ventricle size
Value: greater than average size of the right ventricle

Subject: abnormal fetal ductus arteriosus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the fetal vessel that connects the left pulmonary artery with the descending aorta; the ductus arteriosus normally regresses into a fibrous cord, the ligamentum arteriousum after birth

Subject: absent fetal ductus arteriosus
Value: absence of the fetal vessel that connects the left pulmonary artery with the descending aorta

Subject: abnormal left posterior bundle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the left branch of the atrioventricular bundle that separates at the bundle of His, descends the septal wall of the left ventricle and connects to the terminal Purkinje fiber

Subject: abnormal right bundle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the right branch of the atrioventricular bundle that separates just below the bundle of His, descends the septal wall of the right ventricle and connects to the terminal Purkinje fibers

Subject: abnormal bulbus cordis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a transient fetal dilation of the distal (or cranial) heart tube located where the arterial trunk joins the ventral roots of the aortic arches

Subject: papillary muscle hypertrophy
Value: increased bulk size of the group of myocardial bundles which terminate in the chordae tendineae that attach to the cusps of the atrioventricular valves

Subject: prolonged ST segment
Value: increase in the length of time between the end of S-wave and the beginning of T-wave; reflects the amount of time the ventricles remain electrically depolarized

Subject: shortened ST segment
Value: reduction in the length of time between the end of S-wave and the beginning of T-wave; reflects the amount of time the ventricles remain electrically depolarized

Subject: persistent right dorsal aorta
Value: persistence of the right dorsal aorta after development; the right dorsal aorta normally regresses but when it persists, a double aortic arch develops; if the left dorsal aorta also regresses, a right aortic arch forms

Subject: left dorsal aorta regression
Value: regression of the left dorsal aorta which normally develops into the aortic arch; together with a persistent right dorsal aorta, a right aortic arch forms

Subject: aorta dilation
Value: the luminal space of the aorta is increased in volume or area, usually with an increase of contained fluid

Subject: aortic arch dilation
Value: the luminal space of the aortic arch is increased in volume or area, usually with an increase of contained fluid

Subject: premature closure of the ductus arteriosus
Value: premature regression of the ductus arteriosus that normally regresses into a fibrous cord, the ligamentum arteriousum after birth

Subject: abnormal heart right ventricle size
Value: anomaly of the average size of the right ventricle compared to the average for a particular population

Subject: abnormal heart left ventricle size
Value: anomaly of the average size of the left ventricle compared to the average for a particular population

Subject: increased heart left ventricle size
Value: greater than average size of the left ventricle

Subject: decreased heart left ventricle size
Value: less than average size of the left ventricle compared to the average for a particular population

Subject: abnormal atrium myocardial trabeculae morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the supporting bundles of muscular fibers lining the walls of the atria

Subject: abnormal bulbus cordis septation
Value: anomaly in the process in which the distal swelling of the primitive heart tube separates into an inferior end, which will form much of the right ventricle, and a superior end, which first form an outflow channel called the conotruncus; the conotruncus will in turn give rise to the more proximal conus cordis and the more distal truncus arteriosus

Subject: abnormal conotruncus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the distal portion of the bulbus cordis that will give rise to the conus cordis, which will give rise to the outflow regions of the ventricles, and the truncus arteriosus which will be divided into proximal ends of the ascending aorta and pulmonary trunk

Subject: abnormal conotruncus septation
Value: anomaly in the process in which the conotruncus separates into the conus cordis, which will give rise to the outflow regions of the ventricles, and the truncus arteriosus which will be divided into proximal ends of the ascending aorta and pulmonary trunk

Subject: abnormal conotruncal ridge morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the pair of spiral mesenchymal swellings in the primordial ventricular outflow tract, that eventually fuse to form the conotruncal septum, dividing the subvalvular outflow tract and contributing to the membranous interventricular septum

Subject: absent conotruncal ridges
Value: absence of the pair of spiral mesenchymal swellings in the primordial ventricular outflow tract, that eventually fuse to form the conotruncal septum, dividing the subvalvular outflow tract and contributing to the membranous interventricular septum

Subject: conotruncal ridge hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the pair of spiral mesenchymal swellings in the primordial ventricular outflow tract, that eventually fuse to form the conotruncal septum, dividing the subvalvular outflow tract and contributing to the membranous interventricular septum

Subject: conotruncal ridge hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size of the pair of spiral mesenchymal swellings in the primordial ventricular outflow tract, that eventually fuse to form the conotruncal septum, dividing the subvalvular outflow tract and contributing to the membranous interventricular septum

Subject: common truncal valve
Value: a single outflow tract valve that opens into the truncus arteriosus that is frequently present in cases of truncus arteriosus septation defects

Subject: common truncal valve stenosis
Value: abnormal constriction or narrowing of the single outflow tract valve that opens into the truncus arteriosus that is frequently present in cases of truncus arteriosus septation defects

Subject: enlarged aortic valve
Value: an increase in the total area occupied by the aortic valve

Subject: abnormal atrioventricular septum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the wall of the heart that separates the right atrium and left ventricle; and is located just above the septal cusp of the tricuspid valve

Subject: thick aortic valve cusps
Value: an increase in the ratio of the aortic valve cusp thickness to the aortic wall thickness

Subject: thick aortic valve
Value: an increase in the ratio of the aortic valve wall thickness to the aortic wall thickness

Subject: abnormal aortic valve cusp morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the three fibrous triangular components and associated flap of the aortic valve

Subject: unicuspid aortic valve
Value: the presence of one cusp and associated flap in the aortic valve instead of three

Subject: absent aortic valve cusps
Value: absence of the three fibrous triangular components and associated flaps of the aortic valve

Subject: abnormal aortic valve anulus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the fibrous ring of the aortic valve that attaches the cusps of aortic valve to the wall of left ventricle, and which consists of portions of the fibrous scallops of the posterior, right anterior and left anterior cusps

Subject: abnormal fetal atrioventricular canal septation
Value: anomaly in the process by which the dorsal and ventral endocardial cushions develop in the walls of the common atrioventricular canal, grow toward each other and fuse, dividing the common atrioventricular canal into right and left atrioventricular canals and the atrioventricular septum

Subject: enlarged pulmonary valve
Value: an increase in the total area occupied by the pulmonary valve

Subject: thick pulmonary valve
Value: an increase in the ratio of the pulmonary valve wall thickness to the pulmonary artery wall thickness

Subject: abnormal pulmonary valve cusp morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the three fibrous triangular components and associated flap of the pulmonary valve

Subject: unicuspid pulmonary valve
Value: the presence of one cusp and associated flap in the pulmonary valve instead of three

Subject: absent pulmonary valve cusps
Value: absence of the three fibrous triangular components and associated flaps of the pulmonary valve

Subject: thick pulmonary valve cusps
Value: an increase in the ratio of the pulmonary valve cusp thickness to the pulmonary artery wall thickness

Subject: abnormal pulmonary valve anulus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the fibrous ring of the pulmonary valve that attaches the cusps of pulmonary valve to the wall of right ventricle, and which consists of portions of the fibrous scallops of the anterior, right posterior and left posterior cusps

Subject: common atrioventricular valve
Value: the presence of a single atrioventricular valve instead of both a mitral and tricuspid valve, most commonly due to incomplete or failure of fetal atrioventricular canal septation

Subject: abnormal chordae tendineae morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tendinous strands that connect the papillary muscles on the wall of the ventricles to the leaflets of the atrioventricular valves; the chordae tendineae serve to prevent the AV valves from prolapsing back into the atria

Subject: absent chordae tendineae
Value: absence of the tendinous strands that connect the papillary muscles on the wall of the ventricles to the leaflets of the atrioventricular valves; the chordae tendineae serve to prevent the AV valves from prolapsing back into the atria

Subject: patent aortic valve
Value: the aortic valve remains open during the cardiac cycle

Subject: patent pulmonary valve
Value: the pulmonary valve remains open during the cardiac cycle

Subject: muscular subaortic stenosis
Value: a narrowing or obstruction of the left ventricular outflow tract resulting from hypertrophy of the interventricular septum, which results in obstruction to blood flow

Subject: abnormal mitral valve anulus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the fibrous ring of the mitral valve that attaches the cusps of mitral valve to the heart, and which consists of portions of the fibrous scallops of the anterior and posterior cusps

Subject: abnormal mitral valve cusp morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the two fibrous components and associated flaps of the mitral valve

Subject: unicuspid mitral valve
Value: the presence of one cusp and associated flap in the mitral valve instead of two

Subject: absent mitral valve cusps
Value: absence of the two fibrous components and associated flaps of the mitral valve

Subject: thick mitral valve cusps
Value: an increase in the ratio of the mitral valve cusp wall thickness to the atrioventricular septum thickness

Subject: enlarged mitral valve
Value: an increase in the total area occupied by the mitral valve

Subject: patent mitral valve
Value: the mitral valve remains open during the cardiac cycle

Subject: thick mitral valve
Value: an increase in the ratio of the mitral valve wall thickness to the atrioventricular septum thickness

Subject: abnormal tricuspid valve anulus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the fibrous ring of the tricuspid valve that attaches the cusps of tricuspid valve to the heart, and which consists of portions of the fibrous scallops of the anterior cusp (infundibular cusp), the posterior cusp (marginal cusp), and the septal cusp (medial cusp)

Subject: abnormal tricuspid valve cusp morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the three fibrous triangular components and associated flaps of the tricuspid valve

Subject: bicuspid tricuspid valve
Value: the presence of two cusps and associated flaps in the tricuspid valve instead of three

Subject: unicuspid tricuspid valve
Value: the presence of one cusp and associated flap in the tricuspid valve instead of three

Subject: absent tricuspid valve cusps
Value: absence of the three fibrous triangular components and associated flaps of the tricuspid valve

Subject: thick tricuspid valve cusps
Value: an increase in the ratio of the tricuspid valve cusp wall thickness to the atrioventricular septum thickness

Subject: enlarged tricuspid valve
Value: an increase in the total area occupied by the tricuspid valve

Subject: patent tricuspid valve
Value: the tricuspid valve remains open during the cardiac cycle

Subject: thick tricuspid valve
Value: an increase in the ratio of the tricuspid valve wall thickness to the atrioventricular septum thickness

Subject: abnormal cardiac muscle tissue morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the involuntary muscle comprising the myocardium of the heart and the walls of the pulmonary veins and superior vena cava; cardiac muscle is striated and multinucleate, and the cardiomyocytes branch and are joined to one another via intercalated discs

Subject: increased Q wave amplitude
Value: increase in the size (height or maximum displacement) of the downward deflection in the ECG occurring after the PR interval that represents depolarization of the interventricular septum

Subject: cardiac muscle necrosis
Value: morphological changes resulting from pathological death of cardiomyocytes or a portion of the cardiac muscle tissue; usually due to irreversible damage

Subject: myocardium hypertrophy
Value: an increase in size of the myocardium, not due to increased cell number

Subject: increased QRS amplitude
Value: increased in the size (height or maximum displacement) of the largest-amplitude portion of the ECG, caused by currents generated when the ventricles depolarize prior to their contraction, suggesting ventricular excitation defects

Subject: aorta pulmonary collateral arteries
Value: small ectopic arteries or arterial branches that connect the aorta, aortic branches and/or subclavian artery regions directly to the lung parenchyma, usually seen in conjunction with pulmonary atresia, ventricular septal defect (VSD) and/or closed ductus arteriosus

Subject: bundle branch block
Value: intraventricular block resulting from an interruption or partial or complete block of conduction in one of the two atrioventricular bundle branches; a prolonged QRS complex seen on an ECG indicates defects in bundle branch conduction; blocks in each branch result in a distinct QRS ECG waveform morphology

Subject: sinus bradycardia
Value: a type of decreased heart rhythm in which fewer than the normal number of impulses arise from the sinoatrial (SA) node

Subject: absent intercalated disks
Value: absence of the electron dense junctional complex, at the end to end contacts of cardiac muscle cells, that contains two types of membrane junctions i.e. gap junctions and desmosomes

Subject: altered tumor pathology
Value: any changes associated with the chemistry, immunohistology, cellular alterations or environmental interactions of tumors compared to the expected state

Subject: ventricular myocardium compact layer hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the ventricular portion of the outer, dense layer of the myocardium

Subject: descending aorta stenosis
Value: diffuse constriction or narrowing of the descending aorta

Subject: absent third pharyngeal arch
Value: absence of the structure of the third arch which contributes to the development of the hyoid bone, stylopharyngeus muscle, inferior parathyroid gland, and thymus

Subject: absent fourth pharyngeal arch
Value: absence of the structure of the fourth arch which contributes to development of the cartilage of the larynx, laryngeal, pharyngeal, and soft palate muscles, superior parathyroid gland, and C-cells of the thymus

Subject: absent sixth pharyngeal arch
Value: absence of the structure of the sixth arch which contributes to the development of the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles

Subject: failure of conotruncal ridge closure
Value: failure of the conotruncal ridges to develop from the conotruncus, meet at the midline and fuse to form the conotruncal septum

Subject: absent pulmonary vein
Value: absence of the veins that return oxygenated blood from the lungs to the left atrium of the heart

Subject: left atrium hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the left upper chamber of the heart, usually due to reduced cell number

Subject: right atrium hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the right upper chamber of the heart, usually due to reduced cell number

Subject: dilated pulmonary trunk
Value: the luminal space of the pulmonary trunk is increased in volume or area, usually with an increase of contained fluid

Subject: abnormal aorticopulmonary septum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the spiral septum that separates the truncus arteriosus into a ventral pulmonary trunk and the dorsal aorta

Subject: aorticopulmonary septal defect
Value: an abnormal communication in the septum between the aorta and pulmonary artery, resulting from incomplete separation of the common tube of the truncus arteriosus and the aorticopulmonary trunk

Subject: absent aorticopulmonary septum
Value: absence of the spiral septum that separates the truncus arteriosus into a ventral pulmonary trunk and the dorsal aorta

Subject: abnormal Wallerian degeneration
Value: any anomaly in the process of progressive degeneration of axons distal to an injury

Subject: slow Wallerian degeneration
Value: an increase in the length of time for the process of progressive degeneration of axons distal to an injury to occur

Subject: absent cardiac jelly
Value: absence of the gelatinous noncellular material between the endothelial lining and the myocardial layer of the developing heart

Subject: thick myocardium
Value: increased thickness of the heart muscle layer

Subject: absent pulmonary trunk
Value: absence of the region of the pulmonary artery that arises from the right ventricle to the division of the right and left pulmonary artery

Subject: thoracic aorta aneurysm
Value: a protruding sac formed by the dilation of the wall of the part of the aorta that extends from the origin at the heart to the diaphragm, resulting from a weakening of the vessel wall

Subject: abdominal aorta aneurysm
Value: a protruding sac formed by the dilation of the wall of the part of the descending aorta that begins at the diaphragm and continues to the point of the common iliac arteries, resulting from a weakening of the vessel wall

Subject: descending thoracic aorta aneurysm
Value: a protruding sac formed by the dilation of the wall of the of the part of the aorta that extends from the arch of the aorta to the diaphragm, resulting from a weakening of the vessel wall

Subject: ascending aorta aneurysm
Value: a protruding sac formed by the dilation of the wall of the of the part of the aorta that arises from the base of the left ventricle and extends upward to the aortic arch, resulting from a weakening of the vessel wall

Subject: abnormal intersomitic artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small branching sprouts of the dorsal aorta that grow across the medial surface of the somite, turn right angles to grow over that surface and then fuse with other sprouts and form the vertebral arteries adjacent to the neural tube; the intersomitic arteries supply the body wall and persist in the adult as the posterior intercostal, subcostal and the lumbar arteries

Subject: abnormal brachiocephalic trunk morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the short first aortic arch branch which divides into the right subclavian artery and the right common carotid artery

Subject: abnormal vitelline artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the paired arteries that carry blood to the yolk sac from the dorsal aorta; the vitelline arteries give rise to the celiac artery, superior mesenteric artery, and inferior mesenteric artery in the adult

Subject: persistent vitelline artery
Value: failure of the vitelline arteries to regress and remodel into the celiac artery, superior mesenteric artery, and inferior mesenteric artery in the adult

Subject: abnormal vitelline vein morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the paired veins that carry blood from the yolk sac back to the embryo

Subject: abnormal umbilical vein morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the vein that returns oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus through the umbilical cord

Subject: abnormal hepatic portal vein morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the wide short vein formed from the confluence of the superior mesenteric, inferior mesenteric and splenic veins, and then divides into the right and left branches which ramify with the liver; the hepatic portal vein carries venous blood from the GI tract, spleen and pancreas to the liver

Subject: abnormal activation-induced B cell apoptosis
Value: any anomaly in the process in which B cell apoptosis occurs upon engagement of either the B cell receptor or CD40, but not both; the engagement leads to expression of fas or related receptors that make the B cell susceptible to fas-ligand mediated death

Subject: abnormal activation-induced cell death of T cells
Value: any anomaly in the process of the type of T cell apoptosis that occurs towards the end of the expansion phase following the initial activation of mature T cells by antigen and is triggered by T cell receptor stimulation and signals transmitted via various surface-expressed members of the TNF receptor family such as Fas ligand, Fas, and TNF and the p55 and p75 TNF receptors

Subject: abnormal Tc17 cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a CD8-positive, alpha-beta positive T cell with the phenotype CCR6-positive, CCR5-high, CD45RA-negative, and secreting IL-17 and some IFNg

Subject: increased Tc17 cell number
Value: increased cell number of a CD8-positive, alpha-beta positive T cell with the phenotype CCR6-positive, CCR5-high, CD45RA-negative, and secreting IL-17 and some IFNg

Subject: decreased Tc17 cell number
Value: reduced cell number of a CD8-positive, alpha-beta positive T cell with the phenotype CCR6-positive, CCR5-high, CD45RA-negative, and secreting IL-17 and some IFNg

Subject: increased activation-induced B cell apoptosis
Value: increased frequency of B cell apoptosis that occurs upon engagement of either the B cell receptor or CD40, but not both; the engagement leads to expression of fas or related receptors that make the B cell susceptible to fas-ligand mediated death

Subject: decreased activation-induced B cell apoptosis
Value: decreased frequency of B cell apoptosis that occurs upon engagement of either the B cell receptor or CD40, but not both; the engagement leads to expression of fas or related receptors that make the B cell susceptible to fas-ligand mediated death

Subject: increased activation-induced cell death of T cells
Value: increased frequency of the type of T cell apoptosis that occurs towards the end of the expansion phase following the initial activation of mature T cells by antigen and is triggered by T cell receptor stimulation and signals transmitted via various surface-expressed members of the TNF receptor family such as Fas ligand, Fas, and TNF and the p55 and p75 TNF receptors

Subject: decreased activation-induced cell death of T cells
Value: decreased frequency of the type of T cell apoptosis that occurs towards the end of the expansion phase following the initial activation of mature T cells by antigen and is triggered by T cell receptor stimulation and signals transmitted via various surface-expressed members of the TNF receptor family such as Fas ligand, Fas, and TNF and the p55 and p75 TNF receptors

Subject: abnormal skin adnexa morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tissue or structures associated with or embedded in the skin such as hair and hair follicles, sweat glands, sebaceous glands and claws or nails

Subject: abnormal arrector pilli muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bundles of smooth muscle fibers that connect the hair follicle with the papillary layer of the dermis, and serve to pull hair shafts erect

Subject: abnormal skin adnexa physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the tissue or structures associated with or embedded in the skin such as hair and hair follicles, sweat glands, sebaceous glands and claws or nails

Subject: abnormal hair follicle bulb morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thickened portion of the proximal portion of the hair follicle that contains rapidly proliferating matrix cells, melanocytes and outer root sheath cells

Subject: abnormal hair follicle infundibulum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the most proximal part of the hair follicle relative to the epidermis, extending from the sebaceous duct to the epidermal surface

Subject: dilated hair follicle infundibulum
Value: the luminal space of the hair follicle infundibulum is increased in volume or area, sometimes with an increase of contained fluid or sebum

Subject: abnormal hair follicle outer root sheath morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the outermost layer of the hair follicle that merges proximally with the basal layer of the interfollicular epidermis and distally with the hair bulb

Subject: abnormal hair follicle inner root sheath morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the multilayered tube composed of terminally differentiated hair follicle keratinocytes that is surrounded by the outer root sheath; the layers of the inner root sheath include the companion layer, Henle's layer, Huxley's layer and the inner root sheath cuticle

Subject: abnormal hair follicle matrix region morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bulb region adjacent to the dermal papilla that contains rapidly proliferating matrix cells that give rise to the various cell lineages of the hair shaft and inner root sheath

Subject: absent hair follicle dermal papilla
Value: absence of the mesodermal signaling center of the hair follicle consisting of closely packed specialized mesenchymal fibroblasts

Subject: hair follicle outer root sheath hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due to a increased number of cells, outermost layer of the hair follicle that merges proximally with the basal layer of the interfollicular epidermis and distally with the hair bulb

Subject: thin hair follicle outer root sheath
Value: reduced thickness of the hair follicle that merges proximally with the basal layer of the interfollicular epidermis and distally with the hair bulb

Subject: thick hair follicle outer root sheath
Value: increased thickness of the hair follicle that merges proximally with the basal layer of the interfollicular epidermis and distally with the hair bulb

Subject: hair follicle inner root sheath hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due to a increased number of cells, of the multilayered tube composed of terminally differentiated hair follicle keratinocytes that is surrounded by the outer root sheath

Subject: thick hair follicle inner root sheath
Value: increased thickness of the multilayered tube composed of terminally differentiated hair follicle keratinocytes that is surrounded by the outer root sheath

Subject: thin hair follicle inner root sheath
Value: reduced thickness of the multilayered tube composed of terminally differentiated hair follicle keratinocytes that is surrounded by the outer root sheath

Subject: abnormal hair follicle isthmus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the middle part of the hair follicle that extends from the sebaceous duct to the bulge

Subject: abnormal blood pressure regulation
Value: any anomaly in the process that modulates the force with which blood travels through the circulatory system, which is controlled by a balance of processes that increase pressure and decrease pressure

Subject: increased siderocyte number
Value: the presence of abnormal red blood cells that have iron granule deposits that are not part of the hemoglobin

Subject: abnormal systemic arterial blood pressure regulation
Value: anomaly in the process that modulates the force with which blood travels through the systemic arterial circulatory system

Subject: abnormal impulsive behavior control
Value: any anomaly in the ability of an individual to exert restraint over behavior

Subject: dilated hair follicles
Value: the luminal space of the hair follicle is increased in volume or area, sometimes with an increase of contained fluid or sebum

Subject: hair follicle comedo
Value: a dilated or widened hair follicle filled with keratin squamae (skin debris), bacteria, and/or sebum (oil)

Subject: fusion of atlas and odontoid process
Value: the large protuberance that projects upward from the cervical axis (C2), around which the cervical atlas normally rotates, is instead fused to elements of the atlas; the odontoid process may or may not remain attached to the axis

Subject: split cervical atlas
Value: the first (topmost, C1) cervical vertebra is divided into two branches by a median cleft

Subject: split cervical axis
Value: the second cervical vertebra (C2) is divided into two branches by a median cleft

Subject: abnormal optic canal morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the short canal through the orbitosphenoid bone at the apex of the orbit that gives passage to the optic nerve and the ophthalmic artery; the optic foramen is the opening to the optic canal

Subject: absent metoptic pillar
Value: absence of the posterior border of the optic nerve foramen

Subject: ventral rotation of lens
Value: a circular shift toward the ventral pole in the position of the equator of the lens relative to the optic nerve exit point

Subject: decreased ventral retina size
Value: decreasd size of the ventral portion of the retina

Subject: absent iris stroma
Value: absence of the lamellated vascular connective tissue of the iris

Subject: absent eye anterior chamber
Value: absence of the space in the eye, filled with aqueous humor, and bounded anteriorly by the cornea and a small portion of the sclera and posteriorly by a small portion of the ciliary body, the iris, and part of the crystalline lens

Subject: absent sclera
Value: absence of the fibrous, outer envelope of the eyeball, covering it entirely excepting the segment covered anteriorly by the cornea

Subject: persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous
Value: persistence of the embryonic fibrovascular mesodermal tissue located between the optic cup and lens vesicle that normally regresses during the development of the vitreous body

Subject: absent nasolacrimal duct
Value: absence of the paired channels leading from the lacrimal sacs to the inferior meatus of the nose, through which tears are conducted through the nasal cavity

Subject: corneal-lenticular stalk
Value: persistent central adhesion between the lens and the cornea

Subject: iris coloboma
Value: congenital defect of the iris in which some part of the structure is absent

Subject: retina coloboma
Value: congenital defect of the retina in which some part of the structure is absent

Subject: optic disk coloboma
Value: congenital defect of the optic disk in which some part of the structure is absent

Subject: optic nerve coloboma
Value: congenital defect of the optic nerve in which some part of the structure is absent

Subject: choroid coloboma
Value: congenital defect of the choroid and retinal pigment epithelium in which some part of the structures are absent, exposing the sclera; the defect is usually situated below the optic disk in the region of fetal (choroid) fissure

Subject: ciliary body coloboma
Value: congenital defect of the ciliary body in which some part of the structure is absent

Subject: absent sublingual duct
Value: absence of the canals that drain the sublingual gland

Subject: short sublingual duct
Value: decreased length of the canals that drain the sublingual gland

Subject: persistent cervical thymus
