Value: the solid lobe of the thymus fails to descend to the mediastinum

Subject: paternal effect
Value: expression of a phenotypic trait in a male animal's offspring that is dependent on the paternal genotype

Subject: thick interventricular septum
Value: increased thickness of the wall between the two lower chambers of the heart

Subject: thin interventricular septum
Value: decreased thickness of the wall between the two lower chambers of the heart

Subject: abnormal collateral sprouting
Value: aberrant response of a neuron to form new neuritic processes (sprouts) that emerge from the nerve fibers or terminal arborizations in response to nerve injury (such as section or denervation), application of neurotoxin, or target tissue atrophy (usually due to disease)

Subject: increased glioblastoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a fast-growing type of central nervous system tumor that forms from glial tissue of the brain and spinal cord and has cells that look very different from normal cells; glioblastoma usually occurs in adults and affects the brain more often than the spinal cord

Subject: fusion of atlas and occipital bones
Value: union of elements of the atlas and the bone at the lower, posterior part of the skull into one structure

Subject: absent arcus anterior
Value: absence of the arch that connects the lateral masses of the atlas anteriorly and articulates with the anterior articular facet of the dens of the axis

Subject: absent odontoid process
Value: absence of the large protuberance that projects upward from the cervical axis, around which the cervical atlas rotates

Subject: absent ventral tubercle of atlas
Value: absence of the conical ventral projection on the arch of the atlas

Subject: abnormal node of Ranvier morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the short unmyelinated segments of an axon between myelinated segments, where voltage gated channels accumulate and regenerate an action potential as it is conducted along the axon

Subject: abnormal axon initial segment morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the short unmyelinated axon segment adjacent to the cell soma where voltage gated channels accumulate and axon potential initiation usually occurs

Subject: abnormal paranode morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the axon region immediately adjacent to nodes of Ranvier, where a series of cytoplasmic loops from the overlying glial cell form septate-like junctions with the axon; the axoglial junctions act as a diffusion barrier between the node and internode

Subject: abnormal paranodal axoglial junction morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the structure in which the myelin sheath attaches to the axon at each end of each myelin segment; the axoglial junctions act as a diffusion barrier between the node and internode, maintaining domain-specific axolemmal membrane components

Subject: abnormal extraembryonic ectoderm morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the layer of the ectoderm of the extraembryonic tissue

Subject: abnormal juxtaparanode morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the region of an axon near a node of Ranvier that is between the paranode axoglial junction and the internode regions; the juxtaparanode axolemma is enriched in potassium channels

Subject: abnormal internode morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the intervening axon segment that is located between the juxtaparanodes and is surrounded by a single compact myelin sheath

Subject: abnormal axolemma morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the plasma membrane of an axon

Subject: abnormal dendritic cell chemotaxis
Value: anomaly in the movement of a dendritic cell in response to an external stimulus

Subject: abnormal melanocyte proliferation
Value: anomaly in the ability of a melanocyte cell population to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: increased Schwann cell number
Value: greater than normal number of cells that sheath the axons of the peripheral nervous system

Subject: delayed cranial suture closure
Value: late onset of closure of one or more of the joints (sutures) between the bones of the skull

Subject: abnormal cervical flexure morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the ventrally concave flexure of the embryonic brain occurring at the junction of hindbrain and spinal cord

Subject: abnormal pre-Botzinger complex morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the group of interneurons within the medulla oblongata's ventral respiratory group that are important for the generation of ventilatory (inspiratory) rhythmogenesis

Subject: abnormal pre-Botzinger complex physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the group of interneurons within the medulla oblongata's ventral respiratory group that are important for the generation of ventilatory (inspiratory) rhythmogenesis

Subject: abnormal enamel organ morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the circumscribed mass of ectodermal cells which bud off from the dental lamina; it becomes cup-shaped and develops on its internal face the ameloblast layer of cells that produces the enamel cap of a developing tooth

Subject: abnormal visual evoked potential
Value: anomaly in the electroencephalographic pattern recorded from the occipital area generated in response to retinal stimulation such as flashing lights or inverting a contrasting image; may be used to evaluate optic nerve damage or visual perception

Subject: absent visual evoked potential
Value: absence of a characteristic electroencephalographic pattern recorded from the occipital area generated in response to retinal stimulation such as flashing lights or inverting a contrasting image; absence may indicate blindness

Subject: increased susceptibility to parasitic infection induced morbidity/mortality
Value: increased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by a parasitic invasion or from components of or toxins produced by parasites

Subject: decreased susceptibility to parasitic infection induced morbidity/mortality
Value: decreased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by a parasitic invasion or from components of or toxins produced by parasites

Subject: impaired mucociliary clearance
Value: reduced ability to remove mucus and other foreign particles and microorganisms from the lungs by directed ciliary movement and secretory activity of the tracheobronchial submucosal glands

Subject: improved mucociliary clearance
Value: enhanced ability to remove mucus and other foreign particles and microorganisms from the lungs by directed ciliary movement and secretory activity of the tracheobronchial submucosal glands

Subject: abnormal heart left ventricle pressure
Value: any anomaly in the pressure within the left cardiac ventricle

Subject: abnormal heart right ventricle pressure
Value: any anomaly in the pressure within the right cardiac ventricle

Subject: decreased right ventricle peak pressure
Value: decrease in the difference between right ventricular systolic and diastolic pressures

Subject: decreased right ventricle diastolic pressure
Value: decrease in the pressure of the right ventricle between heart beats when the heart is relaxed

Subject: increased right ventricle systolic pressure
Value: increase in the pressure in the right ventricle as the heart contracts and pumps blood into the arteries

Subject: decreased right ventricle systolic pressure
Value: decrease in the pressure in the right ventricle as the heart contracts and pumps blood into the arteries

Subject: abnormal macrophage chemotaxis
Value: anomaly in the accumulation of macrophages in a specific location in response to a wide variety of substances released at the sites of inflammatory reactions

Subject: abnormal microglial cell chemotaxis
Value: anomaly in the movement of a microglial cell guided by a specific chemical concentration gradient

Subject: abnormal microglial cell activation
Value: any anomaly in change in morphology and behavior of a microglial cell resulting from exposure to a cytokine, chemokine, cellular ligand, or soluble factor, during the maturation to the fully active phagocytic form

Subject: abnormal hematopoietic stem cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the multipotent, self-renewing stem cells found in the bone marrow and the fetal liver; HSCs give rise to all the types of both the myeloid and lymphoid cell lineages

Subject: abnormal granulocyte chemotaxis
Value: anomaly in the movement of a granulocyte guided by a specific chemical concentration gradient

Subject: impaired granulocyte chemotaxis
Value: reduced ability in the movement of a granulocyte guided by a specific chemical concentration gradient

Subject: abnormal NK cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of a lymphocyte that can spontaneously kill a variety of target cells without prior antigenic activation via germline encoded activation receptors, and also regulate immune responses via cytokine release and direct contact with other cells

Subject: abnormal female meiosis I arrest
Value: any anomaly in the process in which oocytes stop at the diplotene stage of meiosis I and lie dormant, often for long periods of time

Subject: mortality/aging
Value: the observable characteristics related to the ability of a mammalian organism to live and age that are manifested throughout development and life span

Subject: abnormal survival
Value: deviation from the expected viability or life span of an organism

Subject: preweaning lethality
Value: <death anytime between fertilization and weaning age (Mus: approximately 3-4 weeks of age)>

Subject: integument phenotype
Value: the observable morphological and physiological characteristics of the skin and its associated structures, such as the hair, nails, sweat glands, sebaceous glands and other secretory glands that are manifested through development and lifespan

Subject: abnormal pollex morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the first or primary digit on the radial side of the hand

Subject: supernumerary molars
Value: increased number of the most posterior teeth located on either side of the jaw, and characterized by a large crown and broad chewing surface

Subject: abnormal lymph node follicular mantle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the part of the secondary follicle in which naive B cells reside along with some helper T cells, macrophages and follicular dendritic cells; these are displaced by the expanding germinal centre and form a 'mantle' around it

Subject: abnormal scaphoid morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bone of the hand located at the radial side of the carpus and which articulates with the radius, trapezium, trapezoideum, capitate, and lunate bones

Subject: abnormal placenta metrial gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the group of granular epithelial cells in the uterine muscle beneath the placenta that develops during pregnancy in rodents and some other species, but not in primates

Subject: absent placenta metrial gland
Value: absence of the group of granular epithelial cells in the uterine muscle beneath the placenta that develops during pregnancy in rodents and some other species, but not in primates

Subject: abnormal stomach fundus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the region of the stomach that lies above the cardiac notch that functions to store undigested food and to collect stomach gases produced by chemical digestion

Subject: abnormal stomach muscularis externa morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the smooth muscle layer of the stomach wall that functions to churn and mix food and gastric secretions as well as to move food along the digestive tract to the intestines

Subject: abnormal stomach smooth muscle circular layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the middle layer of the muscularis; it is continuous with the circular layer of the esophagus, but is absent in the fundus and lies concentric to the longitudinal axis of the stomach; the circular layer is normally tonically constricted forming a functional pyloric sphincter, which controls the movement of chyme into the duodenum

Subject: pyloric sphincter hypertrophy
Value: increase in the bulk size of the thick circular layer of gastric musculature encircling the gastroduodenal junction at the gastric outlet of the stomach, due to cell enlargement or accumulation of fluids

Subject: stomach smooth muscle circular layer hypertrophy
Value: increase in the bulk size of the middle layer of the muscularis due to cell enlargement or accumulation of fluids

Subject: abnormal stomach wall morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the layered structure that makes up the stomach, consisting of a serous coat, a muscular coat, a mucous membrane, and other tissue layers in between

Subject: abnormal forestomach morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the distinct rodent non-glandular region of the stomach which is demarcated from the glandular stomach by the limiting ridge (margo plicatus); the forestomach accounts for about 60% (rat) and 70% (mouse) of the stomach volume and receives the esophagus at the cardiac antrum; the wall of the forestomach consists of, from inside to outside, stratified squamous epithelium, the lamina propria (epithelium and lamina propria form the mucosa), the muscularis mucosae, the submucosa, the muscularis interna and externa (inner circular and outer longitudinal layers of smooth muscle), and the serosa

Subject: abnormal stomach pyloric region morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the stomach tissue region surrounding and controlling the distal outlet of the stomach, which opens into the duodenum

Subject: stomach fundus hypertrophy
Value: increase in the bulk size of the stomach fundus due to cell enlargement or accumulation of fluids

Subject: gastric cysts
Value: abnormal membranous sacs in the wall of the stomach

Subject: stomach hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the stomach

Subject: abnormal stomach mesentery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the double layer of peritoneum that encloses the stomach and connects it to the abdominal wall

Subject: abnormal stomach pyloric antrum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the area at the bottom of the stomach on the caudal side of the pyloric canal that contains gastrin-producing G cells, which stimulate acid production, and the luminal pH-sensitive population of somatostatin-producing D cells

Subject: abnormal pyloric canal morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the short narrow part of the stomach extending from the pyloric antrum to the pyloric sphincter

Subject: abnormal stomach mucosa morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the mucous layer of the stomach wall which contains the gastric pits and glands, and consists of epithelium, lamina propria, and the muscularis mucosae

Subject: abnormal stomach serosa morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the outermost layer of the stomach wall, consisting of layers of connective tissue continuous with the peritoneum

Subject: abnormal stomach submucosa morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the fibrous connective tissue layer beneath the stomach mucosa

Subject: abnormal cardiac gastric gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the gastric glands in the cardiac region of the stomach; cardiac glands are fewer in number than in the fundus and body, and secrete mucin which coats the stomach and protects it

Subject: abnormal intermediate gastric gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the branched tubular glands in the mucosa of the fundus and body of the stomach that secrete most of the digestive substances secreted by the stomach

Subject: abnormal pyloric gastric gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the gastric glands in the pyloric region of the stomach; the pyloric glands secrete mucin, which coats the stomach and protects it, and hormones such as gastrin and enkephalin

Subject: abnormal stomach cardiac region morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the stomach region where the esophagus empties into the stomach

Subject: stomach mucosa hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due to an increase in the number of cells, of the mucous layer of the stomach wall which contains the gastric pits and glands, and consists of epithelium, lamina propria, and the muscularis mucosae

Subject: abnormal submucous nerve plexus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the gangliated plexus of unmyelinated nerve fibers that ramify the stomach and intestinal submucosa

Subject: abnormal myenteric nerve plexus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the plexus of unmyelinated nerve fibers and postganglionic autonomic cell bodies lying in the muscular coat of the esophagus, stomach and intestines that communicate with the submucosal, subserosal and enteric plexuses

Subject: abnormal intestinal enteroendocrine cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the various hormone- or neurotransmitter-secreting cells present throughout the mucosa of the intestinal tract

Subject: abnormal stomach enteroendocrine cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the various hormone- or neurotransmitter-secreting cells present throughout the mucosa of the stomach

Subject: abnormal stomach smooth muscle inner oblique layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the innermost layer of the muscularis; it is not present in all sections of the stomach but is clearly seen in the fundus and near the lesser curvature of the corpus; the oblique fibers disappear distally (towards the pyloric antrum); the oblique layer is responsible for creating the motion that churns and physically breaks down the food

Subject: abnormal stomach smooth muscle outer longitudinal layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the most superficial layer of the muscularis; it has two sections, a longitudinal layer that is common with the esophagus and ends in the corpus, and a longitudinal layer that originates in the corpus and spreads into the duodenum

Subject: abnormal stomach muscularis mucosa morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thin layer of smooth muscle in the mucosal layer of the stomach that functions to agitate the surface area stomach mucosa by moving the villi back and forth

Subject: abnormal stomach position or orientation
Value: the stomach is displaced from the normal left-sided position and/or orientation

Subject: right-sided stomach
Value: stomach is present on the right side of the body instead of the left

Subject: abnormal club cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the rounded, club-shaped, nonciliated cell protruding between ciliated cells in bronchiolar epithelium, believed to be secretory in function

Subject: increased type II pneumocyte number
Value: greater number of the granular and roughly cuboidal cells typically found at the alveolar-septal junction that modulate the fluid surrounding the alveolar epithelium by secreting and recycling surfactants, and also contribute to tissue repair and can differentiate after injury into a type I pneumocyte; type II cells cover a much smaller surface area than type I cells (less than 5 percent), but are much more numerous and contain lamellar bodies on the apical surface where surfactant is stored

Subject: decreased type II pneumocyte number
Value: reduced number of the granular and roughly cuboidal cells typically found at the alveolar-septal junction that modulate the fluid surrounding the alveolar epithelium by secreting and recycling surfactants, and also contribute to tissue repair and can differentiate after injury into a type I pneumocyte; type II cells cover a much smaller surface area than type I cells (less than 5 percent), but are much more numerous and contain lamellar bodies on the apical surface where surfactant is stored

Subject: absent type II pneumocytes
Value: absence of the granular and roughly cuboidal cells typically found at the alveolar-septal junction that modulate the fluid surrounding the alveolar epithelium by secreting and recycling surfactants, and also contribute to tissue repair and can differentiate after injury into a type I pneumocyte; type II cells cover a much smaller surface area than type I cells (less than 5 percent), but are much more numerous and contain lamellar bodies on the apical surface where surfactant is stored

Subject: abnormal alveolar lamellar body morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the specialized secretory organelles found in the cytoplasm of type II pneumocytes and involved in the synthesis, secretion, and reutilization of pulmonary surfactant

Subject: absent alveolar lamellar bodies
Value: absence of the specialized secretory organelles found in the cytoplasm of type II pneumocytes and involved in the synthesis, secretion, and reutilization of pulmonary surfactant

Subject: enlarged alveolar lamellar bodies
Value: increased size of the specialized secretory organelles found in the cytoplasm of type II pneumocytes and involved in the synthesis, secretion, and reutilization of pulmonary surfactant

Subject: decreased type I pneumocyte number
Value: reduced number of the flattened, branched squamous cells that covers more than 98 percent of the alveolar surface, and have thin (50-100 nm) cytoplasmic extensions to form the air-blood barrier essential for normal gas exchange

Subject: absent type I pneumocytes
Value: absence of the flattened, branched squamous cells that covers more than 98 percent of the alveolar surface, and have thin (50-100 nm) cytoplasmic extensions to form the air-blood barrier essential for normal gas exchange

Subject: adhesive atelectasis
Value: alveolar collapse in the presence of patent airways, especially when surfactant is inactivated or absent, and is seen in newborn respiratory distress syndrome, acute radiation pneumonitis, or viral pneumonia

Subject: primary atelectasis
Value: nonexpansion of the lungs after birth, seen in stillborn organisms and in live born animals that do not establish respiration

Subject: abnormal pleura morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the serous membrane surrounding the lungs and lining the walls of the pleural cavity

Subject: abnormal visceral pleura morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the pleura layer attached to and covering the lungs, and which intercalates into the fissures between the lobes

Subject: pneumothorax
Value: free air or gas is present in the pleural cavity

Subject: abnormal parietal pleura morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the part of the pleura that lines and is attached to the wall of the thoracic cavity

Subject: absent right lung accessory lobe
Value: absence of the right lung lobe which lies against the diaphragm and has a considerable volume residing in the left hemi-thorax

Subject: abnormal lung saccule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the transient dilations of the developing alveolar (or transient) ducts, which transform into a transitory alveolar duct as soon as it develops further branches; the last transitory saccule formed on each pathway is a terminal saccule that develops into an alveolar sac after birth

Subject: absent lung saccules
Value: absence of the transient dilations of the developing alveolar (or transient) ducts, which transform into a transitory alveolar duct as soon as it develops further branches; the last transitory saccule formed on each pathway is a terminal saccule that develops into an alveolar sac after birth

Subject: small lung saccule
Value: reduced size of the transient dilations of the developing alveolar (or transient) ducts, which transform into a transitory alveolar duct as soon as it develops further branches; the last transitory saccule formed on each pathway is a terminal saccule that develops into an alveolar sac after birth

Subject: abnormal bronchioalveolar stem cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a respiratory stem cell found at the junction of the terminal (conductive) bronchiole and the respiratory bronchiole, which gives rise to alveolar cell types and Clara cells in response to lung injury

Subject: increased bronchioalveolar stem cell number
Value: greater numbers of a respiratory stem cell found at the junction of the terminal (conductive) bronchiole and the respiratory bronchiole, which gives rise to alveolar cell types and Clara cells in response to lung injury

Subject: decreased bronchioalveolar stem cell number
Value: reduced numbers of a respiratory stem cell found at the junction of the terminal (conductive) bronchiole and the respiratory bronchiole, which gives rise to alveolar cell types and Clara cells in response to lung injury

Subject: lethality, incomplete penetrance
Value: the appearance of lower than Mendelian ratios of offspring of a given genotype due to death of some, but not all of the organisms

Subject: lethality during fetal growth through weaning
Value: <death anytime between the completion of organogenesis and weaning age (Mus: E14 to approximately 3 weeks of age)>

Subject: abnormal memory T cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of distinctly differentiated long-lived T cells that have the phenotype CD45RO-positive and CD127-positive

Subject: abnormal CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a CD4-positive, alpha-beta long-lived T cell with the phenotype CD45RO-positive and CD127-positive, or also described as being CD25-negative, CD44-high, and CD122- high

Subject: increased CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cell number
Value: increased number of CD4-positive, alpha-beta long-lived T cells with the phenotype CD45RO-positive and CD127-positive, or also described as being CD25-negative, CD44-high, and CD122- high

Subject: decreased CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cell number
Value: reduced number of CD4-positive, alpha-beta long-lived T cells with the phenotype CD45RO-positive and CD127-positive, or also described as being CD25-negative, CD44-high, and CD122- high

Subject: abnormal CD8-positive, alpha-beta memory T cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cell with memory phenotype indicated by being CD45RO and CD127-positive, or also described as being CD25-negative, CD44-high, and CD122- high

Subject: increased CD8-positive, alpha-beta memory T cell number
Value: increased number of CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells with memory phenotype indicated by being CD45RO and CD127-positive, or also described as being CD25-negative, CD44-high, and CD122- high

Subject: decreased CD8-positive, alpha-beta memory T cell number
Value: decreased number of CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells with memory phenotype indicated by being CD45RO and CD127-positive, or also described as being CD25-negative, CD44-high, and CD122- high

Subject: abnormal central memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cell with the phenotype CCR7-positive, CD127-positive, CD45RO-positive, and CD25-negative

Subject: increased central memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cell number
Value: increased number of CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells with the phenotype CCR7-positive, CD127-positive, CD45RO-positive, and CD25-negative

Subject: decreased central memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cell number
Value: reduced number of CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells with the phenotype CCR7-positive, CD127-positive, CD45RO-positive, and CD25-negative

Subject: abnormal effector memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cell with the phenotype CCR7-negative, CD127-positive, CD45RO-positive, and CD25-negative

Subject: increased effector memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cell number
Value: increased number of CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells with the phenotype CCR7-negative, CD127-positive, CD45RO-positive, and CD25-negative

Subject: decreased effector memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cell number
Value: reduced number of CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cells with the phenotype CCR7-negative, CD127-positive, CD45RO-positive, and CD25-negative

Subject: abnormal central memory CD8 positive, alpha-beta T cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a CD8-positive, alpha beta memory T cell with the phenotype CCR7-positive, CD127-positive, CD45RO-positive, and CD25-negative

Subject: increased central memory CD8 positive, alpha-beta T cell number
Value: increased number of CD8-positive, alpha beta memory T cells with the phenotype CCR7-positive, CD127-positive, CD45RO-positive, and CD25-negative

Subject: decreased central memory CD8 positive, alpha-beta T cell number
Value: reduced number of CD8-positive, alpha beta memory T cells with the phenotype CCR7-positive, CD127-positive, CD45RO-positive, and CD25-negative

Subject: abnormal effector memory CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cell number
Value: any structural anomaly of a CD8-positive, alpha beta memory T cell with the phenotype CCR7-negative, CD127-positive, CD45RO-positive, and CD25-negative

Subject: increased effector memory CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cell number
Value: increased number of CD8-positive, alpha beta memory T cells with the phenotype CCR7-negative, CD127-positive, CD45RO-positive, and CD25-negative

Subject: decreased effector memory CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cell number
Value: reduced number of CD8-positive, alpha beta memory T cells with the phenotype CCR7-negative, CD127-positive, CD45RO-positive, and CD25-negative

Subject: absent epidermal lamellar bodies
Value: absence of a membrane-bounded organelle, specialized for the storage and secretion various substances (glycoproteins and acid phosphates) which are arranged in the form of tightly packed, concentric, membrane sheets or lamellae

Subject: abnormal lung position or orientation
Value: the lung is displaced from the normal position and/or has an altered left/right orientation

Subject: lung situs inversus
Value: anomaly in the asymmetry of the lung such that lung lobes on both the left and right side have the morphology normally seen on the opposite side of the body

Subject: pulmonary hyperemia
Value: increased amount of blood flow into the lungs

Subject: dilated respiratory conducting tubes
Value: expansion or widening of the lumens of the tubes of the respiratory system that allow passage of air from the trachea to the alveoli of the lungs

Subject: pulmonary necrosis
Value: morphological changes resulting from pathological death of pulmonary tissue; usually due to irreversible damage

Subject: pulmonary epithelial necrosis
Value: morphological changes resulting from pathological death of pulmonary epithelial tissue; usually due to irreversible damage

Subject: abnormal anterior commissure pars anterior morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small horseshoe-shaped anterior part of the anterior commissure which pass into the two olfactory bulbs

Subject: abnormal anterior commissure pars posterior morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the large posterior part of the anterior commissure which connects the right and left temporal lobes

Subject: increased respiratory mucosa goblet cell number
Value: greater number of the cells of the respiratory epithelial lining that produce and secrete mucins

Subject: decreased respiratory mucosa goblet cell number
Value: reduced number of the cells of the respiratory epithelial lining that produce and secrete mucins

Subject: absent respiratory mucosa goblet cells
Value: absence of the cells of the respiratory epithelial lining that produce and secrete mucins

Subject: abnormal enamel knot morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a transient cluster of cells in the central part of the dental epithelium facing the dental mesenchyme, which acts as an organizing center, providing positional information for tooth morphogenesis and regulating the growth of tooth cusps

Subject: prenatal growth retardation
Value: slow or limited development during the prenatal period

Subject: abnormal prenatal body size
Value: anomaly in the average body weight, height and/or length of an organism compared to controls at anytime prior to birth

Subject: abnormal bone trabecula morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the network of intersecting plates and spicules in cancellous bone which form a meshwork of intercommunicating spaces filled with blood vessels and marrow; in mature bone, the trabeculae are aligned in parallel with the lines of major compressive or tensile force

Subject: increased bone trabecula number
Value: increased number of intersecting plates and spicules in cancellous bone which form a meshwork of intercommunicating spaces filled with blood vessels and marrow; in mature bone, the trabeculae are aligned in parallel with the lines of major compressive or tensile force

Subject: decreased bone trabecula number
Value: decreased number of intersecting plates and spicules in cancellous bone which form a meshwork of intercommunicating spaces filled with blood vessels and marrow; in mature bone, the trabeculae are aligned in parallel with the lines of major compressive or tensile force

Subject: absent bone trabeculae
Value: absence of intersecting plates and spicules in cancellous bone which form a meshwork of intercommunicating spaces filled with blood vessels and marrow; in mature bone, the trabeculae are aligned in parallel with the lines of major compressive or tensile force

Subject: abnormal trabecular bone mass
Value: anomaly in the total amount of trabecular bone tissue contained in the skeleton

Subject: increased trabecular bone mass
Value: greater total amount of trabecular bone tissue contained in the skeleton

Subject: decreased trabecular bone mass
Value: reduced total amount of trabecular bone tissue contained in the skeleton

Subject: abnormal bone volume
Value: any anomaly in the amount of space occupied by bone tissue in the skeleton

Subject: increased bone volume
Value: increased amount of space occupied by bone tissue in the skeleton

Subject: decreased bone volume
Value: reduced amount of space occupied by bone tissue in the skeleton

Subject: abnormal trabecular bone volume
Value: any anomaly in the amount of space occupied by trabecular bone tissue in the skeleton

Subject: increased trabecular bone volume
Value: increase in the amount of space occupied by trabecular bone tissue in the skeleton

Subject: decreased trabecular bone volume
Value: decrease in the amount of space occupied by trabecular bone tissue in the skeleton

Subject: small esophagus
Value: reduced size of the part of the digestive canal through which food passes from the pharynx to the stomach

Subject: esophagus hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or decreased size of the esophagus, usually due a reduced number of cells

Subject: trachea hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the trachea, usually due a reduced number of cells

Subject: trachea stenosis
Value: abnormal narrowing or constriction of the trachea

Subject: esophagus stenosis
Value: abnormal narrowing or constriction of the esophagus

Subject: absent trachea
Value: absence of the tube descending from the larynx and branching into the right and left main bronchi

Subject: absent minor salivary glands
Value: all of the smaller, largely mucus-secreting, exocrine glands of the oral cavity, consisting of the labial, buccal, molar, lingual, and palatine glands are absent

Subject: pale lung
Value: lung lacking normal reddish coloration; often occurs with a bloodless or reduced vasculature condition

Subject: small alveolar lamellar bodies
Value: decreased size of the specialized secretory organelles found in the cytoplasm of type II pneumocytes and involved in the synthesis, secretion, and reutilization of pulmonary surfactant

Subject: decreased alveolar lamellar body number
Value: reduced number of the specialized secretory organelles found in the cytoplasm of type II pneumocytes and involved in the synthesis, secretion, and reutilization of pulmonary surfactant

Subject: increased alveolar lamellar body number
Value: greater number of the specialized secretory organelles found in the cytoplasm of type II pneumocytes and involved in the synthesis, secretion, and reutilization of pulmonary surfactant

Subject: increased oligodendrocyte progenitor number
Value: greater number of cells that differentiate into a type of glial cell in the central nervous system

Subject: abnormal posterior commissure morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the band of nerve fiber tracts that span the longitudinal fissure beneath the habenula of the pineal body and over the cerebral aqueduct, interconnecting the left and right pretectal regions and some midbrain nuclei

Subject: pulmonary alveolar edema
Value: an effusion of serous fluid into the pulmonary alveoli; usually caused by the movement of blood components through the pulmonary capillary walls as a result of a change in osmotic pressure, an increased permeability of the walls, or related factors

Subject: increased lung compliance
Value: increased ability of the lung to distend in response to pressure without disruption, usually expressed as the unit volume of change in the lung per unit of pressure

Subject: decreased lung compliance
Value: reduced ability of the lung to distend in response to pressure without disruption, usually expressed as the unit volume of change in the lung per unit of pressure

Subject: abnormal bronchiole epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the epithelial layer of the bronchioles

Subject: abnormal pulmonary alveolus epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the epithelial layer of the alveoli

Subject: abnormal pulmonary alveolar system morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the portion of the lung comprised of the pulmonary acinus and the alveolar parenchyma

Subject: abnormal pulmonary interalveolar septum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tissue intervening between two adjacent pulmonary alveoli, which consists of the basement membranes of alveolar-lining epithelium (mostly type I pneumocytes) and capillary endothelium; thicker alveolar septal regions may also contain elastic fibers, collagen, interstitial cells, smooth muscle cells, mast cells, lymphocytes and monocytes

Subject: abnormal pulmonary alveolar parenchyma morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the distinguishing cell types of the lung alveolar tissue, including pulmonary epithelial cells (pneumocytes), alveolar capillary endothelial cells, interstitial cells (fibroblasts) and alveolar macrophages

Subject: abnormal pulmonary alveolar sac morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small terminal dilation of the alveolar ducts around which the alveoli form pocket-like clusters

Subject: abnormal alveolar pore morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the openings in the alveolar septum that permit air flow between adjacent alveoli

Subject: absent alveolar pores
Value: absence of the openings in the alveolar septum that permit air flow between adjacent alveoli

Subject: abnormal lung bud morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the primary outgrowth of the embryonic trachea i.e. blunt end of the respiratory diverticulum which grows ventrally out of the proximal end of the foregut, then extends caudally and divides into two, forming the anlage of a primary bronchus and all its branches

Subject: absent lung buds
Value: absence of the blunt end of the respiratory diverticulum which normally grows ventrally out of the proximal end of the foregut, then extends caudally and divides into two, forming the origins of the bronchial tree

Subject: dilated pulmonary alveolar ducts
Value: expansion or widening of the lumens of the respiratory conducting tubes distal to the respiratory bronchiole that lead to the alveolar sacs and the alveoli

Subject: pulmonary alveolar hemorrhage
Value: bleeding into the small sac-like dilations of the distal airspace of the lung

Subject: bronchiolar epithelial hyperplasia
Value: increased size, often due to increased epithelial cell number, of the epithelial layer of the bronchioles

Subject: abnormal pulmonary acinus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the part of the airway consisting of a respiratory bronchiole and all of its branches

Subject: herniated liver
Value: protrusion of any portion of the liver from its normal anatomical position

Subject: abnormal neuroendocrine cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a neuron that has the specialized function to produce and secrete hormones, contains neruosecretory granules, and that constitutes, in whole or in part, an endocrine organ or system

Subject: abnormal solitary pulmonary neuroendocrine cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the specialized non-ciliated, round- to oval-shaped epithelial cells found as solitary cells in the nasal respiratory epithelium and the mucosa of the larynx, trachea and bronchi up to the terminal bronchioles; PNECs are the first cell type to differentiate during early fetal lung development, produce amine (e.g. serotonin, 5-HT) and peptides (e.g. bombesin, calcitonin) with growth factor-like properties, and appear to be involved in processes ranging from lung development and respiratory physiology to repair, disease and carcinogenesis

Subject: increased solitary pulmonary neuroendocrine cell number
Value: increased number of the specialized non-ciliated, round- to oval-shaped epithelial cells found as solitary cells in the nasal respiratory epithelium and the mucosa of the larynx, trachea and bronchi up to the terminal bronchioles; PNECs are the first cell type to differentiate during early fetal lung development, produce amine (e.g. serotonin, 5-HT) and peptides (e.g. bombesin, calcitonin) with growth factor-like properties, and appear to be involved in processes ranging from lung development and respiratory physiology to repair, disease and carcinogenesis

Subject: decreased solitary pulmonary neuroendocrine cell number
Value: decreased number of the specialized non-ciliated, round- to oval-shaped epithelial cells found as solitary cells in the nasal respiratory epithelium and the mucosa of the larynx, trachea and bronchi up to the terminal bronchioles; PNECs are the first cell type to differentiate during early fetal lung development, produce amine (e.g. serotonin, 5-HT) and peptides (e.g. bombesin, calcitonin) with growth factor-like properties, and appear to be involved in processes ranging from lung development and respiratory physiology to repair, disease and carcinogenesis

Subject: absent solitary pulmonary neuroendocrine cells
Value: absence of the specialized non-ciliated, round- to oval-shaped epithelial cells found as solitary cells in the nasal respiratory epithelium and the mucosa of the larynx, trachea and bronchi up to the terminal bronchioles; PNECs are the first cell type to differentiate during early fetal lung development, produce amine (e.g. serotonin, 5-HT) and peptides (e.g. bombesin, calcitonin) with growth factor-like properties, and appear to be involved in processes ranging from lung development and respiratory physiology to repair, disease and carcinogenesis

Subject: abnormal pulmonary neuroendocrine body morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the corpuscular, organoid structures composed of PNECs, found as distinctive innervated clusters only within intrapulmonary airways, where they appear concentrated at airway branch points; NEBs reach from the basement membrane to the airway lumen and are thought to function as oxygen sensors

Subject: increased number of pulmonary neuroendocrine bodies
Value: greater number of the corpuscular, organoid structures composed of PNECs, found as distinctive innervated clusters only within intrapulmonary airways, where they appear concentrated at airway branch points; NEBs reach from the basement membrane to the airway lumen and are thought to function as oxygen sensors

Subject: decreased number of pulmonary neuroendocrine bodies
Value: reduction in the number of the corpuscular, organoid structures composed of PNECs, found as distinctive innervated clusters only within intrapulmonary airways, where they appear concentrated at airway branch points; NEBs reach from the basement membrane to the airway lumen and are thought to function as oxygen sensors

Subject: absent pulmonary neuroendocrine bodies
Value: absence of the corpuscular, organoid structures composed of PNECs, found as distinctive innervated clusters only within intrapulmonary airways, where they appear concentrated at airway branch points; NEBs reach from the basement membrane to the airway lumen and are thought to function as oxygen sensors

Subject: alveolitis
Value: inflammation of the small sac-like dilations of the distal airspace of the lung; acute pulmonary alveolitis involves exudate into the pulmonary alveoli and impaired gas exchange

Subject: calcified pulmonary alveolus
Value: pathologic deposition of calcium salts in the pulmonary alveoli

Subject: abnormal osteoid morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of newly formed organic bone matrix secreted by osteoblasts, that exists prior to calcification; it is comprised mainly of type I collagen fibers, chondroitin sulfate and osteocalcin

Subject: abnormal osteoid volume
Value: any anomaly in the amount of space occupied by newly formed organic bone matrix secreted by osteoblasts

Subject: increased osteoid volume
Value: increase in the amount of space occupied by newly formed organic bone matrix secreted by osteoblasts

Subject: decreased osteoid volume
Value: reduction in the amount of space occupied by newly formed organic bone matrix secreted by osteoblasts

Subject: abnormal osteoid thickness
Value: anomaly in the width of the layer of newly formed organic bone matrix secreted by osteoblasts

Subject: increased osteoid thickness
Value: increase in the width of the layer of newly formed organic bone matrix secreted by osteoblasts

Subject: decreased osteoid thickness
Value: reduction in the width of the layer of newly formed organic bone matrix secreted by osteoblasts

Subject: abnormal trabecular bone connectivity density
Value: any anomaly in the extent of attachments between trabeculae; it may be expressed in ratios of nodes to free ends, trabecular bone pattern factor, and related measures

Subject: increased trabecular bone connectivity density
Value: increase in the extent of attachments between trabeculae; it may be expressed in ratios of nodes to free ends, trabecular bone pattern factor, and related measures

Subject: decreased trabecular bone connectivity density
Value: reduction in the extent of attachments between trabeculae; it may be expressed in ratios of nodes to free ends, trabecular bone pattern factor, and related measures

Subject: increased subcutaneous adipose tissue amount
Value: increase in amount of adipose tissue beneath the skin

Subject: increased airway resistance
Value: greater opposition to flow of air caused by the forces of friction, measured as the ratio of driving pressure to the rate of air flow

Subject: decreased airway resistance
Value: reduced opposition to flow of air caused by the forces of friction, measured as the ratio of driving pressure to the rate of air flow

Subject: increased total lung capacity
Value: greater volume of air contained in the lungs at the end of maximal inspiration

Subject: decreased total lung capacity
Value: reduced volume of air contained in the lungs at the end of maximal inspiration

Subject: abnormal mandibular prominence morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the paired ventral prominences formed by bifurcation of the first pharyngeal arches in the embryo; the two prominences unite ventrally and fuse to form the mandible and lower lip

Subject: abnormal maxillary prominence morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the paired dorsal prominences formed by bifurcation of the first pharyngeal arches in the embryo that unite with the ipsilateral medial nasal process to form the upper jaw

Subject: abnormal foramen magnum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the large orifice in the occipital bone through which the spinal cord passes to the cranial cavity and becomes continuous with the medulla oblongata

Subject: abnormal respiratory epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the pseudostratified ciliated epithelium that lines much of the conducting portion of the airway, including part of the nasal cavity and larynx, the trachea, and bronchi

Subject: abnormal bronchus epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the epithelial layer of the bronchi

Subject: respiratory epithelium hypertrophy
Value: increase in the bulk size of the pseudostratified ciliated epithelium that lines much of the conducting portion of the airway, including part of the nasal cavity and larynx, the trachea, and bronchi; may be due to cell enlargement or excessive production/accumulation of mucus material

Subject: lung epithelium hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due an increased number of cells in the epithelial layer of the lung

Subject: hyperpnea
Value: breathing that is deeper and more rapid than normal

Subject: abnormal single-strand DNA break repair
Value: anomaly in the process of repair of single strand breaks in DNA; repair of such breaks is mediated by the same enzyme systems as are used in base excision repair

Subject: abnormal double-strand DNA break repair
Value: any annomaly in the process of repair of double-strand breaks in DNA via homologous and nonhomologous mechanisms to reform a continuous DNA helix

Subject: decreased club cell number
Value: reduced number of the rounded, club-shaped, nonciliated cells found between ciliated cells in bronchiolar epithelium

Subject: abnormal lung hysteresivity
Value: anomaly in the lung tissue property defined as the ratio of dissipated energy to stored energy over a respiratory cycle; it can be measured as the area enclosed by a pressure-volume loop of the lung, and is dependent on composition and microstructure of the tissue components such as the elastic connective tissue

Subject: abnormal lipid oxidation
Value: anomaly in the process of removal of one or more electrons from a lipid, with or without the concomitant removal of a proton or protons, by reaction with an electron-accepting substance, by addition of oxygen or by removal of hydrogen

Subject: abnormal fatty acid beta-oxidation
Value: anomaly in the process that results in the complete oxidation of a long-chain fatty acid, beginning with the addition of coenzyme A to a fatty acid, with successive cycles of reactions during each of which the fatty acid is shortened by a two-carbon fragment removed as acetyl coenzyme A; the cycle continues until only two or three carbons remain (as acetyl-CoA or propionyl-CoA respectively)

Subject: abnormal fatty acid oxidation
Value: anomaly in the process of removal of one or more electrons from a fatty acid, with or without the concomitant removal of a proton or protons, by reaction with an electron-accepting substance, by addition of oxygen or by removal of hydrogen.

Subject: abnormal cellular respiration
Value: anomaly in the enzymatic release of energy from organic compounds (especially carbohydrates and fats) which either requires oxygen (aerobic respiration) or does not (anaerobic respiration)

Subject: abnormal respiratory electron transport chain
Value: anomaly in the process in which a series of electron carriers operate together to transfer electrons from donors such as NADH and FADH2 to any of several different terminal electron acceptors to generate a transmembrane electrochemical gradient

Subject: abnormal mitochondrial ATP synthesis coupled electron transport
Value: anomaly in the transfer of electrons through a series of electron donors and acceptors, generating energy that is ultimately used for synthesis of ATP, as it occurs in the mitochondrial inner membrane and mediated by multisubunit enzyme complexes known as complex I-IV

Subject: abnormal aerobic respiration
Value: any anomaly in the process of enzymatic release of energy from organic compounds (especially carbohydrates and fats) which requires oxygen as the terminal electron acceptor

Subject: abnormal tricarboxylic acid cycle
Value: any anomaly in the universal metabolic pathway in which the acetyl group of acetyl coenzyme A is effectively oxidized to two CO2 and four pairs of electrons are transferred to coenzymes; the acetyl group combines with oxaloacetate to form citrate, which undergoes successive transformations to isocitrate, 2-oxoglutarate, succinyl-CoA, succinate, fumarate, malate, and oxaloacetate again, thus completing the cycle

Subject: abnormal oxidative phosphorylation
Value: any anomaly in the process of phosphorylation of ADP to ATP that accompanies the oxidation of a metabolite through the operation of the respiratory chain; oxidation of compounds establishes a proton gradient across the membrane, providing the energy for ATP synthesis

Subject: abnormal compact bone mass
Value: anomaly in the total amount of compact bone tissue contained in the skeleton

Subject: increased compact bone mass
Value: greater than normal total amount of compact bone tissue contained in the skeleton

Subject: decreased compact bone mass
Value: less than normal total amount of compact bone tissue contained in the skeleton

Subject: abnormal compact bone volume
Value: any anomaly in the amount of space occupied by compact bone tissue in the skeleton

Subject: increased compact bone volume
Value: greater than normal amount of space occupied by compact bone tissue in the skeleton

Subject: decreased compact bone volume
Value: less than normal amount of space occupied by compact bone tissue in the skeleton

Subject: abnormal compact bone area
Value: anomaly in the total amount of cross-sectional area of compact bone tissue

Subject: increased compact bone area
Value: increase in the total amount of cross-sectional area of compact bone tissue

Subject: decreased compact bone area
Value: reduction in the total amount of cross-sectional area of compact bone tissue

Subject: absent compact bone
Value: absence of the outer layers of solid, hard bone that covers spongy bone

Subject: abnormal compact bone lamellar structure
Value: any structural anomaly of the concentric layers of calcified matrix interspersed with osteocytes lodged in lacunae between the lamellae that comprise the cylindrical osteons

Subject: abnormal periosteum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thick fibrous membrane that closely invests the entire surface of a bone except the articular cartilage at synovial joints

Subject: absent periosteum
Value: absence of the thick fibrous membrane that closely invests the entire surface of a bone except the articular cartilage at synovial joints

Subject: increased periosteum thickness
Value: increased width of the thick fibrous membrane that closely invests the entire surface of a bone except the articular cartilage at synovial joints

Subject: decreased periosteum thickness
Value: decreased width of the thick fibrous membrane that closely invests the entire surface of a bone except the articular cartilage at synovial joints

Subject: abnormal lung lobe morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the anatomically and functionally distinct subunits (lobes) comprising the left or right lung, where each lobe receives air from its own secondary bronchus and is separated from it neighbors by one or more fissures (walls of connective tissue)

Subject: small lung lobe
Value: reduced size of any of the anatomically and functionally distinct subunits (lobes) comprising the left or right lung, where each lobe receives air from its own secondary bronchus and is separated from it neighbors by one or more fissures (walls of connective tissue)

Subject: fused right lung lobes
Value: complete or partial fusion of the right lung lobes, indicative of defective lobar septation during embryonic lung development

Subject: absent ureteric bud
Value: absence of the epithelial swelling on the Wolffian duct that elongates to invade the adjacent metanephric mesenchyme

Subject: small ureteric bud
Value: reduced size of the epithelial swelling on the Wolffian duct that elongates to invade the adjacent metanephric mesenchyme

Subject: ectopic ureteric bud
Value: ureteric bud(s) are not located in the normal or expected position

Subject: abnormal branching involved in ureteric bud morphogenesis
Value: anomaly in the process in which the branching structure of the ureteric bud is generated and organized

Subject: abnormal ureteric bud elongation
Value: any anomaly in the process in which a ureteric bud grows along its axis

Subject: abnormal ureteric bud invasion
Value: any anomaly in the process in which the ureteric bud grows into the metanephric mesenchyme, and contributes to the formation of the metanephros

Subject: abnormal metanephric mesenchyme morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the embryonic connective tissue made up of loosely aggregated mesenchymal cells, supported by interlaminar jelly, that gives rise to the developing metanephros; interactions between the ureteric bud and the metanephric mesenchyme leads to the initiation of outgrowth and repetitive branching of the UB that ultimately generates the definitive renal collecting system and induces formation of renal vesicles from the mesenchyme tissue

Subject: abnormal kidney mesenchyme morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the embryonic connective tissue made up of loosely aggregated mesenchymal cells, supported by interlaminar jelly, that gives rise to the developing kidney

Subject: abnormal mesonephric mesenchyme morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the embryonic connective tissue made up of loosely aggregated mesenchymal cells, supported by interlaminar jelly, that gives rise to the developing mesonephros

Subject: abnormal nephrogenic mesenchyme morphogenesis
Value: any structural anomaly of the embryonic connective tissue made up of loosely aggregated mesenchymal cells, supported by interlaminar jelly, that gives rise to the developing nephron

Subject: abnormal bronchial cartilage morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the hyaline cartilaginous structures that support the bronchi, present as irregular rings in the larger bronchi (and not as regular as in the trachea), and as small plates and islands in the smaller bronchi; as the branching continues through the bronchial tree, the amount of hyaline cartilage in the walls decreases until it is absent in the smallest bronchioles

Subject: fused bronchial cartilage rings
Value: fusion of the hyaline cartilaginous structures that support the bronchi

Subject: increased surfactant secretion
Value: greater production or release from pneumocytes of surfactant, a phospholipid present in the lungs that controls surface tension in the alveoli

Subject: decreased surfactant secretion
Value: decreased production or release from pneumocytes of surfactant, a phospholipid present in the lungs that controls surface tension in the alveoli

Subject: aerophagia
Value: excessive swallowing of air or gas

Subject: abnormal lung alveolus development
Value: anomaly in the formation of the sacs for holding air in the lungs, which are formed by the terminal dilation of air passageways

Subject: increased aorta wall thickness
Value: increased depth of the part of the aorta that encloses the luminal space

Subject: decreased aorta wall thickness
Value: decreased depth of the part of the aorta that encloses the luminal space

Subject: pulmonary alveolar proteinosis
Value: abnormal intra-alveolar accumulation of an amorphous, largely cell-free, surfactant-like lipoproteinaceous material that is not easily cleared from the lungs

Subject: proteinosis
Value: disordered protein formation and distribution, especially manifested by the accumulation of excess or abnormal proteins in tissues

Subject: abnormal allogrooming behavior
Value: defects in the standard of behavior in which individuals in a cohort clean or maintain one another's outer body or appearance

Subject: absence of AMPA-mediated synaptic currents
Value: absence of a measured amplitude, current density or response to stimulation of NMDA receptors

Subject: enhanced AMPA-mediated synaptic currents
Value: increase in the measured amplitude, current density or duration of response to stimulation of AMPA receptors

Subject: reduced AMPA-mediated synaptic currents
Value: reduction in the measured amplitude, current density or duration of response to stimulation of AMPA receptors

Subject: abnormal epidermal stem cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a somatic stem cell that is part of the epidermis

Subject: abnormal epidermal stem cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of a somatic stem cell that is part of the epidermis

Subject: abnormal epidermal stem cell proliferation
Value: anomaly in the ability of a somatic stem cell population that is part of the epidermis to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: abnormal epidermal stem cell apoptosis
Value: change in the timing or the number of somatic stem cells that are part of the epidermis, undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal circulating glutamate dehydrogenase level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration in the blood of the enzymes which catalyze the reaction of L-glutamate, water and NAD+, producing alpha-ketoglutarate, ammonia, and NADH

Subject: increased circulating glutamate dehydrogenase level
Value: increased concentration in the blood of the enzymes which catalyze the reaction of L-glutamate, water and NAD+, producing alpha-ketoglutarate, ammonia, and NADH

Subject: decreased circulating glutamate dehydrogenase level
Value: reduced concentration in the blood of the enzymes which catalyze the reaction of L-glutamate, water and NAD+, producing alpha-ketoglutarate, ammonia, and NADH

Subject: impaired lung lobe morphogenesis
Value: failure to form any of the anatomically and functionally distinct subunits (lobes) comprising the left or right lung

Subject: bronchiectasis
Value: a chronic inflammatory or degenerative condition marked by permanent dilatation (widening) of one or more bronchi and loss of elasticity of the bronchial walls

Subject: bronchiolectasis
Value: a chronic inflammatory or degenerative condition marked by permanent dilatation (widening) of one or more bronchioles and loss of elasticity of the bronchiolar walls

Subject: decreased core body temperature
Value: reduced degree of heat natural to the internal center of a living being

Subject: decreased body surface temperature
Value: reduced degree of heat natural to skin-environment interface of a living being

Subject: increased core body temperature
Value: increased degree of heat natural to the internal center of a living being

Subject: increased body surface temperature
Value: increased degree of heat natural to the skin-environment interface of a living being

Subject: pulmonary hyaline membrane formation
Value: abnormal presence of an eosinophilic hyaline (glass-like) material composed of fibrin, proteinaceous exudate and cellular debris, and lining or filling the alveoli, alveolar ducts and bronchioles; hyaline membranes block gas exchange and are usually found at autopsy in individuals that have died of respiratory distress syndrome in the neonatal stages

Subject: abnormal adaptive thermogenesis
Value: anomaly in the regulated production of heat in response to short term environmental changes, such as stress, diet or reduced temperature, often resulting in metabolic inefficiency or death

Subject: abnormal circadian temperature homeostasis
Value: any anomaly in the process in which an organism modulates its internal body temperature at different values with a regularity of approximately 24 hours

Subject: abnormal circadian regulation of heart rate
Value: anomaly in the process in which an organism modulates its heart rate at different values with a regularity of approximately 24 hours

Subject: abnormal circadian regulation of systemic arterial blood pressure
Value: any anomaly in the process in which an organism modulates its blood pressure at different values with a regularity of approximately 24 hours

Subject: abnormal branching involved in lung morphogenesis
Value: anomaly in the process in which the branched structure of the respiratory airway tree is generated and organized

Subject: abnormal branching involved in trachea morphogenesis
Value: anomaly in the process in which the two main branches of the trachea is generated and organized

Subject: impaired branching involved in trachea morphogenesis
Value: partial or complete failure of the process in which the two main branches of the trachea is generated and organized

Subject: abnormal branching involved in bronchus morphogenesis
Value: anomaly in the process in which the branched structure of the bronchus is generated and organized

Subject: impaired branching involved in bronchus morphogenesis
Value: partial or complete failure of the process in which the branched structure of the bronchus is generated and organized

Subject: abnormal branching involved in preterminal bronchiole morphogenesis
Value: anomaly in the process in which the branched structure of the preterminal bronchioles are generated and organized

Subject: impaired branching involved in preterminal bronchiole morphogenesis
Value: partial or complete failure of the process in which the branched structure of the preterminal bronchioles are generated and organized

Subject: abnormal branching involved in terminal bronchiole morphogenesis
Value: anomaly in the process in which the branched structure of the terminal bronchioles are generated and organized

Subject: impaired branching involved in terminal bronchiole morphogenesis
Value: partial or complete failure of the process in which the branched structure of the terminal bronchioles are generated and organized

Subject: abnormal branching involved in respiratory bronchiole morphogenesis
Value: anomaly in the process in which the branched structure of the respiratory bronchioles are generated

Subject: impaired branching involved in respiratory bronchiole morphogenesis
Value: partial or complete failure of the process in which the branched structure of the respiratory bronchioles are generated

Subject: abnormal branching involved in alveolar duct morphogenesis
Value: anomaly in the process in which the branched structure of the alveolar ducts are generated

Subject: impaired branching involved in alveolar duct morphogenesis
Value: partial or complete failure of the process in which the branched structure of the alveolar ducts are generated

Subject: abnormal branching involved in alveolar sac morphogenesis
Value: anomaly in the process in which the terminal alveolar sacs are generated

Subject: impaired branching involved in alveolar sac morphogenesis
Value: partial or complete failure of the process in which the terminal alveolar sacs are generated

Subject: abnormal vestibuloocular dark reflex
Value: any anomaly in the nystagmus or deviation of the eyes in response to stimulation of the vestibular system when the test is run without light

Subject: abnormal vestibuloocular light reflex
Value: any anomaly in the nystagmus or deviation of the eyes in response to stimulation of the vestibular system when the test is run with light

Subject: abnormal vertical vestibuloocular reflex
Value: any anomaly in the nystagmus or deviation of the eyes in response to stimulation along the vertical axis of the vestibular system

Subject: abnormal horizontal vestibuloocular reflex
Value: any anomaly in the nystagmus or deviation of the eyes in response to stimulation along the horizontal axis of the vestibular system

Subject: abnormal lung elastance
Value: anomaly in the ability of the lung to recoil toward its resting dimensions upon removal of pressure without disruption, usually expressed as the unit volume of change in the lung per unit of decreased pressure change; the reciprocal of compliance

Subject: increased lung elastance
Value: faster ability of the lung to recoil toward its resting dimensions upon removal of pressure without disruption, usually expressed as the unit volume of change in the lung per unit of decreased pressure change; the reciprocal of compliance

Subject: decreased lung elastance
Value: reduced ability of the lung to recoil toward its resting dimensions upon removal of pressure without disruption, usually expressed as the unit volume of change in the lung per unit of decreased pressure change; the reciprocal of compliance

Subject: abnormal lung tissue damping
Value: anomaly in the respiratory mechanical parameter (G) that is closely related to tissue resistance and reflects the energy dissipation in the lung tissues

Subject: increased lung tissue damping
Value: increased value of the respiratory mechanical parameter (G) that is closely related to tissue resistance and reflects the energy dissipation in the lung tissues

Subject: decreased lung tissue damping
Value: reduced value of the respiratory mechanical parameter (G) that is closely related to tissue resistance and reflects the energy dissipation in the lung tissues

Subject: impaired adaptive thermogenesis
Value: inability or reduced ability to produce heat in response to short term environmental changes, such as stress, diet or reduced temperature, often resulting in metabolic inefficiency or death

Subject: abnormal respiratory motile cilium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the multiple epithelial tiny, motile hair-like projections, which have a variable arrangement of axonemal microtubules, contains molecular motors, and beat with a characteristic whip-like pattern that promote transport of fluids and other cells across the epithelium of the respiratory tract

Subject: abnormal respiratory motile cilium number
Value: anomaly in the number of the multiple epithelial tiny, motile hair-like projections, which have a variable arrangement of axonemal microtubules, contains molecular motors, and beat with a characteristic whip-like pattern that promote transport of fluids and other cells across the epithelium of the respiratory tract

Subject: increased respiratory motile cilia number
Value: greater number of the multiple epithelial tiny, motile hair-like projections, which have a variable arrangement of axonemal microtubules, contains molecular motors, and beat with a characteristic whip-like pattern that promote transport of fluids and other cells across the epithelium of the respiratory tract

Subject: decreased respiratory motile cilia number
Value: reduced number of the multiple epithelial tiny, motile hair-like projections, which have a variable arrangement of axonemal microtubules, contains molecular motors, and beat with a characteristic whip-like pattern that promote transport of fluids and other cells across the epithelium of the respiratory tract

Subject: absent respiratory motile cilia
Value: absence of the multiple epithelial tiny, motile hair-like projections, which have a variable arrangement of axonemal microtubules, contains molecular motors, and beat with a characteristic whip-like pattern that promote transport of fluids and other cells across the epithelium of the respiratory tract

Subject: abnormal respiratory motile cilium physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the multiple epithelial tiny, motile hair-like projections, which have a variable arrangement of axonemal microtubules, contains molecular motors, and beat with a characteristic whip-like pattern that promote transport of fluids and other cells across the epithelium of the respiratory tract; may include alterations in ciliary beating pattern or frequency

Subject: abnormal brain ependyma motile cilium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tiny, motile hair-like projections from the epithelial cells that line the ventricles in the brain, which beat in concert and to move cerebrospinal fluid

Subject: absent brain ependyma motile cilia
Value: absence of the tiny, motile hair-like projections from the epithelial cells that line the ventricles in the brain, which beat in concert and to move cerebrospinal fluid

Subject: abnormal spinal cord motile cilium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tiny, motile hair-like projections from the epithelial cells that line the central canal of the spinal cord, which beat in concert and to move cerebrospinal fluid

Subject: abnormal ependyma motile cilium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tiny, motile hair-like projections from the epithelial cells that line the ventricles in the brain and the central canal of the spinal cord, which beat in concert and to move cerebrospinal fluid around the central nervous system

Subject: abnormal kinocilium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the nonmotile primary cilium that is found at the apical surface of auditory receptor cells

Subject: abnormal inner hair cell kinocilium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the nonmotile primary cilium that is found at the apical surface of inner hair cells

Subject: abnormal outer hair cell kinocilium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the nonmotile primary cilium that is found at the apical surface of outer hair cells

Subject: absent inner hair cell kinocilia
Value: absence of the nonmotile primary cilium that is found at the apical surface of inner hair cells

Subject: abnormal vestibular hair cell kinocilium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the nonmotile primary cilium that is found at the apical surface of vestibular hair cells

Subject: abnormal kidney epithelial cell primary cilium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the single non-motile cilium of a kidney epithelial cell that projects into the luminal space of the tubules and ducts where it is thought to act as a flow sensor

Subject: abnormal renal tubule epithelial cell primary cilium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the single non-motile cilium of a renal tubule epithelial cell that projects into the luminal space of the tubules where it is thought to act as a flow sensor

Subject: abnormal somatostatin level
Value: anomaly of the blood or tissue concentration of a tetradecapeptide capable of inhibiting the release of somatotrophin by the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland and the release of insulin and gastrin from digestive system tissues

Subject: abnormal ependyma motile cilium physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the tiny, motile hair-like projections from the epithelial cells that line the ventricles in the brain and the central canal of the spinal cord, which beat in concert and to move cerebrospinal fluid around the central nervous system

Subject: abnormal brain ependyma motile cilium physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the tiny, motile hair-like projections from the epithelial cells that line the ventricles in the brain, which beat in concert and to move cerebrospinal fluid

Subject: abnormal spinal cord motile cilium physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the tiny, motile hair-like projections from the epithelial cells that line the central canal of the spinal cord, which beat in concert and to move cerebrospinal fluid

Subject: absent club cells
Value: absence of the rounded, club-shaped, nonciliated cells found between ciliated cells in the bronchiolar epithelium

Subject: abnormal macrophage cytokine production
Value: any anomaly in the appearance of macrophage-derived cytokine(s) due to biosynthesis or secretion following a cellular stimulus, resulting in a change to its intracellular or extracellular levels

Subject: abnormal macrophage apoptosis
Value: excessive or absent cell death in macrophages

Subject: abnormal macrophage nitric oxide production
Value: any anomaly in the appearance of macrophage-derived nitric oxide due to biosynthesis or secretion following a cellular stimulus, resulting in an increase in its intracellular or extracellular levels

Subject: abnormal macrophage activation involved in immune response
Value: anomaly in the process in which a change in response and behavior of a macrophage results from exposure to a cytokine, chemokine, cellular ligand, or soluble factor, leading to the initiation or perpetuation of an immune response

Subject: increased macrophage nitric oxide production
Value: greater production of macrophage-derived nitric oxide due to biosynthesis or secretion following a cellular stimulus, resulting in an increase in its intracellular or extracellular levels

Subject: decreased macrophage nitric oxide production
Value: reduced production of macrophage-derived nitric oxide due to biosynthesis or secretion following a cellular stimulus, resulting in an increase in its intracellular or extracellular levels

Subject: increased macrophage cytokine production
Value: greater production of macrophage-derived cytokine(s) due to biosynthesis or secretion following a cellular stimulus, resulting in an increase in its intracellular or extracellular levels

Subject: decreased macrophage cytokine production
Value: reduced production of macrophage-derived cytokine(s) due to biosynthesis or secretion following a cellular stimulus, resulting in an decrease in its intracellular or extracellular levels

Subject: increased macrophage apoptosis
Value: greater incidence of cell death in macrophages

Subject: decreased macrophage apoptosis
Value: reduced incidence of cell death in macrophages

Subject: abnormal gastrointestinal motility
Value: anomaly in the propulsive movements of the digestive system, resulting in the transit of the contents along the gastrointestinal tract

Subject: lethality at weaning, complete penetrance
Value: premature death at weaning age of all organisms of a given genotype in a population, often due to the inability to make the transition to solid food

Subject: lethality at weaning, incomplete penetrance
Value: the appearance of lower than Mendelian ratios of organisms of a given genotype due to death of some, but not all of the organisms at weaning age

Subject: postnatal lethality, complete penetrance
Value: <premature death anytime between the neonatal period and weaning age of all organisms of a given genotype in a population (Mus: P1 to approximately 3 weeks of age)>

Subject: postnatal lethality, incomplete penetrance
Value: <the appearance of lower than Mendelian ratios of organisms of a given genotype due to death of some, but not all of the organisms anytime between the neonatal period and weaning age (Mus: P1 to approximately 3 weeks of age)>

Subject: neonatal lethality, complete penetrance
Value: <death of all organisms of a given genotype in a population within the neonatal period after birth (Mus: P0)>

Subject: neonatal lethality, incomplete penetrance
Value: <the appearance of lower than Mendelian ratios of organisms of a given genotype due to death of some, but not all of the organisms within the neonatal period after birth (Mus: P0)>

Subject: perinatal lethality, complete penetrance
Value: <death of all organisms of a given genotype in a population within the perinatal period (Mus: E18.5 through postnatal day 1)>

Subject: perinatal lethality, incomplete penetrance
Value: <the appearance of lower than Mendelian ratios of organisms of a given genotype due to death of some, but not all of the organisms within the perinatal period (Mus: E18.5 through postnatal day 1)>

Subject: prenatal lethality, complete penetrance
