Value: <death of all organisms of a given genotype in a population between fertilization and birth (Mus: approximately E18.5)>

Subject: embryonic lethality, complete penetrance
Value: <death of all organisms of a given genotype in a population within the embryonic period prior to the completion of organogenesis (Mus: prior to E14)>

Subject: embryonic lethality at implantation, complete penetrance
Value: <death of all organisms of a given genotype in a population at the point of implantation (Mus: E4.5)>

Subject: embryonic lethality before implantation, complete penetrance
Value: <death of all organisms of a given genotype in a population between fertilization and implantation (Mus: E0 to less than E4.5)>

Subject: embryonic lethality between implantation and placentation, complete penetrance
Value: <death of all organisms of a given genotype in a population between the point of implantation and the initiation of placentation (Mus: E4.5 to less than E9)>

Subject: embryonic lethality between implantation and somite formation, complete penetrance
Value: <death of all organisms of a given genotype in a population between the point of implantation and somite formation (Mus: E4.5 to less than E8)>

Subject: embryonic lethality between somite formation and embryo turning, complete penetrance
Value: <death of all organisms of a given genotype in a population between somite formation and the initiation of embryo turning (Mus: E8 to less than E9)>

Subject: embryonic lethality during organogenesis, complete penetrance
Value: <death of all organisms of a given genotype in a population between embryo turning and the completion of organogenesis (Mus: E9-9.5 to less than E14)>

Subject: lethality throughout fetal growth and development, complete penetrance
Value: <death of all organisms of a given genotype in a population between the completion of organogenesis and birth (Mus: E14 to approximately E18.5)>

Subject: preweaning lethality, complete penetrance
Value: <death of all organisms of a given genotype in a population between fertilization and weaning age (Mus: approximately 3-4 weeks of age)>

Subject: prenatal lethality, incomplete penetrance
Value: <the appearance of lower than Mendelian ratios of organisms of a given genotype due to death of some, but not all of the organisms between fertilization and birth (Mus: approximately E18.5)>

Subject: embryonic lethality, incomplete penetrance
Value: <the appearance of lower than Mendelian ratios of organisms of a given genotype due to death of some, but not all of the organisms within the embryonic period prior to the completion of organogenesis (Mus: prior to E14)>

Subject: embryonic lethality at implantation, incomplete penetrance
Value: <the appearance of lower than Mendelian ratios of organisms of a given genotype due to death of some, but not all of the organisms at the point of implantation (Mus: E4.5)>

Subject: embryonic lethality before implantation, incomplete penetrance
Value: <the appearance of lower than Mendelian ratios of organisms of a given genotype due to death of some, but not all of the organisms between fertilization and implantation (Mus: E0 to less than E4.5)>

Subject: embryonic lethality between implantation and placentation, incomplete penetrance
Value: <the appearance of lower than Mendelian ratios of organisms of a given genotype due to death of some, but not all of the organisms between the point of implantation and the initiation of placentation (Mus: E4.5 to less than E9)>

Subject: embryonic lethality between implantation and somite formation, incomplete penetrance
Value: <the appearance of lower than Mendelian ratios of organisms of a given genotype due to death of some, but not all of the organisms between the point of implantation and somite formation (Mus: E4.5 to less than E8)>

Subject: embryonic lethality between somite formation and embryo turning, incomplete penetrance
Value: <the appearance of lower than Mendelian ratios of organisms of a given genotype due to death of some, but not all of the organisms between somite formation and the initiation of embryo turning (Mus: E8 to less than E9)>

Subject: embryonic lethality during organogenesis, incomplete penetrance
Value: <the appearance of lower than Mendelian ratios of organisms of a given genotype due to death of some, but not all of the organisms between embryo turning and the completion of organogenesis (Mus: E9-9.5 to less than E14)>

Subject: lethality throughout fetal growth and development, incomplete penetrance
Value: <the appearance of lower than Mendelian ratios of organisms of a given genotype due to death of some, but not all of the organisms between the completion of organogenesis and birth (Mus: E14 to approximately E18.5)>

Subject: preweaning lethality, incomplete penetrance
Value: <the appearance of lower than Mendelian ratios of organisms of a given genotype due to death of some, but not all of the organisms between fertilization and weaning age (Mus: approximately 3-4 weeks of age)>

Subject: lethality during fetal growth through weaning, complete penetrance
Value: <death of all organisms of a given genotype in a population between the completion of organogenesis and weaning age (Mus: E14 to approximately 3 weeks of age)>

Subject: lethality during fetal growth through weaning, incomplete penetrance
Value: <the appearance of lower than Mendelian ratios of organisms of a given genotype due to death of some, but not all of the organisms between the completion of organogenesis and weaning age (Mus: E14 to approximately 3 weeks of age)>

Subject: abnormal airway basal cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a long-lived multipotent stem cell of the pseudostratified airway epithelium which is restricted to the tracheal epithelium in mice; airway BCs have been shown to be capable of self renewal, give rise to secretory (Clara) cells and ciliated cells, and play important roles both in epithelial homeostasis and in pathological airway remodeling

Subject: abnormal airway basal cell differentiation
Value: abnormal or arrest of differentiation of the long-lived multipotent stem cell population of the pseudostratified airway epithelium; changes in the lineage choice of BCs or their undifferentiated daughters might contribute to the mucous cell hyperplasia, metaplasia or squamous metaplasia seen in many respiratory disorders

Subject: airway basal cell hyperplasia
Value: increased number of the long-lived multipotent stem cells of the pseudostratified airway epithelium

Subject: absent Reichert's membrane
Value: absence of the extraembryonic basement membrane that forms on the inner surface of the trophectoderm during placenta morphogenesis and is secreted by the distal endoderm; normally required for the maternofetal exchange of nutrients and important for postgastrulation development

Subject: abnormal susceptibility to weight gain
Value: anomaly in body weight over time when compared to the average increase in weight on the same diet, with equal energy (calorie) intake

Subject: abnormal susceptibility to weight loss
Value: anomaly in body weight over time when compared to the average decrease in weight in response to dietary modification, fasting or caloric restriction

Subject: abnormal primordial ovarian follicle number
Value: abnormal numbers of the ovarian follicle in which the primary oocyte is surrounded by a single layer of flattened follicular cells; primordial follicles are indiscernible to the naked eye and develop to primary, secondary, and finally mature vesicular follicles

Subject: increased primordial ovarian follicle number
Value: greater than normal numbers of the ovarian follicle in which the primary oocyte is surrounded by a single layer of flattened follicular cells; primordial follicles are indiscernible to the naked eye and develop to primary, secondary, and finally mature vesicular follicles

Subject: decreased primordial ovarian follicle number
Value: fewer than normal numbers of the ovarian follicle in which the primary oocyte is surrounded by a single layer of flattened follicular cells; primordial follicles are indiscernible to the naked eye and develop to primary, secondary, and finally mature vesicular follicles

Subject: absent primordial ovarian follicles
Value: absence of the ovarian follicle in which the primary oocyte is surrounded by a single layer of flattened follicular cells; primordial follicles are indiscernible to the naked eye and develop to primary, secondary, and finally mature vesicular follicles

Subject: abnormal primary ovarian follicle number
Value: abnormal numbers of the ovarian follicle prior to the appearance of an antrum, normally marked by developmental changes in the primary oocyte and follicular cells so that the latter form one or more layers of cuboidal or columnar cells; the follicle becomes surrounded by a sheath of stroma, the theca

Subject: increased primary ovarian follicle number
Value: greater than normal numbers of the ovarian follicle prior to the appearance of an antrum, normally marked by developmental changes in the primary oocyte and follicular cells so that the latter form one or more layers of cuboidal or columnar cells; the follicle becomes surrounded by a sheath of stroma, the theca

Subject: decreased primary ovarian follicle number
Value: fewer than normal numbers of the ovarian follicle prior to the appearance of an antrum, normally marked by developmental changes in the primary oocyte and follicular cells so that the latter form one or more layers of cuboidal or columnar cells; the follicle becomes surrounded by a sheath of stroma, the theca

Subject: absent primary ovarian follicles
Value: absence of the ovarian follicle prior to the appearance of an antrum, normally marked by developmental changes in the primary oocyte and follicular cells so that the latter form one or more layers of cuboidal or columnar cells; the follicle becomes surrounded by a sheath of stroma, the theca

Subject: abnormal secondary ovarian follicle number
Value: abnormal numbers of the ovarian follicle in which the primary oocyte attains its full size and is surrounded by an extracellular glycoprotein layer (zona pellucida) that separates it from a peripheral layer of follicular cells permeated by one or more fluid-filled antra; the primary oocyte occupies the cumulus oophorus while the theca of the follicle develops into internal and external layers

Subject: increased secondary ovarian follicle number
Value: greater than normal numbers of the ovarian follicle in which the primary oocyte attains its full size and is surrounded by an extracellular glycoprotein layer (zona pellucida) that separates it from a peripheral layer of follicular cells permeated by one or more fluid-filled antra; the primary oocyte occupies the cumulus oophorus while the theca of the follicle develops into internal and external layers

Subject: decreased secondary ovarian follicle number
Value: fewer than normal numbers of the ovarian follicle in which the primary oocyte attains its full size and is surrounded by an extracellular glycoprotein layer (zona pellucida) that separates it from a peripheral layer of follicular cells permeated by one or more fluid-filled antra; the primary oocyte occupies the cumulus oophorus while the theca of the follicle develops into internal and external layers

Subject: absent secondary ovarian follicles
Value: absence of the ovarian follicle in which the primary oocyte attains its full size and is surrounded by an extracellular glycoprotein layer (zona pellucida) that separates it from a peripheral layer of follicular cells permeated by one or more fluid-filled antra; the primary oocyte occupies the cumulus oophorus while the theca of the follicle develops into internal and external layers

Subject: abnormal lung endothelial cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the squamous cells forming the lining of the pulmonary vasculature

Subject: abnormal lung endothelial cell migration
Value: anomaly in the movement of endothelial cells or their precursors to the appropriate location in the pulmonary vasculature

Subject: increased lung endothelial cell migration
Value: increased or faster movement of endothelial cells or their precursors to the appropriate location in the pulmonary vasculature

Subject: decreased lung endothelial cell migration
Value: reduced or slower movement of endothelial cells or their precursors to the appropriate location in the pulmonary vasculature

Subject: abnormal lung endothelial cell adhesion
Value: altered ability of an endothelial cell in the pulmonary vasculature to adhere to another cell or to a non-cellular component of the environment

Subject: increased lung endothelial cell adhesion
Value: increased ability of an endothelial cell in the pulmonary vasculature to adhere to another cell or to a non-cellular component of the environment

Subject: decreased lung endothelial cell adhesion
Value: decreased ability of an endothelial cell in the pulmonary vasculature to adhere to another cell or to a non-cellular component of the environment

Subject: abnormal lung endothelial cell proliferation
Value: altered ability of an endothelial cell in the pulmonary vasculature to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: increased lung endothelial cell proliferation
Value: greater ability of an endothelial cell in the pulmonary vasculature to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: decreased lung endothelial cell proliferation
Value: reduced ability of an endothelial cell in the pulmonary vasculature to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: increased lung endothelial cell apoptosis
Value: acceleration in the timing or in the number of endothelial cells in the pulmonary vasculature undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal lung-associated mesenchyme development
Value: abnormality in the formation of the lung tissue comprised of multiple cell types (including connective tissue, endothelial cells, lymphatics, smooth muscle cells surrounding airways and blood vessels, myofibroblasts involved in septum formation, and cartilage-forming cells in the trachea), with most cells thought to be derived from the splanchnic mesenchyme, and other cells (endothelial, smooth muscle) believed to invade the lung as it expands; lung mesenchyme is a critical determinant of the shape and size of the developing lung, the extent and patterning of epithelial branching, and the formation of the pulmonary vasculature and interstitial mesenchymal components of the adult lung

Subject: thick lung-associated mesenchyme
Value: increased thickness of the mesenchymal cell layer due to delay or failure of the mesenchymal compartment to thin down during the late stages of embryonic lung development

Subject: thin lung-associated mesenchyme
Value: decreased thickness of the mesenchymal cell layer in the developing lung

Subject: abnormal mesenchymal cell differentiation involved in lung development
Value: abnormal or arrest of differentiation of the mesenchymal cell population in the developing lung

Subject: abnormal mesenchymal cell proliferation involved in lung development
Value: anomaly in the ability of the differentiating lung mesenchymal cell population to undergo expansion by cell division in the developing lung

Subject: increased mesenchymal cell proliferation involved in lung development
Value: increase in the expansion rate of a lung mesenchymal cell population by cell division

Subject: decreased mesenchymal cell proliferation involved in lung development
Value: reduction in the expansion rate of a lung mesenchymal cell population by cell division

Subject: abnormal hippocampus stratum oriens morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the layer that is part of the CA fields of the hippocampus consisting of a narrow relatively cell free layer located deep to the pyramidal cell layer extending through areas CA1, CA2 and CA3

Subject: abnormal hippocampus stratum radiatum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the layer located immediately above the pyramidal cell layer in CA2 and CA1 and superficial to the stratum lucidum in CA3. Suprapyramidal region in which CA3 to CA3 associational connections and CA3 to CA1 Schaffer collateral connections are located

Subject: thick hippocampus molecular cell layer
Value: increase in the width of the cytoarchitectural region of the hippocampus consisting of a composite of the two outermost layers of the hippocampus, the Stratum lacunosum-moleculare and the Stratum radiatum

Subject: thick hippocampus stratum oriens
Value: increase in the width of the layer that is part of the CA fields of the hippocampus consisting of a narrow relatively cell free layer located deep to the pyramidal cell layer extending through areas CA1, CA2 and CA3

Subject: thick hippocampus stratum radiatum
Value: increase in the width of the layer located immediately above the pyramidal cell layer in CA2 and CA1 and superficial to the stratum lucidum in CA3

Subject: absent hippocampus stratum oriens
Value: absence of the layer that is part of the CA fields of the hippocampus consisting of a narrow relatively cell free layer located deep to the pyramidal cell layer extending through areas CA1, CA2 and CA3

Subject: abnormal hypodermis fat layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the superficial portion of the subcutaneous tissue which is specialized for fat storage

Subject: abnormal hypodermis muscle layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the skeletal muscle layer in the superficial fascia

Subject: absent hypodermis muscle layer
Value: absence of the skeletal muscle layer in the superficial fascia

Subject: abnormal epidermal-dermal junction morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the multi-layer basement membrane between the dermis and epidermis that serves to adhere the dermis and epidermis, provide mechanical support for the epidermis, and forms a barrier to cells and large molecules across the junction

Subject: dermal-epidermal separation
Value: the appearance of gaps or clefts in the normally continuous junctional interface between the dermis and epidermis

Subject: increased hypodermis neovascularization
Value: new or excessive vessel proliferation in the irregular layer of loose connective tissue containing fibroblasts, adipose cells, and macrophages, that is immediately deep to the skin and superficial to the deep fascia

Subject: abnormal wet-to-dry lung weight ratio
Value: any deviation from the standard ratio, calculated by dividing the wet lung weight (measured immediately after lung excision) to the oven-dried lung weight, compared to control samples; may be used as an index of extravascular fluid accumulation (pulmonary edema) and/or tissue damage after lung injury

Subject: increased wet-to-dry lung weight ratio
Value: an increase in the ratio of wet lung weight (measured immediately after lung excision) to oven-dried lung weight relative to control samples; may reflect an inability to expel remaining amniotic fluid out of the lungs during or shortly after birth, or increased fluid accumulation (pulmonary edema) and/or tissue damage after lung injury

Subject: panniculitis
Value: inflammation of the subcutaneous adipose tissue

Subject: abnormal tooth root development
Value: aberrant or incomplete formation of the part of a tooth that is implanted in the gum; the root is normally located below the neck of the tooth, covered by cementum rather than enamel, and attached by the periodontal ligament to the alveolar bone

Subject: absent molar root
Value: absence of the part of a molar tooth that is implanted in the gum; mandibular and maxillary molars usually have two and three roots, respectively

Subject: abnormal adipose tissue development
Value: anomaly in the process of the formation of the connective tissue composed of fat cells enmeshed in areolar tissue

Subject: abnormal fat cell differentiation
Value: abnormal or arrest of differentiation of fat-storing cells found mostly in the abdominal cavity and subcutaneous tissue of mammals

Subject: abnormal white fat cell differentation
Value: abnormal or arrest of differentiation of fat cells with light coloration and few mitochondria; these contain a scant ring of cytoplasm surrounding a single large lipid droplet or vacuole

Subject: abnormal brown fat cell differentiation
Value: abnormal or arrest of differentiation of cells from the thermogenic form of adipose tissue found in newborns of many species, including humans, and in hibernating mammals

Subject: increased number of Heinz bodies
Value: presence of intracellular inclusions usually attached to the red blood cell membrane, resulting from oxidative injury to and precipitation of hemoglobin in red blood cells

Subject: abnormal otic pit morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the pair of depressions of thickened otic placode epithelium, that further develops into the otic vesicles

Subject: abnormal otic placode morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of two paired thickened areas of ectoderm close to the hindbrain from which the vestibular system and the auditory system develops; the otic placode invaginates into the mesenchyme adjacent to the rhombencephalon to form the otic pit

Subject: lipodystrophy
Value: abnormal or degenerative conditions of the body's adipose tissue resulting in bodily or focal loss and the appearance of redistribution of fat tissue; adipose tissue loss may be total, partial, or localized

Subject: platyspondylia
Value: flatness of the bodies of the vertebrae; one or many vertebrae may be affected

Subject: abnormal erythroblast morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the nucleated precursor of erythrocytes

Subject: abnormal erythroblast number
Value: altered number of the nucleated precursor of erythrocytes

Subject: increased erythroblast number
Value: greater number of the nucleated precursor of erythrocytes

Subject: decreased erythroblast number
Value: reduced number of the nucleated precursor of erythrocytes

Subject: abnormal hematopoietic cell number
Value: any anomaly in the expected number of cells of the hematopoietic lineage

Subject: increased hematopoietic cell number
Value: greater than expected number of cells of the hematopoietic lineage

Subject: decreased hematopoietic cell number
Value: fewer than expected number of cells of the hematopoietic lineage

Subject: abnormal primitive endoderm morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the transient thin monolayer of cuboidal cells that comprise the lower layer of the bilaminar embryonic disk; the hypoblast cells contribute to several extraembryonic structures, but do not contribute to the embryo

Subject: absent embryonic epiblast
Value: absence of the transient structure derived from the inner cell mass which lies above the hypoblast; the epiblast tissue gives rise to the three primary germ layers (ectoderm, definitive endoderm, and mesoderm) and to the extraembryonic mesoderm of the visceral yolk sac, the allantois, and the amnion

Subject: absent primitive endoderm
Value: absence of the transient thin monolayer of cuboidal cells that comprise the lower layer of the bilaminar embryonic disk; the hypoblast cells contribute to several extraembryonic structures, but do not contribute to the embryo

Subject: abnormal visceral endoderm morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the primitive endoderm-derived tissue which remains in contact with and surrounds the extra-embryonic ectoderm and the epiblast and provides signals for the differentiation and patterning of the epiblast; a small number of visceral endoderm cells also contribute to the endoderm of the embryonic gut

Subject: abnormal parietal endoderm morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the primitive endoderm-derived tissue that lines the luminal surface of the mural trophectoderm

Subject: increased erythrocyte protoporphyrin level
Value: an accumulation of the intermediates of heme biosynthesis in red blood cells

Subject: small embryonic epiblast
Value: reduced size of the transient structure derived from the inner cell mass which lies above the hypoblast; the epiblast tissue gives rise to the three primary germ layers (ectoderm, definitive endoderm, and mesoderm) and to the extraembryonic mesoderm of the visceral yolk sac, the allantois, and the amnion

Subject: thick embryonic epiblast
Value: increased thickness of the transient structure derived from the inner cell mass which lies above the hypoblast; the epiblast tissue gives rise to the three primary germ layers (ectoderm, definitive endoderm, and mesoderm) and to the extraembryonic mesoderm of the visceral yolk sac, the allantois, and the amnion

Subject: increased embryonic epiblast cell apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of embryonic epiblast cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: decreased embryonic epiblast cell proliferation
Value: reduction in the expansion rate of the embryonic epiblast cells by cell division

Subject: embryonic epiblast cell degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of the cells comprising the transient structure derived from the inner cell mass which lies above the hypoblast; the epiblast tissue gives rise to the three primary germ layers (ectoderm, definitive endoderm, and mesoderm) and to the extraembryonic mesoderm of the visceral yolk sac, the allantois, and the amnion

Subject: abnormal hair follicle physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the invagination of the epidermis from which the hair shaft develops

Subject: increased hair follicle apoptosis
Value: greater than expected levels of programmed cell death of cells in the epidermis from which the hair shaft develops

Subject: decreased hair follicle apoptosis
Value: reduced from expected levels of programmed cell death of cells in the epidermis from which the hair shaft develops

Subject: abnormal proamniotic cavity morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cavity of the developing embryo that is formed within the epiblast tissue prior to the closing of the proamniotic canal by the amniotic folds

Subject: absent proamniotic cavity
Value: absence of the cavity of the developing embryo that is formed within the epiblast tissue prior to the closing of the proamniotic canal by the amniotic folds

Subject: abnormal amniotic cavity morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the closed space between the embryo and the amnion, containing the amniotic fluid; it is formed by the fusion of the parts of the anterior and posterior amniotic folds

Subject: abnormal extraembryonic coelom morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the fluid-filled spaces formed within the mass of extraembryonic mesoderm that later fuse to become a large extraembryonic cavity

Subject: abnormal visceral yolk sac cavity morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the closed space containing the yolk, formed by the fusion of the edges of the embryonic epiblast (hypoblast) and later surrounded by the visceral yolk sac (hypoblast and visceral yolk sac mesoderm)

Subject: abnormal ectoplacental cavity morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the closed space within the ectoplacental cone, formed by the fusion of the parts of the amniotic fold that separate it from the amniotic cavity

Subject: abnormal parietal yolk sac morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tissue that consists of two cellular layers (parietal endoderm and trophoblast) separated by a relatively thick nonvascular basement membrane (Reichert's membrane), and acts as a protective layer to supports and facilitates transport of nutrients between the uterine tissue and the yolk sac cavity

Subject: abnormal visceral yolk sac blood island morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the masses of developing blood cells attached to endothelium in the yolk sac

Subject: excessive folding of visceral yolk sac
Value: the appearance of wrinkles or folds on the surface of the visceral yolk sac

Subject: absent visceral yolk sac
Value: absence of the extraembryonic tissue membrane, formed from the visceral endoderm and the extraembryonic mesoderm, which is located ventral to the embryonic disc and is connected to the presumptive midgut of the embryo

Subject: absent ectoplacental cavity
Value: absence of the closed space within the ectoplacental cone, formed by the fusion of the parts of the amniotic fold that separate it from the amniotic cavity

Subject: small proamniotic cavity
Value: reduced size of the cavity of the developing embryo that is formed within the epiblast tissue prior to the closing of the proamniotic canal by the amniotic folds

Subject: absent extraembryonic coelom
Value: absence of the fluid-filled spaces formed within the mass of extraembryonic mesoderm that later fuse to become a large extraembryonic cavity

Subject: abnormal temporomandibular joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the synovial articulation between the head of the mandibular condoyloid process and the mandibular fossa and articular tubercle of the temporal bones

Subject: abnormal common peroneal nerve morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a nerve arising at the terminal division of the sciatic nerve at the popliteal fossa and extending to the neck of the fibula, ultimately innervating the Peroneus muscles

Subject: absent common peroneal nerve
Value: absence of the nerve arising at the terminal division of the sciatic nerve at the popliteal fossa and extending to the neck of the fibula, ultimately innervating the Peroneus muscles

Subject: abnormal brain copper level
Value: an anomaly in the amount of copper present in brain tissue

Subject: increased brain copper level
Value: a greater accumulation of copper in the brain tissue compared to controls

Subject: decreased brain copper level
Value: a reduced amount of copper in the brain tissue compared to controls

Subject: abnormal brainstem copper level
Value: an anomaly in the amount of copper present in brainstem tissue

Subject: increased brainstem copper level
Value: a greater accumulation of copper in the brainstem tissue compared to controls

Subject: decreased brainstem copper level
Value: a reduced amount of copper in the brainstem tissue compared to controls

Subject: abnormal intestinal calcium absorption
Value: any anomaly in the ability of the body to take up calcium into the blood by absorption from the small intestine

Subject: increased intestinal calcium absorption
Value: augmented ability of the body to take up calcium into the blood by absorption from the small intestine

Subject: decreased intestinal calcium absorption
Value: reduced ability of the body to take up calcium into the blood by absorption from the small intestine

Subject: abnormal lymph node medullary sinus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the channels in the lymph node medulla that separate the medullary cords and are crossed by a reticulum of cells and fibers and bounded by littoral cells; lymph flows through the medullary sinus from the cortical sinuses and into the efferent lymphatic vessels

Subject: dilated lymph node medullary sinus
Value: the luminal space of the lymph node medulla is increased in volume or area, usually with an increase in contained fluid

Subject: abnormal lymph node medullary cord morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the dense rope-like structures of lymphatic tissue located between the medullary sinuses in the medulla of a lymph node

Subject: lymph node medullary cord hyperplasia
Value: increase in the number of normal cells in normal arrangement in the lymph node medullary cords, resulting in a thickening or enlargement of the structure, caused by stimuli including increased physiological demand, inflammatory response, hormonal changes or hormonal dysfunctions, and/or compensation due to a pathological cause elsewhere

Subject: abnormal thiamin level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration of thiamine (vitamin B1), a water soluble vitamin present in fresh vegetables and meats, especially liver

Subject: abnormal vitamin B12 level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration of cobalamin (vitamin B12), a water-soluble vitamin characterized by possession of a corrin nucleus containing a cobalt atom

Subject: abnormal vitamin D level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration of vitamin D, any of a group of related, fat-soluble compounds that are derived from delta-5,7 steroids and play a central role in calcium metabolism; specific forms of vitamin D include calciferol (ergocalciferol; vitamin D2) and cholecalciferol (calciol; vitamin D3)

Subject: abnormal vitamin C level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration of L-ascorbic acid (vitamin C), which is a common co-factor and has anti-oxidant activities in many species

Subject: abnormal folic acid level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration of the vitamin B family member that stimulates the hematopoietic system, is present in the liver and kidney and is found in mushrooms, spinach, yeast, green leaves, and grasses, and is used in the treatment and prevention of folate deficiencies and megaloblastic anemia

Subject: abnormal vitamin E level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration of vitamin E, tocopherol, including a series of eight structurally similar compounds; alpha-tocopherol is the most active form in humans and is a powerful biological antioxidant

Subject: abnormal vitamin A level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration of any of the vitamin A compounds, retinol, retinal (retinaldehyde) and retinoic acid; animals can not synthesize vitamin A de novo, but form it through oxidative cleavage of carotenoids supplied in the diet

Subject: abnormal vitamin A metabolism
Value: altered ability to metabolize any of the vitamin A compounds, retinol, retinal (retinaldehyde) and retinoic acid; animals can not synthesize vitamin A de novo, but form it through oxidative cleavage of carotenoids supplied in the diet

Subject: abnormal retinol level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration of retinol, which plays an essential role in metabolic functioning of the retina, and growth and differentiation

Subject: abnormal blood oxygen capacity
Value: the maximum amount of oxygen that will combine chemically with a given amount of hemoglobin in a unit volume of blood is not as expected

Subject: increased blood oxygen capacity
Value: an increase in the maximum amount of oxygen that will combine chemically with a given amount of hemoglobin in a unit volume of blood

Subject: decreased blood oxygen capacity
Value: a decrease in the maximum amount of oxygen that will combine chemically with a given amount of hemoglobin in a unit volume of blood

Subject: abnormal inner ear development
Value: atypical initial production, differentiation, migration or maturation of the labyrinth, including the semicircular canals, vestibule and cochlea

Subject: abnormal skin coloration
Value: a variation in an expected skin color or complexion that may be due to inflammation, pigment defects or other causes

Subject: abnormal fetal derived definitive erythrocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a fetal liver derived enucleated erythrocyte, which matures in macrophage islands within the liver, enucleates, and then enters the bloodstream; these resemble adult erythrocytes in that they are small (3- to 6- times smaller than primitive erythrocytes) and produce adult hemoglobins

Subject: abnormal fetal derived definitive erythrocyte cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of a fetal liver derived enucleated erythrocytes, which mature in macrophage islands within the liver, enucleate, and then enter the bloodstream; these resemble adult erythrocytes in that they are small (3- to 6- times smaller than primitive erythrocytes) and produce adult hemoglobins

Subject: increased fetal derived definitive erythrocyte cell number
Value: increased number of fetal liver derived enucleated erythrocytes, which mature in macrophage islands within the liver, enucleate, and then enter the bloodstream; these resemble adult erythrocytes in that they are small (3- to 6- times smaller than primitive erythrocytes) and produce adult hemoglobins

Subject: decreased fetal derived definitive erythrocyte cell number
Value: reduced number of fetal liver derived enucleated erythrocytes, which mature in macrophage islands within the liver, enucleate, and then enter the bloodstream; these resemble adult erythrocytes in that they are small (3- to 6- times smaller than primitive erythrocytes) and produce adult hemoglobins

Subject: absent fetal derived definitive erythrocytes
Value: absence of fetal liver derived enucleated erythrocytes, which mature in macrophage islands within the liver, enucleate, and then enter the bloodstream; these resemble adult erythrocytes in that they are small (3- to 6- times smaller than primitive erythrocytes) and produce adult hemoglobins

Subject: abnormal fetal derived definitive erythrocyte physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of a fetal liver derived enucleated erythrocyte, which matures in macrophage islands within the liver, enucleates, and then enters the bloodstream; these resemble adult erythrocytes in that they are small (3- to 6- times smaller than primitive erythrocytes) and produce adult hemoglobins

Subject: abnormal fetal liver hematopoietic progenitor cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a hematopoietic stem cell that resides in the fetal liver

Subject: abnormal yolk sac hematopoietic stem cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a hematopoietic stem found in the yolk sac

Subject: visceral organ asymmetry
Value: lateral duplication of some or all internal organs

Subject: abdominal situs inversus
Value: lateral transposition or mirroring of the viscera of the abdomen, sometimes incomplete, with all organs maintaining the normal relative position with respect to each other

Subject: abdominal situs ambiguus
Value: an abnormality in which the abdominal organs are positioned in such a way with respect to each other and the left-right axis as to be not clearly lateralised and thus have neither the usual, or normal (situs solitus), nor the mirror-imaged (situs inversus) arrangements

Subject: bronchial situs inversus
Value: anomaly in the asymmetry of the bronchi of the lung such that these structures on both the left and right side have the morphology normally seen on the opposite side of the body

Subject: situs inversus totalis
Value: the complete right to left reversal (transposition) of the thoracic and abdominal organs, including the heart (dextrocardia)

Subject: situs inversus with levocardia
Value: situs inversus of thoracic and abdominal viscera with the heart remaining normally situated on the left; usually associated with congenital cardiac abnormalities such as transposition of the great vessels and/or spleen defects including asplenia or polysplenia

Subject: superior-inferior ventricles
Value: an abnormality in which the heart ventricles are in a superior-inferior relationship due to abnormal displacement of the ventricular mass along the horizontal plane of its long axis; this frequently occurs together with criss-cross atrio-ventricular relationships

Subject: abnormal anterior visceral endoderm cell migration
Value: any anomaly in the movement of the cells of the extraembryonic tissue that is responsible for the proper orientation of the anterior-posterior axis of the embryo and for appropriate patterning of adjacent embryonic tissue

Subject: abnormal neural fold morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the elevated margins of the neural groove

Subject: abnormal head fold morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the crescent-shaped, ventrally located fold of the embryonic disc at the future cephalic end of the developing embryo; it constitutes the first body fold, and initiates brain, foregut and heart development

Subject: abnormal tail fold morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the crescent-shaped, ventrally located fold of the embryonic disc at the future caudal end of the developing embryo

Subject: abnormal cephalic neural fold morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the elevated margins of the neural groove that are located in the future cephalic region of the embryo

Subject: abnormal head mesenchyme morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the primordial embryonic connective tissue of the developing head, consisting of mesenchymal cells supported in interlaminar jelly, that derive mostly from the mesoderm and contribute to head connective tissue, bone and musculature in conjunction with cranial neural crest cells

Subject: abnormal limb mesenchyme morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the primordial embryonic connective tissue of the developing limbs, autopods and digits, consisting of mesenchymal cells supported in interlaminar jelly, that derive mostly from the mesoderm and contribute to limb connective tissue, bone and musculature in conjunction with myotome cells

Subject: abnormal pharyngeal arch mesenchyme morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the primordial embryonic connective tissue associated with the branchial arches, consisting of mesenchymal cells supported in interlaminar jelly, that derive mostly from the mesoderm and contribute to facial and cranial nerve-associated structures

Subject: abnormal spleen mesenchyme morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the embryonic connective tissue made up of loosely aggregated mesenchymal cells, supported by interlaminar jelly, that gives rise to the developing spleen

Subject: abnormal cardiac mesenchyme morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the embryonic connective tissue made up of loosely aggregated mesenchymal cells, supported by interlaminar jelly, that gives rise to the developing cardiac structures

Subject: abnormal pancreas mesenchyme morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the embryonic connective tissue made up of loosely aggregated mesenchymal cells, supported by interlaminar jelly, that gives rise to the developing pancreas

Subject: abnormal frontonasal mesenchyme morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the embryonic connective tissue made up of loosely aggregated mesenchymal cells, supported by interlaminar jelly, that gives rise to the frontonasal region of the head

Subject: abnormal excitatory postsynaptic current amplitude
Value: anomaly in the size (height or maximum displacement) or shape of the evoked excitatory postsynaptic current wave

Subject: biphasic excitatory postsynaptic current amplitude
Value: the appearance of two peaks instead of one peak in the evoked excitatory postsynaptic current wave

Subject: increased excitatory postsynaptic current amplitude
Value: increase in the size (height or maximum displacement) of the evoked excitatory postsynaptic current wave

Subject: decreased excitatory postsynaptic current amplitude
Value: reduction in the size (height or maximum displacement) of the evoked excitatory postsynaptic current wave

Subject: prolonged excitatory postsynaptic current rise time
Value: an increase in the time required for a signal to change from resting to the peak amplitude value in the evoked excitatory postsynaptic current wave

Subject: short excitatory postsynaptic current rise time
Value: an decrease in the time required for a signal to change from resting to the peak amplitude value in the evoked excitatory postsynaptic current wave

Subject: abnormal behavioral response to light
Value: unexpected change in the activity of an organism (in terms of movement, outward responses) as a result of a light stimulus, electromagnetic radiation of wavelengths classified as infrared, visible or ultraviolet light

Subject: increased tail pigmentation
Value: visually detectable excess of pigment present on the tail surface

Subject: decreased tail pigmentation
Value: visually detectable dilution of pigment present on the tail surface

Subject: increased ear pigmentation
Value: visually detectable excess of pigment present in the outer ear

Subject: decreased ear pigmentation
Value: visually detectable dilution of pigment present in the outer ear

Subject: abnormal flank coat pigmentation
Value: irregular or unusual pigmentation of the hair between the last rib and the hip

Subject: abnormal olfactory epithelium cilium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cilia of the epithelial cells that line the interior of the nose

Subject: increased podocyte apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of podocytes undergoing programmed cell death; podocyte apoptosis is an early step in the pathophysiological progression to proteinuria and glomerulosclerosis

Subject: abnormal erythropoietin level
Value: anomalous fluid or tissue concentration of a sialic acid-containing glycoprotein hormone that enhances erythropoiesis and participates in wound healing; it is formed in the kidney and liver and can be detected in plasma and urine

Subject: abnormal circulating erythropoietin level
Value: anomalous blood concentration of a sialic acid-containing glycoprotein hormone that enhances erythropoiesis and participates in wound healing; it is formed in the kidney and liver and can be detected in plasma and urine

Subject: increased circulating erythropoietin level
Value: greater blood concentration of a sialic acid-containing glycoprotein hormone that enhances erythropoiesis and participates in wound healing; it is formed in the kidney and liver and can be detected in plasma and urine

Subject: decreased circulating erythropoietin level
Value: reduced blood concentration of a sialic acid-containing glycoprotein hormone that enhances erythropoiesis and participates in wound healing; it is formed in the kidney and liver and can be detected in plasma and urine

Subject: increased erythropoietin level
Value: greater fluid or tissue concentration of a sialic acid-containing glycoprotein hormone that enhances erythropoiesis and participates in wound healing; it is formed in the kidney and liver and can be detected in plasma and urine

Subject: decreased erythropoietin level
Value: reduced fluid or tissue concentration of a sialic acid-containing glycoprotein hormone that enhances erythropoiesis and participates in wound healing; it is formed in the kidney and liver and can be detected in plasma and urine

Subject: abnormal nephron number
Value: anomaly in the total number of the filtering units of the kidney; nephron number can be used as an index of the efficiency of ureteric branching and nephrogenesis

Subject: decreased nephron number
Value: reduction in the total number of filtering units of the kidney

Subject: nephron necrosis
Value: morphological changes resulting from pathological death of nephron tissue; usually due to irreversible damage

Subject: absent nephron
Value: complete absence of functional filtering units in the kidney

Subject: dilated nephron
Value: stretched or widened aperture of the luminal space of the filtering unit of the kidney

Subject: renal glomerulus hypertrophy
Value: increase in the bulk size of the capillary loops of the kidney that normally function as a filtration unit, due to cell enlargement

Subject: abnormal tubuloglomerular feedback response
Value: any anomaly in the blood flow control mechanism that is operated in the juxtaglomerular apparatus of the kidney and involved in renal autoregulation by limiting changes in the glomerular filtration rate. TGF responds to changes in the concentration of NaCl in the tubular fluid at the level of the macula densa

Subject: decreased tubuloglomerular feedback response
Value: attenuation of the blood flow control mechanism that is operated in the juxtaglomerular apparatus of the kidney and involved in renal autoregulation by limiting changes in the glomerular filtration rate. TGF responds to changes in the concentration of NaCl in the tubular fluid at the level of the macula densa

Subject: absent tubuloglomerular feedback response
Value: absence of the blood flow control mechanism that is operated in the juxtaglomerular apparatus of the kidney and involved in renal autoregulation by limiting changes in the glomerular filtration rate. TGF responds to changes in the concentration of NaCl in the tubular fluid at the level of the macula densa

Subject: ureter hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the ureter, usually due to a reduced number of cells

Subject: abnormal macula densa morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the specialized group of densely packed epithelial cells marking the origin of the convoluted portion of the distal tubule of a nephron, in contact with the afferent arteriole of the renal corpuscle and contiguous with the juxtaglomerular cells; these cells are tall, thin and columnar, have prominent nuclei, and act as sensors of solute concentration and flow of tubular fluid

Subject: abnormal juxtaglomerular cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the specialized smooth muscle cells that synthesize, store, and secrete renin and are found in the wall of each afferent arteriole of a kidney glomerulus near its point of entry adjacent to a macula densa; J-G cells are distinguished by their granulated cytoplasm and play a critical role in the renin-angiotensin system and thus in renal autoregulation

Subject: juxtaglomerular cell hyperplasia
Value: increased number of the specialized smooth muscle cells that synthesize, store, and secrete renin and are found in the wall of each afferent arteriole of a kidney glomerulus near its point of entry adjacent to a macula densa

Subject: abnormal extraglomerular mesangial cell morphology
Value: <any structural anomaly of the light-staining cells in the kidney found outside the glomerulus, near the vascular pole and macula densa; lacis cells form the juxtaglomerular apparatus in combination with two other types of cells: the macula densa of the distal convoluted tubule and juxtaglomerular cells of the afferent arteriole>

Subject: absent kidney papilla
Value: absence of the apex (tip) of a renal pyramid i.e. the location where each medullary pyramid empties urine into a minor calyx

Subject: kidney papillary atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of the apex (tip) of a renal pyramid associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: dilated kidney calyx
Value: an expansion in the lumen volume or area of any of the branches of the renal pelvis that surround each renal papilla and collect urine

Subject: absent kidney pelvis
Value: absence of the funnel shaped proximal portion of the ureter, normally formed by convergence of the major calices

Subject: kidney medulla cysts
Value: abnormal membranous sacs appearing in the inner portion of the kidney which consists of the renal pyramids

Subject: kidney corticomedullary cysts
Value: development of abnormal membranous sacs in the corticomedullary junction of the kidney

Subject: abnormal kidney arterial blood vessel morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the network of tubes that supply blood to the renal tissues

Subject: abnormal kidney capillary morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small branching blood vessels in the kidney that form a network between the arterioles and venules, where the exchange of water, oxygen, carbon dioxide, and other nutrient and waste chemical substances occurs between the blood and the surrounding tissues

Subject: abnormal kidney venous blood vessel morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the network of tubes that return blood from the renal tissues to the systemic circulation

Subject: abnormal kidney afferent arteriole morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the blood vessels that branch from the kidney interlobular artery, convey blood to the glomerular capillaries, and play an important role in the regulation of blood pressure as a part of the tubuloglomerular feedback mechanism

Subject: abnormal kidney efferent arteriole morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the blood vessels that convey blood from the glomerulocapillary network to the capillary bed of the proximal convoluted tubule

Subject: abnormal kidney cortex artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the network of tubes that supplies blood to the renal cortex

Subject: abnormal kidney arcuate artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the curved arteries at the corticomedullary border of the kidney that arise from the interlobar arteries and give rise to the interlobular arteries

Subject: abnormal kidney interlobular artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the branches of the arcuate arteries of the kidney that radiate outward throught the renal columns and supply the glomeruli

Subject: abnormal renal artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the pair of major vessels which arise off the side of the abdominal aorta, immediately below the superior mesenteric artery, and supply the kidneys with blood; small branches of the renal artery also supply the suprarenal gland, the ureter and some surrounding tissues

Subject: abnormal right renal artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the major vessel which arises off the side of the abdominal aorta, immediately below the superior mesenteric artery, and supplies the right kidney with blood

Subject: abnormal left renal artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the major vessel which arises off the side of the abdominal aorta, immediately below the superior mesenteric artery, and supplies the left kidney with blood

Subject: abnormal glomerular capillary morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small branching blood vessels in the kidney glomerulus that receives blood from the kidney afferent arterioles; these capillaries are under high pressure for filtering within the glomerulus

Subject: abnormal peritubular capillary morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tiny blood vessels that receive blood from the efferent arterioles of the glomerulus, and interact with superficial cortical nephrons allowing reabsorption and secretion between blood and the inner lumen of the nephron; peritubular capillaries are situated around the tubule and are at low pressure

Subject: abnormal kidney cortex vein morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the network of tubes that receives blood from the renal cortex

Subject: abnormal renal vein morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the pair of major vessels which arise from the renal hilus and return blood from the kidneys, suprarenal gland and the ureter to the inferior vena cava

Subject: abnormal kidney arcuate vein morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the veins that parallel the arcuate arteries, receive blood from the interlobular veins and straight venules, and terminate in the interlobar veins

Subject: abnormal interlobular vein morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the veins that parallel the interlobular arteries, receiving blood from the peritubular capillary plexus and empty into the arcuate veins

Subject: abnormal left renal vein morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the longer of the two renal veins that receives blood from the left kidney; the left renal vein usually receives the left inferior phrenic vein, the left suprarenal vein, the left gonadal vein (left testicular vein in males, left ovarian vein in females) and the left second lumbar vein whereas these veins on the right side drain directly into the inferior vena cava

Subject: abnormal right renal vein morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the shorter of the two renal veins that receives blood from the right kidney; the left renal vein usually receives the left inferior phrenic vein, the left suprarenal vein, the left gonadal vein (left testicular vein in males, left ovarian vein in females) and the left second lumbar vein whereas these veins on the right side drain directly into the inferior vena cava

Subject: abnormal papillary duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the largest straight excretory ducts in the kidney medulla and papillae that are a continuation of the collecting tubules, and that open into the area cribosa

Subject: abnormal kidney outer medulla morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the outer medullary region of the adult kidney containing the short Loops of Henle and collecting ducts

Subject: abnormal kidney inner medulla morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the inner medullary region of the adult kidney containing collecting ducts and the long loops of Henle

Subject: abnormal nephrogenic zone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the region found at the periphery of the developing metanephros within which the metanephric mesenchyme aggregates around the tips of the ureteric tree to form the nephrons; in rodents including mice, this region normally disappears within the first postnatal week when nephrogenesis ceases and only mature nephrons are present; in humans, it is lost by 36 weeks of gestation

Subject: abnormal kidney pelvis smooth muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the smooth muscle tissue surrounding the urothelium of the kidney pelvis

Subject: abnormal kidney pelvis urothelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the epithelial lining of the luminal space of the kidney pelvis

Subject: abnormal perihilar interstitium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the part of the renal interstitium surrounding the pelvis

Subject: abnormal mesangial matrix morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the extracellular matrix secreted by intraglomerular mesangial cells

Subject: abnormal glomerular mesangium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the inner layer of the glomerulus within the basement membrane surrounding the glomerular capillaries that contain the intraglomerular mesangial cells

Subject: abnormal extraglomerular mesangium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tissue comprised of mesangial cells that fill the triangular space between the macula densa and the afferent and efferent arterioles of the juxtaglomerular apparatus

Subject: abnormal loop of Henle descending limb morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the portion of the renal tubule that constitutes the proximal part of the loop of Henle, has low permeability to ions and urea, and is highly permeable to water; it consists of an initial short thick segment lined by low simple cuboidal epithelium and a long thin segment lined by simple squamous epithelium; however, this distinction is not as important physiologically as in the ascending limb, so often the two are treated as one structure

Subject: abnormal loop of Henle ascending limb morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the distal part of the loop of Henle that is impermeable to water and actively pumps sodium out of the filtrate to generate the hypertonic interstitium that drives countercurrent exchange; it consists of an initial very thin segment lined by simple squamous epithelium followed by a distal thick segment lined by simple cuboidal epithelium

Subject: abnormal loop of Henle ascending limb thin segment morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the initial sub-portion of the ascending loop of Henle localized in the juxtamedullary nephron of the kidney; it is lined by simple squamous epithelium, impermeable to water but permeable to ions and other small particles

Subject: abnormal loop of Henle ascending limb thick segment morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the distal sub-portion of the ascending loop of Henle which is lined by simple cuboidal epithelium and enters the renal cortex to empty a hypotonic filtrate into the distal convoluted tubule

Subject: truncated loop of Henle
Value: failure of the developing loop of Henle to elongate and extend into the medullary zone of the kidney

Subject: renal tubule atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of the loops of Henle, the proximal convoluted tubule or the distal convoluted tubule associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: abnormal kidney medullary ray morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the center of a renal, cortical lobule, consisting of the ascending or descending limbs of the loop of Henle or of the collecting tubules; medullary rays are regions where parallel arrays of straight tubules travel perpendicular to the capsule and extend from the cortex to the medulla

Subject: abnormal renal glomerulus basement membrane morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the layer of extracellular matrix that lies between the endothelium of the glomerular capillaries and the podocytes of the inner or visceral layer of the Bowman capsule; it is a fusion of the endothelial cell and podocyte basal laminas and acts as a physical barrier and an ion-selective filter

Subject: abnormal renal glomerulus basement membrane thickness
Value: increased or decreased width of the layer of extracellular matrix that lies between the endothelium of the glomerular capillaries and the podocytes of the inner or visceral layer of the Bowman capsule

Subject: abnormal proximal convoluted tubule brush border morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the densely packed microvilli that cover the luminal surface of epithelial cells of the proximal convoluted tubule; microvilli increase the luminal surface area of cells, sense the fluid flow in the tubule lumen and convert this information via biochemical responses into reabsorption

Subject: absent proximal convoluted tubule brush border
Value: failure to form a brush border of densely packed microvilli on the luminal surface of epithelial cells of the proximal convoluted tubule

Subject: proximal convoluted tubule brush border loss
Value: attenuation or degeneration of the microvillus brush border normally present on the luminal surface of epithelial cells of the proximal convoluted tubule; may be associated with renal tubular injury and/or cystic changes

Subject: expanded mesangial matrix
Value: increase in the amount of mesangial matrix present in the basement membrane surrounding the glomerular capillaries that also contain the intraglomerular mesangial cells

Subject: absent renal glomerulus
Value: complete absence of the tuft formed of capillary loops and mesangium at the beginning of each nephretic tubule in the kidney that normally function as a filtration unit

Subject: abnormal kidney interlobar artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the branches of the segmental arteries of the kidney that cross between the renal lobes and give rise to the arculate arteries in the cortex

Subject: renal artery stenosis
Value: diffuse constriction or narrowing of one or both renal arteries

Subject: supernumerary renal arteries
Value: two or more arteries branch from the abdominal aorta and supply a single kidney

Subject: renal artery aneurysm
Value: a protruding sac formed by the dilation of the wall of a renal artery, resulting from a weakening of the vessel wall or heart muscle

Subject: decreased glomerular capillary number
Value: reduced number of the small branching blood vessels in the kidney glomerulus that receives blood from the kidney afferent arterioles

Subject: kidney cortex hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the outer portion of the kidney, which contains the renal corpuscles, the renal tubules (except for parts of the loop of Henle which descend into the renal medulla), blood vessels and cortical collecting ducts

Subject: pelvic kidney
Value: an ectopic kidney located outside the renal fossa and within the pelvic cavity; pelvic kidneys may also, on occasion, occur as fused midline horseshoe kidneys

Subject: ectopic adrenal gland
Value: an adrenal gland located outside of its normal position

Subject: renal glomerulus atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of the capillary loops of the kidney associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: abnormal metanephros morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the primordium of the permanent kidney, which develops later than and caudal to the mesonephros, from the mesonephric duct and nephrogenic cord; the metanephros is an endocrine and metabolic organ that filters the blood and excretes the end products of body metabolism in the form of urine

Subject: small metanephros
Value: reduced size of the primordium of the permanent kidney, which develops later than and caudal to the mesonephros, from the mesonephric duct and nephrogenic cord

Subject: absent metanephros
Value: absence of the primordium of the permanent kidney, which develops later than and caudal to the mesonephros, from the mesonephric duct and nephrogenic cord

Subject: abnormal kidney apoptosis
Value: change in the timing or the number of kidney cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: increased kidney apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of cells of the kidney undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: increased renal glomerulus apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of cells of the kidney glomerulus undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: increased mesangial cell apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of phagocytic cells in the capillary tuft of the renal glomerulus undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: decreased kidney apoptosis
Value: decrease in the number of cells of the kidney undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: decreased renal tubule apoptosis
Value: decrease in the number of renal tubule cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: decreased mesangial cell apoptosis
Value: decrease in the number of phagocytic cells in the capillary tuft of the renal glomerulus undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: decreased podocyte apoptosis
Value: decrease in the number of podocytes undergoing programmed cell death; podocyte apoptosis is an early step in the pathophysiological progression to proteinuria and glomerulosclerosis

Subject: decreased renal glomerulus apoptosis
Value: decrease in the number of cells of the kidney glomerulus undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal kidney corticomedullary boundary morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the region demarcating the renal medulla from the surrounding cortex; end-stage renal failure may be associated with loss of the normal corticomedullary boundary

Subject: renal glomerulus fibrosis
Value: formation of fibrous tissue in the renal glomerulus as a result of repair or a reactive process

Subject: abnormal kidney outer medulla inner stripe morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the deep, centrally located portion of the renal outer medulla that is traversed by thin descending and thick ascending portions of the loops of Henle

Subject: abnormal kidney outer medulla outer stripe morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the region of the kidney outer medulla that lies just below the cortex; the proximal straight tubules are present in this region

Subject: enlarged brain ventricles
Value: increased size of one or more of the four communicating cavities within the brain that are continuous with the central canal of the spinal cord

Subject: abnormal kidney lobe morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the portion of a kidney consisting of a renal medullary pyramid and the renal cortex above it; human kidneys have multilobar (multipyramidal) architecture while mice and rats have unilobar (unipyramidal) kidneys

Subject: abnormal kidney lobule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the portion of a renal lobe consisting of nephrons grouped around a single medullary ray and draining into a single collecting duct; human kidneys have multilobular, multipapillary architecture while mice and rats have unilobular, unipapillary kidneys

Subject: abnormal kidney capsule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tough fibrous layer surrounding the kidney which is covered in a thick layer of perirenal adipose tissue that functions to provide some protection from trauma and damage

Subject: abnormal progesterone level
Value: anomaly in the concentration of the antiestrogenic steroid released by the corpus luteum that stimulates the uterus to prepare for pregnancy

Subject: abnormal testosterone level
Value: anomaly in the concentration of a potent androgen that promotes development of male secondary sex characteristics and the development of spermatozoa and may regulate sexual desire and help maintain bone and muscle health in both males and females

Subject: increased metanephric mesenchyme apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of cells of the metanephric mesenchyme (MM) undergoing programmed cell death; usually due to failure of MM cells to interact with the ureteric bud (UB) tips after UB invasion

Subject: absent metanephric mesenchyme
Value: absence of the embryonic connective tissue made up of loosely aggregated mesenchymal cells, supported by interlaminar jelly, that gives rise to the developing metanephros; normally, interactions between the ureteric bud and the metanephric mesenchyme lead to the initiation of outgrowth and repetitive branching of the UB that ultimately generates the definitive renal collecting system and induces formation of renal vesicles from the mesenchyme tissue

Subject: absent heart
Value: absence of the hollow, muscular organ that maintains the circulation of the blood

Subject: absent optic disk
Value: absence of the area in the retina where all of the axons of the ganglion cells exit the retina to form the optic nerve

Subject: abnormal fetal cardiomyocyte physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of fetal and neonatal heart cells that undergo proliferation and are not yet terminally differentiated into binucleate or multinucleate cardiac myocytes

Subject: abnormal fetal cardiomyocyte apoptosis
Value: change in the timing or the number of fetal cardiomyocytes undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: increased fetal cardiomyocyte apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of fetal cardiomyocytes undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: decreased fetal cardiomyocyte apoptosis
Value: reduction in the number of fetal cardiomyocytes undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: increased fetal cardiomyocyte proliferation
Value: increase in the ability of the differentiating cardiac muscle cell population to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: decreased fetal cardiomyocyte proliferation
Value: reduced ability of the differentiating cardiac muscle cell population to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: abnormal sleep behavior
Value: any anomaly in the actions, reactions, or performance of an organism during a periodic, readily reversible state of reduced awareness and metabolic activity

Subject: endoneurial edema
Value: an excessive accumulation of serous fluid in the interstitial connective tissue of a peripheral nerve

Subject: abnormal endoneurial fluid pressure
Value: measureable anomalies in the fluid of the ganglia and peripheral nerves that lie outside the brain and spinal cord which may interfere with normal nerve physiology

Subject: increased endoneurial fluid pressure
Value: a measureable increase of serous fluid in the interstitial connective tissue of a peripheral nerve which may interefere with normal nerve physiology

Subject: lethality, complete penetrance
Value: all individuals of a given genotype in a population die before the end of the normal lifespan but time(s) of death are unspecified

Subject: abnormal vascular smooth muscle development
Value: anomaly in the process of forming the nonstriated, involuntary muscle tissue of the blood vessels

Subject: renal cast
Value: any of the various casts formed from gelled protein precipitated in the distal convoluted tubules and collecting ducts of nephrons and molded to the tubular or duct lumen which dislodge and pass into the urine; types named for their constituent material include acellular casts (e.g. granular, hyaline, waxy, or fatty casts) and cellular casts (e.g. red or white blood cell casts)

Subject: pyelonephritis
Value: a diffuse pyogenic infection of the pelvis and parenchyma of the kidney; an ascending urinary tract infection that has reached the pyelum or pelvis of the kidney usually resulting from noncontagious bacterial infection of the bladder

Subject: pyelitis
Value: acute inflammation of the pelvis of the kidney, caused by bacterial infection

Subject: tubulointerstitial nephritis
Value: diffuse or local inflammation and edema of the interstitial tissue of the kidney, including the renal tubules; usually secondary to drug sensitization, systemic infection, graft rejection, or autoimmune disease

Subject: abnormal retrotrapezoid nucleus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the loose collection of neurons that reside in the rostral medulla close to the medullary surface, ventral and immediately caudal of nVII, that are crucial for CO2 sensing in the brain

Subject: absent nephrogenic zone
Value: absence of the region found at the periphery of the developing metanephros within which the metanephric mesenchyme aggregates around the tips of the ureteric tree to form the nephrons;in rodents including mice, this region normally persists for a few days postnatally, although it is lost in humans by 36 weeks of gestation

Subject: renal tubule hypertrophy
Value: increase in the bulk size of the loop of Henle, the proximal convoluted tubule or the distal convoluted tubule, due to cell enlargement

Subject: increased renal glomerulus basement membrane thickness
Value: increased width of the layer of extracellular matrix that lies between the endothelium of the glomerular capillaries and the podocytes of the inner or visceral layer of the Bowman capsule

Subject: ectopic testis
Value: one or both of the testes located outside the normal pathway of descent into the scrotum

Subject: abnormal gonadal ridge morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the elevation of thickened mesothelium and underlying mesenchyme found on the ventromedial border of the embryonic mesonephros in which the primordial germ cells become embedded, establishing it as the primordium of the testis or ovary

Subject: gonadal ridge hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the elevation of thickened mesothelium and underlying mesenchyme found on the ventromedial border of the embryonic mesonephros, usually due to reduced cell number; normally, primordial germ cells become embedded in it, establishing it as the primordium of the testis or ovary

Subject: colorless urine
Value: absence of the usual straw-coloration of the urine

Subject: erythruria
Value: passage of red colored urine

Subject: abnormal aldosterone level
Value: anomaly in the concentration of the hormone that is secreted by the adrenal cortex and regulates sodium conservation and potassium secretion in the distal renal tubule

Subject: abnormal testis interstitial tissue morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the delicate connective tissue stroma that separates the seminiferous tubules and contains clusters of endocrine Leydig cells which secrete testosterone

Subject: abnormal renal transport
Value: any anomaly of the directed movement of substances through the kidney

Subject: leukocyturia
Value: presence of white blood cells in the urine

Subject: erythrocyturia
Value: presence of red blood cells in the urine

Subject: pyuria
Value: presence of pus in the urine when voided; a sign of inflammation often related to urinary tract infection

Subject: cylindruria
Value: presence of renal cylinders or casts in the urine

Subject: kidney medulla atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of the inner portion of the kidney consisting of the renal pyramids, associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: kidney cortex atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of the outer portion of the kidney located between the renal capsule and the renal medulla, associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: decreased urine uric acid level
Value: abnormally low amount in the urine of the final oxidation product of purine catabolism in humans and primates, but which in rodents and most other mammals is normally is further oxidized by uricase to allantoin that is excreted in the urine

Subject: abnormal kidney interstitium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the kidney region located between the nephrons, ureteric epithelia (ureteric tips, trunk and collecting duct system) and renal vasculature, and composed of renal support cells, including fibroblasts and macrophages, and mesenchymal stroma or interstitial cells; the renal vasculature lies within the renal interstitium but is not a part of it; various conditions can lead to scarring (fibrosis) and congestion of this area, which can cause kidney dysfunction and failure

Subject: abnormal ureter smooth muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the smooth muscle tissue surrounding the epithelium of the ureter

Subject: mesangial cell hyperplasia
Value: increased number of the phagocytic cells in the capillary tuft of the renal glomerulus, interposed between endothelial cells and the basement membrane in the central or stalk region of the tuft

Subject: mesangial cell hypoplasia
Value: decreased number of the phagocytic cells in the capillary tuft of the renal glomerulus, interposed between endothelial cells and the basement membrane in the central or stalk region of the tuft

Subject: absent mesangial cell
Value: absence of the phagocytic cells in the capillary tuft of the renal glomerulus, normally interposed between endothelial cells and the basement membrane in the central or stalk region of the tuft

Subject: mesangiolysis
Value: an injurious glomerular process that affects primarily the mesangium, starting with loosening and detachment of its matrix and progressing to dissolution/attenuation with degeneration of mesangial cells; mesangial cells may show only edema and vacuolization, or may undergo severe degeneration and necrosis

Subject: increased urine flow rate
Value: increased volume of urine produced in a specified period of time

Subject: decreased urine flow rate
Value: reduced volume of urine produced in a specified period of time

Subject: glomerular capillary congestion
Value: obstruction of the normal flux of blood within the renal glomerular capillaries

Subject: abnormal urine magnesium level
Value: any change in the amount of magnesium in the urine

Subject: increased urine magnesium level
Value: higher than normal amount of magnesium in the urine

Subject: decreased urine magnesium level
Value: lower than normal amount of magnesium in the urine

Subject: glomerulus hemorrhage
Value: bleeding in the renal glomerulus

Subject: absent kidney medulla
Value: failure of the inner portion of the kidney, normally consisting of the renal pyramids, to form

Subject: abnormal kidney cell proliferation
Value: anomaly in the ability of any kidney cell population to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: increased kidney cell proliferation
Value: increase in the expansion rate of any kidney cell population by cell division
