Subject: decreased kidney cell proliferation
Value: decrease in the expansion rate of any kidney cell population by cell division

Subject: abnormal renal sodium ion transport
Value: any anomaly in the directed movement of sodium ions (Na+) by the kidney

Subject: abnormal renal water transport
Value: any anomaly in the directed movement of water (H2O) by the kidney

Subject: abnormal renal water homeostasis
Value: any anomaly in the kidney processes involved in the maintenance of an internal steady state of water in the body

Subject: abnormal renal protein reabsorption
Value: any anomaly in the process in which proteins are taken up from the collecting ducts and proximal and distal loops of the nephron

Subject: abnormal renal albumin reabsorption
Value: any anomaly in the process in which albumin is taken up from the collecting ducts and proximal and distal loops of the nephron

Subject: abnormal renal glucose reabsorption
Value: any anomaly in the process in which glucose is taken up from the collecting ducts and proximal and distal loops of the nephron

Subject: decreased dopaminergic neuron number
Value: fewer than normal numbers of the neurons that utilize dopamine as a neurotransmitter

Subject: increased dopaminergic neuron number
Value: greater than normal numbers of the neurons that utilize dopamine as a neurotransmitter

Subject: ectopic dopaminergic neuron
Value: abnormal location of one or more of the neurons that utilize dopamine as a neurotransmitter

Subject: increased susceptibility to dopaminergic neuron neurotoxicity
Value: greater than normal amount of dopaminergic neuronal cell death following exposure to a neurotoxic compound, such as MPTP-induced cell death occurring through interference in mitochondrial metabolism

Subject: decreased susceptibility to dopaminergic neuron neurotoxicity
Value: less than normal amount of dopaminergic neuronal cell death following exposure to a neurotoxic compound, such as MPTP-induced cell death occurring through interference in mitochondrial metabolism

Subject: abnormal glomerular capillary endothelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thin, extremely flattened layer of cells that line the interior surface of glomerular capillaries and is densely perforated by large transcellular pores (aka fenestrae or fenestrations) that, unlike those of other fenestrated capillaries, are generally thought to lack diaphragms

Subject: abnormal glomerular endothelium fenestra morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the large plasma membrane-lined circular pores that perforate the flattened glomerular endothelium and, unlike those of other fenestrated capillaries, are not spanned by diaphragms; the density and size of glomerular fenestrae account, at least in part, for the high permeability of the glomerular capillary wall to water and small solutes

Subject: absent glomerular endothelium fenestra
Value: absence of the large plasma membrane-lined circular pores that normally perforate the flattened glomerular endothelium; loss of fenestrae may lead to a reduction in the glomerular filtration rate or proteinuria

Subject: abnormal ureter ureteric bud development
Value: any anomaly in the development of the elongated stalk of the ureteric bud that contributes to the morphogenesis of the ureter; the ureter ureteric bud is the initial structure that forms the ureter

Subject: abnormal metanephric ureteric bud development
Value: any anomaly in the development of the portion of the ureteric bud tube that contributes to the morphogenesis of the metanephros

Subject: abnormal urine chloride ion level
Value: any change in the amount of chloride ion in the urine

Subject: increased urine chloride ion level
Value: abnormally large amounts of chloride ion in the urine

Subject: decreased urine chloride ion level
Value: abnormally low amounts of chloride ion in the urine

Subject: abnormal urine bicarbonate level
Value: any change in the amount of bicarbonate in the urine

Subject: increased urine bicarbonate level
Value: an increased amount of bicarbonate in the urine compared to the normal state

Subject: decreased urine bicarbonate level
Value: a reduced amount of bicarbonate in the urine compared to the normal state

Subject: bilirubinuria
Value: presence of conjugated bilirubin in the urine

Subject: abnormal urine urea nitrogen level
Value: any change in the amount of nitrogen in the form of urea in the urine

Subject: increased urine urea nitrogen level
Value: abnormally high amounts of nitrogen in the form of urea in the urine

Subject: decreased urine urea nitrogen level
Value: abnormally low amounts of nitrogen in the form of urea in the urine

Subject: abnormal urine amino acid level
Value: any anomaly in the amount in the urine of a carboxylic acid containing one or more amino groups (-NH2) and a carboxyl (-COOH) group

Subject: abnormal urine creatinine level
Value: any change in the amount of creatinine in the urine

Subject: increased urine creatinine level
Value: an increased amount of creatinine in the urine compared to the normal state

Subject: decreased urine creatinine level
Value: a reduced amount of creatinine in the urine compared to the normal state

Subject: abnormal urine glycosaminoglycan level
Value: any change in the amount of glycosaminoglycan in the urine, including chondroitin sulfate, dermatan sulfate, keratan sulfate, heparin sulfate, heparin, and/or hyaluronan and other long unbranched polysaccharides consisting of a repeating disaccharide unit

Subject: increased urine glycosaminoglycan level
Value: greater in the amount of glycosaminoglycan in the urine, including chondroitin sulfate, dermatan sulfate, keratan sulfate, heparin sulfate, heparin, and/or hyaluronan and other long unbranched polysaccharides consisting of a repeating disaccharide unit

Subject: decreased urine glycosaminoglycan level
Value: reduced amount of glycosaminoglycan in the urine, including chondroitin sulfate, dermatan sulfate, keratan sulfate, heparin sulfate, heparin, and/or hyaluronan and other long unbranched polysaccharides consisting of a repeating disaccharide unit

Subject: abnormal glycosaminoglycan level
Value: any change in the amount of glycosaminoglycan, including chondroitin sulfate, dermatan sulfate, keratan sulfate, heparin sulfate, heparin, and/or hyaluronan and other long unbranched polysaccharides consisting of a repeating disaccharide unit

Subject: abnormal urine nucleotide level
Value: any change in the urinary level of glycosamines consisting of a nucleobase, a five-carbon sugar moiety (ribose or deoxyribose), and may be mono-, di- or triphosphate; this definition includes cyclic-nucleotides (nucleoside cyclic phosphates)

Subject: abnormal urine nucleoside level
Value: any change in the urinary level of glycosylamines consisting of a nucleobase bound to a ribose or deoxyribose sugar via a beta-glycosidic linkage, including cytidine, uridine, adenosine, guanosine, thymidine and inosine and deoxynucleosides

Subject: abnormal urine catecholamine level
Value: any anomaly in the urinary amount of catecholamines, including adrenaline, noradrenaline and L-dopamine; catecholamines act as hormones or neurotransmitters and are derived from the amino acid tyrosine

Subject: abnormal catecholamine level
Value: any anomaly in the amount of catecholamines, including adrenaline, noradrenaline and L-dopamine; catecholamines are act as hormones or neurotransmitters and are derived from the amino acid tyrosine

Subject: impaired ureteric peristalsis
Value: any anomaly in the wavelike sequence of involuntary muscular contraction and relaxation that passes along the ureter, thus propelling urine from the kidney pelvis to the urinary bladder

Subject: anterior iris synechia
Value: adhesion of the iris to the cornea

Subject: posterior iris synechia
Value: adhesion of the iris to the capsule of the lens or to the surface of the vitreous body

Subject: renal glomerular synechia
Value: presence of adhesions (synechiae) between the Bowman's capsule and the glomerular tuft; may develop when areas of glomerular capillary basement membrane denuded of visceral epithelial cells come in contact with the parietal epithelium of Bowman's capsule

Subject: abnormal ureter urothelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the epithelial lining of the luminal space of the ureter

Subject: abnormal urethra urothelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the epithelial lining of the luminal space of the urethra

Subject: ectopic ureter
Value: an abnormally placed opening of the ureter, either into the urinary bladder or at another site in the lower urinary or genital tract; commonly a result of a duplicated renal collecting system, a duplex kidney with two ureters where usually one ureter terminates at the urinary bladder, while the duplicated ureter being ectopic, ends in the vagina, the urethra or the vulval vestibule

Subject: abnormal ureteropelvic junction morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the junction between the ureter and the renal pelvis of the kidney

Subject: abnormal ureterovesical junction morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the valve-like structure found at the site of entry of the ureter into the urinary bladder, normally displays an oblique angulation through the detrusor to avoid reflux of urine up the ureters and the kidney

Subject: ureteropelvic junction atresia
Value: congenital absence or closure of the connection between the ureter and the renal pelvis

Subject: ureteropelvic junction stenosis
Value: a constriction or narrowing of the junction between the ureter and the renal pelvis

Subject: ureteropelvic junction obstruction
Value: a partial or total blockage of the flow of urine through the junction of the renal pelvis and the proximal ureter

Subject: ureterovesical junction obstruction
Value: a partial or total blockage of the valve-like structure found at the site of entry of the ureter into the urinary bladder

Subject: double ureter
Value: two ureters open separately into the renal pelvis superiorly and drain separately into the urinary bladder or genital tract; if two ureteral buds arise from the Wolffian duct, a duplex kidney with complete ureteral duplication ensues where the additional ureter may result in a ureterocele, or an ectopic ureter

Subject: abnormal pigmentation pattern
Value: hair and/or skin coloration shows specific and consistent deviations from an expected display

Subject: abnormal head shape
Value: any anomaly in the characteristic surface outline or contour of a head of an organism

Subject: abnormal head size
Value: anomaly in the average size of the portion of the body containing the brain and organs of sight, hearing, taste, and smell

Subject: abnormal glomerular capsule visceral layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the inner layer of the glomerular capsule surrounding the capillary endothelial cells and composed of highly specialized epithelial cells (podocytes) that are separated by filtration slits; the visceral layer is separated from the outer parietal layer by the urinary space (also known as the Bowman's or capsular space)

Subject: abnormal glomerular capsule parietal layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the outer layer of the glomerular capsule composed of a single layer of simple squamous epithelium

Subject: abnormal glomerular capsule space morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the luminal region between the glomerular capsule visceral and parietal layers, into which filtrate enters after passing through the filtration barrier from the glomerular capillaries

Subject: decreased glomerular capsule space
Value: reduced volume of the luminal region between the glomerular capsule visceral and parietal layers, into which filtrate enters after passing through the filtration barrier from the glomerular capillaries

Subject: increased glomerular capsule space
Value: increased volume of the luminal region between the glomerular capsule visceral and parietal layers, into which filtrate enters after passing through the filtration barrier from the glomerular capillaries

Subject: parietal capsular epithelium metaplasia
Value: a metaplastic change or transformation of the single layer of the parietal epithelium of Bowman's capsule from the normal structural appearance of simple squamous epithelium to a cuboidal or low columnar epithelium; also referred to as a prominent parietal epithelium

Subject: distended jejunum
Value: an expansion in the volume of the portion of the small intestine that extends from the duodenum to the ileum

Subject: abnormal limb long bone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the several elongated bones of the extremities

Subject: camptomelia
Value: a skeletal dysplasia characterized by the bending of the long bones of the extremities

Subject: glomerular crescent
Value: formation of a crescent-shaped (semi-lunar) glomerular lesion corresponding to extracapillary proliferation of Bowman's capsular epithelium and acquiring a fibroblast-like spindled morphology, possibly stimulated by release of fibrinogen from a ruptured glomerular basement membrane; epithelial crescents occur in aggressive forms of glomerulonephritis, may be accompanied by collagen and fibrin deposition and/or monocyte and macrophage proliferation, may protrude into Bowman's space, and ultimately compress and destroy the glomerular tuft

Subject: abnormal kidney thrombosis
Value: any anomaly in the formation or presence of one or more thrombi within the blood vessel network of the organ of secretion

Subject: abnormal glomerular capillary thrombosis
Value: any anomaly in the formation or presence of one or more thrombi within the renal glomerular capillaries

Subject: dilated glomerular capillary
Value: stretched or widened aperture of the luminal space of the small branching blood vessel in the kidney glomerulus that receives blood from the kidney afferent arteriole

Subject: mesangial cell interposition
Value: spreading of mesangial cells into the contiguous space between the adjacent glomerular endothelial cells and the glomerular basement membrane (GBM)

Subject: abnormal vertebral artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the first branch of the left and right subclavian arteries that merge to form the single midline basilar artery; branches of the vertebral arteries supply the musculature of the neck

Subject: skin hemorrhage
Value: bleeding into the skin

Subject: purpura
Value: a smooth, moderately sized hemorrhagic area, typically dark red to reddish purple, resulting from extarvasation of blood into the skin, mucous membrane, or serosal surface; a pupura becomes brown-yellow as it fades and does not blanch on applying pressure

Subject: aspartylglucosaminuria
Value: high urinary levels of aspartylglucosamine, a derivative of aspartic acid; caused by deficient activity of the enzyme N-aspartyl-beta-glucosaminidase (aspartylglucosaminidase) which normally cleaves long sugar chains known as oligosaccharides in the lysosome

Subject: hyperoxaluria
Value: abnormally high levels of oxalic acid or oxalates in the urine; many metal ions form insoluble precipitates with oxalate, a prominent example being calcium oxalate, the primary constituent of the most common kind of kidney stones

Subject: abnormal cell chemotaxis
Value: any anomaly in the directed movement of a motile cell guided by a specific chemical concentration gradient; movement may be towards a higher concentration (positive chemotaxis) or towards a lower concentration (negative chemotaxis)

Subject: abnormal placenta labyrinth size
Value: anomaly in the size of the structure where embryonic blood vessels are surrounded by trophoblast cells and maternal blood

Subject: increased placental labyrinth size
Value: increase in the size of the structure where embryonic blood vessels are surrounded by trophoblast cells and maternal blood

Subject: decreased placental labyrinth size
Value: reduction in the size of the structure where embryonic blood vessels are surrounded by trophoblast cells and maternal blood

Subject: abnormal placental labyrinth villi morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the vascularized and branched structures arising from the rodent trophoblast-derived epithelium that allow an increase its surface area for the efficient exchange of nutrients and wastes between the maternal and fetal circulation

Subject: thin placenta labyrinth
Value: decrease in the width of the structure where embryonic blood vessels are surrounded by trophoblast cells and maternal blood

Subject: thick placenta labyrinth
Value: increase in the width of the structure where embryonic blood vessels are surrounded by trophoblast cells and maternal blood

Subject: abnormal placenta intervillous maternal lacunae morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the spaces of the placenta occupied by maternal blood, into which the fetal labyrinth villi project

Subject: abnormal placenta fetal blood space morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the spaces of the placenta occupied by fetal blood, primarily within the fetal labyrinth villi

Subject: disorganized placental labyrinth
Value: derangement of the placental layers where embryonic blood vessels are surrounded by trophoblast cells and maternal blood

Subject: abnormal placental labyrinth villi branching morphogenesis
Value: any anomaly in the process in which the branches of the fetal placental villi are generated and organized from the trophoblast-derived epithelium

Subject: increased placenta intervillous maternal lacunae size
Value: increased size of the spaces of the placenta occupied by maternal blood, into which the fetal labyrinth villi project

Subject: fused radius and ulna
Value: anomaly of the radius and ulna resulting in some portion of or all the two bones being merged together

Subject: abnormal syncytiotrophoblast morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the multi-nucleated, terminally differentiated syncytial epithelial layer of the placental villi that forms the major nutrient transport surfaces within the labyrinth layer of the rodent placenta

Subject: decreased urine major urinary protein level
Value: reduced amount in the urine of a family of alpha2-microglobulin-related liver secretory proteins that comprise a major protein component of mouse urine

Subject: increased urine major urinary protein level
Value: increased amount in the urine of a family of alpha2-microglobulin-related liver secretory proteins that comprise a major protein component of mouse urine

Subject: granular kidney
Value: a kidney in which fairly uniform, diffusely and evenly situated foci of scarring of the interstitial tissue of the cortex (and sometimes scarring of glomeruli), and the associated slight degree of bulging of groups of dilated tubules, leads to the development of a minutely bosselated surface; such kidneys are seen in arteriolar nephrosclerosis or chronic glomerulonephritis

Subject: increased urination frequency
Value: increased frequency of urination episodes; urination at short frequent intervals occurs without an increase in daily volume of urinary output and may be caused by reduced bladder capacity or urinary tract infection

Subject: decreased urination frequency
Value: decreased frequency of urination episodes; urination at long intervals occurs without an decrease in daily volume of urinary output

Subject: uraturia
Value: passage of an increased amount of any salt or ester of uric acid (urate) in the urine

Subject: abnormal urine hormone level
Value: any change in the urine amount of any of the chemical substances that have specific regulatory effects on the activity of a certain organ or organs

Subject: abnormal urine aldosterone level
Value: any change in the urine amount of the hormone that is secreted by the adrenal cortex and regulates sodium conservation and potassium secretion in the distal renal tubule

Subject: increased urine aldosterone level
Value: an increased amount of aldosterone in the urine compared to the normal state

Subject: decreased urine aldosterone level
Value: a reduced amount of aldosterone in the urine compared to the normal state

Subject: abnormal urine antidiuretic hormone level
Value: any change in the urine amount of the polypeptide hormone secreted by the posterior lobe of the pituitary gland (neurohypophysis) that increases mean arterial pressure by promoting vasoconstriction and reduces excretion of urine by increasing the reabsorption of water by the kidney tubules

Subject: increased urine antidiuretic hormone level
Value: an increased amount of antidiuretic hormone in the urine compared to the normal state

Subject: decreased urine antidiuretic hormone level
Value: a reduced amount of antidiuretic hormone in the urine compared to the normal state

Subject: abnormal urine progesterone level
Value: any change in the urine amount of the antiestrogenic steroid released by the corpus luteum that stimulates the uterus to prepare for pregnancy

Subject: increased urine progesterone level
Value: an increased amount of progesterone in the urine compared to the normal state

Subject: decreased urine progesterone level
Value: a reduced amount of progesterone in the urine compared to the normal state

Subject: abnormal urine corticosterone level
Value: any change in the urine amount of the corticosteroid produced in the adrenal cortex that induces glycogen deposition and regulates sodium conservation and potassium secretion

Subject: increased urine corticosterone level
Value: an increased amount of corticosterone in the urine compared to the normal state

Subject: decreased urine corticosterone level
Value: a reduced amount of corticosterone in the urine compared to the normal state

Subject: variegated eye pigmentation pattern
Value: an irregular and random patchwork of two or more colors in the eye

Subject: abnormal urine deoxycorticosterone level
Value: any change in the urine amount of the steroid hormone secreted by the adrenal cortex, related to corticosterone and involved in regulating water and electrolyte balance

Subject: increased urine deoxycorticosterone level
Value: an increased amount of deoxycorticosterone in the urine compared to the normal state

Subject: decreased urine deoxycorticosterone level
Value: a reduced amount of deoxycorticosterone in the urine compared to the normal state

Subject: increased urine microglobulin level
Value: greater than the normal amount of any globulin (or any fragment of a globulin) of low molecular weight in the urine

Subject: increased urine beta2-microglobulin level
Value: greater than the normal amount of beta2-microglobulin in the urine; may indicate renal tubule disease, drug-induced renal toxicity, heavy metal-induced renal disease, lymphomas, leukemia, or myeloma

Subject: increased susceptibility to induced choroid neovascularization
Value: increased rate or amount of new growth of new, abnormal blood vessels that originate in the choroid through a break in the Bruch membrane into the sub-retinal pigment epithelium or subretinal space and may result in visual loss as a result of chemical or mechanical manipulation (e.g. laser-induced trauma)

Subject: abnormal urine insulin level
Value: any change in the amount of insulin in the urine

Subject: increased urine insulin level
Value: a greater amount of insulin in the urine compared to the normal state

Subject: decreased urine insulin level
Value: a reduced amount of insulin in the urine compared to the normal state

Subject: renal glomerulus lipidosis
Value: presence of lipid deposits and/or lipid-laden foam cells in the renal glomerular tufts

Subject: abnormal urine prostaglandin level
Value: any change in the urinary amount of any of a class of mediators with effects of vasodilation, vasoconstriction, and smooth muscle stimulation

Subject: increased urine prostaglandin level
Value: a greater amount of any prostaglandin in the urine compared to the normal state

Subject: decreased urine prostaglandin level
Value: a reduced amount of any prostaglandin in the urine compared to the normal state

Subject: kidney papillary hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the apex of the renal pyramid that normally projects into a calyx

Subject: abnormal complement protein level
Value: deviation from the normal levels, or accumulation of the proteins that act sequentially to allow for the direct killing of microbes, the disposal of immune complexes, and the regulation of other immune processes

Subject: increased renal glomerulus lobularity
Value: distortion of the renal glomerular architecture usually accompanied by increased mesangial cell proliferation and following crowding of the proliferated cells towards the axis of the capillary loops and peripheral recanalization, giving the glomerular tuft a lobular or hypersegmented appearance

Subject: decreased foot pigmentation
Value: visually detectable dilution of pigment present on the foot surface

Subject: abnormal azygos vein morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the unpaired vein which in humans arises from the right ascending lumbar vein or the vena cava, enters the thorax through the aortic orifice in the diaphragm, and terminates in the superior vena cava; unlike humans, mice have a single and left-sided azygos vein that develops from the paired embryonic cardinal venous system and drains most of the right and left thoracic walls into the left anterior vena cava

Subject: esophageal achalasia
Value: failure of the normal relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter associated with the uncoordinated contractions of the thoracic esophagus, resulting in functional obstruction

Subject: enlarged inferior vena cava valve
Value: increased size of the semicircular fold of endocardium located on the right atrium at the point of attachment of the inferior vena cava

Subject: abnormal aorta bulb morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the portion of the left ventricular outflow tract delineated by the sinotubular ridge superiorly and the bases of the valve leaflets inferiorly; it comprises the aortic sinuses, the aortic valve leaflets, the commissures, and the interleaflet triangles

Subject: abnormal sinotubular junction morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the point in the ascending aorta where the aortic sinuses end and the aorta becomes a tubular structure

Subject: dilated sinotubular junction
Value: the luminal space of the sinotubular junction is increased in diameter or area

Subject: dilated aorta bulb
Value: the luminal space of the aorta bulb is increased in volume or area, usually with an increase of contained fluid

Subject: absent cervical atlas
Value: absence of the first (topmost, C1) cervical vertebra which supports the globe of the head

Subject: abnormal lipoprotein lipase activity
Value: <anomaly in the ability to catalyze the reaction: triacylglycerol + H2O = diacylglycerol + a carboxylate>

Subject: increased lipoprotein lipase activity
Value: <greater ability to catalyze the reaction: triacylglycerol + H2O = diacylglycerol + a carboxylate>

Subject: decreased lipoprotein lipase activity
Value: <reduced ability to catalyze the reaction: triacylglycerol + H2O = diacylglycerol + a carboxylate>

Subject: abnormal triglyceride lipase activity
Value: <anomaly in the ability to catalyze the reaction: triacylglycerol + H2O = diacylglycerol + a fatty acid anion>

Subject: increased triglyceride lipase activity
Value: <greater ability to catalyze the reaction: triacylglycerol + H2O = diacylglycerol + a fatty acid anion>

Subject: decreased triglyceride lipase activity
Value: <reduced ability to catalyze the reaction: triacylglycerol + H2O = diacylglycerol + a fatty acid anion>

Subject: abnormal alkaline phosphatase activity
Value: <anomaly in the ability to catalyze the reaction: an orthophosphoric monoester + H2O = an alcohol + phosphate, with an alkaline pH optimum>

Subject: increased alkaline phosphatase activity
Value: <greater ability to catalyze the reaction: an orthophosphoric monoester + H2O = an alcohol + phosphate, with an alkaline pH optimum>

Subject: decreased alkaline phosphatase activity
Value: <reduced ability to catalyze the reaction: an orthophosphoric monoester + H2O = an alcohol + phosphate, with an alkaline pH optimum>

Subject: abnormal ornithine carbamoyltransferase activity
Value: <anomaly in the ability to catalyze the reaction: carbamoyl phosphate + L-ornithine = phosphate + L-citrulline>

Subject: increased ornithine carbamoyltransferase activity
Value: <greater ability to catalyze the reaction: carbamoyl phosphate + L-ornithine = phosphate + L-citrulline>

Subject: decreased ornithine carbamoyltransferase activity
Value: <reduced ability to catalyze the reaction: carbamoyl phosphate + L-ornithine = phosphate + L-citrulline>

Subject: abnormal hormone-sensitive lipase activity
Value: <anomaly in the ability to catalyze the reactions: diacylglycerol + H2O = monoacylglycerol + a carboxylate; triacylglycerol + H2O = diacylglycerol + a carboxylate; and monoacylglycerol + H2O = glycerol + a carboxylate>

Subject: increased hormone-sensitive lipase activity
Value: <greater ability to catalyze the reactions: diacylglycerol + H2O = monoacylglycerol + a carboxylate; triacylglycerol + H2O = diacylglycerol + a carboxylate; and monoacylglycerol + H2O = glycerol + a carboxylate>

Subject: decreased hormone-sensitive lipase activity
Value: <reduced ability to catalyze the reactions: diacylglycerol + H2O = monoacylglycerol + a carboxylate; triacylglycerol + H2O = diacylglycerol + a carboxylate; and monoacylglycerol + H2O = glycerol + a carboxylate>

Subject: abnormal catalase activity
Value: <anomaly in the ability to catalyze the reaction: 2 hydrogen peroxide = O2 + 2 H2O>

Subject: increased catalase activity
Value: <greater ability to catalyze the reaction: 2 hydrogen peroxide = O2 + 2 H2O>

Subject: decreased catalase activity
Value: <reduced ability to catalyze the reaction: 2 hydrogen peroxide = O2 + 2 H2O>

Subject: abnormal purine-nucleoside phosphorylase activity
Value: <anomaly in the ability to catalyze the reaction: purine nucleoside + phosphate = purine + alpha-D-ribose 1-phosphate>

Subject: increased purine-nucleoside phosphorylase activity
Value: <greater ability to catalyze the reaction: purine nucleoside + phosphate = purine + alpha-D-ribose 1-phosphate>

Subject: decreased purine-nucleoside phosphorylase activity
Value: <reduced ability to catalyze the reaction: purine nucleoside + phosphate = purine + alpha-D-ribose 1-phosphate>

Subject: abnormal phosphatidylcholine-sterol O-acyltransferase activity
Value: <anomaly in the ability to catalyze the reaction: phosphatidylcholine + a sterol = a sterol ester + 1-acylglycerophosphocholine>

Subject: increased phosphatidylcholine-sterol O-acyltransferase activity
Value: <greater ability to catalyze the reaction: phosphatidylcholine + a sterol = a sterol ester + 1-acylglycerophosphocholine>

Subject: decreased phosphatidylcholine-sterol O-acyltransferase activity
Value: <reduced ability to catalyze the reaction: phosphatidylcholine + a sterol = a sterol ester + 1-acylglycerophosphocholine>

Subject: abnormal glutathione peroxidase activity
Value: <anomaly in the ability to catalyze the reaction: 2 glutathione + hydrogen peroxide = oxidized glutathione + 2 H2O>

Subject: increased glutathione peroxidase activity
Value: <greater ability to catalyze the reaction: 2 glutathione + hydrogen peroxide = oxidized glutathione + 2 H2O>

Subject: decreased glutathione peroxidase activity
Value: <reduced ability to catalyze the reaction: 2 glutathione + hydrogen peroxide = oxidized glutathione + 2 H2O>

Subject: abnormal glucokinase activity
Value: <anomaly in the ability to catalyze the reaction: ATP + D-glucose = ADP + D-glucose-6-phosphate>

Subject: increased glucokinase activity
Value: <greater ability to catalyze the reaction: ATP + D-glucose = ADP + D-glucose-6-phosphate>

Subject: decreased glucokinase activity
Value: <reduced ability to catalyze the reaction: ATP + D-glucose = ADP + D-glucose-6-phosphate>

Subject: abnormal glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (NAD+) (phosphorylating) activity
Value: <anomaly in the ability to catalyze the reaction: D-glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate + phosphate + NAD+ = 3-phospho-D-glyceroyl phosphate + NADH + H+>

Subject: increased glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (NAD+) (phosphorylating) activity
Value: <greater ability to catalyze the reaction: D-glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate + phosphate + NAD+ = 3-phospho-D-glyceroyl phosphate + NADH + H+>

Subject: decreased glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (NAD+) (phosphorylating) activity
Value: <reduced ability to catalyze the reaction: D-glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate + phosphate + NAD+ = 3-phospho-D-glyceroyl phosphate + NADH + H+>

Subject: abnormal primordial germ cell apoptosis
Value: change in the timing or the number of primordial germ cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal circulating ghrelin level
Value: any anomaly in the blood concentration of the peptide hormone produced mainly by P/D1 cells lining the fundus of the stomach and epsilon cells of the pancreas that stimulates hunger and serves as a potent stimulator of growth hormone from the anterior pituitary gland; in addition to stimulating appetite and growth, ghrelin also plays various roles in energy homeostasis, neuropathy, and in the cardiovascular and immune systems

Subject: increased circulating ghrelin level
Value: greater than the normal blood concentration of the peptide hormone produced mainly by P/D1 cells lining the fundus of the stomach and epsilon cells of the pancreas that normally stimulates hunger and serves as a potent stimulator of growth hormone from the anterior pituitary gland

Subject: decreased circulating ghrelin level
Value: less than the normal blood concentration of the peptide hormone produced mainly by P/D1 cells lining the fundus of the stomach and epsilon cells of the pancreas that normally stimulates hunger and serves as a potent stimulator of growth hormone from the anterior pituitary gland

Subject: slow aging
Value: later than normal occurrence of the normal signs of aging

Subject: submucous cleft palate
Value: a cleft of the palate with cardinal signs including a bifid uvula, a V-shaped notch at the back of the hard palate, and/or a translucent line in the midline of the soft palate and a short palate

Subject: abnormal nonassociative learning
Value: anomaly in the process of a simple form of learning whereby the repeated presence of a stimulus leads to a change in the probability or strength of the response to that stimulus; there is no association of one type of stimulus with another, rather it is a generalized response to the environment

Subject: abnormal habituation
Value: anomaly in the process in which there is a progressive decline of behavioral response probability with a repetitive stimulus

Subject: abnormal sensitization
Value: anomaly in the process in which a progressive amplification of a behavioral response follows repeated administration of a stimulus

Subject: abnormal dishabituation
Value: anomaly in the process in which there is a temporary recovery of response to a stimulus when a novel stimulus is added

Subject: abnormal habituation to a new environment
Value: anomaly in the process in which there is a progressive decline of behavioral response probability with an exposure to a new environment

Subject: abnormal habituation to a novel object
Value: anomaly in the process in which there is a progressive decline of behavioral response probability with an exposure to a novel object

Subject: abnormal habituation to a novel odor
Value: anomaly in the process in which there is a progressive decline of behavioral response probability with an exposure to a novel odor

Subject: abnormal habituation to xenobiotic
Value: anomaly in the process in which there is a progressive decline of behavioral response probability with exposure to xenobiotics

Subject: abnormal sensitization to xenobiotic
Value: anomaly in the process in which a progressive amplification of a behavioral response follows repeated administration of a xenobiotic

Subject: cystolithiasis
Value: caliculi, or a solid concretion or crystal aggregation, found in the urinary bladder; often embedded in a glycoprotein matrix which may also contain some nonglycoproteins when associated with infection

Subject: orotic acid urinary bladder stones
Value: presence of caliculi, or a solid concretion or crystal aggregation formed from orotic acid, found in the urinary bladder; often embedded in a glycoprotein matrix which may also contain some nonglycoproteins when associated with infection

Subject: decreased skin pigmentation
Value: visually detectable dilution of pigment present in the skin

Subject: increased mitochondrial number
Value: greater than normal number of the cellular organelles responsible for energy production

Subject: decreased mitochondrial number
Value: fewer than normal number of the cellular organelles responsible for energy production

Subject: increased mitochondrial size
Value: enlarged the cellular organelles responsible for energy production

Subject: decreased mitochondrial size
Value: reduced size of the cellular organelles responsible for energy production

Subject: dilated mitochondria
Value: the luminal space of the mitochondria is increased in volume or area, usually with an increase of contained fluid

Subject: abnormal mitochondrial shape
Value: any anomaly in the characteristic surface outline or contour of a mitochondria

Subject: abnormal mitochondrial inner membrane morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the inner, i.e. lumen-facing, lipid bilayer of the mitochondrial envelope, which is highly folded to form cristae

Subject: disorganized mitochondrial cristae
Value: derangement of the pattern of the inward folds of the mitochondrial inner membrane

Subject: abnormal mitochondrial matrix morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the gel-like material, with considerable fine structure, that lies in the matrix space, or lumen, of a mitochondrion, and contains the enzymes of the tricarboxylic acid cycle and, in some organisms, the enzymes concerned with fatty acid oxidation

Subject: abnormal mitochondrial chromosome morphology
Value: any structrual anomaly of the chromosome found in the mitochondrion of a eukaryotic cell

Subject: decreased mitochondrial DNA content
Value: less than expected amount of DNA contained within the mirochondria of a eukaryotic cell

Subject: abnormal aorta collagen fibril morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the connective tissue bundles in the extracellular matrix of aorta tissue that are composed of collagen, and play a role in tissue strength and elasticity

Subject: abnormal pulmonary collagen fibril morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the connective tissue bundles in the extracellular matrix of pulmonary tissue that are composed of collagen, and play a role in tissue strength and elasticity

Subject: abnormal bone collagen fibril morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the connective tissue bundles in the extracellular matrix of bone tissue that are composed of collagen, and play a role in tissue strength and elasticity

Subject: abnormal tendon collagen fibril morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the connective tissue bundles in the extracellular matrix of tendon tissue that are composed of collagen, and play a role in tissue strength and elasticity

Subject: abnormal oviduct epithelium motile cilium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the multiple epithelial tiny, motile hair-like projections, which have a variable arrangement of axonemal microtubules, contains molecular motors, and beat with a characteristic whip-like pattern that promote transport of fluids and other cells across the epithelium of the oviduct

Subject: absent oviduct epithelium motile cilium
Value: absence of the multiple epithelial tiny, motile hair-like projections, which have a variable arrangement of axonemal microtubules, contains molecular motors, and beat with a characteristic whip-like pattern that promote transport of fluids and other cells across the epithelium of the oviduct

Subject: abnormal sinuatrial valve morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the valve at the sinuatrial orifice at the opening of the sinus venosus into the primordial right atrium

Subject: absent sinuatrial valve
Value: absence of the valve at the sinuatrial orifice at the opening of the sinus venosus into the primordial right atrium

Subject: thick heart valve cusps
Value: an increase in the heart cusp wall thickness

Subject: immotile respiratory cilia
Value: failure of the multiple epithelial tiny, motile hair-like projections of the repiratory tract epithelium to beat with a characteristic whip-like pattern in order to promote transport of fluids and other cells across the epithelium of the respiratory tract

Subject: abnormal corneal stroma collagen fibril morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the connective tissue bundles in the extracellular matrix of corneal stroma that are composed of collagen, and play a role in tissue strength and elasticity

Subject: abnormal circulating histidine level
Value: the amount of the amino acid histidine in the blood is more or less than expected

Subject: increased circulating histidine level
Value: the amount of the amino acid histidine in the blood is more than expected

Subject: decreased circulating histidine level
Value: the amount of the amino acid histidine in the blood is less than expected

Subject: histidinuria
Value: increased excretion of histidine and related imidazole metabolites in urine

Subject: abnormal systemic artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the arteries that carry oxygenated blood away from the heart to the body, as opposed to the pulmonary arteries, which carry deoxygenated blood to the lungs

Subject: coronary arterio-venous fistula
Value: an abnormal communication between the terminus of a coronary artery, bypassing the myocardial capillary bed and entering any segment of the systemic or pulmonary circulation

Subject: coronary-cameral fistula
Value: an abnormal communication between the terminus of a coronary artery, bypassing the myocardial capillary bed and entering a chamber of the heart (coronary-cameral fistula)

Subject: interrupted aortic arch, type a
Value: complete discontinuation/blockage between the ascending and descending aorta with the interruption located distal to the subclavian artery that is ipsilateral to the second carotid artery

Subject: interrupted aortic arch, type b
Value: complete discontinuation/blockage between the ascending and descending aorta with the interruption located between second carotid artery and ipsilateral subclavian artery

Subject: ectopia cordis
Value: congenital condition in which the heart is exposed and/or protruding from the thorax due to abnormal development of the sternum, pericardium and/or the abdominal wall

Subject: persistent truncus arteriosus type i
Value: complete failure of the common arterial trunk opening out of both ventricles to divide into the aorta and pulmonary artery during development; type i is characterized by origin of a single pulmonary trunk from the left lateral aspect of the common trunk, with branching of the left and right pulmonary arteries from the pulmonary trunk

Subject: persistent truncus arteriosus type ii
Value: complete failure of the common arterial trunk opening out of both ventricles to divide into the aorta and pulmonary artery during development; type II is characterized by separate but proximate origins of the left and right pulmonary arterial branches from the posterolateral aspect of the common arterial trunk

Subject: persistent truncus arteriosus type iii
Value: complete failure of the common arterial trunk opening out of both ventricles to divide into the aorta and pulmonary artery during development; in type iii the branch pulmonary arteries originate independently from the common arterial trunk or aortic arch, most often from the left and right lateral aspects of the trunk; this occasionally occurs with origin of one pulmonary artery from the underside of the aortic arch, usually from a ductus arteriosus

Subject: persistent truncus arteriosus type iv
Value: complete failure of the common arterial trunk opening out of both ventricles to divide into the aorta and pulmonary artery during development; type i is a form of the lesion with neither pulmonary arterial branch arises from the common trunk, and is more commonly recognized to be a form of pulmonary atresia with ventricular septal defect rather than truncus arteriosus

Subject: d-loop transposition of the great arteries
Value: complete transposition of the great arteries; the d- refers to the dextroposition of the bulboventricular loop (ie, the position of the right ventricle, which is on the right side); in addition, the aorta also tends to be on the right and anterior, and the great arteries are parallel rather than crossing

Subject: double outlet right ventricle, ventricular defect committed to aorta
Value: a form of DORV in which a ventricular septal defect is located just below the aorta; the left ventricular outflow is directed toward the aorta, resulting in aortic oxygen saturations that exceed pulmonary saturations; pulmonary stenosis is also often present

Subject: double outlet right ventricle with atrioventricular septal defect
Value: a form of DORV in which there is also a complete atrioventricular canal

Subject: double outlet right ventricle, Taussig bing type
Value: a form of DORV in which blood from the left ventricle passes through a ventricular septal defect to the pulmonary artery, and blood from the right ventricle is directed to the aorta

Subject: double outlet right ventricle, doubly committed ventricular septal defect
Value: a form of DORV in which there are two ventricular septal defects, one below the aorta and one below the pulmonary artery and the left ventricular outflow is equally shared by the aorta and pulmonary artery

Subject: double outlet right ventricle, noncommitted ventricular septal defect
Value: a form of DORV in which the ventricular septal defect is distant from both the aorta and pulmonary artery and blood mixes in the right ventricle before entering these vessels, with the majority of deoxygenated blood entering the aorta

Subject: double aortic arch, balanced arches
Value: defect in which the aortic arch splits into equally sized large left and right branches, encircling the trachea and esophagus, before becoming one tube to go to the lower body

Subject: aortic arch obstruction
Value: any impediment or blockage causing a cessation or reversal of the normal flow of the blood through the aortic arch

Subject: abnormal olfactory sensory neuron physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of cells that innervate the olfactory epithelium and are responsible for receiving and transmitting odorant signals

Subject: abnormal vomeronasal sensory neuron physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of chemosensitive cells that innervate the vomernasal organ epithelium and are responsible for receiving and transmitting pheromone signals

Subject: abnormal vomeronasal sensory neuron morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of chemosensitive cells that innervate the vomernasal organ epithelium and are responsible for receiving and transmitting pheromone signals

Subject: tricuspid valve hypoplasia
Value: decrease in the number of normal cells in normal arrangement in the tricuspid valve, resulting in a decreased size caused by underdevelopment or incomplete development of the structure

Subject: atrium cysts
Value: abnormal membranous sacs in any portion of the paired upper chambers of the heart

Subject: renal glomerulus cysts
Value: abnormal membranous sacs in any portion of the renal glomerulus

Subject: dual inferior vena cava
Value: presence of two inferior vena cavae, often resulting from the persistence of both supracardinal veins during development; the two structures may be symmetric or asymmetric but typically join together at the renal vein

Subject: coronary-cameral fistula to right ventricle
Value: an abnormal communication between the terminus of a coronary artery, bypassing the myocardial capillary bed and entering the right ventricle

Subject: abnormal limb paddle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the transient developing limb structure that develops from the limb bud; it is a dorsoventral flattening of the limb bud structure and develops into the foot plate

Subject: increased epidermal stem cell number
Value: greater than expected number of somatic stem cells that are part of the epidermis

Subject: decreased epidermal stem cell number
Value: a reduction in the number of somatic stem cells that are part of the epidermis

Subject: absent epidermal stem cells
Value: absence of the somatic stem cells that are part of the epidermis

Subject: absent neutrophils
Value: absence of the immature or mature forms of a granular leukocyte that in its mature form has a nucleus with three to five lobes connected by slender threads of chromatin, and cytoplasm containing fine inconspicuous granules and stainable by neutral dyes

Subject: absent basophils
Value: absence of the immature or mature forms of a granular leukocyte that in its mature form has an irregularly shaped, pale-staining nucleus that is partially constricted into two lobes, and with cytoplasm that contains coarse, bluish-black granules of variable size; these cells contain vasoactive amines such as histamine and serotonin, which are released on appropriate stimulation

Subject: absent bronchioalveolar stem cells
Value: absence of the respiratory stem cells found at the junction of the terminal (conductive) bronchiole and the respiratory bronchiole, which gives rise to alveolar cell types and Clara cells in response to lung injury

Subject: increased chondrocyte number
Value: greater number of polymorphic cells that form cartilage

Subject: absent chondrocytes
Value: absence of polymorphic cells that form cartilage

Subject: absent eosinophils
Value: any structural anomaly of the immature or mature forms of a granular leukocyte with a nucleus that usually has two lobes connected by one or more slender threads of chromatin, and cytoplasm containing coarse, round granules that are uniform in size and which can be stained by the dye eosin

Subject: absent hematopoietic stem cells
Value: absence of the multipotent, self-renewing stem cells found in the bone marrow, yolk sac and the fetal liver; HSCs give rise to all the types of both the myeloid and lymphoid cell lineages

Subject: absent mast cells
Value: any structural anomaly of a cell that is found in almost all tissues containing numerous basophilic granules and capable of releasing large amounts of histamine and heparin upon activation; progenitors leave bone marrow and mature in connective and mucosal tissue; mature mast cells are found in all tissues, except the bloodstream.

Subject: vacuolated lens
Value: fluid filled cavities are present in the cytoplasm of the transparent structure of the eye responsible for focusing light

Subject: abnormal brown adipose tissue physiology
Value: any functional anomaly in the thermogenic form of adipose tissue that is composed of brown adipocytes

Subject: abnormal brown adipose tissue thermogenesis
Value: any anomaly in the process of heat production in brown adipocytes

Subject: increased cumulus expansion
Value: greater ability of the ovarian cumulus cells to secrete an extensive extracellular matrix required for successful fertilization

Subject: decreased cumulus expansion
Value: reduced ability of the ovarian cumulus cells to secrete an extensive extracellular matrix required for successful fertilization

Subject: abnormal fibroblast proliferation
Value: anomaly in the ability of a fibroblast cell population to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: increased fibroblast proliferation
Value: greater the expansion rate of a fibroblast cell population by cell division

Subject: decreased fibroblast proliferation
Value: reduction in the expansion rate of a fibroblast cell population by cell division

Subject: absent fibroblast proliferation
Value: failure of a fibroblast cell population to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: abnormal fibroblast migration
Value: any anomaly of fibroblast cell migration that is accomplished by extension and retraction of a fibroblast pseudopodium

Subject: impaired fibroblast cell migration
Value: failure of cell migration that is accomplished by extension and retraction of a fibroblast pseudopodium

Subject: decreased fibroblast cell migration
Value: reduced frequency of or less rapid fibroblast cell migration that is accomplished by extension and retraction of a fibroblast pseudopodium

Subject: increased fibroblast cell migration
Value: greater frequency of or more rapid fibroblast cell migration that is accomplished by extension and retraction of a fibroblast pseudopodium

Subject: enhanced osteoblast differentiation
Value: increased ability or increased rate of production of skeletogenic cells that secrete osteoid, are capable of producing mineralized (hydroxyapatite) matrix, are located adjacent to or within osteoid tissue, and arise from the transformation of a preosteoblast cell

Subject: impaired osteoblast differentiation
Value: reduced ability or inability to produce skeletogenic cells that secrete osteoid, are capable of producing mineralized (hydroxyapatite) matrix, are located adjacent to or within osteoid tissue, and arise from the transformation of a preosteoblast cell

Subject: arrested osteoblast differentiation
Value: inability to produce skeletogenic cells that secrete osteoid, are capable of producing mineralized (hydroxyapatite) matrix, are located adjacent to or within osteoid tissue, and arise from the transformation of a preosteoblast cell, due to a block in the process to create a mature osteoblast

Subject: abnormal natural killer cell mediated cytotoxicity
Value: any anomaly in the process of directed killing of a target cell by a natural killer cell through the release of granules containing cytotoxic mediators or through the engagement of death receptors

Subject: abnormal ossification involved in bone remodeling
Value: any anomaly in the formation or growth of bone or of a bony substance, or the conversion of fibrous tissue or of cartilage into bone, involved in response to injury or other physical, physiological or environmental stress stimuli

Subject: abnormal bone mineralization involved in bone maturation
Value: anomaly in the deposition of calcium phosphate in bone tissue, involved in the progression of the developing skeleton from its formation to its mature state

Subject: abnormal ossification involved in bone maturation
Value: anomaly in the formation of bone or of a bony substance, or the conversion of fibrous tissue or of cartilage into bone, involved in the progression of the developing skeleton from its formation to its mature state

Subject: ectopic neuron
Value: appearance of a neuron or group of neurons in a region where it is not normally found

Subject: ectopic cortical neuron
Value: appearance of a cerebral cortical neuron or group of cerebral cortical neurons in a region where it is not normally found

Subject: neuronal leptomeningeal ectopia
Value: during development, migrating cortical neurons fail to stop at the border of the marginal zone and continue through this layer and occasionally through the pial-glial layer into the meninges

Subject: ectopic Cajal-Retzius cell
Value: appearance of a Cajal-Retzius cell in a region where it is not normally found

Subject: ectopic ovary
Value: one or both of the ovaries located outside the normal pathway of descent from the lumbar region to a shallow depression on the lateral wall of the pelvis known as the ovarian fossa; the fossa usually lies beneath the external iliac artery and in front of the ureter and the internal iliac artery; ovarian maldescent may be associated with Mullerian malformations

Subject: abnormal pineal gland physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the small flattened endocrine gland located in the depression between the superior colliculi of the brain

Subject: abnormal pineal gland melatonin secretion
Value: anomaly in the production and/or release of a catecholamine hormone by the pineal body that controls behavior influenced by seasonal changes

Subject: increased myelin sheath thickness
Value: increase in the depth of the insulating envelope that surrounds nerve fibers or axons

Subject: decreased myelin sheath thickness
Value: decrease in the depth of the insulating envelope that surrounds nerve fibers or axons

Subject: decreased somite size
Value: reduced size of mesodermal clusters that are arranged segmentally along the anterior posterior axis of an embryo

Subject: fused somites
Value: a defect in which there is an appearance of a single enlarged somite resulting from partial or complete fusion of the two somitic anlage

Subject: abnormal urine ammonia level
Value: any change in the amount of ammonia in urine

Subject: increased urine ammonia level
Value: a greater amount of ammonia in the urine compared to the normal state

Subject: decreased urine ammonia level
Value: a reduced amount of ammonia in the urine compared to the normal state

Subject: hypodipsia
Value: abnormally diminished thirst with a consequential reduction of fluid intake; often related to dysfunction of the thirst osmoreceptor in the anterior hypothalamus

Subject: anasarca
Value: widespread swelling due to effusion of serous fluid into the extracellular space, especially into the connective tissue

Subject: abnormal Boettcher cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the polyhedral cells located on the basilar membrane beneath the Claudius cells in the basal turn of the cochlea, and considered supporting cells for the organ of Corti; Boettcher cells interweave with each other, project microvilli into the intercellular space, show high levels of calmodulin, and may be involved in mediating Ca(2+) regulation and ion transport

Subject: abnormal urine nitrite level
Value: anomaly in the amount of nitrite (NO2-) in the urine; may be suggestive of impaired nitric oxide (NO) release, or of a urinary tract infection

Subject: increased urine nitrite level
Value: higher than normal amount of nitrite (NO2-) in the urine, usually indicative of a urinary tract infection; commonly a result of the action of Escherichia coli, Proteus vulgaris, and other microorganisms that may reduce nitrates

Subject: decreased urine nitrite level
Value: lower than normal amount of nitrite (NO2-) in the urine; suggestive of impaired nitric oxide (NO) release

Subject: abnormal Golgi apparatus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the compound membranous cytoplasmic organelle of eukaryotic cells, consisting of flattened, ribosome-free vesicles arranged in a more or less regular stack; Golgi apparatus processes proteins produced on the ribosomes of the rough endoplasmic reticulum; such processing includes modification of the core oligosaccharides of glycoproteins, and the sorting and packaging of proteins for transport to a variety of cellular locations

Subject: abnormal kidney epithelial cell primary cilium physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the non-motile primary cilia found on renal epithelial cells and thought to act as a mechanical sensor to detect renal tubular fluid; impaired mechanical response of primary cilia to physiological fluid flow, or abnormalities in intracellular Ca2+ increase in response to fluid stress may alter renal (tubular) cell proliferation and differentiation and lead to renal cyst formation

Subject: isolation of the left subclavian artery
Value: the loss of continuity between the left subclavian artery and the aorta, with persistent connection to the homolateral pulmonary artery through the patent (PDA) or nonpatent ductus arteriosus

Subject: spleen fibrosis
Value: invasion of fibrous connective tissue into the spleen, often resulting from inflammation or injury

Subject: myelofibrosis
Value: appearance of fibrous connective tissue in the bone marrow, often resulting from inflammation or injury; especially replacement of the marrow with collagenous connective tissue fibers, frequently accompanied by splenomegaly and anemia or cytopenias

Subject: intestinal fibrosis
Value: formation of fibrous tissue in any part of the intestine as a result of repair or a reactive process

Subject: perivascular fibrosis
Value: invasion of fibrous connective tissue into the perivascular tissue, often resulting from inflammation or injury

Subject: abnormal seminiferous tubule epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the stratified epithelial lining of the seminiferous tubules, consisting of the developing spermatozoa and the supporting Sertoli cells, which are tall, columnar type cells that line the tubule

Subject: abnormal X-Y chromosome synapsis during male meiosis
Value: an anomaly in the process in which the side by side pairing and physical juxtaposition of X and Y chromosomes is created at the metaphase plate, usually resulting in incorrect sex chromosome disjunction

Subject: abnormal X-Y chromosome synaptonemal complex assembly during male meiosis
Value: an anomaly in the process in which forms the structure that holds the X and Y chomosomes together during prophase I of male meiosis and results in exchange of X and Y chromatin during prophase I, or results in exchange of X and Y chromatin outside the chromatin associated with the pseudoautosomal region

Subject: decreased podocyte number
Value: reduced number of the modified epithelial cells of the visceral layer of the Bowman capsule in the renal corpuscle

Subject: abnormal kidney collecting duct intercalated cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the functionally distinct subtypes of cells (alpha or beta) found on the kidney collecting duct epithelium that regulate acid-base homeostasis and play an important role in the kidney's response to acidosis and alkalosis; alpha-intercalated cells secrete acid whereas beta-intercalated cells secrete base; metabolic acidosis results in the conversion of beta- cells to alpha-intercalated cells giving the kidney a greater ability to secrete protons and return pH to the normal range

Subject: abnormal kidney collecting duct alpha-intercalated cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tall, columnar epithelial cells found on the kidney collecting duct epithelium which secrete acid (via an apical H+-ATPase and H+/K+ exchanger) in the form of hydrogen ions and reabsorb bicarbonate (via band 3, a basolateral Cl-/HCO3- exchanger);damage to the alpha-intercalated cell's ability to secrete acid can result in distal renal tubular acidosis

Subject: abnormal kidney collecting duct beta-intercalated cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the shorter, flatter cells found on the kidney collecting duct epithelium which secrete bicarbonate (via pendrin, a specialized apical Cl-/HCO3- exchanger) and reabsorb acid (via a basal H+-ATPase)

Subject: abnormal kidney collecting duct principal cell morphology
Value: any structural abnormality of the cuboidal epithelial cells found in the collecting ducts of the kidney which regulate sodium and potassium balance via channels located on the cells apical membrane. Aldosterone increases the number of Na+/K+-ATPase pumps that allow increased sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion whereas antidiuretic hormone (vasopressin) determines the expression of aquaporin channels on the cell surface; together, aldosterone and vasopressin let the principal cell control the quantity of water that is reabsorbed

Subject: renal ischemia
Value: inadequate blood flow to one or both kidneys, or nephrons, usually due to functional constriction or actual obstruction of a blood vessel; a significant cause of renal dysfunction and cortical and medullary necrosis

Subject: absent Rathke's pouch
Value: absence of the diverticulum arsing from the embryonic buccal cavity from which the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland is developed

Subject: abnormal ureteric bud tip morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the terminal ends of the ureteric tree; the ureteric tip cells are proliferating immature cells located at the branching points that induce the adjacent cap mesenchyme to undergo nephrogenesis

Subject: abnormal ureteric bud trunk morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the ureteric bud cells that elongate to form a rigid structure (stalk) consisting of polarized epithelial cells without branching; the stalks differentiate into the collecting system of the mature kidney, while the tip cells interact with the adjacent cells of the metanephric mesenchyme, inducing their conversion into nephrons

Subject: renal/urinary system inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the renal/urinary system; may involve inflammation of the urethra, urinary bladder, ureters or kidneys

Subject: urethritis
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the urethra, usually caused by an infection

Subject: ureteritis
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in a ureter, usually caused by infection or by the mechanic irritation of a stone; the epithelial reaction may be cystic if the reaction is liquefaction, or glandular if the epithelial reaction is by metaplasia

Subject: oroticaciduria
Value: increased level of orotic acid, an intermediate of pyrimidine synthesis, in the urine

Subject: abnormal urinary bladder mucosa morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the mucous membrane lining the urinary bladder

Subject: ureterocele
Value: saccular dilation of the terminal portion of the ureter that protrudes into the lumen of the urinary bladder, probably due to a congenital stenosis of the ureteric orifice meatus; most often associated with a duplicated collection system, where two ureters drain their respective kidney instead of one

Subject: abnormal urinary bladder trigone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the smooth triangular region of the wall of the urinary bladder formed by the two ureteral orifices and the internal urethral orifice; it is an area in which the muscle fibers are closely adherent to the mucosa

Subject: urinary bladder fibrosis
Value: invasion of fibrous connective tissue into the urinary bladder, often resulting from inflammation or injury

Subject: increased urine selenium level
Value: greater than normal amount of selenium in the urine

Subject: abnormal genital tubercle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the embryonic anlage of the external genitalia, which emerges as paired swellings ventral to the cloacal membrane, is proposed to be derived from all three germ layers, and gives rise to the penis, clitoris, scrotum, labia, and foreskin; GT development is indistinguishable in male and female mouse embryos until approximately E16, when the urethral plate begins to be masculinized to form the penile urethra, marking the beginning of an androgen-dependent phase of sexual differentiation

Subject: genital tubercle hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the embryonic anlage of the external genitalia, usually due to a reduced number of cells

Subject: abnormal urinary bladder blood vessel morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the network of tubes that carries blood through the distensible musculomembranous organ that serves to collect and store urine excreted by the kidneys

Subject: abnormal urinary bladder detrusor smooth muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bundles of smooth muscle fibers forming the muscular wall of the urinary bladder, which are arranged in a longitudinal and a circular layer and, on contraction, serve to expel urine

Subject: rectal atresia
Value: congenital absence, closure, or constriction of the lumen of the terminal portion of the intestinal tube adjacent to the anus, leading to abdominal distention after birth

Subject: abnormal male urethra morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the male fibromuscular tubular canal which extends from the internal urethral orifice in the urinary bladder to the external urethral orifice at the tip of the penis and provides an exit for urine as well as semen during ejaculation; the male urethra is longer than the urethra of females and comprises three major portions, the (i) prostatic, (ii) membranous (aka intermediate), and (iii) cavernous (aka spongy or penile)

Subject: abnormal male prostatic urethra morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the widest and most dilatable part of the male urethra canal which runs almost vertically through the prostate from its base to its apex, lying nearer its anterior than its posterior surface; this portion of the urethral canal is spindle-shaped, being wider in the middle than at either extremity, and narrowest below, where it joins the membranous portion; it is lined by transitional epithelium and contains in its posterior wall, or floor, the orifices of the prostatic utricle, ejaculatory ducts, and prostatic ducts, collectively known as the seminal colliculus (aka verumontanum)

Subject: abnormal male membranous urethra morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the shortest, least dilatable, and, with the exception of the external orifice, the narrowest part of the male urethral canal located in the deep perineal pouch and lined by pseudostratified columnar epithelium; it extends downward and forward, with a slight anterior concavity, between the apex of the prostate and the bulb of the urethra, perforating the urogenital diaphragm below and behind the pubic symphysis; the membranous portion of the urethra is completely surrounded by the fibers of the sphincter urethrae membranaceae; on either side near its termination are the bulbourethral glands

Subject: abnormal male spongy urethra morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the that longest part of the male urethra contained in the corpus spongiosum and extending from the end of the membranous portion to the external urethral orifice; commencing below the inferior fascia of the urogenital diaphragm it passes forward and upward to the front of the symphysis pubis; and then, in the flaccid condition of the penis, it bends downward and forward; while narrow and of uniform size in the body of the penis, it is dilated behind, within the bulb, and again anteriorly within the glans penis, where it forms the fossa navicularis urethrae; the spongy urethra is lined by pseudostratified columnar epithelium proximally, and by stratified squamous epithelium distally

Subject: abnormal female urethra morphology
Value: <any structural anomaly of the short and relatively simple female fibromuscular tubular canal which extends from the urinary bladder outlet to the perineum adjacent to the anterior wall of the vagina, and opens in the vestibule of the vagina posterior to the clitoris and anterior to the vaginal orifice; small mucus urethral glands (Skene's glands) open along its entire length and drain into a single paraurethral duct, which empties at the lateral margin of the external urethral orifice: its epithelial lining changes from transitional epithelium at the bladder end to non-keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium distally>

Subject: abnormal bulbourethral gland physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the small paired racemose (compound tubulo-alveolar) glands below the apex of the prostate in males, located posterolateral to the membranous portion of the urethra at the base of the penis, which produce a clear, salty, viscous secretion known as pre-ejaculate (aka as pre-ejaculatory fluid, preseminal fluid, or Cowper's fluid) upon sexual stimulation; this fluid is believed to lubricate the urethra for spermatozoa to pass through and neutralize traces of acidic urine in the urethra

Subject: abnormal internal urethral orifice morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the usually crescent-shaped opening of the urinary bladder into the urethra, placed at the anteroinferior angle (apex) of the urinary bladder trigone

Subject: abnormal ureteral orifice morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the slit-like opening of either ureter into the bladder; normally, the two ureteral orifices are placed at the posterolateral angles of the urinary bladder trigone while the internal urethral orifice is placed at its anteroinferior angle (apex); wide gaping usually indicates vesicoureteral reflux

Subject: abnormal urinary bladder neck morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the constricted portion of the urinary bladder, formed by the meeting of its inferolateral surfaces proximal to the opening of the urethra

Subject: abnormal urinary bladder fundus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the base or posterior surface of the urinary bladder, which contains the trigone of the bladder and the outlet where urine empties through the internal urethral orifice

Subject: rectourethral fistula
Value: an abnormal anatomical passage connecting the urethra and the rectum

Subject: abnormal Bartholin's gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the paired glands located slightly posterior and to the left and right of the opening of the vagina in the superficial perineal pouch in females; they secrete mucus to lubricate the vagina and are homologous to bulbourethral (Cowper's) glands in males

Subject: absent urethra
Value: absence or failure to form of any part of the male or female urethra

Subject: increased urethra carcinoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of malignant neoplasms arising from the epithelial lining of the urethra in a given population in a given time period

Subject: increased urethral gland adenocarcinoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of malignant neoplasms arising from urothelial lining or surrounding glands of the urethra in a given population in a given time period

Subject: increased bulbourethral gland adenocarcinoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of malignant neoplasm of epithelial cells in the bulbourethral glands, usually with a glandular organization in a given population in a given time period

Subject: abnormal urethral gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the numerous small mucous-secreting glands located in the wall of the male or female urethra that help protect the epithelium from the corrosive urine

Subject: abnormal female urethral gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the numerous mucous-secreting glands found in several female mammalian species (including rodents and humans) on the anterior wall of the vagina, around the lower end of the urethra, and possessing a common paraurethral duct which opens (on each side) near the external urethral orifice; they are homologous with the prostate gland in males, have highly variable anatomy, and are believed to be the source of the female ejaculate, a lubricating fluid with a similar consistency to male prostatic fluid that is expelled through the urethra during sexual stimulation; like the male prostate, these glands are susceptible to infection (skenitis), cyst development, and cancer

Subject: abnormal male urethral gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the numerous small mucous-secreting glands located in the wall of the penile urethra

Subject: abnormal urinary bladder development
Value: incomplete or aberrant differentiation of the distensible musculomembranous organ situated in the anterior part of the pelvic cavity in which urine collects before excretion

Subject: abnormal external urethral orifice morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the external opening or orifice of the urethra through which urine and seminal fluid (in males only) leave the body; in males the meatus presents as a vertical slit normally positioned at the tip of glans penis; in females the meatus is located either within the clitoris or between the clitoris and the vagina in the vulvular vestibule of the female genitalia, depending on the species

Subject: blind ureter
Value: a ureter ending in a blind-ended segment or pouch

Subject: abnormal urinary bladder weight
Value: anomaly in the average weight of the distensible musculomembranous organ that serves to collect and store urine excreted by the kidneys compared to controls

Subject: increased urinary bladder weight
Value: greater than average weight of the distensible musculomembranous organ that serves to collect and store urine excreted by the kidneys compared to controls

Subject: decreased urinary bladder weight
Value: less than average weight of the distensible musculomembranous organ that serves to collect and store urine excreted by the kidneys compared to controls

Subject: urethra obstruction
Value: any impediment or blockage of the canal through which urine is discharged from the bladder in most mammals and through which semen is discharged in the male; usually caused by calculus, or plugs composed of proteinaceous material, cellular debris and possibly crystals

Subject: seminal vesiculitis
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the seminal vesicle(s), usually caused by an infection

Subject: double kidney pelvis
Value: duplication of the funnel shaped proximal portion of the ureter that is formed by convergence of the major calices

Subject: increased cell migration
Value: increased or faster movement of cells from one site to another, often occurring during developmental or chemotactic processes

Subject: decreased cell migration
Value: reduced or slower movement of cells from one site to another, often occurring during developmental or chemotactic processes

Subject: decreased dermal fibroblast proliferation
Value: reduction in the expansion rate of a dermal fibroblast cell population by cell division

Subject: decreased lung fibroblast proliferation
Value: reduction in the expansion rate of a lung fibroblast cell population by cell division

Subject: abnormal myoblast differentiation
Value: anomaly in the process in which a relatively unspecialized cell acquires specialized features of a myoblast, a mononucleate cell type that, by fusion with other myoblasts, gives rise to the myotubes that eventually develop into striated muscle fibers

Subject: abnormal anoikis
Value: anomaly in the apoptosis response triggered by inadequate or inappropriate adherence to substrate e.g. after disruption of the interactions between normal epithelial cells and the extracellular matrix

Subject: increased anoikis
Value: increase in the apoptosis response triggered by inadequate or inappropriate adherence to substrate e.g. after disruption of the interactions between normal epithelial cells and the extracellular matrix

Subject: decreased anoikis
Value: reduction in the apoptosis response triggered by inadequate or inappropriate adherence to substrate e.g. after disruption of the interactions between normal epithelial cells and the extracellular matrix

Subject: increased cranium length
Value: having an increased dorsal-to-ventral distance of the cranium

Subject: long maxilla
Value: increased length of the upper jaw bone

Subject: abnormal pre-pro B cell morphology
