Value: any structural anomaly of a pro-B cell that CD45R/B220-positive, CD43-positive, HSA-low, BP-1-negative and Ly6c-negative. This cell type is also described as being lin-negative, AA4-positive, Kit-positive, IL7Ra-positive and CD45R-positive

Subject: increased pre-pro B cell number
Value: increased number of pro-B cells that are CD45R/B220-positive, CD43-positive, HSA-low, BP-1-negative and Ly6c-negative; this cell type is also described as being lin-negative, AA4-positive, Kit-positive, IL7Ra-positive and CD45R-positive

Subject: decreased pre-pro B cell number
Value: reduced number of pro-B cells that are CD45R/B220-positive, CD43-positive, HSA-low, BP-1-negative and Ly6c-negative; this cell type is also described as being lin-negative, AA4-positive, Kit-positive, IL7Ra-positive and CD45R-positive

Subject: absent pre-pro B cells
Value: absence of pro-B cells that are CD45R/B220-positive, CD43-positive, HSA-low, BP-1-negative and Ly6c-negative; this cell type is also described as being lin-negative, AA4-positive, Kit-positive, IL7Ra-positive and CD45R-positive

Subject: abnormal pancreatic beta cell proliferation
Value: anomaly in the ability of the cells that secrete insulin and are located towards the center of the islets of Langerhans in the pancreas to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: increased pancreatic beta cell proliferation
Value: increase in the ability of the cells that secrete insulin and are located towards the center of the islets of Langerhans in the pancreas to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: decreased pancreatic beta cell proliferation
Value: reduction in the ability of the cells that secrete insulin and are located towards the center of the islets of Langerhans in the pancreas to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: abnormal CD8-positive, alpha-beta memory T cell proliferation
Value: anomaly in the ability of the CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cell with memory phenotype indicated by being CD45RO and CD127-positive, or also described as being CD25-negative, CD44-high, and CD122- high, to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: increased CD8-positive, alpha-beta memory T cell proliferation
Value: increase in the ability of the a CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cell with memory phenotype indicated by being CD45RO and CD127-positive, or also described as being CD25-negative, CD44-high, and CD122- high, to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: decreased CD8-positive, alpha-beta memory T cell proliferation
Value: reduction in the ability of the a CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cell with memory phenotype indicated by being CD45RO and CD127-positive, or also described as being CD25-negative, CD44-high, and CD122- high, to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: increased cell chemotaxis
Value: increase in the directed movement response of a motile cell guided by a specific chemical concentration gradient; movement may be towards a higher concentration (positive chemotaxis) or towards a lower concentration (negative chemotaxis)

Subject: decreased cell chemotaxis
Value: reduction in the directed movement response of a motile cell guided by a specific chemical concentration gradient; movement may be towards a higher concentration (positive chemotaxis) or towards a lower concentration (negative chemotaxis)

Subject: abnormal lymphocyte chemotaxis
Value: any anomaly in the directed movement of a lymphocyte in response to an external stimulus

Subject: impaired neuron differentiation
Value: decreased production of or inability to produce the mature cells of the nervous system that receive, conduct, and transmit impulses

Subject: urinary bladder cysts
Value: abnormal membranous pouches or sacs usually filled with a fluid or viscous substance found along the internal lining of the urinary bladder

Subject: vesicovaginal fistula
Value: an abnormal fistulous tract extending between the bladder and the vagina, with resulting leakage of urine into the vaginal cavity

Subject: ectopic hair follicle melanin granules
Value: any aberration in normal location of pigment granules in the hair follicle that results in variation from expected hair color

Subject: abnormal visual contrast sensitivity
Value: any abnormality in the ability to distinguish between increments of light versus dark

Subject: abnormal visual acuity
Value: any abnormality in the spatial resolution or resolving power of the visual processing system

Subject: abnormal cremaster muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thin layer of skeletal muscle that envelops the spermatic cord and testis of most male mammals in a series of loops; it is a continuation of the obliquus internus, arising from the inguinal ligament and inserting into the crest of the pubis and into the sheath of the rectus abdominis; it is innervated by the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve and functions to draw the testis up toward the superficial inguinal ring in response to cold or to stimulation of the nerve; in females it is represented by only a few muscle loops that envelop the round ligament of the uterus

Subject: abnormal female preputial gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the paired, lobulated, modified sebaceous glands located on the side of the clitoris in female rodents; in contrast to the preputial glands in male rodents, clitoral glands are a minor source of olfactory stimuli contributing to sexual attractivity; unlike other sebaceous glands, they undergo progressive atrophy of the glandular portion with marked ductal ectasia as rodents age; there is no true anatomical equivalent in humans

Subject: abnormal urogenital fold morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the pair of folds derived from the cloacal folds which give rise to a portion of the external genitalia; in male embryos they close over the urethral plate and fuse to form the spongy (penile) urethra and ventral aspect of the penis, not including the glans; failure of fusion of the urethral folds leads to hypospadias; in female embryos they fuse only anterior to the anus and form the labia minora

Subject: abnormal cloacal fold morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the pair of mesenchymal swellings (folds) located on either side of the cloacal membrane during the indifferent stage of embryonic development; cranial to the cloacal membrane the folds unite to form the genital tubercle; caudally the folds are subdivided into urogenital folds anteriorly and anal folds posteriorly

Subject: abnormal cloacal membrane morphology
Value: <any structural anomaly of the membrane that covers the embryonic cloaca, formed by the union of proctodeal (anal pit) ectoderm and cloacal endoderm, with no intervening mesoderm; the urorectal septum joins the cloacal membrane and divides it into an anal membrane and a urogenital membrane; the point where the urorectal septum intersects the cloacal membrane is the future site of the perineal body; proliferation of mesoderm and ectoderm around the cloacal membrane produces primordial tissues of the external genitalia in both sexes: the genital tubercle, genital folds, and genital swellings>

Subject: abnormal navicular fossa morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the dilated terminal portion of the male spongy urethra located in the glans penis right before the external urethral orifice, also referred to as the most distal pendulous urethra; it is lined by stratified squamous, non-keratinizing epithelium; during development, the glans of the penis is initially solid but cannulates to give rise to the navicular fossa

Subject: abnormal Guerin's valve morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the fold or valve of mucus membrane on the upper wall of the navicuar fossa

Subject: abnormal urethral crest morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the longitudinal mucosal fold in the dorsal wall of the urethra

Subject: abnormal male urethral crest morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the narrow longitudinal fold of mucosa on the posterior wall of the male urethra, extending from the uvula of the bladder through the prostatic urethra; when distended, it may serve to prevent the passage of the semen backward into the bladder; on either side of the male urethral crest is a slightly depressed fossa, the prostatic sinus, the floor of which is perforated by the orifices of the prostatic ducts from the lateral lobes of the prostate; the ducts of the middle lobe open behind the crest; at the forepart of the crest, below its summit, is a median elevation, the colliculus seminalis, upon or within the margins of which are the orifices of the prostatic utricle and the slit-like openings of the ejaculatory ducts

Subject: abnormal female urethral crest morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the conspicuous longitudinal fold of mucosa on the posterior wall of the female urethra

Subject: abnormal kidney collecting duct epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the simple cuboidal epithelium lining the lumen of kidney collecting ducts; the mature and differentiated CD epithelium comprises two unique cells types with principal cells responsible for vasopressin-regulated water reabsorption, and intercalated cells regulating acid-base homeostasis; injury to the epithelium is believed to cause epithelial cells to acquire mesenchymal characteristics via epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT), a process through which tubular epithelial cells may transform into interstitial fibroblasts and promote renal fibrosis

Subject: kidney collecting duct atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of the kidney collecting ducts associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: abnormal kidney collecting duct number
Value: anomaly in the number of any of the kidney ducts that collect urine from the distal convoluted tubules, merge and become larger as they descend from the renal cortex into the medulla, and respond to vasopressin and aldosterone to regulate water, electrolyte and acid-base balance

Subject: decreased kidney collecting duct number
Value: smaller than expected number of the kidney ducts that collect urine from the distal convoluted tubules, merge and become larger as they descend from the renal cortex into the medulla, and respond to vasopressin and aldosterone to regulate water, electrolyte and acid-base balance

Subject: increased kidney collecting duct number
Value: larger than expected number of the kidney ducts that collect urine from the distal convoluted tubules, merge and become larger as they descend from the renal cortex into the medulla, and respond to vasopressin and aldosterone to regulate water, electrolyte and acid-base balance

Subject: abnormal vagina vestibule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the space posterior to the glans clitoridis, between the labia minora; located within the vestibule are the openings of the vagina, the urethra, and the ducts of the lesser vestibular glands, the greater vestibular (Bartholin's) glands, and the paraurethral (Skene's) glands, which release mucus into the vestibule to maintain a moist, lubricated vestibular environment; the vestibule is also moistened by secretions from the cervical mucus glands located in the inferior region of the uterus

Subject: abnormal clitoral bone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the ossified region of endochondral and membranous bone located in the clitoris of most mammals except humans;it is homologous to the penile bone (aka as baculum, penis bone or os penis) in male mammals

Subject: absent clitoral bone
Value: absence of the unique bone located in the clitoris of most mammals except humans

Subject: abnormal embryonic cloaca development
Value: failure or anomaly in the formation of a pouch-like dilation of the caudal end of the hindgut by the process of folding of the caudal region of the embryonic disk; during the tail-fold process, the posteriorly placed allantois, or allantoic diverticulum of the yolk sac, becomes an anterior extension of the cloaca; soon after the cloaca forms, it receives posterolaterally the caudal ends of the paired mesonephric ducts and hence becomes a junctional cistern for the allantois, the hindgut, and the ducts; a cloacal membrane, composed of ectoderm and endoderm, is the caudal limit of the primitive gut and temporarily separates the cloacal cavity from the extraembryonic confines of the amniotic cavity; subsequent growth of the urorectal septum eventually subdivides the once single cloaca chamber into the primitive urogenital sinus (ventrally) and the anorectal canal of the hindgut (dorsally)

Subject: patent urachus
Value: failure of complete urachal lumen closure resulting in an open channel between the urinary bladder and the umbilicus and leakage of urine through the umbilicus

Subject: abnormal urorectal septum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the ridge of mesoderm covered with endoderm that in the early developing embryo partitions the endodermal cloaca into the primary urogenital sinus (ventrally) and the anorectal canal of the hindgut (dorsally); the urorectal septum eventually fuses with the cloacal membrane, dividing it into a dorsal anal membrane and a larger ventral urogenital membrane - this area of fusion is represented in the adult by the perineal body

Subject: cerebral edema
Value: excess accumulation of water in the intra- and/or extracellular spaces of the brain

Subject: abnormal glomerular filtration barrier morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the highly specialized blood filtration interface that displays a high conductance to small and midsized solutes in plasma but retains relative impermeability to macromolecules; its integrity is maintained by physicochemical and signalling interplay among its three core constituents -- the fenestrated endothelium of the glomerular capillaries, the glomerular basement membrane, and the filtration slits of the visceral epithelial cell (podocyte)

Subject: abnormal glomerular filtration barrier function
Value: anomaly in the function of the highly specialized blood filtration interface that displays a high conductance to small and midsized solutes in plasma but retains relative impermeability to macromolecules; its integrity is maintained by physicochemical and signalling interplay among its three core constituents -- the fenestrated endothelium of the glomerular capillaries, the glomerular basement membrane, and the filtration slits of the visceral epithelial cell (podocyte); the barrier permits the passage of water, ions, and small molecules from the bloodstream into the Bowman's space and prevents the loss of large and/or negatively charged proteins (e.g. serum albumin) from blood into urine

Subject: short kidney papilla
Value: reduced average length of the apex of the renal pyramid that projects into a calyx

Subject: elongated kidney papilla
Value: increased average length of the apex of the renal pyramid that projects into a calyx

Subject: decreased renal glomerulus basement membrane thickness
Value: reduced width of the layer of extracellular matrix that lies between the endothelium of the glomerular capillaries and the podocytes of the inner or visceral layer of the Bowman capsule

Subject: abnormal peritubular capillary endothelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thin sheet of endothelial cells along the basal lamina of renal tubular cells characterized by their attenuated shape and numerous regularly-spaced transcellular pores (aka fenestrae or fenestrations); the fenestrae of peritubular capillaries differ from the fenestrae of glomerular capillaries in that they are much smaller and possess a small overlying diaphragm

Subject: increased cranium height
Value: increase in the rostral-caudal distance between the cranial base and the upper domelike portion of the skull

Subject: decreased cranium length
Value: having an decreased dorsal-to-ventral distance of the cranium

Subject: abnormal podocyte physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of a modified epithelial cell of the visceral layer of the Bowman capsule in the renal corpuscle; it has a small perikaryon and a number of primary and secondary foot processes that interdigitate with those of other podocytes and are attached to the outer surface of the glomerular capillary basement membrane

Subject: abnormal podocyte adhesion
Value: any anomaly in the adhesive properties of glomerular podocytes, resulting in abnormal cell to cell and cell to extracellular matrix (ECM) interactions; podocytes adhere tightly to ECM components of the glomerular basement membrane via an integrin-laminin-actin axis to maintain a functional filtration barrier in the presence of mechanical stress

Subject: abnormal podocyte motility
Value: any anomaly in the ability of podocyte foot processes (FPs) to retract or elongate and hence move quickly along the glomerular basement membrane (GBM); motility refers to the dynamic reorganization of the interdigitating FP structure in vivo , and to the cell migration of cultured podocytes in vitro that is seen as surrogate for the former; alterations in podocyte motility are considered to underlie foot process effacement, with changes in the leading edge of the cell and its interactions with the GBM; a rather stationary podocyte phenotype is believed to reflect a stable FP structure with intact slit diaphragms, whereas hypermotility is believed to promote the development of FP effacement and proteinuria

Subject: increased podocyte motility
Value: greater ability of podocyte foot processes (FPs) to retract or elongate and hence move quickly along the glomerular basement membrane (GBM)

Subject: decreased podocyte motility
Value: reduced ability of podocyte foot processes (FPs) to retract or elongate and hence move quickly along the glomerular basement membrane (GBM)

Subject: podocyte microvillus transformation
Value: aberrant formation of numerous slender cellular projections resembling microvilli or vesicle-like structures along the apical surface of podocytes, suggestive of podocyte injury

Subject: detached podocyte
Value: detachment or loss of adhesion of podocyte foot processes from the glomerular basement membrane (GBM); as a consequence, denuded GBM areas at peripheral capillary loops can become foci for adhesions to parietal epithelial cells (glomerular synechiae) and crescent formation, and podocytes and podocyte-specific proteins may be found in the urine

Subject: abnormal podocyte polarity
Value: <any anomaly in the establishment or maintenance of podocyte cell polarity; podocytes exhibit polarity along at least two axes: (i) an apical-basal axis perpendicular to the glomerular basement membrane in which the apical and basolateral membrane domains of the podocyte are separated by a boundary created by the intercellular junctions of the foot process and (ii) a second plane parallel to the basement membrane that determines the unique orientation of interdigitating foot processes>

Subject: podocyte hypertrophy
Value: increase in the bulk size of the modified epithelial cell of the visceral layer of the Bowman capsule in the renal corpuscle, due to cell enlargement

Subject: absent xiphoid process
Value: absence of the caudal tip of the sternum

Subject: enlarged uterine horn
Value: increased size of the uterine horn

Subject: enlarged urinary bladder
Value: increased size of the distensible musculomembranous organ that serves to collect and store urine excreted by the kidneys

Subject: absent stomach
Value: absence of the sac-like structure of the digestive canal between the esophagus and the small intestine

Subject: absent penis
Value: absence of organ of copulation and urination in the male

Subject: absent liver
Value: absence of the bile-secreting exocrine gland, which is important for detoxification; for fat, carbohydrate, and protein metabolism; and for glycogen storage

Subject: jejunum atresia
Value: congenital blockage or absence of the lumen of the jejunum

Subject: ileum atresia
Value: congenital blockage or absence of the lumen of the ileum

Subject: absent duodenum
Value: missing portion of the small intestine that extends from the pyloris to the junction with the jejunum

Subject: distended duodenum
Value: an expansion in the volume of the portion of the small intestine that extends from the pyloris to the junction with the jejunum, as by stretching or distention

Subject: enlarged duodenum
Value: increased size of the portion of the small intestine that extends from the pyloris to the junction with the jejunum

Subject: absent diaphragm
Value: absence of the thin musculomebranous barrier that separates the abdominal and thoracic cavities; these muscles often used for breathing control

Subject: absent colon
Value: absence of the portion of the large intestine between the cecum and the rectum

Subject: abnormal circulating lipase level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration of lipase in the blood, in particular the serum; the measurement of serum lipase activity is widely used for the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis

Subject: increased circulating lipase level
Value: elevated blood level of lipase in the blood, in particular the serum

Subject: decreased circulating lipase level
Value: reduced blood level of lipase in the blood, in particular the serum

Subject: abnormal circulating total protein level
Value: total circulating protein concentration is outside the normal range

Subject: abnormal circulating ferritin level
Value: deviation from the normal concentration of ferritin, a ubiquitous intracellular protein that stores iron and releases it in a controlled fashion; some ferritin is also found in the blood and is measured in tests for overall iron levels, anemia and chronic diseases

Subject: increased circulating ferritin level
Value: elevated concentration in the blood of ferritin, a ubiquitous intracellular protein that stores iron and releases it in a controlled fashion; some ferritin is also found in the blood and is measured in tests for overall iron levels, anemia and chronic diseases

Subject: decreased circulating ferritin level
Value: reduced concentration in the blood of ferritin, a ubiquitous intracellular protein that stores iron and releases it in a controlled fashion; some ferritin is also found in the blood and is measured in tests for overall iron levels, anemia and chronic diseases

Subject: abnormal circulating transferrin level
Value: deviation from the normal concentration in the blood of a plasma protein that reversibly binds and transports iron and other metal ions through the blood to the liver, spleen and bone marrow

Subject: increased circulating transferrin level
Value: elevated concentration in the blood of a plasma protein that reversibly binds and transports iron and other metal ions through the blood to the liver, spleen and bone marrow

Subject: decreased circulating transferrin level
Value: reduced concentration in the blood of a plasma protein that reversibly binds and transports iron and other metal ions through the blood to the liver, spleen and bone marrow

Subject: abnormal circulating unsaturated transferrin level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration of transferrin that is not saturated (bound) with iron; this represents the reserve capacity of transferrin and is often measured by the Unsaturated Iron Binding Capacity (UIBC) test

Subject: increased circulating unsaturated transferrin level
Value: increase in the concentration of transferrin that is not saturated (bound) with iron; this represents the reserve capacity of transferrin and is often measured by the Unsaturated Iron Binding Capacity (UIBC) test

Subject: decreased circulating unsaturated transferrin level
Value: reduction in the concentration of transferrin that is not saturated (bound) with iron; this represents the reserve capacity of transferrin and is often measured by the Unsaturated Iron Binding Capacity (UIBC) test

Subject: abnormal platelet cell number
Value: anomaly in the normal numbers of the non-nucleated cells found in the blood and involved in blood coagulation

Subject: podocyte vacuolization
Value: abnormal presence of cavities or fluid-filled vesicles in the cytoplasm of the modified epithelial cell of the visceral layer of the Bowman capsule in the renal corpuscle, often indicative of podocyte injury

Subject: podocyturia
Value: presence of kidney podocytes, their cell fragments, or podocyte-specific proteins in the urine; urinary loss of viable podocytes may serve as a diagnostic tool for pre-eclampsia and as a marker of active renal disease

Subject: abnormal hematopoietic stem cell proliferation
Value: anomaly in the ability of a hematopoietic stem cell population to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: increased hematopoietic stem cell proliferation
Value: increase in the expansion rate of a hematopoietic stem cell population by cell division

Subject: decreased hematopoietic stem cell proliferation
Value: reduction in the expansion rate of a hematopoietic stem cell population by cell division

Subject: abnormal Schwann cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the cells which form the insulating myelin sheaths of peripheral axons

Subject: abnormal Schwann cell proliferation
Value: any anomaly in the ability of a Schwann cell to undergo rapid expansion by cell division

Subject: increased Schwann cell proliferation
Value: increase in the expansion rate of a Schwann cell population by cell division

Subject: decreased Schwann cell proliferation
Value: reduction in the expansion rate of a Schwann cell population by cell division

Subject: abnormal pancreatic endocrine progenitor cell proliferation
Value: anomaly in the ability of a pancreatic endocrine progenitor cell population to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: increased pancreatic endocrine progenitor cell proliferation
Value: increased ability of a pancreatic endocrine progenitor cell population to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: decreased pancreatic endocrine progenitor cell proliferation
Value: reduced ability of a pancreatic endocrine progenitor cell population to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: abnormal pancreatic endocrine progenitor cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of a multi-fate stem cell that is able to differentiate into the pancreas alpha, beta and delta endocrine cells

Subject: abnormal circulating fibronectin level
Value: aberrant concentration in the blood of the glycoprotein that binds to integrins or components of the extracellular matrix; plays a major role in cell adhesion, growth, migration, differentiation, wound healing, and embryonic development

Subject: abnormal reticulocyte cell number
Value: altered number of immature (nucleated) erythrocytes

Subject: decreased heart left atrium weight
Value: less than average weight of the left atrium

Subject: increased heart left atrium weight
Value: more than average weight of the left atrium

Subject: decreased heart right atrium weight
Value: less than average weight of the right atrium

Subject: increased heart right atrium weight
Value: more than average weight of the right atrium

Subject: abnormal PQ interval
Value: anomaly in the length of time between the beginning of atrial depolarization and the end of atrial repolarization (or recovery), measured by the interval from the beginning of the P wave to the end of the Q wave

Subject: abnormal R wave
Value: any anomaly in the R wave which represents ventricular depolarization and corresponds to electrical impulses rather than mechanical ventricular contractions; irregular or multiple R waves may indicate arrhythmia and the shape of the R waves may indicate ventricular problems

Subject: abnormal S wave
Value: any anomaly in the S wave which represents the end of ventricular depolarization and corresponds to an isoelectric state rather than mechanical ventricular relaxation

Subject: abnormal adrenal gland zona intermedia morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the region between the zona glomerulosa and zona fasciculata that is relatively thin and contains mostly undifferentiated cells

Subject: abnormal circulating osteocalcin level
Value: aberrant concentration in the blood of this noncollagenous protein hormone found in bone and dentin, which is secreted by osteoblasts

Subject: abnormal bladder urine volume
Value: any anomaly in the amount of space occupied by urine in the bladder

Subject: abnormal liver zinc level
Value: anomaly in the amount of zinc present in the liver tissue

Subject: abnormal heart echocardiography feature
Value: any anomaly in echocardiographic representation of systolic and diastolic function, ventricular compliance, valvular function, or interventricular septum features

Subject: abnormal heart valve physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the membranous folds of the heart that prevent reflux of fluid

Subject: abnormal cardiac valve flow
Value: any anomaly of the regulated one-way movement of blood through the heart valves

Subject: abnormal mitral valve flow
Value: abnormality of valve function causing passive filling of the left ventricle or active filling of the left atrium

Subject: abnormal aortic valve flow
Value: abnormality impeding normal blood flow or allowing blood to backflow through this valve into the left ventricle

Subject: abnormal tricuspid valve flow
Value: abnormality of valve function causing passive filling of the right ventricle or active filling of the right atrium

Subject: abnormal pulmonary valve flow
Value: abnormality impeding normal blood flow or allowing blood to backflow through this valve into the right ventricle

Subject: abnormal endocrine pancreas development
Value: anomaly in the formation of the smaller portion of the pancreas that secretes a number of hormones into the blood stream that are produced by the cells in the islets of Langerhans

Subject: abnormal exocrine pancreas development
Value: anomaly in the formation of the acinar gland portion of the pancreas that secretes digestive enzymes

Subject: abnormal branching involved in pancreas development
Value: any anomaly in the process in which the branches of the developing pancreas are generated and organized

Subject: abnormal pancreatic bud formation
Value: any anomaly in the process in which the foregut region specified to become the pancreas forms a bud

Subject: abnormal PP interval
Value: any anomaly in the distance between consecutive P waves in the electrocardiogram, representing the length of the cardiac cycle; this value is often used in calculating heart rate and heart rate variability

Subject: shortened PP interval
Value: decrease in the distance between consecutive P waves in the electrocardiogram, representing the length of the cardiac cycle

Subject: prolonged PP interval
Value: increase in the distance between consecutive P waves in the electrocardiogram, representing the length of the cardiac cycle

Subject: increased food intake
Value: increase in the total number of calories/food amount taken in over time when compared to the normal state

Subject: decreased food intake
Value: reduction in the total number of calories or food amount taken in over time when compared to the normal state

Subject: increased fluid intake
Value: increase in the total amount of fluid taken in over time when compared to the normal state

Subject: decreased fluid intake
Value: reduction in the total amount of fluid taken in over time when compared to the normal state

Subject: abnormal circadian feeding behavior
Value: anomaly in the fluctuation pattern in feeding behavior (amount and instances) that occurs over an approximately 24 hour light/dark cycle

Subject: abnormal eating frequency
Value: anomaly in the number of discrete instances of initiation of eating over time, regardless of amount eaten

Subject: increased eating frequency
Value: increase in the number of discrete instances of initiation of eating over time, regardless of amount eaten

Subject: decreased eating frequency
Value: reduction in the number of discrete instances of initiation of eating over time, regardless of amount eaten

Subject: abnormal fluid intake
Value: significant anomaly in the total amount of fluid taken in over time when compared to the normal state

Subject: abnormal drinking frequency
Value: anomaly in the number of discrete instances of initiation of drinking over time, regardless of amount ingested

Subject: increased drinking frequency
Value: increase in the number of discrete instances of initiation of drinking over time, regardless of amount ingested

Subject: decreased drinking frequency
Value: reduction in the number of discrete instances of initiation of drinking over time, regardless of amount ingested

Subject: increased cardiac stroke volume
Value: increase in the volume of blood pushed into the aorta with each beat of the heart

Subject: decreased cardiac stroke volume
Value: reduction in the volume of blood pushed into the aorta with each beat of the heart

Subject: prolonged PQ interval
Value: increase in the length of time between the beginning of atrial depolarization and the end of atrial repolarization (or recovery), measured by the interval from the beginning of the P wave to the end of the Q wave

Subject: shortened PQ interval
Value: decrease in the length of time between the beginning of atrial depolarization and the end of atrial repolarization (or recovery), measured by the interval from the beginning of the P wave to the end of the Q wave

Subject: phenotypic reversion by gene product interaction
Value: two or more mutant gene products, when existing together in one organism, result in a wild-type phenotype when each independent mutation shows a phenotype

Subject: abnormal compensatory feeding amount
Value: anomaly in the amount of food consumed after a period of fasting

Subject: decreased compensatory feeding amount
Value: decreased amount of food consumed after a period of fasting

Subject: increased compensatory feeding amount
Value: increased amount of food consumed after a period of fasting

Subject: abnormal eye posterior chamber depth
Value: anomaly in the distance between the iris and the lens at the center plane (maximum distance) of the posterior chamber, compared to controls

Subject: abnormal eye anterior chamber depth
Value: anomaly in the distance between the iris and the cornea at the center plane (maximum distance) of the anterior chamber, compared to controls

Subject: abnormal cornea thickness
Value: increased or decreased width of the cornea in the center plane

Subject: increased cornea thickness
Value: increased width of the cornea in the center plane

Subject: abnormal total retina thickness
Value: increased or decreased width of the retina through the center plane

Subject: increased total retina thickness
Value: increased width of the retina through the center plane

Subject: decreased total retina thickness
Value: decreased width of the retina through the center plane

Subject: abnormal auditory brainstem response waveform shape
Value: any anomaly in the characteristic pattern of electrical activity recording of a series of vertex positive waves generated by neurons in the ascending auditory system, that can be recorded from scalp electrograms by using computer-averaged responses to short tone bursts

Subject: increased or absent threshold for auditory brainstem response
Value: increase in the value at which one or more sound frequencies or broadband clicks first elicits a recordable response generated by electrical activity of neurons in the ascending auditory system, or complete lack of a recordable response at any frequency or broadband click

Subject: decreased threshold for auditory brainstem response
Value: reduction in the value at which one or more sound frequencies or broadband clicks first elicits a recordable response generated by electrical activity of neurons in the ascending auditory system

Subject: abnormal circulating triglyceride level
Value: abnormal concentration of naturally occurring esters of three fatty acids and glycerol in the blood; triglycerides are widespread in adipose tissue, commonly circulate in the blood in the form of lipoproteins, and are involved in the process of bidirectional transference of adipose fat and blood glucose with the liver

Subject: abnormal circulating lactate dehydrogenase level
Value: abnormal blood level of the tetrameric enzyme that, along with the coenzyme NAD+, catalyzes the interconversion of lactate and pyruvate; measurements of circulating levels are used clinically as a diagnostic indicator of tissue breakdown, some forms of cancer or particular infection types

Subject: increased circulating lactate dehydrogenase level
Value: elevated blood level of the tetrameric enzyme that, along with the coenzyme NAD+, catalyzes the interconversion of lactate and pyruvate; measurements of circulating levels are used clinically as a diagnostic indicator of tissue breakdown, some forms of cancer or particular infection types

Subject: decreased circulating lactate dehydrogenase level
Value: reduced blood level of the tetrameric enzyme that, along with the coenzyme NAD+, catalyzes the interconversion of lactate and pyruvate; measurements of circulating levels are used clinically as a diagnostic indicator of tissue breakdown, some forms of cancer or particular infection types

Subject: abnormal circulating glycerol level
Value: abnormal blood level of trihydroxy sugar alcohols that are precursors for synthesis of triacylglycerols, and of phospholipids and cellular glucose in the liver and adipose tissue; fat catabolism results in the release of glycerol and fatty acids into the bloodstream to be used as an energy source

Subject: intestinal stenosis
Value: abnormal narrowing or constriction of the segment of the alimentary canal extending from the pyloric sphincter of the stomach to the anus

Subject: neuronal cytoplasmic inclusions
Value: presence of aggregates of protein within the cytoplasm of neurons; hallmark of neurodegenerative disorders

Subject: sweet preference
Value: subjects demonstrate predilection for sweet tasting substances over other offered substance

Subject: abnormal sodium ion homeostasis
Value: anomaly in the processes involved in the maintenance of an internal equilibrium of sodium ions within the body or between a cell and its external environment

Subject: abnormal potassium ion homeostasis
Value: anomaly in the processes involved in the maintenance of an internal equilibrium of potassium ions within the body or between a cell and its external environment

Subject: abnormal magnesium ion homeostasis
Value: anomaly in the processes involved in the maintenance of an internal equilibrium of magnesium ions within the body or between a cell and its external environment

Subject: absent Langerhans cell precursors
Value: absence of the yolk sac-derived primitive myeloid progenitors that populate the skin before the onset of fetal liver hematopoiesis

Subject: abnormal microglial cell differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce the small, migratory, phagocytic, interstitial cells derived from myeloid progenitor cells and found in the parenchyma of the central nervous system

Subject: decreased microglial cell number
Value: reduced number of the small, migratory, phagocytic, interstitial cells derived from myeloid progenitor cells and found in the parenchyma of the central nervous system

Subject: abnormal Ito cell differentiation
Value: atypical production of or inability to produce the fat-storing cells that line the hepatic sinusoids

Subject: decreased enteroendocrine cell number
Value: reduction in the number of the various hormone- or neurotransmitter-secreting epithelial cells present throughout the mucosa of the digestive tract

Subject: abnormal macrophage proliferation
Value: anomaly in the ability of macrophages to undergo expansion by cell division; macrophages are large mononuclear phagocytes which differentiate from monocytes, are typically resident in a particular tissue, and capable of phagocytosing a variety of extracellular particulate material, including immune complexes, microorganisms, and dead cells

Subject: decreased macrophage proliferation
Value: reduced ability of macrophages to undergo expansion by cell division; macrophages are large mononuclear phagocytes which differentiate from monocytes, are typically resident in a particular tissue, and capable of phagocytosing a variety of extracellular particulate material, including immune complexes, microorganisms, and dead cells

Subject: abnormal GABAergic neuron physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the neurons that utilize gamma-aminobutyric acid as a neurotransmitter

Subject: increased mating frequency
Value: increased number of attempts of sexual behavioral contact between an initiating organism and a receptive partner

Subject: abnormal porphyrin level
Value: aberrant concentration of porphyrins or protoporphyrins

Subject: decreased porphyrin level
Value: reduced concentration of porphyrins or protoporphyrins

Subject: aortic cartilaginous metaplasia
Value: transformation of cells comprising the aorta epithelium to arterial chondrocytes that express type II collagen, resulting in heterotopic formation of cartilage and may lead to calcification in the aorta

Subject: increased erythrocyte catalase activity
Value: <greater capacity to catalyze the reaction: 2 hydrogen peroxide = O2 + 2 H2O, in erythorcytes>

Subject: increased foot pad temperature
Value: increased degree of heat natural to the foot pad-environment interface of a living being

Subject: increased nerve conduction velocity
Value: increase in the rate at which an electrical impulse travels through a nerve

Subject: decreased leukemia incidence
Value: less than the expected number of neoplasms derived from blood or bone marrow in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: abnormal retinal inner nuclear layer thickness
Value: anomaly in the thickness of the retinal layer that contains the cell bodies of bipolar, horizontal, and amacrine cells

Subject: abnormal retinal outer nuclear layer thickness
Value: anomaly in the thickness of the retinal layer that contains the nuclei and cell bodies of rods and cones

Subject: decreased embryonic cilium length
Value: reduced length of the cilia of the mouse embryo found on the cells of the embryonic node

Subject: abnormal tail length
Value: any anomaly in the length of tail relative to average of a given reference population

Subject: abnormal limb position
Value: anomaly in the location or orientation of the limbs on the body relative to other body parts or axes

Subject: abnormal touch escape response
Value: anomaly in the ability of an animal to respond to the approach of a human hand by fleeing from it

Subject: impaired touch escape response
Value: impaired ability of an animal to respond to the approach of a human hand by fleeing from it, including fleeing only after a touch or stroke, or not responding to touch by fleeing

Subject: abnormal septum of telencephalon morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the gray matter structures of the telencephalon and limbic system in the brain; included is the cortical septal area, subcortical septal nuclei, and the septum pellucidum; however, many authorities consider the septal region to be made up of the septal area and the septal nuclei, but excluding the septum pellucidum

Subject: abnormal septum pellucidum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thin, triangular, vertical membrane separating the anterior horns of the left and right lateral ventricles of the septum, which has strong projections to hypothalamic and midbrain regions and receives projections from the hippocampus and amygdala

Subject: abnormal septum pellucidum size
Value: anomaly in the size of the thin, triangular, vertical membrane separating the anterior horns of the left and righ of the septum, which has strong projections to hypothalamic and midbrain regions and receives projections from the hippocampus and amygdala

Subject: abnormal hippocampus physiology
Value: any functional anomaly related to processes in the deep lying structure of the cerebrum involved with memory storage and spatial navigation

Subject: abnormal chloride level
Value: any change in the amount of chloride, the major extracellular anion in mammals; it plays roles in tissue fluid homeostasis and also helps maintain proper blood volume, blood pressure, and body fluid pH

Subject: delayed parturition
Value: the process of labor and delivery in female animals occurs later in gestation than expected or lack of progress in a labor already initiated

Subject: early parturition
Value: the process of labor and delivery in female animals occurs earlier in gestation than expected

Subject: parturition failure
Value: the process of labor and delivery in female animals does not initiate or complete

Subject: febrile seizures
Value: a convulsion associated with a significant rise in body temperature (fever)

Subject: abnormal innate olfactory avoidance response
Value: any anomaly in the naive behavioral response of an individual to an aversive olfactory stimulus, in which the tendency to act defensively is stronger than the tendency to attack

Subject: abnormal innate avoidance response
Value: any anomaly in the naive behavioral response of an individual to an aversive stimulus, in which the tendency to act defensively is stronger than the tendency to attack

Subject: abnormal olfactory neuron innervation pattern
Value: any changes in the placement, morphology or number of axons from olfactory neurons to an effector tissue or to olfactory glomeruli or olfactory bulb

Subject: abnormal eumelanosome eumelanin content
Value: anomaly in the amount or distribution of black (or brown) pigment in the eumelanosomes of melanocytes

Subject: abnormal hair follicle eumelanosome eumelanin content
Value: anomaly in the amount or distribution of black (or brown) pigment in the eumelanosomes of the hair follicle melanocytes

Subject: grizzled coat color
Value: amount and distribution of yellow pigment (phaeomelanin) relative to black or brown pigment (eumelanin) is decreased compared to wild-type agouti producing hair that is partly gray or streaked with gray

Subject: abnormal oviduct physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the tube through which the ova pass from the ovary to the uterus

Subject: abnormal oviduct epithelium motile cilium physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the multiple epithelial tiny, motile hair-like projections, which have a variable arrangement of axonemal microtubules, contains molecular motors, and beat with a characteristic whip-like pattern that promote transport of fluids and other cells across the epithelium of the oviduct

Subject: abnormal olfactory epithelium physiology
Value: any functional anomaly in the epithelial cells that line the interior of the nose

Subject: abnormal melanocyte number
Value: deviation from the average number of the cells that produce pigment

Subject: increased melanocyte number
Value: greater number of the cells that produce pigment

Subject: decreased melanocyte number
Value: reduced number of the cells that produce pigment

Subject: abnormal nephron morphogenesis
Value: any anomaly in the process in which the nephron is generated and organized; the nephron is the filtering unit of the kidney that includes the renal corpuscle, proximal and distal convoluted tubules, and loop of Henle

Subject: abnormal comma shaped body morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of precursor structure to the S-shaped body that contributes to the morphogenesis of the nephron

Subject: abnormal S-shaped body morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the successor of the comma-shaped body that contributes to the morphogenesis of the nephron

Subject: abnormal embryonic cilium location or orientation
Value: embryonic cilia are displaced from the normal position and/or do not orient in a typical pattern

Subject: abnormal visceral endoderm physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the primitive endoderm-derived tissue which remains in contact with and surrounds the extra-embryonic ectoderm and the epiblast and provides signals for the differentiation and patterning of the epiblast; a small number of visceral endoderm cells also contribute to the endoderm of the embryonic gut

Subject: abnormal electroretinogram waveform feature
Value: any anomaly in the pattern of the graphic record of the integrated ensemble response from many vision related neuronal and glial populations as a consequence of the serial processing within the retina, represented as changes in voltage over time after visual photonic stimulation

Subject: abnormal a wave amplitude
Value: anomaly in the size (height or maximum displacement) of the a wave as measured in the electroretinogram

Subject: abnormal b wave amplitude
Value: anomaly in the size (height or maximum displacement) of the b wave as measured in the electroretinogram

Subject: abnormal ERG latency
Value: anomaly in the time from onset of stimulus to beginning of a waveform feature

Subject: abnormal ERG implicit time
Value: anomaly in the time from the onset of light stimulus to the peak of a waveform feature

Subject: abnormal a wave shape
Value: any anomaly in the graphical representation of the a wave in the electroretinogram; the a wave represents the general physiological health of the photoreceptors in the outer retina

Subject: abnormal b-wave shape
Value: any anomaly in the graphical representation of the b wave in the electroretinogram; the b wave represents the health of the inner layers of the retina, including the ON bipolar cells and the Muller cells

Subject: abnormal a wave latency
Value: anomaly in the time from onset of stimulus to beginning of the a wave

Subject: abnormal b wave latency
Value: anomaly in the time from onset of stimulus to beginning of the b wave

Subject: abnormal a wave implicit time
Value: anomaly in the time from the onset of light stimulus to the peak of the a wave

Subject: abnormal b wave implicit time
Value: anomaly in the time from the onset of light stimulus to the peak of the b wave

Subject: abnormal c wave shape
Value: any anomaly in the graphical representation of the c wave in the electroretinogram; the ERG c-wave can be used to assess the functional integrity of the photoreceptors, the pigment epithelial cells and the interactions between them.

Subject: increased susceptibility to pulmonary hyaline membrane formation
Value: increased likelihood of the presence of an eosinophilic hyaline (glass-like) material composed of fibrin, proteinaceous exudate and cellular debris, and lining or filling the alveoli, alveolar ducts and bronchioles

Subject: low alcohol preference
Value: decreased predilection to ingest alcohol over other substances

Subject: increased myoepithelioma incidence
Value: greater than the expected occurrence of a benign tumor of myoepithelial cells, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: abnormal phospholipase A2 level
Value: anomaly in the amount of any of the enzymes that release fatty acids from the second carbon group of glycerol

Subject: increased susceptibility to hypertension
Value: more likely than normal to develop sustained high blood pressure at a level that is likely to result in cardiovascular disease and/or other pathological states

Subject: decreased susceptibility to hypertension
Value: less likely than normal to develop sustained high blood pressure at a level that is likely to result in cardiovascular disease and/or other pathological states

Subject: abnormal cholinesterase level
Value: anomaly in the amount of any of the enzymes that catalyze the hydrolysis of the neurotransmitter acetylcholine into choline and acetic acid

Subject: altered response to retinal ischemic injury
Value: altered response to lack of adequate blood flow, due to trauma or disease, to support the normal functioning of the retina

Subject: increased susceptilbility to retinal ischemic injury
Value: increased frequency or more severe response, such as necrotic tissue size, to lack of adequate blood flow, due to trauma or disease, to support the normal functioning of the retina

Subject: decreased susceptilbility to retinal ischemic injury
Value: decreased frequency or less severe response, such as necrotic tissue size, to lack of adequate blood flow, due to trauma or disease, to support the normal functioning of the retina

Subject: spasticity
Value: a motor disorder characterized by a velocity-dependent increase in tonic stretch reflexes with increased muscle tone, exaggerated (hyperexcitable) tendon reflexes and increased resistance to stretch

Subject: hypertonicity
Value: abnormally increased muscle tone or strength that impairs proper movement

Subject: limb hypertonicity
Value: limbs exhibit abnormally increased muscle tone; can be due to muscle genetic defects or some CNS disorders and may be evident in arm or leg deformities

Subject: abnormal phrenic nerve innervation pattern
Value: any changes in the placement, morphology or number of phrenic nerve fibers providing motor supply to the diaphragm as well as sensory fibers to the central tendon, or in the thorax, phrenic nerve sensory fibers to the mediastinal pleura and pericardium

Subject: abnormal phrenic nerve innervation pattern to diaphragm
Value: any changes in the placement, morphology or number of the portion of phrenic nerve fibers providing motor supply to the diaphragm

Subject: abnormal polar trophectoderm morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the trophectoderm portion that surrounds the inner cell mass (ICM); unlike mural trophectoderm cells which stop proliferating and become large polyploid cells (the primary trophoblastic giant cells) by endoreduplication, polar trophectoderm cells remain diploid, continue to proliferate and give rise to both the ectoplacental cone and the extraembryonic ectoderm

Subject: abnormal mural trophectoderm morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the trophectoderm portion distal to the ICM that overlays the blastocyst cavity and gives rise to polyploid trophoblast giant cells

Subject: abnormal morula morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the globular solid mass of blastomeres formed by cleavage of a zygote that typically precedes the blastula, typically after the zygote has divided into 32 cells

Subject: thick diaphragm muscle
Value: increased thickness of the diaphragm muscle

Subject: abnormal diaphragm central tendon morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the three-lobed cloverleaf-shaped aponeurosis situated at the center of the diaphragm; the central tendon is fused with the fibrous pericardium that provides attachment for the muscle fibers

Subject: small tail bud
Value: decreased size or area of the primordial region of the embryo that arises to form the tail of the adult

Subject: absent tail bud
Value: missing the primordial region of the embryo that arises to form the tail of the adult

Subject: abnormal astrocyte number
Value: anomaly in the number of the large neuroglial (macroglial) cells in the central nervous system - the largest and most numerous neuroglial cells in the brain and spinal cord

Subject: increased astrocyte number
Value: increase in the number of the large neuroglial (macroglial) cells in the central nervous system - the largest and most numerous neuroglial cells in the brain and spinal cord

Subject: decreased astrocyte number
Value: reduction in the number of the large neuroglial (macroglial) cells in the central nervous system - the largest and most numerous neuroglial cells in the brain and spinal cord

Subject: abnormal olfactory gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the Bowman's glands (aka glands of Bowman, olfactory glands), situated in the olfactory mucosa, beneath the olfactory epithelium, in the lamina propria, a connective tissue also containing fibroblasts, blood vessels, and bundles of fine axons from the olfactory neurons; Bowman's glands consists of an acinus in the lamina propria and a secretory duct going out through the olfactory epithelium

Subject: abnormal globose cell of olfactory epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the rounded or elliptical epithelial cells, with pale-staining open face nucleus and pale cytoplasm rich in free ribosomes and clusters of centrioles, that form a distinct basal zone spaced slightly from the basal surface of the olfactory epithelium

Subject: abnormal horizontal basal cell of olfactory epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the flat or angular epithelial cell with condensed nuclei and darkly staining cytoplasm containing numerous intermediate filaments inserted into desmosomes contacting surrounding supporting cells, that lie in contact with the basal lamina of olfactory epithelium

Subject: altered susceptibility to osteoporosis
Value: a change in the likelihood that an organism will develop a reduction in bone mass or atrophy of skeletal tissue, usually accompanied by gross changes to bone matrix, leading to bone fragility

Subject: increased susceptibility to osteoporosis
Value: greater likelihood that an organism will develop a reduction in bone mass or atrophy of skeletal tissue, usually accompanied by gross changes to bone matrix, leading to bone fragility

Subject: decreased susceptibility to osteoporosis
Value: reduced likelihood that an organism will develop a reduction in bone mass or atrophy of skeletal tissue, usually accompanied by gross changes to bone matrix, leading to bone fragility

Subject: premature mammary gland growth during pregnancy
Value: faster progression of the extensive and rapid branching of the mammary ducts, expansion of mammary epithelium in the stroma between the ducts with or without abnormalities in nipple maturation in preparation for lactation

Subject: failure of mammary gland growth during pregnancy
Value: arrest, or failure ti initiate the extensive and rapid branching of the mammary ducts, expansion of mammary epithelium in the stroma between the ducts with or without abnormalities in nipple maturation in preparation for lactation

Subject: impaired mammary gland growth during pregnancy
Value: defect in the extensive and rapid branching of the mammary ducts, expansion of mammary epithelium in the stroma between the ducts with or without abnormalities in nipple maturation in preparation for lactation

Subject: abnormal agouti pigmentation
Value: amount and distribution of yellow pigment (phaeomelanin) relative to black or brown pigment (eumelanin) is variably increased or decreased compared with a wild-type agouti pattern resulting in a range of coat color from yellow to almost black

Subject: webbed neck
Value: the skin on the neck appears as loose folds that develop a web-like appearance from the ears to the shoulder during growth and maturation

Subject: abnormal tail ring morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the segmentally patterned skin ridges appearing on the tail of rodents

Subject: abnormal spinal reflex
Value: any anomaly in the reflexive action mediated by cells of the spinal cord, or the involuntary movement reaction caused by the application of a stimulus to an organism; these include signals originating from heat from burning, sharp sensations, and other painful feelings

Subject: chylous ascites
Value: the extravasation of milky triglyceride-rich chyle into the peritoneal cavity; often a secondary symptom of neoplasms

Subject: absent heart tube
Value: absence of the primitive epithelial cardiac tube before the division into the chambers of the mature heart

Subject: delayed heart development
Value: late onset of the induction and/or differentiation of the heart

Subject: absent foregut
Value: absence of the anterior portion of the primitive digestive tube of the embryo that lies cephalic to the junction of the yolk stalk, consists of endodermal tissue, and gives rise to the pharynx, lower respiratory system, esophagus, stomach, duodenum proximal to the biliary tract, liver, pancreas, biliary tract, and gall bladder

Subject: truncated foregut
Value: shortened foregut that terminates abruptly as if having an end or point cut off

Subject: midface hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment of the midfacial region comprising the nasal, maxillary, and zygomatic bones, leading to a concave-looking face

Subject: absent hindgut
Value: absence of the caudal portion of the primitive digestive tube of the embryo

Subject: absent midbrain
Value: absence of the brain region derived from the middle of the three cerebral vesicles of the embryo; this region controls sensory and motor functions in the adult, including eye movement and coordination of auditory and visual reflexes

Subject: abnormal midbrain size
Value: deviation from the average range of midbrain size compared to normal

Subject: decreased midbrain size
Value: size reduction or truncation of the brain region derived from the middle of the three cerebral vesicles of the embryo; this region controls sensory and motor functions in the adult, including eye movement and coordination of auditory and visual reflexes

Subject: midbrain hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the brain region derived from the middle of the three cerebral vesicles of the embryo; this region controls sensory and motor functions in the adult, including eye movement and coordination of auditory and visual reflexes

Subject: increased midbrain size
Value: greater than average size of the brain region derived from the middle of the three cerebral vesicles of the embryo; this region controls sensory and motor functions in the adult, including eye movement and coordination of auditory and visual reflexes

Subject: diencephalon hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or decreased size, usually due an increased number of cells in the rostral portion of the brain stem

Subject: absent nodal flow
Value: absence of the leftward movement of extra-embryonic fluid at the ventral node; nodal flow is autonomously generated by the rotation of cilia that are tilted toward the posterior on cells of the ventral node and is the central process in symmetry breaking on the left-right axis; when nodal cilia are immotile or absent, nodal flow does not occur

Subject: abnormal Reichert's membrane thickness
Value: anomaly in the width of the extraembryonic basement membrane that forms on the inner surface of the trophectoderm during placenta morphogenesis and is secreted by the distal parietal endoderm

Subject: increased Reichert's membrane thickness
Value: increased width of the extraembryonic basement membrane that forms on the inner surface of the trophectoderm during placenta morphogenesis and is secreted by the distal parietal endoderm

Subject: decreased Reichert's membrane thickness
Value: reduced width of the extraembryonic basement membrane that forms on the inner surface of the trophectoderm during placenta morphogenesis and is secreted by the distal parietal endoderm

Subject: abnormal spongiotrophoblast size
Value: anomaly in the size of the middle layer of the placenta between the outermost giant cells and the innermost labyrinth layer; it has a structural role and also produces several layer-specific secreted factors

Subject: increased spongiotrophoblast size
Value: greater size of the middle layer of the placenta between the outermost giant cells and the innermost labyrinth layer; it has a structural role and also produces several layer-specific secreted factors

Subject: decreased spongiotrophoblast size
Value: reduction of the size of the middle layer of the placenta between the outermost giant cells and the innermost labyrinth layer; it has a structural role and also produces several layer-specific secreted factors

Subject: absent spongiotrophoblast
Value: absence of the middle layer of the placenta between the outermost giant cells and the innermost labyrinth layer; it has a structural role and also produces several layer-specific secreted factors

Subject: acoria
Value: absence of the pupil of the eye

Subject: absent trophectoderm
Value: absence of the outermost layer of cells in the blastodermic vesicle, which will develop into the trophoblast layer and then contact the endometrium and take part in establishing the embryo's means of nutrition

Subject: abnormal bilaminar embryonic disk morphology
Value: <any structural anomaly of the flattened, almost circular bilaminar plate of cells formed when the inner cell mass (aka embryoblast) forms two epithelial layers, each of a distinct lineage, separated by an extracellular basement membrane: the external (dorsal) layer is called the epiblast and the internal (ventral) layer is called the hypoblast (aka primitive endoderm); together, they compose the bilaminar embryonic disc>

Subject: small amniotic cavity
Value: reduced size of the closed space between the embryo and the amnion which contains the amniotic fluid and is formed by the fusion of the parts of the anterior and posterior amniotic folds

Subject: delayed gastrulation
Value: late onset of the development and invagination of the embryonic germ layers

Subject: impaired exercise endurance
Value: impaired performance during controlled physical activity

Subject: enhanced exercise endurance
Value: improved performance during controlled physical activity

Subject: increased trophoblast glycogen cell number
Value: greater number of the glycogen-accumulating trophoblast cells that arise in the junctional zone of the placenta

Subject: decreased trophoblast glycogen cell number
Value: reduced number of the glycogen-accumulating trophoblast cells that arise in the junctional zone of the placenta

Subject: increased hair follicle number
Value: greater number of the epidermal invaginations from which the hair shaft develops

Subject: failure of morula compaction
Value: inability to initiate or maintain the first cell differentiation event in mammalian development, occurring at the late eight-cell stage in the mouse, whereby cells on the outer part of the morula become flattened and bound tightly together with the formation of desmosomes and gap junctions, becoming nearly indistinguishable

Subject: increased inner cell mass proliferation
Value: enhanced expansion rate of the inner cell mass

Subject: decreased inner cell mass proliferation
Value: reduced expansion rate of the inner cell mass

Subject: absent inner cell mass proliferation
Value: absence of expansion of the inner cell mass

Subject: increased trophectoderm apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of trophectoderm cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: trophectoderm cell degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of trophectoderm cells

Subject: sclerocornea
Value: a congenital anomaly of the eye in which partial or complete corneal opacity is present and resembles the sclera, with no clear boundary between these structures

Subject: abnormal iris transillumination
Value: any anomaly in the radial light dispersion pattern of the iris when a focused light beam is passed through it; particular dispersion pattern anomalies are indicative of abnormalities in iris pigment distribution and for the presence of glaucoma, atrophy and/or infection

Subject: abnormal bronchoconstrictive response
Value: anomaly in the expected bronchoconstrictive response to provocation challenge with lipopolysaccharide, bradykinin, histamine or other antigen/allergen or agent, often measured by plethysmography

Subject: increased bronchoconstrictive response
Value: enhanced or greater than expected bronchoconstrictive response to provocation challenge with lipopolysaccharide, bradykinin, histamine or other antigen/allergen or agent, often measured by plethysmography

Subject: decreased bronchoconstrictive response
Value: reduction in the expected bronchoconstrictive response to provocation challenge with lipopolysaccharide, bradykinin, histamine or other antigen/allergen or agent, often measured by plethysmography

Subject: abnormal placenta hemotrichorial membrane morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the three trophoblast cell layers found in rodent placentas between fetal blood vessels and maternal blood sinuses

Subject: absent placenta hemotrichorial membrane
Value: absence of the three trophoblast cell layers found in rodent placentas between fetal blood vessels and maternal blood sinuses

Subject: abnormal blastocyst formation
Value: atypical formation of a blastocyst from a solid ball of cells known as a morula, including anomalies in the formation of a fluid-filled cavity (blastocoele) and/or initiation of inner cell mass and trophectoderm differentiation

Subject: failure of blastocyst formation
Value: inability to form a blastocyst from a solid ball of cells known as a morula

Subject: abnormal morula formation
Value: atypical formation of the spherical embryonic mass of blastomeres formed before the blastula and resulting from cleavage of the fertilized ovum

Subject: small visceral yolk sac
Value: reduced size of the extraembryonic tissue membrane, formed from the visceral endoderm and the extraembryonic mesoderm, which is located ventral to the embryonic disc and is connected to the presumptive midgut of the embryo

Subject: abnormal midbrain-hindbrain boundary morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the midbrain-hindbrain domain of the embryonic brain that is comprised of the mesencephalic vesicle and the first rhombencephalic vesicle at early somitogenesis stages; normally, an organizing center located at the boundary patterns the midbrain and hindbrain primordia of the neural plate

Subject: absent midbrain-hindbrain boundary
Value: absence of the midbrain-hindbrain domain of the embryonic brain that is comprised of the mesencephalic vesicle and the first rhombencephalic vesicle at early somitogenesis stages; normally, an organizing center located at the boundary patterns the midbrain and hindbrain primordia of the neural plate

Subject: absent umbilical cord
Value: absence of or failure to form the connective stalk between the fetus and the placenta

Subject: embryonic-extraembryonic boundary constriction
Value: an invagination or pinching in the visceral endoderm that is centered at the boundary between embryonic and extra-embryonic regions of the developing embryo, often resulting in physical separation of embryonic and extraembryonic ectoderm

Subject: absent forebrain
Value: absence of the anterior of the three primary divisions of the developing chordate brain or the corresponding part of the adult brain (in vertebrates, includes especially the cerebral hemispheres, the thalamus, and the hypothalamus and especially in higher vertebrates is the main control center for sensory and associative information processing, visceral functions, and voluntary motor functions)

Subject: abnormal forebrain size
Value: deviation from the average range of forebrain size compared to normal

Subject: decreased forebrain size
Value: size reduction or truncation of the anterior of the three primary divisions of the developing chordate brain or the corresponding part of the adult brain (in vertebrates, includes especially the cerebral hemispheres, the thalamus, and the hypothalamus and especially in higher vertebrates is the main control center for sensory and associative information processing, visceral functions, and voluntary motor functions)

Subject: increased forebrain size
Value: greater than average size of the anterior of the three primary divisions of the developing chordate brain or the corresponding part of the adult brain (in vertebrates, includes especially the cerebral hemispheres, the thalamus, and the hypothalamus and especially in higher vertebrates is the main control center for sensory and associative information processing, visceral functions, and voluntary motor functions)

Subject: forebrain hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due to a increased number of cells, of the anterior of the three primary divisions of the developing chordate brain or the corresponding part of the adult brain (in vertebrates, includes especially the cerebral hemispheres, the thalamus, and the hypothalamus and especially in higher vertebrates is the main control center for sensory and associative information processing, visceral functions, and voluntary motor functions)

Subject: absent hindbrain
Value: absence of the part of the brain developed from the posterior of the three primary brain vesicles of the embryonic neural tube from which the metencephalon and myelencephalon are derived; the metencephalon (anterior part of the embryonic hindbrain), gives rise to the cerebellum and pons while the myelencephalon (posterior portion of the embryonic hindbrain) gives rise to the medulla oblongata

Subject: absent amniotic cavity
Value: absence of the closed space between the embryo and the amnion which contains the amniotic fluid and is formed by the fusion of the parts of the anterior and posterior amniotic folds

Subject: decreased a wave amplitude
Value: reduction in the size (height or maximum displacement) of the a wave as measured in the electroretinogram

Subject: decreased b wave amplitude
Value: reduction in the size (height or maximum displacement) of the b wave as measured in the electroretinogram

Subject: increased a wave amplitude
Value: increase in the size (height or maximum displacement) of the a wave as measured in the electroretinogram

Subject: increased b wave amplitude
Value: increase in the size (height or maximum displacement) of the b wave as measured in the electroretinogram

Subject: increased a wave implicit time
Value: increase in the time from the onset of light stimulus to the peak of the a wave

Subject: decreased a wave implicit time
Value: decrease in the time from the onset of light stimulus to the peak of the a wave

Subject: decreased b wave implicit time
Value: decrease in the time from the onset of light stimulus to the peak of the b wave

Subject: increased b wave implicit time
Value: increase in the time from the onset of light stimulus to the peak of the b wave

Subject: increased a wave latency
Value: increase in the time from onset of stimulus to beginning of the a wave

Subject: decreased a wave latency
Value: decrease in the time from onset of stimulus to beginning of the a wave

Subject: increased b wave latency
Value: increase in the time from onset of stimulus to beginning of the b wave

Subject: decreased b wave latency
Value: decrease in the time from onset of stimulus to beginning of the b wave

Subject: abnormal optic pit morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of either of the two pits that appear bilaterally in the region destined to become the forebrain as the cranial neural folds fuse; these optic pits or sulci continue to deepen laterally and bulge from the two sides of the forebrain to become the optic vesicles

Subject: rostral-caudal axis duplication
Value: partial or complete duplication of rostral-caudal axis structures

Subject: rostral body truncation
Value: rostral part of body truncated; typically with the caudal portion of the body relatively normal

Subject: absent visceral endoderm
Value: absence of the primitive endoderm-derived tissue which remains in contact with and surrounds the extra-embryonic ectoderm and the epiblast and provides signals for the differentiation and patterning of the epiblast; a small number of visceral endoderm cells also contribute to the endoderm of the embryonic gut

Subject: absent anterior visceral endoderm
Value: absence of the extraembryonic tissue that is responsible for the proper orientation of the anterior-posterior axis of the embryo and for appropriate patterning of adjacent embryonic tissue

Subject: expanded anterior visceral endoderm
Value: the extraembryonic tissue that is responsible for the proper orientation of the anterior-posterior axis of the embryo and for appropriate patterning of adjacent embryonic tissue occupies a greater area in the extraembryonic region

Subject: absent distal visceral endoderm
Value: absence of the precursors of the anterior visceral endoderm that arises at the distal tip of the embryo

Subject: absent parietal endoderm
Value: absence of the primitive endoderm-derived tissue that lines the luminal surface of the mural trophectoderm

Subject: abnormal dental mesenchyme morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the mesenchyme enclosed by dental organ

Subject: abnormal conjunctiva goblet cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a goblet cell that is part of the epithelium of the conjunctiva, and is the source of tear mucins which are secreted from it

Subject: absent neural folds
Value: absence of the elevated margins of the neural groove

Subject: absent neural plate
Value: absence of the flat, thickened layer of ectodermal cells in the neuroectodermal area of the embryo's dorsal surface that develops into the neural tube and neural crest

Subject: abnormal epigenetic regulation of gene expression
Value: any anomaly in the process that modulates the frequency, rate or extent of gene expression, in which the process is mitotically or meiotically heritable, or is stably self-propagated in the cytoplasm of a resting cell, and does not entail a change in DNA sequence

Subject: abnormal optic placode morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the paired thickenings of surface ectoderm that become invaginated to form the embryonic lens vesicles

Subject: optic placode degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of the paired thickenings of surface ectoderm that normally become invaginated to form the embryonic lens vesicles

Subject: absent optic placodes
Value: absence of the paired thickenings of surface ectoderm that normally become invaginated to form the embryonic lens vesicles

Subject: oligohydramnios
Value: presence of an abnormally low amniotic fluid volume in the amniotic sac; the opposite of polyhydramnios

Subject: abnormal amniotic fluid composition
Value: any alteration in the expected chemical makeup of the watery liquid within the amnion that surrounds and cushions a growing fetus; normally, early in gestation, amniotic fluid is similar to maternal plasma, mainly water with electrolytes, and later in gestation, proteins, carbohydrates, lipids, phospholipids originating from the lungs, fetal cells, and urea are deposited in the fluid

Subject: short rostral-caudal axis
Value: length reduction or truncation of the axis that runs from the head to the tail of the body

Subject: flat head
Value: the appearance of a flattened surface outline or contour of a normally rounded head of an organism

Subject: flat face
Value: the appearance of a flattened surface outline or contour of a normally rounded face of an organism

Subject: abnormal head development
Value: anomaly in the process in which the anatomical structures of the head are generated and organized

Subject: delayed head development
Value: late onset of the induction and/or differentiation of the head

Subject: absent frontonasal prominence
Value: absence of the unpaired embryonic prominence that is formed by the tissues surrounding the forebrain vesicle and develops into the forehead and bridge of the nose/snout

Subject: abnormal splanchnic mesoderm morphology
