Value: any structural abnormality of the inner layer of lateral plate mesoderm, located above (dorsally) the endoderm, which forms the circulatory system and future gut wall

Subject: abnormal somatic mesoderm morphology
Value: any structural abnormality of the outer layer of lateral plate mesoderm, located under (ventrally) the ectoderm, which forms the future body wall

Subject: increased somite number
Value: increase in the average number of somites formed relative to littermates or other controls

Subject: abnormal presomitic mesoderm morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the unsegmented field of paraxial mesoderm present posterior to the most recently formed somite pair, from which somites will form

Subject: decreased paraxial mesoderm size
Value: reduced size or deficiency of the mesoderm lying at either side of the midline embryonic notochord that, on segmentation, forms the paired somites

Subject: absent paraxial mesoderm
Value: absence or loss of the mesoderm normally found at either side of the midline embryonic notochord that, on segmentation, forms the paired somites.

Subject: abnormal muscle precursor cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of cells that will develop into muscle cells

Subject: abnormal muscle precursor cell physiology
Value: anomaly in the function of cells that will develop into muscle cells

Subject: abnormal intraembryonic coelom morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the part of the coelom in the embryo between the somatopleuric and splanchnopleuric mesoderm; the principal body cavities of the trunk (thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic) arise from this embryonic part of the coelom

Subject: increased regulatory T cell apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of regulatory T cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: decreased regulatory T cell apoptosis
Value: decrease in the number of regulatory T cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: increased cytotoxic T cell apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of cytotoxic T cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: decreased cytotoxic T cell apoptosis
Value: decrease in the number of cytotoxic T cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal keratinocyte migration
Value: anomaly in the movement of keratinocyes or their precursors to the appropriate location in the body

Subject: increased keratinocyte migration
Value: increased or faster movement of keratinocyes or their precursors to the appropriate location in the body

Subject: decreased keratinocyte migration
Value: reduced or slower movement of keratinocyes or their precursors to the appropriate location in the body

Subject: impaired neural crest cell differentiation
Value: abnormal or arrest of differentiation of the transient and highly migratory group of cells that delaminate in early embryonic development from the dorsal neural tube and give rise to a variety of differentiated cell types

Subject: abnormal myofibroblast differentiation
Value: anomaly in the process in which a relatively unspecialized cell acquires specialized features of a myofibroblast, a cell that has characteristics of both a fibroblast cell and a smooth muscle cell and is reportedly capable of secreting IL-1beta, IL-6, and TNF-alpha

Subject: impaired myofibroblast differentiation
Value: reduced ability or inability to produce myofibroblasts, cells that have characteristics of both a fibroblast cell and a smooth muscle cell and are reportedly capable of secreting IL-1beta, IL-6, and TNF-alpha

Subject: absent interphalangeal joint
Value: absence of a hinge joint(s) that connects one phalanx to another along a proximodistal axis

Subject: abnormal interphalangeal joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a hinge joint that connects one phalanx to another along a proximodistal axis

Subject: increased endothelial cell proliferation
Value: greater expansion rate of a endothelial cell population by cell division

Subject: decreased endothelial cell proliferation
Value: reduction in the expansion rate of a endothelial cell population by cell division

Subject: abnormal endothelial cell proliferation
Value: anomaly in the ability of an endothelial cell population to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: abnormal neuronal stem cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of an undifferentiated cell that originates from the neuroectoderm and has the capacity both to perpetually self-renew without differentiating and to generate multiple types of lineage-restricted progenitors

Subject: abnormal neuronal stem cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of an undifferentiated cell that originates from the neuroectoderm and has the capacity both to perpetually self-renew without differentiating and to generate multiple types of lineage-restricted progenitors

Subject: abnormal neuronal stem cell self-renewal
Value: any anomaly in the process by which stem cells divide and proliferate to make more stem cells, perpetuating the stem cell pool; self-renewal is division with maintenance of the undifferentiated state

Subject: increased neuronal stem cell self-renewal
Value: an increased rate in the process by which stem cells divide and proliferate to make more stem cells, perpetuating an increase in the stem cell pool; self-renewal is division with maintenance of the undifferentiated state

Subject: decreased neuronal stem cell self-renewal
Value: an decreased rate in the process by which stem cells divide and proliferate to make more stem cells, perpetuating an decrease in the stem cell pool; self-renewal is division with maintenance of the undifferentiated state

Subject: abnormal hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase level
Value: altered level of the enzyme that catalyzes conversion of hypoxanthine to inosine monophosphate and guanine to guanosine monophosphate via transfer of the 5-phosphoribosyl group from 5-phosphoribosyl 1-pyrophosphate

Subject: decreased hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase level
Value: reduced level of the enzyme that catalyzes conversion of hypoxanthine to inosine monophosphate and guanine to guanosine monophosphate via transfer of the 5-phosphoribosyl group from 5-phosphoribosyl 1-pyrophosphate

Subject: increased hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase level
Value: greater level of the enzyme that catalyzes conversion of hypoxanthine to inosine monophosphate and guanine to guanosine monophosphate via transfer of the 5-phosphoribosyl group from 5-phosphoribosyl 1-pyrophosphate

Subject: decreased thalamus hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase level
Value: reduced level in the thalamus of the enzyme that catalyzes conversion of hypoxanthine to inosine monophosphate and guanine to guanosine monophosphate via transfer of the 5-phosphoribosyl group from 5-phosphoribosyl 1-pyrophosphate

Subject: increased thalamus hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase level
Value: greater level in the thalmus of the enzyme that catalyzes conversion of hypoxanthine to inosine monophosphate and guanine to guanosine monophosphate via transfer of the 5-phosphoribosyl group from 5-phosphoribosyl 1-pyrophosphate

Subject: decreased hypothalamus hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase level
Value: reduced level in the hypothalamus of the enzyme that catalyzes conversion of hypoxanthine to inosine monophosphate and guanine to guanosine monophosphate via transfer of the 5-phosphoribosyl group from 5-phosphoribosyl 1-pyrophosphate

Subject: increased hypothalamus hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase level
Value: greater level in the hypothalmus of the enzyme that catalyzes conversion of hypoxanthine to inosine monophosphate and guanine to guanosine monophosphate via transfer of the 5-phosphoribosyl group from 5-phosphoribosyl 1-pyrophosphate

Subject: abnormal plasmalogen level
Value: anomaly in the amount of the glycerophospholipid class of lipids that contain a vinyl ether moiety at the sn-1-position of the glycerol backbone and are and enriched in polyunsaturated fatty acids at the sn-2 position of the glycerol backbone

Subject: decreased plasmalogen level
Value: reduction in the amount of the glycerophospholipid class of lipids that contain a vinyl ether moiety at the sn-1-position of the glycerol backbone and are and enriched in polyunsaturated fatty acids at the sn-2 position of the glycerol backbone

Subject: increased plasmalogen level
Value: greater amount of the glycerophospholipid class of lipids that contain a vinyl ether moiety at the sn-1-position of the glycerol backbone and are and enriched in polyunsaturated fatty acids at the sn-2 position of the glycerol backbone

Subject: decreased brain plasmalogen level
Value: reduction in the amount in the brain of the glycerophospholipid class of lipids that contain a vinyl ether moiety at the sn-1-position of the glycerol backbone and are and enriched in polyunsaturated fatty acids at the sn-2 position of the glycerol backbone

Subject: increased brain plasmalogen level
Value: greater amount in the brain of the glycerophospholipid class of lipids that contain a vinyl ether moiety at the sn-1-position of the glycerol backbone and are and enriched in polyunsaturated fatty acids at the sn-2 position of the glycerol backbone

Subject: abnormal ether lipid level
Value: anomaly in the amount of lipids in which one or more of the carbon atoms on glycerol is bonded to an alkyl chain via an ether linkage, as opposed to the usual ester linkage

Subject: abnormal circulating prothrombin level
Value: anomaly in the blood level of an inactive plasma serine protease precursor produced in the liver in the presence of vitamin K which is proteolytically cleaved into active thrombin by the action of various components (as thromboplastin) of the coagulation cascade

Subject: decreased circulating prothrombin level
Value: reduction in the blood level of an inactive plasma serine protease precursor produced in the liver in the presence of vitamin K which is proteolytically cleaved into active thrombin by the action of various components (as thromboplastin) of the coagulation cascade

Subject: increased circulating prothrombin level
Value: greater blood level of an inactive plasma serine protease precursor produced in the liver in the presence of vitamin K which is proteolytically cleaved into active thrombin by the action of various components (as thromboplastin) of the coagulation cascade

Subject: abnormal sterol level
Value: anomaly in the level of any of a group of predominantly unsaturated solid alcohols of the steroid group, usually with a hydroxyl group (OH) attached to the third carbon atom, and are present in the fatty tissues of plants and animals; sterols may be found either as free sterols, acylated, alkylated, sulfated, or linked to a glycoside moiety which can be itself acylated

Subject: decreased sterol level
Value: reduction in the level of any of a group of predominantly unsaturated solid alcohols of the steroid group, usually with a hydroxyl group (OH) attached to the third carbon atom, and are present in the fatty tissues of plants and animals; sterols may be found either as free sterols, acylated, alkylated, sulfated, or linked to a glycoside moiety which can be itself acylated

Subject: increased sterol level
Value: greater level of any of a group of predominantly unsaturated solid alcohols of the steroid group, usually with a hydroxyl group (OH) attached to the third carbon atom, and are present in the fatty tissues of plants and animals; sterols may be found either as free sterols, acylated, alkylated, sulfated, or linked to a glycoside moiety which can be itself acylated

Subject: decreased brain sterol level
Value: reduced level in the brain of any of a group of predominantly unsaturated solid alcohols of the steroid group, usually with a hydroxyl group (OH) attached to the third carbon atom, and are present in the fatty tissues of plants and animals; sterols may be found either as free sterols, acylated, alkylated, sulfated, or linked to a glycoside moiety which can be itself acylated

Subject: increased brain sterol level
Value: greater level in the brain of any of a group of predominantly unsaturated solid alcohols of the steroid group, usually with a hydroxyl group (OH) attached to the third carbon atom, and are present in the fatty tissues of plants and animals; sterols may be found either as free sterols, acylated, alkylated, sulfated, or linked to a glycoside moiety which can be itself acylated

Subject: abnormal ganglioside level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration of the molecule composed of a glycosphingolipid (ceramide and oligosaccharide) with one or more sialic acids linked on the sugar chain

Subject: abnormal ceramide level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration of the subclass of sphingoid base derivatives with an amide-linked fatty acid, where the fatty acids are typically saturated or monounsaturated with chain lengths from 14 to 26 carbon atoms

Subject: abnormal hepatic diverticulum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the out-pocket of thickened ventral foregut epithelium adjacent to the developing heart that constitutes the first morphological sign of the embryonic liver

Subject: abnormal liver bud morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the liver primordium formed as hepatoblasts delaminate from the anterior portion of the hepatic diverticulum and invade the adjacent septum transversum mesenchyme

Subject: abnormal cholangiocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the epithelial cells of the bile duct that have primary cilia extending from their apical membrane into the ductal lumen; cholangiocytes are cuboidal epithelium in the small interlobular bile ducts, but become columnar and mucus secreting in larger bile ducts approaching the porta hepatis and the extrahepatic ducts

Subject: increased cholangiocyte apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of epithelial cells of the bile duct undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal cholangiocyte primary cilium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the primary cilia found on the epithelial cells of the bile duct and extending from their apical membrane into the ductal lumen

Subject: abnormal cholangiocyte primary cilium physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the primary cilia found on the epithelial cells of the bile duct and extending from their apical membrane into the ductal lumen; cholangiocyte cilia respond to mechanical stimuli (i.e. luminal fluid flow) by alterations in intracellular Ca2+ and cAMP and are thought to act as osmosensors that play an important role in ductal bile formation by detecting changes in luminal tonicity and inducing bicarbonate secretion

Subject: abnormal hepatoblast morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bi-potent cell that retains the ability to divide and proliferate throughout life to provide progenitor cells that can differentiate into hepatocytes and cholangiocytes

Subject: abnormal hepatoblast physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the bi-potent cell that retains the ability to divide and proliferate throughout life to provide progenitor cells that can differentiate into hepatocytes and cholangiocytes

Subject: abnormal hepatoblast differentiation
Value: developmental anomaly or inability of hepatoblasts to differentiate into hepatocytes and cholangiocytes

Subject: decreased hepatoblast number
Value: reduced number of the bi-potent cells that retain the ability to divide and proliferate throughout life to provide progenitor cells that can differentiate into hepatocytes and cholangiocytes

Subject: increased hepatoblast apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of hepatoblasts undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal hepatoblast migration
Value: atypical migration of hepatoblasts across the basement membrane of the liver bud and/or invasion of the neighboring septum transversum mesenchyme

Subject: abnormal hepatic cord morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the three-dimensional arrangement formed by plates of hepatocytes, usually one cell thick, that radiates from the center of the liver lobule; hepatic laminae are highly branched, irregular structures bordered by endothelial lined vascular spaces called hepatic sinusoids

Subject: absent cornea
Value: absence of the transparent anterior portion of the fibrous coat of the eye that serves as the chief refractory structure

Subject: absent dermatome
Value: absence of the mesoderm that is derived from the somite that is fated to become the dermis

Subject: absent myotome
Value: absence of the mesoderm that is derived from the somite that is fated to become the musculature

Subject: absent heart valves
Value: failure to form all of the membranous folds of the heart that prevent reflux of fluid

Subject: abnormal diaphragm development
Value: malformation or incomplete differentiation of the thin musculomembranous barrier separating the abdominal and thoracic cavities and functioning in respiration

Subject: abnormal septum transversum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thick plate of mesodermal tissue that occupies the space between the thoracic cavity and yolk stalk in the early embryo, forming a transverse partition partially separating the coelomic cavity into thoracic and abdominal portions; the cranial part of the septum transversum gives rise to the central tendon of the diaphragm and is the origin of the myoblasts that invade the pleuroperitoneal folds resulting in the formation of the muscular diaphragm, and the caudal part of the septum transversum is invaded by the hepatic diverticulum which divides within it to form the liver and thus gives rise to the ventral mesentery of the foregut

Subject: abnormal intersomitic vessel morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the primary blood vessel sprouts that originate from the dorsal aorta and posterior cardinal vein and align dorsoventrally at the myotomal boundaries between somites

Subject: absent intersomitic vessels
Value: absence of the primary blood vessel sprouts that originate from the dorsal aorta and posterior cardinal vein and align dorsoventrally at the myotomal boundaries between somites

Subject: abnormal intersomitic vein morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the vein that sprouts from the posterior cardinal vein, growing dorsally between the somites, and then joining, and draining the dorsal longitudinal anastomosing vessel

Subject: abnormal philtrum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the vertical groove found on the median line of the upper lip

Subject: absent philtrum
Value: absence of the vertical groove normally found on the median line of the upper lip

Subject: philtrum hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the philtrum, usually due to a reduced number of cells

Subject: meningocele
Value: a protrusion of meninges through dehiscences in the base of the skull or gaps between the vertebrae, resulting in a cyst filled with cerebrospinal fluid; nervous tissue remains unaffected

Subject: encephalomeningocele
Value: hernial protrusion of the brain and its meninges through an opening or defect in the skull, most often occurring in the occipital region

Subject: increased hindbrain apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of cells of the hindbrain undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal hindbrain size
Value: deviation from the average range of hindbrain size compared to normal

Subject: decreased hindbrain size
Value: size reduction or truncation of the part of the brain developed from the posterior of the three primary brain vesicles of the embryonic neural tube from which the metencephalon and myelencephalon are derived

Subject: hindbrain hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the part of the brain developed from the posterior of the three primary brain vesicles of the embryonic neural tube from which the metencephalon and myelencephalon are derived

Subject: increased hindbrain size
Value: greater than average size of the part of the brain developed from the posterior of the three primary brain vesicles of the embryonic neural tube from which the metencephalon and myelencephalon are derived

Subject: hindbrain hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due to a increased number of cells, of the part of the brain developed from the posterior of the three primary brain vesicles of the embryonic neural tube from which the metencephalon and myelencephalon are derived

Subject: abnormal red nucleus morphology
Value: any anomaly of the pale pink structure located in the tegmentum of the midbrain next to the substantia nigra and involved in motor coordination

Subject: absent red nucleus
Value: absence of the pale pink structure located in the tegmentum of the midbrain next to the substantia nigra and involved in motor coordination

Subject: nuchal edema
Value: abnormal accumulation of subcutaneous fluid in the nuchal region i.e. at the back of the neck

Subject: cardiac edema
Value: abnormal accumulation of fluid in the interstitial tissues and cavities of the body due to impaired cardiac function or congestive heart failure; usually characterized by increased venous and capillary pressures and often associated with renal sodium retention

Subject: abnormal chordamesoderm morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the area of axial mesoderm that develops into the notochord

Subject: decreased axial mesoderm size
Value: reduced size or deficiency of the part of the middle of the three primary germ layers of the embryo which includes the prechordal mesoderm and the chordamesoderm and gives rise to the prechordal plate and to the notochord

Subject: axial mesoderm hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the part of the middle of the three primary germ layers of the embryo which includes the prechordal mesoderm and the chordamesoderm and gives rise to the prechordal plate and to the notochord

Subject: increased axial mesoderm size
Value: greater than average size of the part of the middle of the three primary germ layers of the embryo which includes the prechordal mesoderm and the chordamesoderm and gives rise to the prechordal plate and to the notochord

Subject: abnormal prechordal mesoderm morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the area of axial mesoderm that develops into the prechordal plate

Subject: absent prechordal mesoderm
Value: absence of or failure to form the area of axial mesoderm that develops into the prechordal plate

Subject: increased tail bud apoptosis
Value: increased number of cells undergoing programmed cell death in the primordial region of the embryo that arises to form the tail of the adult

Subject: abnormal cardiogenic mesoderm morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the splanchnic mesoderm in the cardiogenic region where the heart develops; it gives rise to endocardial heart tubes that fuse to form the primordial cardiac tube, the heart primordium

Subject: wide sternum
Value: an increase in the width of the long flat bone of the chest that articulates with the clavicle and first seven rib pairs

Subject: abnormal sternebra size
Value: atypical size of any of the segments of the primordial sternum of the embryo; these segments fuse to form the body of the adult vertebrate sternum

Subject: decreased sternebra size
Value: reduced average size of any of the segments of the primordial sternum of the embryo; these segments fuse to form the body of the adult vertebrate sternum

Subject: abnormal sternebra number
Value: deviation from the average number of the segments of the primordial sternum of the embryo; these segments fuse to form the body of the adult vertebrate sternum

Subject: decreased sternebra number
Value: reduced average number of the segments of the primordial sternum of the embryo; these segments fuse to form the body of the adult vertebrate sternum

Subject: increased sternebra number
Value: increased average number of the segments of the primordial sternum of the embryo; these segments fuse to form the body of the adult vertebrate sternum

Subject: misaligned sternebrae
Value: abnormal alignment of the sternebrae along the ventral midline

Subject: decreased frequency of paradoxical sleep
Value: decreased incidence or duration of the sleep stage in which dreams occur and the body undergoes marked changes including rapid eye movement, loss of reflexes, and increased pulse rate and brain activity

Subject: increased frequency of paradoxical sleep
Value: increased incidence or duration of the sleep stage in which dreams occur and the body undergoes marked changes including rapid eye movement, loss of reflexes, and increased pulse rate and brain activity

Subject: abnormal paradoxical sleep pattern
Value: any anomaly in the frequency or duration of the sleep stage in which dreams occur and the body undergoes marked changes including rapid eye movement, loss of reflexes, and increased pulse rate and brain activity

Subject: abnormal non-rapid eye movement sleep pattern
Value: any anomaly in the frequency or duration of the sleep stages characterized by distinct EEG patterns, decreased metabolic activity, slowed breathing and heart rate, and the absence of rapid eye movement and dreaming

Subject: abnormal slow-wave sleep pattern
Value: any anonaly in the third, or deep sleep stage of NREM sleep

Subject: increased slow-wave sleep duration
Value: increased length of time of the third, or deep sleep stage of NREM sleep

Subject: decreased slow-wave sleep duration
Value: reduced length of time of the third, or deep sleep stage of NREM sleep

Subject: impaired active avoidance behavior
Value: impaired ability to escape a hostile environment to actively avoid the unpleasant or punishing stimuli ( e.g. shock) previously encountered in this environment

Subject: enhanced active avoidance behavior
Value: enhanced ability to escape a hostile environment to actively avoid the unpleasant or punishing stimuli ( e.g. shock) previously encountered in this environment

Subject: enhanced discrimination learning
Value: enhanced ability to exhibit a differential response to different stimuli that is achieved by the reinforcement of the desired response for each particular stimulus

Subject: impaired discrimination learning
Value: impaired ability to exhibit a differential response to different stimuli that is achieved by the reinforcement of the desired response for each particular stimulus

Subject: hyperactivity elicited by feed restriction
Value: increased activity after restriction of food

Subject: hypoactivity in response to feed restriction
Value: decreased activity after restriction of food

Subject: hydropic allantois
Value: excessive accumulation of fluid within the allantoic sac

Subject: abnormal umbilical cord blood vessel morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the three blood vessels, usually one large umbilical vein and two small umbilical arteries, buried within Wharton's jelly, that transport blood to and from the placenta, where exchange between the mother and fetus takes place; the umbilical vein carries oxygenated, nutrient-rich blood from the placenta to the fetus, and the umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated, nutrient-depleted blood from the fetus to the placenta

Subject: absent umbilical cord blood vessels
Value: absence of any of the three blood vessels, usually one large umbilical vein and two small umbilical arteries, buried within Wharton's jelly, that transport blood to and from the placenta, where exchange between the mother and fetus takes place

Subject: umbilical artery stenosis
Value: abnormal constriction or narrowing of one or both umbilical arteries that carry deoxygenated, nutrient-depleted blood from the fetus to the placenta

Subject: umbilical vein stenosis
Value: abnormal constriction or narrowing of the unpaired umbilical vein that carries oxygenated, nutrient-rich blood from the placenta to the fetus

Subject: short umbilical cord
Value: decreased average umbilical cord length compared to normal

Subject: umbilical cord hemorrhage
Value: bleeding into or from the umbilical cord

Subject: enhanced spatial learning
Value: enhanced ability to ascertain or acquire spatial location information in order to improve navigation or other behavior using such location cues

Subject: impaired spatial learning
Value: impaired ability to ascertain or acquire spatial location information in order to improve navigation or other behavior using such location cues

Subject: salt preference
Value: subjects demonstrate predilection for salty tasting substances over other offered substances

Subject: abnormal ductus caroticus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the segment of dorsal aorta located between the third (III) and fourth (IV) aortic arches; it normally regresses early in development to allow the carotid axis to take its definitive appearance

Subject: persistent ductus caroticus
Value: uni- or bilateral persistence of the segment of dorsal aorta located between the third (III) and fourth (IV) aortic arches, which normally regresses early in development; persistence of ductus caroticus with regression of third arch or fourth arch causes the internal and external carotid arteries to arise from the aortic arch on the left side

Subject: decreased defecation amount
Value: decrease in the amount of discharge of feces from the body

Subject: impaired avoidance learning behavior
Value: impaired ability to associate a previously neutral stimulus with an unpleasant or punishing stimuli so that the animal learns to avoid the previously neutral stimulus

Subject: enhanced avoidance learning behavior
Value: enhanced ability to associate a previously neutral stimulus with an unpleasant or punishing stimuli so that the animal learns to avoid the previously neutral stimulus

Subject: enhanced learning
Value: enhanced ability to aquire lasting change in behavior that is the result of experience

Subject: impaired learning
Value: impaired ability to aquire lasting change in behavior that is the result of experience

Subject: enhanced conditioning behavior
Value: enhanced ability to change behavior in response to a reward or punishment each time an action is performed

Subject: impaired conditioning behavior
Value: impaired ability to change behavior in response to a reward or punishment each time an action is performed

Subject: slow extinction of fear memory
Value: impaired ability or inability to extinguish aversive memories associated with a traumatic incident

Subject: fast extinction of fear memory
Value: enhanced ability to extinguish aversive memories associated with a traumatic incident

Subject: abnormal body fat mass
Value: aberrant physical bulk or volume of fat in the whole body

Subject: abnormal total tissue mass
Value: aberrant physical bulk or volume of the body including lean body mass, fat body mass, and bone tissue

Subject: decreased total tissue mass
Value: decreased physical bulk or volume of the body including lean body mass, fat body mass, and bone tissue

Subject: increased total tissue mass
Value: increased physical bulk or volume of the body including lean body mass, fat body mass, and bone tissue

Subject: abnormal circulating antithrombin level
Value: aberrant blood level of the family of glycoproteins which neutralize the ability of thrombin to promote blood coagulation

Subject: decreased circulating antithrombin level
Value: lower than normal levels of the family of glycoproteins which neutralize the ability of thrombin to promote blood coagulation; low levels are associated with vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism

Subject: increased circulating antithrombin level
Value: higher than normal levels of the family of glycoproteins which neutralize the ability of thrombin to promote blood coagulation

Subject: abnormal circulating factor VIII level
Value: aberrant levels of the antihemophilic factor that is part of the factor VIII/von Willebrand factor complex; it is produced in the liver and acts in the intrinsic pathway of blood coagulation; it serves as a cofactor in factor X activation and this action is markedly enhanced by small amounts of thrombin

Subject: decreased circulating factor VIII level
Value: reduced levels of the antihemophilic factor that is part of the factor VIII/von Willebrand factor complex; it is produced in the liver and acts in the intrinsic pathway of blood coagulation; it serves as a cofactor in factor X activation and this action is markedly enhanced by small amounts of thrombin

Subject: increased circulating factor VIII level
Value: greater levels of the antihemophilic factor that is part of the factor VIII/von Willebrand factor complex; it is produced in the liver and acts in the intrinsic pathway of blood coagulation; it serves as a cofactor in factor X activation and this action is markedly enhanced by small amounts of thrombin

Subject: decreased circulating fibrinogen level
Value: reduced levels in the blood of a globulin that is converted into fibrin by the action of thrombin in the presence of ionized calcium to produce coagulation of the blood

Subject: increased circulating fibrinogen level
Value: greater levels in the blood of a globulin that is converted into fibrin by the action of thrombin in the presence of ionized calcium to produce coagulation of the blood

Subject: decreased circulating fibronectin level
Value: reduced blood level of the glycoprotein that binds to integrins or components of the extracellular matrix; plays a major role in cell adhesion, growth, migration, differentiation, wound healing, and embryonic development

Subject: increased circulating fibronectin level
Value: greater blood level of the glycoprotein that binds to integrins or components of the extracellular matrix; plays a major role in cell adhesion, growth, migration, differentiation, wound healing, and embryonic development

Subject: decreased circulating homocysteine level
Value: reduced amount in the blood of sulfur-containing alpha-amino acid found in the plasma; blood levels are regulated by folic acid, vitamin B6 and vitamin B12

Subject: increased circulating homocysteine level
Value: greater amount in the blood of sulfur-containing alpha-amino acid found in the plasma; blood levels are regulated by folic acid, vitamin B6 and vitamin B12

Subject: decreased vitamin D level
Value: reduced level of vitamin D, any of a group of related, fat-soluble compounds that are derived from delta-5,7 steroids and play a central role in calcium metabolism; specific forms of vitamin D include calciferol (ergocalciferol; vitamin D2) and cholecalciferol (calciol; vitamin D3)

Subject: increased vitamin D level
Value: greater level of vitamin D, any of a group of related, fat-soluble compounds that are derived from delta-5,7 steroids and play a central role in calcium metabolism; specific forms of vitamin D include calciferol (ergocalciferol; vitamin D2) and cholecalciferol (calciol; vitamin D3)

Subject: decreased bile salt level
Value: reduced level of the steroid salts derived from cholesterol in the liver, produced as bile acids and secreted in the biliary system as bile salts; these play an important role in the digestion and absorption of fats

Subject: hyperkalemia
Value: excessively high concentrations of potassium in the circulating blood; may be due to renal insufficiency or to mineralocorticoid deficiency or resistance

Subject: decreased testicular teratoma incidence
Value: less than the expected number of a usually benign tumor found in the testis that is the result of an anomaly of germ cell development, occurring in a specific population in a given time period; teratomas typically contains a diversity of tissues often representing all organ systems such as hair, teeth, bone, thyroid, or nerve tissue

Subject: low preference for an addictive substance
Value: reduced behavioral response induced by a foreign compound, such as low consumption preference, low induced hyperactivity or stereotypic behavior

Subject: high preference for an addictive substance
Value: enhanced behavioral response induced by a foreign compound, such as high consumption preference, high induced hyperactivity or stereotypic behavior

Subject: increased gnawing activity
Value: increased biting or chewing on something

Subject: decreased gnawing activity
Value: decreased biting or chewing on something

Subject: increased tail rattling
Value: increased movement of the tail in rapid succession

Subject: decreased tail rattling
Value: decreased movement of the tail in rapid succession

Subject: low sweet preference
Value: subjects demonstrate a low predilection for sweet tasting substances over other offered substances

Subject: decreased susceptibility to induction of seizure by inducing agent
Value: higher threshold to induction of seizure activity response by an agent that normally can induce uncontrolled electrical activity in the brain, producing a physical convulsion and/or minor change in physical behavior

Subject: increased susceptibility to induction of seizure by inducing agent
Value: lower threshold to induction of seizure activity response by an agent that normally can induce uncontrolled electrical activity in the brain, producing a physical convulsion and/or minor change in physical behavior

Subject: increased aggression towards males in competition for females
Value: when compared to controls, subjects exhibit greater than the normal level of domineering, assaultive posture and/or hostile physical action toward males when in competition for females

Subject: cornea degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of the transparent anterior portion of the fibrous coat of the eye that serves as the chief refractory structure

Subject: progressive cornea degeneration
Value: the state or process of the cornea deteriorating progressively over time

Subject: bilateral cornea degeneration
Value: the state or process of the cornea deteriorating in both eyes

Subject: abnormal prothrombin time
Value: abnormal amount of time it takes plasma to clot after the addition of tissue factor e.g., platelet tissue factor, factor III, thromboplastin, CD142; measure of the quality of the extrinsic pathway of coagulation

Subject: decreased prothrombin time
Value: decreased amount of time it takes plasma to clot after the addition of tissue factor e.g., platelet tissue factor, factor III, thromboplastin, CD142; measure of the quality of the extrinsic pathway of coagulation

Subject: increased prothrombin time
Value: increased amount of time it takes plasma to clot after the addition of tissue factor e.g., platelet tissue factor, factor III, thromboplastin, CD142; measure of the quality of the extrinsic pathway of coagulation

Subject: abnormal partial thromboplastin time
Value: abnormal amount of time it takes blood to clot after the addition of phospholipid, calcium, and an activator, e.g., silica, kaolin; measure of the quality of the intrinsic and common coagulation pathways

Subject: decreased partial thromboplastin time
Value: decreased amount of time it takes blood to clot after the addition of phospholipid, calcium, and an activator, e.g., silica, kaolin; measure of the quality of the intrinsic and common coagulation pathways

Subject: increased partial thromboplastin time
Value: increased amount of time it takes blood to clot after the addition of phospholipid, calcium, and an activator, e.g., silica, kaolin; measure of the quality of the intrinsic and common coagulation pathways

Subject: abnormal large unstained cell number
Value: aberrant number of larger than normal cells which are unstained using routine blood count methodologies; large unstained cells (LUC) are larger than normal lymphocytes, and may be atypical lymphocytes, myeloperoxidase deficient cells or peroxidase negative blasts

Subject: decreased large unstained cell number
Value: decreased number of larger than normal cells which are unstained using routine blood count methodologies; large unstained cells (LUC) are larger than normal lymphocytes, and may be atypical lymphocytes, myeloperoxidase deficient cells or peroxidase negative blasts

Subject: increased large unstained cell number
Value: increased number of larger than normal cells which are unstained using routine blood count methodologies; large unstained cells (LUC) are larger than normal lymphocytes, and may be atypical lymphocytes, myeloperoxidase deficient cells or peroxidase negative blasts

Subject: abnormal erythrocyte sodium level
Value: anomaly in the amount in red blood cells of sodium

Subject: decreased erythrocyte sodium level
Value: decrease in the amount in red blood cells of sodium

Subject: increased erythrocyte sodium level
Value: increase in the amount in red blood cells of sodium

Subject: abnormal erythrocyte magnesium level
Value: anomaly in the amount in red blood cells of magnesium

Subject: decreased erythrocyte magnesium level
Value: decrease in the amount in red blood cells of magnesium

Subject: increased erythrocyte magnesium level
Value: increase in the amount in red blood cells of magnesium

Subject: abnormal erythrocyte potassium level
Value: anomaly in the amount in red blood cells of potassium

Subject: decreased erythrocyte potassium level
Value: decrease in the amount in red blood cells of potassium

Subject: increased erythrocyte potassium level
Value: increase in the amount in red blood cells of potassium

Subject: abnormal erythrocyte ion content
Value: abnormal quantity in red blood cells of atoms carrying an electric charge

Subject: abnormal erythrocyte magnesium ion content
Value: abnormal quantity in red blood cells of magnesium atoms carrying an electric charge

Subject: decreased erythrocyte magnesium ion content
Value: decreased quantity in red blood cells of magnesium atoms carrying an electric charge

Subject: increased erythrocyte magnesium ion content
Value: increased quantity in red blood cells of magnesium atoms carrying an electric charge

Subject: abnormal erythrocyte potassium ion content
Value: abnormal quantity in red blood cells of potassium atoms carrying an electric charge

Subject: decreased erythrocyte potassium ion content
Value: decreased quantity in red blood cells of potassium atoms carrying an electric charge

Subject: increased erythrocyte potassium ion content
Value: increased quantity in red blood cells of potassium atoms carrying an electric charge

Subject: abnormal erythrocyte sodium ion content
Value: abnormal quantity in red blood cells of sodium atoms carrying an electric charge

Subject: decreased erythrocyte sodium ion content
Value: decreased quantity in red blood cells of sodium atoms carrying an electric charge

Subject: increased erythrocyte sodium ion content
Value: increased quantity in red blood cells of sodium atoms carrying an electric charge

Subject: abnormal blood cell physiology
Value: aberrant measurable or observable characteristic related to the function of or processes in any of the cells found in the blood

Subject: abnormal erythrocyte ion transport
Value: aberrant measurable or observable characteristic related to the movement in red blood cells of atoms carrying an electric charge

Subject: abnormal erythrocyte potassium:chloride symporter activity
Value: <aberrant catalysis in red blood cells of the transfer of a solute or solutes from one side of a membrane to the other according to the reaction: K+(out) + Cl-(out) = K+(in) + Cl-(in)>

Subject: decreased erythrocyte potassium:chloride symporter activity
Value: <decreased catalysis in red blood cells of the transfer of a solute or solutes from one side of a membrane to the other according to the reaction: K+(out) + Cl-(out) = K+(in) + Cl-(in)>

Subject: increased erythrocyte potassium:chloride symporter activity
Value: <increased catalysis in red blood cells of the transfer of a solute or solutes from one side of a membrane to the other according to the reaction: K+(out) + Cl-(out) = K+(in) + Cl-(in)>

Subject: abnormal erythrocyte sodium:hydrogen antiporter activity
Value: <aberrant catalysis in red blood cells of the transfer of a solute or solutes from one side of a membrane to the other according to the reaction: Na+(out) + H+(in) = Na+(in) + H+(out)>

Subject: decreased erythrocyte sodium:hydrogen antiporter activity
Value: <decreased catalysis in red blood cells of the transfer of a solute or solutes from one side of a membrane to the other according to the reaction: Na+(out) + H+(in) = Na+(in) + H+(out)>

Subject: increased erythrocyte sodium:hydrogen antiporter activity
Value: <increased catalysis in red blood cells of the transfer of a solute or solutes from one side of a membrane to the other according to the reaction: Na+(out) + H+(in) = Na+(in) + H+(out)>

Subject: abnormal erythrocyte sodium:potassium-exchanging ATPase activity
Value: <aberrant catalysis in red blood cells of the transfer of a solute or solutes from one side of a membrane to the other according to the reaction: ATP + H2O + Na+(in) + K+(out) = ADP + phosphate + Na+(out) + K+(in)>

Subject: decreased erythrocyte sodium:potassium-exchanging ATPase activity
Value: <decreased catalysis in red blood cells of the transfer of a solute or solutes from one side of a membrane to the other according to the reaction: ATP + H2O + Na+(in) + K+(out) = ADP + phosphate + Na+(out) + K+(in)>

Subject: increased erythrocyte sodium:potassium-exchanging ATPase activity
Value: <increased catalysis in red blood cells of the transfer of a solute or solutes from one side of a membrane to the other according to the reaction: ATP + H2O + Na+(in) + K+(out) = ADP + phosphate + Na+(out) + K+(in)>

Subject: abnormal erythrocyte calcium-activated potassium channel activity
Value: aberrant catalysis in red blood cells of the calcium concentration-regulatable energy-independent passage of potassium ions across a lipid bilayer down a concentration gradient

Subject: decreased erythrocyte calcium-activated potassium channel activity
Value: decreased catalysis in red blood cells of the calcium concentration-regulatable energy-independent passage of potassium ions across a lipid bilayer down a concentration gradient

Subject: increased erythrocyte calcium-activated potassium channel activity
Value: increased catalysis in red blood cells of the calcium concentration-regulatable energy-independent passage of potassium ions across a lipid bilayer down a concentration gradient

Subject: abnormal nucleated erythrocyte cell number
Value: abnormal numbers of nucleated red blood cells at stages when these cells are normally replaced by mature, enucleated, red blood cells

Subject: decreased nucleated erythrocyte cell number
Value: decreased numbers of nucleated red blood cells at stages when these cells are normally replaced by mature, enucleated, red blood cells

Subject: short nails
Value: decrease in the length of the nails

Subject: nail dystrophy
Value: the presence of misshapen or partially destroyed nail plates, fequently with keratin often accumulating between the dystrophic nail plate and nail bed; often due to trauma or infection

Subject: long nails
Value: increased length of the nails

Subject: abnormal nail bed morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the dermis and epidermis directly below the nail plate

Subject: abnormal nail plate morphology
Value: any structural anomally of the hard and translucent portion of the nail, composed of keratin, which serves to protect the tips of digits

Subject: abnormal nail color
Value: a variation in an expected nail color, that may be due to infection, inflammation or other causes

Subject: abnormal nail matrix morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the nail-forming area of the nail bed comprised of a germinal matrix, responsible for most of the nail production, and the sterile matrix, a secondary site of nail production which is tightly adherent to the nail plate

Subject: increased stomach glandular epithelium tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of tumors originating in the stomach glandular epithelium in a given population in a given time period

Subject: increased gastric gastrinoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of an epithelial tumor in the stomach that secretes an excess of gastrin, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased duodenum glandular epithelium tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of tumors originating in the duodenal glandular epithelium in a given population in a given time period

Subject: increased duodenal gastrinoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of an epithelial tumor in the duodenum that secretes an excess of gastrin, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased pancreatic gastrinoma incidence
Value: higher than normal incidence of a tumor in the pancreas that secretes an excess of gastrin, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased granulosa cell tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplasms derived from somatic cells of the sex cord in the ovary a given population in a given time period

Subject: increased Type B reticulum cell tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplasms derived from reticulum cells in a given population in a given time period; type B neoplasms are tumors of mixed cellularity of reticulum cells, lymphocytes, plasma cells, eosinophils, and neutrophils

Subject: decreased muscle tumor incidence
Value: less than the expected number of tumors originating in muscle tissue in a given population in a given time period

Subject: decreased rhabdomyosarcoma incidence
Value: less than the expected number of a malignant tumor derived from skeletal (striated) muscle, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: decreased sarcoma incidence
Value: less than the expected number of a connective tissue neoplasm associated with the proliferation of embryonically-derived mesodermal cells, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: decreased gland tumor incidence
Value: less than the expected number of tumors originating in a gland in a given population in a given time period

Subject: decreased reproductive system tumor incidence
Value: less than the expected number of tumors originating in the reproductive system in a given population in a given time period

Subject: decreased eye tumor incidence
Value: less than the expected number of tumors originating in the eye in a given population in a given time period

Subject: decreased cardiovascular system tumor incidence
Value: less than the expected number of tumors originating in the cardiovascular system in a given population in a given time period

Subject: decreased hemolymphoid system tumor incidence
Value: less than the expected number of tumors originating in the hemolymphoid system in a given population in a given time period

Subject: decreased hepatobiliary system tumor incidence
Value: less than the expected number of tumors originating in the hepatobiliary system in a given population in a given time period

Subject: decreased integument system tumor incidence
Value: less than the expected number of tumors originating in the integument system in a given population in a given time period

Subject: decreased nervous system tumor incidence
Value: less than the expected number of tumors originating in the nervous system in a given population in a given time period

Subject: decreased alimentary system tumor incidence
Value: less than the expected number of tumors originating in the alimentary system in a given population in a given time period

Subject: decreased respiratory system tumor incidence
Value: less than the expected number of tumors originating in the respiratory system in a given population in a given time period

Subject: decreased skeletal tumor incidence
Value: less than the expected number of neoplasms in the skeletal tissue, usually in the form of a distinct mass, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: decreased urinary system tumor incidence
Value: less than the expected number of tumors originating in the urinary system in a given population in a given time period

Subject: decreased granulosa cell tumor incidence
Value: less than the expected number of neoplasms derived from somatic cells of the sex cord in the ovary a given population in a given time period

Subject: decreased myoepithelioma incidence
Value: less than the expected number of neoplasms of the cells usually found in glandular epithelium as a thin layer above the basement membrane but generally beneath the luminal cells, in a given population in a given time period

Subject: decreased Type B reticulum cell tumor incidence
Value: less than the expected number of neoplasms derived from reticulum cells in a given population in a given time period; type B neoplasms are tumors of mixed cellularity of reticulum cells, lymphocytes, plasma cells, eosinophils, and neutrophils

Subject: increased lymphoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplasms characterized by a proliferation of malignant lymphocytes in lymphoid tissue in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: decreased prostate gland tumor incidence
Value: less than the expected number of neoplams in the prostate gland occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: decreased ovarian tumor incidence
Value: less than the expected number of neoplams in the ovary occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: decreased intestinal adenoma incidence
Value: less than the expected number of a benign epithelial neoplasm with a glandular organization arising in the small and/or large intestine, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: decreased colon tumor incidence
Value: less than the expected number of neoplasms in the colon, usually in the form of a distinct mass, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased colon tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplasms in the colon, usually in the form of a distinct mass, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased Harderian gland tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplams in the Harderian gland, usually in the form of a distinct mass, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: decreased Harderian gland tumor incidence
Value: less than the expected number of neoplams in the Harderian gland, usually in the form of a distinct mass, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: decreased pituitary gland tumor incidence
Value: less than the expected number of neoplams in the pituitary gland, usually in the form of a distinct mass, in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: abnormal neutrophil cell number
Value: deviation in the count of the immature or mature forms of a granular leukocyte that in its mature form has a nucleus with three to five lobes connected by slender threads of chromatin, and cytoplasm containing fine inconspicuous granules and stainable by neutral dyes

Subject: abnormal monocyte cell number
Value: any deviation in the count of the large, phagocytic mononuclear leukocytes produced in the vertebrate bone marrow and released into the blood

Subject: abnormal basophil cell number
Value: deviation of the count of the immature or mature forms of a granular leukocyte that in its mature form has an irregularly shaped, pale-staining nucleus that is partially constricted into two lobes, and with cytoplasm that contains coarse, bluish-black granules of variable size

Subject: increased corpus callosum size
Value: larger thick bundle of nerve fibers comprising a commissural plate connecting the two cerebral hemispheres; it consists of contralateral axon projections that provides communications between the right and left cerebral hemispheres

Subject: thin hippocampus molecular cell layer
Value: decrease in the width of the cytoarchitectural region of the hippocampus consisting of a composite of the two outermost layers of the hippocampus, the Stratum lacunosum-moleculare and the Stratum radiatum

Subject: thin hippocampus stratum radiatum
Value: decrease in the width of the layer located immediately above the pyramidal cell layer in CA2 and CA1 and superficial to the stratum lucidum in CA3

Subject: thin hippocampus stratum oriens
Value: decrease in the width of the layer that is part of the CA fields of the hippocampus consisting of a narrow relatively cell free layer located deep to the pyramidal cell layer extending through areas CA1, CA2 and CA3

Subject: thick cerebellar granule layer
Value: increased thickness of the innermost cortical layer of the cerebellum that contains granule cells

Subject: abnormal primary motor cortex morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the part of the cerebral cortex that receives projections from the motor thalamus and which projects to motor neurons in the brainstem and spinal cord; the primary motor cortex, or M1, is located on the precentral gyrus and on the anterior paracentral lobule on the medial surface of the brain

Subject: increased primary motor cortex size
Value: greater size of the part of the cerebral cortex that receives projections from the motor thalamus and which projects to motor neurons in the brainstem and spinal cord

Subject: decreased primary motor cortex size
Value: reduced size of the part of the cerebral cortex that receives projections from the motor thalamus and which projects to motor neurons in the brainstem and spinal cord

Subject: abnormal retrosplenial granular cortex morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the subregion consisting of two divisions of the retrosplenial cotex, retrosplenial granular cortex A(Rga) and retrosplenial granular cortex B (Rgb), which receive dense projections from the hippocampal formation

Subject: increased retrosplenial granular cortex size
Value: greater size of the subregion consisting of two divisions of the retrosplenial cotex, retrosplenial granular cortex A(Rga) and retrosplenial granular cortex B (Rgb), which receive dense projections from the hippocampal formation

Subject: decreased retrosplenial granular cortex size
Value: reduced size of the subregion consisting of two divisions of the retrosplenial cotex, retrosplenial granular cortex A(Rga) and retrosplenial granular cortex B (Rgb), which receive dense projections from the hippocampal formation

Subject: abnormal mammillothalamic tract morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bundle of nerve fibers that projects from the mammillary body in the posterior hypothalamic region to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus

Subject: increased mammillothalamic tract size
Value: greater size of the bundle of nerve fibers that projects from the mammillary body in the posterior hypothalamic region to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus

Subject: decreased mammillothalamic tract size
Value: reduced size of the bundle of nerve fibers that projects from the mammillary body in the posterior hypothalamic region to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus

Subject: increased hippocampus pyramidal cell length
Value: increased length of a multipolar projection neuron in the hippocampus pyramidal cell layer

Subject: decreased hippocampus pyramidal cell length
Value: reduced length of a multipolar projection neuron in the hippocampus pyramidal cell layer

Subject: increased dentate gyrus size
Value: greater size of one of two interlocking gyri of the hippocampus formation that contains granule cells, which project to the pyramidal cells and interneurons of the CA3 region of the ammon gyrus

Subject: decreased dentate gyrus size
Value: reduced size of one of two interlocking gyri of the hippocampus formation that contains granule cells, which project to the pyramidal cells and interneurons of the CA3 region of the ammon gyrus

Subject: increased brain internal capsule size
Value: greater size of the area of white matter in the brain that lies between the lenticular and caudate nuclei, and contains a group of myelinated ascending and descending axonal fiber tracts that connects the cerebral cortex to the brain stem and spinal cord

Subject: decreased brain internal capsule size
Value: reduced size of the area of white matter in the brain that lies between the lenticular and caudate nuclei, and contains a group of myelinated ascending and descending axonal fiber tracts that connects the cerebral cortex to the brain stem and spinal cord

Subject: increased optic tract size
Value: greater size of the paired bands of optic nerve fibers running from the optic chiasma mostly to the lateral geniculate body, with a smaller number of fibers terminating in the superior colliculus and the pretectal region

Subject: decreased optic tract size
Value: reduced size of the paired bands of optic nerve fibers running from the optic chiasma mostly to the lateral geniculate body, with a smaller number of fibers terminating in the superior colliculus and the pretectal region

Subject: increased hippocampal fimbria size
Value: greater size of the flattened band of efferent fibers arising from the subiculum and medial border of the hippocampus, which then thickens to form the fornix and fibers of the hippocampal commissure

Subject: decreased hippocampal fimbria size
Value: reduced size of the flattened band of efferent fibers arising from the subiculum and medial border of the hippocampus, which then thickens to form the fornix and fibers of the hippocampal commissure

Subject: increased striatum size
Value: greater size of a large cluster of dopaminergic nerve cells, consisting of the caudate nucleus and the putamen, that controls movement, balance, and walking

Subject: decreased striatum size
Value: reduced size of a large cluster of dopaminergic nerve cells, consisting of the caudate nucleus and the putamen, that controls movement, balance, and walking

Subject: increased genu of the facial nerve size
Value: greater size of the bend in the facial nerve at the lateral end of the internal acoustic meatus

Subject: decreased genu of the facial nerve size
Value: reduced size of the bend in the facial nerve at the lateral end of the internal acoustic meatus

Subject: increased cerebellum interpositus nucleus size
Value: greater size of the nucelus composed of the globose and emoliform nuclei of the cerebellum; in some mammalian species the globose nucleus is not distinguishable

Subject: decreased cerebellum interpositus nucleus size
Value: reduced size of the nucelus composed of the globose and emoliform nuclei of the cerebellum; in some mammalian species the globose nucleus is not distinguishable

Subject: increased cingulate cortex size
Value: greater size of the thick belt of cortex encircling the corpus callosum that responsible for producing emotional responses to physical sensations of pain and for cognitive control

Subject: decreased cingulate cortex size
Value: reduced size of the thick belt of cortex encircling the corpus callosum that responsible for producing emotional responses to physical sensations of pain and for cognitive control

Subject: increased piriform cortex size
Value: increased size of the subdivision of the laminated olfactory cortex with only three main layers that receive monosynaptic input from the olfactory bulb via the lateral olfactory tract

Subject: decreased piriform cortex size
Value: reduced size of the subdivision of the laminated olfactory cortex with only three main layers that receive monosynaptic input from the olfactory bulb via the lateral olfactory tract

Subject: increased secondary somatosensory cortex size
Value: greater size of the area of the upper bank of the lateral sulcus that is involved in somatic sensation

Subject: decreased secondary somatosensory cortex size
Value: reduced size of the area of the upper bank of the lateral sulcus that is involved in somatic sensation

Subject: increased amygdala size
Value: greater size of the almond-shaped body of basal nuclei anterior to the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle of the brain, within the temporal lobe; this area is involved in aggression and fear responses

Subject: decreased amygdala size
Value: reduced size of the almond-shaped body of basal nuclei anterior to the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle of the brain, within the temporal lobe; this area is involved in aggression and fear responses

Subject: increased habenula size
Value: greater size of the group of nuclei that makes up the small eminence on the dorsomedial surface of the thalamus, just in front of the dorsal commissure on the lateral edge of the habenular trigone

Subject: decreased habenula size
Value: reduced size of the group of nuclei that makes up the small eminence on the dorsomedial surface of the thalamus, just in front of the dorsal commissure on the lateral edge of the habenular trigone

Subject: increased corticospinal tract size
Value: greater size of the corticospinal fibers that arise from the pyramidal cells within the cerebral cortex layer V of the precentral motor area, the premotor area and the postcentral gyrus, then descend into and through the medulla to form the lateral corticospinal tract and the anterior corticospinal tract

Subject: decreased corticospinal tract size
Value: reduced size of the corticospinal fibers that arise from the pyramidal cells within the cerebral cortex layer V of the precentral motor area, the premotor area and the postcentral gyrus, then descend into and through the medulla to form the lateral corticospinal tract and the anterior corticospinal tract

Subject: increased cochlear VIII nucleus size
Value: greater size of two paired brainstem nuclei, the dorsal cochlear nucleus and the ventral cochlear nucleus, that lie dorsal and ventral, respectively, to the inferior cerebellar peduncle at the rostral pole of the medulla; the cochlear nuclei receive input from the cochlear nerve and send projections to the inferior colliculus, the medial geniculate, and other forebrain structures

Subject: decreased cochlear VIII nucleus size
Value: reduced size of two paired brainstem nuclei, the dorsal cochlear nucleus and the ventral cochlear nucleus, that lie dorsal and ventral, respectively, to the inferior cerebellar peduncle at the rostral pole of the medulla; the cochlear nuclei receive input from the cochlear nerve and send projections to the inferior colliculus, the medial geniculate, and other forebrain structures

Subject: increased cerebellum dentate nucleus size
Value: greater size of the largest and most lateral of the deep cerebellum nuclei; it receives axons of Purkinje cells in the lateral cerebellar hemisphere (neocerebellum) and receives its afferents from the premotor cortex and the supplementary motor cortex through the pontocerebellar system, and its efferents project through the superior cerebellar peduncle and is a major source of its fibers

Subject: decreased cerebellum dentate nucleus size
Value: reduced size of the largest and most lateral of the deep cerebellum nuclei; it receives axons of Purkinje cells in the lateral cerebellar hemisphere (neocerebellum) and receives its afferents from the premotor cortex and the supplementary motor cortex through the pontocerebellar system, and its efferents project through the superior cerebellar peduncle and is a major source of its fibers

Subject: abnormal retrosplenial region morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of one of the key brain regions required for cognitive functions, including episodic memory, navigation, imagination and planning for the future; the retrosplenial region can be divided into three parts, the retrosplenial granular cortex A, the retrosplenial granular cortex B and the retrosplenial dysgranular cortex; each subdivision of the retrosplenial cortex projects to a discrete terminal field in the hippocampal formation

Subject: abnormal cochlear VIII nucleus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of two paired brainstem nuclei, the dorsal cochlear nucleus and the ventral cochlear nucleus, that lie dorsal and ventral, respectively, to the inferior cerebellar peduncle at the rostral pole of the medulla; the cochlear nuclei receive input from the cochlear nerve and send projections to the inferior colliculus, the medial geniculate, and other forebrain structures

Subject: larynx stenosis
Value: abnormal narrowing or constriction of the organ of voice production located between the pharynx and the trachea

Subject: pharyngeal arch artery hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the vessels formed within the six (five in mammals) pairs of branchial arches in embryogenesis; in the adult, some of these vessels give rise to the great vessels

Subject: absent pharyngeal arch arteries
Value: absence of the vessels formed within the six (five in mammals) pairs of branchial arches in embryogenesis; in the adult, some of these vessels give rise to the great vessels

Subject: dilated pharyngeal arch arteries
Value: stretched or widened aperture of the luminal space of the vessels formed within the six (five in mammals) pairs of branchial arches in embryogenesis; in the adult, some of these vessels give rise to the great vessels

Subject: pharyngeal arch artery stenosis
Value: diffuse constriction or narrowing of the vessels formed within the six (five in mammals) pairs of branchial arches in embryogenesis; in the adult, some of these vessels give rise to the great vessels

Subject: abnormal pleuropericardial membrane morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the membrane formed by the paired folds that grow out from the lateral part of the body wall; the folds fuse and meet with the dorsal and ventral mesentery of the foregut, separating the pleural cavities from the pericardial cavity

Subject: absent pleuropericardial membrane
Value: absence of the membrane formed by the paired folds that grow out from the lateral part of the body wall; the folds fuse and meet with the dorsal and ventral mesentery of the foregut, separating the pleural cavities from the pericardial cavity

Subject: abnormal cardiogenic plate morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the splanchnic mesodermal thickening which forms cranial and lateral to the developing neural plate; angiogenic cell clusters (aka angioblastic cords) located in a horse-shoe shape configuration in the cardiogenic plate coalesce to form the right and left endocardial heart tubes which then fuse in cephalo-caudal direction to form a single primitive heart tube

Subject: absent cardiogenic plate
Value: absence of the splanchnic mesodermal thickening which forms cranial and lateral to the developing neural plate; normally, angiogenic cell clusters (aka angioblastic cords) located in a horse-shoe shape configuration in the cardiogenic plate coalesce to form the right and left endocardial heart tubes which then fuse in cephalo-caudal direction to form a single primitive heart tube

Subject: abnormal angioblastic cord morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cordlike masses of splanchnic mesenchymal cells ventral to the primordial pericardial coelom that arrange themselves side by side to form the primordia of the endocardial heart tubes

Subject: abnormal pericardial cavity morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anatomical body cavity in which the heart lies; the pericardial cavity forms in the lateral plate mesoderm above the buccopharyngeal membrane, as part of the early intraembryonic coelom, and is initially continuous with the two early pleural cavities

Subject: decreased hindbrain apoptosis
Value: decrease in the number of cells of the hindbrain undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: increased midbrain apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of cells of the midbrain undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: increased forebrain apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of cells of the forebrain undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: increased neural tube apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of cells of the neural tube undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: brain atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of the brain associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: midbrain atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of the midbrain associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: forebrain atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of the forebrain associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: neural tube degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of the hollow epithelial tube found on the dorsal side of the vertebrate embryo that develops into the central nervous system (i.e. brain and spinal cord)

Subject: abnormal aortic sac morphology
Value: any structural abnormality of the dilated structure that is lined by endothelial cells and located at the arterial pole of the heart just above (distal to) the truncus arteriosus in mammalian embryos; it is the primordial vascular channel from which the aortic arches (and eventually the dorsal aortae) arise; the aortic sac is homologous to the ventral aorta of gill-bearing vertebrates

Subject: dilated aortic sac
Value: abnormally stretched or widened aperture of the luminal space of the endothelial lined dilation that is located at the arterial pole of the heart just above (distal to) the truncus arteriosus in mammalian embryos; it is the primordial vascular channel from which the aortic arches (and eventually the dorsal aortae) arise; the aortic sac is homologous to the ventral aorta of gill-bearing vertebrates

Subject: abnormal sternum body morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the middle and longest portion of the sternum, lying between the manubrium superiorly and the xiphoid process inferiorly; the body of the sternum (gladiolus), is considerably lengthier, narrower, and thinner than the manubrium, attaining its greatest breadth close to the lower end

Subject: absent sternum body
Value: absence of the middle and longest portion of the sternum, lying between the manubrium superiorly and the xiphoid process inferiorly; the body of the sternum (gladiolus) is considerably lengthier, narrower, and thinner than the manubrium, attaining its greatest breadth close to the lower end

Subject: pectus excavatum
Value: a caved-in or sunken appearance of the anterior chest wall; the congenital deformity can either be present at birth or may not be visible until puberty

Subject: abnormal heart apex morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the lowest superficial part of the heart, normally directed downward, forward, and to the left, and overlapped by the left lung and pleura; the heart apex is formed by the inferolateral part of the left ventricle and responsible for regulating ventricle contraction

Subject: absent metencephalon
Value: absence of the anterior part of the developing vertebrate hindbrain or the corresponding part of the adult brain normally composed of the cerebellum and the pons Varolii

Subject: absent diencephalon
Value: absence or loss of the paired caudal parts of the prosencephalon from which the thalamus, hypothalamus, epithalamus and subthalamus are derived; these regions regulate autonomic, visceral and endocrine function, and process information directed to the cerebral cortex

Subject: abnormal Brunner's gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the branched acinotubular glands found in the submucosa of the duodenum located above the Sphincter of Oddi; their main function is to produce a mucus-rich alkaline secretion (containing bicarbonate) to protect the duodenum from the acidic content of chyme, provide an alkaline condition for the intestinal enzymes to be active (thus enabling absorption to take place), and lubricate the intestinal walls; they also secrete urogastrone, which inhibits parietal and chief cells of the stomach from secreting acid and their digestive enzymes

Subject: dilated Brunner's glands
Value: stretched or widened aperture of the luminal space of the branched acinotubular glands found in the submucosa of the duodenum located above the Sphincter of Oddi; their main function is to produce a mucus-rich alkaline secretion (containing bicarbonate) to protect the duodenum from the acidic content of chyme, provide an alkaline condition for the intestinal enzymes to be active (thus enabling absorption to take place), and lubricate the intestinal walls; they also secrete urogastrone, which inhibits parietal and chief cells of the stomach from secreting acid and their digestive enzymes

Subject: absent Brunner's glands
Value: absence of the branched acinotubular glands found in the submucosa of the duodenum located above the Sphincter of Oddi; their main function is to produce a mucus-rich alkaline secretion (containing bicarbonate) to protect the duodenum from the acidic content of chyme, provide an alkaline condition for the intestinal enzymes to be active (thus enabling absorption to take place), and lubricate the intestinal walls; they also secrete urogastrone, which inhibits parietal and chief cells of the stomach from secreting acid and their digestive enzymes

Subject: abnormal buccopharyngeal membrane morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thin bilaminar membrane derived from the prechordal plate that is devoid of mesoderm and formed by the apposition of the stomodeal ectoderm with the foregut endoderm; after the embryonic head fold has evolved it lies at the caudal limit of the stomodeum, forming a septum between the primitive mouth and pharynx; the membrane eventually disappears, and thus a communication is established between the mouth and the future pharynx

Subject: abnormal stomodeum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the primordial mouth region of the developing head, initially a midline ectodermal depression between the forebrain bulge (cranially) and the heart bulge (caudally) and between the maxillary and mandibular components of the first pharyngeal arch; the stomodeum is separated from the anterior end of the foregut by the buccopharyngeal membrane; the mouth is developed partly from the stomodeum, and partly from the floor of the anterior portion of the foregut; the lips, teeth, and gums are formed from the walls of the stomodeum, but the tongue is developed in the floor of the pharynx

Subject: abnormal upper lip morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the muscular fold forming the superior border of the mouth

Subject: abnormal lower lip morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the muscular fold bounding the opening of the mouth inferiorly

Subject: abnormal rhombic lip morphology
