Value: any structural anomaly of the posterior section of the developing metencephalon recognized transiently within the vertebrate embryo; the rhombic lip extends posteriorly from the roof of the fourth ventricle to dorsal neuroepithelial cell and can be divided into eight structural units based on rhombomeres 1-8 (r1-r8), recognized at early stages of hindbrain development; producing granule cells and five brainstem nuclei, the rhombic lip plays an important role in developing a complex cerebellar neural system

Subject: abnormal upper rhombic lip morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anterior-most region of dorsal hindbrain within rhombomere 1, adjacent the midbrain-hindbrain boundary

Subject: abnormal lower rhombic lip morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the posterior portion of the rhombic lip contained within rhombomeres 2-8 which gives rise to several brainstem nuclei and the choroid plexus

Subject: abnormal zone of polarizing activity morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the subset of cells found in the posterior mesenchyme region of the vertebrate limb bud; Sonic hedgehog (Shh) produced by ZPA represents the key mediator of the polarizing activity that regulates patterning of the limb along the anterio-posterior (A-P) axis

Subject: abnormal decidua basalis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the area of uterine endometrium found between the implanted chorionic vesicle and the myometrium; with continued growth of the embryo, the decidua basalis becomes incorporated into the maternal component of the definitive placenta

Subject: abnormal decidua capsularis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the layer of uterine endometrium overlying the implanted chorionic vesicle and facing the uterine cavity

Subject: delayed limb development
Value: late onset of the induction and/or differentiation of the limbs

Subject: abnormal surface ectoderm morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the surface (external) layer of ectoderm which begins to proliferate shortly after separation from the neuroectoderm; cells from the surface ectoderm differentiate to form the epidermis; epithelia lining the mouth and nasal cavities; hair follicles and nails; the lacrimal, tarsal, salivary, sebaceous, sweat, and mammary glands, and anterior pituitary gland (adenohypophysis); inner and outer ear structures; the lens, and conjunctival and corneal epithelia; dental enamel; and the apical ectodermal ridge inducing development of the limb buds

Subject: uveal coloboma
Value: congenital defect of the uvea in which some part of the structure is absent

Subject: abnormal optic fissure morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the ventral groove formed by invagination of the optic cup and its stalk by vascular mesenchyme from which the hyaloid vessels develop; a transient gap in the ventral margin of the developing optic cup that eventually closes to complete the eye wall inferiorly and enclose the hyaloid vessels in a canal in the optic stalk

Subject: abnormal optic fissure closure
Value: failure to initiate and/or complete closure of the transient gap in the ventral margin of the developing optic cup; fusion of the optic fissure begins with apposition of the inferior lips of the ventral-most optic cup and continues anteriorly toward its rim and posteriorly along the optic stalk; failure or late closure of the optic fissure prevents the establishment of normal fetal intraocular pressure and can result in microphthalmia associataed with colobomas

Subject: delayed optic fissure closure
Value: late onset of the initiation and/or completion of closure of the transient gap in the ventral margin of the developing optic cup; fusion of the optic fissure begins with apposition of the inferior lips of the ventral-most optic cup and continues anteriorly toward its rim and posteriorly along the optic stalk

Subject: abnormal hyaloid artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the artery which arises from the dorsal ophthalmic artery and enters the eye cup through the optic (choroid) fissure; the hyaloid artery is contained within the optic stalk of the eye, extends from the optic disc through the vitreous humor to the lens, and serves to supply nutrients to the developing lens in the growing fetus; it usually regresses (around 2 weeks after birth in mice and before birth in humans), with its proximal portion remaining as the central artery of the retina; regression of the hyaloid artery leaves a clear central zone through the vitreous humor, called the hyaloid canal or Cloquet's canal

Subject: persistent hyaloid artery
Value: incomplete regression of the hyaloid artery, usually accompanied by persistence of the hyperplastic primary vitreous; small remnants of the artery may remain with free remnants sometimes seen as floating material (aka muscae volitantes); an anterior remnant of the hyaloid artery can be seen as Mittendorf's dot, a small pinpoint-like scar on the posterior surface of the lens; a posterior remnant may be seen where the artery left the optic disc, and is known as Bergmeister's papilla

Subject: Bergmeister's papilla
Value: a posterior remnant of the fetal hyaloid artery that arises from the center of the optic disc and consists of a small tuft of fibrous tissue

Subject: abnormal lamina terminalis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anterior-most (rostral) portion of the wall of the neural tube, formed by closure of the anterior neuropore; the median strip of the anterior wall of the prosencephalon, which persists in a relatively unchanged state as the cerebral hemispheres grow out forward beyond the original anterior end of the prosencephalon; in the developed brain, the lamina terminalis remains as the thin rostral wall of the third ventricle, stretching from the bases of the major cerebral commissures (the anterior commissure, the commissure of the fornix, and the rostrum of the corpus callosum) to the dorsal surface of the optic chiasm

Subject: absent lamina terminalis
Value: absence of the anterior-most (rostral) portion of the wall of the neural tube, formed by closure of the anterior neuropore; agenesis of the lamina terminalis results in anencephaly

Subject: abnormal neuropore morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of either the anterior or posterior temporary opening leading from the central canal of the embryonic neural tube to the exterior; the anterior and posterior neuropores connect the lumen of the neural tube with the amniotic cavity

Subject: abnormal rostral neuropore morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the temporary opening at the extreme rostral (cephalic) end of the early embryonic prosencephalon (forebrain); the anterior neuropore appears before the process of neural tube closure is complete

Subject: abnormal caudal neuropore morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the temporary opening at the extreme caudal end of the neural tube in early embryos; the posterior neuropore appears before the process of neural tube closure is complete

Subject: syringomyelia
Value: a condition whereby a fluid-filled cyst or cavity (syrinx) develops within the spinal cord

Subject: triangular face
Value: a face whose lower half becomes relatively thin, approaching an appearance of a triangle with a tip facing downwards; usually associated with a prominent forehead and micrognathia

Subject: spina bifida cystica
Value: spinal bifida in which a hernial cyst containing meninges (meningocele), spinal cord (myelocele), or both (myelomeningocele) protrudes through a congenital cleft in the vertebral column; the protruding sac is encased in a layer of skin or a fine membrane that readily ruptures, causing leakage of cerebrospinal fluid and an increased risk of meningeal infection

Subject: myelocele
Value: hernial protrusion of the spinal cord through an opening or defect in the vertebral column

Subject: hypoxemia
Value: subnormal arterial oxygen tension; deficient oxygenation of arterial blood

Subject: respiratory acidosis
Value: acidosis caused by retention of and increased blood carbon dioxide concentration, often caused by decreased ventilation (hypoventilation); results in decreased blood pH unless kidneys compensate by retaining bicarbonate

Subject: metabolic acidosis
Value: decreased pH and bicarbonate concentration in tissues and/or body fluids caused when the body produces too much acid or when the kidneys are not removing enough acid from the body, as in diarrhea or in kidney disease

Subject: lactic acidosis
Value: a form of acidosis in which an accumulation of lactic acid in tissues occurs; causes include tissue hypoxia and drug effects

Subject: decreased serum complement activity
Value: decreased ability of the complement proteins to act sequentially to directly kill microbes, dispose of immune complexes, and regulate other immune processes

Subject: increased serum complement activity
Value: increased ability of the complement proteins to act sequentially to directly kill microbes, dispose of immune complexes, and regulate other immune processes

Subject: decreased cell death
Value: decreased occurrence of the cessation of function at the cellular level

Subject: increased cell death
Value: increased occurrence of the cessation of function at the cellular level

Subject: decreased calcium uptake by cardiac muscle
Value: decreased directed movement of calcium ions into cardiac muscle; decreased or disrupted uptake may give rise to energetic deficit and oxidative stress. leading to cardiac disease

Subject: increased calcium uptake by cardiac muscle
Value: increased directed movement of calcium ions into the cardiac muscle; increased mitochondrial calcium ion uptake can trigger programmed necrosis in cardiac muscle

Subject: decreased forebrain volume
Value: decrease from the average range of forebrain volume compared to normal

Subject: increased forebrain volume
Value: increase from the average range of forebrain volume compared to normal

Subject: decreased foot pad temperature
Value: decreased degree of heat natural to the foot pad-environment interface of a living being

Subject: blood vessel degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of the network of tubes that carries blood through the body

Subject: increased tumor incidence following infection
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplasms in a specific population after infection with a pathogen in a given time period, usually of a specific type

Subject: decreased tumor incidence following infection
Value: less than the expected number of neoplasms in a specific population after infection with a pathogen in a given time period, usually of a specific type

Subject: perivasculitis
Value: inflammation of a perivascular sheath surrounding a blood or lymph vessel, and the surrounding tissue

Subject: decreased susceptibility to experimental autoimmune orchitis
Value: greater likelihood that an organism will develop disease characterized by lymphocytes surrounding the tubuli recti, spermatogenic disturbance and irreversible damage to the seminiferous epithelium

Subject: increased susceptibility to experimental autoimmune orchitis
Value: reduced likelihood that an organism will develop disease characterized by lymphocytes surrounding the tubuli recti, spermatogenic disturbance and irreversible damage to the seminiferous epithelium

Subject: decreased mammary gland tumor incidence in breeding females
Value: less than the expected number of neoplams in the mammary gland in female organisms that are actively mating and producing offspring

Subject: decreased mammary gland tumor incidence in virgin females
Value: less than the expected number of neoplams in the mammary gland in female organisms that have never had sexual intercourse

Subject: increased mammary gland tumor incidence in breeding females
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplams in the mammary gland in female organisms that are actively mating and producing offspring

Subject: increased susceptibility to chemically induced skin inflammation
Value: decreased dosage threshold or greater inflammatory response of the skin after topical application of chemical irritants

Subject: decreased susceptibility to chemically induced skin inflammation
Value: increased dosage threshold, or reduced or no inflammation of the skin after topical application of chemical irritants

Subject: decreased noradrenaline level
Value: reduced amount of the hormone secreted by the adrenal medulla and acts as a neurotransmitter in the sympathetic peripheral nervous system and in some tracts of the CNS; noradrenaline is the demethylated biosynthetic precursor of epinephrine

Subject: increased noradrenaline level
Value: greater than normal amount of the hormone secreted by the adrenal medulla and acts as a neurotransmitter in the sympathetic peripheral nervous system and in some tracts of the CNS; noradrenaline is the demethylated biosynthetic precursor of epinephrine

Subject: abnormal kidney glutathione peroxidase activity
Value: <anomaly in the ability to catalyze the reaction: 2 glutathione + hydrogen peroxide = oxidized glutathione + 2 H2O in kidney tissue>

Subject: decreased kidney glutathione peroxidase activity
Value: <reduced ability to catalyze the reaction: 2 glutathione + hydrogen peroxide = oxidized glutathione + 2 H2O in kidney tissue>

Subject: increased kidney glutathione peroxidase activity
Value: <increased ability to catalyze the reaction: 2 glutathione + hydrogen peroxide = oxidized glutathione + 2 H2O in kidney tissue>

Subject: abnormal peroxidase activity
Value: <anomaly in the ability to catalyze the reaction: donor + hydrogen peroxide = oxidized donor + 2 H2O>

Subject: decreased peroxidase activity
Value: <reduced ability to catalyze the reaction: donor + hydrogen peroxide = oxidized donor + 2 H2O>

Subject: decreased eosinophil peroxidase activity
Value: <reduced ability to catalyze the reaction: donor + hydrogen peroxide = oxidized donor + 2 H2O in eosinophils>

Subject: increased peroxidase activity
Value: <increased ability to catalyze the reaction: donor + hydrogen peroxide = oxidized donor + 2 H2O>

Subject: increased eosinophil peroxidase activity
Value: <increased ability to catalyze the reaction: donor + hydrogen peroxide = oxidized donor + 2 H2O in eosinophils>

Subject: abnormal catechol O-methyltransferase activity
Value: <anomaly in the ability to catalyze the reaction: S-adenosyl-L-methionine + a catechol = S-adenosyl-L-homocysteine + a guaiacol>

Subject: decreased catechol O-methyltransferase activity
Value: <reduction in the ability to catalyze the reaction: S-adenosyl-L-methionine + a catechol = S-adenosyl-L-homocysteine + a guaiacol>

Subject: increased catechol O-methyltransferase activity
Value: <greater ability to catalyze the reaction: S-adenosyl-L-methionine + a catechol = S-adenosyl-L-homocysteine + a guaiacol>

Subject: decreased brain catechol O-methyltransferase activity
Value: <reduced ability of brain tissue to catalyze the reaction: S-adenosyl-L-methionine + a catechol = S-adenosyl-L-homocysteine + a guaiacol>

Subject: increased brain catechol O-methyltransferase activity
Value: <greater ability of brain tissue to catalyze the reaction: S-adenosyl-L-methionine + a catechol = S-adenosyl-L-homocysteine + a guaiacol>

Subject: abnormal choline O-acetyltransferase activity
Value: <anomaly in the ability to catalyze the reaction: acetyl-CoA + choline = acetylcholine + CoA>

Subject: decreased choline O-acetyltransferase activity
Value: <reduction in the ability to catalyze the reaction: acetyl-CoA + choline = acetylcholine + CoA>

Subject: increased choline O-acetyltransferase activity
Value: <greater ability to catalyze the reaction: acetyl-CoA + choline = acetylcholine + CoA>

Subject: decreased brain choline acetyltransferase activity
Value: <reduced ability of the brain to catalyze the reaction: acetyl-CoA + choline = acetylcholine + CoA>

Subject: increased brain choline acetyltransferase activity
Value: <greater ability of the brain to catalyze the reaction: acetyl-CoA + choline = acetylcholine + CoA>

Subject: abnormal glutamate decarboxylase activity
Value: <anomaly in the ability to catalyze the reaction: L-glutamate = 4-aminobutanoate + CO2>

Subject: decreased glutamate decarboxylase activity
Value: <reduction in the ability to catalyze the reaction: L-glutamate = 4-aminobutanoate + CO2>

Subject: increased glutamate decarboxylase activity
Value: <greater ability to catalyze the reaction: L-glutamate = 4-aminobutanoate + CO2>

Subject: abnormal nicotinamide N-methyltransferase activity
Value: <anomaly in the ability to catalyze the reaction: S-adenosyl-L-methionine(1+) + nicotinamide = 1-methylnicotinamide + S-adenosyl-L-homocysteine>

Subject: decreased nicotinamide N-methyltransferase activity
Value: <reduction in the ability to catalyze the reaction: S-adenosyl-L-methionine(1+) + nicotinamide = 1-methylnicotinamide + S-adenosyl-L-homocysteine>

Subject: increased nicotinamide N-methyltransferase activity
Value: <greater ability to catalyze the reaction: S-adenosyl-L-methionine(1+) + nicotinamide = 1-methylnicotinamide + S-adenosyl-L-homocysteine>

Subject: abnormal glutathione level
Value: anomaly in the amount of a tripeptide compound consisting of glutamic acid attached via its side chain to the N-terminus of cysteinylglycine

Subject: decreased glutathione level
Value: reduction in the amount of a tripeptide compound consisting of glutamic acid attached via its side chain to the N-terminus of cysteinylglycine

Subject: decreased kidney glutathione level
Value: reduction in the amount of a tripeptide compound consisting of glutamic acid attached via its side chain to the N-terminus of cysteinylglycine in the kidney

Subject: increased glutathione level
Value: increase in the amount of a tripeptide compound consisting of glutamic acid attached via its side chain to the N-terminus of cysteinylglycine

Subject: increased kidney glutathione level
Value: increase in the amount of a tripeptide compound consisting of glutamic acid attached via its side chain to the N-terminus of cysteinylglycine in the kidney

Subject: abnormal acetylcholinesterase activity
Value: <anomaly in the catalysis of the reaction: acetylcholine + H2O = choline + acetate>

Subject: decreased acetylcholinesterase activity
Value: <decreased rate of the catalysis of the reaction: acetylcholine + H2O = choline + acetate>

Subject: increased acetylcholinesterase activity
Value: <increased rate of the catalysis of the reaction: acetylcholine + H2O = choline + acetate>

Subject: decreased brain acetylcholinesterase activity
Value: <decreased rate of the catalysis of the reaction: acetylcholine + H2O = choline + acetate in the brain>

Subject: increased brain acetylcholinesterase activity
Value: <increased rate of the catalysis of the reaction: acetylcholine + H2O = choline + acetate in the brain>

Subject: abnormal monoamine oxidase activity
Value: <anomaly in the ability to catalyze the reaction: RCH2NHR' + H2O + O2 = RCHO + R'NH2 + H2O2; oxygen is used to remove an amine group from a monoamine, requiring FAD as an enzymatic cofactor, and produces aldehyde and ammonia>

Subject: decreased monoamine oxidase activity
Value: <reduction in the ability to catalyze the reaction: RCH2NHR' + H2O + O2 = RCHO + R'NH2 + H2O2; oxygen is used to remove an amine group from a monoamine, requiring FAD as an enzymatic cofactor, and produces aldehyde and ammonia>

Subject: increased monoamine oxidase activity
Value: <increase in the ability to catalyze the reaction: RCH2NHR' + H2O + O2 = RCHO + R'NH2 + H2O2; oxygen is used to remove an amine group from a monoamine, requiring FAD as an enzymatic cofactor, and produces aldehyde and ammonia>

Subject: decreased brain monoamine oxidase activity
Value: <reduction in the ability to catalyze the reaction: RCH2NHR' + H2O + O2 = RCHO + R'NH2 + H2O2 in the brain; oxygen is used to remove an amine group from a monoamine, requiring FAD as an enzymatic cofactor, and produces aldehyde and ammonia>

Subject: increased brain monoamine oxidase activity
Value: <increase in the ability to catalyze the reaction: RCH2NHR' + H2O + O2 = RCHO + R'NH2 + H2O2 in brain tissue; oxygen is used to remove an amine group from a monoamine, requiring FAD as an enzymatic cofactor, and produces aldehyde and ammonia>

Subject: abnormal 5-aminolevulinate synthase activity
Value: <any anomaly in the ability to catalyze the reaction: glycine + H(+) + succinyl-CoA = 5-aminolevulinate + CO(2) + CoA>

Subject: decreased 5-aminolevulinate synthase activity
Value: <reduced ability to catalyze the reaction: glycine + H(+) + succinyl-CoA = 5-aminolevulinate + CO(2) + CoA>

Subject: increased 5-aminolevulinate synthase activity
Value: <increased ability to catalyze the reaction: glycine + H(+) + succinyl-CoA = 5-aminolevulinate + CO(2) + CoA>

Subject: decreased circulating ceruloplasmin level
Value: decreased amount in the blood of any of ceruloplasmin, a ferroxidase enzyme

Subject: increased circulating ceruloplasmin level
Value: increased amount in the blood of any of ceruloplasmin, a ferroxidase enzyme

Subject: decreased haptoglobin level
Value: decreased amount of haptoglobin, a protein that binds free hemoglobin (Hb) released from erythrocytes with high affinity and thereby inhibits its oxidative activity

Subject: decreased circulating haptoglobin level
Value: decreased amount in the blood of any of haptoglobin, a protein that binds free hemoglobin (Hb) released from erythrocytes with high affinity and thereby inhibits its oxidative activity

Subject: increased haptoglobin level
Value: increased amount of any of haptoglobin, a protein that binds free hemoglobin (Hb) released from erythrocytes with high affinity and thereby inhibits its oxidative activity

Subject: increased circulating haptoglobin level
Value: increased amount in the blood of any of haptoglobin, a protein that binds free hemoglobin (Hb) released from erythrocytes with high affinity and thereby inhibits its oxidative activity

Subject: split sternal manubrium
Value: the appearance of an abnormal division of the cranial most segment of the sternum

Subject: absent sternal manubrium
Value: absence of the cranial most segment of the sternum

Subject: abnormal somite segmentation clock
Value: anomaly or loss of the oscillatory mechanism governed by periodic shifts in gene expression and operating in the presomitic mesoderm that drives the regular periodicity with which somites are formed in the course of vertebrate segmentation. The total number of somites formed and the periodicity with which they are produced are species-specific parameters (e.g. humans have 33 somites with a somitogenesis period of approximately 6 hours while mice have 65 somites with a period of approximately 2 hours)

Subject: prolonged somite segmentation clock period
Value: extension of the somite segmentation clock period; may lead to decreased numbers of somites and their resultant vertebrae

Subject: retinal spots
Value: the appearance of roundish lesions on the retina, frequently white, and may be due to inflammation, degeneration, vasculitis, exudates, edema or mineral deposits

Subject: enlarged trachea
Value: increased size of the tube descending from the larynx and branching into the right and left main bronchi

Subject: aberrant crypt foci
Value: a neoplastic lesion in which large, thick clusters of abnormal tube-like glands are found in the lining of the colon and rectum; aberrant crypt foci are precursors of colorectal polyps, adenoma and colon cancer

Subject: tomacula
Value: focal myelin swellings due to redundant folding of myelin sheaths; often sausage-shaped and excessively folded

Subject: enlarged floor plate
Value: increased size of the specialized glial structure (non-neuronal cells) situated at the ventral midline of the embryonic neural tube; this structure spans the anteroposterior axis from the midbrain to the tail regions, separating the left and right basal plates of the developing neural tube, and serves as an organizer to ventralize tissues in the embryo as well as to guide neuronal positioning and differentiation along the dorsoventral axis of the neural tube

Subject: dilated brain ventricles
Value: the luminal space of one or more of the four communicating cavities within the brain that are continuous with the central canal of the spinal cord is increased in volume or area, usually with an increase in contained fluid

Subject: absent brain ventricles
Value: absence of one or more of the four communicating cavities within the brain that are continuous with the central canal of the spinal cord

Subject: absent fourth ventricle
Value: absence of the irregularly shaped cavity in the rhombencephalon, normally located between the medulla oblongata, the pons, and the isthmus in front, and the cerebellum behind; the fourth ventricle is continuous with the central canal of the cord below and with the cerebral aqueduct above, and through its lateral and median apertures it communicates with the subarachnoid space

Subject: absent third ventricle
Value: absence of the narrow cleft located inferior to the corpus callosum, within the diencephalon, between the paired thalami; its floor is formed by the hypothalamus, its anterior wall by the lamina terminalis, and its roof by ependyma; it communicates with the fourth ventricle by the cerebral aqueduct, and with the lateral ventricles by the interventricular foramina

Subject: absent lateral ventricles
Value: absence of the cavity in each of the cerebral hemispheres derived from the cavity of the embryonic neural tube; lateral ventricles are separated from each other by the septum pellucidum, and each communicates with the third ventricle by the foramen of Monro, through which also the choroid plexuses of the lateral ventricles become continuous with that of the third ventricle

Subject: collapsed brain ventricles
Value: the luminal space of one or more of the four communicating cavities within the brain that are continuous with the central canal of the spinal cord are severely reduced in volume or area, possibly due to reduced or absent cerebrospinal fluid production; collapsed ventricles can be a sign of increased intracranial pressure and accumulation of water in the brain parenchyma

Subject: abnormal septal nucleus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the groups of neural nuclei situated in the septal region which have afferent and cholinergic efferent connections with a variety of forebrain and brainstem areas including the hippocampus, the lateral hypothalamus, the tegmentum, and the amygdala

Subject: absent telencephalon
Value: absence of the enlarged anteriolateral part of the brain; consists of the paired cerebral hemispheres and olfactory bulbs, the basal ganglia and the connecting structures

Subject: abnormal pleural cavity morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the potential space between the two pleurae (visceral and parietal) of the lungs; the pleural cavity, with its associated pleurae, aids optimal functioning of the lungs during breathing; it normally contains a thin film of serous fluid which lubricates the opposed pleural membranes so that they can glide smoothly against one another during ventilation

Subject: abnormal primitive streak elongation
Value: any anomaly in the process by which the primitive streak extends anteriorly and elongates towards the distal (cranial) end of the embryo to reach its full length

Subject: everted embryonic neuroepithelium
Value: an inside-out appearance of the embryonic neuroepithelium characteristic of defective primary neurulation resulting from failure of neural fold elevation; everted neural folds assume a convex instead of a concave morphology and fail to bend toward each other and fuse at the dorsal midline leading to exencephaly

Subject: abnormal heart atrium weight
Value: abnormal average weight of both the left and right atria

Subject: abnormal heart ventricles weight
Value: abnormal average weight of both the left and right ventricles together

Subject: abnormal adrenal gland weight
Value: abnormal weight of the pair of endocrine glands located above the kidney that are responsible for steroid hormone secretion from the cortex and neurotransmitter (such as epinephrine and norepinephrine) secretion from the medulla

Subject: abnormal stride length
Value: abnormal average distance between steps

Subject: abnormal acetaminophen metabolism
Value: altered ability to metabolize acetaminophen, used as a non-narcotic analgesic, a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory and an anti-pyretic agent

Subject: abnormal fluoxetine metabolism
Value: altered ability to metabolize fluoxetine, an antidepressant of the selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) class which is commonly used to treat various psychiatric disorders

Subject: abnormal haloperidol metabolism
Value: altered ability to metabolize haloperidol, a butyrophenone-type antipsychotic medication used in the treatment of schizophrenia, acute psychosis, and delirium

Subject: abnormal lithium metabolism
Value: altered ability to metabolize lithium, commonly used as a mood-stabilizing drug, primarily in the treatment of bipolar disorder in the treatment of both depressive and particularly of mania episodes

Subject: abnormal nicotine metabolism
Value: altered ability to metabolize nicotine, a potent parasympathomimetic alkaloid that acts as a stimulant in mammals; nicotine activates the mesolimbic pathway in the central nervous system, which regulates feelings of reward and pleasure, and this response is thought to contribute to the addictive nature of nicotine

Subject: abnormal trichloroethene metabolism
Value: altered ability to metabolize trichloroethylene, a toxic, colorless, photoreactive, chlorinated hydrocarbon liquid, used as an industrial solvent, and was used a anesthetic and as an inhaled obstetrical analgesic

Subject: abnormal maternal body weight gain
Value: anomaly in the expected amount of female body weight gain during pregnancy

Subject: increased maternal body weight gain
Value: greater than the expected amount of female body weight gain during pregnancy

Subject: decreased maternal body weight gain
Value: reduction in the expected amount of female body weight gain during pregnancy

Subject: abnormal endocardial heart tube morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the paired, longitudinal, endothelial-lined channels formed from the cardiogenic mesoderm in embryonic development; angiogenic cell clusters (aka angioblastic cords) located in a horse-shoe shape configuration in the cardiogenic plate coalesce to form the right and left endocardial heart tubes which then fuse in cephalo-caudal direction to form a single primitive heart tube

Subject: increased embryonic neuroepithelium apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of cells of the embryonic neuroepithelium undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: increased embryonic neuroepithelium thickness
Value: increased width of the epithelial cell layer that lines the neural tube and develops into the nervous system and into the neural crest cells

Subject: decreased embryonic neuroepithelium thickness
Value: reduced width of the epithelial cell layer that lines the neural tube and develops into the nervous system and into the neural crest cells

Subject: abnormal embryonic neuroepithelial cell proliferation
Value: any anomaly in the ability of the cells of the embryonic neuroepithelium to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: increased embryonic neuroepithelial cell proliferation
Value: increase in the expansion rate of the cells of the embryonic neuroepithelium by cell division

Subject: decreased embryonic neuroepithelial cell proliferation
Value: decrease in the expansion rate of the cells of the embryonic neuroepithelium by cell division

Subject: incomplete caudal neuropore closure
Value: incomplete joining together of the neural folds of the caudal opening of the neural tube; failure of caudal neuropore closure results in spina bifida, the severity of which depends on how much of the spinal cord remains exposed

Subject: delayed rostral neuropore closure
Value: a delay in the fusion of the cephalic neural folds

Subject: delayed caudal neuropore closure
Value: a delay in the joining together of the neural folds of the caudal opening of the neural tube

Subject: diastematomyelia
Value: a rare congenital anomaly that results in the splitting of the spinal cord in a longitudinal direction, usually at the level of the upper lumbar vertebra; this condition occurs in the presence of an osseous (bone), cartilaginous or fibrous septum in the central portion of the spinal canal which then produces a complete or incomplete sagittal division of the spinal cord into two hemicords, each half being surrounded by a dural sac; when the split does not reunite distally to the spur, the condition is referred to as a diplomyelia

Subject: diplomyelia
Value: true duplication of the spinal cord; each cord has two dorsal and two ventral horns and paired nerve roots, but the two cords are contained within a single dural sac

Subject: spinal cord degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of the spinal cord

Subject: abnormal ventral ectodermal ridge morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the morphologically distinct group of ectodermal cells that serves as an important signaling center in the mouse tail-bud following completion of gastrulation, and contains progenitor cells that contribute to the ventral midline ectoderm of the tail; ablation of the VER leads to defects in somitogenesis and tail elongation

Subject: decreased ventral ectodermal ridge size
Value: reduced size of the morphologically distinct group of ectodermal cells that serves as an important signaling center in the mouse tail-bud following completion of gastrulation, and contains progenitor cells that contribute to the ventral midline ectoderm of the tail

Subject: abnormal hemangioblast morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the pluripotent precursor cell in the yolk sac that can give rise to mesenchymal cells including erythrocytes and endothelial cells; hemangioblasts are the progenitors that form the blood islands

Subject: abnormal hemangioblast number
Value: deviation from the normal numbers of pluripotent precursor cells in the yolk sac that can give rise to mesenchymal cells including erythrocytes and endothelial cells; hemangioblasts are the progenitors that form the blood islands

Subject: increased hemangioblast number
Value: increased number of the pluripotent precursor cells in the yolk sac that can give rise to mesenchymal cells including erythrocytes and endothelial cells; hemangioblasts are the progenitors that form the blood islands

Subject: decreased hemangioblast number
Value: reduced number of the pluripotent precursor cells in the yolk sac that can give rise to mesenchymal cells including erythrocytes and endothelial cells; hemangioblasts are the progenitors that form the blood islands

Subject: abnormal neck morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the part of body by which the head is connected to the trunk extending from the base of the cranium to the top of the shoulders

Subject: elongated neck
Value: increased length of the neck

Subject: short neck
Value: decreased length of the neck

Subject: absent neck
Value: absence of the part of body by which the head is connected to the trunk extending from the base of the cranium to the top of the shoulders

Subject: abnormal nuchal region morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the posterior region of the neck, including the suboccipital region

Subject: absent head fold
Value: inability to form the crescent-shaped, ventrally located fold of the embryonic disc at the future cephalic end of the developing embryo; the head fold constitutes the first body fold, and initiates brain, foregut and heart development

Subject: small sebaceous gland
Value: decreased size of the sebum secreting glands of the hair shaft

Subject: abnormal uterine spiral artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the corkscrew-like arteries in premenstrual or progestational endometrium; uterine spiral arteries play a vital role in supplying nutrients to the placenta and fetus, and are thus remodeled into highly dilated inelastic vessels by the action of invading trophoblast (physiological change)

Subject: abnormal uterine spiral artery remodeling
Value: any anomaly of the physiological conversion of the uterine spiral arteries into highly dilated vessels by the action of invading trophoblast; in pregnancy, trophoblast invasion and uterine spiral artery remodeling are important for lowering maternal vascular resistance and increasing uteroplacental blood flow; this process involves loss of smooth muscle and elastic lamina from the vessel wall, and significant dilation at the mouth of the vessel; impaired spiral artery remodeling has been implicated in preeclampsia, fetal growth restriction, and preterm labor

Subject: abnormal somite border morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anatomical surface separating somites; somite formation requires the physical separation of somitic tissue from the initially continuous presomitic mesoderm (PSM), coalescence of cells in the forming somite, and the establishment of a stable border between the somite and the PSM; when a somite forms in the anterior end of the PSM, an intersomitic boundary (also called a fissure, gap, or cleft) emerges, and it is rapidly followed by a mesenchymal-to-epithelial transition of cells that face a forming gap

Subject: abnormal common carotid artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the left or right common carotid arteries which extend headward on each side of the anterior neck and deliver oxygenated nutrient filled blood from the heart to the head, neck and brain; the left originates in the arch of the aorta over the heart; the right originates in the brachiocephalic trunk, the largest branch from the arch of the aorta; each common carotid artery divides into an external and an internal carotid artery

Subject: abnormal internal carotid artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the terminal branch of the left or right common carotid artery which supplies oxygenated blood to the brain and eyes

Subject: abnormal external carotid artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the terminal branch of the left or right common carotid artery which supplies oxygenated blood to the throat, neck glands, tongue, face, mouth, ear, scalp and dura mater of the meninges

Subject: abnormal perineural vascular plexus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the capillary bed that initially surrounds the relative avascular brain and spinal cord; the perineural vascular plexus (PNVP) is the precursor to the blood brain barrier formed by angioblasts which migrate away from somites and is recruited to surround the neural tube in response to VEGF; vascularization of the brain and spinal cord occurs via angiogenesis as sprouting vessels from the PNVP invade the neuroepithelium and grow inward toward the ventricular lumen

Subject: abnormal behavioral response to methamphetamine
Value: anomaly in the behavioral response induced by methamphetamine such as induced hyperactivity or stereotypic behavior

Subject: abnormal response to radiation
Value: any anomaly in the physiological changes induced by ionizing radiation such as UV light, X-rays, or gamma rays

Subject: abnormal response to exercise
Value: any anomaly in the physiological changes induced by controlled exercise

Subject: abnormal polar body morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of one of the small cells that are produced during the development of an oocyte and ultimately degenerate; a polar body contains one of the nuclei derived from the first or second meiotic division but little or no cytoplasm

Subject: abnormal primary polar body morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small cell formed by the first meiotic division of oocytes

Subject: abnormal secondary polar body morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small cell formed by the second meiotic division of oocytes; in mammals, the second polar body may fail to form unless the ovum has been penetrated by a sperm cell

Subject: abnormal anterior primitive streak morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anterior region of the vertebrate primitive streak which gives rise to the axial and paraxial mesoderm, the definitive endoderm, the primitive groove, and the primitive node

Subject: abnormal posterior primitive streak morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the posterior region of the vertebrate primitive streak which gives rise to the extraembryonic mesoderm

Subject: decreased neural crest cell proliferation
Value: reduced ability of the transient and migratory group of cells that emerge from the dorsal region of the neural tube and migrate to many peripheral locations to form various tissues of the adult to undergo rapid expansion by cell division

Subject: increased neural crest cell proliferation
Value: enhanced ability of the transient and migratory group of cells that emerge from the dorsal region of the neural tube and migrate to many peripheral locations to form various tissues of the adult to undergo rapid expansion by cell division

Subject: increased inner cell mass apoptosis
Value: increased number of cells of the blastocyst that develop into the body of the embryo undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: increased neural crest cell apoptosis
Value: increased number of (any population) of neural crest cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal neural crest cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly in the complex process by which multipotent neural crest progenitors acquire migratory and invasive properties, emigrate from the dorsal aspect of the neural tube, migrate along distinct pathways, and differentiate into diverse cell types

Subject: abnormal neural crest cell delamination
Value: any anomaly in the process by which a neural crest cell (NCC) physically dissociates from the neuroepithelium in the dorsal aspect of the neural tube; premigratory NCCs exist within a fully polarized epithelial layer, adjoined by adherens junctions and tight junctions; NCC delamination involves an epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) during which epithelial cells are converted into migratory mesenchymal cells; EMT requires loss of apical-basal cell polarity and dissolution of tight junctions and is accompanied by changes in cytoskeletal organization and a switch in adhesive properties so that cells can separate from the neuroepithelium and emigrate

Subject: abnormal cardiac neural crest cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cardiac neural crest cells (NCCs), a subpopulation of cranial NCCs originating from the lower hindbrain between the otic placode and third somite; cardiac NCCs migrate to the circumpharyngeal ridge (an arc-shape ridge located dorsal to the forming caudal pharyngeal arches) and then into the 3rd, 4th and 6th pharyngeal arches and the cardiac outflow tract (OFT); cardiac NCCs contribute to the remodeling of arch arteries, septation of the cardiac OFT, closure of the ventricular septum, and innervation of the cardiac ganglia

Subject: increased cardiac neural crest cell number
Value: greater than expected number of cardiac neural crest cells (NCCs), a subpopulation of cranial NCCs originating from the lower hindbrain between the otic placode and third somite; cardiac NCCs contribute to the remodeling of arch arteries, septation of the cardiac OFT, closure of the ventricular septum, and innervation of the cardiac ganglia

Subject: decreased cardiac neural crest cell number
Value: reduction in the number of cardiac neural crest cells (NCCs), a subpopulation of cranial NCCs originating from the lower hindbrain between the otic placode and third somite; cardiac NCCs migrate to the circumpharyngeal ridge and then into the 3rd, 4th and 6th pharyngeal arches and the cardiac outflow tract (OFT), and contribute to the remodeling of arch arteries, septation of the cardiac OFT, closure of the ventricular septum, and innervation of the cardiac ganglia

Subject: absent cardiac neural crest cells
Value: absence or loss of the cardiac neural crest cells (NCCs), a subpopulation of cranial NCCs originating from the lower hindbrain between the otic placode and third somite; cardiac NCCs contribute to the remodeling of arch arteries, septation of the cardiac OFT, closure of the ventricular septum, and innervation of the cardiac ganglia; ablation of cardiac NCCs results in cardiac outflow defects

Subject: impaired cardiac neural crest cell differentiation
Value: abnormal or arrest of differentiation or patterning of the cardiac neural crest cells (NCCs), a subpopulation of cranial NCCs originating from the lower hindbrain between the otic placode and third somite; cardiac NCCs have the potential to differentiate into smooth muscle cells of the cardiac outflow tract and its septum, walls of aortic and arch-derived arteries, all of the parasympathetic innervation of the heart, and the connective tissue of the glands in the head and neck region, including the thymus, thyroid and parathyroid glands

Subject: abnormal cardiac neural crest cell migration
Value: any anomaly in the migratory path of cardiac neural crest cells (NCCs), a subpopulation of cranial NCCs which originate from the lower hindbrain between the otic placode and third somite and migrate to the circumpharyngeal ridge (an arc-shape ridge located dorsal to the forming caudal pharyngeal arches) and then into the 3rd, 4th and 6th pharyngeal arches and the cardiac outflow tract (OFT); cardiac NCCs undergo migration away from the neural tube by following a dorsolateral path under the ectoderm, leading them to the pharyngeal arches; after pausing, they resume migration under the pharyngeal endoderm and, along the aortic arch arteries, populate the cardiac OFT where they contribute the aorticopulmonary septum, and ultimately colonize the heart to form the ventricular septum and cardiac ganglia

Subject: increased cardiac neural crest cell apoptosis
Value: increased number of cardiac neural crest cells (NCCs) undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal cranial neural crest cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the neural crest cells (NCCs) originating in the anterior part of the developing embryo and residing between the mid-diencephalon and the forming hindbrain; cranial NCCs migrate dorsolaterally to form the craniofacial mesenchyme that differentiates into various craniofacial cartilages and bones, cranial neurons, glia, and connective tissues of the face; these cells enter the pharyngeal pouches and arches where they give rise to thymic cells, bones of the middle ear and jaw (mandible), and the odontoblasts of the tooth primordia; like their counterparts in the trunk, cranial NCCs also contribute to the developing peripheral nervous system, along with the pigmented cell (i.e. melanocyte) lineage

Subject: decreased cranial neural crest cell number
Value: reduction in the number of neural crest cells (NCCs) originating in the anterior part of the developing embryo and residing between the mid-diencephalon and the forming hindbrain; cranial NCCs migrate dorsolaterally to form the craniofacial mesenchyme that differentiates into various craniofacial cartilages and bones, cranial neurons, glia, and connective tissues of the face; these cells enter the pharyngeal pouches and arches where they give rise to thymic cells, bones of the middle ear and jaw (mandible), and the odontoblasts of the tooth primordial; like their counterparts in the trunk, cranial NCCs also contribute to the developing peripheral nervous system, along with the pigmented cell (i.e. melanocyte) lineage

Subject: impaired cranial neural crest cell differentiation
Value: abnormal or arrest of differentiation or patterning of the cranial neural crest cells

Subject: abnormal cranial neural crest cell migration
Value: any anomaly in the migratory path of the cranial neural crest cells (NCCs), which originate in the anterior part of the developing embryo and reside between the mid-diencephalon and the forming hindbrain; cranial NCCs migrate dorsolaterally to form the craniofacial mesenchyme that differentiates into various craniofacial cartilages and bones, cranial neurons, glia, and connective tissues of the face; these cells enter the pharyngeal pouches and arches where they give rise to thymic cells, bones of the middle ear and jaw (mandible), and the odontoblasts of the tooth primordial; like their counterparts in the trunk, cranial NCCs contribute to the developing peripheral nervous system, along with the pigmented cell (i.e. melanocyte) lineage

Subject: abnormal cranial neural crest cell proliferation
Value: any anomaly in the ability of the cranial neural crest cells (NCCs) to undergo rapid expansion by cell division

Subject: increased cranial neural crest cell proliferation
Value: enhanced ability of the cranial neural crest cells (NCCs) to undergo rapid expansion by cell division

Subject: decreased cranial neural crest cell proliferation
Value: reduced ability of the cranial neural crest cells (NCCs) to undergo rapid expansion by cell division

Subject: increased cranial neural crest cell apoptosis
Value: increased number of cranial neural crest cells (NCCs) undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal alpha-beta T cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a T cell that expresses an alpha-beta T cell receptor complex

Subject: abnormal alpha-beta T cell number
Value: aberrant number of T cells that expresses an alpha-beta T cell receptor complex

Subject: increased alpha-beta T cell number
Value: greater number of T cells that expresses an alpha-beta T cell receptor complex

Subject: decreased alpha-beta T cell number
Value: reduced number of T cells that expresses an alpha-beta T cell receptor complex

Subject: abnormal KLRG1-positive NK cell number
Value: deviation in the number of KLRG1 positive NK cells that represent a maturation subset of NK cells and is linked to NK cell proliferation

Subject: increased KLRG1-positive NK cell number
Value: increase in the number of KLRG1 positive NK cells that represent a maturation subset of NK cells and is linked to NK cell proliferation

Subject: decreased KLRG1-positive NK cell number
Value: decrease in the number of KLRG1 positive NK cells that represent a maturation subset of NK cells and is linked to NK cell proliferation

Subject: abnormal CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of CD4-positive, alpha-beta long-lived T cells with the phenotype CD45RO-positive and CD127-positive, or also described as being CD25-negative, CD44-high, and CD122- high

Subject: abnormal effector memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of a CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cell with the phenotype CCR7-negative, CD127-positive, CD45RO-positive, and CD25-negative

Subject: abnormal central memory CD4-positive, alpha-beta T cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of a CD4-positive, alpha-beta memory T cell with the phenotype CCR7-positive, CD127-positive, CD45RO-positive, and CD25-negative

Subject: abnormal central memory CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cell number
Value: an anomaly in the number of CD8-positive, alpha beta memory T cells with the phenotype CCR7-positive, CD127-positive, CD45RO-positive, and CD25-negative

Subject: abnormal CD4-positive, CD25-positive, alpha-beta regulatory T cell number
Value: any anomaly in the number of the CD4-positive, CD25-positive T cell subset which regulates overall immune responses as well as the responses of other T cell subsets through direct cell-cell contact and cytokine release

Subject: abnormal CD8-positive, alpha-beta memory T cell number
Value: an anomaly in the number of CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cell with memory phenotype indicated by being CD45RO and CD127-positive; this cell type is also described as being CD25-negative, CD44-high, and CD122-high

Subject: abnormal brain weight
Value: anomaly in the average weight of the brain

Subject: abnormal liver cholesterol level
Value: aberrant amount in the liver of the principal sterol of vertebrates and the precursor of many steroids, including bile acids and steroid hormones; it is a component of the plasma membrane lipid bilayer and of plasma lipoproteins and can be found in all animal tissues

Subject: abnormal liver glycogen level
Value: abnormal concentration of a readily converted carbohydrate reserve in liver

Subject: abnormal liver triglyceride level
Value: aberrant concentration of naturally occurring esters of three fatty acids and glycerol in the liver; triglycerides are widespread in adipose tissue, commonly circulate in the blood in the form of lipoproteins, and are involved in the process of bidirectional transference of adipose fat and blood glucose with the liverower than normal concentration of triacylglycerols in the liver

Subject: abnormal brain cholesterol level
Value: aberrant amount in the brain of the principal sterol of vertebrates and the precursor of many steroids, including bile acids and steroid hormones; it is a component of the plasma membrane lipid bilayer and of plasma lipoproteins and can be found in all animal tissues

Subject: abnormal phospholipid transfer protein activity
Value: altered ability of phospholipid transfer proteins to transfer phospholipids from triglyceride-rich lipoproteins to high density lipoprotein (HDL)

Subject: increased phospholipid transfer protein activity
Value: greater ability of phospholipd transfer proteins to transfer phospholipids from triglyceride-rich lipoproteins to high density lipoprotein (HDL)

Subject: decreased phospholipid transfer protein activity
Value: reduction in the ability of phospholipd transfer proteins to transfer phospholipids from triglyceride-rich lipoproteins to high density lipoprotein (HDL)

Subject: abnormal extensor digitorum longus weight
Value: anomaly in the weight of the penniform muscle of the lateral front part of the leg responsible for extension of the toes and dorsiflexion of the ankle

Subject: abnormal rhombomere 1 morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the first transiently divided segment of the developing rhombencephalon; rhombomeres are lineage restricted, express different genes from one another, and adopt different developmental fates; rhombomeres are numbered in caudal to rostral order with the first rhombomere arising next to the midbrain-hindbrain boundary, or isthmus

Subject: decreased rhombomere 1 size
Value: reduced size of the first transiently divided segment of the developing rhombencephalon; rhombomeres are lineage restricted, express different genes from one another, and adopt different developmental fates; rhombomeres are numbered in caudal to rostral order with the first rhombomere arising next to the midbrain-hindbrain boundary, or isthmus

Subject: increased rhombomere 1 size
Value: increased size of the first transiently divided segment of the developing rhombencephalon; rhombomeres are lineage restricted, express different genes from one another, and adopt different developmental fates; rhombomeres are numbered in caudal to rostral order with the first rhombomere arising next to the midbrain-hindbrain boundary, or isthmus

Subject: absent rhombomere 1
Value: absence of the first transiently divided segment of the developing rhombencephalon; rhombomeres are lineage restricted, express different genes from one another, and adopt different developmental fates; rhombomeres are numbered in caudal to rostral order with the first rhombomere arising next to the midbrain-hindbrain boundary, or isthmus

Subject: abnormal rhombomere 2 morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the second transiently divided segment of the developing rhombencephalon; rhombomeres are lineage restricted, express different genes from one another, and adopt different developmental fates; rhombomeres are numbered in caudal to rostral order

Subject: decreased rhombomere 2 size
Value: reduced size of the second transiently divided segment of the developing rhombencephalon; rhombomeres are lineage restricted, express different genes from one another, and adopt different developmental fates; rhombomeres are numbered in caudal to rostral order

Subject: increased rhombomere 2 size

Value: absence of the eighth transiently divided segment of the developing rhombencephalon; rhombomeres are lineage restricted, express different genes from one another, and adopt different developmental fates; rhombomeres are numbered in caudal to rostral order

Subject: abnormal rhombomere boundary morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anatomical surface separating the rhombomere segments

Subject: rhombomere fusion
Value: the union of one or more rhombomeres into a single structure

Subject: rhombomere transformation
Value: homeotic transformation of a specific rhombomere to adopt the fate of another

Subject: absent cerebral aqueduct
Value: absence of the channel in the mesencephalon that connects the third and fourth ventricles

Subject: abnormal enteric neural crest cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the neural crest cells that arise predominantly from the vagal region of the neural tube (vagal neural crest), adjacent to somites 1-7 and migrate rostro-caudally along the gastrointestinal tract to form two ganglionated plexuses of neurons and glial cells that comprise the enteric nervous system (ENS); a smaller proportion of ENCCs come from the sacral neural crest, caudal to somite 28, and migrate caudo-rostrally to colonize the distal gut; neural crest cells are termed enteric neural crest-derived cells upon entering the foregut at E9-9.5 in mice (after 4 weeks gestation in humans)

Subject: decreased enteric neural crest cell number
Value: a reduction in the number of neural crest cells that arise predominantly from the vagal region of the neural tube (vagal neural crest), adjacent to somites 1-7 and migrate rostro-caudally along the gastrointestinal tract to form two ganglionated plexuses of neurons and glial cells that comprise the enteric nervous system (ENS); a smaller proportion of ENCCs come from the sacral neural crest, caudal to somite 28, and migrate caudo-rostrally to colonize the distal gut

Subject: absent enteric neural crest cell
Value: absence or loss of the neural crest cells that arise predominantly from the vagal region of the neural tube (vagal neural crest), adjacent to somites 1-7 and migrate rostro-caudally along the gastrointestinal tract to form two ganglionated plexuses of neurons and glial cells that comprise the enteric nervous system (ENS); a smaller proportion of ENCCs come from the sacral neural crest, caudal to somite 28, and migrate caudo-rostrally to colonize the distal gut

Subject: abnormal enteric neural crest cell proliferation
Value: any anomaly in the ability of the enteric neural crest cells to undergo rapid expansion by cell division

Subject: decreased enteric neural crest cell proliferation
Value: reduced ability of the enteric neural crest cells to undergo rapid expansion by cell division

Subject: abnormal enteric neural crest cell migration
Value: any anomaly in the migratory path or behavior of the neural crest cells (NCCs) that arise predominantly from the vagal (neck) region of the neural tube (vagal neural crest), adjacent to somites 1-7, and migrate rostro-caudally along the gastrointestinal tract to form two ganglionated plexuses of neurons and glial cells that comprise the enteric nervous system (ENS); a smaller proportion of ENCCs come from the sacral neural crest, caudal to somite 28, and migrate caudo-rostrally to colonize the distal gut; NCCs are termed enteric neural crest-derived cells upon entering the foregut at E9-9.5 in mice (after 4 weeks gestation in humans) and the colonization process is complete by E15.5 (after 7 weeks gestation in humans)

Subject: abnormal vagal neural crest cell migration
Value: any anomaly in the migratory path or behavior of the neural crest cells (NCCs) that arise from the vagal (neck) region of the neural tube (vagal neural crest), adjacent to somites 1-7; at approximately E8.5-9 in the mouse, vagal NCCs invade the anterior foregut and migrate in a rostral to caudal direction to colonize the entire foregut, midgut, cecum, and hindgut and give rise to the majority of the enteric nervous system (ENS); colonization is complete by E15.5 (or after 7 weeks gestation in humans); the most caudal vagal NCCs, emanating from a region overlapping with the most anterior trunk NCCs, make a small contribution to the ENS of the esophagus and the anterior stomach

Subject: abnormal sacral neural crest cell migration
Value: any anomaly in the migratory path or behavior of the neural crest cells (NCCs) that arise from the sacral region of the neural tube (sacral neural crest), caudal to somite 28, and migrate caudo-rostrally to contribute to a small fraction of enteric neurons and glia in the distal midgut and hindgut; in the mouse, sacral NCCs emigrate from the neural tube at E9.5, accumulate bilateral to the hindgut to form prospective pelvic ganglia at E11.5, and from there enter the distal hindgut through its ventrolateral side at E13.5; they then migrate along nerve fibers extending from the pelvic ganglia toward the proximal hindgut, intermingling with rostrocaudally migrating vagal NCCs to differentiate into neurons and glia

Subject: increased vagal neural crest cell apoptosis
Value: increased number of vagal neural crest cells (NCCs) undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal vagal neural crest cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the neural crest cells (NCCs) that arise from the vagal (neck) region of the neural tube (vagal neural crest), adjacent to somites 1-7 (the cranial part of the vagal level overlaps the caudal part of the cranial level, as the first few somites form adjacent to the rhombencephalon, not the spinal cord); the vagal neural crest produces the neurons and glial cells of the enteric nervous system (ENS); like NCCs from other axial levels, the vagal neural crest contributes to the neurons and glial cells of the peripheral nervous system and the melanocytes that populate the skin

Subject: absent vagal neural crest cells
Value: absence of the neural crest cells (NCCs) that arise from the vagal (neck) region of the neural tube (vagal neural crest), adjacent to somites 1-7

Subject: abnormal trunk neural crest cell migration
Value: <any anomaly in the migratory path or behavior of the neural crest cells (NCCs) that arise from the trunk neural crest which lies between the vagal and sacral neural crest; there are two major pathways taken by the migrating trunk NCCs: (1) one group of cells fated to become melanocytes (the melanin-forming pigment cells) migrates dorsolaterally into the ectoderm towards the ventral midline and colonizes the skin and hair follicles; (2) a second group of cells migrates ventrolaterally through the anterior portion of each sclerotome; the cells that remain in the sclerotome form the dorsal root ganglia containing the sensory neurons, whereas those that continue more ventrally form the sympathetic ganglia, chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla, Schwann (precursor) cells, and the nerve clusters surrounding the aorta>

Subject: abnormal trunk neural crest cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the neural crest cells (NCCs) that arise from the trunk neural crest (located between the vagal and sacral neural crest) and differentiate into a variety of cell types, including melanocytes, the neurons and glia of the dorsal root and sympathetic ganglia, Schwann (precursor) cells, chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla, and the nerve clusters surrounding the aorta

Subject: increased trunk neural crest cell apoptosis
Value: increased number of trunk neural crest cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: obsolete abnormal CD4-positive, alpha beta T cell number
Value: aberrant number of T cells that expresses an alpha-beta T cell receptor complex and the CD4 coreceptor but not NK cell markers

Subject: obsolete increased CD4-positive, alpha beta T cell number
Value: reduced number of T cells that expresses an alpha-beta T cell receptor complex and the CD4 coreceptor but not NK cell markers

Subject: obsolete decreased CD4-positive, alpha beta T cell number
Value: increased number of T cells that expresses an alpha-beta T cell receptor complex and the CD4 coreceptor but not NK cell markers

Subject: obsolete abnormal CD8-positive alpha beta T cell number
Value: aberrant number of T cells that expresses an alpha-beta T cell receptor complex and the CD8 coreceptor but not NK cell markers

Subject: obsolete increased CD8-positive, alpha beta T cell number
Value: greater number of T cells that expresses an alpha-beta T cell receptor complex and the CD8 coreceptor but not NK cell markers

Subject: obsolete decreased CD8-positive, alpha beta T cell number
Value: reduced number of T cells that expresses an alpha-beta T cell receptor complex and the CD8 coreceptor but not NK cell markers

Subject: abnormal Ly6C high monocyte number
Value: deviation in the number of monocytes that express high levels of Ly6C and low MHC class II that represent a subset of circulating inflammatory monocytes that are recruited to infected or inflamed tissues

Subject: increased Ly6C high monocyte number
Value: increase in the number of monocytes that express high levels of Ly6C and low MHC class II that represent a subset of circulating inflammatory monocytes that are recruited to infected or inflamed tissues

Subject: decreased Ly6C high monocyte number
Value: decrease in the number of monocytes that express high levels of Ly6C and low MHC class II that represent a subset of circulating inflammatory monocytes that are recruited to infected or inflamed tissues

Subject: abnormal Ly6C low monocyte number
Value: deviation in the number of monocytes that express low levels of Ly6C and low MHC class II that represent a subset of patrolling monocytes

Subject: increased Ly6C low monocyte number
Value: increase in the number of monocytes that express low levels of Ly6C and low MHC class II that represent a subset of patrolling monocytes

Subject: decreased Ly6C low monocyte number
Value: decrease in the number of monocytes that express low levels of Ly6C and low MHC class II that represent a subset of patrolling monocytes

Subject: wounding
Value: an injury resulting in damage that tears, cuts or breaks tissue

Subject: open abrasion
Value: damage to the skin consisting of loss of the epidermis and portions of the dermis but not the complete thickness of the skin

Subject: open avulsion
Value: a wound where the tissue has been torn from its attachment.; avulsion of skin on the extremities is sometimes called degloving

Subject: open incision
Value: a wound created by a sharp object; edges are smooth and trauma to surrounding tissue is minimal

Subject: open laceration
Value: an irregular wound created by tearing of tissue; damage to both superficial and underlying tissue is variable

Subject: open puncture
Value: a penetrating wound cause by pointed object (e.g. bites)

Subject: closed contusion
Value: damage of the skin and/or underlying strutures without breaking the skin (e.g. bruising, crush)

Subject: greasy abdomen coat
Value: fur on the abdomen is oily in appearance or texture

Subject: greasy thorax coat
Value: fur on the thorax is oily in appearance or texture

Subject: greasy tail
Value: tail is oily in appearance or texture

Subject: greasy head/neck
Value: head and/or neck is oily in appearance or texture

Subject: focal hair loss in abdominal region
Value: focal absence of hair on the abdomen, in those areas where hair is normally expected, resulting in visible patches of skin and uneven spots of hair growth on the body

Subject: focal hair loss in head/neck region
Value: focal absence of hair in the head and/or neck region, in those areas where hair is normally expected, resulting in visible patches of skin and uneven spots of hair growth on the body

Subject: focal hair loss in thorax region
Value: focal absence of hair on the thorax, in those areas where hair is normally expected, resulting in visible patches of skin and uneven spots of hair growth on the body

Subject: swellings
Value: appearance of abnormal enlargements of all descriptions (hard, soft, different shapes etc) under the skin

Subject: abdomen swellings
Value: appearance of abnormal enlargements of all descriptions (hard, soft, different shapes etc) under the skin in the abdominal region

Subject: urogenital swellings
Value: appearance of abnormal enlargements of all descriptions (hard, soft, different shapes etc) under the skin in the urogenital region

Subject: testicular swellings
Value: appearance of abnormal enlargements of all descriptions (hard, soft, different shapes etc) under the skin of the testicles

Subject: tail swellings
Value: appearance of abnormal enlargements of all descriptions (hard, soft, different shapes etc) under the skin of the tail

Subject: head/neck swellings
Value: appearance of abnormal enlargements of all descriptions (hard, soft, different shapes etc) under the skin in the head/neck region

Subject: mouth swellings

Subject: thorax swellings
Value: appearance of abnormal enlargements of all descriptions (hard, soft, different shapes etc) under the skin in the thorax region

Subject: teat swellings

Subject: epistaxis
Value: hemorrhage from the nose, usually apparent when the blood drains out through the nostrils

Subject: nipple hemorrhage
Value: bleeding from the nipples

Subject: abnormal tooth color
Value: anomaly in the color and shading of the teeth, which normally present in shades of white

Subject: abnormal gum color
Value: anomaly in the color and shading of the gums, which normally present in shades of red

Subject: pale lips
Value: lips lack normal reddish coloration; often occurs with a bloodless or reduced vasculature condition

Subject: pale gums
Value: gums lack normal reddish coloration; often occurs with a bloodless or reduced vasculature condition

Subject: pale limbs
Value: limbs lack normal ruddy coloration; often occurs with a bloodless or reduced vasculature condition

Subject: poor circulation in autopods
Value: insufficient movement of blood throughout the autopods, resulting in a pale appearance and cool to touch

Subject: poor circulation in tail
Value: insufficient movement of blood throughout the tail, resulting in a pale appearance and cool to touch

Subject: genital discharge
Value: the emission or secretion of unusual fluid from the genitals

Subject: nipple discharge
Value: the emission or secretion of unusual fluid from the nipples

Subject: thin body
Value: lean or slender in form

Subject: moribund
Value: in terminal decline and approaching death; lacking vitality or vigor and becoming unresponsive

Subject: excessive vocalization
Value: producing sound from the vocal organs more frequently or more loudly than expected

Subject: sexually aggressive behavior
Value: subjects exhibit greater than the normal level of domineering, assertive posturing and/or hostile physical action toward partners while mating

Subject: anal soreness
Value: tenderness or irritation of the anal area, usually evident by redness of the area

Subject: penis inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the penis

Subject: eye discharge
Value: the emission or secretion of unusual fluid from the eyes

Subject: eye lesions
Value: lesions on or around the eyes

Subject: limb paralysis
Value: severe or complete loss of power of voluntary movement in muscles of the limbs through injury or disease of muscles or of the nerve supply

Subject: mastitis
Value: inflammation of the teats or mammary glands

Subject: macrodactyly
Value: significant increase in the length and girth dimensions of most or all of a digit compared to the expected size

Subject: head/neck piloerection
Value: anomaly in the involuntary bristling of hairs on the head and/or neck that occurs when an organism is cold or experiences strong emotions such as fear or awe

Subject: abnormal incidence of induced tumors
Value: aberration from the normal frequency of tumor incidence induced by a carcinogen, mutagen or virus

Subject: abnormal organ/body region tumor incidence
Value: anomaly in the expected number of tumors originating in a specific body region or organ in a given population in a given time period

Subject: abnormal KLRG1+ CD8 alpha beta T cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of CD8+ alpha beta T cells that express KLRG1, a marker of effector and memory T cells

Subject: increased KLRG1+ CD8 alpha beta T cell number
Value: increase in the number of CD8+ alpha beta T cells that express KLRG1, a marker of effector and memory T cells

Subject: decreased KLRG1+ CD8 alpha beta T cell number
Value: decrease in the number of CD8+ alpha beta T cells that express KLRG1, a marker of effector and memory T cells

Subject: abnormal KLRG1+ CD4 alpha beta T cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of CD4+ alpha beta T cells that express KLRG1, a marker of effector/memory and regulatory T cells

Subject: increased KLRG1+ CD4 alpha beta T cell number
Value: increase in the number of CD4+ alpha beta T cells that express KLRG1, a marker of effector/memory and regulatory T cells

Subject: decreased KLRG1+ CD4 alpha beta T cell number
Value: reduction in the number of CD4+ alpha beta T cells that express KLRG1, a marker of effector/memory and regulatory T cells

Subject: impaired muscle regeneration
Value: inability, defects in ability or delayed ability to repair muscle after injury or disease

Subject: improved muscle regeneration
Value: faster or more complete repair to muscle after injury or disease

Subject: abnormal thyroid gland isthmus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the narrow median bridge that joins together the lower thirds of the two lateral (right and left) lobes of the thyroid gland and usually covers the second and the third tracheal rings; the thyroid isthmus is variable in presence and size, can change shape and size, and can encompass a cranially extending pyramid lobe (lobus pyramidalis or processus pyramidalis), remnant of the thyroglossal duct

Subject: absent thyroid gland isthmus
Value: absence of the narrow median bridge that joins together the lower thirds of the two lateral (right and left) lobes of the thyroid gland

Subject: abnormal forelimb bud morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the limb bud that develops into a forelimb (usually the arm or front limb in mammalian species)

Subject: absent forelimb buds
Value: absence or loss of the limb bud that normally develops into a forelimb (usually the arm or front limb in mammalian species)

Subject: small forelimb buds
Value: reduced size of the limb bud that normally develops into a forelimb (usually the arm or front limb in mammalian species)

Subject: abnormal hindlimb bud morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the limb bud that develops into a hindlimb (usually the leg or back limb in mammalian species)

Subject: absent hindlimb buds
Value: absence or loss of the limb bud that normally develops into a hindlimb (usually the leg or back limb in mammalian species)

Subject: small hindlimb buds
Value: reduced size of the limb bud that normally develops into a hindlimb (usually the leg or back limb in mammalian species)

Subject: eye swellings
Value: appearance of abnormal enlargements of all descriptions (hard, soft, different shapes etc) on or around the eyes

Subject: ear hemorrhage
Value: bleeding through the ear canal

Subject: miscarriage
Value: accidental or natural termination of a clear pregnancy at a stage where the fetus is incapable of surviving independently of the mother

Subject: trigeminal ganglion degeneration
Value: retrogressive pathological change of the group of sensory neuron cell bodies associated with the trigeminal nerve (fifth cranial nerve)

Subject: pharynx stenosis
Value: abnormal narrowing or constriction of the passage between the mouth and the posterior nares and the larynx and esophagus

Subject: bifurcated tail
Value: the appearance of an abnormal division in the flexible elongated appendage located at the caudal end of the torso in many species

Subject: abnormal tail position or orientation
Value: tail is displaced from the normal location and/or does not orient in a typical pattern

Subject: abnormal tail tip morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the distal end of the tail

Subject: tail necrosis
Value: morphological changes resulting from pathological death of tail tissue; usually due to irreversible damage

Subject: wavy tail
Value: undulations or a sinusoidal shape of the tail

Subject: truncated tail bud
Value: shortened tail bud that terminates in a blunt end (instead of a tapered end)

Subject: absent placenta
Value: absence of the organ of metabolic interchange between fetus and mother, which is partly of embryonic origin and partly of maternal origin

Subject: increased spinal cord apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of cells of the spinal cord undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: absent trigeminal ganglion
Value: absence of the group of sensory neuron cell bodies associated with the trigeminal nerve (fifth cranial nerve)

Subject: hemorrhagic ascites
Value: the presence of bloody or blood-stained serous fluid, frequently resulting from metastatic carcinoma, in the peritoneal cavity

Subject: absent anterior definitive endoderm
Value: absence of the mesendoderm which first migrates from the node and which gives rise to the gut

Subject: abnormal basilar artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the unpaired artery that is formed by the union of the two vertebral arteries, runs forward within the skull just under the pons, divides into the two posterior cerebral arteries, and supplies the pons, cerebellum, posterior part of the cerebrum, and the inner ear

Subject: dilated basilar artery
Value: stretched or widened aperture of the luminal space of the unpaired artery that is formed by the union of the two vertebral arteries, runs forward within the skull just under the pons, divides into the two posterior cerebral arteries, and supplies the pons, cerebellum, posterior part of the cerebrum, and the inner ear

Subject: abnormal gastrocnemius weight
Value: any anomaly of the weight of the two-headed large muscle of the posterior portion of the lower hindleg, the most superficial of the calf muscles

Subject: abnormal exploration in a new environment
Value: anomaly in the amount of time spent investigating new location

Subject: abnormal sebaceous gland number
Value: any anomaly in the number of the holocrine glands that secrete sebum into the hair follicles, or in hairless areas into ducts

Subject: increased sebaceous gland number
Value: greater than normal numbers of the holocrine glands that secrete sebum into the hair follicles, or in hairless areas into ducts

Subject: decreased sebaceous gland number
Value: fewer than normal numbers of the holocrine glands that secrete sebum into the hair follicles, or in hairless areas into ducts

Subject: sebaceous gland hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment and decreased size of the sebum secreting glands of the hair shaft, usually due to a decrease in the number of cells

Subject: absent anterior primitive streak
