Value: absence of the anterior region of the vertebrate primitive streak which normally gives rise to the axial and paraxial mesoderm, the definitive endoderm, the primitive groove, and the primitive node

Subject: abnormal anterior primitive streak formation
Value: anomaly in the establishment of the anterior region of the vertebrate primitive streak which normally gives rise to the axial and paraxial mesoderm, the definitive endoderm, the primitive groove, and the primitive node

Subject: abnormal posterior primitive streak formation
Value: anomaly in the establishment of the posterior region of the vertebrate primitive streak which gives rise to the extraembryonic mesoderm

Subject: decreased embryonic cilium number
Value: reduced number of the cilia of the mouse embryo found on the cells of the embryonic node

Subject: absent head mesenchyme
Value: absence of the primordial embryonic connective tissue of the developing head, normally consisting of mesenchymal cells supported in interlaminar jelly, that derive mostly from the mesoderm and contribute to head connective tissue, bone and musculature in conjunction with cranial neural crest cells

Subject: increased head mesenchyme apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of cells of the head mesenchyme undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: head mesenchyme hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the head mesenchyme, usually due to a reduced cell number

Subject: head mesenchyme hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size of the head mesenchyme, usually due to an increased cell number

Subject: abnormal cilium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the specialized eukaryotic organelle that consists of a filiform extrusion of the cell surface; each cilium is bounded by an extrusion of the cytoplasmic (plasma) membrane, and contains a regular longitudinal array of microtubules, anchored basally in a centriole

Subject: abnormal primary cilium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a cilium found on many different cell types that is typically present in a single copy per cell; a primary cilium may have a variable array of axonemal microtubules and may or may not contain molecular motors

Subject: obsolete abnormal motile primary cilium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a primary cilium which may contain a variable array of axonemal microtubules and also contains molecular motors; motile primary cilia display a distinct twirling motion that directs fluid flow asymmetrically across the cellular surface to affect asymmetric body plan organization

Subject: abnormal nonmotile primary cilium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a primary cilium which contains a variable array of axonemal microtubules but does not contain molecular motors; nonmotile primary cilia are found on many different cell types and function as sensory organelles that concentrate and organize sensory signaling molecules

Subject: abnormal motile cilium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a cilium which has a variable arrangement of axonemal microtubules, contains molecular motors, and beats with a characteristic whip-like pattern that promotes cell motility or transport of fluids and other cells across a cell surface; motile cilia are typically found in multiple copies on epithelial cells that line the lumenal ducts of various tissues and may also function as sensory organelles

Subject: absent endoderm
Value: absence of the innermost of the three primary germ layers of the embryo (the others being mesoderm and ectoderm) that is formed during gastrulation

Subject: abnormal cilium physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the specialized eukaryotic organelle that consists of a filiform extrusion of the cell surface; each cilium is bounded by an extrusion of the cytoplasmic (plasma) membrane, and contains a regular longitudinal array of microtubules, anchored basally in a centriole

Subject: abnormal motile cilium physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of a cilium which has a variable arrangement of axonemal microtubules, contains molecular motors, and beats with a characteristic whip-like pattern that promotes cell motility or transport of fluids and other cells across a cell surface; motile cilia are typically found in multiple copies on epithelial cells that line the lumenal ducts of various tissues and may also function as sensory organelles

Subject: abnormal primary cilium physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of a cilium found on many different cell types that is typically present in a single copy per cell; a primary cilium may have a variable array of axonemal microtubules and may or may not contain molecular motors

Subject: abnormal nonmotile primary cilium physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of a primary cilium which contains a variable array of axonemal microtubules but does not contain molecular motors; nonmotile primary cilia are found on many different cell types and function as sensory organelles that concentrate and organize sensory signaling molecules

Subject: obsolete abnormal motile primary cilium physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of a primary cilium which may contain a variable array of axonemal microtubules and also contains molecular motors; motile primary cilia display a distinct twirling motion that directs fluid flow asymmetrically across the cellular surface to affect asymmetric body plan organization

Subject: abnormal embryonic neuroepithelium primary cilium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the primary non-motile microtubule-based structures of the embryonic neuroepithelium which are typically short and straight, project apically into the neural tube lumen, and play an essential role in Sonic hedgehog (Shh) signalling and neural tube patterning

Subject: decreased embryonic neuroepithelium primary cilium number
Value: reduced number of the primary non-motile microtubule-based structures of the embryonic neuroepithelium which are typically short and straight, project apically into the neural tube lumen, and play an essential role in Sonic hedgehog (Shh) signalling and neural tube patterning

Subject: abnormal haptoglobin level
Value: anomaly in the amount of any of haptoglobin, a protein that binds free hemoglobin (Hb) released from erythrocytes with high affinity and thereby inhibits its oxidative activity

Subject: absent ectoderm
Value: absence of the outer of the three primary germ layers of the embryo (the others being mesoderm and endoderm) that originates in the epiblast and is formed during gastrulation

Subject: abnormal posterior definitive endoderm morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the posterior region of the definitive endoderm which evolves into the midgut and hindgut, which will eventually differentiate into the large and small intestine

Subject: abnormal substantia nigra pars reticulata morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anterior (ventral) part of grey matter of the substantia nigra which contains smaller and loosely packed cells than the pars compacta, only some of which contain a small amount of pigment; the cells of pars reticulata bear a strong structural and functional resemblance to the inner segment of the globus pallidus; many cells in this region use GABA as a neurotransmitter

Subject: abnormal substantia nigra pars compacta morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the posterior (dorsal) part of grey matter of the substantia nigra which contains large, polygonal, and densely packed dopamine-producing cells; pars compacta neurons are pigmented in many species

Subject: increased pancreas apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of cells of the pancreas undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: pancreatic acinar-to-ductal metaplasia
Value: a reprogramming event that induces transdifferentiation of pancreatic acinar cells to a duct-like phenotype in response to inflammatory injury; ADM is associated with an increased risk of exocrine pancreatic cancer and is considered a precursor of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma

Subject: abnormal first pharyngeal pouch morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the first endodermal branchial pouch located between the first and second branchial arches; in mammals, the first pouch elongates to form a diverticulum known as the tubotympanic recess; the distal portion of this recess expands to reach the first branchial groove and form the middle ear cavity (aka tympanic cavity) and mastoid antrum; its proximal part remains tubular and forms the auditory tube (aka Eustachian or pharyngotympanic tube), which forms a communication between the nasopharynx and tympanic cavity

Subject: abnormal second pharyngeal pouch morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the second branchial pouch located between the second and third branchial arches; the dorsal elongation of the second pouch endoderm of all mammals, with the exception of rodents, gives rise to the epithelial lining of palatine tonsils; in rodents, the ventral portion of the second pouch appears to degenerate whereas the remaining part is incorporated into the lateral border of the pharynx; it appears that rodents no longer require tonsils as their function is carried out by the NALT (Nose/Nasal-Associated Lymphoid Tissue) system in the upper respiratory tract

Subject: absent second pharyngeal pouch
Value: absence of the second branchial pouch, normally located between the second and third branchial arches; the dorsal elongation of the second pouch endoderm of all mammals, with the exception of rodents, gives rise to the epithelial lining of palatine tonsils

Subject: abnormal third pharyngeal pouch morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the third endodermal branchial pouch located between the third and fourth branchial arches; in mammals, the cranial dorsal aspect of the third pouch generates the inferior parathyroids (or parathyroid III), whereas the caudal ventral part of the pouch gives rise to the thymus epithelium

Subject: absent third pharyngeal pouch
Value: absence of the third endodermal branchial pouch, normally located between the third and fourth branchial arches; in mammals, the cranial dorsal aspect of the third pouch generates the inferior parathyroids (or parathyroid III), whereas the caudal ventral part of the pouch gives rise to the thymus epithelium

Subject: small brain ventricles
Value: decreased size of one or more of the four communicating cavities within the brain that are continuous with the central canal of the spinal cord

Subject: brain ventricle stenosis
Value: abnormal narrowing or constriction of one or more of the four communicating cavities within the brain that are continuous with the central canal of the spinal cord

Subject: abnormal brain ventricle size
Value: any anomaly in the size of one or more of the four communicating cavities within the brain that are continuous with the central canal of the spinal cord

Subject: abnormal cervical sinus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the temporary triangular depression found in the nuchal region caudal to the second (hyoid) branchial arch, and containing the succeeding branchial arches and grooves; the sinus is overgrown by the second branchial arch and is ultimately obliterated during extension of the cervical flexure

Subject: abnormal pharyngeal groove morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the ectodermally lined depressions (grooves or clefts) that separate the branchial arches externally on each side; only the first of the four pairs of branchial grooves persists in the adult to form the epithelium of the external auditory meatus and part of the tympanic membrane; the second, third, and fourth grooves are overlapped by the development of branchial arch 2 and form a slit-like depression known as the cervical sinus which is ultimately obliterated by the fusion of its walls during extension of the cervical flexure

Subject: abnormal pharyngeal membrane morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the four membranes that separate the branchial pouches from the corresponding branchial grooves in a developing embryo; each membrane is initially composed of an inner layer formed by the endodermal lining of a branchial pouch and an outer layer formed by the ectodermal lining of the branchial groove; later, these two layers become separated by a thin layer of mesoderm; only the first branchial membrane contributes to the formation of an adult structure, i.e. the tympanic membrane (aka eardrum); the second, third, and fourth membranes are obliterated

Subject: ectopic thyroid gland
Value: a thyroid gland located outside of its normal position anterior to the laryngeal cartilages; usually due to abnormal migration of the thyroid diverticulum down from the foramen cecum at the posterior aspect of the tongue to its permanent pre-tracheal location; ectopic thyroid tissue is frequently found along the course of the thyroglossal duct or laterally in the neck, as well as in distant places such as the mediastinum and the subdiaphragmatic organs; the most common ectopic location is near its embryological origin at the foramen caecum, resulting in a lingual thyroid

Subject: abnormal tongue foramen cecum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the median pit on the dorsum of the posterior part of the tongue, from which the limbs of a V-shaped furrow run forward and outward; the foramen cecum is the point of attachment of the thyroglossal duct and is formed during the embryological descent of the thyroid gland

Subject: abnormal thyroglossal duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the embryological anatomical structure that forms an open connection between the initial area of development of the thyroid gland and its final position; it is located exactly midline, between the anterior 2/3rds and posterior 1/3rd of the tongue; this duct normally atrophies and closes off as the foramen cecum before birth

Subject: ovary degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of one or both ovaries

Subject: abnormal skeletal muscle regeneration
Value: anomaly in the ability to repair skeletal muscle after injury or disease

Subject: abnormal cardiac muscle regeneration
Value: anomaly in the ability to repair cardiac muscle after injury or disease

Subject: impaired skeletal muscle regeneration
Value: reduced ability to repair skeletal muscle after injury or disease

Subject: impaired cardiac muscle regeneration
Value: reduced ability to repair cardiac muscle after injury or disease

Subject: embryo tissue necrosis
Value: morphological changes resulting from pathological death of some or all embryo tissue; usually due to irreversible damage

Subject: abnormal amino acid metabolism
Value: any anomaly in the chemical reactions and pathways involving an amino acid, including metabolic, catabolic and biosynthetic processes

Subject: abnormal carbohydrate metabolism
Value: any anomaly in the chemical reactions and pathways involving a carbohydrate, including metabolic, catabolic and biosynthetic processes

Subject: abnormal vitamin metabolism
Value: any anomaly in the chemical reactions and pathways involving a vitamin, including metabolic, catabolic and biosynthetic processes

Subject: abnormal lipid metabolism
Value: any anomaly in the chemical reactions and pathways involving a lipid, including metabolic, catabolic and biosynthetic processes

Subject: abnormal peptide metabolism
Value: any anomaly in the chemical reactions and pathways involving a peptide, including metabolic, catabolic and biosynthetic processes

Subject: placenta necrosis
Value: morphological changes resulting from pathological death of placenta tissue; usually due to irreversible damage

Subject: placenta junctional zone necrosis
Value: morphological changes resulting from pathological death of placenta junctional zone tissue; usually due to irreversible damage

Subject: adipose tissue necrosis
Value: morphological changes resulting from pathological death of adipose tissue; usually due to irreversible damage

Subject: abnormal dental pulp morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the soft tissue within the pulp cavity located in the center of a tooth, comprised of living connective tissue containing blood vessels, nerves and lymphatics, and a layer of odontoblasts at the periphery, which participate in dentin repair

Subject: dental pulp necrosis
Value: morphological changes resulting from pathological death of dental pulp tissue; usually due to irreversible damage

Subject: head mesenchyme necrosis
Value: morphological changes resulting from pathological death of head mesenchyme tissue; usually due to irreversible damage

Subject: outer ear necrosis
Value: morphological changes resulting from pathological death of outer ear tissue; usually due to irreversible damage

Subject: abnormal angiotensin I-converting enzyme activity
Value: altered activity of the exopeptidase that catalyses the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II, a potent vasoconstrictor, and is also involved in the inactivation of bradykinin

Subject: abnormal circulating thrombin level
Value: anomaly in the blood level of the a serine protease that converts soluble fibrinogen into insoluble strands of fibrin, as well as catalyzing many other coagulation-related reactions; it is generated from regulated proteolytic cleavage of prothrobmin during the coagulation cascade

Subject: increased circulating thrombin level
Value: increased blood level of the a serine protease that converts soluble fibrinogen into insoluble strands of fibrin, as well as catalyzing many other coagulation-related reactions; it is generated from regulated proteolytic cleavage of prothrobmin during the coagulation cascade

Subject: decreased circulating thrombin level
Value: reduction in the blood level of the a serine protease that converts soluble fibrinogen into insoluble strands of fibrin, as well as catalyzing many other coagulation-related reactions; it is generated from regulated proteolytic cleavage of prothrobmin during the coagulation cascade

Subject: abnormal extracellular matrix morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the structure lying external to one or more cells, which provides structural support for cells or tissues; in mammals, the extracellular matrix is completely external to the cell

Subject: abnormal dendritic cell apoptosis
Value: change in the timing or the number of dendritic cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: decreased dendritic cell apoptosis
Value: reduction in the timing or the number of dendritic cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: absent epiglottis
Value: missing the most superior of the laryngeal cartilages, which normally is found at the root of the tongue and folds back over the entrance to the larynx during swallowing, preventing inhalation of food or drink

Subject: abnormal mouth floor morphology
Value: any structural morphology of the ventral area of the mouth; in organisms with a tongue, a small horseshoe-shaped region situated beneath the movable part of the tongue and above the muscular diaphragm formed by the mylohyoid muscles; a median fold of mucous membrane, the lingual frenulum, connects the inferior surface of the tongue to the floor of the mouth

Subject: abnormal tongue frenulum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small fold of mucous membrane extending from the floor of the mouth to the midline of the underside of the tongue

Subject: tongue ankylosis
Value: partial or complete fusion or adherence of the tongue to the floor of the mouth, resulting in varying degrees of restricted tongue mobility; partial ankyloglossia (aka tongue-tie) is caused by a lingual frenulum that is abnormally short or is attached too close to the tip of the tongue; in complete ankyloglossia the tongue is tethered to the floor of the mouth

Subject: abnormal fourth pharyngeal pouch morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the fourth endodermal branchial pouch located between the fourth and sixth branchial arches (a fifth arch never establishes itself in amniotes); in most mammals, excluding rodents, the dorsal part of each fourth pouch develops into a superior parathyroid gland (parathyroid IV), which lies on the dorsal surface of the thyroid gland (the parathyroid glands derived from the third pouches descend with the thymus and are carried to a more inferior position than the parathyroid glands that are derived from the fourth pouches); the elongated ventral part of each fourth pouch develops into the ultimopharyngeal body, which fuses with the thyroid gland, giving rise to the calcitonin-producing parafollicular or C-cells of the thyroid gland

Subject: absent fourth pharynegal pouch
Value: absence of the fourth endodermal branchial pouch, normally located between the fourth and sixth branchial arches (a fifth arch never establishes itself in amniotes); in most mammals, excluding rodents, the dorsal part of each fourth pouch develops into a superior parathyroid gland (parathyroid IV), which lies on the dorsal surface of the thyroid gland; the elongated ventral part of each fourth pouch develops into the ultimopharyngeal body, which fuses with the thyroid gland, giving rise to the calcitonin-producing parafollicular or C-cells of the thyroid gland

Subject: first pharyngeal arch hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the first pharyngeal arch, usually due to reduced cell number

Subject: second pharyngeal arch hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the second pharyngeal arch, usually due to reduced cell number

Subject: third pharyngeal arch hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the third pharyngeal arch, usually due to reduced cell number

Subject: fourth pharyngeal arch hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the fourth pharyngeal arch, usually due to reduced cell number

Subject: sixth pharyngeal arch hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the sixth pharyngeal arch, usually due to reduced cell number

Subject: abnormal translation
Value: any anomaly in the cellular metabolic process in which a protein is formed, using the sequence of a mature mRNA molecule to specify the sequence of amino acids in a polypeptide chain; translation is mediated by the ribosome, and begins with the formation of a ternary complex between aminoacylated initiator methionine tRNA, GTP, and initiation factor 2, which subsequently associates with the small subunit of the ribosome and an mRNA; translation ends with the release of a polypeptide chain from the ribosome

Subject: abnormal translational elongation
Value: any anomaly in the process of successive addition of amino acid residues to a nascent polypeptide chain during protein biosynthesis

Subject: abnormal vitamin or vitamin cofactor metabolism
Value: any anomaly in the chemical reactions and pathways involving a vitamin or cofactor, including metabolic, catabolic and biosynthetic processes

Subject: abnormal xenobiotic metabolism
Value: any anomaly in the chemical reactions and pathways involving a xenobiotic, including metabolic, catabolic and biosynthetic processes

Subject: absent alpha-beta T cells
Value: absence of the lymphocytes that are responsible for cell-mediated immunity and immune system regulation and express an alpha-beta T cell receptor complex

Subject: abnormal fasting circulating glucose level
Value: any anomaly in the amount of glucose in the blood at some defined time point after eating compared to controls

Subject: decreased fasting circulating glucose level
Value: reduction in the amount of glucose in the blood at some defined time point after eating compared to controls

Subject: increased fasting circulating glucose level
Value: increase in the amount of glucose in the blood at some defined time point after eating compared to controls

Subject: abnormal cytotoxic T cell cytolysis
Value: altered ability of cytotoxic T cells to induce pathological breakdown of target cells by the destruction of their outer membrane

Subject: increased cytotoxic T cell cytolysis
Value: increased ability of cytotoxic T cells to induce pathological breakdown of target cells

Subject: urinary bladder exstrophy
Value: a herniation of the urinary bladder through an anterior abdominal wall defect; refers to congenital absence of a portion of the lower anterior abdominal wall and the anterior urinary bladder wall, with eversion of the posterior bladder wall through the defect, an open pubic arch, and widely separated ischia connected by a fibrous band

Subject: failure of ventral body wall closure
Value: failure of the lateral body wall folds (a combination of mesoderm and ectoderm arising on each side of the embryo) to progress ventrally and meet in the midline and/or fuse to close the ventral body wall; normally, this closure is aided by growth of the head and tail folds that cause the embryo to curve into the fetal position and is complete except in the region of the connecting stalk (future umbilical cord); if closure fails, ventral body wall defects occur in the thorax, abdomen, and pelvis and involve the heart (ectopia cordis), abdominal viscera (gastroschisis), and/or urogenital organs (bladder or cloacal exstrophy), depending upon the location and size of the abnormality

Subject: abnormal renal glomerular filtration
Value: anomaly in the process in which plasma is filtered through the glomerular membrane which consists of capillary endothelial cells, the basement membrane, and epithelial cells

Subject: abnormal renal filtration
Value: any anomaly in the renal system process in which fluid circulating through the body is filtered through a barrier system

Subject: abnormal sperm capacitation
Value: anomaly in the change undergone by spermatozoa in the female genital tract that enables them to penetrate and fertilize an egg

Subject: abnormal acrosome reaction
Value: abnormality in the cellular exocytosis of a single, anterior secretory granule following a sperm's attachment to the zona pellucida surrounding an oocyte

Subject: premature acrosome reaction
Value: spontaneous initiation of the cellular exocytosis that allows sperm to penetrate the zona pellucida of ovulated eggs, occurring prior to encountering conditions that induce sperm capacitation

Subject: abnormal mitotic cytokinesis
Value: any anomaly in the process that results in the division of the cytoplasm of a cell after mitosis, this process consists of two distinct processes furrowing and abscission

Subject: persistent ultimobranchial bodies
Value: partial or complete failure of the ultimobranchial bodies to fuse with the ventral thyroid primordium; as a result, ultimobranchial bodies remain as unilateral or bilateral vesicles composed exclusively of calcitonin-producing cells

Subject: ectopic pancreas
Value: presence of well-developed and normally organized pancreatic tissue lying outside its normal location without any anatomical and vascular continuity with the pancreas proper; although an ectopic pancreas can occur throughout the entire gastrointestinal tract, it is most commonly located in the stomach, duodenum, jejunum or Meckel's diverticulum

Subject: embryonic lethality prior to organogenesis
Value: <death prior to the completion of embryo turning (Mus: E9-9.5)>

Subject: embryonic lethality prior to tooth bud stage
Value: <death prior to the appearance of tooth buds (Mus: E12-E12.5)>

Subject: prenatal lethality prior to heart atrial septation
Value: <death prior to the completion of heart atrial septation (Mus: E14.5-15.5)>

Subject: pancreas atrophy
Value: acquired size diminution of any portion of the pancreas, associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: abnormal susceptibility to induced colitis
Value: difference in the severity or induction threshold of colitis upon treatment of an organism with intestinal inflammation agents such as dextran sodium sulfate (DSS)

Subject: abnormal susceptibility to colitis induced morbidity/mortality
Value: differences from the expected moribund state caused by colitis upon treatment of an organism with intestinal inflammation agents such as dextran sodium sulfate (DSS)

Subject: increased susceptibility to colitis induced morbidity/mortality
Value: increased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by colitis upon treatment of an organism with intestinal inflammation agents such as dextran sodium sulfate (DSS)

Subject: decreased susceptibility to colitis induced morbidity/mortality
Value: reduced likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by colitis upon treatment of an organism with intestinal inflammation agents such as dextran sodium sulfate (DSS)

Subject: abnormal submandibular gland physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of either of the large major salivary glands situated beneath the mandible

Subject: abnormal pancreas iron level
Value: anomaly in the amount of iron present in the pancreas tissue

Subject: increased pancreas iron level
Value: increase in the amount of iron present in the pancreas tissue

Subject: decreased pancreas iron level
Value: reduction in the amount of iron present in the pancreas tissue

Subject: osteophytes
Value: bony projections that form along joint margins at bone edges, including the spine; these are frequently found in areas affected by arthritis such as the disc or joint spaces where cartilage has deteriorated

Subject: isosthenuria
Value: inability of the kidneys to produce either a concentrated or a dilute urine; refers to a state in chronic renal disease in which the kidney cannot form urine with a higher or a lower specific gravity (concentration) than that of protein-free plasma; the specific gravity of the urine becomes fixed, irrespective of the fluid intake

Subject: abnormal tela choroidea morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of that portion of the brain pia mater that covers the ependymal roof or, in the case of the lateral ventricle, medial wall of a cerebral ventricle; vascularized tela choroidea is choroid plexus

Subject: increased adrenal gland weight
Value: greater average weight of the pair of endocrine glands located above the kidney that are responsible for steroid hormone secretion from the cortex and neurotransmitter (such as epinephrine and norepinephrine) secretion from the medulla

Subject: decreased adrenal gland weight
Value: reduced average weight of the pair of endocrine glands located above the kidney that are responsible for steroid hormone secretion from the cortex and neurotransmitter (such as epinephrine and norepinephrine) secretion from the medulla

Subject: adrenal gland cyst
Value: presence of fluid-filled usually benign growths in the adrenal gland

Subject: abnormal adrenal gland development
Value: aberrant formation or incomplete differentiation of the pair of endocrine glands located above the kidney that are responsible for steroid hormone secretion from the cortex and neurotransmitter (such as epinephrine and norepinephrine) secretion from the medulla

Subject: abnormal ovary capsule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tough, fibrous capsule surrounding each ovary

Subject: absent ovary capsule
Value: missing the tough, fibrous capsule surrounding each ovary

Subject: female preputial gland hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of any of the paired, lobulated, modified sebaceous glands located on the side of the clitoris in female rodents

Subject: abnormal eumelanosome morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the elliptical-shaped pigment organelles that synthesize and store eumelanin (black/brown) pigment, which is deposited in smooth laminated fibrils of mature eumelanosomes

Subject: abnormal pheomelanosome morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the oval-shaped pigment organelles that synthesize and store pheomelanin (yellow) pigment, which is deposited in dense granular deposits within pheomelanosomes

Subject: abnormal pheomelanosome pheomelanin content
Value: anomaly in the amount or distribution of yellow pigment in the pheomelanosomes of melanocytes

Subject: abnormal seminal vesicle development
Value: aberrant or incomplete differentiation of either of the paired sac-like glandular structures situated posterolateral to the urinary bladder in the male and functioning as part of the reproductive system; seminal vesicles develop from the segments of the Wolffian ducts immediately adjacent to the urogenital sinus

Subject: abnormal branching involved in seminal vesicle morphogenesis
Value: anomaly in the process in which the seminal vesicle is generated and organized in many mammals including mice and humans; in mice, the initial seminal vesicle buds form cane-shaped tubes off of the Wolffian ducts before birth; after birth, the initial tubes develop lateral branches that elongate and often undergo secondary branching morphogenesis; branching morphogenesis is largely complete by 2 weeks of age

Subject: seminal vesicle atrophy
Value: acquired size diminution of the seminal vesicles, associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: dilated seminal vesicles
Value: an expansion in the lumen volume of either of the paired sac-like glandular structures situated posterolateral to the urinary bladder in the male and functioning as part of the reproductive system, as by stretching or distention

Subject: squamous metaplasia of seminal vesicles
Value: a benign non-cancerous transformation of the pseudostratified columnar epithelium lining the seminal vesicle(s) into stratified squamous epithelium; may occur in response to irritation or inflammation and involve keratinization

Subject: squamous metaplasia of prostate gland
Value: a benign non-cancerous transformation of the prostatic glandular epithelium into stratified squamous epithelium

Subject: abnormal ampullary gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the paired accessory, glandular, androgen-dependent outpouchings of the proximal ductus deferens, one on each side, that produce and secrete lipids and glycogen, components of the seminal fluid; they open into the ampullae at the level of the colliculus seminalis, are lined by simple columnar epithelium with large, oval nuclei, and may be distinguished from those of the prostate as they are surrounded by a characteristic, dense, fibromuscular stroma; the epithelium forms longitudinal folds and the glands contain homogeneous, dense, eosinophilic secretions with characteristic holes that impart a Swiss cheese-like appearance

Subject: abnormal female reproductive gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any sex gland that is part of the female reproductive system

Subject: abnormal male reproductive gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any sex gland that is part of the male reproductive system

Subject: abnormal female reproductive gland physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of any sex gland that is part of the female reproductive system

Subject: abnormal male reproductive gland physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of any sex gland that is part of the male reproductive system

Subject: visceromegaly
Value: abnormal enlargement of the internal organs in the abdomen, including liver, spleen, stomach, kidneys, or pancreas

Subject: abnormal preputial gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the paired, lobulated, modified sebaceous glands located in the inguinal region adjacent to the penis and vagina, with pheromonal functions in male rodents; in males, the preputial gland empties into the preputial cavity and in females, the preputial (aka clitoral) gland duct empties into the clitoral fossa

Subject: abnormal male accessory sex gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any gland, other than the gonad, associated with the genital tract, such as the ampulla of the ductus deferens and the bulbourethral, prostate and seminal vesicles of the male

Subject: abnormal lacrimal gland development
Value: aberrant formation or incomplete differentiation of the paired almond-shaped glands, one for each eye, that secrete the aqueous layer of the tear film; each lacrimal gland develops through branching morphogenesis regulated by FGF signaling; at E12.5, the conjunctival epithelium at the temporal side of the mouse eyes invades the Fgf10-expressing mesenchyme to form the initial lacrimal gland bud; the bud elongates posteriorly until E15.5 when secondary branching begins to establish the complex tubuloalveolar structure; this eventually gives rise to the mature lacrimal gland composed of numerous ducts, acini and connective tissue

Subject: peliosis
Value: presence of multiple cyst-like blood-filled lakes or cavities that lack endothelial linings within parenchymatous organs, typically found in the liver, spleen, bone marrow and lymph nodes; also described in other organs such as lungs, kidneys, parathyroids and pancreas

Subject: pituitary gland peliosis
Value: presence of cyst-like blood-filled lakes or cavities (extravasated erythrocytes not contained in capillaries) within the pituitary gland; commonly found in hyperplastic and adenomatous pituitary glands

Subject: adenohypophysis peliosis
Value: presence of cyst-like blood-filled lakes or cavities (extravasated erythrocytes not contained in capillaries) within the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland

Subject: hepatic peliosis
Value: presence of cyst-like blood-filled lakes or cavities that lack endothelial linings in the liver parenchyma

Subject: pituitary gland hypertrophy
Value: increase in the bulk size of the pituitary gland due to cell enlargement

Subject: abnormal adenohypophysis development
Value: aberrant formation or incomplete differentiation of the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland which arises as a pouch-like outgrowth of ectoderm known as the hypophyseal (Rathke's) pouch from the dorsal midline roof of the stomodeum (primitive oral cavity); the hypophyseal pouch grows toward the brain and the neurohypophyseal bud; as the hypophyseal pouch and the infundibulum make contact, the hypophyseal pouch loses its connection with the pharynx, creating a hollow ball of cells that lies inferior to the floor of the diencephalon posterior to the optic chiasm; these cells undergo division, the central chamber gradually disappears, and this endocrine mass becomes the anterior pituitary gland; the fully developed adenohypophysis consists of a glandular pars distalis, a thin proximal extension called the pars tuberalis, and a narrow pars intermedia

Subject: abnormal neurohypophysis development
Value: aberrant formation or incomplete differentiation of the posterior lobe of the pituitary gland which develops as a neurohypophyseal bud, a depression in the neuroectoderm of the floor of the hypothalamus; the infundibulum, another diverticulum from the inferior aspect of the diencephalon, develops as an outgrowth of the neurohypophyseal bud and connects the neurohypophysis to the hypothalamus; the neurohypophysis develops as the infundibulum grows inferiorly from the diencephalon to meet the developing adenohypophysis (anterior pituitary lobe); the fully developed neurohypophysis consists of the infundibulum and the pars nervosa; the neural connection between the hypothalamus and pars nervosa is through the hypothalamohypophyseal tract that develops within the infundibulum

Subject: abnormal neurohypophyseal bud morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the outgrowth of neuroectoderm located on the floor of the embryonic hypothalamus that gives rise to the neurohypophysis (posterior lobe) of the pituitary gland

Subject: abnormal pituicyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the distinctive fusiform cells present in the pars nervosa of the posterior pituitary gland which resemble astrocytes/glial cells of the CNS and assist in the storage and release of neurohypophysial hormones

Subject: abnormal folliculo-stellate cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the star-shaped and follicle-forming cells in the anterior pituitary gland that stain positive for S-100 protein (a marker for FS-cells); ascribed functions include the formation of an extensive and complex tridimentional network, scavenger activity by engulfing degenerated cells, paracrine regulation of endocrine cells by producing various growth factors and cytokines, such as interleukin-6, leukemia inhibitory factor, basic fibroblastic growth factor, vascular endothelial cell growth factor and follistatin, and large-scale inter-cellular communication by means of their long cytoplasmic processes and gap junctions

Subject: bifurcated Rathke's pouch
Value: the appearance of an abnormal division in the diverticulum arsing from the embryonic buccal cavity from which the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland is developed

Subject: abnormal pituitary gland apoptosis
Value: change in the timing or the number of any pituitary gland cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: increased pituitary gland apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of any cells of the pituitary gland undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: decreased pituitary gland apoptosis
Value: decrease in the number of any cells of the pituitary gland undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: increased melanotroph apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of cells of the intermediate pituitary that produce melanocyte stimulating hormone and other peptides from the post-translational processing of pro-opiomelanocortin (POMC) undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: increased corticotroph apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of anterior pituitary ACTH-producing basophilic cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: adenohypophysis hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size of the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland, usually due to increased cell number

Subject: small Rathke's pouch
Value: reduced size of the pouch of ectoderm which grows out from the upper surface of the embryonic stomodeum and gives rise to the anterior and intermediate lobes of the pituitary gland

Subject: Rathke's pouch hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of Rathke's pouch, usually due to a reduced number of cells

Subject: abnormal Rathke's pouch development
Value: any anomaly in the formation of the pouch of ectoderm which grows out from the upper surface of the embryonic stomodeum and gives rise to the anterior and intermediate lobes of the pituitary gland

Subject: abnormal Rathke's pouch apoptosis
Value: any change in the timing or number of Rathke's pouch cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: Rathke cleft cyst
Value: an intrasellar or suprasellar cyst lined by cuboidal epithelium derived from remnants of the Rathke pouch

Subject: increased Rathke pouch tumor incidence
Value: a suprasellar neoplasm, usually cystic, that develops from the nests of epithelium derived from Rathke pouch

Subject: adenohypophysis hypertrophy
Value: increase in the bulk size of the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland due to cell enlargement

Subject: ectopic pituitary gland
Value: a pituitary gland located outside of its normal position

Subject: ectopic adenohypophysis
Value: an anterior pituitary gland located outside of its normal position due to arrest of migration from a pharyngeocranial location to the sellar region; a portion or all of the adenohypophysis may persist in the pathway of the pharyngeal pouch, either in the nasopharyngeal wall or within the sphenoid bone

Subject: ectopic neurohypophysis
Value: a posterior pituitary gland displaced distally in the infundibulum (pituitary stalk) due to defective neuronal migration during embryogenesis, tumors, trauma, or surgical transection of the pituitary stalk; may present with an empty pituitary fossa, hypoplasia or absence of the infundibular stalk and resultant short stature due to growth hormone deficiency; the location of the ectopic lobe can vary, but it is most commonly located along the median eminence in the floor of the third ventricle

Subject: abnormal pinealocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the principal cell of the pineal gland, characterized by two or more long cell processes ending in bulbous expansions that terminate in perivascular spaces surrounding capillaries; pinealocytes are secretory cells organized into cords and clusters resting on a basal lamina and surrounded by connective tissue, blood vessels lined by fenestrated endothelial cells, and nerves; their cytoplasm contains abundant mitochondria and multiple synaptic ribbons that are randomly distributed; the primary function of the pinealocytes is the secretion of melatonin; pinealocytes receive a direct innervation from sympathetic neurons that form recognizable synapses

Subject: abnormal pineal recess morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the diverticulum of the thin roof of the dorsocaudal third ventricle that projects into the stalk of the pineal gland

Subject: absent pineal recess
Value: absence of the diverticulum of the thin roof of the dorsocaudal third ventricle that projects into the stalk of the pineal gland

Subject: absent pineal gland
Value: absence of the unpaired epithalamic structure that is shaped like a tiny pine cone and located above the posterior commissure near the level of the habenular complex and the sylvian aqueduct; the pineal is both a circumventricular organ and an endocrine organ that secretes melatonin, a serotonin-derived hormone involved in the regulation of circadian rhythms

Subject: abnormal pineal gland development
Value: aberrant formation or incomplete differentiation of the pineal gland which normally develops from a saccular outpocketing of the posterior diencephalic roof in the midline of the third ventricle; continued diverticulation and infolding result in a solid parenchymal mass of cords and clusters of pinealocytes and glial-like interstitial cells supported by a meninges-derived connective tissue that carries blood vessels and nerves to the pineal gland

Subject: enlarged pineal gland
Value: increased size of the unpaired epithalamic structure that is shaped like a tiny pine cone and located above the posterior commissure near the level of the habenular complex and the sylvian aqueduct; the pineal is both a circumventricular organ and an endocrine organ that secretes melatonin, a serotonin-derived hormone involved in the regulation of circadian rhythms

Subject: increased pineal gland tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplams in the pineal gland occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: adrenal gland atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of the pair of endocrine glands located above the kidney and responsible for steroid hormone secretion from the cortex and neurotransmitter secretion from the medulla, associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: parotid gland inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in either of the largest of the major salivary glands situated below and in front of each ear

Subject: abnormal sweat gland physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the coiled tubular glands of the skin that secrete sweat

Subject: abnormal sweat gland secretion
Value: altered ability of the coiled tubular glands of the skin to produce or secrete sweat in response to appropriate stimuli

Subject: anhidrosis
Value: complete absence of sweating in response to appropriate stimuli

Subject: hypohidrosis
Value: decreased sweating in response to appropriate stimuli

Subject: hyperhidrosis
Value: abnormally increased sweating in response to appropriate stimuli

Subject: increased sebum secretion
Value: increased production and/or release of the lipid-rich substance that is produced by the sebaceous glands, acts to lubricate and waterproof the skin and hair of mammals, and provides antibacterial activity; sebum is released by disintegrating sebocytes that are continuously replaced from progenitors in the periphery of the sebaceous gland; its composition varies across species

Subject: increased sebaceous gland tumor incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of neoplams in the sebaceous gland occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: abnormal sebocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the highly specialized, sebum-producing epithelial cells of the sebaceous glands that release their content by rupture of the cell membrane and cellular degradation (holocrine secretion); these cells are most commonly found in the skin in association with hair follicles (forming the pilosebaceous unit), where they arise from hair follicle keratinocytes, but there are also sebaceous glands not associated with a hair follicle; the latter have special functions as secretion of pheromones or corneal protection

Subject: abnormal sebocyte differentiation
Value: abnormal formation or arrest of differentiation of the sebum-producing epithelial cells of the sebaceous glands that release their content by rupture of the cell membrane and cellular degradation; these cells are most commonly found in the skin in association with hair follicles (forming the pilosebaceous unit), where they arise from hair follicle keratinocytes, but there are also sebaceous glands not associated with a hair follicle; the latter have special functions as secretion of pheromones or corneal protection; sebocyte differentiation is defined by increasing accumulation of lipid droplets, the major component of sebum

Subject: abnormal sebocyte number
Value: any deviation from the normal numbers of the highly specialized, sebum-producing epithelial cells of the sebaceous glands that release their content by rupture of the cell membrane and cellular degradation

Subject: increased sebocyte number
Value: greater than expected number of the highly specialized, sebum-producing epithelial cells of the sebaceous glands that release their content by rupture of the cell membrane and cellular degradation

Subject: decreased sebocyte cell number
Value: fewer than expected number of the highly specialized, sebum-producing epithelial cells of the sebaceous glands that release their content by rupture of the cell membrane and cellular degradation

Subject: absent sebocyte
Value: failure of formation or loss of the highly specialized, sebum-producing epithelial cells of the sebaceous glands that release their content by rupture of the cell membrane and cellular degradation

Subject: abnormal perianal sebaceous gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the modified holocrine gland that is part of the pilosebaceous unit of a hair located in the area around the anus; each of the specialized large hair follicles that surround and form a network around the anus has a pair of large sebaceous glands that empty into the follicle; perianal glands may function as scent glands

Subject: small perianal sebaceous gland
Value: decreased size of the modified holocrine gland that is part of the pilosebaceous unit of a hair located in the area around the anus; each of the specialized large hair follicles that surround and form a network around the anus has a pair of large sebaceous glands that empty into the follicle; perianal glands may function as scent glands

Subject: increased sebaceous gland adenoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign epithelial neoplasm with a glandular organization arising in any sebaceous gland, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: abnormal Zymbal's gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of either of the paired multilobulated modified auditory sebaceous glands located anterior and ventral to the exterior ear canal in rodents; each gland consists of acinar sebaceous cells and excretory ducts lined by stratified squamous epithelium; the ducts of Zymbal's gland empty into the external ear canal

Subject: abnormal Meibomian gland development
Value: aberrant formation or incomplete differentiation of the sebaceous glands located at the rim of the eyelids inside the tarsal plate and responsible for the supply of meibum, an oily substance that prevents evaporation of the eye's tear film; in mice, meibomian gland development is initiated around E18.5 with the formation of an epithelial placode and mesenchymal condensation, similar to that observed in hair follicle development; invagination of the epithelium into the developing mesenchyme then continues from birth to about P3 with initial branching of the epithelial cord detected at P5; by P8 the developing meibomian gland shows extensive ductal branching and the formation of distinct acini with mature meibomian glands present by P15 or eyelid opening

Subject: enlarged Meibomian gland
Value: increased size of the meibum-secreting modified lobulated sebaceous glands located at the rim of the eyelids inside the tarsal plate

Subject: Meibomian gland hypertrophy
Value: increase in the bulk size of the meibum-secreting modified lobulated sebaceous glands located at the rim of the eyelids inside the tarsal plate due to cell enlargement

Subject: small Meibomian gland
Value: decreased size of the meibum-secreting modified lobulated sebaceous glands located at the rim of the eyelids inside the tarsal plate

Subject: Meibomian gland hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the meibum-secreting modified lobulated sebaceous glands located at the rim of the eyelids inside the tarsal plate, usually due to a reduced number of cells

Subject: Meibomian gland cyst
Value: a non-malignant fluid-filled swelling (cyst) of the eyelid area due to non-infectious obstruction or malfunctioning of a Meibomian gland causing extravasation of lipid material in the eyelid soft tissues with focal secondary granulomatous inflammation

Subject: abnormal Meibomian gland physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the meibum-secreting modified lobulated sebaceous glands located at the rim of the eyelids inside the tarsal plate; dysfunctional Meibomian glands may produce an excessive amount of oil, cause dry eyes, or contribute to blepharitis

Subject: Meibomian gland inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the meibum-secreting modified lobulated sebaceous glands located at the rim of the eyelids inside the tarsal plate; chronic Meibomian gland inflammation can lead to a lump in the eyelid known as a Meibomian gland cyst (aka chalazion)

Subject: symblepharon
Value: partial or complete adhesion of the palpebral conjunctiva of the eyelid to the bulbar conjunctiva of the eyeball

Subject: abnormal palpebral conjunctiva morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thin transparent mucous membrane that covers the posterior surface of the eyelids and is continuous with the bulbar conjunctiva at the conjunctival fornicies

Subject: eyelid hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the skin folds covering the front of the eyeball, usually due to a decreased cell number

Subject: eyelid hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size of the skin folds covering the front of the eyeball, usually due to an increased cell number

Subject: abnormal Zeis gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the unilobar sebaceous glands located on the margin of the eyelid that service the eyelash; these glands produce an oily substance that is issued through the excretory ducts of the sebaceous lobule into the middle portion of the hair follicle

Subject: uterus fibrosis
Value: invasion of fibrous connective tissue into the uterus, often resulting from inflammation or injury

Subject: endometrium fibrosis
Value: invasion of fibrous connective tissue into the endometrium, often resulting from inflammation or injury

Subject: abnormal endometrial gland development
Value: aberrant formation or incomplete differentiation of the simple or branched tubular glands found in the mucus membrane of the uterus

Subject: increased endometrial gland number
Value: greater than normal numbers of the simple or branched tubular glands found in the mucus membrane of the uterus

Subject: abnormal bulbar conjunctiva morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the conjunctiva covering the anterior surface of the sclera and the surface epithelium of the cornea

Subject: abnormal circulating lactate level
Value: any anomaly of the amount of lactate in the blood which is produced from pyruvate by lactate dehydrogenase

Subject: decreased circulating lactate level
Value: reduced amount of lactate in the blood which is produced from pyruvate by lactate dehydrogenase

Subject: increased circulating lactate level
Value: greater amount of lactate in the blood which is produced from pyruvate by lactate dehydrogenase

Subject: abnormal epidermal immune compartment
Value: any anomaly in the constitution or organization of the immune cells residing in the skin epidermal layer

Subject: abnormal dendritic epidermal T cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of T cells with dendritic appearance residing in the skin epidermis, usually expressing a canonical gamma-delta T cell receptor and is involved in the regulation of wound healing

Subject: abnormal dendritic epidermal T cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of T cells with dendritic appearance residing in the skin epidermis, usually expressing a canonical gamma-delta T cell receptor and is involved in the regulation of wound healing

Subject: increased dendritic epidermal T cell number
Value: increase in the number of T cells with dendritic appearance residing in the skin epidermis, usually expressing a canonical gamma-delta T cell receptor and is involved in the regulation of wound healing

Subject: decreased dendritic epidermal T cell number
Value: reduction in the number of T cells with dendritic appearance residing in the skin epidermis, usually expressing a canonical gamma-delta T cell receptor and is involved in the regulation of wound healing

Subject: abnormal Langerhans cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of stellate dendritic cells of myeloid origin, that appear clear on light microscopy and has a dark-staining, indented nucleus and characteristic inclusions (Birbeck granules) in the cytoplasm; Langerhans cells are found principally in the stratum spinosum of the epidermis, but they also occur in other stratified epithelia and have been identified in the lung, lymph nodes, spleen, and thymus

Subject: increased Langerhans cell number
Value: increase in the number of stellate dendritic cells of myeloid origin, that appear clear on light microscopy and has a dark-staining, indented nucleus and characteristic inclusions (Birbeck granules) in the cytoplasm; Langerhans cells are found principally in the stratum spinosum of the epidermis, but they also occur in other stratified epithelia and have been identified in the lung, lymph nodes, spleen, and thymus

Subject: abnormal myeloid cell number in bone marrow
Value: any anomaly in the number of CD45+ CD11b+ GR1- myeloid cells in the bone marrow

Subject: decreased myeloid cell number in bone marrow
Value: reduction in the number of CD45+ CD11b+ GR1- myeloid cells in the bone marrow

Subject: increased myeloid cell number in bone marrow
Value: increase in the number of CD45+ CD11b+ GR1- myeloid cells in the bone marrow

Subject: abnormal memory-marker gamma-delta T cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of memory-marker gamma-delta T cells with a CD44+ CD62L- phenotype

Subject: decreased memory-marker gamma-delta T cell number
Value: reduction in the number of memory-marker gamma-delta T cells with a CD44+ CD62L- phenotype

Subject: increased memory-marker gamma-delta T cell number
Value: increase in the number of memory-marker gamma-delta T cells with a CD44+ CD62L- phenotype

Subject: abnormal CD5-positive gamma-delta T cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of CD5+ gamma-delta T cells

Subject: decreased CD5-positive gamma-delta T cell number
Value: reduction in the number of CD5+ gamma-delta T cells

Subject: increased CD5-positive gamma-delta T cell number
Value: increase in the number of CD5+ gamma-delta T cells

Subject: abnormal KLRG1-positive gamma-delta T cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of gamma-delta T cells positive for KLRG1, a marker associated with activation

Subject: decreased KLRG1-positive gamma-delta T cell number
Value: reduction in the number of gamma-delta T cells positive for KLRG1, a marker associated with activation

Subject: increased KLRG1-positive gamma-delta T cell number
Value: increase in the number of gamma-delta T cells positive for KLRG1, a marker associated with activation

Subject: abnormal memory-marker NK cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of memory-marker NK cells with a CD44+ CD62L- phenotype

Subject: decreased memory-marker NK cell number
Value: reduction in the number of memory-marker NK cells with a CD44+ CD62L- phenotype

Subject: increased memory-marker NK cell number
Value: increase in the number of memory-marker NK cells with a CD44+ CD62L- phenotype

Subject: abnormal memory CD4-positive, CD25-positive, alpha-beta regulatory T cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of the CD4+, CD25+ alpha-beta regulatory T cells with a CD44+ CD62L- memory phenotype

Subject: decreased memory CD4-positive, CD25-positive, alpha-beta regulatory T cell number
Value: reduction in the number of the CD4+, CD25+ alpha-beta regulatory T cells with a CD44+ CD62L- memory phenotype

Subject: increased memory CD4-positive, CD25-positive, alpha-beta regulatory T cell number
Value: increase in the number of the CD4+, CD25+ alpha-beta regulatory T cells with a CD44+ CD62L- memory phenotype

Subject: abnormal KLRG1-positive CD4-positive, CD25-positive, alpha-beta regulatory T cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of KLRG1+ CD4+, CD25+, alpha-beta regulatory T cell number positive for KLRG1, a marker associated with activation

Subject: decreased KLRG1-positive CD4-positive, CD25-positive, alpha-beta regulatory T cell number
Value: reduction in the number of KLRG1+ CD4+, CD25+, alpha-beta regulatory T cell number positive for KLRG1, a marker associated with activation

Subject: increased KLRG1-positive CD4-positive, CD25-positive, alpha-beta regulatory T cell number
Value: increase in the number of KLRG1+ CD4+, CD25+, alpha-beta regulatory T cell number positive for KLRG1, a marker associated with activation

Subject: abnormal CD8-positive, naive alpha-beta T cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of the naïve regulatory subset of T lymphocytes that are involved in MHC class I restricted interactions with a CD44-low CD62L+ phenotype

Subject: decreased CD8-positive, naive alpha-beta T cell number
Value: reduction in the number of the naïve regulatory subset of T lymphocytes that are involved in MHC class I restricted interactions with a CD44-low CD62L+ phenotype

Subject: increased CD8-positive, naive alpha-beta T cell number
Value: increase in the number of the naïve regulatory subset of T lymphocytes that are involved in MHC class I restricted interactions with a CD44-low CD62L+ phenotype

Subject: decreased phytosterol level
Value: decreased amount of plant sterols often as a result of hyperabsorbtion of phytosterols and decreased biliary excretion of dietary sterols; commonly ingested phytosterols include beta-sitosterol, campesterol, and stigmasterol

Subject: dysmyelination
Value: reduced amount of myelin present in the form of a myelin sheath surrounding an axon due to defects in the synthesis and formation of myelin

Subject: abnormal Harderian gland development
Value: aberrant formation or incomplete differentiation of the sebaceous gland located behind the eyeball that excretes fluid that facilitates movement of the nictitating membrane; in rodents, the Harderian gland originates from the nasal part of the conjunctival epithelium at E16 and forms a branched structure behind the eyeball; in contrast to the acinar morphology of the lacrimal gland, the Harderian gland has a tubulo-alveolar organization and is composed exclusively of one type of secretory cell; in primates, the HG is either absent or vestigial

Subject: abnormal exorbital lacrimal gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the large exorbital (extra-orbital) lacrimal glands that are located subcutaneously at the anteroventral base of the ear adjacent to the parotid gland

Subject: abnormal intraorbital lacrimal gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small intra-orbital lacrimal glands that are located superficially at the lateral canthus, where both the lacrimal gland and Harderian gland ducts open

Subject: abnormal Harderian gland size
Value: anomaly in the average size of the sebaceous gland located behind the eyeball that excretes fluid that facilitates movement of the nictitating membrane

Subject: Harderian gland hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due to an increased number of cells, of the sebaceous gland that is located behind the eyeball and excretes fluid that facilitates movement of the nictitating membrane

Subject: Harderian gland hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a decreased number of cells, of the sebaceous gland that is located behind the eyeball and excretes fluid that facilitates movement of the nictitating membrane

Subject: Harderian gland atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of the sebaceous gland that is located behind the eyeball and excretes fluid that facilitates movement of the nictitating membrane, associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: enlarged Harderian gland
Value: increased size of the sebaceous gland that is located behind the eyeball and excretes fluid that facilitates movement of the nictitating membrane

Subject: Harderian gland hypertrophy
Value: increase in the bulk size, due to cell enlargement, of the sebaceous gland that is located behind the eyeball and excretes fluid that facilitates movement of the nictitating membrane

Subject: small Harderian gland
Value: decreased size of the sebaceous gland that is located behind the eyeball and excretes fluid that facilitates movement of the nictitating membrane

Subject: abnormal lacrimal lake morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small cistern-like area of the conjunctiva at the medial angle of the eye, in which the tears collect after bathing the front surface of the eyeball and the conjunctival sac

Subject: abnormal lacrimal apparatus physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the network of orbital structures of the eye that secrete and drain tears from the surface of the eyeball into the nasal cavity; these parts include the lacrimal glands, lacrimal lake, lacrimal ducts, lacrimal canals, lacrimal sacs, nasolacrimal ducts, and lacrimal puncta

Subject: nasolacrimal duct obstruction
Value: any impediment or blockage of the paired channels leading from the lacrimal sacs to the inferior meatus of the nose, through which tears are conducted through the nasal cavity; may be either congenital or acquired; obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct leads to the excess overflow of tears called epiphora

Subject: increased lacrimal gland apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of cells of the lacrimal gland undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: enlarged lacrimal gland
Value: increased size of any of the paired glands that secrete the aqueous layer of the tear film

Subject: lacrimal gland hypertrophy
Value: increase in the bulk size of any of the paired glands that secrete the aqueous layer of the tear film due to cell enlargement

Subject: lacrimal gland atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of any of the paired glands that secrete the aqueous layer of the tear film, associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: abnormal eccrine gland number
Value: aberration in the number of the coiled tubular glands normally situated on the digits and footpads of the paws of rodents, and both in the histologically thick skin of the palmar and plantar surfaces and in the thin skin that covers most of the rest of the body in humans; in mice these are the only sweat glands present

Subject: increased eccrine gland number
Value: greater than normal numbers of the coiled tubular glands situated on the digits and footpads of the paws of rodents, and both in the histologically thick skin of the palmar and plantar surfaces and in the thin skin that covers most of the rest of the body in humans; in mice these are the only sweat glands present

Subject: decreased eccrine gland number
Value: fewer than normal numbers of the coiled tubular glands situated on the digits and footpads of the paws of rodents, and both in the histologically thick skin of the palmar and plantar surfaces and in the thin skin that covers most of the rest of the body in humans; in mice these are the only sweat glands present

Subject: perioral dermatitis
Value: an inflammatory skin condition characterized by multiple small papules, pustules and vesicles localized to the perioral skin (around the mouth), perinasal or nasolabial folds (around the nostrils), or periocular area (around the eyes)

Subject: periocular dermatitis
Value: inflammation of the skin on the eyelids and around the eyes; a variant of perioral dermatitis

Subject: abnormal conjunctiva fornix morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the space formed by the junction of the bulbar and palpebral portions of the conjunctiva, that of the upper lid being the superior conjunctival fornix (fornix conjunctivae superior) and that of the lower lid, the inferior conjunctival fornix (fornix conjunctivae inferior); the fornix is loose and flexible, allowing the free movement of the lids and eyeball

Subject: abnormal conjunctiva goblet cell number
Value: aberration in the number of the mucin-secreting cells found on the conjunctival epithelium; changes in goblet cell numbers are associated with alterations in tear mucin level

Subject: increased conjunctiva goblet cell number
Value: greater than normal numbers of the mucin-secreting cells found on the conjunctival epithelium

Subject: decreased conjunctiva goblet cell number
Value: fewer than normal numbers of the mucin-secreting cells found on the conjunctival epithelium; goblet cell loss has been reported in several inflammatory diseases of the ocular surface, including Stevens-Johnson syndrome, ocular mucous membrane pemphigoid, alkali burn, neutrophilic keratitis, graft-versus-host-disease, and Sjogrens's syndrome

Subject: abnormal conjunctiva goblet cell differentiation
Value: abnormal or arrested formation of the mucin-secreting cells of the conjunctival epithelium from conjunctival precursor/stem cells; in mice, mucin-rich goblet cells normally emerge from the conjunctival epithelium around P7-P9, increase in number and form goblet cell clusters between the second and third week of postnatal development

Subject: keratoconjunctivitis sicca
Value: inflammation of the cornea and conjuctiva caused by eye dryness which, in turn, is caused by either decreased tear production or increased tear film evaporation

Subject: diaphragmitis
Value: inflammation of the diaphragm

Subject: chromodacryorrhea
Value: shedding of red or blood-stained tears due to continuous or excessive secretion of porphyrin from the Harderian gland; as these secretions overflow from the eye and drain through the nasal passages to exit the nares dark rust-colored staining, or crust, can be seen around the eyes and nostrils; these secretions may be transferred to the paws and muzzle during grooming; red tears may be associated with nutritional deficiencies, chronic physiological stress, chronic light exposure, or dacryoadenitis

Subject: abnormal lacrimal gland bud morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the single bud-like invagination of the conjunctival fornix epithelium at the temporal aspect of the eye that signals lacrimal gland formation; in mouse, the primary bud arises around E13.5 and extends caudally into the surrounding neural-crest derived periocular mesenchyme; between E15.5 and E16.5 the bud undergoes branching morphogenesis, forming both a major extra-orbital lobe and a minor intraorbital lobe

Subject: absent lacrimal gland bud
Value: absence of the single bud-like invagination of the conjunctival fornix epithelium at the temporal aspect of the eye that signals lacrimal gland formation; in mouse, the primary bud arises around E13.5 and extends caudally into the surrounding neural-crest derived periocular mesenchyme at E14.5

Subject: small lacrimal gland bud
Value: <reduced size of the single bud-like invagination of the conjunctival fornix epithelium at the temporal aspect of the eye that signals lacrimal gland formation; in mouse, the primary bud arises around E13.5 and extends caudally into the surrounding neural-crest derived periocular mesenchyme at E14.5; following elongation, the bud invades the mesenchymal sac at E16.5 and begins a period of rapid growth and branching to form prospective lobular structures: the intra- and ex-orbital lobes>

Subject: abnormal lacrimal gland bud elongation
Value: <anomaly in the process by which the primary lacrimal bud extends caudally into the surrounding neural-crest derived periocular mesenchyme; in mice, the primary bud formed at E13.5 elongates at E14.5; following elongation, the bud invades the mesenchymal sac at E16.5 and begins a period of rapid growth and branching to form prospective lobular structures: the intra- and ex-orbital lobes>

Subject: ectopic lacrimal gland bud
Value: lacrimal gland bud(s) are located other than in the normal or expected position

Subject: abnormal lacrimal gland branching morphogenesis
Value: anomaly of the lacrimal gland bud to repeatedly divide into lobules during development of the lacrimal gland; in mouse, the primary bud arises around E13.5 and extends caudally into the surrounding neural-crest derived periocular mesenchyme; branching is initiated between E15.5 and E16.5 from the tip of the lacrimal bud; by E18.5, the gland consists of an extensively branched exorbital lobe and a small intraocular lobe derived from a single branch of the proximal duct; branching and differentiation of lacrimal glands is complete by around eyelid opening

Subject: delayed reproductive senescence
Value: loss of reproductive capacity occurring at a later than expected age; often accompanied by inability to carry offspring to term

Subject: abnormal Harderian gland porphyrin secretion
Value: anomaly in the production and/or release of porphyrin(s), the pigment(s) responsible for the red discoloration of ocular and/or nasal discharges in rodents; in rats, protoporhyrin IX accounts for most of the porphyrin produced and stored in the Harderian gland; in some rodents the concentration of porphyrins in the Harderian glands varies according to gender and species, and tends to be higher in females than in males

Subject: abnormal cornea limbus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the edge of the cornea where it joins the sclera; the limbus is a common site for the occurrence of corneal epithelial neoplasm

Subject: corneal limbitis
Value: inflammation of the corneal limbus

Subject: scleritis
Value: inflammation of the sclera, the tough white outer coat of the eyeball; may impair vision and occur in association with systemic collagen diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis, Wegener's granulomatosis and, less often, lupus

Subject: cyclitis
Value: inflammation of the ciliary body of the eye

Subject: abnormal ileum crypts of Lieberkuhn morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the intestinal crypts located in the mucosa of the ileum, the portion of the small intestine that extends from the jejunum to the colon

Subject: abnormal duodenum crypts of Lieberkuhn morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the intestinal crypts located in the mucosa of the duodenum, the first division of the small intestine that extends from the pyloris to the junction with the jejunum

Subject: abnormal jejunum crypts of Lieberkuhn morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the intestinal crypts located in the mucosa of the jejunum, the portion of the small intestine that extends from the duodenum to the ileum

Subject: abnormal Paneth cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of the large secretory cells containing coarse granules found at the base of the crypts of Lieberkuhn in the small intestine

Subject: increased Paneth cell number
Value: greater than normal numbers of the large secretory cells containing coarse granules found at the base of the crypts of Lieberkuhn in the small intestine

Subject: decreased Paneth cell number
Value: fewer than normal numbers of the large secretory cells containing coarse granules found at the base of the crypts of Lieberkuhn in the small intestine

Subject: abnormal Paneth cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the large secretory cells found at the base of the crypts of Lieberkuhn in the small intestine; Paneth cells contribute to the mucosal defense mechanism through the secretion of granules filled with antimicrobial (poly)peptides such as lysozyme, phospholipase A2, and defensins (called cryptdins in mice); Paneth cells secrete factors that help sustain and modulate the epithelial stem and progenitor cells that cohabitate in the crypts of Lieberkuhn and rejuvenate the small intestinal epithelium; dysfunction of Paneth cell biology contributes to the pathogenesis of chronic inflammatory bowel disease

Subject: increased keratoacanthoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of low-grade skin tumors that originate in the pilosebaceous glands and closely resemble squamous cell carcinoma, occurring in a specific population in a given time period; keratoacanthomas are spontaneously regressing growths that rarely develop into invasive or metastatic carcinoma; in rare instances, multiple keratoacanthomas are associated with a disease process called Muir-Torre syndrome

Subject: abnormal infundibular recess of third ventricle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the funnel-shaped diverticulum that extends downward from the anterior aspect of the floor of the third ventricle into the infundibulum of the hypophysis; the embryonic structure gives rise the neural component of the pituitary (pas nervosa)

Subject: absent infundibular recess of third ventricle
Value: absence of the funnel-shaped diverticulum that normally extends downward from the anterior aspect of the floor of the third ventricle into the infundibulum of the hypophysis; the embryonic structure gives rise the neural component of the pituitary (pas nervosa)

Subject: abnormal Herring body morphology
