Value: any structural anomaly of the dilated terminal portions of neurosecretory axons constituting the hypothalamohypophyseal tract, found in close proximity to sinusoidal capillaries in the posterior pituitary; Herring bodies consist of aggregates of membrane-bound neurosecretory vesicles where oxytocin or antidiuretic hormone (ADH) are stored prior to release; each Herring body also contains ATP and either neurophysin I or neurophysin II which bind to oxytocin and ADH, respectively

Subject: oral erythroplakia
Value: any lesion of the oral mucosa that presents as bright red plaques or macules with a soft and velvety texture and well-demarcated borders, commonly found in the floor of the mouth, buccal vestibule, the tongue, and the soft palate; an adjacent area of leukoplakia may be found along with the erythroplakia; although erythroplakia is much less common than leukoplakia, erythroplakia carries a significantly higher risk containing dysplasia or carcinoma in situ, and of eventually transforming into invasive squamous cell carcinoma (e.g. oral cancer)

Subject: abnormal trachea submucosa morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the loose fibrous connective tissue located under the tracheal mucosa and composed of abundant blood and lymphatic vessels, diffuse lymphatic tissue and lymphatic nodules, and seromucous tracheal glands; the submucosa ends with the perichondrium of the tracheal cartilages

Subject: abnormal trachea gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tubuloacinar seromucous glands located principally in the submucosa of the trachea whose excretory ducts pass through the lamina propria to the tracheal lumen; they secrete mucus, lysozyme, defensins, and other agents that help protect the lungs from particles and infectious agents; in the mouse, they are restricted to the upper trachea, more specifically to the regions between the first few cartilage rings, with the precise distribution depending on genetic background

Subject: decreased trachea gland number
Value: fewer than normal numbers of the tubuloacinar seromucous glands which are principally located in the submucosa of the trachea, open into the tracheal lumen through short ducts, and secrete mucus, lysozyme, defensins, and other agents that help protect the lungs from particles and infectious agents; in the mouse, they are restricted to the upper trachea, more specifically to the regions between the first few cartilage rings, with the precise distribution depending on genetic background

Subject: abnormal trachea development
Value: aberrant formation or incomplete differentiation of the tube descending from the larynx and branching into the right and left main bronchi

Subject: trachea occlusion
Value: any impediment or blockage of the tube descending from the larynx and branching into the right and left main bronchi

Subject: trachea inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the trachea

Subject: trachea fibrosis
Value: invasion of fibrous connective tissue into the trachea, often resulting from inflammation or injury

Subject: abnormal fibroblast apoptosis
Value: change in the timing or the number of fibroblast cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: increased fibroblast apoptosis
Value: increase in the timing or the number of fibroblast cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: decreased fibroblast apoptosis
Value: reduction in the timing or the number of fibroblast cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal embryonic tissue cell apoptosis
Value: change in the timing or the number of cells in embryonic tissue undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: increased embryonic tissue cell apoptosis
Value: increase in the timing or the number of cells in embryonic tissue undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: decreased embryonic tissue cell apoptosis
Value: decrease in the timing or the number of cells in embryonic tissue undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal ovary apoptosis
Value: change in the timing or the number of cells in ovary tissue undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: increased ovary apoptosis
Value: increase in the timing or the number of ovary cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: increased granulosa cell apoptosis
Value: increase in the timing or the number of granulsa cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal CD4-negative NK T cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of CD4-negative NK T cells

Subject: decreased CD4-negative NK T cell number
Value: reduction in the number of CD4-negative NK T cells

Subject: increased CD4-negative NK T cell number
Value: increase in the number of CD4-negative NK T cells

Subject: abnormal memory-marker CD4-negative NK T cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of memory-marker CD4-negative NK T cells with a CD44+ CD62L- phenotype

Subject: decreased memory-marker CD4-negative NK T cell number
Value: reduction in the number of memory-marker CD4-negative NK T cells with a CD44+ CD62L- phenotype

Subject: increased memory-marker CD4-negative NK T cell number
Value: increase in the number of memory-marker CD4-negative NK T cells with a CD44+ CD62L- phenotype

Subject: abnormal KLRG1-positive CD4-negative NK T cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of KLRG1-positive CD4-negative NK T cells, a marker associated with activation

Subject: decreased KLRG1-positive CD4-negative NK T cell number
Value: reduction in the number of KLRG1-positive CD4-negative NK T cells, a marker associated with activation

Subject: increased KLRG1-positive CD4-negative NK T cell number
Value: increase in the number of KLRG1-positive CD4-negative NK T cells, a marker associated with activation

Subject: abnormal CD4-positive NK T cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of CD4-positive NK T cells

Subject: decreased CD4-positive NK T cell number
Value: reduction in the number of CD4-positive NK T cells

Subject: increased CD4-positive NK T cell number
Value: increase in the number of CD4-positive NK T cells

Subject: abnormal memory-marker CD4-positive NK T cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of memory-marker CD4-positive NK T cells with a CD44+ CD62L- phenotype

Subject: decreased memory-marker CD4-positive NK T cell number
Value: reduction in the number of memory-marker CD4-positive NK T cells with a CD44+ CD62L- phenotype

Subject: increased memory-marker CD4-positive NK T cell number
Value: increase in the number of memory-marker CD4-positive NK T cells with a CD44+ CD62L- phenotype

Subject: abnormal KLRG1-positive CD4-positive NK T cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of KLRG1-positive CD4-positive NK T cells, a marker associated with activation

Subject: decreased KLRG1-positive CD4-positive NK T cell number
Value: reduction in the number of KLRG1-positive CD4-positive NK T cells, a marker associated with activation

Subject: increased KLRG1-positive CD4-positive NK T cell number
Value: increase in the number of KLRG1-positive CD4-positive NK T cells, a marker associated with activation

Subject: absent conjunctiva goblet cells
Value: absence or failure to develop the mucin-secreting cells of the conjunctival epithelium from conjunctival precursor/stem cells; in mice, mucin-rich goblet cells normally emerge from the conjunctival epithelium around P7-P9, increase in number and form goblet cell clusters between the second and third week of postnatal development

Subject: thyroid gland cyst
Value: presence of fluid-filled cavities (cysts) in the thyroid most commonly resulting from degenerating thyroid adenomas; often, solid components are mixed with fluid in thyroid cysts; thyroid cysts are usually benign, but they occasionally contain malignant solid components

Subject: decreased nipple number
Value: fewer than the expected number of structures located on the apex of the mammary gland on the integument surface into which the lactiferous ducts open; normal female mice have five pairs of mammary glands and nipples (males have no nipples); two pairs of nipples are situated in the abdomino-inguinal region (inguinal group) and three pairs in the ventral thoracic region (pectoral or thoracic group)

Subject: abnormal periderm morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the outermost layer of the bilaminar embryonic/fetal epidermis, the first non-basal layer formed at approximately E9.5; it is a temporary structure composed of simple squamous epithelium that serves as the first barrier to the embryo's physical environment, exists throughout the entire keratinocyte stratification process, and sheds off at approximately E17, when it is replaced by corneocytes; desquamated peridermal cells are a considerable component of the vernix caseosa, a white, cheesy, protective substance that covers the fetal skin

Subject: abnormal periderm development
Value: abnormal formation of the outermost layer of the bilaminar embryonic/fetal epidermis; periderm cells emerge at approximately E9.5 and form simple squamous epithelium, the most superficial embryonic layer; these cells form the first, but temporary, embryonic permeability barrier, and are replaced by the cornified envelope, that forms during keratinocyte stratification, by E16.5

Subject: abnormal parotid gland physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of either of the largest of the major salivary glands situated below and in front of each ear

Subject: sublingual gland inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in either of the small mucin-producing salivary glands located in the floor of the mouth beneath the tongue, anterior to the submandibular gland

Subject: abnormal major salivary gland physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the three largest glands of the oral cavity that secrete most of the saliva, including the parotid, submandibular, and sublingual glands

Subject: abnormal minor salivary gland physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the smaller, largely mucus-secreting, exocrine glands of the oral cavity, consisting of the labial, buccal, molar, lingual, and palatine glands

Subject: abnormal sublingual gland physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the small mucin-producing salivary glands in the floor of the mouth beneath the tongue, anterior to the submandibular gland

Subject: increased salivary gland adenoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign epithelial neoplasm with a glandular organization arising in any salivary gland, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased Harderian gland adenoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign epithelial neoplasm with a glandular organization arising in the Harderian gland, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased ovary adenoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a benign epithelial neoplasm with a glandular organization arising in the ovary, occurring in a specific population in a given time period

Subject: increased submandibular gland apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of cells of the submandibular gland undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal submandibular gland development
Value: aberrant formation or incomplete differentiation of either of the paired compound tubuloalveolar (aka tubuloacinar) major salivary glands composed of both serous and mucous secretory cells and situated beneath the mandible; in mice, submandibular gland development initiates as a thickening of the oral epithelium; around E12 an initial (single) epithelial bud on a stalk grows into a condensing neural crest-derived mesenchyme; clefts in the epithelium result in 3-5 epithelial buds at E13.5, and branching morphogenesis occurs with continued proliferation, successive rounds of cleft formation, duct elongation, and duct lumen formation, so that by E14 the gland is highly branched (multi-lobed); functional differentiation, with the appearance of proacinar cells and secretory products begins after E15 and continues to birth; acinar differentiation continues postnatally with final differentiation of the granular convoluted tubules at puberty

Subject: abnormal holocrine gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any exocrine gland whose secretion consists of its own disintegrated secretory cells along with its secretory product; holocrine secretions are produced in the cytoplasm of the cell and released by the rupture of the plasma membrane, which destroys the cell and results in the secretion of the product into the lumen

Subject: abnormal merocrine gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any exocrine gland whose secretions are excreted via exocytosis from secretory cells into an epithelial-walled duct or ducts and thence onto a bodily surface or into the lumen; the gland releases its product and no part of the gland is lost or damaged

Subject: cleft hard palate
Value: cleft in the anterior portion of the palate consisting of bone and mucous membranes; the hard palate is formed from bony processes of the maxilla, premaxilla and palatine bones

Subject: cleft soft palate
Value: a cleft in the soft tissue constituting the back of the roof of the mouth; the soft palate is the posterior portion of the palate extending from the posterior edge of the hard palate to the back of the mouth

Subject: submucous cleft soft palate
Value: a cleft of the soft palate which is characterized by a midline deficiency or lack of muscular tissue and incorrect positioning of the muscles, but cleft is covered over by the mucous membrane of the roof of the mouth; frequently associated with a bifid or cleft uvula

Subject: submucous cleft hard palate
Value: a cleft of the hard palate characterized by a bony defect in the midline or center of the bony part of the palate, but cleft is covered over by the mucous membrane of the roof of the mouth

Subject: abnormal primary palate morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tissues normally uniting to form the primary palate; the primary palate will form the premaxillary portion of the maxilla (anterior one-third of the final palate

Subject: decreased cerebellar granule cell precursor proliferation
Value: reduction in the ability of a cerebellar granule cell precursor population to undergo rapid expansion by cell division

Subject: increased cerebellar granule cell precursor proliferation
Value: increase in the ability of a cerebellar granule precursor cell population to undergo rapid expansion by cell division

Subject: increased macrophage proliferation
Value: increased ability of macrophages to undergo expansion by cell division; macrophages are large mononuclear phagocytes which differentiate from monocytes, are typically resident in a particular tissue, and capable of phagocytosing a variety of extracellular particulate material, including immune complexes, microorganisms, and dead cells

Subject: abnormal apocrine gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any exocrine gland whose cells bud their secretions off through the plasma membrane producing membrane-bound vesicles in the lumen; the apical portion of the secretory cell of the gland pinches off and enters the lumen; it loses part of its cytoplasm in their secretions; apocrine secretion is functional during hormonal stress or puberty; an example of true apocrine glands are mammary glands, responsible for secreting breast milk

Subject: abnormal apocrine gland physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of any exocrine gland whose cells bud their secretions off through the plasma membrane producing membrane-bound vesicles in the lumen; the apical portion of the secretory cell of the gland pinches off and enters the lumen; it loses part of its cytoplasm in their secretions; apocrine secretion is functional during hormonal stress or puberty; an example of true apocrine glands are mammary glands, responsible for secreting breast milk

Subject: abnormal holocrine gland physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of any exocrine gland whose secretion consists of its own disintegrated secretory cells along with its secretory product; holocrine secretions are produced in the cytoplasm of the cell and released by the rupture of the plasma membrane, which destroys the cell and results in the secretion of the product into the lumen

Subject: abnormal merocrine gland physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of any exocrine gland whose secretions are excreted via exocytosis from secretory cells into an epithelial-walled duct or ducts and thence onto a bodily surface or into the lumen; the gland releases its product and no part of the gland is lost or damaged

Subject: abnormal exocrine gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the glands of the exocrine system that secrete their essential product by way of a duct to some environment external to itself, either inside the body or on a surface of the body; the duct portion may be branched (compound) or unbranched (simple); the glandular portion may be tubular or acinar, or may be a mix of the two (tubuloacinar or tubuloalveolar); if the glandular portion branches, then the gland is called a branched gland Typical exocrine glands include sweat glands, salivary glands, mammary glands, stomach, liver, pancreas

Subject: abnormal exocrine gland physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of any of the glands of the exocrine system that secrete their essential product by way of a duct to some environment external to itself, either inside the body or on a surface of the body; the duct portion may be branched (compound) or unbranched (simple); the glandular portion may be tubular or acinar, or may be a mix of the two (tubuloacinar or tubuloalveolar); if the glandular portion branches, then the gland is called a branched gland Typical exocrine glands include sweat glands, salivary glands, mammary glands, stomach, liver, pancreas

Subject: abnormal endocrine gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the glands of the endocrine system that secrete their products directly into the circulatory system rather than through a duct

Subject: abnormal endocrine gland physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of any of the glands of the endocrine system that secrete their products directly into the circulatory system rather than through a duct

Subject: abnormal circumventricular organ morphology
Value: any structural abnormality of any of the secretory or sensory organs located in the brain region around or in relation to the ventricular system that are characterized by extensive vasculature and a lack of a normal blood brain barrier (BBB) and allow for the linkage between the central nervous system and peripheral blood flow; CVOs contain neural tissue and are an integral part of neuroendocrine function; all of the CVOs, besides the subcommissural organ, contain extensive vasculature and fenestrated capillaries which leads to a leaky BBB at the site of the organs; the lack of a BBB allows CVOs to act as an alternative route for peptides and hormones in the neural tissue to the peripheral blood stream, while still protecting it from toxic substances

Subject: abnormal secretory circumventricular organ morphology
Value: any structural abnormality of any of the circumventricular organs that are responsible for secreting hormones and glycoproteins into the peripheral vascular system using feedback from both the brain environment and external stimuli

Subject: abnormal sensory circumventricular organ morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the circumventricular organs that have the ability to sense plasma molecules and then pass that information into other regions of the brain, thereby providing direct information to the autonomic nervous system from systemic circulation

Subject: abnormal adrenal gland capsule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thick capsule of dense irregular connective tissue that surrounds each adrenal gland and contains scattered elastic fibers; the capsule contains a rich plexus of blood vessels (mainly small arteries) and numerous nerve fibers; some blood vessels and nerves enter the substance of the gland in the trabeculae that extend inward from the capsule and then leave the trabeculae to enter the cortex

Subject: dilated gastric glands
Value: stretched or widened aperture of the luminal space of any of the branched tubular glands found in the mucosa of the fundus and body of the stomach which contain parietal cells that secrete hydrochloric acid and zymogenic cells that produce pepsin

Subject: gastric gland atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of any of the gastric glands, associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal change

Subject: gastric gland degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of any of the branched tubular glands found in the mucosa of the fundus and body of the stomach which contain parietal cells that secrete hydrochloric acid and zymogenic cells that produce pepsin

Subject: gastric gland hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due to an increased number of cells, of any of the branched tubular glands found in the mucosa of the fundus and body of the stomach which contain parietal cells that secrete hydrochloric acid and zymogenic cells that produce pepsin

Subject: abnormal neuroendocrine gland physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of any of the organized aggregations of cells that function as secretory or excretory organs and that release hormones in response to neural stimuli

Subject: abnormal parathyroid gland capsule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the dense and irregular connective tissue capsule surrounding each parathyroid gland

Subject: abnormal parathyroid gland chief cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of an epithelial cell that are collectively arranged in wide, irregular interconnecting columns in the parathyroid gland, that is responsible for the synthesis and secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH)

Subject: abnormal parathyroid gland development
Value: aberrant formation or incomplete differentiation of either of the two small, paired endocrine glands, usually found embedded in the connective tissue capsule on the posterior surface of the thyroid gland, which secrete parathyroid hormone (PTH), a hormone that regulates calcium and phosphorous metabolism; in mouse, the parathyroids develop with the thymus from two common parathyroid/thymus primordia originating from the third pharyngeal pouch endoderm; the third pharyngeal pouches are formed at E9.5-E10 and are patterned into dorsal/anterior parathyroid and ventral/posterior thymus domains; the third pouch endoderm proliferates to form bilateral parathyroid/thymus common primordia at E11-E11.5; each primordium separates into one parathyroid gland and one thymus lobe at E12.5-E13.5, which then migrate to their eventual adult locations by about E14.5; in the adult mouse, the parathyroids are located near or embedded within the thyroid gland, and the thymus is situated in the anterior chest cavity

Subject: ectopic parathyroid gland
Value: a parathyroid gland located outside of its normal position; in the normal adult mouse, the parathyroids are usually found embedded in the connective tissue capsule on the posterior surface of the thyroid gland; because of their common pharyngeal pouch origin, ectopic thyroid and parathyroid tissue can occasionally be found in the thymus

Subject: abnormal forestomach-glandular stomach junction morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the distinct low fold of tissue that separates the non-glandular area of the stomach (forestomach) from the glandular stomach; the limiting ridge extends circumferentially from the large curvature of the stomach to the small curvature, just below the esophagus; at the esophagus, the course of the limiting ridge bends into a U-shape and almost surrounds the esophageal opening

Subject: small forestomach
Value: reduced size of the distinct rodent non-glandular region of the stomach which is demarcated from the glandular stomach by the limiting ridge (margo plicatus)

Subject: forestomach hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the distinct rodent non-glandular region of the stomach which is demarcated from the glandular stomach by the limiting ridge (margo plicatus)

Subject: abnormal stomach glandular region morphology
Value: <any structural anomaly of the distinct glandular stomach area which in rodents is demarcated from the non-glandular forestomach by the limiting ridge (margo plicatus); the glandular stomach is connected to the small intestine (duodenum); the wall of the glandular stomach consists of, from inside to outside, simple columnar epithelium containing gastric glands, the lamina propria (epithelium and lamina propria form the glandular mucosa), the muscularis mucosae, the submucosa, the muscularis interna and externa (inner circular and outer longitudinal layers of smooth muscle), and the serosa; the gastric glands lined by simple columnar epithelium form deep gastric pits (foveolae) that are perpendicular to the wall of the stomach; three types of gastric glands exist; the cardiac glands, located near the limiting ridge, contain mucous cells; the pyloric glands also contain mucous cells; the fundic glands, which make up the majority of the gastric glands, contain a variety of cells: mucous neck cells, small, basophilic chief cells, and large, round parietal cells with a granular eosinophilic cytoplasm>

Subject: increased adrenal gland apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of any cells of the adrenal gland undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal nasal gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the seromucous glands found in the respiratory region of the nasal mucous membrane, including anterior serous glands, seromucous glands, and Bowman glands

Subject: nasal gland degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of any of the seromucous glands found in the respiratory region of the nasal mucous membrane

Subject: abnormal lateral nasal gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the lateral nasal glands (the largest nasal secretory glands in rodents) which surround the maxillary sinus located in the lateral wall adjacent to each nasal passage and are characterized by cytologic features similar to those described for the major serous salivary glands; secretory contents of the LNG drain into the nasal vestibule; the LNG is a major site for the synthesis and secretion of odorant-binding proteins that serve as odorant carriers in nasal mucus; it also, synthesizes large amounts of immunoglobulin A, which is important for immune defense of the upper respiratory tract, and testosterone and salivary androgen-binding proteins, which are likely important in olfaction and reproductive behavior

Subject: salivary gland degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of any of the saliva-secreting glands of the oral cavity

Subject: pancreas degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of the organ that secretes pancreatic juice into the duodenum and secretes glucagon and insulin into the bloodstream

Subject: thymus cortex atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the outer part of a thymus lobule that surrounds the medulla and is composed of closely packed lymphocytes, associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: thymus medulla atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the inner area of thymus lobules associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: absent thymus medulla
Value: lacking the inner area of thymus lobules

Subject: small thymus medulla
Value: decreased size of the inner area of thymus lobules

Subject: thymus medulla hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced cell number, of the inner area of thymus lobules

Subject: enlarged thymus medulla
Value: increased size of the inner area of thymus lobules

Subject: thymus medulla hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due to an increased cell number, of the inner area of thymus lobules

Subject: small thymus cortex
Value: decreased size of the outer part of a thymus lobule that surrounds the medulla and is composed of closely packed lymphocytes

Subject: enlarged thymus cortex
Value: increased size of the outer part of a thymus lobule that surrounds the medulla and is composed of closely packed lymphocytes

Subject: abnormal parotid gland acinus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the secretory units (acini) of either parotid gland which in human and rodent consist almost exclusively of serous secretory cells with their lumina continuous with intercalated ducts; in mouse, parotid gland acini are very small and consist of 3-4 tall pyramidal cells with strongly basophilic cytoplasm and basally located, large spherical nuclei; the serous secretory cells contain many secretory granules having an electron-lucent profile which are situated in the supranuclear cytoplasm; the serous secretory cells have a well-developed rough endoplasmic reticulum in the infranuclear region and are surrounded by myoepithelial cells

Subject: absent vomeronasal organ
Value: lacking the tubular, crescent-sensory organ with a luminal epithelium that contains chemosensitive receptor cells with microvilli that are thought to detect pheromones and transmit signals to the remainder of the accessory olfactory system

Subject: abnormal vomeronasal organ physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the tubular, crescent-sensory organ with a luminal epithelium that contains chemosensitive receptor cells with microvilli that are thought to detect pheromones and transmit signals to the remainder of the accessory olfactory system; the organ lies at the base the nasal cavity and is split into two, separated by the nasal septum

Subject: small vomeronasal organ
Value: reduced size of the tubular, crescent-sensory organ with a luminal epithelium that contains chemosensitive receptor cells with microvilli that are thought to detect pheromones and transmit signals to the remainder of the accessory olfactory system

Subject: Leydig cell hypertrophy
Value: increased size of the interstitial cells that are found adjacent to the seminiferous tubules in the testicle and produce testosterone in the presence of luteinizing hormone (LH)

Subject: Leydig cell atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the interstitial cells that are found adjacent to the seminiferous tubules in the testicle and produce testosterone in the presence of luteinizing hormone (LH), associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: testis degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of either or both of the male reproductive glands

Subject: increased testis apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of cells of the male reproductive glands undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal Leydig cell differentiation
Value: atypical formation of or inability to produce the interstitial cells that are found adjacent to the seminiferous tubules in the testicle and produce testosterone in the presence of luteinizing hormone; in most mammals, normal Leydig cell (LC) development comprises two sequential but overlapping cell lineages known as the fetal and adult type LC populations, which display distinct functional characteristics reflected by different morphology, hormonal regulation, and steroidogenic output

Subject: abnormal fetal Leydig cell differentiation
Value: atypical formation of or inability to produce the first or fetal population of Leydig cells (FLCs); in mice, FLCs arise in the testicular interstitium between E12.5 and E13.0, approximately 1 day after the appearance of Sertoli cells; Sertoli cells trigger differentiation of steroidogenic factor 1-positive (SF1-positive) progenitor cells into FLCs via paracrine regulation; the intercellular Notch signaling pathway is also involved in FLC establishment and maintenance; the FLC population increases dramatically during embryonic development despite the fact that differentiating FLCs are mitotically inactive, suggesting that expansion of FLC populations results from differentiation of progenitor cells, rather than cell division of existing FLCs; the SF1-positive cells in gonadal primordia are the primary source of FLCs but other sources such as neighboring mesonephros, migrating neural crest cells, and cells from the coelomic epithelium or interstitium are potential contributors also; at the end of fetal life and during the first 2 postnatal weeks in rodents, FLCs are gradually replaced by adult Leydig cells (ALCs)

Subject: abnormal adult Leydig cell differentiation
Value: atypical formation of or inability to produce the second or adult population of Leydig cells (ALCs) between birth and puberty; ALCs arise in the interstitium of adult testes from unknown progenitor cells and become the major source of androgens that control differentiation of the male reproductive tract and spermatogenesis; ALCs are not derived from fetal Leydig cells (FLCs), and the origin and the molecular events that control ALC differentiation are poorly understood

Subject: abnormal ovarian bursa morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the peritoneal recess between the medial aspect of the ovary and the mesosalpinx

Subject: abnormal ovarian fossa morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the shallow depression in the parietal peritoneum of the pelvis that lodges the ovary

Subject: ovary fibrosis
Value: invasion of fibrous connective tissue into the ovary, often resulting from inflammation or injury

Subject: abnormal ovarian cortex morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the layer of the ovarian stroma lying immediately beneath the tunica albuginea, composed of connective tissue cells and fibers, among which are scattered primary and secondary (antral) follicles in various stages of development; the cortex varies in thickness according to the age of the individual, becoming thinner with advancing years; included in the follicles are the cumulus oophorus, membrana granulosa (and the granulosa cells inside it), corona radiata, zona pellucida, and primary oocyte; the zona pellucida, theca of follicle, antrum and liquor folliculi are also contained in the follicle; also in the cortex is the corpus luteum derived from the follicles

Subject: abnormal ovarian medulla morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the highly vascular stroma found in the center of the ovary that forms from embryonic mesenchyme and contains blood vessels, lymphatic vessels, and nerves; this stroma forms the tissue of the hilum by which the ovarian ligament is attached, and through which the blood vessels enter; it does not contain any ovarian follicles

Subject: abnormal rete ovarii morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the canal structure formed from the primary sex cords in females; a transient network of cells in the developing ovary that is homologous to the rete testis in males

Subject: abnormal bile duct epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the epithelium lining the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts

Subject: enlarged caudal vertebrae
Value: increased size of the bony segments of the coccyx or tail

Subject: abnormal volumetric bone mineral density
Value: anomaly of the mineral mass per unit volume of bone, the hard, rigid form of connective tissue constituting most of the skeleton of vertebrates and composed chiefly of calcium salts; this is expressed as the amount of mineral per cubic cm of bone (usually in mgHA/cm^3), with results generated from Quantitative computed tomography (QCT) and other tests

Subject: abnormal areal bone mineral density
Value: anomaly of the mineral mass per unit area of bone, the hard, rigid form of connective tissue constituting most of the skeleton of vertebrates and composed chiefly of calcium salts; expressed as the amount of mineral per area cm^2 of bone (usually in g/cm^2), with results generated from Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA or DEXA) tests

Subject: increased volumetric bone mineral density
Value: increase in the mineral mass per unit volume of bone, the hard, rigid form of connective tissue constituting most of the skeleton of vertebrates and composed chiefly of calcium salts; this is expressed as the amount of mineral per cubic cm of bone (usually in mgHA/cm^3), with results generated from Quantitative computed tomography (QCT) and other tests

Subject: decreased volumetric bone mineral density
Value: reduction in the mineral mass per unit volume of bone, the hard, rigid form of connective tissue constituting most of the skeleton of vertebrates and composed chiefly of calcium salts; this is expressed as the amount of mineral per cubic cm of bone (usually in mgHA/cm^3), with results generated from Quantitative computed tomography (QCT) and other tests

Subject: increased areal bone mineral density
Value: increase in the mineral mass per unit area of bone, the hard, rigid form of connective tissue constituting most of the skeleton of vertebrates and composed chiefly of calcium salts; expressed as the amount of mineral per area cm^2 of bone (usually in g/cm^2), with results generated from Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA or DEXA) tests

Subject: decreased areal bone mineral density
Value: reduction of the mineral mass per unit area of bone, the hard, rigid form of connective tissue constituting most of the skeleton of vertebrates and composed chiefly of calcium salts; expressed as the amount of mineral per area cm^2 of bone (usually in g/cm^2), with results generated from Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA or DEXA) tests

Subject: abnormal long bone internal diameter
Value: anomaly of the cross-sectional distance that extends from one lateral edge of a long bone marrow cavity, through its center and to the opposite lateral edge of the bone marrow cavity through the mid point of the bone

Subject: increased internal diameter of femur
Value: increased cross-sectional distance that extends from one lateral edge of the femur long bone marrow cavity, through its center and to the opposite lateral edge of the bone marrow cavity through the mid point of the femur

Subject: decreased internal diameter of femur
Value: reduced cross-sectional distance that extends from one lateral edge of the femur long bone marrow cavity, through its center and to the opposite lateral edge of the bone marrow cavity through the mid point of the femur

Subject: abnormal femur compact bone thickness
Value: reduced or increased width of the superficial layer of compact bone at the midpoint of the femur

Subject: increased femur compact bone thickness
Value: increased width of the superficial layer of compact bone at the midpoint of the femur

Subject: decreased femur compact bone thickness
Value: reduced width of the superficial layer of compact bone at the midpoint of the femur

Subject: increased femur yield load
Value: increase in load (N) on the femur at which elastic deformation ends

Subject: decreased femur yield load
Value: decrease in load (N) on the femur at which elastic deformation ends

Subject: increased vertebra yield load
Value: increase in load (N) on a vertebra at which elastic deformation ends

Subject: decreased vertebra yield load
Value: decrease in load (N) on a vertebra at which elastic deformation ends

Subject: abnormal bone trabecular spacing
Value: any deviation in the amount of space between trabeculae in cancellous bone

Subject: increased bone trabecular spacing
Value: increase in the amount of space between trabeculae in cancellous bone

Subject: decreased bone trabecular spacing
Value: decrease in the amount of space between trabeculae in cancellous bone

Subject: increased femur maximal load
Value: increase in the maximal load (N) sustained by the femur

Subject: decreased femur maximal load
Value: decrease in the maximal load (N) sustained by the femur

Subject: increased femur fracture load
Value: increase in the load at which material failure occurs after plastic deformation

Subject: decreased femur fracture load
Value: decrease in the load at which material failure occurs after plastic deformation

Subject: abnormal bone stiffness
Value: deviation in material stiffness (N/mm) during elastic deformation

Subject: increased femur stiffness
Value: increase in material stiffness (N/mm) during elastic deformation in the femur

Subject: decreased femur stiffness
Value: decrease in material stiffness (N/mm) during elastic deformation in the femur

Subject: decreased bone stiffness
Value: decrease in material stiffness (N/mm) during elastic deformation

Subject: increased bone stiffness
Value: increase in material stiffness (N/mm) during elastic deformation

Subject: increased vertebra stiffness
Value: increase in material stiffness (N/mm) during elastic deformation in a vertebra

Subject: decreased vertebra stiffness
Value: decrease in material stiffness (N/mm) during elastic deformation in a vertebra

Subject: decreased vertebra maximal load
Value: decrease in the maximal load (N) sustained by a vertebra

Subject: increased vertebra maximal load
Value: increase in the maximal load (N) sustained by a vertebra

Subject: increased energy dissipated prior to femur fracture
Value: increase in the fraction of total energy dissapated prior to ultimate material failure (low energy fracture) by the femur

Subject: decreased energy dissipated prior to femur fracture
Value: decrease in the fraction of total energy dissapated prior to ultimate material failure (high energy fracture) by the femur

Subject: abnormal CD11b-high dendritic cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of dendritic cells expressing high levels of CD11b which usually depend on Irf4 for their development

Subject: increased CD11b-high dendritic cell number
Value: increase in the number of dendritic cells expressing high levels of CD11b which usually depend on Irf4 for their development

Subject: decreased CD11b-high dendritic cell number
Value: reduction in the number of dendritic cells expressing high levels of CD11b which usually depend on Irf4 for their development

Subject: abnormal CD11b-low dendritic cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of dendritic cells expressing low levels of CD11b which usually express CD8, depend on Irf8 and Batf3 for their development and are responsible for cross-presentation

Subject: increased CD11b-low dendritic cell number
Value: increase in the number of dendritic cells expressing low levels of CD11b which usually express CD8, depend on Irf8 and Batf3 for their development and are responsible for cross-presentation

Subject: decreased CD11b-low dendritic cell number
Value: reduction in the number of dendritic cells expressing low levels of CD11b which usually express CD8, depend on Irf8 and Batf3 for their development and are responsible for cross-presentation

Subject: abnormal CD103-positive CD11b-low dendritic cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of CD11b-low dendritic cells expressing CD103, a marker of tissue residency

Subject: increased CD103-positive CD11b-low dendritic cell number
Value: increase in the number of CD11b-low dendritic cells expressing CD103, a marker of tissue residency

Subject: decreased CD103-positive CD11b-low dendritic cell number
Value: reduction in the number of CD11b-low dendritic cells expressing CD103, a marker of tissue residency

Subject: abnormal hematopoietic cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the cells of the hematopoietic lineage

Subject: abnormal blood cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of cells found in the blood

Subject: abnormal myeloid cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a cell of the monocyte, granulocyte, mast cell, megakaryocyte, or erythroid lineage

Subject: abnormal erythroid lineage cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of an immature or mature cell in the lineage leading to and including erythrocytes

Subject: abnormal bone marrow hematopoietic cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of hematopoietic cells that are resident in the bone marrow, including hematopoietic stem cells (lymphoid stem cells and myeloid stem cells) and the precursor cells for thrombocytes, erythrocytes, basophils, neutrophils, eosinophils, monocytes and lymphocytes

Subject: abnormal myeloid cell number
Value: any anomaly in the expected number of cells of the myeloid lineage

Subject: decreased myeloid cell number
Value: reduction in the expected number of cells of the myeloid lineage

Subject: increased myeloid cell number
Value: greater than the expected number of cells of the myeloid lineage

Subject: abnormal immature B cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of the cells of the B lymphocyte lineage that have undergone VDJ rearrangement of the heavy chain and V-J rearrangement of the light chain; these cells express IgM on the cell surface but have not yet been selected for self-reactivity

Subject: abnormal immature NK cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of NK cells lacking expression of the maturation marker CD11b

Subject: decreased immature NK cell number
Value: reduction in the number of NK cells lacking expression of the maturation marker CD11b

Subject: increased immature NK cell number
Value: increase in the number of NK cells lacking expression of the maturation marker CD11b

Subject: abnormal Ly6C-positive immature NK cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of immature NK cells expressing the memory marker Ly6C

Subject: decreased Ly6C-positive immature NK cell number
Value: reduction in the number of immature NK cells expressing the memory marker Ly6C

Subject: increased Ly6C-positive immature NK cell number
Value: increase in the number of immature NK cells expressing the memory marker Ly6C

Subject: abnormal mature NK cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of NK cells expressing the maturation marker CD11b

Subject: decreased mature NK cell number
Value: reduction in the number of NK cells expressing the maturation marker CD11b

Subject: increased mature NK cell number
Value: increase in the number of NK cells expressing the maturation marker CD11b

Subject: abnormal Ly6C-positive mature NK cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of mature NK cells expressing the memory marker Ly6C

Subject: decreased Ly6C-positive mature NK cell number
Value: reduction in the number of mature NK cells expressing the memory marker Ly6C

Subject: increased Ly6C-positive mature NK cell number
Value: increase in the number of mature NK cells expressing the memory marker Ly6C

Subject: abnormal Ly6C-positive NK T cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of NK T cells expressing the memory marker Ly6C

Subject: decreased Ly6C-positive NK T cell number
Value: reduction in the number of NK T cells expressing the memory marker Ly6C

Subject: increased Ly6C-positive NK T cell number
Value: increase in the number of NK T cells expressing the memory marker Ly6C

Subject: abnormal germinal center B cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of a rapidly cycling mature B cell which have downregulated IgD expression and exhibit high levels of binding by peanut agglutinin (PNA), and are involved in T-dependent immune responses; germinal center B cells are found typically in the germinal centers of lymph nodes and spleen

Subject: abnormal early germinal center B cell number
Value: any structural anomaly of germinal center B cells with residual expression of IgD

Subject: abnormal late germinal center B cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of germinal center B cells expressing IgG1 and lacking expression of IgD

Subject: decreased early germinal center B cell number
Value: reduction in the number of germinal center B cells with residual expression of IgD

Subject: increased early germinal center B cell number
Value: increase in the number of germinal center B cells with residual expression of IgD

Subject: decreased late germinal center B cell number
Value: reduction in the number of germinal center B cells expressing IgG1 and lacking expression of IgD

Subject: increased late germinal center B cell number
Value: increase in the number of germinal center B cells expressing IgG1 and lacking expression of IgD

Subject: abnormal CD5-positive T cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of T cells expressing CD5, a negative regulator of T cell signaling

Subject: decreased CD5-positive T cell number
Value: reduction in the number of T cells expressing CD5, a negative regulator of T cell signaling

Subject: increased CD5-positive T cell number
Value: increase in the number of T cells expressing CD5, a negative regulator of T cell signaling

Subject: abnormal CD5-positive Ly6C-positive T cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of CD5-positive T cells expressing the memory marker Ly6C

Subject: decreased CD5-positive Ly6C-positive T cell number
Value: reduction in the number of CD5-positive T cells expressing the memory marker Ly6C

Subject: increased CD5-positive Ly6C-positive T cell number
Value: increase in the number of CD5-positive T cells expressing the memory marker Ly6C

Subject: abnormal hemopoiesis
Value: any anomaly in the process whose specific outcome is the progression of the myeloid and lymphoid derived organ/tissue systems of the blood and other parts of the body over time, from formation to the mature structure; the site of hemopoiesis is variable during development, but occurs primarily in bone marrow in mammals

Subject: abnormal granulocyte monocyte progenitor cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a hematopoietic progenitor cell that is committed to the granulocyte and monocyte lineages; these cells are CD123-positive, and do not express Gata1 or Gata2 but do express C/EBPa, and Pu.1

Subject: abnormal granulocyte monocyte progenitor cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of a hematopoietic progenitor cell that is committed to the granulocyte and monocyte lineages; these cells are CD123-positive, and do not express Gata1 or Gata2 but do express C/EBPa, and Pu.1

Subject: increased granulocyte monocyte progenitor cell number
Value: increase in the number of a hematopoietic progenitor cell that is committed to the granulocyte and monocyte lineages; these cells are CD123-positive, and do not express Gata1 or Gata2 but do express C/EBPa, and Pu.1

Subject: decreased granulocyte monocyte progenitor cell number
Value: reduction in the number of a hematopoietic progenitor cell that is committed to the granulocyte and monocyte lineages; these cells are CD123-positive, and do not express Gata1 or Gata2 but do express C/EBPa, and Pu.1

Subject: absent granulocyte monocyte progenitor cells
Value: absence of hematopoietic progenitor cells that are committed to the granulocyte and monocyte lineages; these cells are CD123-positive, and do not express Gata1 or Gata2 but do express C/EBPa, and Pu.1

Subject: abnormal immature NK cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly in the number of NK cells lacking expression of the maturation marker CD11b

Subject: abnormal mature NK cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of NK cells expressing the maturation marker CD11b

Subject: abnormal mature B cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of the mature form of B cells, a type of lymphocyte whose defining characteristic is the expression of an immunoglobulin complex

Subject: abnormal megakaryocyte-erythroid progenitor cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a progenitor cell committed to the megakaryocyte and erythroid lineages

Subject: abnormal megakaryocyte-erythroid progenitor cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of a progenitor cell committed to the megakaryocyte and erythroid lineages

Subject: increased megakaryocyte-erythroid progenitor cell number
Value: increase in the number of a progenitor cell committed to the megakaryocyte and erythroid lineages

Subject: decreased megakaryocyte-erythroid progenitor cell number
Value: reduced number of a progenitor cell committed to the megakaryocyte and erythroid lineages

Subject: absent megakaryocyte-erythroid progenitor cells
Value: absence of progenitor cells committed to the megakaryocyte and erythroid lineages

Subject: abnormal hematopoietic precursor cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a hematopoietic cell that is a precursor of some other hematopoietic cell type

Subject: abnormal hematopoietic precursor cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of a hematopoietic cell that is a precursor of some other hematopoietic cell type

Subject: abnormal cervical mammary gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of either of two mammary glands located in the cervical (i.e. neck) region, forward of the axial area of the forelimbs (mice have a single pair of cervical mammary glands)

Subject: abnormal abdominal mammary gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of either of the two mammary glands located in the abdominal wall (mice have a single pair of abdominal mammary glands)

Subject: abnormal inguinal mammary gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of either of the two mammary glands located in the inguinal region between the hind legs (mice have a single pair of inguinal mammary glands)

Subject: abnormal thoracic mammary gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the mammary glands located in the thoracic (i.e. pectoral or chest wall) region (mice have two pairs of thoracic mammary glands)

Subject: decreased nipple size
Value: reduced size of the erectile projection at the apex of the mammary gland where the lactiferous ducts open

Subject: abnormal mammary gland number
Value: anomaly in the expected number of the specialized accessory gland of the skin of mammals that secretes milk

Subject: decreased mammary gland number
Value: fewer than the expected number of the specialized accessory gland of the skin of mammals that secretes milk

Subject: hypolactation
Value: partial failure, or reduced ability to produce or secrete milk from the mammary gland

Subject: hyperlactation
Value: secretion of milk from the mammary gland in excessive amount, or for an abnormally prolonged period

Subject: galactostasis
Value: abnormal accumulation of milk within the mammary gland alveoli and ducts due to failure of ejection (letdown) from the gland; may be associated with nipple anatomic abnormalities

Subject: pale mammary gland
Value: loss of the normal reddish-pink color of mammary gland tissue

Subject: abnormal mammary line morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of either of the presumptive bilateral epidermal ridges (milk lines) formed at the onset of mammogenesis and running in an anteroposterior direction ventrally between fore- and hindlimbs, one line along each flank of the embryo; in mouse, mammary gland development begins shortly after mid-gestation (about E10.5); epidermal cells within the milk line become columnar and multilayered, defining a ridge that protrudes above and below the plane of the single-layered primitive epidermis or periderm; by E11.5, five pairs of lens-shaped placodes form along the mammary line at the site of each future nipple

Subject: abnormal mammary placode morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the transient lens-shaped thickening of surface ectoderm that will give rise to the mammary bud proper; in mouse, five pairs of symmetrically positioned mammary placodes (three thoracic and two inguinal) form at reproducible locations along the mammary line at E11.5; the individual pairs develop asynchronously and in a distinct order; pair 3 is first, followed by pair 4, then by pairs 1 and 5 (which develop together), and finally by pair 2; the orientation of placodal cells is not uniform, suggesting that placodes are formed by migration of cells from the mammary line; between E11.5 and E12.5, each mammary placode expands and invaginates into the underlying mesenchyme to form an early bulb-shaped mammary bud

Subject: abnormal circulating tyrosine level
Value: aberrant concentration in the blood of tyrosine or 4-hydroxyphenylalanine, a non-essential amino acid with a polar side group present in most proteins and synthesized metabolically from phenylalanine; tyrosine is a precursor of melanin, catecholamines, and thyroid hormones

Subject: increased circulating tyrosine level
Value: increase in the amount per unit of blood of tyrosine

Subject: decreased circulating tyrosine level
Value: reduction in the amount per unit of blood of tyrosine

Subject: abnormal mammary gland cord morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the solid cord of epithelial cells that emerges from the mammary bud and grows down from the primary mammary mesenchyme and into a second stromal compartment, the fat pad precursor, beneath the dermis; in female mouse embryos, the primary mammary cord (mammary sprout) is formed between E15.5 and E16.5; once the primary cord reaches the adipocytes of the fat pad (around E16), it begins to branch in a characteristic dichotomous fashion to form the initial ductal tree

Subject: abnormal mammary gland cord formation
Value: any anomaly in the process by which the mammary gland cord forms by elongation of the mammary bud; in female mouse embryos, the cord is formed between E15.5 and E16.5, once the elongating bud breaks through the primary mammary mesenchyme and reaches the fat pad precursor, and remains connected to the epidermis; by E16.5 a lumen develops within the sprout resulting in a primary duct opening to the exterior, and the nipple forms by differentiation of the overlying epidermis in response to signals from specialized mammary mesenchyme; in male mouse embryos, the activation of androgen receptors causes the mammary buds to separate from the epithelium between E14.5 and E15.5 and subsequently degenerate

Subject: abnormal nipple sheath morphology
Value: any structural abnormality of the circular ingrowth of the epidermis around the origin of the mammary cord (mammary sprout); in female mouse embryos, the nipple sheath is the first histological evidence of nipple formation seen at E16.5; at E18, the epidermis at the bottom of this epidermal ingrowth is lifted, making a rounded elevated portion, which is the anlage of the nipple

Subject: abnormal nipple sheath formation
Value: any anomaly in the developmental process pertaining to the initial formation of the nipple sheath from the unspecified epidermis; in female mouse embryos, this process begins with a circular ingrowth of the epidermis around the origin of the mammary cord (mammary sprout) at E16.5 and ends before the underlying epidermis begins to elevate

Subject: absent nipple sheath
Value: absence or failure of formation of the circular ingrowth of the epidermis around the origin of the mammary cord (mammary sprout); in female mouse embryos, the nipple sheath is the first histological evidence of nipple formation seen at E16.5

Subject: glutathionuria
Value: elevated concentrations of the reducing agent glutathione in urine

Subject: immature cataract
Value: an early stage cataract in which the lens is partially opaque, absorbs fluid and increases by swelling; the lens is only slightly opaque and the cortex is clear

Subject: mature cataract
Value: cataract in which the both the lens nucleus and cortex are opaque and lens fibers are swollen

Subject: squamous metaplasia of bulbourethral gland
Value: a benign non-cancerous transformation of the bulbourethral glandular epithelium into stratified squamous epithelium; keratinization may be present

Subject: squamous metaplasia of preputial gland
Value: a benign non-cancerous transformation of the preputial glandular epithelium into stratified squamous epithelium; keratinization may be present

Subject: squamous metaplasia of urethral gland
Value: a benign non-cancerous transformation of the urethral glandular epithelium into stratified squamous epithelium; keratinization may be present

Subject: abnormal bulbourethral gland development
Value: aberrant formation or incomplete differentiation of either of the small paired racemose (compound tubulo-alveolar) glands below the apex of the prostate in males, located posterolateral to the membranous portion of the urethra at the base of the penis, between the two layers of the fascia of the urogenital diaphragm, in the deep perineal pouch, and enclosed by transverse fibers of the sphincter urethrae membranaceae muscle; in mouse, bulbourethral glands are first identifiable at E17.5 and epithelial branching normally starts at postnatal day P1; during development, bulbourethral glands arise as epithelial outgrowths of the endodermal urogenital sinus invading the condensed mesenchyme flanking the primitive urethra; during subsequent development the epithelium branches extensively, filling the mesenchymal capsule and giving rise to the highly arborized ductal system of the mature organ

Subject: small bulbourethral gland
Value: reduced size of either of the small paired racemose (compound tubulo-alveolar) glands below the apex of the prostate in males, located posterolateral to the membranous portion of the urethra at the base of the penis, between the two layers of the fascia of the urogenital diaphragm, in the deep perineal pouch, and enclosed by transverse fibers of the sphincter urethrae membranaceae muscle

Subject: abnormal testis tunica albuginea morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the dense fibrous connective tissue layer that covers the testis

Subject: abnormal testis tunica vaginalis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the outer coelomic epithelial covering of the testis; a sac of serous tissue covering the testis and the epididymis within which the testis can move about; it covers the tunica albuginea

Subject: Meibomian gland hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due to an increased number of cells, of the meibum-secreting modified lobulated sebaceous glands located at the rim of the eyelids inside the tarsal plate

Subject: absent thymus corticomedullary boundary
Value: complete absence or loss of the dense region demarcating the thymus medulla from the surrounding cortex that is characterized by numerous blood vessels (predominantly arterioles) with some perivascular connective tissue, mature and immature T lymphocytes, dendritic cells, variable numbers of perivascular B-lymphocytes and plasma cells; normally, this is the site of entry of bone marrow stem cells and exit of mature, functional T cells

Subject: absent ciliary body
Value: absence of the thickened portion of the vascular tunic, which lies between the choroid and the iris

Subject: ciliary body hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the thickened portion of the vascular tunic which lies between the choroid and the iris

Subject: abnormal conjunctival sac morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the space bound by the conjunctival membrane between the palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva, into which the lacrimal fluid is secreted; it is a closed space when eye is closed; when eye is open, the sac is open anteriorly through the palpebral fissure (between the eyelids)

Subject: abnormal eyelid margin morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the confluence of the mucosal surface of the conjunctiva, the edge of the orbicularis, and the cutaneous epithelium

Subject: abnormal parotid intralobular duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the tubular canals of the parotid gland located within the parenchymal (secretory) tissue i.e. within lobules; both intercalated and striated (secretory) ducts are intralobular ducts

Subject: abnormal parotid intercalated duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small intralobular tubular canal that leads directly from the serous acinus of the parotid gland to a striated (secretory) duct; in mouse, the intercalated ducts are short and narrow and are lined by low cuboidal epithelial cells with large central nuclei; they secrete bicarbonate ion into and absorb chloride ion from the acinar product

Subject: abnormal parotid striated duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the intralobular secretory duct of the parotid gland which connects an intercalated duct to an interlobular excretory duct; striated ducts are lined by cuboidal to columnar acidophilic cells and are so-named because of characteristic striations in the basal portions of the cells which are due to the alignment of mitochondria between deep infoldings of the basal cell membrane; the nucleus is in the central part of the cell above the striations; as they approach the excretory ducts, their diameter may exceed that of the acini; striated ducts reabsorb sodium and secrete potassium

Subject: abnormal parotid interlobular duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the excretory ducts of the parotid gland which are found in the connective tissue septa i.e. between lobules

Subject: abnormal parotid excretory duct morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the interlobular excretory ducts of the parotid gland which are found in the connective tissue septa and formed by the union of several intralobular striated (secretory) ducts; ultimately, the excretory ducts of the parotid gland coalesce and form a single main excretory duct (Stensen's duct) that opens into the oral cavity; excretory ducts do not change the secretory product

Subject: increased cystadenoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a histologically benign neoplasm derived from glandular epithelium, in which cystic accumulations of retained secretions are formed, occurring in a specific population in a given time period; in some instances, considerable portions of the neoplasm, or even the entire mass, may be cystic

Subject: stridor
Value: a high-pitched breath sound resulting from turbulent air flow in the larynx or lower in the bronchial tree; it should not to be confused with stertor which is a noise originating in the pharynx; stridor is a physical sign which is caused by a narrowed or obstructed airway; it can be inspiratory, expiratory or biphasic, although it is usually heard during inspiration

Subject: tracheomalacia
Value: a condition characterized by flaccidity of the tracheal support cartilage which leads to tracheal collapse especially when increased airflow is demanded; the trachea normally dilates slightly during inspiration and narrows slightly during expiration; these processes are exaggerated in tracheomalacia, leading to airway collapse on expiration; the usual symptom of tracheomalacia is expiratory stridor or laryngeal crow

Subject: abnormal ocular surface morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the integrated unit (of the eye) that consists of the conjunctiva, the corneal surface, and the ocular mucosal adnexa including the lid margins and the meibomian gland openings, the lacrimal glands and the lacrimal drainage system, all which are critical to maintain ocular surface integrity and provide protection from external antigens and pathogenic microorganisms

Subject: abnormal intestinal phytosterol absorption
Value: any anomaly in the process in which phytosterols are taken up from the contents of the intestine; commonly ingested phytosterols include beta-sitosterol, campesterol, and stigmasterol

Subject: increased intestinal phytosterol absorption
Value: increased ability to take up phytosterols from the contents of the intestine; commonly ingested phytosterols include beta-sitosterol, campesterol, and stigmasterol

Subject: decreased intestinal phytosterol absorption
Value: reduced ability to take up phytosterols from the contents of the intestine; commonly ingested phytosterols include beta-sitosterol, campesterol, and stigmasterol

Subject: increased intestinal glucose absorption
Value: increased ability of the small intestine to absorb glucose into the bloodstream

Subject: decreased intestinal glucose absorption
Value: reduced ability of the small intestine to absorb glucose into the bloodstream

Subject: abnormal T-helper cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of an effector T cell that provides help in the form of secreted cytokines to other immune cells

Subject: abnormal T-helper cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of an effector T cell that provides help in the form of secreted cytokines to other immune cells

Subject: increased T-helper cell number
Value: increase in the number of an effector T cell that provides help in the form of secreted cytokines to other immune cells

Subject: decreased T-helper cell number
Value: reduction in the number of an effector T cell that provides help in the form of secreted cytokines to other immune cells

Subject: iris hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size of the iris, usually due to an increased number of cells

Subject: absent palatal rugae
Value: absence of the transverse folds (ridges) of the mucosa located on the anterior third part of the secondary (hard) palate of most mammalian species

Subject: decreased palatal rugae number
Value: reduced number of transverse folds (ridges) of the mucosa located on the anterior third part of the secondary (hard) palate of most mammalian species

Subject: decreased marginal zone precursor B cell number
Value: reduction in the number of CD23-positive, CD21-positive B cells in the marginal zone of lymphoid tissues

Subject: increased marginal zone precursor B cell number
Value: increase in the number of CD23-positive, CD21-positive B cells in the marginal zone of lymphoid tissues

Subject: abnormal effector memory T-helper cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of CD4-positive alpha-beta T-helper cells with a CD44-positive, CD62L-negative memory phenotype

Subject: decreased effector memory T-helper cell number
Value: reduction in the number of CD4-positive alpha-beta T-helper cells with a CD44-positive, CD62L-negative memory phenotype

Subject: increased effector memory T-helper cell number
Value: increase in the number of CD4-positive alpha-beta T-helper cells with a CD44-positive, CD62L-negative memory phenotype

Subject: abnormal KLRG1-positive T-helper cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of CD4-positive alpha-beta T-helper cells expressing KLRG1, a marker associated with activation

Subject: decreased KLRG1-positive T-helper cell number
Value: reduction in the number of CD4-positive alpha-beta T-helper cells expressing KLRG1, a marker associated with activation

Subject: increased KLRG1-positive T-helper cell number
Value: increase in the number of CD4-positive alpha-beta T-helper cells expressing KLRG1, a marker associated with activation

Subject: bone marrow failure
Value: inherited or acquired dysfunction of hematopoietic stem cells that can result in abnormalities in one or more of the stem cell lineages (erythroid, myeloid, megakaryocytic)

Subject: spontaneous remission from bone marrow failure
Value: a lessening of symptoms or intensity of disease due to bone marrow failure that occurs without treatment and may be temporary or permanent

Subject: abnormal mammary gland myoepithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the outer cell layer of the mammary gland epithelium bilayer which is located basal to the luminal (secretory) cells and adjacent to the basement membrane; basal cells (aka myoepithelial cells) are specialized epithelial cells that express smooth muscle-specific contractile and cytoskeletal properties; in lactating females, milk is produced by luminal cells, secreted into the alveolar lumen and collected in the ducts for expulsion out of the body through the nipple, due to the contractile activity of the basal myoepithelial cells

Subject: abnormal mammary gland myoepithelium physiology
Value: <any functional anomaly of the outer cell layer of the mammary gland epithelium bilayer which is located basal to the luminal (secretory) cells and adjacent to the basement membrane; basal cells (aka myoepithelial cells or MECs) are specialized epithelial cells that express smooth muscle-specific contractile and cytoskeletal properties; during lactation, MECs contract in response to oxytocin to generate the contractile force required for milk ejection; MECs are involved in all developmental stages of mammary gland morphogenesis, modulating proliferation and differentiation of luminal cells; they take part in the formation of extracellular matrix, synthesizing its components and secreting proteinases and their inhibitors; in addition, MECs are regarded as natural cancer suppressors: they secrete suppressor proteins limiting cancer growth, invasiveness, and neoangiogenesis; MECs are markedly resistant to malignant transformation and they are able to suppress the transformation of neighboring luminal cells>

Subject: decreased mammary myoepithelial cell contraction
Value: reduced ability of the mammary myoepithelial cells to contract in response to oxytocin and generate the contractile force required for successful milk ejection and lactation

Subject: abnormal mammary gland luminal epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the inner cell layer of the mammary epithelium bilayer that lines the luminal surface of mammary gland ducts and alveoli; luminal cells have only limited contact with the underlying basement membrane and surrounding connective tissue; they are secretory epithelial cells characterized by the expression of the receptors for systemic hormones, i.e. estrogens, progesterone and prolactin

Subject: abnormal mammary duct terminal end bud morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the unique club-shaped epithelial structure that develops at the tip of the mammary duct at the onset of puberty (approximately 3 weeks of age in mouse) under the action of circulating hormones; terminal end buds (TEBs) consist of an outer layer of undifferentiated myoepithelial progenitor cells (cap cells), and a multilayered inner core of luminal epithelial cells (body) fated to form the walls of the ductal lumen; both layers have high rates of mitosis, consistent with a motile organ dedicated to ductal morphogenesis; TEBs proliferate, ramify, and actively invade the fad pad to allow the formation of a complex branching structure; this process of branching morphogenesis concludes at about 10-12 weeks of age in mouse, when TEBs have traversed the length of the fat pad and a fully developed ductal tree has formed

Subject: absent mammary duct terminal end bud
Value: failure to develop or maintain the unique club-shaped epithelial structure normally formed at the tip of the mammary duct at the onset of puberty (approximately 3 weeks of age in mouse) under the action of circulating hormones; normally, TEBs proliferate, ramify, and actively invade the fad pad to allow the formation of a complex branching structure; this process of branching morphogenesis concludes at about 10-12 weeks of age in mouse, when TEBs have traversed the length of the fat pad and a fully developed ductal tree has formed; absence of TEBs is often associated with reduced ductal outgrowth and impaired branching morphogenesis

Subject: abnormal mammary gland bud elongation
Value: any anomaly in the process in which a mammary bud grows along its axis; in mouse embryos, the distal end of the mammary bud begins to elongate into the underlying dermal mesenchyme to form a mammary cord (sprout) by E15.5

Subject: abnormal mammary gland bud morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the morphologically distinct bulb of epithelial cells formed once each mammary placode expands and invaginates into the underlying mesenchyme; in mouse embryos at E12.5, each epithelial bud with its contiguous mesenchyme is elevated above the surrounding ectoderm as a knob or dome; at E13.5, the buds sink into the underlying dermal mesenchyme, and by E14.5 they can no longer be detected externally; in female mouse embryos, five pairs of anlagen or buds are formed along the mammary line between E12.5 and E14.5 by proliferation of basal epidermal cells; while further mammary development is temporarily arrested in females, androgen receptor activation in male embryos causes degeneration of the buds between E13.5 and E15.5; in female mice, further development is resumed at around E15.5 when each bud elongates to form a mammary cord (sprout), invading the underlying fat pad precursor

Subject: abnormal mammary gland bud formation
Value: any anomaly in the morphogenetic process in which a distinct bulb of epithelial cells forms from a mammary placode

Subject: photophobia
Value: abnormal aversion or avoidance behavior in response to light; photophobia is symptom of abnormal intolerance to visual perception of light; as a medical symptom, photophobia is not a morbid fear or phobia, but an experience of discomfort or pain to the eyes due to light exposure or by presence of actual physical sensitivity of the eyes

Subject: external nares atresia
Value: congenital blockage, fusion, or absence of the normal anterior openings to the nasal cavity; the naris may be closed by membrane, cartilage or, rarely, bone

Subject: small external nares
Value: decreased size of the anterior openings to the nasal cavity

Subject: single external naris
Value: presence of only one anterior opening to the nasal cavity as opposed to the normal two; usually associated with midline facial defects arising from cleavage anomalies

Subject: absent external nares
Value: absence or failure to form both of the anterior openings to the nasal cavity

Subject: abnormal small intestine goblet cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the glandular simple columnar epithelial cell found in the mucosal lining of the small intestine, whose primary function is to secrete gel-forming mucins, the major components of mucus

Subject: abnormal large intestine goblet cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the glandular simple columnar epithelial cell found in the mucosal lining of the large intestine, whose primary function is to secrete gel-forming mucins, the major components of mucus

Subject: abnormal intestinal villus goblet cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the glandular simple columnar epithelial cell found in the mucosal lining of the villi of the small intestine, whose primary function is to secrete gel-forming mucins, the major components of mucus

Subject: abnormal colon goblet cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the glandular simple columnar epithelial cell found in the mucosal lining of the colon, whose primary function is to secrete gel-forming mucins, the major components of mucus

Subject: abnormal duodenal goblet cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the glandular simple columnar epithelial cell found in the mucosal lining of the duodenum of the small intestine, whose primary function is to secrete gel-forming mucins, the major components of mucus

Subject: abnormal ileal goblet cell morphology
