Value: any structural anomaly of the glandular simple columnar epithelial cell found in the mucosal lining of the ileum of the small intestine, whose primary function is to secrete gel-forming mucins, the major components of mucus

Subject: abnormal jeujunal goblet cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the glandular simple columnar epithelial cell found in the mucosal lining of the jejunum of the small intestine, whose primary function is to secrete gel-forming mucins, the major components of mucus

Subject: abnormal intestinal goblet cell physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the glandular simple columnar epithelial cell found in the mucosal lining of the small and large intestine, whose primary function is to secrete gel-forming mucins, the major components of mucus; intestinal goblet cells produce a number of effector molecules including a range of mucins and antimicrobial proteins, such as trefoil factors and resistin-like molecules, which enable these to play a key part in innate defense mechanisms in the gut, against both bacterial and parasitic infections

Subject: abnormal pericardial fat pad morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the encapsulated adipose tissue surrounding the cardiac tissue

Subject: abnormal subscapular fat pad morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the encapsulated adipose tissue located beneath the scapulae

Subject: abnormal IgG2 level
Value: deviation from the normal levels of the total immunoglobulin class G2 level

Subject: increased IgG2 level
Value: greater than normal immunoglobulin class G2 level

Subject: decreased IgG2 level
Value: less than normal immunoglobulin class G2 level

Subject: myeloid metaplasia
Value: a progressive disease of the bone marrow where neoplastic bone marrow stem cells lodge and grow at sites outside the bone marrow, and the marrow is replaced by fibrous (scar) tissue; may lead to anemia, enlarged spleen, the presence of nucleated red blood cells and immature granulocytes in the blood, and the occurrence of extramedullary hematopoiesis in the spleen and liver

Subject: encephalopathy
Value: any diffuse disorder of the brain that alters brain function or structure

Subject: generalized edema
Value: generalized abnormal accumulation of fluid beneath the skin, or in one or more cavities of the body

Subject: abnormal tunnel of Corti morphology
Value: any structrual anomaly of the triangular, fluid-filled space normally found between the inner and outer rows of supporting pillar cells in the organ of Corti

Subject: absent pectinate muscle
Value: absence of the prominent ridges of atrial myocardium located on the inner surface of most of the right atrium and both the right and left auricular regions

Subject: absent brachiocephalic trunk
Value: absence of the short first aortic arch branch which divides into the right subclavian artery and the right common carotid artery

Subject: abnormal orbital vein morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the highly complex and variable set of veins that drain blood from the eye and supporting tissue, including the superior and inferior ophthalmic veins, the middle and medial ophthalmic veins, four collateral veins), variable orbital venous networks, and variable venous tributaries

Subject: enlarged orbital veins
Value: increased size of the highly complex and variable set of veins that drain blood from the eye and supporting tissue, including the superior and inferior ophthalmic veins, the middle and medial ophthalmic veins, four collateral veins), variable orbital venous networks, and variable venous tributaries

Subject: dilated hepatic portal vein
Value: an expansion in the lumen volume of the wide short vein formed from the confluence of the superior mesenteric, inferior mesenteric and splenic veins, which then divides into the right and left branches which ramify with the liver

Subject: abnormal hepatic portal vein connection
Value: any anomaly of the connection site of the right or left branch of the hepatic portal vein to the liver

Subject: abnormal digastric muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small suprahyoid muscle located below the body of the mandible, and extending, in a curved form, from the mastoid notch to the symphysis menti; it consists of two muscular bellies, an anterior and a posterior belly, united by an intermediate rounded tendon attaching to the hyoid bone through a fibrous loop; the two bellies have different embryological origins and are supplied by different cranial nerves

Subject: absent digastric muscle
Value: absence of the small suprahyoid muscle located below the body of the mandible, and extending, in a curved form, from the mastoid notch to the symphysis menti; it consists of an anterior and a posterior belly, united by an intermediate rounded tendon attaching to the hyoid bone through a fibrous loop

Subject: absent nasal cavity
Value: absence of the cavity of the respiratory tract that extends from the nares to the pharynx; the nasal cavity is lined with ciliated mucosa

Subject: abnormal oral cavity morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anatomical cavity at the start of the digestive tract that is enclosed by the mouth

Subject: abnormal acromioclavicular joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any joint connecting the acromonion of the scapula and clavicle

Subject: absent optic cup
Value: absence of the double walled structure formed by expansion and invagination of the distal end of the optic vesicle that develops into the pigmented and neuronal layers of the retina, with the mouth of the optic cup developing into the pupil of the eye

Subject: abnormal cerebral artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of three main pairs of arteries and their branches, which irrigate the cerebrum of the brain

Subject: abnormal anterior cerebral artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a pair of arteries on the brain that supply oxygen to most medial portions of frontal lobes and superior medial parietal lobes; the anterior cerebral arteries arise from the internal carotid artery and are part of the Circle of Willis

Subject: absent segment of anterior cerebral artery
Value: absence of a portion of a pair of arteries on the brain that supply oxygen to most medial portions of frontal lobes and superior medial parietal lobes

Subject: abnormal hypoglossal canal morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bony canal in the occipital bone through which the hypoglossal nerve emerges from the skull

Subject: small hypoglossal canal
Value: reduced size of the bony canal in the occipital bone through which the hypoglossal nerve emerges from the skull

Subject: absent hypoglossal canal
Value: absence of the bony canal in the occipital bone through which the hypoglossal nerve emerges from the skull

Subject: thin oculomotor nerve
Value: slender appearance of the third cranial nerve, which normally sends motor fibers to the levator muscles of the eyelid and to the superior rectus, inferior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles of the eye

Subject: thin facial nerve
Value: a slender apperance of the sensory and motor nerve that supplies the muscles of facial expression and the expression and taste at the anterior two-thirds of the tongue

Subject: thin splanchnic nerve
Value: slender appearance of the major nerves supplying sympathetic innervation to the abdomen, including the greater, lesser, and lowest (or smallest) splanchnic nerves that are formed by preganglionic fibers from the spinal cord, which pass through the paravertebral ganglia and then to the celiac ganglia and plexuses, and the lumbar splanchnic nerves carry fibers which pass through the lumbar paravertebral ganglia to the mesenteric and hypogastric ganglia

Subject: abnormal intrathoracic topology of vagus nerve
Value: abnormal position of the vagus nerve in the intrathoracic region

Subject: vagus nerve compression
Value: a flattened or pressed appearance of the vagus nerve as if by applied pressure

Subject: thin vagus nerve
Value: slender appearance of the autonomic, sensory and motor axons of the tenth cranial nerve

Subject: absent olfactory nerve
Value: absence of the first cranial nerve, which conveys the sense of smell

Subject: thin hypoglossal nerve
Value: slender appearance of the motor nerve which innervates all the intrinsic and all but one of the extrinsic muscles of the tongue

Subject: absent hypoglossal nerve
Value: absence of the motor nerve which innervates all the intrinsic and all but one of the extrinsic muscles of the tongue

Subject: abnormal hypoglossal nerve topology
Value: abnormal position of the hypoglossal nerve

Subject: abnormal vagus nerve topology
Value: abnormal position of the vagus nerve

Subject: small caudate nucleus
Value: decreased size of one or both C-shaped structures that border the lateral ventricle and contain input neurons involved with control of voluntary movement in the brain

Subject: abnormal posterior cerebral artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of one of a pair of blood vessels that supplies oxygenated blood to the posterior aspect of the brain; it arises near the intersection of the posterior communicating artery and the basilar artery and connects with the ipsilateral middle cerebral artery (MCA) and internal carotid artery via the posterior communicating artery

Subject: absent segment of posterior cerebral artery
Value: absence of a portion of one of a pair of blood vessels that supplies oxygenated blood to the posterior aspect of the brain

Subject: abnormal lymphatic vessel topology
Value: abnormal position of any component of the network of vessels that carries lymph around the body

Subject: ductus venosus stenosis
Value: narrowing of the lumen of the embryonic connection between the portal vein and inferior vena cava formed by the left umbilical vein that allows oxygenated blood to bypass the developing liver during the time when this connection is normally open; this normally closes during develpment to adulthood

Subject: hepatic portal vein stenosis
Value: narrowing of the lumen of the wide short vein formed from the confluence of the superior mesenteric, inferior mesenteric and splenic veins, which then divides into the right and left branches which ramify with the liver; the hepatic portal vein carries venous blood from the GI tract, spleen and pancreas to the liver

Subject: abnormal perichondrial ossification
Value: formation of bone in the perichondrium, which is normally cartilaginous

Subject: abnormal eye muscle topology
Value: abnormal position of eye muscles

Subject: retropharyngeal edema
Value: accumulation of watery or serous fluid in the retropharyngeal space

Subject: retropleural edema
Value: accumulation of watery or serous fluid in the retropleural space

Subject: subcutaneous edema
Value: accumulation of watery or serous fluid in the subcutaneous region below the skin

Subject: absent abducens nerve
Value: absence of the sixth cranial nerve, which originates in the abducens nucleus of the pons and sends motor fibers to the lateral rectus muscles of the eye

Subject: absent posterior commissure
Value: absence of the band of nerve fiber tracts that span the longitudinal fissure beneath the habenula of the pineal body and over the cerebral aqueduct, interconnecting the left and right pretectal regions and some midbrain nuclei

Subject: abnormal Wolffian duct topology
Value: aberrant postition of the transient embryonic drainage tubes of the embryonic kidney (mesonephric tubules) that empty into the cloaca and later develop into the ductus deferens in the male

Subject: abnormal Mullerian duct topology
Value: aberrant position of the transient embryonic drainage tubes of the embryonic kidney (mesonephric tubules) that empty into the cloaca and in the female develop into the oviducts, uterus, and vagina

Subject: abnormal hepatic portal vein formation
Value: aberrant formation of the wide short vein formed from the confluence of the superior mesenteric, inferior mesenteric and splenic veins, and then divides into the right and left branches which ramify with the liver

Subject: abnormal celiac artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the short, thick trunk which arises from the front of the abdominal aorta immediately below the aortic opening in the diaphragm; it lies below the liver and on the upper border of the pancreas and branches into the left gastric, hepatic, and splenic arteries

Subject: absent celiac artery
Value: absence of the short, thick trunk which arises from the front of the abdominal aorta immediately below the aortic opening in the diaphragm

Subject: celiac artery compression
Value: increased pressure exerted on the celiac artery by the median arcuate ligament of the diaphragm

Subject: abnormal abdominal muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a muscle that is part of the abdomen

Subject: abnormal azygos vein topology
Value: abnormal position(s) of the unpaired vein which in humans arises from the right ascending lumbar vein or the vena cava, enters the thorax through the aortic orifice in the diaphragm, and terminates in the superior vena cava; unlike humans, mice have a single and left-sided azygos vein that develops from the paired embryonic cardinal venous system and drains most of the right and left thoracic walls into the left anterior vena cava

Subject: abnormal vitelline vein connection
Value: aberrant or missing attachment of the paired veins that carry blood from the yolk sac back to the embryo

Subject: abnormal pancreas topology
Value: abnormal postion of the organ that secretes pancreatic juice into the duodenum and secretes glucagon and insulin into the bloodstream

Subject: abnormal cecum position
Value: abnormal placement of the large sac normally located at the ileum and large intestine junction

Subject: abnormal paraumbilical vein morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of one or more of small superficial veins that run from the umbilicus along the round ligament of the liver and terminate as accessory portal veins in the liver; these are susceptible to varicosity during portal hypertension

Subject: enlarged paraumbilical vein
Value: increased size of one or more of small superficial veins that run from the umbilicus along the round ligament of the liver and terminate as accessory portal veins in the liver

Subject: abnormal dorsal pancreas topology
Value: aberrant location or orientation of the transient embryonic structure that fuses with the ventral pancreas during development to form a single organ

Subject: abnormal dorsal pancreas morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the transient embryonic structure that fuses with the ventral pancreas during development to form a single organ; the dorsal pancreatic bud gives rise to the body, tail, and isthmus of the pancreas

Subject: abnormal ventral pancreas morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the transient embryonic structure that fuses with the dorsal pancreas during development to form a single organ; the ventral pancreatic bud gives rise to the pancreatic head and uncinate process

Subject: abnormal ventral pancreas topology
Value: abnormal location or orientation of the transient embryonic structure that fuses with the dorsal pancreas during development to form a single organ

Subject: vascular diverticulum
Value: a pouch or sac opening from the lumen of a vessel

Subject: abnormal stapedial artery topology
Value: abnormal location or orientation of the small artery that passes through the ring of the stapes; while the stapedial artery is a temporary artery thought to disappear at late embryonic stage in humans, the mouse stapedial artery is complete by E13 and persists into adulthood

Subject: abnormal jugular vein morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the set of veins that drain deoxygenated blood from the head

Subject: abnormal ductus venosus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the embryonic connection between the portal vein and inferior vena cava formed by the left umbilical vein that allows oxygenated blood to bypass the developing liver during the time when this connection is normally open; this normally closes during develpment to adulthood

Subject: abnormal ductus venosus topology
Value: aberrant position or orientation of the embryonic connection between the portal vein and inferior vena cava formed by the left umbilical vein that allows oxygenated blood to bypass the developing liver during the time when this connection is normally open; this normally closes during develpment to adulthood

Subject: absent ductus venosus valve
Value: absence of the valve present on the right side of the ductus venosus at the site of the junction with the inferior vena cava

Subject: abnormal ductus venosus valve morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the valve present on the right side of the ductus venosus at the site of the junction with the inferior vena cava

Subject: abnormal ductus venosus valve topology
Value: abnormal position of the valve present on the right side of the ductus venosus at the site of the junction with the inferior vena cava

Subject: duplication of ductus venosus
Value: duplication of the embryonic connection between the portal vein and inferior vena cava formed by the left umbilical vein that allows oxygenated blood to bypass the developing liver during the time when this connection is normally open; this normally closes during develpment to adulthood

Subject: absent ductus venosus
Value: absence of the embryonic connection between the portal vein and inferior vena cava formed by the left umbilical vein that allows oxygenated blood to bypass the developing liver during the time when this connection is normally open; this normally closes during development to adulthood

Subject: abnormal CD4-positive, CD25-positive NK T cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of CD4-positive NK T cells expressing the activation marker CD25

Subject: decreased CD4-positive, CD25-positive NK T cell number
Value: reduction in the number of CD4-positive NK T cells expressing the activation marker CD25

Subject: increased CD4-positive, CD25-positive NK T cell number
Value: increase in the number of CD4-positive NK T cells expressing the activation marker CD25

Subject: abnormal CD4-negative, CD25-positive NK T cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of CD4-negative NK T cells expressing the activation marker CD25

Subject: decreased CD4-negative, CD25-positive NK T cell number
Value: reduction in the number of CD4-negative NK T cells expressing the activation marker CD25

Subject: increased CD4-negative, CD25-positive NK T cell number
Value: increase in the number of CD4-negative NK T cells expressing the activation marker CD25

Subject: abnormal T cell compartment
Value: anomaly in the distribution of subsets or occurrence of new subsets within the T cell compartment

Subject: abnormal CD8-positive, CD25-positive alpha-beta T cell number
Value: anomaly in the number of CD8-positive alpha-beta T cells expressing the activation marker CD25

Subject: decreased CD8-positive, CD25-positive alpha-beta T cell number
Value: reduction in the number of CD8-positive alpha-beta T cells expressing the activation marker CD25

Subject: increased CD8-positive, CD25-positive alpha-beta T cell number
Value: increase in the number of CD8-positive alpha-beta T cells expressing the activation marker CD25

Subject: increased common myeloid progenitor cell number
Value: increased number of progenitor cells committed to myeloid lineage, including the megakaryocyte and erythroid lineages

Subject: increased common lymphocyte progenitor cell number
Value: increased number of a progenitor cell committed to the lymphoid lineage

Subject: decreased common lymphocyte progenitor cell number
Value: reduced number of a progenitor cell committed to the lymphoid lineage

Subject: abnormal behavioral response to amphetamine
Value: anomaly in the behavioral response induced by amphetamine such as induced hyperactivity or stereotypic behavior

Subject: abnormal eyelid cilium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the hairs that grow at the edge of the upper or lower eyelid; eyelashes protect the eye from debris and are sensitive to touch, thus providing a warning that an object is near the eye (which is then closed reflexively)

Subject: abnormal eyelid cilium number
Value: anomaly in the number of the hairs that grow at the edge of the upper or lower eyelid

Subject: decreased eyelid cilium number
Value: reduction in the number of the hairs that grow at the edge of the upper or lower eyelid

Subject: short eyelid cilia
Value: decreased length of any of the hairs that grow at the edge of the upper or lower eyelid

Subject: abnormal seminal vesicle epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the pseudostratified columnar epithelium that lines the seminal vesicles and consists of tall, non-ciliated columnar cells and short, rounded basal cells that rest on the basal lamina; polarized columnar cells show features typical of secretory epithelium, including a well-developed Golgi complex, abundant rough endoplasmic reticulum, numerous mitochondria, and apical secretory vesicles; basal cells are the stem cells from which the columnar cells are derived

Subject: absent female preputial gland
Value: absence of the paired, lobulated, modified sebaceous glands located on the side of the clitoris in female rodents; in contrast to the preputial glands in male rodents, clitoral glands are a minor source of olfactory stimuli contributing to sexual attractivity; unlike other sebaceous glands, they undergo progressive atrophy of the glandular portion with marked ductal ectasia as rodents age; there is no true anatomical equivalent in humans

Subject: abnormal seminal vesicle physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the sac-like glandular structures situated posterolateral to the urinary bladder in the male and functioning as part of the reproductive system; seminal vesicles secrete a whitish yellow alkaline fluid that constitutes 60-70 percent of the ejaculate in humans; seminal vesicle fluid secretion is androgen-dependent, fructose-rich, and important for semen coagulation, sperm motility, and stability of sperm chromatin and suppression of the immune activity in the female reproductive tract

Subject: abnormal seminal vesicle fluid composition
Value: any alteration in the expected chemical makeup or appearance of the whitish yellow alkaline fluid secreted by the seminal vesicles that constitutes 60-70 percent of the ejaculate in humans; the secretory product of the columnar epithelial cell, which may be seen in the lumen of seminal vesicles, is strongly acidophilic; it contains large amounts of fructose (used by spermatozoa as an energy source for motility) in addition to water, K+ ions, phosphorylcholine, prostaglandins, flavins, citrate, ascorbic acid, and several amino acids and enzymes; seminal vesicle fluid is responsible for coagulation of the ejaculate, can alter sperm motility and capacitation, and acts as an immunosuppressant in the female reproductive tract

Subject: abnormal seminal vesicle muscle layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thick muscular layer of the seminal vesicle consisting of an inner circular and outer longitudinal layer of smooth muscle which contracts during the emission phase of ejaculation to expel seminal vesicle fluid into the prostatic urethra

Subject: preputial gland inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in any of the paired, lobulated, modified sebaceous glands located in the inguinal region adjacent to the penis and vagina, with pheromonal functions in male rodents; in males, the preputial gland empties into the preputial cavity and in females, the preputial (aka clitoral) gland duct empties into the clitoral fossa

Subject: absent embryonic telencephalon
Value: absence of the paired diverticula of the embryonic telencephalon, from which the forebrain develops

Subject: abnormal cerebrospinal fluid flow
Value: any anomaly in the dynamic process by which CSF circulates from the sites of secretion to the sites of absorption according to a unidirectional rostrocaudal flow in ventricular cavities and a multidirectional flow in subarachnoid spaces; CSF produced by the choroid plexuses in the lateral ventricles travels through interventricular foramina to the third ventricle, and then the fourth ventricle via the cerebral aqueduct and finally to the subarachnoid spaces via the median aperture (foramen of Magendie) of the fourth ventricle; in the cranial subarachnoid space, CSF circulates rostrally to the villous sites of absorption or caudally to the spinal subarachnoid space; CSF circulation through the ventricular system is driven by motile cilia on ependymal cells of the brain; CSF flow is pulsatile, corresponding to the systolic pulse wave in choroidal arteries; additional factors such as respiratory waves, the subject's posture, jugular venous pressure and physical effort also modulate CSF flow dynamics and pressure

Subject: small lateral ventricles
Value: decreased size of the cavity in each of the cerebral hemispheres derived from the cavity of the embryonic neural tube; they are separated from each other by the septum pellucidum, and each communicates with the third ventricle by the foramen of Monro, through which also the choroid plexuses of the lateral ventricles become continuous with that of the third ventricle

Subject: small third ventricle
Value: decreased size of the narrow cleft inferior to the corpus callosum, within the diencephalon, between the paired thalami; its floor is formed by the hypothalamus, its anterior wall by the lamina terminalis, and its roof by ependyma; it communicates with the fourth ventricle by the cerebral aqueduct, and with the lateral ventricles by the interventricular foramina

Subject: small fourth ventricle
Value: decreased size of the irregularly shaped cavity in the rhombencephalon, between the medulla oblongata, the pons, and the isthmus in front, and the cerebellum behind; it is continuous with the central canal of the cord below and with the cerebral aqueduct above, and through its lateral and median apertures it communicates with the subarachnoid space

Subject: fused vestibular saccule and utricle
Value: union of the saccule and utricle of the inner ear vestibule into one structure

Subject: obsolete abnormal circardian rhythm entrainment
Value: anomaly in the synchronization of a circadian rhythm to environmental time cues such as light

Subject: absent costovertebral joint
Value: one or more ribs are not connected to vertebra, where this connection is normally made

Subject: absent intracranial segment of vertebral artery
Value: absence of a segment of a vertebral artery when the absent segment would normally be located inside the skull

Subject: abnormal brachial plexus formation
Value: abnormal formation of the arrangement of nerve fibers, running from the spine, formed by the ventral rami of the lower cervical and upper thoracic nerve root, specifically from below the fifth cervical vertebra to above the first thoracic vertebra

Subject: decreased intestine length
Value: reduced length of the digestive tube passing from the stomach to the anus, consisting of the small and large intestine divisions

Subject: abnormal endolymphatic sac topology
Value: abnormal position of the dilated blind extremity of the endolymphatic duct, which lies external to the dura on the posterior aspect of the petrous part of the temporal bone

Subject: abnormal response to electrical stimuli
Value: ny deviation from the expected reflex action normally induced by an electrical stimulus

Subject: hyperresponsive to electrical stimuli
Value: lower threshold to exhibit an expected reflex action normally induced by an electrical stimulus

Subject: hyporesponsive to electrical stimuli
Value: higher threshold to exhibit an expected reflex action normally induced by an electrical stimulus

Subject: unresponsive to electrical stimuli
Value: inability to exhibit an expected reflex action normally induced by an electrical stimulus

Subject: small prevertebral sympathetic ganglia
Value: decreased size of the sympathetic ganglia located in front of the vertebral column and are associated with the major branches of the abdominal aorta; these include the celiac, aorticorenal, superior and inferior mesenteric ganglia

Subject: abnormal dural venous sinus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the endothelium-lined venous channels in the dura mater

Subject: absent neurohypophysis
Value: absence of the posterior lobe of the pituitary gland

Subject: abnormal facial nerve topology
Value: abnormal position of the sensory and motor nerve that supplies the muscles of facial expression and the expression and taste at the anterior two-thirds of the tongue

Subject: thin motoric part of trigeminal nerve
Value: slender appearance of the portion of the trigeminal nerve containing motor fibers, motor fibers are only found in the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve and derive from the basal plate of the embryonic pons

Subject: fragmented Meckel's cartilage
Value: the Meckel's carilage is broken into separate pieces

Subject: short Meckel's cartilage
Value: length reduction or truncation of the cartilage bar in the mandibular arch that forms a temporary supporting structure in the embryonic mandible and gives rise to middle ear bones and sphenomandibular and anterior malleolar ligaments

Subject: abnormal thymus topology
Value: abnormal position of the primary lymphoid organ that is required for maturation of T cells and secretion of thymosins, hormones that stimulate the development of antibodies

Subject: abnormal esophagus topology
Value: abnormal position of the part of the digestive canal through which food passes from the pharynx to the stomach

Subject: abnormal plasmablast morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of an activated mature (naive or memory) B cell that is secreting immunoglobulin, typified by being CD27-positive, CD38-positive, CD138-negative

Subject: abnormal plasmablast number
Value: anomaly in the number of an activated mature (naive or memory) B cell that is secreting immunoglobulin, typified by being CD27-positive, CD38-positive, CD138-negative

Subject: abnormal enthesis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the connective tissue between tendon and bone insertion sites; the area which acts to transmit tensile load from soft tissues to bone; they may be of the dense fibrous connective tissue or fibrocartilage type; fibrous entheses attach directly to bone or periosteum primarily via fibrous tissue, and fibrocartilaginous entheses attach to bone through a transitional layer of fibrocartilage from the fibrous tendon tissue

Subject: enthesitis
Value: inflammation of the entheses, the sites where tendons or ligaments insert into the bone; the entheses are any point of attachment of skeletal muscles to the bone, where recurring stress or inflammatory autoimmune disease can cause inflammation or occasionally fibrosis and calcification

Subject: abnormal ureter topology
Value: abnormal position of the tube that conducts the urine from the renal pelvis to the bladder

Subject: abnormal elbow joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the joint that connects the forelimb zeugopod and stylopod skeletons

Subject: abnormal paraaortic body morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the chromaffin paraganglion located at the bifurcation of the aorta or at the origin of the inferior mesenteric artery

Subject: abnormal dorsal root ganglion topology
Value: abnormal position of the dorsal root ganglion in relation to other structures

Subject: abnormal descending aorta topology
Value: abnormal position of the descending aorta in relation to other structures

Subject: left sided brachiocephalic trunk
Value: the brachiocephalic trunk arises on the left side of the body, often seen in conjunction with right aortic arch

Subject: increased intestine length
Value: increased length of the digestive tube passing from the stomach to the anus, consisting of the small and large intestine divisions

Subject: increased colon length
Value: increased length of the portion of the large intestine between the cecum and the rectum

Subject: decreased colon length
Value: reduced length of the portion of the large intestine between the cecum and the rectum

Subject: increased small intestine length
Value: increased length of the portion of the digestive tube between the stomach and the cecum, consisting of the duodenum, ileum and jejunum

Subject: decreased small intestine length
Value: reduced length of the portion of the digestive tube between the stomach and the cecum, consisting of the duodenum, ileum and jejunum

Subject: increased large intestine length
Value: increased length of the portion of the digestive tube extending from the ileocecal valve to the anus, consisting of the cecum, colon, rectum and anal canal

Subject: decreased large intestine length
Value: reduced length of the portion of the digestive tube extending from the ileocecal valve to the anus, consisting of the cecum, colon, rectum and anal canal

Subject: abnormal Hensen stripe morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the dark, nonstriated, V-shaped band (ridge) found on the underside of the tectorial membrane (TM) in the basal region of the cochlea, from which fine gelatinous trabeculae extend to fix the TM to the border cells, i.e. cells directly adjacent to the inner phalangeal cells; Hensen's stripe is continuous with a more external homogeneous basal layer, from which a marginal band of an amorphous substance originates; the marginal net extends from the marginal band and attaches the lateral border of the TM to Hensen's cells of the organ of Corti. Hensen's stripe and the homogeneous basal layers display interruptions through which the fibrillar structure of the TM is visible

Subject: absent Hensen stripe
Value: absence of the dark, nonstriated, V-shaped band (ridge) that is normally found on the underside of the tectorial membrane (TM) in the basal region of the cochlea, from which fine gelatinous trabeculae extend to fix the TM to the border cells, i.e. cells directly adjacent to the inner phalangeal cells

Subject: absent tongue muscles
Value: absence of any or all of the extrinsinc or intrinsic muscles of the tongue

Subject: abnormal infrahyoid muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the four paired muscles located in the anterior neck below the hyoid bone, within the muscular triangle; these muscles are long and flat in shape, similar to a belt or strap, and are responsible for depressing the hyoid during swallowing; they either originate from or insert on to the hyoid bone and include the sternohyoid, sternothyroid, thyrohyoid and omohyoid muscles

Subject: inverse situs of great intrathoracic arteries
Value: anomaly in the asymmetry of the large arteries of the thoracic region (aorta, pulmonary arteries, common carotid arteries, subclavian arteries) such that these structures on both the left and right side have the morphology normally seen on the opposite side of the body

Subject: abnormal superior mesenteric vein morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the blood vessel that drains blood from the small intestine, it combines with the splenic vein to form the hepatic portal vein

Subject: abnormal umbilical vein topology
Value: abnormal position of the umbilical vein in relationship to other umbilical cord structures

Subject: abnormal vitelline vein topology
Value: abnormal position of the paired veins that carry blood from the yolk sac back to the embryo

Subject: absent intrahepatic inferior vena cava segment
Value: absence of the portion of the of inferior vena cava that connects to the hepatic veins

Subject: abnormal common iliac artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the two large arteries that originate from the aortic bifurcation of the abdomainal aorta; the right and left common iliac arteries run along each side of the body towards the edges of the pelvis, where they each split again into internal and external iliac arteries at the pelvic inlet

Subject: anastomosis between basilar artery and common carotid artery
Value: any anomalous cross-connection between the basilar artery and the common carotid artery

Subject: abnormal parasellar internal carotid artery branch morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the branches of the segment of the internal carotid artery located in region in the brain next to the hollow in the skull bone that contains the pituitary gland running from the superomedial petrous apex to the proximal dural ring

Subject: abnormal internal carotid artery topology
Value: abnormal position of the terminal branch of the left or right common carotid artery which supplies oxygenated blood to the brain and eyes

Subject: absent canalicular internal carotid artery segment
Value: absence of the segment of the internal carotid artery that passes through the carotid canal

Subject: absent parasellar internal carotid artery
Value: absence of the segment of the internal carotid artery located in region in the brain next to the hollow in the skull bone that contains the pituitary gland running from the superomedial petrous apex to the proximal dural ring

Subject: anastomosis between internal carotid artery and basilar artery
Value: any anomalous cross-connection between the basilar artery and the internal carotid artery

Subject: abnormal vertebral artery topology
Value: abnormal position of the first branch of the left and right subclavian arteries that merge to form the single midline basilar artery; branches of the vertebral arteries supply the musculature of the neck

Subject: absent extracranial vertebral artery segment
Value: absence of a segment of a vertebral artery when the absent segment would normally be located outside the skull

Subject: additional anastomosis between intracranial vertebral arteries
Value: greater than the expected number of connections between the segments of the vertebral arteries located within the skull

Subject: absent basilar artery segment
Value: absence of a portion of the basilar artery

Subject: abnormal posterior communicating artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of one or both of the pair of right-sided and left-sided blood vessels in the circle of Willis that connect the three cerebral arteries of the same side

Subject: absent posterior communicating artery
Value: missing the pair of right-sided and left-sided blood vessels in the circle of Willis that connect the three cerebral arteries of the same side

Subject: abnormal labyrinthine artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the long slender branch of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery (85%-100% cases) or basilar artery (<15% cases) that arises from near the middle of the artery; it accompanies the vestibulocochlear nerve through the internal acoustic meatus, and is distributed to the internal ear

Subject: absent labyrinthine artery
Value: missing the long slender branch of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery (85%-100% cases) or basilar artery (<15% cases) that arises from near the middle of the artery

Subject: anastomosis between middle cerebral arteries
Value: any anomalous cross-connection between the middle cerebral arteries

Subject: abnormal peroxisome morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a small cytoplasmic organelle enclosed by a single membrane that contains peroxidases and other enzymes which are important for a variety of metabolic processes including free radical detoxification, lipid catabolism and biosynthesis, and hydrogen peroxide metabolism

Subject: abnormal ovary tissue architecture
Value: any anomaly in the texture of the ovarian tissue

Subject: abnormal cranial blood vasculature morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of blood vasculature that is part of a head

Subject: abnormal cerebellar artery morphology
Value: any structural artery of an artery that supplies blood to the cerebellum

Subject: abnormal anterior inferior cerebellar artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a basilar artery branch that supplies the anterior portion of the inferior surface of the cerebellum

Subject: abnormal superior cerebellar artery morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the artery that arises near the termination of the basilar artery and passes lateralward immediately below the oculomotor nerve arriving at the upper surface of the cerebellum where it divides into branches which ramify in the pia mater and anastomose with those of the inferior cerebellar arteries

Subject: abnormal circle of Willis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the circle of arteries that supply blood to the brain

Subject: abnormal Wolffian duct connection
Value: aberrant attachment or incomplete connection of the transient embryonic drainage tubes of the embryonic kidney (mesonephric tubules) to the cloaca

Subject: embryo tumor
Value: presence of an unspecified tumor or aberrant growth in a prenatal orgnaism

Subject: heterochrony
Value: a developmental change in the timing or rate of events resulting in changes in size or shape to a tissue or anatomical part

Subject: abnormal duodenum topology
Value: abnormal position of the first division of the small intestine that extends from the pyloris to the junction with the jejunum

Subject: increased subchondral bone mineral content
Value: increased amount (usually in grams/cm) of bone mineral divided by a bone-scanned area in the bone region of the epiphysis that provides underlying mechanical and physiological support for the cartilage of joint articular surfaces

Subject: decreased subchondral bone mineral content
Value: decreased amount (usually in grams/cm) of bone mineral divided by a bone-scanned area in the bone region of the epiphysis that provides underlying mechanical and physiological support for the cartilage of joint articular surfaces

Subject: abnormal respiratory epithelial transmembrane transport
Value: any anomaly in the directed movement of a substance from one side of the respiratory epithelial cell membrane to the other

Subject: abnormal respiratory epithelial chloride transmembrane transport
Value: any anomaly in the directed movement of a chloride from one side of the respiratory epithelial cell membrane to the other

Subject: decreased respiratory epithelial chloride transmembrane transport
Value: decrease in the directed movement of a chloride from one side of the respiratory epithelial cell membrane to the other

Subject: increased respiratory epithelial chloride transmembrane transport
Value: increase in the directed movement of a chloride from one side of the respiratory epithelial cell membrane to the other

Subject: abnormal mucous gland physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of any exocrine gland in which the principal secretory cells are mucus-secreting cells; mucus is a slippery secretion with lubricating or protective function produced by, and covering, mucous membranes; mucous fluid is typically produced from cells found in mucous glands, but may also originate from mixed glands, which contain both serous and mucous cells; mucous cells secrete products that are rich in glycoproteins and water; mucus is a viscous colloid containing antiseptic enzymes (such as lysozyme), immunoglobulins, inorganic salts, proteins such as lactoferrin, and glycoproteins known as mucins that are produced by goblet cells in the mucous membranes and submucosal glands

Subject: abnormal submucosal gland physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the mucous-secreting glands located in the dense irregular connective tissue that lines organs and supports the mucosal membrane

Subject: abnormal mucous gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any exocrine gland in which the principal secretory cells are mucus-secreting cells; mucus is a slippery secretion with lubricating or protective function produced by, and covering, mucous membranes; mucous glands typically stain lighter than serous glands during standard histological preparation; most are multicellular, but goblet cells are single-celled glands

Subject: abnormal submucosal gland morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the mucous-secreting glands located in the dense irregular connective tissue that lines organs and supports the mucosal membrane

Subject: abnormal submucosal gland secretion
Value: any anomaly in the secretion of mucous and other substances from a submucosal gland

Subject: decreased submucosal gland secretion
Value: a reduction in the rate or amount of secretion of mucous and other substances from a submucosal gland

Subject: meconium ileus
Value: obstruction of the intestine due to abnormally thick meconium in the fetus and neonate

Subject: stranguria
Value: difficulty in micturition in which the urine is passed intermittently or drop by drop, and is associated with pain and tenesmus

Subject: increased hepatocyte number
Value: greater than normal number of parenchymal liver cells

Subject: abnormal sheltering behavior
Value: deviation from the usual behavior of visiting a shelter or nest used for resting/sleeping

Subject: increased cellular sensitivity to DNA damaging agents
Value: greater incidence of cell death following exposure to agents that cause DNA damage

Subject: increased cellular sensitivity to cisplatin
Value: greater incidence of cell death following exposure to cisplatin

Subject: decreased cellular sensitivity to DNA damaging agents
Value: reduced incidence of cell death following exposure to agents that cause DNA damage

Subject: decreased cellular sensitivity to cisplatin
Value: reduced incidence of cell death following exposure to cisplatin

Subject: absent cardiac outflow tract
Value: absence of or complete failure to form the common arterial trunk that normally forms the aorta and pulmonary artery and the ventricular outflow regions

Subject: Mallory bodies
Value: stereotypical manifestations of hepatocyte injury that present as cytoplasmic inclusion bodies consisting of intermediate filament components (e.g., modified cytokeratins, chaperones and protein degradation machinery)

Subject: abnormal mitophagy
Value: any anomaly in the autophagic process in which mitochondria are delivered to the vacuole and degraded in response to changing cellular conditions

Subject: abnormal gut-associated lymphoid tissue physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the regional immune system located in the gut

Subject: abnormal Peyer's patch physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the protruding lymphoid tissue located on the mucosa of the small intestine that is composed of densely packed B cell follicles

Subject: increased T cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia incidence
Value: an aggressive (fast-growing) type of leukemia (blood cancer) in which too many T-cell lymphoblasts (immature white blood cells) are found in the bone marrow and blood

Subject: increased B cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia incidence
Value: an aggressive (fast-growing) type of leukemia (blood cancer) in which too many B-cell lymphoblasts (immature white blood cells) are found in the bone marrow and blood; it is the most common type of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)

Subject: abnormal maxillary-premaxillary suture morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the line of union of the two portions of the maxilla (pre- and postmaxilla)

Subject: increased male germ cell apoptosis
Value: greater number of male germs cells that undergo programmed cell death

Subject: dry hair
Value: hair characterized by the lack of natural or normal moisture

Subject: abnormal sebocyte physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the highly specialized, sebum-producing epithelial cells of the sebaceous glands that release their content by rupture of the cell membrane and cellular degradation (holocrine secretion); these cells are most commonly found in the skin in association with hair follicles (forming the pilosebaceous unit), where they arise from hair follicle keratinocytes, but there are also sebaceous glands not associated with a hair follicle; the latter have special functions as secretion of pheromones or corneal protection

Subject: abnormal sebocyte proliferation
Value: any anomaly in the expansion rate of sebocytes by cell division

Subject: increased sebocyte proliferation
Value: increase in the expansion rate of sebocytes by cell division

Subject: abnormal mammary gland stroma morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the complex non-epithelial mammary gland tissue composed of fibrous connective tissue extracellular matrix (ECM) proteins, and a wide variety of cell types, including inter- and intralobular fibroblasts, adipocytes, endothelial cells, and innate immune cells (both macrophages and mast cells); the mammary gland stroma is the support network for the epithelium, providing both nutrients and blood supply, and immune defenses, as well as physical structure to the gland; each of the different stromal cell types secrete instructive signals that are crucial for various aspects of the development and function of the epithelium

Subject: abnormal mammary gland stroma physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the complex non-epithelial mammary gland tissue composed of fibrous connective tissue extracellular matrix (ECM) proteins, and a wide variety of cell types, including inter- and intralobular fibroblasts, adipocytes, endothelial cells, and innate immune cells (both macrophages and mast cells); the mammary gland stroma is the support network for the epithelium, providing both nutrients and blood supply, and immune defenses, as well as physical structure to the gland; each of the different stromal cell types secrete instructive signals that are crucial for various aspects of the development and function of the epithelium

Subject: abnormal photoreceptor connecting cilium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the nonmotile primary cilium that has a 9+0 microtubule array and forms the portion of the axoneme traversing the boundary between the retinal photoreceptor inner and outer segments

Subject: abnormal platelet alpha-granule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the most abundant secretory organelle found in blood platelets, and which store adhesive molecules such as von Willebrand factor and fibrinogen, growth factors and inflammatory and angiogenic mediators, which play crucial roles in inflammatory responses and tumor genesis

Subject: ethmocephaly
Value: the rarest form of holoprosencephaly, which occurs due to an incomplete cleavage of the forebrain; ethmocephaly presents with a proboscis situated above hypoteloric orbits in the midline, microphthalmos, absent nasal structures (arrhinia) and lowset malformed ears

Subject: nervous system inclusion bodies
Value: nuclear or cytoplasmic aggregates of stainable substances within cells of the nervous system

Subject: Lafora bodies
Value: abnormal presence of insoluble periodic acid-Schiff-positive deposits that contain polyglucosan, a poorly branched form of glycogen, seen in familial myoclonic epilepsy; Lafora bodies develop in many tissues, including muscle, liver, and neurons, but it is generally believed that Lafora body accumulation ultimately leads to neuronal cell death

Subject: argyrophilic inclusion bodies
Value: presence of abundant argyrophilic grains and coiled bodies on microscopic examination of brain tissue

Subject: Rosenthal fibers
Value: thick, elongated, worm-like or corkscrew eosinophilic bundle that are found on H&E staining of the brain in the presence of long standing gliosis, occasional tumors, and some metabolic disorders

Subject: Hirano bodies
Value: eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions which have a highly characteristic crystalloid fine structure; these inclusions occur predominantly in the neuronal processes of the CA1 area in Ammon's horn but have been noted in other areas of the nervous system; these bodies contain epitopes of actin, actin-associated proteins, tau, middle molecular weight neurofilaments subunit and a C-terminal fragment of beta-amyloid precursor protein; these inclusions have been observed in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis and parkinsonism-dementia complex on Guam, Alzheimer's disease, Pick's disease and 'normal' elderly individuals and animal models

Subject: abnormal muscle glycogen level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration of a readily converted carbohydrate reserve in muscle tissue

Subject: abnormal skeletal muscle glycogen level
Value: any anomaly in the normal concentration of a readily converted carbohydrate reserve in skeletal muscle tissue

Subject: abnormal cardiac muscle glycogen level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration of a readily converted carbohydrate reserve in heart muscle

Subject: increased cardiac muscle glycogen level
Value: greater than the normal concentration of a readily converted carbohydrate reserve in heart muscle

Subject: decreased cardiac muscle glycogen level
Value: less than the normal concentration of a readily converted carbohydrate reserve in heart muscle

Subject: abnormal brain glycogen level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration of a readily converted carbohydrate reserve in brain

Subject: increased brain glycogen level
Value: greater than the normal concentration of a readily converted carbohydrate reserve in brain

Subject: decreased brain glycogen level
Value: less than the normal concentration of a readily converted carbohydrate reserve in brain

Subject: absent Paneth cells
Value: absence or loss of the large secretory cells containing coarse granules normally confined to the base of the crypts of Lieberkuhn in the small intestine

Subject: ectopic Paneth cells
Value: abnormal position of the large secretory cells containing coarse granules normally confined to the base of the crypts of Lieberkuhn in the small intestine

Subject: small intestinal villus atrophy
Value: erosion or abnormal flattening of the surface secondary to the shortening and blunting of the small intestinal villi; villus atrophy is a non-specific reaction of the intestinal mucosa to a variety of injuries; the pathogenesis is either associated with a hyper-regenerative increase in crypt cell mitoses leading to crypt elongation or it results from hyporegeneration, that is, reduced mitotic rate with shortened crypts

Subject: decreased small intestinal villus number
Value: fewer than normal numbers of the tiny hair-like projections which protrude from the inside of the small intestine and contain blood vessels that capture digested nutrients that are absorbed through the intestinal wall

Subject: fused small intestinal villi
Value: partial or complete fusion of the tiny hair-like projections which protrude from the inside of the small intestine and contain blood vessels that capture digested nutrients that are absorbed through the intestinal wall

Subject: branched small intestinal villi
Value: atypical formation of branched tree-like structures in the tiny hair-like projections which protrude from the inside of the small intestine and contain blood vessels that capture digested nutrients that are absorbed through the intestinal wall; branching may occur in association with increased or ectopic epithelial proliferation

Subject: decreased small intestinal villus height
Value: decreased height of the tiny hair-like projections which protrude from the inside of the small intestine and contain blood vessels that capture digested nutrients that are absorbed through the intestinal wall; usually accompanied by crypt elongation or hyperplasia

Subject: blunted small intestinal villi
Value: abnormal flattening of the surface of the tiny hair-like projections which protrude from the inside of the small intestine and contain blood vessels that capture digested nutrients that are absorbed through the intestinal wall; usually due to intestinal damage or injury

Subject: clubbed small intestinal villi
Value: club-shaped small intestinal villi with tips broader than the base; usually accompanied by cytoplasmic swelling and vacuolization

Subject: stomach non-glandular epithelium hyperkeratosis
Value: abnormal thickening of the stratum corneum in the stratified squamous epithelium lining the distinct rodent non-glandular region of the stomach, i.e. the forestomach (aka anterior or proximal stomach); hyperkeratosis frequently accompanies epithelial hyperplasia

Subject: hemangioma
Value: a benign tumor characterized by blood-filled spaces lined by benign endothelial cells

Subject: retrolental blood
Value: presence of blood behind the lens

Subject: abnormal Kimura membrane morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thickening of the lower surface of the tectorial membrane into which the hair bundles of the outer hair cells are imbedded

Subject: abnormal tectorial membrane marginal band morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the dense thickening of the lateral edge of the tectorial membrane

Subject: abnormal tectorial membrane covernet morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anastomosing network of large caliber fibrils that run predominantly longitudinally over the upper surface of the tectorial membrane; in mice, the covernet fibrils are continuous with the underlying striated-sheet matrix of the TM, and appear as electron-dense rods that can be a micron or more in diameter

Subject: abnormal tectorial membrane striated-sheet matrix morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the laminated, striated-sheet matrix within which collagen fibrils of the TM are imbedded; the striated sheet matrix is formed by two types of fine-diameter collagen filaments, a light and a dark staining type that lie in parallel within the plane of each sheet and are extensively linked along their length by staggered cross bridges; it originates medially within the sulcal zone, extends to the marginal band and is particularly evident in apical regions of the cochlea, where it has a less compressed appearance

Subject: abnormal pancreatic primary cilium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the nonmotile primary cilia that assemble in the normal duct, islet, and centroacinar cells of the pancreas and function in sensing and signal transduction

Subject: decreased pancreatic primary cilium length
Value: reduced length of the nonmotile primary cilia that are found in the normal duct, islet, and centroacinar cells of the pancreas and function in sensing and signal transduction

Subject: decreased pancreatic primary cilium number
Value: reduced number of the nonmotile primary cilia that are found in the normal duct, islet, and centroacinar cells of the pancreas and function in sensing and signal transduction

Subject: decreased pancreatic acinar cell zymogen granule number
Value: fewer than the expected number of membrane-bounded, cytoplasmic secretory granules found in pancreatic acinar cells that contain inactive digestive enzyme precursors

Subject: abnormal pancreatic amylase secretion
Value: anomaly in the production and/or release of alpha-amylase, the main starch digesting enzyme component of pancreatic juice, from the acinar cells of the exocrine pancreas; pancreatic alpha-amylase is released into pancreatic ducts in its active form and acts at random locations along the starch chain to break down long-chain carbohydrates, ultimately yielding maltotriose and maltose from amylose, or maltose, glucose and limit dextrin from amylopectin

Subject: increased pancreatic amylase secretion
Value: greater production and/or release of alpha-amylase, the main starch digesting enzyme component of pancreatic juice, from the acinar cells of the exocrine pancreas; pancreatic alpha-amylase is released into pancreatic ducts in its active form and acts at random locations along the starch chain to break down long-chain carbohydrates, ultimately yielding maltotriose and maltose from amylose, or maltose, glucose and limit dextrin from amylopectin

Subject: decreased pancreatic amylase secretion
Value: reduction in the production and/or release of alpha-amylase, the main starch digesting enzyme component of pancreatic juice, from the acinar cells of the exocrine pancreas; pancreatic alpha-amylase is released into pancreatic ducts in its active form and acts at random locations along the starch chain to break down long-chain carbohydrates, ultimately yielding maltotriose and maltose from amylose, or maltose, glucose and limit dextrin from amylopectin

Subject: abnormal chondrocyte proliferation
Value: any anomaly in multiplication or reproduction of chondrocytes by cell division, resulting in the expansion of their population

Subject: increased chondrocyte proliferation
Value: increased amount of multiplication or reproduction of chondrocytes by cell division, resulting in the expansion of their population

Subject: decreased chondrocyte proliferation
Value: decreased amount of multiplication or reproduction of chondrocytes by cell division, resulting in the expansion of their population

Subject: abnormal chondrocyte apoptosis
Value: change in the timing or the number of chondrocytes undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: increased chondrocyte apoptosis
Value: increased number of chondrocytes undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: decreased chondrocyte apoptosis
Value: reduced number of chondrocytes undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal chondrocyte differentiation
Value: any anomaly in the process in which a chondroblast acquires specialized structural and/or functional features of a chondrocyte

Subject: delayed chondrocyte differentiation
Value: delay in the process in which a chondroblast acquires specialized structural and/or functional features of a chondrocyte

Subject: premature chondrocyte differentiation
Value: early occurance of the process in which a chondroblast acquires specialized structural and/or functional features of a chondrocyte

Subject: calcified pancreas
Value: pathologic deposition of calcium salts in the pancreas; commonly seen in chronic pancreatitis

Subject: increased pancreatic alpha cell proliferation
Value: increase in the ability of the glucagon-producing cells of the islets of Langerhans in the endocrine pancreas to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: absent ventral pancreas
Value: absence of the transient embryonic structure that fuses with the dorsal pancreas during development to form a single organ; the ventral pancreatic bud gives rise to the pancreatic head and uncinate process

Subject: small ventral pancreas
Value: reduced size of the transient embryonic structure that fuses with the dorsal pancreas during development to form a single organ; the ventral pancreatic bud gives rise to the pancreatic head and uncinate process

Subject: absent dorsal pancreas
Value: absence of the transient embryonic structure that fuses with the ventral pancreas during development to form a single organ; the dorsal pancreatic bud gives rise to the body, tail, and isthmus of the pancreas

Subject: small dorsal pancreas
Value: reduced size of the transient embryonic structure that fuses with the ventral pancreas during development to form a single organ; the dorsal pancreatic bud gives rise to the body, tail, and isthmus of the pancreas

Subject: abnormal cognition
Value: any anomaly in the operation of the mind by which an organism becomes aware of objects of thought or perception; it includes the mental activities associated with thinking, learning, and memory

Subject: cognitive inflexibility
Value: inability to change attention or a cognitive behavior as an adaptation to the demands of external stimuli

Subject: abnormal pancreatic beta cell apoptosis
Value: change in the timing or the number of pancreatic beta cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: increased pancreatic beta cell apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of pancreatic beta cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: decreased pancreatic beta cell apoptosis
Value: decrease in the number of pancreatic beta cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal mandibular nerve innervation pattern
Value: any changes in the placement, morphology or number of mandibular nerve fibers providing motor and sensory nerve supply from the auricle, the external acoustic meatus, tympanic membrane, temporal region, the cheek, the skin overlying the mandible, the anterior portion of the tongue, the floor of the mouth, lower teeth and gingiva and transmits motor information from the muscles of mastication, the mylohyoid muscle and digastric muscle and the muscles tensor tympani and tensor veli palatini

Subject: focal seizures
Value: seizures characterized by localized cerebral ictal onset

Subject: increased pancreatic islet cell apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of pancreatic islet cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: decreased pancreatic islet cell apoptosis
Value: decrease in the number of pancreatic islet cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal amylin secretion
Value: any anomaly in the production or release of the polypeptide hormone that is co-secreted with insulin by the beta cells of the pancreatic islets of Langerhans and is known to inhibit glucagon secretion, delay gastric emptying, and act as a satiety agent

Subject: increased amylin secretion
Value: greater than normal production or release of the polypeptide hormone that is normally co-secreted with insulin by the beta cells of the pancreatic islets of Langerhans and is known to inhibit glucagon secretion, delay gastric emptying, and act as a satiety agent

Subject: decreased amylin secretion
Value: reduction in the production or release of the polypeptide hormone that is normally co-secreted with insulin by the beta cells of the pancreatic islets of Langerhans and is known to inhibit glucagon secretion, delay gastric emptying, and act as a satiety agent

Subject: increased mammary gland apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of any cells of a mammary gland undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: increased thymoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a malignant neoplasm originating from the epithelial cells of the thymus, occurring in a specific population in a given time period; thymoma is an uncommon tumor linked with myasthenia gravis and other autoimmune diseases

Subject: increased Harderian gland adenocarcinoma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of a malignant neoplasm of acinar epithelial cells in the Harderian gland, occurring in a specific population in a given time period; these usually are larger than adenomas and may cause facial selling and/or exophthalmos; they are highly cellular and disorganized compared to adenomas, with piling up of pleomorphic cells; areas of medullary or solid growth patterns are common; there may necrosis or hemorrhage, invasion beyond the orbit, and distant metastasis to the lungs, local lymph nodes, thymus or liver

Subject: thymus fibrosis
Value: invasion of fibrous connective tissue into the thymus, often resulting from inflammation or injury

Subject: thymus cysts
Value: presence of fluid-filled spaces lined by epithelium within the thymus; thymic cysts are rare mediastinal lesions and are thought to result from the congenital persistence of thymopharyngeal tracts and acquired, progressive cystic degeneration of thymic (Hassall) corpuscles and epithelial reticulum of the thymus; congenital cysts are unilocular, whereas acquired cysts are usually multilocular and result as a consequence of inflammatory processes

Subject: abnormal tear film morphology
Value: <any alteration in the structure, biochemical composition, or stability of the thin acellular fluid layer that adheres to the most superficial layer of the corneal epithelium and lubricates and protects the ocular surface; the film is generally composed of three layers: (i) an inner mucous layer, secreted largely by the conjunctival goblet cells with contributions from the lacrimal glands, which coats the cornea, provides a hydrophobic layer, and allows for even distribution of the tear film; (ii) a middle aqueous layer, secreted by the lacrimal glands, which keeps the corneal surface moist, and provides a mechanism for oxygenation and nutrient exchange with the avascular anterior corneal tissue; and (iii) an outer lipid layer, secreted principally by the Meibomian (tarsal) glands although lipid tear elements also are contributed by the Harderian glands; tear film lipids form a monolayer on the tear surface, and function by enhancing the surface tension which supports the integrity of the tear film against collapse due to gravity and also slows down the loss of the tear film by evaporation; in addition , the lipid layer provides a glassy, smooth interface between the air and the transparent cornea>

Subject: abnormal tear film physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the thin acelullar fluid layer that covers the anterior surface of the mammalian eye and has a variety of constituents that are essential for the maintenance of the avascular transparent corneal epithelium; this film keeps the cornea wet, thus allowing gas exchange between the air and the epithelium, it cleans debris from the transparent surface, providing a clear optical path to the retina, and protects the ocular surface from invasion by bacteria and viruses; the tear film also provides essential metabolites such as retinol, which serves to preserve the transparent nature of the epithelium

Subject: obsolete abnormal Pavlovian conditioned approach
Value: any anomaly in propensity to attribute motivational properties to stimuli which predict reward; critical component of drug addition

Subject: abnormal embryo morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of an embryo

Subject: abnormal extraembryonic mesoderm morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the mesoderm of the extraembryonic tissue that is involved in forming the amnion, chorion, yolk sac, and body stalk

Subject: abnormal extraembryonic endoderm morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the derivative of the hypoblast cells that migrate into the blastocyst cavity, and line the cavity, giving rise to the primary and definitive yolk sacs; the extraembryonic endoderm fills the remaining cavity of the blastocyst

Subject: abnormal germ layer morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the layer of cells produced during the process of gastrulation during the early development of the animal embryo, which is distinct from other such layers of cells, as an early step of cell differentiation

Subject: abnormal ectoderm morphology
Value: primary germ layer that is the outer of the embryo's three germ layers and gives rise to epidermis and neural tissue

Subject: abnormal endoderm morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the primary germ layer that lies remote from the surface of the embryo and gives rise to internal tissues such as gut

Subject: abnormal mesoderm morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the middle germ layer of the embryo, between the endoderm and ectoderm

Subject: increased body fat mass
Value: increased physical bulk or volume of fat in the whole body

Subject: decreased body fat mass
Value: decreased physical bulk or volume of fat in the whole body

Subject: abnormal white adipose tissue mass
Value: aberrant physical bulk or volume of white adipose tissue

Subject: increased white adipose tissue mass
Value: increased physical bulk or volume of white adipose tissue

Subject: decreased white adipose tissue mass
Value: decreasd physical bulk or volume of white adipose tissue

Subject: lacrimal gland necrosis
Value: morphological changes resulting from pathological death of lacrimal gland tissue; usually due to irreversible damage

Subject: lacrimal gland degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of the tubuloacinar exocrine glands that secrete the aqueous layer of the tear film (tears); mice have two lacrimal glands (intra- and exorbital)

Subject: abnormal lacrimal gland innervation pattern
Value: any structural or position anomaly of the supply of nerve fibers that connect to the tubuloacinar exocrine glands that secrete the aqueous layer of the tear film (tears)

Subject: lacrimal gland hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due to an increased number of cells, of the glands that secrete tears

Subject: lacrimal gland hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a decreased number of cells, of the glands that secrete tears

Subject: absent exorbital lacrimal gland
Value: absence of the large extra-orbital lacrimal gland that, in mice, is normally located subcutaneously at the anteroventral base of the ear adjacent to the parotid gland

Subject: absent intraorbital lacrimal gland
Value: absence of the small intra-orbital lacrimal gland that, in mice, is normally located superficially at the lateral canthus, where both the lacrimal gland and Harderian gland ducts open

Subject: Meibomian gland degeneration
Value: a retrogressive impairment of function or destruction of the meibum-secreting modified lobulated sebaceous glands located at the rim of the eyelids inside the tarsal plate

Subject: absent olfactory epithelium
Value: absence of the epithelial cells that line the interior of the nose

Subject: abnormal lacrimal gland myoepithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the stellate-shaped contractile cells with flattened nuclei and long slender processes that surround the secretory acini and intralobular ducts of the lacrimal gland, located between the epithelium and the basement membrane; myoepithelial cells not only exhibit characteristics of other epithelial cells, such as expression of cytokeratin, but also exhibit properties of smooth muscle cells, such as expression of alpha-smooth muscle actin; their contraction might aid in the expulsion of fluid out of the secretory tubules or help maintain the patency of acinar and ductal lumens

Subject: alacrima
Value: absence of tear production; may occur in association with other disorders or as an isolated congenital defect

Subject: esophagus fibrosis
Value: invasion of fibrous connective tissue into the esophagus, often resulting from inflammation or injury

Subject: stomach fibrosis
Value: invasion of fibrous connective tissue into the stomach, often resulting from inflammation or injury

Subject: abnormal circulating cortisol level
Value: any anomaly in the blood concentration of the principal glucocorticoid produced by the zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex within the adrenal gland; cortisol is released in response to stress and a low level of blood glucose; it functions to increase blood sugar through gluconeogenesis, to suppress the immune system, and to aid the metabolism of fat, protein, and carbohydrate; it also decreases bone formation

Subject: increased circulating cortisol level
Value: greater than the normal blood concentration of the principal glucocorticoid produced by the zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex within the adrenal gland and released in response to stress and a low level of blood glucose

Subject: decreased circulating cortisol level
Value: less than the normal blood concentration of the principal glucocorticoid produced by the zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex within the adrenal gland and released in response to stress and a low level of blood glucose

Subject: abnormal ciliary muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the ring of smooth muscle in the eye's vascular layer that forms the main part of the ciliary body, controls accommodation for viewing objects at varying distances, and regulates the flow of aqueous humor into the canal of Schlemm

Subject: abnormal ciliary process morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the pigmented processes that radiate from the ciliary muscle and give attachments to ligaments supporting the lens of the eye; these processes increase in thickness as they advance from the orbiculus ciliaris to the external border of the iris, and together with the folds (plicae) in the furrows between them, constitute the corona ciliaris; ciliary processes produce aqueous humor

Subject: absent ciliary process
Value: absence or loss of any of the pigmented processes that radiate from the ciliary muscle and give attachments to ligaments supporting the lens of the eye; ciliary processes produce aqueous humor

Subject: ectopic cranial bone
Value: the appearance of an extra bone structure at an atypical location in or near the cranium

Subject: ectopic bone
Value: the appearance of an extra bone structure at an atypical location

Subject: abnormal brown adipose tissue mass
Value: aberrant physical bulk or volume of brown adipose tissue

Subject: decreased brown adipose tissue mass
Value: decreased physical bulk or volume of brown adipose tissue

Subject: increased brown adipose tissue mass
Value: increased physical bulk or volume of brown adipose tissue

Subject: increased fatty acid oxidation
Value: increased rate or incidence of the process of removal of one or more electrons from a fatty acid, with or without the concomitant removal of a proton or protons, by reaction with an electron-accepting substance, by addition of oxygen or by removal of hydrogen

Subject: decreased fatty acid oxidation
Value: decreased rate or incidence of the process of removal of one or more electrons from a fatty acid, with or without the concomitant removal of a proton or protons, by reaction with an electron-accepting substance, by addition of oxygen or by removal of hydrogen

Subject: increased fatty acid beta-oxidation
Value: increased rate or incidence of the process that results in the complete oxidation of a long-chain fatty acid, beginning with the addition of coenzyme A to a fatty acid, with successive cycles of reactions during each of which the fatty acid is shortened by a two-carbon fragment removed as acetyl coenzyme A; the cycle continues until only two or three carbons remain (as acetyl-CoA or propionyl-CoA respectively)

Subject: decreased fatty acid beta-oxidation
Value: decreased rate or incidence of the process that results in the complete oxidation of a long-chain fatty acid, beginning with the addition of coenzyme A to a fatty acid, with successive cycles of reactions during each of which the fatty acid is shortened by a two-carbon fragment removed as acetyl coenzyme A; the cycle continues until only two or three carbons remain (as acetyl-CoA or propionyl-CoA respectively)

Subject: abnormal ciliary epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the double layer lining the inner surfaces of the ciliary processes and the pars plana (i.e. the posterior portion of the ciliary body, aka orbicularis ciliari); the outer layer is the pigmented epithelium, which is composed of low cuboidal cells and is adjacent to the stroma and continuous with the retinal pigmented epithelium; the inner layer is formed by non-pigmented epithelium, a columnar epithelium, adjacent to the aqueous humor in the posterior chamber and continuous with the retina; these two layers of the epithelium are appositioned in their apical surfaces

Subject: abnormal cilary zonule morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the circumferential suspensory ligaments that anchor the lens to the ciliary process and are made of bundles of fibrillin microfibrils, an elaborate system of fibers that spans the gap between the lens and the adjacent nonpigmented ciliary epithelium; this fibrous rigging ensures lens centration; in species that accommodate, the zonule transmits the forces that flatten the lens, allowing the eye to focus on distant objects
