Value: presence of small extra bone segments, usually of irregular shape and variable size, arising in fontanelles and/or adjacent to or along the cranial sutures, and formed from additional and separate centers of ossification of the cranium; in humans, Wormian bones are most frequently located in the lambdoid or coronal suture, and have been seen in the fontanelles, particularly the posterior fontanelle

Subject: abnormal forehead morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the part of the face above the eyes; in human anatomy, the forehead is the fore part of the head, an area of the head bounded by three features, two of the skull and one of the scalp; the top of the forehead is marked by the hairline, the edge of the area where hair on the scalp grows while the bottom of the forehead is marked by the supraorbital ridge, the bone feature of the skull above the eyes; the two sides of the forehead are marked by the temporal ridge, a bone feature that links the supraorbital ridge to the coronal suture line and beyond

Subject: high forehead
Value: an abnormally increased height of the forehead

Subject: abnormal nasal bridge morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the saddle-shaped area that includes the nasal root and the lateral aspects of the nose; it lies between the glabella and the inferior boundary of the nasal bone, and extends laterally to the inner canthi

Subject: depressed nasal bridge
Value: posterior positioning of the saddle-shaped area that includes the nasal root and the lateral aspects of the nose in relation to the overall facial profile for age; normally, it lies between the glabella and the inferior boundary of the nasal bone, and extends laterally to the inner canthi

Subject: small nasal bridge
Value: reduced size of the saddle-shaped area that includes the nasal root and the lateral aspects of the nose; it lies between the glabella and the inferior boundary of the nasal bone, and extends laterally to the inner canthi

Subject: short nasal bridge
Value: reduced length of the saddle-shaped area that includes the nasal root and the lateral aspects of the nose; it lies between the glabella and the inferior boundary of the nasal bone, and extends laterally to the inner canthi

Subject: prominent nasal bridge
Value: anterior positioning of the saddle-shaped area that includes the nasal root and the lateral aspects of the nose in comparison to the usual positioning for age

Subject: abnormal periorbital region morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the region around the eye socket

Subject: abnormal facial muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the striated skeletal muscles innervated by the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) that, among other things, control facial expression; facial muscles are derived from the second branchial/pharyngeal arch

Subject: absent facial muscle
Value: absence of any of the striated skeletal muscles innervated by the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) that, among other things, control facial expression; facial muscles are derived from the second branchial/pharyngeal arch

Subject: abnormal forehead size
Value: deviation from the average range of forehead size for an organism

Subject: large forehead
Value: presence of an abnormally large forehead

Subject: small forehead
Value: presence of an abnormally small forehead

Subject: short forehead
Value: an abnormally decreased height of the forehead

Subject: abnormal forehead shape
Value: any anomaly in the characteristic surface outline or contour of the forehead

Subject: round forehead
Value: forehead appearance is more circular than usual as viewed from the front

Subject: flat forehead
Value: abnormal flatness of the forehead

Subject: sloping forehead
Value: apparently excessive posterior sloping of the forehead in a lateral view

Subject: prominent forehead
Value: forward prominence of the entire forehead, due to protrusion of the frontal bone; not to be confused with frontal bossing

Subject: large mandible
Value: increased size of the lower bony framework of the mouth where the inferior teeth are held

Subject: increased foot pigmentation
Value: darker color of the foot surface due to excess pigment

Subject: abnormal forehead pigmentation
Value: anomaly in the coloration of the skin of the forehead due to changes in the amount, shape, or distribution of cells producing pigment

Subject: increased forehead pigmentation
Value: visually detectable excess of pigment present in the forehead

Subject: decreased forehead pigmentation
Value: visually detectable dilution of pigment present in the forehead

Subject: small lacrimal bone
Value: reduced size of the thin plate that forms part of the medial wall of the orbit behind the frontal process of the maxilla

Subject: lacrimal bone hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the thin plate that forms part of the medial wall of the orbit behind the frontal process of the maxilla

Subject: absent lacrimal bone
Value: absence of the thin plate that forms part of the medial wall of the orbit behind the frontal process of the maxilla

Subject: erythrodontia
Value: reddish, brown opalescent discoloration of teeth in normal light

Subject: absent ethmoturbinates
Value: absence of the conchae of the ethmoid bone which normally occupy the caudal part of the nasal fossae and form the lateral and superior portions of the turbinate bones in mammals

Subject: absent nasal pit
Value: absence of one or both of a pair of depressions formed in the developing face that give rise to the rostral portion of the nasal meatus; the nasal pits indent the frontonasal process and divide it into a medial and two lateral nasal processes

Subject: absent otic pit
Value: absence of the paired depression of thickened otic placode epithelium marking the location of the future otic vesicles

Subject: choanal stenosis
Value: abnormal narrowing of either of the pair of posterior apertures of the nasal cavity that open into the nasopharynx

Subject: abnormal face size
Value: deviation from the average range of face size for an organism

Subject: small face
Value: presence of an abnormally small face

Subject: face hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the face, usually due to a reduced number of cells

Subject: short face
Value: an abnormally decreased height (length) of the face

Subject: narrow face
Value: a reduction in the width of the upper and lower face

Subject: large face
Value: presence of an abnormally large face

Subject: broad face
Value: increased width of the upper and lower face

Subject: long face
Value: an abnormally increased height (length) of the face

Subject: abnormal face shape
Value: any anomaly in the characteristic surface outline or contour of the face

Subject: round face
Value: facial appearance is more circular than usual as viewed from the front

Subject: square face
Value: facial contours, as viewed from the front, show a broad upper face/cranium and lower face/mandible, creating a square appearance

Subject: coarse facial features
Value: absence of fine and sharp appearance of facial features, usually because of rounded and heavy features or thickened skin with or without thickening of subcutaneous and bony tissues

Subject: hairy ears
Value: excessive hair growth on the external ear; may involve the meatal opening, pinnae or external rim

Subject: abnormal cranial cavity morphology
Value: any anomaly of the space formed within the skull and occupied by the brain, pineal and hypophysis cerebri, parts of the cranial and spinal nerves, blood vessels, meninges and cerebrospinal fluid

Subject: small cranial cavity
Value: reduced size of the space formed within the skull and occupied by the brain, pineal and hypophysis cerebri, parts of the cranial and spinal nerves, blood vessels, meninges and cerebrospinal fluid

Subject: synotia
Value: fusion or abnormal approximation of the ears in front of the neck, often accompanied by the absence or defective development of the lower jaw

Subject: small incisors
Value: reduced size of the set of long teeth that are the most anterior and prominent in the jaw

Subject: small lower incisors
Value: reduced size of the lower set of long teeth that are the most anterior and prominent in the jaw

Subject: small upper incisors
Value: reduced size of the upper set of long teeth that are the most anterior and prominent in the jaw

Subject: long lower incisors
Value: increased length or overgrowth of the lower set of long teeth that are the most anterior and prominent in the jaw

Subject: long upper incisors
Value: increased length or overgrowth of the upper set of long teeth that are the most anterior and prominent in the jaw

Subject: tympanic ring hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the bony ring at the ear canal to which the tympanic membrane is attached

Subject: syngnathia
Value: fusion of the upper and lower jaw; fusion can range from simple mucosal bands (synechiae) to complete bony fusion (synostosis); syngnathia can occur in the midline, or laterally, and it can be uni- or bilateral

Subject: bony syngnathia
Value: bony fusion of the upper and lower jaw

Subject: fibrous syngnathia
Value: complete or nearly complete soft tissue fusion of the alveolar ridges

Subject: microdontia
Value: abnormal reduction in the size of one or more teeth

Subject: short lower incisors
Value: reduced length of the lower set of long teeth that are the most anterior and prominent in the jaw

Subject: short upper incisors
Value: reduced length of the upper set of long teeth that are the most anterior and prominent in the jaw

Subject: macrodontia
Value: abnormal increase in the size of one or more teeth

Subject: abnormal outer ear helix morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the outer rim of the ear that extends from the insertion of the ear on the scalp (root) to the termination of the cartilage at the earlobe

Subject: absent maxillary sinus
Value: absence of the largest of the paranasal sinuses, a paired pyramid-shaped air sinus located within the maxillary bone which drains via the maxillary ostium into the infundibulum, then through the hiatus semilunaris into the middle meatus of the nose

Subject: foramen magnum stenosis
Value: abnormal narrowing or constriction of the large orifice in the occipital bone through which the spinal cord passes to the cranial cavity and becomes continuous with the medulla oblongata

Subject: abnormal midface morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the midface region which extends, superiorly, from the inferior orbital margin to, inferiorly, the level of nasal base; it is formed by the maxilla (upper jaw) and zygoma and cheeks and malar region; traditionally, the nose and premaxilla are not included in the midface

Subject: abnormal periauricular region morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the region around the ear

Subject: preauricular pit
Value: small indentation anterior to the insertion of the ear

Subject: periorbital fullness
Value: increase in periorbital soft tissue

Subject: facial asymmetry
Value: an abnormal difference between the left and right sides of the face

Subject: hemifacial hypoplasia
Value: unilateral underdevelopment or size reduction of the facial tissues, including muscles and bones; usually due to a reduced number of cells

Subject: carious teeth
Value: formation of cavities in the teeth due to a multifactorial bacterial infection that causes demineralization and destruction of the hard tissues of the teeth (enamel, dentin and cementum), usually by production of acid by bacterial fermentation of the food debris accumulated on the tooth surface

Subject: absent orbitosphenoid bone
Value: missing the bone that is situated in the orbit on either side of the presphenoid; it generally forms a part of the sphenoid in the adult, and may be independent in the young

Subject: abnormal orbit shape
Value: any anomaly in the characteristic surface outline or contour of the orbits of an organism

Subject: round orbits
Value: orbits present a more circular rather than the ususal oval appearance

Subject: bushy muzzle
Value: excessive hair growth on or around the muzzle

Subject: small incus
Value: reduced size of the anvil-shaped, central bone of the three auditory ossicles which articulates with the head of the malleus anteromedially and the stapes inferomedially

Subject: incus hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to reduced cell number, of the anvil-shaped, central bone of the three auditory ossicles which articulates with the head of the malleus anteromedially and the stapes inferomedially

Subject: abnormal incudostapedial joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small synovial joint located between the lenticular process on the long crus of the incus and the head of the stapes

Subject: abnormal incudomalleolar joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the saddle-shaped synovial joint located between the incus and the malleus

Subject: incudomalleolar fusion
Value: bony fusion of the incus and the malleus into a single structure

Subject: absent temporomandibular joint
Value: absence of the synovial articulation between the head of the mandibular condoyloid process and the mandibular fossa and articular tubercle of the temporal bones

Subject: zygomatic bone hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the quadrilateral bone that forms the prominence of the cheek

Subject: maxillary sinus inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the maxillary sinuses

Subject: abnormal nasal columella morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tissue that links the nasal tip to the nasal base, and separates the nares; it is the inferior margin of the nasal septum

Subject: abnormal nasal tip morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tip of the nose located at the junction of the inferior margin of the nasal ridge and the columella

Subject: bifid nasal tip
Value: a splitting of the nasal tip; visually assessable vertical indentation, cleft, or depression of the nasal tip

Subject: bifid nose
Value: visually assessable vertical indentation, cleft, or depression of the nasal bridge, ridge and tip

Subject: rhinosinusitis
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the mucous membranes of the nose and in one or more paranasal sinuses

Subject: abnormal retrotympanic process morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the posterior extension of the squamosal bone that lies just above the incus

Subject: absent retrotympanic process
Value: absence of the posterior extension of the squamosal bone that normally lies just above the incus

Subject: small temporal bone squamous part
Value: reduced size of the anterosuperior portion of the temporal bone that is thin, scale-like, and translucent and forms part of the lateral wall of the cranial vault

Subject: temporal bone squamous part hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the anterosuperior portion of the temporal bone that is thin, scale-like, and translucent and forms part of the lateral wall of the cranial vault

Subject: small middle ear ossicles
Value: reduced size of the three bones of the middle ear

Subject: middle ear ossicle hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the three bones of the middle ear, usually due to reduced cell number

Subject: small gonial bone
Value: reduced size of the investing bone that lies on the surface of the malleus

Subject: torticollis
Value: involuntary contractions of the neck musculature resulting in an abnormal posture of or abnormal movements of the head

Subject: small stapes
Value: reduced size of the stirrup-shaped ossicle that is the smallest and innermost of the three auditory ossicles

Subject: stapes hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the stirrup-shaped ossicle that is the smallest and innermost of the three auditory ossicles

Subject: tongue inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins and leukocytes in the tongue

Subject: gum inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the gums

Subject: abnormal periodontium morphology
Value: <any structural anomaly of the specialized tissues that both surround and support the teeth, maintaining them in the maxillary and mandibular bones; it consists of four principal components: the gums (gingiva), periodontal ligament, cementum, and alveolar bone proper>

Subject: periodontium inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the periodontium (including the gums and supporting structures of the teeth)

Subject: small third pharyngeal arch
Value: reduced size of the third branchial arch

Subject: small fourth pharyngeal arch
Value: reduced size of the fourth branchial arch

Subject: small sixth pharyngeal arch
Value: reduced size of the sixth branchial arch

Subject: abnormal lower incisor morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the lower set of long teeth that are the most anterior and prominent in the jaw

Subject: abnormal upper incisor morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the upper set of long teeth that are the most anterior and prominent in the jaw

Subject: abnormal lower incisor color
Value: anomaly in the color and shading of the lower incisors, which normally presents in shades of white

Subject: abnormal upper incisor color
Value: anomaly in the color and shading of the upper incisors, which normally presents in shades of white

Subject: facial muscle atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of facial muscle tissue associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes; occurs with age, immobilization, weightlessness, malnutrition or denervation

Subject: facial paralysis
Value: severe or complete loss of power of voluntary movement in muscles of the face through injury or disease of it or its nerve supply; facial muscles are innervated by the facial nerve (i.e., the seventh cranial nerve)

Subject: facial muscle degeneration
Value: pathological deterioration of facial muscle tissue, often accompanied by loss of function

Subject: facial muscle spasm
Value: sudden, repetitive, nonrhythmic motor movements (spasms) involving the muscles of the face; common types of facial spasms include rapid, repetitive squinting or blinking, grimacing, mouth twitching, and nose twitching

Subject: abnormal facial muscle physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of any of the striated skeletal muscles innervated by the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) that, among other things, control facial expression

Subject: abnormal digastric anterior belly morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anterior belly of the digastric muscle which arises from a depression on the inner side of the lower border of the mandible called the digastric fossa, close to the symphysis, and passes downward and backward; the anterior body originates from the first pharyngeal arch and is supplied by the trigeminal via the mylohyoid nerve, a branch of the inferior alveolar nerve, itself a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve

Subject: abnormal digastric posterior belly morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the longer, posterior belly of the digastric muscle arising from the mastoid notch which is on the inferior surface of the skull, medial to the mastoid process of the temporal bone; the posterior belly is supplied by the digastric branch of facial nerve

Subject: abnormal digastric muscle physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the digastric muscle whose action elevates the hyoid when the mandible is fixed and depresses the mandible when the hyoid is fixed; when the two bellies of the digastric contract, they pull upward on the hyoid bone; but if the hyoid is fixed from below, the digastric assists in extreme opening of the mouth such as yawning or taking a large bite

Subject: abnormal mylohyoid muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the flat and triangular paired muscle that runs from the mandible to the hyoid bone forming the muscular floor of the oral cavity of the mouth; it is a suprahyoid muscle derived from the first pharyngeal arch that is situated immediately superior to the anterior belly of the digastric muscle

Subject: abnormal stylohyoid muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the slender suprahyoid muscle lying anterior and superior of the posterior belly of the digastric muscle; it arises from the styloid process of the temporal bone and inserts into the body of the hyoid bone; it is perforated, near its insertion, by the intermediate tendon of the digastric muscle; the stylohyoid elevates and retracts the hyoid bone, elongating the floor of the mouth during swallowing

Subject: absent stylohyoid muscle
Value: absence of the slender suprahyoid muscle lying anterior and superior of the posterior belly of the digastric muscle that elevates and retracts the hyoid bone, elongating the floor of the mouth during swallowing

Subject: abnormal buccinator muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thin quadrilateral muscle occupying the interval between the maxilla and the mandible at the side of the face that forms the anterior part of the cheek or the lateral wall of the oral cavity; it compresses the cheeks against the teeth and is used in acts such as blowing; it is an assistant muscle of mastication and in neonates it is used to suckle

Subject: abnormal depressor anguli oris muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the facial muscle that originates from the mandible and inserts into the angle of the mouth; it is innervated by the marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve and receives its blood supply from the facial artery; the muscle depresses the corners of the mouth which is associated with frowning

Subject: dental pulp inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in dental pulp tissue; commonly associated with a bacterial infection but can also be due to other insults such as repetitive trauma or in rare cases periodontitis

Subject: abnormal tympanic cavity morphology
Value: <any structural anomaly of the small, air-filled, mucosa-lined cavity that is located in the petrous portion of the temporal bone and houses the auditory ossicles and intratympanic muscles (tensor tympani and stapedius) as well as the chorda tympani and the tympanic plexus of nerves; it is split into two parts: the tympanic cavity proper (the space directly internal to the tympanic membrane) and the epitympanic recess or attic (the space superior to the tympanic membrane)>

Subject: absent tympanic cavity
Value: absence of the small, air-filled, mucosa-lined cavity that is located in the petrous portion of the temporal bone and houses the auditory ossicles and intratympanic muscles (tensor tympani and stapedius) as well as the chorda tympani and the tympanic plexus of nerves

Subject: abnormal tympanic cavity muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of either of the two tiny striated muscles (tensor tympani and stapedius) located within the tympanic cavity; these muscles contract in response to loud noise, inhibiting the vibrations of the malleus, incus and stapes, and reducing the transmission of sound to the inner ear

Subject: abnormal stapedius muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tiny striated muscle found in the pyramidal eminence on the posterior wall of the tympanic cavity, whose tendon inserts onto the neck of the stapes; like the tensor tympani, it helps to dampen loud sounds; it is innervated by a small branch from the facial nerve

Subject: absent stapedius muscle
Value: missing the tiny muscle normally found in the pyramidal eminence on the posterior wall of the tympanic cavity, whose tendon inserts onto the neck of the stapes

Subject: abnormal tensor tympani muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tiny striated muscle that originates superior to the pharyngotympanic tube, the sphenoid, and the temporal bone and inserts into the handle of the malleus; it tenses the tympanic membrane and dampens the movements of the auditory ossicles to prevent ear damage from loud sounds; it is innervated by the trigeminal nerve

Subject: abnormal auditory bulla morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the hollow bony structure on the ventral, posterior portion of the skull that encloses parts of the middle and inner ear; in most species, it is formed by the tympanic part of the temporal bone

Subject: absent auditory bulla
Value: absence of the hollow bony structure normally found on the ventral, posterior portion of the skull that encloses parts of the middle and inner ear; in most species, it is formed by the tympanic part of the temporal bone

Subject: absent hyoid bone body
Value: absence of the main curve of the hyoid bone from which the horns extend

Subject: abnormal canthus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of either corner of the eye where the upper and lower eyelids meet; more specifically, the inner and outer canthi are, respectively, the medial and lateral ends/angles of the palpebral fissure

Subject: abnormal inner canthus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the inner corner of the eye where the upper and lower eyelids meet, i.e. the medial end/angle of the palpebral fissure

Subject: abnormal outer canthus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the outer corner of the eye where the upper and lower eyelids meet, i.e. the lateral end/angle of the palpebral fissure

Subject: increased inner canthal distance
Value: increased distance between the inner corners (medial canthi) of the eyes where the eyelids meet; may be present without or with ocular hypertelorism (where interpupillary distance is increased)

Subject: decreased inner canthal distance
Value: decreased distance between the inner corners (medial canthi) of the eyes where the eyelids meet

Subject: thin upper lip
Value: upper lips having a reduced amount of soft tissue

Subject: thick upper lip
Value: upper lips having an abundance and often an excess of soft tissue

Subject: absent mandibular symphysis
Value: absence of the fibrocartilagenous union of the two halves of the mandible (embryonic stages)

Subject: absent extraocular muscles
Value: missing the striated muscles that are located within the orbit but are extrinsic and separate from the eyeball itself and control the movements of the eyeball and the superior eyelid

Subject: abnormal eyelid muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the muscles that attach to an eyelid

Subject: abnormal orbicularis oculi muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the ring-like (sphincter) facial muscle composed of skeletal muscle fibers and arranged in concentric bands around the upper and lower eyelids; its function is to close the eyelids, and to help in the passing and draining of tears through the punctum, canaliculi, and lacrimal sac, all parts of the tear drainage system

Subject: absent orbicularis oculi muscle
Value: absence of the ring-like (sphincter) facial muscle composed of skeletal muscle fibers and arranged in concentric bands around the upper and lower eyelids; its primary function is to close the eyelids

Subject: orbicularis oculi muscle hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the orbicularis oculi muscle, usually due to a reduced number of cells

Subject: abnormal levator labii superioris muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the facial muscle that is shaped like a broad, flat sheet, the origin of which extends from the side of the nose to the zygomatic bone; its main function is to elevate the upper lip

Subject: absent levator labii superioris muscle
Value: missing the facial muscle that is shaped like a broad, flat sheet, the origin of which extends from the side of the nose to the zygomatic bone; its main function is to elevate the upper lip

Subject: abnormal scalp morphology
Value: <any structural anomaly of the soft tissue envelope of the cranial vault that extends from the external occipital protuberance and superior nuchal lines to the supraorbital margins; it consists of 5 layers: the skin (and head hair), connective tissue, epicranial aponeurosis, loose areolar tissue, and pericranium; the first 3 layers are bound together as a single unit that can move along the loose areolar tissue over the pericranium, which is adherent to the calvaria>

Subject: abnormal oral epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the stratified squamous epithelium that forms part of the oral mucosa and lines the inner aspect of the oral cavity; depending on the mouth region, the epithelium may be non-keratinized or keratinized; non-keratinized squamous epithelium covers the soft palate, inner lips, inner cheeks, and the floor of the mouth, and ventral surface of the tongue; keratinized squamous epithelium is present in the attached gingiva and hard palate as well as areas of the dorsal surface of the tongue

Subject: abnormal nasal fin morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the transient epithelial seam that develops by fusion between the epithelial linings of the medial and lateral nasal swellings; shortly after its formation the nasal fin regresses and is replaced by mesenchyme, with exception of its most posterior portion which remains as the bucconasal membrane

Subject: persistent nasal fins
Value: failure of the nasal fins to rupture during development leading to choanal obstruction/atresia

Subject: abnormal oronasal membrane morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thin, transient epithelial sheet which separates the primordial nasal cavity from the stomatodeum; in mammals, bucconasal membranes demarcate the locations of the paired primitive choanae

Subject: persistent oronasal membrane
Value: failure of the oronasal membrane to rupture during development leading to choanal obstruction

Subject: abnormal zygomaticus muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the zygomaticus major and/or minor facial muscles that originate from the body of the zygoma and pass downwards to insert into the corner of the mouth and lateral aspect of the upper lip, respectively; these muscles receive their nerve supply on their deep surface from the zygomatic and buccal branches of the facial nerve and lift the corners of the mouth

Subject: abnormal minor zygomaticus muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the slender band of muscle on each side of the face that arises from the zygomatic bone, inserts into the upper lip between the zygomaticus major and the levator labii superioris, and acts to raise the upper lip upward and laterally

Subject: abnormal major zygomaticus muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the slender band of muscle on each side of the face that arises from the zygomatic bone, inserts into the orbicularis oris and skin at the corner of the mouth, and acts to pull the corner of the mouth upward and backward when smiling or laughing

Subject: abnormal epitympanic recess morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the upper portion of the tympanic cavity located above the tympanic membrane; it contains the head of the malleus and the body of the incus

Subject: round snout
Value: appearance of the anterior facial part of the face or muzzle containing the oral and nasal regions is more circular than usual

Subject: broad snout
Value: increased width of the anterior facial part of the face or muzzle containing the oral and nasal regions

Subject: small snout
Value: decreased size of the anterior facial part of the face or muzzle containing the oral and nasal regions

Subject: narrow snout
Value: decreased width of the anterior facial part of the face or muzzle containing the oral and nasal regions

Subject: downturned snout
Value: muzzle has a curve or tilt such that the tip points downwards

Subject: short philtrum
Value: decreased length of the vertical groove found on the median line of the upper lip

Subject: abnormal intermaxillary suture morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the anterior median suture between the two maxillae of the upper jawbone, located between the inferior border of the nasal aperture and the central incisor teeth; it usually ossifies later in life and becomes a synostosis

Subject: abnormal internasal suture morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cranial suture found between the left and right nasal bones

Subject: abnormal nasomaxillary suture morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cranial suture found between the nasal bone and the frontal process of the maxilla

Subject: small nasal septum
Value: reduced size of the dividing wall that runs down the midline of the nose, separating the nasal cavity into the two nostrils

Subject: nasal septum hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the nasal septum, usually due to a reduced number of cells

Subject: deviated nasal septum
Value: displacement of the nasal septum in which the top of the cartilaginous ridge leans to the left or the right, causing obstruction of the affected nasal passage; normally, the septum lies centrally, and thus the nasal passages are symmetrical

Subject: abnormal nasal septum cartilage morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the hyaline cartilage of the nasal septum that is somewhat quadrilateral in shape, thicker at its margins than at its center, and completes the separation between the nasal cavities

Subject: absent nasal septum cartilage
Value: absence of the hyaline cartilage of the nasal septum that is somewhat quadrilateral in shape, thicker at its margins than at its center, and completes the separation between the nasal cavities

Subject: nasal septum cartilage hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the nasal septum cartilage, usually due to a reduced number of cells

Subject: short nasal septum
Value: reduced length of the dividing wall that runs down the midline of the nose, separating the nasal cavity into the two nostrils

Subject: large nasal septum
Value: increased size of the dividing wall that runs down the midline of the nose, separating the nasal cavity into the two nostrils

Subject: thick nasal septum
Value: increased width of the dividing wall that runs down the midline of the nose, separating the nasal cavity into the two nostrils

Subject: thin nasal septum
Value: decreased width of the dividing wall that runs down the midline of the nose, separating the nasal cavity into the two nostrils

Subject: absent zygomaticus muscle
Value: absence of the zygomaticus major and/or minor facial muscles that originate from the body of the zygoma and pass downwards to insert into the corner of the mouth and lateral aspect of the upper lip, respectively

Subject: abnormal intrinsic tongue muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the four paired muscles that originate and insert within the tongue, running along its length; these muscles alter the shape of the tongue by lengthening and shortening it, curling and uncurling its apex and edges, and flattening and rounding its surface; they include the superior longitudinal muscle, the inferior longitudinal muscle, the vertical muscle, and the transverse muscle

Subject: abnormal extrinsic tongue muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the four paired muscles that originate outside of and insert into the tongue and act to alter the position of the tongue, allowing for protrusion, retraction, and side-to-side movement; these muscles include the genioglossus, the hyoglossus (often including the chondroglossus), the styloglossus, and the palatoglossus

Subject: abnormal genioglossus muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the paired, fan-shaped extrinsic tongue muscle which forms the majority of the body of the tongue, arises from the mental spine of the mandible and inserts into the hyoid bone and the bottom of the tongue; its action protracts and depresses the tongue

Subject: abnormal styloglossus muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the paired extrinsic tongue muscle that arises from the anterior surface of the styloid process of the mastoid bone and the proximal quarter of the stylohyoid ligament; it passes inferiorly and anteriorly to insert into the side and inferior aspects of the tongue; the muscle fibers of styloglossus merge with those of the hyoglossus; its action aids to retract the tongue and draw up the sides of the tongue to create a trough for swallowing

Subject: abnormal hyoglossus muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thin, quadrilateral extrinsic tongue muscle that arises from the side of the body and from the whole length of the greater cornu of the hyoid bone, and passes almost vertically upward to enter the side of the tongue, between the styloglossus and the inferior longitudinal muscle of the tongue; its action depresses and retracts the tongue and makes the dorsum more convex

Subject: gonial bone hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size of the investing bone that lies on the surface of the malleus, usually due to an increased number of cells

Subject: muscle fasciculation
Value: small, local, involuntary muscle contractions affecting a small number of muscle fibers, often causing a flicker of movement visible under the skin; fasciculations result from increased irritability of an axon (which in turn is often a manifestation of disease of a motor neuron); this leads to sporadic discharges of all the muscle fibers controlled by the axon in isolation from other motor units

Subject: facial muscle fasciculation
Value: fasciculations affecting the musculature of the face

Subject: tongue muscle fasciculation
Value: fasciculations affecting the tongue muscle

Subject: abnormal piriform aperture morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the pear-shaped bony inlet comprising the most anterior and narrowest bony portion of the nasal airway, formed by the nasal and maxillary bones; the maxillary spines mark the inferior margin of the piriform aperture

Subject: piriform aperture stenosis
Value: abnormal narrowing of the pear-shaped bony inlet comprising the most anterior and narrowest bony portion of the nasal airway; an unusual cause of neonatal nasal obstruction that is due to bony overgrowth of the nasal lateral process of the maxilla

Subject: jaw cysts
Value: presence of saccular lesions lined with epithelium and contained within pathologically formed cavities in the jaw; also non-epithelial cysts (pseudocysts) as they apply to the jaw, e.g., traumatic or solitary cyst, static bone cavity, and aneurysmal bone cyst; true jaw cysts are classified as odontogenic or non-odontogenic

Subject: mandibular cysts
Value: presence of saccular lesions lined with epithelium and contained within pathologically formed cavities in the mandible

Subject: maxillary cysts
Value: presence of saccular lesions lined with epithelium and contained within pathologically formed cavities in the maxilla

Subject: hyperostosis
Value: excessive growth or abnormal thickening of bone tissue; it may lead to exostosis

Subject: mandibular hyperostosis
Value: hyperostosis (bony overgrowth) of the mandible

Subject: abnormal soft palate muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the five paired muscles of the soft palate that play important roles in swallowing and breathing; these muscles include the tensor veli palatini, palatoglossus, palatopharyngeus, levator veli palatini, and the musculus uvulae muscles

Subject: abnormal cranial vertex morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the midline bony landmark at the most superior part of the calvaria, near the midpoint of the sagittal suture (i.e. between the bregma and lambda)

Subject: middle ear polyps
Value: development of numerous growths that are connected to and protrude from the mucous membrane of the middle ear

Subject: abnormal tubotympanic recess morphology
Value: any structural morphology of the elongate recess derived from the first pharyngeal pouch; its distal part contributes to the formation of the tympanic membrane, its proximal part elongates to form the auditory tube, and its cavity gives rise to the tympanic cavity and mastoid antrum

Subject: absent tubotympanic recess
Value: absence of the elongate recess derived from the first pharyngeal pouch; its distal part contributes to the formation of the tympanic membrane, its proximal part elongates to form the auditory tube, and its cavity gives rise to the tympanic cavity and mastoid antrum

Subject: abnormal craniofacial suture morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the dense, fibrous connective tissue joints between cranial and/or facial bones

Subject: abnormal facial suture morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the dense, fibrous connective tissue joints between facial bones

Subject: abnormal zygomaticomaxillary suture morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the suture between the zygomatic process of the maxilla and the maxillary margin of the zygomatic bone

Subject: abnormal mandibular canal morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the canal located within the internal aspect of the mandible which contains the inferior alveolar nerve, artery and the vein; it starts at the mandibular foramen, on the lingual side of the ramus, continues on the buccal surface of the body of the mandible, and ends at the mental foramen

Subject: absent mandibular canal
Value: absence of the canal that is normally located within the internal aspect of the mandible and contains the inferior alveolar nerve, artery and the vein

Subject: abnormal mandibular foramen morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the opening located on the medial surface of the ramus of the mandible that is the entrance to the mandibular canal; it transmits the inferior alveolar nerve, a branch of the posterior division of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve that supplies all the ipsilateral teeth up to the midline

Subject: absent mandibular foramen
Value: absence of the opening that is normally located on the medial surface of the ramus of the mandible and forms the entrance to the mandibular canal

Subject: abnormal mental foramen morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small opening located on the anterior surface of the mandible; the mental nerve, a terminal branch of inferior alveolar nerve, and the mental artery leave the mandibular canal through it

Subject: absent mental foramen
Value: absence of the small opening located on the anterior surface of the mandible; normally, the mental nerve, a terminal branch of inferior alveolar nerve, and the mental artery leave the mandibular canal through it

Subject: abnormal extraocular muscle development
Value: any anomaly in the differentiation of any of the striated muscles that are located within the orbit but are extrinsic and separate from the eyeball and control the movements of the eyeball and the superior eyelid; these include the superior rectus, inferior rectus, medial rectus, lateral rectus, inferior oblique, superior oblique, and levator palpebrae superioris

Subject: abnormal intraocular muscle development
Value: any anomaly in the differentiation of any of the smooth muscles located within the eye

Subject: abnormal suprahyoid muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the four muscles located above the hyoid bone in the neck; these muscles include the digastric, stylohyoid, geniohyoid, and mylohyoid muscles and are all pharyngeal muscles, with the exception of the geniohyoid muscle; they have different actions but in general assist in elevating the hyoid bone and widening the esophagus during swallowing

Subject: absent optic pit
Value: absence of either or both of the two pits that appear bilaterally in the region destined to become the forebrain as the cranial neural folds fuse; these optic pits or sulci continue to deepen laterally and bulge from the two sides of the forebrain to become the optic vesicles

Subject: small optic pit
Value: reduced size of either or both of the two pits that appear bilaterally in the region destined to become the forebrain as the cranial neural folds fuse; these optic pits or sulci continue to deepen laterally and bulge from the two sides of the forebrain to become the optic vesicles

Subject: abnormal chin morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the inferior portion of the face lying inferior to the lower lip and including the central prominence of the lower jaw

Subject: short chin
Value: decreased vertical dimension of the inferior portion of the face lying inferior to the lower lip and including the central prominence of the lower jaw

Subject: round head
Value: overall shape of the head is more circular than usual as viewed from the front

Subject: abnormal cheek morphology
Value: any anomaly of the cheek - one of two bilateral soft tissue structures located in the midface region between the zygoma and the mandible

Subject: prominent cheeks
Value: increased prominence or roundness of the soft tissues between the zygomata and the mandible

Subject: narrow maxilla
Value: reduced width of the upper bony framework of the mouth where the superior teeth are held

Subject: small frontonasal prominence
Value: reduced size of the unpaired embryonic process that is formed from the tissues surrounding the forebrain vesicle and develops into the forehead and bridge of the nose/snout

Subject: frontonasal prominence hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the unpaired embryonic process that is formed from the tissues surrounding the forebrain vesicle and develops into the forehead and bridge of the nose/snout

Subject: broad frontonasal prominence
Value: increased width of the unpaired embryonic process that is formed from the tissues surrounding the forebrain vesicle and develops into the forehead and bridge of the nose/snout

Subject: narrow frontonasal prominence
Value: decreased width of the unpaired embryonic process that is formed from the tissues surrounding the forebrain vesicle and develops into the forehead and bridge of the nose/snout

Subject: vertical orbital dystopia
Value: the orbits do not lie on the same horizontal plane, that is, one eye is lower than the other

Subject: abnormal dental arch morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of either of the two arches (crescent arrangements) of teeth, one on each jaw, that together constitute the dentition

Subject: abnormal maxillary dental arch morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the dental arch formed by the teeth of the maxilla (upper jaw bone)

Subject: abnormal mandibular dental arch morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the dental arch formed by the teeth of the mandible (lower jaw bone)

Subject: increased tongue papilloma incidence
Value: greater than the expected number of benign tumors consisting of villous or arborescent outgrowths of fibrovascular stroma covered by neoplastic epithelial cells in the tongue

Subject: small mandibular condyloid process
Value: reduced size of the round bump of bone and constricted neck portion that arises from the upper surface of the mandibular ramus (perpendicular portion) and articulates with the articular disk of the temporomandibular joint

Subject: mandibular condyloid process hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the mandibular condyloid process

Subject: abnormal palatomaxillary suture morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the transverse suture across the back of the hard palate that separates the maxillary shelf of the palate from the horizontal plates of the palatine bones

Subject: abnormal temporal bone zygomatic process morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the long, arched process that projects from the lower region of the squamous part of the temporal bone and articulates with the zygomatic bone; this process is at first directed lateralward, its two surfaces looking upward and downward; it then appears as if twisted inward upon itself, and runs forward, its surfaces now looking medialward and lateralward

Subject: frontal bossing
Value: bilateral bulging of the lateral frontal bone prominences with relative sparing of the midline; this is not the same as prominent forehead

Subject: cranial bossing
Value: abnormal prominence or protrusion of various bones of the skull; most often occurs in the frontal bones beneath the forehead

Subject: occipital bossing
Value: an area of marked prominence or protrusion in the occipital region at the back of the skull

Subject: parietal bossing
Value: an area of marked prominence or protrusion in the parietal region

Subject: small vomer bone
Value: reduced size of the triangular flat bone of the nasal septum

Subject: decreased basicranium angle
Value: a decrease in the expected angle formed by a line representing the floor of the anterior cranial fossa intersecting a line representing the axis of the clivus of the base of the skull

Subject: agnathia
Value: congenital, complete or partial, absence of one or both jaws; total absence of the maxilla and/or mandible is extremely rare in mammals; when agnathia occurs, it may be combined with cyclopia or synotia

Subject: absent mandibular ramus
Value: absence of the upturned perpendicular extremity of the mandible

Subject: retrogenia
Value: abnormal posterior-shifted positioning of the chin in relation to the rest of the facial skeleton; occlusion is normal

Subject: abnormal foramen rotundum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the circular aperture (foramen) located in the middle cranial fossa, inferomedial to the superior orbital fissure at the base of greater wing of sphenoid; its medial border is formed by the lateral wall of the sphenoid sinus; it runs downwards and laterally in an oblique path and joins the middle cranial fossa with the pterygopalatine fossa; it transmits the maxillary branch of trigeminal nerve, artery of foramen rotundum, and emissary veins

Subject: abnormal cranial foramen ovale morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the oval-shaped opening in the middle cranial fossa located at the posterior base of the greater wing of the sphenoid bone, lateral to the lingual; it transmits the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, accessory meningeal artery, emissary veins between the cavernous sinuses and pterygoid plexus, otic ganglion, and occasionally the nervus spinosus and lesser petrosal nerve

Subject: mandibular retrognathia
Value: abnormal posterior-shifted positioning of the lower jaw (mandible) relative to the facial skeleton and soft tissues

Subject: maxillary retrognathia
Value: abnormal posterior-shifted positioning of the upper jaw (maxilla) relative to the facial skeleton and soft tissues

Subject: thin frontal bone
Value: reduced thickness of the single bone forming the forehead and roof of the eye orbit

Subject: anterior cranium occultum
Value: presence of an abnormal skin-covered gap in the front of the head, usually due to increased distance between the frontal bones

Subject: thin interparietal bone
Value: reduced thickness of the bone of the cranium that lies above and anterior to the occipital bone in some mammals

Subject: thick neurocranium
Value: increased thickness of the bones of the skull enclosing the brain

Subject: thin neurocranium
Value: decreased thickness of the bones of the skull enclosing the brain

Subject: short parietal bone
Value: length reduction of the paired membranous bones located between the frontal and occipital bones that are large, curved and quadrilateral in outline, articulate with each other at the midline in the sagittal suture, and form most of the superior and lateral aspects of the cranium

Subject: thin parietal bone
Value: reduced thickness of the paired membranous bones located between the frontal and occipital bones that are large, curved and quadrilateral in outline, articulate with each other at the midline in the sagittal suture, and form most of the superior and lateral aspects of the cranium

Subject: broad supraoccipital bone
Value: increased width of the bone on the dorsal side of the great foramen of the skull, which usually forms a part of the occipital in the adult, but is distinct in the young

Subject: small mandibular coronoid process
Value: reduced size of the thin, flattened, triangular eminence that arises from the upper surface of the mandibular ramus (perpendicular portion)

Subject: short mandibular coronoid process
Value: length reduction or truncation of the thin, flattened, triangular eminence that arises from the upper surface of the mandibular ramus (perpendicular portion)

Subject: mandibular coronoid process hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the thin, flattened, triangular eminence that arises from the upper surface of the mandibular ramus (perpendicular portion)

Subject: occipital bone hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the bone at the lower, posterior part of the skull

Subject: enlarged occipital bone
Value: increased size of the bone at the lower, posterior part of the skull

Subject: broad occipital bone
Value: increased width of the bone at the lower, posterior part of the skull

Subject: flat occipital bone
Value: abnormal flatness of the bone at the lower, posterior part of the skull

Subject: absent soft palate
Value: absence of the musculomembranous fold that partly separates the mouth and pharynx, located behind the hard palate in the adult

Subject: short soft palate
Value: reduced length of the musculomembranous fold that partly separates the mouth and pharynx, located behind the hard palate in the adult

Subject: abnormal tensor veli palatini muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the broad, thin, ribbon-like muscle that tenses the soft palate

Subject: small tensor veli palatini muscle
Value: reduced size of the broad, thin, ribbon-like muscle that tenses the soft palate

Subject: abnormal levator veli palatini muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the paired cylindrical muscle that forms a V-shaped sling behind and above the soft palate; it originates from the apex of the inferior surface of the petrous temporal bone and the medial rim of the auditory tube, and inserts into the palatine aponeurosis between the two heads of palatopharyngeus; it elevates and laterally deviates the soft palate; it also aids the tensor veli palatini in opening the auditory tube on swallowing to allow equalization of pressure between the middle ear and pharynx

Subject: small levator veli palatini muscle
Value: reduced size of the paired cylindrical muscle that forms a V-shaped sling behind and above the soft palate; it originates from the apex of the inferior surface of the petrous temporal bone and the medial rim of the auditory tube, and inserts into the palatine aponeurosis between the two heads of palatopharyngeus; it elevates and laterally deviates the soft palate; it also aids the tensor veli palatini in opening the auditory tube on swallowing  to allow equalization of pressure between the middle ear and pharynx

Subject: abnormal infraorbital foramen morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of either of a pair of external openings (foramina) in the maxillary bone of the skull located below the infraorbital margin of the orbit; it transmits the infraorbital artery and vein, and the infraorbital nerve, a branch of the maxillary nerve

Subject: outer ear hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of all or part of the outer ear

Subject: jaw transformation
Value: homeotic transformation of either jaw to adopt the fate of the other

Subject: lower jaw to upper jaw transformation
Value: homeotic transformation of lower jaw (mandibular) elements into upper jaw-like (maxillary) structures

Subject: upper jaw to lower jaw transformation
Value: homeotic transformation of upper jaw (maxillary) elements into lower jaw-like (mandibular) structures

Subject: abnormal maxillary frontal process morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the upward extension from the body of the maxilla which articulates with the frontal bone; the frontal process has a vertical ridge which constitutes the medial border of the orbit (anterior lacrimal crest); posteriorly it forms the lacrimal groove together with the lacrimal bone; superomedially it is in close contact with the anterior ethmoidal sinuses

Subject: abnormal maxillary zygomatic process morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the rough triangular eminence situated at the angle of separation of the anterior, zygomatic, and orbital surfaces; in front, it forms part of the anterior surface; behind, it is concave, and forms part of the infratemporal fossa; above, it is rough and serrated for articulation with the zygomatic bone; below, it presents the prominent arched border which marks the division between the anterior and infratemporal surfaces

Subject: small ethmoid bone
Value: reduced size of the single midline facial bone that separates the nasal cavity from the brain, located at the roof of the nose between the two orbits

Subject: abnormal cribriform plate morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the sieve-like structure located between the anterior cranial fossa and the nasal cavity; it is a part of the ethmoid bone and supports the olfactory bulb, which lies in the olfactory fossa; it is perforated by foramina for the passage of the olfactory nerves and the anterior ethmoidal nerves to the upper part of the nasal septum, the latter of those to the superior nasal concha

Subject: small cribriform plate
Value: reduced size of the sieve-like structure located between the anterior cranial fossa and the nasal cavity; it is a part of the ethmoid bone and supports the olfactory bulb, which lies in the olfactory fossa

Subject: abnormal cranial fossa morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the three large depressions in the posterior, middle, and anterior aspects of the floor of the cranial cavity; each cranial fossa accommodates a different part of the brain

Subject: abnormal anterior cranial fossa
Value: any structural anomaly of the depression in the floor of the cranial base which houses the projecting frontal lobes of the brain; it is formed by the orbital plates of the frontal, the cribriform plate of the ethmoid, and the small wings and front part of the body of the sphenoid; it is limited behind by the posterior borders of the small wings of the sphenoid and by the anterior margin of the chiasmatic groove; the lesser wings of the sphenoid separate the anterior and middle fossae

Subject: abnormal middle cranial fossa morphology
Value: <any structural anomaly of the butterfly-shaped depression which is centrally located in the cranial floor, narrow in the middle and wider laterally, and houses the temporal lobes of the cerebrum and the pituitary gland; it is separated from the posterior fossa by the clivus and the petrous crest; it is bounded: in front, by the posterior margins of the lesser wings of the sphenoid bone, the anterior clinoid processes, and the ridge forming the anterior margin of the chiasmatic groove; behind, by the superior angles of the petrous portions of the temporal bones and the dorsum sellae; laterally, by the temporal squamae, sphenoidal angles of the parietals, and greater wings of the sphenoid; it is traversed by the squamosal, sphenoparietal, sphenosquamosal, and sphenopetrosal sutures>

Subject: abnormal posterior cranial fossa morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the most inferior and deepest of the cranial fossae, located between the foramen magnum and tentorium cerebelli, which houses the brainstem and cerebellum; it is bounded anteriorly and medially by the dorsum sellae of the sphenoid bone; anteriorly and laterally by the superior border of the petrous part of the temporal bone; and posteriorly by the internal surface of the squamous part of the occipital bone; its floor consists of the mastoid part of the temporal bone and the squamous, condylar and basilar parts of the occipital bone

Subject: abnormal cranial foramen morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the openings or orifices (foramina) in the skull through which cranial nerves, arteries, veins and other structures pass into and out of the cranium

Subject: abnormal mandibular fossa morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the depression in the temporal bone that articulates with the mandible; it is a part of the temporomandibular joint and lodges the condyle of the mandible; in the temporal bone, the mandibular fossa is bounded anteriorly by the articular tubercle and posteriorly by the tympanic portion of the temporal bone, which separates it from the external acoustic meatus; the fossa is divided into two parts by a narrow slit, the petrotympanic fissure

Subject: enlarged pharyngeal arch
Value: increased size of one or more of the transient structures of the embryo that develop into regions of the head, neck and ears

Subject: abnormal face development
Value: any anomaly in the process in which the anatomical structures of the face are generated and organized

Subject: absent primary palate
Value: missing the initial portion of the palate formed from the intermaxillary segment

Subject: small neurocranium
Value: decreased size of the bones of the skull enclosing the brain

Subject: enlarged neurocranium
Value: increased size of the bones of the skull enclosing the brain

Subject: absent maxillary zygomatic process
Value: absence of the rough triangular eminence situated at the angle of separation of the anterior, zygomatic, and orbital surfaces; in front, it forms part of the anterior surface; behind, it is concave, and forms part of the infratemporal fossa; above, it is rough and serrated for articulation with the zygomatic bone; below, it presents the prominent arched border which marks the division between the anterior and infratemporal surfaces

Subject: enlarged maxillary zygomatic process
Value: increased size of the rough triangular eminence situated at the angle of separation of the anterior, zygomatic, and orbital surfaces; in front, it forms part of the anterior surface; behind, it is concave, and forms part of the infratemporal fossa; above, it is rough and serrated for articulation with the zygomatic bone; below, it presents the prominent arched border which marks the division between the anterior and infratemporal surfaces

Subject: abnormal temporal bone petrous part morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the dense, pyramid-shaped portion of the temporal bone that is wedged in at the base of the skull between the sphenoid and occipital bones; directed medially, forward, and a little upward, it presents a base, an apex, three surfaces, and three angles, and houses in its interior, the components of the inner ear; the petrous portion is among the most basal elements of the skull and forms part of the endocranium

Subject: abnormal temporal bone tympanic part morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the curved plate of bone that is situated inferiorly to the squamous part and anteriorly to the mastoid part of the temporal bone; it surrounds the external auditory meatus, forming the anterior wall, floor and some of the posterior wall of the bony external acoustic meatus; its lateral border gives the attachment to the cartilaginous part of the external acoustic meatus; its anteroinferior surface forms the posterior boundary of the mandibular fossa

Subject: abnormal tegmen tympani morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thin plate of bone which separates the middle ear (tympanic) cavity from the dura of the middle cranial fossa and forms the roof of the middle ear cavity; it is formed in part by the petrous portion of the temporal bone, and the squamous portion of the temporal bone

Subject: styloid process hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the slender needle-like pointed projection that runs downward and slightly forward from the base of the inferior surface of the petrous portion of the temporal bone where it joins the tympanic portion; it gives attachment to the styloglossus, stylohyoid, and stylopharyngeus muscles and the stylohyoid and stylomandibular ligaments

Subject: short styloid process
Value: length reduction or truncation of the slender needle-like pointed projection that runs downward and slightly forward from the base of the inferior surface of the petrous portion of the temporal bone where it joins the tympanic portion; it gives attachment to the styloglossus, stylohyoid, and stylopharyngeus muscles and the stylohyoid and stylomandibular ligaments

Subject: abnormal anterior head development
Value: any anomaly in the process in which the anatomical structures of the anterior part of the head are generated and organized

Subject: abnormal periocular mesenchyme apoptosis
Value: change in the timing or the number of cells of the periocular mesenchyme undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: decreased periocular mesenchyme apoptosis
Value: reduction in the number of cells of the periocular mesenchyme undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: temporomandibular joint ankylosis
Value: fusion or adherence of the mandibular condyle to the base of the skull, resulting in limitation of jaw opening; true ankylosis may be bony or fibrous; in bony ankylosis, the condyle or ramus is attached to the temporal or zygomatic bone by an osseous bridge; in fibrous ankylosis a soft tissue (fibrous) union of joint components occurs while the bone components appear normal

Subject: glossopalatal ankylosis
Value: presence of an intraoral band of variable thickness attaching the tongue to the hard palate or maxillary alveolar ridge

Subject: absent temporal bone petrous part
Value: absence of the dense, pyramid-shaped portion of the temporal bone that is wedged in at the base of the skull between the sphenoid and occipital bones; directed medially, forward, and a little upward, it presents a base, an apex, three surfaces, and three angles, and houses in its interior, the components of the inner ear; the petrous portion is among the most basal elements of the skull and forms part of the endocranium

Subject: abnormal temporomandibular joint disk morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the oval, biconcave, avascular fibrocartilaginous structure located between the condyle of the mandible and the mandibular (glenoid) fossa of the temporal bone; the disk provides the gliding surface for the mandibular condyle, resulting in smooth joint movement; it splits the temporomandibular joint into two synovial joint cavities, each lined by a synovial membrane, and separates translational and rotational motion

Subject: absent temporomandibular joint disk
Value: missing the oval, biconcave, avascular fibrocartilaginous structure located between the condyle of the mandible and the mandibular (glenoid) fossa of the temporal bone; the disk provides the gliding surface for the mandibular condyle, resulting in smooth joint movement; it splits the temporomandibular joint into two synovial joint cavities, each lined by a synovial membrane, and separates translational and rotational motion

Subject: accelerated temporomandibular joint osteoarthritis
Value: earlier onset or more rapid progression of a degenerative condition of the temporomandibular joint that results from breakdown of joint cartilage and underlying bone; erosive lesions and joint space narrowing usually indicate acute or early changes, whereas sclerosis, flattening, subchondral cysts, and osteophytes may indicate late changes

Subject: abnormal palatine bone perpendicular plate morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the part of the palatine bone that extends vertically upward from the horizontal lamina; it forms part of the lateral wall of the nasal cavity

Subject: absent sixth pharyngeal arch artery
Value: failure to develop or absence of the sixth pharyngeal arch artery

Subject: absent third pharyngeal arch artery
Value: failure to develop or absence of the third pharyngeal arch artery

Subject: third pharyngeal arch artery hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the third pharyngeal arch artery, usually due to a reduced number of cells

Subject: enlarged third pharyngeal arch artery
Value: increased size of the third pharyngeal arch artery

Subject: dilated third pharyngeal arch artery
Value: stretched or widened aperture of the luminal space of the third pharyngeal arch artery

Subject: absent second pharyngeal arch artery
Value: failure to develop or absence of the second pharyngeal arch artery

Subject: absent fourth pharyngeal arch artery
Value: failure to develop or absence of the fourth pharyngeal arch artery

Subject: fourth pharyngeal arch artery hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of the fourth pharyngeal arch artery, usually due to a reduced number of cells

Subject: small maxillary prominence
Value: reduced size of the paired dorsal prominences formed by bifurcation of the first pharyngeal arches in the embryo that unite with the ipsilateral medial nasal process to form the upper jaw

Subject: maxillary prominence hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the paired dorsal prominences formed by bifurcation of the first pharyngeal arches in the embryo that unite with the ipsilateral medial nasal process to form the upper jaw

Subject: absent maxillary prominence
Value: absence of the paired dorsal prominences formed by bifurcation of the first pharyngeal arches in the embryo that unite with the ipsilateral medial nasal process to form the upper jaw

Subject: enlarged maxillary prominence
Value: increased size of the paired dorsal prominences formed by bifurcation of the first pharyngeal arches in the embryo that unite with the ipsilateral medial nasal process to form the upper jaw

Subject: small mandibular prominence
Value: reduced size of the paired ventral prominences formed by bifurcation of the first pharyngeal arches in the embryo; the two prominences unite ventrally and fuse to form the mandible and lower lip

Subject: mandibular prominence hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the paired ventral prominences formed by bifurcation of the first pharyngeal arches in the embryo; the two prominences unite ventrally and fuse to form the mandible and lower lip

Subject: enlarged mandibular prominence
Value: increased size of the paired ventral prominences formed by bifurcation of the first pharyngeal arches in the embryo; the two prominences unite ventrally and fuse to form the mandible and lower lip

Subject: absent coronal suture
Value: failure to form the dense, fibrous connective tissue joint between the parietal bones and the frontal bone

Subject: premature coronal suture closure
Value: early closure of the coronal suture of the skull

Subject: wide coronal suture
Value: an abnormally increased width of the coronal suture for age-related norms

Subject: absent sagittal suture
Value: failure to form the dense, fibrous connective tissue joint between the two parietal bones of the skull

Subject: wide sagittal suture
Value: an abnormally increased width of the sagittal suture for age-related norms

Subject: premature sagittal suture closure
Value: early closure of the sagittal suture of the skull; premature closure of this suture results in a long, narrow, and boat-shaped skull (scaphocephaly)

Subject: absent lambdoid suture
Value: failure to form the dense, fibrous connective tissue joint between the superior border of the occipital bone and the posterior borders of the right and left parietal bones

Subject: premature lambdoid suture closure
Value: early closure of the lambdoid suture of the skull

Subject: wide lambdoid suture
Value: an abnormally increased width of the lambdoid suture for age-related norms

Subject: premature squamoparietal suture closure
Value: early closure of the squamoparietal suture of the skull

Subject: cranial suture sclerosis
Value: an increased density in one or more cranial sutures following obliteration

Subject: coronal suture sclerosis
Value: an increased density in the coronal suture following obliteration

Subject: lambdoid suture sclerosis
Value: an increased density in the lambdoid suture following obliteration

Subject: sagittal suture sclerosis
Value: an increased density in the sagittal suture following obliteration

Subject: abnormal anterior fontanelle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the diamond-shaped membranous interval between the two frontal and two parietal bones of the developing fetal skull; it is the largest fontanelle, located at the bregma, at the junction of the coronal, sagittal and metopic (frontal) sutures of the cranium

Subject: abnormal posterior fontanelle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the triangle-shaped membranous interval between the pair of parietal bones and the occipital bone; it is located at the lambda, at the junction between the sagittal suture and the lambdoid suture

Subject: abnormal sphenoid fontanelle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small membranous interval located on the side of the skull, at the site of apposition of the frontal, parietal, and squamous part of the temporal bone and sphenoid bone

Subject: abnormal mastoid fontanelle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small membranous interval between the posterolateral angle of the parietal bone and the mastoid regions of the temporal and occipital bones in the developing skull

Subject: premature metopic suture closure
Value: early closure of the metopic suture of the skull; premature closure of this suture compromises the transverse growth of both the frontal bones and can cause a narrow, triangular shaped forehead (trigonocephaly) that is associated with orbital hypotelorism

Subject: trigonocephaly
Value: presence of a wedge-shaped, or triangular head, with the apex of the triangle at the midline of the forehead and the base of the triangle at the occiput; trigonocephaly can be caused by premature fusion of the metopic suture

Subject: abnormal jugum limitans morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bony ridge that, in rodents, runs paracoronally and divides the metopic (interfrontal) suture transversely into the anterior and posterior frontal sutures; it is a landmark between the posterior and anterior frontal sutures

Subject: absent jugum limitans
Value: missing the bony ridge that, in rodents, runs paracoronally and divides the metopic (interfrontal) suture transversely into the anterior and posterior frontal sutures

Subject: delayed sagittal suture closure
Value: late onset of fusion of the sagittal suture of the skull

Subject: enlarged Meckel's cartilage
Value: increased size of the cartilage bar in the mandibular arch that forms a temporary supporting structure in the embryonic mandible and gives rise to middle ear bones and sphenomandibular and anterior malleolar ligaments

Subject: Meckel's cartilage hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due to an increased number of cells, of the cartilage bar in the mandibular arch that forms a temporary supporting structure in the embryonic mandible and gives rise to middle ear bones and sphenomandibular and anterior malleolar ligaments

Subject: Meckel's cartilage hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or decreased size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the cartilage bar in the mandibular arch that forms a temporary supporting structure in the embryonic mandible and gives rise to middle ear bones and sphenomandibular and anterior malleolar ligaments

Subject: short zygomatic arch
Value: decreased length of the bony arch that, in vertebrates, extends along the side or front of the skull beneath the eye socket and is formed by the temporal process of the zygomatic bone and the zygomatic process of the temporal bone

Subject: thick zygomatic arch
Value: increased thickness of the bony arch that, in vertebrates, extends along the side or front of the skull beneath the eye socket and is formed by the temporal process of the zygomatic bone and the zygomatic process of the temporal bone

Subject: zygomatic arch hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the bony arch that, in vertebrates, extends along the side or front of the skull beneath the eye socket and is formed by the temporal process of the zygomatic bone and the zygomatic process of the temporal bone

Subject: abnormal frontal bone nasal part morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the smallest part of the frontal bone which is connected to the frontal processes of the maxilla and the nasal bones, forming the stem (root) of the nose

Subject: abnormal frontal bone squamous part morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the vertical and largest, flat part of the frontal bone which forms the forehead and comprises the frontal sinuses; this part contains the supraorbital notch, the superciliary arches, the glabella, and the zygomatic processes which arise caudolaterally from the squamous part and articulate with the zygomatic bone

Subject: abnormal frontal bone zygomatic process morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the inferior extension of the squamous part of the frontal bone that joins with the frontal process of the zygomatic bone

Subject: abnormal frontal bone orbital part morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the horizontal part of the frontal bone composed of two thin triangular plates, the orbital plates, which form the vaults of the orbits and the ethmoidal sinuses, and are separated from one another by a median gap, the ethmoidal notch; this part also comprises the anterior and posterior ethmoidal foramina

Subject: absent paranasal sinus
Value: missing one or more of the paired air-filled cavities surrounded by the bones of the face that are lined by mucous membranes and are continuous with the nasal cavity

Subject: small presphenoid bone
Value: reduced size of the anterior part of the body of the sphenoid bone in front of the basisphenoid; it is usually a separate bone in the young or fetus, but becomes a part of the sphenoid in the adult

Subject: short facial bone
Value: length reduction or truncation of one or more facial bones

Subject: absent facial bone
Value: failure to develop or absence of one or more facial bones

Subject: facial bone hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size of one or more facial bones, usually due to a reduced number of cells

Subject: large posterior fontanelle
Value: an abnormally increased size of the triangle-shaped membranous interval between the pair of parietal bones and the occipital bone for age-related norms; the posterior fontanelle is located at the lambda, at the junction between the sagittal suture and the lambdoid suture

Subject: large fontanelles
Value: an abnormally increased size of one or more fontanelles for age-related norms, generally resulting from delayed or incomplete fontanelle closure

Subject: small fontanelles
Value: an abnormally decreased size of one or more fontanelles for age-related norms
