Subject: premature facial suture closure
Value: early closure of one or more of the joints (sutures) between facial bones

Subject: premature zygomaticomaxillary suture closure
Value: early closure of the suture between the zygomatic process of the maxilla and the maxillary margin of the zygomatic bone

Subject: premature fontanelle closure
Value: early closure of one or more of the membranous intervals at the margins of cranial bones; premature fontanelle closure can result from microcephaly, premature closure of the cranial sutures, or hyperthyroidism

Subject: delayed fontanelle closure
Value: late onset of closure of one or more of the membranous intervals at the margins of cranial bones

Subject: abnormal incus short process morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the short limb (crus) of the incus that fits into a depression (fossa incudis) in the epitympanic recess; it is attached to the cavity wall by the posterior incudal ligament

Subject: absent incus short process
Value: missing the short limb (crus) of the incus that, normally, fits into a depression (fossa incudis) in the epitympanic recess

Subject: abnormal incus long process morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the long limb (crus) of the incus; at the tip of the long crus there is a small knob, the lenticular process, that articulates with the head of the stapes

Subject: abnormal incus lenticular process morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the ovoid end of the incus that articulates with the head of the stapes; it is attached to the long process by a thin strut or pedicle

Subject: absent incus lenticular process
Value: missing the ovoid end of the incus that articulates with the head of the stapes; normally, it is attached to the long process by a thin strut or pedicle

Subject: abnormal incus body morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the flat, main part of the incus that articulates with the head of the malleus; two spines, the short and long processes, arise from the lower posterior part of the body and diverge from each other in a right angle

Subject: abnormal stapes annular ligament morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the ring of fibrous tissue that connects the base of the stapes to the oval window (aka fenestra vestibuli) of the inner ear

Subject: absent stapes annular ligament
Value: missing the ring of fibrous tissue that connects the base of the stapes to the oval window (aka fenestra vestibuli) of the inner ear

Subject: abnormal stapes head morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the concave portion of the stapes, located on top of the neck, which articulates with the lenticular process of the long limb of the incus through the incudostapedial joint

Subject: absent stapes head
Value: missing the concave portion of the stapes, located on top of the neck, which articulates with the lenticular process of the long limb of the incus through the incudostapedial joint

Subject: abnormal stapes obturator foramen morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the central foramen (hole) located between the crura and the footplate of the stapes through which the stapedial artery passes

Subject: small stapes obturator foramen
Value: reduced size of the central foramen (hole) located between the crura and the footplate of the stapes through which the stapedial artery passes

Subject: absent stapes obturator foramen
Value: missing the central foramen (hole) located between the crura and the footplate of the stapes through which the stapedial artery passes

Subject: abnormal stapes crus morpholgy
Value: any structural anomaly of either of the two (anterior and posterior) limbs of the stapes that pass from the head to the base or footplate; in mice, the anterior crus is curved and the posterior crus is more straight whereas in humans, the anterior crus is more straight than the posterior crus

Subject: abnormal stapes posterior crus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the generally longer arching stem of the stapes that projects medially from the neck, forming the posterior border of the bone, and joins the flat, disc-like base

Subject: abnormal stapes anterior crus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the generally shorter stem of the stapes that projects medially from the neck, forming the anterior border of the bone, and joins the flat, disc-like base

Subject: middle ear effusion
Value: fluid accumulation in the middle ear cavity due to dysfunction of the Eustachian tube

Subject: small round window
Value: reduced size of the opening on the medial wall of the middle ear leading into the cochlea, closed in life by the secondary tympanic membrane; it serves to regulate fluid pressure in the inner ear

Subject: absent round window
Value: absence of the opening on the medial wall of the middle ear leading into the cochlea, closed in life by the secondary tympanic membrane; it serves to regulate fluid pressure in the inner ear

Subject: tympanic membrane retraction
Value: a condition in which a segment of the tympanic membrane (eardrum) collapses inwards towards the middle ear space and lies more medially (deeper) than its normal position; the retracted segment is often known as a retraction pocket

Subject: tympanic membrane perforation
Value: presence of a hole or tear in the tympanic membrane (eardrum)

Subject: premature intermaxillary suture closure
Value: early closure of the anterior median suture between the two maxillae of the upper jawbone, located between the inferior border of the nasal aperture and the central incisor teeth

Subject: absent temporal bone zygomatic process
Value: missing the long, arched process that projects from the lower region of the squamous part of the temporal bone and articulates with the zygomatic bone

Subject: craniofacial hyperostosis
Value: excessive growth of the craniofacial bones

Subject: facial hyperostosis
Value: excessive growth of the facial bones

Subject: excessive cerumen
Value: excess buildup of cerumen, a yellowish waxy substance (earwax), in the external auditory canal

Subject: short basicranium
Value: decreased length of the anterior and/or posterior portions of the skull base

Subject: tongue muscle hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the muscular portion of the tongue

Subject: abnormal outer ear cartilage morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the elastic cartilage components of the auricles and/or external acoustic meatus

Subject: abnormal pinna cartilage morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the elastic cartilage component of the auricles

Subject: premature palatomaxillary suture closure
Value: early closure of the transverse suture across the back of the hard palate that separates the maxillary shelf of the palate from the horizontal plates of the palatine bones

Subject: wide intermaxillary suture
Value: an abnormally increased width of the anterior median suture between the two maxillae of the upper jawbone for age-related norms

Subject: facial muscle hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of any of the striated skeletal muscles innervated by the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) that, among other things, control facial expression

Subject: abnormal neck muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any skeletal muscle that is part of the cervical (neck) region

Subject: abnormal scalene muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the three pairs of muscles in the lateral neck, namely the scalenus anterior, scalenus medius, and scalenus posterior; the scalenes are innervated by the cervical spinal nerves C4-C8, act as accessory muscles of respiration, and perform flexion at the neck

Subject: abnormal levator nasolabialis muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the flat, thin muscle lying beneath the skin on the lateral surface of the maxillary bone; it arises from the maxillary bone, over the dorsum of the nose, and runs cranioventrally to insert partly on the wing of the nostril and partly into the lateral part of the upper lip; it acts to dilate the nostrils and elevate and retract the upper lip

Subject: absent levator nasolabialis muscle
Value: missing the flat, thin muscle that lies beneath the skin on the lateral surface of the maxillary bone; it arises from the maxillary bone, over the dorsum of the nose, and runs cranioventrally to insert partly on the wing of the nostril and partly into the lateral part of the upper lip; it acts to dilate the nostrils and elevate and retract the upper lip

Subject: wide metopic suture
Value: an abnormally increased width of the metopic suture for age-related norms

Subject: large cranial foramen ovale
Value: increased size of the oval-shaped opening in the middle cranial fossa located at the posterior base of the greater wing of the sphenoid bone, lateral to the lingula of the mandible

Subject: large foramen rotundum
Value: increased size of the circular hole (foramen) in the sphenoid bone that connects the middle cranial fossa and the pterygopalatine fossa

Subject: premature maxillary-premaxillary suture closure
Value: early closure of the maxillary-premaxillary suture, the line of union of the two portions of the maxilla (pre- and postmaxilla)

Subject: premature craniofacial suture closure
Value: early closure of any joint (suture) between cranial and/or facial bones

Subject: premature frontonasal suture closure
Value: early closure of the joint (suture) between the frontal bone and the two nasal bones

Subject: abnormal osteoblast proliferation
Value: anomaly in the ability of osteoblasts to undergo expansion by cell division; osteoblasts are skeletogenic cells that secrete osteoid, are capable of producing mineralized (hydroxyapatite) matrix, are located adjacent to or within osteoid tissue, and arise from the transformation of a preosteoblast cell

Subject: increased osteoblast proliferation
Value: increase in the expansion rate of osteoblasts by cell division; osteoblasts are skeletogenic cells that secrete osteoid, are capable of producing mineralized (hydroxyapatite) matrix, are located adjacent to or within osteoid tissue, and arise from the transformation of a preosteoblast cell

Subject: decreased osteoblast proliferation
Value: reduction in the expansion rate of osteoblasts by cell division; osteoblasts are skeletogenic cells that secrete osteoid, are capable of producing mineralized (hydroxyapatite) matrix, are located adjacent to or within osteoid tissue, and arise from the transformation of a preosteoblast cell

Subject: abnormal osteoblast apoptosis
Value: change in the timing or the number of osteoblasts undergoing programmed cell death; osteoblasts are skeletogenic cells that secrete osteoid, are capable of producing mineralized (hydroxyapatite) matrix, are located adjacent to or within osteoid tissue, and arise from the transformation of a preosteoblast cell

Subject: increased osteoblast apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of osteoblasts undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: decreased osteoblast apoptosis
Value: reduction in the number of osteoblasts undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal cranial synchondrosis
Value: any anomaly in the development of cartilaginous joints or growth centers between bones of the skull base by the formation of hyaline cartilage which is abundant during the growth phase and ultimately ossifies during skeletal maturation; synchondroses are composed of mirror-image growth plates with a central resting zone, proliferative zones, and hypertrophic zones on both sides; in mouse, there are two synchondroses in the midline cranial base, the sphenooccipital and presphenoidal synchondroses

Subject: premature cranial synchondrosis closure
Value: early fusion or ossification of one or more cranial base synchondroses relative to age- and gender-matched controls; can lead to midface hypoplasia, as seen in patients with specific forms of syndromic craniosynostosis

Subject: abnormal sphenooccipital synchondrosis
Value: any anomaly in the development of the cartilaginous joint (growth center) between the basioccipital and basisphenoid bones that is an important driver of facial and cranial base growth; sphenooccipital synchondroses are among the last to fuse and may remain patent until early adulthood

Subject: premature sphenooccipital synchondrosis closure
Value: early closure or ossification of the sphenooccipital synchondrosis relative to age- and gender-matched controls; premature fusion has been associated with midface hypoplasia in animal models and patients with specific forms of syndromic craniosynostosis

Subject: abnormal presphenoid synchondrosis
Value: any anomaly in the development of the cartilaginous joint (growth center) between the presphenoid and basisphenoid bones of the skull base

Subject: premature presphenoid synchondrosis closure
Value: early closure or ossification of the presphenoid synchondrosis relative to age- and gender-matched controls

Subject: tooth ankylosis
Value: solid fixation of a tooth resulting from fusion of the dental cementum and alveolar bone, with obliteration of the periodontal ligament

Subject: abnormal enamel mineralization
Value: anomaly in the process by which calcium salts, mainly carbonated hydroxyapatite, are deposited into the dental enamel

Subject: abnormal dentin mineralization
Value: anomaly in the process by which calcium salts are deposited into dentin

Subject: abnormal cementum mineralization
Value: anomaly in the process by which calcium salts, mainly carbonated hydroxyapatite, are deposited into the initial acellular cementum

Subject: abnormal odontoblast morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the skeletogenic cell on the outer surface of the dental pulp that secretes dentin matrix, is derived from the odontogenic papilla, and develops from a preodontoblast cell

Subject: abnormal odontoblast number
Value: deviation from the normal number of skeletogenic cells on the outer surface of the dental pulp that secrete dentin matrix, are derived from the odontogenic papilla, and develop from preodontoblast cells

Subject: increased odontoblast number
Value: greater than normal number of the skeletogenic cells on the outer surface of the dental pulp that secrete dentin matrix, are derived from the odontogenic papilla, and develop from preodontoblast cells

Subject: abnormal odontoblast differentiation
Value: anomaly in the process by which a relatively unspecialized cell of neural crest origin acquires the specialized features of an odontoblast, a skeletogenic cell on the outer surface of the dental pulp that secretes dentin matrix, is derived from the odontogenic papilla, and develops from a preodontoblast cell

Subject: abnormal molar cusp morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of an elevation or mound on the crown of a molar tooth making up a part of the occlusal (masticatory) surface

Subject: abnormal tooth wear
Value: change in the progression or severity of loss of tooth substance, usually resulting from abrasion, attrition and erosion acting singly or concurrently; tooth wear is a normal, age-dependent physiological process that leads to surface loss of dental hard tissues

Subject: abnormal tooth attrition
Value: change in the physiologic wearing away of tooth structure as a result of abnormal tooth-to-tooth contact, as in mastication, occurring only on the occlusal, incisal, and proximal surfaces

Subject: enamel pits
Value: presence of small depressions in the dental enamel

Subject: abnormal sphenosquamosal suture morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the vertical cranial suture located between the sphenoid and temporal bones bilaterally; it is formed by the articulation between the posterior border of the greater wing of the sphenoid bone and the anterior border of the squamous part of the temporal bone

Subject: tooth abscess
Value: a pocket of pus localized within a region of a tooth, usually caused by a bacterial infection

Subject: apical tooth abscess
Value: a tooth abscess that occurs at or around the tip of the root (apex) of a tooth; may result from pulp infection due to carious lesion or pulp necrosis resulting from injury

Subject: abnormal cranial cartilage morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any cartilage element that is part of the cranial skeleton

Subject: absent oval window
Value: missing the oval opening on the medial wall of the tympanic cavity leading into the vestibule, close to the foot of the stapes

Subject: alveolar process atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of the alveolar process associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: abnormal cranial cartilage development
Value: anomaly in the formation of any cartilage element that is part of the cranial skeleton

Subject: abnormal carotid canal morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the passageway within the petrous temporal bone that transmits the internal carotid artery and sympathetic plexus; its inferior opening is the carotid foramen situated anteriorly to the jugular fossa and medially to the tympanic plate; the carotid canal is initially directed superiorly, then turns anteromedially to reach up to the petrous apex, runs within the petrous bone, and opens into the middle cranial fossa superior to the foramen lacerum

Subject: optic canal stenosis
Value: abnormal narrowing or constriction of the short canal through the orbitosphenoid bone at the apex of the orbit that gives passage to the optic nerve and the ophthalmic artery

Subject: abnormal jugular foramen morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the large irregular opening from the posterior cranial fossa that is bounded anteriorly by the petrous part of the temporal bone and posteriorly by the jugular notch of the occipital bone; it transmits the inferior petrosal sinus, the glossopharyngeal, vagus, and accessory nerves, and the internal jugular vein

Subject: abnormal ameloblast differentiation
Value: any anomaly in the process in which a relatively unspecialized cell acquires specialized features of a functional ameloblast, a tall, columnar, polarized epithelial cell in the innermost layer of the enamel organ of a developing tooth involved with the formation of enamel matrix

Subject: fused teeth
Value: union of two separately developing tooth germs typically leading to one less tooth than normal in the affected arch

Subject: fused molars
Value: union of two adjacent molar teeth in the maxilla and/or mandible

Subject: fused incisors
Value: union of two adjacent incisor teeth in the maxilla and/or mandible

Subject: fused lower incisors
Value: union of two adjacent incisor teeth in the mandible

Subject: fused upper incisors
Value: union of two adjacent incisor teeth in the maxilla

Subject: abnormal osteocyte physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of a mature osteoblast that has become embedded in the bone matrix (osteoid) in a small cavity called lacuna and that extends cytoplasmic (dendritic) processes away from the cell body toward other osteocytes and neighboring cells in small channels called canaliculi

Subject: abnormal osteocyte apoptosis
Value: change in the timing or the number of osteocytes undergoing programmed cell death; an osteocyte is a mature osteoblast that has become embedded in the bone matrix (osteoid) in a small cavity called lacuna and that extends cytoplasmic (dendritic) processes away from the cell body toward other osteocytes and neighboring cells in small channels called canaliculi

Subject: increased osteocyte apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of osteocytes undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: decreased osteocyte apoptosis
Value: reduction in the number of osteocytes undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal osteocyte number
Value: deviation from the average number of mature osteoblasts that have become embedded in the bone matrix (osteoid) in small cavities called lacunae and that extend cytoplasmic (dendritic) processes away from the cell body toward other osteocytes and neighboring cells in small channels called canaliculi

Subject: increased osteocyte number
Value: greater than average number of mature osteoblasts that have become embedded in the bone matrix (osteoid) in small cavities called lacunae and that extend cytoplasmic (dendritic) processes away from the cell body toward other osteocytes and neighboring cells in small channels called canaliculi

Subject: decreased osteocyte number
Value: reduction in the number of mature osteoblasts that have become embedded in the bone matrix (osteoid) in small cavities called lacunae and that extend cytoplasmic (dendritic) processes away from the cell body toward other osteocytes and neighboring cells in small channels called canaliculi

Subject: abnormal osteocyte lacuna morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small cavity within the bone matrix that is occupied by an osteocyte cell body, and from which slender canaliculi radiate and penetrate the adjacent lamellae to anastomose with the canaliculi of neighboring lacunae, thus forming a system of cavities interconnected by minute canals

Subject: abnormal osteocyte lacunocanalicular system morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the large network intercommunicating the lacunae and canaliculi which contain the osteocytes and their cytoplasmic processes within the mineralized bone matrix

Subject: abnormal osteocyte canaliculus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the slender canals situated between the lacunae of ossified bone where osteocyte cytoplasmic (dendritic) processes reside; osteocyte canaliculi are used for exchange of nutrients and waste products through gap junctions

Subject: abnormal osteocyte dendritic process morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the long, slender cytoplasmic processes by which mature osteocytes communicate with one another, receive mechanosensory signals and participate in the regulation of bone turnover; these processes radiate from the osteocyte cell body, run along narrow canaliculi, and are linked to other neighboring osteocytes processes by gap junctions, as well as to cytoplasmic processes of osteoblasts and bone lining cells on the bone surface

Subject: abnormal tooth socket morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the cavities or sockets in the alveolar process of the mandible or maxilla, in which the roots of the teeth are held by fibers of the periodontal ligament

Subject: abnormal molar socket morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the cavities or sockets in the alveolar process of the mandible or maxilla, in which the roots of molar teeth are held by fibers of the periodontal ligament

Subject: periodontal pocket
Value: a pathologic deepening of the gingival sulcus as a result of apical migration of the junctional epithelium and the destruction of alveolar bone and periodontal ligament fiber bundles

Subject: dental pulp stones
Value: nodular, calcified masses appearing in either or both the coronal and root portion of the pulp organ in teeth

Subject: abnormal dentoalveolar joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the specialized peg-in-socket fibrous joint between the root of a tooth and the socket in the maxilla or mandible; this type of joint permits very limited or no movement under normal conditions and is functionally classified as a synarthrosis

Subject: abnormal tooth root morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the part of a tooth that is implanted in the gum; the root is located below the neck of the tooth, covered by cementum rather than enamel, and attached by the periodontal ligament to the alveolar bone

Subject: abnormal molar root morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the part of a molar tooth that is implanted in the gum

Subject: absent tooth root
Value: absence of or failure to develop the part of a tooth that is implanted in the gum; normally, the root is located below the neck of the tooth, covered by cementum rather than enamel, and attached by the periodontal ligament to the alveolar bone

Subject: taurodontia
Value: a developmental anomaly involving molar teeth, whereby the body of the tooth and pulp chamber is enlarged vertically at the expense of the roots and the root canal length; characteristic features include an enlarged pulp chamber, absence of the usual constriction at the cemento-enamel junction, and apical shift of the pulp chamber floor and furcation area down the root

Subject: short tooth root
Value: decreased length of the part of a tooth that is implanted in the gum; the root is located below the neck of the tooth, covered by cementum rather than enamel, and attached by the periodontal ligament to the alveolar bone

Subject: abnormal dental lamina morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the U-shaped stripe of thickened oral epithelium marking the future tooth row; the primary dental lamina is the earliest morphological structure of the tooth formed in the embryo; local thickenings of the dental lamina from which individual teeth are initiated are known as tooth placodes

Subject: conical tooth
Value: a peg-shaped (coniform) tooth whose sides converge or taper together incisally

Subject: conical molar
Value: a molar tooth whose sides converge or taper together incisally forming a peg-shaped (coniform) crown

Subject: abnormal incisive canal morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of several bony canals leading from the floor of the nasal cavity into the incisive fossa on the palatal surface of the maxilla; they convey the nasopalatine nerves and branches of the greater palatine arteries that anastomose with the septal branch of the sphenopalatine artery

Subject: abnormal incisive foramen morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any oral opening of the nasopalatine (incisive) canal; it is located in the maxilla in the incisive fossa, midline in the palate posterior to the central incisors, at the junction of the medial palatine and incisive sutures; it can be single or multiple; it transmits the greater palatine artery and vein from the oral to the nasal cavity and the nasopalatine nerve in the opposite direction

Subject: abnormal tooth neck morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the slightly constricted part of a tooth between the crown and the root

Subject: abnormal cementoenamel junction morphology
Value: any anomaly of the interface between the cementum and enamel at the cervical region (neck) of a tooth; it represents the anatomic limit or line of division between the crown and root surface

Subject: tooth impaction
Value: cessation of eruption of a tooth caused by a clinically or radiographically detectable physical barrier in the eruption path or by an ectopic position of the tooth; an impacted tooth is one that is unable to fully erupt in its proper location because it is blocked by tissue, bone or another tooth

Subject: abnormal dental follicle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the loose ectomesenchyme-derived connective tissue sac that surrounds the enamel organ and the dental papilla of the developing tooth germ before eruption; it is believed that this tissue contains stem cells and lineage-committed progenitor cells or precursor cells for cementoblasts, periodontal ligament (PDL) cells and osteoblasts; dental follicle cells form the PDL by differentiating into PDL fibroblasts that secrete collagen and interact with fibers on the surface of adjacent bone and cementum

Subject: abnormal dental papilla morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the condensation of ectomesenchymal cells called odontoblasts seen in histologic sections of a developing tooth; the dental papilla lies below a cellular aggregation known as the enamel organ and differentiates into the dentin and dental pulp

Subject: abnormal dental epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the epithelium that is part of a developing tooth or dental (enamel) organ

Subject: increased number of epithelial cell rests of Malassez
Value: increased number of epithelial cell remnants derived from the fragmentation of Hertwig's epithelial root sheath during root development that persist in the periodontal ligament close to the cementum surface

Subject: abnormal tooth placode morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the local thickening that is formed within the primary dental lamina and grows into a solid epithelial tooth bud that invades the underlying mesenchyme; the placodes consist of thickened epithelium and underlying neural crest derived mesenchyme, and they function as the first signaling centers of the tooth

Subject: abnormal dentinoenamel junction morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the interface that joins two distinct calcified tissues, enamel and dentin; it presents a scalloped contour, with its concave side toward the enamel and the convex side toward the dentin, thought to increase adherence of the enamel to the dentin, especially in areas of occlusal stress; DEJ plays a key role in resisting crack propagation from enamel to dentin

Subject: abnormal Tomes' process morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the pyramidal extension at the apical pole of a secretory ameloblast that plays an important role in organizing the enamel crystals into a complex network of rod (prism) and interrod enamel; Tomes' processes interdigitate with the surface of the forming enamel giving it a picket fence appearance and determine the orientation of the newly formed (nucleated) enamel hydroxyapatite crystals; as the secretory stage ends, Tomes' processes are lost and accordingly the last formed layers of enamel are rodless or prismless

Subject: short Tomes' process
Value: decreased length of the pyramidal extension at the apical pole of a secretory ameloblast that plays an important role in organizing the enamel crystals into a complex network of rod (prism) and interrod enamel

Subject: absent Tomes' process
Value: failure to form the pyramidal extension at the apical pole of a secretory ameloblast that plays an important role in organizing the enamel crystals into a complex network of rod (prism) and interrod enamel

Subject: periodontal ligament necrosis
Value: morphological changes resulting from pathological death of periodontal ligament tissue; usually due to irreversible damage

Subject: abnormal junctional epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the collar-like band of non-keratinized squamous epithelium that attaches the gingival soft tissue to the tooth surface; the term epithelial attachment refers to the attachment apparatus, i.e. the internal basal lamina and hemidesmosomes, that connects the junctional epithelium (JE) to the tooth surface; in the initiation of periodontitis, JE detaches from the tooth surface and converts gradually, by sprouting laterally and migrating apically, to pathological pocket epithelium

Subject: detached junctional epithelium
Value: partial or complete detachment of the junctional epithelium from the tooth surface, typically leading to periodontal pocket formation

Subject: abnormal outer dental epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the layer of cuboidal cells located on the periphery of the enamel organ in a developing tooth; this layer is first seen during the bell stage

Subject: abnormal inner dental epithelium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the inner layer of columnar cells of the enamel organ, located on the rim nearest the dental papilla; this layer is first seen during the cap stage of tooth development, in which inner enamel epithelium cells are pre-ameloblast cells; these will differentiate into ameloblasts which are responsible for secretion of enamel during tooth development

Subject: oral mucosa blisters
Value: localized pockets of fluid that form within or beneath the oral mucosa; may appear as pustules, vesicles, or bullae; color varies according to content of blister, which may include blood, serum, mucin, or suppuration

Subject: abnormal cervical loop morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the most cervical part of an enamel organ where the inner enamel epithelium and the outer enamel epithelium merge in a loop, thus delineating the end of the anatomic crown and the site where root formation begins; to form the root region, the cervical loop begins to grow deeper into the surrounding ectomesenchyme of the dental sac, elongating and moving away from the newly completed crown area to enclose more of the dental papilla, forming Hertwig's epithelial root sheath (HERS)

Subject: abnormal stellate reticulum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the network of star-shaped cells found in the core of the dental (enamel) organ between the stratum intermedium and outer enamel epithelium which secrete hydrophilic glycosaminoglycans into the extracellular compartment; the stellate reticulum is most fully developed at the bell stage when intercellular spaces become fluid-filled, presumably related to osmotic effects arising from the high concentration of glycosaminoglycans; the main function of the stellate reticulum is mechanical, protecting the underlying dental tissues against physical disturbance and maintaining tooth shape

Subject: abnormal stratum intermedium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the layer of two or three flattened cells located between the inner enamel epithelium and the newly forming cells of the stellate reticulum; it first appears during the early bell stage of tooth development, has a notably high alkaline phosphatase activity, and forms a part of the dental (enamel) organ; this layer, along with the inner enamel epithelium, is responsible for the tooth enamel formation

Subject: abnormal tooth root resorption
Value: pathologic resorption in which cementum or dentin is lost from the root of a tooth owing to cementoclastic or osteoclastic activity in conditions such as trauma of occlusion or neoplasms

Subject: abnormal Hertwig epithelial root sheath morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bilayered epithelial sheath formed from the fusion of the inner and outer enamel epithelia below the level of the cervical margin of the crown; in mammals, HERS is a transient structure and fragments to form the epithelial cell rests of Malassez; HERS cells appear to be involved in the initiation of the root formation process, in root elongation, and in stimulating both cementogenesis and root dentinogenesis

Subject: abnormal enamel cord morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the transient structure of the dental (enamel) organ present at the early cap stage of molar tooth development; the enamel cord is a strand of epithelial cells that runs from (links) the enamel knot to the outer dental epithelial cells, dividing the dental organ into two parts

Subject: absent enamel cord
Value: missing the transient structure of the dental (enamel) organ that is normally present at the early cap stage of molar tooth development; the enamel cord is a strand of epithelial cells that runs from (links) the enamel knot to the outer dental epithelial cells, dividing the dental organ into two parts

Subject: abnormal neck skin morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a zone of skin that is part of the cervical (neck) region

Subject: abnormal head skin morphology
Value: any anomaly in a zone of skin that is part of the head

Subject: abnormal outer ear skin morphology
Value: any anomaly in a zone of skin that is part of an outer ear

Subject: abnormal facial skin morphology
Value: any anomaly in a zone of skin that is part of the face

Subject: abnormal periorbital skin morphology
Value: any anomaly in a zone of skin that is part of the periorbital region of the face

Subject: abnormal snout skin morphology
Value: any anomaly in a zone of skin that is part of the snout

Subject: abnormal forehead skin morphology
Value: any anomaly in a zone of skin that is part of the forehead

Subject: abnormal hypoglossal cord morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the condensed mesenchymal band formed as migratory myoblasts arising from the myotomes of the occipital somites coalesce beside somite four and extend ventrally as an elongated column; the hypoglossal cord eventually becomes located ventral to the caudal region of the pharynx; most of the myoblasts of the hypoglossal cord remain ventral and shift cranially to form the intrinsic and extrinsic tongue muscles; some of these myoblasts shift dorsally to form the intrinsic laryngeal muscles

Subject: abnormal diastema morphology
Value: any anomaly of the space or gap between two adjacent teeth in the same dental arch; in rodents, the diastema is the toothless (edentulous) region that normally separates a continuously growing single incisor from a segment of three molars in each quadrant of the adult jaw; although tooth primordia develop in the rodent embryonic diastema, they undergo apoptosis and regress to ensure that this region remains tooth-free

Subject: abnormal notochordal process morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the midline cellular cord formed from the migration of mesenchymal cells from the primitive knot; the notochordal process is a mesodermal hollow tube structure that grows cranially between the ectoderm and the endoderm until it reaches the prechordal plate

Subject: abnormal notochordal plate morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the dorsal part of the notochordal process when the ventral portion breaks down; it is continuous laterally with the endoderm that composes the roof of the primitive foregut and is in contact dorsally with the neural tube; the folding off of the notochordal plate gives rise to the notochord

Subject: abnormal head paraxial mesoderm morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the paraxial mesoderm located on either side of the neural tube, anterior to the occipital somites; in the head region, the unsegmented cranial paraxial mesoderm contributes to the developing heart, specific skull bones and skeletal muscles of the head and neck region

Subject: misaligned teeth
Value: abnormal alignment, positioning, or spacing of the teeth

Subject: misaligned incisors
Value: abnormal alignment of the upper and lower incisor teeth, usually resulting in malocclusion; in gnawing rodents, where incisors are rootless and grow continually, signs of incisor malocclusion include uneven wear patterns, sloping of the cutting edges, fractured teeth, altered pigmentation, and obvious pathological overgrowth of the incisors

Subject: abnormal dentin development
Value: any anomaly in the process whose specific outcome is the formation of dentin, the hard portion of the tooth surrounding the pulp, covered by enamel on the crown and cementum on the root; dentinogenesis begins prior to enamel formation and is initiated by the odontoblasts of the dental pulp; dentin is derived from the dental papilla of the tooth germ; after apposition of predentin and maturation into dentin, the cell bodies of the odontoblasts remain in the pulp inside the tooth, along its outer wall; unlike enamel, dentin continues to form throughout life and can be initiated in response to stimuli, such as tooth decay or attrition

Subject: abnormal predentin morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the initial type I collagen-rich unmineralized extracellular matrix synthesized and secreted by odontoblasts and located at the dentin-pulp interface; predentin is converted to dentin when hydroxyapatite crystals are deposited on the predentin

Subject: abnormal enamel development
Value: <any anomaly in the process whose specific outcome is the formation of dental enamel, the hard outer coating of the exposed portion of the tooth; amelogenesis occurs after the first establishment of dentin, via cells known as ameloblasts, and can generally be divided into two broad stages: (i) a secretory stage that involves proteins and an organic matrix forming a partially mineralized enamel and (ii) a maturation stage which completes enamel mineralization>

Subject: abnormal acellular cementum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the acellular layer of cementum, a living tissue that does not incorporate cells (cementocytes) into its structure, consisting only of extracellular matrix components and mineral; acellular cementum is the first cementum deposited on the dentin of the forming root, and is predominantly found on the cervical/coronal portion of the tooth root; it anchors the primary collagen fibers of the periodontal ligament, providing a strong attachment between the tooth and surrounding alveolar bone

Subject: abnormal cellular cementum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the layer of cementum that contains cementocytes in lacunae; it is most abundant on the apical portion of the tooth root and in the furcation areas of multirooted teeth, and has a role in posteruptive adjustment of tooth position

Subject: abnormal cementum development
Value: any anomaly in the process whose specific outcome is the formation of dental cementum, a bone-like rigid connective tissue covering the root of a tooth

Subject: abnormal cementoid morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the organic matrix secreted by cementoblasts, which forms the most recent unmineralized layer covering the surface of cellular cementum

Subject: abnormal cementocyte lacunocanalicular system morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the osteocyte-like network of lacunae and canaliculi housing the cementocytes and their cytoplasmic processes within the cellular cementum; although cementocytes resemble osteocytes, they show profound differences in terms of dendrite number, lacunar shape, and canalicular network density, suggesting less communication between, to, and from cementocytes compared with osteocytes

Subject: abnormal cementoblast morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the large cuboidal cells differentiated from fibroblasts of the dental follicle (or possibly from Hertwig's epithelial root sheath cells by epithelial-mesenchymal transformation) that, during formation of cellular cementum, secrete a layer of unmineralized extracellular matrix called cementoid; as cementoid deposition progresses, some cementoblasts become embedded in cementoid matrix and become cementocytes

Subject: abnormal cementoblast number
Value: deviation from the average number of the large cuboidal cells differentiated from fibroblasts of the dental follicle (or possibly from Hertwig's epithelial root sheath cells by epithelial-mesenchymal transformation) that, during formation of cellular cementum, secrete a layer of unmineralized extracellular matrix called cementoid; as cementoid deposition progresses, some cementoblasts become embedded in cementoid matrix and become cementocytes

Subject: decreased cementoblast number
Value: fewer than the expected number of the large cuboidal cells differentiated from fibroblasts of the dental follicle (or possibly from Hertwig’s epithelial root sheath cells by epithelial-mesenchymal transformation) that, during formation of cellular cementum, secrete a layer of unmineralized extracellular matrix called cementoid; as cementoid deposition progresses, some cementoblasts become embedded in cementoid matrix and become cementocytes

Subject: increased cementoblast number
Value: greater than the expected number of the large cuboidal cells differentiated from fibroblasts of the dental follicle (or possibly from Hertwig’s epithelial root sheath cells by epithelial-mesenchymal transformation) that, during formation of cellular cementum, secrete a layer of unmineralized extracellular matrix called cementoid; as cementoid deposition progresses, some cementoblasts become embedded in cementoid matrix and become cementocytes

Subject: abnormal cementocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of an apparently terminally differentiated cementoblast that has become embedded in the cellular cementum in a small cavity called lacuna and that extends long cytoplasmic (dendritic) processes away from the cell body toward other cementocytes and neighboring cells in small channels called canaliculi

Subject: abnormal cementocyte lacuna morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the small cavity within the cellular cementum that is occupied by a cementocyte cell body; cementocyte lacunae are described as larger and more irregular in size and shape (from oval to tubular) and with rougher walls than the typical ellipsoid osteocyte lacunae; occasionally, empty lacunae or lacunae containing more than one cell are observed in cellular cementum, not typically observed in osteocyte lacunae

Subject: abnormal cementocyte canaliculus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the slender canals situated between lacunae of the cellular cementum where cementocyte cytoplasmic (dendritic) processes reside; cementocyte canaliculi appear to be less organized, more sparse, and do they radiate outward, with the majority of them oriented toward the vascular periodontal ligament for nutrition, unlike osteocyte canaliculi which are radiating, more dense and arranged in a complex network

Subject: abnormal cementocyte dendritic process morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the long, slender cytoplasmic processes that extend from the cementocyte cell body, run along narrow canaliculi, and are linked to neighboring cementocytes processes via gap junctions; cementocytes harbor fewer dendritic processes than osteocytes

Subject: absent nasopharynx
Value: failure to form the section of the pharynx that lies above the soft palate

Subject: abnormal dental pulp canal morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the portion of the dental pulp cavity within the root of a tooth

Subject: enlarged dental pulp canal
Value: increased size of the portion of the dental pulp cavity within the root of a tooth

Subject: abnormal dental pulp chamber morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the portion of the dental pulp cavity within the crown of a tooth

Subject: enlarged dental pulp chamber
Value: increased size of the portion of the dental pulp cavity within the crown of a tooth

Subject: detached periodontal ligament
Value: partial or complete loss of attachment of the periodontal ligament to the cementum covering the root of a tooth

Subject: thick myocardium compact layer
Value: increased thickness of the outer, dense layer of the myocardium

Subject: decreased circulating ammonia level
Value: reduced concentration of ammonia or its compounds in the blood

Subject: abnormal A band morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the dark-staining region of a sarcomere that is situated between two I bands and marked by partial overlapping of thin (actin) and thick (myosin) filaments; an A band is anisotropic to polarized light and contains the entire length of a single thick filament; its center is traversed by the paler H zone, which in turn contains the M line

Subject: abnormal I band morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the light band on each side of the Z disc (aka Z line), comprising a region of the sarcomere where thin (actin) filaments are not overlapped by thick (myosin) filaments; the I band is isotropic to polarized light and contains actin, troponin, and tropomyosin; each sarcomere includes half of an I band at each end

Subject: abnormal H zone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the relatively pale zone traversing the center of the A band of a sarcomere, visible in relaxed muscle fibers; it consists of the central portion of thick (myosin) filaments that are not overlapped by thin (actin) filaments; within the H zone is a thin dark M line, the attachment site for the thick filaments in the center of the sarcomere

Subject: glomerular capillary endotheliosis
Value: a renal lesion characterized by glomerular endothelial swelling with glomerular hypertrophy, obliteration of endothelial fenestrae, and narrowing or occlusion of the capillary lumens

Subject: abnormal piliary canal morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the tubular connection that is found between the epidermal surface and the most distal part of the hair follicle inner root sheath and contains the hair shaft

Subject: dilated piliary canal
Value: stretched or widened aperture of the luminal space of the tubular connection that is found between the epidermal surface and the most distal part of the hair follicle inner root sheath and contains the hair shaft; the infundibulum is the opening of the hair canal to the skin surface

Subject: abnormal pilosebaceous unit morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of an epidermal invagination consisting of hair, hair follicle, arrector pili muscle and sebaceous gland

Subject: abnormal hair follicle cell proliferation
Value: anomaly in the ability of any hair follicle cell population to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: increased hair follicle cell proliferation
Value: increase in the expansion rate of a hair follicle cell population by cell division

Subject: decreased hair follicle cell proliferation
Value: reduction in the expansion rate of a hair follicle cell population by cell division

Subject: abnormal keratinocyte adhesion
Value: any anomaly in the adhesive properties of keratinocytes, resulting in abnormal cell to cell and cell to extracellular matrix (ECM) interactions

Subject: increased keratinocyte adhesion
Value: increased ability of a keratinocyte to adhere to another cell or to a non-cellular component of the environment

Subject: decreased keratinocyte adhesion
Value: decreased ability of a keratinocyte to adhere to another cell or to a non-cellular component of the environment

Subject: thoracoabdominoschisis
Value: a congenital fissure of both the thoracic and abdominal walls

Subject: abnormal hair follicle placode morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the local epithelial thickenings in the embryonic epidermis that define the location of the hair follicles; in mouse, embryonic hair follicle development is initiated by the first dermal signal, originating from dermal fibroblasts, leading to the formation of placodes at ~E13.5; each placode sends a message back to underlying dermis, which results in the formation of an aggregate of mesenchymal cells known as the dermal condensate; the placodes then grow downward, giving rise to the hair germ by E15.5, the hair peg by E17.5, and the bulbous hair peg by E18.5

Subject: absent hair follicle placode
Value: absence of the local epithelial thickening in the embryonic epidermis that normally gives rise to the hair follicle bud (aka hair germ)

Subject: abnormal hair follicle placode formation
Value: any anomaly in the developmental process in which a hair placode forms; in mouse, hair placode formation is initiated at ~E13.5 in response to the first dermal signal originating from dermal fibroblasts; the resulting primary hair placode cells signal to the underlying dermis, triggering formation of dermal condensates that will coordinate further differentiation of hair-forming cells; hair placode formation progresses through 3 successive waves (1) primary hair placodes form at E14.5 and produce guard hair, (2) secondary hair placodes form at E16-17 and produce awl hair, and (3) the third wave of hair follicle induction produces tertiary placodes and generate zig-zag hair

Subject: abnormal hair follicle peg morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the solid column of keratinocytes growing into the dermis during embryonic hair follicle development; the concave proximal end starts to encase the dermal condensate, the future dermal papilla

Subject: skin atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of skin tissue associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: enhanced behavioral response to amphetamine
Value: increased sensitivity to amphetamine resulting in a behavioral response, such as induced hyperactivity or stereotypic behavior, or decreased dosage threshold for the appearance of the behavioral response

Subject: impaired behavioral response to amphetamine
Value: decreased sensitivity to amphetamine resulting in a behavioral response, such as induced hyperactivity or stereotypic behavior, or increased dosage threshold for the appearance of the behavioral response

Subject: abnormal pancreatic alpha cell mass
Value: anomaly in the total physical bulk or volume of a pancreatic alpha cell compared to the normal state

Subject: decreased pancreatic alpha cell mass
Value: reduced total physical bulk or volume of a pancreatic alpha cell compared to the normal state

Subject: increased pancreatic alpha cell mass
Value: greater total physical bulk or volume of a pancreatic alpha cell compared to the normal state

Subject: abnormal sperm fibrous sheath morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the unique cytoskeletal component in the principal-piece segment of the sperm flagellum which surrounds the axoneme and outer dense fibers and contains two longitudinal columns that are connected by closely organized semicircular transverse ribs; the fibrous sheath is believed to regulate the degree of flexibility, flagellar motion and shape of the flagellar beat during the lifespan of a sperm cell

Subject: absent sperm fibrous sheath
Value: missing the unique cytoskeletal component of the principal-piece segment of the sperm flagellum which surrounds the axoneme and outer dense fibers and contains two longitudinal columns that are connected by closely organized semicircular transverse ribs

Subject: abnormal manganese homeostasis
Value: anomaly in the processes involved in the maintenance of an internal steady state of manganese ions within an organism or cell; manganese ions function as cofactors for a large variety of enzymes with many functions; while the element is a required trace mineral for all known living organisms, it also acts as a neurotoxin in larger amounts

Subject: abnormal manganese level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration of manganese in the body

Subject: abnormal brain manganese level
Value: any anomaly in the amount of manganese present in brain tissue

Subject: increased brain manganese level
Value: a greater accumulation of manganese in brain tissue compared to controls

Subject: decreased brain manganese level
Value: a reduced amount of manganese in brain tissue compared to controls

Subject: abnormal liver manganese level
Value: any anomaly in the amount of manganese present in liver tissue

Subject: increased liver manganese level
Value: a greater accumulation of manganese in liver tissue compared to controls

Subject: decreased liver manganese level
Value: a reduced amount of manganese in liver tissue compared to controls

Subject: abnormal circulating manganese level
Value: any anomaly in the blood concentration of manganese

Subject: increased circulating manganese level
Value: greater than normal concentration of manganese in the blood

Subject: decreased circulating manganese level
Value: less than the normal concentration of manganese in the blood

Subject: increased sperm number
Value: increased concentration of spermatozoa in the seminal fluid

Subject: abnormal ammonia homeostasis
Value: anomaly in the processes involved in the maintenance of an internal equilibrium of ammonia in the fluids and tissues

Subject: abnormal corneocyte morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the de-nucleated, dead keratin-filled squamous cell of the stratum corneum; a corneocyte is the last stage of development of a keratinocyte where the keratinocyte flattens, loses its nucleus and eventually delaminates from the epidermis

Subject: abnormal gingival sulcus moprhology
Value: <any anomaly in the area of potential space between a tooth and the surrounding gingival tissue that is lined by sulcular epithelium; the depth of the sulcus is bounded by two entities: apically by the gingival fibers of the connective tissue attachment and coronally by the free gingival margin>

Subject: abnormal sex cord morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cord-like masses of epithelial tissue that invaginate from the germinal epithelium of the gonad and give rise to seminiferous tubules and rete testes in the male, and primary ovarian follicles and rete ovarii in the female

Subject: decreased tooth number
Value: reduction in the number of the bony structures of the upper and lower jaws used in mastication

Subject: decreased incisor number
Value: reduction in the number of the long teeth, normally consisting of two pairs, top and bottom, that are the most anterior and prominent in the jaw

Subject: absent teeth
Value: absence of all of the bony structures of the upper and lower jaws used in mastication

Subject: abnormal tooth number
Value: anomaly in the number of the bony structures of the upper and lower jaws used in mastication

Subject: organic aciduria
Value: increased excretion of non-amino organic acids in urine

Subject: dicarboxylic aciduria
Value: an increased concentration of dicarboxylic acid in the urine, occurring during increased mobilization or inhibited beta-oxidation of fatty acids, where a number of 3-hydroxydicarboxylic acids are excreted in urine

Subject: methylmalonic aciduria
Value: increased concentration of methylmalonic acid in the urine

Subject: ethylmalonic aciduria
Value: increased concentration of ethylmalonic acid in the urine; ethylmalonic acid is a dicarboxylic acid obtained by substitution of one of the methylene hydrogens of malonic acid by an ethyl group

Subject: hyperglycinuria
Value: excretion of excessive amounts of glycine in the urine

Subject: hyperglutaminuria
Value: excretion of excessive amounts of glutamine in the urine

Subject: tryptophanuria
Value: excretion of excessive amounts of tryptophan in the urine

Subject: homogentisic aciduria
Value: excretion of excessive amounts of homogentisic acid (an intermediate in the tyrosine degradation pathway) and its oxidized form (benzoquinoneacetate) in the urine, giving it an unusually dark color on prolonged exposure to air

Subject: valinuria
Value: excretion of excessive amounts of valine in the urine

Subject: abnormal cysteine level
Value: anomaly in the amount of cysteine, a sulfur-containing amino acid that is propanoic acid with an amino group at position 2 and a sulfanyl group at position 3; the thiol side chain in cysteine is susceptible to oxidation to give the disulfide derivative cystine, which serves an important structural role in many proteins

Subject: increased cysteine level
Value: increase in the amount of cysteine, a sulfur-containing amino acid that is propanoic acid with an amino group at position 2 and a sulfanyl group at position 3

Subject: decreased cysteine level
Value: reduction in the amount of cysteine, a sulfur-containing amino acid that is propanoic acid with an amino group at position 2 and a sulfanyl group at position 3

Subject: abnormal circulating cysteine level
Value: anomaly in the amount per unit of blood of cysteine, a sulfur-containing amino acid that is propanoic acid with an amino group at position 2 and a sulfanyl group at position 3

Subject: increased circulating cysteine level
Value: increase in the amount per unit of blood of cysteine, a sulfur-containing amino acid that is propanoic acid with an amino group at position 2 and a sulfanyl group at position 3

Subject: decreased circulating cysteine level
Value: reduction in the amount per unit of blood of cysteine, a sulfur-containing amino acid that is propanoic acid with an amino group at position 2 and a sulfanyl group at position 3

Subject: abnormal methylmalonic acid level
Value: any anomaly in the amount of methylmalonic acid, a dicarboxylic acid that is malonic acid in which one of the methylene hydrogens is substituted by a methyl group

Subject: increased methylmalonic acid level
Value: increase in the amount of methylmalonic acid, a dicarboxylic acid that is malonic acid in which one of the methylene hydrogens is substituted by a methyl group

Subject: decreased methylmalonic acid level
Value: reduction in the amount of methylmalonic acid, a dicarboxylic acid that is malonic acid in which one of the methylene hydrogens is substituted by a methyl group

Subject: increased circulating methylmalonic acid level
Value: increased concentration in the blood of methylmalonic acid, a dicarboxylic acid that is malonic acid in which one of the methylene hydrogens is substituted by a methyl group

Subject: abnormal urine creatine level
Value: any change in the amount of creatine in the urine; creatine is a glycine derivative having methyl and amidino groups attached to the nitrogen

Subject: increased urine creatine level
Value: an increased concentration of creatine in the urine; creatine is a glycine derivative having methyl and amidino groups attached to the nitrogen

Subject: decreased urine creatine level
Value: a decreased concentration of creatine in the urine; creatine is a glycine derivative having methyl and amidino groups attached to the nitrogen

Subject: abnormal taurine level
Value: anomaly in the amount of taurine, an amino sulfonic acid that is the 2-amino derivative of ethanesulfonic acid; taurine is a naturally occurring amino acid derived from methionine and cysteine metabolism

Subject: increased taurine level
Value: increase in the amount of taurine, an amino sulfonic acid that is the 2-amino derivative of ethanesulfonic acid; taurine is a naturally occurring amino acid derived from methionine and cysteine metabolism

Subject: decreased taurine level
Value: reduction in the amount of taurine, an amino sulfonic acid that is the 2-amino derivative of ethanesulfonic acid; taurine is a naturally occurring amino acid derived from methionine and cysteine metabolism

Subject: abnormal circulating taurine level
Value: anomaly in the amount per unit of blood of taurine, an amino sulfonic acid that is the 2-amino derivative of ethanesulfonic acid; taurine is a naturally occurring amino acid derived from methionine and cysteine

Subject: increased circulating taurine level
Value: increase in the amount per unit of blood of taurine, an amino sulfonic acid that is the 2-amino derivative of ethanesulfonic acid; taurine is a naturally occurring amino acid derived from methionine and cysteine

Subject: decreased circulating taurine level
Value: reduction in the amount per unit of blood of taurine, an amino sulfonic acid that is the 2-amino derivative of ethanesulfonic acid; taurine is a naturally occurring amino acid derived from methionine and cysteine

Subject: abnormal methionine level
Value: anomaly in the amount of methionine, a sulfur-containing, essential amino acid found in peptide linkage in proteins; methionine is butyric acid bearing an amino substituent at position 2 and a methylthio substituent at position 4

Subject: increased methionine level
Value: increase in the amount of methionine, a sulfur-containing, essential amino acid found in peptide linkage in proteins

Subject: decreased methionine level
Value: reduction in the amount of methionine, a sulfur-containing, essential amino acid found in peptide linkage in proteins

Subject: abnormal circulating methionine level
Value: anomaly in the amount per unit of blood of methionine, a sulfur-containing, essential amino acid found in peptide linkage in proteins

Subject: increased circulating methionine level
Value: increase in the amount per unit of blood of methionine, a sulfur-containing, essential amino acid found in peptide linkage in proteins

Subject: decreased circulating methionine level
Value: reduction in the amount per unit of blood of methionine, a sulfur-containing, essential amino acid found in peptide linkage in proteins

Subject: abnormal ornithine level
Value: anomaly in the amount of ornithine, an amino acid only rarely found in proteins, but which is important in living organisms as an intermediate in the reactions of the urea cycle and in arginine biosynthesis; ornithine is an alpha-amino acid that is pentanoic acid bearing two amino substituents at positions 2 and 5

Subject: increased ornithine level
Value: increase in the amount of ornithine, an amino acid only rarely found in proteins, but which is important in living organisms as an intermediate in the reactions of the urea cycle and in arginine biosynthesis

Subject: decreased ornithine level
Value: reduction in the amount of ornithine, an amino acid only rarely found in proteins, but which is important in living organisms as an intermediate in the reactions of the urea cycle and in arginine biosynthesis

Subject: abnormal circulating ornithine level
Value: anomaly in the amount per unit of blood of ornithine, an amino acid only rarely found in proteins, but which is important in living organisms as an intermediate in the reactions of the urea cycle and in arginine biosynthesis

Subject: increased circulating ornithine level
Value: increase in the amount per unit of blood of ornithine, an amino acid only rarely found in proteins, but which is important in living organisms as an intermediate in the reactions of the urea cycle and in arginine biosynthesis

Subject: decreased circulating ornithine level
Value: reduction in the amount per unit of blood of ornithine, an amino acid only rarely found in proteins, but which is important in living organisms as an intermediate in the reactions of the urea cycle and in arginine biosynthesis

Subject: abnormal circulating glutathione level
Value: aberrant concentration in the blood of glutathione, a tripeptide compound consisting of glutamic acid attached via its side chain to the N-terminus of cysteinylglycine

Subject: increased circulating glutathione level
Value: increase in the amount per unit of blood of glutathione, a tripeptide compound consisting of glutamic acid attached via its side chain to the N-terminus of cysteinylglycine

Subject: abnormal circulating glycine level
Value: aberrant concentration in the blood of glycine, the simplest (and the only achiral) proteinogenic amino acid that has a single hydrogen atom as its side chain

Subject: increased circulating glycine level
Value: increase in the amount per unit of blood of glycine, the simplest (and the only achiral) proteinogenic amino acid that has a single hydrogen atom as its side chain

Subject: decreased circulating glycine level
Value: reduction in the amount per unit of blood of glycine, the simplest (and the only achiral) proteinogenic amino acid that has a single hydrogen atom as its side chain

Subject: abnormal glycine level
Value: anomaly in the amount of glycine, the simplest (and the only achiral) proteinogenic amino acid that has a single hydrogen atom as its side chain; glycine is a major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the mammalian central nervous system

Subject: increased glycine level
Value: increase in the amount of glycine, the simplest (and the only achiral) proteinogenic amino acid that has a single hydrogen atom as its side chain

Subject: decreased glycine level
Value: reduction in the amount of glycine, the simplest (and the only achiral) proteinogenic amino acid that has a single hydrogen atom as its side chain

Subject: abnormal circulating arginine level
Value: aberrant concentration in the blood of arginine, an alpha-amino acid that is glycine in which the alpha- is substituted by a 3-guanidinopropyl group

Subject: increased circulating arginine level
Value: increase in the amount per unit of blood of arginine, an alpha-amino acid that is glycine in which the alpha- is substituted by a 3-guanidinopropyl group; usually associated with a deficiency of arginase

Subject: decreased circulating arginine level
Value: reduction in the amount per unit of blood of arginine, an alpha-amino acid that is glycine in which the alpha- is substituted by a 3-guanidinopropyl group

Subject: abnormal arginine level
Value: anomaly in the amount of arginine, an alpha-amino acid that is glycine in which the alpha- is substituted by a 3-guanidinopropyl group

Subject: increased arginine level
Value: increase in the amount of arginine, an alpha-amino acid that is glycine in which the alpha- is substituted by a 3-guanidinopropyl group

Subject: abnormal ischiofemoral ligament morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the triangular band of strong fibers on the posterior side of the hip joint; its fibers span from the ischium at a point below and behind the acetabulum to blend with the circular fibers at the posterior end of the joint capsule and attach at the intertrochanteric line of the femur

Subject: abnormal calcaneal tendon morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the large, strong tendon that serves to attach the plantaris, gastrocnemius (calf) and soleus muscles to the calcaneus (heel) bone

Subject: calcified calcaneal tendon
Value: pathologic deposition of calcium salts in the large, strong tendon that serves to attach the plantaris, gastrocnemius (calf) and soleus muscles to the calcaneus (heel) bone

Subject: abnormal urine citrate level
Value: any anomaly in the urinary amount of citrate, 2-hydroxy-1,2,3-propanetricarboyxlate, an important intermediate in the tricarboxylic acid cycle

Subject: increased urine citrate level
Value: greater than the normal urinary amount of citrate, 2-hydroxy-1,2,3-propanetricarboyxlate, an important intermediate in the tricarboxylic acid cycle

Subject: decreased urine citrate level
Value: less than the normal urinary amount of citrate, 2-hydroxy-1,2,3-propanetricarboyxlate, an important intermediate in the tricarboxylic acid cycle

Subject: increased urine glycerol level
Value: an increased amount of glycerol in the urine compared to the normal state

Subject: decreased urine glycerol level
Value: a reduced amount of glycerol in the urine compared to the normal state

Subject: abnormal urine glycerol level
Value: any change in the amount of glycerol in the urine

Subject: abnormal posterior longitudinal ligament morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the ligament that runs within the vertebral canal along the posterior aspect of the vertebral bodies; it is attached mainly to the intervertebral (IV) discs and less so to the posterior aspects of the vertebral bodies from C2 (axis) to the sacrum, often bridging fat and vessels between the ligament and the bony surface; it weakly resists hyperflexion of the vertebral column and helps prevent or redirect posterior herniation of the nucleus pulposus of an IV disc; the posterior longitudinal ligament is well provided with nociceptive (pain) nerve endings and is a much narrower, somewhat weaker band than the anterior longitudinal ligament

Subject: abnormal iliofemoral ligament morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the strong triangular ligament that is attached by its apex to the anterior inferior spine of the ilium and acetabular margin and by its base to the intertrochanteric line of the femur; it stabilizes the hip joint and limits extension and lateral rotation of the hip

Subject: abnormal falciform ligament morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the broad and thin, sickle-shaped peritoneal ligament that attaches the liver to the anterior body wall and is a remnant of the ventral mesentery of the fetus; it is situated in an anteroposterior plane but lies obliquely so that one surface faces forward and is in contact with the peritoneum behind the right rectus abdominis and the diaphragm, while the other is directed backwards and is in contact with the left lobe of the liver

Subject: absent falciform ligament
Value: missing the broad and thin, sickle-shaped peritoneal ligament that attaches the liver to the anterior body wall and is a remnant of the ventral mesentery of the fetus; normally, it is situated in an anteroposterior plane but lies obliquely so that one surface faces forward and is in contact with the peritoneum behind the right rectus abdominis and the diaphragm, while the other is directed backwards and is in contact with the left lobe of the liver

Subject: abnormal cranial suspensory ligament morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the ligament that connects the cranial tip of the future gonad to the dorsocranial abdominal cavity; during male embryogenesis, outgrowth of the gubernaculum and regression of the CSL result in transabdominal descent of the testes, whereas in the female, development of the CSL in conjunction with failure of the gubernaculum development holds the ovaries in a position lateral to the kidney

Subject: abnormal femur head morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the highest, globular part of the thigh bone which comprises two-thirds of a sphere and articulates with the acetabulum in the pelvic bone forming the hip joint; the head is attached to the femoral body or shaft by the neck of the femur; its surface is smooth, coated with cartilage in the fresh state, except over an ovoid depression, the fovea capitis femoris, which is situated a little below and behind the center of the head, and gives attachment to the ligament of head of femur

Subject: abnormal femur neck morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the flattened pyramidal process of bone, connecting the femoral head with the femoral shaft, and forming with the latter a wide angle opening medialward

Subject: coxa vara
Value: a hip deformity that includes all forms of decrease of the femoral neck shaft angle (the angle between the neck and the shaft of the femur) to less than 120 degrees; it may be congenital often syndromic, acquired, or developmental

Subject: club-shaped femur
Value: an abnormal conformation of the femur that becomes gradually enlarged at one end

Subject: large femur head
Value: increased size of the femur head

Subject: short femur neck
Value: decreased length of the femur neck

Subject: broad femur neck
Value: increased width of the femur neck

Subject: joint dislocation
Value: displacement of one or more bones of a joint from the normal position; common sites include the shoulder, patella, elbow, wrist, finger and hip; a partial dislocation is referred to as a subluxation

Subject: hip dislocation
Value: displacement of the femur from its normal location in the hip joint

Subject: joint laxity
Value: looseness or lack of stability of a joint; may be caused by a number of factors including intraarticular disease and injury or slacking of extraarticular structures such as joint capsules, ligaments, and muscles

Subject: joint contracture
Value: chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement of joints; a flexion contracture is a bent (flexed) joint that cannot be straightened actively or passively

Subject: abnormal tendon sheath morphology
Value: <any structural anomaly of the membrane that wraps around a tendon; it allows the tendon to stretch and prevents it from adhering to the overlying fascia; tendon sheaths consist of two layers: a fibrous layer, made of tight collagenous tissue, and a synovial layer; the synovial part of the tendon sheath consists of a visceral and parietal layer separated by synovial fluid, which keeps the tendon moist and lubricated>

Subject: abnormal patellar ligament morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the central portion of the common tendon of the quadriceps femoris; it is attached to the apex of the patella and to the lower part of the tubercle of the tibia; it is sometimes called the patellar tendon as it is a continuation of the quadriceps tendon

Subject: tendonitis
Value: inflammation of a tendon

Subject: abnormal tendon physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of the fibrous bands or cords of connective tissue at the ends of muscle fibers that attach muscles to bones and other structures

Subject: abnormal tendon cell morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the elongated fibrocytes in which the cytoplasm is stretched between the collagen fibers of the tendon; tendon cells have a central cell nucleus with a prominent nucleolus, a well-developed rough endoplasmic reticulum, and are responsible for synthesis and turnover of tendon fibers and ground substance

Subject: abnormal synovial joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any joint in which the articulating bones or cartilages are connected by an articular capsule which encloses a synovial membrane and a synovial cavity (e.g. temporomandibular joint, knee joint)

Subject: abnormal limb joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any joint that is part of a (free) limb

Subject: abnormal autopod joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any limb joint that is part of an autopod

Subject: abnormal forelimb joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any limb joint that is part of a forelimb

Subject: abnormal hindlimb joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any limb joint that is part of a hindlimb

Subject: abnormal humeroradial joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the hinge joint between the head of the radius and the capitulum of the humerus

Subject: abnormal atlanto-occipital joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of either of a pair of condyloid synovial joints between the superior articular facets of the atlas and the condyles of the occipital bone

Subject: abnormal hand joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any skeletal joint that is part of a hand (manus)

Subject: abnormal metacarpophalangeal joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the condylar or ellipsoid synovial joints between the heads of the metacarpal bones and the bases of the proximal phalanges

Subject: abnormal hand interphalangeal joint morphology
Value: <any structural anomaly of any hinge-joints of the phalanges of the hand; there are two sets in each finger (except in the thumb): (i) proximal interphalangeal joints (PIP), those between the first (also called proximal) and second (intermediate) phalanges and (ii) distal interphalangeal joints (DIP), those between the second and third (distal) phalanges; a similar group of articulations also function in the toes>

Subject: abnormal wrist joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the joint connecting the forelimb zeugopod skeleton with the carpal skeleton

Subject: abnormal radiocarpal joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the major condyloid synovial joint of the wrist which occurs proximally between the distal end of the radius and the articular disc of the distal radioulnar joint, and distally by the proximal carpal row (the scaphoid, lunate and triquetral bones)

Subject: abnormal shoulder joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the joint that is formed by the union of the humerus, the scapula (or shoulder blade), and the clavicle (or collarbone)

Subject: abnormal glenohumeral joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the main articulation of the shoulder joint; the glenohumeral joint is the multiaxial ball-and-socket synovial joint formed by the articular surfaces of the glenoid cavity of the scapula and the head of the humerus

Subject: abnormal girdle joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any skeletal joint that is part of an appendage girdle region

Subject: abnormal pelvic girdle joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any synovial joint that is part of a pelvic girdle region

Subject: abnormal pectoral girdle joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any synovial joint that is part of a pectoral girdle region

Subject: abnormal sacroiliac joint morphology
