Value: any structural anomaly of the synovial joint that forms between the lateral articulating surfaces of the sacrum and the articulating surfaces of the ilium; it is supported by a number of strong ligaments which increase joint stability and reduce the incidence of dislocations

Subject: sacroiliac joint inflammation
Value: inflammation of one or both of the sacroiliac joints; it may be a symptom of other inflammatory arthritic conditions

Subject: increased femur size
Value: greater than average size of the long bone of the thigh (femur)

Subject: increased femur weight
Value: greater than average weight of the long bone of the thigh (femur)

Subject: decreased femur size
Value: less than average size of the long bone of the thigh (femur)

Subject: decreased femur weight
Value: less than average weight of the long bone of the thigh (femur)

Subject: femur fracture
Value: a crack or break in the long bone of the thigh (femur)

Subject: abnormal obturator foramen morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the large opening created by the ischium and pubis bones of the pelvis through which nerves and blood vessels pass

Subject: abnormal hip joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the multi-axial, ball-and-socket synovial joint between the femur head and the acetabulum of the innominate bone

Subject: abnormal acetabulum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the large cup-shaped cavity on the anterolateral aspect of the pelvis that articulates with the femoral head to form the hip joint; it is formed by the three bones of the pelvis (the ischium, ilium and pubis) and is the socket portion of the ball-and-socket hip joint

Subject: abnormal glenoid fossa morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the shallow, pyriform articular surface located on the lateral angle of the scapula; it is directed laterally and forward and articulates with the head of the humerus

Subject: abnormal scapular coracoid process morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the hook-shaped bone structure that projects anterolaterally from the superior aspect of the scapular neck and serves as an important anchor for several tendinous and ligamentous structures

Subject: small acromion
Value: reduced size of the outer end of the spine of the scapula that protects the glenoid cavity, forms the outer angle of the shoulder, and articulates with the clavicle

Subject: acromion hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the outer end of the spine of the scapula that protects the glenoid cavity, forms the outer angle of the shoulder, and articulates with the clavicle

Subject: abnormal ankle joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a joint that connects the hindlimb autopod and zeugopod skeletons

Subject: abnormal tibiofibular joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of a joint that connects the tibia and the fibula

Subject: abnormal knee joint morphology
Value: <any structural anomaly of the synovial hinge joint formed between the femur, tibia, and patella; it involves two articulations: the tibiofemoral joint, connecting the proximal tibia to the distal femur, and the patellofemoral joint, connecting the patella to the femur; the knee joint allows flexion and extension of the leg, as well as slight medial rotation in end extension, and lateral rotation when unlocking the knee>

Subject: abnormal acetabular fossa morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the roughened depression in the acetabular floor which extends superiorly from the acetabular notch and hosts the ligamentum teres

Subject: abnormal acetabular notch morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the deep notch (depression) located anteroinferiorly along the margin of the acetabulum; it is bridged by the transverse ligament and thus forms the acetabular foramen through which nutrient vessels and nerves enter the hip joint; the ligamentum teres has part of its origin from the acetabular notch

Subject: abnormal acetabular labrum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the horse-shaped fibrocartilaginous structure that attaches to the peripheral rim of the acetabulum, contacts the articular surface of the femoral head, and blends inferiorly with the transverse acetabular ligament; it increases the depth of the acetabulum, increasing static stability and contributes to hydrostatic pressurization of the intra-articular space, joint lubrication, and load distribution

Subject: abnormal transverse acetabular ligament morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the fibrous continuation of the acetabular labrum that is completely collagenous and contains no chondrocytes or cartilage; it consists of strong, flattened fibers which cross the acetabular notch and convert it into the acetabular foramen through which nutrient vessels and nerves enter the hip joint; it prevents inferior displacement of head of femur

Subject: absent subarcuate fossa
Value: missing the irregular depression normally found on the posterior inner surface of the petrous portion of the temporal bone just below its crest and above and lateral to the internal acoustic meatus

Subject: elbow dislocation
Value: dislocation of the distal humerus out of the elbow joint, where the radius, ulna, and humerus meet

Subject: abnormal pubis body morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the flattened medial portion of the pubic bone entering into the pubic symphysis; superior and inferior rami extend from it; the body forms one-fifth of the acetabulum, contributing by its external surface both to the lunate surface and the acetabular fossa; its internal surface enters into the formation of the wall of the lesser pelvis and gives origin to a portion of the obturator internus

Subject: abnormal pubic ramus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of either of the two bar-like processes (branches or rami) of the pubic bone that extend laterally and posteriorly from the pubic symphysis; the inferior ramus articulates with the ischium; the superior ramus articulates with the ilium and forms the front of the acetabulum

Subject: abnormal superior pubic ramus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bar of bone, triangular in section, which extends posterosuperiorly from the body of the pubis to form the superior boundary of the obturator foramen; it contributes about one fifth of the articular surface of the acetabulum

Subject: abnormal inferior pubic ramus morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the inferior extension from body of pubic bone that meets with the ramus of the ischium below the obturator foramen to form the ischiopubic ramus

Subject: short ilium
Value: reduced length of the broad, flaring portion of the hip bone, which is distinct at birth, but later fuses with the ischium and the pubis

Subject: wide ilium
Value: increased width of the broad, flaring portion of the hip bone, which is distinct at birth, but later fuses with the ischium and the pubis

Subject: abnormal ilium body morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the thick lower part (base) of the ilium that forms about the upper two-fifths of the acetabulum; its external surface is partly articular, partly non-articular; the articular segment forms part of the lunate surface of the acetabulum, the non-articular portion contributes to the acetabular fossa; the internal surface of the body is part of the wall of the lesser pelvis and gives origin to some fibers of the obturator internus; below, it is continuous with the pelvic surfaces of the ischium and pubis, only a faint line indicating the place of union

Subject: abnormal iliac fossa morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the large, smooth, concave surface on the internal surface of the ilium; the fossa is bounded above by the iliac crest, below by the arcuate line, and in front and behind, by the anterior and posterior borders of the ilium; it gives origin to the iliacus muscle

Subject: abnormal ilium wing morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the large, expanded (wing-like) portion of the ilium which bounds the greater pelvis laterally

Subject: abnormal iliac crest morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the superior border of the wing of ilium and the superolateral margin of the greater pelvis; it runs from the anterior superior iliac spine to the posterior superior iliac spine; many of the important abdominal and core muscles are attached to the iliac crest

Subject: atlanto-occipital joint dislocation
Value: separation of the joints formed by the occipital condyles and the atlas (C-1)

Subject: abnormal olecranon fossa morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the deep triangular depression on the posterior side of the humerus, superior to the trochlea, in which the summit of the olecranon is received during extension of the forearm

Subject: abnormal olecranon morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the large bony prominence at the proximal end of the ulna which articulates with the olecranon fossa of the humerus and is palpable at the posterior aspect of the elbow; while the olecranon is an attachment site for several muscle groups including the flexor carpi ulnaris and anconeus, the major muscle attachment is that of the triceps brachii muscle

Subject: absent olecranon
Value: missing the large bony prominence at the proximal end of the ulna which articulates with the olecranon fossa of the humerus and is palpable at the posterior aspect of the elbow

Subject: small olecranon
Value: size reduction of the large bony prominence at the proximal end of the ulna which articulates with the olecranon fossa of the humerus and is palpable at the posterior aspect of the elbow

Subject: absent sesamoid bone of gastrocnemius
Value: missing the small sesamoid bones situated behind the condyles of the femur

Subject: patellar dislocation
Value: complete displacement of the patella (kneecap) from its normal position in the patellofemoral groove (trochlea), the V-shaped notch on the front of the femur; the most common direction for a dislocated patella is lateral

Subject: abnormal triquetrum morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the bone in the proximal row of the carpus that has a pyramidal shape and that is situated between the lunate and pisiform bones

Subject: absent triquetrum
Value: missing the bone in the proximal row of the carpus that has a pyramidal shape and that is situated between the lunate and pisiform bones

Subject: decreased joint mobility
Value: reduced ability to move joints in a full range of motion and with ease

Subject: wrist dislocation
Value: displacement of any of the small carpal bones which make up the wrist out of their normal position in the wrist joint

Subject: abnormal synovial joint cavity morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the minute space enclosed by the synovial membrane and articular cartilages in a synovial joint; it is the site at which the articulating surfaces of the bones contact each other; it contains synovial fluid, a highly viscous, hyaluronic acid–rich fluid that lubricates the joint surfaces

Subject: abnormal synovial joint membrane morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the connective tissue membrane that lines the cavity of a synovial joint and produces the synovial fluid; it lines all internal surfaces of the cavity except for the articular cartilage of the bones

Subject: small thyroid cartilage
Value: size reduction of the largest of the laryngeal cartilages

Subject: absent thyroid cartilage
Value: missing the largest of the laryngeal cartilages

Subject: thyroid cartilage hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or decreased size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the largest of the laryngeal cartilages

Subject: abnormal superior horn of thyroid cartilage morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of either of a pair of upward projections from the posterior border of the thyroid cartilage; it is long and narrow, directed upward, backward, and medialward, and ends in a conical extremity, which gives attachment to the lateral hyothyroid ligament

Subject: abnormal inferior horn of thyroid cartilage morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of either of a pair of downward projections from the posterior border of the thyroid cartilage; it is short and thick, directed downward, with a slight inclination forward and medialward, and presents, on the medial side of its tip, a small oval articular facet for articulation with the side of the cricoid cartilage

Subject: small cricoid cartilage
Value: size reduction of the most inferior of the laryngeal cartilages

Subject: absent cricoid cartilage
Value: missing the most inferior of the laryngeal cartilages

Subject: cricoid cartilage hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or decreased size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the most inferior of the laryngeal cartilages

Subject: abnormal cartilaginous joint morphology
Value: <any structural anomaly of any joint that lacks a joint cavity and involves bones that are joined together by either hyaline cartilage or fibrocartilage; there are two main types: synchondroses (or primary cartilaginous joints) where the bones are united by hyaline cartilage, and symphyses (or secondary cartilaginous joints) where the bones are united by a layer of fibrocartilage>

Subject: abnormal costochondral joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the hyaline cartilaginous joint (synchondrosis) between each rib and its costal cartilage; the articulation is between the cup-shaped depression in the sternal end of a rib and the lateral end of a costal cartilage; the rib and its cartilage are firmly bound together by the continuity of the periosteum of the rib with the perichondrium of the cartilage; no movement normally occurs at these joints

Subject: abnormal symphysis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any cartilaginous joint in which the articulating bones or cartilages are connected by fibrocartilage; a symphysis is a slightly movable joint (amphiarthrosis)

Subject: abnormal fibrous joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any joint that lacks a joint cavity and involves bones that are joined together by dense fibrous connective tissue, consisting mainly of collagen; most (but not all) fibrous joints are immovable (synarthroses)

Subject: abnormal syndesmosis morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any fibrous joint where the gap between two adjacent bones may be narrow, with the bones joined by ligaments, or the gap may be wide and filled in by a broad sheet of connective tissue called an interosseous membrane; syndemoses are slightly moveable (amphiarthrodial)

Subject: abnormal infrapatellar fat pad morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the partly adipose wedge-shaped mass formed in the anterior region of the knee that is intracapsular but extrasynovial (and thus extra-articular); it extends superiorly from the patella and alar folds to the tibia and infrapatellar bursa and is delimited anteriorly by the patellar ligament and joint capsule and posteriorly by the synovial membrane

Subject: abnormal knee morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the segment of the hindlimb that corresponds to the joint connecting a hindlimb stylopod and zeugopod

Subject: abnormal radius head morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the proximal articular surface of the radius that forms part of the elbow joint and that is palpable on the lateral side of the elbow, immediately distal to the lateral epicondyle of the humerus; the radial head articulates with the ulna at the proximal radioulnar joint and with the humerus at the radiohumeral joint; at the proximal radioulnar joint, the radial head sits in the radial notch of the proximal ulna and is held in place by the annular ligaments; at the radiohumeral joint, the radial head sits adjacent to the capitellum of the humerus

Subject: dislocated radius head
Value: a dislocation of the head of the radius from its socket in the elbow joint

Subject: rachitic rosary
Value: abnormal expansion of the anterior rib ends at the costochondral junctions; most frequently seen in rickets as nodularity (prominent bony knobs) at the costochondral junctions

Subject: increased radius size
Value: greater than average size of the short bone of the lateral forearm

Subject: decreased radius size
Value: less than average size of the short bone of the lateral forearm

Subject: abnormal sternoclavicular joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the synovial joint between the clavicle and the manubrium of the sternum; it is the only attachment of the upper limb to the axial skeleton and consists of the sternal end of the clavicle, the manubrium of the sternum, and part of the first costal cartilage; the articular surfaces are covered with fibrocartilage (as opposed to hyaline cartilage); the joint is separated into two compartments by a fibrocartilaginous articular disk

Subject: absent arytenoid cartilage
Value: missing the paired triangular cartilages that normally are located postlaterally at the level of the thyroid cartilage

Subject: small arytenoid cartilage
Value: size reduction of the paired triangular cartilages located postlaterally at the level of the thyroid cartilage

Subject: arytenoid cartilage hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or decreased size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the paired triangular cartilages located postlaterally at the level of the thyroid cartilage

Subject: small epiglottis
Value: size reduction of the most superior of the laryngeal cartilages, which is found at the root of the tongue and folds back over the entrance to the larynx during swallowing, preventing inhalation of food or drink

Subject: epiglottis hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or decreased size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the most superior of the laryngeal cartilages, which is found at the root of the tongue and folds back over the entrance to the larynx during swallowing, preventing inhalation of food or drink

Subject: enlarged epiglottis
Value: increased size of the most superior of the laryngeal cartilages, which is found at the root of the tongue and folds back over the entrance to the larynx during swallowing, preventing inhalation of food or drink

Subject: epiglottis hyperplasia
Value: overdevelopment or increased size, usually due to an increased number of cells, of the most superior of the laryngeal cartilages, which is found at the root of the tongue and folds back over the entrance to the larynx during swallowing, preventing inhalation of food or drink

Subject: abnormal tibiofemoral joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the modified hinge synovial joint that joins the distal femur to the proximal tibia; it is the weight-bearing joint of the knee; the articulation occurs between the medial and lateral femoral condyles and the tibial condyles

Subject: abnormal patellofemoral joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the synovial joint between the condyles of the femur and the articular surface of the patella

Subject: abnormal humeroulnar joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the simple hinge-type synovial joint between the trochlea on the medial aspect of the distal end of the humerus and the trochlear notch on the proximal ulna

Subject: abnormal first sternocostal joint morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the synchondrosis type of cartilaginous joint in which hyaline cartilage unites the first rib to the manubrium of the sternum.; it forms an immobile joint (synarthrosis); the rest of the sternocostal joints are synovial plane joints

Subject: laryngeal cleft
Value: presence of a gap in the posterior laryngotracheal wall with a continuity between the larynx and the esopahagus

Subject: decreased ulna size
Value: less than average size of the medial and larger of the two bones of the forearm

Subject: increased ulna size
Value: greater than average size of the medial and larger of the two bones of the forearm

Subject: abnormal ulnar styloid process morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the cylindrical, pointed, palpable projection from the medial and posterior aspect of the head of the ulna, to the tip of which is attached the ulnar collateral ligament of the wrist

Subject: small ulnar styloid process
Value: reduced size of the cylindric, pointed, palpable projection from the medial and posterior aspect of the head of the ulna, to the tip of which is attached the ulnar collateral ligament of the wrist

Subject: abnormal melanoblast physiology
Value: any functional anomaly of a cell that originates from the neural crest and differentiates into a pigment cell

Subject: abnormal melanoblast proliferation
Value: anomaly in the ability of melanoblasts to undergo expansion by cell division; a melanoblast is a cell that originates from the neural crest and differentiates into a pigment cell

Subject: decreased melanoblast proliferation
Value: reduction in the expansion rate of melanoblasts by cell division; a melanoblast is a cell that originates from the neural crest and differentiates into a pigment cell

Subject: increased melanoblast proliferation
Value: increase in the expansion rate of melanoblasts by cell division; a melanoblast is a cell that originates from the neural crest and differentiates into a pigment cell

Subject: abnormal melanocyte differentiation
Value: any anomaly in the process in which a relatively unspecialized cell acquires specialized features of a melanocyte

Subject: abnormal melanocyte adhesion
Value: any anomaly in the adhesive properties of melanocytes, resulting in abnormal cell to cell and cell to extracellular matrix (ECM) interactions

Subject: abnormal melanoblast apoptosis
Value: change in the timing or the number of melanoblasts undergoing programmed cell death; a melanoblast is a cell that originates from the neural crest and differentiates into a pigment cell

Subject: increased melanoblast apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of melanoblasts undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: decreased melanoblast apoptosis
Value: reduction in the number of melanoblasts undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal melanosome formation
Value: any anomaly in the aggregation, arrangement or bonding together of a set of components required to form a melanosome, a tissue-specific, membrane-bounded cytoplasmic organelle within which melanin pigments are synthesized and stored

Subject: abnormal endosome to melanosome transport
Value: any anomaly in the directed movement of substances from endosomes to the melanosome, a tissue-specific, membrane-bounded cytoplasmic organelle within which melanin pigments are synthesized and stored

Subject: abnormal melanosome maturation
Value: any anomaly in the developmental processes that are required for a melanosome to attain its fully functional state; melanosome maturation occurs through sequential stages (I-IV) that can be defined based on morphology and melanin content; stage I pre-melanosomes are roughly spherical, lack pigment, contain intraluminal vesicles, and resemble multivesicular bodies i.e. structures found along the endosomal pathway; stage II melanosomes are elongated (ellipsoidal) in shape, lack pigment, and contain intraluminal matrix fibers organized in a striated array; deposition of melanin along the matrix fibers begins in stage III melanosomes; stage IV melanosomes, corresponding to fully-melanized mature organelles, are characterized by a dense homogeneous deposit of melanin that covers all the internal structures of the matrix

Subject: abnormal melanosome size
Value: anomaly in the average size of the tissue-specific, membrane-bounded cytoplasmic organelle within which melanin pigments are synthesized and stored

Subject: enlarged melanosome
Value: greater than average size of the tissue-specific, membrane-bounded cytoplasmic organelle within which melanin pigments are synthesized and stored; giant melanosomes may become frequent in conditions of pathological melanogenesis

Subject: small melanosome
Value: less than average size of the tissue-specific, membrane-bounded cytoplasmic organelle within which melanin pigments are synthesized and stored

Subject: absent hair follicle bulb
Value: missing the thickening of the proximal end of the hair follicle that contains rapidly proliferating, rather undifferentiated matrix cells (transient amplifying cells), melanocytes and outer root sheath cells

Subject: small hair follicle bulb
Value: reduced size of the thickening of the proximal end of the hair follicle that contains rapidly proliferating, rather undifferentiated matrix cells (transient amplifying cells), melanocytes and outer root sheath cells

Subject: abnormal hair club morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the club-shaped structure which forms from keratinized epithelial cells at the base of the hair shaft during catagen, and interdigitates with the surrounding outer root sheath to anchor the hair in place; the club is necessary for the retention of a completed hair

Subject: absent hair club
Value: missing the club-shaped structure which forms from keratinized epithelial cells at the base of the hair shaft during catagen, and interdigitates with the surrounding outer root sheath to anchor the hair in place; the club is necessary for the retention of a completed hair

Subject: abnormal hair follicle ostium morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the openings of the hair follicles through which the hair fibers emerge from the skin

Subject: early exit from telogen phase
Value: anomaly in the resting or quiescent phase of the hair growth cycle resulting a shortened telogen phase

Subject: early exit from anagen phase
Value: anomaly in the growth phase of the hair cycle resulting a shortened anagen phase

Subject: increased skin pigmentation
Value: visually detectable excess of pigment present in the skin

Subject: decreased telomere length
Value: reduction in the average length of the terminal repetitive DNA section of a chromosome that is involved in chromosomal replication and senescence and protects the end of the chromosome from deterioration; normal length is a few hundred base pairs

Subject: increased telomere length
Value: increase in the average length of the terminal repetitive DNA section of a chromosome that is involved in chromosomal replication and senescence and protects the end of the chromosome from deterioration; normal length is a few hundred base pairs

Subject: increased digit pigmentation
Value: visually detectable excess of pigment present on the finger or toe surface

Subject: decreased digit pigmentation
Value: visually detectable dilution of pigment present on the finger or toe surface

Subject: increased nipple pigmentation
Value: visually detectable excess of pigment present on the surface of the nipple and/or areola

Subject: hypopyon
Value: an accumulation of pus or white blood cells in the anterior chamber of the eye, appearing as a whitish or gray fluid between the cornea and the iris

Subject: hyphema
Value: hemorrhage within the anterior chamber of the eye

Subject: decreased primordial germ cell proliferation
Value: reduced ability of a primordial germ cell population to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: increased primordial germ cell apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of primordial germ cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: increased mitochondrial DNA content
Value: greater than expected amount of DNA contained within the mirochondria of a eukaryotic cell

Subject: abnormal reticulophagy
Value: any anomaly in the selective autohagy process in which parts of the endoplasmic reticulum are loaded into autophagosomes, delivered to the vacuole, and degraded in response to changing cellular conditions

Subject: abnormal autophagosome formation
Value: any anomaly in the formation of a double membrane-bounded structure, the autophagosome, that occurs when a specialized membrane sac, called the isolation membrane, starts to enclose a portion of the cytoplasm

Subject: impaired autophagy
Value: impairment of the catabolic process involving the degradation of a cell's own components through the lysosomal machinery

Subject: enhanced autophagy
Value: enhancement of the catabolic process involving the degradation of a cell's own components through the lysosomal machinery

Subject: abnormal microtubule organizing center morphology
Value: any anomaly of the intracellular structure that can catalyze gamma-tubulin-dependent microtubule nucleation and that can anchor microtubules by interacting with their minus ends, plus ends or sides

Subject: abnormal centrosome morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the non-membrane-bound organelle comprised of a core structure (in most organisms, a pair of centrioles) and peripheral material from which a microtubule-based structure, such as a spindle apparatus, is organized; centrosomes occur close to the nucleus during interphase in many eukaryotic cells, though in animal cells it changes continually during the cell-division cycle

Subject: abnormal pericentriolar material morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the network of small fibers that surrounds the centrioles; it contains the microtubule nucleating activity of the centrosome

Subject: abnormal myoblast migration
Value: any anomaly in the orderly movement of a myoblast from one site to another during development; a myoblast is a mononucleate cell type that, by fusion with other myoblasts, gives rise to the myotubes that eventually develop into striated muscle fibers

Subject: abnormal myoblast proliferation
Value: anomaly in the ability of myoblasts to undergo expansion by cell division; a myoblast is a mononucleate cell type that, by fusion with other myoblasts, gives rise to the myotubes that eventually develop into striated muscle fibers

Subject: increased myoblast proliferation
Value: increase in the expansion rate of myoblasts by cell division; a myoblast is a mononucleate cell type that, by fusion with other myoblasts, gives rise to the myotubes that eventually develop into striated muscle fibers

Subject: decreased myoblast proliferation
Value: reduction in the expansion rate of myoblasts by cell division; a myoblast is a mononucleate cell type that, by fusion with other myoblasts, gives rise to the myotubes that eventually develop into striated muscle fibers

Subject: abnormal Golgi vesicle transport
Value: any anomaly in the directed movement of substances into, out of or within the Golgi apparatus, mediated by vesicles

Subject: abnormal synaptic vesicle exocytosis
Value: anomaly in the fusion of intracellular membrane-bounded vesicles with the pre-synaptic membrane of the neuronal cell resulting in impaired release of neurotransmitter into the synaptic cleft

Subject: abnormal endocytosis
Value: any anomaly in the vesicle-mediated transport process in which cells take up external materials or membrane constituents by the invagination of a small region of the plasma membrane to form a new membrane-bounded vesicle

Subject: abnormal Golgi stack morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the set of thin, flattened membrane-bounded compartments, called cisternae, which form the central portion of the Golgi complex; the stack usually comprises cis, medial, and trans cisternae; the cis- and trans-Golgi networks are not considered part of the stack

Subject: abnormal Golgi cisterna morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the thin, flattened membrane-bounded compartments that form the central portion of the Golgi complex

Subject: abnormal Golgi cis cisterna morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the Golgi cisterna closest to the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), the first processing compartment through which proteins pass after export from the ER

Subject: abnormal Golgi trans cisterna morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the Golgi cisterna farthest from the endoplasmic reticulum, the final processing compartment through which proteins pass before exiting the Golgi apparatus; this is the compartment in which N-linked protein glycosylation is completed

Subject: abnormal neuronal precursor cell migration
Value: any anomaly in the orderly movement of a neuroblast embryonic cell from one site to another during development

Subject: abnormal myotube morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of any of the multinucleated cells that are formed when proliferating myoblasts exit the cell cycle, differentiate and fuse

Subject: abnormal myotube differentiation
Value: any anomaly in the process in which a relatively unspecialized cell acquires specialized features of a myotube cell; myotube differentiation starts with myoblast fusion and the appearance of specific cell markers (this is the cell development step); then individual myotubes fuse to form bigger myotubes and start to contract

Subject: abnormal myoblast fusion
Value: any anomaly in the process in which non-proliferating myoblasts fuse to existing fibers or to myotubes to form new fibers; a myoblast is a mononucleate cell type that, by fusion with other myoblasts, gives rise to the myotubes that eventually develop into skeletal muscle fibers

Subject: abnormal diapedesis
Value: any anomaly in the passage of a leukocyte between the tight junctions of endothelial cells lining blood vessels, typically the fourth and final step of cellular extravasation

Subject: abnormal outer hair cell kinocilium location or orientation
Value: outer hair cell kinocilia are displaced from the normal position and/or do not orient in a typical pattern

Subject: abnormal inner hair cell kinocilium location or orientation
Value: inner hair cell kinocilia are displaced from the normal position and/or do not orient in a typical pattern

Subject: abnormal brain ependyma motile cilium location or orientation
Value: brain ependyma motile cilia are displaced from the normal position and/or do not orient in a typical pattern

Subject: decreased brain ependyma motile cilium length
Value: reduced length of the tiny, motile hair-like projections from the epithelial cells that line the ventricles in the brain, which beat in concert to move cerebrospinal fluid

Subject: increased brain ependyma motile cilium length
Value: increased length of the tiny, motile hair-like projections from the epithelial cells that line the ventricles in the brain, which beat in concert to move cerebrospinal fluid

Subject: decreased brain ependyma motile cilium number
Value: reduced number of the tiny, motile hair-like projections from the epithelial cells that line the ventricles in the brain, which beat in concert to move cerebrospinal fluid

Subject: abnormal circulating adiponectin level
Value: any anomaly in the blood concentration of a protein hormone that regulates glucose homeostasis and metabolism of lipids; it is normally produced by adipose tissue

Subject: decreased circulating adiponectin level
Value: less than the normal concentration in the blood of a protein hormone that regulates glucose homeostasis and metabolism of lipids; it is normally produced by adipose tissue

Subject: increased circulating adiponectin level
Value: greater than the normal concentration in the blood of a protein hormone that regulates glucose homeostasis and metabolism of lipids; it is normally produced by adipose tissue

Subject: ketosis
Value: an abnormal increase of ketone bodies in the body tissues; it is typically pathological in conditions such as diabetes, or may be the consequence of a diet that is very low in carbohydrates

Subject: ketoacidosis
Value: acidosis resulting from accumulation of ketone bodies

Subject: increased myoblast apoptosis
Value: increase in the number of myoblasts undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: impaired gluconeogenesis
Value: reduction in the rate of formation of glucose from noncarbohydrate precursors, such as pyruvate, amino acids and glycerol

Subject: enhanced gluconeogenesis
Value: increase in the rate of formation of glucose from noncarbohydrate precursors, such as pyruvate, amino acids and glycerol

Subject: placenta hemorrhage
Value: presence of bleeding in the placenta

Subject: impaired sperm penetration of zona pellucida
Value: reduced ability or inability of sperm to infiltrate the zona pellucida in order to reach the oocyte; the process involves digestive enzymes from a modified lysosome called the acrosome, situated at the head of the sperm

Subject: impaired sperm-egg recognition
Value: reduced ability or inability to establish the initial contact between the sperm plasma membrane and the outer layer of the egg during fertilization

Subject: impaired binding of sperm to zona pellucida
Value: reduced ability or inability to execute the process in which the sperm binds to the zona pellucida glycoprotein layer of the egg; the process begins with the attachment of the sperm plasma membrane to the zona pellucida and includes attachment of the acrosome inner membrane to the zona pellucida after the acrosomal reaction takes place

Subject: decreased spinal cord weight
Value: lower than average weight of the spinal cord

Subject: abnormal acroplaxome morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the F-actin-keratin cytoskeletal plate limited by a desmosome-like marginal ring that anchors the developing acrosome to the nuclear envelope and is thought to play a pivotal role in acrosome biogenesis and spermatid head shaping

Subject: abnormal dentate gyrus subgranular zone morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the the narrow layer of cells located between the granule cell layer and hilus of the dentate gyrus, where adult neurogenesis occurs

Subject: abnormal copulatory plug formation
Value: anomaly in the deposition of a plug of sperm or other gelatinous material into the opening of the vulva by a male at the termination of copulation; probably acts to prevent subsequent matings by other males

Subject: failure of copulatory plug formation
Value: inability to initiate and/or complete the deposition of a plug of sperm or other gelatinous material into the opening of the vulva by a male at the termination of copulation

Subject: increased circulating osteocalcin level
Value: greater than the normal blood concentration of this noncollagenous protein hormone found in bone and dentin, which is secreted by osteoblasts

Subject: decreased circulating osteocalcin level
Value: less than the normal blood concentration of this noncollagenous protein hormone found in bone and dentin, which is secreted by osteoblasts

Subject: striatum atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of the striatum associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes

Subject: spinal cord inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the spinal cord

Subject: dysosmia
Value: any qualitative alteration or distortion of the perception of smell; qualitative alterations differ from quantitative alterations, which include anosmia and hyposmia

Subject: decreased spongiotrophoblast cell number
Value: reduction in the number of trophoblast cells that arise in the junctional zone of the placenta

Subject: nerve inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in one or more nerves

Subject: optic nerve inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the optic nerve

Subject: atrioventricular cushion hypoplasia
Value: underdevelopment or reduced size, usually due to a reduced number of cells, of the mounds of embryonic connective tissue that bulge into the fetal atrioventricular canal

Subject: abnormal adipose tissue glycogen level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration of a readily converted carbohydrate reserve in adipose tissue

Subject: decreased adipose tissue glycogen level
Value: less than the normal concentration of a readily converted carbohydrate reserve in adipose tissue

Subject: increased adipose tissue glycogen level
Value: greater than the normal concentration of a readily converted carbohydrate reserve in adipose tissue

Subject: decreased pacinian corpuscle number
Value: fewer than the expected number of the rapidly adapting mechanoreceptors found in subcutaneous tissue beneath both hairy and glabrous skin which normally contain an afferent nerve fiber surrounded by a capsule with multiple concentric layers and transmit signals generated by vibrations when grasping an object

Subject: absent pacinian corpuscles
Value: absence of all of the rapidly adapting mechanoreceptors found in subcutaneous tissue beneath both hairy and glabrous skin which normally contain an afferent nerve fiber surrounded by a capsule with multiple concentric layers and transmit signals generated by vibrations when grasping an object

Subject: small pacinian corpuscles
Value: decreased size of the rapidly adapting mechanoreceptors found in subcutaneous tissue beneath both hairy and glabrous skin which normally contain an afferent nerve fiber surrounded by a capsule with multiple concentric layers and transmit signals generated by vibrations when grasping an object

Subject: abnormal glycogen synthesis
Value: any anomaly in the reactions and pathways involved in the formation of glycogen, a polydisperse, highly branched glucan composed of chains of D-glucose residues

Subject: decreased glycogen synthesis
Value: any anomaly in the reactions and pathways involved in glycogen biosynthesis that results in reduced glycogen formation

Subject: increased glycogen synthesis
Value: any anomaly in the reactions and pathways involved in glycogen biosynthesis that results in increased glycogen formation

Subject: abnormal kidney glycogen level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration of a readily converted carbohydrate reserve in kidney

Subject: increased kidney glycogen level
Value: greater than the normal concentration of a readily converted carbohydrate reserve in kidney

Subject: decreased kidney glycogen level
Value: less than the normal concentration of a readily converted carbohydrate reserve in kidney

Subject: abnormal lung glycogen level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration of a readily converted carbohydrate reserve in lung

Subject: increased lung glycogen level
Value: greater than the normal concentration of a readily converted carbohydrate reserve in lung

Subject: decreased lung glycogen level
Value: less than the normal concentration of a readily converted carbohydrate reserve in lung

Subject: decreased bone marrow adipose tissue amount
Value: decreased quantity of the bone marrow fat-storing cells/tissue

Subject: abnormal sperm-egg fusion
Value: any anomaly in the binding and fusion of a sperm with the plasma membrane of the oocyte during the process of fertilization

Subject: failure of sperm-egg fusion
Value: failure to initiate and/or complete the binding and fusion of a sperm with the plasma membrane of the oocyte during the process of fertilization

Subject: abnormal sperm migration in female genital tract
Value: any anomaly in the ability of ejaculated sperm to migrate through the female genital tract to reach the oocyte in the oviduct; during their transit in the female tract, sperm encounter different environments with various mechanical and biochemical properties; to complete the journey, each sperm has to swim in a highly viscous medium in the cervix, avoid immunological detection in the uterus, cross the uterotubal junction, and ascend into the oviduct isthmus to ultimately reach the site of fertilization, the ampullary region of the oviduct

Subject: impaired sperm migration in female genital tract
Value: impaired ability of ejaculated sperm to migrate through the female genital tract and reach the oocyte at the site of fertilization, the ampullary region of the oviduct

Subject: abnormal egg activation
Value: any anomaly in the series of biochemical and morphological events that converts a metaphase-II-arrested oocyte into a fertilized egg ready to begin embryogenesis; in most mammals, oocyte activation is a spatial-temporal regulated process induced by sperm entry that involves early events such a transient rise in intracellular calcium concentration, cortical granule exocytosis and meiotic cell-cycle resumption, and later events such as pronuclear formation, translation of maternal mRNAs and meiosis-to-mitosis transition

Subject: polyspermy
Value: increased incidence of fertilized oocytes fused with two or more sperm due to reduced ability or inability to prevent fertilization by multiple sperm during the egg activation process; normally only a single sperm fuses with the egg plasma membrane and injects its nucleus and other organelles into the egg cytoplasm; if more than one sperm fuses, multipolar or extra mitotic spindles are formed, resulting in faulty segregation of chromosomes during cell division; nondiploid cells are produced, and development usually stops

Subject: abnormal granulosa cell apoptosis
Value: change in the timing or the number of granulosa cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: decreased granulosa cell apoptosis
Value: decrease in the number of granulosa cells undergoing programmed cell death

Subject: abnormal granulosa cell proliferation
Value: anomaly in the ability of a granulosa cell population to undergo expansion by cell division

Subject: decreased granulosa cell proliferation
Value: reduction in the expansion rate of a granulosa cell population by cell division

Subject: increased granulosa cell proliferation
Value: increase in the expansion rate of a granulosa cell population by cell division

Subject: premature ovarian failure
Value: cessation of ovarian function occurring at an earlier than expected age

Subject: abnormal gallbladder smooth muscle morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the layer of loose smooth muscle bundles (tunica muscularis) located beneath the mucosa of the gallbladder wall and composed of fibers that are not arranged in distinct layers but lie in circular, longitudinal, and oblique directions; when these fibers contract, the gallbladder’s contents are released through the cystic duct into the bile duct and eventually emptied into the duodenum to aid in the digestion of fats

Subject: hepatic megalocytosis
Value: a condition in which hepatocytes exhibit gross enlargement of cytoplasmic and nuclear volume without the formation of mitotic spindles and mitosis, potentially indicating irreversible injury

Subject: decreased susceptibility to Riboviria infection induced morbidity/mortality
Value: decreased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by a Riboviria iinfection or from components of or toxins produced by a virus from this Realm

Subject: increased susceptibility to Riboviria infection induced morbidity/mortality
Value: increased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by a Riboviria iinfection or from components of or toxins produced by a virus from this Realm

Subject: decreased susceptibility to Herpesvirales infection induced morbidity/mortality
Value: decreased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by a Herpesvirales infection or from components of or toxins produced by a virus from this Order

Subject: increased susceptibility to Herpesvirales infection induced morbidity/mortality
Value: increased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by a Herpesvirales infection or from components of or toxins produced by a virus from this Order

Subject: decreased susceptibility to Ortervirales infection induced morbidity/mortality
Value: decreased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by an Ortervirales infection or from components of or toxins produced by a virus from this Order

Subject: increased susceptibility to Ortervirales infection induced morbidity/mortality
Value: increased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by an Ortervirales infection or from components of or toxins produced by a virus from this Order

Subject: decreased susceptibility to Parvoviridae infection induced morbidity/mortality
Value: decreased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by a Parvoviridae infection or from components of or toxins produced by a virus from this Family

Subject: increased susceptibility to Parvoviridae infection induced morbidity/mortality
Value: increased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by a Parvoviridae infection or from components of or toxins produced by a virus from this Family

Subject: decreased susceptibility to Hepadnaviridae infection induced morbidity/mortality
Value: decreased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by a Hepadnaviridae infection or from components of or toxins produced by a virus from this Family

Subject: increased susceptibility to Hepadnaviridae infection induced morbidity/mortality
Value: increased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by a Hepadnaviridae infection or from components of or toxins produced by a virus from this Family

Subject: decreased susceptibility to Poxviridae infection induced morbidity/mortality
Value: decreased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by a Poxviridae infection or from components of or toxins produced by a virus from this Family

Subject: increased susceptibility to Poxviridae infection induced morbidity/mortality
Value: increased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by a Poxviridae infection or from components of or toxins produced by a virus from this Family

Subject: decreased susceptibility to Adenoviridae infection induced morbidity/mortality
Value: decreased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by an Adenoviridae infection or from components of or toxins produced by a virus from this Family

Subject: increased susceptibility to Adenoviridae infection induced morbidity/mortality
Value: increased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by an Adenoviridae infection or from components of or toxins produced by a virus from this Family

Subject: decreased susceptibility to Retroviridae infection induced morbidity/mortality
Value: decreased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by a Retroviridae infection or from components of or toxins produced by a virus from this Family

Subject: increased susceptibility to Retroviridae infection induced morbidity/mortality
Value: increased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by a Retroviridae infection or from components of or toxins produced by a virus from this Family

Subject: decreased susceptibility to Picornaviridae infection induced morbidity/mortality
Value: decreased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by a Picornaviridae infection or from components of or toxins produced by a virus from this Family

Subject: increased susceptibility to Picornaviridae infection induced morbidity/mortality
Value: increased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by a Picornaviridae infection or from components of or toxins produced by a virus from this Family

Subject: decreased susceptibility to Togaviridae infection induced morbidity/mortality
Value: decreased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by a Togaviridae infection or from components of or toxins produced by a virus from this Family

Subject: increased susceptibility to Togaviridae infection induced morbidity/mortality
Value: increased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by a Togaviridae infection or from components of or toxins produced by a virus from this Family

Subject: decreased susceptibility to Flaviviridae infection induced morbidity/mortality
Value: decreased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by a Flaviviridae infection or from components of or toxins produced by a virus from this Family

Subject: increased susceptibility to Flaviviridae infection induced morbidity/mortality
Value: increased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by a Flaviviridae infection or from components of or toxins produced by a virus from this Family

Subject: decreased susceptibility to Orthomyxoviridae infection induced morbidity/mortality
Value: decreased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by an Orthomyxoviridae infection or from components of or toxins produced by a virus from this Family

Subject: increased susceptibility to Orthomyxoviridae infection induced morbidity/mortality
Value: increased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by an Orthomyxoviridae infection or from components of or toxins produced by a virus from this Family

Subject: decreased susceptibility to Coronaviridae infection induced morbidity/mortality
Value: decreased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by a Coronaviridae infection or from components of or toxins produced by a virus from this Family

Subject: increased susceptibility to Coronaviridae infection induced morbidity/mortality
Value: increased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by a Coronaviridae infection or from components of or toxins produced by a virus from this Family

Subject: decreased susceptibility to Paramyxoviridae infection induced morbidity/mortality
Value: decreased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by a Paramyxoviridae infection or from components of or toxins produced by a virus from this Family

Subject: increased susceptibility to Paramyxoviridae infection induced morbidity/mortality
Value: increased likelihood that an organism will display the expected moribund state caused by a Paramyxoviridae infection or from components of or toxins produced by a virus from this Family

Subject: lymph node hemorrhage
Value: bleeding into one or more lymph nodes

Subject: lymph node necrosis
Value: morphological changes resulting from pathological death of some or all lymph node tissue; usually due to irreversible damage

Subject: pleuritis
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the invaginated serous membrane that surrounds the lungs (visceral portion) and lines the walls of the pleural cavity (parietal portion)

Subject: bronchiolitis
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the noncartilaginous conducting airways of the lungs found terminal to the bronchi

Subject: bronchitis
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the bronchial tubes

Subject: bitter preference
Value: subjects demonstrate predilection for bitter tasting substances over other offered substances

Subject: low bitter preference
Value: subjects demonstrate a low predilection for bitter tasting substances over other offered substances

Subject: hepatosplenomegaly
Value: simultaneous enlargement of the liver and spleen

Subject: increased circulating C-reactive protein level
Value: abnormal elevation of the plasma protein that circulates in increased amounts during inflammation or after tissue damage and binds to phosphocholine expressed on the surface of dead or dying cells, including all types of pneumococci, in order to activate the complement system via the C1Q complex

Subject: decreased circulating C-reactive protein level
Value: abnormal reduction of the plasma protein that circulates in increased amounts during inflammation or after tissue damage and binds to phosphocholine expressed on the surface of dead or dying cells, including all types of pneumococci, in order to activate the complement system via the C1Q complex

Subject: abnormal erythrocyte sedimentation rate
Value: a deviation in the rate at which red blood cells (RBCs) descend under the influence of gravity in a vertical column of anticoagulated whole blood over a period of one hour; the rate at which RBCs settle out from the plasma is measured as the number of millimeters of clear plasma present at the top of the column after one hour (mm/hr); a non-specific measure of inflammation

Subject: decreased erythrocyte sedimentation rate
Value: a reduction in the rate at which red blood cells (RBCs) descend under the influence of gravity in a vertical column of anticoagulated whole blood over a period of one hour; a decreased rate may be seen in polycythemia or in certain blood diseases in which RBCs have an irregular or smaller shape that causes slower settling

Subject: increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate
Value: an increase in the rate at which red blood cells descend under the influence of gravity in a vertical column of anticoagulated whole blood over a period of one hour; an elevated rate may indicate inflammation or may be caused by any condition that elevates fibrinogen

Subject: abnormal circulating procalcitonin level
Value: any anomaly in the blood concentration of procalcitonin, a peptide precursor of the hormone calcitonin produced by parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid and by the neuroendocrine cells of the lung and the intestine; the level of procalcitonin is virtually undetectable in the bloodstream of healthy individuals but can rise significantly in systemic bacterial infections and sepsis

Subject: increased circulating procalcitonin level
Value: greater concentration in the blood of procalcitonin, a peptide precursor of the hormone calcitonin produced by parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid and by the neuroendocrine cells of the lung and the intestine; the level of procalcitonin is virtually undetectable in the bloodstream of healthy individuals but can rise significantly in systemic bacterial infections and sepsis; it does not rise significantly with viral or non-infectious inflammations

Subject: cytokine storm
Value: dysregulated and excessive cytokine and chemokine release in response to infection and other stimuli; can cause acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) or multiple-organ dysfunction, leading to physiological deterioration and death

Subject: abnormal blood oxygen saturation level
Value: any anomaly in the amount of oxygen bound to hemoglobin in the blood expressed as a percentage of the maximal binding capacity

Subject: decreased blood oxygen saturation level
Value: a reduction in the amount of oxygen bound to hemoglobin in the blood expressed as a percentage of the maximal binding capacity

Subject: increased blood oxygen saturation level
Value: an increase in the amount of oxygen bound to hemoglobin in the blood expressed as a percentage of the maximal binding capacity

Subject: hemophagocytosis
Value: a pathologic process of engulfment of erythrocytes, leukocytes, platelets, and their precursors by histiocytes, either in the bone marrow or in other parts of the reticuloendothelial system; it is a nonspecific phenotypic feature observed in several conditions including hemolytic anemia, malignant disease, infections, and hemophagocytic syndrome (also known as hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis, a rare hyperinflammatory syndrome caused by severe hypercytokinemia due to a highly stimulated but ineffective immune process)

Subject: lymph node atrophy
Value: acquired diminution of the size of lymph node tissue associated with wasting as from death and reabsorption of cells, diminished cellular proliferation, decreased cellular volume, pressure, ischemia, malnutrition, reduced function or malfunction, or hormonal changes; occurs with age, immobilization, weightlessness, malnutrition or denervation

Subject: abnormal circulating type I collagen C-terminal telopeptide level
Value: any deviation from the normal amount of type I collagen C-terminal telopeptide (CTX) in the blood circulation; beta-CTX is released into the bloodstream during bone resorption and serves as a specific marker for the degradation of mature type I collagen

Subject: decreased circulating type I collagen C-terminal telopeptide level
Value: less than the normal amount of type I collagen C-terminal telopeptide (CTX) in the blood circulation; beta-CTX is released into the bloodstream during bone resorption and serves as a specific marker for the degradation of mature type I collagen

Subject: increased circulating type I collagen C-terminal telopeptide level
Value: greater than the normal amount of type I collagen C-terminal telopeptide (CTX) in the blood circulation; beta-CTX is released into the bloodstream during bone resorption and serves as a specific marker for the degradation of mature type I collagen; elevated serum levels of beta-CTX indicate increased bone resorption

Subject: abnormal circulating troponin level
Value: eviation from the normal concentration in the blood of troponin, a complex of three contractile regulatory proteins (troponin C, T and I) that control the calcium mediated interactions between actin and myosin in cardiac and skeletal muscles; in humans, cardiac-specific troponins I and T are regarded as the preferred biomarkers for the diagnosis of myocardial infarction due to their unique specificity for myocardial cell injury/necrosis

Subject: decreased circulating troponin level
Value: reduced concentration in the blood of troponin, a complex of three contractile regulatory proteins (troponin C, T and I) that control the calcium mediated interactions between actin and myosin in cardiac and skeletal muscles; in humans, cardiac-specific troponins I and T are regarded as the preferred biomarkers for the diagnosis of myocardial infarction due to their unique specificity for myocardial cell injury/necrosis

Subject: increased circulating troponin level
Value: increased concentration in the blood of troponin, a complex of three contractile regulatory proteins (troponin C, T and I) that control the calcium mediated interactions between actin and myosin in cardiac and skeletal muscles; in humans, elevated serum levels of cardiac-specific troponins (I and T) are highly sensitive and specific indicators of myocardial injury and used in the diagnosis of myocardial infarction

Subject: increased circulating troponin T level
Value: greater than the normal concentration in the blood of troponin T (TnT), a cardiac regulatory protein that controls the calcium mediated interaction between actin and myosin; elevated serum cardiac troponin T levels are highly sensitive and specific indicators of myocardial injury and used in the diagnosis of myocardial infarction

Subject: increased circulating troponin I level
Value: greater than the normal concentration in the blood of troponin I (TnI), a cardiac regulatory protein that controls the calcium mediated interaction between actin and myosin; elevated serum cardiac troponin I levels are highly sensitive and specific indicators of myocardial injury and used in the diagnosis of myocardial infarction

Subject: pulmonary embolism
Value: an embolus (an abnormal particle circulating in the blood) located in the pulmonary artery and thereby blocking blood circulation to the lung; usually the embolus is a blood clot that has developed in an extremity (for instance, a deep venous thrombosis), detached, and traveled through the circulation before becoming trapped in the pulmonary artery

Subject: abnormal circulating D-dimer level
Value: any anomaly in the concentration in the blood of this fibrin degradation product (FDP), a small protein fragment present in the blood after a blood clot is degraded by fibrinolysis; D-dimer constitutes two adjacent fibrin D domains that are cross-linked and released as an intact fragment

Subject: decreased circulating D-dimer level
Value: reduced concentration in the blood of this fibrin degradation product (FDP), a small protein fragment present in the blood after a blood clot is degraded by fibrinolysis

Subject: increased circulating D-dimer level
Value: increased concentration in the blood of this fibrin degradation product (FDP), a small protein fragment present in the blood after a blood clot is degraded by fibrinolysis; elevations can occur as a result of thrombotic disease (such as deep-vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism or disseminated intravascular coagulation), in vasoocclusive crisis of sickle cell anemia, in malignancies, and in surgery

Subject: decreased erythrocyte osmotic fragility
Value: decreased propensity of erythrocytes to hemolyze when exposed to increasingly hypotonic saline solutions; seen in chronic liver disease, iron deficiency anemia, thalassemia, hyponatremia, polycythemia vera, and sickle cell anemia after splenectomy

Subject: increased erythrocyte osmotic fragility
Value: increased propensity of erythrocytes to hemolyze when exposed to increasingly hypotonic saline solutions; seen in hereditary spherocytosis, some forms of hemolytic anemia, and hypernatremia

Subject: wheezing
Value: a high-pitched whistling sound associated with labored breathing

Subject: abnormal pneumocyte desquamation
Value: any anomaly in the shedding of alveolar epithelial cells into the alveolar space in response to infection/injury

Subject: coughing
Value: <a sudden expulsion of air through the large breathing passages that can help clear them of fluids, irritants, foreign particles and microbes; as a protective reflex, coughing can be repetitive with the cough reflex following three phases: an inhalation, a forced exhalation against a closed glottis, and a violent release of air from the lungs following opening of the glottis, usually accompanied by a distinctive sound>

Subject: sneezing
Value: a semi-autonomous, convulsive expulsion of air from the lungs through the nose and mouth, usually caused by foreign particles irritating the nasal mucosa; a sneeze expels air forcibly from the mouth and nose in an explosive, audible, spasmodic involuntary action resulting chiefly from irritation of the nasal mucous membrane

Subject: ageusia
Value: complete absence or loss of the sense of taste, i.e. inability to detect sweetness, sourness, bitterness, saltiness, and umami (pleasant/savory taste)

Subject: hypogeusia
Value: partial loss of taste or reduced ability to detect sweetness, sourness, bitterness, saltiness and/or umami (pleasant/savory taste); may be general to all tastants, partial to some tastants, or specific to one or more tastants

Subject: dysgeusia
Value: a distortion or an alteration in the perception of a tastant; an unpleasant perception may occur when a normally pleasant taste is present, or the perception may occur when no tastant is present

Subject: multiple organ failure
Value: altered function in two or more organ systems during an acute illness such that homeostasis cannot be maintained without intervention

Subject: organomegaly
Value: abnormal enlargement of one or more visceral organs (internal organs enclosed in a cavity) of the body

Subject: pharyngitis
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins and leukocytes in the pharynx, most often caused by viral or bacterial infections; less common causes include allergies, trauma, cancer, reflux, and certain toxins

Subject: conjunctival hyperemia
Value: abnormal dilatation of the blood vessels of the conjunctiva leading to a red appearance of the sclera

Subject: conjunctival chemosis
Value: abnormal swelling (or edema) of the conjunctiva; in chemosis, the integrity of conjunctival capillaries is compromised, leading to increased permeability and leakage of serous fluid; causes include conjunctival irritation, infection, inflammation, trauma, and severe intraorbital inflammation

Subject: abnormal sputum production
Value: any anomaly in the amount of material expectorated (coughed up) from the respiratory system; sputum is composed of mucus but may contain other substances such as pus, blood, microorganisms, and fibrin in disease states

Subject: abnormal sputum morphology
Value: any anomaly in the gross appearance or other physical characteristics of sputum, that is, the material expectorated (coughed up) from the respiratory system, including its color, consistency, taste, and smell; sputum is composed of mucus but may contain other substances such as pus, blood, microorganisms, and fibrin in disease states

Subject: hemoptysis
Value: expectoration (coughing up) of blood or blood-tinged sputum from the lungs or tracheobronchial tree

Subject: nasal obstruction
Value: a blockage within the nasal cavity, resulting in insufficient airflow through the nose; causes of obstruction include swelling of the mucous membrane (nasal congestion), nasal polyps, nasopharyngeal carcinoma or foreign bodies

Subject: rhinorrhea
Value: increased discharge of fluid (typically a watery mucus fluid) from the nose; a common symptom of allergies or certain viral infections

Subject: skin rash
Value: an eruption in the skin which affects its appearance and/or texture; a rash may be localized to one part of the body, or affect all the skin; rashes may cause the skin to change color, itch, become warm, bumpy, dry, cracked or blistered, swell and may be painful

Subject: crackles
Value: <fine, short, high-pitched, intermittently crackling sounds heard in a lung field that has fluid in the small airways; crackles are commonly heard in the bases of the lung lobes during inspiration; the cause of crackles can be from air passing through fluid, pus or mucus; crackles can be further categorised as coarse or fine: the sound quality of fine crackles is similar to the sound of hair rubbed between your fingers near the ear and may be heard in congestive heart failure and pulmonary fibrosis; coarse crackles are lower-pitched and moist-sounding, like pouring water out of a bottle or ripping open velcro, and are often a sign of adult respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), early congestive heart failure, asthma and pulmonary edema>

Subject: rhonchi
Value: continuous low-pitched, rattling lung sounds that often resemble snoring, frequently caused by obstruction or secretions in larger airways; they can be heard in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), bronchiectasis, pneumonia, chronic bronchitis, or cystic fibrosis

Subject: altered susceptibility to pulmonary hyaline membrane formation
Value: a change in the likelihood that an organism will form an eosinophilic hyaline (glass-like) material composed of fibrin, proteinaceous exudate and cellular debris, and lining or filling the alveoli, alveolar ducts and bronchioles

Subject: abnormal circulating myoglobin level
Value: anomaly in the blood level of myoglobin, a low molecular weight oxygen binding heme protein that is normally found exclusively in heart and skeletal muscle cells; in blood, myoglobin is bound primarily to plasma globulins, a complex which is filtered by the kidneys; if the plasma concentration exceeds the plasma binding capacity, myoglobin begins to appear in the urine; monitoring myoglobin levels in blood (and urine) has been used as a means to detect skeletal or cardiac muscle cell injury

Subject: increased circulating myoglobin level
Value: increased blood level of myoglobin, a low molecular weight oxygen binding heme protein that is normally found exclusively in heart and skeletal muscle cells; in blood, myoglobin is bound primarily to plasma globulins, a complex which is filtered by the kidneys; if the plasma concentration exceeds the plasma binding capacity, myoglobin begins to appear in the urine; myoglobin is rapidly released into the bloodstream after muscle damage, and thus can be a useful biomarker in the early phases of heart or skeletal muscle injury

Subject: subarachnoid hemorrhage
Value: bleeding into the space between the arachnoid mater and the pia mater

Subject: meningitis
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the protective membranes (meninges) covering the brain and spinal cord, commonly caused by a bacterial or viral infection

Subject: meningoencephalitis
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the brain and its surrounding protective membranes (meninges)

Subject: rhabdomyolysis
Value: breakdown of skeletal muscle fibers leading to leakage of muscle contents into the bloodstream; damage to the sarcolemma results in loss of its intrinsic function, an influx of calcium, activation of intracellular proteases, and release of intracellular contents (e.g. myoglobin, creatine phosphokinase, aldolase, lactate dehydrogenase, aspartate transaminase, and potassium) into the circulation; common causes include trauma, prolonged exertion, hyperthermia, infections, electrolyte abnormalities, electrical current injury, drugs or toxins, and conditions that cause tissue hypoxia; complications may include acute renal failure, metabolic abnormalities, and disseminated intravascular congestion

Subject: pulmonary parenchymal consolidation
Value: replacement of alveolar air by fluid (exudate/transudate/blood), cells (inflammatory), tissue, or other material, rendering the pulmonary parenchyma airless; consolidated tissue is more radio-opaque than normally aerated lung parenchyma, so that it is clearly demonstrable in radiography and on CT scans

Subject: increased circulating gamma-glutamyl transferase level
Value: elevated blood level of the enzyme that catalyzes the transfer of gamma-glutamyl functional groups from molecules such as glutathione to an acceptor that may be an amino acid, a peptide or water (forming glutamate); GGT plays a key role in the gamma-glutamyl cycle, a pathway for the synthesis and degradation of glutathione as well as drug and xenobiotic detoxification; GGT is present in many organs throughout the body, with the highest concentrations found in liver, and elevated in the blood in most diseases that cause damage to the liver or bile ducts

Subject: macrovesicular hepatic steatosis
Value: a common form of hepatic steatosis characterized by the presence of large lipid droplets that displace the nucleus and organelles to the cell periphery in affected hepatocytes; may be caused by oversupply of lipids due to obesity, obstructive sleep apnea, insulin resistance, or alcoholism

Subject: microvesicular hepatic steatosis
Value: a less common form of hepatic steatosis characterized by accumulation of multiple small lipid droplets giving the cytoplasm a foamy appearance without displacing the nucleus in affected hepatocytes; causes include tetracyclines, acute fatty liver of pregnancy, Reye's syndrome, and hepatitis C

Subject: subdural hemorrhage
Value: bleeding into the subdural space, the potential space between the dura and arachnoid mater of the meninges around the brain

Subject: cardiovalvulitis
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in one or more valves of the heart

Subject: pulmonary cavitation
Value: presence of an abnormal gas-filled space within a zone of pulmonary consolidation or within a pulmonary mass or nodule appearing as a lucency or low-attenuation area on plain chest radiography or computed tomography; a pulmonary cavity may contain a fluid level and is surrounded by a wall, usually of varied thickness

Subject: decreased susceptibility to induced thrombosis
Value: decreased frequency, rate or severity of thrombus formation following stimulation of thrombosis by an external agent

Subject: increased susceptibility to induced thrombosis
Value: increased frequency, rate or severity of thrombus formation following stimulation of thrombosis by an external agent

Subject: areflexia
Value: complete absence or loss of neurological reflexes

Subject: abnormal anterior longitudinal ligament morphology
Value: any structural anomaly of the strong, broad fibrous band that covers and connects the anterolateral aspects of the vertebral bodies and intervertebral (IV) discs; this ligament extends from the pelvic surface of the sacrum to the anterior tubercle of vertebra C1 (atlas) and the occipital bone anterior to the foramen magnum; it prevents hyperflexion of the vertebral column, maintaining stability of the joints between the vertebral bodies; it is the only ligament that limits extension; all other ligaments of the vertebral column, like the IV ligaments, limit forms of flexion

Subject: aortic valve inflammation
Value: local accumulation of fluid, plasma proteins, and leukocytes in the aortic valve

Subject: aspiration pneumonia
Value: pneumonia occurring after abnormal entry of material from the oral cavity or upper gastrointestinal tract into the lungs through the larynx; aspirated material can include saliva, nasopharyngeal secretions, bacteria, liquids, toxic substances, food, or gastric contents; can result in pulmonary complications by way of chemical pneumonitis, bacterial infection, or mechanical obstruction

Subject: gangrene
Value: necrosis or death of soft tissue due to lack of blood flow resulting from injury, infection or other conditions that affect blood circulation

Subject: dry gangrene
Value: a form of coagulative necrosis that develops in ischemic tissue, where the blood supply is inadequate to keep tissue viable, in the absence of superimposed microbial infection; can be due to peripheral artery disease or acute limb ischemia; the affected body part is dry, shrunken, and dark reddish-black and can fall off (autoamputate) if not removed surgically

Subject: cardiovascular shunt
Value: an abnormal communication (shunt) between the right and left sides of the heart or between the systemic and pulmonary vessels, allowing blood to flow directly from one circulatory system to the other; blood can either be shunted from the systemic circulation to pulmonary circulation (i.e. left-to-right shunt) or between the pulmonary circulation and systemic circulation (i.e. right-to-left shunt); rarely, the shunted blood returns to the same cardiac chamber without traversing a capillary bed (i.e. circular shunt); most commonly shunts are the result of congenital heart disease

Subject: left-to-right shunt
Value: a left-to-right shunt allows the oxygenated, pulmonary venous blood to return directly to the lungs rather than being pumped to the body thereby reducing the cardiac output by the amount of the shunted volume; as a result, tissue oxygen delivery is reduced

Subject: right-to-left shunt
Value: a right-to-left shunt allows the deoxygenated, systemic venous return to bypass the lungs and return directly to the systemic arterial circulation; the oxygen content of the systemic arterial blood falls in proportion to the volume of systemic venous blood mixing with the normal pulmonary venous return; with reduced oxygen content, even with normal cardiac output, tissue oxygen delivery falls and the work capacity of muscles is limited

Subject: myocardial fiber disarray
Value: loss of the normal parallel alignment of cardiac myocytes, whereby adjacent myocytes are arranged obliquely or perpendicularly to each other around foci of interstitial collagen (plexiform fibrosis) in a pinwheel or herringbone pattern; disarray is characterized by regions of architectural disorganization of hypertrophied myocytes and distinct nuclear changes

Subject: increased artery tortuosity
Value: increase in the degree of twisting of one or more arteries

Subject: increased aorta tortuosity
Value: increase in the degree of twisting of the aorta

Subject: increased carotid artery tortuosity
